title: VOTERS' REAL OPPORTUNITY TO HELP STOP THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. OWNERS MAKE NEW OFFER
description: On the sixth Sunday of the National Football League strike, the owners yesterday produced some optimism with their first money offer since the walkout - guaranteeing a yearly raise to every player for the length of his contract as part of a $1.28 billion package.

title: HELP FOR HIGH COURT
description: The burdened United States Supreme Court needs relief, and there is a practical solution.

title: Gunmen Kill 2 Filipinos
description: A gang of heavily armed men in fatigues sprayed a crowded village dance hall with gunfire, killing two people and wounding 11 during a religious celebration, the police said today.

title: CAUTION CAN'T MASK HOLIDAY'S TRUE FACE: HALLOWEEN'S A PARTY
description: Halloween was marked with caution and restraint yesterday as thousands of families in the New York metropolitan area chose costume contests, parades and private parties over trick or treating.

title: CANDIDATES ON TUESDAY'S BALLOTS IN NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA
description: Following is a list of candidates in the New York metropolitan area in tomorrow's election. Asterisk (*) denotes incumbent. The abbreviations are D Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, RTL - Right To Life, L - Liberal, LIB - Libertarian, FL - Free Libertarian, U - Unity, IND - Independent, SW - Socialist Worker, NA - New Alliance, NF - Nuclear Freeze, CIT - Citizens, LIT - Long Island Traditionalists, STO - Sewer Tax Oppostion, IV - Independent Voters, SI - Statewide Independent, VET - Veterans, POP - Popular, COM Communist, PAC - People Against Crime, IN - Independent Neighbors, GR - Grass Roots, WF - World Federalist, UI - Unbossed Indpendent, CON - Constitution Party, PC - Politicians Are Crooks, ML - Mr. Liberty, AT - Action Talks NEW YORK STATEWIDE CANDIDATES U.S. SENATE * Daniel P. Moynihan, D, L Florence M. Sullivan, R, C, RTL James J. McKeown, FL Steven Wattenmaker, SW GOVERNOR Mario M. Cuomo, D, L Lewis E. Lehrman, R, C, IND Robert J. Bohner, RTL John H. Northrup, FL Jane Benedict, U Daine Wang, SW Nancy Ross, NA LIEUT. GOVERNOR Alfred B. DelBello, D, L James L. Emery Jr, R, C, IND Paul F. Callahan, FTL David Hoesly, FL Angela M. Gilliam, U Peter A. Theirjung, SW Lenora B. Fulani, NA

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOBBYING

title: 'Poltergeist' Actress in Coma After Being Choked on Coast
description: Dominique Dunne, an actress who appeared in the recent horror movie ''Poltergeist,'' was reported to be in a coma and in critical condition tonight at Cedars Sinai Medical Center here, a sheriff's spokesman said.

title: MINORITY GROUP CHOICES PIVOTAL IN SOME CONTESTS
description: With white voters divided over which party can better handle the recession, the votes of members of minority groups could decide the outcome of many important races across the nation.

title: THE DANCE: 6 WORKS BASED ON SCHLEMMER'S ART
description: THE notion of an avant-garde past might seem a contradiction in terms and yet it was delightfully and brilliantly embodied Saturday night in a program that reconstructed six ''Bauhaus Dances'' of the 1920's by the late German painter and sculptor, Oskar Schlemmer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ONE FELL SOUP. Or I'm Just a Bug on the Windshield of Life. By Roy Blount Jr. 278 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $13.95. READ ALL ABOUT IT! The Collected Ad- ventures of a Maverick Reporter. By Sidney Zion. 362 pages. Summit. $16.50.

title: KNOXVILLE WORLD'S FAIR CLOSES ITS 6-MONTH RUN
description: A generous autumn sun descended over a color collage in the mountains of East Tennessee today as the 1982 World's Fair closed with bands, tributes and declarations of success.

title: CAREY AND WILSON STAYING ON CAMPAIGN'S SIDELINES
description: The Governor of New York, a Democrat, and the state's last Republican Governor have been conspicuously absent from the current gubernatorial campaign.

title: ON ARMS: REMEMBERING KHRUSHCHEV
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are blaming each other for the arms race these days. President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger have repeatedly called for increased military spending to counter what they contend are Soviet advantages in key areas of missile development and conventional arms. Last week Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, charged that the Reagan Administration was intensifying its military preparations ''to an unprecedented level'' and threatening to push the world ''into the flames of a nuclear war.''

title: DEMOCRATS EXPECT FIVE OR MORE GAINS IN GOVERNORSHIPS
description: A list of the candidates on ballots in the New York metropolitan area and a guide to the key issues in the major races begin on page B10.

title: TV: MORTIMER ADLER VIEWS 'SIX GREAT IDEAS'
description: MORTIMER ADLER is the Poobah of popularizers. While lesser practitioners feed biofeedback to the masses, he deals in nothing less than freedom and God. He has spent a long and highly successful career mingling the goods of scholarship with the tinsel of merchandising - from the Encyclopedia Britannica to the Great Books project to the Aspen Institute's executive seminars, where top people come for a glimpse of the bottommost bottom line.

title: SOCIAL ISSUES PLAY SMALL ELECTION ROLE
description: Last week, President Reagan shared a campaign platform with Senator Jesse Helms, hero of the New Right and leading Congressional advocate of such ''social issues'' as abortion and school prayer. But in a four-page speech, the President mentioned these issues only once.

title: MORE OF THE AGED SEEK WORK FOR EXTRA MONEY
description: Last of a series of articles appearing periodically on how changing economic conditions are affecting some American families CLEVELAND - Lou Pearlman spent 43 years of his life wrestling a beer truck around Cleveland, and when he finally retired, he figured he had earned the right to take it easy. But what he had earned, it turned out, was not enough to cover the gap between what a meager pension and Social Security brought in and what it cost him and his wife to live.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rebuilding in Brownsville

title: INTERNATIONAL TRADE UNIT KEEPS BUSY
description: What are the effects on the American economy of a suspension of duties on bulk fresh carrots? Which countries were the principal suppliers last year of benzenoid chemicals, of hotrolled carbon steel sheet and strip? Does Japan pose a threat to what is left of the American motorcyle industry?

title: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIA FIRED MISSILES AT JETS AND MISSED
description: The Israeli military command said today that two antiaircraft missiles had been fired from Syria at Israeli aircraft over eastern Lebanon. The announcement said both missiles missed their targets.

title: MUSIC: 2D SYMPHONY OF CLEMENTI IS OFFERED
description: MOZART called Muzio Clementi, ''a charlatan,'' but the Rome-born composer wrote some quite interesting music throughout his career as pianist, publisher and pedagogue. In fact, the Northeastern Arts Ensemble brought his Second Symphony to Symphony Space on Tuesday night, leaving the impression that on this occasion Mozart was certainly too harsh a critic.

title: CHARLES N. JOHNSON
description: Charles N. Johnson, a partner in the accounting concern of Arthur Anderson & Company of New York City, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Brooklyn Heights.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Thanksgiving Parade, A Halloween Rehearsal

title: U.S. Official Due in Pakistan
description: Attorney General William French Smith, on an Asian tour, arrives in Pakistan Monday for talks on Afghan refugees and the country's problem as the world's largest supplier of heroin.

title: Audit Bureau to Tally Cable TV Subscribers
description: Certainly good news for the cable television community is the announcement last week that the 68-year-old Audit Bureau of Circulations in the coming year will begin to audit the subscriber lists of cable systems that are used by cable networks to sell advertising space.

title: Warden, Taken Captive, Foils Inmates' Escape Bid
description: A warden who was taken captive Saturday along with his mother by two inmates armed with knives, deliberately crashed his pickup truck and grabbed a guard's gun, touching off a burst of shooting that left one prisoner dead and the other wounded.

title: ANNOUNCEMENTS BY REAGAN TIMED WITH VOTING IN MIND
description: While President Reagan has been waging a campaign against the evils of government, his Administration has proved adept this fall at announcing new programs or policy shifts aimed at pleasing constituent groups around the country.

title: THE REGION;
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has announced that it has provided a $25,000 grant so the papers of Cyrus R. Vance, former Secretary of State, will be catalogued and preserved at Yale University. The University of Notre Dame was also given $25,000 to preserve the papers of the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, its president.

title: P.L.O. LEADER SAYS ISRAELI FORCES MUST PULL OUT BEFORE GUERRILLAS
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's senior military commander said today that any P.L.O. withdrawal from Lebanon must be preceded by an evacuation of Israeli forces and the signing of a new agreement between the guerrilla group and the Lebanese Government guaranteeing the safety of Palestinian civilians.

title: VOTERS' REAL OPPORTUNITY TO HELP STOP THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: HATED CHAINS BIND MOZAMBICANS TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Only a slender causeway holds this redoubt of rock and sand and surf to Africa's mainland, and in that vulnerability lies a parallel between the tumbledown island and modern-day Mozambique.

title: Missouri Representative Ill
description: Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, was admitted today to the intensive care unit of St. Joseph Hospital.

title: MUSIC: MASUR CONDUCTS GEWANDHAUS OF LEIPZIG
description: IN the music-reviewing trade, it is considered dereliction of duty to begin any discussion of Leipzig's Gewandhaus Orchestra without a solemn invocation of its immortal conductors, beginning with J.S. Bach in 1743. So let us get the litany out of the way: Felix Mendelssohn, Arthur Nikisch, Gustav Mahler, Wilhelm Furtwangler - that partial list ought to be enough to persuade anyone that the orchestra has tradition on its side.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Catalogue Assignment
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver has become the agency for Popular Services of Garfield, N.J., a 40-year-old company whose Popular Club Plan has saleswomen going door to door selling a variety of products from catalogues.

title: SCHOLARS DISCOVERING LESS SUBTLE VIRGINIA WOOLF
description: In an early draft of her first novel, Virginia Woolf wrote a scene in which Rachel, her heroine, scuffles on the ground with her beautiful aunt Helen, who is feeling resentful that Rachel has fallen in love with a young man.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982
description: International Pope John Paul II arrived in Spain on the first papal visit ever made to the predominantly Roman Catholic country. He began his 10-day visit at a time of high political excitement in Spain, which last week elected its first post-Franco Socialist Government. In an address to the Spanish bishops he urged them to defend the church positions against abortion and divorce. The Socialists are expected to seek legalization of abortion. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) A P.L.O. withdrawal from Lebanon must be preceded by an evacuation of Israeli forces and the signing of a new agreement between the guerrilla group and the Lebanese Government guaranteeing the safety of Palestinian civilians, the P.L.O.'s senior military commander said. Khalil al-Wazir, widely known by his guerrilla name, Abu Jihad, said that the P.L.O. wanted to retain some kind of symbolic military presence in Lebanon under the authority of the Lebanese Government. He said this would assure the 500,000 Palestinian refugees living in Lebanon that they would not be exposed to another massacre such as occurred in the Palestinian camps outside Beirut last month. (A1:1-2.)

title: Crusader for Thorpe
description: Jim Thorpe has not yet received complete justice, according to Paul Ohl, a French-Canadian writer who is the president of the International Committee for the Reinstatement of James Francis Thorpe.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; India May Offer Sikhs Major Concessions

title: Household To Sue Eagle
description: Household International Inc. has announced that negotiations concerning the sale of its subsidiary, Wein Air Alaska Inc., to the Eagle International Corporation had been terminated. Household said that it would sue Eagle and its chairman, Neil Bergt, who is also chief executive officer of Western Air Lines, for breach of contract.

title: Dearie Charges Fraud On Political Brochure
description: Assemblyman John Dearie, Democrat of the Bronx, called yesterday for investigations into campaign literature that declared ''Dearie has done more to integrate Parkchester and our community than any other politician.''

title: Seychellois Face Expulsion
description: South Africa is expelling Seychelles expatriates opposing the island nation's Socialist Government, The Sunday Times newspaper said. A band of mercenaries left from South Africa for the Seychelles last November to stage a coup that failed.

title: An Expert Can Add to Fun; Of a Club Duplicate Game
description: As thousands of players can attest, a club duplicate game provides a satisfactory evening's entertainment at very modest cost. The pleasure can be considerably enhanced if an expert is available to answer questions about the deals while the scores are being calculated. And a pregame lecture or quetion-and-answer period also adds to the fun.

title: NEW YORK TO OPEN A SEPARATE COURT ON BUILDING LAWS
description: A separate section of Criminal Court will be created in Manhattan to deal solely with prosecutions of landlords who disregard buildingsafety laws.

title: MRS. FENWICK AND LAUTENBERG MEET IN FINAL DEBATE
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick and Frank R. Lautenberg met yesterday for their final debate of the campaign for a United States Senate seat from New Jersey. The encounter reflected both the apparent closeness of the race and the acrimony that has often marked its final stages.

title: AT CAMPAIGN'S END, FLOOD OF TV ADS YIELDS CONFLICT AND CLUTTER
description: Television viewers in the New York metropolitan area were subjected to such a barrage of political advertisements over the weekend that some media consultants said the effect of the advertisements could be confusing and not helpful to the candidates.

title: Market Place; Genentech's Outlook Now
description: GENENTECH Inc. offers speculators the quintessential fad stock. Genentech, the highly acclaimed leader in the promising field of genetic engineering, has carried a stratospheric price/earnings multiple since the public offering of 1.1 million shares at $35 each in October 1981. Few would question that this tiny company, with revenues of $15 million last year, was overvalued at a P/E ratio of more than 100.

title: Sinn Fein Will Run For British Parliament
description: Sinn Fein, the legal political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, declared at its annual conference today that it planned to run for seats in the British Parliament.

title: People
description: * James Brandhorst to join Kenyon & Eckhardt as senior vice president and executive assistant to the president, a new post.

title: IT'S 'TALLYHO!' FOR HUNTSMEN PURSUING PART OF HERITAGE ON L.I.
description: From deep in the woods came the off-key blare of a hunting horn, the throaty bark of hounds and the pounding of hooves.

title: Altar Boy On Offense
description: IN other years, the Notre Dame offense often was as sparkling as the Golden Dome itself. If the offense wasn't projecting a Heisman Trophy winner, it sometimes had an all-American or two. Once upon a time, when Knute Rockne was the coach, Notre Dame's backfield had perhaps the most appealing nickname in college football history - the Four Horsemen.

title: VOTERS' REAL OPPORTUNITY TO HELP STOP THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT SAYS 'BIG SPENDERS' FORCED BAN ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: President Reagan, in a closing election appeal for the Republican Party, today accused unidentified ''big spenders'' of forcing the end of prayer in schools.

title: INQUEST ON DEATH OF SOUTH AFRICAN DRAWS TO CLOSE
description: An inquest into the death of a white trade union organizer who died in police custody last February is drawing to a close here after eight weeks of hearings spread over more than six months.

title: Washington Watch; New Car Limit With Japanese
description: WASHINGTON IT looks as if the Government will win early approval from Tokyo to extend the agreement limiting the number of cars that Japan is allowed to ship to the United States.

title: FOR KEVIN, A WAY OF LIFE, AND DEATH
description: In the end, they covered Kevin P. Mulcahy's coffin with an American flag. One of his relatives said it was the right thing to do.

title: KARL R. GIEROW, 78, DIES IN STOCKHOLM
description: Karl Ragnar Gierow, one of Sweden's most distinguished theater directors, presenter of the Nobel Prize in Literature and an authority on the American playwright Eugene O'Neill, died yesterday in Stockholm, the Swedish Academy announced. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Lesson From a Street Youngster

title: THAIS SURVIVE YEARLY ATTACK OF THE JITTERS
description: October, a month that has in recent years been a time of political jitters in Thailand, has ended without so much as a mass demonstration, much less an attempted coup. Yet there has been much talk: of cracking down on lawlessness, calls for the dissolution of Parliament, and charges of Government ineptitude, corruption in high places and dark military ambition.

title: Offtrack Betting Over Its Head
description: Comptroller Ned Regan's report on the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation reveals that while illegal bookmakers may get rich on other people's gambling losses, OTB does not. As its costs mount and revenues shrink, the time may be coming for OTB to shrink away with them.

title: TINA TINA TOO WINS HANDICAP
description: Cool and humid conditions were a factor in the upset of Weber City Miss, beaten at odds of 3 to 5 by Tina Tina Too yesterday in the $109,200 Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: WAVERLEY L. ROOT, 79, JOURNALIST
description: Waverley L. Root, a longtime American newspaperman here and an author of books on food, died in his sleep at home early today of a pulmonary ailment. He was 79.

title: GENETIC RESEARCH DETECTS TRANSFERS
description: Recently discovered evidence shows that, early in their evolution, many animal species were ''infected'' by genes from completely unrelated species.

title: 2 WOMEN CANONIZED BY POPE
description: A French settler of colonial Montreal became Canada's first female saint today when she was canonized along with a 17th-century French woman before a congregation of 11,000 people in St. Peter's Basilica.

title: SWARTHMORE'S SHAKESPEAREAN CAST AND OTHER TALES
description: 0 start by the football team, things around Swarthmore College these days ''are rather close to normal,'' a faculty member was saying last Saturday evening as he strolled across campus.

title: YOUNG KNICKS GET A PAINFUL LESSON
description: Twice in 48 hours, the new and young Knicks had been overwhelmed, first by the Philadelphia 76ers and then by the Milwaukee Bucks. And although the two opponents were ''completely different,'' according to the rookie Trent Tucker, the results exposed the deficiencies the team must work on.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Numerical Proliferation

title: No Headline
description: A ROMP FOR MISS NAVRATILOVA

title: Gila Rachel Wiener Bride Of Bruce Kriegel on L.I.
description: Gila Rachel Wiener, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob J. Wiener of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Kriegel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon I. Kriegel of Albany.

title: Sutton Wins First
description: Hal Sutton, a rookie, sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the fourth hole of a playoff with Bill Britton today to capture the $400,000 Walt Disney World golf tournament.

title: GAMBLING A NORTH DAKOTA BALLOT ISSUE
description: ''We didn't contemplate creating a new industry,'' says State Senator Pat Conmy, ''but we sure have.'' He was talking about the country's only legal blackjack tables outside Nevada and Atlantic City.

title: Shelley Garnet Wed To Irwin L. Lubell
description: Shelley Elizabeth Garnet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel David Garnet of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Irwin L. Lubell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lubell of Peekskill, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Sheraton Plaza Inn in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi Bernard Rosenberg.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is there a rule in bowling against switching back and forth from the right hand to the left hand during a game?

title: ISRAEL ASKS WIDER TALKS THAN EGYPT
description: The Israeli Cabinet declared today that an Egyptian request to renew negotiations over a narrow strip of desert land claimed by both Egypt and Israel must be part of a broader effort between the two nations to resolve their growing differences.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bikes on the BMT

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The proliferation of political advertising is incredible. Very frequently you're seeing two or three ads in a row, and you have to wonder whether the effect may be to block any information from getting through at all.'' - Phil Friedman of Campaign Strategies Inc. (B1:2.)

title: Massachusetts and Nuclear Garbage
description: ''Anywhere but here'' - it could become America's political anthem. George Wallace once wanted to ship poor blacks North. Highways, drug treatment centers and shelters for derelicts are nice, as long as they are on the other side of town. John LeBoutillier, the Long Island Congressman, wants to eliminate the need for new prisons in New York by shipping convicts to Alaska. And now some people in Massachusetts want to ''solve'' the nuclear waste disposal problem by making it nearly impossible for state officials to designate a disposal site.

title: At-Sea Incineration Names a President
description: Although it is not unusual for young men to run young companies, Gary L. Wygal has a big job on his hands. Mr. Wygal, a 32-year-old accountant, was named yesterday as president of two-year-old At-Sea Incineration Inc.

title: PARENTS AND GROWN CHILDREN
description: PARENTS and babies. Parents and young children. Parents and t urbulent teens. Much has been written and expounded about those r elationships, but when it comes to parents and their grown children, very little has been said.

title: Kuhn, Justice And the Strike
description: THERE is still no indiction that baseball owners have any longrange plan for their business after they deal with the Bowie Kuhn situation this afternoon. Every indication is that they will inform Kuhn that his contract as commissioner will not be renewed when it expires in August. But then what?

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Elisa A. Spungen Bride of Lawyer
description: Elisa Ann Spungen, an associate with the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, was married yesterday to Robert Lebson Bildner, an associate with the law firm of Lowenstein, Sandler, Brochin, Kohl, Fisher & Boylan in Roseland, N.J.

title: PROFIT DROP BRINGS CUTS IN PAYOUTS
description: The earnings of many of the nation's leading corporations plunged in the third quarter as high interest rates, the slack economy and the strong dollar took their expected toll.

title: FREDERICK BOWES JR.
description: Frederick Bowes Jr., a retired first vice president of Pitney Bowes, the Connecticut-based business equipment company, died Friday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Bowes, who lived in New Canaan, Conn., was 74 years old.

title: G.M. Financing Rate Cut
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that its General Motors Acceptance Corporation unit would offer a 10.9 percent financing rate for new 1982 G.M. automobiles, beginning today. The program will result in savings of $1,300 to $2,125 for customers who finance their car purchases through G.M.A.C., the company said. The new rate, which General Motors said was below its previous financing offers, affects automobiles and trucks delivered through Dec. 31.

title: PHILANTHROPIC OUTLOOK SOMBER
description: To meet their philanthropic commitments, a number of corporations across the country are drawing down the reserves of their company foundations and these resources may soon be exhausted, according to the companies' executives.

title: EGYPT ARRESTS SADAT'S BROTHER
description: The brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat has been jailed pending trial on charges of masterminding a series of business swindles, the Egyptian Prosecutor General's Office announced today.

title: Arizona Sect Members Indicted in Shootout
description: Ten members of the Christ Miracle Healing Center Church have been indicted in connection with a battle with sheriff's deputies that left two church leaders dead and another church member severely wounded.

title: OUTDOORS: COD-FISHING TRIPS FOR THE HARDY ANGLER
description: ALTHOUGH most East Coast saltwater anglers from Massachusetts to New Jersey put away their gear by late October, a few hardy offshore fishermen persist at the sport deep into winter, and a major quarry is the Atlantic cod.

title: EX-MISSISSIPPI MAYOR DENIES ROLE IN RIVAL'S DEATH
description: Eddie James Carthan, the former Mayor of the Delta town of Tchula, denied on the witness stand Saturday that he had hired two men to kill a political rival.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO PLOT AGAINST SANDINISTS
description: The United States Ambassador to Honduras is ''overseeing'' a covert campaign to arm, train and direct thousands of Nicaraguan exiles in Honduras to ''harass and undermine'' Nicaragua's three-year-old Marxist Sandinist Government, according to an article in Newsweek magazine.

title: Student Riders Tested in Horse Shows
description: TENNIS players and golfers regularly take lessons from club professionals to polish the finer points of their games. Now horseback riders are discovering, too, that although being a hack out on the trails can be as stimulating or relaxing as one wishes, going back for lessons has its own appeal.

title: SWEATSHIRTS A LA MODE
description: It had to happen. Those sweatshirt clothes that Norma Kamali put on countless young women have been picked up by the grade-school crowd.

title: THE NEW PRICING WAR AT THE GASOLINE PUMPS
description: Selling a gallon of gasoline has always been a highly competitive game. These days, in a time of weakened demand for gasoline and a deregulated marketplace, that competition - and the confusion it has engendered - may be more intense than ever.

title: Coast Aliens Defrauded In Sale of False Papers
description: Swindlers posing as immigration experts are bilking thousands of dollars from illegal aliens by selling them false amnesty papers, Orange County officials say.

title: JAPAN AIR SEEKS FUEL SAVINGS
description: Every time the American dollar rises by 10 yen, the fuel bill for Japan Air Lines increases $20 million a year, because the fuel is priced in dollars.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT PENGUINS, 6-2
description: The Rangers gave the crowd at Madison Square Garden 60 energyfilled minutes of hockey last night that produced a 6-2 triumph over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: PROGRAM IN YEAR
description: The number of children participating in the national school lunch program declined 3.2 million in the last year, and more than 2,700 schools have dropped out of the program, according to the Department of Agriculture.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Week in Review yesterday incorrectly listed a Suffolk County ballot proposition. Only a proposition on a nuclear-weapons freeze is on the ballot, and a court challenge to that proposition is sched- uled to be decided today.

title: AN ISRAELI GENERAL TELLS OF MASSACRE
description: The senior Israeli commander in Lebanon testified today that he ordered Christian Phalangist militiamen to halt their assault on two Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut last month because of an ''uneasy feeling'' that the militiamen ''overdid it.''

title: LEON SPINKS RETURNS WITH A VICTORY
description: The ring adventures of Leon Spinks resumed today when the former heavyweight champion was awarded a 12-round unanimous decision against Jesse Burnett, a 36-year-old former light-heavywight contender, for the vacant North American Boxing Federation cruiserweight title.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A Pirate's Booty
description: Bill Madlock of the Pittsburgh Pirates failed by 12 points to win his fourth National League batting championship last season. He finished with a .319 average, second to the .331 of Al Oliver of the Montreal Expos. But Madlock has not shown great disappointment.

title: Numbers to Phone For Voter Inquiries
description: A special telephone number for New York City voters who are not certain of the addresses of their polling places has been set up by the city's Board of Elections. The number, 267-9800, will operate from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. tomorrow, which is Election Day.

title: THE KEY ISSUES IN THE THREE MAJOR CONTESTS IN CONNECTICUT AND NEW JERSEY
description: For Senator from New Jersey: Democrat Frank R. Lautenberg Taxes Prepared to vote, if necessary, for new taxes, especially on the wealthy and large corporations. Supports plan by Senator Bill Bradley to simplify tax system and close loopholes. Middle East Favors an autonomous homeland for Palestinians. Supports Camp David accords.

title: NEW ALTERNATIVES TO LITIGATION
description: Business litigation may be a necessary evil, but many corporate executives are beginning to think that there are times when it is more evil than necessary.

title: PLANNING TRIP TO RESTLESS REGIONS
description: Pope John Paul II stepped off an airliner onto Spanish soil today for the start of the first visit by any Pope to this predominantly Roman Catholic nation.

title: Hospital Chief To Lead Shared Medical Systems
description: If Mark S. Levitan were a physician, it might be said that he is going into private practice. As it is, the 48-year-old executive director of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, in Philadelphia, is merely going private.

title: Sears to Close Flagship Store
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, will close its flagship department store on Chicago's State Street next spring and sell the 91-year-old National Historic Landmark building for conversion into an office building.

title: WEICKER AND MOFFETT VOICE OPTIMISM
description: Both the Democratic and Republican candidates for the United States Senate in Connecticut were expressing optimism today, but they were pursuing different courses.

title: SUIT OVER '67 RAID IS COMING TO TRIAL
description: A 15-year struggle for vindication by two former Appalachian antipoverty workers, whose home was raided in 1967 by Kentucky officers, will come to trial in Federal District Court here this week.

title: New Head of Jersey Bell Returning From Indiana
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which long has groomed its top officers by moving them around like chess pieces, has brought home Philip A. Campbell, 46, as president of New Jersey Bell Telephone.

title: U.S. MILITARY HOUSING AREA IN GERMANY IS BOMBED
description: A powerful bomb destroyed at least 20 cars, shattered windows and damaged buildings at a United States Army housing area in the south German town of Giessen today. It was the latest in a series of attacks that the police say are apparently part of coordinated attempts to intimidate American soldiers.

title: LEHRMAN AND CUOMO WINDING UP THEIR CAMPAIGNS
description: Predicting that he would win ''the biggest upset in the history of New York politics,'' Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican-Conservative candidate for governor, set off today on a final campaign tour of the state and urged voters to reject ''politics as usual'' by supporting his candidacy.

title: SENATE HOPEFULS CLASH ON BLAME FOR THE ECONOMY
description: The major candidates for United States Senate from New York addressed the issues of spending and taxation yesterday as they wrapped up their final weekend of campaigning.

title: A U.S. SUPREMACY PASSES INTO HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: MOVIE ON MODELS
description: year-old model, looks at Betsy, an over-the-hill model at 28, and cries accusingly: ''You were my mom, my sister, my idol, my (pause) everything.'' By the end of ''Born Beautiful,'' tonight's television movie on NBC at 9, alert viewers may wonder how much territory that ''everything'' covers. This being a Procter & Gamble Production, intimate details are not always explicit but there is ample opportunity for speculation.

title: REDISTRICTING PITS TWO INCUMBENTS IN A 'FAIR FIGHT'
description: ''I don't know what is fair about it, but this sure is becoming quite a fight,'' Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Republican, said as he introduced himself to a group of businessmen here.

title: RATE OUTLOOK LINKED TO FED
description: Although fundamental economic forces such as declining inflation and weaker credit demand are sustaining hopes for a long-term drop in interest rates, the near-term rate outlook will be guided by the Federal Reserve, many analysts suggest.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1982; The Economy
description: Corporate third-quarter profits plunged because the recession, high interest rates and a strong dollar combined to slash domestic and foreign sales. The poor profits in turn provoked dividend cuts, plant closings and increased unemployment. (Page D1.) A compilation of earnings reports appears on page D8.

title: Advertising
description: HAVING quietly announced last week that its name had been changed from Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. to Prudential-Bache Securities, the brokerage house is now going to be shouting it from the rooftops. Or at least from the media.

title: Nigerian Toll Put at 452 In Religious Riots
description: A newspaper here reported today that the death toll in religious rioting in northeast Nigeria had risen to 452.

title: Fumes Overcome 76 Football Fans
description: At least 76 persons were overcome by chlorine fumes when gas released from a chemical plant drifted into a stadium during a college football game, the police said.

title: Many Happy Returns
description: The guest of honor at a dinner on Nov. 9 at Caesars Tahoe hotel in Lake Tahoe, Nev., will be Albert Benjamin Chandler, better known as Happy. Chandler, who was the commissioner of major league baseball from 1946 until 1951, will be toasted by friends and celebrities for his induction last summer into the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. The recognition came when Chandler was 84 years old and 31 years removed from the commissioner's office.

title: COORS, ADOLPH, CO reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 3
RHODE ISLAND DEMOCRAT GETS BOOST FROM LABOR
description: With the theme from the movie ''Rocky'' blaring from a sound truck, Edward J. McElroy Jr., president of the state A.F.L-C.I.O., exhorted his listeners to ''Send a fighter to Washington - elect Julie Michaelson to the U.S. Senate.''

title: FUEL OIL COOPERATIVE GROWS IN NASSAU AS COST OF ENERGY RISES
description: ''I'm here because I just can't afford to heat my house anymore,'' said Diana Franklin, a 63-year-old retired nurses' aide. ''Maybe the co-op can help.''

title: TAX-EXEMPT OFFERINGS, TREASURY ISSUES HEAVY
description: The Treasury has scheduled two note sales this week, consisting of $6 billion of three-year notes on Nov.3 and $4 billion of 10-year notes on Nov.4. The three-year issue is available in minimum units of $5,000, while the 10-year notes and the 30-year bonds scheduled for sale on Nov.9 are available in $1,000 units.

title: CANADA'S GAS HURT BY ITS HIGH PRICE
description: Come winter, two of Canada's principal exports to the United States become more noticeable: Arctic cold and natural gas. Residents of northern states have long wished that Canadians would keep their cold to themselves, and they are beginning to feel the same way about Canada's exports of gas, much of which is used for domestic heating.

title: Edmund Coffin Weds Patricia Carbone
description: Patricia Carbone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Carbone of North Andover, Mass., was married yesterday in Ipswich, Mass., to Edmund Sloane Coffin of Wenham, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Coffin of Strafford, Vt., formerly of Glen Head, L.I. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., uncle of the bridegroom and senior minister of Riverside Church, performed the ceremony at Castle Hill.

title: REBUILDING AT COLUMBIA BEGINS WITH WITKOWSKI
description: There are no football heroes anymore at Columbia. On Saturday afternoon, the reserved seats are at Butler Library. The students are likely talking scores, but they are asking about the mean score of the organic chemistry test. Was it 54 or 63?

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Calgary Flames, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Devils will attempt to end their five-game losing streak.

title: Kaiser to Cut Ghana Output
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has announced that an energy shortage in Ghana would cause its 90 percent-owned affiliate there, the Volta Aluminum Company, to curtail aluminum production for about a year.

title: BP CANADA PLANS SALE TO OTTAWA
description: BP Canada Inc. agreed over the weekend to sell its refining and marketing activities to the Government's Petro-Canada for $347.5 million (Canadian). The deal would double Petro-Canada's share of the market, to 12 percent.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $194,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $1,376,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $275,000 from discontinued operations

title: Kurdish Rebels Said to Seize A Key Town in Western Iran
description: Supporters of Iranian Kurdish rebels said today that the rebels had captured the important town of Bukan in western Azarbaijan from Government forces.

title: FOR THE NETS' WILLIAMS, WORK IS THE GAME
description: For a moment, it appeared as if Buck Williams were an impartial observer. He stood near the left side of the basket Saturday night during the Nets' game against the 76ers in Philadelphia. His hands rested on his thighs, and he stared at a teammate who held the ball near midcourt.

title: More Unmarked Graves Reported in Argentina
description: A human rights group said today that 188 more unmarked graves, believed to contain victims of the Government's war on terrorism in the late 1970's, have been found near Buenos Aires,

title: BRUNO WOLFE
description: Bruno Wolfe, a retired senior partner of Wolfe & Company, a New York brokerage concern, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: TWO MINERS IN GRUELING RACE TO LEAD UNION
description: If you want to understand coal miners, and the land where coal is mined, go to a bathhouse. It is to a bathhouse that the men who go far into the ground to dig for coal come after a shift in the mines before they go home. They remove their work clothes, one layer after another - heavy jackets, thick shirts, overalls, sometimes long underwear - and there they stand, naked, the whiteness of their bodies spoiled only by the darkest black coal dust that covers their hands and faces. They hang their clothes on hooks, then go to the steaming shower room.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha Microsystems, Irvine, Calif., has elected Richard A. Cortese president and chief executive officer, succeeding Robert E. Hitchcock, who is assuming the new positions of vice chairman and director of research.

title: 5 MINUTES TO MIDNIGHT
description: The Israeli Government already holds, or can easily take under a procedure it now uses, between 55 and 60 percent of the land in the West Bank. It is using most of the land not for pioneer settlements but for huge suburban developments. Israelis are attracted to them by cheap subsidized housing; at present rates 100,000 Israelis will live in the West Bank by 1987.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRISIS REPORTED IN MENTAL CARE OF AGED IN CITY
description: Thousands of elderly psychiatric patients are being kept hospitalized much longer than necessary in New York City because most nursing homes will not accept them.

title: Peter Ward, Guitarist, and Mai Cramer Married
description: The marriage of Mai Cramer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Cramer of New York and Sheffield, Mass., to Peter Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Ward of Lewiston, Me., took place yesterday. Rabbi David Whitman performed the ceremony at the Lyman House in Waltham, Mass.

title: FEMALE FIREFIGHTERS AN ISSUE IN SEATTLE
description: There are more female firefighters in Seattle than in any other city in the country, according to union figures. The situation engenders considerable pride and some resentment in the department.

title: Pekingese Is Best
description: Champion Mike-Mar's China Dragon, a Pekingese owned by Mrs. Alan Robson and Michael Wolf and handled by Wolf, was chosen yesterday as best at the 50th annual All-Toy Show of the Progressive Dog Club. The selection, at Loew's Summit Hotel, was made by William Bergum of Ventura, Calif.

title: CIVIL TRIAL ON BLAME FOR ACCIDENT AT THREE MILE ISLAND OPENS TODAY
description: The long-awaited trial to determine responsibility for the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in 1979 is scheduled to begin in Federal District Court in Manhattan today.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Republican Christmas

title: NO ROOM FOR THE FRAIL ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE GAUGES WARS OF THE 2000'S
description: The Air Force has peered into the next century and has seen a world of diffused military power, of many nations armed with advanced and even nuclear weapons, of frequent regional wars and worldwide terrorism.

title: THE ART OF CONCESSION
description: After election returns are in this week, more than half the candidates will face the need to concede. Here are instructions from a former concession-speech specialist on how best to turn that last, hold-back-the-tears moment on television into a gracious time of opportunity.

title: NBC RATINGS HURTING TOM SNYDER
description: FOR the second time in less than a year, Tom Snyder is suffering at the hands of NBC-TV. In December, NBC unceremoniously replaced Mr. Snyder's ''Tomorrow'' with ''Late Night With David Letterman.'' That left Mr. Snyder without a job.

title: THE OTHER DEFENDER OF THE CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bugles of Ankara
description: When a coup in Ankara dissolved democracy two years ago, Turkey's friends muted their displeasure. Terrorism was bleeding the country while its politicians fiddled and the economy foundered. The junta said military rule was a temporary expedient, the last resort of generals eager to step down once order was restored.

title: Commodities; A Lesson On Futures Spreading
description: SPREADING may be the most conservative form of futures trading, but a recent costly debacle in London illustrated that it takes more than a knowledge of computer programming to make these spreads pay off: it also takes a fundamental knowledge of how a particular market works and, more important, how markets can change overnight and make time-honored trading strategies outmoded in that time.

title: PHILADELPHIA CANDIDATES TAP MOOD OF THE VOTERS
description: ''When you get to Washington,'' shouted Frank Lanzilotta, his face growing livid with emotion, ''you tell them our younger generation has got to have jobs. That's the way to protect our Social Security.''

title: An I.M.F. Loan Would Aid Apartheid
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICA IN BRIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: DON'T TRUST POLITICIANS WHO QUOTE THE DEAD
description: Issues and party identification are still of some importance in choosing among candidates for the United States Senate. But as issues have become more complicated and confusing and party labels less meaningful, the application of other standards has become more important. Many objective indicators of behavior bear significantly on how a senator is likely to perform in office.

title: ELWAY'S CHARISMA PART OF UPSET VICTORY
description: Coach Paul Wiggin, whose Stanford team came from 10 points back to upset previously undefeated Washington, 43-31, Saturday, said: ''There is elation. We climbed a mountain, and when you get to the top it feels good.''

title: A U.S. SUPREMACY PASSES INTO HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILIES OF MENTALLY ILL: GETTING INVOLVED
description: ''You relatives of the mentally ill,'' said Dr. Judy Blitman, ''haven't been treated so well in the past. Until recently, doctors tried to keep you away, and wouldn't even take your phone calls.''

title: Injured Actress Is Improving
description: Eileen Brennan, the actress who portrays Capt. Doreen Lewis on the television series ''Private Benjamin,'' was reported in stable and improved condition today with injuries she suffered Wednesday when she was hit by a car.

title: John Henry Wins
description: John Henry, showing the form that earned him horse-of-the-year honors in 1981, finished strongly today to score a convincing victory in the $300,000 Oak Tree Invitational on the turf at Santa Anita.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item Saturday in New York Day by Day misstated Joseph A. Lehman's plea in Manhattan Criminal Court to charges of practicing medicine without a license. He pleaded not guilty.

title: DISABLED PSYCHOTHERAPISTS DISCUSS THEIR WORK
description: Ruth Jean Eisenbud, a psychotherapist and childhood polio victim, remembered the time one of her regular patients first noticed Dr. Eisenbud's limp.

title: 4 Conductors Named For Residency Program
description: Affiliate Artists Inc. has named four conductors to its Exxon-Arts Endowment Conductors Program. Andrew Litton will join the National Symphony Orchestra, Kirk Trevor the Dallas Symphony, Rachel Worby the Spokane Symphony and Christopher Wilkins the Oregon Symphony.

title: THIS IS SOCIALISM?
description: By definition, Socialism frightens rich people and entrepreneurs. For them, it is synonymous with waste and statist economic regulation. The French left is trying to change that image. Indeed, a cultural revolution is under way in Socialist France: the rehabilitation of the entrepreneurial spirit.

title: Rights Group Urges U.S. to Stop Sending Arms to Colombians
description: Citing numerous instances of politically inspired torture, murder and kidnappings in Colombia, the Americas Watch Committee has called for an end to United States military aid to that country.

title: HARD BARGAINING WITH GREECE EXPECTED
description: Hard bargaining is expected at the Greek-American talks that opened here this week on the future of four major air force and naval bases and other installations that the United States has operated in Greece since 1953.

title: The Dean Smith Plan
description: Between greeting a prospective recruit and directing basketball practice, North Carolina's head coach, Dean Smith, took a few hours last week to participate in a university seminar called ''Sports and American Values.''

title: THE STING EASED, THE RING PULLS COONEY BACK
description: THIS is the other neighborhood where Gerry Cooney grew up, a place where trucks with dirty exhausts clog traffic and suffocate the air during the day; a place where men lean at night against parked cars, talking street talk and drinking from brown paper bags. Someone from the suburbs might never really feel comfortable around here, and yet, this is Cooney's boxing home. It is at Gleason's, the ramshackle little gymnasium on Seventh Avenue and 30th Street where Cooney learned his trade and has returned to practice it again.

title: THE KEY ISSUES IN THE NEW YORK STATE CAMPAIGNS FOR GOVERNOR AND SENATOR
description: FOR GOVERNOR: DEMOCRAT Mario M. Cuomo Taxes and Budget Proposes temporarily capping state budget. Says "dramatic" tax cuts will not be possible in near future, but vows to "hold the line" on taxes on personal income, business and sales. Would, when possible, begin "gradual" income-tax cuts.

title: Warsaw Says Protests Prolong Military Rule
description: The Government, showing concern over calls for worker demonstrations and strikes next month, has warned Poles and Western nations that such protests could only prolong martial law.

title: PILOBOLUS: 'ELEGY FOR THE MOMENT'
description: ''THIS is ridiculous,'' a woman murmured on Friday night as the curtain went down on a dance by Pilobolus at the C.W. Post Concert Theater in Brookvale, L.I. ''It isn't even dance.'' A truer thought has likely seldom been phrased about the company. Pilobolus does call itself a dance theater group, and uses trained bodies for its outbursts of pictorial, gymnastic wit. But the company has never fit into any familiar category of dance and has remained, at its best, poised at some electric spot between the seriously ridiculous and the absurd sublime.

title: NORTH WEST TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PREP SCHOOLS FOR THE MILITARY ARE FLOURISHING
description: JENNY O'BRIEN and Ben Cotton attend a preparatory school, yet they are hardly typical preppies. Neither has any intention of applying to Yale, Harvard or Princeton. Their goal is to enter the United States Military Academy at West Point. Like their classmates at the Military Academy Preparatory School at Fort Monmouth, N.J., they wear Army fatiques to class rather than the Brooks Brothers shirts de rigueur at other exclusive schools.

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After income of $48,000 from discontinued operations for the latest qr and $83,000 for the yr-earlier period and after capital gains of $85,000 for the latest qr and $100,000 for the earlier period...C-After income of $14,000 from discontinued operations and a capital loss of $394,000...D-After a loss of $712,000 from discontinued operations and a capital gain of $55,000

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $133,000 for the latest first qr and $2,647,000 on the yr-ago first qr on the sale of assets

title: PAGANINI'S VIOLIN TO MAKE ITS NEW YORK CITY DEBUT
description: Niccolo Paganini's violin - a Guarnerius del Gesu, which was constructed in 1742 and which he called his ''cannon'' - will be heard for the first time in New York City on Thursday night when Salvatore Accardo, the Neapolitan virtuoso, performs all 24 of Paganini's caprices in Carnegie Hall.

title: ANTI-JEWISH VIOLENCE WITH EUROPEAN ROOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Telephone to Limit Billing Pay Calls to 3d Number
description: Beginning Dec. 1, the New York Telephone Company will no longer bill to a third telephone number calls made from pay phones unless the party being billed approves the call, the company said yesterday.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $104,000 for the qr and $278,000 for the 9 mos; the 1981 results were restated to include the results of Pam Systems Inc acquired ona pooling of interests basis

title: HEARING IS SET IN LEGAL AID STRIKE
description: City and court officials were ordered yesterday to appear in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Nov. 10 to answer charges by lawyers from the Legal Aid Society, in their 11-day-old strike.

title: AGRA INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $2,587,973

title: AS VOTING NEARS, 2 PARTIES PRESS ATTACKS ON ECONOMY
description: Republicans and Democrats continued their last-minute attacks over the economy and Social Security yesterday, as about 60 million Americans prepared to give President Reagan some sort of midterm report card by voting in today's off-year elections.

title: ...AND WHAT TO WATCH IN THE RETURNS
description: The professional politicians will be watching the early returns in Indiana, Maine, Rhode Island, New Jersey and Virginia tonight, seeking the first clues on how the Democrats are doing in their efforts to win the mid-term election.

title: 3 MILE ISLAND OWNERS AND BUILDER FAULT EACH OTHER FOR '79 ACCIDENT
description: Attorneys for the builder of the reactor damaged in the accident in 1979 at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania and the plant's operator traded strong accusations yesterday about which was to blame for the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident.

title: Soccer Arrows Are Sold
description: The Arrows, champions in each of the Major Indoor Soccer League's four previous seasons, have been sold by John Luciani to a Kansas City group headed by David Schoensteadt, a physician who is also the principal owner of the league's Kansas City Comets.

title: Hematoma Cited In Player's Death
description: A subdural hematoma - bleeding around the brain - caused the death of Travis Kelly, a punter for North Carolina A.& T., a state medical examiner reported today.

title: BIO-GAS OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Robot by Toshiba
description: The Toshiba Corporation said it had developed a fully computerized inspection robot for use in complex surroundings and dangerous environments such as nuclear power plants. It declined to state when it will start to market the robot or the price.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Stay the Course,' Again

title: U.S. Allows Chinese to Sue It
description: The Justice Department decided yesterday that Americans would be allowed to use Chinese courts to press their claims against the Chinese, and as a result agreed to allow a $4.4 million Chinese maritime lawsuit in American courts against the United States Government to proceed.

title: CITY OPERA: 'CARMEN' DEBUTS
description: THE City Opera performance of Bizet's ''Carmen'' on Saturday afternoon offered two debuts and one unscheduled replacement. Garry Grice replaced David Borgeson, who bowed out as Don Jose after Act I because of illness. Mr. Grice began rather woodenly, but he warmed up by the fourth act, in which he sang very passionately and stabbed his gypsy lover very energetically.

title: Kenty Is Puzzled
description: Hilmer Kenty still doesn't know why he quit. The former lightweight champion of the World Boxing Association, complaining that he didn't ''feel right,'' abandoned his fight Oct. 24 against Roberto Elizondo after just two rounds at McAfee, N.J. Hospital tests ordered by the New Jersey State Athletic Commission all were negative, so yesterday Kenty entered a hospital in Detroit, his hometown, for further examination.

title: REAGAN REFELCTS G.O.P. SENSITIVITY TO SOCIAL SECURITY ISSUE ON EVE OF VOTING
description: President Reagan spent his day in noncampaign work at the White House today, but he managed, at a brief public outing, to reflect the Republicans' last-minute concern over the Social Security issue in the Congressional elections.

title: IS A REPTILE ON THE VERGE OF BEING A MAMMAL
description: million-year-old grave in South Africa, had belonged to an animal the size of a ferret, about a foot long. This was one species, Thrinaxodon liorhinus, of the therapsids that dominated terrestrial life for millions of years before the rise of dinosaurs.

title: U.S. Observers Going To 3 Southern States
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was sending 264 observers to Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi to monitor the elections Tuesday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A list of candidates in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly identified one contender in the 84th Assembly District. He is J. Henry Neale Jr., running on the Democrtic and Liberal lines.

title: IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Charlotte Curtis; Awards Day In Texas
description: STONEWALL, Tex. THE indefatigable Lady Bird Johson gave her 13th annual highway beautification awards and barbecue in the Lyndon B. Johnson State Park here the other day. By 11 A.M., the former First Lady had fed the finalists and judges coffee and cookies in what used to be President Johnson's office at the LBJ Ranch and had arrived at the Visitor Center, which was already swarming with Texas highway men, their families, friends and neighbors. Backstage in the auditorium, Representative J.J. (Jake) Pickle climbed into his litter costume and Liz Carpenter, Mrs. Johnson's former press secretary, told him how much she appreciated his lastminute pinch-hitting, since the man who was supposed to play the litter part had been rained out in Beaumont, Tex., his airplane grounded.

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JURORS HEAR TAPES IN TRIAL OF PRESIDENT OF TEAMSTERS' UNION
description: The Government played its first wiretap evidence today in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Inside Sports Suspends Publication
description: Inside Sports magazine, which was just beginning to see light at the ends of both advertising and circulation tunnels, has suspended publication. Valerie Salembier, who holds the publisher's post, yesterday attributed the magazine's difficulties to ''no cash and not enough investors.''

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Index; International
description: French-Manitobans win their case A2 Soviet bars pacificist group from holding news conference A3 Attorney General Smith ''heart- ened'' by visit to Thailand A4 Around the World A5 U.S. backing raids on Nicaraguan border A6 Three members of hospital staff testify before massacre panel A13 Government/Politics Cuomo appeals to his supporters to get out the vote B1 City must answer charges by striking Legal Aid lawyers B3 Senate candidates in Jersey seek votes of independents B4 Challengers in Connecticut contests continue campaigning B4 Reagan shows concern on Social Security as election issue D22 ELECTION DAY Poll hours - New York, 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.; New Jersey, 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Connecticut, 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Stock and commodity markets, and banks - Some open, some closed; see page D2. HO Federal offices - Open. State and municipal offices - New York and New Jersey, closed; Connecticut, open. Post offices - Regular operations. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on regular weekday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - New York, closed; New Jersey and Connecticut, closings vary.

title: Housing Bond Backed by C.D.
description: A new type of bond has emerged in the tax-exempt market that gives bondholders the benefit of up to $100,000 of insurance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, a Government agency that insures deposits of savings and loan associations.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. San Diego Clippers, at Bryne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. Clippers' Randy Smith can tie Johnny Kerr's N.B.A. record of playing in 844 consecutive games. (Television -Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.).

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS: A SURVIVOR
description: A year and a half after its maiden flight, People Express Airlines is still aloft and even turning a profit in what has proved to be a dream-shattering atmosphere for some of its competitors.

title: Tribute to Sports In Stained Glass
description: The picture postcards of the stained-glass Rose Window are still the biggest seller to sightseers at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine at 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. ''That's the one everybody sends back to Aunt Edna,'' said Marietta Drummond, the manager of the Cathedral Shop.

title: ROCHESTER T he Moncton Alpines of the American Hockey League, having just tied the Rochester Americans on a last-second goal Sunday night, were happily turning their attention to more pressing concerns in the locker room.
description: ''Where's the beer?'' said Bill Riley, a right wing. ''Is this pro hockey or what? Let's get some beer in here.'' A few feet away, Paul Mulvey, the left wing on Riley's line, was still dripping from his shower as he held two dirty towels. ''Look at these things,'' he told an attendant. ''You call these clean?''

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRI-SOUTH INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits

title: VAN SCHAACK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOXBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Postal Service Reports Surplus for Fiscal Year
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger said today that the Postal Service finished the fiscal year 1982 with a surplus of $688 million, the second in three years.

title: Panel Sees Minimal Risk Of Big Nuclear Accident
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission made public today a study concluding that the probability of a ''worst case'' accident at a nuclear plant that could bring 100,000 deaths and billions of dollars in damage was ''extremely remote,'' one in a billion.

title: Bridge: Special Decks Are Revived In Package for Instructors
description: An old idea for effective bridge instruction has recently been revived with success. Special decks of cards are manufactured with marked backs, and the markings tell the dealer how to distribute the cards on a particular numbered deal. The deals are constructed to illustrate instructive points in bidding and play.

title: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Andrew J. Dempsey has been named executive vice president and Frank Zilla a vice president of the McCall Publishing Company.

title: APPEALS ON BOSTON LAYOFFS ACCEPTED
description: The ''reverse discrimination'' issue that spawned notable court cases in the 1970's reached the Supreme Court again today, this time with a new twist for the fiscally troubled 1980's.

title: MUSIC: EARLY AMERICAN SONGS WITH A EUROPEAN INFLUENCE
description: THE Alliance for American Song had some early American music for its audience at the Union Theological Seminary Sunday afternoon. Though most of the composers represented here were wanderers from Europe, there was a rough-cut, innocent craftsmanship in the music that mirrored their new world as well.

title: CHRISTIANS WON VAST NEW POWER IN LEBANON WAR
description: Second article of a series appearing periodically on the new balance of power in the Middle East since the war in Lebanon. BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 28 - The Israeli invasion of Lebanon did more than simply devastate the Palestine Liberation Organization militarily. It turned Lebanese politics upside down, tipping the balance of power radically in favor of the Maronite Christian minority and leaving the Moslem majority submissive and disillusioned.

title: MOFFETT AND ROME CAMPAIGNING TO THE END
description: Connecticut's major candidates today wound up in sharply contrasting manners their last full day of campaigning before Tuesday's election.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Rock, 5,000 Years' Closes
description: ''Rock 'N Roll! The First 5,000 Years,'' the musical conceived by Bob Gill and Robert Rabinowitz, closed after Sunday evening's performance at the St. James Theater. Directed and choreographed by Joe Layton, the play ran for 16 previews and 16 regular performances.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations for closely contested races. As always, our strongest recommendation is nonpartisan: vote. The polls are open in New York State from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. NEW YORK GOVERNOR AND LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR Mario Cuomo and Alfred Del Bello (D-L). COMPTROLLER Edward Regan (R-C). ATTORNEY GENERAL Robert Abrams (D-L). UNITED STATES SENATE Daniel Patrick Moynihan (D-L).

title: Western Airlines Chief Says He'll Stay in Post
description: Neil G. Bergt, the chairman and chief executive officer of Western Airlines, told the company's directors today that he has ''no immediate plans'' to leave Western, the company said.

title: Erie Lackawanna
description: The Erie Lackawanna Railway Company, which has been involved in reorganization proceedings since 1972, said that Federal Judge Robert B. Krupansky in Cleveland had affirmed the trustees' plan of reorganization. As provided in the plan, capital stock will be issued to satisfy certain claims in whole or part at the rate of one share for each $100 of claim. Other claims, which could be satisfied by issuing reorganization notes, instead will be paid in cash.

title: WALTON IS NOW ON A TIMETABLE
description: SAN DIEGO M ost basketball careers are measured by statistics, some by championships, and some by million-dollar contracts. Bill Walton's career has been measured by injuries and comebacks.

title: Foster Wheeler Job in Nigeria
description: A subsidiary of the Foster Wheeler Corporation said it had been named managing consultant for a petrochemical complex to be built in Nigeria.

title: UNITED CENTRAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WRONG DIRECTION IN NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: The Reagan Administration is pursuing a nuclear strategy that reverses the policies of every President since Dwight D. Eisenhower - policies that have avoided nuclear war for 37 years. Since the 1950's United States policy has stressed the importance of deterring nuclear war, promoting nuclear stability and reducing the possibility of accidental or unintentional nuclear war. Today, the Reagan Administration is moving rapidly in the opposite direction. The new Reagan policies, if carried out, will substantially increase the risk of nuclear holocaust.

title: MAN, 35, IS SOUGHT IN TYLENOL INQUIRY
description: The police in two states are searching for a man wanted for questioning in the cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Tylenol deaths here last month.

title: Halloween Activity Cut After Poison Scare
description: Trick-or-treating was noticeably reduced in most communities Sunday night after the seven deaths from cyanide in Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules in Chicago. The nation's grocery stores reported that candy sales had dropped 20 to 50 percent.

title: WRIGHT, WILLIAM E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTION DAY: WHO, WHEN, WHERE...
description: Today is Election Day. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York State, from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. in New Jersey and from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. in Connecticut. These are the principal contests:

title: Advertising; Election Ads Draw Criticism
description: NO matter what the individual results of Election Day voting are, one thing is certain, the advertising agency industry is generally appalled by the 1982 versions of political advertising. It's giving their business a bad name.

title: ON EXHIBIT, AN ART PROMOTER'S ART
description: Back in 1902, Alice Pike Barney, a well-known local playwright and painter of pastels, told a Washington newspaper, ''Washington is an ideal city for art, but its people are not at all artistic.''

title: WEINBERGER CONFERS IN SINGAPORE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger conferred with Singapore's leaders today on the first stop of an Asian tour to warn about a Soviet military buildup in the region.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: REAGAN. By Lou Cannon. 464 pages. Illus- trated. G.P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

description: B-After losses of $99,000 for the qr and $1,126,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Including a gain of $16,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net income after a loss of $246,000 from discontinued operations

title: Damson-Juniper
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said it had begun an offer for shares of the Juniper Petroleum Corporation that it does not already own. It is offering $10 a share. Damson owns 2.19 million common shares, or 49 percent, of Juniper.

title: Total Won't Sell Stake to Canadians
description: Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd., a subsidiary of the Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles, said today that it had withdrawn from a plan to increase Canadian ownership of its Canadian assets.

title: Nissan Profit Rises by 12.7%
description: The Nissan Motors Company, Japan's secondlargest car maker, after the Toyota Motor Company, said today that its unconsolidated profit rose 12.7 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30 because of foreign exchange gains and reduced taxes.

title: Financial Futures Up In Active Trading
description: Prices of all financial futures shot upward yesterday in active pre-Election Day trading. But the strong gains had little to do with politics. Rather, traders said, the heavy buying was partly attributed to the short covering that normally precedes bank and market closings and partly to the bullish mood that precedes a Treasury refunding.

title: MARRIOTT AGREES TO BOW OUT AS PLAYLAND MANAGER
description: Westchester County and the Marriott Corporation have agreed that Marriott will end its role as manager of Playland, the amusement park in Rye, next summer.

title: WESTCHESTER RENT RISES VOTED
description: The Westchester Rent Guidelines Board voted early today for rent increases of 4, 6 and 9 percent on one-, two- and three-year leases for apartments covered by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it had completed the acquisition of Federated Investors Inc. of Pittsburgh, an investment management services concern, for 1.25 million shares of Aetna common stock valued at about $210 million.

title: DANCE: CLASSICAL KOREAN
description: ''THE LAND OF MORNING CALM'' was a fine title for Sunday night's program of Korean classical dance and music at the Ohio Theater. The dances were as fresh as a spring morning, and they all progressed at an unruffled pace.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an unrealized foreign currency translation loss of $233,000

title: Israel Opens New Hotel In Disputed Sinai Area
description: Israel defied Egyptian protests today and opened a luxury hotel in the disputed Taba border zone of Sinai. The Avia Sonesta, a 10-story white structure just 200 yards from the present Egytian border, is expected to increase tourism to Taba and Israel's neighboring port, Eilat.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a net gain of $220,000 for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of a subsidiary

title: AS A CAREER LEADS TO SELF-EXAMINATION
description: AMERICAN psychiatrists are increasingly distressed because they believe too few medical school students are being attracted to the profession to keep psychiatry vital and to meet the nation's mental health needs.

Lautenberg, the Democratic candidate. He does not favor the creation of an independent Palestinian homeland; he favors a territory federated with Jordan.

title: SENATE NOMINEES IN JERSEY SEEK INDEPENDENT VOTE
description: The Republican and Democratic candidates for the United States Senate in New Jersey used their last full day of campaigning today to shore up their support and to try to lure the state's large bloc of independent voters to their side.

title: REAGAN TO EXPAND DUTIES OF MARINES INTO EAST BEIRUT
description: President Reagan has agreed to expand the mission of the United States Marines in Lebanon to include patrols in East Beirut, the State Department said today.

title: Curbs on Iran Extended
description: President Reagan today extended for one year limitations on financial dealings with Iran that resulted from the hostage crisis in 1980.

title: France Drops Freeze in Favor of a Controls Plan
description: France's Socialist Government today scrapped its unpopular four-month-old program of wage and price freezes and replaced it with new restrictions that have been reluctantly accepted by workers' and employers' groups.

title: GRUBB & ELLIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago 9 mos shr earnings reflect an adjustment for the issuance of 3 million shrs in connection with the Feb 1981 merger with GMR Properties

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Income Gains 1.7% in Period
description: Americans' personal income rose 1.7 percent in the April-June quarter, with residents of all but three states sharing in the gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 5 MEN PLEAD GUILTY TO 822 CRIMES AGAINST 100 IN WILD SPREE ON L.I.
description: Five Brooklyn men pleaded guilty today to a total of 822 charges, including robbery, rape and attempted murder, stemming from a crime spree on Long Island last May that involved more than 100 victims. The crimes took place in a private home and two diners.

title: Market Place; The Attraction Of Manville
description: THE Manville Corporation offers the unusual spectacle of a company that earns money while operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: TRENCH REPORTED 'DUG' BY LIGHTNING
description: LIGHTNING can start forest fires, split trees and electrocute those foolish enough to stand under them, but it is not reputed as an excavator. Nevertheless, last April 3 it apparently dug several trenches, one of them 10 feet long, near a home in New Hartford, Conn.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRANSAMERICA TO BUY FRED S. JAMES
description: The Transamerica Corporation, one of the nation's leading insurance companies, has signed an agreement to buy Fred S. James & Company, the big insurance broker, for about $300 million, both said yesterday.

title: RUDDICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
ONE SMALL STEP ON JOBS
description: The Job Training Partnership Act of 1982, signed by the President on Oct. 13, revives the Great Society approach to job training. As such, it represents a victory of pragmatism over ideology in the Reagan Administration. But despite its great potential to train or retrain many of those in need, this legislation is not designed to serve the vast majority of those who are least equipped to get and hold a regular job. And since it is not designed to create jobs, it will have no effect on current high unemployment.

Mayotte Is Upset
description: Michael Westphal, a West German teen-ager, scored a big upset today by beating second-seeded Tim Mayotte of the United States, 4-6, 6-4, 7-5, in the Seiko Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LARGE AND SMALL

title: ALEXANDER WRITE-OFF INCREASED
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. announced today that it would take a further $15 million write-off in the value of the Alexander Howden Group, which it purchased earlier this year.

title: TV: CHESTER'S PRIEST, FATHER BROWN, IN SERIES
description: BRAGGING about her dead husband's unflagging cheerfulness, the lady haughtily explains, ''We had Christmas in this house 365 days a year.'' The mild-mannered priest quickly murmurs, ''Oh dear, how terrible for you!'' This is the special, often paradoxical world of Father Brown, the detective priest first created by G.K. Chesterton in 1911 and now, beginning tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET and for the next three weekly installments, the star of public television's ''Mystery!''series.

title: Playboy to Cut Circulation Rate Base
description: Playboy, which has been having difficulty meeting its 5 million circulation rate base, will cut it to 4.4 million with its January issue.

SHERRITT GORDON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLIBURTON TUMBLES BY 38%
description: The Halliburton Company reported yesterday that a marked drop in results from domestic oilfiled services caused net income in the third quarter to plunge 38 percent and revenues to shrink by 21.4 percent.

title: Mead Cuts Payout
description: The Mead Corporation said directors had halved the quarterly dividend 25 cents a common share, payable Dec. 1 to holders of record Nov. 10. The paper producer said the cut had been made to conserve cash and maintain financial strength. It added that its cost-cutting steps should place it in an ''enviable position when the economy recovers.''

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split

title: KILLING IN CENTRAL PARK IS 10th THERE THIS YEAR
description: An unidentified man dressed in a jogging outfit was found murdered yesterday morning in Central Park, the 10th person slain so far this year in the park. There were four slayings in the park in 1981 and two in 1980.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: A NEW VERSION OF 'THE PLAY OF DANIEL'
description: NOAH GREENBERG'S New York Pro Musica version of the 13th-century ''Play of Daniel'' bowed at the Cloisters in January 1958 and quickly became the most famous medieval staged production of its time. Its frequent revivals and tours and its subsequent recording made it an American institution. More cruically, it awakened a national audience for pre-Baroque music, and determined our very notion of how medieval music should sound.

title: INDIANA GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Talking Politics ''Money never wins elections.'' - Guy Vander Jagt, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
