title: MONDALE ON THE ROAD FOR DISTANT GOAL
description: ''Do you remember what I told you back in 1980?'' Walter F. Mondale asks in countless speeches across the country these days. More often than not, he is finding the answer is yes.

title: Voting Coverage On TV and Radio
description: Election coverage on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks will begin tonight at 7 P.M. and continue until 2 A.M. Among the public television channels, election coverage will begin on Channel 50 at 8 P.M. and on Channel 31 at 10 P.M. Channel 13 will present its election coverage with a 30-minute special at 11 P.M. Other channels will provide updates in their regularly scheduled news programs.

title: PYRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $942,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $13.5 million

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Curbside Esoterica

title: SHOWDOWN NEARS IN FEUD OVER ALCOHOL STUDIES
description: ABITTER decade-long feud in the field of alcoholism research appears to be heading for a showdown. Several investigations now under way may finally determine whether the authors of a major alcoholism study perpetrated an immense fraud or whether their critics have made unjust accusations based on flimsy evidence.

title: Bannister Trade Looms
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers say they have agreed to a trade with the Seattle Mariners if they can sign Floyd Bannister, the Mariners' left-handed pitcher, within 72 hours. Bannister, who led the American League in strikeouts this year, has turned down the Mariners' final contract offer of $2 million for three years.

title: 796 A WINNING NUMBER
description: I n football jargon the play is described as 796 sprintout, and it was the means to an end for St. John's in a 49-46 victory over Hofstra last Saturday. Todd Jamison, the quarterback for the Redmen, accounted for four touchdowns with the 796 sprintout, three by running and one by passing.

title: A SCHOOL SYSTEM CHANGES THE MIX
description: THERE is a waiting list of more than 500 pupils at the Dennison Fundamental School in Tanglewood, Colo. - enough to fill another entire school. The fundamental school bears no relation to fundamentalist religion; it is merely an alternative public school with a bluntly stated commitment to traditional education. Its popularity is a sign of the times, proof of a conservative trend in education as in politics.

title: Guatemalan Refugees In Mexico Worry U.N.
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has expressed his ''great concern'' to the Mexican Government about threats to the security of some 30,000 Guatemalan peasants who have sought refuge in Mexico.

title: Cyanamid in Swiss Bid
description: The American Cyanamid Company has requested permission to buy a line of Swiss skin care toiletries, the Federal Trade Commission said today. Under a 1973 order, Cyanamid cannot acquire any concern that makes or sells toiletries in the United States without prior consent. The company seeks to acquire Laboratoire LaPrarie S.A., which makes skin care products, from Armin Mattli of Zurich.

title: IS THE ALARM OVER HERPES EXCESSIVE?
description: IS the widespread public alarm over genital herpes justified by what is actually known about its past and present prevalence in the United States? Or is it only another case in which a disease comes from nowhere in particular to become medically fashionable for a number of years, then fade out as the spotlight moves on to some other disorder?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Saturday incorrectly stated the number of positions possible for the Rubik's Cube. It is 43,252,003,274,489,856,000.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: IF IT'S ELECTION NIGHT, IT'S TIME TO PARTY
description: ''I tried to rent a funeral home but couldn't find one,'' Richard A. Viguerie, the conservative fund raiser, said with a laugh.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Are there any physiological effects from the lights in copying machines?

title: OPERA: 'CARMEN' OPENS CAPITAL SEASON
description: In the two seasons since Martin Feinstein became its general director, the Washington Opera has grown greatly in stature, if not in daring or imagination.

title: INVESTIGATION OF JUDGE POINTS UP U.S.-NEVADA RIFT
description: An unusual grand jury investigation of a Federal district judge is reviving the issue of the proper role of state and Federal officials in controlling crime in Nevada.

title: A BIT OF SUSPICION BUILT INTO THE CIRCUITRY
description: AWHILE ago, I purchased some sheet music ($4.25) and a clarinet reed ($1.20) at a small-town store not yet endowed with a bell-andwhistle-equipped electronic cash register. The sales clerk used a calculator to total the sale and figure in the tax before ringing up the final amount ($7.73). When I remonstrated that $7.73 couldn't possibly be the correct figure, she pointed to the calculator's authoritative red display, which verified that sum was indeed $7.73.

title: POCKET TV, ULTRALIGHT
description: Close on the heels of the phenomenally successful Sony Walkman comes its logical successor, the Sony Watchman, weighing in at 19 ounces.

title: WESTERN SAVINGS IN WEBB STOCK PACT
description: Western Savings, the nation's 29th-largest savings and loan association and the biggest in Arizona, said today that it had agreed to acquire a nearly 25 percent stake in the Del E. Webb Corporation for $26 million.

title: SUITS FORCE CHAPTER 11
description: Following the lead of the Manville Corporation, the Amatex Corporation said yesterday that a continuing flood of asbestosrelated suits had forced it to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: PRO-KUHN OWNERS LOOKING TO RESTORE HIM TO OFFICE
description: The dispute over the re-election of Bowie Kuhn as baseball's commissioner apparently did not end today with his failure to win a third seven-year term. As soon as the votes had been counted, his supporters began what seemed a more subtle effort to have Kuhn succeed himself.

title: MIDLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: UNITED MISSOURI BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Appalachia in the City

title: U.S. Agency Plans Test On Cleaning Up Toxin
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would test a ''promising'' new technique for cleaning up a deadly chemical at a contaminated site in Missouri.

title: U.S. BACKING RAIDS AGAINST NICARAGUA
description: The United States is supporting small-scale clandestine military operations against Nicaragua intended to harass but not to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: THAI VISIT 'HEARTENS' U.S. AIDE
description: Attorney General William French Smith left here today feeling ''heartened'' by Thailand's attacks on the region's opium production and heroin traffic, but also with a keener sense of the obstacles to controlling narcotics at their source.

title: A Movable Slogan
description: T he race for governor that finally comes to an end today offers a lesson on how political slogans really can be just so many interchangeable parts.

title: Opera: Ramey Is Mefistofele
description: PERHAPS the greatest virtue of the New York City Opera's ''Mefistofele'' is its audience. New Yorkers seem to adore Boito's massively ambitious opera, and they love the way this company does it.

title: Icahn Motion Denied
description: Dan River Inc. said yesterday that a Federal court had denied a motion by Carl C. Icahn and his affiliated companies to transfer the company's lawsuit against the Icahn group to New York from Virginia. Dan River also said it had amended its complaint to charge, among other things, that the Icahn group's tender offer for control of the textile concern violates securities laws and to block the group from buying any shares that might be tendered to it.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; shr earnings are fully diluted and have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-3 common stock split declared in Mar 1982

title: TELECONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock splits of July 1, 1982 and July 1, 1981

title: Iran Says It Launches; Offensive Near Iraqi Port
description: Iranian forces have launched an offensive near Iraq's strategic oil port of Basra, the Iranian press agency reported today.

title: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-Net income; the results for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect a nonrecurring net provision of $4,725,000 for actions taken to improve efficiencies by centralizing operations

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago 9 mos results include a gain equal to 21 cents a shr from nonoperating items

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the 1981 results restated for adoption of F.A.S.B.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: FRENCH-MANITOBANS WIN CASE: VIVE LE FRANCAIS!
description: In order to regain official status for their mother tongue and reverse what they see as cultural erosion, members of the old but newly assertive French-speaking population of Manitoba have challenged the validity of Englishlanguage traffic tickets and in the process has called into question all the laws of this prairie province.

title: CUOMO AND LEHRMAN MAKE FINAL APPEALS FOR SUPPORT
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who began his formal quest for the governorship on a cold and rainy day last March, wound up his campaign under sunny skies yesterday with an appeal to his supporters to get out the vote today.

title: What the Election Is Not About
description: ''They,'' says President Reagan at the end of the campaign, ''even drove prayer out of our nation's classrooms.'' Who are They and in any case what does forced prayer in public schools have to do with today's election?

title: More G.E. Layoffs
description: The General Electric Company said it would lay off 5,200 of its remaining 10,000 employees at its Appliance Park plant here from the end of November. The company said appliance sales are 15 percent below last year's levels. A G.E. spokesman said employees affected by the move were expected to be back at work on Jan. 3.

title: DIVISION HEAD RETIRING AT McDONNELL DOUGLAS
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that John C. Brizendine, 57, president of its Douglas Aircraft Company division since 1973, had decided to retire. James E. Worsham, who joined the company earlier this year, was named to succeed him.

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices rallied strongly, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 13.98 points, to 1,005.70. Analysts said that higher bond prices, which reduce the competitive edge those debt securities have over equities, fueled the rally. Wall Street's feeling that G.O.P. candidates will not fare too badly in today's elections was also a factor, they said. (Page D1.)

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $34,000

title: MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after income of $1,901,000 from cumulative effect of an accountingchange; the 1981 periods were restated

title: HONDA'S FIRST U.S. BUILT CAR ROLLS OUT
description: Honda's first American-built car rolled off the assembly line here at 8:30 A.M. today. There was none of the hoopla usually associated with such an event -no ribbon-cutting, no speeches by dignitaries, no news reporters and no television cameras. Only Honda employees and executives were on hand to watch a slate-gray Accord emerge. It is the only model planned for now at this assembly plant, 35 miles northwest of Columbus.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rise Foreseen In Car Output
description: The five major American auto makers will increase production slightly in the first quarter of 1983, according to a report published today in Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: DART & KRAFT CHOOSES FOOD BRANCH PRESIDENT
description: Michael A. Miles, the 43-year-old former senior vice president of Heublein Inc. and chairman of its Kentucky Fried Chicken enterprise, has been elected president of Kraft Inc., the food products unit of the Chicago-based conglomerate Dart & Kraft Inc. Mr. Miles succeeds Arthur W. Woelfle, 62, who will become chairman and continue as Kraft's chief operating officer, Dart & Kraft announced.

title: Diamond Accepts Goldsmith Merger
description: The Diamond International Corporation said it had agreed to merge with a company affiliated with Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who already holds about 40 percent of the company's common stock.

title: William & Mary Wins 5-Mile Run
description: William and Mary won the university division title, and Brandeis, the defending champion, took the college division crown in the 74th IC4A cross-country championships at Franklin Park today.

title: Prosecutor Denies Morris Entrapped
description: The prosecutor in Mercury Morris's drug trial said today that the former Miami Dolphin star was motivated by greed, and was not entrapped by investigators.

title: PEOPLES JEWELERS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes $1 million gain on a sale of property and a $8,714,000 loss on the sale of the company's U.S. division...C-Net income after a special loss of $746,00

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Company has appointed Alan E. Christie and Norman Gittleman vice presidents.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
A BLASS VIEW OF STYLE: FLUID AND CIVILIZED
description: As the spring openings entered their second week Bill Blass, in his own way, made a fairly revolutionary statement yesterday morning: He came out strongly for clean-cut, nondistorting clothes. At a time when some designers here and abroad have decided that the era of easy, casual clothes was winding down and women were now ready for clothes that pinched and clutched the body, Mr. Blass has presented fluid designs that look slick but comfortable.

title: STAGE: 'NEW FACES OF 1952' REVIVED
description: OF the seven editions of ''New Faces'' revues that the late Leonard Sillman produced on Broadway between 1934 and 1968, the most celebrated was the 1952 edition. It launched more successful careers than any of the other editions (Eartha Kitt, Paul Lynde, Alice Ghostley, Ronny Graham, Carol Lawrence). It had more memorable songs (''Lizzie Borden,'' ''Monotonous,'' ''Love Is a Simple Thing,'' ''Guess Who I Saw Today,'' ''Boston Beguine,'' ''Penny Candy''). And it was the source of both an original cast album and a film version.

title: BRINK'S WITNESS TESTIFIES ON SWITCH OF GETAWAY VEHICLES IN HOLDUP
description: A 20-year-old woman testified in the Brink's robbery pretrial hearings today that she saw a red van and a U-Haul truck in a shopping center parking lot adjacent to her home, and then watched a man with a rifle run from one vehicle to the other. She immediately called the police, she said.

title: DISPUTE ON WAGE CLAUSE IMPEDES TALKS
description: The optimism that surrounded the National Football League's labor negotiations Sunday dissipated quickly yesterday when the players charged management with misleading the union about management's latest contract proposal.

title: Key Rates
description: ** Split rate, 11.50-12.00 * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: G.M. Maintains Dividend Rate
description: The General Motors Corporation's board voted to maintain the quarterly dividend at 60 cents a share, payable Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 10. The company said the dividend ''is due in large part to improved operating results in 1982, reflecting a new spirit of cooperation between management and employees, which has improved quality and lowered costs.''

title: FREE THE 18 MILLION
description: When Lewis Lehrman said the other day that he was going over the heads of the political establishment to appeal directly to the ''18 million free people ... of the State of New York,'' I trust he wasn't implying the existence of an unacknowledged body of enslaved people in our state.

title: Court to Rule on State Bank Taxes
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state that imposes a tax on bank shares can include the bank's holdings of Federal notes and bonds in calculating the value of the shares.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DISTORTED IMAGES OF EAST TIMOR'S PAST AND PRESENT
description: To the Editor:

title: VERMONT RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Chess: Kudrin and Miles Win Title In Benedictine Tournament
description: The fifth Benedictine International Tournament, in Manchester, England, was won by the international master Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn., and the grandmaster Anthony Miles of Britain. Each tallied 7 1/2-1 1/2 in the nine-round Swiss system event.

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rader Ranger Manager
description: Doug Rader, an unpredictable, carefree soul during his 11 years as a major league third baseman, was named manager yesterday of the Texas Rangers. The 38-year-old Rader, who has never managed in the big leagues before, spent the last three years as manager of the San Diego Padres' Hawaii farm in the Pacific Coast League.

title: PEREZ DE CUELLER ASSAILS U.N. PAPER
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar described as ''unfortunate and ill-considered'' today a section of a United Nations report that unfavorably compared the Western press with that of the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: ASK MEN WHO KNOW
description: President Reagan has promised to decide within the next couple of weeks on a plan for MX missiles to present to the new Congress. The decision was deliberately deferred until after the election, but then it will come quickly.

title: WITNESS SAYS SUSPECT DESCRIBED AMBUSH OF JUDGE
description: An El Paso lawyer who has pleaded guilty to complicity in the assassination of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. testified today that the person accused of being the triggerman, a previously convicted hired killer, had told him he killed the judge with a single ''clean shot'' in the back.

title: LITCO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EMETT & CHANDLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $474,000 or 25 cents a shr for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of a subsidiary

title: POPE IS MET JOYFULLY BY NUNS IN THE HOMELAND OF ST. TERESA
description: Pope John Paul II journeyed into the heartland of Spanish monasticism today on the first full day of his trip to Spain. He was following the footsteps of St. Teresa of Avila, the mystical nun who shaped convent life as it is known today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Short Rebellion

title: BOXING COVERAGE FILLS FOOTBALL VOID
description: T elevision viewers who once felt overwhelmed by too much pro football may be punchy from last weekend's seemingly endless stream of network boxing shows.

title: THE THERMAL MAN
description: N ow that Bowie Kuhn is a lame duck baseball commissioner, his thermal underwear should be retired and sent to the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: FRASER INC (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results have been restated

title: Election Day Closings
description: The nation's stock markets will be open today, Election Day, but most of the commodity markets will be closed. Banks in New York and New Jersey will be closed, while those in Connecticut will be open.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1982 figures were restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 concerning foreign currency translations

title: ATLANTIC ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPENDING OFF 0.2% FOR CONSTRUCTION
description: Spending on building construction declined a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in September, although construction spending for housing continued to rise as interest rates declined, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRUMMOND PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-The company did not provide yr-ago comparative results because it purchased most of its asset base in Aug 1981

title: '82 Loss Seen By U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, will report a loss for the full year, David M. Roderick, chairman of the company, said yesterday at a meeting of the New York Society of Securities Analysts.

title: DOW POSTS 13.98 GAIN, TO 1,005.70
description: Stocks rallied yesterday in response to climbing bond prices and growing sentiment on Wall Street that Republican candidates would not fare as badly in today's elections as forecasters had expected last week.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $296,000 from a refund of windfall profits tax withheld and income of $208,526 from discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $44,306 for the qr and $38,437 for the 9 mos...D-Includes a loss of $368,608 from discontinued operations

title: TREASURY YIELDS FALL SHARPLY
description: Amid widespread anticipation of lower interest rates in coming weeks, yields fell sharply yesterday for outstanding Treasury notes and bonds and for those scheduled to be sold this week and next.

title: SOVIET BLOCKS PACIFISTS' NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Soviet authorities once again today prevented a news conference by Moscow's battered group of unsanctioned pacifists, barring members and Western reporters from the building where the meeting was to take place.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: THE INTER-GENERATIONAL COMPACT
description: To the Editor:

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLIGHT OF THE POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: UP-RIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business and the Law; S.E.C. Dispute On Dirks Case
description: THE Federal Government frequently speaks with a forked tongue, but it is rare that the split is as obvious as in the Securities and Exchange Commission's case against Raymond L. Dirks, the man who blew the whistle on the Equity Funding Corporation of America scandal nearly 10 years ago.

title: RIDER, AT 38, AIMS FOR QUICK SUCCESS
description: Rodney Jenkins says he loves New York - but only for a week at a time. ''I'm just a country boy,'' the nation's premier rider, who is from Virginia, said between jumps at the Great Lawn of Central Park yesterday. ''Coming here 20 years ago was a great experience. I like it for a week, but I don't know how much more I can take after that.''

title: Allied Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, which recently consolidated its Stern's and Gertz store divisions, said it will change the name of its Gertz stores to Stern's on March 1. Stern's operates seven stores in New Jersey and Gertz has eight stores on Long Island.

title: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Newsprint Prices Cut
description: Two Canadian newsprint producers cut prices today to match earlier reductions by leading United States manufacturers. MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. and British Columbia Forest Products Ltd. both announced 6.3 percent reductions in the price of newsprint sold in the United States, effective immediately. The price of a metric ton of newsprint, about 2,205 pounds, was cut to $468.50 from $500.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $60,000 for the qr and $400,000 for the yr...C-Net income including extraordinary gains of $301,000 for the qr and $436,000 for the yr

title: CLEMSON INQUIRY DECISION REACHED
description: The infractons committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has reached a decision after an investigation of Clemson's football program but will not make it public now, according to a committee member, Minette Massey of the University of Miami.

title: Ogilvy & Mather's Net Declines 28.2%
description: Ogilvy & Mather International issued its third-quarter financial statement yesterday and it was a downer.

title: KING VIDOR, 88, DIRECTOR OF FILMS FOR MORE THAN 40 YEARS, IS DEAD
description: King Vidor, the director of many pace-setting movies beginnning more than half a century ago, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his ranch in the rolling seaside hills of Paso Robles, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Too Quick on Trigger
description: Don Nehlen, the West Virginia football coach, says he has enough to worry about besides the team's rifle-toting, trigger-happy Mountaineer mascot.

title: RYDER SYSTEM FILLS TOP EXECUTIVE POST
description: Ryder System Inc., the big vehicle-leasing company with projected revenues of $2.3 billion this year, announced yesterday that M. Anthony Burns had been moved up to chief executive officer.

title: CREPERIES TO KABOB-ITS
description: Ruth Hanson realizes that this may sound a little silly, but she has been bothered for some time by a nagging realization that her automatic drip coffee maker is not quite so nice as the automatic drip coffee makers of her friends and neighbors.

title: WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: The yr-ago 9 mos results include a gain equal to 9 cents a shr on the sale of aportion of business operations

NEW YORK AIR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
London's Brixton Area Erupts in Violence
description: About 300 youths set fires and hurled bricks and bottles at policemen in London's Brixton district today after scores of officers evicted squatters from the rundown area where fierce riots flared last year, Scotland Yard said.

title: Referendum on Arms Is Upheld for Suffolk
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that an advisory referendum question on a nuclear arms freeze could remain on the ballot today in Suffolk County.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOMINION FOUNDRIES & STEEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: CHEMICAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officer Held as Thief; Killed 'Angel' in 1981
description: The city policeman who fatally shot a member of the Guardian Angels last winter was suspended without pay from the police force today pending a departmental investigation of charges that he stole a Cadillac from a parking lot.

title: Gladys Attwood, Aided Orphans in World War I
description: Gladys Hollingsworth Attwood, a descendant of early settlers of New Canaan, Conn., and a leader in the American program for helping European war orphans during World War I, died Sunday at her home in New Canaan. She was 94 years old.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: CIGARETTE PRICES TIPTOE HIGHER
description: The nation's cigarette companies, hoping to avoid the jolt of a major price increase on Jan. 1 when an 8-cent-a-pack increase in the Federal excise tax goes into effect, have decided on a strategy of gradual price increases for the remainder of 1982.

title: WADELL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ST JUDE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: LEBANESE SAYS ISRAEL IS PARALYZING GOVERNMENT IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan accused Israel today of ''paralyzing Government functions'' in the areas of Lebanon that its troops occupy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Che Guevara era of Lebanese politics is over. People here have had their fling with radicalism.

title: Insurance Merger
description: The ISU Companies and Insurers Group Inc. said they had agreed to merge.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Astrodome in Houston has been selected as the site for the World Boxing Council's heavyweight title fight between Larry Holmes and the challenger, Randy (Tex) Cobb. It is scheduled for Monday, Nov. 22, or Friday, Nov. 26. ... The American Bowling Congress has rejected an appeal by Glenn Allison to recognize three consecutive 300 games he bowled last summer. ... Coach Howard Schnellenberger of Miami of Florida suspended his quarterback, Mark Richt, and Richt's roommate, Bruce Fleming, a freshman linebacker, for one game for violating an undisclosed team rule, and said that Kyle Vanderwende, a freshman, would start at quarterback against Maryland Saturday. ... Steve Pelluer, the University of Washington quarterback who injured his elbow in a loss to Stanford Saturday, will miss the Huskies' game against U.C.L.A. this weekend.

title: MAPLE LEAF GARDENS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $331,588 from transfer of Colorado hockey franchise to NewJersey

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Guilty of Voting Fraud Freed by Alabama Panel
description: Two black women whose conviction of voting fraud became a rallying cry for extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 won their freedom today.

title: SCOUTING;
description: At the end of the Golden State Warriors' practice in Oakland, Calif., yesterday, John Bach, the assistant coach, walked back to his office, picked out the yellow-lined sheet with Michael Ray Richardson's name on it and added $150 to Richardson's fine.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $68,000...C-Net income including a tax credit of $52,000 for the qr and 6 mos...D-Including a tax credit of $136,000

title: SYSTEMATICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $271,220 gain from the sale of surplus real estate...C-Net loss

title: MONEY FUNDS EXAMINE PRIVATE INSURANCE IDEA
description: The country's mutual fund companies, stung by new competition for consumers' savings, are exploring the possibility of offering insurance to back the deposits in their money market funds. They also say they are considering lower minimum deposits to attract more customers.

title: WHEN THERE'S MONEY LEFT IN THE CAMPAIGN KITTY
description: The four members of Congress come from different corners of America, but they share an unusual condition. With the 1982 campaign all but over, they, like a number of their colleagues who have had no significant political opposition, have lots of money left in their coffers.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1982
description: International A widening of the marines' mission in Lebanon to include patrols in East Beirut has been approved by President Reagan, the State Department said. Administration officials said the action was requested by President Amin Gemayel, who wants the American-Italian-French force to assume more important responsibilities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israeli forces were criticized by Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan of Lebanon. He accused the Israeli occupation forces of ''paralyzing local government functions by interfering in public affairs'' and he warned Lebanese officials and civilians that they might be stripped of their citizenship in cases of ''collaboration with Israel.'' (A12:1-4.)

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOCTORS TESTIFY ABOUT MASSACRE
description: Three members of the staff of a hospital in Beirut said here today that they had heard gunfire and artillery during the Christian Phalangist operations in nearby Palestinian refugee camps in September but testified that they thought they were the sounds of battle, not the mass slaughter that was taking place.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $424,622 related to the company's repurchase of $2,630,900 principal amount of its debentures

title: WAVERLEY ROOT, A JOURNALIST AND ESSAYIST ON FRENCH FOOD
description: Waverley Root, the food essayist who was the very image of the cultivated American expatriate, and whose occasional horror over adulterated Bordeaux could be as keen as his repeated ecstasies over French gastronomy, died Sunday in Paris of a pulmonary ailment. He was 79 years old.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BANKER IS NAMED TO EXPANDED POST FOR CITY FINANCES
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that Karen N. Gerard, his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, was resigning and would be replaced by Kenneth Lipper, a 41-year-old investment banker.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IF it seemed that it was Halloween all last week, it was in large p art because of the American spring collections, which were filled w ith the sort of clothes that many of us hoped had died with the R etro movement and Jacques Fath. Heavy satin, peplums - the most i nsidious device ever invented to make the hips look bigger - and w ide belts have been revived with a vengeance. Worse, many of the A merican spring collections seemed blatantly to ape those of Europe, t hough with little of the design expertise, a fact noted by many f oreign visitors.

title: INDIA AND PAKISTAN LEADERS AGREE TO FORM PANEL TO SOLVE PROBLEMS
description: The leaders of India and Pakistan met today and agreed to establish a permanent joint commission to work out problems between their countries as they arise. The move appeared to hasten progress on improving relations between them.

title: KUHN IS VOTED OUT AS BASEBALL COMMISSIONER
description: Bowie Kuhn was deposed as commissioner of baseball today when five teams in the National League voted not to renew his contract after 14 years in office.

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Buyer Drops Plan On Algeria L.N.G.
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it would withdraw from a project to import large quantities of liquefied natural gas from Algeria.

title: Dunes Casino
description: Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc. said a subsidiary had agreed to a contract with First Continental Trust Ltd. to raise $175 million in financing for its Atlantic City Hotel-Casino. The financing is to be completed by Feb. 25. Construction of the complex was halted in 1979 because of a lack of funds.

title: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 25 percent stock divd which was paid in Sept 1982

title: CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a loss of $221,000 for the qr and a gain of $373,000 for the9 mos from discontinued operations, a gain of $5,677,000 for the 9 mos on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,027,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-After a loss of $2,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $280,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations

title: BARRINGER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Net Doubles At Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday that its net income in the third quarter more than doubled to $16.3 million, or $1.20 a share, from $5.8 million, or 42 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Sales edged up 3.5 percent, to $522.1 million, from $504.3 million.

title: DWINDLING CATCHES PLAGUE SHRIMPERS IN CAROLINA
description: Before dawn one morning late last week, at the height of the shrimp season, Bobby Chaplin fired up the diesel of his 45-foot trawler and eased into the blackness of Port Royal Sound, expecting to return after sunset with a good catch.

title: FLAMES SEND DEVILS TO 6TH LOSS IN ROW
description: The New Jersey Devils, after scoring three goals in the first period, lost their aggressiveness and sharpness and were beaten, 6-3, by the Calgary Flames tonight. It was the Devils' sixth consecutive loss.

title: DRUG CASE DEFENDANT IS ACCUSED OF THREAT TO SHOOT PROSECUTOR
description: A narcotics defendant was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a Federal charge of threatening to ''put a bullet in the head'' of the prosecutor handling his case.

title: VERSATILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; after preferred divids there were no shr earnings for the latest 9 mos

title: POLES FLOCK PEACEFULLY TO CEMETERIES
description: Poles observed All Saints' Day today by flocking to cemeteries all over this deeply Roman Catholic country to place flowers and lighted candles on the graves of relatives and friends.

title: Talks on Fate of Bases Resume in Athens
description: Greek and United States negotiators resumed their talks in Athens today to decide on the possible renewal of a 29-year-old agreement on the status and operation of American military bases in Greece.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Smith Barney Suit
description: Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company has filed a $20.3 million suit against Suffolk County, and has also accused E.F. Hutton & Company. The firm said it developed a plan to refinance a sewer district for Suffolk County, and that the county hired Hutton instead. ''The complicated plan was disclosed to the county on a confidential basis,'' a spokesman said.

title: SIFCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TWIN CITY BARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOUIS SUSMAN
description: Louis Susman, a former trial lawyer, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Gulf Resources
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation of Houston said it had sold the Idaho assets of its Bunker Hill subsidiary to three Idaho businessmen and the J.R. Simplot Company for an undisclosed sum of cash and notes. Gulf has been closing Bunker Hill's mining and smelting operations. In 1981, Gulf wrote off $83.3 million for estimated losses on the closings.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FROM WALL STREET TO CITY HALL
description: Yesterday afternoon, Kenneth Lipper was looking for a place to sit down to talk about his appointment as Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. He picked a bench in City Hall Park.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income; the company is listed on the Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: Arrows to Play Only in Nassau
description: The Arrows plan to play all their home games this season at Nassau Coliseum, their arena since the Major Indoor Soccer League was founded four years ago.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Florida, Miami, has named Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, president, to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: Economic Scene; The Search For Reality
description: THE philosopher Mortimer Adler has been explaining on television this week that truth is not a matter of belief but of objective reality that can be empirically tested, a reality that is the same for all people no matter what they think about it.

title: Addenda
description: * The New York Times increasing its advertising rates an average 12 percent, effective Jan. 1.

title: G.O.P. RETAINS 2 SEATS IN HOUSE IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Republican Party in Connecticut hung on to its two seats in the House of Representatives and three Democratic incumbents appeared headed for re-election early today.

title: Copelan Favored In Jersey Stakes
description: Copelan, the 2-year-old colt who is undefeated in six races and the early favorite for the 1983 Kentucky Derby, has drawn post 10 in a field of 12 for the $300,000 Young America Stakes tomorrow night at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: BRIEFING
description: Preservation Project

title: Texaco Germany
description: Texaco Inc. said its West German subsidiary plans to proceed with development of the first oil production in the Baltic Sea, at a cost of $148 million. It said Deutsch Texaco A.G. and Wintershall A.G. each have a 50 percent interest in the Schwedeneck-see field, discovered about four years ago.

title: Careers; A Graduate Program In Therapy
description: THE middle-aged college graduate who has been trained as an occupational or physical therapist or registered nurse may have the opportunity to work at a paying job for a year while studying for a master's degree in developmental disabilities.

title: Union Carbide May Take Blame for Rusty Rain
description: Union Carbide, which first denied responsibility for mysterious ''rusty rain'' that damaged paint on hundreds of automobiles here, now says it is probably to blame. ''It's very, very likely that we were at fault,'' a spokesman for Union Carbide, Frank Stowers, said Monday.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ex-V.A. Head Wins in Georgia
description: The former director of the Veterans Administration, Max Cleland, a triple amputee who fought in the Vietnam war, won election today as Secretary of State in Georgia.

title: More Good News
description: One week after she finished the New York City Marathon and visited the White House, Linda Down still can't believe what has happened to her.

title: No Candidates For the Election
description: Can pro football have a man of the year among its players if there is no pro football season? That is the problem confronting the Miller Brewing Company as it ponders how to handle its third annual National Football League Man of the Year program.

title: NIAGARA FRONTIER SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lockheed Change
description: The Lockheed Corporation said it had temporarily suspended work on a proposal to convert aging Boeing 727 three-engine jetliners to twin-jets with more fuel-efficient, Pratt & Whitney engines. The project would have saved the jobs of several hundred Lockheed workers already scheduled for layoff in Palmdale, Calif. It would also have been the first major refitting by one aircraft manufacturer on a competitor's planes.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC UP 1.7%
description: Internorth Inc. reported yesterday that weakness in its natural gas operations caused net income in the third quarter of this year to plunge 48.8 percent on an increase in revenues of 8.7 percent.

title: U.S. Witness Disputes Case in Fallout Trial
description: A pathologist testified today that exposure to radiation increases the incidence of some cancers, but he said that most occurred after dosages higher than those the plaintiffs contend in a lawsuit against the Government.

title: BRITONS PRESS COMPETITIVENESS
description: The Confederation of British Industries, Britain's ''bosses' union,'' wrapped up its closely watched convention at this seaside resort today, committed to improving the competitiveness of British business at home and abroad with a minimum of Government intervention.

title: Braniff Deal Called in Jeopardy
description: Braniff's chairman, Howard Putnam, said a bankruptcy judge's decision to postpone rulings on disputed pensions could jeopardize the grounded airline's struggle to put its planes back in the air. United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers on Monday delayed settlement of pilots' pension fund disputes until Dec. 7, and set a pretial hearing Nov. 10 and trial Nov. 22 for members of the machinists' and teamsters' unions.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE 'TOUGHER' HURDLES FOR ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: White House officials said tonight that the loss of Republican seats in the House of Representatives would make it ''tougher'' to win House support for President Reagan's economic program. But they said a pro-Reagan coalition could be assembled there ''from time to time.''

WASHINGTON HEIGHTS FRUSTRATED BY A BILLBOARD
description: A giant cigarette billboard advertisement that recently went up between the Henry Hudson Parkway and Riverside Drive West at 158th Street has aroused the ire of Washington Heights residents who consider it an esthetic ''eyesore'' that should be removed.

title: GATT Bid By Poland
description: Poland today called on the agency that polices world trade to urge the repeal of sanctions imposed by President Reagan on American imports of Polish products.

title: A Six-Year Plan
description: Free agency has enriched the lives and pockets of many professional stars. For the first time, 45 career minor league baseball players are entitled to shop their services as free agents.

title: COUPLE PLEAD GUILTY IN $5 MILLION U.S. FRAUD CASE
description: A husband and wife pleaded guilty yesterday in a Federal fraud case involving more than $5 million in which a witness was slain after being abducted from a West Side parking garage.

title: Guggenheim Works To Be Sent to New York
description: The iron gates of the palace where Peggy Guggenheim kept her legendary art collection will close Monday for a million-dollar renovation.

title: Drexel Burnham's Chief To Lead Industry Group
description: The Securities Industries Association has nominated Robert E. Linton, chairman and chief executive officer at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., to be its chairman for 1983.

title: Costa Rica Default Bid
description: In a move that could spark similar actions elsewhere, a Swiss investor has taken legal action to have Costa Rica formally declared in default on a loan.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1982
description: The 1982 Elections Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo claimed victory in an extremely close governor's race in New York as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan won a second term by a record margin, defeating his Republican opponent, Florence M. Sullivan. Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat-Liberal, led by a narrow margin over his Republican-Conservative opponent, Lewis E. Lehrman, who had led in the running tally until well over half the votes had been counted. (Page A1, Column 6.) A strong Democratic tide swept across the nation, with Republican Representatives and other officeholders defeated from New England to the Southwest in midterm elections fueled by dissatisfaction over President Reagan's economic record. The Democratic trend was strongest in the House races, where some Republican incumbents believed to be secure suffered unexpected defeats. (A1:1-2.)

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss on the disposition of equity securities of $5,329,000; under an exchange agreement arising from the merger of Equitable Savings and Loan Assoc, the company realized a loss of $5,329,000 during the latest third qr

title: Birth Control in China
description: A commune worker recently was expelled from the Communist Party after she gave birth to her fourth child, the provincial daily Hebei newspaper reported today.

title: MYERS, L E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nickel at Lows In London
description: Nickel prices fell to record lows on the London Metal Exchange today in line with a general long-term decline by metals because of the world recession.

title: SENATE WINNER
description: Chosen for second six-year term as United States Senator ... served in Cabinet or in subcabinet posts under Presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon and Ford ... was Ambassador to India and United Nations representative ... although criticized by some liberals as a ''neoconservative,'' was a 1982 target of National Conservative Political Action Committee ... this cemented his credentials with liberals ... was awarded Liberal Party line, then won Democratic nomination over token opposition ... ran $3 million general election campaign against Florence M. Sullivan, the Republican, Conservative and Right to Life candidate ... boasted of pressing for ''fair share'' of Federal aid for New York, of seeking control of nuclear arms ... pressed for tuition tax credits ... born March 16, 1927, in Tulsa, Okla. ... grew up in Manhattan ... Navy gunnery officer in World War II ... graduate of Tufts University and Fletcher School of Diplomacy ... taught at Harvard ... author of several books, including ''Beyond the Melting Pot,'' highly regarded study of New York City ethnic groups ... he and his wife, the former Elizabeth Brennan, have three children and live in Pindars Corners, outside Oneonta.

title: Prices Firm in Light Trading; Many Issues Due Today
description: Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds were firm yesterday in very light trading as most securities firms operated with reduced staffs and concentrated on selling recent issues.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conrail Is Sued
description: The Grand Trunk Western Railroad Company and the Detroit, Toledo & Ironton Railroad Company have filed suit in United States District Court seeking to stop the Consolidated Rail Corporation from denying them use after Nov. 13 of the rails that connect them to East Coast cities.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRUTH IN CORPORATE POLITICKING
description: To the Editor:

title: MCFADDEN AND PARNIS: A RANGE OF STYLES
description: WOMEN dress in different styles - even the same woman often wants to look austere one day and frivolous the next. Or change her style the same day.

title: U.S. BACKS ARGENTINE BID IN U.N. ON FALKLANDS
description: The United States said today that it would back an Argentine resolution in the General Assembly urging Britain and Argentina to negotiate their dispute over the Falkland Islands.

title: Skipping Lunch
description: The Federal Food and Nutrition Service recently proposed to index the charge for reduced-price school lunches to food costs so that, in the words of one official, ''near-poor children (may) bear a fair share of inflation.''

HABIB SELECTION SEEN FOR MIDEAST POST
description: The appointing of special negotiators is a delicate and intricate dance in Washington, filled with important political and bureaucratic implications.

title: A BASIC SLANT OPENS WAY FOR JOYNER
description: Maryland was not expected to beat North Carolina in Kenan Stadium at Chapel Hill last Saturday. North Carolina had won 26 of its previous 30 games, and had entered the game ranked first among major colleges in rushing defense and total defense.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
6 in Nuclear Protest Seized at Shipyard
description: Six nuclear arms protesters were arrested today at the Electric Boat Shipyard when they tried to lock the gates leading to the administration building, the police said.

title: AS ALL INCUMBENTS BUT ONE WIN
description: Democrats gained one seat in New Jersey's 14-member Congressional delegation yesterday as all but one incumbent easily won re-election. The only Representative to lose was Harold C. Hollenbeck, a Republican. A 31-year-old political newcomer, Robert G. Torricelli, turned aside Mr. Hollenbeck's bid for a fourth term in Bergen County's Ninth District.

title: Stars 7, Whalers 6
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Al MacAdam scored a short-handed goal to give Minnesota a 7-3 lead. The North Stars had to hold off the Whalers, who rallied on a power-play goal by Kris Kotsopoulos and goals from Blaine Stoughton and Bobby Sullivan, with Sullivan's goal coming at the 18:20 mark.

title: WALLACE CAPTURES 4th TERM AS GOVERNOR OF ALABAMA
description: George C. Wallace, riding a wave of black and rural support and economic discontent, easily won election to a fourth term as Governor of Alabama today.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Delay Granted In Raider Suit
description: The damage phase of the antitrust suit filed by the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum against the National Football League was delayed today until March 14 by Judge Harry Pregerson of United States District Court.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATS MAKE BIG NATIONAL; GAINS; MOYNIHAN, WEICKER, LAUTENBERG WIN
description: Democrats won key elections across the nation yesterday with Republican officeholders defeated from New England to the Southwest in voting fueled by unhappiness over President Reagan's economic record.

title: BRENTANO'S STUDIES CLOSING MAIN STORE
description: Brentano's, the bookstore chain that closed its two Washington stores over the weekend, has told employees it may close its flagship store on Fifth Avenue as well.

title: Two Aces Scored On Same Hole
description: Leslye Johnson and Jennifer Creps, both college freshmen, scored holes-in-one on the same hole while playing in the same threesome during today's Lady Wolfpack Invitational.

title: FOR TENDERIZING MEATS
description: THOUGH meat pounders come in all shapes and sizes, all you need, essentially, is a fairly broad base and a little weight to do the job. In a pinch chefs will use anything from heavy saucepans to wine bottles.

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $400,000 for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations and tax credits of $378,393 for the qr and $715,019 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: PIANO MUSIC: ABBEY SIMON
description: THE final variations of Brahms's ''Variations on a Theme by Paganini'' showed the pianist Abbey Simon at his best in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon. The variations built on one another, the dolce singing lines supported by a firm, almost diaphragmatic pulse, the frantic leaps regulated by attention to voicings.

title: JAMES BRODERICK, 55, ACTOR WAS IN 'BRENNER' AND 'FAMILY'
description: James Broderick, an actor who appeared on stage, in films and on television, including ''Brenner'' and ''Family,'' died of cancer Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived on Washington Square North.

title: European Architecture
description: An exhibition of rare books focusing on European architectural theory and practice from 1485 to 1804 will begin Thursday at the Rotunda of Low Memorial Library at Columbia University. The time span of the works is from the 15th-century treatise on architecture by Giovanni Battista Alberti to the early 19th-century drawings of a Utopian community by the neo-classic architect Claude-Nichoas Ledoux. More than 50 volumes from the Avery Architectural Fine Arts Library collection will be on view Mondays through Fridays from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. through Dec. 2.

title: 1. Rainy Day Handbags
description: Like it or not, wet weather is inevitable at this time of the year. And few things are more annoying than being caught in the rain with a handbag made of leather that may stain when wet. A company called Dooney & Burke has come up with a leather that is said to be waterrepellent. The leather is tanned to shrink into a pebbly grain and is treated with silicones so it doesn't soak up moisture. It may be cleaned by sponging it off and then shining it with a wax polish, preferably one containing silicones. A neat, tailored pouch with a shoulder-strap made of the treated leather is $80 on Bloomingdale's main floor.

title: INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPERTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Real Estate; An Office Project in Purchase
description: WHEN a chunk of earth at a project in Westchester County, the Centre at Purchase, is ceremoniously turned over tomorrow it will mark more than the symbolic beginning of a 550,000-square-foot office park. The ground-breaking will also spotlight an unusual partnership between Related Properties Inc. and Manhattanville College, the neighboring liberal arts institution on the former Reid estate.

title: MOYNIHAN WINS OVERWHELMING VICTORY
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan won a second term yesterday with the biggest majority in a Senate race in New York history, piling up a total that makes him the fifth United States Senator to win reelection by a million-vote margin.

title: Golfers on Blacklist
description: The American golfers Jack Nicklaus, Johnny Miller and Lee Trevino are among hundreds of athletes on the latest blacklist of the Center Against Apartheid, a United Nations-backed group that tries to enforce an international boycott of sporting ties with South Africa. The latest list, covering events from January through June of this year, cited Nicklaus, Miller and Trevino, along with Severiano Ballesteros of Spain, for taking part in a $1 million South African golf tournament. The Center Against Apartheid seeks to have those on its blacklist barred from international competition.

title: CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
September Orders Up By 0.7%; Durables Drop; Inventories Off
description: New orders for the manufactured goods of American companies rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Housing Generosity Rejected
description: FOR SALE: Community-managed, city-owned apartment in a formerly abandoned building on Manhattan's West Side. Partially renovated at city expense, free of major code violations.

title: Yoplait's Cultures
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Although the text of the article ''The New Yogurts: Are They Really Yogurt?'' (Sept. 15) summarized Yoplait as having active cultures, the more readable chart indicated that active cultures were ''not listed'' for Yoplait. Yoplait does contain active cultures, and it is listed on every package. MICHAEL J. JEARY Senior Vice President Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc. Manhattan

title: BUCKBEE-MEARS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 'IMMENSE CHALLENGE' OF SOVIET STUDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: 2D INDEPENDENT TV CHANNEL IN BRITAIN
description: Britain's first new television channel in 18 years had its debut today with a bill of fare that ranges from American football and ''I Love Lucy'' reruns to punk-rock shows and shocking movies.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIAL IN JUDGE'S MURDER HEARS TAPE OF PLOTTING TO ESCAPE JAIL
description: Jamiel (Jimmy) Chagra and his wife discussed a plan in 1980 to break him out of a Federal prison while they were being investigated as suspects in the assassination of a Federal judge, according to recordings made by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and disclosed today.

title: Rose Reluctant to Rest
description: Pete Rose, who will be 42 years old just after the next baseball season begins, signed a one-year contract with the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday and got an extra show of kindness from the club. Bill Giles, the Phillies' president, said he and Manager Pat Corrales wanted Rose to take a few days off during the season to maintain batting strength.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC ALONG SILK ROUTE
description: FROM Loyang, through Tashkent, Samarkand and Bokhara the ''silk route'' ran. For a thousand years, over the backs of camels, swathes of cloth were borne from China, westward to Persia and Europe. With the the merchants, musical instruments also made their way eastward.

title: NATIONAL COUNCIL OF CHURCHES FACES NEW TYPE OF CRITIC
description: The National Council of Churches has taken extraordinary steps to counter magazine and broadcast reports that its leaders say have unfairly linked the group to leftist political and social programs.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The Governor of New York State walked down Fifth Avenue, on his way to see his wife. At 52d Street he entered the Olympic Tower, walking through its mirrored atrium to 51st Street, and then to the Helmsley Palace Hotel. ''I like things government didn't build,'' he said. He was buffeted by messengers and businessmen on their way to somewhere; only a lone boy in a T-shirt and a laborer in a billed cap stopped to shake his hand.

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: A TALE OF TWO YANKEE CATCHERS UNFOLDS
description: Because of injuries and illness, the Yankees never had a chance last season to see how much a problem they would have in trying to keep two starting catchers happy. They will likely get the chance next season.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR ASSERTS HE WON'T SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Mayor William J. Green stunned friends and political foes alike today with an announcement that he would not run for election to a second term.

title: JERSEY SENATE TALLY
LUMEX reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $57,000 in the qr and $138,000 forthe 9 mos

title: TO HOLLYWOOD STARS, LOVE IS NOW A TV ROLE
description: HOLLYWOOD ACTORS and actresses who would have spurned television offers a few years ago are now eagerly seeking jobs in movies produced for television. As a result, Dyan Cannon, Candice Bergen, Tommy Lee Jones, Kirk Douglas, Glenda Jackson, Marsha Mason, Raquel Welch, Robert Mitchum, Peter O'Toole, Michael York, Maximilian Schell, Jodie Foster and Gregory Peck have recently appeared or will soon be appearing on the 19-inch screen in millions of living rooms.

title: WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRETORIA'S NAMIBIA PLOY
description: South Africa has manipulated the United States into an impasse on the issue of Namibian independence, and it seems clear that Pretoria would like to stall indefinitely and never withdraw its military forces from Namibia. In fact, South Africa cannot put off its departure forever, but it may be able to postpone a settlement for years to come. There is perhaps little Ronald Reagan can do about this, but if he does nothing at all, he may jeopardize his entire African policy, which is built on the cornerstone of a Namibian settlement.

title: 2 Rock Queens Turn to Literature
description: LYDIA LUNCH, the leader of such influential, notorious yet shortlived rock bands as Teenage Jesus and the Jerks and 8 Eyed Spy, and Exene Cervenka, lead singer and lyricist with the acclaimed Los Angeles quartet X, were on their way to B. Dalton's Greenwich Village book store the other day and they were excited. Their first book, ''Adulterers Anonymous'' had just been published by Grove Press and the store was featuring it in a window display.

title: High Court Ruling On Color Additives
description: For more than two decades the Food and Drug Administration has delayed certifying the safety of many of the most commonly used color additives, much to the chagrin of some consumer groups.

title: VALMAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: The Challenge of a Hustler May Be Too Easy to Ignore
description: Most people understand that if they attempt to Find the Lady, accepting an invitation from a three-card monte man on a city street, the chance of winning is virtually zero. Bridge players are slightly better off if they accept the traditional challenge from a bridge hustler: ''Look at this hand: Would you rather play or defend?''

title: REPUBLICAN IN VIRGINIA WINS BYRD'S SENATE SEAT
description: Paul S. Trible, a three-term member of the House of Representatives, won a narrow victory in Virginia's Senate race today, giving the Republicans possession of a seat that has been the province of the Byrd political dynasty for half a century.

title: J. LESTER ALBERTSON, FOUNDER OF A NEW ROCHELLE LAW FIRM
description: J. Lester Albertson, senior partner in the law firm of Albertson, Simmons, Bobrow & Agatston of New Rochelle, N.Y., and chairman of the New Rochelle Water Company, died Monday at his home in New Rochelle. He was 79 years old.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: For the yr-ago periods results for Macke Co acquired Jan 30, 1981 are reported on the equity method prior to the acquisition and on a consolidated basis thereafter

title: Market Place; Power Tools And Problems
description: AFTER World War II, the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company redesigned its pioneering 1916 pistol-grip power drill for consumers. ''Do it yourself'' did the rest, and for many years Black & Decker dominated the market for small hand tools. Institutional investors rushed to buy the company's stock.

title: T, as in Torn, Shirt
description: Torn T-shirts - the artfully deliberate kind - have been around for a while, especially among devotees of punk, who like to rend their garments in provocative spots.

title: THE FOOD TASTES OF TASTEMAKERS
description: USED in its narrowest and most basic sense, taste refers to the perception and evaluation of food flavors as experienced in the mouth. But in broader usage, taste refers to a judgment based on discerning, appreciating and evaluating beauty, proportions, appropriatness or esthetic excellence in manners, art, music, clothing, design or other creative endeavor.

title: MARINES TO START PATROLLING CHRISTIAN-DOMINATED EAST BEIRUT TODAY
description: The United States Marine contingent here said today that its first patrols would enter East Beirut on Wednesday to extend its presence to what has been the stronghold of Christian militiamen.

title: JURY HEARS OF WITHDRAWN BID FOR LAND TEAMSTERS OWNED
description: Another witness in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, testified today that efforts by Mr. Williams and four co-defendants to discourage high bids on a teamster-owned property in Las Vegas, Nev., had caused the withdrawal of an offer of $1.6 million for the land.

title: WEINBERGER MEETS THAI OFFICIALS ON SECOND STOP OF 5-NATION TOUR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger met with Thai leaders here today on a tour designed to show American support for friendly nations in Southeast Asia and the Pacific.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KEEPING FAITH. Memoirs of a Presi- dent. By Jimmy Carter. 622 pages. Il- lustrated. Bantam hardcover. $22.50.

title: Doyle Dane Awarded Cigna Corp. Account
description: The Cigna Corporation, an insurance giant that resulted from the merger of the INA Corporation and Connecticut General last March, has concluded an agency search by selecting Doyle Dane Bernbach. The selection means that INA's agency - Geer, DuBois - and Connecticut General's Della Femina, Travisano & Partners were passed over.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida said it had received temporary approval from the Civil Aeronautics Board for a nonstop Miami-to-Madrid flight with additional flights on to Tel Aviv; the C.A.B. will hold hearings to make a permanent award for the route.

title: REDM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: The great majority of voters saw yesterday's Congressional elections as a referendum on President Reagan's economic program and used the opportunity to shift back toward the political center by giving Democratic candidates a decided preference around the nation, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GUAM DELEGATE TO CONGRESS IS RE-ELECTED BY 952 VOTES
description: Guam, Nov. 2 (UPI) - Antonio B. Won Pat was re-elected today to his seat as Guam's nonvoting delegate to Congress by 952 votes.

description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Luck Charm Lost
description: As the clouds gathered over St. Louis, the prospects of spending the sixth game of the World Series sitting in a box seat in the rain increased. That thought made Richie Phillips pine for the Meadowlands Race Track where his thoroughbred, Philadelphia Lady, was running the same night.

title: Nabisco Brands
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. said it now owns 17.26 million ordinary shares, or around 23.8 percent of the issued shares, of Huntley & Palmer Foods P.L.C. This follows the purchase by Nabisco of the entire issued and fully paid share capital of Precis One Hundred from N.M. Rothschild & Sons. Precis, which has been acting in concert with Nabisco, owns 9.6 million Huntley & Palmer shares. Nabisco renewed its bid for Huntley last week after Britain's Monopolies Commission said the proposed merger was not against the public interest.

title: DIVER TO INSPECT FISHING BOAT THAT SANK AND LEFT 8 DEAD
description: Coast Guard officials said yesterday that they had authorized a civilian scuba diver to search the sunken fishing boat Joan La Rie III and try to determine what caused the boat to capsize and sink about 8.5 miles off Point Pleasant, N.J., with the loss of eight persons.

title: DEMOCRATIC EDGE RISES IN NEW YORK ASSEMBLY
description: Aided by reapportionment and a strong campaign organization, Democrats sharply increased their control of the New York State Assembly yesterday and could come close to a two-thirds majority. In the State Senate, Republicans maintained their majority.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNEMPLOYMENT: CONSEQUENCES AND DAMAGES
description: IN Detroit last month, several thousand desperate people, ranging from a 19-year-old unmarried mother to a 55-year-old unemployed automobile worker, lined up for a handful of job openings as unskilled laborers. In New York two weeks ago, 60 people spent the weekend in line, sleeping on the sidewalk to assure acceptance of their applications as carpenters' apprentices. Some of the out-of work families who left the industrial Middle West for the supposedly greener pastures of Texas are being forced to live in their cars. In Austin last week, 2,817 applicants lined up for 187 jobs.

title: Basketball on TV
description: Because of unexpected programming space caused by the the pro football players' strike, CBS-TV has decided to televise Sunday's game between the Seattle SuperSonics and the Milwaukee Bucks, the National Basketball Association has announced.

title: BROOKLYN PHARMACIST FOUND DEAD IN BASEMENT OF HOUSE
description: The 38-year-old owner of a pharmacy in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn was found dead in the basement of his home early yesterday morning, handcuffed to a pipe and with tape over his face, the police said.

title: WALBAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATTORNEY GENERAL SPEAKS TO AFGHANS
description: Attorney General William French Smith toured an Afghan refugee camp in Peshawar today and offered the largest refugee population in the world Washington's ''firm support in these difficult times.''

title: ROBERT A. MCKENNAN
description: Robert A. McKennan, an anthropologist who served on the faculty of Dartmouth College for nearly 40 years, died Sunday at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 78 years old.

AFGHANS ARE SAID TO STOP DRAFTING MOSLEM TRIBESMEN AFTER PROTEST
description: The Government of Afghanistan reportedly ended the conscription of Moslem tribesmen into the army recently after 2,000 of them held a three-day peaceful protest in Kabul.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR APPARENTLY LOSES
description: Attorney General Mark White, a Democrat who waged a populist campaign that hit hard at rising utility rates, appeared tonight to have defeated Gov. William Clements, the first Republican to hold the office in 105 years.

title: Abba Lerner, 79, Dies; Economist and Author
description: Abba P. Lerner, an economist who was a prolific author of books and articles on economic theory, inflation and unemployment, died here last Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: STENNIS EASILY RE-ELECTED, WINNING 7th SENATE TERM
description: John C. Stennis, the 81-year-old Democrat who has served in the United States Senate since 1947, easily won election to a seventh term today.

title: OPERA: BEL CANTO'S 'TEMISTACLE'
description: THE adventurous Bel Canto Opera presented on Saturday the United States premiere of Johann Christian Bach's 1772 ''Temistacle,'' probably the first of the composer's several operas to be produced on an American stage. This production, which used an abridged performing edition by Edward Downes and H.C. Robbins Landon, came as a revelation, for ''Temistacle''is a solemn, stately and beautiful opera.

title: Defendant Pleads Guilty In Gulf Extortion Try
description: A former reserve police officer who the Federal Bureau of Investigation says has admitted planting five bombs inside a refinery of the Gulf Oil Chemicals Company has pleaded guilty to Federal extortion charges and agreed to testify against his four co-defendants.

title: Chlorine Gas Link Sought in Autopsy
description: An autopsy was conducted today on the body of a Niagara Falls woman who died following the accidental release of chlorine gas from a chemical plant on Saturday.

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND RETURNS TO MET AS LUCIA
description: THERE has never been any question about why opera audiences stomp and scream for Joan Sutherland: No other soprano of our time produces such steady streams of mellifluous, unforced tone or handles so securely the florid embellishments of bel canto style. She always had serious shortcomings as a singing actress, but connoisseurs of vocal technique as well as casual operagoers long ago decided to overlook the flaws and simply luxuriate in the sound of Sutherland. That was true at the beginning of her career and it is still true, as the Australian diva's appearance at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night in the season's first ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' eloquently testified.

title: POLISH DEBT REFINANCING SAID TO BE NEAR SIGNING
description: Poland's creditor banks in the West have agreed to lend Poland $600 million as part of an accord to ease the repayment of Polish debt that comes due this year, diplomatic sources reported today.

title: Faulty Inspections Made at Nine Mile 2
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has found that more than 1,300 welds were improperly inspected last year at the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power plant, being built near Oswego.

title: IN CONNECTICUT, A YEAR OF WORK GOES FOR NOUGHT
description: Lewis B. Rome campaigned for more than a year to unseat Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut, but about a half hour after the polls closed at 8 P.M., he conceded the election with a telephone call to his opponent.

The company was to have performed at the Joyce Theater Nov. 23 through 28. The tour was canceled when financing from the French Ministry of Culture was delayed.

title: THEATER: 'BACK TO BACK,' G.I.'S IN VIETNAM
description: THE two men we find side by side in Al Brown's ''Back to Back'' are lowly American grunts patrolling a demilitarized zone in the South Vietnam of 1966. They have nothing in common except their fear. Verville (Eugene Lee) is a black from the Philadelphia ghetto; Hughes (Keith Gordon) is a middle-class white from Rhode Island. In ''Back to Back,'' these young soldiers while away a long, hot, uneventful day by playing card and word games, by reminiscing about the lives they left back home, by bickering about food and cigarettes. As Mr. Brown sees it, an anguished war could also be, for those who waged it, painfully boring. Or so it was until nightfall, when the ''black pajama devils'' might suddenly emerge from the jungle to show the Americans what real pain was about.

title: PENGUINS HALT ISLANDER HOME STRING AT 30
description: The Islanders can lose on home ice, after all. That rarity happened tonight when the Pitsburgh Penguins handed the Islanders a 3-1 defeat at Nassau Coliseum. It was New York's first loss in 31 regular-season home games. Their last previous regular-season loss here - they lost two home playoff games to the Rangers last April - was a 5-4 setback to the Montreal Canadiens on Dec. 29, 1981. The defeat was only the third over all this season for the three-time defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: NEIGHBORS JOIN DRIVE TO RESTORE BUNCHE PARK
description: Two years ago a small park with a 50-foot gleaming steel obelisk was dedicated proudly across from the United Nations as a memorial to Ralph J. Bunche, the late Nobel Peace Prize laureate.

description: In a recent series in these pages, ''The Changing Face of Sports,'' the evidence seemed to be that Americans do not worship athletes as automatically as they once did.

description: Kenneth R. Asbury, an aide to Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, was found beaten to death in his apartment today, the police reported. Officials said they had no suspects and no idea why the 34-year old aide was slain. an autopsy was to be performed.

title: WINE TALK
description: KATONAH, N.Y. THE cellar has an earthen floor and is dark and musty, with an oak door that creaks with age as Edward Giobbi swings it open and flips a light switch. The atmosphere is cool and damp from the surrounding earth, and the odor of spilled wine fills the air. Racks of bottles, some with a coating of mold, line the walls.

title: Regional Cookbooks

title: Hallmark Cards Founder Left Most of Fortune to Charity
description: Joyce C. Hall, the founder and chairman of the board of Hallmark Cards Inc., left more than $100 million to charity, according to lawyers for Hallmark. Mr. Hall died Friday at the age of 91.

title: Series of Films to Mark Paramount's 70th Year
description: To celebrate the 70th anniversary of Paramount Pictures, the Museum of Modern Art will present eight films released by the company in the last decade, starting Nov. 18 and continuing through Nov. 30. The films will be ''Atlantic City'' (1981), ''Chinatown'' (1974), ''Days of Heaven'' (1978), ''The Godfather'' (1972) and ''The Godfather Part II'' (1975), ''Nashville'' (1975), ''Popeye''(1980) and ''Saturday Night Fever'' (1977).

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I first arrived in America some 40 years ago, the principal ''exotic'' foreign dishes here were curried foods. There was, of course, a lot of spaghetti and meatballs and lasagne was staple fare, but these had been highly Americanized and were not as you would find them in Rome or Milan.

description: Democrats scored major victories in House races yesterday and seriously damaged President Reagan's ability to push his legislative program through Congress.
