description: Iranian forces launched their third offensive of the year Monday night, striking at Iraqi troops still holding Iranian territory along the central front west of Dizful.

title: Robert Abrams
description: Chosen for second four-year term as state's chief legal officer ... served three terms as State Assemblyman ... was Bronx Borough President from 1970 until election as Attorney General in 1978 ... had been unsuccessful Democratic nominee for attorney general in 1974 ... politicians consider him a possible future candidate for governor or United States senator ... unopposed in 1982 primary ... ran $1 million general election campaign as Democratic-Liberal candidate against Frances A. Sclafani, lightly financed Republican-Conservative ... boasted of reorganizing ''second biggest law office in the world,'' opposing environmental polluters, obtaining refunds for consumers from public utilities, opposing casino gambling, winning $1 million lawsuit against milk industry ... born July 4, 1938, and grew up in the Bronx, where his parents ran a candy store ... graduated from public schools, Columbia College and New York University's Law School ... started in ''reform'' faction politics while in school ... he and his wife, the former Diane Schulder, have a daughter, Rachel, and live on Manhattan's East Side. Edward V. Regan

MASSACHUSETTS GIVES BIG VICTORIES TO KENNEDY, O'NEILL AND DUKAKIS

title: LEBANESE PREMIER SEEKS POWER TO RULE BY DECREE
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan asked Parliament today for emergency powers to allow the Administration of President Amin Gemayel to rule Lebanon by decree for eight months.

description: The Cook County Board gave final approval Monday to a $1.85 million settlement of a 12-year-old civil rights suit filed by survivors of two Black Panther Party leaders shot to death in a police raid.

title: Bunker Hill Mine Acquired
description: COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, Nov. 2 (AP) - Four Idaho businessmen have purchased the sprawling Bunker Hill Company mine and smelter in Kellogg, but the buyers, led by Duane Hagadone, owner of the Coeur d'Alene Press, said copper, lead and zinc production would not resume until metals prices increased drastically.

title: PIANO: MISS URIBE PLAYS SCARLATTI
description: BLANCA URIBE'S Sunday night recital at Alice Tully Hall offered crisp, clear and energetic pianism imbued with a warm intelligence. Miss Uribe's program opened with five Scarlatti sonatas, yoked together into a miniature suite.

title: Qaddafi in Belgrade for Talks
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya arrived in Belgrade today for talks with Yugoslav leaders. The Middle East conflict and African problems are expected to be the main topics.

title: DOW RISES BY 16.38, TO 1,022.08
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.38 points yesterday, to 1,022.08, as trading volume soared above 100 million shares. Wall Street analysts said this buoyant performance reflected investor expectations that yesterday's election results would not materially change the economy's direction toward lower inflation and interest rates.

title: JAPANESE PLAN TO PROTEST DECISION BY WHALING BOARD TO IMPOSE BAN
description: The Japanese Government announced today that it would file a formal complaint against the International Whaling Commission's decision to end commercial whaling in three years.

ON L.I., MRAZEK SCORES A VICTORY OVER INCUMBENT
description: Representative John LeBoutillier, Republican of Westbury, L.I., considered one of the most conservative members of the House of Representatives, was defeated yesterday by a Democratic Suffolk County legislator, Robert J. Mrazek of Centerport.

title: Canadiens' 3-Goal Rally Beats Devils, 5-4
description: The New Jersey Devils outplayed Montreal for the first two periods tonight, but it was not enough. They faltered in the third period and the Canadiens scored the game's last three goals and won, 5-4, at the Forum here.

title: MUSIC: ALBAN BERG QUARTET
description: IT was a weekend for Central European chamber musicians at the Metropolitan Museum. After the Takacs Quartet on Friday, the Alban Berg Quartet performed similar music on the same stage the very next evening.

title: MUSIC: LEIPZIG GEWANDHAUS
description: THE Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig returned to Carnegie Hall Monday for its second appearance in two nights. This time the music was by Richard Strauss, Beethoven and Dvorak.

title: Healthdyne Link
description: Healthdyne Inc. said the staff of the Federal Trade Commission did not intend to seek authority from the commission to block its purchase of common stock of Narco Scientific Inc. Healthdyne has offered to buy 711,000 Narco Scientific shares at $31.50 each. However, Healthdyne said it was also informed by the F.T.C. that the commission staff is continuing its previously announced antitrust investigation of the offer.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market surged in heavy trading. Analysts said it was buoyed by hopes that the election will not change the economy's direction toward lower inflation and interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.38 points, to 1,022.08. Volume expanded to 104.8 million shares from Monday's 73.5 million. (Page D1.)

title: Advertising; New Focus For Legal Magazines
description: WHAT occupational group can note that 43 percent of its largely male membership owns 10 or more suits each, has an average household income in the $100,000 range and is the target of advertising for such automobiles as Rolls-Royce, BMW and Mercedes?

title: Reese Says He's Sorry
description: A former Miami judge said Don Reese, the former pro football lineman sentenced to prison for violating probation, telephoned him last weekend to apologize. The judge, Joseph Durant, was widely criticized in 1977 when he sent Reese to prison for only a year for selling cocaine, a decision that allowed Reese freedom on probation in mid-1978.

title: THE DANCE: MURRAY LOUIS AT THE JOYCE
description: THE Murray Louis Dance Company, which opened last night at the Joyce Theater for a three-week season, is the first modern-dance troupe to perform in the theater, which was renovated and reopened in June.

title: South African Inquest Hears Police Denounced
description: Two security policemen should be convicted of homicide for driving Neil Aggett to hang himself in his jail cell, lawyers for the Aggett family said today.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR AND SENATOR IN CALIFORNIA RUN CLOSE RACES
description: Races for Governor and Senator in California were extremely close in early returns tonight. Surveys of voters leaving the polls found Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, the Democratic nominee for Governor, as the likely victor. But with 11 percent of the vote counted, Attorney General George Deukmejian, a Republican, was leading by 56 percent to 44 percent. However, this included a heavy weighting of absentee ballots, which usually tend toward Republicans.

title: British Coal Miners Vote Against a Strike Mandate
description: Britain's coal miners voted today not to authorize a strike to press demands for a 31 percent pay increase and instead voted overwhelmingly in a secret ballot to accept an 8.5 percent offer.

title: PCB WASTE OIL FOUND IN BRISTOL IS TRACED TO G.E.
description: A repair shop of the General Electric Company near Southington, Conn., has been identified by state and company officials as the source of an illegal shipment of contaminated waste oil discovered at a treatment plant in Bristol last week.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Oakland, Calif. Two weeks ago, the Knicks traded Michael Ray Richardson to the Warriors for Bernard King.

title: Warsaw Ridicules Underground Activists
description: The Government, in a new tactic aimed at countering Solidarity's call for a nationwide strike, ridiculed underground activists today as bungling and indecisive.

BRAHMANS, THE WHIPPING BOYS OF EGALITARIANISM?
description: In his Western-style trousers and his T-shirt with ''Honda'' written across the chest, V.I. Ramachandran, a 25-year-old graduate engineer, does not advertise his caste. Only the lingering traces on his forehead of the three horizontal stripes of white ash that mark him as a worshiper of Shiva offer any clue.

ENVOY OF U.S. WARNS SALVADOR OF AID CUT IF 'ABUSES' CONTINUE
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador, describing the Salvadoran legal system as ''rotten,'' has threatened an end to military aid unless human rights ''abuses'' by the security forces here are stopped.

title: McNAMARA, LILLIS ARE HIRED
description: Some of the confusion over who would manage which baseball clubs next season was cleared up yesterday when John McNamara was hired by the California Angels and Bob Lillis by the Houston Astros. Both received one-year contracts.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANKING MERGERS FLOURISH
description: A major change in Pennsylvania's banking code has created a banking free-for-all in this state. A wave of mergers and acquisitions among the state's 350 banks has followed the move last March to allow statewide banking. In addition, there has been substantial interest by investors in the stocks of small, profitable banks in growth markets within the state. The price of stock in such banks, which are considered eventual takeover candidates by larger banks in Philadelphia or Pittsburgh, began rising last October, when the statewide banking amendment was first introduced by Pennsylvania's Secretary of Banking.

title: DUKE HALTS WORK ON 2 REACTORS
description: The Duke Power Company said yesterday that it was canceling construction of two large nuclear reactors on which it has spent $68 million since work began in 1974.

title: JERSEY DEMOCRAT, IN FIRST CONTEST, UPSETS REP. FENWICK FOR THE SENATE
description: Frank R. Lautenberg, a 58-year-old business executive making his first bid for elective office, yesterday upset his popular Republican opponent, Representative Millicent Fenwick, in the race for the United States Senate from New Jersey.

title: People

title: 29 Arrested at Pentagon
description: Twenty-nine demonstrators were arrested by the police at the Pentagon today in an Election Day protest against arms spending.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS ARE SAFER IN CONGRESS'S HANDS
description: Congress and the Reagan Administration differ on the role of government in enforcing the Bill of Rights. Debates on abortion, school prayer, voting rights, legal services for the poor and other civil liberties issues have pitted the President against a surprisingly bipartisan civil libertarian majority in a Congress supposedly dominated by ''conservatives.'' Sadly, the Administration has found ways to circumvent the will of Congress on this front.

title: AN AMERICAN WINE BROKER IN BURGUNDY
description: Eunice Fried is a wine writer who lives in New York.BEAUNE, France ''BURGUNDY is Byzantine,'' Rebecca Wasserman said as she drove from her office in this small old town, which is considered the wine capital of Burgundy, to the cellars of a small wine producer in Meursault. ''It's intricate, full of nuances, complexities. But only a few wine makers are making wines with these qualities. They are the wines I look for.''

description: Oscar Adams became the first black man to win election to a statewide office in Alabama since Reconstruction when he was voted in today as a member of the state's Supreme Court.

title: WARRIORS' ROMAR FILLING A BIG GAP
description: Normally, the best a seventh-round draft choice can hope for is to become the last man on the 12-man roster; work hard in practice; get some playing time; survive the constant threats of being waived, and earn the minimum salary.

title: NOT THROUGH YET, KUHN SAYS
description: One day after he was denied re-election as commissioner of baseball, Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that he would soon initiate the process of searching for his successor. But he added that he did not feel like a ''lame duck,'' and he did not rule out the possibility of somehow staying in office.

description: West Germany's opposition Social Democrats have embarked on a new and uncertain course with the designation of Hans-Jochen Vogel, the party's West Berlin leader, to take over from Helmut Schmidt as its candidate for Chancellor in elections promised for next March.

title: Drug Defendant Pleads Guilty
description: Vincent Cord, one of Eugene (Mercury) Morris's two co-defendants in a cocaine-trafficking trial, pleaded guilty today and agreed to testify for the state against the former star running back.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Holiday Limits Trading
description: Because of the Election Day holiday, there was no foreign-exchange trading yesterday in the United States. Most commodity exchanges were closed or limited trading to a few commodities. Also, there was no trading in Treasury bills, notes and bonds or in Government agency bonds.

title: COMMERCIAL PAPER SALE BY BANKS RULED LEGAL
description: A Federal appeals court held today that banks may compete directly with securities firms in selling commercial paper to investors.

title: U.S. SAYS ALLIES BLOCK PIPELINE ACCORD
description: High State Department officials said today that three negotiating sessions with American allies in Washington had failed to resolve the dispute over the sanctions that the United States has imposed against builders of the Soviet natural gas pipeline to Europe.

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $58,000 for the qr and an $83,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income including extraordinary credits of $111,000 for the qr and $347,000 for the 9 mos

title: SOUTH AFRICA DRAWS INVESTORS
description: When E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company opened a marketing office here last January, it did so with barely a peep.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCHMITT LOSES NEW MEXICO SENATE SEAT
description: In one of the biggest upsets of the 1982 election, Harrison H. Schmitt, the Republican Senator who first gained fame 10 years ago as an astronaut who walked on the moon, was defeated today by his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Jeff Bingaman.

title: POLITICAL GROUPS LAG ON DONATIONS
description: The leading independent political action committees are distributing to candidates for Federal office only a small percentage, often less than 10 percent, of the millions of dollars they have raised.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $15,000 for the qr and $34,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $21,000 for the qr and $88,000 for the9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: Handling Prejudice; In the Classroom
description: Yesterday's question for a group of city public-school teachers was how many of them had experienced ethnic or racial prejudice in the classroom. Most hands went up.

title: O'NEILL BEATS ROME IN CONNECTICUT RACE FOR THE GOVERNORSHIP
description: Two incumbents, Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat, and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a maverick Republican, won election yesterday in Connecticut.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISRAEL NEEDS SUPPORT FROM THE DIASPORA
description: To the Editor:

title: WHOM BANKRUPTCY LAW SHOULD NOT PROTECT
description: To the Editor:

title: FIXED HOSPITAL FEES WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: INCUMBENTS HAVE THE EDGE IN WINNING SENATE CONTESTS
description: Republicans appeared to have retained control of the Senate yesterday as incumbent Democrats and Republicans won re-election in 20 races.

title: MACANDREWS & FORBES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Qtr includes a charge from acquisition related activities before taxes of $520,000 and for the 9 mos after a pre-tax gain of $805,000

title: Head of Cowles Media Takes Charge of Paper
description: John Cowles Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Cowles Media Company, has announced that he is also taking over as publisher of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune newspaper.

title: HELD SEVERAL RECORDS IN AVIATION
description: Henry Tindall (Dick) Merrill, a pioneer aviator who in 1936 made the first trans-Atlantic round-trip flight in an airplane, died Sunday at his summer home in Lake Elsinore, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: From Russia, With Worry
description: They don't have elections in the Soviet Union. President Brezhnev need never fear that Pravda will find him less than infallible. But even within a nominally monolithic society there are clashing interests, and domestic discontent matters. In a real sense, Mr. Brezhnev spoke last week as a beleaguered incumbent worried about his own troops' campaign morale.

title: LOCKING UP TIGHT
description: For five weeks I traveled across beautiful autumnal America. It was like a booby hatch of the criminally insane. In Detroit they were finding razor blades in hot dogs sold at the grocery. In California somebody had laced eyewash with corrosive chemicals. In Chicago, capsules sold as headache remedies came packed with cyanide. In New York and its suburbs, not to be outdone, people spent the weekend inserting needles and pins into candy they planned to give children on Halloween.

title: POPE, IN SPAIN, CONDEMNS ALL ABORTIONS
description: Pope John Paul II, cheered by a crowd estimated at more than one million, condemned divorce and abortion today in terms of exceptional force.

title: COMPANY EXONERATED ON DIVORCE
description: A company has no obligation to ''monitor and safeguard'' the marriages of its employees, a court says. The ruling Monday by the Washington State Court of Appeals came in a suit filed against the United States Steel Corporation by a Montana woman who said that her husband divorced her to marry another woman after he was transferred to Seattle by the company.

title: CBS to Sell Parts Of Paperback Unit
description: CBS Inc. announced that it had agreed to sell major portions of its Popular Library paperback books unit to Warner Publishing.

title: DEMOCRATS CAPTURE A MAJORITY OF 36 GOVERNORSHIPS
description: Democrats won a majority of the 36 governorships decided yesterday. The party rode a strong vote in economically depressed areas that appeared likely to cost Republicans at least seven of the 16 Republican-held governorships at stake.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly reported the impact of Conoco Inc. earnings on E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's third-quarter results. Without the Conoco subsidiary's contribution, Du Pont would have had net income of 27 cents a share.

title: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NETS TOP CLIPPERS DESPITE SLOPPY PLAY
description: The Nets overcame a rash of turnovers and fouls tonight and defeated the San Diego Clippers, 110-100, before 10,220 spectators at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A $1 SPONGE SUPPORTED FOR BIRTH CONTROL
description: If the Government approves the recommendation of one of its advisory committees, an over-the-counter contraceptive sponge that will cost about a dollar and is said to be as effective as the diaphragm could be on the market next year.

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SEAGULL PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW-HOME SALES CLIMB 23.7% WHILE PRICES FALL
description: Sales of new single-family homes jumped almost 24 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today, while the recession knocked the average sales price down almost $7,000, to $82,300, the biggest one-month drop on record.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
80% of Voters in City Said to Have Balloted
description: About 80 percent of the city's registered voters cast ballots on Election Day, an official of the city's Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: TO STOP THE TRADE IN STOLEN ANTIQUITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: The Center, Rediscovered; 'Liberal' Is No Longer A Dirty Word
description: Oh, the conservative joy in 1980: Ronald Reagan swept into the White House and Republicans won the Senate and gained 33 seats in the House. A major political realignment, it was called. Cowed Democrats began calling themselves progressive, pragmatic. ''Liberal'' became a dirty word.

title: News Analysis
description: Tuesday's election results are likely to produce important compromises in economic policy that in turn would result in more progress against inflation, political and economic analysts said today.

title: General Foods Dividend
description: The General Foods Corporation said today that its board had raised the quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share from 55 cents, payable Dec. 3, for shareholders of record Nov. 16. The company last raised its dividend, from 50 cents, in June 1980.

title: CITY GREENHOUSES: LETTING THE LIGHT IN
description: AS out-of-towners like to point out, New Yorkers savor the outdoors in roundabout ways: sunbathing on roofs, gardening on fire escapes, fussing over views of water towers. Now New Yorkers are discovering the urban greenhouse. As is their habit, they are making the idea their own, pushing the greenery out, moving themselves in.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1982
description: The 1982 Elections Democrats widened their majority in the House by 26 votes Tuesday in an election that raised doubts about President Reagan's ability to protect his conservative economic program from alteration by Congress. The Republicans retained firm control of the Senate, but White House strategists estimated that the election had cut about 24 conservatives from the bipartisan coalition that helped pass Mr. Reagan's key economic legislation. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan was conciliatory about the sizable Republican losses in the House and predicted that both he and the Democrats would have to make ''concessions and compromises'' on major issues. (A1:5.)

title: SUBURBAN COUNTY OFFICES
description: Following are unofficial results of elections in the New York metropolitan area. The results of some contests will not be available until they are certified by state election authorities.

title: TANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Required Reading Buttons and Pies
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, speaking before the Multi-Unit Food Service Operators Conference, Washington, Oct. 26, 1982: Trying to make things work in government is sometimes like trying to sew a button on a custard pie.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Scandinavian Banking Corp. has appointed Alan R. Buggy a senior vice president.

title: 328 ARE ARRESTED, 105 HELD OVERNIGHT, IN SWEEP OF SUBWAYS
description: A small army of 350 Transit Authority police officers scattered through the subway system in Queens last night and arrested 328 people, most for jumping turnstiles, but one for carrying a loaded pistol and several for attempted robbery, according to the police.

title: DEMOCRATIC TIDE AND THE ROCK
description: In New England Tuesday, there were the rule and the exception, the tide and the rock that stood above it. The tide was a Democratic surge, drawn up as by gravity in opposition to President Reagan's economic policies. It showed in different ways.

title: T.D. STEINWAY OF PIANO MKAER
description: Theodore Davis Steinway, who retired in 1979 as chief engineer of Steinway & Sons, the piano manufacturer, died on Monday at his home in Llewellyn Park, N.J., after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: FRIENDS AND FOES OF THE DOW
description: How now, Dow Jones? The Dow Jones industrial average, which reached a new high of 1,065.49 yesterday in rising a record 43.41 points, is certainly the world's most widely watched market indicator. But behind the euphoria its performance brought to Wall Street and the celebration that erupted on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange when the market closed, there are nagging doubts about its value.

title: On the Retirement Of William S. Paley
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTE RESULTS IN NEW JERSEY
description: Following are unofficial results of elections in the New York metropolitan area. The results of some contests will not be available until they are certified by state election authorities. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent, and a dagger (+) denotes complete returns. The abbreviations are: D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, RTL - Right to Life, L - Liberal, LIB - Libertarian, COM - Communist, FL, Free Libertarian and CIT - Citizens Party. U denotes a candidate who was unopposed.

title: REAGAN FACING DEMANDS FOR COMPROMISE ON ECONOMY AFTER 26-SEAT LOSS IN HOUSE
description: Business executives said the election results may have reversed the conservative flow of the Administration's economic policies. Pragmatism and bipartisanship on economic matters in Congress seemed to be the most likely effect of Tuesday's balloting. Page D1.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLAIN OLD-FASHIONED POLITICS
description: The ailing economy and President Reagan's failure to provide a cure for it appear to have played a major role in the Republican Party's loss of the only Governor it was able to elect in Texas in more than a century and the defeat of a Republican Senator in New Mexico.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRIME ISSUE CITED AS FACTOR IN STRONG LEHRMAN SHOWING
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, in winning election as the 52d Governor of New York, was aided by unemployment and the other economic issues that helped many Democrats Tuesday, politicians and consultants on both sides agreed yesterday.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST MARINE PATROL IN EAST BEIRUT IS DELAYED A DAY
description: The Lebanese Army strengthened its presence in East Beirut today, but the United States Marines postponed the patrols they had scheduled to help the Government increase its sovereignty in the predominantly Christian eastern sector of the capital.

title: Bolivia Seeks Help on Debt
description: Bolivia will ask deferment of payments on its foreign debt through negotiations with overseas creditor banks, Finance Minister Ernesto Aranibar said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00N.A. Not Available ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $23,900...C-Net loss

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY LATE RALLY
description: Sam Williams, who started at power forward because Larry Smith was sidelined with a hamstring injury, made two free throws with two seconds left to give the Golden State Warriors a 99-97 victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Including tax credits of $310,000 for the qr and $740,000 for the yr

title: Harvester Pact On Assets Sale
description: The International Harvester Company said it had agreed to terms on the sale of two of its secondary businesses. Harvester, which termed the agreements ''another step in the company's reduction of its break-even point,'' said the separate transactions would net it between $65 million and $70 million.

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN ON ALL FRONTS
description: A parade of Southern Democrats strongly critical of the economic programs of President Reagan chalked up victories in Congressional races Tuesday, stunning Republicans and the conservative Democrats who have supported Mr. Reagan.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPECTRA-PHYSICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from the sale of real estate of $326,062 for the qr and $4,189,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income of $28,236 for the qr and $2,103,000 for the 9 mos

title: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $43.2 million investment loss and a loss of $2.2 million from discontinued operations...C-Net income includes a $229,000 capital gain and a $2.2 million loss on discontinued operations...D-Includes a capital loss of $42.7 million and a loss on discontinued operations of $6.9 million...E-Includes an investment loss of $139,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $3.5 million; the 1981 earnings are restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: G.O.P. SHAKEN IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: ''Let's everyone take a deep breath,'' Gov. Dick Thornburgh told his supporters this morning at a delayed celebration of a victory that had not come as early or as handily as the experts had expected.

title: RESULTS OF CONNECTICUT RACES
description: Following are unofficial results of elections in the New York metropolitan area. The results of some contests will not be available until they are certified by state election authorities.

title: REP. FENWICK TRIES TO FIGURE WHY SHE LOST
description: Representative Millicent Fenwick today attributed her defeat Tuesday in the election for the United States Senate from New Jersey to high unemployment, an expensive advertising campaign by her opponent, poor advice and what she called the mystery of electoral politics.

title: Nets Routed
description: If the Nets had forgotten how to play a tough, aggressive type of basketball game, the Washington Bullets gave them a painful reminder tonight. They trounced the Nets, 104-85, with the result prompting Coach Larry Brown to say, ''I think we realize we're not a very good team right now.''

title: WIDESPREAD VOTE URGES NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Voters in eight states and several major cities, which together include about one-fourth of the country's population, called for a worldwide nuclear freeze in Tuesday's elections despite warnings from the Reagan Administration that such a policy would damage the security of the United States.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VOTERS APPROVE A PUBLIC UTILITY RUN BY THE CITY
description: The candidates drew most of the attention in Tuesday's election, but when voters went to the polls Tuesday in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, they also cast ballots for more than a dozen issues. Here is a breakdown of the issues in the area: New York City

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN 5 GOVERNORS
description: The Democrats, seizing on the rare opportunity of five retiring Republican Governors, captured five new governorships in the Middle West in the election and clung to a slim chance at a sixth.

title: Genentech Posts a Loss
description: Genentech Inc., a San Francisco genetic engineering company, reported a net loss of $1.2 million in the third quarter of 1982, after a profit of $246,000, or 3 cents a share, in the similar period of 1981. Sales for the period rose 15.3 percent, to $7.2 million, from $6.1 million.

title: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $13.4 million from unrealized foreign currencytranslations and nonrecurring items...D-Includin g nonrecurring gains, net of unrealized foreign losses, of $9.5 million

title: VUCKOVICH OF BREWERS WINS CY YOUNG
description: The Milwaukee Brewers began collecting the rewards for their first American League pennant yesterday when Pete Vuckovich was named winner of the Cy Young Award as the league's best pitcher of 1982.

title: Technology; Oil Drilling Offshore
description: INCREASINGLY, the search for new energy supplies is taking major oil companies to remote offshore drilling sites that challenge existing technology.

title: CERONE WILL SIGN 4-YEAR YANKEE PACT
description: The hold of the Yankees and a four-year, $2.4 million contract combined yesterday to keep Rick Cerone in New York. Cerone, the team's No.1 catcher the last three years, reached agreement on the new contract with the Yankees and thus passed up his chance to be the most attractive catcher in the free-agent market.

title: High Winds Damage Texas Resort Towns
description: Hurricane-force winds, spawned by a powerful cold front moving through the South Texas Gulf Coast early this morning, left an estimated $2 million in damage in the tiny resort towns of Port Isabel and the city of South Padre Island.

title: Market Place; Acton Focuses On Cable TV
description: WALL STREET doesn't like a cable company with egg on its face. When the Acton Corporation realized this, it spun off its egg and snack food company to draw attention to its cable television operations. Now Acton plans to sell its telephone service units and its radio stations and become a pure play in cable.

title: Topics; Public Entertainments; Broadway Theater
description: For all lovers of drama, a list of performances enjoyed during a noon walk around Times Square: 1. On 42d Street, an old man and two life-size mannequins are seated in a raised booth under a sign that says ''Intermission.''

title: Injection Found Helping Heart Attack Victims
description: Injections of a clot-dissolving medicine soon after heart attacks reduces the death rate by about 20 percent, according to a report.

title: Phillips to Sell Sealright Co. Unit
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced it had agreed to sell its Sealright Company Inc. subsidiary for an undisclosed amount to a group of investors composed mainly of Sealright management.

title: PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENTS; Sobering Up
description: American elections rival the Grand Canyon as an unceasing source of wonder for foreign observers, whose views may also serve to moderate the passions of American participants. For a morning-after remedy to the campaigns consider James Bryce's classic ''American Commonwealth,'' originally published in 1894.

title: U.S. MOVES TO BROADEN ITS CASE AGAINST TEAMSTER
description: Federal prosecutors today began to broaden their bribery conspiracy case against Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters union, by linking the son-in-law of Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada, to charges that the defendants plotted to bribe the Senator.

title: London Index Also a Record
description: Stock prices on the London Stock Exchange reached a record yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEM HEADED FOR BIGGEST ASSEMBLY EDGE SINCE '48
description: The New York State Legislature will have at least 30 new names on the roll call next year and the smallest Republican representation in the Assembly in recent years.

title: Polish Debt Due in '82 Is Deferred
description: Poland and its Western bankers signed an agreement today deferring the repayment of 95 percent of Poland's 1982 debt for eight years and calling for the payment of interest on the debt in three installments, beginning this month.

title: Film May Give Clues On Sinking Off Jersey
description: A diver's film footage of a sunken charter fishing vessel that capsized, claiming the lives of eight men, ''may have the reason the boat sank,'' his wife said today.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A BEST SELLER FOR THE 1980's: ENERGY-EFFICIENT SUN SPACE
description: FOR Eric Thompson, it is another weapon in the war against energy inefficiency in his creaking yellow Victorian house, which seems to gobble up oil on cold winter days. In the last five years, Commander Thompson, a physician in the United States Navy, has insulated his north-facing windows, installed two wood-burning stoves and tacked three solar panels onto the roof. Now he is spending $15,500 to erect a glass, wood and brick ''sun space'' on the south side of his 109-year-old home.

title: PERU'S PRESIDENT CANCELS A TRIP TO U.S. OVER IMPORT DUTY ON COTTON
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru, said by Peruvian officials to be angry over trade issues with the United States, has canceled an official trip to the United States that was to have begun next Tuesday.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3.4 million for the qr and $3.9million for the 9 mos and a charge of $564,000 from the reversal of a tax credit...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $155,000 for the qr and $810,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary tax credits of $343,000 for the qr and $376,000 for the 9 mos

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Income restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52; shr earnings in 1981 reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in Dec 1981

title: CBS/Fox Venture Fills Top Office
description: CBS/Fox, a joint venture formed earlier this year to sell home video products, announced yesterday that it had named Lawrence B. Hilford president and chief executive effective Jan. 1.

title: A Restless Wind
description: Would Alberto Salazar and Grete Waitz have set world records in the New York City Marathon without the stiff headwinds and crosswinds that followed them for much of the 26-mile 385-yard race? Jack Daniels, an exercise physiologist, says yes.

title: THEY FOUGHT IN SPAIN: NOW THE CAUSE IS REDEEMED
description: Once they were fighters, men who tried to stop fascism in Spain with guns and grenades. Today, more than 40 years later, Americans who volunteered in the Loyalist cause in the Spanish Civil War are watching proudly as a Socialist government is coming to power in that country.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Advertising; Celebration Is Planned At Esquire
description: HAVING pulled Esquire magazine back from the brink of disaster, the rescue team headed by Phillip W. Moffitt, editor, and H. Christopher Whittle, president, is now planning a yearlong 50th anniversary celebration capped by a media event that it hopes will challenge the glories of television.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INCOME SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: OPEC Output Drop Is Seen

title: News Analysis
description: By publicly launching a campaign against the Salvadoran courts and security forces, the Reagan Administration is not only trying to get results in two celebrated murder cases involving American victims but is also seeking to bolster those forces in El Salvador it believes are more moderate and able to bring about the desired social and economic changes. Administration officials said the ostensible reason for the blunt statements in recent days by Ambassador Deane R. Hinton was the need to drive home to Salvadoran political figures that the American Government and public will not continue to supply military aid if the killers of the Americans are not brought to justice.

title: British Arts Festival Will Open April 13
description: The largest British arts festival outside the United Kingdom will begin April 13 in New York.

title: LESTER ROLOFF, RADIO PREACHER, 68, DIES AS HIS PLANE CRASHES IN TEXAS
description: Lester Roloff, killed in a small-plane crash in Texas Tuesday, was a radio evangelist who fought an eight-year battle with the State of Texas over his management of homes for troubled teen-agers.

title: DANCE: '10 IMAGINARY' WORKS
description: NOW it's ''imaginary'' dances. With no dancers to pay and no music rights to be acquired, they should be the wave of the future for impoverished dance companies. Remy Charlip contributed 10 of them to Dance Uptown's program Saturday at the Minor Latham Playhouse. The form, devised by Mr. Charlip, consists of a reader stating the title and theme of the work, then allowing a few moments of silence for the audience to envision it all.

title: Service for Valerie Bettis
description: A service for Valerie Bettis, the modern-dance choreographer, dancer and actress who died in September, will be given Monday at the Cathedral St. John the Divine. The program, which will begin at 7:30 P.M., will include excerpts from Miss Bettis's last work for the Omega Liturgical Dance Company and a tribute written by Jose Ferrer. The singer Thelma Carpenter and the pianist Leo Schmitt will be among those participating.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCAES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
AN INTERNAL DISPUTE BUILDS ON MILITARY SPENDING
description: With the Congressional elections behind them, President Reagan and his senior advisers are about to plunge into a swirling guerrilla war over continued high levels of military spending.

title: Rough Courses
description: Golfers from the metropolitan New York area have not exactly burned up the pro tour in recent years. Bill Britton says he knows why.

title: Kuwait Quits Talks On Gulf Assets Sale
description: Kuwait has pulled out of negotiations with the Gulf Oil Corporation on a takeover of Gulf's oil refining and distribution network in Europe, the official Kuwait News Agency reported today. A Gulf spokesman in Pittsburgh confirmed that the negotiations had ended, but would not elaborate.

title: FOR POLICE, IT'S OFTEN A VAIN FIGHT TO IDENTIFY PETTY CRIMINALS
description: Last June 7, as Olivia Bridges was leaving a check-cashing store on 96th Street at Second Avenue, she was surrounded on the street by five youths who demanded her money. When one of the youths warned the 49-year-old woman that he would cut her throat if she resisted, she turned over $234. A week later Mrs. Bridges was interviewed by detectives at the 23d Precinct station. She said she had been ''too nervous'' to get a close look at any of the youths and declined to view photographs of possible suspects. The case was closed.

title: MOFFETT, STUNNED BY WEICKER, SAYS HE CANNOT EXPLAIN LOSS
description: Representative Toby Moffett, describing himself as ''semi-shell-shocked,'' sat on his front steps here today searching for answers on why he was defeated in Tuesday's election for the United States Senate from Connecticut by the Republican incumbent, Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Thanksgiving With No Football
description: There might be no live network television of football - professional or college - on Thanksgiving Day for the first time in many years if the National Football League players strike continues or if the N.F.L. owners cancel the season.

title: Prof. Robert Atkinson, Pioneer in Astronomy
description: Robert d'Escourt Atkinson, adjunct professor emeritus of astronomy at the University of Indiana, died last Thursday at Bloomington, Ind., Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Bloomington.

title: Move by Nixon Helped in 1973
description: President Richard M. Nixon played a central role in propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its previous record nearly 10 years ago.

title: CONCERT: PHILARMONIQUE DE LA LOIRE
description: AFrench orchestra new to us, the Orchestre Philharmonique des Pays de la Loire, made its New York debut at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night under the direction of Marc Soustrot. This 10-year-old ensemble is not Parisian; it centers its activity around the cities of Angers and Nantes.

title: SOVIET'S KURDS' PLIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Asks Tokyo Not to Defy Whaling Ban
description: The United States has sent a message to Tokyo urging the Japanese not to defy the ban on commercial whaling that takes effect in 1985, the State Department said today.

title: JWT Loses $669,000 From Operations
description: The JWT Group released its third-quarter results yesterday, showing an operating loss of $669,000, compared with a profit of $2.8 million in the corresponding quarter of last year.

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN SEAT ON CITY COUNCIL
description: The apparent defeat in Tuesday's voting of Angelo J. Arculeo, the only Republican holding a district seat in the New York City Council, has left Democrats in control of all 35 district seats.

title: MANHATTAN LIBERALS WIN SUPREME COURT RACE
description: The Liberal Party was the major beneficiary from a slip-up last month that left two Democratic candidates for the State Supreme Court in Manhattan off the ballot in Tuesday's election.

title: FOSTERED REHABILITATION FIELD
description: Dr. Arthur S. Abramson, founder and chairman of the department of rehabilitation medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a nationally known figure in the treatment of the physically handicapped, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Students in Seoul Rally Against Regime
description: Students shouting for freedom of the press and labor unions staged anti-Government demonstrations today, and were dispersed when policemen fired tear gas.

title: 300 HONOR SIDNEY HOOK AS DEFENDER OF REASON
description: The very first article, some 69 years ago, contained a bit of the foolishness of a bright but badly informed 11-year-old. Dear editor, it said to The New York Tribune in 1913, I'm shocked to learn that the entire 3,000-mile border with Canada is unfortified.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In Case of Fire ...

title: A BEVY OF MacKINTOSH FURNITURE DESIGNS
description: AS part of Lord & Taylor's dedication to modern furniture classics, it is opening an exhibition tomorrow of a dozen furniture designs by Charles Rennie Mackintosh. Re-creations of furniture by the Scottish architect-designer, who was active from the late 1890's until the early 1920's, will be displayed in the store's eighth-floor gallery, Circa: 20th Century.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rhetorical Everests At Campaign's End

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1982; The Elections
description: Stock prices, buoyed by the election, soared to new highs. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 43.31 points, its biggest one-day advance on record, and closed at 1,065.49, its highest closing level in history. The Big Board's composite index and Standard & Poor's index also set records. Volume was 137 million shares in the fifthbusiest session ever. Analysts said Wall Street regarded the election outcome as a mandate to Washington to keep interest rates under control. (Page A1.) The Dow, though it is the world's most closely watched market indicator, has its critics on Wall Street. (D1.)

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ACOLUMN on weatherstripping for windows on Sept. 23 described insulating materials that can be used on windows and doors to reduce heat loss and infiltration of cold air in the winter and the reverse when air-conditioning is used. Readers have since written to ask for more particulars on dealing with doors, so this column will discuss the most suitable types of stripping and their installation.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos include a reserve of $160,000 for possible payment of a claim by Security Ins Co. against Acmat

title: DEVON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q A
description: Q. From the time our house was built in 1969 the concrete floor of our garage has granulated. I have been told that a new layer of concrete cannot be put on top of the existing one to remedy the situation. Is there some paint or sealer I can apply that will solve the problem?

title: PROSECUTOR LINKS CHIEF AT WARNER TO BRIBE PLAN
description: A Federal prosecutor asserted yesterday that Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications, had designated the company's assistant treasurer as the ''banker or overseer of a secret cash fund'' containing $170,000 obtained as bribes.

title: CELLU-CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $70,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 9 mos and a gain of $204,000 or 10 cents a shr for the qr and 9 mos from an antitrust settlement...C-Including tax credits of $70,000 for the qr and $212,000 for the 9 mos

title: WHERE STOCKHOLDERS DO A FIRM'S WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Having started the season with a fourgame unbeaten streak, the Devils have reverted to the losing form they displayed when they were the Colorado Rockies, with seven straight defeats.

title: CITY COUNCIL AND REFERENDUM
description: Following are unofficial results of elections in the New York metropolitan area. The results of some contests will not be available until they are certified by state election authorities. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent, and a dagger (+) denotes complete returns. The abbreviations are: D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, RTL - Right to Life, L - Liberal, LIB - Libertarian, COM - Communist, FL, Free Libertarian and CIT - Citizens Party. title: Ex-Mental Patient Killed in Queens
description: Irwin Riback, a 47-year-old resident of a Queens facility that houses former patients of state mental hospitals was killed yesterday in a dispute with another resident, the police reported.

title: CHAMBER: MUSICAL ELEMENTS
description: THE chamber ensemble Musical Elements opened its generally praiseworthy concert at Monday Cooper Union with a misfire. This was ''Anaktoria'' a blasting, tedious work by Iannis Xenakis, full of squeals, crashes, and a disproportionate amount of lengthy rests - all undoubtedly proving some very important theory, and monumentally unmusical.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We ordered champagne for our stock traders five minutes after the market closed and we're going for a vintage number.'' - John A. Conlon Jr. of E. F. Hutton & Company, celebrating the stock market's record performance. (A1:6.)

title: THEATRICAL LESSONS OF 1800's
description: ITHINK it's about time for a few cautionary remarks. Whenever we h appen to dwell, in our idle hours, on the legitimate theater that p receded our own - I mean the 19th century that preceded the 20th -wea re inclined to smile a bit smugly, shudder with some distaste, and p erhaps give a small sigh of relief that we're a smarter bunch than o ur forebears were. Not that we really spend many hours dwelling on d rama that made the most of Little Eva's ascent into heaven or E liza's flight across the ice. Every once in a while, though, the a mbiance of the period asserts itself as we leaf through this or thatv olume of memoirs, and there are times when it can give us, with our s uperior airs, a good shaking up.

title: SYBARITIC BEDROOMS: ALL THE TRAPPINGS
description: ATRIO of new home-furnishings boutiques are providing soft and sensual linens for the bedroom and bathroom that will help make staying at home a cosy, if costly, experience. The wares reflect the personal tastes and design esthetics of their three creators. The trend is to the overdressed bed, square bed pillows, frills, flounces, appliques, soft plaids and sherbetlike pastels.

title: DEFENSE LINKED TO MENSTRUATION DROPPED IN CASE
description: A Brooklyn woman who had contended that charges against her should be dismissed because stress from the approach of her menstrual period had caused her to beat her child dropped that claim in Criminal Court yesterday.

title: Pan Am Shortfall On Employee Cuts
description: Pan American World Airways said 2,120 of its workers had volunteered for various programs intended to cut the company work force - far below its announced goal of cutting 5,000 employees from the payroll. Pan Am said 902 workers had volunteered for early retirement, 418 would take voluntary furlough and 800 flight attendants would take a leave of absence.

title: AND HOUSE
description: Senate Republican leaders predicted yesterday that the election results would place them in the difficult role of mediating between the conservative Republican White House and the increasingly liberal Democratic House of Representatives.

title: Sydney M. Rogers, Arranged Major Mortgages in New York
description: Sydney M. Rogers, the co-founder and former chairman of the New York Urban Servicing Company, which arranged mortgage financing for insurance companies and other major developers, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 10 percent stock divd distributed in July

title: 2 BROTHERS, 2 PATTERNS
description: O n those special Friday nights at the University of Iowa, the night before the Hawkeyes play, Ronnie Harmon can sit in his dormitory room and listen to the noise of an autumn ritual, the start of the big-time football weekend.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
CHRYSLER FEARS CANADA STRIKE
description: In the midst of its worst economic morass since the Depression, Canada faces two ominous labor disputes, one of which threatens to shut down the Chrysler Corporation in the United States.

title: Gina Knee, 84, Artist Known For Semi-Abstract Works
description: Gina Knee, a painter and etcher, died Sunday at Riverhead (L.I.) Hospital on her 84th birthday. Miss Knee, the widow of the painter Alexander Brook, had won prizes for her oils and watercolors, delicately rendered but firmly constructed semi-abstractions based on concrete themes.

title: AMERICAN FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OF GOD, CAESAR AND TEACHERS' LICENSES
description: To the Editor:

title: Met Opera Council To Honor 4 Founders
description: The Metropolitan Opera National Council will honor four of its founding members at a 30th-anniversary dinner in the Plaza Hotel tonight.

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LITTER ON POLITICAL LANDSCAPE
description: From San Diego to Fairbanks, derailed careers and rejected ballot proposals littered the political landscape today after a puzzling performance at the polls.

title: MART DEVELOPERS IN TIMES SQ. PLAN DROPPED BY CITY
description: The developers of a merchandise mart - a key facet in the proposed $1 billion Times Square redevelopment plan - have been removed from the project because of their difficulties acquiring funds, the project's administrator said yesterday.

title: SIKH CAMPAIGN FOR AUTONOMY NEARING A SHOWDOWN IN INDIA
description: Nearly a month after Sikhs wielding swords and spears attacked India's Parliament House, the increasingly violent campaign on behalf of greater autonomy for the Sikhs' home state, Punjab, appears about to reach a showdown with the central Government.

title: 2 Get Prison Terms In Car's Ambush
description: Two men who shot and seriously wounded two security guards in the ambush and robbery of an armored car 17 months ago were sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison.

title: No Headline
description: McENROE TROUNCES BORG

title: Mishap With U.S. Missile Kills a West German
description: A West German was crushed to death and two G.I.'s were injured in a hamlet near here when a 20-ton United States Army Pershing missile carrier broke away from a convoy late Tuesday, crashed through a wall and overturned on a car.

title: Millicom Continues Management Growth
description: Orhan I. Sadik-Khan, an Afghanistan-born corporate executive, has been named president and chief executive of Millicom Inc., a small company traded over the counter with a stake in the new technology of cellular radio and digital messaging systems.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: AUSEFUL gadget has appeared in several forms recently. A small light, it clamps onto a book for reading in bed at night without disturbing your bedmate.

title: Voting by County For Attorney General and Comptroller; ATTORNEY GENERAL
NEWS HAS COMIC SIDE AT WABC
description: MULTIPART special reports focusing on sex and violence have long been staples of local newscasts during ratings periods, but now WABC is trying a novel approach to the news: a comedy series, starring its own anchors and reporters.

title: ITALY BACKS U.S. STAND ON PIPELINE
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy said today that he would try to persuade France to accept a revised American proposal for restricting East-West trade, in an effort to break an impasse over trade sanctions that Washington has imposed against companies involved in the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline to Europe.

title: CBS COVERAGE DRAWS WHITE HOUSE COMPLAINT
description: A top White House official, concerned that CBS News was overstating the magnitude of Democratic gains in the Election, telephoned one of the network's correspondents to register a protest early yesterday.

title: NEW TRIBE LEADER PICKED BY NAVAJOS
description: In an upset, Peter MacDonald, one of America's most powerful Indian leaders, was defeated Tuesday in his bid for re-election as tribal chairman of the 175,000-member Navajo reservation.

title: SOLID STATE SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $35,000 for the qr and $151,000 for the 9mos

title: WHAT TO LOOK FOR IN BUYING A SUN SPACE
description: ASUN space can reduce heating bills by as much as 30 percent if it is correctly attached to an energy efficient home, according to proponents of solar energy. But if it is not properly designed, insulated and installed it can overheat in the summer and lose energy at night and on cold days.

title: THE POLLS: A LOOK BACK AT FLUCTUATIONS
description: There were few surprise winners in the New York metropolitan region in Tuesday's elections, but there were wide fluctuations in the polls during the campaign's final month in almost all the contests.

title: ISRAEL PUTS PALESTINIAN INFILTRATORS IN BEKAA VALLEY AT 2,000 TO 3,000
description: An Israeli Foreign Ministry official said today that 2,000 to 3,000 Palestinian guerrillas had infiltrated the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon since they were evacuated from West Beirut to Syria in August.

title: THE HERITAGE OF SIR JOHN SOANE
description: WHEN Sir John Soane died in 1837 at the age of 83 he left behind him a museum in Lincoln's Inn Fields that is one of the unsung delights of London. One of his assistants called it ''a very odd shell - denoting the abode of a very odd fish.'' But the few people who frequent it would prefer to call it a tour de force of amenity and ingenuity. Not only is it a prodigy of architectural invention within a comparatively small space, it is a complete and genuine museum, an arsenal of ideas, that is to say, of which every single one has kept its powder dry.

title: JWT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $3.5 million in the qr and $6.2 million for the 9 mos; the 1981 figures were restated for syndication adjustment and an accounting change; foreign exchange losses for the latest qr were $1.8 million and $3.6 millionfor the 9 mos and for the yr-ago periods foreign exchange losses totaled $357,000 for the qr and $2.4 million for the 9 mos

title: CONTRADICTORY LESSONS OF '82 ELECTION
description: Tuesday's elections carried more lessons than usual, perhaps because many of them seemed to contradict one another. Put most simply, the elections amounted to a solid Democratic success, but one that was not as broad as it could have been. For the Republicans, the losses were not vast, but they were most painful when measured against their early expectations of gains that never materialized.

title: United States Team Gains Nations' Cup
description: The United States Equestrian Team continued its dominance of the 99th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night with an easy triumph in the Nations' Cup event.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Plenty of Sweepers, Not Enough Litter

title: U.S. Backs Case Against N.C.A.A.
description: The Justice Department today lined up with major football powers challenging the exclusive right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to market televised football games.

title: NUCLEAR BOOKS PROLIFERATING, BUT FEW SELL WELL
description: Daniel Ford will have pulled off publishing's equivalent of the hat-trick when his third book this year will be published Nov. 15, four days after his second book and eight months after his first. Issued by three different publishers, each deals with nuclear energy or nuclear warfare: ''Three-Mile Island: Thirty Minutes to Meltdown,'' ''The Cult of the Atom: The Secret Papers of the Atomic Energy Commission'' and ''Beyond the Freeze: The Road to Nuclear Sanity,'' with Henry Kendall and Steven Nadis.

title: POPE ASSAILS SCIENTISTS' STRESS ON ARMS
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the concentration of scientific effort on the development of arms of war was ''a scandal of our times.''

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the reorganization of the company which resulted in the spin-off of its non-utility operations

title: JUSTICE WILEY RUTLEDGE ON STATE 'BARBARISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPIC HALL OF FAME
description: O f the 998 Americans who have won Olympic gold medals, either individually or as team members, which one deserves to be hailed as the best of the best?

title: I.M.F. LOAN TO PRETORIA IS VOTED
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved a $1.1 billion loan to South Africa despite opposition from many third-world countries and strong criticism of its racial policies even by governments supporting the loan.

title: 5 STATES RE-ELECT INCUMBENTS
description: All Congressional and gubernatorial incumbents in the five-state Rocky Mountain region were returned to office Tuesday. The voters seemed more comfortable with preserving the status quo than with change.

title: CITY AND SUBURBAN JUDGES
description: Following are unofficial results of elections in the New York metropolitan area. The results of some contests will not be available until they are certified by state election authorities. An asterisk (*) denotes an incumbent, and a dagger (+) denotes complete returns. The abbreviations are: D - Democrat, R - Republican, C - Conservative, RTL - Right to Life, L - Liberal, LIB - Libertarian, COM - Communist, FL, Free Libertarian and CIT - Citizens Party. U denotes a candidate who was unopposed.

title: EDO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 50 percent stock divd paid Sept 30, 1982

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day Oct. 25 incorrectly stated the leverage ratios of the Crocker National Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation. For the third quarter, primary capital - the amount of money held permanently by the banks - averaged 5.45 percent of total assets at Crocker National, and 4.74 percent at Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: TAX CREDITS? MAYBE
description: MANY sun space and greenhouse manufacturers advertise that their products may qualify for a Federal tax credit of 40 percent, up to $4,000. But their claims can be misleading, the Internal Revenue Service says.

title: Work Clothes Renter Tracks Unemployment
description: Bruce L. Cohen is not an economist but he has a good track record forecasting the nation's unemployment rate. Mr. Cohen, 39, is the newly elected president and chief executive of Servisco, a Hillside, N.J., company that rents work clothes and uniforms to more than 45,000 companies, including airlines, oil companies, manufacturers and fast-food outlets.

title: LAUTENBERG TOURS STATE TO THANK VOTERS
description: Frank R. Lautenberg today savored what he described as his ''sweet victory'' over Representative Millicent Fenwick in the election Tuesday for the United States Senate from New Jersey by traveling the length of the state to talk to newsmen and well-wishers.

title: DEGAS 'DANCERS RESTING' SELLS FOR $1.3 MILLION, AUCTION TOP
description: Two 1870's paintings of dancers by Edgar Degas became the stars of last night's multi-million dollar art auction when they sold for $1.3 million and $1 million, the highest prices of the sale at Christie's.

title: Inco Sets Share Offer
description: Inco Ltd. said today that it planned a public offering of about 6 million common shares in the United States, Canada and international markets.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; all figures for 1981 reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 on foreign currency translations

title: STOCK-BUYING SURGE AFTER ELECTION SENDS MARKET TO NEW HIGH
description: A huge buying surge by investors who saw the election results as good news for the nation's economy shattered two stock market records yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 43.41 points, more than it had ever gone up in a single day, and closed at 1,065.49, its highest closing level ever.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

No 52; the shr earnings reflect a 1-for-3reverse stock split in Aug as part of the company's partial liquidation plan

title: A New Enterprise
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, who has been racing thoroughbred horses for several years, has now entered into a deal that will involve him in the breeding and racing of pacers and trotters. Steinbrenner has teamed with Morton Finder and Louis Guida, two of the leaders in the syndication of standardbreds, to purchase yearlings, and two such purchases have already been made. The new group has bought Carleton Speed, a Speedy Crown colt, for $115,000, and Turaco, an Albatross colt, for $110,000.

title: 'A SINO-SOVIET ALLIANCE IS NOT IN THE CARDS'
description: One of Moscow's primary goals in seeking to improve relations with Peking is to undermine Chinese relations with Washington. The Soviet Union probably will not succeed in this: Relations between Washington and Peking are too close, and too many of their fundamental interests coincide. A Sino-Soviet alliance is not in the cards. But Peking's openness to Moscow does reflect a basic foreign policy shift - a new concern for other third-world countries, including those traditionally thought to be Soviet allies, and a turn toward a more nonaligned international stance.

title: AMERICAN PERSPECTIVE AT THE I.M.F.
description: Three times a week, they drift into the well guarded entrance of a 12th-floor boardroom and take their assigned places around an oversized oak table.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: PHOTOS AND ANTIQUES
description: Precursors of Postmodernism: Milan 1920's-30's, Urban Center, 457 Madi- son Avenue (51st Street), 212-753- 1722.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Coca Cola Co. is issuing a $100 million Eurobond, due in 1987 and priced at par with a 10 3/8 percent coupon, through Morgan Guaranty.

title: Coast Federal Sale
description: Coast Federal Savings and Loan Association said it has sold securities backed by $350 million of mortgages on California properties to the California State Retirement Fund. The sale, which was arranged with the help of two national secondary market agencies, is believed to be the largest single sale to a state pension fund. Coast Federal said it had used $158 million of securities guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association and $92 million guaranteed by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation in the sale.

title: Dividends Slashed At 3 Companies
description: Northwest Industries cut its quarterly dividend to 67 cents, from $1.10 a share, payable Jan. 3, 1983, to shareholders of record Dec. 15, 1982. The company said the reason was the adverse effect on its subsidiary, the Lone Star Steel Company, of an ''unprecedented'' decline in oil and gas drilling activity in the United States and other business uncertainties.

title: JOEL I. BROOKE, 67, EDUCATOR AND EX-HEAD OF PEACE FUND
description: Dr. Joel I. Brooke, retired president of the Fund for Peace and a leader in civic and educational affairs in Connecticut, died Tuesday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived in Noroton, Conn.

title: MEMBERS OF NEW U.S. SENATE
description: Following is a list of the members of the new Senate that will take office in January., The letters D and R designate Democrats and Republicans. An asterisk designates a winner in Tuesday's election. In Rhode Island the contest between Senator John H. Chafee and Julius C. Michaelson has not been decided. ALABAMA

title: STORER BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a $2.4 million gain on the sale of a radio station

title: NEW HOUSE SEEMS LESS IN TUNE WITH REAGAN
description: According to a candidate-by-candidate survey by The New York Times and CBS News, the newly elected Congress will be more inclined than the current one to cut back scheduled increases in military spending, more opposed to trimming domestic social programs and differs more with President Reagan on a full range of issues from abortion and the nuclear freeze to Social Security.

title: Another Walton Injury
description: Bill Walton has another injury to contend with. His team, the San Diego Clippers, announced yesterday that while playing last Friday against Phoenix in his first regular-season game in more than two years, Walton fractured a cheekbone while scrambling for a loose ball.

title: IRAN REPORTS NEW GAINS IN OFFENSIVE
description: Iran said today that its forces had destroyed 40 Iraqi tanks and armored cars and had overrun two more border posts on the central front on the second day of an offensive that began on Monday night.

title: SAI GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a gain of $462,000 for an accounting adjustment

title: O'NEILL, HAVING WON TOP POST ON HIS OWN, EXPECTS TO MAKE CHANGES IN CONNECTICUT
description: After filling in as Governor for 22 months, William A. O'Neill on Tuesday won a term of his own, and immediately declared, ''There may be massive changes all across the board.''

title: Brett's Ultimatum
description: George Brett, who last month completed the first season of a fiveyear contract worth approximately $1 million annually, is demanding that the Kansas City Royals either give him a contract covering the rest of his playing career or trade him. That word came from Bobby Brett, his brother and financial adviser, who said that at the heart of the demand was the 29-year-old star third baseman's desire to ''be a Royal the rest of his career.''

title: Ray Fisher, 95, Was Oldest Former Player for Yankees
description: Ray Fisher, the oldest former player of the New York Yankees and the Cincinnati Reds, died today at the age of 95.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Mount Vernon Slaves

title: Saarstahl Gets Loan
description: The West German Cabinet granted Arbed Saarstahl G.m.b.H. a $30 million bridging loan pending a final decision on federal aid later this month, the chief Government spokesman, Diether Stolze, said today.

title: HERS
Barclays Merger
description: The Barclays Bank of New York, a subsidiary of the London-based Barclays Bank P.L.C., said it had completed a $26.5 million acquisition of a subsidiary of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. Bankers Trust sold its 25-branch Hudson Valley division as part of its move out of retail banking, a corporate strategy change that was announced last year. Barclays spokesmen have said most Hudson Valley branches and employees will be retained.

title: SHOPPING SERVICES IN MANY LANGUAGES
description: IT should come as no surprise that Tiffany's, Saks and Bloomingdale's are often as important to foreign visitors as the Statue of Liberty, a Broadway show or closing a business deal. This city is, after all, an international shopping haven.

title: Books Of The Times
description: LORD BYRON: Selected Letters and Jour- nals. Edited by Leslie A. Marchand. 400 pages. Belknap. $17.50. BYRON. By Frederic Raphael. 224 pages. Thames & Hudson. $18.95.

title: TV: BRITISH COMEDY, A GALACTIC HITCHHIKE
description: ARTHUR DENT is a mild-mannered English suburbanite who wakes up one morning to discover that his pretty little home is about to be demolished to make way for a highway bypass. Arthur throws himself in front of the bulldozer. Little does he know, however, that the entire planet Earth is about to be destroyed to make way for a hyperspace bypass. As the helpful, unseen narrator explains, ''Arthur no more knows his destiny than a tea leaf knows the history of the East India Company.''

title: Nationwide Sets In-House Mergers
description: The Nationwide Corporation, an insurance holding company, announced a proposed merger under which it would become part of a Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company subsidiary.

title: CREDIT MARKETS PRICES CLIMB, THEN EASE OFF
description: Rates on short-term money market instruments closed a touch higher, where they changed at all. ''The election results had little, if any, influence on the bond market,'' said Thomas G. Gribbon, executive vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Government Securities Inc. ''The early sharp advance was caused by institutional buying that was largely based on expectations of an imminent cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate.''

title: U.N. PANEL SHELVES PRESS REPORT
description: Top United Nations officials today shelved a report that compared Western news outlets with those in the Soviet Union.

title: Dodging A Ballot
description: ''Nothing in life is so exhilarating,'' wrote Winston Churchill in 1898, ''as to be shot at without result.'' No wonder Ronald Reagan looks so peppy today: his Administration dodged the midterm ballot that brought down so many Presidencies. This year's liberal countertrend, which manifested itself in the primaries of both parties earlier this autumn, continued respectably in the elections to the House but failed to make a dent in the Senate.

title: PLAYERS OFFERED BONUSES
description: A National Football League player could earn as much as $15,000 a year above his annual salary in collectively bargained incentive bonuses, if the N.F.L. Players Association accepts management's current contract offer.

title: U.S. HOUSE DELEGATIONS RETAINING PARTY BALANCE
description: The Congressional delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut went against the national trend of Democratic gains in the House of Representatives and emerged from Tuesday's elections with the balance little changed between Republicans and Democrats.

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $62,000...C-Including a tax credit of $57,000...D-Including a tax credit of $192,000 and a gain of $577,000 from a subsidiary disposed of in Apr

title: COPELAN FLOURISHES UNDER SPECIAL CARE
description: Three years ago, Mitchell Griffin was enjoying his work as a technician and cable-splicer for the telephone company in Pensacola, Fla.

title: MISSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DE LA RENTA'S LUXURIOUS EVENINGS
description: OSCAR DE LA RENTA left none of the season's fashion bases untouched in his spring show yesterday in the auditorium of the Parsons School of Design. He attracted a glittering audience of top retail executives (Melvin Jacobs of Saks Fifth Avenue, John W. Christian Jr. of B. Altman & Company, Robert T. Sakowitz of Sakowitz Inc. and Geraldine Stutz of Henri Bendel, among them) and of private clients (Nan Kempner, Casey Ribicoff, Fran Stark, Elizabeth Rowayton, Nancy Kissinger), along with store buyers and the press.

title: Operetta to Be Signed
description: The 2 P.M. Saturday performance of ''The Merry Widow'' at the New York City Opera will be interpreted in sign language. Two interpreters in costume will be at the left side of the stage; all available front orchestra seats are being set aside for people with hearing impairments. Information: 870-5637.

title: MEMBERSHIP OF THE NEW U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
description: Following is a list of the members of the new House of Representatives. The letters D and R designate Democratic and Republican candidates. Other party candidates are designated by an O. In districts listing two names the race has not been decided; in two districts in Georgia, the election will be held Nov, 30.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES UP BY 9.1%
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that sales rose 9.1 percent in the last 10 days of October. But despite the rise, sales for all of October were at their lowest level since June.

title: M.I.S.L. Conflict
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League announced yesterday that the syndicate that had just bought the Arrows included the majority owners of two rival teams. The league also said it had a solution for this apparent conflict of interest.

title: F.A.A. RECONSIDERS ITS STANCE ON IMPROVING FLIGHT RECORDERS
description: A long-standing deadlock between two Federal agencies over an airline safety issue has been unexpectedly loosened by a change in stance by one of the parties.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Creation Science Law' Challenged in Louisiana
description: Louisiana's ''Creation science law'' moved to the courtroom today with attorneys arguing whether the state school board or the Legislature should establish the public school curriculum.

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLANTS THAT DO WELL IN A SUN SPACE
description: RAISING plants in a sun space is easy if one vital point is kept in mind: extremes. The sun-warmed environment is subject to major fluctuations in temperature - in the 80's or 90's during the day as the sun pours in and 50 degrees or even lower on cold nights. If there are many sunless days little if any heat can be trapped in the glass-enclosed space.
