title: HUDSON BAY MINING & SMELTING CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOW BUSINESS READS THE VOTE
description: Many businessmen and private economists yesterday greeted results of Tuesday's off-year elections as an opportunity for the President and Congress to make necessary midcourse economic corrections. And the stock market, in a record-shattering session, added its own endorsement of the election returns.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Cardinals of the National Football League re-signed their coach, Jim Hanifan, through the 1984 season.

title: U.S. ASSISTANCE WANES FOR THE SOLAR INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON IN an average week last year, the Federal Solar Heating and Cooling Information Center answered 4,000 to 6,000 consumer inquiries. Its operators and staff provided technical information about solar equipment problems and solutions, Government assistance programs and shopping guidelines.

title: Bridge: Big Prizes in Fall Nationals Fail to Draw Many Experts
description: Bridge experts are a suspicious lot, and most would rebuff a stranger who offered to sell them a gold brick for a modest price. They would feel foolish, however, if the offer turned out to be genuine.

title: 2 PLEAD GUILTY TO DUMPING CHEMICALS INTO HUDSON
description: A former oil company president implicated in years of toxic waste dumping in the New York area pleaded guilty yesterday with an associate in Newark to Federal charges of extensive chemical dumping into the Hudson River and elsewhere.

title: HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
'Iron Man' Mark to Smith
description: Calling it ''my most memorable night,'' Randy Smith set a National Basketball Association record tonight by playing in his 845th consecutive game. His team, the San Diego Clippers, lost to the Philadelphia 76ers, 130-111, for its fourth straight setback.

title: Soviet Move On Silver Seen
description: The Soviet Union has bought as much as 10 million ounces of silver in recent weeks, dealers here said today.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FORD REDUCES FINANCING RATE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had lowered to 10.75 the interest rate it will charge to finance the purchases of all 1982 Ford and Lincoln-Mercury models. The company also instituted rebates of $200 to $1,000 on selected models to help increase the sales of leftover 1982 models.

title: QUEEN PRESENTS TORIES' TOUGH POLICIES
description: Queen Elizabeth II opened a new session of Parliament today with a speech proclaiming the Conservative Government's intention to stand firm in the fight against inflation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said its Advanced Mobile Phone Service subsidiary had given the F.C.C. the details of its agreements with 18 other telephone companies on providing mobile telephone service in 13 areas.

title: FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOME BEAT
description: JENS QUISTGAARD was a sculptor before he became a designer for Dansk International Designs. That, no doubt, is why he sees his flatware, glasses, ceramic casserole dishes, teak trays and bowls as three-dimensional objects.

title: TO STOP THE TRADE IN STOLEN ANTIQUITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Caldor Takeovers
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation said that its Caldor discount store subsidiary would take over the five Stewart & Company stores in Maryland, starting next spring.

title: Mine Closings
description: The United States Steel Corporation's Quebec Cartier Mining Company unit said it would proceed with the previously announced shutdown of its Mount Wright and Gagnon iron ore operations next Monday. A spokesman for Quebec Cartier said the Mount Wright facility would reopen on Jan. 3; operations at the company's 8 percent owned Gagnon facilities at Fire Lake and Lac Jeannine will not reopen before Jan. 15.

title: FOR CHAIR REPAIR, GLUE AND CLAMPS
description: If there was one piece that tested the skill of any furniture maker, it must have been the chair. In the great shops of the 18th century, the golden age of cabinetmaking, the chair maker reigned supreme. It was a specialized part of the business, for cutting the wood was complicated further when it came to the chair, because for the most part the joinery came in at angles.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE STOP THAT HURT ISLANDERS
description: I n the opening round of the National Hockey League playoffs last season, the Pittsburgh Penguins extended the Islanders to a fifth and final game at Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders won, 4-3, in overtime after having rallied from two goals down late in the third period.

title: Felipe Gonzalez Expects To Take Office Dec. 9
description: Prime Minister-elect Felipe Gonzalez said today that he planned to take office and announce his Cabinet on Dec. 9.

title: BRADLEY LOSES CLOSE CONTEST ON COAST
description: California bucked the national trend Tuesday by electing Republicans to major offices. George Deukmejian, the state Attorney General, ruined the bid by Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles to become the first black in the nation to be elected governor, and Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego defeated Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. in their race for the United States Senate.

title: MOST BOND ISSUES ON BALLOT APPROVED
description: Preliminary returns indicated yesterday that voters had approved most of the bond issue proposals on the ballots in Tuesday's elections.

title: THE MEDIA AND JURIES
description: In 1964, in a decision heralded by one prominent legal scholar as ''an occasion for dancing in the streets,'' the United States Supreme Court held that broad aspects of the common law of defamation violate the First Amendment. The landmark decision in New York Times v. Sullivan was premised on the Court's recognition that large defamation verdicts rendered against the news media can serve to punish unpopular expression and to inhibit robust and wide-open debate on public issues. Eighteen years and hundreds of judicial pronouncements later, the time has come to acknowledge that this exercise in constitutional intervention has been a stunning, if wellintentioned, failure.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: L.I. HIGH SCHOOL CLOSED
description: More than 2,300 students and teachers were removed from Hauppauge High School on Long Island yesterday after a mysterious odor spread through the hallways, causing many to became dizzy and nauseated.

title: Baseball; CY YOUNG VOTING
description: Following are the results of the voting by members of the Baseball Writers Association of America for the 1982 Cy Young Award in the American League. A pitcher receives 5 points for each first-place vote, 3 for second and 1 for third. First Second Third Total Pete Vuckovich 14 4 5 87 Jim Palmer 4 12 3 59 Dan Quisenberry 4 5 5 40 Dave Stieb 5 3 2 36 Rick Sutcliffe 1 2 3 14 Geoff Zahn - 1 4 7 Bob Stanley - 1 1 4 Bill Caudill - - 4 4 Dan Petry - - 1 1 CY YOUNG WINNERS 1982 - Pete Vuckovich, Milwaukee 1981 - Rollie Fingers, Milwaukee 1980 - Steve Stone, Baltimore 1979 - Mike Flanagan, Baltimore 1978 - Ron Guidry, Yankees 1977 - Sparky Lyle, Yankees 1976 - Jim Palmer, Baltimore 1975 - Jim Palmer, Baltimore 1974 - Catfish Hunter, Oakland 1973 - Jim Palmer, Baltimore 1972 - Gaylord Perry, Cleveland 1971 - Vida Blue, Oakland 1970 - Jim Perry, Minnesota 1969 - Mike Cuellar, Baltimore, and Denny McLain, Detroit, tie 1968 - Denny McLain, Detroit 1967 - Jim Lonborg, Boston 1964 - Dean Chance, California 1961 - Whitey Ford, Yankees 1959 - Early Wynn, Chicago 1958 - Bob Turley, Yankees Prior to 1967, the Cy Young was a com- bined award given to the top pitcher in the major leagues.

title: NEWCOMER TO THE TOP: MARIO M. CUOMO
description: Mario Matthew Cuomo, who was elected Tuesday as the 52d Governor of New York State, comes to his new job from a lifetime of watching government work but with little experience as a top decision-maker.

title: WEINBERGER, ON ASIAN TOUR, HAS MILITARY TALKS WITH SUHARTO
description: Continuing his tour of reassurance through Southeast Asia and the Pacific region, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met with President Suharto here today on what Mr. Weinberger called ''matters that affect the security of both our countries.''

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Famed Course Is Saved
description: The Jockey Club of England, which conducts thoroughbred racing in Britain, has agreed to buy Aintree Race Course, thus assuring the future of Aintree's Grand National, one of the world's most famed steeplechase races. Fears had been expressed about the possibility of closing the track because of the financial problems of its owner, Bill Davies. Those fears dissipated yesterday with the Jockey Club's announcement of its purchase, in which more than $6.5 million changed hands among the club, Davies and his creditors.

title: Icahn Broadens Dan River Offer
description: Carl C. Icahn and his affiliated companies said they had broadened a tender offer to increase their stake in Dan River Inc., a textile concern that is fighting the group's advances. Mr. Icahn, through his Icahn Capital Corporation and other companies, already owns 15 percent of Dan River.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TO BORROW FOR PENSION CHECKS
description: The Treasury, confirming that the Social Security old-age trust fund is nearly empty, announced today that the fund would borrow $1 billion Friday to make sure it has enough money to cover this month's $12.2 billion of benefit payments.

title: STAGE: COUNTRY FANTASY
description: NOWADAYS, more and more musicals that are supposedly designed for adults aggressively cultivate a spirit of childlike innocence. And the AMAS Repertory Theater's latest production, ''Louisiana Summer,'' which bills itself as a ''country fantasy,'' would like to fit into this category, along with ''Annie,'' ''Little Shop of Horrors'' and ''Pump Boys and Dinettes.''

title: DEMOCRATS REGAIN CONTROL IN HOUSE
description: The Democrats regained effective control of the House of Representatives by picking up at least 26 seats in Tuesday's elections, according to Congressional leaders in both parties.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grey Net Off 7%
description: Grey Advertising reported that third-quarter net income declined 7 percent, to $1.3 million, or $2.14 a share, from $1.4 million, or $2.28 a share. Revenue, however, surged 18.2 percent, to $33.1 million from $28 million. For the nine months, revenue gained 26.1 percent, to $101.9 million, from $80.8 million, but net income was up only two-tenths of 1 percent, to about $4.5 million.

title: GOVERNORSHIPS SEEN AS REAGAN PROBLEM
description: Democrats won 27 of the 36 governorships at stake in the election Tuesday, a net gain of seven that leaders of both parties said had implications for President Reagan's campaign to promote his ''new federalism'' proposals and for the 1984 Presidential election.

title: Heart Attack Fatal To Robbery Victim
description: A self-employed distributor of handbags and umbrellas suffered a fatal heart attack Tuesday night as he was telling two police officers that he had been abducted from outside a Brooklyn bank and robbed of about $2,000 in cash, the police said yesterday.

title: TOXIC SHOCK CASE WEIGHED BY COURT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, facing hundreds of damage suits that contend its Rely tampons caused toxic shock syndrome, went to court here today in an effort to obtain records on the potentially fatal disease from a Federal health agency.

title: MILTON AVERY
description: TWENTY YEAR AGO, when the English painter and art critic Patrick Heron was visiting New York, a friend took him to see the paintings of the American artists Milton Avery. Heron was thne an ardent champion of the New American Painting, as Abstract Expressionism was called - Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko and Willem de Kooning, among others - but, like most foreign visitors to the New York art world at that time, he had never heard of Avery, who had been painting and showing his work much longer than his better-known contemporaries.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LA MILANESE

title: THE CITY
description: A workman was seriously injured when he was struck in the head yesterday by a piece of steel that had fallen nine stories from scaffolding on a midtown hotel, the police said.

title: POP: LYDIA LUNCH'S QUINTET
description: NOTHING in Lydia Lunch's Halloween set at the Peppermint Lounge was faster than a death march or friendlier than a slammed door. Thurston Moore would plunk an ominous, minor-key bass riff, Richard Edson would join him with a drumbeat, Jim Sclavunos would counter with alto saxophone wails, Pat Place would scratch and worry her guitar and Miss Lunch would speak-sing her lyrics clearly and discordantly, lurching around the stage.

title: A RESOURCE LIST FOR THE ENERGY CONSCIOUS
description: Here is a partial listing of companies that sell sun spaces. (For others, check the Yellow Pages under ''greenhouse'' or ''solar,'' or call your local chapter of the American Institute of Architects for referrals.)
