description: Shr earning reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1982; shr earnings are fully diluted

title: LOSSES AT HANNA AND NLT
description: The Hanna Mining Company, hard hit by weakness in the iron ore industry, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $17.1 million in the third quarter, compared with earnings of $8.6 million, or 97 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1981. Sales plummeted to $45.5 million from $86.8 million.

title: BIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A NEW TREATMENT FOR INFANT CATARACTS
description: Surgery and soft contact lenses fitted soon after birth can save the sight of babies born with severe cataracts, eye specialists report.

title: Islanders Tie on Potvin Goal
description: The Islanders tonight ran into difficulties with a last-place team for the second consecutive night and struggled to a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
SURRENDER AFTER A 16-HOUR SIEGE
description: Nine Turkish gunmen who said they were against the military regime in Turkey seized the Turkish Consulate here and dozens of hostages in a storm of gunfire Wednesday, but gave themselves up early today after nearly 16 hours of negotiations, the police reported. They said all of the hostages were released.

title: Israel H. Levinthal, 94, Brooklyn Center Rabbi
description: Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal, the spiritual leader of the Brooklyn Jewish Center in the Crown Heights section since 1919, died Sunday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 94 years old and resided in New Rochelle.

title: RETURNS IN U.S. SENATE RACES
description: Following are the latest returns in the 33 races for the Senate. The percentage of precincts counted is listed after each state name. The letters D and R designate Democratic and Republican candidates. An asterisk signifies an incumbent.

title: CONSERVATIVES WIN VOTE IN ALBERTA
description: Premier Peter Lougheed and his Progressive Conservatives won a virtual sweep of legislative elections here Tuesday, overwhelming the Western Canada Concept, a vaguely secessionist party that has evolved over the last five years.

title: THEATER: GOETHE'S 'FAUST, PARTS I AND II,' BY C.S.C.
description: LED by Christopher Martin, the C.S.C. Repertory has made its most intrepid contribution as an explorer of larger-than-life dramatic masterpieces - with a cycle of William Butler Yeats's ''Cuchulain'' plays, a three-play Oedipus cycle, and, last year, a two-part ''Peer Gynt.'' Mr. Martin has opened this season by undertaking perhaps his most formidable task - staging both parts of Goethe's ''Faust.''

title: Anthony S. Earl
description: Newly elected Governor of Wisconsin ... 46-year-old Democrat ... former member of the State Legislature ... a liberal with strong support from groups of political activists ... campaigned for a nuclear arms freeze ... served as Secretary of Administration and later as Secretary of Natural Resources under Gov. Patrick J. Lucey in the 1970's ... won gubernatorial nomination this year by defeating Martin J. Schreiber, the one-time acting governor. Richard H. Bryan

title: FIRST CONSEQUENCES
description: The MX missile may now never be built. Congress will take a harder look at all the plans for nuclear weapons, and at the rising defense budget generally. President Reagan will have strong new political incentives to negotiate seriously with the Russians on arms control.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lakers 135, Nuggets 134
description: DENVER (AP) - James Worthy's tip-in with four seconds remaining in overtime gave Los Angeles the victory.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings adjusted for stock split in Oct 1982

title: KREMLINOLOGY: NEW SENSE OF URGENCY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said recently that after many briefings on the succession struggle in the Soviet Union he was convinced that nobody really knew what was going to happen in the Kremlin when Leonid I. Brezhnev was replaced.

title: 15-Year-Old Elected To County Weed Unit
description: Fifteen-year-old Eric Salem won in his first try for elected office, but he was a bit tired after it was all over.

title: Help for Disabled
description: Gene Mayer, a member of the United States Davis Cup team and one of the world's top-ranked tennis players, is especially sensitive to the needs of the disabled. Now he is joining Suzanne Lippe of Hewlett, L.I., a ranking Eastern player, who teaches physically handicapped children in the New York City school system, to establish the National Tennis Association for the Disabled.

title: Dominique Dunne, Actress, Dies After Being Choked
description: Dominique Dunne, a 22-year-old actress who made her movie debut in ''Poltergiest,'' died today without regaining consciousness after being choked by an assailant five days ago.

title: DEMOCRATS MADE WIDEPREAD GAINS IN STATES CONTROL
description: Late tabulations showed yesterday that Democrats captured 11 more state legislative houses in the elections Tuesday. The results almost wiped out Republican gains in grass-roots rebuilding that had been under way since the Watergate scandals of the early 1970's damaged the party on all levels.

title: 3 ON PHILADELPHIA POLICE RESIGN IN SHAKEDOWN CASE
description: An investigation of police corruption, apparently set off by a former soldier of fortune fighting shakedowns of a nude modeling agency he had established here, is gathering data for presentation to a Federal grand jury.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for QTr to Sept 24
description: The 1981 results reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 on foreign currency translation

title: SLEWPY, 28-1, UPSETS COPELAN
description: Slewpy, a 28-1 shot who lost his previous race by 18 lengths, slipped through on the rail and drew off to a 3 1/4-length victory tonight in the $326,500 Young America Stakes for 2-year-olds at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: A DECADE OF CUBAN DOCUMENTARIES
description: CUBAN documentary films -lively glimpses of life made to entertain as much as to educate Cuba's thousands of avid moviegoers - are the subject of an unusual festival this weekend at New York's Film Forum 1.

title: Fire Union Is Seeking To Block Graduation
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association went to court yesterday in an effort to prevent the graduation at the Fire Academy today of 11 women and 103 men.

title: Soviet Politburo Lineup Drops Kirilenko Portrait
description: A portrait of Andrei P. Kirilenko was not posted along with those of his Politburo colleagues in displays erected today for the national holiday next Sunday, adding credence to reports that he was stepping down from the Soviet leadership group.

title: SAILOR'S LAMENT: WHAT DID THEY DO TO SHANGHAI?
description: Once Shanghai ranked among the world's rowdiest ports of call, with a licentiousness that outstripped even its own reputation.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PARTISAN DEBATE FLARES ON SAVING SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee, declared today that in light of Democratic gains in the House of Representatives the Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., should explain how the Democrats proposed to shore up the finances of the Social Security System.

title: Market Place; What 'E.T.' Does for MCA
description: THAT benign make-believe creature from outer space, E.T., is doing for MCA today what the movie ''Jaws'' did for the company seven years ago.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Weinberger in Australia
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived here today as part of his Southeast Asian tour. He plans to confer with J. Douglas Anthony, Minister for Trade and Resources, who is acting Prime Minister while Malcolm Fraser is hospitalized; with Defense Minister Ian Sinclair and with William J. Hayden, the leader of the Labor opposition.

title: DeNARDIS CONCESSION RECEIVED BY MORRISON
description: Representative Lawrence J. DeNardis has dropped his demand for a recount and has conceded defeat to Bruce A. Morrison in Connecticut's Third District.

title: TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TERRORISTS KILL A TOP GENERAL IN MADRID
description: Two men on a motorcycle drew up beside a car carrying a top Spanish general this morning and killed him with a hail of submachine gun fire.

title: Iraq Contends Iranians Were Again Repulsed
description: Iraq said today that Iranian troops had made another attempt to cross into Iraqi territory but had again been repulsed. The attackers, a communique said, were wiped out.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: College Top 20 Computer ranking based on games through Oct. 30
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. SuperSonics, at Seattle. The Knicks have neither won nor scored 100 points in any of their three games this season. (Radio - WNEW, 1130; 11 P.M.) Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Richfield, Ohio. The Nets were 6-0 against the Cavaliers last season and have an eight-game winning streak against them. The last time they lost to Cleveland was on Jan. 22, 1981. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; 8 P.M.) Boxing Mark Medal vs. Steve Michalerya, 10 rounds, junior middleweights; Euclides Valdez vs. Pete McIntyre, 10 rounds, light heavyweights; Jose Baret vs. Richard Gregory, 10 rounds, welterweights; at Felt Forum, Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable 7:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.).

title: New Lehrman Campaign?
description: Those Lehrman-for-Governor television commercials were so ubiquitous that it was no great surprise when one of them somehow got on the air 20 minutes after the polls closed.

title: Friday; BEST IN ART PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Ansel Adams, one of the masters of American photography, will be recognized in an award presentation at the third annual Fine Art Photography Exposition, which opens this afternoon at 4:30 in the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street. The three-day event will provide an overview of art photography from the 19th century to the present, displaying works from 45 galleries and dealers in North America and Europe. The nude in photography will be the topic of a special exhibition as well as of a symposium tomorrow at 10 A.M. There will be other symposiums for collectors and curators tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to noon. Admission: $10 a day ($15 for three days), plus tax. 40 EXPLORERS IN GLASS ART

title: I AM NOT AN L
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, apparently worrying about whether President Reagan will certify that Chile has made progress in human rights to meet a Congressional condition for resumption of military aid, has named a commission to consider the status of Chilean exiles abroad. I am one of those exiles.

title: Monday Cuisine
description: A pro football strike and the absence of Monday Night Football was not what the Chilton Book Co. of Radnor, Pa., expected when it published ''The Monday Night Football Cookbook and Restaurant Guide'' on Oct. 1. The first printing was about 20,000 copies, according to Alan Turner, the company's editorial director.

title: Suez Canal Record Broken
description: Eighty ships from 29 countries passed through the Suez Canal today, a record number for a single day in the waterway's 113-year history, according to the Canal Authority Chairman, Mashhour Ahmed Mashhour.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has elected to its board Don T. McKone, chairman and chief executive officer of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, and Harold S. Mohler, chairman of the Hershey Foods Corporation.

title: AND WHERE ONE WOMAN IS PLAYING STRIDE PIANO
description: BRAD SWETT, who owns Hanratty's, the restaurant at Second Avenue near 91st Street, where pianists play who lean toward stride, ragtime and other early jazz styles, was amazed when he saw the pianist he had brought in from California to make a New York debut last week.

title: JAZZ: BOBBY MCFERRIN, SINGER, WITH QUARTET
description: SINCE making his local concert debut a year and a half ago, Bobby McFerrin has been widely acclaimed as a formidable technician in the spontaneous jazz vocal tradition. And at the Bottom Line on Tuesday, Mr. McFerrin, working with bass, drums, piano and guitar, displayed his full battery of vocal effects.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
RECORD NUMBER RECEIVING UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS
description: A record number of Americans drew unemployment checks in mid-October, Government figures showed today, leading private economists to predict a further increase in the national unemployment rate.

title: THEATER: 'TWICE AROUND THE PARK' BY SCHISGAL
description: MURRAY SCHISGAL has always been an exasperatingly uneven writer, so it's no surprise that ''Twice Around the Park,'' his pair of one-act comedies that opened last night at the Cort, splits directly down the middle. No sooner has Mr. Schisgal severely tried our patience with his strained curtain-raiser, ''A Need for Brussels Sprouts,'' than he gets us laughing, freely and almost continuously, with his loony and shrewdly crafted second sketch, ''A Need for Less Expertise.''

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
15 HURT ON PACKED SUBWAY TRAIN IN A SWITCH BLAST IN BRONX TUNNEL
description: A northbound Lexington Avenue IRT subway train carrying 1,800 rushhour commuters jolted to a halt last night when an electrical switch short-circuited with a deafening explosion, filling the tunnel just north of the 149th Street station in the Bronx with smoke, a Transit Authority spokesman said.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swarthmore Protest
description: The undefeated Swarthmore College football team, angered by a review of athletics at the suburban Philadelphia school, is refusing to wear the college insignia on its helmets. ''I told them, it's your prerogative,'' said Coach Tom Lapinski.

title: BELL SPINOFF CAPITALIZED AT $5 BILLION
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved a $5 billion capitalization plan for American Bell Inc., the new American Telephone and Telegraph Company unit that will sell telephone equipment after Jan. 1.

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $5.3 million for the qr and $27.7 million for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $5.1 million for the qr and $18.3 million for the 9 mos

title: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Commodore Filing
description: The Commodore Resources Corporation said that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. It called the action necessary because of a ''business reversal'' over the past several days and its inability to obtain alternative sources of financing for current operations. Commodore, an oil, gas and mineral development concern, reported a net loss of $2.8 million on revenue of $103,000 for its fiscal year ended March 31.

title: PENNCORP FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $6,872,000 for the qr and $15,300,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net loss

title: HEROIN BY PRESCRIPTION: PROVEN SOLUTION TO AN AMERICAN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor: Drug abuse in China has been virtually eliminated, but not, as David Bertan suggests, by ''execut(ing) all the pushers and addicts'' (letter Oct. 18). v. hen the Communists came to power in 1949, drug addiction had been a massive problem for almost 150 years.

title: IT'S HARD FOR GRETZKY TO KEEP HIS PACE
description: Before the start of the second period of Wednesday night's game here between the hometown Oilers and the Winnipeg Jets, Wayne Gretzky stepped onto the ice a few minutes early. He had to accept yet another award.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market set a record for trading volume, with 149.4 million shares changing hands. But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.27 points, to 1,050.22. Analysts said investors were cashing in on Wednesday's surge, during which the Dow rose to a new high of 1,065.49. (Page D1.) With volume soaring, the pressure on stock traders was intense. (D1.) Private economists are more skeptical than Wall Street over the prospects for recovery. (D1.)

title: Leonard's Plans Change
description: Recently pronounced fit to resume his boxing career, Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that his plans for the future had ''changed drastically.'' Leonard, who has completely recovered from his operation last May for a detached retina in his left eye, also said he was ''optimistic'' that he could resume fighting without risking serious injury.

title: 10 Americans Sue U.S.  On Iran Hostage Crisis
description: Ten Americans taken hostage or forced into hiding by the takeover of the United States Embassy in Iran filed a $100 million suit against the Federal Government today, three years after the seizure.

title: SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring after-tax charge of $675,000

title: Pregnant Runner Won't Ease Pace
description: Kathy Horton is a devoted runner who averages 50 miles a week and has finished marathons in times below 3 hours. She is also seven months pregnant, which might normally cause some training problems.

title: SEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $3,231,000 and a charge for taxes on prior yr's unremitted foreign earnings of $5,250,000

title: Index; International
description: Once-sinful Shanghai now a para- dise for prudes A2 Polish Archbishop back in War- saw after talks with Pope A3 Canada orders extradition of Nazi war criminal A3 Irish Government falls A4 Around the World A5 U.S. assails Israel over settle- ment plans for West Bank A7 U.S. Marines begin patrolling Christian East Beirut A8 Salvadoran calls U.S. envoy's charge unfair A9 Britain denounces U.N.'s Falk- land vote A10 Government/Politics Another Daley is seeking to run Chicago A12 Plan calls for retired judges to- handle minor court matters B4 Washington Talk The White House: After the elec- tion, back to reality A14 Kremlinologists make a habit of watching and waiting A14 Briefing A14 General Around the Nation A12 Biographer delays evidence on charge against Johnson A15 Federal scientists study L.I. school closed by fumes B3 481 arrested or given summonses in drive on subway crime B4 150 arraigned without lawyers in Queens court B4 Former Bergen Democratic chief acquitted in bribery case B5 Lilco proposed a rate increase to pay for its nuclear plant B6 Style The Evening Hours B8 Halston for the spring: Glittering wraparounds B8 A Chinese banquet honors the Mayor B8 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 New dishes at **** restau- rants C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: MORRIS: PAIN LED TO DRUGS
description: Mercury Morris, the former running back for the Miami Dolphins, testifying for more than five hours in his own defense against cocaine charges, broke into tears today as he recalled considering suicide because of pain that he said led him to drug use.

title: Author Defends Study At Nevada Fallout Trial
description: A Government witness today defended a study that indicates people who lived downwind from the Nevada atomic tests were not exposed to harmful levels of radiation.

title: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Quotations of the Day
description: ''Once the American people understand the Democrats don't have any ideas, that they don't want to do anything, then we can come in and save the system in a responsible way.''

title: 3 GUITAR RECITALS, WITH DIVERSITY THE KEY
description: Dozens of guitarists play solo recitals in New York every year. All too often, they tend to be limited to Renaissance and Baroque dances written for lute and tidbits transcribed from the cello or violin or piano repertory, along with a few moody, conventional works by Spanish or Latin American guitarist-composers. While the performers display their dexterity and perhaps bemoan the lack of a serious guitar literature from the classical era, too often the effect is like dining on hors d'oeuvres and dessert.

title: FALL TURKEY SEASON HAS SPECIAL RITUAL
description: Fall turkey hunting in New York State is under way, and in the days ahead fewer leaves aloft will improve visibility and increase chances of hunting success.

title: Saudi Sheik Held in Contempt After Leaving With Children
description: A Florida court today ordered Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi held in contempt for leaving the country with his four children in violation of an injunction granted to his former wife.

title: 56 YEARS AFTER PREMIERE, THE ORIGINAL 'TURANDOT'
description: After more than 56 years, a few bruised egos and a lot of detective work, Puccini's opera ''Turandot'' was finally presented here last night as it was originally to be heard at its world premiere.

title: MITCHUM AS DETECTIVE
description: ''ONE SHOE MAKES IT MURDER,'' on CBS, Channel 2, tomorrow at 9 P.M., is a nifty little detective drama that marks the televisionmovie debut of Robert Mitchum. Adapted by Felix Culver from Eric Bercovici's novel ''So Little Cause for Caroline,'' the film offers Mr. Mitchum as Harold Shillman (Shill for short), a former San Diego policeman who, after failing at suicide, now spends his life repossessing cars by day and drinking himself into a stupor by night. Heavy lidded, thick around the middle, moving like a block of granite, Mr. Mitchum is superbly convincing.

title: Armco Trims Its Spending
description: Harry Holiday, chairman of Armco Inc., said the steel producer had reduced its capital sepnding to $340 million from the $370 million estimated earlier this year.

title: Oppenheimer Official Joins Dillon, Read
description: Timothy G. Dalton Jr. has been named president of a new investment management subsidiary established by Dillon, Read & Company. Mr. Dalton, 43, joins Dillon, Read from the Oppenheimer Capital Corporation, where he was a senior vice president. ''It's been part of the Dillon, Read game plan to get into the money management business,'' Mr. Dalton said.

title: 'THE MISSIONARY' PLAYED BY MICHAEL PALIN
description: IN 1906, with Edward VII on the throne and the British Empire at the peak of its self-assurance, the Bishop of London recalls one of his most successful young missionaries from Africa to solve a pressing local problem.

title: RAMADA ALSO GAINS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation reported yesterday that strong gains by its aerospace group lifted net income in the third quarter 39.9 percent as sales advanced 29.2 percent.

title: SLOW DAY FOR TREASURY ISSUES
description: A modest rally late yesterday in the prices of Treasury securities ended a day of slow and directionless trading in which the money markets again waited in vain for the Federal Reserve to reduce two key interest rates.

title: U.S., Allies Discuss Trade
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy said today that the United States and key allies were moving closer to an East-West trade policy that would allow the Reagan Administration to drop its sanctions against companies taking part in the construction of the Siberian gas pipeline.

title: SUSPECT CHARGED IN SLAYING OF OFF-DUTY YONKERS OFFICER
description: A Bronx man was charged early this morning with the September slaying of an off-duty Yonkers policeman who was fatally shot while working as a night clerk at the Deegan Motel in the Bronx.

title: A CHINESE BANQUET HONORS THE MAYOR
description: Had Mayor Koch been running for political office, he would have swept the Chinese vote Wednesday night. At a banquet prepared in his honor in the Shun Lee West kitchen by chefs from eight Chinese restaurants, Mr. Koch sliced the skin from the Peking duck with a cleaver so deftly that the chefs oohed, aahed and applauded.

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $13,000 for the qr and $45,000 for the 9 mos

title: The Reagan Threat, the Soviet Shield
description: There are guns galore in Moscow these days, rolling noisily through the streets in rehearsal for Sunday's celebration of Soviet Communism's 65th anniversary. But there is no butter, or sausage, except at the end of excruciating lines. The choice between guns and butter that Ronald Reagan would like to force upon Leonid Brezhnev and his successors was made long ago, and firmly.

title: Scores Missing From Boat
description: Thirty passengers were rescued from a boat accident near the Indonesia province of Irian Jaya, but scores were missing, the Antara press agency said today.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Investment income represents net investment income

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mal Graham, who played basketball with New York University and then was with the Boston Celtics from 1967 to 1969, has been nominated by Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts as a justice of the Roxbury District Court. Graham, 37, was a 1974 graduate of the Boston College Law School. ... Ken Anderson, the former quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengams who led the National Football League in passing percentage with 62.6 in 1981, has failed to pass the Ohio bar examination.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEADEYE DICK. By Kurt Vonnegut. 240 pages. Delacorte-Seymour Lawrence. $14.95.

title: 150 ARRAIGNED WITHOUT LAWYERS IN QUEENS COURT
description: About 150 criminal defendants who said they could not afford lawyers were arraigned without attorneys in Queens Criminal Court yesterday and Wednesday as a result of the strike by members of the Legal Aid Society, the court's administrative judge said.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTHOR DELAYS EVIDENCE OF JOHNSON CHARGE
description: Robert A. Caro has dropped from the first volume of his projected three-volume biography of Lyndon B. Johnson the charge that Johnson, as a Senator and as Vice President, accepted envelopes stuffed with cash for Congressional campaigns.

title: HALSTON FOR THE SPRING: GLISTENING WRAPAROUNDS
description: Evening clothes fared well as the two weeks of spring fashion openings drew to a close. Though there has been no dearth of flash and glitter, Halston introduced a new twist: dresses that wrapped around the body and, even more significantly, were softly constructed, not stiff.

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LUNDY ELECTRONICS & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIEBERT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Direct Line to a Cop

title: THE END OF THE AFFAIR
description: There is no Reagan Revolution. American voters made that clear on Nov. 2, by substantially strengthening the Democrats' control of the House of Representatives and of state governments, and narrowing Republican control of the Senate.

title: NATIONAL SEA PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUCTIONS
description: CONTEMPORARY art, which the auction galleries define as works produced since World War II, will be up for bidding in sales next week at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, and at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. The sale of the week is expected to be at Christie's next Wednesday night at 7, when the collection of 47 paintings and sculptures of Dr. Joseph Gosman, a retired orthopedist from Toledo, and his wife, Mildred, is auctioned.

title: LOUISE BOURGEOIS, A LIFE IN SCULPTURE, AT MODERN MUSEUM
description: THERE is nothing like a full-scale exhibition to convey the power and scope of a major artist's work, especially when that work has been seen mostly in bits and pieces over the years. That's the case with the sculptor Louise Bourgeois, who only since the late 70's has been gaining the recognition she has long deserved. Now - at the ripe age of 71 - she is having her first real retrospective, at the Museum of Modern Art (through Feb. 8).

title: U.S. ASSAILS ISRAEL FOR STICKING TO SETTLEMENT PLANS
description: The United States assailed Israel today for repeating that it would continue to establish Jewish settlements in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip despite President Reagan's call for a freeze on such settlements.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table listing the new Congress yesterday incorrectly showed the win- ners of three races. In the Eighth Dis- trict of Indiana, the winner was Fran- cis X. McCloskey; in the Sixth District of Michigan, Bob Carr; in the First District of Minnesota, Timothy J. Penny. All are Democrats.

title: MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
PORTA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After charges of $591,000 resulting from reclamation of line testing equipment shipped to Mexico National Telephone Co

title: South African Voters Buoy Ruling Party
description: A handful of by-election results indicated today that the governing National Party may have halted the erosion of its support among white voters who have been unsettled by Prime Minister P.W. Botha's moves to give some nonwhite population groups a subordinate role in the central government.

title: G.E.-Telecom Deal
description: The General Electric Company and Northern Telecom Inc. said they planned to jointly develop, manufacture and market complete cellular mobile telephone systems for the North American market.

title: UNSTOPPABLE PENSION
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY'S ELECTROSHOCK VOTE AFFECTING TREATMENT
description: Psychiatrists in Berkeley, Calif., were making arrangements yesterday for four patients undergoing electroshock therapy to get the treatment in hospitals in other California cities, according to a spokesman for the hospital where they have been treated. The plans were required by an unusual referendum passed by Berkeley voters Tuesday banning the use of electroshock therapy in Berkeley.

title: BERGEN DEMOCRAT ACQUITTED OF BRIBERY
description: A Superior Court jury tonight found the former Bergen County Democratic chairman, Vincent P. Rigolosi, not guilty of bribery, conspiracy and other charges in what the prosecution said was a plot to bribe a state trooper.

title: GETTING READY FOR WINTER AT APARTMENT COMPLEXES
description: For some people this week's spell of Indian summer may have conjured up pleasant thoughts of spring, but it did nothing to deter Robert M. Freedman from concentrating on the winter that is ahead.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for on a pooling of interests basis

title: Add SALT to the Freeze
description: The 3-to-2 vote across the country for a nuclear freeze, plus the election of 11 new Representatives who support it, sends a warning to the White House. The Administration's belligerent talk of nuclear war and its reluctant approach to arms control have stirred wide concern. The freeze won in eight of nine states and all but two of about thirty localities.

title: SALVADORAN CALLS U.S. ENVOY'S CHARGE UNFAIR
description: Salvador's Defense Minister said today that he agreed with American criticism of the nation's legal system, but said it was ''unfair'' of the American Ambassador to maintain that as many as 30,000 Salvadorans had been murdered in the last three years.

title: HELLER, WALTER E, INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WIFE SAYS DE LOREAN HAS BIDS FOR FILM DEAL
description: John Z. De Lorean, the maverick entrepreneur who has been charged with trafficking in cocaine, has been offered millions of dollars for film rights to his life story, his wife, Cristina, said in New York yesterday. The bids, mostly from movie companies, she said, have been turned over to the couple's lawyers for study.

title: STECHER-TRAUNG-SCHMIDT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net gain

title: Judge Objects To a Tax on Oil
description: The Federal windfall profits tax on oil companies was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal judge, who cited the exemption of oil produced in Alaska from the 1980 tax.

title: A Vote for Cleveland
description: Ted Stepien, the owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, is undaunted by the his team's poor record and poor attendance. The Cavaliers, who set a league record for consecutive losses with 22 earlier this week, drew only 2,978 fans to their last home game, and there have been reports that the team is headed for Toronto.

title: Braniff to Collect Disputed Fares
description: Braniff International will be allowed to collect as much as $7 million that travel agents owe the airline, United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers ruled.

title: Marketing and Media Sold to Two Executives
description: Norman R. Glenn yesterday sold Marketing and Media Decisions, the trade magazine he founded in 1966, to Robert C. Gardner, 55 years old, and David W. Bentley, 44, his president and publisher, respectively, for $7 million.

title: 'BURNING,' FROM HORROR GENRE
description: NASTY little campers are huddled together, planning a prank. They want to get even with Old Cropsy, the camp's drunken caretaker, and so they scare him with a maggotty skull. But the skull catches fire, and Cropsy does too. He is so badly burned that, five years later, he terrorizes a new generation of campers. He dismembers some, punctures others, slices a few with the shears that are his trademark. So much for the plot of ''The Burning,'' which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters.

title: A Cross for St. Peter's
description: St. Peter's Lutheran Church views its mission as an urban ministry, and its appearance bespeaks its role. The futuristic building of brown Caledonia granite, pierced with large, clear windows, is part of the vast Citicorp Center at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.

title: ART: MARK TANSEY IN FIRST SOLO SHOW
description: THERE'S a detective story that hinges on the inadequacy of words as a means of identification. The wrong man was caught not because he resembled the killer (which he didn't), but because he fitted the killer's written description.

title: DESIGNED RESIDENTIAL PROJECTS
description: Irwin Clavan, an architect in New York City for more than four decades before his retirement in 1973, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TOPICAL SUSPENSE
description: ALAN RUDOLPH'S ''Endangered Species,'' which opens today at the Festival Theater, is a topical suspense melodrama that sounds as if it had been fearlessly torn from the headlines of your favorite supermarket tabloid.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMF Inc. said that as part of a restructuring program it would sell its Wheel Goods division, which makes bicycles and children's riding toys, to a company formed by the division's management, for an amount that it did not disclose.

title: G.P.U.'s Earnings Grow
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, parent of the three companies that own the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, today reported third-quarter earnings of $15 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $14.1 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $600 million, from $538.7 million.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,707,000 for the qr and $3,981,000 for the 9 mos

title: WARSAW PRELATE IS BACK FROM ROME
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, returned today after meeting with Pope John Paul II in Rome and promptly called for new talks between the church and the Government.

title: Goldwater Has Heart Surgery; His Full Recovery Is Expected
description: Senator Barry Goldwater underwent a successful triple-bypass heart operation today, and his condition ''couldn't be better,'' his doctor said.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIGHT NEW TALENTS LIGHT UP THE SKY OFF BROADWAY
description: A PLENITUDE of fresh new performing talent is brightening Off Broadway, but in most cases the talent is new only to New York. Many of these actors and actresses, young and old, are seasoned professionals who have appeared on a variety of stages, especially in America's regional theaters. Not only has regional theater become a primary source of new plays, but it is also serving the valuable function of grooming actors and sending them - along with those new plays - to the New York theater.

title: Hormats Gets Post At Goldman, Sachs
description: Robert D. Hormats, who resigned in August as Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, has joined Goldman, Sachs & Company to head a new international financial services group.

title: NEW HOSPITAL OPENS DOORS, 6 YEARS LATE
description: Six years late and nearly four times its original projected cost, Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center opened yesterday as a municipal hospital in northern Brooklyn and admitted its first patients.

title: U.N., BACKING ARGENTINA, CALLS FOR FALKLAND TALKS
description: By an overwhelming vote that was a diplomatic victory for Argentina, the General Assembly adopted a resolution today urging the British and the Argentines to negotiate their quarrel over ownership of the Falkland Islands.

title: HECTIC SCENE IN TRADING ROOM
description: ''We missed a call. You guys stink!'' Prudential Bache Securities had just lost a trade to another brokerage firm, and William Schlicher, senior vice president of institutional stock trading, hurled his insult across the floor to the block traders, who ignored it for the 10th time yesterday.

title: A Farewell to Golf
description: Barney Thompson, who has been on the Professional Golfers' Association tour for nine years, has decided it is time to quit. ''It just got to the point where, when you do something for so long and aren't successful at it, you get tired of it,'' he said from his home in New Smyrna Beach, Fla.

title: Champion Accord
description: Under an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission, Champion Home Builders is to pay $500 to $1,500 apiece to customers who bought solar furnaces that failed to live up to performance claims.

title: LILCO OFFERS PLAN TO RAISE RATES 50% OVER 3 YEARS
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has proposed a plan under which its customers' electric bills would rise by 50 percent over the next three years to help pay for the utility's $3 billion nuclear power plant near completion at Shoreham.

title: SIERRA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOW THAT THE ELECTION IS OVER, IT'S BACK TO REALITY
description: By the wistful rhetoric of his own political campaigning, President Reagan is now left to sigh again back here in the heart of ''unreality,'' the capital of ''disenchantment,'' as he described this city in salutations to the crowds he visited out there on his Congressional campaign trips.

title: Mortgage Rate Falls
description: The average interest rate charged for new mortgages dropped in October to 15.73 percent, the lowest since May 1981, the Government said today.

title: Kuenn Cited
description: Harvey Kuenn of the Milwaukee Brewers was named the American League manager of the year by United Press International, receiving 20 votes from a panel of 53 baseball correspondents, six more than Earl Weaver of Baltimore.

title: HARRODS SPINOFF FROM HOUSE OF FRASER EXPECTED
description: Lonhro Ltd., the mining conglomerate that controls 30 percent of the House of Fraser, the retailing giant, is expected to announce on Friday shareholder approval of its motion to spin off the renowned Harrods of Knightsbridge from Fraser, spokesmen for both companies said today.

title: Before the curtain at Lincoln Center.
description: SERVICEABLE is the word that comes to mind when evaluating Centre Court, the new steakhouse just across from the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. It is, in fact, only the highly visible location and the large and trendy young crowd it has managed to attract since it opened three months ago that make Centre Court worth reviewing.

title: Bridge: 3 Teams End a Year's Play For the Von Zedtwitz Title
description: Very few recreational events take a year to complete. One of them is the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which will conclude in New York next Wednesday and Friday in a three-team final at the Cavendish Club to decide the 1982 title, just as the 1983 event is getting under way.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLEVELAND ELECTRIC ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Broadway may get 2 Neil Simon plays in the spring.
description: NEIL SIMON, who seems to be writing for the theater at lightning speed these days, could have two plays opening on Broadway this season. The first, which has been announced, is ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' which will open the last week in March. A month earlier, on Feb. 23, the other play, ''Actors and Actresses,'' will begin a tryout at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn. If all goes well there, ''Actors and Actresses'' will move to New York in April.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreigncurrency translations

title: Witness Tells of Threats On Judge Before Killing
description: A convicted narcotics dealer, Jamiel Chagra, talked of ''putting a price on the head'' of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. several months before Judge Wood was killed, Mr. Chagra's younger brother testified today.

title: UNESCO'S SELECTION OF FAVORITE ATHLETES
description: To the Editor:

title: Timing of Honduran Exercise Is Affected by Reagan's Trip
description: Plans for joint United States-Honduran military maneuvers are continuing but their timing has still not been decided, Administration officials said today.

title: Ginsberg Getting Name On Door at Avrett, Free
description: Those of you who think that executive vice president is about as far as a body can go while retaining the ''vice'' in one's title, come meet Frank Ginsberg of Avrett, Free & Fischer.

title: CAMPAIGN FUNDS CALLED A KEY TO OUTCOME OF HOUSE RACES
description: Despite the defeats of some big spenders, campaign money counted heavily in the overall results of House elections, a New York Times computer analysis of election returns and campaign spending reports shows.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $3.4 million for the latest first qr and $932,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: IRAN MARKS A 3d ANNIVERSARY IN FLOWERS, CHEERS AND SCORN
description: Three years ago today, Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr., an American diplomat, stood at his window in the United States Embassy and saw beneath him what he later called ''this sea of fanatical faces.'' And he heard the voices - ''lowing for death,'' as he said - of the students who had come to take him and his colleagues captive.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STEER THE COURSE
description: The White House would have us believe that nothing happened in this election. In fact, voters across the country gave a number of clear answers to the question implied on their ballots - whether they shared Ronald Reagan's determination to ''stay the course.''

title: CANADA ORDERS EXTRADITION OF ACCUSED NAZI
description: A former Gestapo officer accused of murdering 11,584 Lithuanian Jews, was ordered extradited today to West Germany to stand trial.

title: DE LOREAN MOTOR NAMES CREDITORS
description: John Z. De Lorean's automobile company owed money to dinner and athletic clubs in New York, a Mercedes-Benz dealership in Beverly Hills, a popular bar in London, a delicatessen in Manhattan and the National Football League, according to court papers on file here.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net losses after an extraordinary loss of $76 million for the qr and 9 mos

title: SANDINISTA ATROCITIES ULTIMATELY AIMED AT THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Tigers Re-Sign Cabell
description: The Detroit Tigers retrieved Chet Lemon and Enos Cabell from the free-agent market yesterday only hours after the players had filed for the draft.

title: Devils Tie, End 7-Game Slide
description: The New Jersey Devils, who led by 3-0 with the game half over, settled for a 4-4 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight. But there was little gloom among the Devils for having dissipated an apparent victory, for too many good things happened to them.

title: A ROOKIE LEARNS THE HARD WAY
description: The Knicks have Scott Hastings tagged for future delivery. Dave DeBusschere, who heads the club's basketball operations, recently said: ''Scott is going to be a good player. All we want him to do this season is learn the N.B.A.''

title: HEROIN BY PRESCRIPTION: PROVEN SOLUTION TO AN AMERICAN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: SWEEP BY POLICE IN CITY SUBWAYS NETS 120 ARRESTS
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that 481 persons were arrested or given summonses overnight in its latest drive against subway crime - an unannounced, 10-hour sweep by 350 transit officers on trains and station platforms in Queens.

title: IS WALL STREET TOO BULLISH?
description: The stock market's three-month surge may have given hope to investors for a long-awaited business recovery, but private economists are somewhat more skeptical than Wall Street about the economy's prospects for 1983.

title: BEVERLY C. OHLANDT
description: Beverly C. Ohlandt, retired vice chairman of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital. Mr. Ohlandt, a resident of Manhattan, was 84 years old.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $387,000...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $391,000; the 1981 figures for the qr and 9 mos were restated to reflect a loss from discontinued operations resulting from the company's withdrawal from an uranium mine venture in Mar 1982

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
From China's Borders; To New York Shores
description: A hundred flowers bloomed at ''Music and Dance of the Silk Route'' performances this week at the Asia Society. There were New York Chinese-Americans who confessed near-ignorance of Chinese arts.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Envoy in Syria for Talks
description: Morris Draper, the American envoy who is negotiating the pullout of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon, met today with Syria's Foreign Minister, Abdul Halim Khaddam.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $52,000 for the qr and $394,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JORDAN AND THE SEARCH FOR PEACE: HUSSEIN IS EAGER BUT HEMMED IN
description: King Hussein of Jordan, facing new uncertainty after the war in Lebanon, feels that Arab governments, Palestinians, Americans and Israelis must all make bold new moves before there can be a settlement in the Middle East.

title: 'SPLIT IMAGE,' YOUNG RECRUIT IN CULT
description: A TEEN-AGE athlete is exercising, alone in a gymnasium, working so hard that his hands are cut and bleeding. He applies some rosin and then works even harder. Afterwards, at a public competition, he revels in the fierce, close attention of his uniformed teammates, in the discipline that goes with the sport, in the chanting that's meant to bring on victory.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Rev figures represent closed contracts

title: Pesticide Brings Transfer
description: Ten families at the Naval Air Station here will be moved to civilian quarters until a pesticide is cleared from their homes, officials say. Chlordane, a pesticide widely used to combat termites, apparently leaked into the ventilation systems of the 10 homes and all 40 residents will be moved at Navy expense, according to Lieut. Cmdr. Glenn Cutler of the base public works office.

title: U.S. Insurance Of Thrift Units
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it was considering charging federally insured thrift institutions variable-rate, risk-related insurance premiums.

title: MURDOCH BID FOR PAPER REPORTED
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian who has built a press empire in his country, in Britain and in the United States, is negotiating to buy The Boston Herald American from the Hearst Corporation, according to industry sources here and in New York.

title: HAMILTON INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $93,000 for the qr and $153,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $96,000 for the qr and $2,237,088for the 9 mos

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After securities gains of $45,366 for the qr and $108,038 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $19,000 for the qr and $46,000 for the 9 mos

title: CLARINET: JEAN KOPPERUD
description: After each composition that Jean Kopperud played in her clarinet recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night, there was an afterbreath -a pause in which applause seemed an intrusion. Each performance was woven tightly, each phrase played just so - clearly defined, yet supple and warm.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A lone revolving klieg light lit up the skies in front of 19 East 7 1st Street the other night as guests streamed into the Monique K nowlton gallery to get a glimpse of what are said to be the last p hotographs ever taken of Marilyn Monroe.

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Both N.F.L. Negotiators Agree Wide Gap Exists
description: Jack Donlan and Ed Garvey, the chief negotiators, gave pessimistic assessments yesterday of the status of the 45-day-old National Football League strike.

title: Search for Man Clarified In the Tylenol Case
description: Despite assertions that a man sought for questioning held a grudge against two stores where cyanide-filed Tylenol capsules were purchased, ''there's still nothing to indicate'' he was involved in the killings, a law-enforcement source said today.

title: Chrysler's Talks in Canada Stalled
description: The union representing Chrysler's 10,000 Canadian workers said today that a strike would begin Friday if last-minute negotiations failed to win a pay increase that Chrysler says it can not afford.

title: ANOTHER DALEY SEEKS TO RUN CHICAGO
description: Richard M. Daley, whose father ruled Chicago for nearly a quarter of a century, made it official today. At an old-fashioned political pep rally in a downtown hotel ballroom packed with campaign signs, smiling relatives and cheering supporters wearing funny hats, the oldest son of Richard J. Daley formally announced that he would seek to follow his father's footsteps and become mayor of the country's second largest city.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Income for 1981 has been restated fore the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 regardingforeign currency translation

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DON'T SPECULATE. INVEST
description: It is no secret that America is not investing enough in its own future. The drop in long-term capital growth has come at a time when speculation attracts record numbers of risk-takers and money markets beckon the less venturesome. Speculation in real estate, precious metals and commodities has replaced baseball as the national pastime, and money markets are replacing traditional savings institutions. Government, which helped to create the problem, can help to solve it.

title: No Headline
description: MONTREAL DEFEATS STARS, 8-3

title: VIOLIN RECITAL: ACCARDO
description: THE idea for last night's recital at Carnegie Hall must have sounded inspired when it was first suggested: why not have all 24 of Paganini's Caprices for solo violin played on one program by Salvatore Accardo, a renowned specialist in his music, in honor of the 200th anniversary of the composer's birth? Furthermore, just for this occasion, have Paganini's own violin, the 1742 Guarnerius del Gesu, transported here from his native city of Genoa for Mr. Accardo's use. A surefire package deal. What could go wrong?

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 results reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52 on foreign currency translations

title: Advertising; Focusing on Consumers
description: LAST summer, when it was in competition for the Olympus Camera Company account, the Marschalk Company's creative people looked long and hard at the market for 35-millimeter, single-lens reflex cameras and decided that since the advertising of the competitors in the field all seemed to be focused on the hardware, the agency should find a different approach.

title: Not-So-Secret War in Honduras
description: ''Bay of Pigs II?'' was the cover headline on a June 1981 New Republic article on war games in Honduras by forces that seek to destabilize Nicaragua. Now a Newsweek cover story explores ''America's Secret War,'' asserting that an American-managed covert operation in Honduras is nearly out of control.

title: BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Optioned Larry Whisenton and Bob Porter, outfielders, to its American Association affiliate at Richmond. Promoted Rich Behenna and Brian Fisher, pitchers, and Miguel Sosa, shortstop, to the major league roster. CHICAGO (NL) - Announced that Ferguson Jenkins, pitcher, agreed in principle on a two-year contract. Traded Mike King, pitcher for Midland of the Texas League, to Omaha, the Kansas City Royals' affiliate in the American Association, for Jim Wright, pitcher. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Mike Ferraro to a two-year contract as manager, replacing Dave Garcia, whose contract was not renewed. Named Birdie Tebbetts special asssignment scout. DETROIT (AL) - Signed Chet Lemon, outfielder, and Enos Cabell, infielder, to one-year contracts, and Larry Herndon and Chet Lemon, outfielders, to multiyear contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Announced that George (Doc) Medich, pitcher, decided to become a full-time physician and declined free agency. OAKLAND (AL) - Released Mickey Klutts, infielder, unconditionally and called up Mark Ferguson, Mike Warren, and Bill Kueger, pitchers, and Rusty McNealy, outfielder, from the minors. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Released Willie Montanez, first baseman, and Stan Bahnsen, pitcher. Announced that Bill Robinson, outfielder, was filing for the free-agent draft. Called up Marty Decker and Kelly Downs, pitchers, and Gerry Willard, catcher, from Oklahoma City of the American Association. Recalled Tony Ghelfi and Bill Johnson, pitchers; Juan Samuel, second baseman; Jeff Stone, outfielder, and Darren Daulton, catcher, from Peninsula of the Carolina League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Jason Thompson, first baseman, to a fiveyear contract. Purchased the contracts of Rich Ranteria and Ron Wotus, infielders, and Pete Rice, pitcher, from Portland of the Pacific Coast League.

title: A QUIET PURSUIT OF THE WORLD CUP
description: In the grand American sport of baseball, when players are traded between two clubs, the deal is usually described as ''a trade that will help both teams.''

title: FILM: THE DOLBY 'FANTASIA'
description: WALT DISNEY'S ''Fantasia'' is one of the landmarks of American animation, as well as a key document in the popularization of classical music. Its imaginative abstractions and kitschy, loving anthropomorphizations of nature have endeared it to audiences since its release in 1940.

title: PETROTECH NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV, MONEY AND VOTES
description: Between the flashing lights and views of grins and groans, the TV talk election night focused on money. The cost of all the campaigns around the country totaled $1 billion, according to one commentator. Another said 300 percent more had been spent this year, though with typical TV zip he didn't quite make clear more than when or on what.

title: BRIEFING
description: Coming Up, 1984

title: STOCKS FALL IN BUSIEST DAY EVER
description: The stock market, buoyed by Wednesday's record advance in the Dow Jones industrial average, continued its trading spree yesterday, with volume surging to a record 149.4 million shares.

title: DE ROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $40,000 for the qr and $350,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $110,000 for the qr and $150,000 for the 9 mos

title: Great Adventure Hires Della Femina Agency
description: The frolicsome folk at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners have won the advertising account of Six Flags Great Adventure Amusement and Safari Park, Jackson, N.J., with its $3.5 million in billings.

title: MARK MORRIS, A CHOREOGRAPHER WHO MAKES THINGS HAPPEN
description: ''It was like getting drunk and dancing to Bulgarian music all night,'' Mark Morris said the other day. ''My favorite thing.'' He was talking, strangely enough, of the work of one of the most formal of postmodernist choreographers, with whom he danced for a time. But Mr. Morris is full of surprises.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money Fund Assets Up $1.3 Billion in Week
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $231.23 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 16
description: The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Boston and Pacific stock exchanges

title: TAPES OF SUNKEN VESSEL SHOW UNFASTENED HOSE
description: A videotape showing a disconnected hose in the engine room of a fishing vessel lying on the ocean floor in 78 feet of water was turned over yesterday to a panel investigating the sinking of the vessel. The boat, the Joan La Rie III, capsized in stormy seas off Point Pleasant, N.J., on Oct. 24 with the loss of eight lives.

title: Name's the Same
description: When Deukoo Kim of South Korea takes on Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini on Nov. 13 in their lightweight title fight, he will have a cornerful of Kims helping him.

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net losses reflect a charge of about $17 million net of taxes relating to theclosing of the company's textile manufacturing operations in Spartanburg, S.C.

title: PLAN CALLS FOR EX-JUDGES TO AID COURTS
description: A plan to relieve court congestion by using at least 200 retired judges to work indefinitely as hearing officers in civil and criminal cases was announced yesterday in Manhattan by members of the bench and the bar.

title: SHORTCUT TO A LOWER UNEMPLOYMENT RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $7,636,000...C-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $24,313,000

title: New N.A.M. Chairman
description: The National Association of Manufacturers held a two-day meeting on international economic policy in New York this week, and it used the session as an opportunity to introduce its new chairman, Bernard J. O'Keefe.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Smoke Bomb Disrupts Showing of Soviet Film
description: A smoke bomb in the Carnegie Hall Cinema disrupted the showing of a Soviet film last night forcing 100 viewers from their seats and into the lobby of the movie house. A second smoke bomb -which did not ignite - was also rolled down an aisle at the same time, at 9:05 P.M., by one of two men in the rear of theater, according to Shawn Cunningham, the theater's general manager.

title: Cameroon Leader Announces Resignation After 22 Years
description: President Ahmadou Ahidjo, President of Cameroon since it became independent in 1960, said today that he was resigning.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ferraro Is Named Manager of Indians
description: Mike Ferraro, a former coach and minor league manager for the New York Yankees, was named manager of the Cleveland Indians today.

title: Wilkison Rallies to Win
description: Tim Wilkison remained the only seeded player among the men in the Hong Kong Tennis Classic when he came back from a first-set loss and beat Tim Gullikson today.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY AIR IN L.I. SCHOOL CLOSED BY FUMES
description: Scientists from a specially assembled Federal team sampled the air today inside a Long Island high school that was closed Wednesday after the effects of a mysterious odor sent dozens of students and teachers to the hospital.

title: Even Not in Transit,; Commuters Endure Delays
description: ''There are activities which have priority and have to be done in a limited time frame,'' read the official explanation for why - yet again -impatient M.T.A. commuters had been kept waiting in the lurch.

title: **** RESTAURANTS
description: NEW YORK has only four restaurants that maintain the extraordinary consistency that a four-star rating indicates. But the good news is that these restaurants have added three dozen or so exciting dishes to their menus since they were reported on between 1977 and 1980. With the year's most festive season just ahead, this seems a good time to catch up with those new dishes, a delectable bit of research if ever there was one. Most of the dishes sampled were spectacular. Just a few were disappointing and then only by comparison.

title: 33 FILMS BY GOLDWYN, RETROSPECTIVE OF AN ERA
description: He helped create the motion-picture industry and quickly became one of its virtuoso practitioners. He produced close to 80 films, an extraordinary number of which endure as classics. And at his death in 1974 at the age of 91, Samuel Goldwyn was a legend, renowned not only for his formidable body of work but also for the eccentricities that made him one of Hollywoods's most colorful characters.

title: London Brokers Merge
description: Two discount brokers, Jessel, Toynbee & Company and the Gillett Brothers Discount Company, have agreed to merge by exchanging three Jessel ordinary shares for each Gillett ordinary share, a joint statement said today. The resources of the company, to be named Jessel, Toynbee & Gillett P.L.C., will be about 17.5 million.

title: Thunder Puddles Draws Rail
description: Thunder Puddles, an American horse to be ridden by Angel Cordero, drew the rail position today for the 31st running of the $250,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course Saturday.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $841,000 from the early retirement of debt

title: U.S. SETS UP RULES ON DRUG PACKAGES TO BAR TAMPERING
description: Tamper-resistant packaging will be required within 15 months on almost all nonprescription drugs on store shelves in the United States.

title: U.S. Women Lead in Cup, 2-0
description: The United States women's tennis team won both of the opening singles matches today in its attempt to win a 44th Wightman Cup victory over Britain.

title: On the road for 'Five Days One Summer.'
description: ''FIVE DAYS ONE SUMMER'' opens Sunday at Cinema 1, and two of its three leads are working the publicity circuit. Its star, Sean Connery, is too rich and famous to have to, which isn't the case with Lambert Wilson and Betsy Brantley.

title: Compaq Computer
description: A portable computer that can run on programs written for the International Business Machines Corporation's personal computer and can accept its peripheral equipment was introduced by the Compaq Computer Corporation, a Houston company founded by three former senior managers of Texas Instruments Inc. The company said its new machine has the same capabilities as I.B.M.'s popular desk-top computer but, at 28 pounds, is portable, and costs about $600 less. It will be available early next year at a suggested list price of $2,995, Compaq said.

title: POP JAZZ
description: WOMEN have been singing and playing jazz since jazz began, and for an equally long time they have been subjected to misunderstanding, condescension and sometimes outright hostility from male jazz fans and even male musicians. In 1938, for example, a leading jazz publication published an article called ''Why Women Musicians Are Inferior,'' which stated, ''The woman musician never was born who was capable of sending anyone further than the nearest exit.'' Three years later, the same magazine asserted: ''Good jazz is a hard, masculine music with a whip to it. Women like violins, and jazz deals with drums and trumpets.''

title: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a $43.2 million investment loss and a loss of $2.2 million from discontinued operatoins...C-Net income includes a $229,000 capital gain and a $2.2 million loss on discontinued operations...D-Includes a capital loss of $42.7 million and a loss on discontinued operations of $6.9 million...E-Includes an investment loss of $139,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $3.5 million; the 1981 earnings are restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: MARINES, AFTER DELAY, GO ON PATROLS IN EAST BEIRUT
description: The United States Marine Corps extended its presence to Christian-dominated East Beirut today, sending 11 men in four jeeps to patrol a lightly populated section for three hours.

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $62,000...C-Including a tax credit of $57,000...D-Including a tax credit of $192,000 and a gain of $577,000 from a subsidiary disposed of in Apr

CHICAGO SCHOOL, NO

description: Dutch quilders have been translated into U.S. dollars at the rate of 2.75 equals $1.00

title: PANEL CLEARS 2 ACCUSED OF SCIENTIFIC FRAUD IN ALCOHOLISM STUDY
description: Two alcoholism researchers who had been accused of perpetrating a scientific fraud were exonerated by a prestigious review committee in a report released here today.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on pages A12-15, A28, B10 and D18. Gas Pipeline Explosion Leaves 5 Dead in Iowa

title: Body Language
description: The success of the movie ''Rocky III'' has enhanced the notoriety of Mr.T, the bodyguard/actor/singer/ wrestler, who played the part of Clubber Lang, Rocky Balboa's menacing challenger. Mr.T has been touring the television talk-show circuit recently discussing his attributes as a bodyguard (he once worked for Leon Spinks), but Bob DiGiulio and other so-called ''boys in the trade'' say it's time for a showdown.

title: POST-ELECTION OPTIMISM IN EUROPE LIFTS DOLLAR
description: The dollar rose against major European currencies again today, buoyed by the American election results and the expectations they have generated.

title: JURY CLEARS A FORMER MAYOR IN MISSISSIPPI KILLING OF FOE
description: A jury today found former Mayor Eddie Carthan of Tchula not guilty of hiring two men to kill a political rival in the predominantly black Mississippi Delta town.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 9 mos to Sept 30
ZONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tribute to O'Neill and Strindberg Is Set
description: Actors from the Royal Dramatic Theater of Sweden will join American performers at the Circle in the Square next Thursday for ''Strindberg and O'Neill: A Shared Legacy.'' The program is a tribute to the Swedish and American playwrights.

title: Rita Bouboulidi Recital To Aid Leukemia Group
description: The pianist Rita Bouboulidi will perform a concert at Carnegie Hall to benefit the New York chapter of the Leukemia Society of America.

title: Qaddafi Vows to Quit U.N.
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, threatened at a dinner here Wednesday night to withdraw his country from the United Nations unless the Security Council is reorganized, the state press agency said today. He did not discuss a reorganization but criticized the United Nations for not solving international problems. He also assailed the United States for what he called unlimited support of Israel.

title: Wheelabrator Disposal Plant
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. said that the City of Baltimore, Baltimore County and a state agency had granted it contracts to design and build a refuse disposal plant that would also generate electricity. Wheelabrator, based in Hampton, N.H., said that the capital costs of the plant would be about $190 million.

title: 3 RIDERS BREAK JUMP RECORD
description: Three international riders set a National Horse Show jump record of 7 feet 6 inches last night and shared the William Coburn Cox Memorial Challenge Trophy for the Puissance Class.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Turbo Offers A Settlement
description: Financially troubled Turbo Resources Ltd. offered to settle its longstanding problems with the Ontario Securities Commission and the minority shareholders of Merland Explorations Ltd.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1982
description: International King Hussein believes that all nations seeking peace in the Middle East must make bold new moves to achieve a settlement. The Jordanian monarch is known to be eager to become an active participant in the American-sponsored peace process if the United States can get Israel to modify its position. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) A top Spanish general was murdered by two gunmen on a Madrid street. The police said they believed that the assassins, who escaped, were Basque separatist extremists. The victim was Gen. Victor Lago Roman, commander of the elite Brunete First Armored Division. (A3:4-6.)

title: Bail Set in Idaho Killing
description: A judge ruled Wednesday that Claude Dallas Jr., an indigent trapper, could be released on $100,000 bond until he was sentenced Dec. 1 for the slaying of two Idaho fish and game officers. Mr. Dallas, 32 years old, was convicted of voluntary manslaughter after a month-long trial. The judge said that friends could post property for the defendant.

title: GULF ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRADE GAP IN QUARTER IS A RECORD
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit surged to $13.1 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 30, the biggest threemonth trade shortfall ever, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRITON ASSAILS THE U.N. RESOLUTION AS 'ARGENTINE-INSPIRED CHARADE'
description: Foreign Secretary Francis Pym lashed out today at supporters of the United Nations resolution calling for negotiations on the future of the Falkland Islands, and rejected the General Assembly decision.

Daimler Shop in China
description: Daimler Benz A.G. said today that it had opened a vehicle workshop and spare parts depot in China.
