description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,811,000 for the qr and $9,924,000 for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $618,000 forthe qr and $414,000 for the 9 mos

title: PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economic Scene; Misery Index: Impact on Vote
description: THE Republican losses in Congressional and gubernatorial elections were clearly linked to rising unemployment. The rise in the jobless rate to 10.1 percent in September outweighed the effects on voters of news about declining inflation. President Reagan, anticipating the release today of the October unemployment figure, has already given notice that the rate is likely to go ''a few fractions'' of a point higher.

title: IMPELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
7 Companies Win Satellite Permits
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a new round of satellite-to-home television applications today, bringing to eight the number of concerns authorized to build such systems.

title: CITY LOSES A BID TO ALTER ACCORD ON THE HOMELESS
description: A judge yesterday rejected New York City's bid to reduce the cost of operating shelters for homeless men by providing fewer toilets and showers and consolidating centers for meals at a few sites.

title: Eurobonds Sell Briskly
description: Bond dealers here said today that $700 million worth of Eurobonds had been offered in the last 24 hours and were generally quick to find buyers. Investors are accepting even aggressive pricing from quality-name borrowers, they added.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $567,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $5,205,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations, a provision of $28 million for pre-opening costs to open Atlantic City casino and a pretax loss of $35,335,000 on marketable secur...C-After a loss of $1,482,000 from disc oper, a loss of $3,382,000 on the disp of disc oper, a provision of $28 mil for costs to open Atlantic City casino and a pretax loss of $35,335,000 on marketable securities

title: Recital by Perahia
description: Murray Perahia will play a piano recital at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard, tomorrow night at 8:30.

title: WOODHULL HOSPITAL, A CONTROVERSIAL GIANT, CAST IN A 60's MOLD; An Appraisal
description: The Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in North Brooklyn is a rust-colored machine of steel and glass that rises out of the urban jumble of Flushing Avenue with immense self-assurance and power.

title: GUNMAN SHOOTS 2 AT MEDICAL CENTER
description: A former employee of Beth Israel Medical Center who had been dismissed from his job three years ago returned to the hospital yesterday carrying a semiautomatic weapon and two handguns, herded some employees into an office and shot two of his former co-workers, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: Cavaliers' Streak Reaches 23 Losses

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Algoma Steel Corp. said it had signed a $100 million (U.S.) credit agreement with a Canadian chartered bank at a floating interest rate based on the London interbank rate and secured by floating-rate debentures due in 1990.

title: John Henry Set For East Race
description: John Henry, the Horse of the Year in 1981, will make his first Eastern appearance in 13 months when he carries high weight of 129 pounds in the $400,000 Meadowlands Cup Nov. 13.

title: Illness of 29 More People Linked to Hamburgers
description: Twenty-nine more cases of an unusual diarrheal illness traced to eating hamburgers were reported today by the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: U.S. DRUG AGENTS ARREST 13 AFTER MAJOR HEROIN INQUIRY
description: Narcotics agents arrested 13 suspects in a series of raids in the New York area Wednesday night and yesterday morning in the culmination of a major 16-month undercover investigation of heroin trafficking by organized crime.

title: NIXON, ON TV, SAYS PRESIDENT WILL STICK TO SAME POLICY LINE
description: President Reagan will neither ''dig his feet in'' nor dramatically change his course as a result of the Democratic gains made in Congress, Richard M. Nixon predicted today.

title: HAUGHEY CABINET FALLS IN IRELAND
description: The Government of Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey fell today after failing to win a vote of confidence in the Irish Parliament. The vote was 82 to 80.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: LONDON AND PARIS UNWILLING TO BEND ON PIPELINE ISSUE
description: France and Britain made clear today that they are unwilling to offer the United States any major concessions to halt American trade sanctions against Western European companies involved in the construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline.

title: STATELY STEPS IN THE BUDGET PROCESS
description: When leaves start fluttering down from the elms and oaks and maples on the north lawn of the White House, it is a sure sign of a new season in Washington: the budget season.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a capital gain of $8,758,000 for the qr and $208,000 for the 9 mos...C-After a capital loss of $212,000...D-Including a capital gain of $200,000 for the 9 mos

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $125,000 for the qr and $208,000 for the 9 mos

title: Shoemaker Milestone
description: Bill Shoemaker, at age 51, topped $90 million in career earnings yesterday when he rode Cold to a second-place finish behind Durable in the $23,000 feature race at Hollywood Park.

title: FOR THE LIBRARY, A PRIDE OF LITERARY LIONS
description: Laughter, applause and convivial conversation echoed through the New York Public Library until almost midnight, but not a censuring ''Shhhh!'' was heard all evening. There are, indeed, those who say that even the marble lions that guard the Fifth Avenue entrance purred approvingly.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1982
description: THE ECONOMY The jobless rate rose to 10.4 percent in October, another post-Depression high. The Labor Department said the rise of 0.3 of a percentage point left 11.5 million people out of work. (Page 1). The jobless rate in New York State rose to 9.4 percent, highest in five years. (10). In the Plains states, unemployment isn't as severe as it is elsewhere. (10).

title: DR. RAYFORD LOGAN, PROFESSOR WHO WROTE BOOKS ON BLACKS
description: Dr. Rayford W. Logan, professor emeritus of history at Howard University and the author of many books about American blacks, died Thursday of a heart ailment at Howard University Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Washington.

title: YOUTH IS WOUNDED IN CONEY I.
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot and critically wounded last night for no apparent reason as he stood with friends on a Coney Island street corner, the police said.

title: Football Players Face New Dispute
description: A hundred of New York's strongest, healthiest and highest-salaried young men - the players for the Jets and Buffalo Bills - may start collecting unemployment insurance next Tuesday. That possibility was described yesterday as ''unconscionable'' by the Erie County Executive, Edward J. Rutkowski, before a State Senate hearing in Manhattan.

title: Your Money; Insurance Loan Rates
description: LOANS against permanent, or whole life, insurance policies have long been a bargain for borrowers who could take advantage of interest rates of 5 to 8 percent. But more and more purchasers of new policies are finding that this kind of a good deal is gone forever.

title: OLGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MILWAUKEE COMBINATION EXCELS AT SHOW
description: Few people think of horses when they think of Milwaukee. Beer, maybe. The Brewers, maybe. Yet there is an effective Milwaukee Connection at the 99th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Symbolism, Cuomo-Style

title: Travelers Income Down
description: The Travelers Corporation reported yesterday that its operating income in the third quarter dropped 18.5 percent, to $72.2 million, or 86 cents a share, from $88.6 million, or $1.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The Hartford insurance company said its net income in the third quarter dropped 27.1 percent, to $64.4 million, or 76 cents a share, from $88.3 million, or $1.04 a share, in the 1981 quarter.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRO-DART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
2 Indicted in Chase Fatal to Policeman
description: Two Bronx men were indicted today on charges stemming from a robbery in New Rochelle and a high-speed chase on the New England Thruway on Sept. 14 in which a New Rochelle police officer was killed and another seriously injured.

title: U.S. REFUSES ORDER FOR DATA ON DRAFT
description: Government prosecutors paved the way today for dismissal of charges against a young draft resister by refusing a Federal judge's order that the counselor to the President testify and that White House documents be made available to the defense.

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BECK-ARNLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the United Nations resolution urging talks on the Falkland Islands incorrectly reported the Dominican Republic's vote. It favored the resolution.

title: SUSPICIONS RISE ON MILITARY'S ROLE
description: Nearly 1,000 unidentified bodies have been discovered in six cemeteries over the last few weeks. The discovery has heightened public suspicions that the military, despite its denials, was responsible for the fate of 6,000 people who disappeared during a leftist insurgency in the 1970's.

title: GREECE AND RUMANIA URGE TALKS TO RID BALKANS OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has announced after a visit to Rumania that the Greek and Rumanian Governments have agreed to call a conference of Balkan leaders to discuss turning the region into a zone free of nuclear weapons within 18 months.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Belgian Atom Plant Leaks
description: About 13,000 gallons of lightly radioactive water spilled inside a Belgian nuclear power plant today and a small amount of lightly radioactive gas escaped into the atmosphere when a compressor pump malfunctioned, the Government said. The Public Health and Environment State Secretary, Firmin Aerts, said the water remained inside the Tihange plant 50 miles east of Brussels and was pumped into a special holding tank.

title: Bus Passengers Set Atlantic City Mark
description: A record total of a million passengers aboard 31,000 buses visited this resort's nine casino hotels during October, officials of the Atlantic County Transportation Authority said today.

title: LUCKY PARISIAN RIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'THE ROSENBERGS,' 2-PART FRENCH DOCUDRAMA ON CABLE
description: Docudrama comes to cable this weekend with a vengeance. The fourand-a-half-hour French film ''The Rosenbergs,'' a hit on French television five years ago, can be seen on TeleFrance USA Cable Network in two parts: the first part tonight and Sunday at 9:30 P.M.; the second part next weekend.

title: KISSINGER GIVES OPTIMISTIC VIEW ON WORLD ISSUES
description: Henry A. Kissinger yesterday summed up a cautiously optimistic global outlook with a paradox he often heard from Chinese leaders: ''There is turmoil under the heavens but the situation is excellent.''

title: PLAINS STATES ESCAPE RAVAGES OF THE SOARING RATE OF JOBLESS
description: Tucked awayed among the picturesque Black Hills, this farming and meat-packing community of 81,000 people is a fairly insular place. It pays little attention to the outside world, and outsiders willingly return the favor.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Selloff Planned at Diamond
description: The Diamond International Corporation has disclosed that Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier, intends to sell off most of the company's assets once he acquires it.

title: HARD-UP LEBANON PUTS THE SQUEEZE ON SMUGGLERS
description: Smuggling, as natural to Lebanon's economy as armed violence has been to its politics, still thrives in this Mediterranean port five miles up the coast from Beirut, as it does at several other ports.

title: Sakharov Is Warned Against Speaking Out
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, has been warned by the Soviet authorities to stop making public statements, his wife, Yelena Bonner, said today.

title: JMB REALTY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $2,410,467 on the disposition of investment properties

title: COMTECH GROUP INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $52,428...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $19,940

title: Sign of Improvement
description: Normand Leveille, the 19-year-old Boston Bruin forward who has remained unconscious at General Hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, since he was felled by a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 23, has now been removed from a life-support system and is breathing on his own. Therese Leveille, his mother, said that the family was ''very encouraged'' and that ''the question now is not will he live, but how he will live.''

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5 ARE ACQUITTED IN BROOKLYN OF PLOT TO RUN GUNS TO I.R.A.
description: Five men charged with conspiring to smuggle weapons to the Irish Republican Army were acquitted in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday, apparently because a jury believed defense contentions that the Central Intelligence Agency had sanctioned their gun-running operation.

title: Fraser to Consider Harrods Spinoff
description: The House of Fraser was ordered today by shareholders to consider spinning off its flagship store, Harrods. In a victory for Lonrho Ltd., the mining conglomerate that owns 30 percent of Fraser, a 90-day investigation of the spinoff was mandated by a poll of the House of Fraser's 30,000 shareholders.

title: 7TH-DAY ADVENTISTS FACE CHANGE AND DISSENT
description: Tom Pangborn, who was once extolled by Seventh-day Adventist ministers as a model for other youths and later became an Adventist pastor, is severing his ties with the church.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JOHN H. PINTO
description: John H. Pinto, vice president of Technicolor Inc., died Wednesday at his home in Bel Air, Calif. He was 62 years old and had lived in New York City for many years.

title: ...AND RISKS IN NEW YORK STATE MINING
description: To the Editor:

title: AN EXPERIENCED BUT CONTROVERSIAL MANAGER
description: The selection of Donald Paul Hodel as the new Energy Secretary has put the department for the first time under the leadership of an energy specialist with long experience. Nonetheless, Mr.

title: Tests Fail to Show L.I. Fumes' Source
description: Tests have yet to find the source of fumes that sickened about 50 administrators, teachers and students at Hauppauge Senior High School, officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Soviet Way Of Dealing With a Leak

title: SIERRA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN A 13-YEAR OLD ASKS FOR AN ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swedish Royal Couple Due at Brooklyn Gala
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf and Queen Silvia of Sweden will be the guests of honor at a gala evening next Wednesday to celebrate the American debut of the Cullberg Ballet Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: OPTIMISM GROWS OVER BALLET TALKS
description: Things seem to be looking up for the first time in the American Ballet Theater's nine-week labor dispute with its dancers. Spokesmen for both the Ballet Theater management and the dancers, who are represented by the American Guild of Musical Artists, showed guarded optimism yesterday, with three consecutive days of solid negotiating behind them and the prospect for continuing talks over the weekend.

title: Memorable Mistakes
description: When a member of the Fontana (Calif.) High School football team makes a mental mistake during a game, his punishment follows swiftly.

title: BUYER EMERGES FOR DE LOREAN
description: An Ohio businessman is attempting a feat that the British Government, several hundred investors and a certain former high-ranking executive of the General Motors Corporation could not manage: to make money on the De Lorean sports car.

title: KNICKS DROP 4th; NETS DEFEAT CAVS
description: Almost everything about David Thompson looks the way it did before last season: His looping jumpers from 20 feet out, his drives to the basket and his constant adjustments of his socks.

title: Provincetown Taking Writers' Applications
description: The Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, Mass., is accepting applications for its 1983-84 winter residency program for young artists and writers.

title: INQUIRY ON SINKING ENDS WITH RESCUE TESTIMONY
description: A marine investigation board yesterday ended its formal inquiry into the sinking of a fishing boat Oct. 24 off Point Pleasant, N.J., after a charter-boat captain testified that he had passed within a mile of the vessel during Coast Guard rescue operations and that no help had been requested.

title: GI EXPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: B-After charges of $15 million for the qr and $9 million for the 9 mos to reflect the writedown in the company's investment in oil and gas properties...C-Net income

title: News Analysis
description: Despite its relatively small vote in last Tuesday's election, the Liberal Party is likely to have a major voice in the Cuomo administration - just as it does in the Carey administration -because it played a critical role in Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's campaign for governor.

title: MORRIS CONVICTED IN DRUG TRIAL
description: Mercury Morris, the former Miami Dolphin star back, was convicted today of trafficking in cocaine. Sentencing was set for Jan. 20.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After charges of $591,000 resulting from reclamation of line testing equipment shipped to Mexico National Telephone Co

title: LUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Fuji Introduces X-Ray System
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company Ltd. introduced a computerized X-ray photograph system that it said requires far less X-ray exposure and produces clearer photos than conventional systems.

title: Cowles Holders Back Liquidation
description: Cowles Communications Inc., a New York company, said its shareholders had approved a plan to liquidate the company and spin off its broadcasting subsidiary, Cowles Broadcasting. Cowles's principal assets are two television stations, in Daytona Beach, Fla., and in Des Moines; in addition, the company also owns about 2.6 million shares of The New York Times Company class A stock, representing about 20 percent of the Times Company stock outstanding.

title: 10 Turkish Dissidents Seize Travel Agency in Amsterdam
description: About 20 policemen stormed the Turkish national travel agency in Amsterdam today, breaking down the door with a sledgehammer and ending a two-hour takeover by 10 opponents of Turkey's military regime.

title: Who's Final Concert To Be on Pay TV
description: The Who's final concert on its North American farewell tour Dec. 17 will be televised on pay-per-view systems by 20th Century-Fox Pay-Television.

title: GTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After net charges of $188,000 for the qr and $136,000 for the 9 mos for doubtful accounts...C-Net income

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Resorts Posts a Profit
description: Resorts International Inc. announced yesterday that it had net income in the third quarter of 1982 of $13.4 million, or $1.35 a share, contrasted to a loss of $10 million in the third quarter a year earlier. Revenues edged up 2.9 percent, to $103 million, from $100.1 million. Included in net income for the latest period were gains from securities transactions of $8.6 million; in the preceding year, Resorts had losses from such transactions amounting to $27.1 million.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including investment gains of $3,860 for the qr and $208,643 for the 9 mos and a loss of $878,314 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net loss after a loss of $231,739 from discontinued operations and an investment gain of $31,285...D-Net income after a loss of $805,668 from discontinued operations and a loss from investments of $28,895; yr-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations

title:
PATENTS;
Untangled Phone Cords
description: Robert J. Nilsen of Colonia, N.J., was granted patent 4,357,500 this week for a flexible, rod-like device to be inserted in the central hollow of spiral telephone cords to prevent their entanglement. Mr. Nilsen is manager of an engineering company and an adjunct instructor at Kean College in Union, N.J., where he teaches economics and corporate finance.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.Y.U.'s Decision
description: From the 1930's to the 1950's, New York University ranked among the nation's college basketball powers. After that, its basketball fortunes slipped, and in 1971, when the financial burden became too great, it dropped the sport.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax loss carryforward of $184,500 for the qr and $453,800 for theyr...C-Including a tax loss carryforward of $25,000 for the qr and for the yr

title: UPSET IN WESTCHESTER CLERK RACE
description: A Westchester County school administrator, Andrew J. Spano, become the first Democrat to win the County Clerk's job in Westchester since the turn of the century, according to the unofficial ballot count completed today. His victory came after a campaign made controversial by apparent confusion over a name.

title: N.C.A.A. Assailed On Its TV Policy
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's controls on the televising of football games have created a football elite rather than prevented one, legal counsel for two perennial college powers contended today.

title: Absentee Vote Gives Chafee a Second Term
description: Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, was assured of re-election to a second term today as the counting of absentee ballots continued. .

title: Cruel Joke on Poverty Law
description: Having failed to destroy the Legal Services Corporation, President Reagan now seeks to bury it in ridicule. Congress created the corporation in hopes that a federally funded agency could give legal help to poor people without political interference. The President, an old foe of poverty lawyers, has tried to stack the corporation's board with other enemies of the program. But the law mandates that some directors represent ''eligible clients'' - poor people -not just lawyers.

title: Chrysler May Add To Foreign Parts
description: The Chrysler Corporation is considering a more than 300 percent increase in the quantity of foreign parts in Chrysler cars by 1990, a company official said.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes realized investment gains of $333,000 in 1982 and $229,000 in 1981

title: STAMFORD TO LOSE CONOCO
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it would close the Stamford, Conn. corporate headquarters of its recently acquired Conoco subsidiary and move the 180-member staff to Du Pont's home in Wilmington, Del.

title: JACQUES TATI, ACTOR AND DIRECTOR WHO CREATED MR. HULOT, IS DEAD
description: Jacques Tati, the French actor, writer and director who created the memorable bungler Hulot in ''Mr. Hulot's Holiday,'' and whose ''Mon Oncle'' won the 1958 Oscar for foreign picture, died of a pulmonary embolism yesterday in Paris. He was 75 years old.

title: Dogs Up Close
description: Of the 900 all-breed dog shows in the United States this year, only nine are held under a format known as ''benched.'' One of these, and the only one in New Jersey, will be the Union County Kennel Club's show tomorrow at the Dunn Sports Center, 600 Pearl Street, Elizabeth.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allbritton Communications Co. signed a letter of understanding to acquire television stations KATV of Little Rock, Ark., and KTUL-TV of Tulsa, Okla., from Leake TV Inc.

title: ALASKA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dr. Henry van Zile Hyde, 76; Chief of Medical Federation
description: Dr. Henry van Zile Hyde, a member of the United States delegation that helped form the World Health Organization in 1946, died today at the United States Naval Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: M.T.A.'s $7,000 Robot Shakes Up Rail Commuters

title: West Virginia Bank Is Closed
description: The Comptroller of the Currency today closed the First National Bank of South Charleston, W.Va., and appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver.

title: LAW ON REALTY TAX PAYMENTS VOIDED
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday overturned a New York City law requiring many property owners to pay real-estate taxes twice a year instead of quarterly.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THOMPSON APPEARS THE ILLINOIS WINNER, EXCEPT TO STEVENSON
description: On the basis of unofficial and disputed returns, Gov. James R. Thompson, the Republican incumbent, appeared today to have won the unusually close gubernatorial race here.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RUSHING INTO THE TYLENOL GAP
description: Two American Home Products plants are working around the clock to turn out Anacin 3, the company's aspirin-free product, which competes head-to-head with Tylenol.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INTROSPECTIVE

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
HIGH SCHOOL PRINCIPALS SHAKEN BY MACCHIAROLA TENURE POLICY
description: In four years as Chancellor of the New York City public schools, Frank J. Macchiarola has replaced over 60 percent of the system's high school principals, using forced retirements, reassignments and outright dismissals to bring about much of the turnover.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Republic Steel, Allis Cutbacks
description: Two major companies announced layoffs, and the Tandem Computer Corporation of Cupertino, Calif., said all employees would take a two-and-a-half-day unpaid vacation at Thanksgiving time, as part of an undetailed cost-cutting package.

title: TURKS ARE URGED TO BACK A NEW CONSITITUTION
description: Turkey's chief of state has toured the country for nearly two weeks to ask people to vote for the proposed new constitution in next Sunday's referendum. A yes vote, he has said, will be an indication that they trust him and do not want to ''return to terror and anarchy.''

title:
PATENTS;
Patenting Appearance, Not Structure
description: Design patents, of which 85 were issued this week for terms of 14 years, protect only the appearance of an article, not its structure or utilitarian features. But some of the concepts are intriguing.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $36,554 for the qr and $1.3 million for the 9 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $124,960

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Power Line Break Delays Trains
description: Service on the Amtrak line between Newark and New York City was disrupted during yesterday's morning rush period when a New Jersey Transit commuter train brought down an overhead power line near the Portal Bridge, about five miles west of New York.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.7 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply continued to grow rapidly in the week ended Oct. 27, although loan demand at commercial banks is falling and the economy is weak.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After special writeoffs totaling $4,655,000 for the qr and 9 mos mostly due to writeoff of Pelex product line and conversion costs for European sales organization...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $521,000 for the qr and $1,708,000 for the 9 mos and a tax credit of $10,000 for the 9 mos

title: Lunchtime Theater At Bus Terminal
description: The Arts and Business Council Inc. will present a series of free lunchtime performances in the Port Authority Bus Terminal from Nov. 15 through Nov. 19. The program is designed to help artists earn income and stimulate audience development.

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 16
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Soviet Aide Warns U.S. On New Missiles

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK STORE SALES UP BY 4.5%
description: New York City retail sales in October rose 4.5 percent from a year earlier, their best year-to-year gain since a 5 percent increase in February, a spot-check of seven major retailers found yesterday.

title: Artist Leaves $3.56 Million
description: Ben Nicholson, an abstract painter who died Feb. 6 at the age of 87, left $3.56 million, according to his will, published today. The bulk of the estate went to his family, including three sons and three daughters. He also left $16,800 to Sir Norman Reid, former director of the Tate Gallery, where many of Mr. Nicholson's works are on exhibition.

title: 4 LAWMAKERS APPEAL FOR RACKETEER
description: Representative Mario Biaggi and three state legislators have urged a Federal judge to suspend a five-year prison sentence for a convicted labor racketeer and permit him to work as a volunteer youth counselor.

title: HEILEMAN AND PABST IN MERGER ACCORD
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said yesterday that by Friday it would offer stockholders in the Pabst Brewing Company $25 a share for six million shares, or a 73 percent interest.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUYING HABITS CHANGED BY SCARE
description: In the weeks since the contamination of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules spread fear through the pain-reliever market, consumers have altered their buying habits, becoming much more curious and skeptical about packaged products, drugstore executives say.

title: WHAT PROTECTIONISTS FAIL TO PROTECT
description: To the Editor:

title: MONEY AND TALKING COMPUTERS
description: Women, crime, money and computer skills all made a difference in Tuesday's election in New York State. Women would appear to be more liberal than men, at least in this electorate, and more of them voted for Mario Cuomo than did men. One exit poll showed that 56 percent of women voters chose Mr. Cuomo, the Democrat-Liberal, while men split about evenly between him and the Republican-Conservative loser, Lewis Lehrman.

title: GIANT PORTLAND & MASONRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOSS AT UNITED BRANDS
description: United Brands Inc. reported yesterday that it had a loss of $15.8 million in its first fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, wider that its loss of $11.9 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales dropped 14.3 percent, to $802 million, from $936 million. The company attributed the weakness mainly to losses in its banana operations.

title: WHEN I SHAVED OFF MY MUSTACHE
description: I first grew a mustache because I wanted to look older. That was about 1970, before anyone had a mustache. I was working on a book about Berlin in the 1920's, which required me to interview a number of aged survivors, and I wanted them to think of me as a sympathetic listener, a partner of the older generation.

title: Higher Fees Asked To Cross Hudson
description: A six-member panel has recommended increases in the tolls on the bridges and tunnels between New York and New Jersey and in the fare on the PATH subway under the Hudson River, a spokesman for Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: THREE DIFFERENT VIEWS END SEVENTH AVE. FASHION SHOWS
description: The spring fashion openings on and off Seventh Avenue ended yesterday, not with a bang, but with fairly intimate showings in which viewers could not only touch the fabrics but also find out from the designer how he felt about the new season.

title: STUDY OF DAY CARE IN U.S. FINDS CHURCHES ARE THE MAIN SUPPLIERS
description: Churches are the largest suppliers of day care to American families, with more than 25,000 of them involved in some type of child care program, according to a study made public yesterday by the National Council of Churches.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kentucky Sheriff Guilty In Plot to Murder Two
description: The sheriff of Harlan County, a mining area in eastern Kentucky, was convicted Thursday night on two charges of conspiring to murder a county commissioner and a school official.

title: Chill Wind's Effect
description: The effects of the frostbite suffered by the San Diego Charger quarterback Dan Fouts and some of his teammates in last January's bitterly cold American Conference championship game have still not totally disappeared. The wind-chill factor at that game, played in Cincinnati, fell to as low as 59 degrees below zero, causing damage to Fouts's fingers and toes, and he says he still feels pain when the weather turns cold.

title: GENSCHER IS PICKED BY GERMAN PARTY
description: A meeting of the Free Democratic Party reelected Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher as its chairman today after hearing criticism of the way in which he led the party into a new coalition with the Christian Democrats.

title: A NEW UNION PROPOSAL IS REJECTED
description: The National Football League labor negotiations appeared to be on the verge of an extended recess or collapse yesterday, after management negotiators had rejected the players association's latest contract proposal and threatened to break off the talks.

title: Wider Loss at Playboy
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. reported yesterday that its loss in the first fiscal quarter, ended Sept. 30, widened to $2.2 million, from a loss of $1.3 million a year earlier. Revenues fell 6.5 percent, to $47.2 million, from $50.5 million.

title: A QUESTION QUESTIONED
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE ALTERS ITS MX BASING PLAN
description: The Air Force has modified its plan for putting all the proposed MX missiles close together, asserting that the changes will make the missile silos nearly invulnerable to airbursts of even very powerful Soviet nuclear weapons.

title: Edward Carr Is Dead; Key British Historian
description: Edward Hallett Carr, eminent historian of the Soviet Union and former assistant editor of The Times of London, died at his home in Cambridge. He was 90 years old.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Up 1.56, to 1,051.78, as Volume Falls
description: Rounding out a tumultuous week that saw stock prices and daily trading volume soar to new records, the market took a breathing spell yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average registering a modest advance of 1.56 points, to 1,051.78. Shares of several railroad holding companies scored sharp gains on acquisition rumors.

title: Auto Layoffs Reach 251,490
description: The number of United States auto workers on indefinite layoff this week reached 251,490, the highest level in seven months, while an industry report showed that car and truck production fell to a 12-year low in October.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISRAEL DEPORTS BRITON WHO REFUSED TO SIGN PLEDGE ON P.L.O.
description: A British biology instructor was deported today for refusing to sign a form that Israel requires from foreigners before they can teach at schools in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: FRANCE HALTS INTERFERON STUDY
description: Government-backed tests of the drug interferon with cancer patients have been suspended because four patients died of heart attacks while being treated with a type made by the Pasteur Institute, French doctors and officials said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Fire and Parking Meters Monitored at a Distance
description: Jerome H. Lemelson, who has at least 350 patents, has got two more.

title: BRADY BACK ON THE JOB, PART TIME
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, returned to work part time today for the first time since March 30, 1981, when he was gravely wounded in the attempt to assassinate President Reagan.

title: French Player with a Yen For Publicity Merits Some
description: An Olympic marathon runner would find a gold medal somewhat easier to win if each country were permitted only one entry. In a bridge context such a limitation applies in three years out of every four, but it did not apply recently in the world championships in Biarritz, France. In the Olympiad (a deliberate misnomer, due to the fact that intellectual activities are not eligible for the Olympic Games) each country could be represented in proportion to its bridge population.

title: NEW YORK JOBLESS RATE AT 9.4%, A 5-YEAR HIGH
description: Unemployment in New York State reached its highest level in five years last month, according to figures released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but the seasonally adjusted 9.4 percent rate remained well below the national figure of 10.4 percent.

title: AFTER THE OIL GLUT
description: United States oil consumption is expected to fall again this year - for the fourth year in a row - while world demand has dropped 7 percent since 1979 and continues downward this year as well. Combined with increased oil production in countries that are not members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, such as Mexico and Britain, the fuel savings have created the now famous oil glut and its softening effect on petroleum prices worldwide.

title: G.O.P. Group Is Reimbursing; Watt for Two Private Parties
description: The Republican National Committee is reimbursing James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior, for the $6,517 he was ordered to pay the Government for two private parties he gave at a historic mansion.

title: United Airlines Adds to Flights
description: United Airlines, the principal subsidiary of the holding company UAL Inc., announced that it would substantially increase the number of flights and seat capacity during the holiday season starting Dec. 16. United said 34 new flights combined with the substitution of larger aircraft in 16 markets would produce 11,467 additional seats daily, a 7 percent increase over the present level.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Overreacts
description: British irritation over a toothless Falkland resolution in the United Nations is understandable, but British anger is not. Last spring, when it counted most, President Reagan sided with Prime Minister Thatcher in opposing Argentina's misguided invasion. That surely matters more than the American decision now to join with a General Assembly majority in urging fresh negotiations - a recommendation Britain is free to ignore.

title: EMMET CROZIER
description: Emmet Crozier, a reporter, editor and war correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday, his 89th birthday, at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital.

title: CHRYSLER CANADA PLANTS SHUT BY U.A.W. STRIKE
description: The Chrysler Corporation's 10,000 Canadian workers walked off their jobs at six Ontario plants today, beginning a strike whose effects will spill over onto the company's United States operations as early as Monday.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''France and Great Britain are suffering from this unjust and unilateral decision. These sanctions, are they being applied to the Soviet Union and Poland or to the European allies?'' -President Francois Mitterrand of France. (1:4.)

title: PETROTECH NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metromedia to Get Telephone Units
description: A telecommunications committee of the Federal Communications Commission authorized Metromedia Inc. to acquire paging and mobile telephone systems in four of the country's largest metropolitan areas for $137.5 million

title: Dr. George Winter Dies at 75; Structural Engineering Expert
description: Dr. George Winter, retired chairman of the department of structural engineering at Cornell University, died Tuesday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and a resident of Ithaca.

title: FORT DEARBORN INCOME SECURITIES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Released Randy Jones, pitcher, unconditionally. Added five players to winter roster: Jeff Bittiger, pitcher; Darryl Strawberry, outfielder; Billy Beane, outfielder; Mike Davis, infielder, and Scott Dye, pitcher.

title: Honduran Base Linked To Nicaraguan Rebels
description: Nicaraguan rightist rebels using United States arms and equipment freely train and operate from bases inside Honduras in their campaign to overthrow the leftist Government in Managua, according to border residents.

title: CROESUS GRINS AT THE FOLKS
description: Many of my fellow millionaires have written angrily and even abusively. ''A fine millionaire you are, Buster,'' writes a typical millionaire from the Sun Belt. ''While the rest of us are out here squandering fortunes to become governors and senators, what are you doing? Sitting there in New York mooning over money funds, I'll bet.''

title: CARDINALS SCORE DOUBLE VICTORY
description: T he moral, no doubt, is this: Don't mess with the St. Louis Cardinals. On the field this season, they won the National League pennant and the World Series. Off the field, they pulled the rug out from under the commissioner of baseball. No team in the business did more.

title: CHALLENGE IN MUSICIANS' UNION
description: Max L. Arons, president, and other top officers of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians are being challenged in an election this month by a group that is sharply critical of the longestablished leadership.

title: New Rail Rule Proposed
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today proposed lifting controls over the shipment of many farm products by rail, thus giving railways more freedom to compete with truckers. The I.C.C. said it was considering exempting all commodities except grain and soybeans from its regulations.

title: FRUIT THAT'S IN A CLASS BY ITSELF
description: If summer is known for its bounty of wonderful fruit, fall should be celebrated for the golden persimmon, the subtle and sophisticated fruit that is technically a berry and is at its best in November and December.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $144,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net income including income of $6,882,000 from discontinued operations

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 5. 1. The Guarnerius del Gesu, which was constructed in 1742, belonged to the composer Niccolo Paganini, who called it his ''cannon.''

title: DANCE: DIANA BYER'S BALLETFORE EMPHASIZES THE PAST
description: Just how difficult ballet is to perform was made clear in Thursday night's opening at Riverside Church by Balletfore, a company directed by Diana Byer.

title: Kidnappers Thwarted in Italy
description: Fifty paramilitary policemen stormed an apartment in a town north of Rome Thursday night and freed the kidnapped 19-year-old daughter of a wealthy businessman. Eight Sardinians were arrested, officers reported. Maria Luisa Achille, who was abducted near her family's villa on the outskirts of Rome Sept. 22, was reported in good condition.

title: Field to Sell Coast Station
description: Field Enterprises Inc., a privately held communications concern with interests in newspapers, electronic publishing and cable television systems, announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its San Francisco UHF television station to United Television Inc. of Minneapolis for $23 million in cash.

title: RLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROTHMANS OF PALL MALL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Sudden Popularity of Andrew Cuomo
description: Everybody is after Andrew. The resumes rush in, a snowstorm of paper, and the phone with all the buttons rings and rings.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Preferred divd requirements were greater in the latest qr

title: OILERS SET BACK RANGERS, 5-1
description: Eddie Mio saw a game that was 1-1 after two periods turn into a rout at Northlands Coliseum tonight as the goaltender and his Ranger teammates surrendered four third-period goals and lost, 5-1, to Edmonton.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On Housing Subsidies Building a Stimulus Into the Economy To the Editor: In your Oct. 23 editorial ''What's So Special About Housing?'' opposing any Congressional action to adopt a housing stimulus package, you cite some favorable developments affecting housing but neglect to mention other significant trends that be-speak the continuing severity of the problem.

title: MUSIC: SEVEN FROM MARLBORO
description: Seven young musicians representing Music from Marlboro played chamber music by Mozart, Beethoven and Dvorak Thursday night in the Metropolitan Museum. The youthful energy of these virtuoso performers worked both for and against the music - sometimes giving it the kind of elasticity that only the young seem to possess, sometimes floating along in its own world of narcissistic rapture and barely touching the heart of the music at all.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14. 1. At a concert in Carnegie Hall, the violinist pictured above played second fiddle to the violin. Explain. 2. President Reagan agreed to a request by Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. What effect will that have on the United States Marines stationed in that country?

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pope Beatifies Nun On Trip to Andalusia
description: Pope John Paul II visited Andalusia today and beatified a nun who founded an order dedicated to serving ''the poorest of the poor.''

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Infant Girl Undergoes A Liver Transplant
description: Doctors gave 11-month-old Jamie Fiske a new liver and a fresh chance for life today, using an organ from a brain-dead boy.

title: PROTECTION FOR INFANTS ON AIRCRAFT
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration has approved a safety restraint f or infant passengers on commercial aircraft. The restraint, while n ot mandatory, was termed a ''first'' in aviation history by the man w ho campaigned for it.

title:
Patents;
Armor Suit To Protect Divers
description: WASHINGTON A photographer who is also a marine biologist was granted a patent this week for an armored skin-diving suit, intended to provide protection from sharks.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $387,000...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $391,000; the 1981 figures for the qr and 9 mos were restated to reflect a loss from discontinued operations resulting from the company's withdrawal from an uranium mine venture in Mar 1982

description: B-Including income of $502,000 from discontinued operations which includes a gain of $287,000 on the disposition of Treadway Inns...C-Including income of $258,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $185,000 on the disposition of assets; shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to paid Nov 15

title: THE GOOD PROPERTY TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Costa Rican Appeals For Economic Aid
description: President Luis Alberto Monge of Costa Rica said today that his nation needed economic support, but not military aid, to resist Communist forces mounting ''an aggressive expansionist offensive'' in Central America.

title:
PATENTS;
Study of Body Fluids Finds Damaged Tissue
description: Staff members at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee have invented for the Department of Energy a method of detection of diseased or damaged tissue by analysis of body fluids.

title: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $154,000

title: DRILLING REPORTED AT WILDERNESS SITE
description: An oil company began drilling in a Federal wilderness area in New Mexico this week despite a Congressional ban on such drilling and the refusal of the Interior Department to grant a permit.

title: No Headline
description: Press Panel Attacks Actions Of South Africa and Argentina

title: WOMEN GRADUATE AS CITY FIREFIGHTERS, AND A NEW ERA STARTS NEXT WEEK
description: Women became full-fledged firefighters in New York City yesterday for the first time. Eleven women and 103 men graduated from the Fire Academy in a windswept ceremony on Randalls Island filled with an awareness of what a historic day it was for the 117-year-old Fire Department. The graduates, who start work next week, were the survivors of an original 155-member probationary class that began training shortly after having been sworn into the Fire Department by Mayor Koch on Sept. 22.

title: Italy Open to Increase In Beirut Peace Force
description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy said today that his Government would respond favorably to a Lebanese request to expand the multinational peacekeeping force if the conditions were acceptable to the other troop contributors, France and the United States.

title: MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 9 mos net figures include nonrecurring gains of more than $2 million both this yr and last yr from the sale of interests in oil leases

title: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline

title: Hypnosis Tape Admitted in Court
description: A judge in Bergen County ruled today that videotaped testimony of a hypnotized defendant could be admitted as evidence.

title: Spanish Bank Takeover
description: The Bank of Spain is taking over Banca Catalana, one of Spain's main banking groups, a spokesman for the central bank said today.

title: SEATTLE SLEW FINDS SUCCESS AS A SIRE
description: When Bold Ruler died in 1971, the search began for his successor - for the one throughbred stallion whose bloodlines would most faithfully perpetuate the qualities that made Bold Ruler the most influential sire in recent racing history.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
WALLACE REDUX
description: George Wallace has picked up where Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. left off, and if you were black or liberal and living in Alabama you would have voted for him for Governor on Tuesday.

title: LURIA, L, & SON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
What's Polluted in Lebanon
description: The September massacre of Palestinians in Lebanon horrified the outside world. Israel, whose forces might have been able to halt the tragedy, has been going through anguish. This is only appropriate for a society in which moral sensitivity is a principle of political life.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $564,000 for the qr and the 9 mos from the sale of the company's Kansas City plant

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After securities gains of $45,366 for the qr and $108,038 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $19,000 for the qr and $46,000 for the 9 mos

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1982
description: International No major concessions to the U.S. will be made by France and Britain in order to halt American trade sanctions against Western European countries involved in the construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced in Paris. (Page 1, Column 3.) Human rights leaders in Argentina are seeking court orders to have exhumed the nearly 1,000 bodies recently discovered in six cemeteries around Buenos Aires so that identities can be established. (1:2-3.) Israel will not officially respond to the Reagan Administration's denunciation of the Government's plan to build five new settlements in the occupied territories, Israeli officials said. The Deputy Minister of Agriculture, Michal Dekel, told the Israeli state radio that the five settlements were part of a master plan for 20 new communities in the next year. (3:1.)

title: MODEL ANTINARCOTICS FORCE IN MIAMI IS SAID TO DISRUPT ROUTE OF SMUGGLERS
description: President Reagan has announced that he wants to create 12 special regional forces in January, patterned after a group created here this year, to combat narcotics smuggling and organized crime. But just how effective the model force in Miami has been is difficult to assess, its task being so unending.

title: GOODY CHAIN AND EX-OFFICIAL ARE SENTENCED IN TAPES CASE
description: A retired vice president of the Sam Goody music stores was sentenced to a year in prison and the company was fined $10,000 after both pleaded no contest yesterday to Federal charges involving trafficking in counterfeit tape recordings.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THOMAS R. CARSKADON, WRITER AND 20TH CENTURY FUND AIDE
description: Thomas Reynolds Carskadon, a retired associate director of the 20th Century Fund, died Thursday at the Starkville (Miss.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and had lived in Starkville since moving from the New York area four years ago.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nixon's Roadrunners

description: To the Editor:

title: BOXER'S BIG CHANCE
description: B illy Costello will climb into a ring sometime after 2 o'clock on Sunday afternoon and, thanks to television's search for an autumn divertissement to replace that of professional football, he will have the chance to climb into living rooms across America.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Investment income represents net investment income

title: Mets Release Randy Jones
description: The Mets released Randy Jones yesterday, ending a two-year attempt to revive the fortunes of a pitcher who won 22 games and the National League Cy Young Award in 1976, then had elbow surgery and never had another winning season.

title: ISRAELIS ARE SILENT ON CRITICISM BY U.S.
description: Israeli officials said today that there would be no official response to the Reagan Administration's denunciation of the Government's plan to build new settlements in the occupied territories.

title: Jennifer O'Neill Faces Gun Inquiry
description: The gun with which the actress Jennifer O'Neill shot herself was not registered in New York, and the case will be turned over to a grand jury, the Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS RISES TO 10.4% OF LABOR FORCE
description: With more than 11,551,000 people out of work in October, the nation's unemployment rate rose three-tenths of a percentage point to 10.4 percent of the labor force, another post-Depression high, the Labor Department announced today.

EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Penalty for Payments
description: Virginia Tech declared 22 of its track and field athletes temporarily ineligible after the team's coach had admitted that he paid them $1 for each point they scored in the Metro Conference championships last spring. Athletic Director Bill Dooley said he had notified the National Collegiate Athletic Association that the coach, Russ Whitenack, had violated N.C.A.A. rules by making the payments, which totaled $170, and that members of the team who accepted the money would remain ineligible ''until a review of all the circumstances can be made.'' Whitenack, in his eighth year as coach, said the payments had been meant to supplement a meal allowance of $6 a day permitted each team member on the trip to the championships, which were held in Tallahassee, Fla.

title: U.S. DRUG CHARGES CITE 4 CUBAN AIDES
description: Four high-ranking Cuban officials, including the chief of the Cuban Navy, were among 14 people indicted here today on Federal charges of smuggling narcotics into the United States.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $83,000...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $750,000

title: TO SAVE HOUSING FOR A CITY'S POOR
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT NAMES WATT'S TOP AIDE FOR ENERGY POST
description: President Reagan today nominated Under Secretary of the Interior Donald P. Hodel as the new Secretary of Energy, settling one of a broad variety of personnel questions that the Administration faces as it reaches midterm.

title: Tales From The Beetle Wars
description: T he Great TriBeCa Beetle Tug-of-War was played in lower Manhattan yesterday, but the only winner was a tiny insect, about an eighth of an inch long, that got to live on borrowed time.

title: POP: LINDA RONSTADT RETURNS
description: Linda Ronstadt's opening-night concert in the Radio City Music Hall, where she'll be performing through Tuesday, had the air of a grand retrospective. Though Miss Ronstadt sang brief sets last spring at the Concerts for Nuclear Disarmament, and before that performed for several months on Broadway in ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' Thursday's concert was her first in New York in two years in support of an album.

title: Carpenter Willing
description: Rob Carpenter, the Giants' unsigned free-agent fullback, says that he would come back to the team the minute the players' strike ended. ''If the strike ends tonight and the Giants want me back, I'll be there tomorrow morning,'' he said yesterday by telephone from Houston.

title: PENNCORP FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $6,872,000 for the qr and $15,300,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net loss

title: THEATER: HARRY HAMLIN IN 'HAMLET' AT MC CARTER
description: Harry Hamlin's ''Hamlet'' - those words have a hearty alliterative ring, like Hubert Horatio Humphrey. Before playing Hamlet for the McCarter Theater Company, Mr. Hamlin's most notable ''classical'' appearance was as Perseus in the ''Clash of the Titans.'' Nevertheless, he offers a vigorous personification of a Hamlet that to a great extent has been shaped in his image.

description: MIRACLE AT MIDWAY. By Gordon W. Prange, Donald M. Goldstein and Kath- erine V. Dillon. 397 pages. McGraw-Hill Book Company. $19.95.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Trail Blazers, at Portland, Ore. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8 P.M. The first game of a home-and-home weekend set with the Flyers. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 97.5; 8 P.M.) Devils vs. Red Wings, at Detroit. The feature is the $50,000-added Discovery Handicap for 3-year-olds at a mile and an eighth. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M., tape; SportsChannel, 7 P.M., tape).

title: FRANCES DAVIS COHEN
description: Frances Davis Cohen, an author and former war correspondent, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: Church Council Issue Put Off
description: The National Council of Churches will not decide for a year whether a denomination organized primarily for homosexuals is eligible for membership.

title: Weinberger, in Australia, Holds Military Talks
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met with Defense Minister Ian M. Sinclair of Australia today to discuss military cooperation between their two countries.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified Chet Forte's job with ''Monday Night Football'' on ABC-TV. He is the director.

title: Libel Verdict Overturned On Appeal by Penthouse
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a $12.5 million verdict in a lawsuit, ruling that an article in Penthouse magazine describing the sexual activities of a beauty contestant was ''gross, unpleasant and crude'' but not libelous.

title: U.S. Leads In Cup, 3-1
description: Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Jo Durie, 6-2, 6-2, tonight and gave the United States a 3-0 lead over Britain in the seven-match Wightman Cup tennis series at Royal Albert Hall.

title: Rise in Fares Linked To Clout of N.J.E.A.
description: In ''We Must Fill the Gaps in School Budgets'' (Opinion Page, Oct. 17), A.J. Cimino disposed very quickly of the cause of the 25 percent fare increase facing mass-transit users in New Jersey. President Reagan's cuts in transportation funds are the culprit, he said.

title: Dr. Brian Lloyd Tell To Marry Linda Nass
description: Edna K. Nass of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Linda Rachel Nass, to Dr. Brian Lloyd Tell, son of Frieda Tell of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Dr. Meyer Tell.

title: No Headline
description: CLEMSON TOPS NORTH CAROLINA

title: Michael Welcome Weds Carolyn Beach in Albany
description: Carolyn Maitland Beach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Beach of Loudonville, N.Y., was married yesterday in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Albany to Michael Wayne Welcome, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Clifford Welcome of Riverbank, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Laman H. Bruner Jr., performed the ceremony.

title: Billion-Dollar Questions About Three Mile Island
description: The nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island has lain wounded for more than three years, but lawyers met in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week to kick around the matter of responsibility. ''A frightening episode of corporate misconduct,'' charged David Klingsberg, attorney for General Public Utilities, the plant operator.

title: FORDHAM LAW SCHOOL TO START $6.8 MILLION EXPANSION PROJECT
description: A $6.8 million expansion project at Fordham Law School, which will nearly double the school's space, is expected to begin next spring, officials said.

title: COUNTY SEEKS NEW OPERATOR FOR PLAYLAND
description: NOW that the Marriott Corporation has bowed out, the search is on for someone to manage Playland, the financially troubled county amusement park in Rye, until its future is decided.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: WORLD'S OCEANS BECAME CLEANER OVER THE LAST DECADE, STUDY FINDS
description: The world's oceans, believed by many to be in danger of becoming sinks for man's pollutants, are able to assimilate the toxic substances in most areas and remain in relatively stable condition, an extensive international scientific study has determined.

title: KEEP THE 55-M.P.H. SPEED LIMIT
description: ON OCT. 2, The New York Times carried an article by an advertising executive who opposes the Federal 55-miles-an-hour speed limit and who ''relies heavily on a CB radio'' to rescue him from radar traps and patrolling police officers.

title: THE TIME IS NEW YEAR'S EVE, 1999
description: THE TWOFOLD VIBRATION By Raymond Federman. 175 pp. Bloomington, Ind.: Indiana University Press. $10.95.

title: MANITOBA LOBBYING AGAINST U.S. WATER PLAN
description: The Government of this province has begun an intense lobbying campaign in Washington aimed at halting a longplanned irrigation project for North Dakota. People here believe that the project threatens fish, fishermen and fish-eating Indian tribes of Manitoba.

title: Deborah Malloy Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Malloy of Purchase, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Malloy, to John Pearce, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Pearce of Palmerston North, New Zealand.

title: A Worse Worst Case
description: In a report issued last week on the risks and consequences of accidents at nuclear power plants, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission concluded that a hypothetical worst-case event - meltdown with breach of containment - could cause 100,000 early deaths and $300 billion in damages at certain locations. A similar study in 1975 had put these figures at 3,300 deaths and $14 billion cost.

title: Sara Perkins Has Nuptials
description: Sara Scott Perkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Clark Perkins Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Louis Frederic Kyle, son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Clayton Kyle of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 1880, edited and translated by Francis Steegmuller. (Belknap/Harvard University Press, $15.)

title: C.I.A. Maneuvers Against Managua
description: In 1961, the Central Intelligence Agency sponsored an invasion of Cuba by Cuban emigres that was designed to topple Fidel Castro but ended in military and diplomatic disaster in the Bay of Pigs. That fiasco notwithstanding, the Reagan Administration revealed last week that the C.I.A. was supporting covert operations by exiled Nicaraguan forces in Honduras against the leftist Sandinist regime in Managua.

title: GW SLEPT HERE
description: Skeptics, be quiet. George Washington not only slept at the Roe Tavern in East Setauket, L.I., on April 22, 1790, he even gave it a review.

title: FUMIGATION OF KHAPRA BEETLES TO START WEDNESDAY
description: Federal officials and community leaders met yesterday to discuss a plan to use toxic gas to fumigate a TriBeCa warehouse infested with beetles and agreed to begin the procedure Wednesday. At the request of the community, the officials also agreed to take extra safety steps during the fumigation.

title: COURT SAYS U.S. SPY AGENCY CAN TAP OVERSEAS MESSAGES
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the National Security Agency may lawfully intercept messages between United States citizens and people overseas, even if there is no cause to believe the Americans are foreign agents, and then provide summaries of these messages to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 13 Die in Philippine Bus Fire
description: At least 13 people were killed today when a bus burst into flames in a Manila suburb, the Philippine News Agency said. Witnesses said one passenger was able to get out of the bus, which was rocked by a series of explosions before catching fire. The police said the cause of the fire was not known.

title: Liverpool Wins by 5-0 As Rush Scores 4 Goals
description: Ian Rush scored four goals as Liverpool defeated Everton, 5-0, today and took a 2-point lead in the English League First Division soccer standings.

title: Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER:INSURING AGAINST AN EMERGENCY
description: T he telephone call reached Paris at 3 o'clock in the morning, bringing word to American travelers of a personal emergency that would require them to return home as soon as possible. It is an unhappy circumstance that many vacationers must face from time to time.

title: LIKE PLANTS AND ANIMALS
David A. Halsey to Marry Katie Terhune Doremus
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Peter Doremus Jr. of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katie Terhune Doremus, to David Alexander Halsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Van Rensselaer Halsey of Locust, N.J., and New York.

title: DINU LIPATTI'S TALENT HIGHLIGHTS NEW PIANO DISKS
description: One of the profound artistic calamities of the 20th century was the early death, from leukemia, of the Rumanian pianist Dinu Lipatti. Only 33 when he died in 1950, he was recognized as a prodigious talent while still a child, and began his recording career at the age of 19. In his few remaining years, Mr. Lipatti made only a scant handful of recordings, yet these have guaranteed his posthumous reputation, as they are on a uniformly high level.

title: THEATER GROUP DEFINES AIMS
description: A FLEDGLING experimental theater has just opened in New Haven aimed at involving the audience in each of its productions, as well as entertaining them in the traditional manner.

title: ODOR'S CAUSE UNKNOWN, L.I. SCHOOL TO REOPEN
description: Administrators of Hauppauge High School on Long Island have decided to reopen the school tomorrow after tests failed to determine the cause of a mysterious odor that forced the evacuation of the school last week.

title: Index; International
description: C.I.A. puts Soviet penal labor at four million people 3 Kohl is said to seek a ''better un- derstanding'' with U.S. 3 Around the World 5 Yugoslav curb on travel stalls trade in city across border 6 Yugoslavia faces an economic crisis 7 China plans a new campaign to hold down its birth rate 8 Some Turks strongly oppose pro- posed constitution 10 Australian town is shaken by a racial clash 15 Nicaraguan exiles build up strength 17 Argentine journalists fearful as regime shuts three magazines 18 Lebanese Christian militiamen worry about future role 21 Manitobans press case against North Dakota water project 23 Government/Politics Pentagon aides say MX program is in deep trouble 27 Bipartisan approach sought on Social Security problems 28 Challenges await Governor-elect Deukmejian of California 30 Reagan bids Congress deal with economy in special session 32 Environmental groups cite suc- cesses in election 36 Officials confer on plan to gas beetles in warehouse 38 General Around the Nation 28 Kentucky mining concern finds 70% of oxygen units unusable 35 Strike by Legal Aid lawyers en- ters its third week 38 Tests find no cause for fumes at L.I. school, and it will reopen 39 Health/Science U.S. says farmers can continue to use two risky fungicides 35 Education/Welfare Job prospects for college seniors called worst in decade 32 Evanston, Ill., may tax students at Northwestern U. 33 Arts/Entertainment Dance design by Remy Charlip 71 ''Five Days One Summer'' on screen 72 Music debuts in review 73 Style For women, safe places to stay 74 Obituaries John Lee Denson, edited News- week and other publications 44 News Analysis Drew Middleton assesses Soviet naval buildup 4

title: Jo Ann Emmens Engaged
description: The engagement of Jo Ann McQueen Emmens to William Kent Yates has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William D. McQueen of Bloomfield, N.J. Mr. Yates is a son of Joyce Yates of Roseland, N.J., and William Yates of Pittsburgh. A spring wedding is planned. The bride's marriage ended in divorce.

title: WOODMERE SCHOOL SALE EYED
description: ON Tuesday, residents of the Hewlett-Woodmere School District will vote on a much-discussed referendum on whether to sell the 5 1/4-acre Woodmere South complex - for $3.75 million, a figure believed to be a record price for a Long Island school property - to local developers who plan luxury condominiums.

title: STATE SET TO ACT ON OWN DRUG RULES
description: The following article is based on reporting by Anthony DePalma and Louise Saul and was written by Mr. DePalma.

title: Mrs. Roe Racing Again
description: Allison Roe of New Zealand, who set a women's world record of 2 hours 25 minutes 29 seconds in the 1981 New York City Marathon, missed this year's recent running of the race because of a problem with an Achilles' tendon. But she will return to competition today in a 10,000-meter race in South Bend, Ind., where the weather recently has been cold and blustery.

title: NIXON GATHERING MARKS 1972 ELECTION TRIUMPH
description: The guest list read like a ''Who's Who'' of the Watergate scandals: Richard M. Nixon, John N. Mitchell, H.R. Haldeman, Ronald L. Ziegler, Rose Mary Woods, Charles W. Colson.

title: BIOTECH IDEA PUSHED
description: THE State University at Stony Brook has filed an application for designation as a biotechnology center by the New York State Science and Technology Foundation as the first step in an aggressive campaign to develop and market its medical and biological research programs.

title: UNION PLANS TO OPEN CENTERS IN NORTHEAST TO HELP JOBLESS
description: Contending that the Government does too little for the unemployed, the United Automobile Workers union says it plans to open a string of storefront centers in the Northeast designed to help the region's jobless survive the winter or find work.

title: MINE OXYGEN UNITS CALLED DEFECTIVE
description: A Kentucky coal mining company has found that 70 to 80 percent of its 300 emergency breathing devices are unusable. Officials of the mining company, Leeco, of London, Ky., said the devices were found defective in a safety inspection a week ago and that all 300 had been withdrawn from the mines for further inspection.

title: SEARCH IS INTENSIFIED FOR GRAND PRIX SITE
description: Now that the New York Grand Prix is on next season's international racing schedule, the event's organizers must select an appropriate site for the race and inform New Yorkers about what to expect from the first major motor sports event to be held in the metropolitan area.

title: Wagner Defeats Springfield
description: Bill Marak's 28-yard field goal with 42 seconds remaining gave Wagner a 16-14 victory over Springfield yesterday afternoon at Benedum Field, Springfield, Mass.

title: THE POPE AND POLITICS
description: The Pope and Politics I was touched by Kenneth A. Briggs's article ''The Pope: The World Is His Pulpit'' (Oct. 10).

title: KNICKS FALL TO THE TRAIL BLAZERS, 110-102
description: The Knicks' problems continued to mount tonight as they lost their fifth straight game, 110-102, at Memorial Coliseum. It was the first victory in five games for the Trail Blazers.

title: JOB PROSPECTS FOR GRADUATES CALLED THE WORST IN A DECADE
description: This year's college seniors face the worst job market in at least a decade, with fewer jobs being offered than last year and with little or no increase in salaries, according to college job placement officers surveying the employment outlook for next June.

title: HIGH SPIRITS BUOY A JONI MITCHELL ALBUM
description: ''Wild Things Run Fast'' (Geffen GHS 2O19), Joni Mitchell's first studio album in three years, is an artistically fruitful return to the jazz-inflected rock of her biggest hit record, ''Court and Spark,'' from 1974.

title: LAKERS 104, JAZZ 101
description: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) - Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Earvin Johnson scored 22 points apiece, and Norm Nixon added 18 points for the Lakers, 12 in the third quarter.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MEDIATION: EASING THE PAIN THAT IS WED TO DIVORCE
description: ''OUR marriage,'' Jane said, ''hasn't been working for years. I don't want to get into some crazy miserable legal hassle - I just want out of the marriage.''

title: Privileges
description: To the Editor: In respect to the Practical Traveler article, ''Age Has Its Privileges'' (Travel, Sept. 12), I thought you might be interested in our experience while waiting in line to purchase tickets to board the Queen Mary in Long Beach, Calif., last year.

title: Alice Beck Is Affianced
description: Alice Whitman Beck and Robert Andrew Dubow, alumni of the University of Pennsylvania, class of '81, plan to be married Dec. 26. The future bride is the daughter of Associate Judge Phyllis W. Beck of the Superior Court of Pennsylvania and Dr. Aaron T. Beck of Wynnewood, Pa., who have announced her engagement to the son of Claire Dubow of New York and the late David Dubow.

title: New at the Eiffel Tower
description: The first landing of the Eiffel Tower, closed for nearly two years for repairs, reopened recently with a new restaurant, cinema and shops. The restaurant, La Belle France, is aimed at the tourist trade, with a $13 menu and limited wine list.

title:
ART;
MYSTERIES OF TANTRISM
description: EAST ISLIP OF all the Oriental religions that have fascinated Westerners, the cult of Tantric Buddhism is perhaps the most remote. Nurtured principally in the Himalayas, its practices developed from a melding of Hindu ritual imported from India via ancient trade routes and the established shamanism called Bon, whose magical demons became reconciled with the more benign deities of Buddhism.

title: DANCE: DEBUT OF MURRAY LOUIS'S 'MANY SEASONS'
description: Words such as bounce, bounce, bob, twitch, twist, hinge, hang, slide and sway spring to mind when watching Murray Louis's choreography. It is, in fact, springy movement, light rather than weighted and yet not lightweight.

title: AIR FORCE WINNER OVER ARMY BY 27-9
description: The Air Force defeated Army at Michie Stadium today, 27-9, and achieved a long sought goal: beating both Army and Navy in the same football season.

title: Jill L. Weissinger, J.W. Northrop Married Upstate
description: Jill Lockhart Weissinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Weissinger of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Johnston Willard Northrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston Northrop of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: A MASTER GUITARIST
description: Narciso Yepes, who plays the 10-string guitar as though he invented it (and he did), once said: ''If I have a 10-string guitar, I have within it a six-string guitar; but if I have only six strings, I do not have 10. I have all the advantages, and none of the disadvantages.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday on the mar- riage of Mary Pendergast to David Vladeck gave the occupations of the bridegroom's parents incorrectly. His mother, Mrs. Stephen C. Vladeck of New York, is a labor lawyer and sen- ior partner in the New York law firm of Vladeck, Waldman, Elias & Engle- hard, formerly known as Vladeck & Elias; the bridegroom's late father was a founder and senior partner. An article last Sunday on the en- gagement of Alice Belknap Chrystie to Peter Hunt Wyman identified his mother incorrectly. She is Mrs. Ste- phen V.R. Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y.

title: THE POPE AND POLITICS
description: I read with considerable interest Kenneth Briggs's article on the Pope, but for reasons quickly understandable I feel obliged to point out a factual error. Mr. Briggs noted the NBC News report, which was mine, that in August 1980 the Pope sent an envoy to the Kremlin with a letter saying that he would ''lay down the crown of St. Peter'' and return to Poland if the Russians invaded his homeland. True. But then, Mr. Briggs wrote that the Vatican ''emphatically denied that a message was ever sent.''

title: U.S. DROPS REFUSAL TO TALK TO SOVIET AT MADRID PARLEY
