description: The United States, seeking to avoid a political rift in the Atlantic alliance, has dropped its refusal to resume negotiations in Madrid on East-West cooperation.

title: PRIEST IN ASSISI FEARS SHRINE'S FAMED ART
description: Whenever the earth shakes in this quake belt of Umbria, it alarms lovers of art and people engaged in its preservation, especially a Franciscan priest.

title: Troubling Trend In College Sports
description: To the Sports Editor: Two articles appearing in recent editions of The New York Times saddened this lover of collegiate sports. Both are indications of a growing sickness.

title: STRIKE AT CANADA'S CHRYSLER
description: Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca (left), saw 10,000 company employees in Canada go out on strike Friday over pay issues, following his warnings that a strike ''will cripple the company and perhaps ruin it.'' Analysts said the strike could seriously hurt Chrysler if it lasted more than a few weeks, when inventories of parts made in Canada would be depleted and U.S. plants would have to be closed. Some 2,500 American employees at factories that supply the Canadian plants were told they would be laid off Monday, but U.S. plants would be kept open.

title: Future Events Fall Frolics
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Role Models Nov. 3 - Mary F. Rockefeller, the philanthropist, and Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, will be honored as New York's outstanding women of 1982 at the annual ''Salute to Women Achievers'' luncheon of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York. At the event in the New York Hilton's Grand Ballroom the honorees will receive the Elizabeth Cutter Morrow Award, named for the longtime Y.W.C.A. board member and Smith College trustee, who was no mean achiever herself. Mrs. Morrow, a poet, was the wife of Dwight W. Morrow, United States Senator and Ambassador to Mexico, and mother of Anne Morrow Lindbergh. The 1982 award will be in the form of a gold medallion designed and crafted by Norma Zotos, who teaches at the Y.W.C.A. Craft Students League. Tickets to luncheon, a benefit for the Y.W.C.A., $150.

title:
GARDENING;
YEAR-ROUND SUMMER: CITRUS INDOORS
description: COLD nights, chilly days and the passing of daylight time reminds us that winter is not far away. For those of us who enjoy green grass and sunshine to warm our bones, the mere thought of winter brings on depression.

title: An Israeli's Worst Fears
description: At least one Israeli commander appears to have had forebodings about allowing Lebanese militiamen into Palestinian camps outside Beirut. Maj. Gen. Amir Drori, the senior Israeli commander in Lebanon in mid-September, told an Israeli inquiry last week that he had discussed his apprehensions with a colleague and had warned Christian Phalangist militia commanders ''that they should behave like human beings, that they should not hurt nonfighters, women, children, old people.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The "Gallery View" column on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today is incorrectly bylined. It is by John Russell.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BOTH the county and its booming cable television industry got some good news last week when Time Inc. announced that its latest publishing venture, TV-Cable Week magazine, will be edited and published in White Plains.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT INCREASES TO 10.4%
description: U.S. unemployment rose to 10.4 percent in October, the highest rate since 1940, from 10.1 percent in September. In all, 11.6 million people were without jobs. The White House said President Reagan was ''sympathetic and concerned'' over the rate, but that he remained confident that his economic policies were working.

title: POPULATION BOOM SEEN FOR MOUNTAIN STATES
description: The fastest-growing area in the country in terms of population over the next two decades will be the mountain states of the West, according to a new study.

title: PEDDLING ADVICE TO THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: THE very rich are different from you and me, F. Scott Fitzgerald once said. Not only do they have more money, asE rnest Hemingway pointed out, but they have advisers to tell them w hat to do with it.

title: New Navajo Leader
description: For the Navajo, it was a case of too many Indians and not enough jobs. Thus, after a campaign that stressed the 175,000-member tribe's 80 percent unemployment rate, Peter MacDonald last week lost the job of tribal chairman to Peterson Zah. Mr. MacDonald, who was regarded as one of the most powerful native American leaders, boasted that the tribe had made more progress in 12 years under his stewardship than it had in the previous half-century. Mr. Zah pledged improvements through better management of the tribe's vast natural resources - under some leases the Navajo receive as little as 25 cents a ton for coal - rather than the Federal grants and treaty payments that were relied upon previously and that have been sharply curtailed by the Reagan Administration.

title: IN AUSTRIA, THE DEFINITIVE DOWNHILL
description: JAMES SALTER is a novelist and the author of the screenplay for the movie ''Downhill Racer.'' His latest book is ''Solo Faces.''

title:
GARDENING;
YEAR-ROUND SUMMER: CITRUS INDOORS
description: COLD nights, chilly days and the passing of daylight time reminds us that winter is not far away. For those of us who enjoy green grass and sunshine to warm our bones, the mere thought of winter brings on depression.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
GOODBYE AND GOOD RIDDANCE--MAYBE
description: OUR lovely Long Island village holds an annual event called ''Fall Cleanup.'' On that one weekend each year, every person in town turns his house upside down and gives it a good shake, and anything that isn't nailed or bolted down gets put at curbside.

title: Charlotte Terrell Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Terrell 3d of Columbus, Miss., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Charlotte White Terrell, to Scott Alexander Frances, son of Evan Frances Agnew of New York, and the late Alexander Frances.

title:
GARDENING;
YEAR-ROUND SUMMER: CITRUS INDOORS
description: COLD nights, chilly days and the passing of daylight time reminds us that winter is not far away. For those of us who enjoy green grass and sunshine to warm our bones, the mere thought of winter brings on depression.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: OPEN your closet and dust off those old baseball cards that have been tucked away for years. If you're lucky enough to have a 30-yearold picture of Mickey Mantle or a 1954 Ted Williams, these can be sold for more than $500 today at the Baseball Card and Sports Memorabilia Show at the Sheraton Inn, Bridgeport.

title: AMERICAN CATHOLICS
description: Andrew Greeley writes, ''If you could eat meat on Friday, could you not practice birth control?'' Granted, he is seeking to paraphrase attitudes of postconciliar Catholics, but he establishes a false parallelism and then drops it without clarification. Meatless Fridays were a disciplinary rule, made by the church and subject to abrogation or elimination; birth control has to do with life itself and is a matter of divine law.

title: SILVER AND ITS EVOLUTION; NEW HAVEN, Conn.
description: Silver has always sparked passionate pursuits, dramatically altering the lives of men who could not resist the precious metal, transforming them into explorers, panhandlers, thieves, bankers, collectors and museum curators. If the chase has produced disastrous as well as distinguished results, it has certainly rarely been dull. Indeed, the wide-ranging attraction of silver in raw or rarified forms, and the effects it has had on people's lives, has frequently altered the course of history.

title: TRUMBULL ROLLS, 36-12
description: Trumbull played nearly errorless football yesterday and took advantage of seven Andrew Warde turnovers to win, 36-12. The victory, at Fairfield, kept Turnbull unbeaten in the Eastern Division at 4-0-1.

title: KEEPING THE FAITH
description: KEEPING FAITH Memoirs of a President. By Jimmy Carter. Illustrated. 622 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $22.50.

title: Fashion Profile; CARRYING ON
description: Although the house of Chanel has undergone many changes recently, the late Coco Chanel's nonpareil use of accessories is enduring under the direction of an American.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Soviet Union is continuing to expand its military power in the Pacific, according to senior officers in the United States Navy. Adm. Robert Long, commander of American forces in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, said Backfire bombers were flying missions from the Kamchatka Peninsula in the Soviet Far East and from Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam.

title: BANK LEAVES ITS TRAILER HOME
description: THE five-month-old Bank of Stamford moved out of its inelegant trailer office on Prospect Street last week and into its nearby new building with brick arches, but with no appliances or sets of dishes in sight to lure new customers. Indeed, the bank never even placed an advertisement in the local paper to announce that it was in business.

title: Leila C. Jenkins To Be Wed Jan. 1
description: Leila Cassel Jenkins, a vice president of Shields Associates, investment counselors in New York, plans to be married Jan. 1 to Edward Judson Waite 3d, general attorney and assistant secretary for the Crompton & Knowles Corporation, a specialty chemicals concern in New York.

title: Marin Scordato to Marry Paula Monopoli in January
description: Mrs. Richard V. Monopoli of Hadley, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Paula Ann Monopoli, to Marin Roger Scordato, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Scordato of Silver Spring, Md.

title: TOWERS TRIBUTE
description: When a Federal agency tried to end rent stabilization at the Lincoln Towers complex in Manhattan about five years ago, it reckoned without the influence of Shirley Quill. The president of the Towers Tenants Association, she had been a labor organizer before she met her husband, Michael J. Quill, the late president of the Transport Workers Union. Mrs. Quill responded to the Federal threat by organizing an intensive lobbying campaign and an outdoor rally of the Towers' 9,000 tenants.

title: HOW LAUTENBERG BEAT THE ODDS
description: THAN-EXPECTED turnout across the state and lopsided Democratic pluralties in Essex and Hudson Counties were two of the keys to the victory of Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of Montclair, over Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of Bernardsville, in the race for United States Senate.

title: POPULATION VIEWED AS 'BOTTOMING OUT'
description: THE causes of the population loss shown in the 1980 census appear to be easing more rapidly than expected, according to a report to be released this week by the county's Planning Department. The report, which examines in detail the changing profile of the county's population in terms of age, sex and ethnic background, concludes that ''Westchester County's population level will probably bottom out and begin to slowly grow again before the rest of the tri-state region, which was also affected, stabilizes and rebounds.''

title: EDITED MAJOR PUBLICATIONS
description: John Lee Denson, who over a 50-year career was an editor of some of the nation's leading publications, including Newsweek and The New York Herald Tribune, died Friday night at Lakeside Health Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Palm Beach Shores, Fla.

title: AT DAY'S END, ONE SCREEN TOO MANY
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERCOMING HUMBLE ORIGINS
description: Beets - or beetroots, as they are known in the British Isles - seem to occupy a curious place in gastronomy. They are much appreciated by many people and looked on with disdain as mere animal food by others.

title: NEW YORK WARNED OF GAP IN REVENUE
description: The Koch administration, which has already imposed a hiring freeze and ordered spending reductions in each municipal agency, must take additional ''stringent'' measures to balance New York City's budget, the State Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: DEUKMEJIAN FACES TOUGH CHALLENGES IN CALIFORNIA
description: Governor-elect George Deukmejian of California acknowledges that he faces severe tests of his ability to solve problems in a hostile environment.

title: WHAT HAS HAPPENED IN HER LIFE SO FAR
description: YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN An Intimate Journey. By Nora Johnson. 274 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: MUSTO FILES APPEAL
description: NEWARK ATTORNEYS for former Mayor William V. Musto of Union City and three co-defendants convicted with him of Federal racketeering charges have appealed the convictions on the ground that the trial judge committed serious legal errors during the three-month proceeding.

title:
STAMPS;
UNITED NATIONS ISSUE STRESSES CONSERVATION
description: For its final issue of the year the United Nations has again returned to the theme of the ''Conservation and Protection of Nature.'' The new issue consists of a set of six commemoratives that call attention to programs currently under way to combat the depletion of the world's living resources in both developed and developing countries.

title: NEW PAPER SEEKS TO WIN OVER ALBUQUERQUE
description: ''Read it!'' command the bright orange and blue billboards that have sprung up all over Albuquerque. ''It'' is a species of printed matter that has become rare in these times, a new newspaper.

title: TOP-RANKED PITT LOSES TO NOTRE DAME BY 31-16
description: Buoyed by an errorless defense and a bit of offensive trickery, Notre Dame stunned previously-unbeaten Pittsburgh, the top-ranked team in the country, 31-16, today before 60,162 fans at Pitt Stadium.

title: BITTER STRIKE AT A HOSPITAL EMBROILS OHIO CITY
description: When 700 workers at a hospital walked off their jobs Aug. 1 after their three-year contract expired, officials thought the strike would be over in a day or two.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TEANECK
description: ''Teenakut,'' to its ancestral Minsi Indian tribe, ''TieneN eck'' to its Dutch settlers, ''Tee Neck,'' to Robert Erskine, G eorge Washington's cartographer, who mapped it in 1778 - is a small t own on the high ground of Bergen County four miles west of the G eorge Washington Bridge. Route 4 cuts through its center and the n ewer Route 80 runs along its southern rim.

title: Divorce to Elizabeth Taylor
description: The actress Elizabeth Taylor was granted a divorce Friday from her seventh husband, Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, a spokesman said yesterday. The no-fault decree was granted in the Circuit Court of Fauquier County, Va., the spokesman said. Miss Taylor, 50 years old, and Mr. Warner were married on Dec. 4, 1976, and separated on Sept. 1, 1981.

title: U.S. ALLOWS FARMERS TO CONTINUE TO USE 2 RISKY FUNGICIDES
description: Farmers may continue to use two fungicides suspected of causing birth defects, genetic damage and cancer because ''the benefits of these products exceed the risks,'' the Environmental Protection Agency says.

title: CONGRESS TO CONSIDER JOB PROGRAM TO CURB UNEMPLOYMENT RISE
description: Members of Congress from both parties are trying to devise a job program to deal with unemployment, now at the highest point in 42 years.

title: No Headline
description: BAYLOR UPSETS ARKANSAS

title: Miss Stringfellow Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hargrave Stringfellow of Greensboro, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Stuart Burwell Stringfellow, to Thomas Scott Carter, son of the Rev. Thomas Eugene Carter of Roanoke, Va., and the late Mrs. Carter.

title: GEORGE M. GRANT
description: George M. Grant, who served 12 terms as a United States Representative from Alabama, died Thursday of a heart attack while on a cruise aboard the Queen Elizabeth II.

title: A WAY TO USE EQUITY
description: JUST a few years ago, if you wanted a second mortgage and you lived i n New York, you went to Connecticut. New York law discouraged l enders from giving second mortgages, but determined borrowers could w ork through companies like Grammatin Investors Corporation, a p rivate finance company with offices in Queens.

title: JERSEY TIDELANDS VOTE STYMIES HOME SELLERS
description: The election Tuesday left thousands of homeowners in New Jersey in the predicament of having to repurchase their homes, this time from the state, to make the houses salable.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: JAZZ Dave Frishberg used to be primarily a jazz pianist. During the late 50's and the 60's he was Carmen McRae's accompanist and he played with Kai Winding, Gene Krupa, Ben Webster and the team of Al Cohn and Zoot Sims.

title: NEW HOPE FOR NORWALK RENEWAL
description: NORWALK WHEN two census tracts in the heart of South Norwalk were designated recently as one of six enterprise zones in the state, Roderick Johnson, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, called it ''a real shot in the arm for Norwalk's redevelopment project.''

title: No Headline
description: 76ers Defeat Celtics In Double Overtime

title: CAN CUOMO REPLACE CONFLICT WITH CONSENSUS?
description: IN the eight years since he entered public life, there have been two main questions about Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The first was whether a lawyerly intellectual with a penchant for long-winded analysis could win election in his own right. The second was, if he did win, could he actually run a government?

title: OPERA: MOZART'S 'BASTEIN AND BASTIENNE'
description: The enterprising Chamber Opera Theater of New York has come up with another smart new production in Mozart's ''Bastien and Bastienne,'' which it introduced Wednesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater on a double-bill with Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Mozart and Salieri,'' which was new last year.

title: 4 Escape in Plane Collision
description: Two small jets hit each other over the Outer Banks today but returned safely to the airport here with no injuries reported, the Coast Guard said. One plane, which lost its landing gear, skidded off the runway of caught fire briefly before all four people aboard escaped unharmed, the Coast Guard said. It was not immediately known how many people were aboard the other plane.

title: Cintra Eglin Sets Nuptials For Spring
description: Cintra Emlen Eglin, a legal assistant with the Philadelphia law firm of Drinker, Biddle & Reath, will be married in May to Wayne Clifford Willcox, an investment officer with the Republic Venture Group in Dallas.

title: PREPARING FOR COMPROMISE BUT REFUSING TO CONCEDE
description: WASHINGTON AS the dust and debris from last week's Congressional elections settled, the Republicans emerged as diminished and the Democrats with gained ground. Yet the central figure in the political landscape remained unchanged. It is President Reagan.

title: EXPERTS PONDER JOBLESS-RATE RISE
description: UNEMPLOYMENT in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has shown an unexpectedly sharp rise, surprising some economists who had long insisted that because of the Island's well-diversified economy it was somewhat immune from the national ills of recession and double-digit jobless rates.

title: COMBATTING PROLIFERATION OF GEESE
description: IN spring and fall, there is no more haunting sound than the calling of migrating Canada geese high overhead, a wild music that brings visions of the forbidding tundra or muskeg country where some of them breed, or of the great, handsome birds setting their wings as they approach a hunter's decoys under dark November skies.

title: Nicholas Lorimer to Wed Sue Marlieb
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Marlieb of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sue Ellen Marlieb, to Nicholas Gregory Lorimer, son of Mrs. George Horace Lorimer 2d of Florence and the late Mr. Lorimer. A May wedding is planned.

title: Soviet Reports Emigre Has Sour View of U.S.
description: Soviet Jews who emigrated to the United States live in poverty, and are homesick and disgusted with the immorality of American life, a regional newspaper has told its readers.

title: Marines Patrol In East Beirut
description: American marines last week made a largely symbolic stab at helping Lebanon to look like a country again. After giving French and Italian patrols from the multinational force a 24-hour head start that proved uneventful, 11 marines in four jeeps began cruising deserted neighborhoods on the edge of Christian East Beirut.

title: RIZZO TO ENTER PHILADELPHIA MAYORAL RACE
description: Finally, with one blunt sentence, former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo put his intentions in unequivocal terms. The Cisco Kid, as he was once known in his climb from tough cop to hardknuckled Mayor, will ride the campaign trail again.

title: JAPANESE BOSSES PONDER MYSTERIOUS U.S. WORKERS
description: When the workers at the Sanyo Manufacturing Corp. in Forrest City, Ark., went on strike, Tanemichi Sohma, the vice president for administration, found himself in a cross-cultural bind.

title: NUMERICAL GUIDELINES TO UNDERSTANDING AUDIO
description: A character in Joseph Conrad's ''The Secret Sharer'' exhorts a partner in conversation: ''Be lucid, but spare me the details.'' Similar admonitions are often addressed to me. In particular, I am told to ''take it easy on the numbers.'' It seems that many listeners prefer to have sound equipment described without recourse to numerical specifications, and while I usually defer to these wishes, I am not altogether in sympathy with them. I agree that the ultimate touchstone of any sound equipment is its ability to render justice to music, and that measurements are at best an indirect and equivocal index to this ability. Nonetheless, the reproduction of sound is a physical process and can be numerically analyzed and assessed in much the same way as other physical phenomena, with much to be learned from such an approach. That is why, from time to time, verbal description should be bolstered with more rigorous information quantitatively obtained and conveyed.

title: HIGH GLASS
description: Etched glass, an old favorite with practitioners of the fern-and-bare-brick school of restaurant design, now has been discovered by the architectural avant-garde.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT IN 4 CONNECTICUT RAPES GRANTED BAIL AGAIN
description: A 29-year-old railroad repairman from Clinton, Conn., who has been arrested and charged with four rapes and released each time on bail, has been released in an attempted-rape case until a hearing Nov. 16.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In our efforts to revive our economy, jobs must be our most urgent priority and lasting solutions must be our constant and consistent principle.'' - President Reagan. (32:4.)

title: No Headline
description: U.S. GOLFERS LEAD JAPAN

title: A TALE OF TWO DELIS
description: MARIAN BURROS reports on food for The New York Times.

title: PRINCETON, N.J.
description: There is a saying that the Holy Roman Empire was neither holy, nor Roman nor even really an empire - at least not in the sense its unholy predecessor was. It was an important presence, nonetheless, and one that, comprised of many principalities, spread over what now are France, the Low Countries, both Germanies and Austria, as well as parts of Poland, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland and Italy. Inaugurated in 800 A.D. with the crowning of the Frankish Charlemagne, it lasted until the Napoleonic era, although its temporal and spiritual powers had already diminished by the end of the 13th century.

title: Gen. Sidney Kirkman; Key Montgomery Aide
description: Gen. Sir Sidney Kirkman, described by his World War II commander, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, as ''the best artilleryman in the British Army,'' died Friday at the age of 87, his family reported.

title: PROUD PHALANGIST FORCES FEAR LOSS OF POWER
description: Lebanese Christian militiamen who guard mountaintop outposts a few miles east of here say they exchange machinegun fire every few days with Syrian soldiers holding positions on peaks a few hundred yards away.

title: Correction
description: The photographic credits on pages 38 and 39 in the issue of Oct. 24 were transposed. The color photograph of the artificially created hybrid cell was taken by David Scharf. The black-and-white photograph was from Hybritech Inc., San Diego.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
'SQUARED QUARTER' SATIRIZES THE U.S. ECONOMY
description: Bad economic conditions tend to inspire satirical numismatic issues - as when the Hard Times tokens appeared in this country in the late 1830's and early 1840's. Now, the downbeat state of the current United States economy has helped provide the impetus for a new satirical piece: A pseudo-coin described by its creator, New York artist Andor Orand, as the ''Squared Quarter.''

title: THE VOTERS MADE SOME POLLTAKERS LOSERS, TOO
description: LEWIS E. LEHRMAN spent the final days of New York's gubernatorial campaign urging supporters to ignore newspaper polls that had him well behind. The Republican said his surveys indicated he was within three points of victory. The candidate's polls proved correct, but the other surveys may have contributed to their accuracy by depressing campaign workers when their enthusiasm was needed most. Then again, they may have helped Mr. Lehrman by keeping Democrat Mario M. Cuomo's supporters home.

title: HOW'S BUSINESS? IT ALL DEPENDS
description: WOODBURY HOW'S business? Nearly 550 executives with industrial and commercial companies on Long Island will tell you they're holding their own - but they're worried about the guy down the street.

title: Letters; Rent Histories
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS HEARS THE SIREN SONG OF PRAGMATISM
description: WASHINGTON AFTER Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader, narrowly survived a tough race in his Illinois district, he told the crowd at his Tuesday night victory party: ''I've gotten your message, and I'll take it back to the President.''

title: APRIL RUN TRIUMPHS IN D.C. INTERNATIONAL
description: ''It's a nice feeling to have good fillies and see them win big races, especially against colts,'' Bert Firestone said in the winner's circle today at Laurel Race Course.

title: Ex-Mayor Acquitted
description: Former Mayor Eddie Carthan of Tchula, Miss. insisted all along that the deciding vote in his political dispute with Alderman Roosevelt Granderson was not cast by a hired gun. After he was acquitted last week of paying two men to kill Mr. Granderson in 1981, he called it a ''victory for equal treatment under the law.'' Mr. Carthan is black, as was Mr. Granderson, and he asserted that he was tried for murder because he had refused as Mayor to cooperate with ''the white power structure.'' He contended that the testimony of the two witnesses against him was ''purchased'' with a grant of immunity. Mr. Carthan drew the support of some national civil rights figures who believed his assertion that the charges against him were racially motivated.

title: TWO NEW PLAYS THAT FOCUS ON THE MALE LONER
description: David Mamet's ''Edmond,'' at the Provincetown Playhouse, is a play about a man who wants people to care for him and is willing to get plenty rough with anybody who doesn't. John Ford Noonan's ''Some Men Need Help,'' at the 47th Street Theater, is a play about a man who doesn't want anyone to care for him and is willing to get plenty rough with the one fellow who does. I tell you, these people don't know what they want.

title: L.S.U. DEFEATS ALABAMA
description: The football was tucked under his left arm and chances were that Jerry Stovall wasn't going to part with it real soon. Even a hug from an appreciative alumnus and a couple of firm handshakes from the representatives of the Orange and Sugar Bowls couldn't shake it loose. It isn't every year that L.S.U. beats Alabama, and in recent seasons, the Tigers weren't even coming close. So Stovall clutched the football to remind him this wasn't a dream.

title: HOW NOVELS GET TITLES
description: ''MY mind running, like high seas, on names,'' Charles Dickens wrote his friend John Forster in the midst of an anguished quest for a title for ''David Copperfield.'' He went on to subject Forster to a blizzard of possibilities, including ''The Copperfield Disclosures,'' ''The Copperfield Survey of the World as It Rolled'' and ''Copperfield, Complete.''

title: ACT I OF A ZONING DRAMA IN THE THEATER DISTRICT
description: WHEN the Board of Estimate adopted the new midtown zoning resolutionl ast May it also declared a moratorium on the demolition of Broadway t heaters and directed the City Planning Commission to produce a c omprehensive plan to protect them against redevelopment pressures.

title: Nursery for Bugs
description: The strategy called for pitting insect against insect - enlisting ''good'' types to attack those that kill crops and wreak other environmental havoc. As part of the plan, the New Jersey Department of Agriculture said last March that it would build a $3 million Beneficial Insect Rearing Laboratory.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 6 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 10 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 3 10 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 4 4 11 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 6 7 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic romance survives the stresses and strains of World War II. 6 5 14 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) Four novellas with mainly nonhorror themes by a modern master of horror. 7 7 4 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: fourth volume of s.f. stories in ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 8 11 5 MAX, by Howard Fast.

title: SYRIA'S ASSAD MAY BE RUNNING OUT OF SECURITY BLANKETS
description: When it comes to diplomatic chess, Syrian President Hafez el-Assad has always been considered a grandmaster. He has managed to emerge from 12 years of brutish Syrian politics and two losing wars with Israel with his grip on power as solid as ever. His survivability seems to derive from a finely honed sense of brinksmanship - an ability to take his enemies and allies right to the edge, but never beyond, at every new challenge.

title:
DINING OUT;
TASTE OF SPAIN PREVAILS IN NEWARK
description: RECOMMENDATIONS for restaurants that include the words ''reasonable prices'' and ''enormous portions'' are usually enough to make a reviewer cringe. Experience has shown that, although the portions are indeed enormous, the quality of the food is often unacceptable.

title: Mother Asks Court in Georgia To Enforce Its Custody Order
description: A woman who won a bitter custody fight for her 3-year-old son in the Georgia Supreme Court four months ago has asked the court to enforce its order, contending that ''the integrity of the Georgia judiciary is at stake.''

title: AUCTIONING AWAY HOUSING'S WOES
description: CHICAGO FROM the looks of things it could have been a weekend estate sale, even though it sounded more like a cattle auction: a white-haired, bespectacled auctioneer in a dark blue suit rapidly spewing out streams of five-digit numbers from the ballroom podium of the suburban Sheraton-Naperville Hotel.

title: SOPHISTICATED FOOD IN CAFE SETTING
description: RIDGEFIELD AT first glance, the Food Chandler looks like yet another gourmet takeout shop. Refrigerated glass-fronted cases filled with tempting homemade salads greet you as you enter. In the store's center are jars of special mustards, jams, vinegars, other condiments and culinary temptations. Then, if you wend your way around the labyrinth of display cases you will see two modest groupings of tables, one arranged around the front window and the second in the rear. Blue-andwhite checked tablecloths, fresh flowers in tiny bottles on each table and ice cream parlor-type chairs add to the bistro look.

title: AMERICAN CATHOLICS
description: Andrew Greeley lets the cat out of the bag when he states, ''The American Catholic Church will continue to be a noisy, contentious, disorderly place. No one will mistake it for a a mausoleum.''

title: NEIGHBORS ARE WARY OF PLAN FOR AN ISLAMIC CULTURAL CENTER
description: PURCHASE "It happened very suddenly," a woman in the local library said, shaking her head in consternation.

title: PENN SURPRISES COLGATE
description: Tim Chambers's third interception of the game set up Pennsylvania's winning touchdown in the fourth quarter today, and the Quakers held on to defeat Colgate, 21-13, in the first football game between the two universities.

title: THE BATTLE FOR NORTH AFRICA
description: The blacked-out transports and destroyers rocked gently in the Mediterranean as infantrymen clambered down nets and into waiting landing craft. Minutes later, the soldiers scrambled across beaches at Algiers, Oran and Casablanca. Some met the rattle of machine guns right off. Others were first picked up by searchlight beams and then shelled as they made their way inland. A lucky few encountered only darkness and silence. It was the early morning of Nov. 8, 1942. The Allied invasion of French North Africa had begun.

title: ATLANTIC CITY BATTLES VEGAS FOR BOXING-CAPITAL CROWN
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE hotel-casinos in this gambling-oriented resort have made another move to replace Las Vegas as the boxing capital of America. A triple-header set for Nov. 20 is significant in that it will be staged at the city's huge Convention Hall on the Boardwalk and not at one of the hotels, as has been the practice.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION
description: 2 Major Objections To Arts Center

title: AMERICAN CATHOLICS
description: Perhaps, from Andrew Greeley's perspective, priests in the past were ''facing the wall,'' but where I attended mass, they were facing the altar. TED HUMES Phoenix

title: BRINK'S DEFENSE CHALLENGING POLICE ACTIONS AT ROADBLOCK
description: Pretrial hearings in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and triple murder centered this week on attacks on the legality of police actions that led to the seizure of a defendant, Kathy Boudin.

title: SKETCHES OF THE JUDGES ON STATE'S COURT OF APPEALS
description: Lawrence H. Cooke Appointed Chief Judge by Governor Carey on Jan. 2, 1979, succeeding Charles D. Breitel ... Born on Oct. 15, 1914, in Monticello, N.Y., the son of a county court judge ... President of senior classes at both Georgetown University and Albany Law School ... Elected county judge and surrogate of Sullivan County in 1955 and Supreme Court Justice in 1961 ... Named by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller to Appellate Division in 1968 ... Elected to the Court of Appeals in 1974 ... Passion is court administration and hero is the late Arthur Vanderbilt, who as Chief Justice of New Jersey revolutionized court operations in that state ... Considered a centrist on the court ... An active volunteer firefighter for many years.

title: 'Arson' Fire Kills Man At Queens Social Club
description: A 22-year-old man was killed early yesterday in an arson fire at a Queens social club, the police said. Seven other patrons and employees escaped.

title: Klan Rally Held Near Capital
description: Twenty-six members of the Ku Klux Klan held a peaceful rally today at a park near this Washington suburb. The Klansmen, wearing white robes but no hoods, stood silently about 50 yards behind more than 250 helmeted police officers in a parking lot at Lake Needlewood Park.

title: Miss Piper Is Max de La Fuente's Bride
description: Anastasia Piper, daughter of Mrs. Henry B. Hyde of New York and the late Eugene S. Piper, was married yesterday to Max de la Fuente, a career diplomat serving as counselor of the Permanent Mission of Peru to the United Nations. He is the son of Clara P. de la Fuente of Lima, Peru, and the late Max de la Fuente, former Peruvian Ambassador to Canada, Switzerland and Portugal.

title: ON THE MERITS OF 'GOOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: SNOWSHOEING: THE ULTIMATE ESCAPE ROUTE
description: NELSON BRYANT writes the Outdoors column for The New York Times Sports section.

title: BALTIMORE RADIO CALL-IN NETS 91 DRUG ARESTS
description: A radio call-in program planned to gather information on drug dealing drew 250 calls that brought 91 arrests, and the police say that there will probably be more charges.

title: Executive Weds Katherine Carton
description: Katherine Lynch Carton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence A. Carton of Lake Forest, Ill., and Joseph Wilson Hammer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Levering Hammer Jr. of Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest. The Rev. John A. Bellingham performed the ceremony.

title: Tennis Title To Miss Fuchs
description: Top-seeded Jennifer Fuchs of Half Hollow Hills West High School in Suffolk County defeated Alyson Farlow of Harley-Allendale-Columbia of Rochester, 6-3, 6-1, today to win the New York State scholastic girls' tennis championship at the Sundown East club.

title: Motives Vary In a 50-Mile Race
description: A 50-mile race in Central Park attracted 32 runners yesterday, only two of whom were from outside the metropolitan area. One was Don Paul of San Francisco, who was attempting to break a record within the race. The other was Alfonso Ramirez of Sweden, who was attempting to finish in time to catch a flight home.

title: HERE'S THE DATA ON DATA PROCESSING
description: LAURA STEIBEL SESSIONS of Glen Cove was facing a problem. Here she was, employed as a data-processing recruiter in the Jericho offices of the Robert Half of Long Island Inc. employment agency - one of the largest such concerns in the country. And here were beginners calling to ask her and her colleague, Michele Briggs, about entrylevel jobs.

title: HOW NASSAU SPENDS GRANTS
description: THIS month Nassau County will start spending the fourth-largest allocation of Federal community-development bloc-grant funds of any county's in the country.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE HITE REPORT ON MALE SEXUALITY. By Shere Hite. (Ballantine, $4.50.) Shere Hite rewrote portions of her 1981 best seller to produce this shorter version, which includes a new preface. Although her sample population - 7,239 men aged 13 to 97 - is not representative and her findings won't be news to therapists, our reviewer, Roger L. Gould, credited the book with pulverizing any remaining myths about ''normal'' male sexuality. The general reader, he said, might find it ''an eye opener in the tradition of the original reports of Alfred Kinsey.'' (Wardell B. Pomeroy's 1972 biography, DR. KINSEY AND THE INSTITUTE FOR SEX RESEARCH, has now been reissued by Yale University Press at $10.95 in paperback. It's a vivid and informative but not entirely objective portrait of Kinsey by a man who was his closest collaborator for 13 years.)

title: Bouts Between Sexes
description: After the legality of boxing matches between women and men was argued by the American Civil Liberties Union, the five-member board of the California Athletic Commission voted to approve professional boxing matches between the sexes effective immediately. ''We had no recourse but to approve it,'' said Don Fraser, the commission's executive officer.

title: A CHOREOGRAPHER PASSES APPRENTICESHIP
AN ALPINE HIGH AT LAKE PLACID
description: CRAIG R. WHITNEY is the Foreign Editor of The New York Times.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: ON GETTING OUT OF THE AIRPORT AND OTHER TIPS

title: WHY THEY CHOSE 'MODERN'
description: The question of why dancers become dancers is so basic that it is rarely asked. When we see an excellent dancer, there appears a certain inevitability about the course he or she has taken. How could Mikhail Baryshnikov have been anything but a dancer or even the kind of dancer he is, we say - or rather, we do not say it at all, accepting his gifts as part of his destiny.

title:
PAPERBACK TALK;
The Small-Start Syndrome
description: If he'd been able to peer into the future when Simon & Schuster published his book, ''The Road Less Traveled,'' in 1978, M. Scott Peck would have been astonished. Dr. Peck, a psychiatrist who practices in Connecticut, didn't expect much. The book had become what the trade calls an orphan because his editor left the house several months before it came out; its first printing was only 5,000 copies, and it wasn't going to be heavily advertised or publicized.

title: JAPANESE MENU WITH INNOVATIONS
description: BONBORI in Huntington occupies a trim little house on a side street. Small wooden tables are set in a connecting series of rooms on the first floor. One of the rooms is a sunny porch and another has been fitted with a sushi bar. Contrasts of light walls and ark wood with some highlights of Japanese fabric make for an attractively subdued setting.

title: TWIN SHIPS PLUMB THE SOUND
description: PORT JEFFERSON IS Long Island Sound deep enough and free of obstructions for large vessels? The only way to tell is by a painstaking and time-consuming line-dragging process that requires two ships to cruise parallel to each other at a top speed of one knot.

title: PLAY HITS HOME LIKE TRUTH
description: NEW HAVEN ANYONE who thinks contemporary playwrights aren't confronting contemporary and crucial issues ought to look in on Shirley Lauro's ''Open Admissions'' and be duly jolted.

title: OCEAN DUMPING STILL DEBATED
description: The following article is based on reporting by Leo H. Carney and Karen Tortarella and was written by Mr. Carney. SWEDE LOVGREN, a fisherman and dock owner from Point Pleasant Beach, caused something of a stir last weekend when, during a conference on ocean dumping at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, he suddenly rose from the audience.

title: JAPAN'S 'UNKNOWN' ISLANDS
description: BRAD LEITHAUSER, a lawyer who works at the Comparative Law Center in Kyoto, Japan, is the author of ''Hundreds of Fireflies,'' a book of poems (Knopf). John Chapman helped him to prepare this article.

title:
ART;
FOLK ART OF A HIGH ORDER
description: NEWARK AS THE current folk-art exhibition at the Newark Museum proves, there's nothing like starting early in the business of collecting art.

title: A CONVERSION TO THE REAL WORLD
description: WHEN THINGS OF THE SPIRIT COME FIRST Five Early Tales. By Simone de Beauvoir. Translated by Patrick O'Brian. 212 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95

title: No Headline
description: PENN STATE TRIUMPHS BY 54-0

title: AMERICAN JEWS AND ISRAEL
description: I was always sure that Goethe's line ''Im Krieg geboren, im Krieg gefallen,'' (''Born in war, died in war'') would apply to me. Born immediately after World War II, and, like much of my generation, raised on it, I expected to die in combat. I have escaped Goethe's pronouncement, but I fear that as a Jew I am still convinced, deep within me where it may matter most, that I will spend my last days in a camp - defeated, disempowered, unable to protect my family. Though for an American Jew this is anything but a realistic expectation, it remains quite possible for others, and, perhaps for their sake, in 1972 and 1973 I found myself, along with many other Americans, in the Israeli Army. Most of us were there, I believe, in much the same way that the Flying Tigers were in China, that Faulkner joined the Royal Canadian Air Force, and that Americans enlisted in the R.A.F. or fought with the Loyalists in Spain. There was a slight difference, however. We had Auschwitz on our minds.

title: MUCH GOSSIP AND A LITTLE MELANCHOLY
description: LORD BYRON Selected Letters and Journals. Edited by Leslie A. Marchand. 400 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap/Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: 4 Canadian Groups Pledge Closer Cuban Ties
description: Four Canadian nongovernmental organizations today pledged to promote continued technical and scientific collaboration with Cuba and called on the Government in Ottawa to reconsider its suspension of aid to the Cubans.

title: In Darwin's Footsteps
description: Where is it that a cactus grows only on lava where there is no soil? Where is it that a tomato grows from a seed that germinates only after passing through the intestines of a tortoise?

title:
DINING OUT;
GROWTH, CHANGE IN FORMAL SETTING
description: OPEN almost a year, La Petite affaire in Briarcliff Manor certainly answers the need in the midwestern part of the county for an attractive, formal restaurant that serves good food. Judith Losapio, the managing co-owner (her husband, Sergio of Sergio's in Hartsdale owns the other half) has turned the old Villa Pietro into a cheerful place, once touched with a comfortable bourgeois elegance.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
LET'S REESTABLISH PUBLIC EDUCATION AS A PRIORITY
description: THE ''wrongs'' of public education have been counted and recounted ad nauseam until even good teachers are feeling tainted and inadequate. But what about the ''rights''? Aren't the schools doing anything right?

title: TIED TO RIGHT FOR REASONS GONE WRONG
description: In a nation where irony and tragedy abound, El Salvador has abruptly witnessed a striking turn in United States policy. The shift illustrates not only the changing perceptions about El Salvador in the Reagan Administration, but also reflects the limits of American power in this battered country.

title: READY, SET, SPEND: SPRINT TO WHITE HOUSE IS EARLIEST EVER
description: WASHINGTON AMONG the crowds of Democrats celebrating at last week's election night parties in the capital, the signs of the future were unmistakable: ''Mondale '84,'' read some lapel buttons ; ''Kennedy - 1984,'' declared others. Meanwhile, across town at a victory party at the Georgetown home of former Gov. W. Averell Harriman, Senator Ernest F. Hollings paused at curbside to shake a few hands. ''He's working the chauffeurs,'' explained his wife, laughing at her husband's incorrigible politicking.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: IN ONE of the longest-running conservation battles in the history of New Jersey, the Watchung Nature Club, a plaintiff in a Federal suit to prevent the construction of a disputed final link of Interstate 78, has made a public appeal for financial help.

title: LEARNING THEIR LESSONS THROUGH SPORTS
description: RUBBER sneakers slapped against concrete as 150 students rushed up five flights of stairs, intent on beating the 8:30 A.M. bell. At the top, they ran past the green paper sign that identifies the floor as ''the Sports School'', down the hall that is plastered with pictures of athletes, straight to the chart that ranks the school's intramural teams.

title: PAWTUCKET NATIVITY SCENE HELD UNCONSTITUTIONL BY APPEAL COURT
description: A city-built Nativity scene that has been a Christmas tradition for 40 years in downtown Pawtucket, R.I., is unconstitutional and cannot be used again, a Federal court has ruled.

title:
DANCE;
DANCES AND MUSIC OF CLASSICAL JAPAN
description: THE Paramount Center for the Performing Arts in Peekskill will present a rare performance of classical Japanese dance and music today at 3 P.M. with Suzushi Hanayagi and Fusako Yoshida. Part of the Paramount's 11-event international fall festival, this afternoon's performance is sponsored by the Asia Society of New York City. Miss Hanayagi will present dances in the Kabuki style, Miss Yoshida will accompany her and play solo works for the koto.

title: LACK OF MOTIVE FAILS TO DAMPEN THEIR SPIRIT
description: The Interzonal Tournament in Moscow was really over for both Gari Kasparov, a Soviet grandmaster, and Dragoljub Velimirovic, a Yugoslav grandmaster, when they met in the last round. The 19-year-old Kasparov was so far ahead that even a loss could not cost him his first prize; and the 40-year-old Velimirovic was so mired down in the middle of the field that a victory could not earn him a slot in the world championship candidates matches.

title: HOSPITAL PRIX FIXE: THE LOSER IS THE PATIENT
description: To the Editor:

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
SEARCHING FOR AN ANSWER BURIED IN THE PAST
description: A MISTAKE used to be something I made - not something I was. After my aunt told me this surprising and not-altogether-pleasant bit of news, my mother confessed that she had indeed thrown caution to the wind and had trusted her future to luck, which went ahead and betrayed her. One hasty action and nothing is ever the same again.

title: THE TOUGHEST STEP
description: A quick exchange of political fire between Senator Bob Dole and Speaker Tip O'Neill does not augur well for perhaps the most pressing issue facing the new Congress - how to stabilize the Social Security system.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
COMPOSING WITHOUT HEARING THE MUSIC
description: WHEN Dana Richardson of Malverne was little, he recalls, his mother used to put him and his brothers to sleep by singing opera arias. Dana Richardson, now 29 years old, is still hearing music in the family home, some of it on the main floor, where there are two pianos; but a lot of it is in his imagination, in the basement, outside the flow of family traffic.

title: Army Agrees to Settlement
description: The Army has agreed to pay $2.4 million to the families of two Hughes Helicopter test pilots who died in an air collision in 1980, said Marshall Foreman, the lawyer who filed a wrongful death suit on behalf of Patricia L. Groulx, the widow of James W. Groulx, and Linda Ludwig, the widow of John E. Ludwig.

title: No Headline
description: Michigan Beats Illinois, 16-10

title: 4 Burned in Doughnut Shop
description: A cleaning solution apparently mistaken for a doughnut topping caused mouth burns to four people and led to the temporary closing of a Dunkin Donuts shop in this Delaware County town. Leon T. Gonshor, an official of the State Department of Environmental Resources, said Friday that the burns were tentatively traced to apple crumb doughnuts that were found to be contaminated with a caustic cleaner used in the shop. The texture and color of the cleaner closely resembled the crumb topping used on the doughnuts, he said.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLLECTOR'S CHOICE IN RIDGEWOOD
description: RIDGEWOOD HESTER BATEMAN lived 200 years ago, but she might have felt right at home with those of today's feminists making their way in the business world.

title: CRIME
description: Sandra Johnson's first novel, "The Cuppi," was published just about three years ago. It was a neat, well-organized piece of work, but Miss Johnson has clearly learned a great deal since then, for her new book, WALK A WINTER BEACH (Delacorte, $13-95), leaves it far behind. "Walk a Winter Beach" primarily concerns the quest of an honest cop for his wife's killer, so ti can be classified as a police procedural. But it has much more to offer than the routine procedural, what with a moral crisis, a romance, a Mafia element, some unusually well-drawn types and a lot of activity in Montauk, L.I.

title: OFF CAMERA, ON TYPEWRITER
description: ANCHORWOMAN By Jessica Savitch. l9l pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. ''THIS IS JUDY WOODRUFF AT THE WHITE HOUSE'' By Judy Woodruff With Kathleen Maxa. 229 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. $12.95. AM I GETTING PAID FOR THIS? By Betty Rollin. 311 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $14.95.

title: THE DEMOCRATS TRY PROTECTIONISM
description: TRADE was a major issue in many of this year's Congressional races a nd promises to become even more important as the 1984 Presidential e lection approaches.

title: FOR 62'S AND OLDER
description: They will not be completed until 1984, but now is the time to apply for one of the l50 rent-subsidized apartments to be erected for the elderly in Cooper Square. The Jewish Association for Services for the Aged has been named sponsor of the building and its spokesman, Mimi Koren, said thousands of applications are expected.

title: A TRIP TO THE ATTIC STIRS OLD MEMORIES
description: THE pull-down stairs creak and move slightly under my feet. I pause on the top step to accustom myself to the dimness and the feeling of remoteness from the rest of the house. The attic has become a dusty mausoleum of useless old objects, unused new ones, and relics of bygone days. I don't come here often - there's little need.

title: RISE OF A NEWCOMER TO SEAT IN CONGRESS
description: THE closest Congressional race in Connecticut in more than a decade did not truly end until 9 P.M. Wednesday, 25 hours after the polls closed. But when it came, the certification by the Secretary of the State that Bruce A. Morrison, a Democrat, had ousted Lawrence J. DeNardis, the incumbent Republican, appeared to have at least two important effects.

title: NEW CLINIC STUDIES LOSS OF TASTE AND SMELL
description: FARMINGTON SUPPOSE you had lost your sense of smell - what odor sensation would you most miss? Roses in a summer garden? Perfume? Filet mignon broiling on the barbecue?

title: INDOOR SOCCER STARTS A NEW SEASON AS A ONE-LEAGUE SPORT
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League opened its fifth season Friday night with 14 teams, including three participants from the North American Soccer League, which has abandoned the indoor game.

title: Miss Shanahan Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds C. Springborn of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Springborn's daughter, Kimberly Anne Shanahan, to Renaud Callet of Paris and Cap Benat, France. A Dec. 19 wedding is planned.

title: NORTH FORK AT A TURNING POINT?
description: ORIENT PARTICULARLY when a cold front is about to barrel through, bringing an almost unreal clarity to the atmosphere, the sunsets to be seen from the narrow spit of land that is the Island's North Fork take on spectacular proportions. Perhaps it is because of the frame in which the fiery reds and golds are displayed - the contrasting blackness of Long Island Sound, the rocky beaches, the steep bluffs.

title: North Rockland Wins, 21-14
description: North Rockland clinched at least a tie for the P.S.A.L. championship with a 21-14 victory over Suffern on the next-to-last weekend of play.

title: C.W. Post Captures Field Hockey Regional
description: Melinda Smith recorded her second consecutive shutout of the tournament as C.W. Post (15-5) defeated Villanova (8-11), 3-0, in the final of the Eastern Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division II field hockey regional today. The Pioneer goals were scored by Rose Malanaphy, Maria DiCostanzo and Gina Curiale.

title: IN WAKE OF ELECTION, G.O.P OPPORTUNITIES
description: THE Democratic victory in last week's gubernatorial election has opened the way for new Republican opportunities in the county, beginning with the Republican's replacement of County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, now Lieutenant Governor-elect.

title: GIDEON II
description: Until 1963, a state could convict an indigent defendant of a felony and send him to prison even though he had not been defended by a lawyer at trial. Then, in the case of Clarence Earl Gideon, the United States Supreme Court recognized that the right to counsel is essential to a fair trial and that it cannot be constitutionally denied on the basis of poverty.

title: Lebanon Irked by Qaddafi
description: Lebanon has demanded a public apology from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for saying that President Amin Gemayel was ''elected against the will of the people of Lebanon and under Israeli occupation,'' officials said today.

title: HELPING EAST SIDE'S ELDERLY POOR
description: ON the Upper East Side, New York's most affluent neighborhood, t here is a hidden population of more than 7,000 old people who live a t or below the poverty line and feel threatened by rising rents, v aulting land values and developers' dreams.

title: Mexico's Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADERS OF BOTH PARTIES FACING TOUGH CHOICES ON SOCIAL SECURITY PROBLEMS
description: With the elections out of the way, the leaders of Congress are girding themselves for a major legislative debate on Social Security in 1983, one that could lead to increases in the payroll tax and tighter limits on the future growth of benefits.

title: Christmas Tree Trade Booms
description: Growers of Christmas trees say that they are cashing in on a bumper crop this year and that prospects are so good poachers are stealing trees in the fields. One commercial grower, Darryl Rad, said he already had buyers for all the 400,000 trees he will harvest in the next couple of weeks.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Boston Celtics, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel and WHT, 7 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7 P.M) Bucks vs. Seattle SuperSonics, at Milwaukee. With no pro football, CBS got the Bucks to make this an afternoon game and start the network's N.B.A coverage earlier than scheduled. The first CBS game was to have been next Jan. 30 between Los Angeles and Boston. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Inglewood, Calif. This is the first of 12 appearances on cable television for the champion Lakers, featuring Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Magic Johnson. (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) Boxing Bill Costello vs. Willie Rodriguez, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at Municipal Auditorium, Kingston, N.Y. Costello is 24-0, with 17 knockouts. Rodriguez is 28-8; two of his losses were to LeRoy Haley, the World Boxing Council's junior welterweight champion, and Sugar Ray Leonard. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.) Steve Hearon vs. Sanford Ricks, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, and Curtis Parker vs. Rocky Shakespeare, 10 rounds, middleweights, at Americana Great Gorge Resort, McAfee, N.J. Also to be shown is a tape of last Saturday's middleweight title bout between Marvin Hagler, the champion, and Fulgencio Obelmejias. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M. Hockey Islanders vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Philadelphia. Second of a home-and-home series. (Television -Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7 P.M.) Other Events Auto Racing: NASCAR Atlanta 500, at Atlanta International Speedway, (Television - ESPN, 12:30 P.M.) CART Phoenix 150, at Phoenix, International Speedway.

title: RICH BUT 'EMBARASSING' PRIZE
description: IN A scenario reminiscent of the old television series ''The Millionaire,'' seven Princeton University professors have discovered how it feels to answer the knock on the door - or, in this case, the ring of the telephone - and find themselves relieved of many, if not all, of their financial problems for five years.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $127,500 5 Palmer Court *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old colonial; *2*central airconditioning, 2-car garage; taxes $2,610. Edison $115,000 5 Dorset Way *2*6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; *2*full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,122. Metuchen $51,500 162 Newman Street *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old condominium; *2*partially finished basement, monthly charges $75; taxes $670. Milltown $80,000 46 John F. Kennedy Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; *2*finished basement, garage; taxes $1,473. Piscataway $85,000 189 North Randolphville Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath 6-year-old bi-level; *2*family room, 2-car garage; taxes $1,687. Woodbridge $76,000 37 Taras Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old split-level; *2*family room, new roof, basement; taxes $1,411. OTHER AREAS Redding, Conn. $120,750 15 Deerhill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year old raised ranch; *2*two fireplaces, 2.3 acres, taxes $1,960. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $200,000 45 Woodfield Road *2*4-bedroom, 21/2-bath, 54-year-old stone-masonry Dutch colonial; *2*heated pool, greenhouse, cabana, 3/4 acre; taxes $5,465. Baldwin, L.I. $63,000 1353 Harvey Court *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*fireplace in living room, partially finished basement, *2*60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $1,700.

title: THE HERB GARDEN MOVES INDOORS
HOCKEY GAMES TO BE HELD
description: GREENS FARMS AT a time of growing interest in girls' field hockey in Fairfield County, Greens Farms Academy is to offer one of the sport's showpieces next Saturday and Sunday with the United States Field Hockey Association's Northeast Tournament.

title: AT 85, HER BOOK IS BEST MEDICINE
description: HAMPTON BAYS ALTHOUGH in almost 60 years of practicing medicine Emma L. Bellows delivered thousands of babies, looked down a comparable number of throats and made countless house calls, she thought she would like to ''leave something nice after me - something to be remembered by.''

title: A STRONG SEASON FOR TAX-EXEMPTS
description: YIELDS on tax-exempt bonds issued by local governments and a uthorities have fallen, it is true, but forces unique to that marketg ave yields an upward push starting in mid-October that was much g reater than the increase among Treasury or corporate bonds.

title: THE SHOWOFFS
description: It's a question of chic, not security. While it is nice to know that hardly anyone, especially a jewel thief, would mistake such big, showy stuff for the precious reality, the true reason many women are decking out in these fake "gems" is simply that it is glamorous, dress-up fashion.

title: Rorke's Long Runs Lead to a Triumph For Brooks School
description: With Matt Rorke, it's a case of the hometown boy making good by staying in his hometown. The junior tailback scored twice while rushing for 271 yards on 30 carries to lead the Brooks School of North Andover, Mass., to a 28-6 victory over Buckingham Browne & Nichols. He has now rushed for 1,113 yards this season.

title: FURNITURE DESIGN
description: Architects, it seems, are responsible for every major change in modern furniture design, according to Lisa Phillips, organizer of the survey of this subject on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford Friday through Jan. 26.

title: Mark C. Kelly To Wed Kim Daly
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Daly of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Elizabeth Daly, to Mark Carroll Kelly, son of Mrs. Richard McShane Kelly of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kelly.

title: YESTERDAY'S TABOOS ARE TAKEN FOR GRANTED NOW
description: Different times, different standards and practices, at least as far as television's censors are concerned. Arguments continue unabated as to whether television merely reflects society or is a major influence, for better or worse, on social changes. Most likely, it does both to varying degrees. But television itself certainly does change. Consider subjects that were taboo or highly sensitive in the not-too-distant past but today are almost commonplace.

title: DEMOCRATS MAKE INROADS IN G.O.P. BASTION
description: THE Nassau Republican organization and its embattled chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, suffered unexpected defeats in last Tuesday's election that cast doubt on Mr. Margiotta's future as county chairman, according to Democratic and Republican politicians.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY WILL BE CLOSED FOR RESTORATION IN 1984 FOR AS LONG AS A YEAR
description: The Statue of Liberty, which has been greeting travelers on their arrival in New York Harbor for 96 years, will be closed for restoration for as long as a year beginning in 1984.

title: FOR WOMEN: SAFE PLACES TO STAY
description: Bernadine Forney is a model from North Carolina who lives in the Hotel Martha Washington. Amy Larson comes from Wisconsin, is an officer at Security Pacific International Bank and lives in the Webster Apartments on West 34th Street.

title: CANCER CASES WORRY BELLEVILLE
description: ALTHOUGH state and local health officials have concluded that 11 cancer deaths among municipal employees here were coincidental, investigators representing the state's Department of Health say they will continue to look for a possible environmental link.

title: Arthur Comstock Romaine To Wed Deborah Vaughan
description: Deborah Vaughan, an assistant with the Williams Real Estate Company in New York, and Arthur Comstock Romaine, a vice president of Webster Management, a Kidder Peabody & Company division in New York, plan to be married Dec. 18.

title: VENTURE CAPITAL LURES OLD-LINE INVESTMENT BANKS
description: IN the days of America's industrial empire building, bankers such asJ ames Stillman and Andrew Mellon poured millions of dollars, a lot ofi t their own, into railroads and steel mills, smelters and oil r efineries. The risks were substantial, but so were the eventual r ewards.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE There is almost an embarrassment of riches this week in dance. To start, two European companies will make their American debuts in New York. The Cullberg Ballet's founder, Birgit Cullberg, is familiar to dancegoers here because of her ''Miss Julie.'' The much-performed classic of modern dramatic ballet will be seen on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, along with Miss Cullberg's ''Adam and Eve'' and ''Soweto-South Africa'' by Mats Ek, her son. The company opens its seven-performance season on Tuesday with a ''modern version'' of ''Giselle.'' Is the world ready?

title: GUITAR: BREAM DOES BAROQUE AND MODERN
description: Guitarists and guitar aficionados crowded into Town Hall on Friday night for the chance to hear the playing of Julian Bream. Mr. Bream responded with a program of substance and the musicality and technique needed to make it work.

title: No Headline
description: American Catholics are not (at least not all of us) still listening docilely to what our pastors dish out.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
COMMUNICATING WITH A CONCERTO
description: IN stating his musical preferences, Benjamin Lees is not ambiguous. ''I want a composer who communicates,'' he says, ''not one who plays cerebral games.''

title: A NEW HALL IS OPENING
description: KING DAVID, according to the poet Stephen Vincent Benet, ''worshipped the Lord in a tuneful carol,'' thereby anticipating the twin purposes of the new Sommer Center for Worship and the Performing Arts, which opens today on the Bronxville campus of Concordia College.

title: TO SAVE ON HEAT, KEEP RADIATORS CLEAN AND UNOBSTRUCTED
description: IN homes and apartments that are heated by hot water or steam, the heat is generated by a centrally located boiler in the basement or utility room, but it is the radiators scattered throughout the house that actually deliver this heat to the various rooms. Anything that interferes with the efficient dispersal of heat from all the radiators not only keeps that room from getting as warm as it should, but it can also waste a considerable amount of energy and thus make already high fuel bills climb even higher during the winter months.

title: THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE UNDER STRESS
description: IT'S a world that seems like paradise. There's the fat salary. The shower of perks. The art-filled office. The sleek limousines. The jets. The p restige. The power. Musing about its glittery trappings, a former i nhabitant once remarked, ''They sort of handle you like a precious e gg.''

title: PIONEER PILOT MARKS 55TH YEAR IN THE AIR
description: LAKEVILLE THE scrapbooks of newspaper clippings and old photographs that are kept in the library of a Lakeville home tell the life story of Nancy Hopkins Tier. They show a deeply tanned young woman with a boyish haircut, wearing a close-fitting leather helmet and a happy, confident smile. ''Niece of Lady Astor Places Fourth in Dixie Derby,'' reads the headline of one clipping. ''Aviatrix Escapes Death,'' proclaims another.

title: RIGHTS GROUP TELLS OF DEAD JOURNALISTS
description: A report by Amnesty International points out one of the hidden dangers of being a journalist. The report from the human rights organization, which is based in London and campaigns in support of political prisoners, lists 298 writers, journalists and other workers in newsgathering who have been killed or jailed by government agents or disappeared over the last decade. The list includes 17 journalists killed or jailed this year.

title: DANCE: A REMY CHARLIP DESIGN
description: In addition to being a dancer and choreographer, Remy Charlip is an artist and writer, and his experience in various art forms was evident in Remy Charlip Dances, his delightful Thursday night program at Performance Space 122. As a choreographer, he possessed a prose stylist's concern for a well-turned phrase and a draftsman's love of fine line.

title: RENTERS WIN ROUND IN COURT OVER BIG HAWAII LANDOWNER
description: A jury has told more than 250 lessees on part of the $1.9 billion Bishop Estate in east Oahu that they will have to pay a total of $2.5 million if they want to acquire the house lots on which they live.

title: IN LEAN TIMES, BAUBLES AND BANGLES LURE BUYERS
description: AFEW weeks ago, Jeff Kass, a 33-year-old biologist, was lured into b uying his first home, a new $55,000, two-bedroom condominium at S ociety Hill North in New Brunswick, N.J., with the promise of a freem icrowave oven, worth approximately $450, and $1,000 in credit t oward any major appliance or other option, such as finer carpeting.

title: 'GREEN VOTE' CITED AS FACTOR IN RACES
description: The environmental movement succeeded beyond its expectations in the elections, contributing to the victories of dozens of candidates and particularly those it regards as House and Senate leaders on environmental issues.

title: OLD HOSPITAL FILLS MODERN-DAY ROLE
description: ONE of New Jersey's most depressed cities is home base for one of the state's most sophisticated emergency life-saving systems. Operating from West Jersey Hospital here, a Mobile Intensive Care Unit, whose core is a computer, can send one of its four specially equipped vans to the aid of, say, a heart-attack victim, a diabetic in a coma or someone severely burned.

title: DE LOREAN ANTIQUES ARE SOLD
description: John Z. De Lorean's 18th century French furniture, valued at $108,500 to $152,000, sold for $58,250 when it was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet. Eight of the 18 offerings belonging to the automobile maker, who has been charged with trafficking in cocaine, did not find buyers.

title: LEGAL AID LAWYERS' STRIKE ENTERS 3D WEEK WITH NO TALKS PLANNED
description: A strike by the approximately 570 lawyers of the Legal Aid Society of New York has gone into its third week with no negotiations scheduled between the society and the lawyers' union.

title: LET OUR OLDER WORKERS WORK FEWER HOURS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Sunday, November 7, 1982 International Talks on East-West cooperation with the Soviet Union will be resumed in Madrid by the United States to avoid a rift in the Atlantic alliance. Talks were halted after the crackdown in Poland. (Page 1, Column 6).

title: Chaminade Triumphs In Cross-Country Meet
description: Chaminade established itself yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: MAPLE LEAFS 3, BLUES 3
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Peter Ihnacak scored with 3:35 left to lift Toronto into a tie.

title: PEALE EXHIBIT REFLECTS VERSATILITY OF THE ARTIST
description: Charles Willson Peale, the American portrait painter, naturalist and inventor, filled his life and his museum to the brim with his portraits, artifacts and inventions.

title: 'THE PLAGUE OF POLITICS'
description: The British usually try to make the best of whatever happens, but they are clearly concerned about the growing economic and political instability of the non-Communist world.

title: BRITAIN BY THE BOOKS
description: reviser of Roget's International Thesaurus.

title: TIME PEACES
description: Wright Morris, novelist and photographer, is the author of the recently published ''Photographs and Words.'' Last month, he received the Common Wealth Award for distinguished service to literature.

title: Jury Awards $1,000 to Black Who Sued His School on Bias
description: An all-white jury has awarded a black student $1,000 in his suit charging that school officials sanctioned discrimination by allowing white students to wear Ku Klux Klan costumes to a Halloween assembly.

title: HOW 'FOXFIRE' JOURNEYED TO BROADWAY
U.S. ARTS AGENCY TO AID SMALL ORGANIZATIONS
description: The National Council on the Arts has approved a one-year pilot program calling for $1 million to $2 million in Federal grants to be given to small, community-based arts organizations instead of funneling most funds through state councils, as is now the case.

title: FRED ZINNEMANN DISTILLS A NEW FILM FROM AN OLD DREAM
Deirdre Goadby Loew, Bank Officer, And William Guenther Are Married
description: The marriage of Deirdre Goadby Loew, an assistant secretary with the Soviet and East European section of the Chemical Bank, to William Henderson Guenther, deputy director of operationsadministration for Newsweek magazine, took place yesterday in Whitemarsh, Pa. The Rev. Richard Hawkins performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: COLONIAL COMFORT IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: The physical reminders of the American colonial period in Asia are unremarkable, some lovely parks and a few war memorials. But then there is the Manila Hotel, a green-roofed, white edifice resembling a California mission that sits on the curve of Manila Bay.

title: ON THE MERITS OF 'GOOD'
description: To the Editor:$

title: SALUTE TO A WRITER
description: The membership of the World Bridge Federation now totals 83 countries, perhaps greater than any comparable organization. Much of the credit for the expansion in recent years must go to the President, Jaime Ortiz-Patino of Switzerland, who is intelligent, dedicated and determined. His promotional tours of the People's Republic of China and Eastern Europe have attracted much attention, but one of his most skillful plays was unobtrusive: To recruit as his Executive Assistant one of the world's best bridge writers - Albert Dormer of England.

title: THE OVAL OFFICE AESOP
description: The election is over, the Republic stands, but how long can democracy stand the type of talk we are drifting into as the nation deliberates the choice of leaders?

title: EXPLORING THE 'WHITE TOWNS' OF SPAIN
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of the humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: IRANIAN OFFICERS, SEEKING REVENGE, TALK OF PURSUING ARMY INTO IRAQ
description: With most Iraqi forces having been driven back across the border this week, some Iranian officers said today they were eager to press on into Iraq, just a mile west of this devastated village.

title: Bag With $350,000 in Jewelry Reportedly Stolen at Waldorf
description: A Brazilian art dealer told the police that a bag with $350,000 in jewelry had been stolen from him in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 30. The police said they were investigating the reported theft.

title: Unbeaten L.I.U. Downs Fairleigh in Soccer, 5-3
description: Albert Nah scored two goals, including the game-winner with less than eight minutes remaining, as undefeated Long Island University beat Fairleigh Dickenson-Teaneck, 5-3, in a Metropolitan Conference soccer game yesterday at the winner's field in Brooklyn.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: Question:My adult daughters and I are going to be in London for Christmas this year. What can you suggest for traditional holiday entertainment? (We particularly love music.) Also, where might we go for an elegant Christmas dinner? - W.K.C., San Pedro, Calif. Answer:Among traditional holiday entertainments in London are pantomimes. ''Cinderella,'' for example, is scheduled for at least three theaters thus far: the Lewisham Concert Hall (Rushey Green, Catford SE6; Dec. 27 through Jan. 29), Richmond Theatre (The Green, Richmond; Dec. 17 through Jan. 29) and the Tower Theatre (Canonbury Place N1; Dec. 17 through Jan. 8).

title: LAUTENBERG'S CALCULATED CAMPAIGN
description: TRENTON FRANK R. LAUTENBERG was one millionaire who didn't waste his money - or the skills with which he earned it - in his running for public office. The 58-year-old Senator-elect, who helped build Automatic Data Processing into a corporate giant by showing clients how to manage information, used some of the same techniques to program his campaign.

title: BIOLOGIST WEIGHS FUTURE OF WATER
description: ''WE'RE going to be hearing much more about water-related issues in the next 10 years,'' Dr. Marjorie Holland, an assistant professor of biology at the College of New Rochelle, said recently. ''I think that's going to be the next big area where people are going to feel the crunch, and I think water rates will have to go up.''

title: NEW LUSTER FOR ESSEX
description: MILLBURN COLLECTORS, interior designers and browsers can welcome the recent opening of the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery in the upbeat business section of this Essex County suburb. (Essex County, incidentally, now has more galleries that carry fine crafts than any other section of the state).

title: Retailers' Fall
description: To the Business Editor: Isadore Barmash told it like it is in ''A Bewildering Fall for Retailers'' (Oct.10). Have you tried to purchase anything in a department store in the last few years? To begin with, there is practically no sales help.

title: Mark Kenyon Marries Carol Jane Gamberg
description: Carol Jane Gamberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Gamberg of New York and Severna Park, Md., and Mark Elmore Kenyon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Kenyon of Houston, were married yesterday at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Annapolis, Md. The Rev. John S. Sivley performed the ceremony.

title: Amy McNicol Engaged to Thomas Harrington Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Campbell A. McNicol of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Elizabeth McNicol, to Thomas Dennis Harrington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrington of Cincinnati. The marriage will take place on Dec. 30 at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington.

title: A DESTRUCTIVE MIDWEST WEED IS INVADING STATE FARM FIELDS
description: A new and destructive weed, wild proso millet, has entered New York State from the Middle West and poses a serious potential threat to farm fields, according to Dr. Russell R. Hahn, a weed expert at the State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences here.

title: McCarter Theater Cites Its Insolvency
description: The article about Clement A. Price, new chairman of the State Council on the Arts (Oct. 24), accurately addressed many of the issues facing the arts community nationally, as well as in New Jersey.

title: Play-by-Play for Dad
description: One of the staunchest fans of the Idaho University football team lives and works in Damman, Saudi Arabia.

title: A RECONSIDERED LOOK AT ADULT EDUCATION
description: ''LIFE is full of untapped sources of pleasure. Education should train us to discover and exploit them.'' That premise of Norman Douglas - along with apple pie and motherhood - is about the most unassailable fact of life in our 50 loosely united states.

title: The Brandywine
description: To the Editor: Seth S. King's article on ''Legacy of the DuPonts'' (Travel, Sept. 9) gave a fine and sprightly account of the historical interest and delights of the Eleutherian Mills/Hagley Museum in the Brandywine area of Delaware. However, it omitted mention of one very important fact about the museum and library complex in that historical spot.

title: STORM OVER WOMEN FIREFIGHTERS
