description: My husband has been a New York City firefighter in Harlem for almost 15 years. I've often seen him come home with red-rimmed eyes and a hacking cough due to the irritation and inhalation of smoke.

title: HISTORY LESSON
description: To The Business Editor: Professor Stigler claims that we know nothing about the attitudes of the lower classes in the past toward laissez-faire capitalism. (He seems to be thinking especialy of 18th century Europe.)

title: Mother and 13-Year-Old Son Are Killed in Fire in Brooklyn
description: A mother and her 13-year-old son were killed early yesterday in a two-alarm fire at their Brooklyn home that also left two firefighters injured, authorities said.

title: Rights Activists Paroled
description: Vote fraud has never been regarded as a particularly heinous crime in Alabama. So there was some consternation among civil rights leaders there and elsewhere in 1979 when Julia Wilder, 70 years old, and Maggie Bozeman, 51, were sentenced to five and four years respectively on charges that they forged 39 absentee ballots.

title: DUCK-EATING SEASON UPON US
description: DUCKS do not depend on the seasons. Domestic ducks raised on farms are available fresh and frozen all year round. But the appetite for duck is something else. When the weather turns cold, the succulent, full-flavored flesh of these well-fatted birds has the most appeal.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. TAKES WIGHTMAN CUP

title: New Packaging Rules Announced
description: With over-the-counter drug sales down and ''copycat'' contaminations rising in the aftermath of Chicago's Tylenol poisonings, the Government and the pharmaceutical industry moved quickly to announce new packaging regulations last week. Tamperresistant protection will be required on almost every nonprescription shelf drug within 15 months from tomorrow.

title: Noise in a Water Circuit Halts Nuclear Plant in Connecticut
description: The Millstone II nuclear power plant automatically shut down Friday because of a signal in the reactor's protective system, a Northeast Utilities spokesman said today.

title: U.S. PLANS TO PUSH LEBANON PULLOUT
description: President Reagan has decided to begin a new, high-level effort to bring about the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Deborah Dunn Is Married to Christopher Gaertner
description: Deborah Marie Dunn and Christopher J. Gaertner were married yesterday at Our Lady of Consolation Roman Catholic Church in Wayne, N.J. by Msgr. Carl Wolsin.

title: Mayor Green Gives Notice
description: This year's epidemic of grand ambitions among big city mayors apparently didn't spread to Pennsylvania. Ed Koch of New York and Tom Bradley of Los Angeles tried to leave their jobs for bigger ones, but William J. Green of Philadelphia said last week that being Mayor was taking too much of his time and he would give it up when his term expires next year.

title: A Correction
description: A recent article in the Long Island Weekly credited Arnold Goldstein as the composer of the song ''Apples Don't Fall Far From the Tree.'' His co-authors were Ted Lehrman, Libby Bush and Audrey Landers.

title: ANOTHER CONFRONTATION LOOMS WITH JAPAN
description: ANOTHER series of trade confrontations with the United States and E urope, on one side, and Japan, on the other, seems imminent as J apan's growing trade surpluses put greater strain on the i nternational trading system.

title: No Headline
description: SOMALIA TO BOYCOTT GATHERING OF O.A.U. IF QADDAFI HEADS IT

title: FLYERS SET BACK ISLANDERS, 6-3
description: The Philadelphia Flyers came to Nassau Coliseum tonight for the first time this season and played as if it were their home ice. They trounced the Islanders, 6-3, with three goals in the final period after having dominated most of the game.

title: TOP SCHOOLS ON THE SLOPES
description: There is no investment that pays off as readily as good, professional ski instruction. It is a necessary foundation for beginners. Intermediates, stuck at a plateau, can become advanced with proper guidance, and even experts can become better still. In each country where skiing is a major sport, a national ski school federation certifies instructors and has a standard teaching progression. In the United States, the Professional Ski Instructors of America's American Teaching Method (A.T.M.) starts first-time skiers with short skis and no poles. They learn how to stop and steer through simple, slow, linked turns. They graduate to longer skis, begin using poles and make more sophisticated turns at higher speeds.

title: ZINNEMAN OFFERS 5 DAYS ONE SUMMER
description: Alps, chalets, glaciers and hobnailed boots. These are all things about ''Five Days One Summer'' that make much stronger impressions than anything the characters do or say.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ST. MORITZ
description: PAUL LEWIS is a Paris-based correspondent of The Times.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Because Denis Herron, a goalie, suffered a concussion in a 4-4 tie with the New Jersey Devils Thursday night, the Pittsburgh Penguins have called up Roberto Romero from Baltimore of the American Hockey League. Until Herron is recovered, Romero will serve as a backup to Michel Dion. ... Rafael (Bazooka) Limon of Mexico will defend his World Boxing Council super featherweight title against Bobby Chacon of Los Angeles Dec.11 at Sacramento, Calif., in a bout to be televised live by ABC-TV.

title: Anne Marie Wiseman Married to John B. French
description: Anne Marie Wiseman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Wiseman of Andover, Mass., was married there yesterday to John Billings French, son of John French 3d of Bedford, N.Y., and Mrs. S. Wesley Adams of Rutland, Vt. The Rev. James Vitali performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church.

title: REGIONALLY, PARTIES COME OUT EVEN
description: REAGANOMICS and reapportionment inflicted seemingly random casualties among candidates in the tristate region, leaving the balance of power between the parties virtually unchanged.

title: REPUBLICANS AGREE IN LAWSUIT TO AVOID INTIMIDATING VOTERS
description: The national Republican Party and the New Jersey Republican organization have signed a pledge in Federal District Court that they will not allow tactics anywhere in the country that could intimidate Democratic voters.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday on the marriage of Mary Pendergast to David Vladeck gave the occupations of the bridegroom's parents incorrectly. His mother, Mrs. Stephen C. Vladeck of New York, is a labor lawyer and senior partner in the New York law firm of Vladeck, Waldman, Elias & Englehard, formerly known as Vladeck & Elias; the bridegroom's late father was a founder and senior partner.

title: Great Neck South Tops Hewlett for Title
description: Great Neck South defeated Hewlett, 24-6, yesterday for its seventh straight victory and won the Intra-League championship. The loss was the first of the season for Hewlett after six triumphs.

title: SEWAGE DEBATE: CITY VS. ISLAND
description: THE latest skirmish in the long-running dispute over New York City's sewage treatment plants and their effects on Long Island erupted the other day when Representative Norman F. Lent accused the Environmental Protection Agency of relaxing its regulations in a way that would pose a significant pollution threat to the Island's beaches.

title: KLING HELPS CHATHAM BOROUGH WIN
description: Jim Kling, a senior fullback, rushed for 112 yards on 15 carries and scored a touchdown in the second quarter to pace Chatham Borough to a 7-0 victory over Mountain Lakes yesterday in Mountain Lakes.

title: Knoxville Adds It Up
description: Can a city of 183,000 souls pull off a successful world's fair? Officials of Knoxville, Tenn. bet the town's assets they could, and when the fair closed last week they insisted they had.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS ON CONGRESS TO ACT ON THE ECONOMY IN SPECIAL SESSION
description: President Reagan today called on Congressional Democrats and Republicans to deal with the ailing economy in the coming special session, saying, ''Our needs are too great to wait until next year.''

title: No Headline
description: DEVILS PLAY 1-1 DEADLOCK

title: 'OLD HOME WEEK' FOR BALLET MISTRESS
description: WHEN the Ohio Ballet pulls into Hempstead on Friday for a three-day stand, it will be like old home week for at least one member of the troupe: Brenda Steady, the ballet mistress.

title: 90 AND STILL A FAN
description: Dorothy Thomas, who was born in China 90 years ago, has survived the Boxer Rebellion, the San Francisco earthquake and service with the United States Intelligence in the Russian Revolution. Yesterday, she was in her customary box at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
SHOREHAM: 'NO' TO INTERIM LICENSING
description: POWER experiment is about to begin in this country, and Long Island could be the first test site. In 1981, the House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly for legislation authorizing a new kind of ''low-level'' nuclear power plant operating license called ''interim'' license - a temporary license for nuclear reactors. The legislation was sent to conference and the final version, already passed by the Senate, is expected to be voted on and passed by the House after the October recess. I have been the only member of the Long Island delegation to oppose this legislation from its inception.

title: Kathleen Ahearne To Become Bride Of W.C. Moyers
description: Kathleen Connolly Ahearne, an artist, and William Cope Moyers, a reporter for The Dallas Times Herald, plan to be married Nov. 27. The future bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allan J. Ahearne of Garden City, L.I., who have announced her engagement to the son of Bill D. Moyers, the broadcast journalist, and Mrs. Moyers, also of Garden City.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss Lawsuits in Missile Case
description: A Federal district judge has denied several motions asking for dismissal of the remaining damage claims resulting from a Titan II missile accident near Rock, Kan., in 1978.

title: C.I.A. SAYS 4 MILLION IN SOVIET ARE DOING PENAL LABOR
description: The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that 4 million people in the Soviet Union are being compelled to undertake some kind of ''forced labor.'' Of that number, 10,000 are said to be political prisoners.

title: 17 YEARS OF IDEOLOGICAL ATTACK ON A CULTURAL TARGET
description: Jerzy Kosinski, the author of 10 books, one a National Book Award winner, another made into a succesful movie, has become a man defined by rumors. They shadow him; they envelop him; they say he is a fraud. The most insidious suggest he doesn't write his own books and that he serves the C.I.A. The contradiction is that Mr. Kosinski is a public person, a constant guest on television, a featured actor in the movie ''Reds,'' the subject of scholarly dissertations. His life has been examined many times. Still, the rumors persist.

title: Lisa Stone to Be Wed To Charles Berman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Stone of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Ann Stone, to Charles Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Jerome Berman of Lawrence, L.I. The wedding is planned for Dec. 5.

title: THE POPE AND POLITICS
description: Pope John Paul II has strayed far from his religious purview in meeting with Yasir Arafat, who is head of an organization, not a head of state. I was informed, in writing, by the Pontiff's Secretary of State that such meetings are not Vatican policy when I requested a similar audience with the Pope to discuss with him precisely the same issue - that of Middle East refugees.

title: Jack Westland Dead; Lawmaker and Golfer
description: Jack Westland, a Republican who served six terms as Representative from the State of Washington's Second District from 1952 to 1964, died here Wednesday. He was 77 years old.

title: Gen. Edwin A. Pollock, A Retired Marine Hero
description: Gen. Edwin A. Pollock of the Marines, a World War II hero at Guadalcanal, died Friday at the Medical University of South Carolina Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Weinberger Sees Australian
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met here today with the Australian Defense Minister, Ian Sinclair, to discuss cooperation in what the United States and Australia view as a Soviet military buildup in the Pacific. ''The Soviet threat can only be described as very large and growing very rapidly and becoming increasingly dangerous,'' Mr. Weinberger said in a speech later at the National Press Club.

title:
REDRAWING THE LINE BETWEEN BANKERS AND BROKERS;
KEEPING THE DISTINCTION
description: NOT since 1933, when Congress passed the Glass-Steagall Act, has thed ebate over the merits of separating commercial banking and i nvestment banking been so contentious. Many, and not just commercialb ankers, are arguing that this separation is no longer needed, that w inners in the financial system should be determined by letting all i nstitutions ''compete'' on a ''level playing field.'' On the s urface, this idea is appealing. But one fact remains: Banks and b rokers still serve distinctly different functions. Perhaps G lass-Steagall should be modified, but the reasons for this s eparation remain valid today.

title: GEORGIA ROLLS, 44-0
description: Herschel Walker had his best game of this season today as he scored three touchdowns, rushed for 219 yards, broke three more records and led undefeated Georgia to an unexpectedly easy 44-0 victory over Florida.

title: POPE URGES BASQUE YOUTHS TO AVOID THE VIOLENT PATH
description: Pope John Paul II traveled today to the Basque region of Spain, where a Marxist separatist organization is conducting a terrorist campaign, and appealed to young Basques to reject violence.

title: Robin F. White Wed in New York
description: The marriage of Robin F. White, daughter of Henry S. White of New York and Westhampton, L.I., and the late Elizabeth F. White, to Michael David Owen took place in New York yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Arnold L. Fein performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Burger. Mr. Owen is the son also of the late Sir David Owen, former Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations in charge of economic affairs.

title: An Expired Abatement
description: Question: My J-51 tax abatement expired June 30. I have a fiveapartment brownstone on West 91st Street. When I bought it nine years ago, the building was already rented and had been renovated by someone who converted it from a rooming house. For lease renewals, am I under any restrictions regarding rents that I may charge? And what may I charge if an apartment becomes vacant?... I.M.V., Manhattan Answer:In determining what happens to a building when its J-51 abatement expires, it is necessary to look at the status of each apartment as if the building never had the abatement, according to Howard Malatzky, counsel to the Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance. There are different rules covering different periods, the rules are complex and you must find out which ones apply by researching the original status of the units.

title: BRITIAN ACQUIRES A TASTE FOR BITTER PILLS
description: Last week, with all the spectacle that the 900-year-old monarchy can summon, Queen Elizabeth II stood before Parliament and in eight minutes, delivered her annual speech succinctly setting out the agenda of Her Majesty's Government for the coming legislative year.

title: COLOR POWER FOR THE GAMUT OF EMOTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Merri Uhlfelder to Be Wed In April to Irwin I. Kotcher
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin Uhlfelder of Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Merri H. Uhlfelder, to Irwin I. Kotcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norton J. Kotcher of Valley Stream, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: EVANSTON, ILL., MAY TAX UNIVERSITY STUDENTS
description: The City Council is considering imposing a $120 tax on each of nearly 10,000 students at Northwestern University.

title: 15 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health named 15 food establishments last week that had violated the city's health code. The department also listed 10 restaurants that had been allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and eight that had been closed for failure to do so.

title:
CAMERA;
CREATIVE EFFECTS WITH INSTANT CAMERAS AND FILMS
SIKHS RAISE THE ANTE AT A PERILOUS COST TO INDIA
description: Even in so exotic a land as India, the Sikhs stand out. Their turbans and beards make them instantly recognizable. Their energy and enterprise have thrust them into prominence in many facets of Indian life, where they wield influence far greater than their 2 percent share of the 700,000,000 population might suggest. Their martial temper and reputation as fierce fighters are internationally known. And more than any other group, they have brought about the agricultural revolution that has made India virtually self-sufficient in food.

title: A BREAK IN ROUTINE FOR TEACHERS
description: AS CONVENTIONS go, the gathering of the New Jersey Education Association in Atlantic City Thursday through Saturday has variety, depth and promise.

title: THE SPIRIT OF THE ZUNI PUEBLO
description: ANNA DOOLING is a writer who lives in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: No Headline
description: Certainly, women are equal to men in motivation, but the lack of upper-body strength is a scientific fact and of critical importance in the daily business of firefighting. WILLIAM J. MORRISSEY (Deputy Chief, New York Fire Department, retired), Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Attorney General in Rome
description: Attorney General William French Smith arrived here today on a five-day visit for talks on fighting Mafia drug smuggling to the United States.

title: Boxer Skips Bout
description: Ted Sanders, a middleweight from Los Angeles, failed to appear yesterday for a scheduled 10-round rematch with Alex Ramos in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that was to have been televised nationally as part of NBC's ''Sportsworld'' program. Sanders missed the weigh-in Friday, and after he missed the prefight weigh-in yesterday, the promoters learned he had flown to Los Angeles Friday night.

title: CITY ADDING 3,500 HOTEL ROOMS
description: TRAVEL from abroad has declined and hotel occupancy has slipped, butt he momentum of new hotel construction in Manhattan is continuing as w ork proceeds on seven new or totally reconstructed hotels.

title:
GARDENING;
YEAR-ROUND SUMMER: CITRUS INDOORS
description: COLD nights, chilly days and the passing of daylight time reminds us that winter is not far away. For those of us who enjoy green grass and sunshine to warm our bones, the mere thought of winter brings on depression.

title: FROM THE CECIL B. DEMILLES OF PITTSBURGH: 'CREEPSHOW'
description: LOS ANGELES Nowadays, people build movie empires wherever they can find bricks. Hollywood no longer has a monopoly on Hollywood. Although George Romero and Richard Rubenstein's Laurel is no match for George Lucas's northern California Lucasfilm in either prestige or wealth, ''At least,'' says Mr. Rubinstein, ''we are the Cecil B. DeMilles of Pittsburgh.''

title: Peter McGowan, Sally Jayson Wed
description: Sally Beth Jayson, daughter of Mrs. Edward P. Clarke of Darien, Conn., and Richard N. Jayson of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Michael McGowan, son of Vera L. McGowan of Montauk, L.I., and Joseph T. McGowan of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence M. Horton, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Pierre A. Botton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the ceremony at Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
FOR WILLIAM WEGMAN, SLAPSTICK IS SERIOUS
description: There flourishes today a new kind of modern photography that is as unorthodox in its modernism as the New Wave in painting. Its leading practitioners have turned their backs on everything represented by Cartier-Bresson, Robert Frank and the Museum of Modern Art. They are not even, strictly speaking, photographers at all.

title: Research Dispute Resists an Ending
description: When a cancer researcher paints black spots on white mice, that's fraud and everyone knows it. But for Dr. Mark Sobell and Dr. Linda Sobell, who were recently accused of deceit in their groundbreaking alcoholism studies of the 1970's, the issues have not been quite so clear.

title: West Bank Expansion
description: Israel last week emptied another bucket of cold water on President Reagan's peace formula, starting with his proposed freeze on new Jewish settlements in occupied territory. Israeli officials said five new settlements would be added soon - 20 during the next year - in the West Bank, where 103 settlements with 25,000 Jewish residents have already been established.

title: A CASE FOR LAWRENCE
description: ''Among the major writers of the first half of this century,'' Diana Trilling said, ''D.H. Lawrence is, I think, unique for the ambiguous response he receives from his readers.'' The difficulty with his work, she continued, was in ''separating Lawrence's sheer literary gift, the energy of his communication,'' from what was ''overcharged and excessive even as poetic statement.''

title: BUILDERS FIND SMALL CAN BE BEAUTIFUL
description: IT USED to be that a developer's professional prowess could be j udged by the size of the projects he undertook. These days, however,d evelopers are not only thinking small when planning dwelling-units, b ut they are building smaller projects, usually on small parcels in c ommunities that have already been substantially built up.

title: CHANGE IN COURT SYSTEM IS LIKELY
description: ''LOOK out voters,'' Robert G. Jaekle warned before last Tuesday's election. ''If Question 4 passes, Connecticut taxpayers will end up paying the tab for increased state spending on a new court system and for higher costs of litigation through increased appeals of cases,'' said Mr. Jaekle, a lawyer from Stratford.

title: No Headline
description: CORNELL DEFEATS YALE BY 26-20

title: FRANK STELLA EXHIBITS AT HIS ALMA MATER
description: There are schools that kill, and schools that give life. One of the schools that give life is the Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and one of the things that makes that possible is the presence on campus of one of the best small private picture galleries on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Lunch Program Leaner, Meaner
description: The Federal school lunch program looks decidedly undernourished, a recent study has found, the result in part of deliberate belttightening. ''For years, Government gave schools subsidies to guarantee a nutritious meal a day for all children,'' said Lynn Parker, a nutritionist with the Food Research and Action Center, a nonprofit group that conducted the study.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: FREEPORT THE strip of Brookside Avenue between Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road is miles shorter than 42d Street, but on that strip these fall evenings there has been a definite air evoking ''42nd Street,'' the old movie and the new, modern musical, not 42d Street, the street. Go out there a kid and come back a star! The whole west side of the strip here is occupied by Freeport High School, the performing home of the Freeport Community Chorale. The number 42 is practically cabalistic. The chorale is entering its 42d season by preparing its production of ''My Fair Lady.''

title: WHY PEACE SITES?
description: IN THE winter of my life, my main concern has been how to keep my feet warm. But shortly after retiring in mid-1980, I realized that there were larger issues than my feet.

title: Barry Steiner to Wed Susan P. Underwood
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Underwood of Cranbury, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Patricia Underwood, to Barry John Steiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Steiner of Bakersfield, Calif. and Deer River, Minn. A late January wedding is planned.

title: Man Beaten and 3 Shot In Danbury Crime Spree
description: One man was arrested and another was being sought today in a crime spree here in which a 76-year-old man was severely beaten and three other persons were shot, the police said.

title: FIELD HOCKEY SHOWCASE ON TAP
description: MANY of the county's top female players will be seen in action next Saturday and Sunday as the Stuyvesant Association plays host to the United States Field Hockey Association's Northeast Tournament at Greens Farms, Conn.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY
description: One would not expect a chamber group called Music Today to begin a program with music from the 17th century. However, Gerard Schwarz's ensemble did just that Wednesday at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: TURKS VOTE TODAY ON MUCH-CRITICIZED NEW CHARTER
description: Despite the likelihood that a constitution proposed by Turkey's military Government will be approved in a referendum Sunday, there is a strong current of opposition to it and some officials believe that a substantial negative vote could be a serious blow to the ruling junta.

title: Debra Freedman and Andrew Sidman to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Freedman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Michele Freedman, to Andrew William Sidman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sidman of Bethpage, L.I. The wedding will take place next month.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WE MUST NOT FORGET THOSE WHO SERVED
description: waving, now that Bicentennial enthusiasm has waned, is unfashionable in some circles.

title: PHOBICS FIND AID IN GROUP THERAPY
description: ''SOME days, I can actually do it. I can pick out something at the supermarket and stand on line at the checkout. Other times, I just can't. I get dizzy, my vision blurs and I have to make a beeline for the nearest exit.''

title: RETAILERS' FALL
description: To the Business Editor: I believe the No.1 problem facing retailers today is the lack of trained professional sales people. There are two basic ingredients to be found in a good salesman - enthusiasm and product knowledge.

title: AFTER THE VOTING, A HARD LOOK AT THE RESULTS
description: HARTFORD THE lawn signs are gone and the bumper stickers have lost their meaning. But the results of last Tuesday's election endure, to mock the skills of the opinion pollsters, provide fodder for discussions of political trends and, of course, determine who will govern for the next few years.

title: SELF-INTEREST CRUCIAL TO THE PUBLIC INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Murder
description: He sold insurance, taught Sunday school and was, in the words of his pastor, ''the last person to hurt a flea.'' But a month after he left town unexpectedly, five members of his family - his mother, wife and three teen-aged children - were found shot to death in the family home in Westfield, N.J. In December 1971 the police put out an international alert for the mild-mannered man, John Emil List.

title: SECAUCUS SEEKS BERGEN TIE
description: NOT too long ago, this Hudson County community was best known for its pig farms - more than 50 of them in their heyday. Its most famous farmer, Henry Krajewski, twice ran for President as an independent populist who would fight for farmers' rights.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: New, Improved Pimpernel?

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: GOVERNMENT PRINTING OFFICE LAUDS ITS 'BEST SELLERS' IN ADS
description: The Government Printing Office has begun an advertising campaign to increase sales of Government publications and reverse a trend of budget deficits.

title: YUGOSLAVS FEEL THE PINCH OF ECONOMIC CURBS
description: Food shortages abound, the national airline has cut many flights for lack of fuel, gasoline is rationed, foreign travel has been sharply curbed and Government officials have given up riding around in limousines. All are elements of what the Yugoslavs call their current economic crisis.

title: Killing in Spain Mars Papal Tour, Increases Jitters
description: Supporters of democracy have always looked nervously at the First Armored Division stationed just north of Madrid as the possible spearhead of a coup. Last week, they were edgier than ever as the division commander, Maj. Gen. Victor Lago Roman, was killed by two men on a motorcycle who machine-gunned his car in the middle of early morning traffic.

title: A 'SHIPYARD' IN HIS BASEMENT
description: REPRESENTATIVES of North Shore University Hospital will be going into the North Hempstead Town Hall in Manhasset on Tuesday morning with two separate requests for the Town Board.

title: Powerboat Racer Likes Rough Going
description: Unlike most mariners, when Jerry Jacoby heads for sea, he prays for rough weather. Jacoby, the United States and world offshore powerboat champion. is not simply a masochist. He is probably the best rough-water driver in the country, so it's only natural when the breeze is strong and the seas are running high that Jacoby can almost smell success in the salty spray.

title: SAFETY AGENCY OPENS INQUIRY INTO MOTORCYCLE KICKSTANDS
description: The National Highway Safety Traffic Administration has opened an investigation of reported problems with the kickstands on an estimated 600,000 Suzuki motorcycles.

title: Anne Robinson Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Devereux Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Devereux's daughter, Anne Chase Robinson, to Edward J. Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Murphy of Framingham, Mass. Miss Robinson is a daughter also of the late John T. Robinson Jr. A winter wedding is planned.

title: KEY KOHL POLICY: BETTER LINKS TO U.S.
description: After a month in office, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has started to fill in the outlines of a foreign policy that puts considerable stress on improving relations with the United States but without sacrificing West German national interests.

title: A GALACTIC HOLIDAY
description: L.R. Shannon is an editor in the Travel section of The New York Times. Russell Baker is on vacation. With the neodollar continuing to strengthen against the galactic pound, there is little reason to confine yourself to a mundane vacation in Paris, Ulan Bator or the Vineyard. Imagine your best friend's surprise when, apropos of nothing, he slips in a remark about ''that quaint spot on Via Veneto'' and you riposte with ''the incredibly deep green sky, you know, in Saturn's middle rings.''

title: DANCE-FILM SERIES TO BENEFIT DANSPACE
description: The Danspace Project at St. Marks Church will present a benefit dance-film series with panel discussions Nov. 23 and 30 and Dec. 7 and 14.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OLD UTENSILS REVIVE A HOMEY PAST
description: FAIRFIELD IT is not mere acquisitiveness that spurs many today to collect mementos of the American past, nor is it even the comforting thought that the good antique purchased one year will increase in value the next.

title: BASEBALL NEEDS PETE ROZELLE
description: AFTER last Monday's meeting of major league baseball club owners at which Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was granted nine months to conduct a search for his own successor, Ted Turner, the always noisy and often perceptive owner of the Atlanta Braves, was thinking out loud, wishfully but well.

title: SURREALISM IN EXHIBIT AT NEW BRITIAN MUSEUM
description: NEW BRITAIN THE permanent collection at the New Britain Museum of American Art (56 Lexington Street) is about 4,000 pieces strong and it stretches all the way from an unknown colonial portraitist to the very wellknown contemporary sophisticate, Ed Ruscha.

title: STAYING POWER
description: Mother and grandmother remember them: those lipsticks in vivid shades of red, blue-red and orange that would neither wipe nor kiss away. Now, with improved for-mulations, new versions of the classic longlasting lipsticks are in vogue again.

title: HOW SHOULD THE PUBLIC REACT TO A FIASCO?
description: The great Carlo Bini brouhaha has begun to recede into legend, and it is not my intention here once again to vilify or glorify that Italian tenorial journeyman. Just what went on at the Met on the fateful night of Oct. 13 - when Mr. Bini came acropper as a secondact substitute for Placido Domingo in ''La Gioconda'' and was almost booed off the stage - will probably never be known completely to anyone involved, and certainly not to those of us who had the fortune or misfortune not to be there.

title: LATE FLAMES' GOAL TIES RANGERS, 2-2
description: The Rangers were a minute and 22 seconds away from winning for only the second time on the road this season, when Calgary's Paul Reinhart scored to lift the Flames into a 2-2 tie tonight.

title: THE WINDMILL THAT WENT TO COLLEGE
description: SOUTHAMPTON YEARS ago, during the whaling and clipper-ship era, when ships made ready to round Montauk Point on their way toward Sag Harbor, a welcome sight on land was the Mill Hill Mill of Southampton. And today, as students wend their way toward classes at Southampton College, the ''olde Myll'' serves as a landmark of their beacon of education and knowledge on eastern Long Island.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Most of New York's musical debutants are just that - dewy-eyed young things stepping out timorously into the arena of public and critical judgment. But sometimes a more seasoned artist or group will come along, one that has delayed its New York debut for a number of years.

title: U.S. WEATHER DAMAGE FOR '81 DOWN SHARPLY TO $3.6 BILLION
description: Weather-related damage in the United States totaled $3.6 billion last year, down sharply from 1980 when it was almost seven times higher, according to a Government climate analysis.

title: A MARKET RALLY BUILT ON DOUBTS
description: A simple truth often forgotten in the frenzy of a bull market is t hat for every share of stock bought, a share is sold. In the stock m arket's surge over the past two months or so, the institutions have d one the buying and the small investors, by and large, have done the s elling.

title: LATIN AMERICA'S NEW GOSPEL
description: The green canvas roof of the Christian Church of the Word filtered the morning light of Guatemala City, and the little group - Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, his demure wife, Maria Teresa, and the American church elder, Dick Funnell - was merely part of the regular crowd of worshipers. The general clasped the Bible to his knees and watched with fascination as the visiting preacher from Florida stood on one foot, his arms stretched out, and re-enacted how the Holy Spirit had entered him. It had made him jump across church pews, Erskine Holt yelled in English, and it had almost made him levitate. Shouts of ''Hallelujah'' and ''Praise the Lord'' rippled through the tent, and the congregation embraced.

title: American Catholics
description: In his well-researched article ''American Catholics: Going Their Own Way'' (Oct. 10), the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley states, ''As long as you define yourself as Catholic, no one is going to throw you out of the church or refuse the sacraments to you, regardless of what you do in your bedroom or what reservations you may have on doctrinal matters such as papal authority.'' The statement, of course, is true but it does not make good sense for Roman Catholics to practice it.

title: New Rochelle Captures 7th in Row
description: Undefeated New Rochelle rolled to its seventh victory with an 18-6 triumph over Mount Vernon. Coach Harold Crocker's Hugenots, who clinched the Conference A Division I title last weekend with a 22-6 victory over Mahopac, got two touchdowns from Michael Bartee.

title: DEAN OF COLUMBIA COMMITTED TO COEDUCATION
description: As Columbia College prepares to admit women next fall after 228 years as an all-male institution, its new dean, Robert E. Pollack, says he is optimistic about the change and committed to making the transition to coeducation as painless and profitable as possible.

title: TUMULTUOUS FINALE TO CONTEST OVER RENTS
description: TENANTS in 18 Westchester communities will face the smallest rent increases in six years and the smallest in the New York City area when their leases are renewed, after a long-argued, ferociously debated decision last week by the county's Rent Guidelines Board.

title: Fraser Suspends Role As Director of Chrysler
description: Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, has suspended his membership on the Chrysler Corporation's board of directors until contract disputes in Canada and the United States are settled, a union spokesman said today.

title: Miss Hodgman Becomes a Bride
description: Virginia-Adams Hodgman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fee Hodgman of Greenwich, was married there yesterday to David Ingalls Davison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Endicott Peabody Davison of Lyme, Conn. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church by Canon Wendell Phillips, who also officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FOR EVERY TASTE, THERE'S A CATALOGUE WAITING
description: MY grandmother would have called them Wish Books; now they are more prosaically known as mail-order catalogues. For weeks they have been arriving at our house, five or six at a time, and often in duplicate. They represent businesses all over the country and, indeed, the world, and whether glossy or studiously simple, the message is the same: shopping made easy, in the comfort of your own snug home, safe from the intimidations of pursesnatchers, sullen clerks and parking violations. Starting in August, the catalogues in the daily mail outnumber even the bills.

title: The Koch-Cuomo Letters, Imagined
description: Dear Mario: It's true I said I'd make a better governor than you, but a better governor is not what the state needs. It needs a compassionate, generous, forgiving governor and that's what your friends - including me - know you'll be.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE QUESTIONABLE ECONOMICS OF LOTTERIES
description: BALZAC once noted that ''the gambling passion lurks at the bottom o f every heart.'' Recently, those hearts beat faster as the prize in t he New Jersey State Lottery accumulated to $7.2 million and was e ventually divided among four lucky winners.

title: History Lesson
description: To The Business Editor: In ''The Economist as Preacher'' (Oct. 24), Prof. George J. Stigler makes the point that we know more about history through the educated classes. No doubt they knew how to express themselves.

title: ENOUGH OF KHOMEINI
description: The Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, too, must go. The Khomeini regime - the ''mullahtariat,'' so to speak - is inconsistent with the sweep of Iranian history. The sole realistic alternative is a government dedicated to independence and liberty - that is, to the society's basic need.

title: THE CULLBERG BALLET IS SWEDEN'S CRADLE FOR DANCE
Anthony M. Horvat, Valerie Jacobs to Wed
description: The engagement of Valerie Ann Jacobs to Anthony Mladen Horvat, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vladimir Horvat of Erial, N.J., and Craigleith, Ont., has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Jacobs of Greenwich, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: Comsewogue Triumphs, 38-12, as Austin Excels
description: Jean Austin rushed for 142 yards on 20 carries and scored three touchdowns to lead undefeated Comsewogue (7-0) to a 38-12 non-league victory over Smithtown West. His touchdowns came on a pair of 1-yard plunges and on a 42-yard run. He has rushed for 912 yards and scored 21 touchdowns this season. Bob Nelin passed for touchdowns of 40 and 50 yards to Pete Foglia.

title: A FEW HIGH POINTS GLIMPSED ON THE MIDDLE GROUND
description: All of us who write about films regularly have a tendency to overstate a case, either pro or con. It's unfortunate but it happens. And if we don't overstate it, then the ad writers do, as well as the people who read us and tho se who buy the tickets - they aren't always the same. It's easier to remember a rave or a pan than to consider the mixed review, which Variety, the show business weekly, classifies as ''inconclusive.''

title: AUSTRALIAN TOWN IS SHAKEN BY A RACIAL CLASH
description: A fragile peace between white and aboriginal Australians has been shattered in the small town of Moree in New South Wales near the border of Queensland.

title: TRIESTE HURT BY YUGOSLAVS' TRAVEL STRICTURES
description: Until mid-October this was a city of lively traffic between East and West, but now only an occasional car appears at the border to give immigration and customs officials something to do.

title: HELP FOR EX-WAR PRISONERS IS PUSHED
description: SOME still awaken in the middle of the night and smell cordite; some, remembering the barbed wire and prowling searchlights of the sentry towers, claw at bedsheets.

title: BY MARGOT SLADE
description: MARGOT SLADE is an editor of The New York Times Week in Review.

title: A GIFT AT 9 PRODUCES A BUDDING NET STAR
description: RIDGEWOOD AGIFT of a $3.98 tennis racquet to Grace Kim from her parents on her ninth birthday has led, five years later, to a career in the sport.

title: Salzburg
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BECOMING A HEROINE Reading About Women in Novels. By Rachel M. Brownstein. 332 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $17.95.

title: REAGAN REDUCED
description: The pendulum swung back toward the center last week. Voters gave Democrats important gains in Congress and the statehouses, which with victories by women and minorities, seemed to add up to a call for adjustments by the Administration. HOW WHO VOTED

title: THE DRIVE IS ON TO CHANGE THE RULES
description: WASHINGTON FIREFIGHTING in Malmo, Sweden, now involves data links with Cleveland, Ohio, 4,000 miles away, where electronic impulses that control the Swedish alarms and fire pumps are stored. In India and Pakistan, engineers feed their designs through data links to engineering companies in Houston or Los Angeles.

title: FREE-AGENT THREAT SPURS BIG CONTRACTS
description: EVEN the Detroit Tigers are doing it. The Tigers, a team that for the most part has shunned the free-agent market, have become part of the developing variation on the free-agent theme. A few days ago they gave two of their front-line players lucrative, long-term contracts to keep them from going into the seventh annual draft that will be held Wednesday at the New York Sheraton Hotel.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE VERY RIGHTNESS OF NOVEMBER
description: IT is the kind of day - rainy, dark and cold - that recalls to mind those memorable opening lines of ''Jane Eyre'': ''There was no possibility of going for a walk that day.'' Anyone who has ever read that page can conjure up the image of the Victorian child hidden in the red-curtained window seat, gazing out at the dreary, rainswept landscape.

title: No Headline
description: HUSKIES STOP U.C.L.A. BY 10-7

title: FOCUS ON RIGHTS
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney, will give the keynote address at the Civil Liberties Union regional legislative conference scheduled from noon to 6 P.M. Friday in Pace University's Moot Court, at 78 North Broadway in White Plains. The event is free to the public.

title: Eugenia Frey to Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter G. Frey 3d of Meridan, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Eugenia Porter Frey, to William Frederick Braasch 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Braasch of Lincoln, Mass.

title: 'CHEATERS' WITH NEW TWISTS
description: FARMINGDALE SOMETIMES a Broadway loser can be transformed into a local theater winner. In 1978, ''Cheaters'' by Michael Jacobs lasted all of a month on Broadway, where it was casually dismissed as a shallow comedy about wife and husband swapping. At the Broadhollow Theater, the producer, Patricia Zaback (the former Patricia Dolce), is reviving the play for the second time in two seasons.

title: Storm Over Women Firefighters
description: As a New York City resident, I read with some alarm Karen Stabiner's article ''The Storm Over Women Firefighters'' (Sept. 26). The old Test 3040 which the New York Fire Department gave its recruits was designed to separate potential firemen from ordinary males who were not fit enough.

title: MX's All in a Row
description: Air Force officials scrambling to get the MX missile off the ground announced two modifications in the ''dense pack'' basing system last week. They said the changes would make the 100 closely spaced missles nearly impervious to Soviet attack, and hoped they would make the MX acceptable to Congress.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DR.BLACKFOOT'S CARNIVAL EXTRAORDINAIRE Written and illustrated by Ron Chatalbash. 31 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $10.95. (Ages 6 to 10)

title: Berlin
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Germany, I would like to add a note to the article ''Through the Wall to East Berlin'' by Richard Kostelanetz (Travel, Sept. 5).

title: SOME FUN, SOME GLOOM
description: CHRISTMAS AT FONTAINE'S By William Kotzwinkle. Illustrations by Joe Servello. 191 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95.SO THE WIND WON'T BLOW IT ALL AWAY, By Richard Brautigan. 131 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $12.95.

title: Susan Tebaldi Married
description: Susan Lynn Tebaldi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Tebaldi of Delray Beach, Fla., and William Stewart Foley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Foley of New York, were married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow, Mass. Msgr. Thomas F. Devine performed the ceremony. Mrs. Foley is a registered nurse at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
'ANDROGYNY IN ART'
description: With its latest exhibition, Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery is exploring the theme of ''Androgyny in Art.'' The show offers examples from Greek mythology and ancient Egypt, through the late 19th- and early 20th-century works of such artists as Picasso, Beardsley and Man Ray, and up to such contemporary artists as Lucas Samaras, Alfonso Ossorio and Nancy Burson. The exhibition opens today with a reception from 2 to 5 P.M., featuring a one-woman performance by Eleanor Antin as ''The King'' at 3 P.M. The display will run through Dec. 19 and can be seen from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Tuesdays; 10 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Wednesdays through Fridays; and 1 to 5 P.M. weekends on the Hempstead campus.INDIAN CULTURE

title: THE VOICE OF THE PEOPLE HAS A LIBERAL INFLECTION
description: AS Americans have become disillusioned with electoral politics as practiced, they have turned increasingly to the device that permits citizens to vote directly on issues - the initiative and referendum. This year not only were ballots crowded with propositions on gun control and the environment. They also became to a significant degree an instrument of popular expression on foreign policy.

title: MEXICAN PURISTS BATTLE THE ALIEN APOSTROPHE
description: Shakey's Pizza is next door to Arthur's Steak House, but neither stands out among the dozens of shops and restaurants along Mexico City's Insurgentes Avenue that announce themselves in English. Nearby, there is also Memela's Pub, Micky's Hamburgers and the Far West Bar.

title: A NEW EFFORT TO END CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE
description: ''CHILD molestation is four times as prevalent as rape and thus is a more serious problem,'' said Gene G. Abel, director of the Sexual Behavior Clinic in Manhattan. For every child-molestation incident reported, there are 10 unreported cases, he added. ''When therapists fail to ask about child molestation, that behavior can remain hidden.''

title: ZIMBABWE PEASENTS GET A SHARE OF THE LAND
description: As revolutions go, the one that is taking place here, in countryside still dominated by brick tobacco barns built by former white owners, has a sluggish and even inconsequential look.

title: WEST IS DOUBTFUL ON U.S. WATER PLAN
description: Declaring that the Reagan Administration was embarking on a bold new program of water development in the arid West, Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced 10 new water projects for the region worth a total of more than $258 million.

title: READY TO LISTEN
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBEL LAWYER SAYS PENTHOUSE RULING AIDS WRITERS
description: A Federal appeals court ruling that an article in Penthouse magazine about the sexual activities of a beauty contestant was not libelous was described yesterday by a leading lawyer in First Amendment law as ''extremely significant.''

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
A PASSING SEASON
description: A PASSING SEASON By Richard Blessing. 201 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $11.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: COMMERCIALS - SOME VIEWERS SEE THEM DIFFERENTLY
A FOSTER-CARE PLAN FOR AGED
description: HOME program for the frail elderly and the permanently disabled has been undertaken by the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains. The project will help place people in private residences instead of the nursing homes to which they would otherwise be relegated. Patients will be drawn from White Plains Hospital Medical Center, St. Agnes Hospital, and Burke, a private nonprofit hospital specializing in rehabilitation for those with disabilities resulting from illness or injury.

title: 2 Top Officials of Church Slain in Hollywood Hills
description: The founder and treasurer of the Church of Naturalism were shot to death today in their expensive, secluded home in Hollywood Hills.

title: SPAIN'S COMMUNIST LEADER QUITS
description: Santiago Carrillo stepped down today as leader of Spain's Communists after his party's rout in elections last month.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CONCERT: 20th CENTURY MASTERPIECES
description: John Nelson's second New York Philharmonic subscription program this season at Avery Fisher Hall has a nice musical unity. It leads off with Ives's ''The Unanswered Question'' and Shostakovich's ''Suite on Verses of Michelangelo Buonarroti.'' These are not just two masterpieces by major 20th-century composers. They also feature proclamatory trumpet writing in a predominantly somber, chordal context.

title: ARIZONA'S BANKING BROTHERS BRANCH INTO CASINOS, HOTELS AND LAND
description: PHOENIX SINCE the time John Driggs was mayor of this desert metropolis a decade ago, he and his younger brother, Gary, have pursued a rather quiet campaign to retain the area's fading history and its oftenthreatened natural beauty.

title: SOLAR SAVINGS
description: Just thinking about all the free heat that a solar greenhouse or sunspace can provide makes the idea of building one on to an existing home tantalizing. But anyone contemplating such an addition also comes up with questions that demand authoritative answers.

title: RIGHTS AT ISSUE IN BEACH-LOT CASE
description: YEAR legal dispute between the Town of East Hampton and a property owner seeking to subdivide his six acres of oceanfront property appears to have ended.

title: Surgical Feat
description: Donna Civitello was learning about machinery as a management trainee for a printing company in Danbury, Conn., when her hair got caught in a saddle-stich binder. When she arrived at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, a spokesman there said, her scalp was torn off.

title: NEW YORK'S COURT OF APPEALS FACES VAST CHANGES AS A NEW ERA BEGINS
description: The New York Court of Appeals, faced with escalating caseloads, cumbersome procedures and the mandatory retirement of five of its seven members in a little more than three years, is entering what leading lawyers and the judges themselves believe could be both the most troublesome and the most promising period in its history.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: In Camelot

title:
ART;
SHOW OF RODIN BREATHES LIFE
description: RODIN is always with us. On a road to Katonah, there is an advertising poster showing a cartoonish and outsized rendition of Rodin's ''Thinker.'' Yet as familiar as Rodin's imagery is, encountering a slew of his sculpture in the flesh can be a tonic experience.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH OUR DEFENSE
description: At a late-afternoon meeting at the White House a few months ago, President Reagan, who had just returned from horseback riding at Quantico, turned to me in jest, but with a touch of nostalgia, and asked, ''Isn't there some way we can bring back the horse cavalry?'' My reply was: ''Just wait, Mr. President. We are starting by resurrecting battleships.''

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC The music season is in the midst of its busiest time, and this coming week offers a variety of choices. Julius Baker, soon to retire as the New York Philharmonic's principal flutist after 17 years with the orchestra, will appear in more intimate surroundings Monday when he plays a duo recital with the pianist Grant Johannesen.

title: COLIN MCPHEE - A COMPOSER WHO FELL IN LOVE WITH BALI
PENTAGON AIDES DOUBT FUTURE OF MX PROJECT
description: Defense Department and Air Force officials say the MX missile project is in such deep trouble that only strenuous personal and political appeals by President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger can save it.

title: POWER ELITE LOOKS FOR MORE POWER IN COLLEGE SPORTS
description: IN less than three weeks, Division I basketball, which has perhaps become college athletics' most exciting sport, will begin. For many institutions rich in basketball history, tradition and rivalries, and for many emerging members of Division I, this could be their ''last dance.''

title: THAT ICY TINGLE
description: Tammy Wynette, the country singer, was the star performer at a White House South Lawn barbecue for friendly Congressmen. She belted out her theme song, ''Stand By Your Man,'' with her arm around the President of the United States -demonstrating how to stand by one's man.

title: THE LITTLE JOYS (AND TERRORS) OF FAMILY SKIING
description: PETER BENCHLEY is the author of ''Jaws'' and, most recently, ''The Girl of the Sea of Cortez.'' He is at work on a bemused novel about Washington.

title: To the Showers
description: They may be too old to take the field, but big league owners still know how to play hardball. On a pitch last week that some said was low, they got baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn out. Mr. Kuhn, who agreed to stay on until the end of his second seven-year term in August, said he was ''not happy, but not surprised.''

title: MONEY, GENDER, ORGANIZATION AMONG THE KEYS
description: The 1982 elections had something for everyone - Democrats gaining in the House, Republicans holding their Senate and, for traditionalists, charges of fraud in Illinois vote-counting. The gender gap hurt Republicans and the money gap hurt Democrats. Money sometimes seemed irrelevant; some big spenders lost despite spending millions more than their foes. But it was a key factor in holding down Republican House losses. Forty-two of the Republicans who won squeaked through with 55 percent or less after out-raising their Democratic opponents by more than $500,000 each.

title: THEATER: GEORIGA ENGEL IN COMEDY BY CANADIAN
description: A limp farce, ''Nurse Jane Goes to Hawaii,'' has opened at Theater in the Park, in the New York State Pavilion of Flushing Meadow-Corona Park, in Queens, and one wishes it hadn't.

title: Witkowski's Record Day
description: John Witkowski, the Columbia quarterback, set or tied 14 school and Ivy League records in a 56-41 loss to Dartmouth in an Ivy League game today.

title: FLASHY ELECTRONICS, NOT FLASHY STYLING
description: The car of the future - that sultry, gadget-laden expression of designer's fantasy - is quite a bit different today than in the past. At the automobile shows of the 1950's and 1960's, it was a vision of an exuberant time to come, replete with tail fins, exotic engine, swooping styling and instrument panel that would intimidate an airline pilot. In the era of plenty, it promised more.

title: The Importance Of a Playmaker
description: To the Sports Editor: I found Dave DeBusschere's comments about the Knicks' need for a point guard (''Knicks Hedge on Point Guard,'' The New York Times, Oct. 26) very interesting.

title: DIRECTOR ON STAGE AT THE COACHLIGHT
description: IN American theater it is possible to find costume designers who create sets, and set designers who also create costumes, but there are not many who are also directors. David Guthrie, who is now in his fourth year with the Coachlight Dinner Theater at Warehouse Point, East Windsor, may well be the only one.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds 9 Convictions in Docks Trial
description: An appeals court has upheld the convictions of nine persons charged with conspiring to control the shipping business at ports in Florida, Georgia, Alabama and South Carolina.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Consumer Credit Surge?

title: PLAN WENT AWRY
description: PUBLICLY, state Democratic leaders say they could not be happier about the outcome of the Congressional races last week. ''There's no way I could be close to disappointed,'' said James Maloney, the Democratic state chairman, after the party captured one Republican seat.

title: KATIE MONAHAN REGAINS LEAD FOR U.S.
description: Katie Monahan scrutinized the individual standing for the 99th National Horse Show, noted that a Frenchman, Michel Robert, was leading and said: ''Well, we'll just have to go out and get the lead back.''

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
THE WIZARD OF OZ
description: THE WIZARD OF OZ By L. Frank Baum. Illustrated by Michael Hague. 219 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $18.95. (All Ages)

title:
REDRAWING THE LINE BETWEEN BANKERS AND BROKERS;
LET'S RESTORE FAIR COMPETITION
description: CONGRESS has just enacted major legislation that enhances the a bility of commercial banks and thrift institutions to compete more e ffectively in the delivery of financial services to consumers. H aving just taken a large step, there may be a tendency to relax.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART What should a new museum in Brooklyn mount but - a show about Brooklyn! The new center, in Boylan Hall on Brooklyn College's Flatbush campus, is called the Museum of the Borough of Brooklyn, and its concern is Brooklyn's rich ''visual and cultural history.'' Its first exhibition - in celebration of the centennials of Franklin D. Roosevelt and Fiorello LaGuardia - is ''Brooklyn Themes: Art in the Years of Roosevelt and La Guardia'' (through Dec. 7): paintings, prints and photographs produced by artists during and after the Great Depression.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS BUILD UP STRENGTH
description: Nicaraguan exile groups seeking the overthrow of the Sandinist Government have sharply improved their military performance in the last six months because of stepped-up United States aid, according to Honduran and foreign officials here.

title: A FORGOTTEN CORRESPONDENCE
description: A CACHE of recently discovered letters by a major American artist, Thomas Cole, to his patron and friend, Daniel Wadsworth of Hartford, has inspired long-range plans that include publication of the correspondence, a symposium at Trinity College and a lecture followed by a reception at the Wadsworth Atheneum, all in the fall of 1983.

title: Polish Party Says Strike Poses a 'Serious Threat'
description: The Communist Party's ruling Politburo said today that a planned strike and protests called for Wednesday by leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union posed a ''serious threat'' to national peace.

title: VOLUNTEERS ARE COMING FROM NEW AREAS
description: MARLENE is at midlife and under treatment for depression; Betty is 94 and partially blind; Dale is a district data-services manager with a corporation; Jim is juvenile offender convicted of breaking windows.

title: Seasonal Diversions; Adaptation
description: Why must New York, the incubator of William Marcy Tweed and freewheeling politics, constantly yield to the Second City in the finest arts of counting ballots? Because Chicago is more imaginative, and adaptive to change.

title: MORGAN PACES ROMP BY BERGEN CATHOLIC
description: Mike Morgan, the state's leading scorer, scored four touchdowns to increase his point total to 132 and send Bergen Catholic (7-0) to a 47-6 victory over Teaneck (2-4) in Oradell. Morgan scored on runs of 7 and 9 yards, on a 30-yard pass from Tom DeGasperis and a 49-yard punt return. He has 22 touchdowns this season.

title: WILL ARGUELLO'S PUNCH WORK?
description: WHEN Alexis Arguello stepped into the ring last July against Kevin Rooney, he was concerned about the adequacy of his punch. It was his first fight as a junior welterweight (the 140-pound division) after having held titles in three lower divisions. The punch was adequate; he disposed of Rooney in the first round. But his concern was justified. The road that takes a champion or a challenger in one division to a similar rank in a heavier division is littered with bodies; namely, those unfortunates who didn't have the ''portable punch.''

title: ANTI-SEMITISM
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA PLANS A NEW DRIVE TO LIMIT BIRTH RATE
description: China is planning to begin a new campaign to hold down its birth rate in the wake of its latest census results. The preliminary results reported Oct. 28 disclosed that the mainland population was 1,008,175,288 as of July 1. This was five million more people than expected. Specialists attributed the increase more to previous statistical error than to an upsurge in births.

title: THREE RECALL LIFE AS P.O.W.'S
description: It's the little things in life that stil amke a difference to William P. Dorney of Bergenfield - like sitting down to dinner with his family or stopping at a water fountain for a cool drink.

title:
WOODMERE HOSTEL STIRS RARE CLASH;
WOODMERE
description: IN a rare clash between two closely associated Republican administrations, the Town of Hempstead and the County of Nassau will be on opposite sides when a public hearing is held Tuesday on a controversial proposal to establish a hostel in Woodmere for mentally disabled persons.

title: 500 RADIO CABS ARE CONVERTED TO STREET HAIL DUTY
description: A six-month-old experimental program intended to ease the frustrations of pedestrians seeking taxis has led to the conversion of 500 yellow medallion cabs from full- or part-time radio duty to exclusive street-hail service, according to city officials.

title: KOCH IS ABOLOSHING POSITION OF TRANSIT ADVISER
description: Mayor Koch has decided to abolish the post of special transit adviser when Ross Sandler leaves the job at the end of the year. ''We haven't done it officially, but unofficially it will be abolished,'' said Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. He said Mr. Koch felt the job was no longer necessary, primarily because the Mayor had improved his relations with the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Richard Ravitch, and the president of the Transit Authority, John D. Simpson.

title: NEGOTIATIONS BREAK DOWN
description: Negotiations to end the National Football League players strike collapsed last night under the weight of huge economic differences that still exist between the union and the league's Management Council.

title: WHAT A PRIVATE EYE REALLY SEES
description: NIGHT VISION Confessions of Gil Lewis, Private Eye. By John Sedgwick. Illustrations by Terry Allen. 174 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title:
ART;
A LOOK AT THE OVERLOOKED
description: GREENVALE ONE lasting aspect of the Bicentennial is a continued interest in examining all phases of our cultural heritage. An exhibition at the Moseley Galleries, ''The Discerning Eye: Past Talent Rediscovered,'' takes an extensive plunge into re-examination and attempts to be more than a review of 50 paintings by forgotten or frequently overlooked artists.

title: RECITAL: NINA LELCHUK
description: When the very standard repertory is programmed in a piano recital, the musician faces a most difficult task -to reconvince the listener that remarkable music is being played, to give it a distinct and compelling voice. This Nina Lelchuk did not do Wednesday in her Carnegie Hall recital.

title: AS THE TALKS DRAGGED ON
description: WHEN Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, walked to the lecternf or a recent news conference in the Summit Hotel, he was surrounded b y seven men with size 18-and 19-inch necks.

title: Nordiques 4 North Stars 1
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Marian Stastny scored twice in the second period and his brother Anton added a goal and an assist to power the Quebec victory.

title: ECLIPSE PREDICTED FOR RIGHTIST UNIT
description: The power of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, which mounted negative advertising campaigns against several incumbent members of Congress, may be in eclipse, according to leading political strategists from both major political parties.

title: Duty for the Democrats
description: Tip O'Neill's solution (for Social Security) during the campaign was eliminate Republicans.... Well, eliminating Republicans isn't a solution. - Robert Dole, Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Senator Dole is right on the mark. The Democrats effectively exploited public fears that the ogre in the White House wanted to cut Social Security benefits. Polls suggest that the issue played a large part in the Republican loss of 26 seats in the House. But there is a big difference between effective politics and effective government.

title: ADAMS, WAGNER, LEHMAN AND BAYSIDE ADVANCED
description: Adams, Susan Wagner, Lehman and Bayside, the latter two scoring upsets, were victorious in the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League A Division playoffs.

title: Ian Dengler to Wed Kathlyn Haigney
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Eustace Haigney of Larchmont, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathlyn Haigney, to Ian Cargan Dengler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Dengler of Del Rio, Tex., and Big Arm, Mont.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced that the team would not try to retain Terry For- ster, relief pitcher, who has filed for free agency. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Announced an agreement on a multi-year contract with the outfielder Ruppert Jones.

title: AID FOR PREGNANT GIRLS SET
description: WASHINGTON THE Camden County Department of Health is counting on $420,000 that it will receive soon from the Federal Government to help it deal with the county's problem of teen-age pregnancy.

title: 2 LEADERS VIE FOR POWER IN EL SALVADOR
description: A bitter conflict between two of the most powerful figures in the Salvadoran Government has flared in recent weeks and left American officials increasingly concerned about the stability of the political system here.

title: ARGENTINE JOURNALISTS FEARFUL AS REGIME SHUTS 3 MAGAZINES
description: This week's decision by Argentina's military Government to shut three magazines permanently is part of a growing crackdown on the press, Argentine journalists believe.

title: DANCE: CHEN HSEUH-TUNG ADDS THEATER TECHNIQUES
description: Chen Hseuh-tung is interested in the way modern dance - seasoned with just a dash of traditional theater techniques - can express the legends and religious beliefs of his native China. The choreographer continued his explorations with a charming new dance called ''Journey,'' performed by Chen & Dancers Thursday at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery.

title: CONNECTICUT UNIT WARNED ON BUDGET
description: A bipartisan commission studying Connecticut's fiscal problems was told today that the state's deficit would grow to $919 million over the next five years, unless spending was cut or taxes raised.

title: Premier Is Installed As Cameroon President
description: The President of Cameroon, Ahmadou Ahidjo, stepped down today after 22 years in office, handing over leadership to Prime Minister Paul Biya.

title: GREGORIO TRIAL SET TO OPEN
description: JURY selection in the trial of Mayor John T. Gregorio is scheduled to begin tomorrow in Essex County Superior Court in Newark. The trial follows by less than a week Mr. Gregorio's almost twoto-one victory over a Republican challenger for the mayoral post he has held for 16 years.

title: CAREER NOW FOCUSES ON PRODUCING
description: FOR Ronald Lee, the path from performing to producing seems to have been predestined - along with a 23-year detour into the theater party business. At the age of 10, he had a solo tap dancing spot on Milton Berle's television show. Ten years later, when he was strutting about as one of the Sharks in the original cast of ''West Side Story,'' Ronnie Lee, as he was then billed, realized he ''wasn't going to be Fred Astaire or Gene Kelly. I was not ready to ever settle for anything less than that,'' said Mr. Lee, who lives in a house on a lake in Pound Ridge.

title: WHAT SHE WAS AND WHAT SHE FELT LIKE
description: KATHERINE ANNE PORTER A Life. By Joan Givner. Illustrated. 572 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: THE PLAY 'BASEBALL WIVES'
description: THE baseball season ended more than two weeks ago and tonight a different season will come to an end when the play ''Baseball Wives'' closes at the Harold Clurman Theater in New York.

title: GREECE HALTS NATO EXERCISE
description: The Socialist Government announced today that it had canceled a NATO military exercise scheduled to begin in Greece next week because of disagreement over the location of the maneuvers.

title: Julie Beth Arons Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Arons of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Beth Arons, to Mitchell Louis Stave, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Stave of Fairlawn, N.J. Miss Arons is a senior at Fairleigh Dickinson University, where her fiance is a third year student at the School of Dentistry.

title: Missing Element In N.F.L. Talks
description: To the Sports Editor: In the negotiations concerning division of the ''take'' from professional football, one essential party is absent from the bargaining table. That party is the schools and colleges that have paid so dearly to provide the basic training in sports for those chosen few who make it to the riches of the National Football League.

title: Jean Parker Engaged To Barton Hill Levine
description: Mrs. Malcolm Thomson of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert Parker of Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Rachel Parker, to Barton Hill Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Levine of New York.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Bergen County community of New Milford (population: 16,876) is rapidly becoming New Jersey's version of ''the mouse that roared.'' Its school board is taking on the New Jersey School Boards Association because the local board believes that freedom of speech at public meetings is a right, not a privilege.

title: WHEN DID ART BECOME ART?
description: THE RARE ART TRADITIONS The History of Art Collecting and Its Linked Phenomena Wherever These Have Appeared. By Joseph Alsop. Illustrated. 691 pp. Bollingen Series XXXV, No. 27. New Jersey and New York: Princeton University Press/Harper & Row. $59.95.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: About Everything For the Office

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday on the engagement of Alice Belknap Chrystie to Peter Hunt Wyman identified his mother incorrectly. She is Mrs. Stephen V. R. Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y.

title: THE MILITARIZATION OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: THE NUCLEAR DELUSION Soviet-American Relations in the Atomic Age. By George F. Kennan. 208 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title: TECHNOLOGY BRINGS NEW FILM CREDITS
description: Nowadays the oddest occupations are turning up in the interminably long lists of credits that scroll across movie screens.

title: Madagascar President Is Ahead in Balloting
description: President Didier Ratsiraka took a comfortable lead today in presidential elections in this Indian Ocean island.

title: Agency Shifts at Singer, Officenters, Red Devil
description: A number of account switches spiced the end of the week. David Deutsch Associates has become agency for the United States sewing products division of the Singer Company.

title: Commodities; One Vast Market Emerging
description: THOSE who doubt that the stock, commodities and money markets will soon become one vast marketplace were given still another example of this ongoing process on Friday, when the American Stock Exchange quietly began trading in options on 90-day Treasury bills.

title: IN SARATOGA SPRINGS, A MORTGAGE-RECALL FIGHT
description: The main topic in this normally easygoing resort town, even through the elections last week, has been the recalling of mortgages by the largest local bank, which has led to a campaign of picketing and boycotting by some homeowners.

title: RELEARNING A LESSON ABOUT THE MILITARY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE ARE THE AGENTS?
description: SEVEN weeks ago the Giants were about to play the Green Bay Packers in what looms more and more as the last picture show of this National Football League season. In the hours before that Monday night game, George Young, the Giants' general manager, was peering into the future of the N.F.L. Players Association strike that would begin the next morning.

title: AN 1859 BLACK LITERARY LANDMARK IS UNCOVERED
description: Ignored in its own time, her achievement was overlooked for more than a century. But then last year a Yale professor, browsing through a Manhattan bookstore, happened upon a curious old volume: a novel published in 1859 called ''Our Nig,'' whose title page said it was by an author called ''Our Nig.'' He bought it for $50, and although it was months before he got around to reading it, when he did its significance was clear.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our might and vigilance will cool, I think, the hot heads of some imperialist politicians.'' - Leonid I. Brezhnev. (A1:1.)

title: PANEL PROPOSES RISE IN TOLLS AND SELLING OF TRADE CENTER
description: Bridge and tunnel toll increases and the sale of the World Trade Center are proposed in a draft report on the role of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the financing of mass transit, officials said yesterday.

title: STRIKING PLAYERS HELP AT HOTEL
description: Dan Jiggetts, a 6-foot-5-inch, 270-pound offensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, had never been the object of so much attention. Yesterday Jiggetts, the vice president of the National Football League Players Association, stood behind the lobby bar at the Loews Summit hotel and played bartender.

title: VILLAGE AND WEST POINT BATTLE OVER THE LONG GRAY BOTTOM LINE
description: This peaceful little village is embroiled in an unusual dispute with its largest property owner, the United States Military Academy at West Point, over the cost of educating children of military personnel who live and work at the Academy.

title: NATION'S PRISONER POPULATION ROSE 6.9% IN FIRST HALF OF '82
description: The nation's prison population rose 6.9 percent in the first half of this year, to 394,380 inmates, partly because of new sentencing and parole laws that lengthened jail terms, the Justice Department said today.

title: McDonald's In Dutch Shift
description: There are some new business assignments that bring to the victorious agency more pleasure than the mere size of the billings would justify.

title: Holy Cross Takes Catholic Crown
description: Holy Cross defeated Mount St. Michael, 26-14, yesterday at Flushing Memorial Field to win the City Division championship of the Catholic High Schools Football League with a 5-1-1 record.

title: SHOPS OFFER UNUSUAL WARES TO BENEFIT SOME GOOD CAUSES
description: Shoppers and collectors looking for bargains or unusual items can have a great time this month and in addition help worthy causes. All sorts of things, from a Playbill autographed by Katharine Hepburn to recycled designer jeans, will be sold in locations as disparate as the New York Public Library and the thrift shops of Goodwill Industries.

title: NEW MUSIC: A ZORN FOR 18
description: JOHN ZORN is not the first composer to write sets of instructions for improvisers. But his scores may imply the most intricate musical systems since serialism was in flower.

title: Morocco Sets Terms To Attend O.A.U. Talks
description: King Hassan II of Morocco has said that his country will attend the revived 19th conference of the Organization of African Unity in Tripoli, Libya, this month only if the Western Sahara issue is kept off the agenda.

title: BRIEFING
description: Betting on Reagan

title: PIANO: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG'S BACH
description: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG'S recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night was unusual in several ways. First was the music itself, all by Bach. Bach tailored the Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue, and Goldberg Variations to the limited power and great clarity of the harpsichord, intending these pieces for the intimate audiences and settings of his time. To adapt this sophisticated, often inwardlooking music to the ringing, declamatory sound of a grand piano placed grandly on the stage of a large concert hall - and to do so without distorting Bach's message - posed for Mr. Weissenberg a considerable challenge.

title: Fee for Retrieving Towed Cars Rises
description: The fee for retrieving illegally parked cars towed away by the police will be increased today by $10, to $75.

title: Pavelich, the Quiet Man, Pacing Rangers
description: The player leading the New York Rangers in goal scoring is unsung and little known. Mark Pavelich, who has nine goals, does not talk much, preferring to remain anonymous. ''I don't enjoy speaking in front of people or cameras,'' the 24-year-old center said Saturday night, after the Rangers had played to a 2-2 tie against the Flames and he had scored No. 9.

title: Mother Tells of Costly Reward
description: An unemployed mother of two says the Texas Department of Human Resources has cut off her child support payments for the next four and a half months because she won a $500 reward for helping the police to find a murder suspect.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Devils vs. Washington Capitals, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. The Devils will be seeking their first victory in 10 games.

title: RELEARNING A LESSON ABOUT THE MILITARY
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Lessons
description: In few fields do so many rely so much on the brains of so few as in Soviet studies. You could fit around a card table all the Americans who are bilingual experts on Soviet policy in Africa. Or China. Or anywhere. That point alone makes powerfully plain the wisdom of W. Averell Harriman's gift of $11 million to Columbia University for a new Institute for the Advanced Study of the Soviet Union.

title: OBSCURE MINE UNION STILL RESISTS RIVAL
description: At 120 East Scarritt, in a building identified only as the Springfield Chiropractic Clinic, is the home of an all but forgotten part of American labor history: the Progressive Mine Workers of America, or, as they were once known and are still known to some, the Progies.

title: No Headline
description: BORG DEFEATS MCENROE

title: OFFENSE REVIVED IN IRISH UPSET
