description: A few minutes before his Notre Dame team went on the field to face unbeaten and top-ranked Pittsburgh Saturday afternoon, Coach Gerry Faust called for a meeting in the locker room with the quarterback Blair Kiel. It was nothing major, such as a strategy session. He just wanted to talk.

title: Allison Captures Georgia 500 Race
description: Bobby Allison pulled away in a 10-lap sprint to win the Atlanta Journal 500 Grand National stock car race today.

title: AN AMERICAN DEBT TO ISRAELI FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLIVIA'S NEW LEADER ANNOUNCES HARSH STEPS TO COMBAT RECESSION
description: President Hernan Siles Zuazo has announced sweeping economic measures intended to rescue the nation from a severe recession.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Metropolitan Museum Puts an End to an Oasis

title: GARVEY SEEN SURE TO LEAVE DODGERS
description: Steve Garvey, who has played in 1,107 consecutive games for the Los Angeles Dodgers, will almost surely be with another team next season. The first baseman, 34 years old next month, and the Dodgers were unable to reach agreement on a new contract Saturday night. The club had to sign him by midnight Saturday to keep him from going through the re-entry draft next Wednesday.

title: U.S. Golfers Win
description: The United States won both the team and individual titles today in the first $440,000 United States-Japan men's professional team golf match.

title: Member of a Nazi Group Held in Slaying of Youth
description: A member of a neo-Nazi group has been arrested in the slaying of a teen-ager who had talked to the police about racist literature distributed in three schools.

title: DOUBT ON REAGAN PLAN SPURRED VOTERS, POLLS SHOW
description: Americans who voted last Tuesday had far more doubts about the eventual success of President Reagan's economic program than the public as a whole voiced a few days earlier, according to polls conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: KNOTTY ISSUE FOR CENTRAL BANKS
description: In 1974, during a banking crisis brought on by the collapse of a small West German bank, central bankers met in Switzerland and decided they could provide sufficient assistance to the world's banking system, should the need arise.

title: Environmental Group Assesses Acid Rain Belt
description: A major environmental group says that it will present a report Monday showing ''new dramatic evidence'' that acid rain is capable of damaging more regions of the United States than earlier studies had indicated.

title: Joan Rolland Has Bridal
description: Joan Carol Rolland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Rolland of New York, was married yesterday at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue to Dr. Dennis Penzell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Penzell of Massapequa Park, L.I. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf performed the ceremony.

title: TV REVIEW: BURNS CUTS NEW CAPERS
description: IF you hang around long enough, especially in show business, chances are you will evolve into an ''institution'' or a ''beloved figure.'' George Burns, having reached the age of 86, is both.

title: KNICKS' WOES BEGIN AT GUARD
description: Coach Hubie Brown is rarely quiet on the Knicks' bench. He is almost always calling plays, setting up defenses, guiding his players and interjecting comments such as ''nice pass'' or some other compliment when the Knicks follow his instructions.

title: Rizzo Silent on Details Of Philadelphia Race
description: Frank L. Rizzo said today that he would ''have more to say in a couple of weeks'' about whether he will run for a third term as Mayor, according to The Associated Press.

title: Tricky Art Of Political Spending
description: IF Lewis E. Lehrman's defeat was partly due to his being outspent upstate - as some unhappy members of the Republican gubernatorial candidate's camp believe - then it was a self-inflicted disability.

title: People
description: * Jerry I. Reitman, an executive vice president of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, resigning.

title: Carrie Ross Feldman Bride of D.A. Welch
description: The marriage of Carrie Ross Feldman, a picture researcher and librarian with the picture collection at Time Inc., to Douglas Arnold Welch, a freelance illustrator, took place yesterday at 1A East 77th Street. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: AUSTIN L. RAND, 76, ZOOLOGIST, EXPLORER AND WRITER ON BIRDS
description: Austin Loomer Rand, an explorer and zoologist whose travels contributed many rare animal and plant specimens to the collections at the American Museum of Natural History, died Saturday at Walker Memorial Hospital in Avon Park, Fla. He was 76 years old and had lived in Lake Placid, Fla., since his retirement as chief curator of zoology at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.

title: Social Security Plan Proposed
description: House Majority Leader Jim Wright said today that postponing the retirement age to 68 from 65 would ease the pressure on the financially pressed Social Security Trust Fund, and he said income tax credits could be used as an incentive to persuade workers not to retire.

title: PLAYING GAMES WITH PROTECTIONISM
description: With most companies hunkered down for a long recession, times are tough for the machine tool industry. But that doesn't excuse the attempt of one American toolmaker to seek refuge from Japanese competition in American tax laws.

title: BERNHARD IS BULLISH
description: Founder of Value Line Investment Survey predicts that stocks will excel over next five years, but he likes bonds for next year.

title: CORPORATE EARNINGS
description: NOVAR ELECTRONICS (O) Qtr to Oct 2 1982 1981 Revenue 3,765,571 2,872,370 Net inc 396,415 304,144 Share earns .44 .34 9mo rev 9,935,884 8,337,132 Net inc 1,061,924 915,585 Share earns 1.18 1.21 PARALLEL PETROLEUM Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Revenue 167,773 230,326 Net loss 393,829 14,549 9mo rev 721,614 584,600 Net loss 565,580 23,037 PETROTECH Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Revenue 1,381,095 1,081,184 Net loss 1,158,756 523,602 9mo rev 5,213,863 2,574,701 Net loss 2,468,882 1,365,301 PHOTO CONTROL (O) Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Sales 2,126,755 2,058,387 Net inc 145,612 206,882 Share earns .14 .21 PORTA SYSTEMS (A) Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Sales 5,503,000 4,646,000 Net inc b533,000 540,000 Share earns .20 .20 9mo sales 16,689,000 12,714,000 Net inc b1,492,000 1,040,000 Share earns .55 .38 b-After charges of $591,000 resulting from reclamation of line testing equipment shipped to Mexico National Telephone Co. RLI CORPORATION (N) Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Revenue 7,357,832 6,995,057 Net inc 816,756 820,770 Share earns .45 .45 9mo rev 20,979,946 20,105,608 Net inc 1,992,942 2,177,403 Share earns 1.09 1.19 SEIS PROS (A) Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Revenue 10,099,000 11,250,000 Net inc 593,000 1,894,000 Share earns .15 .50 6mo rev 20,576,000 20,959,000 Net inc 1,572,000 3,574,000 Share earns .40 .98 SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES Qtr to Sept 30 1982 1981 Revenue 2,076,700 2,504,000 Net inc b367,300 c310,100 Share earns .19 .16 Yr rev 12,432,400 12,672,200 Net inc b1,008,400 c94,600 Share earns .52 .05 b-Including a tax loss carryforward of $184,500 for the quarter and $453,800 for the year. c-Including a tax loss carryforward of $25,000 for the quarter and for the year.

title: BAGHDAD CONFIRMS FIERCE FIGHTING
description: Iranian infantry and armor have driven west into Iraq for the first time in more than three months, the Teheran Government reported today. The Baghdad radio confirmed the invasion, which began Saturday night, and said ''intense fighting'' was under way today.

title: STATE RENEWS PUSH FOR GROWTH ON ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: After a seven-year hiatus, New York State is moving forward with a plan for North Town II, the second phase of development on Roosevelt Island.

title: Ties Lift Confidence of Devils
description: The Devils say that they are gradually regaining their form after ending a seven-game losing streak with ties in their last two games.

title: No Headline
description: SABRES WIN, 3 TO 1

title: Explosion of a Grenade In Gaza Kills an Arab
description: One Arab was killed and four others were wounded today in a grenade explosion on the main street in Gaza. Military sources said the grenade had been thrown at an Israeli Army jeep.

title: Climbing To the Top
description: WHAT is the first skill needed for a young man from Brooklyn to become a leading apprentice jockey at Aqueduct? Not mucking out stalls, not walking the horses, certainly not pulling the reins at the right time.

title: HOW THE CITY REWARDS TENANTS' HARD WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Jet Hijacked To Turkish NATO Base
description: Three Soviet citizens, reportedly ethnic Germans, seeking political asylum hijacked a Soviet airliner today, stabbed the pilot and forced the plane to land at a Turkish NATO base where they surrendered, officials said.

title: DANCE: MORRIS TROUPE OFFERS ECLECTIC WORKS
description: BY taking choreographic ideas from here, there and everywhere, Mark Morris reveled in eclecticism at his Mark Morris Dance Group's Saturday night concert at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Obviously, for Mr. Morris, movement is the greatest fun in the world.

title: BALLOONISTS ALOFT ON WORLD FLIGHT
description: Maxie Anderson, the first balloonist to cross the Atlantic Ocean and North America, took off tonight in his third attempt to circle the world in a helium balloon.

title: WEEK'S TREASURY SALES INCLUDE 30-YEAR BONDS
description: Treasury securities scheduled for sale this week range in maturity from the three-month and six-month bills to be auctioned today to the 30-year bonds to be auctioned tomorrow.

title: APRIL TRIAL FOR HITACHI
description: An April 15 trial date has been set by United States District Judge Spencer Williams for the I.B.M.- Hitachi Ltd. industrial espionage case. The Japanese electronics company and 11 of its employees were charged in a Federal indictment last summer with conspiring to send computer data stolen from International Business Machines to Japan.

title: 'EXTRAORDINARY BRUTALITY' IN EAST TIMOR
description: To the Editor:

title: BOWLS DISAPPOINTED BY PITT'S FIRST LOSS
description: The president of the Sugar Bowl and the executive vice president of the Cotton Bowl were shocked when they heard that Pittsburgh had been upset by Notre Dame, 31-16, Saturday. Each had a vested interest in Pitt's continuing success.

title: Arson Arrest Made
description: A man said to have been ejected Saturday from a Jamaica, Queens, social club was arrested yesterday and accused of setting a fire at the club later on Saturday that killed a patron.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Knudsen Corp. said a special committee of directors had rejected as inadequate an offer by Knudsen executives to acquire the company at $18 a share in cash.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Subway Etiquette

title: Guardian Fund Officer Gets a Neuberger Post
description: Kent Simons has been named president of Guardian Mutual Fund Inc., succeeding Roy R. Neuberger, 79, the well-known money manager who created the fund in 1950. Mr. Neuberger will remain the fund's chairman.

title: IRANIANS CHALLENGE OIL LIMITS
description: Mohammad Gharazi, Iran's oil minister, tonight dismissed as a meaningless bluff threats by Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries to stage a showdown over oil prices next month.

title: DANCE: GONZALEZ COMPANY
description: ANNABELLA GONZALEZ approaches the artifacts of everyday life in somewhat the way that Paul Klee looked at machines. The table and beanbag hassock that figured prominently in a concert by the Annabella Gonzalez Dance Theater on Saturday at the Theater of the Open Eye were surely on the odd side to begin with, but Miss Gonzalez realized their potential.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982; Companies
description: Douglas A. Fraser, who is temporarily leaving Chrysler's board until contracts in the United States and Canada have been signed, said he wants to avoid any appearance of conflict of interests because of his leadership of the United Automobile workers. (Page A1.)

title: CONCERN GROWS ON SUPER BOWL
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that the collapse of negotiations between the players and owners had seriously jeopardized the remainder of the regular season and Super Bowl XVII, which is scheduled for Jan. 30 in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Bridge: Game Can Be Easily Made Even if Trump Split Is Bad
description: In normal circumstances a 4-4 trump fit in a major suit is highly desirable. It becomes less so if bidding by the opponents indicates that the suit will break badly. In such circumstances, three no-trump may be a more attractive landing place.

title: OPERA BUFFA: SCHWARTZ CONDUCTS A PERGOLESI AT Y
description: ''I DON'T want to be an artist,'' cried the soprano, ''I want to be a prima donna.'' Two hundred years ago, that sentiment probably went over much as it did Saturday night at the 92d Street Y in the buffa opera ''The Music Master.'' With knowing laughs.

title: Agatha E. Pozen Married to Intern
description: Agatha Elizabeth Pozen, daughter of Elizabeth Klup Pozen and Walter Pozen of Washington, was married there yesterday to Dr. Marc Weigensberg. Julius Hyatt, rabbi emeritus of Temple Agudas Achim in Peoria, Ill., officiated at the ceremony at the Hay Adams Hotel.

title: RIGHT ON
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI Cellular Permits
description: The MCI Communications Corporation plans to apply to the Federal Communications Commission for 18 additional cellular mobile radio franchises before the commission's deadline Monday. MCI had previously filed applications in 12 of the 30 biggest cities. It said Friday it would file for others in Birmingham, Ala.; Sacramento, Calif.; Jacksonville and Orlando, Fla.; Honolulu; Greensboro, N.C.; Akron, Columbus and Dayton, Ohio; Oklahoma City and Tulsa, Okla.; Allentown, Pa.; Memphis and Nashville, Tenn.; San Antonio, Tex.; Salt Lake City, and Norfolk and Richmond, Va.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc. said it intended to exchange up to 1.5 million shares of its common stock for up to $25 million principal amount of its debt securities owned by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Infant Girl Is Improving
description: Jamie Fiske, an 11-month-old girl who received a liver transplant Friday, continues to ''show signs of improvement'' and doctors are ''pleased with her progress,'' a spokesman for University of Minnesota Hospitals said today. Doctors had said that without the transplant, she might have died before her first birthday, Nov. 26.

title: THE U.S. CAN COMPETE
description: A group of leading business executives went to the White House recently to plead with top officials to do something about the enormous undervaluation of the yen relative to the dollar - a distortion that has created huge, rapidly rising American trade deficits with Japan. Afterwards, Secretary of State George Shultz said he had no solutions. Treasury Secretary Donald Regan went further - flatly rejecting any initiatives to rectify the situation.

title: SENATE AIDE QUITS TRIAL OF TEAMSTER
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon, a Democrat who has spent nearly 25 years in Congress, was defeated Tuesday, and on Wednesday morning Clendon H. Lee Jr. was gone from the courtroom of Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall.

title: COME TO 'CLUB SEABED'
description: The most expensive junket in world history will be voted upon at the U.N. this week: $20 million is being proposed to enable diplomats and their families to sojourn on the sunny island of Jamaica, where they will set up a permanent poolside bureaucracy to berate the United States for refusing to sign the Law of the Sea Treaty.

title: Video Snoopy Draws Lawsuit
description: A video game called Snoopy pits the cartoon character against his archenemy, the Red Baron, and the trademark owners of the comic strip are trying to put a halt to it.

title: Illegal Lobster Catch Seized
description: State and Federal fisheries agents said they have arrested three men in a boat that was carrying more than 1,000 undersized lobsters and cooked lobster tails. The agents seized the 70-foot commercial boat Friday and arrested the men on charges of illegally possessing undersized lobsters. The men could face fines of more than $55,000.

title: CON ED RATES PROGRAM CLAIMS PROGRESS ON JOBS
description: Almost 4,000 jobs have been created or saved in New York City by an 18-month-old Consolidated Edison Company program that offers reduced electricity rates to commercial customers who agree to expand or relocate in depressed neighborhoods, according to the city and the utility.

title: CLERIC ASKS PEACEFUL SOLUTION FOR CONFRONTATION IN POLAND
description: Archbishop Josef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, speaking just three days before Solidarity's first major trial of strength with the country's martial law regime, said today that the church understood and sympathized with the banned trade union's call for a general strike on Wednesday.

title: STAGE: BRITISH 'TWO FISH IN THE SKY'
description: THE Phoenix Theater, one of this city's most venerable theatrical institutions, surely has good reasons for opening its 30thanniversary season with Michael Hastings's ''Two Fish in the Sky.'' Sad to say, those reasons are not readily apparent on stage at the Phoenix's new home, the Theater at St. Peter's Church, where this minuscule British farce was unveiled last night.

title: The First Fruits of Gene-Splicing
description: Genetic engineering remains a technology of high promise, but those seeking funds to launch it promised too much too soon. Otherwise, the recent advent of the first major product of the new research technique would not seem particularly overdue: the Eli Lilly company received Federal approval to market humulin, human insulin made by genetically tailored bacteria.

title: DANCE: 'KITCHEN TABLE'
description: TWO years ago, Bill Cratty attracted attention with his ''The Kitchen Table,'' a cartoonlike, yet essentially despairing, dance that viewed family life as an arena for petty tyranny and constant bickering. In terms of its energy level, it was a dance that went crash! bang! boom!

title: U.S. to Appeal Oil Tax Ruling
description: A Federal judge's ruling that the oil ''windfall profits'' tax is unconstitutional will be appealed and the Government will continue to collect the tax, Marlin Fitzwater, a Treasury Department spokesman, has announced.

title: Greening of Marvin
description: ''I want you!'' So it seems Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight boxing champion of the world, is saying in his recent campaign to market a variety of products that bear his endorsement. The central target, of course, is the general consumer public, which would help to fill Hagler's coffers if it responds enthusiastically to a full-page advertisement that ran in a national magazine last week.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What happens when my opponent's golf ball comes to rest on the fairway so close to mine that I cannot swing without hitting his ball, too?

title: NIXON REUNION RECALLS A VICTORY AND SOME ASHES
description: Charles W. Colson almost did not make it; he had had three prayer meetings in Indianapolis earlier in the day. H.R. Haldeman did not make it. He canceled at the last minute. And John W. Dean 3d certainly was not there. He was not invited. But 180 men and women who worked for Richard M. Nixon when he was President did turn out Saturday night for a black-tie dinner in honor of the 10th anniversay of Mr. Nixon's re-election. The weekendlong reunion was organized by four former members of the Nixon White House advance team. The guest of honor was their former boss.

title: AT STATE, DISSENT GIVES RISE TO PRAISE
description: Dissent is not a popular commodity in the Federal Government. The bureaucracy has developed numerous and sometimes Draconian ways of stifling differences of opinion and unconventional thinking.

title: HOOKER TALCOTT SR.
description: Hooker Talcott Sr., a retired financial executive and publisher, died Friday in his Manhattan home. He was 87 years old. A graduate of Harvard College in 1918, he had spent his entire business career with James Talcott Inc., a New York factoring and financing concern founded by his grandfather in 1854. Mr. Talcott had served as a vice president and vice chairman of the company.

title: FEMINIST CAUSE LOOKS BACK TO GRASS ROOTS
description: Koryne Horbal is one of a new breed of political feminists - women who have gone the traditional route in politics, found it wanting and, as a result, have turned their focus back to the grass roots, where their political activity began.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Morris Reported Rebuffed on Plea
description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris, convicted last week of trafficking in cocaine, reportedly sought a last-minute plea-bargain agreement for a year's sentence.

title: Dataspeed Radio Linkup
description: Dataspeed Inc. and National Public Radio have announced their intention to join in a nationwide portable information service.

title: STOCKS ARE ALSO UP ABROAD
description: From London to Tokyo and from Toronto to Frankfurt, stock prices around the world rose last week in response to Wall Street's recordbreaking rally.

title: LEHRMAN VYING WITH ANDERSON FOR POLICY ROLE
description: Less than a week after the election, Lewis E. Lehrman and State Senator Warren M. Anderson are on a collision course over who is to be the leading Republican voice in New York State.

title: IN ZIMBABWE, QUEST FOR THE TIGER FISH
description: SANYATI GORGE, Zimbabwe THE water is low this year, the lowest, some say, since they threw the great dam across the Zambezi River two decades ago to flood 175 miles of its valley and form this lake called Kariba, at Central Africa's heart.

title: Los Angeles Police Seek Motive in Estate Killings
description: Two officials of a quasi-religious drug rehabilitation group found shot to death in a heavily guarded Hollywood Hill compound may have been killed by someone who knew them, the police said today.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA created many, many notes and very little music Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. It was one of those occasions that prompted wonder why 100 people would get together and make any sounds at all with their odd-shaped pieces of wood and metal.

title: JAZZ: COMMITMENT, EAST-WEST FUSION
description: FOR decades, jazz has sought East-West fusions. Commitment, the quartet that played Friday at Soundscape, has found one that is integrated, thoughtful and deeply satisfying.

title: ISRAELI GENERAL DESCRIBES UNEASE DURING MASSACRE
description: The commander of the Israeli forces in Beirut testified today that he had heard reports that civilians at two Palestinian refugee camps were being killed by Christian militiamen when the militiamen first entered the camps on Sept. 16. But the commander, Brig. Gen. Amos Yaron, said he did not know the full extent of the killings until the next Monday.

title: Iran Wants to Renew Bonn Submarine Order
description: A special envoy of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has said in a magazine interview that Iran is seeking to renew contracts to buy submarines from a West German shipyard that were annulled after the overthrow of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: TURKEY'S CHARTER SEEMS TO BE WINNING
description: Turkish voters appeared today to have overwhelmingly endorsed a draft constitution that automatically elects Turkey's military ruler, Gen. Kenan Evren, as President for a seven-year term.

title: REAGANS HEAR PERLMAN AND PROTEGE
description: The violinist Itzhak Perlman today opened the second season of ''In Performance at the White House'' by introducing Ken Noda, a 20-year-old pianist who won the applause of President and Mrs. Reagan by his playing of works by Mozart and Chopin.

title: Nepal Enters the Space Age
description: The son of King Birendra of Nepal spoke with Prince Charles of Britain today through a communication satellite earth station linking Nepal with the outside world. Britain provided about $1.2 million to help build the station, which replaces the high frequency radio system used since 1964.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For 5,089 Taxpayers, A Welcome I.R.S. Message

title: Paper Says Pope's Assailant Was 1 of 3 Gunmen in Square
description: At least two other gunmen were in St. Peter's Square ready to shoot Pope John Paul II on the day in 1981 that Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turkish terrorist, tried to kill the Pope, The Daily American reported today.

title: Yankee Come Home
description: When Cash Asmussen, the leading jockey in New York in 1979 and 1980, left the country to ride in France earlier this year, it sounded like the Steve Cauthen story all over again. Cauthen, the leading rider in 1977 and winner of the Triple Crown aboard Affirmed in 1978, went to ride in England in 1980 and has said repeatedly he has no plans to return here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NUKESPEAK. Nuclear Language, Visions and Mindset. By Stephen Hilgartner, Richard C. Bell and Rory O'Connor. Il- lustrated. 282 pages. Sierra Club. $14.95. THE CULT OF THE ATOM. The Secret Papers of the Atomic Energy Commis- sion. By Daniel Ford. Illustrated. 273 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: Alan Friedman, Consultant, Weds Marylene Weisberg
description: At Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York yesterday, Marylene Weisberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Weisberg of Norfolk, Va., was married to Alan Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Friedman of New York and Salisbury, Conn.

title: COWLES TAKES CHARGE AT TROUBLED MINNEAPOLIS PAPER
description: It is the largest newspaper of the Upper Great Lakes and the flagship of the Cowles Media Company, but staff cuts, consolidations and management shake-ups have not solved The Minneapolis Star-Tribune's continuing fight against declining profits.

title: PEPSICO CALLS PROFIT OVERSTATED
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it discovered falsified accounts at two foreign soft-drink bottling plants that caused operating profits of the two subsidiaries to be overstated by about $85 million over the last four years.

title: DON'T CERTIFY CHILE
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the President of Chile, is lobbying hard to persuade Washington that respect for human rights has improved in his country -even as he extends the list of his enemies to include leaders of the Catholic Church and openly threatens opponents with harsher punitive measures. It is hard to imagine what could be harsher that the means he already uses - mass arrests, detention, torture, rape, banishment and disappearance - and yet the White House apparently intends to go through with its shameful certification that General Pinochet has made progress in guaranteeing his people's human rights. If President Reagan persuades Congress to accept the General's claim that rights violations have ceased, the junta will again be eligible to receive American military assistance, and the American taxpayer will bail out his tottering, repressive regime.

title: CELTICS HOLD OFF NETS AND WIN BY 2
description: When the Nets played the Boston Celtics last year, the games were examples of intimidation. The Nets lost five of the six games, by an average of more than 10 points and once by as many as 18. The intimidation was usually supplied by Larry Bird, and the victim was often Albert King, then a rookie.

title: PREDICTIONS OF LOWER RATES WIDESPREAD
description: Treasury securities scheduled for sale this week range in maturity from the three-month and six-month bills to be auctioned today to the 30-year bonds to be auctioned tomorrow.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AFRICAN METAL WORK

title: THE BROTHERS LEHMAN: BATTLING NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: When people mention the Lehman brothers in this town, nobody thinks of the Wall Street investment banking firm. But they do think of the brothers, three of them, who have come to play important roles in the Reagan Administration's defense and arms control policies.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF GAMBLING IN NEW YORK STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUIS ENGEL JR., EX-MERRILL LYNCH PARTNER, DIES
description: Louis H. Engel Jr., a retired partner and vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc, who sought to widen stock ownership by appealing to the average person, died on Saturday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Suspect in Shooting Seized
description: A man wanted for shooting a police officer who was chasing him after the robbery of a gypsy-cab driver in April has been arrested, the police said Saturday.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS LEAGUE OFFERS THE PRO ARTE QUARTET
description: THE PRO ARTE QUARTET plays to win. The ensemble's work is marked by an obvious enthusiasm for the new music it programs, and the desire and ability to impart the same excitement to the audience.

title: Foundation Gives $1 Million To Columbia for Chair in Law
description: One million dollars has been given to Columbia University by the Norman and Rosita Winston Foundation to establish the Arthur Levitt Professorship of Law.

title: Vandals Derail 'Train to the Plane'
description: An express subway train on the way to Manhattan from Kennedy International Airport was derailed in Brooklyn last night by vandals, and although none of the 20 passengers and crew were hurt, service was interrupted on parts of the A line for about an hour, the Transit Authority said.

title: FORECAST GLOOMY FOR SEMICONDUCTORS
description: With demand continuing to slide in what is traditionally the strong autumn sales season, many semiconductor manufacturers and industry analysts anticipate that it could be the middle of 1983 before the industry begins to recover.

title: Addenda
description: * Newsweek magazine increasing its advertising page rates 7.6 percent, effective with the Jan. 3 issue.

title: GEMAYEL IS FACING NEW CHALLENGES
description: After six weeks of establishing his identity at home and abroad as the leader of postwar Lebanon, Amin Gemayel is now entering what many officials here believe may be the most challenging week of his presidency so far.

title: Marjorie Kaplan Bride of Professor
description: Marjorie Sara Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Z. Kaplan of Brookline, Mass., was married there yesterday to Michael Stanislawski, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stanislawski of Montreal. Rabbis Ben-Zion Gold, Juda Mintz and Emanuel Saltzman officiated at Congregation Kehillath Israel.

title: Soldiers Topple Regime In Upper Volta
description: A group of noncommissioned officers and others toppled the Upper Volta Government of Col. Saye Zerbo in a predawn coup today, accusing him of turning the military into ''agents of terror,'' the Ouagadougou radio reported.

title: The Talk of San Salvador
description: It is dusk outside an apartment house near the center of El Salvador's capital, and an American military adviser walks into the courtyard with a visitor, who starts to climb into a waiting taxi.

title: The Bedside Robots
description: Are medical schools turning out the right kind of doctors? Or are they cramming their pupils full of rote-learned facts, omitting the human skills of dealing with patients?

title: A Familiar Face
description: Fans who assembled at Jesuit High School's football field in Tampa, Fla., on Oct. 23 to watch an open tryout for the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League were surprised.

title: Ramapo Wins
description: John Lobman scored touchdowns on runs of 9, 30 and 5 yards to lead Ramapo College (7-2) to a 31-14 victory over Marist today.

title: Miss Trachtenberg and Lawyer Marry
description: At Congregation Ahaveth Torah in Englewood, N.J., yesterday, Shoshanah Trachtenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Trachtenberg of Englewood and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married to Andrew J. Frackman, son of Barbara Kleinberg of New York and the late Leonard M. Frackman. Rabbi Isaac L. Swift, assisted by Cantor Joseph Malovany, performed the ceremony.

title: BREZHNEV RENEWS CALL FOR DETENTE BUT WARNS WEST
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev used the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution today to renew the Soviet Union's commitment to detente with the West. But he warned that ''a crushing retaliatory strike'' awaited any potential aggressor.

title: THRIFT UNITS BEGINNING TO OFFER STOCK SERVICES
description: The aging downtown office of the Perpetual American Savings and Loan Association here seems hardly the place to stage a revolution. Its once fashionable and imposing atrium, decorated in muted turquoise and beige, now lingers awkwardly as a reminder of better times in the once-thriving thrift industry.

title: Diana Brody and Dr. Justin Kaplan Have Nuptials
description: Diana L. Brody, daughter of Judge Warren Brody of the New Jersey Appellate Division and Mrs. Brody of Roselle, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Justin Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kaplan of Fords, N.J. Rabbi Nancy Kreimer performed the ceremony at Woodlawn, a mansion on the campus of Douglass College in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Dane Plans Bank Talks
description: Henning Christophersen, Finance Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, will visit New York, Washington and Frankfurt this week for talks with Denmark's major bank creditors. He will seek to allay growing concern that Denmark is unable to put its financial house in order, according to political analysts and banking sources.

title: Florida Officials Extend Emergency on Measles
description: Health officials are extending a measles emergency declaration to all Dade County schools because of 113 measles cases among students in the past month.

title: INDICATORS OF PURCHASERS STILL DOWN
description: The downward slide of the economy continued in October, with most major indicators declining, according to a report on business conditions by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: FRASER QUITTING CHRYSLER BOARD, CITES DUAL ROLE
description: Douglas A. Fraser, who is stepping down from the Chrysler Corporation's board until the company signs a new labor contract, said today he wanted to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest because of his leadership of the United Automobile Workers union.

title: DE LOREAN MAY HAVE OFFERED STOCK HE DIDN'T OWN IN DEAL;
description: John Z. De Lorean, who former associates say used deceptive methods to build his now-shattered trans-Atlantic automotive empire, may have tried to obtain millions of dollars worth of cocaine from Federal undercover agents with stock that he was not legally entitled to transfer.

title: TRIAL ON JUDGE'S DEATH HEARS ONE JAILED BROTHER DEFAME THE OTHER
description: Joseph Salim Chagra spent most of last week testifying not only about the man accused of shooting a Federal judge but also about his brother, Jamiel, who is to be tried separately on charges of paying the gunman.

title: Washington Watch; Fed's Delay On Rate Signal
description: WASHINGTON THE financial markets have waited in vain during the last two weeks for the Federal Reserve Board to cut the discount rate. This lack of action by the Fed is confounding the markets, which are looking for another signal of further declines in interest rates. The delay appears to be part of an effort by the Fed to show that it is sticking to a tough anti-inflation policy.

title: KOCH SAYS LAYOFFS OF CITY EMPLOYEES WILL BE NECESSARY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City's growing financial troubles would require laying off some city workers. The Mayor, who just last week said he hoped to limit job losses to attrition, declined to be specific about which workers would be involved or how many. The layoffs would be the first of workers under mayoral control since the early days of the city's fiscal crisis in 1975 and 1976.

title: Unbeaten Costello Wins on Decision
description: Billy Costello, the No.10 contender in the junior-welterweight division, remained undefeated today by scoring a unanimous 10-round decison over Willie Rodriguez.

title: LINCOLN WEST: A CLASSIC TALE OF CITY POLITICS AND POWER
description: A few months from now, barring complications, a new neighborhood will begin to rise on Manhattan's West Side - a luxury waterfront housing complex envisioned as so grand and so large that some people are already calling it a city within a city.

title: PARIS AIDE OFFERS VIEWS ON MIDEAST
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France says that a combination of political guarantees and border surveillance using advanced detection equipment could go far to break the impasse on achieving an overall broad Middle East peace.

title: Pope Asks Global Plan In Fighting Joblessness
description: Pope John Paul II called today for a global approach in tackling the problem of unemployment. ''The roads to a just solution of this grave problem demand today a revision of the economic order in its totality,'' he said in a speech devoted to the problems of labor before a large crowd in the capital of Catalonia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bonray Drilling Corp., Oklahoma City, announced that Kenneth L. Hefner had resigned as president.

title: Miss Monahan Wins Show Rider Honor
description: Katie Monahan embellished her selection as rider of the year when she emerged as the star of the 99th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Bank Tie Near In Florida
description: Great American Banks Inc. of Miami has announced that its shareholders have approved the company's acquisition by Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. in a $17 a share transaction valued at about $47 million.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1982
description: International The Soviet commitment to detente was affirmed by Leonid I. Breznhev in an address marking the 65th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. But he warned that ''a crushing retaliatory strike'' awaited any potential aggressor. In an apparent allusion to the Reagan Administration, the Soviet leader added, ''our might and vigilance will cool, I think, the hot heads of some imperialist politicians.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) Iranian troops drove west into Iraq for the first time in more than three months, the Teheran Government said, announcing that its forces had reached the town of Teib in southeastern Iraq. The Baghdad radio confirmed the invasion, which began Saturday night, and said ''intense fighting'' was under way. (A1:3-4.)

title: BRAZIL'S NEW FRONTIER
description: As a North American beneficiary of the 19th century assault on the Old West, I am often torn between applauding and railing at the crusade under way in South America to conquer its huge, unexploited frontiers. I say ''torn,'' but not paralyzed. Because in the end, no matter what the risks and drawbacks, I come down firmly on the side of the huge development efforts that seem certain to increase the size of the continent's economic pie.

title: Shaklee Chief Adds Chairman's Title
description: J. Gary Shansby, president and chief executive officer of the Shaklee Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Shansby also announced that the company had started a search outside the company for a chief operating officer.

title: CANCER RATE LOW, FALLOUT TRIAL TOLD
description: Because Mormon Church doctrine proscribes ''wine, strong drink, tobacco and hot drinks,'' a surgeon has testified in a watershed damages trial here, Utah, the heartland of the church, has had the nation's lowest cancer rate, even in the years after radioactive fallout occurred in the state.

title: Accounts
description: * Singleworld, a wholesaler of worldwide cruises and tours, to Mintzer, Trostler & Rothschild Inc.

title: Islanders Tie Flyers On Bossy's Goal, 2-2
description: The Islanders, beset by a week-long malaise, showed tonight the form that is expected of Stanley Cup champions and rallied in the third period to tie the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-2, in the Spectrum.

title: Chaminade Takes Crown in Soccer
description: Chaminade of Mineola, L.I., defeated St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., 2-0, to win the Nassau-Suffolk Catholic High Schools Soccer League championship today at St. Anthony's.

title: COUNTDOWN TO 5TH FLIGHT OF SPACE SHUTTLE BEGINS
description: With a predawn ''call to stations'' early today for more than 50 technicians and engineers, the countdown was started for the fifth mission of the space shuttle Columbia, which is scheduled to lift off Thursday on a journey in which it will launch two commercial communications satellites.

title: The Name Game
description: For frustrated basketball players who dream of playing in the National Basketball Association someday, the best advice available is: change your name to Johnson. As it has been for several years, that name is easily the most popular on N.B.A. rosters.

title: Alexander Richter Dies at 78; Music Educator in New; York
description: Alexander Richter, chairman of the music department at the High School of Music and Art from 1936 until his retirement in 1969, died Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: News Analysis
description: There is a question about the Socialist-led Government of President Francois Mitterrand that gets asked rather little in France even as it gets more pertinent: Apart from a lot of the speech-making, how much of the Government's leftist program remains intact?

title: 5,000 Greet L.S.U. Team
description: About 5,000 Louisiana State University fans jammed the airport to welcome their football team home Saturday night from its 20-10 upset of Alabama, and they were ready to cheer anything, even the wrong plane.

title: Amcon's Head Resigns; His 'Masters Disagreed'
description: David O. Lloyd-Jacob, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of the Amcon Group and as a board member of the parent company, Consolidated Gold Fields Group.

title: Ford Workers Back Strikers
description: Canadian employees of the Ford Motor Company agreed today to contribute $40,000 a month to help 9,600 Chrysler workers in a strike that could begin forcing American layoffs this week.

title: Ulster Policeman Shot
description: A policeman was wounded in a gunbattle with Irish Republican Army guerrillas today on the border with Ireland, the police reported. The officer, who was not identified, was hit in an arm and leg. He was reported in serious condition.

title: ATOMS AND POLITICS
description: The public campaign to stop the nuclear arms race, which has just had its greatest American success with voter approval of freeze resolutions, has to reckon with a central political fact: Many of President Reagan's key advisers on these questions want an arms race.

title: OUTDOORS: DEER HUNTING IN MAINE
description: GREENVILLE, Me. SITTING on the summit of one of the twin peaks of Prong Pond Mountain, where I could watch for deer moving in the valley below, I shared my lunch of nuts, sunflower seeds and raisins with a pair of chipmunks whose spirits, unlike mine, did not appear to be dampened by the gray skies and intermittent rain.

title: WELCOMING CONVERTS TO JUDAISM
description: SHE was from a family of strict Lutherans. He was Jewish. Although such things were not supposed toh appen in the small Virginia town where they both grew up, the couplef ell in love and married. Nine years later she converted to Judaism, h aving felt a growing affinity for the religion.

title: AARON PRYOR FIGHTING FOR RECOGNITION
description: MIAMI THE stockyards of Cincinnati contain cows and steers, and most of them are so drugged they have to be carried the final yards to the slaughterhouse. These are mere details. In the mind of a 14-year-old from the ghetto, they are bulls with great big horns that can tear you to pieces, and so it was that young Aaron Pryor would sneak into the stockyards, climb into the pens and ride the bulls.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Luring Feathered Migrants

title: Meat Cutters May Strike
description: Meat cutters today threatened to strike selected supermarkets throughout Southern California Tuesday morning, and employers said workers would be locked out of all other stores if a strike is called. Talks between the employers and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union broke off at 5:30 this morning. The unresolved issues were medical care, wages and job security.

title: Oldtime Brawl
description: While all of the National Football League stadiums were empty, a good old-fashioned foot-ball game was played yesterday in Williamsburg, Va. The 18th century version of foot-ball does not bear much resemblance to the game in fashion today. It has more in common with a brawl.

title: Reynolds Sets Belgian Deal
description: R.J. Reynolds, the biggest American cigarette manufacturer, has announced that it has bought ETS Gosset, one of Belgium's top companies in the field.

title: Fullback by Day
description: On Saturday afternoons, Rich Bonaccorsi is a traditional football hero at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind. The 6-foot-1-inch, 205-pound fullback has scored 11 touchdowns for the Tigers as they won eight of nine games. He scored on an 8-yard run and gained 77 yards rushing as DePauw defeated Oberlin, 41-12, on Saturday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mirrors on the Mind

title: Nordic Bourse Plan
description: The industry federations of the four main Scandinavian countries have proposed that companies in Sweden, Norway, Denmark and Finland be listed on each others' stock exchanges, the Swedish federation said today. A joint report, which is being considered by the four governments, said the idea is to increase regional cooperation and widen markets for Scandinavian companies.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Paradyne Corp.
description: The Paradyne Corporation of Largo, Fla., said it was the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning methods it used in procuring material orders and other matters.

title: Car Stockpile Is Still High
description: Domestic new-car stockpiles remained at a 69-day supply at the end of October, unchanged from the month before, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: THE CULINARY GLITCH
description: IT was one of those ''The cupboard is bare, I'm hungry and I don't know what I want to eat,'' moments that somehow seem to strike writers at about 4 o'clock in the morning when they're halfway through a rush book assignment. Then I remembered the micro cookbook program by Virtual Combinatics.

title: City Water Supply Facing Cutbacks
description: Water levels in New York City's three upper Delaware reservoirs have dropped below the drought warning level, the Delaware River Basin Authority said today. The announcement raised the possibility that water supplies might be cut back.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $368,400...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $398,000

title: MISSING BODY IS FOUND IN JERSEY BOAT SINKING
description: The body of one of the three persons missing since the Oct. 24 sinking of the chartered fishing boat Joan La Rie III was found today.

title: DANCERS' 1865 VICTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: DICKENSON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a special gain of $22,000...C-Including a special gain of $3,271,000...D-After a special loss of $364,000...E-Net income including a special gain of $3,733,000

title: DEVILS RALLY FOR TIE
description: After a seven-game losing streak, the Devils now have avoided defeat in their last three games by gaining ties. The latest one was a 2-2 deadlock tonight against the Washington Capitals.

title: U.S. SAID TO PREPARE DRUG CASE AGAINST A BOLIVIAN
description: The United States Attorney in Miami is preparing evidence for a Federal grand jury on accusations that Bolivia's former Interior Minister conspired to smuggle large quantities of cocaine into this country, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: RACE-FIXING CASES DISMISSED
description: The indictments against four jockeys accused of conspiring to fix races at the Meadowlands Race Track were dismissed today by a Superior Court judge.

title: AERO-FLOW DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grace Agrees To Buy Amicon
description: W.R. Grace & Company agreed in principle to acquire the Amicon Corporation for $25 a share, or a total of about $36.5 million, the companies said in a statement.

title: Governor Kean's Tax Window
description: New Jersey's Governor Thomas Kean could not get his gasoline tax approved earlier this year, so to balance the state budget he cut programs and laid off 1,600 workers. That wasn't enough.

title: CONCERT: ARRAU, AT 80, AND SCOTTISH ORCHESTRA
description: THERE are recorded performances by Claudio Arrau that are both noble and exhilarating; but there are others that are surprisingly mundane. It is a contrast worth examining this season, as the distinguished pianist celebrates his 80th birthday. In his first New York appearance on Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Arrau actually compounded the confusion by presenting a performance of the Brahms First Piano Concerto with the Scottish National Orchestra; it sent some members of the audience to their feet and others into a state of passive acquiesence.

title: STAGE: 'THE MARRIAGE CONTRACT'
description: THE only play in any language this season that begins its story with a hassle over seltzer opened over the weekend at (where else?) the Folksbiene Playhouse, at 122 East 55th Street.

title: NEW YORK STATE PLANS $350 MILLION IN NOTES TO PAY BILLS
description: New York State, facing cash problems for the first time since the mid-1970's, will issue $350 million in short-term notes to enable the state to pay its bills during the next two months, the State Comptroller announced yesterday.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
LOEWS POSTS GAIN OF 4.5%
description: MCA Inc. reported yesterday that record revenues from its hit feature film ''E.T. - The Extra Terrestrial'' caused overall earnings in the third quarter to more than triple as revenues climbed 46.4 percent.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CAREY PLANS TRIP TO JAPAN TO TALK ABOUT BUS DEAL
description: Before leaving office at the end of the year, Governor Carey will make a second trip to Japan to complete a deal with Hino Motors Ltd. to build buses in New York State, an aide close to the Governor said today.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a loss of $162,000 from discontinued operations

title: CALIFORNIA, AT 'BOTTON OF BARREL,' PLANNING TO BORROW $400 MILLION TO ; PAY BILLS
description: California's state government has reached ''the bottom of the barrel'' and must borrow $400 million quickly to pay November bills, State Controller Ken Cory announced today.

title: Ralph E. Peck Is Dead at 71; Taught Chemical Engineering
description: Ralph E. Peck, professor emeritus of chemical engineering at the Illinois Institute of Technology and the inventor of a process for the removal of air pollutants from coal, died Saturday of cancer at the Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago. He was 71 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: A RUSSIAN SATIRE
description: As Leonid Brezhnev's reign drags on, American analysts of the Soviet Union have had more and more time to discuss the succession and what it's likely to mean for us. Although each has a special angle, the talk has shown that there is more of a consensus than appears from the arguments.

title: ASBESTOS LAWYERS ASK COURT TO CURB MANVILLE
description: Lawyers representing thousands of workers with asbestos-related claims against the Manville Corporation asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan yesterday to set aside Manville's bankruptcy petition on the ground that it was filed in bad faith and was an abuse of the bankruptcy procedure.

title: YUGOSLAVS SEEK TO QUELL STRIFE IN REGION OF ETHNIC ALBANIANS
description: In Belgrade, three muscular men in black windbreakers boarded a night train to Kosovo, the southern province where nearly all of Yugoslavia's more than 1.5 million ethnic Albanians live.

title: No Headline
description: The National Hockey League said today it had requested videotapes of Sunday's Chicago Black Hawks-Toronto Maple Leafs game in which there were two stick-swinging incidents.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON CITY'S FISCAL PROSPECTS
description: Following are excerpts from a report on New York City's fiscal prospects by the Citizens Budget Commission: The Current Fiscal Outlook And Options

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 and 3 P.M.

title: AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary gains of $93,000 for the qr and $478,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $2,061,000...D-After an extraordinary gain of $10 million

title: Ex-Officer at Warner Begins Trial Testimony
description: A former high executive of Warner Communications Inc. testified in Federal court yesterday that he had pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to cooperate with the Government in hopes of receiving a lenient sentence.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVES CITE BLEAK OIL OUTLOOK
description: Top executives of the nation's major oil companies, saying that their industry faces bleaker short-term prospects than in any recent year, asserted today that domestic demand for crude oil will remain flat for at least another year and that oil prices may fall.

title: MISSISSIPPI PRISON FIRE KILLS 27 AND INJURES 43
description: Twenty-seven prisoners died and at least 43 persons were injured in a fire early this morning at the crowded county jail here.

title: Wilander Is Upset
description: Henri Leconte, a member of France's Davis Cup team, upset top-seeded Mats Wilander, 7-6, 6-3, tonight and won the the $300,000 Stockholm Open tennis championship.

title: RATES UP A BIT IN QUIET DAY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in quiet trading as securities dealers cut prices in advance of Treasury sales of shortterm bills and long-term bonds.

title: Back at the L.B.J. Ranch; Charlotte Curtis
description: cup plastic holders Texans always have in their cars, wheeled her brown Mercury out past the airplane affluent Texans keep in their backyards and drove across the rolling beige grassland studded with live oak, pampas plumes and cactus. Behind her, a platinum sun dropped slowly through the streaky pale-blue sky, trailing clouds of gray and white. ''I come out here as often as I can,'' she said. ''I love our sagey greens.'' A slim bird with a long divided tail flew up in front of the car - a scissors bird, she called it - and to the right, an armadillo waddled into a ditch. Ahead, a herd of deer froze momentarily, then darted into the underbrush. Farther along, Texas longhorns grazed undisturbed. Beyond them, nilgai, those antelopes with small heads, long necks and large bodies, stared at her.

title: Topics; Extravagant Charges; Pot and Kettle
description: You could hardly see for flying mud at the trial under way in Manhattan to settle responsibility for the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island. General Public Utilities, the operator of the reactor, is suing its builder, Babcock & Wilcox, for $4 billion in damages.

title: Athletic Director Quits
description: Wichita State University, which has been penalized for rules violations more often than any other member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, asked Ted Bredehoft, its athletic director, to resign.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Sunday about a strike of Legal Aid lawyers incorrectly described a postponement of a request for an injunction. The postponement was accepted by the lawyers' union, the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys. The Legal Aid Society is not a party to the suit.

title: A SILENT REBUTTAL
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Analysis
description: When more than 90 percent of the 20 million voters in Sunday's referendum approved Turkey's new Constitution, they apparently were not voting for the legal document of 193 articles, which most of them had not read and many opposed.

title: CHADWICK-MILLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Talking Business with Bays of American Hospital Supply; Health Field: Growth Area
description: For years, the medical supply field was highly fragmented, with small producers and distributors offering specialized products and services. Then, under the pressure of extended medical insurance and Federal outlays, there was a boom in this industry, leading to the rise of large medical suppliers.

title: French Standby Credit
description: France has drawn $600 million of its $4 billion standby credit but has not yet used the money, a French Treasury official said today. The credit, signed on Oct. 27, has been arranged to provide funds to defend the franc on foreign exchange markets.

title: BENNETT IS SPARK AT DUKE
description: When Steve Spurrier became offensive coordinator at Duke University in 1980, he inherited a stodgy attack one senior tackle recalls as ''3 yards and a cloud of dust, three plays and kick.''

title: AT CANADIAN OUTPOST, POLAR BEARS APPROACH CLOSE ENOUGH FOR STUDY
description: FIVE miles from this settlement on Hudson Bay, Gordon Stenhouse, a wildlife biologist, has locked himself in a cage. There, he spends long hours watching the wild, hungry polar bears he has lured toward him with strategically placed portions of whale meat.

title: Church's Ex-Caretaker Is Held in 5 Shootings
description: A 67-year-old caretaker who had been dismissed earlier in the day opened fire in a storefront church today, killing two women and wounding three men before he was taken into custody, said the police and the church pastor.

title: KING HUSSEIN TO CONFER WITH REAGAN DEC. 21
description: The White House announced late today that King Hussein of Jordan would come to Washington to meet with President Reagan on Dec. 21.

title: Paine, Webber Sues Merrill
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. filed suit in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., yesterday asking that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.'s patent on the Cash Management Account be declared invalid.

title: Officer at Chemical Taking Post at Baer
description: David E. Bodner has been named president-designate of the Baer American Banking Corporation, the American banking arm of Bank Julius Baer & Company of Zurich.

title: Girl Swallows Pin In Cheese Snack
description: A Bronx high school senior bit into a puffed cheese snack during lunch yesterday and swallowed what was believed to be a straight pin, authorities said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armstrong World Industries and Lone Star Industries said they had formed a joint venture, Arm-Star Venture Associates, to develop polymer concrete technology.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Doo-Wopp' in a Reprise

title: ARABS ON EDGE
description: Since their crushing defeat by Israel in 1967, most Arab regimes have been fighting a rearguard action to cling to power. The resurgence of Islamic movements in this period is in large part a response to the failure of these regimes to fulfill their promises for economic prosperity and national strength. Today, these leaders' impotence in the face of the Israeli assault on the Palestinians in Lebanon threatens to strip them of their last pretense to legitimate rule. After all, Arab leaders had long claimed that what sustained their hostility to Israel was its refusal to recognize the legitimate rights of Palestinians. But when the moment of truth came in the first Israeli-Palestinian war, Arab support was totally ineffective.

title: PROGRESS IS SLOW IN TYLENOL INQUIRY
description: In the nearly six weeks since the first deaths from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules, investigators have compiled volumes of case reports, interviewed thousands of people, worn out one Xerox copying machine, tested more than one million capsules and winnowed through thousands of leads telephoned from throughout the country and overseas.

title: HARVESTER CONFIRMS VENDOR AID
description: The struggling International Harvester Company said today that it had received more than $40 million of the $50 million in concessions it was seeking from its 5,000 suppliers and vendors. Analysts called the response better than expected and predicted that the remaining $10 million would be received within the next 10 days.

title: 3 Banks to Merge In Pennsylvania
description: Three Pennsylvania banks with $860 million in total assets announced plans to merge. The Bucks County Bank and Trust Company, the Union Bank and Trust Company of Southeastern Pennsylvania and the Cheltenham Bank would become wholly owned subsidiaries of a new corporation, to be called Independence Bancorp Inc. The combined banks would have 38 branches.

title: SIR NEVILLE A. PEARSON
description: Sir Neville Arthur Pearson, former chairman of Arthur Pearson Ltd., the publisher of Country Life magazine and other publications in Britain, died Saturday in Hightstown, N.J., where he had lived since leaving Britain in 1977. He was 84 years old.

title: Du Pont Forecast
description: Edward G. Jefferson, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said today that the company expected earnings to be flat to slightly higher in the fourth quarter.

title: DETECTIVE SHOT INVESTIGATING EAST HARLEM ROBBERY REPORT
description: A plainclothes detective investigating a reported robbery in a vacant tenement in East Harlem was shot in the face yesterday afternoon as he and his two partners attempted to enter a fourthfloor apartment in the building, the police said. The building was described by the police as a gathering place for heroin addicts.

title: U.S. CONCEDES ENVOY SAW THE POPE BUT WON'T GIVE TOPICS DISCUSSED
description: Ambassador at Large Vernon Walters made an unpublicized visit to the Vatican Oct. 18 for a discussion with Pope John Paul II on Soviet-American relations and the rationale for the Reagan Administration's nuclear strategy, Administration officials said today.

title: Xerox Lays Off Additional 600
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday announced an additional 600 layoffs from its copier divisions based in Rochester.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $149,100; yr-ago qr and yr shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Nov 6, 1981

title: THE REGION
description: Governor O'Neill sent letters today to 134 state commissioners, deputy commissioners and other top officials of the executive branch, asking for their resignations.

title: SIBLING RIVALRY IN THE N.B.A.
description: The first time he entered a game against the Golden State Warriors as a rookie early last year, Albert King of the Nets had to guard their most physical and highestscoring forward. Al Attles, the Warrior coach, immediately sensed the potential mismatch, and called a play designed to send his player one-on-one against young King.

title: Dan River Rejects New Icahn Offer
description: Dan River Inc. said it had rejected the latest offer for its stock from a group headed by Carl Icahn, the investor.

title: DOMINICAN PESO'S WEAKNESS
description: The Dominican peso has dropped to record lows against the dollar in recent days, alarming businessmen here and causing concern in the new Government of President Salvador Jorge Blanco.

title: 2 G.O.P. PRIMARY LOSERS MAY SUE CONSERVATIVES
description: The two losers in the Republican primary for United States Senator from New York threatened yesterday to sue the Conservative Party over a pamphlet that the Conservatives printed for the winner.

title: PAPER TO KEEP ITS OFFICES
description: The company that owns The Daily News has agreed to sell the paper's 37-story landmark building at 220 East 42d Street to a real estate partnership in a complicated sale and lease-back arrangement, officials said yesterday.

title: BALLET THEATER DANCERS REACH CONTRACT ACCORD
description: The bargaining committees for American Ballet Theater and its dancers reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a new contraqct. The company's dancers met into the early morning today at Ballet Theater's office on Broadway in a meeting delayed by a surprise stalemate among the negotiators, reportedly over the issue of retroactive pay. Their bargaining committee recommended ratification of the contract.

title: Holiday Inns
description: Holiday Inns agreed to buy the 60 percent interest in River Boat Casino Inc. that it does not already own from Claudine Williams and other partners. River Boat owns the Holiday Casino and the adjacent Nob Hill Casino in Las Vegas, Nev. Holiday Inns bought 40 percent of the company in 1979. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Leonard Schaffer, President Of Screw-Machine Company
description: Leonard R. Schaffer, president and chairman of the Mono-Matic Manufacturing Company and a leader in medical and Jewish philanthropies, died Sunday at the Newark Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: ROLLS ROYCE TIGHTENS ITS BELT
description: It is almost a reflex in the aging factory complex here where Rolls-Royce automobiles are assembled. Visitors who ask what happens when the luxury cars break down are smilingly told: ''Our cars don't break down. Occasionally, they fail to proceed.''

title: Britain Reviews Concorde Aid
description: British Airways will keep flying the Concorde, Sir John King, chairman, said today after reports that the Government would end public financing of the supersonic plane. ''Concorde services will go on,'' he said.

title: IRANIAN VOWS A MOVE ON BAGHDAD
description: President Ali Khamenei of Iran said tonight that his country's forces ''will proceed toward Baghdad whenever they deem it necessary.''

title: CITY'S CONTRACTS WITH ITS UNIONS FAULTED IN STUDY
description: The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that New York City's new labor contracts with municipal employees were ''a serious mistake'' and ''too expensive.'' The commission, a nonprofit civic watchdog group that monitors the city's finances and services, urged that the contracts be renegotiated.

title: PURCELL PROPOSES BUDGET OF $1.1 BILLION FOR NASSAU
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, proposed 1983 capital and operating budgets today that total $1.1 billion and would require the average homeowner to pay 13.5 percent, or $78, more in county taxes.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: SERIOUS deficiencies in mathematics and science education have propelled two leading national organizations into action to avert the deepening threat. The National Science Board, the policy-making arm of the National Science Foundation, has established a commission on precollege education in mathematics, science and technology to improve the schools' teaching of those disciplines. The board's commission is expected to draft an interim report next month and issue initial action programs in January. The American Association for the Advancement of Science has just published its own report, ''Education in the Sciences: a Developing Crisis,'' which outlines actions that include support for teachers through production of special mathematics and science materials and efforts to gain recognition for good teachers.

title: P.L.O. OFFERS CONDITIONS ON ISRAEL
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has set two conditions for ''mutual and simultaneous'' recognition with Israel, the semiofficial Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram reported today.

title: Traffic Problems Seen for Olympics
description: The 1984 Olympics pose an enormous traffic problem that could bring the entire Los Angeles community to a halt, even forcing some businesses to shut, a researcher at the University of Southern California says.

title: YIDDISH THEATER CENTENNIAL AT MUSEUM
description: IT was a theater world in which stars denounced one another on stage; in which seasoned actors advised newcomers not to argue with a director during rehearsals, but do what they wished during performance; in which playwrights excoriated actors during shows for improvising on the script; in which partisans of stars fought in the streets, sometimes in the theaters, and in which audiences expected a show to last four or even five hours and brought food in bags for the family.

title: A ROOKIE FINDS NO PLACE TO GO
description: Willie Sydnor has decided that it is time to go out into the real world and look for work. Like many others in the college class of 1982, he is not expecting to find a job that relates to his major in psychology. He cannot be so choosy. ''Odds and ends,'' he said. ''Anything. I don't know what I'm doing. I have no idea.''

title: RSR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
So. Mississippi Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed Southern Mississippi on probation for two years because of promises of ''significant financial benefits'' to high school football recruits during the last four years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No red light was lit on the basis of these things.'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. (A1:6.)

title: Psychotherapy by Ballot
description: A referendum unusual even by California standards prevailed in the city of Berkeley last week: the use of electroshock therapy by psychiatrists was declared a misdemeanor. Rarely does public opinion determine the permissibility of a medical therapy. Is Berkeley a century behind the rest of us, or a century ahead?

title: Upper Volta Broadcast Names Coup Leaders
description: The new rulers of the West African country of Upper Volta were identified tonight, 48 hours after a coup toppled the military Government of Col. Saye Zerbo.

title: Withholding, in the Public Interest
description: A supreme achievement of last summer's Federal tax law was to create withholding on interest and dividends. Banks and savings institutions fought it fiercely, nominally because the paperwork would be overwhelming, perhaps more because interest and dividends would look smaller.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON CAR CRASH EQUIPMENT
description: The Supreme Court, setting the stage for one of the major regulatory rulings of the term, agreed today to decide whether the Reagan Administration had sufficient grounds last year for revoking a rule that required all new cars to be equipped with airbags or other automatic crash protection.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO SPEND BILLIONS ON SYNTHETIC FUELS
description: Question: What creature of Government has been handed $15 billion or so to parcel out to its constituents but has yet to find a single one worthy of its largesse? Hint: It is neither the Department of Defense nor the Department of Education.

title: Jersey Teachers Ratify 2-Year Pact
description: Teachers in this Monmouth County community who staged a one-day walkout last Wednesday ratified an agreement on a two-year contract with the school board today.

title: TORONTO SUN PUBLISHING CORP reports earnings for 13 weeks to Oct 23
A COSTLY HEADACHE FOR THE NETWORKS
description: P eople who watch professional football on television have been forced to find something else to do on Sunday afternoons and Monday nights, which have become a $100 million headache for the networks.

title: SPY SCANDAL RUFFLES A VERY PROPER ENGLISH TOWN
description: Until the spy scandal broke last summer, about the raciest thing to come out of this section of England was a lawn game the young bloods introduced to relieve the summer boredom over at the Duke of Beaufort's estate at Badminton.

title: GERMAN CAUTIONS ON MISSILE DELAY
description: The new Defense Minister of West Germany, Manfred Worner, warned today that failure to deploy Pershing 2 missiles in Europe on schedule a year from now would ''trigger very, very serious consequences.''

title: POP: JEFFERSON STARSHIP
description: THE JEFFERSON STARSHIP that performed at the Byrne Arena, in East Rutherford, N.J., is a different animal from the Jefferson Airplane-Jefferson Starship axis that produced powerfully exhortatory folkrock in the 1960's and 70's. The San Francisco-based septet is now a hard-rock band in which the founder, Paul Kantner, and the most famous member, Grace Slick, play subsidiary roles.

title: District Postpones West Point Tuition
description: The Highland Falls Board of Education has temporarily postponed charging tuition for 178 children of military personnel at the United States Military Academy at West Point who attend the village high school.

title: MILITARY SHAKE-UP IS REPORTED IN CHINA
description: Major changes in China's armed forces appear to be under way with the replacement of the commanders of three strategic military regions.

title: Finnair Orders DC-9's
description: Finnair said today that it had ordered three DC-9 Super 80-passenger jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to replace French Caravelles. ''We made the deal because the price was right and the company said it is able to deliver fast,'' Finnair said. The DC-9's will be used in Europe.

title: Market Place; Maximizing A Stock Gain
description: THE spectacular Wall Street rally is generating mixed emotions for some otherwise happy investors. Some of those who sat through a lackluster stock market during most of the year suddenly have major gains. But in many cases their gains cannot be realized without agonizing tax consequences.

title: NEW GUISE FOR ABERCROMBIE'S
description: For decades, Abercrombie & Fitch catered to the gentleman outdoorsman, whose esoteric needs might call for anything from provisions for an Antarctic expedition to cashmere hunting underwear.

title: FLUKE, JOHN, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 24
Chess: Russians Lead Olympiad, United States Tied for 2d
description: At the halfway point, after seven rounds of the Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland, the top-seeded Soviet team held the lead with a 20-8 record.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
High Speeds in the Sun
description: Data obtained from opposite sides of the earth have provided strong support to the view that most of the solar interior is rotating every 13 days -twice as fast as its surface layers, according to astronomers from the University of Birmingham in England and the Institute of Astrophysics at Tenerife in the Canary Islands.

title: COLUMBIA STARTS DRIVE WITH GOAL OF $400 MILLION
description: Columbia University announced yesterday the formal beginning of a five-year effort to raise $400 million, which officials called the largest campaign for donations ever undertaken by an American institution of higher education.

title: Ahmanson Has Quarterly Loss
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company reported a third-quarter loss of $5.16 million today, down considerably from earnings of $5.29 million, or 22 cents a share, posted for the same quarter last year.

title: ENERGY RESOURCES OF NORTH DAKOTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $351,000 for the qr and $620,300 for the 6 mos

title: GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $291,000...C-Net loss

title: THE FIFTH MISSION: COLUMBIA IS POISED FOR A PAYDAY IN SPACE
description: The testing is over. Now comes the time, after four shakedown flights over the last year and a half, for the first demonstration that the American space shuttle can do what it was designed to do: deliver satellites into orbit around the earth. The satellite launching is scheduled to take place Thursday afternoon, high over the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Brazil.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Tough Man
description: Randy Wright, the Wisconsin quarterback, worked out yesterday and said he felt fine. In last Saturday's 20-17 loss to Indiana, Wright was injured with four minutes left in the first half.

title: WAGE BASE IS SET ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Social Security Administration announced today that $35,700 of an individual's earnings would be subject to the payroll tax in 1983, as against $32,400 this year.

title: Atari Gains In Patent Case
description: Atari Inc. said it had won a temporary injunction against Commodore Business Machines that prevents Commodore from making and selling joystick controllers for video games and home computers that are imitations of the one made by Atari. The ruling affects the joystick made by Commodore for its popular VIC-20 home computer.

title: DE LOREAN'S TASTES REQUIRED FLOW OF BIG MONEY
description: John Zachary De Lorean's extravagant and unusual tastes required a constant supply of big money. So did his dream: a sports car that would bear his name.

title: HONDURANS UPSET AT CIVILIAN RULE
description: A year after this country elected its first civilian Government in a decade, the euphoria and optimism that accompanied President Roberto Suazo Cordova's inauguration appears to have been eroded by increasing doubts about the fruits of democracy.

title: PANGLOSS ON THE ENERGY FUTURE: WISHFUL THINKING
description: Pangloss was the ever-optimistic tutor in Voltaire's ''Candide.'' Whatever calamity befell the innocent Candide, be it shipwreck or public torture, the happily deluded Pangloss inevitably proclaimed that this was the best of all possible worlds, and that everything that happened was for the best.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE outstanding presentation of the recently concluded American s pring collections seemed to be that of a Japanese designer who had a lready shown his collection in Paris and who had come here merely tom ake a guest appearance. The designer is Issey Miyake, who presented h is spring collection Thursday night and, in so doing, beat the A mericans at their own sportswear game - aboard, no less, the A merican aircraft carrier Intrepid.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Woman, 65, Slain; Teen-Ager Held
description: A teen-ager was arrested today and charged with the slaying of a 65-year-old woman in her home here, the Nassau County police said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NEW WATCHWORDS: FIT AND FORMALITY
description: What the leaner, more structured spring clothes, presented recently on both sides of the Atlantic, have in common is a sense of formality.

title: DOW DROPS BY 14.34, TO 1,037.44
description: The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.34 points yesterday as investors displayed their disappointment that the Federal Reserve Board had not cut the discount rate.

title: AMERICAN CITY BANK (LOS ANGELES, CORP) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Mystery' Solved
