title: WEAK SPOTS IN A SCENARIO FOR 'CHINA AFTER DENG'
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET THEATER DISPUTE ENDS IN PACT
description: The dancers of the American Ballet Theater voted 61 to 4 early yesterday morning to ratify a new, four-year contract, bringing to an end a nine-week labor dispute and achieving an agreement that offers significant advances for dancers.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter a special net charge of $33 million in connection with the planned restructuring of the company's banana operations

title: Decision Sought On Super Bowl
description: Southern California cities and businesses, which by one estimate stand to gain or lose as much as $60 million in money generated by the Super Bowl, want the National Football League to decide whether the game will be played or will have to be delayed or canceled because of the player strike.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * H.& R. Block filed with the S.E.C. an offering of 1.5 million shares through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

title: SMART BUYING IN TODAY'S FOOD MARKET
description: INSTEAD of spending an ever-increasing share of the weekly budget for the same amount of groceries - as American shoppers have been doing almost a decade - it has actually been possible in the last few weeks to walk out of the supermarket with a few pennies left over.

title: U.N. OPENS PHOTOGRAPHIC DISPLAY OF PALESTINIANS SLAIN IN MASSACRE
description: A photographic exhibition showing Palestinians killed in Beirut refugee camps opened in the visitors' lobby here today after it had been approved by representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Lebanon.

title: EUROPE'S BRUISED STEELMAKERS
description: First it was the steelmakers of Italy and Britain that were faltering; then those in France and Belgium. Now, even West Germany's perennially profitable steel industry will have to reduce capacity and jobs this year in an effort to assure profitability and competitiveness.

title: NO RECESSION IN IDEAS AT CAPITAL THINK TANKS
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 9 - Help Wanted. International economists needed by new Washington research organization. Requirements: analytical skills, practical experience in Government or international organizations, ability to communicate. Salary negotiable.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
...AND AUSTRALIAN 'WINTER OF DREAMS'
description: JUDY DAVIS, highly praised for her performance in ''My Brilliant Career,'' is the only reason to see ''Winter of Our Dreams,'' John Duigan's 1981 Australian film that opens today at the D.W. Griffith Theater.

title: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $149,100; yr-ago qr and yr shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Nov 6, 1981

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split as of May 24, 1982

title: Kitchenaid Account Goes to N.W. Ayer
description: The Kitchenaid division of the Hobart Corporation, itself a unit of Dart & Kraft Inc., has appointed N.W. Ayer as its advertising agency.

title: 16 MAJOR PAINTINGS TO BE SOLD
description: Sixteen Impressionist paintings collected at the turn of the century by the Henry O. Havemeyers and not seen publicly for a halfcentury will be auctioned in May at Sotheby Parke Bernet. The house values the works at more than $10 million.

title: Court Backs Lee Myles
description: A New York Supreme Court judge has overturned a decision by the state's Attorney General not to allow the Lee Myles Corporation to franchise its transmission repair business in the state.

title: PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Offenders Wrongly Placed on Probation
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia G.O.P. Runoff Held
description: Paul Jones won a primary runoff tonight to gain the Republican nomination for the Fifth Congression District in a very light turnout.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BARS A BLACK ROLE IN 3-HOUSE PARLIAMENTARY SYSTEM
description: Any suggestions that blacks might be given representation in a projected three-chamber South African Parliament have been denounced as ''purposeful lies'' by the Cabinet minister in charge of putting the new system into effect.

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Family Circle Promotions Set
description: Family Circle magazine, a publication of The New York Times Company, yesterday announced a number of top management changes. Thomas C. Redd, 58 years old, currently vice president of advertising, has been appointed publisher and senior vice president.

title: AZL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bell Settlement
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company joined the Justice Department in seeking speedy Supreme Court review to clear the way for implementation of their antitrust settlement. The accord provides for the divestiture of A.T.& T.'s 22 local operating companies and the restructuring of the communications industry.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tom Petty Keeps Rolling Along His Optimistic Way
description: TOM PETTY and the Heartbreakers have forged a successful career in rock's commercial mainstream without seeming to pay the slightest attention to the shifting tides of fashion. When Mr. Petty first arrived in Los Angeles from his native Florida in the mid-1970&s, his brand of melodic, guitar-based rock-and-roll was utterly out of step with the lead-footed heavy metal and the slick, calculating FMprogressive sounds that then ruled the rock best-seller charts. Some critics decided that Mr. Petty and the Heartbreakers were ''new wave,'' but their sound had more to do with the rock-and-roll classicism of the Byrds than with the lightweight pop-rock sound of the California new wave bands.

title: A SECRTARY OF STATE AS BUDGET ADVISER
description: As President Reagan undertakes the task of scrutinizing the proposed budget for the fiscal year 1984, one of his key advisers at the twice-daily sessions is George P. Shultz. The Secretary of State is not there because of any pressing foreign policy need, but because he knows a lot about budgets.

title: Occidental Falls 82.1%; I.T.T. Rises
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, affected by losses from its coal and chemical businesses and high interest expenses related to its forthcoming merger with the Cities Services Company, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter plunged 82.1 percent from a year earlier.

title: 10 YEARS LATER, MISSOURIANS FIND SOIL TAINTED BY DIOXIN
description: The area is known variously as Shady Valley, Tara Hill and Country Club Manor, but in recent weeks the ambiance has been less suburban ease and more apprehension and anger. Ranged around the ranch-style houses and two mobile homes is soil contaminated with the deadly poison dioxin at thousands of times the level at which the Federal Government would ordinarily order a cleanup.

title: IRT DERAILMENT HOLDS UP SERVICE ON THE WEST SIDE
description: Subway service was disrupted on the West Side yesterday morning when a motor dropped off an aging subway car, bounced against an axle and caused the derailment of a southbound IRT express train as it was pulling into the 96th Street station.

title: NEW REAGAN POLICY BACKS AERONAUTICS WORK
description: The Reagan Administration announced yesterday an updated policy on aeronautical research that rejected threatened slashes in funds and concluded that continuing strong support for research promised large advances in both civil and military aviation.

title: Opener to Arrows
description: Fred Grgurev and Steve Zungel each scored twice tonight to lead the New York Arrows to a season-opening 6-4 victory over the San Diego Sockers in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FEW people would need more than one guess to pick America's favorite candy - it's chocolate, of course. The popular children's books ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'' by Roald Dahl and ''Chocolate Fever'' by Robert Kimmel Smith presaged the current best seller, Sandra Boynton's ''Chocolate: The Consuming Passion'' (Workman, $4.95), an amusing closer-to-fact-than-fiction tribute to that universally coveted derivative of the cacao bean.

title: RIFT ON REAGAN BUDGET COURSES HINTED AND DENIED
description: Senate Republican sources complained today that President Reagan's senior advisers were engaged in an ideological fight over budget strategy that could harm the President's program. Their allegations were promptly denied by ranking White House officials.

title: THE SEASON IS AT HAND FOR A TASTE OF THE WILD
description: HERE is a bit of hypocrisy in my attitude toward game. On the one hand I am quite uncomfortable around shotguns, rods and reels, but on the other I yield without hesitation to well-made venison dishes, pates of quail, roast pheasant, roast quail, quail in vine leaves or with grapes. Offer me a platter of venison Bourguignon with a rich old bottle of Chambertin and it will turn any cold winter day's feast into a sumptuous occasion. It occurs to me, however, that no aspect of cookery is more intimidating to home cooks than turning a piece of game into a triumph for the table. One of my earliest frustrations in trying to do so was nearly 40 years ago, when my sister gave me a brace of pheasants as a Christmas present.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Less Than Original

title: HAMILTON MERRILL
description: Hamilton Merrill, former president of Manning, Maxwell & Moore Inc., a valve and gauge manufacturer that is now part of Dresser Industries Inc., of Dallas, died Saturday at his home in Orleans, Mass.

title: Ingenious Tactics May Lie Behind a Bidder's Retreat
description: A player who is doubled in a no-trump contract and fears a heavy penalty will often seek a safe harbor by retreating to his own suit. In one or two very rare situations, however, such a retreat may actually be a request to partner to pick a suit of his own.

title: BALLET: CULLBERG 'GISELLE'
description: century classic of the Romantic ballet such as ''Giselle?'' Most ballet companies might simply dance it. Some might even rethink it. But Mats Ek has taken it apart, reset its second act in an insane asylum, turned it into a modern-dress modern-dance version, filled the stage with sexy decor, thrown in a touch of male nudity and generally tried to pick up the pieces of his own purposefully alogical scenario. At his best, he is outrageous.

title: WOMAN ACCUSED OF PLANNING CRIMES WITH BRINK'S SUSPECTS
description: A 34-year-old woman was arrested in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges that she conspired to commit three robberies with suspects in the $1.6 million Brink's armored-car holdup and triple murder in Rockland County last year.

title: BROADCASTERS' BURDENS
description: Television and radio stations suffer from excessive Federal regulation that inhibits both the free market and free speech. While the owners of newspapers, magazines and publishing houses enjoy the rights conferred by the Constitution upon ordinary citizens, society insists on saddling broadcasters with special obligations. This burden must be eased. If accompanied by the imposition of fees upon broadcasters for the use of channel frequencies, which are granted by the Government, the rewards of such deregulation could be shared by society as a whole. The money collected might even be used to support public television and radio.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Hawks 106, Nuggets 105
description: DENVER (AP) - Wes Matthews hit a 3-point basket at the buzzer to give Alanta the victory. Billy McKinney had put the Nuggets ahead by 105-103 with an 18-foot jump shot with three seconds to play.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 BASQUES SUSPECTED OF PLOT TO KILL POPE ON HIS SPANISH TRIP
description: Two Basque separatists arrested in France are believed to have plotted to assassinate Pope John Paul II during his trip to Spain, press reports said today.

title: Sonics 112, Bulls 111
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Jack Sikma scored 21 points and David Thompson added 20 to lead undefeated Seattle to its seventh straight victory.

title: U.S.-ALLIED ACCORD ON SOVIET PIPELINE DESCRIBED AS NEAR
description: The United States and its key allies have reached virtual agreement on a policy that will enable President Reagan to revoke sanctions imposed on companies that take part in construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline, Administration officials said today.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN AN EARLIER FIGHT ON JOB MEASURE
description: The House Democratic leadership agreed today to press in the postelection session of Congress for legislation that would authorize a public works program to provide jobs for the unemployed.

title: GOING OUT GUIDEIRISH NIGHT
description: The Lower East Side has not in the last hundred years and more been considered Irish turf. It was the home of other, later-arriving immigrants, but for all that, tonight at 8 a tiny piece of the Lower East Side will be very Irish for several hours. That plot will be, St. Mark's Church at Second Avenue and 10th Street, a neighborhood once home of the knish. The Poetry Project in the church is going to present ''Poetry and Music From Irish America.''

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,159,000 for the qr and $2,979,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,411,000 for the qr and $3,976,000 for the 9 mos

title: Poetry Center Program
description: ''Texts,'' a solo performance piece adapted from two Samuel Beckett works, will be presented by Joseph Chaikin on Nov. 29 at 8 P.M. at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street. Mr. Chaikin and Steven Kent, a director currently associated with the Manhattan Theater Club, adapted the piece from Beckett's ''Texts for Nothing'' and ''How It Is.'' Tickets are $8. Information: 427-4410.

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: WHAT DRY BRUT AND DOUX MEAN
description: The words on Champagne labels indicating the degree of dryness are confusing. For example, the English term ''extra dry'' is used to connote a slightly sweet Champagne, whereas the driest is labeled ''brut,'' which means, among other things, extra dry. Consumers who prefer their Champagnes very dry should look for brut on the label, for it means drier than extra dry.

title: PANEL SEES PROBLEM IN STUDY OF EFFECTS OF AGENT ORANGE
description: A panel of experts appointed by the National Academy of Sciences warned in a report released today that a proposed study of the effects of the herbicide Agent Orange on ground troops in Vietnam rested on an ''insecure scientific base.''

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago amounts reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in June

title: JEWS SETTLE ON A 'VOLCANO' IN THE CENTER OF HEBRON
description: Occupied West Bank - The muezzins were summoning the faithful to prayer from mosques all over Hebron, a conservative Moslem town under Israeli occupation since 1967.

title: AMERICAN CITY BANK (LOS ANGELES, CALIF) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $17.8 million on the sale of North Sea interests

title: LEVER HOUSE OFFICE TOWER DECLARED A CITY LANDMARK
description: Lever House became the most contemporary landmark in New York City last night when the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously to grant that status to the 30-year-old mid-Manhattan office tower.

title: Of Passing Interest
description: When Gary Williams of Ohio State catches his first pass against Northwestern on Saturday he will establish a national collegiate record for receptions in consecutive games. It will mark the 43d straight regular-season game in which he has caught a pass, moving him past John Jefferson, who went to Arizona State, and John Filliez, who attended Marshall.

title: Israeli Ban on Strauss Lifted But Wagner Is Still Prohibited
description: The Israel state broadcasting authority lifted its 34-year ban tonight on playing the musical works of Richard Strauss, who served briefly as head of musical affairs under the Nazis, but retained it on the works of Richard Wagner, an outspoken anti-Semite.

title: NEW HAVEN
description: IN his last play, ''The American Clock,'' Arthur Miller nobly attempted to tell the story of an entire generation against a background as large as the United States map. Perhaps it's in reaction to that sprawling work's failure that his two new one-act plays, now receiving their premiere at the Long Wharf Stage 2, are two-character pieces, pared dramatically to the bone. Whatever the reason for its genesis, this evening is a worthy, though unsuccessful, experiment in esthetic simplicity by a writer who's prone to thinking big.

title: ELMORE THWARTS KNICKS
description: Len Elmore, a starter at center last season, has been little more than a sideline observer this season as Darryl Dawkins and Mike Gminski have played larger roles for the New Jersey Nets.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE largest crop of grapes in history has been harvested this year in the Champagne district of France, where ideal weather conditions prevailed throughout the growing season and a plenitude of wine will be produced. The abundant crop will help to offset a shortage of Champagne resulting from a series of mediocre vintages and it should help to stabilize prices.

title: THE CASE OF THE MISIDENTIFIED STRANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economic Scene; Feldstein View Of the Course
description: WITH the election over, President Reagan and his key advisers are trying to decide where they go from here if they are to strengthen the economy's performance and keep Republican control of the White House in 1984.

title: WESTERN GRAIN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUBURBAN PROPANE GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A CURATOR'S PHILOSOPHY: 'I STARTED THE HARD SELL'
description: He is known in the capital as ''The Grand Acquisitor.'' And that he is. For as curator of the Department of State and the White House, Clement E. Conger has scrounged, begged, borrowed and bought almost $20 million of antique furniture, porcelain, paintings and silver for the State Department's diplomatic reception rooms and the state rooms of the White House.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in the Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly characterized the defendants in a race-fixing trial at Uniondale, L.I. They are not grooms.

title: I.L.O. Might Scrutinize Soviet Pipeline Crews
description: The Soviet Union has offered to receive a team of International Labor Organization officials to discuss living and working conditions on the pipeline under construction to carry natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe, the I.L.O. said today.

title: END OF A CAPITAL GAINS TAX STIRS BATTLE OVER REFUNDS
description: In July 1981, a few days before the New York Legislature adjourned for the session, a five-part tax package was signed into law. It was intended to bridge a gap in the public transportation budget. One part of the package imposed a 10 percent capital gains tax on real estate transactions in New York City above $1 million, and it was expected to bring in approximately $54 million over two fiscal years.

title: MIRIAM OTTENBERG
description: Miriam Ottenberg, a reporter for The Washington Star who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1960, died today of cancer.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: G.M. to Begin Worker Recall
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would begin recalling 2,400 laid-off workers at a plant in Pontiac, Mich., in January to prepare for production of its new European-style Fiero sports car.

YIELD DROPS ON 30-YEAR BONDS
description: The Treasury sold new 30-year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 10.46 percent, the lowest since May 1980, but one still high enough to attract both speculators and investors.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Kean and Cabinet Confer on Budget
description: Governor Kean took his cabinet chiefs and top staff aides away from the state capital Monday night to the Seaview Country Club in Atlantic County for two days of discussions on New Jersey's budget problems - present and projected -and possible longrange projects the administration should undertake.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: IN FULL PANOPLY, BEEFEATERS INDUCT 14
description: NO conclusions should be drawn, Chief Warder Whitney I. Gerard said, from the fact that inductees into the Beefeater Club of the Incorporated Ancient Order of the Beefeater were made to kneel in ritual directly following the serving of the English cheese course.

title: Brewers' Yount Voted M.V.P.
description: Robin Yount, the Milwaukee Brewers' shortstop, was voted the American League's most valuable player yesterday, but fell one ballot short of perfection.

title: 2 in Voting Fraud Case Paroled After 11 Months
description: Two black women were freed today after 11 months in custody for voting fraud convictions, and a civil rights leader praised them for inspiring extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $300,000 for the qr and $1,186,000 for the yr from the sale of assets and a gain of $295,000 for the yr from the early repayment of a mortgage...C-Including gains of $53,000 for the qr and $564,000 for the yr from the sale of assets

title: EAST GERMANY IS WARY OF NEW BONN GOVERNMENT
description: The Government of East Germany has been warily watching political developments in West Germany since the Bonn leadership changed hands last month.

title: TORTUOUS ROAD TO NAMIBIAN INDEPENDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: WRIGHT-HARGREAVES MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEFENSE CHIEF PREPARES TO SUBMIT MX MISSILE PROPOSAL TO PRESIDENT
description: Amid tight secrecy, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger put the final touches today on his recommendation to President Reagan for basing the MX nuclear missiles, apparently in an array of sunken silos built close together.

title: Divorce Suit Is Speeded For Dying Mother of 4
description: A Montville woman, hospitalized with terminal brain and lung cancer, says she wants an immediate divorce because she thinks her husband will not provide for their four children after her death.

title: STATE AND U.S. BATTLE OVER I-684 BUS ROUTE
description: Drive down Interstate 684 through Westchester County, and chances are you won't even notice Connecticut go by. One minute you're in this Westchester County village, and not long afterward you're passing the Westchester County Airport. Connecticut, unmarked, is somewhere between.

title: WEST BLOC BIDS EAST ACCEPT FREE UNIONS
description: The two-year-old conference that is reviewing the 1975 Helsinki accords on European security resumed here today with Western nations making fresh demands on the Soviet bloc to accept free trade unions and the right to political self-determination.

title: Wean Closing Site
description: Wean United Inc., which makes machinery and steel and iron products, said it would phase out fabricating operations at its North River Road plant in Warren, Ohio, permanently closing the plant by early next year and affecting about 120 workers. It attributed the shutdown to a declining market.

title: ENDS AT 1,060.25
description: With pension funds and other large institutions actively putting their cash to work, the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 22.81 points yesterday to record its second-highest closing ever, at 1,060.25.

title: SOFTEN THAT SOAP
description: I wonder if the politicial TV commercial hasn't become hopelessly antique. The question occurred to me a few weeks ago when every politician in the country was bombarding the electorate on every channel, as though we were an enemy fortress to be battered into submission.

title: TORTUOUS ROAD TO NAMIBIAN INDEPENDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: JFK Run Derailing Laid to 2 Cousins
description: Two cousins, one 13 years old and the other 14, were arrested yesterday and charged in connection with Sunday's derailment in Brooklyn of a JFK Express subway train traveling from Kennedy International Airport to Manhattan with 20 passengers.

title: Patience Pays
description: Scott Dye, who used to kick field goals for Utah State, made a hard choice six years ago: baseball over football. Then he spent six years struggling in the minor leagues, and often wondered if he had made the wrong choice.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
Nicaragua Says Patrol Boat Was Fired on by Hondurans
description: Two Honduran warships sailed into Nicaraguan waters and shelled a Nicaraguan coast guard boat, the Foreign Ministry said Monday night.

title: Duran Promises To Reveal All
description: Why did Roberto Duran suddenly quit fighting in the eighth round of his second bout against Sugar Ray Leonard in 1980, abandoning the welterweight title and beginning the decline of one of the most successful and profitable careers in boxing?

title: 'CREEPSHOW,' IN FIVE PARTS
description: ''CREEPSHOW'' isn't quite that and it doesn't mean to be, but it means to be funny and most of the time it's simply good-natured. The film, which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is a collaboration between George A. Romero, the Eisenstein of Pittsburgh who directed ''Night of the Living Dead'' and ''Dawn of the Dead,'' and Stephen King, the novelist (''The Shining,'' among others), who wrote the screenplays for this five-part film and acts -outrageously - as the star of one.

title: MOSCOW'S MIDDLE EAST
description: There is a widely held view in Washington that the outcome of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon was a humiliating defeat for the Soviet Union and a welcome triumph for the United States. Some signs point in this direction, but the cheerleading may be premature. Obviously, the Kremlin, which is proud of its image as a superpower, was not overjoyed watching Israel, an ally of the United States, trounce Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization. And, of course, Moscow cannot have been happy that Soviet weapons performed so poorly in Syrian hands. Still, the Politburo appears to believe that, in the long run, the Lebanese war may work to the Soviet rather than to the American advantage.

title: Market Place; Prospecting, After the Rally
description: THE strongest bull market in recent times has sent shares to such high levels that some investors fear there may be no major gains ahead. But other investors argue that the market was so depressed before the August rally that stock prices are simply catching up. Even with the impressive gains of the past three months, these optimists say, the 30 stocks of the Dow Jones industrial average are still only valued at close to stated book value.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: COLLEGE

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $1,181,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr and 9 mos from reduction of silver inventories under LIFO accounting and income of $510,000 for the 9 mos for an increase in gold inventories

title: News Analysis
description: New York City's budget, buffeted by the recession, has drifted so badly out of balance that there is serious talk for the first time since 1975 of renegotiating municipal labor contracts.

title: Air Force Perfects Art Of Deception
description: C adet Martin D. Louthan, the 22-year-old quarterback for the Air Force Academy, majors in behavioral sciences in the classroom and in deception on the football field. Against Army last Saturday at West Point, Louthan's deception in operating the Falcons' wishbone offense kept the Black Knights off balance and contributed heavily to a 27-9 victory for Air Force.

title: TV: SIGNING OF THE ARMISTICE IN 1918
description: THE famed setting for the signing of the Armistice that halted World War I, a lushly appointed railway car on a siding in the Forest of Compiegne not far from the battle lines, is used to full effect in ''Gossip From the Forest,'' a 90-minute drama that can be seen at 9 P.M. on WNET-TV, Channel 13. There, in that symbol of bygone French grandeur, the German delegation capitulated to the demands of the Allies, led by Marshal Foch, ending one war and, it has long been argued, laying the ground for another.

title: New Ashe Role
description: Consider Arthur Ashe. There may be busier people in sports, and more adaptable ones, but probably not many. His tennis playing career, which included winning the Wimbledon and United States Open titles, was shortened by heart surgery.

title: RICHARDSON REPORTS
description: Mychal Thompson, one of seven Portland players to reach double figures, scored 20 points tonight as the Trail Blazers beat the Golden State Warriors 111-96.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.S.P.C.A. Finds Dead Guard Dogs
description: Agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday that they had found the remains of four German shepherd guard dogs at the long-empty former New York Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan.

title: Missouri Publisher Buys The Saturday Review
description: The 29-year-old publisher of a campus newspaper and a regional magazine announced today that he was purchasing The Saturday Review and moving it to Missouri from New York City.

title: Clemson Is Said To Face Sanction
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference's apparent decision to impose sanctions against Clemson for recruiting violations was viewed by some league officials today as an attempt to soften probation that is likely to be imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: SOME IMPORTED FOOD PRICES DECLINE
description: A recent newspaper advertisement for imported furniture began: ''Our foreign policy. When the dollar goes up abroad, our prices come down at home.''

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an insurance recovery of $100,000...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $15,980 for the qr and $91,052 for the 9 mos

title: Meanwhile, the Courts Founder
description: The strike of 550 Legal Aid Society lawyers, already in its third week, is calamitous enough for thousands of defendants in New York City's criminal courts. Their constitutional right to competent legal counsel is eroding daily as the system struggles along with nonstriking supervisors and private lawyers.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ASHORT while back, while dining in the home of a friend, I was served a dish with two ingredients that some cooks may find a curious blend. A souffle made with flaked canned tuna and cheese, it was excellent and something about it stirred my memory.

title: Nehemiah Wins One
description: Renaldo Nehemiah may not be able to compete as an Olympic hurdler because he played professional football, but he has been granted permission to take part in track and field events in this country. The Athletics Congress, the governing body for track and field, voted to let him compete domestically, subject to approval of its board of governors.

title: British Oil Licenses
description: Britain's Energy Department said it had awarded 11 petroleum exploration licenses covering about 1,302 square miles in the north and midland areas of England.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results were restated to reflect foreign currency translation accounting changes

title: METEORITE CRASHES INTO HOUSE IN CONNECTICUT
description: A six-pound meteorite about the size of a grapefruit hurtled out of the sky over Wethersfield, Conn., Monday night and tore through the roof of a house and its second- and first-floor ceilings. It crashed into the living room, and ricocheted through a doorway and into the dining room, where it came to rest at the end of a trail of plaster and splinters.

title: PROFIT SURGES AT MGM/UA
description: The sparkling summer box-office success of two films, ''Rocky III'' and ''Poltergeist,'' helped the MGM/UA Entertainment Company more than double its profit in the quarter ended Aug. 31 compared with a year ago, the company said today.

title: Garvey and Kemp Differ on Objectives
description: Steve Garvey and Steve Kemp, two of the most glamorous players available, enter today's free-agent draft in contrasting positions. Garvey would like the Los Angeles Dodgers to retain their rights to him, but they have said they will not. Kemp would like the Chicago White Sox to relinquish their rights to him, but they have said they will not.

title: L.I.U. Wins, 6-0
description: Amador Carvalho scored two goals and had an assist to lead the undefeated Long Island University soccer team to a 6-0 victory over Marist College yesterday at the L.I.U. Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

title: PEPSI'S FALSE FOREIGN PROFITS
description: Four senior overseas managers of Pepsico Inc. who have been dismissed for inflating sales and overstating profits were apparently receiving performance-related bonuses, which the company said it does not intend to try to recover.

title: MIDDLE AGED YEVTUSHENKO IS BITTEN BY MOVIE BUG
description: Yevgeny Yevtushenko was spotted on a dreary, drizzly day recently beside a pond in Moscow, mustachioed and unshaven, with pajama bottoms tumbling onto unbuckled boots and a worn fez atop his head.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: SOMETIMES it's a shock to realize how old you are. It's more than being young at heart; it's a feeling that the whole chronological thing is unbelievable and that someone else may be 39 or 47 or 58 but certainly not you.

title: JAMESBURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: B-AFter loss from discontinued operations of $420,000

title: Celebrity Cyclist
description: Riding a bicycle through Rock Creek Park in Washington on a Sunday morning can be a heady experience: One might encounter a Congressman or an admiral. But a group of amateur cyclists got an international treat last weekend.

title: 'STARSTRUCK' DOWN UNDER...
description: LIKE Gillian Armstrong's first film, ''My Brilliant Career,'' her second has a red-haired heroine with decidedly headstrong ways. That's where the resemblance ends, however, since ''My Brilliant Career'' was set in turn-of-the-century rural Australia, and the new film takes place among the punk-rock vanguard of modern Sydney.

title: CHALLENGE FOR JAPANESE STEEL
description: The Japanese steel industry, which once seemed immune to the industrial problems in the West, is now facing challenges similar to those confronting its troubled foreign counterparts.

title: IN RIO, AN OLD ENEMY IRKS THE ARMY
description: With less than a week to go in the campaigning for the first free municipal, legislative and gubernatorial elections in Brazil in 17 years, attention has focused on the race in Rio de Janeiro State, where a candidate for governor who is widely resented by the armed forces is leading.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The State Department said today that a new education tax Rumania has imposed on applicants for visas to emigrate could ''gravely jeopardize'' the preferential tariff treatment Rumania receives on its exports to the United States.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Taking a Beating on the Job

title: RICHMOND TO PAY WALCO $425,000 IN S.E.C. CASE
description: Former Representative Frederick W. Richmond agreed today to pay $425,000 to a company he founded to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that he had violated Federal securities laws.

title: WHEELABRATOR AND SIGNAL TO MERGE
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc., the environmental, energy and engineering concern, and the Signal Companies, a maker of aircraft equipment, petrochemical plants and trucks, announced jointly last night that they had agreed to merge in an exchange of stock valued at about $960 million.

title: Denton, Hooper Gain
description: Steve Denton and Chip Hooper, two of the United States' hopes in the $200,000 Benson & Hedges tennis tournament, overcame slow starts today to win their first-round matches.

title: 10 Sect Members in Arizona Plead Not Guilty Over Melee
description: Ten members of an all-black religious sect at Miracle Valley have pleaded notguilty to charges stemming from a confrontation with law enforcement officials on Oct. 23 in which two church members were shot to death.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results restated to reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 16
1. Submarine Mode
description: The French designers Marithe and Francois Girbaud have usually taken their inspiration from young people in the Paris streets. Lately they've been getting ideas from the garments that submarine crews wear. They started with a jacket printed with life-preserver instructions and have now done a submariner's sweat shirt in white cotton with an interesting V-shaped yoke, bands of black at the armholes and a label printed on the outside rather than in. The shirt is made in this country by Complements and is on Lord & Taylor's fifth floor at $44.

title: U.S. ENVOY TO SALVADOR IS ORDERED TO STOP CRITICIZING RIGHTS ABUSE
description: Administration officials said today that the United States Ambassador to El Salvador had been told to refrain from making public criticisms of human rights abuses by Salvadoran security forces.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARGUELLO REACTING LIKE A GENTLEMAN
description: Thirty-year-old Alexis Arguello, who will be striving to become the first boxer to win world titles in four weight classes when he challenges for Aaron Pryor's World Boxing Association junior welterweight championship Friday, is such a gentleman that he is disconcerting.

title: Market Place; The Hard Part: When to Sell
description: MANY investors with large paper profits might consider ways to hold on to those gains and think less about ways of adding to them. The stop-loss order is a well-known device for holding gains, although it is little used in times like these. But one professional investor who focuses on preservation of capital has managed to do better than most on the way up and to limit setbacks by employing such a concept.

title: Times Press Run Was Cut Yesterday
description: The New York Times said yesterday that it had been unable to print the final 165,000 copies of its Wednesday issue because of what it called an illegal job action by pressmen.

title: SOVIET CALLS SHCHARANSKY'S STATE SATISFACTORY
description: The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, an imprisoned dissident, said today that she had been officially informed that her son was in satisfactory health, 45 days after he reportedly began a hunger strike.

title: INTEGRATED ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $429,000 on the sale of its interest in an oiland gas limited partnership...CThe company went public on Nov 10, 1981 so thereare no comparison figures

title: POWER STRUGGLE RACKING SPAIN'S COMMUNISTS
description: A bitter power struggle is unfolding within the Communist Party of Spain and its allied trade union that could determine whether the organization survives as a credible representative of the left.

title: MacLeish Is Released
description: Rick MacLeish, a 32-year-old center-forward, who once was one of the highest scorers in the National Hockey League, was given his unconditional release yesterday by the Pittsburgh Penguins. He played with the Philadelphia Flyers from 1970 through the 1980-81 season, scoring 50 goals in the 1972-73 season and 49 in 1976-77. Last season he scored 13 goals for the Hartford Whalers and the Penguins.

title: Knife-Makers Put Talents on Display
description: M any of this country's most talented creators of custom-made knives are displaying their work at the New York Sheraton this weekend.

title: Prisoner Is Indicted For Murder in Jail Fire
description: Robert E. Pates was ordered held without bond today on murder charges that he set a jailhouse fire in which 27 of his fellow prisoners died.

title: GRAND PRIZ SITE IN WATKINS GLEN BOUGHT BY BANK
description: The winding, 3.4-mile auto race track here, scene of the United States Grand Prix for more than two decades but crippled by debt in recent years, was sold at a bankruptcy auction today to the Bank of New York.

title: Leafs 8, Red Wings 2
description: TORONTO (AP) -Billy Harris and Miroslav Frycer scored two goals apiece as Toronto routed Detroit and its rookie goaltender, Greg Stefan.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERING DRILLING CREW TO QUIT NEW MEXICO REFUGE
description: A Federal judge ordered a natural gas drilling crew out of a Federal wilderness area today, and four protesters blockaded a road to the disputed site.

title: Good Sense and Good Instincts
description: BALTIMORE R ay Leonard always had good sense in the ring - how to stalk an opponent, how to pace himself. On Tuesday night, he showed his usual good instincts by retiring from boxing at the age of 26, leaving a destructive business with his eyesight and his mind still intact.

title: REV. GERALD A. QUINN
description: The Rev. Gerald A. Quinn, the chaplain of the evening division at St. Peter's College in Jersey City from 1965 to 1975, died Saturday at the Murray-Wiegel Hall infirmary at Fordham University. He was 78 years old.

description: B-After a loss of Chromalloy affiliate of $9,651,000...C-After a loss of affiliate of $232,000 and a gain on the sale of a product line of $8,421,000...D-Aftera loss of discontinued operations of affiliate of $1,385,000...E-After a loss of discontinued operations of affiliate of $1,385,000 and a gain of $8,421,000 from disposition of a product line

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reality and TV

title: SOVIET LEADER USED CONSENSUS IN POLITBURO ON DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: As the leader of the Soviet Union, Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev was a canny and careful Communist Party functionary who sought to make his country the military equal of the United States and promote its political influence around the world through the policy of detente.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN a lamp won't light and the problem isn't just a burned-out bulb, then the first place to check for trouble is the power supply. The wall switch to that outlet may have been turned off accidentally, or the circuit breaker or fuse for the circuit may have tripped or blown.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
The Vietnam Names
description: During the Vietnam War, the names belonged to the peace movement. Demonstrators marched past the White House shouting the names of those who had fallen. In a single extraordinary stroke of journalism, Life magazine may have turned millions against the war simply by printing the names and pictures of those who had died in the course of a single week.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $384,000

title: SENSITIVITY TO SPAIN
description: The election of a new Socialist government in Spain presents the United States with a critical choice. Washington could further erase the scars of its support of the Franco dictatorship and build good relations with the new democracy by respecting Spain's need to act independently in its own interests after years of what many Spaniards think was subservience to America. Or it could add one more country to the catalogue of angry Europeans who think America acts only for itself without consideration of allies' needs.

title: Howden Underwriting
description: The underwriting capacity of two Lloyd's syndicates managed by Alexander Howden Underwriting Ltd. could be sharply curtailed in 1983 because of defections by members, officials said today. Some 1,100 syndicate members have said they intend to leave, out of a total of 3,600, the officials said. Howden Underwriting is part of the Alexander Howden Group, which is under investigation by Lloyd's and the Department of Trade for possible bookkeeping irregularities.

title: Product Introductions
description: October marked the fifth straight month this year that new product introductions continued to outpace last year's level. According to the latest edition of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, October introductions numbered 135, 33 percent higher than the 102 reported last year. And for the 10 months to date this year, introductions number 1,209, or 12 percent over the 1,078 for the same period in 1981.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PRESIDENT HAS FAITH IN SALVADOR ENVOY
description: The White House said today that the United States Ambassador to El Salvador, Deane R. Hinton, retained the ''full faith and confidence'' of President Reagan despite the controversy over a recent speech that had not been fully cleared by the Administration.

title: DEAD
description: Harold Birns, a prominent state jurist and a former Commissioner of the New York City Buildings Department, died Tuesday at University Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and a lifelong resident of Manhattan.

title: SELAS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $28,000 for the qr and $69,000 for the 9mos

title: Derailment Delays Northeast Service
description: Traffic in Amtrak's Northeast Corridor between Philadelphia and New York was delayed yesterday following the early-morning derailment of a Conrail mail train near Princeton Junction.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Capital Cities Communications Inc. has elected to its board M. Cabell Woodward Jr., executive vice president and chief financial officer of the International Telephone and Tele- graph Corporation.

title: FIVE TEAMS NOW SUPPORT N.F.L. OFFER
description: Sentiment for accepting management's latest contract offer arose yesterday among the striking players of two more National Football League teams, the Cincinnati Bengals and the Denver Broncos.

title: Judge Approves Boudin Absence
description: Kathy Boudin, a defendant in the Brink's robbery and triple-slaying case, was excused from remaining pretrial hearings today after protesting daily security measures at the Rockland County Jail.

title: Discrimination Suit
description: Lea Sukenik, 26, of New York has filed a suit charging religious discrimination against the supervisors of the United States trials for the sixth world karate championships, which are scheduled this month in Taiwan. She said, in her suit filed in United States District Court here, that the trials were held during Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, on Sept. 18 and 19. Miss Sukenik, who said she is one of the nation's top four female karate experts, said she is ''an observant Jew who was unwilling to violate the laws and precepts of the Jewish faith.''

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. announced that it had begun construction of a plant in Metropolis, Ill., to develop specialty products based on fluorinated carbon; the plant is expected to be operational next year.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NUCLEAR FREEZE PROPONENTS' WRONG VILLAIN
description: T o the Editor: The success of the nuclear weapons freeze plebiscites in the voting on Nov. 3 represents a disturbing shift in public sensibilities. Instead of recognizing that the preservation of peace and decent human life depends on the objectives of the people and regimes that have nuclear weapons, American opinion seems to be increasingly content to decry the weapons as evils in themselves, as if the bombs were self-creating and self-detonating.

title: DANCE: DAVID WOODBERRY, AT PERFORMING GARAGE
description: DAVID WOODBERRY, one of choreography's daredevils, took some fresh risks on Monday night at the Performing Garage. In recent years, Mr. Woodberry has offered dances containing strenuous movements that must be performed with the utmost insouciance. At their best, they have been exhilarating; at their weakest, they have been just a lot of horsing around. But in both the good and the bad Mr. Woodberry has always appeared to be no one other than himself.

description: Iranian troops appear to have repelled a series of Iraqi counterattacks and driven more deeply into enemy territory.

title: BALLET THEATER REHEARSES FOR BENEFIT
description: Music filled the studios of the American Ballet Theater yesterday. But it wasn't Tchaikovsky, or even Ludwig Minkus. Instead, the sound of swing streamed out as the Ballet Theater dancers rehearsed for a gala party-performance that will be held at Roseland on Monday.

description: The Delaware River Basin Commission, citing a four-month dry spell in upstate New York, issued a drought warning today and cut 120 million gallons a day from New York City's allowance of Delaware River water.

title: Bendix Net Falls 84.8%
description: The Bendix Corporation, citing the impact of the recession, reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter plunged 84.8 percent, while sales slipped 6.2 percent.

SCOUTING
description: Brinkmanship Beth Daniel was in Hawaii yesterday playing golf, but she was still wondering about the putt she sank last Sunday in Japan: It made her No.1 in official tournament earnings this year in the Ladies' Professional Golf Association. One year ago, she birdied the final hole of the final tournament, and that made her No.1 in gross money.

title: ERTE, AT 90, IS CAUSE FOR CELEBRATION
description: ''IS this le tout New York?'' asked Ina Ginsburg, surveying, from the safety of her taffeta stole, the crowd that had been invited to celebrate the 90th birthday and retrospective exhibition of Erte, the legendary Russian illustrator.

title: 650,000 MORE SEEK JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: Direct governmental costs of the highest unemployment rate in 40 years continued to increase this week as an additional 650,000 people asked for jobless benefit payments and yet another state was forced by rising unemployment to provide an extra 13 weeks of these payments.

title: BRIEFING
description: On Bureaucratic Time

title: PRESSURE ON BANK REGULATORS
description: Although there is widespread concern about the explosive growth of bank lending abroad and bank exposure to huge losses, there is considerable disagreement about whether Federal regulation of the loans is sufficient.

title: Stepien Ready to Sell
description: After losses that he said amounted to $7 million over the last two years, Ted Stepien said that he had decided to sell the Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association.

title: DEVILS EXTEND VICTORYLESS STREAK TO 11
description: The Washington Capitals completely outplayed the Devils and posted a 3-0 victory tonight before a crowd of 12,445 at Capital Centre.

title: Key Canada Rate Drops
description: The Bank of Canada today lowered its bank rate to 10.84 percent, from 11.2 percent, the first time the rate on loans to commercial banks has been under 11 percent since 1980. In response, the Royal Bank, the country's largest, cut its prime rate by three-quarters of a point, to 13 percent.

title: COULD RAISE $910 MILLION
description: In a major step in its campaign to denationalize state-controlled businesses, the British Government today released details of its plans to offer private investors 51 percent of Britoil P.L.C., which has a stake in almost one-third of all North Sea petroleum properties.

title: YANKS PICK 17, METS 8 IN DRAFT
description: The Yankees, perhaps the biggest contributors to the welfare of free agents, selected more players in the free-agent draft yesterday than they ever did before. Their list of 17 players included Floyd Bannister, one of several left-handed pitchers who were the stars of the draft.

title: FOR REFUGEES IN LEBANON, IT'S 1948 ALL OVER AGAIN
description: The wrinkled old Palestinian man sat in the opening of his new green tent and looked up at the rain, then at the rubble of the Ein al Helweh camp, razed by the Israeli Army last summer.

description: ''You have done commendable things for many people. For this you received personal gratification, affection, respect and high office.

title: BY SUE MITTENTHAL
description: Sue Mittenthal frequently writes on issues that affect children.

title: BALLET: SWEDISH ROYALTY SEES CULLBERG COMPANY
description: IF they weren't chewing up the scenery last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, they were tearing it down. And as the members of Stockholm's Cullberg Ballet Company were yanking away at the curtains and wings onstage to symbolize liberation and revolution in a dance work called ''Soweto,'' King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden leaned forward in his box to get a better look.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SHOWS LOSS
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. reported yesterday that an extraordinary charge of $40 million related to missing accounts of $55 million at a subsidiary in Britain caused the company to show a loss for the third quarter of $36.4 million.

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prince Gets Award
description: Harold Prince is the recipient of this year's Common Wealth Award for the Dramatic Arts, for his contributions to the theater. The award, $14,000 and a commemorative sculpture, will be given to the director at a ceremony today at the Shubert Theater.

title: GEORGE A. SCHREIBER
description: George A. Schreiber, chairman of the Public Service Company of New Mexico, died Sunday at his home in Albuquerque, after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Nursing-Home Owners Fined
description: The owners of a 240-bed nursing home in the Bronx have been fined $10,000 and ordered to sell the facility, State Health Commissioner David Axelrod announced today. He said the owners of the Kings Terrace Nursing Home and Health Related Facility - who include a State Supreme Court justice, Alexander Chananau -have until the end of the month to pay the fine and until Jan. 30 to sell the home.

title: A FEAST OF GLASS FOR MANHATTANITES
description: November has once again been declared Glass Month in New York by Governor Carey and Mayor Koch. The third annual festival, sponsored by the Glassmasters Guild, Christie's and the Donnell Library Center, will feature a number of exhibitions and events that celebrate the beauty and variety of contemporary glass.

title: LEXICON
description: Within the next few weeks, President Reagan will announce what sort of base he prefers for the proposed fleet of 100 MX intercontinental missiles.

title: COLECO'S NEW VIDEO CHALLENGE
description: Attack and defend: In the fantasy world of video games, that is the theme played out daily on millions of American television screens. And much like the characters in those electronic conflicts, Coleco Industries is bent on conquest - the $5 billion home video game market - at the expense of two well-entrenched rivals, Atari Inc. and Mattel Inc.

title: THEATER: 'WORKROOM,' ANTI-SEMITISM IN PARIS
description: In a more somber tone than C.P. Taylor's ''Good,'' and with greater humanity, Jean-Claude Grumberg's ''The Workroom'' (''L'Atelier'') studies indirect forms of anti-Semitism in Paris during and after World War II. The play takes place in a tailor's workroom from 1945 to 1952, and in the course of 10 scenes we see a diversity of characters trying to rebuild their shattered lives. Before they are aware of it, they have gone through a cycle, moving out of a postwar era without markedly altering their condition.

Serrano's Plans
description: Samuel Serrano, the junior lightweight champion of the World Boxing Association, said he he will defend his title for the last time in early December before moving up to the lightweight division. He said he will fight Roger Mayweather, sixth in the rankings, in Puerto Rico or Las Vegas, Nev. Serrano also said his manager, Jose Cordero, is negotiating a lightweight fight with Ray Mancini.

title: FRANCE SKEPTICAL ON A PIPELINE ACCORD
description: A French Foreign Ministry spokesman expressed ''total reservations'' tonight about reports from Washington of an imminent agreement that would link lifting of United States sanctions against Western European companies involved in the Soviet gas pipeline project with a general agreement among the allies on East-West trade policy.

title: Money Funds Show Decline
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $309 million in the four days through Tuesday, to $230.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute announced yesterday. It released the data a day earlier than usual because of the Veterans Day holiday.

title: British Woolworth Deal
description: Paternoster Stores said today it had received tenders for 93.9 percent of Woolworth P.L.C. shares. The Woolworth Company, which owns 52.6 percent of the British chain, had recommended acceptance of the $1.35-a-share bid.

title: Norway Expels Soviet Ship
description: A Soviet ice breaker trespassing in restricted waters off northern Norway was boarded by the Norwegian police and twice warned that it would be torpedoed before it finally left, navy officials said today. Rear Adm. Reidar Berge said the incident took place Monday night when the ice breaker Captain Ismailov entered a military area north of Tromso.

title: Libya Criticizes U.S.
description: Libya accused the United States today of threatening security and peace in many parts of the world by holding military maneuvers with Morocco. The official Libyan press agency said the American and Moroccan troops began joint maneuvers Tuesday.

title: RECITAL: JULIUS BAKER, FLUTIST
description: JULIUS BAKER will retire as first flutist of the New York Philharmonic at the end of this season, and there will be more events to mark that occasion aside from the one that took place Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House. But Mr. Baker is such an institution in American flute-playing that he deserves as many celebratory events as he gets, and Monday's was by no means negligible.

title: BLACK CONGRESSMAN ENTERS CHICAGO MAYOR'S RACE
description: United States Representative Harold Washington joined the race for mayor of Chicago today, saying that he had given in to a ''massive draft'' effort in his predominantly black district.

title: American Airlines
description: In preparation for what American Airlines predicted would be heavy demand during the Christmas season, the carrier said it would expand its schedule by 115 flights a week beginning Dec. 15. American, which is a unit of the AMR Corporation, said the new schedule would also include a new route to Brazil and seasonal adjustment in key winter resort markets. The carrier said it would add 49 new flights domestically, 31 in the Caribbean, 22 to Mexico, 10 to Hawaii and 3 on its new Brazil route.

title: Veterans Day
description: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges will be open today, Veterans Day, but most banks in New York and New Jersey will be closed.

title: 2 Steelmakers Plan Closings
description: Two steel companies announced they were closing down some of their operations because of lack of demand for the product.

title: Q&A
description: Q. While painting my garage door I spattered paint onto the brick on each side of the door. Now I can't seem to get this paint off. I bought some chemical remover from a local paint store, but this only seemed to make the spots messier. Is there anything else I can do?

MAN, 47, MURDERED IN PENTHOUSE HOME ON RIVERSIDE DRIVE
description: A 47-year-old man was found beaten to death last night in his penthouse apartment on Riverside Drive at 75th Street. According to the police, a friend found the man, Jesse N. Petchers, sitting in a chair in the living room of the duplex apartment at about 6 P.M. There was no immediate indication of forced entry into the apartment, but there were signs of robbery and a struggle.

title: WICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEDGESTONE REALTY INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NO IMMEDIATE WORD ON A SUCCESSOR; U.S. FORESEES NO EARLY POLICY SHIFTS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader for 18 years, died yesterday, the state television announced this morning.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reagan News Session Live on TV Networks
description: President Reagan's news conference will be covered live tonight at 8 P.M., Eastern standard time, on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, the Cable News Network and the Satellite News Channel. Some local affiliates of the Public Broadcasting Service will carry the conference, either live or as a taped-delayed broadcast. Channel 13 in New York City, for instance, will broadcast it at 11 P.M.

title: Stevenson Asks Recount Of Voting in Illinois
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d said today that he would seek a recount of the voting in the governor's race after a canvass of Chicago precincts left him trailing Gov. James R. Thompson by more than 5,600 votes out of the 3.6 million cast statewide.

title: Quebec Workers Strike Over Wage Rollbacks
description: More than 220,000 public service employees in this province ignored court orders and picketed schools, hospitals and offices today in a 24-hour protest against wage rollbacks.

title: HANNAFORD BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
No Headline
description: The Islanders recalled Paul Boutilier, a 19-year-old defenseman, today to replace the injured Mike McEwen. Boutilier, the Islanders' No.1 pick in the 1981 draft, was brought up from the St. Jean Beavers of the Quebec Junior Hockey League after McEwen suffered a slight separation of the left shoulder in a collision in Tuesday night's game with the St. Louis Blues. McEwen is expected to be out from seven to 10 days.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-After tax credits of $258,000 for the qr and $409,000 for the 6 mos...C-Aftertax credits of $159,000 for the qr and $300,000 for the 6 mos

title: THE VARIED USE OF HISTORY IN 'GOOD' AND PLENTY'
description: COMPARISONS can be invidious, so no doubt it's a mistake to compare C.P. Taylor's ''Good'' and David Hare's ''Plenty'' just because they're both newly arrived British plays, or because their titles can be combined to form the name of a licorice candy we all know and love. So sue me. I can't resist drawing one parallel that helps explain why ''Plenty'' grips the conscience and ''Good,'' for all its theatricality, does not.

title: 9 Are Sentenced In Nuclear Protest
description: Five persons protesting nuclear weapons have been sentenced to jail for damaging a Trident submarine. Four others, who were not jailed, said they would refuse to pay restitution ordered by a judge.

title: Technology; Co-generation: New Problems
description: NEARLY two years after Harvard University thought it had surmounted the long regulatory delays and legal challenges that have added about $100 million to the cost of a large co-generation power plant, a Massachusetts court has once again put the facility's future in doubt.

title: RESTORING THE OLD REVIVES GALVESTON
description: To look at George Phydias Mitchell, you can hardly tell that he is worth nearly half a billion dollars, that he has impeccable taste in restoring Victorian buildings or that he is the new patron saint of this old port.

title: Study by Cornell Finds Losses on Dairy Farms
description: Dairy farmers in New York State lost money on their work and management efforts in 1981 for the first time in 20 years, according to a study by Cornell University.

title: Inflation Slows In O.E.C.D.
description: Inflation in the 24 countries that belong to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development fell in September to its lowest level since 1973, the O.E.C.D. said today.

title: ALTAIR AIRLINES FILES FOR REORGANIZATION
description: Altair Airlines, a privately owned carrier operating on the East Coast, has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code to protect itself from creditors who are owed more than $2.6 million.

title: NEW CHIEF VOWS TO END RETREAT FOR MINE UNION
description: Richard L. Trumka, the young lawyer who won the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America by easily defeating the old-line miner who heads the union, moved today to plan a takeover of power.

title: CROMPTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a special pretax charge of $13,153,000 for the qr and a pretax charge of $16,901,000 for the yr for estimated costs of plans for asset redeployment...C-Net income...D-Including a credit of $861,000 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change for prior yrs

title: WHAT'S AHEAD IN CHRISTMAS TREES?
description: Your Christmas tree will cost more this year, but you will probably be getting a better-shaped tree and one that may well hold its needles past the holidays, a tree expert says.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Du Pont Economist Wins Forecast Award
description: Charles B. Reeder, the chief economist for E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, sees a continuing drop in interest rates that would lower the banks' prime rate to 8 percent by December 1983.

title: STUDENTS PROTEST WEAPONS SEARCH AT THEIR SCHOOL
description: Hundreds of students overturned tables, chairs and desks in the cafeteria and classrooms of Thomas Jefferson High School in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday before surging into the street to protest a search of individuals for weapons, the police said.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Football Rutgers vs. West Virginia, at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. The Scarlet Knights, 5-4 and still smarting from Saturday's rout at Auburn, will be playing in the Meadowlands for the third time this season.

title: POLISH STRIKE CALL GOES UNHEEDED IN FACE OF GOVERNMENT WARNINGS
description: A national strike called for today by the underground leaders of the Solidarity movement appeared to have been generally unsuccessful in the face of a carefully orchestrated Government campaign backed up by a display of police power.

title: SPY IN BRITAIN GIVEN 35 YEARS FOR SELLING SECRETS TO THE SOVIET
description: A British linguistics expert pleaded guilty today to charges of passing secrets to the Soviet Union on the activities of a classified electronics listening post.

title: CARTER TAKES A BOOK TOUR TO THE CAPITAL
description: It seemed, at first, as though nothing had changed. Jimmy Carter, dressed in familiar blue pin-stripe, flanked by Secret Service agents, strode into the hotel dining room at exactly 8 A.M., shook hands with the two dozen reporters at a long oval table and sat down to field questions on foreign affairs and domestic politics.

title: Rank, Trident Set Cable Unit
description: The Rank Organization and Trident Television today announced the formation of a joint venture to develop business opportunities in cable and satellite television.

title: Advertising; A Proposal To Put Ads On Pay-TV
description: Soft-spoken Edward N. Ney, chairman of Young & Rubicam, the nation's biggest ad agency, made a pitch here today for putting advertising on pay-television. As a member of a panel on ''Communications: A Panorama of Change,'' which dropped the curtain on the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Breakers Hotel, Mr. Ney asked: ''What is the hope for us who just want to talk to people and sell them enough product to keep the economy going?''

title: TEAMSTER, ON WIRETAP TAPE, TALKS OF DEAL WITH SENATOR
description: The tape-recorded twang of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters union, boomed out in Federal court here this afternoon, in a dialogue with an associate that the Government played to support its charges against him of bribery and conspiracy.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ON REDESIGNING A LOFT WITH ENERGY AND EGO
description: RESTORING antiques is a tricky business. In the last 20 years there have been tremendous technical and research findings in the restoring of almost every imaginable antique. Yet the skill required for restoration is the painstaking kind used by master craftsmen of old.

title: New York Times Job Buy-Out Plan
description: The New York Times Company announced that a new bonus-payment program for voluntary termination had been accepted by 127 printers at the newspaper and that this would result in a charge against fourth-quarter earnings of about $11.5 million.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. AID FOR PRIVATE SCHOOLS RISES IN TRISTATE AREA
description: At the same time that Federal aid for education is being reduced in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the state school systems are being required to distribute the money in a way that greatly increases the share received by the 3,500 private and parochial schools in the region, an analysis of Federal and state reports indicates.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $194,000...C-Net loss after a loss of $655,000 from discontinued operations of the Philadelphia Journal and a tax credit of $15,000...D-After a loss of $1,774,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $245,000...E-After a loss of $2,236,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $555,000

title: BUSINESS CONTINUES AT CITY COURTS DURING STRIKE AT LEGAL AID SOCIETY
description: Outside the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street about 75 lawyers marched in cool sunshine yesterday afternoon, chanting: ''Who are we? Legal Aid. What are we? Underpaid.''

title: GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $291,000...C-Net loss

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Costly Commercial

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
JAZZ: JUNIOR MANCE ON PAINO
description: JAZZ pianists in today's mainstream tend to lean toward technical virtuosity and intellectuality rather than emotional appeal. There is much rippling up and down the keyboard but relatively little use of coloristic or rhythmic variety, or the multitude of devices that can make a performance gripping, amusing, charming or, at the very least, different.

title: Court Protects Names In Toxic Shock Study
description: The names of women involved in a study of toxic shock syndrome cannot be released to a tampon manufacturer that claims they are crucial to its defense in a lawsuit, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: 'Tourist Trap' Law Signed by Koch
description: Midtown shops described as tourist traps that stage phony goingout-of-business sales at enormous markups could be put out of business under a law signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: SOVIET SATELLITE SPURS RESCUES IN REMOTE PARTS OF THE GLOBE
description: The 36-foot sailboat Blue Jeans ran aground last Saturday night on a shoal in a remote area 100 miles north of the Dominican Republic, the Coast Guard said. In the dim light the five people aboard saw the outline of a freighter and crowded into their dinghy, hoping to be rescued, only to find that the other vessel was the abandoned hulk of a ship that had grounded nine months ago.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax loss carryforward of $1,823,000...C-Including a tax credit of$5,050,000

title: LEADERS OF UNIFORMED UNIONS PROMISE COOPERATION ON BUDGET
description: Leaders of the uniformed unions met with Mayor Koch yesterday and said afterward that, because of the city's budget problems, they were willing to accept some temporary decrease in the size of the Police and Fire Departments.

title: MOZAMBIQUE KEEPS TO MARXIST ROUTE
description: Although Mozambique appears to be trying to improve relations with the West, there has been no matching domestic move to deviate from Marxist theory.

title: Hasty Tailoring for Jobs
description: Suddenly, everyone has a plan to reduce unemployment. House Democrats unveiled theirs yesterday. Senate Republicans are perfecting theirs. The Department of Transportation has one, the Labor Department another. Even President Reagan is finally thinking beyond his ''stay the course'' slogan. It's all a healthy showing of concern, but it has an unhealthy tinge of political jockeying. Nothing would be more hollow than to lunge for a quick jobs package that produces little new employment, and more inflation.

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOME ALTERNATIVES TO THE POST OFFICE
description: ANEW breed of storefront business is appearing in the New York area, supplementing long-existing establishments that, among other things, provide prestigious downtown mailing addresses and answering-service centers for their customers. The new private postal offices rent mail boxes, mail and receive packages and inform customers when their mail or other deliveries have arrived.

title: RESIDENTS COMPLAIN OF NOISE BY NEW COPTER SHUTTLE
description: A helicopter shuttle service between Manhattan's East 60th Street heliport and Kennedy International Airport has led to a dispute between residents and the operator, Pan American World Airways, over the noise of the flights and the airline's right to continue them.

title: SOVIET BLOC SPURNS WESTERN CALL IN MADRID FOR NEW RIGHTS PLEDGES
description: The Soviet bloc today scorned Western demands at the conference on European security for serious new international commitments on human rights.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Martha Graham to Get 1982 Meadows Award
description: Martha Graham will receive the 1982 Auger H. Meadows Award for Excellence in the Arts on Nov. 19.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRADE WARNING TO JAPAN
description: The Reagan Administration charged today that Japan had not lived up to its commitment to open its markets to American products and warned that the United States might retaliate by taking an even tougher position on imports of Japanese cars, steel, electronics and other products.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: History of the Bronx As Told by Its Residents

title: Wilpon Declines
description: Fred Wilpon, the president of the Mets, wants it known: If nominated for commissioner of baseball, he will not run; if elected, he will not serve.

title: A DETERMINED SEEKER OF CHANGE
description: Richard L. Trumka, president-elect of the United Mine Workers of America, is a personable, aggressive union man, determined, he says, to change his union. He wants to stabilize finances, to root out staff members he regards as incompetent, to improve organizing and to develop innovative tactics to confront coal operators.

title: Bucks 105, Celtics 101
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Sidney Moncrief scored 27 points and teamed with Junior Bridgeman to lead a fourth-quarter rally for the Bucks. The victory was the first for Milwaukee in Boston Garden since Nov. 8, 1980, a stretch of six games.

title: TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SUBURBAN PROPANE GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RICHMOND SENTENCED TO A YEAR AND A DAY AND FINED $20,000
description: Former Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison and fined $20,000 for income-tax evasion, marijuana possession and making an illegal payment to a government employee.
