BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GARDENING
description: AS the chrysanthemums fade and autumnal winds reduce the garden to a few red berries, it's time to look at a decorative and most unusual cool-weather vegetable, the ornamental kale. A strategically placed pot of ornamental kale is guaranteed to enliven any city terrace or yard (not to mention that it will elicit innumerable questions from guests). Its cheerful frilly foliage that often lasts through February might indeed be the perfect counterpoint to winter's solemn gray.

title: Reagan, in Statement, Acclaims Polish Union
description: President Reagan issued a statement today marking the second anniversary of the Polish Government's formal recognition of Solidarity union, saying the struggle goes on despite attempts to destroy the movement.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Analysis
description: Relations between Egypt and Israel, which were expected to improve dramatically after the return of the last occupied area of Sinai to Egypt in April, are at their lowest point since the peace treaty between the two nations was signed in March 1979.

title: BONN SEES NEW ARMS TALK OPTION
description: A Government spokesman described today as conceivable a disarmament agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union, under which the United States would forgo the deployment of some of its new missiles in Western Europe if the Soviet Union agreed to eliminate some of its medium-range missiles.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: BATHROOM appliance manufacturers have come up with several items intended to be substitutes for bidet fixtures. While they will never be as convenient as a real bidet, they do function as reasonable substitutes.

title: FEARS CAUSED BY 3 MILE ISLAND ENDURE
description: The nation's worst nuclear accident, at Three Mile Island, occurred more than three years ago, but the trauma endures here.

title: The Jersey Hills
description: When the national cross-country championships were scheduled for the Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey, everything seemed in place: A field of 1,000 runners headed by Alberto Salazar, the marathon man, and a 6.2-mile course laid out around the perimeter of the race track and the training track. One thing was missing: Hills.

title: TRIBUTE TO VIETNAM DEAD: WORDS, A WALL
description: President Reagan stopped by the National Cathedral to listen for a while to the reading of the names of the Vietnam war dead this evening.

title: TEST PILOTS SAY DUAL-PURPOSE F-18 JET IS UNSUITABLE IN BOMBER ROLE
description: One month after the Navy awarded a $1.14 billion contract to buy the F-18 fighter and attack plane, test pilots filed a confidential report saying the aircraft was ''not operationally suitable.''

title: Youngstown Sued by U.S.
description: The Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit today against the Youngstown Steel Corporation and three officers, charging that an application for a $10 million Federal loan had been falsified.

title: Claims on Penn Square Filed
description: Final claims have been filed against the defunct Penn Square Bank, and the unofficial total is $506 million, just $12 million less than the bank's assets, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE concept of the store is just a bit unusual - ''a department store for children,'' said Jerry Harmyk of the new uptown Johnny Jupiter.

title: WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Biggest Man On Campus at 5-8
description: The biggest man on the campus at Williams College this week is Mark Humman, a political science major, piano player and split end from Maryland, who stands 5 feet 8 inches and weighs 145 pounds.

title: Under the Dining Room Table
description: Proponents of nuclear power are fond of comparing the chance of serious nuclear mishap to the likelihood of being hit by a meteorite. They should not offer this logic to the citizens of Wethersfield, Conn., who have twice come under meteoric bombardment in the last 11 years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday about unem- ployment in the Great Plains incorrectly described the location of Sioux Falls, S.D. It is near the eastern border of the state, about 300 miles east of the Black Hills.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tainted Apple Juice Reported in Jersey
description: A 13-year-old boy drank a mouthful of toxic chemicals that had been poured into a bottle of apple juice he bought on the way to school, but he did not become ill, authorities said today.

description: B-Including a special gain of $22,000...C-Including a special gain of $3,271,000...D-After a special loss of $364,000...E-Net income including a special gain of $3,733,000

FORD IS TRADED TO BUCKS
description: Foots Walker was not surprised that the Nets made a major trade today. What surprised him, Walker said, was that Phil Ford was the one traded, and not himself.

title: DOCUTEL-OLIVETTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BELL GOES TO HIGH COURT
description: Judge Harold H. Greene, who has charge of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company antitrust case here, agreed today to send 22 appeals of his ruling directly to the Supreme Court, thus speeding up the timetable for reorganizing the phone company.

title: PROTEST BY POLES IN A STEEL CENTER
description: Sharp clashes occurred today in the Nowa Huta industrial suburb of this city as demonstrators battled riot police in fog mixed with clouds of stinging tear gas.

description: B-Including a tax credit of $113,000...C-Net income including a tax credit of $562,000

title: WRIGHT-HARGREAVES MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'WOMAN OF THE YEAR' IS REPAYING INVESTORS
description: ''Woman of the Year,'' the hit Broadway musical that provoked controversy last year when it became apparent that its unusual royalty arrangement might prevent it from repaying its investors, has now begun to pay back slowly. Following the revision of its royalty arrangement a year ago, ''Woman of the Year,'' which opened on Broadway 18 months ago, has now repaid investors 10 percent of their original investment of $2 million. The show will probably not repay the balance for another year, according to David Landay, a co-producer.

title: Workers Demonstrate At Modern Museum
description: Chanting ''modern art, ancient wages,'' assistant curators and other members of the union that represents professional and administrative employees of the Museum of Modern Art demonstrated yesterday outside the museum. They contended that management was stalling in contract talks.

title: TERRORISM SAID TO DROP SHARPLY IN ISRAEL
description: Guerrilla attacks on Israel have fallen off sharply since the Israeli Army drove the Palestine Liberation Organization out of southern Lebanon and Beirut, an expert in international terrorism said today.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split declared in Jan 1982

title: The Editorial Notebook; Angell's 'Great Illusion' (Cont'd)
description: When Britain memorialized its dead in the Falklands, this interesting passage occurred in the Archbishop of Canterbury's sermon at St. Paul's:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANNIVERSARY

title: VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bush Is Off on Tour Of 7 African Nations
description: Vice President Bush left today on a 7-nation, 14-day tour of Africa. Mr. Bush was scheduled to stop briefly in Cape Verde, a tiny island nation off the west coast of Africa, before heading to Dakar for talks with officials of the Government of Senegal. The Vice President also plans to visit Nigeria, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Kenya and Zaire. He will deliver what he described as a major statement on the Administration's Africa policy in Nairobi on Nov. 19.

title: Army-Navy Move Is Studied
description: Representatives of Army and Navy said yesterday that they had discussed the possibility of moving the academies' annual football game out of Philadelphia occasionally. They said they were planning to negotiate with authorities in Pasadena, Calif., about holding next year's game in the Rose Bowl. The game, which has been played in Philadephia since 1944, is on Dec. 4 this year.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dan River Offer
description: Carl C. Icahn and his investor group said they would pursue a tender offer of $16.50 a share for up to 2 million shares of Dan River Inc. common stock after Dan River did not meet the conditions of a separate offer. The Icahn group owns 15 percent of the textile concern, and its hostile bid for 2 million more shares would give it just under 50 percent of Dan River's 5.8 million common shares outstanding. The offer will be in effect until midnight Nov. 22.

title: FED ALTERS MONETARY DATA PLAN
description: The Federal Reserve Board today abandoned its plan to stop publication of the volatile weekly measurement of the nation's money supply because of technical problems in preparing a substitute.

title: New Fujitsu Computer
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said today that it would enter the American market with a personal business computer, the Micro 16S, priced below $4,000.

title: CONTACT WITH PRIMITIVE TRIBE IN MALAYSIA WILDS IS REPORTED
description: A primitive nomadic tribe that hunts wild animals in the Malaysian jungle, speaks its own dialect and makes fire by rubbing rocks together has had contact with the Malaysian authorities.

title: 'BRIMSTONE AND TREACLE'
description: NASTINESS was an important part of ''Pennies From Heaven,'' which was written for television and then for the screen by Dennis Potter. It also figures prominently in Mr. Potter's ''Brimstone and Treacle,'' a new film directed by Richard Loncraine. Mr. Potter uses this sourness deliberately, contrasting it with elements that are excessively sweet - vintage Hollywood musicals in the case of ''Pennies From Heaven'' or the treacle of the title this time. The treacle, along with the brimstone, is embodied by Sting, lead singer of the rock group the Police.

title: DEATH BENEFIT VOTED FOR HOMOSEXUAL'S LOVER
description: The homosexual lover and business partner of an assassinated Supervisor, Harvey Milk, should receive a portion of survivor's death benefits, according to a ruling in this city with a large homosexual population.

title: U.S. ECONOMY IN DIRE NEED OF SOME PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: TORSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $670,000...C-Incl uding a gain of$1,538,000 on sale of land...D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,547,000 and a gain of $8,841,000 from the sale of an investment and a loss of $8,987,000 on the divestiture of magazine and film operations

title: NOW, THE CAMPAIGN FOR COMMITTEE ASSIGNMENTS
description: Representative Byron L. Dorgan just finished one election, and now he is running again. The North Dakota Democrat is a candidate for one of three openings on the Ways and Means Committee, a panel with jurisdiction over taxes, Social Security, welfare and a variety of other noteworthy matters. How he fares could influence the fate of these issues months and even years from now.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Honeymoon in Heaven For Two Mice

title: HARVESTER STUDIES PLAN TO CLOSE SEVERAL PLANTS
description: The International Harvester Company intends to close several of its engine and assembly plants as part of its costcutting strategy to avoid bankruptcy, Donald D. Lennox, Harvester's new chief executive officer, said today.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1982
description: International Leonid I. Brezhnev is dead, the Tass news agency reported. The agency said the 75-year-old Soviet leader died ''a sudden death'' at 8:30 A.M. (12:30 A.M. EST) Wednesday. Tass said the announcement was made by the Central Committee of the Communist Party. There was no immediate announcement of a successor. (Page A1, Column 6.) Mexico announced an austerity plan as part of an agreement with the International Monetary Fund designed to revive its troubled economy and avert defaulting on its foreign debt of $78 billion. Under the accord, Mexico could draw up to $3.84 billion from the fund over three years in exchange for curbing spending and imports and raising taxes. (A1:1-2.)

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1981 net income was increased by $710,000 or 33 cents a shr due to a liquidation of the company's Seaview refinery's low-priced LIFO inventory

title: 'BOONDOGGLES' HELPED TO BUILD AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Laker Plans to Start Vacation-Tour Venture
description: Sir Freddie Laker - the pioneer of no-frills flying - announced plans yesterday to start a vacation-tour venture only nine months after his airline collapsed amid huge debt.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
Rutgers Welcomes TV Special Tonight
description: The reason for the unusual scheduling of a college football game in Giants Stadium tonight, Rutgers against West Virginia, is television money. Each university will be paid $175,000 by the Turner Broadcasting System, which plans to televise the game over 4,800 subscribing cable systems in 50 states.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Penn Central
description: The Penn Central Corporation said that some customers might cancel contracts for oil and natural gas drilling equipment worth $78.3 million and that another customer had been allowed to delay a purchase because of a slowdown in the petroleum business. It said the developments were expected to ''significantly impact'' the 1983 profit of Penn Central's Marathon Manufacturing Company, which got no new orders for drilling rigs this year.

title: DIAGNOSTIC RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LETTERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: After reading Joyce Colony's Hers column of Oct. 28, I found her quote in its final paragraph (''A career is not all it's cracked up to be'') misleading.

title: McEnroe Wins
description: John McEnroe beat Claudio Panatta of Italy, 7-5, 6-2, and Mats Wilander was upset by Wojtek Fibak in the first round of the Benson & Hedges tennis tournament today.

title: DWELLERS URGE LOFT BOARD TO MOVE ON SERVICES
description: The Loft Board, newly created to oversee the conversion of lofts in New York City to legal residential dwellings, was urged by witnesses at a public hearing yesterday to move quickly to establish basic maintenance and service entitlements before winter starts.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Including special gains of $4,189,000 for the qr and $5,648,000 for the 9 mos

title: ASIAN WING REOPENS IN BOSTON
description: THE Asiatic wing of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts reopened this week after four years and $6 million worth of renovations with a display of 3,500 objects from what is considered one of the world's finest collections of Oriental art.

title: Hawks 6, Canadiens 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Rich Preston broke a 3-3 tie with a 15-foot backhander in the final period, and teammates Darryl Sutter and Bill Gardner followed with goals for Chicago.

title: 300 Die as Hurricane Sweeps Western India
description: The death toll has reached at least 300 in the hurricane-battered western Indian state of Gujarat, authorities reported today.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE SET FOR CRITICAL CHANGE FROM TESTS TO REAL WORK
description: The nation's space shuttle Columbia is ready to make the critical transition from flight testing to the hauling of orbital freight, the culmination of a decade-long, $11 billion project.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1982; International
description: Mexico had reached agreement with the I.M.F. on an austerity program aimed at restoring its shattered economy. Under the accord, Mexico will receive $3.84 billion worth of credit from the lending agency over the next three years in return for cutting public spending and imports and raising taxes. (Page A1.) Six U.S. banks have reportedly loaned Brazil $600 million. (D2.)

title: The Police Blotter
description: A Queens couple, Frank and Minnie Pasquale, both in their 60's, were arrested yesterday and charged with running a multimilliondollar fencing operation from their home at 133-35 123d Street in Ozone Park, near Kennedy International Airport. They were accused of operating ''a veritable 24-hour depot for fencing stolen airport cargo merchandise,'' including guns, clothing and appliances.

title: REAGAN'S PROBLEM: THAWING ON FREEZE
description: The midterm elections suggest that real progress on nuclear-arms control enjoys tenacious and widespread political support. The Reagan Administration faces a choice: whether it will exploit this strong popular tide or ignore it at its own risk between now and the Presidential election in 1984.

title: No Headline
description: Although he is still recuperating from injuries, Jeff Hostetler may re-emerge as the starting quarterbck for West Virginia against Rutgers, Coach Don Nehlen said today.

title: HBM/Stiefel Addition
description: Michael F. Pedone, 41-year-old executive vice president of Warwick Advertising, is joining HBM/Stiefel as president and chief operating officer. The announcement was made by Humphrey Browning MacDougall of Boston, the new parent company. Mr. Pedone, who was in charge of client services at Warwick, where he worked for nine years, previously was at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn and at John Rockwell Associates. Herbert J. Stiefel, founder and former president, remains chairman and chief executive.

title: PRESUMPTION OF GUILT
description: The press has had a glorious time with John De Lorean since his arrest on charges of drug trafficking, and no wonder. The story has everything: money, power, sex, cafe society, a silver-haired villain.

title: U.S. Banks Lending To Brazil
description: Six leading American banks have made emergency loans totaling $600 million to Brazil to help tide it over until it obtains a larger and longer-term credit from the International Monetary Fund, according to banking sources.

title: Montreal Blaze Kills 7
description: Seven people died in a rooming-house blaze here in Montreal's worst fire in five years, the police said today. Rescue officials have still not determined how many people were in the rooming house in Montreal's Chinatown district at the time of Tuesday's predawn blaze.

title: WHAT A CIGARETTE PACKS IN RADIATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: B-Including a gain of $200,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the sale of an investment

title: RECITAL: JAMES BUSWELL
description: AFTER giving a brief talk on the way in which Bach's music seems to make ''mincemeat'' of all dichotomies - spirit versus mind, unity versus variety, structure versus freedom, humanism versus religion - the violinist James Buswell gave a practical demonstration of his point Monday night at Symphony Space. The Adagio of the Sonata No. 3 in C was both firm and flexible, its breathing pulse giving life to a solid foundation.

title: MUSIC: ROGER GOODMAN
description: THE affection with which Roger Goodman played the harpsichord Tuesday night in the Merkin Concert Hall was most evident in the musical portraits from 18th-century France. These works by Claude Benigne Balbastre (1729-99) and Antoine Forqueray (circa 1671-1745) were images in sound of their confreres in the French court.

title: ALFRED POLITZ, OPINION ANALYST
description: Alfred Politz, an early leader in the techniques of polling and opinion analysis and founder of a market research company, died of cancer Monday at his home in Odessa, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: SECURING SECOND HOMES AGAINST FIRE, THEFT AND THE ELEMENTS
description: THE season is now year-round for many owners of second homes in nearby areas. With the added pleasure of more weekends in the country comes increased concern about frozen pipes, storm damage and theft.

title: THE STOCKHOLDER AS THE CORPORATION'S SOLE MASTER
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ANTIQUES SEMINAR
description: Antiques: Their Use in Design,

title: RAYMOND CHAUNCEY
description: Raymond Chauncey, an officer of the securities concern of Chauncey & Company and a member of the New York Stock Exchange for 64 years, died Monday at the South Nassau Communties Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: NEW YORK STATE BOND RATING IS REDUCED TO ITS LOWEST EVER
description: The credit rating on New York State bonds was lowered one halfstep yesterday to its lowest level ever and to the lowest level of any state. In reducing the rating, the Standard & Poor's Corporation cited the state's difficulty in producing a balanced budget.

title: PETROLEUM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Western Accounts
description: Two Western accounts with New York interests are Subaru Inter-Mountain, which has appointed Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver as its advertising agency. L.H.S.P.& B. has been Subaru's national agency for several years.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Angolan Rebels Say They Captured a Town

title: Women in Work Force
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In regard to Joyce Colony's ''Hers'' (Oct. 28), I would note, while commending Ms. Colony's attention to the impact of male unemployment on the working wife, that there are several implications in the article that reflect underlying, widespread misconceptions about women in the work force.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results were restated to reflect foreign currency translation accounting changes

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $2,570,000; yr-ago results have been restated for implementation of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: McQuay Is Back
description: Leon McQuay, a 32-year-old running back from the University of Tampa who played in the Canadian Football League and the National Football League during the 1970's, was signed by the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League. McQuay, who in 1974 played with the Giants, last played professionally with the Jacksonville Firebirds of the American Football Association in 1980.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Australian Book Contains Some Interesting Problems
description: Books on bridge bidding, like some wines, do not travel at all well. But books on play are another matter, and there have been several excellent ones from Australia. The latest is ''Problems in Play,'' available for $8.50 from The Bridge World Magazine, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Industry Lawyer Takes Job as Legal Aid Chief
description: Donald P. Bogard, a corporate lawyer in Indiana, has agreed to head the Legal Services Corporation, the organization said today.

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,495,000 for the qr and $36,995,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of$739,000 for the qr and $4,956,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been reclassified to segregate discontinued operations and restated to reflect an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: Ex-Colt Is Jailed On Drug Charges
description: Jimmie Kennedy, a former tight end for the Baltimore Colts, surrendered to the police Tuesday and was jailed on several narcotics charges, including possession of cocaine, possession of marijuana and intent to distribute both.

title: 6 Amtrak Workers Injured in Station
description: Two out-of-service Amtrak trains derailed during a coupling maneuver in Pennsylvania Station yesterday, injuring six workers, one seriously, Amtrak officials reported.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago amounts reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in June

title: Rates Edge Up on U.S. Issues
description: Sentiment seemed to be shifting in the Government securities market yesterday, as the widespread expectation of an imminent drop in short-term interest rates gave way in some cases to forecasts of stable or even slightly higher rates in the immediate future.

title: ELIO PETRI, DIRECTOR OF FILMS SATIRIZING THE SOCIETY OF ITALY
description: Elio Petri, the Italian movie director whose ''Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion'' won him an Oscar in 1970, died yesterday in a Roman hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: STOCKS FALL IN VOLATILE SESSION
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday in a volatile session marked by profit taking and renewed investor concern over the near-term course of interest rates.

title: SCOTT INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SALES ROSE A SLIM 0.6% LAST MONTH
description: Retail sales rose a moderate six-tenths of 1 percent in October, helped by the auto industry for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ROCKWELL UP 12% IN 4th QUARTER
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a major manufacturer of aerospace and electronics components, said yesterday that its net income for its fourth fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 12 percent, to $82.9 million, or $1.08 a share, on sales of $1.95 billion. In the corresponding quarter last year, Rockwell's net income, restated, was $74 million, or 96 cents a share, on revenues of $1.82 billion.

title: Viktor V. Grishin
description: 67-year-old head of the Moscow city party organization and Politburo member ... recently emerged as one of Kremlin inner circle ... presumed to be a ''hard-liner'' ... credited with deft handling of 1980 Olympics ... born Sept. 18, 1914, into worker's family in town of Serpukhov in what is now Moscow Oblast ... a well-groomed man, he began his career as a land surveyor in 1932 at age of 18 ... five years later he followed in his father's footsteps as railroad engineer... he was picked to head local party's machinery industry department of Moscow Province in 1950 ... two years later he was appointed second secretary of Moscow Province under Nikita S. Krushchev, then first secretary ... chairman of Soviet Union's trade unions from 1956 to 1967 ... was raised to prestigious post of Moscow city party leader in 1967 ... traveled widely to international congresses abroad ... served 10 years as candidate member of Politburo before promotion to Moscow city party leader by Leonid I. Brezhnev. Yuri V. Andropov

title: JOBS LEGISLATION IS GAINING SUPPORT
description: Bipartisan support for a public works program that would provide jobs for the unemployed solidified in Congress today. There were indications that President Reagan might support a limited jobs program.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 9
description: B-Net income; results for the latest periods reflect a charge of $10 million for the consolidation of British operations; yr-ago results include a British tax credit of $3,346,000

title: Soviet Crop: U.S. Estimate
description: The Agriculture Department today increased its estimate of this year's Soviet grain crop to 180 million metric tons - up 10 million tons from previous projections.

title: No Headline
description: The Mercer County Prosecutor's office today dropped charges against Dan Errico and Joseph Burke, Rutgers football players who were accused in August of having sexually assaulted a Hightstown girl.

title: STUART HOUSE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Steinbrenner Annoyed
description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, yesterday urged baseball's executive council to accelerate efforts to replace Bowie Kuhn as commissioner.

title: LIEDER: HERMANN PREY AND SCHUBERT
description: THE world of German lieder is small, serious and hieratic. Its practitioners guard the tradition like a sacred scroll, and audiences treat them like priests. One of today's chief priests is Hermann Prey, who at 53 years old seems to be improving with age, and who brought a programmatically satisfying, interpretively fulfilling evening of Schubert songs to the 92d Street Y ,ast night.

title: ULSTER CATHOLICS WANTS NO NEW STORMONT
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: ONE morning when my two children, after some prefatory hissing and snarling, were about to lock horns over the breakfast table, it occurred to me to inquire of the Lord why it was thus. Casting up my eyes to the ceiling, ''How long, O Lord,'' I keened, ''must I suffer this torment Thou hast laid upon me?'' The answer I got, audible, fortunately, only to my ears, was so unbargained for I jumped as if struck. Popeyed, their quarrel completely forgotten, ''What did the Lord say?'' the children demanded in one voice.

title: Sonics 94, Mavericks 91
description: DALLAS (AP) - Gus Williams, who missed two games with the flu, bounced back with 24 points as unbeaten Seattle won its eighth game.

title: New York Air Account Shifts Agencies Again
description: Eight months ago New York Air reassigned its advertising account from Ketchum New York to Chiat/ Day.

title: Haig Won't Seek Presidency
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., once mentioned as Presidential timber, said on the CBS ''Morning News'' today that he did not want to be President, and his wife, Patricia, said she would actively discourage him from seeking the White House.

title: RANGER POWER PLAY TURNS BACK BLUES
description: The Rangers and the St. Louis Blues struggled through two periods of helter-skelter hockey last night at Madison Square Garden. But in the third period, the Rangers finally pulled together and won, 5-4.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
TESTIMONY ON WARNER FUND
description: Jay Emmett, a former top executive at Warner Communications, testified yesterday that while the company's chairman, Steven J. Ross, had told him about the existence of a secret cash fund at Warner, he had not explained its purpose.

title: Life Is Returning Janet Lynn's Smile
description: S even years after her painful retirement from figure skating, there are still mornings when Janet Lynn rises before the sun does. But that is not because her ambitions demand that she be awake. There are different demands now: Dustin, the oldest at 5 1/2, who is off to kindergarten each day, and the 3 1/2-year-old twins, Nicolas and Benjamin.

title: Cutbacks at Budd
description: The Budd Company said it would be forced to close some unprofitable plants now that the United Automobile Workers union had rejected its plea for more contract concessions.

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $17,100 for the qr and $25,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss; the company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Nixon Library Is Sought
description: The City Commission voted unanimously Tuesday to invite former President Richard M. Nixon to establish his Presidential library in this northeastern Kansas town. Independence, Mo., Baker, Ore., and Ottumwa, Iowa, have also expressed interest in having the library.

title: Schrafft's Ice Cream Names President
description: John R. LeSauvage has been named president of the Schrafft's Ice Cream Company, succeeding the company's owner, Richard J. Ripp, who becomes chairman.

title: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $149,100; yr-ago qr and yr shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Nov 6, 1981

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cards Ready to Deal
description: Over the last three years, while constructing the team that won this year's World Series, Whitey Herzog, the manager and former general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, created controversy by trading such standouts as Ted Simmons, Rollie Fingers and Garry Templeton. But he got back enough value to make the Cardinals into champions.

title: Pennzoil Reserves
description: The Pennzoil Company said it expected to increase its total proven developed and undeveloped oil reserves by about 40 percent this year, from 99 million barrels at the end of the 1981, after subtracting 1982 production of about 13 million barrels. The company said it would make gross additions of about 50 million barrels to its reserves, mainly because of the recent Hueso discovery in the Santa Maria Basin off California.

title: KOHL TALKS OF KEEPING PLEDGES TO U.S. AND SOVIET
description: The new Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany is leaving here for Washington this weekend, confident that he has political control at home and can establish a more conservative and trusting relationship with the Reagan Administration.

title: William French Smith, In Sicily, Cites Drug Link
description: Attorney General William French Smith asserted today that organized crime elements in Sicily supply about 80 percent of the heroin sold in the northeastern United States and is a major law-enforcement problem.

title: CHECKER MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,011,000 for the qr and 9 mos from LIFO liquidations...C-Net loss

title: ROCK: 5 'MEN' OF AUSTRALIA
description: MEN at Work, a rock quintet from Melbourne, Australia, is this year's overnight success story in pop music, having recently hit No. 1 with its debut album, ''Business as Usual.'' In two sold-out shows at the Ritz over the weekend, the quintet displayed the verve, precision and polish of a thoroughly professional though not widely original pop ensemble.

title: CAVS END SKID AT 24
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers snapped a record 24-game losing streak that spanned two seasons when they defeated the Golden State Warriors tonight in overtime, 132-120.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cello-Piano Recital
description: Lynn Harrell, cellist, and Rudolf Firkusny, pianist, will play duo sonatas by Brahms (No. 2 in F, Op. 99), Beethoven (Op. 102, No. 1) and Chopin (Op. 65) on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $12. Information: 362-1911.

title: WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHILHARMONIC: MOZART AND BRUCKNER'S NO. 9
description: THERE is no such thing as a great primitive composer in the same sense that Grandma Moses is said to be a primitive painter. An irreducible amount of education and training are required, after all, of anyone who writes music seriously. But sophistication is something else again, and on the sophistication scale we can safely say that Mozart ranks somewhere near the top while Bruckner's name would be found considerably lower. For that reason, last night's New York Philharmonic concert made good programming sense: it began with one of Mozart's most refined piano concertos, No. 17 in G (K. 453), and closed with Bruckner's unfinished final symphony, No. 9 in D minor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I look forward to conducting relations with the new leadership in the Soviet Union with the aim of expanding areas where our two nations can cooperate to mutual advantage.'' -President Reagan. (A1:3.)

title: SHUTTLE LIFTS OFF IN FIFTH MISSION WITH CREW OF 4
description: The space shuttle Columbia returned to orbit today, and in its inaugural mission as a space freighter, successfully released the first of two satellites it was hauling for the program's initial paying customers.

title: Clippers Post First Victory
description: Terry Cummings, a rookie forward, hit a short jump shot with 29 seconds to play tonight , putting San Diego ahead to stay as the Clippers posted their first victory of the season, a 109-105 triumph over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: BOSTON PROJECT IS A SHOWCASE FOR GROUP THAT HELPS REBUILD NEIGHBORHOODS
description: The plaza of Villa Victoria, bordered by town houses in Hispanic style, is an inviting place where toddlers play beneath the golden-leafed maples and the elderly stroll without fear. The sign permanently and prominently displayed reads: ''An example of the Puerto Rican struggle.''

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Pfizer Inc., the diversified health-care and chemicals company, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Valleylab Inc. in a tax-free merger involving an exchange of all Valleylab stock for 1.65 million shares of Pfizer common stock.

title: Rail Service to End On a Trenton Line
description: In an effort to cut into an expected $49.9 million deficit in its operating budget for the current fiscal year, the directors of the NJ Transit Corporation, the state's commuter transportation agency, today ordered the elimination of all rail service on the West Trenton line and the dismissal of eight ticket agents.

title: T-Shirt Mania
description: When Jim Drucker recently took his first vacation in four years, the last thing he expected to see in the small town of Hana on the Hawaiian isle of Maui was a person walking down the street wearing a Maine Lumberjacks T-shirt.

title: 2 Women Share $94,535.20 Trifecta
description: Two New Jersey women held the only winning ticket on a fourth-race triple that paid $94,535.20 at the Meadowlands today.

title: Walter J. Detmar Jr., 78, Dies; Retired City Building Official
description: Walter J. Detmar Jr., a retired director of building management in the New York City Public Works Department, who helped plan city receptions for dignitarities, died Wednesday at Catskill (N.Y.) Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Windham, N.Y.

description: The defending champions in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship face an uphill struggle when the two-session final is concluded tonight at the Cavendish Club in New York. In a three-way contest, the team headed by Peter Leventritt and made up of Dick Kahn, Edgar Kaplan, Boris Koytchou, Ronald Blau and Martin Ginsberg trailed in both its matches after Wednesday's play.

description: The Devils could not stop Wayne Gretzky from scoring a second-period goal tonight, but they neutralized his teammates until the early stages of the last period. The Edmonton Oilers took control after that and scored four straight goals for a 5-1 decision over New Jersey, whose string without a victory reached 12 games.

description: An audit of Louisiana State University's athletic department has found mismanagement but no criminal wrongdoing, District Attorney Ossie Brown said Wednesday. ''We've gone through all the documents,'' he said.

FOREIGN AGENTS LINKED TO FREEZE, REAGAN SAYS
description: President Reagan asserted tonight that ''foreign agents'' had helped instigate the American movement toward a freeze in the nuclear arsenals of the Soviet Union and the United States.

Hunt Clears the Foxes From a Jersey Airport
description: State and local officials said today that the sight of red foxes scampering through the woodlands around Mercer County Airport in central New Jersey was just a colorful diversion until the animals got a little too bold. When they began to take over the runway, a fox hunt was organized to drive the animals away.

title: Suit Is Filed Against GAF
description: Samuel J. Heyman, a Westport, Conn., real estate developer and dissident stockholder of the GAF Corporation, charged in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday that the chemical company had issued false and misleading reports to perpetuate company executives in office.

title: REMODELING HOWARD JOHNSON
description: For the past half-century, orange-roofed Howard Johnson's has been a fixture of the American highway, an inevitable stop for the American family on vacation. Times have changed, but the Howard Johnson's chain has not - and that, industry analysts and competitors say, is the source of the problems afflicting the 57-year-old restaurant and lodging company.

title: President Leaves Colonial Life in Rift
description: The Colonial Life and Accident Insurance Company said yesterday that Charles B. Beard, its president since 1980, had resigned over ''basic differences in management philosophy.''

title: Count the House
description: Alexis Arguello and Aaron Pryor aren't the only people who could be hurt in tonight's fight in the Orange Bowl in Miami for the junior welterweight title. A group of businessmen invested $1 million by buying the financial rights to the live gate, and now they are worrying about the weather, the crowd and the impact of cable television.

title: MESSAGE FROM SOVIET LEADERSHIP TO PEOPLE
description: Following are excerpts from an address to the people from the Soviet leadership on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, as distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

description: B-After a loss of $1,306,701 from discontinued operations

description: B-Net income, after an extraordinary credit of $195,000...C-Net income
