Jersey Woman Found Insane In the Slaying of Her Father
description: A 27-year-old woman has been found not guilty by reason of insanity in the stabbing death of her physician father after a psychiatrist testified that the woman thought she was attacking her father's clone.

title: DUNCAN C. MENZIES
description: Duncan Cameron Menzies, retired president and chairman of Servel Inc., manufacturer of refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment, died Tuesday at the Beverly Manor convalescent hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: ART: THE PIONEERING OF MORTON SCHAMBERG
description: IF Morton Livingston Schamberg (1881-1918) hadn't died young, his work might have developed as a major contribution to American modernist art. One of the small band who joined the revolution of European painting in the early 1900's, he is known to the art world today by only a few things, including a one-shot Dada assemblage of plumbing pipes he did around 1916, titled ''God.'' Yet he was an impressive colorist, one of the first painters to bring Cubism to America and a pioneer of the Precisionist movement that was further developed by such artists as Charles Sheeler, Georgia O'Keeffe and Ralston Crawford. What's more, the meticulous renderings of mechanical parts he did in 1916 were among the earliest in that genre, today even thought to antedate the Dada ''machine'' paintings of Francis Picabia.

title: Itel Corp. Files Amended Plan
description: The Itel Corporation, which filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy act in January 1981, said today that it had filed an amended reorganization plan with the bankruptcy court.

title: APPEALS COURT EASES PENALTY FOR JUDGE
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that, though it thought a County Court judge was clearly guilty of misconduct, he should be censured but not removed from office.

title: RUTGERS ROUTED BY WEST VIRGINIA
description: Three big plays, favorable turnovers, superior speed and more talent turned an even game into a rout in the second half as West Virginia defeated Rutgers, 44-17, tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unwonted Informality

title: Lymphoma Researcher Finds Chromosome Abnormalities
description: Detection of genetic abnormalities in cancerous cells of lymphoma patients promises to become an important new tool in understanding some cancers, a University of Minnesota medical researcher says.

title: Freeing Walesa, Squeezing Poland
description: Sadly, the announcement that Lech Walesa will soon be released testifies more to the effectiveness of martial law than to an easing of repressive control in Poland.

title: FOR MUSCOVITES, MUSINGS ABOUT THE 'FREE FOR ALL'
description: At a sweaty, stand-up beer hall on the Tsvetnoi Boulevard, the arrival of the Moscow evening newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva sent a ripple of curiosity through the workers chasing greasy smoked fish with mugs of beer dispensed from 20-kopeck machines.

title: MAYOR SEEKS TO LIMIT SPENDING CUTS
description: Mayor Koch, responding to a warning by Governor Carey that local governments not rely on new taxes and increased state aid to balance their budgets, said yesterday that city services would be devastated if the budget was balanced only through additional spending cuts.

title: Money Fund Yields Fall
description: Donoghue's Money Fund Report, an industry newsletter, said yesterday that for the week ended Wednesday the average seven-day yield for all money market funds fell to 8.65 percent from 8.81 percent the previous week, while the 30-day yield declined to 8.9 percent from 9.07 percent. For institutional funds, the seven-day yield fell to 8.91 percent from 9.02 percent the week before, and the 30-day yield was 9.18 percent compared with 9.32 percent.

title: Bakery Picks Chairman
description: Dale C. Putman, president and chief executive officer of the Interstate Bakeries Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chairman. Interstate, one of the nation's largest bakeries, has 36 plants around the nation.

title: Robins Acquisition
description: The A.H. Robins Company of Richmond said it had acquired U.S. Clinical Products Inc., based in Richardson, Tex., for an undisclosed cash price.

title: College Top 20 Computer ranking based on games through Nov. 6
description: OPPONENTS' PERFORMANCES

title: Tennis Unit Fines Event Organizers
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council has fined the organizers of the Stockholm Open championships $25,000 because the Swedish Government refused visas to four South African players who wanted to compete in the tournament.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: THEATER: JESSICA TANDY IN 'FOXFIRE'
description: JESSICA TANDY is the only real reason to consider seeing ''Foxfire,'' the play that opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore, but that's a reason to be taken seriously. Everything this actress does is so pure and right that only poets, not theater critics, should be allowed to write about her.

title: ON THE MORALITY OF NUCLEAR SABER RATTLING
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISLANDERS HALTED BY NORTH STARS
description: In a hard fought game that in many ways suggested the quality of Stanley Cup playoffs, the Minnesota North Stars broke a scoreless tie in the third period tonight to beat the Islanders, 2-0.

title: NEW HAVEN RUN ON CONRAIL GETS SERIES OF DELAYS
description: The Federal Railway Administration announced yesterday that every train on Conrail's New Haven line must stop every 30 miles so that each wheel of the train can be inspected. In addition, trains will not be permitted to go faster than 55 miles an hour.

title: AFTER BREZHNEV
description: A few days ago a leading American Soviet expert pointed out that the Kremlin's succession had already begun. ''Some people had come to think Stalin was immortal,'' he said, ''but Leonid Brezhnev's death will be no surprise.''

title: Police Rescue Man In Bridge Leap
description: An elderly man leaped from the Roosevelt Island Bridge yesterday morning but was pulled from the East River moments after a passing traffic helicopter spotted him and radioed his position to authorities.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE reason Edie Adams is in town, singing at the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, is, she says, to show people that she has a voice. This may sound like a strange ambition for someone who has been singing on Broadway, on television, in films and in nightclubs for almost 30 years.

title: Mets Choose a Coach
description: Gene Dusan, a 33-year-old minor league manager, will become the Mets' bullpen coach next season, helping to take the place of Bill Monbouquette, who had served as pitching and bullpen coach until being relegated recently to scouting duty. Dusan, who was a minor league catcher for nine years, managed the Mets' team at Jackson, Miss., that qualified for the Texas League playoffs last season and won the Casey Stengel Award as the top manager in the parent club's farm system. In New York, he will work closely with George Bamberger, who plans to do double duty as manager and pitching coach.

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $3,083,000 on the redemption of bonds

title: TALKS SCHEDULED WITH REAGAN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel arrived in the United States yesterday to start a 10-day visit that is to include talks with President Reagan.

title: DOW UP 10.21 IN A STRONG RALLY
description: Stock prices shook off early selling pressure yesterday that was touched off by news of the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, and then staged a strong rally in the final half-hour of trading. Brokerage stocks were particularly strong.

title: SUCCESSION; Yuri V. Andropov
description: If there had been any doubts about the prominence of Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov in the leadership, they were removed yesterday when the 68-year-old former head of the secret police was named chairman of the funeral commission for Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: 2 Named to Fight For Leonard Title
description: Alberto Mendoza of Venezuela, president of the World Boxing Association, said today that Milton McCrory of Detroit and Don Curry of Fort Worth, ranked Nos.1 and 2, would fight for the vacant welterweight title.

title: Unbeaten Teams Have Image Problem
description: Arizona State, Georgia and Southern Methodist, the only remaining undefeated and untied major college football teams this season, are a source of some embarrassment to the college athletic community because each is serving a period of probation for violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: CANADIAN NATIONAL RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $7,871,000 for the qr and $76,641,000 for the 9 mos

title: PUBLISHING: NELSON ACQUIRES EVEREST
description: THOMAS NELSON PUBLISHERS of Nashville, which this year bought the 143-year-old Dodd, Mead company, has now purchased Everest House, a five-year-old adult trade book publisher. Everest House will become an imprint of Dodd, Mead, which will continue as a general trade publisher based in New York. Lewis W. Gillenson, founder and president of Everest House, has been named president of Dodd, Mead, succeeding S. Phelps Platt Jr., who recently retired.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including capital gains of $1,844,127 for the qr and $2,177,269 for the 9 mos...C-After capital losses of $100,576 for the qr and $310,413 for the 9 mos and tax credits of $615,772 for the qr and $890,728 for the 9 mos; the yr-ago qr and9 mos restated to reflect adoption of accounting change for foreign currency translation

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 STUDIOS TO BUY SHARES IN A PAY-TV NETWORK
description: Trying again to win a larger portion of pay television's growing revenues, some of Hollywood's largest studios announced plans yesterday to become partners in an all-movie pay-television network.

title: Take the Fiscal Crises in Order
description: It was clear in January, when Mayor Koch presented his budget plan for New York City's current fiscal year, that a budget storm was brewing. Now the economic downturn has begun to erode revenues. And the otherwise welcome decline in inflation means even less in tax collections. The first gusts are whistling through the trees.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Hawk and the Dove
description: MIAMI W hen he struts into the ring at the Orange Bowl to defend his World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title against Alexis Arguello tonight, Aaron Pryor will turn to his corner and shout, ''What time is it?''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Without Doubt, The Man in Charge

title: REPORT OF A SOUTH AFRICAN GIFT TO MRS. KIRKPATRICK IS DENIED
description: A spokesman for Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Mrs. Kirkpatrick had been wrongly accused of receiving a gift from South African officials and was considering legal action against the British magazine that published the accusation.

title: U.A.W. CAUCUS NOMINATING HEIR TO FRASER TODAY
description: A successor to Douglas A. Fraser as president of the 1.2-million-member United Automobile Workers is expected to be chosen Friday by the union's political caucus.

title: Burnup to Acquire Stake in Coradian
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., a telecommunications and cable TV service company based here, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Coradian Corporation of Albany, a supplier of private telephone systems in New York and New Jersey.

title: A Freshman Star At 29 Years Old
description: Most 29-year-old freshmen don't make the varsity track and field team in college. But then, most 29-year-old freshmen aren't Filbert Bayi, the former world record-holder in the 1,500 meters and the mile run, and now one of the newest members of the team at the University of Oklahoma.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The executive council of major league baseball meets in New York today to consider a successor to Bowie Kuhn. ... The World Boxing Council, concluding its convention in Venice, Italy, chose Larry Holmes, the W.B.C.'s heavyweight champion, as boxer of the year. ... The talk at Baton Rouge has been that Jerry Stovall, the coach of Louisiana State's surprisingly successful football team, will get a contract extension. Stovall said yesterday that he didn't want one but that he would appreciate a raise. He earns $52,400 a year.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Ulster Assembly Opens; Most Catholics Absent

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: It Never Looked That Good Before It Was Stolen

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN PLEDGES AN EFFORT TO IMPROVE TIES; News session transcript, page B6.; Reagan's letter, page A12.
description: President Reagan pledged tonight that his Administration would work with the new leadership in the Soviet Union to improve Soviet-American relations after the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: PURCELL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tryout for Inmate
description: A prison inmate in Illinois who is serving a 12-year sentence for armed robbery was given a free-agent tryout by the Chicago Blitz in the Logan Correctional Center yard. Twenty-three-year-old Mike Sifford, who has served four and a half years and is due for parole at the end of 1983, impressed George Allen, the general manager, part owner and coach of the fledgling United States Football League franchise.

title: An A-Plant Switch by China
description: China has decided to build its first nuclear power plant in Zhejiang Province near Hangzhou in eastern China, the official New China News Agency said Wednesday. The report contradicted an earlier one from Peking that China had begun to build its first nuclear power station near Shanghai.

title: SKETCHES OF THE ASTRONAUTS ORBITING EARTH TODAY ABOARD THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Vance D. Brand

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $5,000 for the qr and $53,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including net claims income of $2,114,000 for the qr and $6,404,000 for the 6 mos relating to pre-Chapter 11 contract and also tax credits of $1,149,000 for the qr and $3,186,000 for the 6 mos; rev figures represent contract income

title: ISRAELI INQUIRY IS TOLD SHARON AIDE KNEW OF MASSACRE
description: An Israeli intelligence officer, contradicting testimony by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon's top assistant, said today that the aide was informed early on the morning of Sept. 17 that a massacre of civilians was under way in two refugee camps, hours after Phalangist militiamen entered the camps.

title: DON'T BET ON 'FRATICIDE'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT OF ALTAIR DISCUSSES PROBLEMS
description: Two days after Altair Airlines petitioned for reorganization in Federal Bankruptcy Court here, Henry Hill, its 38-year-old president, ran through the difficulties his small airline had encountered, somewhat like a football coach after a losing game.

title: BRITISH SPY HURT THE U.S., MRS. THATCHER DECLARES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told an angry Parliament today that a Briton who confessed to passing secrets to the Soviet Union had damaged the security interests of the United States as well as those of the Atlantic alliance.

title: THE CHALLENGE AFTER BREZHNEV
description: THE death of Leonid I. Brezhnev presents Washington with economic opportunities and well as political hazards, at a time when the Western democracies are deeply divided over military and economic issues. The two are closely linked because of the heavy financial burdens that military spending places on the strained Western economies.

title: Dr. Jacqueline Lewis Is Dead; Dean of a Division at Rutgers
description: Dr. Jacqueline Sorkin Lewis, dean of the New Brunswick Division of University College at Rutgers University, died Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan after a long illness. She was 48 years old and lived in Somerset, N.J.

title: PIECES OF SKYLAB GOING ON SALE
description: Charles (Pete) Conrad, the astronaut who was commander of the first Skylab mission, said today that pieces of the crashed space vehicle would be sold as souvenirs, with the revenues to go to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: REAGAN CONSIDERING GAS TAX RISE TO PAY FOR REPAIR OF ROADS
description: President Reagan said tonight that he was seriously considering a gasoline-tax increase to finance road and bridge repairs that would create an estimated 300,000 jobs.

title: Arguello-Pryor Fight 'Has to Be' Great
description: Alexis Arguello tries for a record fourth title tomorrow night, but his fight with Aaron Pryor is not for the history books alone.

title: COMPUTERIZED SYSTEM HELPS A PARALYZED WOMAN TO WALK
description: Nan Davis, with her paralyzed legs wired to a computer that controlled electrical stimulation, took six slow steps today.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * The Detroit Free Press to W.B. Doner & Company, Southfield, Mich. * MCA Advertising has resigned Mattel's Western Publishing account.

title: CONCERT: FAURE'S REQUIEM
description: ST. Thomas Church, on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, offers one of the city's more ambitious church-music programs, and Tuesday night this season's series led off with a well-attended French program of Poulenc's Mass in G (1937), his Concerto in G minor for organ, strings and timpani (1938) and Faure's Requiem (Op. 48).

title: A SCHOOL PROTECTED, NOT MISUSED BY THE P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: MARDEN ON MARBLE, ON CANVAS AND ON PAPER
description: IT would be difficult to imagine, let alone to paint, pictures more distinguished of their kind than Brice Marden's. When his ''Annunciation Series'' of 1977 was shown at the Pace Gallery four years ago, it established itself at once as one of the richest, clearest and most fulfilled of our century's grand designs. It is a misfortune for us all that it was not bought for an American museum and is now widely dispersed.

title: Head of Public Works Is Dismissed by Mayor
description: Mayor Michael Matthews has dismissed the acting head of the city's Public Works Department for describing the agency's employees as lazy and incompetent political appointees who frequently showed up for work drunk.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jakarta Cuts Its Oil Prices
description: Indonesia reduced the contract price of its top-selling Minas crude oil by 47 cents a barrel today and cut prices of other grades by as much as $1.30, the director of the state-owned Pertamina oil company said. The new Minas price is $34.53.

title: DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OWNERS REJECT BID TO RESUME TALKS
description: The National Football League Players Association, on the 52d day of its strike, requested yesterday that negotiations be resumed ''in the spirit of compromise.'' The N.F.L. Management Council, representing the owners of the 28 clubs, rejected the request.

title: Tandy Acquisition
description: The Tandy Corporation said it had agreed to buy the assets of Interconnect Telecommunications Systems Inc. of Lexington, Ky., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: CONSOLIDATED REFINING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $18,000 or 1 cent a shr for the qr and $156,000 or 11 cents a shr for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: Why Python star turned 'Missionary.'
description: WHAT made Michael Palin write, produce and star in ''The Missionary''? ''Greed,'' he says merrily. ''Essentially greed and lust for recognition, power and respect.''

title: Decision File; Solar Bank Now Open
description: The Solar Bank, originally conceived by the Carter Administration as a $3 billion project to subsidize consumer loans for installation of solar energy systems, has finally opened its doors. But it took a court order to put it in business.

title: KREMLIN WATCHERS VIEW BREZHNEV AS CONSOLIDATOR OF COMMUNIST AUTHORITY
description: On the day after his death, Leonid I. Brezhnev was viewed by specialists on the Soviet Union in this country as far more a consolidator than a creator, more a preserver of traditional Communist Party authority than an experimenter in new political or diplomatic forms.

title: A MAGIC CARPET OF NILE MUSIC FOR NEW YORK
description: SAY Egyptian to most dancegoers and they'll think of belly dancing. But the Festival of the Nile troupe may widen a few horizons tonight at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx and on Sunday at Carnegie Hall, part of its first North American tour that ends next week in Washington.

title: Move Pleases Bailey
description: ''Minutes are the difference'' between success and failure in the National Basketball Association, says James Bailey, who adds that because he wasn't playing enough of them, he is happy to have left the Nets. ''I'm glad I'm gone,'' the 25-year-old forward said upon learning Wednesday that he had been acquired by the Houston Rockets in exchange for a second-round draft choice next year and another in 1985.

title: DON SHIRLEY AT COOKERY MAKING A 'COMEBACK'
description: DON SHIRLEY expounds. His large round eyes bulge out of their sockets. There is passion, fury, contradiction and anguish. He is a concert pianist who resents the fact that most of his prominence in this city is due to nightclub engagements.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. The Knicks (0-7) are off to the worst start in their history. Their losing streak over two seasons is 12 games.

title: Top price for sculpture.
description: DAVID SMITH'S ''Two Doors'' brought the highest price ever paid for a post-World War II American sculpture at auction Wednesday night, when it was sold at Christie's for $572,000 to an American buyer who was not identified. The Smith sculpture, fabricated of polished steel in 1964, was one of 10 post-1945 art works that established records in the sale.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * The Alaska Housing Finance Corp. said it would offer $50 million of state-assisted mortgage bonds, series H due in 1992, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: MARTIN S. SELLINGER
description: Martin S. Sellinger, former president of the Keene Corporation, died Wednesday after a long illness.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcan Aluminum Corp., Cleveland, has named Robert W. Marriott president and chief executive officer of the Metal Goods division.

title: BLUE AND GRAY, A SKETCHBOOK
description: IN the 1920's in New York, some of them were still around. They talked familiarly among themselves of places small boys had only read about in history books: Vicksburg, Cold Harbor, Gettysburg and, with lowered voices, a terrible place called the Wilderness. In their cups they would mention ''Lyss'' and ''Cump,'' nicknames for Ulysses S. Grant and William Tecumseh Sherman. They never called it the Civil War; they called it the War of the Rebellion.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART PEOPLE
description: AT the age of 85, the sculptor Reuben Nakian has just finished a major one-man show. Five years and $250,000 of his own money went into the making and casting of the 37 sculptures that were on display at the Marlborough Gallery from Oct. 7 through Nov. 3.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sounders' Distress Call
description: The owners of the Seattle Sounders, just one of the ailing clubs in the the financially troubled North American Soccer League, say the team may have to be sold unless fresh money can be brought in from new investors.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $6,089,082...C-Including a gain of $1,775,762

title: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Per Royal Dutch Petroleum shrs...C-Per Shell Transport & Trading shrs; both Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport & Trading are listed on the New ^York Stock Exchanges; results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations and the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect this adoption

title: ACTORS PAY HOMAGE TO O'NEILL, STRINDBERG
description: A group of Sweden's leading actors were honored last night on Broadway by a group of leading American actors. What they had in common was a passion for two playwrights - the American Eugene O'Neill and Sweden's August Strindberg.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp. said its Barnes & Tucker Co. subsidiary had acquired the assets of two coal mines from LTV Corp.'s Jones & Laughlin subsidiary for an undisclosed amount.

title: YOUTH CHARGED IN FATAL BEATING ON RIVERSIDE DR.
description: A 16-year-old youth was charged last night with the Tuesday slaying of a wealthy Riverside Drive resident who had been host to the teenager, his brother and their mother over the summer.

title: A SENATE OFFICE BUILDING IN A SEARCH FOR SENATORS
description: It's moving time on Capitol Hill, but like a wallflower at the senior prom, the sparkling new Hart Senate Office Building is being snubbed by most senators with enough seniority to say ''No.''

title: Deere to Furlough 400 More Workers
description: Deere & Company announced that 400 more workers at plants here will be put on indefinite furlough on Nov. 22.

title: ITALY'S PREMEIR TRIES TO RESIGN BUT THE OFFER IS REFUSED
description: The Prime Minister of Italy's 42d postwar Government handed in his resignation today, but, in a surprise move, President Sandro Pertini refused to accept it.

title: VIETNAM WAR MEMORIAL: RANCOR, TEARS AND SONG
description: In a bittersweet echo of the 1960's, Vietnam veterans wept and partied together, stared and shouted at the memorial to their war dead today, finally having to bury one fitful burst of rancor by singing hymns to their dead colleagues.

title: THE MARKET FOR CUSTOM BUILT HOMES ON STATEN ISLAND
description: At a pace of 100 to 200 houses a year, the production of custombuilt houses is proceeding in far-flung locations in New York City's least-developed borough, Staten Island.

title: Tastes of Vietnam and a bustling pub.
description: UNTIL recently, the intricate and savory specialties of Vietnam have been only meagerly and indifferently represented in New York. Now the void has been filled most capably and deliciously by the Dao family, which owns and operates Saigon, a tidy little downstairs restaurant on Mulberry Street in Chinatown. The family, Chinese in origin, lived in Vietman for four generations, came to this country four years ago and opened this restaurant last April.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PANEL WARNS OF $150 BILLION 7-YEAR GAP
description: The 15 members of the National Commission on Social Security Reform agreed today that Congress must come up with $150 billion to $200 billion in cuts in benefits or in additional revenue for the Social Security program in the next seven years.

title: Gulf Countries Support Iraq on Ending the War
description: The heads of state of the six-nation Persian Gulf Cooperation Council today backed Iraq's efforts for a peaceful end to the two-year-old war with Iran.

title: INTERNATIONAL TOTALIZATOR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $184,000 or 6 cents a shr for the qr and $392,000 or 13 cents a shr for the 9 mos...C-Net loss...D-After a tax credit of $139,000 or 7 cents a shr

title: VOLUNTEER LABELING PLAN BEGUN ON ASPRIN PRODUCTS
description: A coalition of professional, consumer and business groups today announced a voluntary labeling program to warn consumers of the association between aspirin and Reye's Syndrome, a rare children's disease.

title: 'THE SLUMBER PARTY'
description: WHAT do you get when today's cheap, bloody horror movie format is turned over to a woman screenwriter and a woman director? Not much, and nothing good - even if the director (Amy Jones) has some slight sense of humor, and the writer is the novelist Rita Mae Brown.

title: Fire Sweeps Large Area Of Central Kansas Prairie
description: Firefighters aided by nearly a thousand volunteers battled a prairie fire late tonight that burned about 100 square miles of central Kansas, threatening homes and injuring two hunters, one critically.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TO-WALL AMERICA: A Cultural History of Post-Office Murals in the Great Depression. By Karal Ann Mar- ling. Illustrated. University of Minne- sota Press. 348 pages. $35 (paper, $14.95).

title: FIRST OF NATION'S TITAN MISSILES DEACTIVATED IN ARIZONA
description: Under a new defense plan announced last fall by President Reagan, the first of the nation's 52 Titan II missiles was officially deactivated here this week in a sparsely populated valley about 35 miles south of metropolitan Tucson.

title: DYNATREND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Marvin P. Lazarus, 64, Dies; A Lawyer and Photographer
description: Marvin P. Lazarus, a lawyer and photographer, died Tuesday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: APPEAL OF CREATING JOBS IS BIPARTISAN
description: Some people call it ''The Room of Lost Causes,'' and indeed the Rayburn Room in the Capitol is where the House Democrats traditionally hold major news conferences to announce programs that die aborning. But when Representative Henry S. Reuss, the Democratic chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, took the floor the other day to propose the framework of a Democratic public works jobs programs, he was taken seriously.

title: REAGAN DECIDES TO SEND HABIB BACK TO MIDEAST
description: President Reagan, concerned about the slow pace of negotiations to withdraw all foreign forces from Lebanon, announced today that Philip C. Habib would assume control of Middle East peace discussions.

title: U.S. Home Merger
description: The U.S. Home Corporation has agreed to acquire Brigadier Industries in an exchange of stock valued at $25.5 million, the companies announced. Under terms of the agreement, Brigadier's 6.37 million outstanding shares would be converted on a tax-free basis into a number of U.S. Home shares with a total value of $25.5 million.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MR. FALWELL MEETS AN OUTSPOKEN ANTAGONIST, YALE'S GIAMATTI
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the founder of Moral Majority, met here today with one of the organization's most outspoken critics, A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of Yale University, in a session arranged by Vice President Bush.

title: Let Mrs. Bhutto Go, Pakistani Doctors Urge
description: A medical board has recommended to Pakistan's military Government that Nusrat Bhutto, the ailing widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, be allowed to go abroad for treatment for suspected lung cancer, her doctor said today. Mr. Bhutto was hanged in April 1979.

title: BENDIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a net charge of $5.8 million for the qr and yr for a change in a domestic automotive operation and a loss of $5 million for the qr and yr from discontinued operations...C-Inclu ding a net gain of $32.4 million for the qr and yr fromthe sale of a subsidiary and income of $248,310,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: DANCE AND MUSIC CLUBS THRIVING IN ERA OF CHANGE
description: THE New York dance-club scene, like its patrons, rarely sits still. Every month new clubs open and others shut down, while gimmicks, decor and music policies come and go. In fact, it is always advisable to call a club before going; last-minute changes come with the territory.

title: AN APPARATCHIK AND A BIG FAILURE
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev died Monday, Nov. 10, 1982, one month short of his 76th birthday, a leader who had failed in his two great goals - peace and security for the Soviet Union and a maturing prosperity for his people.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a credit of $242,000 arising from reserves no longer required for previously discontinued operations...C-Net income after a loss of $22,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $6,000 consisting of a loss from discontinued operations and a credit for reserves no longer required for previously discontinued operations...E-Including income of $80,000 from discontinued operations

title: OPERA: 'BALLO'
description: THREE recent Metropolitan Opera performances of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' have involved major company debuts that had not been scheduled when the season was planned and that could have unsettled the production mightily. That this has not happened was apparent in the Tuesday night performance, when Anton Guadagno took over as conductor, replacing Giuseppe Patane, who withdrew under orders from his doctor to rest.

title: Condor Chick a Male; Mate Will Be Sought
description: Wanted: female condor to share a $100,000 pad. Mountain view. Free room and board. After three months, zoologists at the San Diego Wild Animal Park determined Wednesday that the first young California condor taken into captivity was a male.

title: Honduran Will Visit Nicaragua for Talks
description: Foreign Minister Edgardo Paz Barnica of Honduras said tonight that he would fly to Nicaragua on Friday for talks aimed at resolving the tensions that have threatened to erupt into war between the Central American neighbors.

title: ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,566,000 and a loss on the disposal of companies of $600,000...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $384,000 for the qr and $308,000 for the yr...D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,278,000 and a gain on the disposal of a unit of $300,000

title: U.S. Fumigating Warehouse Pests
description: Fumigators began pumping methyl bromide gas into a TriBeCa warehouse yesterday to kill an infestation of khapra beetles after Department of Agriculture officials took special safety measures to protect neighborhood residents from exposure to the toxic gas.

title: BRIEFING
description: Unpunished Disclosures

title: BORDEN COMPLAINT SETTLED BY TEXACO
description: Texaco Inc. will pay Borden Inc. $39 million to settle a two-yearold dispute over canceled natural gas deliveries to Borden chemical plants in Geismar, La., the companies annoucned.

title: Two Brezhnevs
description: For 18 years, Leonid Brezhnev was apparent master of a hostile superpower strong enough to sow a nuclear whirlwind. None was sown, or even threatened. In that time a perilous balance was sustained, and he earned a measure of respect as a hard yet realistic adversary. He was the oligarch we knew, and with his death at 75, Soviet power passes to heirs we barely know.

title: Man Holding 9 Hostages At High School Gives Up
description: An 18-year-old man freed the last of his nine hostages and dropped his high-powered rifle in a high school hallway this morning, ending a 21-hour standoff that the police said followed a spurned marriage proposal.

title: A Major Japanese Newspaper Offers New Service in English
description: A major Japanese newspaper, Asahi Shimbun, has established a news service that offers articles in English focusing on Japan and Southeast Asia.

title: A Recall on 'Happy Mates'
description: A New Jersey company is voluntarily recalling squeeze toys, called Happy Mates, because they are small enough to lodge in a child's throat, the Consumer Product Safety Commisson said Wednesday. The toys have not been cited in any choking or suffocation incidents, the commission said, but toys with similar shapes have been involved in deaths by choking. About 8,000 Happy Mates have been distributed in the past two years, primarily in the Northeast.

title: 'BLUE AND GRAY,' CIVIL WAR SAGA
description: AT a cost of millions, with a cast of hundreds and bearing the imprimatur of noted historians, ''The Blue and the Gray'' comes to television Sunday, beginning its eight-hour run on CBS-TV at 8 P.M. It will continue Tuesday and end Wednesday. This represents a major undertaking for the network, what one vice president has called its ''most ambitious television project'' ever. Unfortunately, the mammoth project is distressingly soft at its dramatic core.

title: UNITED PARK CITY MINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soprano Sings Marta on Short Notice
description: Muriel Costa-Greenspon, a mezzo-soprano who had only hours to learn her part, was called on to fill the role of Marta in last evening's performance by the New York City Opera of ''Mefistofele'' at the New York State Theater.

title: Man Injured as Pipe Erupts
description: A worker was critically injured today as a pipe carrying nitrogen and hydrogen ruptured and burst into flames at a chemical plant of the Olin Corporation, officials said. The injured man, identified as Brian Manuel, 28 years old, was taken by helicopter to the John Sealey Burn Center in Galveston, Tex.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1982; The Economy
description: Recovery is not likely to begin until early 1983, according to the Commerce Department's top economist, Robert Ortner. He said that a previously reported gain in third-quarter growth would probably be revised to a small decline and that, though the fourth quarter might show a slight rise, there would be no ''significant upturn until the first quarter'' of next year. (Page D1.)

title: STRAVINSKY MANUSCRIPT SALE SETS AUCTION RECORD
description: A record price for a musical manuscript was set today when the first completed working draft of Igor Stravinsky's ''The Rite of Spring'' was auctioned at Sotheby Park Bernet for $548,000.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $656,000 on the sale of property

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00N.A. Not available because of the Veterans Day holiday.** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW COMMUNICATIONS ERA FORSEEN WHILE SHUTTLE'S LAUNCHING OF SATELLITE
description: The successful launching of a satellite by the space shuttle Columbia yesterday promises to usher in a new era of lower prices and new capabilities for satellite communications, according to several experts. However, they said, it will take several years to realize the full benefits.

title: PANEL SLOWLY UNTANGLING CLAIMS ON IRAN
description: Scheveningen offers little hint of conflict. The suburb of The Hague is an old beach resort with a boardwalk, a steel pier and a grand hotel that looks a bit like Atlantic City before the casinos.

title: Uniroyal Inc.  Names Chief For Finance
description: John R. Graham, who joined Uniroyal Inc. in February as financial vice president, has been named chief financial officer. He succeeds William J. Crane, 61, who becomes vice chairman, and who has decided to take early retirement in 1983 after 45 years with the company.

title: A LEGACY OF DEFICITS
description: If Leonid I. Brezhnev had been president of any normal organization, he would have been fired long ago. In 1964, he took over a going concern with an annual growth rate of at least 6 percent. There was virtually no foreign debt. Agricultural output hit a record level that year; in 1962, agricultural exports had reached their highest point in half a century. There was good reason to expect that Mr. Brezhnev would have continued his country's economic growth and made the Soviet Union the world's No. 1 economic power, as Nikita S. Khrushchev had boasted it would be. In Mr. Khrushchev's words: ''The Soviet Union will overtake and surpass the United States'' by 1970 or 1980.

title: CORRECTION
description: Part of the Calendar of Events in The Home Section yesterday was mis- placed because of a production error. The lecture by Lady Patricia Jellicoe on ''Romantic Gardens in Exotic Places'' will be delivered next Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The fee is $4, and the reservation phone number is (516) 484-9337.

title: RAYMOND CHAUNCEY
description: Raymond Chauncey, an officer of the securities concern of Chauncey & Company and a member of the New York Stock Exchange for 64 years, died Monday at the South Nassau Communties Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: OSHA Plan To Be Effected
description: Combustion Engineering, a manufacturer of energy-related equipment, has become the nation's first company to win Government approval to police its own plant for health and safety, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced.

title: MEXICAN WRATH FALLS ON TEEN-AGE SEER AND SECT
description: All over Mexico there are shrines to the Virgin Mary and myriad saints that are visited by thousands - in some cases millions - of pilgrims each year. The visitors ask for miracles, give thanks for favors granted or merely seek forgiveness and protection.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: B-After capital losses of $22,000 for the qr and $145,000 for the 9 mos and a nonrecurring tax charge of $8 million for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net income

title: CONCERT: PRAGUE SYMPHONY
description: ONE of the striking aspects of Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony (Op. 95) played Wednesday by the Prague Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was that the music mattered. It was not played as a sonic showpiece or as a collection of melodies.

title: 'Shadow Box' team has two more plays on the way.
description: GORDON DAVIDSON and Michael Cristofer, who have a happy association that goes back to the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''The Shadow Box,'' are busy with two new projects. The first is Mr. Cristofer's play ''Black Angel,'' which Mr. Davidson is directing at Circle Repertory Company. The drama, which is based on the true story of a former Nazi officer who surfaced in a small village in France in 1976, went into rehearsal this week and will open Dec. 16. The other venture is Mr. Cristofer's play ''The Lady and the Clarinet,'' which Mr. Davidson will stage at the Long Wharf in New Haven - with Stockard Channing as the ''lady'' - after the first of the year. If all goes well there, Alexander H. Cohen will bring the play to Broadway.

title: HERBERT L. SMITH JR.
description: Herbert Ludlam Smith Jr., a founding partner of Murphy, Marseilles & Smith, New York stockbrokers, died yesterday in a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. He was 75 years old and had lived in Mill Neck, L.I.

title: FLYERS SCORE 5 IN 2D TO DEFEAT RANGERS
description: The Rangers continued a pattern of poor play on the road tonight when they gave up a string of unanswered goals and lost to the Philadelphia Flyers, 7-3, at the Spectrum.

title: PANELFAB INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TURKS' CLEAR CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN PLEDGES AN EFFORT TO IMPROVE TIES
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, who died suddenly on Wednesday at the age of 75, will be buried in Red Square, the Soviet leadership announced today. A four-day mourning period was declared, indicating that the funeral would be Monday.

title: AT TWO PARTIES, ROYAL ACCENTS
description: There's a season for almost everything, from soft-shell crabs to skiing, and heaven forbid that New York revelers take a back seat to shellfish or a pair of slats. There is, therefore, a social season and right now is it.

title: Goodyear, General Get Tire Contracts
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company have been awarded $28 million in contracts to supply 750,000 tires to the Nissan truck assembly plant here, Nissan officials said.

title: A TOUR OF HASIDIC WILLIAMSBURG
description: A sure sign of a Jewish neighborhood is a synagogue or a kosher butcher shop. But in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, everything seems kosher - the hardware store, the barber shop, the schools, the architecture, the clothing store, even the buses. What's more, there is a synagogue on almost every block.

title: Ex-Aide Collapses After Guilty Verdict
description: A former Bridgeport housing official remained in critical condition today after collapsing outside a Federal courtroom minutes after his conviction on extortion charges.

title: 'COME BACK TO THE 5 & DIME JIMMY DEAN'
description: THERE are some interesting things about Robert Altman's ''Come Back to the 5 & Dime Jimmy Dean, Jimmy Dean,'' but they have less to do with anything on the screen than with the manner in which the film was produced and with Mr. Altman's unflagging if misguided faith in the project.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $39,000 for the qr and $216,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $72,000 for the qr and $164,000 for the 9 mos

title: Profits Fall 13% At Shell Group
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's second-largest oil company, reported today that profits for the third quarter fell about 13 percent from the July-September period last year, to $762 million, from $877 million.

title: MEETING ON DIOXIN CHEERS MISSOURIANS A LITTLE
description: A public meeting today on dioxin contamination left residents of eastern Missouri with some hope that the Government would speed its investigation, but little in the way of practical advice.

title: DANCE: LOUIS 'APERTIF' AND 'REPERTOIRE'
description: BECAUSE dance is an art of the present tense, it can sometimes be risky for choreographers to look back. Unless a choreographer is able to make something out of the past live again in the present, retrospection can be akin to spending an evening with some amiable, but garrulous, friend who insists on showing you every last photo he took on his summer vacation.

title: EMONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $160,207 from the extinguishment of debt

title: WARSAW PLANNING TO RELEASE WALESA WITHIN A FEW DAYS
description: Poland's martial-law authorities announced today that Lech Walesa, the interned leader of the outlawed trade union Solidarity, would be released within the next few days because he was ''no longer a threat to internal security.''

description: B-Net income, including gain from accounting adjustment of $1,406,000

NEW U.S. PLAN ON I.M.F. QUOTA
description: The United States has told four of its allies that it favors increasing the resources of the International Monetary Fund by 40 percent to aid countries that cannot make ends meet, monetary sources reported today.

title: Hungary in I.M.F. Pact
description: Hungary has reached agreement with the International Monetary Fund to draw 475 million special drawing rights, plus an unspecified sum, to partly finance losses arising from the decline in export prices in the second half of 1981 and the first half of 1982, the official M.T.I. press agency said. An S.D.R., which is made up of a basket of currencies, is worth about $1.30.

title: Ex-Cuisine Head to Join Success Magazine
description: Charles D. Colleti, 43, former publisher of Cuisine magazine, which was acquired by CBS Publications, is joining Success magazine in Chicago with the same title.

title: Following are major disputes between Moscow and Washington
description: Arms Control Negotiations are taking place in separate forums in Geneva on limitation of Soviet and American medium-range missiles in Europe and on reducing each side's longer range strategic missiles and bombers. So far, there has been no apparent progress in either set of talks, but American and Soviet leaders have both said that the negotiations were being conducted in a serious way.

title: St. Regis Paper To Sell Kraft Mill
description: The St. Regis Paper Company said it is seeking a buyer for its kraft paper mill in Jacksonville, Fla., and added it was currently holding discussions with interested parties.

title: AN AFTERNOON EXPLORING CHESTERTON
description: If G.K. Chesterton were alive today, he would probably sympathize with antiabortion groups and environmentalists, and poke fun at a conference taking place tomorrow afternoon in the faculty lounge of Fordham University at Lincoln Center.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: NEW GUIDE TO EATING IN FRANCE
description: Le Bottin Gourmand, a new guide to restaurants, hotels and travel in France, has just been published here. The 1,176-page guide was written by Jean Didier, who for 29 years directed the Guide Kleber.

title: Owens-Illinois Cutback
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. said it planned to close and divest itself of its less productive plants around the world in a program that will cut fourth-quarter net income by about $32 million. It said the action will cut full-year net by $45 million.

title: John Henry Faces 8 in Jersey Race
description: In two major races tomorrow, John Henry returns to the East in the $400,000 Meadowlands Cup at the Meadowlands, and two young sons of Seattle Slew are favored in the $200,000 Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rosenfeld Ends Assignment
description: After a three-year relationship, Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has resigned its American Home Products assignments because it could not make money on the business.

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Primer for Parents

title: Frankfurt Police Seize 2 Guerrilla Suspects
description: The West German police today arrested two of the most wanted guerrillas from the Baader-Meinhof gang, both suspects in the attempted assassination of Gen. Frederick J. Kroesen last year, the authorities said.

title: PROBLEM FOR THE ZOO: AN ORNERY ELEPHANT
description: The multimillion-dollar plan to rebuild the Central Park Zoo has come up against what may be the most formidable challenge of all: Tina the elephant.

title: No Headline

title: Transit Officer Is Held in Robbery
description: A 21-year-old probationary transit police officer and two other men were arrested early yesterday and charged with robbing the owner of a purported store-front numbers operation at St. Nicholas Avenue and 180th Street in Manhattan, the police reported.

title: Advertising; Change to Business Magazines
description: IN recent years the ownership of two of the more important business publications in the advertising field has passed, partly at least, into the hands of dropouts from consumer magazines.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1982
description: The Death of Brezhnev Leonid I. Brezhnev, who died Wednesday at the age of 75, will be buried in Red Square, the Kremlin announced. A four-day mourning period was declared, indicating that the service would take place Monday in what is expected to be the largest funeral in Moscow since the death of Stalin in 1953. There was no announcement of any decision on a successor to Mr. Brezhnev, who held power for 18 years. (Page A1, Column 6.) Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev was a canny and careful leader who tried to make his country the military equal of the United States and to promote its global political influence through a policy of detente. (A10:1-6.)

title: Nets' Walker Shows His Versatility
description: F oots Walker was the Nets' starting point guard against the Knicks Wednesday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Earlier in the day, the Nets traded Phil Ford, who started at that position in their first seven games, to the Milwaukee Bucks - a move that returned the starting job to Walker for the first time since last season.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Purchased con- t racts of six minor league players: Mark B rown and Cliff Speck, pitchers, Ricky J ones, shortstop, and Jeff Williams, out- f ielder, from Rochester of the Class AAA I nternational League, and Ken Dixon, p itcher, and Al Pardo, catcher, from Class A A Charlotte, N.C., affiliate. Reassigned f ive players from roster to Rochester: Bill S waggerty, pitcher, Dave Huppert and W illie Royster, catchers, Vic Rodriguez, i nfielder, and Drungo Hazewood, outfield- e r. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Man- a ger Tommy Lasorda for seventh season o n one-year contract.

title: RAILROADS HAIL PROPOSAL FOR FLEXIBILITY ON CROPS
description: Railroads across the country have responded enthusiastically to a new Interstate Commerce Commission proposal to exempt from regulation the hauling of all agricultural shipments except for grain and soybeans.

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF LETTER FROM REAGAN

title: Black Power, White Bigotry
description: Wider democracy was perhaps the biggest winner in last week's midterm election, as an unusually heavy black vote helped to reverse a 20-year trend to declining voter participation. A Republican Senator, Robert Packwood, has said that his party needs to reclaim black support, which now goes overwhelmingly to Democrats. The importance of the black vote to Democratic victories in this election provides irrefutable support for his argument.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $394,000

title: Holiday Delays Data on Money
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said its money supply figures, normally released Friday, would be delayed until 4:10 P.M. Monday because of the Veterans Day holiday.

title: Soviet Says Yes
description: The Soviet-watchers in the National Hockey League have been watching the wire lately for word from Moscow: Would the Soviet allstar hockey team withdraw from its scheduled series against six N.H.L. clubs?

title: COLOMBIA IS OUT
description: The Colombian Football Association formally withdrew today as host of soccer's 1986 World Cup, clearing the way for official bidding by other candidates, which include the United States.

title: HARRIS STEEL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a special loss of $893,115...C-Including a special gain of $221,500

title: WEST EUROPE REACTS CALMLY, EXPECTS NO DRASTIC CHANGE
description: Western Europe, expecting no dramatic changes in Soviet policy as a result of the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, reacted calmly, almost perfunctorily today to the announcement of the Soviet leader's passing.

title: PARNASSUS PLAYERS FOCUS ON THE NEW
description: New music today exists in a bewildering assortment of styles. It can be tonal or atonal, abstract or accessible, scored for string quartet or synthesizer, and there are as many valid compositional styles as there are valid composers. Anything can happen, and there is no longer any one true faith. Although some find this diversity tantamount to anarchy, others rejoice in the knowledge that, for the first time in many years, any listener should be able to find music of our time that will appeal.

title: Friday; JUDITH BLEGEN AS 'ESTHER'
description: Joining the Collegiate Chorale at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8, Judith Blegen, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, will sing the title role in Handel's first English oratorio, ''Esther,'' the biblical story of the Jewish queen who saved her people from slaughter. Vinson Cole, a New York City Opera tenor, will be Esther's husband, the king of Persia, in this concert performance, and Donnie Ray Albert, bass baritone, will be his treacherous adviser. Tickets: $5 to $13. Reservations: 621-9090. FIVE ARTISTS AND JAPAN

title: RECOVERY'S START SEEN IN EARLY '83
description: The long-awaited economic recovery is not likely to begin in earnest until the first quarter of next year, and a previously reported gain in third-quarter growth will probably be revised to a small decline, according to a Commerce Department expert.

title: Sidney Wolff, Lawyer And Labor Arbitrator
description: Sidney A. Wolff, a labor arbitrator and trial lawyer, died yesterday at his Manhattan home after a short illness. He was 77 years old.

description: THIS has been a week when a partygoer could get into black tie and ah ard hat at the unfinished Loewe store in the unfinished Trump Tower ( ''This is really high tech,'' quipped Guy Burgos, eyeing the c oncrete floors and exposed wires), slip into harem pants and veilingf or the Thousand and One Nights gala at the Solomon R. Guggenheim M useum, or wear a ball gown and a king's ransom in jewels for the S panish Institute ball.

title: GEORGE A. SCHREIBER
description: George A. Schreiber, chairman of the Public Service Company of New Mexico, died Sunday at his home in Albuquerque, after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Reagan Sees Gain in Housing
description: President Reagan said tonight that evidence that the economy was improving could be found in the increase in applications for mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Pack of Dogs in Indiana Fatally Mauls Girl, 10
description: A 10-year-old girl riding a bicycle to her grandmother's house was fatally mauled by a pack of dogs Wednesday, and the dogs' owner may face criminal charges, a prosecutor said today.

title: Market Place; The Insiders At Humana
description: HUMANA INC. has made a determined effort to substitute quality for quantity by cutting costs and dropping less profitable units. This strategy must be working because the hospital company's earnings have risen sharply and its shares continue to rate high at Value Line, the advisory service.

title: News Analysis
description: In the 65 years that it has been power, the Soviet Communist Party has failed to devise a means of transferring authority from one leader to another that guarantees that the transition will be safe and trouble-free.

title: October New-Product Introductions Rise
description: Only June and May turned in better new-product introductions figures than October did, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, which puts the monthly total at 135, a 33 percent gain from the 102 in the same month last year.

title: STATEMENT ON FUNERAL
description: Following is the text of a resolution from the Central Committee, the Presidium and the Council of Ministers as distributed yesterday by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Jersey to Explore Sex Bias in Courts
description: Chief Justice Robert Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court said yesterday that he had appointed a 26-member task force to explore the extent and nature of bias against women in the judicial system.

title: EX-AIDE FOUND GUILTY OF TAKING WASTES PAYOFFS
description: A dismissed New York City sanitation superintendent was convicted yesterday of taking illegal payments from toxic-waste dumpers to allow unauthorized chemical dumping at a Staten Island landfill.

title: Dr. Clarence Merskey Dead; Professor at Albert Einstein
description: Dr. Clarence Merskey, professor of medicine and laboratory medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died in his sleep last night at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 68 years old.

title: TYLENOL WILL REAPPEAR IN TRIPLE-SEAL PACKAGE
description: Johnson & Johnson announced yesterday that it would resume retail sales of Tylenol capsules within a few weeks, this time in triplesealed, tamper-resistant packaging. The product is to reappear in most stores by Jan.1.

title: FRANK DENTON, A BANKER, DIES
description: Frank R. Denton, a former chief executive officer of Mellon Bank who directed its expansion into branch banking, died today in the Latrobe, Pa., Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: ISRAELIS KILLED IN BLAST IN SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: An explosion demolished an Israeli military headquarters building today on the outskirts of the port city of Tyre in southern Lebanon, and an Israeli Army spokesman said at least 15 Israelis were killed and 25 wounded.

The Boston Bruins have lost the center Steve Kasper, who underwent shoulder surgery at Massachussets General Hospital, for at least two weeks.

The company now looks back to an earlier, significant work by the South African playwright, ''Hello and Goodbye,'' the middle play in his ''Port Elizabeth Trilogy.''

description: An international cast of singers, dancers and musicians will take part in the 14th Israeli Hasidic Music Festival this weekend at Hunter College, Park Avenue and 69th Street.

description: The Reagan Administration intends to use Leonid I. Brezhnev's funeral as an opportunity to tell the new Soviet leadership that the United States desires better relations but is prepared to continue its military buildup if the Russians prefer confrontation, senior Administration officials said today.

description: Aaron Pryor, the free spirit who seemingly never stops punching, tonight blocked Alexis Arguello's attempt to become boxing's first four-time champion with a dramatic 14th-round knockout.

title: MOODY'S TRIMS ITS CREDIT RATING ON STATE ISSUES
description: A second Wall Street investment-rating concern reduced New York's credit rating today, but only on shortterm notes.

title: Chest Pain Study Cites Diseases of Esophagus
description: As many as one in five patients who are rushed to the hospital with chest pain may have diseases of the esophagus, not heart trouble, according to a study released today.

title: Lakers 127, Rockets 96
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 28 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead the rout by Los Angeles. Houston (0-7) is now the only team in the league without a victory. For the Lakers, the victory was the sixth in a row after a season-opening loss.

title: COLLEGES SEEKING NEW APPROACHES TO FINANCIAL AID
description: Colleges in the tristate New York metropolitan area, spurred by shrinking Federal financial assistance to students, are developing new aid programs and seeking other sources of money.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle yesterday on a voluntary labeling program concerning aspirin and Reye's Syndrome misstated the posi- tion of the American Academy of Pediatrics. The academy's executive board opposes warning labels, but it took no position on the voluntary label- ing program announced by a coalition of professional, consumer and busi- ness groups.

title: ISLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $41,000 and a $142,000 gain fromsale of subsidiaries; in the 1981 periods, pro forma results assume the merger of Isle Resources and House of Harmony Inc had taken place effective Mar 31, 1981

title: Player Suspended
description: Steffond Johnson, a 6-8, 212-pound sophomore forward who played in all but two of Louisiana State's 28 basketball games last season, has been suspended indefinitely from the team for ''violation of team rules and standards regarding academics,'' according to Coach Dale Brown. ... B.B. Flenory, a former high-scoring guard at Duquesne University who last played for the Dukes' basketball team in 1980, was one of five persons charged with criminal homicide in the fatal beating of a man in New Kensington, Pa. All five were held in the Westmoreland County Jail with a hearing set for Nov. 19. Flenory, despite playing well in several Eastern Eight Conference tournaments, was not picked in the National Basketball Association draft.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOURCES ARE CITED FOR CHARGE OF SOVIET TIE TO ARMS FREEZE
description: The White House today cited Government reports and magazine articles as documentation for President Reagan's contention that ''foreign agents'' had helped ''instigate'' the movement in the United States to freeze nuclear arms.

title: Deirdre Ann Fitzpatrick Is Bride of Thomas J. Orr
description: Deirdre Ann Fitzpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Fitzpatrick of Garden City, L.I., was wed there yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Thomas J. Orr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Orr, also of Garden City. The Rev. Brendon Buckley, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHUTTLE MISSION PUTS FOCUS ON RESEARCH CREWMEN
description: The fifth flight of the space shuttle Columbia marks a turning point in the space program. For the first time since an American astronaut was lofted into space 21 years ago, the spotlight is off the daredevil pilots who have long been the heroes of space travel.

title: SHUTTLE COMPLETES MAIN TASK BY LAUNCHING ITS 2D SATELLITE
description: The space shuttle astronauts launched a second communications satellite from the Columbia's bay today, completing their primary objective.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Preview, No Press

title:
PATENTS;
Sharper Color Devised For Teletext Screens
description: For use in teletext systems, Sherwin D. Burrowes of the technical staff at the RCA laboratories in Princeton, N.J., has invented a method of improving the color definition of lettering and pictures.

title: Dantley in Hospital
description: In Utah, Adrian Dantley, leading scorer of the Jazz, was admitted to Lakeview Hospital in Bountiful, north of Salt Lake City, last night with a fractured sinus.

title: FOR THE HARD-TO-FIT: CUSTOM BOOTS
description: Claire Roth has unusual feet. They have very narrow heels and socalled flexible arches, so she found that she could not walk very far in boots without pain.

title: OKLAHOMA HONORS ITS INDIAN BALLERINAS
description: There were embraces, flowers and a visit from the Mayor of Tulsa this afternoon as five of Oklahoma's daughters who are all world-class ballerinas and American Indians were honored as part of the state's diamond jubilee.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1981 have been restated to reflect the change in accounting for compensated absences

title: Home Cooking
description: At age 20, Bobby Czyz is an unusual fighter. He stood sixth in his class of 300 at Lakeland High School in New Jersey in 1980.

title: Doctor on Skates
description: Everyone thinks the most unusual thing about the Edmonton Oilers hockey team is its star, Wayne Gretzky. He won't turn 22 until January, but he already has broken many of the major one-season offensive records in the National Hockey League.

title: Irish Offense Lifted By Pinkett's Power
description: ''The first time I came here to Notre Dame, it was 20 degrees below zero and the wind chill factor was down around minus 70,'' said Allen Pinkett, the freshman tailback who has suddenly become the star running back for the Irish. ''I never had been in anything like that,''

title: BISHOPS' STAND STIRS CATHOLIC PROTEST
description: Led by a former New York City Labor Commissioner, some lay Roman Catholics here are beginning to organize against what they see as a leftward drift in foreign affairs on the part of the official American church.

title: U.S. ORDERS CONSTRUCTION HALT ON OHIO ATOM PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered an Ohio utility to halt construction of its nearly completed atomic power plant until an independent review has found that the plant meets the Government's safety requirements.

title: LOOKING GOOD AT FIRES
description: This week the first women firefighters in the 117-year history of New York City's Fire Department - 11 of them - went on the job. It took a long legal battle to win their entry into this male enclave, but it seemed common-sensical from the start that if women can pass the tests and do the work, they should have their opportunity. And the psychological pressures will be heavy enough without magnifying the glass in their fishbowl.

title: MORE WAYS TO IMPROVE THE COURT OF APPEALS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Inventor of the Year Nominations Sought
description: Nominations for the Inventor of the Year award were invited this week by Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a nonprofit trade association. The winner will receive a $1,000 check and a plaque at ceremonies on National Inventors Day next Feb. 13.

title: KELLY-JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: All shr earnings and shrs outstdng have been adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split effective Oct 13; the yr-ago periods' figures were restated

title: Stock Index Futures Traded
description: Trading in financial stock index futures began yesterday on the New York Futures Exchange. The contract covers the price movement of 203 companies in the New York Stock Exchange financial index, which includes banks, insurance companies, brokers and similar companies.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Not in the Book

title: Pakistan to Let Mrs. Bhutto Go Abroad for Medical Care
description: Nusrat Bhutto, widow of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, said today that she had been given permission to go abroad for treatment of suspected cancer.

title: ARABS AT U.N. RENEW ATTACKS ON ISRAEL
description: Arab countries today reopened their campaign in the Security Council to halt Israeli settlement in the West Bank but, at the urging of the United States, confined themselves to making speeches.

title: HIGH COST OF INSURING SMALL CARS
description: LIGHT ''unibody'' automobiles, designed to save money at the gasoline pump, are driving up the cost of automobile insurance, according to a recent report by two New York State agencies.

title: ARGENTINE JUNTA SEEKS AN ACCORD BEFORE ELECTIONS
description: Argentina's military rulers have asked the country's political leaders to agree to a pact, before a return to civilian rule, on how to deal with major issues facing the country.

title: Boudin Lawyers Ask Venue Change
description: Attorneys for Kathy Boudin, a defendant in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and murder case, filed a motion yesterday asking that the trial of Miss Boudin and five co-defendants be transferred from Rockland County.

title: Children With Children, Everywhere
description: The only thing wrong with what's going on in New Orleans, where Mayor Ernest Morial has rallied community leaders to focus on the increasing numbers of teen-agers having babies, is that it isn't going on everywhere. The growing phenomenon of children having children creates problems for family life, the social fabric and government budgets in nearly every major American city.

title: LEFTIST MOZAMBIQUE SIDLES UP TO WEST
description: In the view of Western diplomats here whose job it is to interpret what is going on in Mozambique, the country's sole political party has shifted somewhat from the staunch pro-Soviet line on which it took power in 1975.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $12,000 from an extraordinary item...C-Includi ng gains from extraordinary items of $138,000 for the qr and $300,000 for the 9 mos

title: Judge Rules Iran May Sue Princess
description: The Government of Iran has the right to sue Princess Ashraf Pahlevi, sister of the late Shah of Iran, for $3 billion in a New York court, a State Supreme Court justice ruled in Manhattan yesterday.

title: TO KEEP ELECTION FUNDS WITHIN BOUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan School District Resumes Isolation Policy
description: Unruly students will again be placed in solitary confinement, in a decision by the Carrollton School District that is being protested by some parents and a school board member.

title: THE REGION
description: An explosive device blew up under the local Police Chief's car while it was parked in his driveway early today, a spokesman for the Camden County Prosecutor's Office said.

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago figures restated for an accounting change

title: Grunding to Lay Off 650
description: -Grundig A. G. said today that it will lay off 650 workers in its videotape recorder division by the end of this year. A company statement said overcapacity among Japanese producers and their sales at 'ruinous, dumping prices' meant Grundig was forded to switch part of production to cheaper videotape recorders

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stenmark's Incentive
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden has a strong goal when the Alpine skiing season opens next month.

title: POSTCARDS FROM THE PAST BECKONING COLLECTORS
description: Imagine a vast room with a painted ceiling and hundreds of thousands of evocations of days gone by. It is the ballroom of the Prince George Hotel, at 14 East 28th Street, where the Metropolitan Post Card Collectors Club is holding its 36th annual convention through the weekend. Dealers and collectors have come here from all over the world to set up exhibits, to buy and trade, to exchange stories, but mostly to browse through thousands of cellophane envelopes and filing boxes filled with postcards.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: B-After capital losses of $22,000 for the qr and $145,000 for the 9 mos and a nonrecurring tax charge of $8 million for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net income

title: SIMILARITIES
description: Could it be 1975 all over again? The talk is of financial crisis. Television lights bathe the nighttime facade of Gracie Mansion as reporters converge. Inside, a Mayor talks of service cutbacks - and tries not to talk about layoffs - while labor leaders sit watchfully at his side.

title: TELLER FAULTED ON BOMB CALCULATIONS
description: Hans Bethe, a Nobel prize-winning physicist, has charged that faulty calculations by Edward Teller, known as the father of the hydrogen bomb, and other technical problems hindered the bomb's development rather than political opposition by the late J. Robert Oppenheimer.

title: BANK RESERVES LESS PLENTIFUL
description: The availability of reserves to the banking system tightened a bit in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Warner Pact Set On Madison Fund
description: Warner Communications Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Madison Fund Inc. under a stock and debenture exchange valued at about $380 million.

title: CONRAIL DELAYS ACCEPTED, MORE OR LESS
description: There was a bit of the resignation of the condemned about the commuters on the Conrail platform here as the 7:06 approached this morning. They knew the train would arrive in Manhattan 30 minutes late and they knew it very well could be that late every morning for as long as 11 months.

title: Driver Without a Car
description: Johnny Rutherford, three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, was left without a car for next year's race when Jim Hall, car owner and designer, announced yesterday that he would not field an Indy car team in 1983. A spokesman for the Chaparral Racing Team said Hall would not be back after five years of Indy car racing.

title: Garvey Pursues Talks
description: In an effort to get the stalled National Football League labor negotiations moving, Ed Garvey, the executive director of the players association, met for about 90 minutes last night in Washington with Kay McMurray, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

title: BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ADAMS DRUG CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALD W. DRESDEN
description: Donald W. Dresden, a restaurant critic and contributor to The Washington Post Magazine, died Thursday at George Washington Hospital.

title: AUTO UNION'S LEADERS BACK CHIEF AT G.M. FOR TOP POST
description: The leadership of the United Automobile Workers nominated Owen Bieber, the vice president in charge of the union's General Motors department, to succeed Douglas A. Fraser as president of the 1.2 million member union.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS CASE IN TRIAL OF WARNER AIDE
description: The prosecution completed its case yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on charges that the assistant treasurer of Warner Communications had fraudulently arranged the company's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: U.S. Mortgages Reduced to 12%
description: The Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration today cut rates on single-family home mortgages to 12 percent, the lowest level in more than two years.

title: SPONSORS STRUGGLE WITHOUT FOOTBALL
description: The advertisers and ad agencies on Madison Avenue have been doing more shifting this season than the Dallas Cowboys backfield as they struggle to cope with the professional football players' strike, nearing the end of its second month.

title: Maine Hunter, Out for Deer, Should Have Stayed at Home
description: Seth Libby returned home from a futile weeklong deer hunt to find that a buck had barged into his home. ''The window was broken, there was shattered glass everywhere, damaged furniture and lots of hair,'' Mr. Libby's wife, Mary, said of the wreckage left when a deer leapt through a window of their winterized porch.

title: Paternoster in Change
description: -Paternoster Stores P.L.C., a recently formed company that acquired the F.W. Woolworth Company's British stores, said today that it had changed its name to Woolworth Holdings P.L.C.

title: JUDGE AGAIN BARS DRILLING FOR GAS
description: A Federal district judge today refused to allow the Yates Petroleum Corporation to resume drilling a natural gas well in the Salt Creek Wilderness because the company has no Federal permits.

title: Howden Shifts
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said it is reorganizing the Bermuda operations of its Alexander Howden Group subsidiary and revising the underwriting management policy of Howden's Bermuda subsidiaries, the Trent Insurance Company and Capital Marine. Peter M. Densen, a senior vice president of Alexander & Alexander and president of the Anistics Risk Management subsidiary will manage the two operations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DEEP TRADE RIFT WITH ALLIES SEEN
description: Western experts attending a conference here on East-West trade agreed today that differences on the subject between the Reagan Administration and its Western European allies ran deep and were unlikely to be much affected by policy talks taking place in Washington.

title: A Winner Again
description: Don't tell Mary Jo Eyerman about life on a losing streak. She is a 21-year-old jockey from Cincinnati, third best in the country in earnings for female jockeys in 1980.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BALLET THEATER EXTENDS RUN IN NEW YORK
