description: The American Ballet Theater will perform longer in New York City than planned next year, but the company has postponed two new productions as a result of its recently concluded labor dispute.

title: TEACHER QUALIFICATION IS A STATE CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIALISTS WHO THRIVE ON DEFICITS
description: These are hard times for Washington lawyers. The recession and Reagan Administration cutbacks in Federal programs and regulations have left many young lawyers looking for jobs and many older ones hurting for clients.

title: One Killed and 3 Hurt In Queens Bar Robbery
description: A shootout in a Queens bar early yesterday left a robbery suspect dead and three other people wounded, including an off-duty state corrections officer, the police said.

title: Colonial Corp., BankTexas in Pact
description: The Colonial Commercial Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last May, said it had reached an agreement with one of its creditors, BankTexas of Dallas, on a revised plan of reorganization.

title: Marino's Chilly Season
description: PITTSBURGH Before Dan Marino's senior season, his fourth year as the starting quarterback at the University of Pittsburgh, the media blitz was as complimentary as it was overwhelming. Marino was portrayed as the blue-collar quarterback in a blue-collar city, and his family's home in the Oakland section of town became something of a sports media shrine.

title: Colorado's Woes
description: The football program at the University of Colorado has seldom been in worse shape, which is why the Buffaloes' first-year head coach, Bill McCartney, believes that today's game against Kansas is more than just the final home game of the season. With a record of 1-7-1, including 0-6 at home, Colorado has no chance to make much of this year. Any success clearly lies in the future, and so McCartney is calling for a capacity crowd of 50,000 fans today, rather than the 35,000 expected, ''to show the high school kids we're trying to recruit in Colorado that we're headed in the right direction and that our program has tremendous morale and support.''

title: Layoffs for 300 At Harvester
description: The struggling International Harvester Company said that it would lay off an additional 300 white-collar employees before the end of the year as part of its continuing cost-cutting plan. The layoffs, which are confined mostly to the company's Chicago headquarters, could increase because of Harvester's continuing restructuring of the remnants of its construction equipment business.

title: TEXT OF THE SPEECH BY ANDROPOV
description: Following is the text of the speech, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass, given by Yuri V. Andropov yesterday at a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee before his election as Leonid I. Brezhnev's successor as party leader:

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1982
description: International The successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev was chosen by the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee. He is Yuri V. Andropov, who until six months ago headed the K.G.B., the Committee for State Security, and was in charge of the internal security police and foreign espionage operations. His appointment as the party's General Secretary was said to have unanimously been approved by the Central Committee. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Leonid I. Brezhnev's funeral will be used by the Reagan Administration as an opportunity to tell the new Soviet leadership that the United Statves desires better relations but is prepared to continue its military buildup if the Russians prefer confrontation, senior officials said. They said that Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who head the American delegation, hope to meet with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko during the 24 hours they will be in Moscow. (6:1-3.)

title: LTV AGREES TO SELL ITS STEAMSHIP UNIT
description: The LTV Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Lykes Brothers Steamship Company subsidiary to the Interocean Steamship Corporation for $150 million.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ousted Coroner to Head Medical Examiners' Unit
description: Dr. Thomas Noguchi, ousted as Los Angeles County coroner after being accused of incompetence, has been voted to head the National Association of Medical Examiners.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Baseball Begins Search
description: Baseball's executive council took the first step yesterday in its task of finding a new commissioner, creating a six-man committee to conduct the search. The five owners named to the committee - one is yet to be appointed - were among the strongest supporters of Bowie Kuhn in his unsuccessful effort to gain a third term.

title: Reagan Chooses Dillon For Council on the Arts
description: C. Douglas Dillon, chairman of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a former member of the Cabinet, was nominated by President Reagan today to serve on the National Council on the Arts.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices retreated. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.81 points, to 1,039.92. Oil issues were off, largely in reaction to the possibility of a 5-cent rise in the Federal gasoline tax. Volume rose to 95.1 million shares. (Page 29.)

title: Jerseyan Accused Of Nazi Atrocities
description: Federal prosecutors filed suit today to revoke the citizenship of an East Brunswick man they say helped Nazi troops execute about 100 unarmed men, women and children in Byelorussia during World War II.

title: KNICKS WIN FIRST AFTER SEVEN LOSSES
description: The Knicks tonight finally got that elusive first victory of the season, one that they tried to give away several times in the closing seconds before defeating the Washington Bullets, 88-87, at Capital Centre.

title: MUGGED, SORT OF
description: I was walking in a shopping plaza in the Bronx and saw a mugging of sorts. On the street, a crowd had gathered to watch a young woman with auburn hair win at a game of three-card monte. As streetwise people know, the player can win if he turns over the only red card - not either of the two blacks. The bet starts at $20. The game is played on a cardboard box -a makeshift table, on a busy street. Once you place your money on a card, you are committed. If, when the card is turned up, it's not red, the card shark picks up the money and places it with the wad of bills in his hand. The wad entices the bettor because the payoff is visible and instantaneous.

title: REAGAN IS ASKED TO HELP FORESTALL L.I.R.R. WALKOUT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority asked yesterday for the appointment of a Presidential Emergency Board in a move to forestall a strike against the Long Island Rail Road that has been threatened for next Friday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Celebration of a Full Life

title: Orioles Name Altobelli
description: The Baltimore Orioles ended months of speculation today by appointing Joe Altobelli to succeed the retired Earl Weaver as manager. The 50-year-old Altobelli, who spent the last two seasons as the Yankees' third-base coach, had earlier been in the Baltimore organization for 14 years, as a minor league player and manager.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IN CAMERA

title: N.M. M'KNIGHT, 82, FORMER DEAN, DIES
description: Nicholas McDowell McKnight, a dean at Columbia College for 26 years, died yesterday at the Pine Rest Nursing Home in Paramus, N.J. Mr. McKnight, who had been a resident of Rutherford and Bay Head, N.J., was 82 years old.

title: K.G.B. PRAISED BY SOME AND FEARED BY MANY
description: The K.G.B., the Committee for State Security, is praised by the Communist leadership as the ''sword and shield'' of the Soviet Union, and, at the same time, is the most widely feared instrument of the Government.

title: 6,000 Salvadoran Troops Move on Rebel Positions
description: Officials said that about 6,000 Salvadoran troops moved on rebel positions in northern El Salvador today while 2,000 Honduran soldiers lined up across the border to block escape.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: By the end of the week, the khapra beetle had caused the cordoning off of a substantial area of lower Manhattan, the presence there of police officers, Consolidated Edison personnel, sewer workers, traffic enforcement agents, the reported death of one cat (greatly exaggerated) and some pigeons (unconfirmed), and the reported collapse of a second cat (momentary).

title: DR. SULA BENET, 76, A SPECIALIST IN LONGEVITY AND EAST EUROPE
description: Dr. Sula Benet, professor emeritus of anthropology at Hunter College who was an authority on longevity and Eastern European culture, died yesterday at University Hospital after a long illness. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 39. 1. It is a meteorite, the second in 11 years to crash into a house in Wethersfield, Conn. 2. General Secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee and the less important post of President of the Soviet Union. 3. Rich Trumka, a lawyer, was elected president of the United Mine Workers of America, defeating the incumbent, Sam M. Church Jr., an old-line leader.

title: A POLISHED PARTY MAN
description: Even before his selection to the Kremlin's most powerful post today, Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov stood out among his comrades on the Politburo.

title: Italian Premier Asks For Vote of Confidence
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini asked Parliament today to confirm his power to rule.

title: THE HAPPY MANN
description: DIARIES 1918-39. By Thomas Mann. Selec- tion and Foreword by Hermann Kesten. Translated from the German by Rich- ard and Clare Winston. Illustrated. 471 pages. Harry N. Abrams. $29.95.

title: SCHOOLS NEED TENURED LEADERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
22% DROP IS NOTED IN STUDENT LOANS
description: The Department of Education reported today that the volume of guaranteed student loans, one of the main sources of Federal aid for college students, had declined 22 percent from last year, in part because of tighter eligibility criteria.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Women's Shifting Fortunes At City Hall

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL KINNEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $573,000 from discontinued business and a tax chargeof $120,000...C-After a provision of $6,775,000 for loss on disposition of discontinued operations...D-Net income after a loss of $106,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $200,000

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nuclear Test Conducted
description: United States scientists conducted the 18th announced underground nuclear test of 1982 at the Nevada Test Site, 90 miles north of Las Vegas. The explosive power of the test was less than 20 kilotons, with a force equivalent to 20,000 tons of TNT, according to the Department of Energy.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: BRIEFING
description: Touching History

title: Get a Grip on Quicksilver
description: In the fast world of high finance, commodity speculation is the fastest game of all. Too fast, according to the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which recently issued its report on the great silver bubble of 1980. The staff's report, which blames the boom and bust in silver prices on the failure of regulation, should spur overdue reforms.

title: Coach Shifts Pitt Lineup
description: Coach Foge Fazio of the University of Pittsburgh has made some lineup changes for the game Saturday against Army at West Point, N.Y.

title: MORE THOUGHTS ON SMOKING AND FOOD
description: The rights of smokers as against those of nonsmokers in restaurants appears to be a matter only slightly less controversial than the issue of capital punishment, and, indeed, for most advocates on both sides of the smoking question only the extreme sentence would seem to do for their opponents. Nonsmokers will have their day Thursday, designated the Great American Smokeout by the American Cancer Society as part of its national effort to discourage smoking for health reasons.

title:
PATENTS;
A Way of Repairing Space Shuttle Tiles
description: An invention that has been used effectively in repairing damage to the delicate tiles on the surface of the space shuttle Columbia was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Glenn M. Icord and Calvin Schomburg, aerospace engineers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, obtained patent 4,358,480 for the materials and process.

title: P.B.A. Ratifies Contract
description: Members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have ratified a new two-year contract with the city, a spokesman reported yesterday. The spokesman, Martin Steadman, said that 7,655 members voted for approval and 3,114 against. The P.B.A., which represents 18,000 city patrolmen, and other unions in the Uniformed Coalition reached agreement with the city last month on the new contract, which provides for 8 percent pay increases in each year.

title: Senior Western Aides Will Attend Funeral
description: The major Western European powers will be represented at the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev by senior Government officals.

title: DOW DROPS BY 14.81, to 1,039.92
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.81 points yesterday, with oil company stocks leading the decline, largely in reaction to President Reagan's statement that he was seriously considering an increase of 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax.

title: Kodak Sets Dividends
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had declared a quarterly cash dividend of 75 cents a share and an extra dividend of 55 cents a share on its common stock, payable Jan. 3 to shareholders of record Dec. 1.

title: Much White Stuff But Less Green
description: Sign of the season: The professional ski racing season opens today in Keystone, Colo. Sign of the times: The skiers report there is plenty of snow, but not as much money because of the economy.

title: Brady Back at Post Again
description: For the second time in a week, James S. Brady was back on the job as the White House press secretary today. Mr. Brady was shot in the head in the assassination attempt against President Reagan on March 30, 1981.

title: ALEXANDRA DANILOVA, 'REFLECTIONS OF A DANCER'
description: Moviegoers who attend ''Reflections of a Dancer: Alexandra Danilova, Prima Ballerina Assoluta'' should take careful note of how Miss Danilova fusses over every last detail of the little rehearsal skirts she wears when she teaches class. Although in her prime as a dancer she was said to have had the loveliest legs in all ballet and those legs still remain photogenic, her meticulousness is not simply a sign of personal pride. Rather, it is indicative of a whole approach to the art of ballet, an approach that some young dancers today ignore, to their peril.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOLIDAY TRAFFIC RULES TAKE EFFECT MONDAY
description: The annual attempt to cope with New York City's Christmastime traffic will begin Monday, the Department of Transportation announced yesterday.

title: Kansas Prairie Fire Kills Hunter and Perils Town
description: Cowboys rode the plains of central Kansas today rounding up cattle trapped by a searing prairie fire that raced over 100 square miles, killing a hunter and endangering a town.

title: 2.2 MILLION JOB HOLDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness Says Baby Sitter Told Sister She Killed 5
description: Christine Falling, a 19-year-old baby sitter accused in the deaths of three children, told her sister at a meeting last July in a Tallahassee mental health facility that she had killed five children who died in her care, an agent in the Florida Department of Law Enforcement testified today.

title: News Analysis
description: Yuri V. Andropov, who surprised Washington by the speed with which he outmaneuvered rivals for the Soviet Communist Party leadership, is regarded here as a tougher, smarter, shrewder competitor for the United States than Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: FOR NEW YORK, THE CENSUS ISN'T OVER YET
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Computer Helps Find Filed Data
description: WASHINGTON THE International Business Machines Corporation has devised a method of using computers to retrieve letters and documents from office correspondence files. The person who wants such material uses plain English to describe it to the computer, which either shows on a screen where it is or displays its text.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN APPRAISAL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $272,000 for the qr and $349,000for the 6 mos and losses of $185,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of discontinued operations...C-Net income including income from discontinued operationsof $65,000 for the qr and $396,000 for the 6 mos and a gain of $250,000 for the6 mos from the sale of discontinued operations

title: PRICE TALKS BY OPEC ARE SHIFTED
description: Nigeria today canceled plans to hold the next OPEC ministerial meeting in Lagos. But the Government denied that it had taken the action to prevent its capital from becoming the scene of a showdown between Nigeria and Saudi Arabia over oil prices.

title: MUSIC: COLLEGIATE CHORALE IN HANDEL 'ESTHER'
description: Handel's ''Esther'' is not often encountered these days, in New York at least. Last night's performance at Carnegie Hall, which opened the Collegiate Chorale's season, was billed as the first in New York in more than a dozen years.

title: POLES TOLD WALESA HAS BEEN FREED
description: The release of Lech Walesa, the interned leader of the outlawed union Solidarity, was ordered today, but it was unclear whether he had left the remote hunting lodge near the Soviet border where he has been held for more than 11 months.

title: Wrapping Up the Beetle
description: Christo, the Bulgarian-born artist, wrapped a mile of the Australian coastline in opaque plastic (''Wrapped Coast, Little Bay, One Million Square Feet''), strung a fabric fence through 24 miles of Northern California (''Running Fence'') and stretched 150,000 square feet of polypropylene over the Atlantic Ocean (''Ocean Front''). But he has had no luck with New York City.

title: VOWS HE WILL CONTINUE; BREZHNEV POLICIES
description: Yuri V. Andropov was chosen by the Communist Party's Central Committee today to succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev as its General Secretary, making him the Soviet Union's principal political leader.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All 1982 results include a $1.7 million writedown of receivables related to certain charges disallowed by Medicare

title: LEBANON BLAST DEATH TOLL REACHES 47
description: The death toll in an explosion that destroyed an Israeli military headquarters building on Thursday at Tyre in southern Lebanon reached 47 today as rescue workers continued to hunt through the rubble for survivors.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per shr earnings reflect the effect of two 100 percent stock distributions in Oct 1981 and Apr 1982

title: New York Phone Net Up
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday reported net income of $190.5 million for the third quarter, up 14.6 percent from $166.2 million a year before.

title: TRIAL PROSECUTION RESTS IN ASSASSINATION OF JUDGE
description: The prosecution rested its case today after calling 83 witnesses in an effort to prove that Charles V. Harrelson assassinated a Federal judge for a fee of $250,000.

title: WHEN A MORAL LESSON BECOMES A WANTON CRUELTY
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO URGES TAX ON BIG REALTY SALES
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he would like to see New York City begin its budget-balancing tax package with a capitalgains tax on large real-estate transactions.

title: INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Youths Demanding Free Ride Attack Bus Driver in Queens
description: A bus driver was beaten and repeatedly stabbed by a group of young men who boarded his bus last night in Laurelton, Queens, and demanded to ride for free, the police said.

title: General Takes Office As Turkish President
description: Gen. Kenan Evren assumed the office of President today. In an inauguration speech, General Evren praised Turkey's belief in parliamentary democracy and said preparations had begun to have general elections in the fall of 1983.

title: XONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SALES OFF
description: Unsold goods held in inventories by American businesses rose a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in September as sales declined three-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Partial Roll Forward

title: PANEL FAULTS RELEASE OF A MENTAL PATIENT CHARGED IN SLAYING
description: A mental hospital committed ''gross institutional negligence'' in 1974 when it released a patient who was later charged with murdering a 9-year-old boy, a special committee of the State Senate has concluded.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McEnroe Gains English Semifinal
description: John McEnroe, the top-seeded player, defeated Henri Leconte, a 19-year-old Frenchman, 6-3, 7-5 tonight to gain the semifinals of the $200,000 Benson and Hedges tennis tournament.

title: 4 SERIOUS AILMENTS PLAGUED BREZHNEV
description: A brief Soviet statement yesterday on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev provided the first detailed medical description of his last years.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a loss of $167,000 from discontinued operations

title: AIR MIDWEST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HELEN OF TROY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $177,215 for the qr and $184,459 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,541 for the qr and $3,772 forthe 9 mos and a tax credit of $64,967 for the qr and 9 mos

title: Prison Sentence For Former Envoy
description: A former vice consul of the Dominican Republic in New York City and a second man were sentenced yesterday to six years in prison for conspiring to smuggle up to $3 million worth of heroin into the United States.

title: A Rematch for John Henry
description: John Henry's improbable rise from being an unfashionably bred horse who ran in claiming races to being the horse of the year in 1981 has made him not only the richest race horse in the world, but also one of the most beloved. Many of the trainers who send their horses against the popular 7-year-old gelding sound almost apologetic for doing so; they also add that it is an honor and a privilege to share the same race track with him.

title: Court Upholds F.C.C.
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today upheld the 1980 decision of the Federal Communications Commission to deregulate the telephone industry.

title: Bridge: Harmonie Club Play Won By Unusually High Score
description: The annual Experts Night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, brings together a group of players who have had great success in the tournament world but are now retired from serious play.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for QTr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago per shr amounts adjusted for 100 percent stock divd paid July 9

title: WORLD TRADE'S FUTURE
description: The system of open international trade may be in peril. Protectionist pressures emanating from the recession, problems of long-term economic adjustment and the perceived inadequacy of existing trade rules pose major challenges to the system. If this month's ministerial meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in Geneva - the first in nine years - fails to re-establish the momentum for trade liberalization, the system could eventually collapse under protectionism.

title: TEMPEST IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI From the brutal beginning to the brutal end, Aaron Pryor's eyes reflected the tempest of the World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion's eventual 14th-round knockout of Alexis Arguello last night that left the Nicaraugan challenger on the canvas for perhaps four minutes before he wobbled to his feet.

title: 82 Lakes in Orlando, Fla., Said to Be Endangered
description: The 82 lakes that give Orlando its picture post card-look will die without the infusion of millions of dollars and stringent drainage and pollution-control ordinances, a consulting group says.

title: TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED ASBESTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a $352,147 charge related to contract settlements with former company officers and capital tax

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In this situation it is the duty of every one of us, the duty of every Communist to close more tightly our ranks, to rally still closer around the Central Committee of the party and to do at one's respective post and in one's life as much as possible for the welfare of the Soviet people, for strengthening peace and for the triumph of Communism.'' - Yuri V. Andropov, newly-elected Soviet Communist Party leader. (4:6.)

title: No Headline
description: PACERS HAND 76ers FIRST LOSS, 117-108

title: PROPOSED GASOLINE TAX RISE MAY SPUR CONTEST FOR FUNDS
description: The effort of Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis to bring together a coalition of highway contractors, mass transit operators, construction unions and mayors behind rebuilding the national transportation system may now be undone.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Asserting Dominion Over a Billboard

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAKING COMPANY TAKEOVERS HARDER
description: On Oct. 12, I became an ex-director of Heublein Inc. as a result of stockholder approval of the merger of that company with R.J. Reynolds Industries Inc. In July, my fellow directors and I had voted unanimously to give up our jobs and to recommend the merger because we thought it was best for Heublein stockholders and for the company. Our decision had nothing to do with success or failure in running Heublein.

title: COVERAGE IS URGED BY SOCIAL SECURITY FOR U.S. WORKERS
description: The National Commission on Social Security Reform reached agreement today on the need to begin bringing all employees of the Federal Government and of private, nonprofit institutions under the Social Security system.

title: HOW TRAINS ARE INSPECTED
description: When a train on the New Haven line stops for a wheel check, it is surrounded by eight inspectors who test each wheel with a heatsensitive rod.

title: TASS STATEMENT ON CHOICE OF ANDROPOV AS PARTY CHIEF
description: Following is the text of a statement, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass, on the meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee that elected Yuri V. Andropov General Secretary today:

title: OCCIDENTAL ASSETS SALE TO CUT DEBT
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that it was planning to sell all or part of several businesses in an effort to raise more than $2 billion and reduce its rapidly mounting debt.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ON BARREN HILL, A FATHER'S MEMORIAL TO SON KILLED IN VIETNAM
description: Back in May 1968, when word came that young David had been killed in Vietnam, Victor Westphall vowed, like so many bereaved parents in those bitter years, to do something that would honor and preserve the memory of his son.

title: Private Dollars for Public Schools
description: The Reagan Administration argues that private charity can offset reduced public financing - a cynical suggestion, especially in light of a recent Washington directive requiring that even reduced Federal funds for education be shared with private schools. Though recent efforts to encourage more private contributions to public education seem hopeful, the hope ultimately rings false.

title: Club for Woody Herman Closes on a Blue Note
description: A nightclub created to bring back Woody Herman and his 15-piece Thundering Herd to the birthplace of jazz has closed after less than a year.

title: AT BREZHNEV'S BIER, GRANDEUR, GLOOM AND THE LURKING PRESENCE OF THE K.G.B.
description: It was a rare moment of intimacy in a day when the Soviet system was at its most austere. First, the country's new leader was chosen behind closed doors, by an obscure process that left unclear who had backed whom.

title: AIR FLORIDA THINKS SMALLER
description: Air Florida, once known as the little airline that could, has discovered that sometimes it can't. Between 1977 and 1982, the carrier catapulted from an intrastate puddle-jumper in Florida to the third-largest airline serving Miami. In the process, it became a darling of Wall Street analysts, who cited it as a model of how to run an airline in the era of deregulation.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MINERAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Children Awarded $285,000 for Abuse
description: Three children who said they were sexually abused and beaten while lodged in a foster home were awarded $285,000 today by a jury in State Supreme Court here.

title: FAST-PACED BULLS DEFEAT NETS
description: Coach Larry Brown warned his New Jersey Nets about the Chicago Bulls' running game before the teams met tonight. At halftime, with the Bulls ahead by 58-41, he warned them again.

title: New Trial Ordered For Nurse in Death
description: A former cardiac-care nurse is entitled to a new trial on reduced manslaughter charges for allegedly giving a patient an incompatible blood transfusion, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FAIRFIELD MANSION RICH IN HISTORY
description: THE Burr Mansion on the Old Post Road in Fairfield is one of the most beautiful and significant buildings in the historic district of Fairfield.

title: BAROQUE CONCERTINO: WITH MICHEL PIGUET
description: The byways of American musical life are still clotted with all manner of small, 1950's-style Baroque string ensembles, often with a woodwind or two obbligato, modeled after I Musici and I Virtuosi di Roma.

title: THE SPACE RACE SINCE SPUTNUK
description: The Space Race Since Sputnik

title: CONCERT: MUSIC PLUS
description: Music Plus, under the direction of Simca Heled, is a worthy organization devoted to presenting concerts with a difference. Each Music Plus production offers the audience a chance to ask questions - about the music, composers, artists or instruments -as well as a guest host and a distinguished artist from a peripheral field.

title: Scott Fish to Wed Claudia D. Howell
description: The engagement of Claudia Dunseith Howell to Scott Kevin Fish has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dewitt Howell Jr. of New York. Mr. Fish is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Boardman Fish of Greenlawn, L.I.

title: Turkish Voters Get the Message
description: Judging by his 90 percent landslide in last week's Turkish national referendum, Gen. Kenan Evren probably could have won fair and square. As it was, opposition politicking was banned and General Evren monopolized the air waves, warning that a negative vote would mean a return to the fear and fusillades that paved the way for the military takeover 26 months ago.

title: Grand Jury Runs Up A $1,188 Dinner Tab
description: Twenty-two members of a grand jury ran up a dinner bill of $1,188.58 by feasting on escargot, filet mignon and baked alaska at Antoine's, one of the city's most luxurious restaurants.

title: PENN STATE AND GEORGIA TRIUMPH
description: Todd Blackledge and Curt Warner combined on a 48-yard touchdown pass early in the fourth quarter today and sparked Penn State to an 11-point rally and a 24-14 victory against Notre Dame. The triumph also pointed the Nittany Lions in the direction of the Sugar Bowl.

title: 7 DEALERS IN AMERICANA IN FREEHOLD
description: FREEHOLD SOMETHING new has been added to the old American Hotel, long known for its collection of horse racing memorabilia, including prints by Currier & Ives and British publishers.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON COLLEGE WINS

title: Gemayel Gets Powers, on Paper
description: President Amin Gemayel was given virtually full power by the Lebanese Parliament last week to rule by decree for six months. Now all he has to do is go out and rule.

title: WHEN A FIREMAN BECOMES A CASUALTY
description: IN MY five years as an active volunteer firefighter, I have been acutely aware of the physical suffering and emotional pain that fire inflicts.

title: Visions of a Smaller and Older America
description: Once an ecology slogan of the 1960's, ''zero population growth'' may be the American reality of the 2050's, according to Census Bureau projections issued last week. By then, the number of Americans should have peaked at 309 million and started to decline, as deaths exceed total births and net immigration.

title: BRITAIN'S BEST
description: To the Editor: We at the British Tourist Authority were extremely pleased by Erica Brown's story on Britain's small museums. I would only take exception to one piece of advice which she gives in the service information following the story.

title: SHOWDOWN NEARS ON SHOREHAM PHASE-IN
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company, nearing completion of its controversial $3 billion nuclear power plant at Shoreham, has proposed a new way for customers to pay for it that would increase electric bills by 50 percent over the next three years.

title: YALE ENDOWMENT FUND SET BACK BY $30 MILLION
description: Yale University's endowment fund lost about $30 million in net value in the 1981-82 fiscal year, according to the school's chief financial officer.

title: 'THE BLUE AND THE GRAY' OFTEN LOSES SIGHT OF THE CIVIL WAR
description: The eight-hour production of ''The Blue and the Gray,'' getting underway tonight at 8 and continuing on Tuesday and Wednesday, has been described by one CBS executive as ''the most ambitious project the network has ever undertaken.'' It looks it. At a reported cost of between $16 million and $18 million, this story of the American Civil War is laden with authentic costumes, grand battle scenes and a starstudded cast that includes Gregory Peck making his TV-movie debut in the role of Abraham Lincoln. In addition, the executive producers, Larry White and Lou Reda, have carefully enlisted the participation of noted historians. We are assured that the story is based on the ''personal views and impressions'' of Bruce Catton, the Pulitizer Prize-winning writer who died in 1978. The original story is credited to Mr. Catton and John Leekley, the editor of his final, posthumously published book.

title: U.S. WEIGHS APPEALING RICHMOND CASE RULING
description: The United States Department of Justice is considering whether to appeal a judge's ruling that declared unconstitutional part of the plea bargain under which former Representative Frederick W. Richmond admitted to various crimes.

title: AN AMERICAN TREASURE FINDS A NEW HOME
description: One day two years ago or so, a young organ buff was wandering through churches in Plains, Pa. - a small city next door to Wilkes-Barre - to see what kinds of instruments they had there. The pickings were pretty slim on the whole, but in the rear gallery of one Roman Catholic church, he came across something curious.

title: Gazpacho
description: To the Editor:

title: NEED FOR MORE HOSPITAL BEDS DEBATED
description: WHILE many Long Island hospitals are trying to expand their facilities to make room for new beds, they are apparently not heeding the second opinion of a regional health agency that is insisting that the Island as a whole has ample beds to meet population needs through 1985.

WITH reference to last week's articles by Senator Jake Garn and R epresentative Charles Schumer, the regulatory problems that confronto ur financial markets and institutions transcend the Glass-Steagall A ct.

title: CAN STAMFORD AFFORD TO BE SO RICH?
description: long factory where until 1957 3,700 people worked. Some of them, now under- or unemployed, still live near the ruins, which after 25 years have been enclosed by a chain-link fence topped with razor wire. It is one sign of many that Stamford's prosperity has had its price.

title: LITERARY PEN PALS
description: POUND/FORD The Story of a Literary Friendship. The Correspondence Between Ezra Pound and Ford Madox Ford and Their Writings About Each Other. Edited by Brita Lindber-Seyersted. 222 pp. New York: New Directions. $22.95.

title: 3 Enter Pleas in Bomb Plot
description: Three men, charged with threatening to blow up a Gulf Oil Chemicals Company refinery near here in late September unless they were paid $15 million, pleaded not guilty Wednesday to Federal extortion charges. The pleas were entered by John Marvin McBride, 46 years old, Michael Worth, 34, and Theodore McKinney 45, all of Durango, Colo. They are being held in lieu of $1 million bond each.

title: CHINA CHILDHOOD
description: HOMESICK My Own Story. By Jean Fritz. Illustrated by Margot Tomes. 163 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: WHAT SPANIARDS LIKE ABOUT THE SOCIALISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Alice Ann Peck Is Married to David Scott Schiller
description: Alice Ann Peck, who is with the media systems department of Harcourt, Brace & Jovanovich in New York, was married yesterday to David Scott Schiller, an editor at the Scott Meredith Literary Agency, also in New York.

title: DEATH TOLL NOW 89 IN LEBANESE BLAST
description: The Israeli military command announced tonight that the death toll in Thursday's explosion at Israeli military headquarters in southern Lebanon had climbed to 89 people, 75 of them Israelis.

title: Bernards Wins Running Titles
description: John Carlotti and Meg Waldron led Bernards to a sweep of the Group One titles in the New Jersey interscholastic cross-country championships today at Holmdel County Park.

title: PARAGUAY TOWN'S FORTUNES EBB AS DAM RISES
description: The water is filling behind the huge Itaipu Dam near here, but to many the completion of the huge gleaming white structure that connects Paraguay and Brazil across the Parana River marks the end of the boom for this frontier town.

title: DANCE: WERKCENTRUM, DUTCH GROUP
description: Werkcentrum Dans, a nine-member Dutch company from Rotterdam, is the latest of the experimental modern-dance companies from abroad that have recently come to Newcastle, or rather, New York, to present dance of American inspiration.

title: Grenade Is Believed Cause Of Blast in Chief's Driveway
description: It apparently was a grenade explosion that damaged an unmarked car in the driveway of this township's Police Chief, authorities said today.

title: DAMAGES ARE HARD TO RECOUP
description: WHETHER you are a landlord or a homeowner, there are risks with t enants that cannot be avoided. Even if you carefully select your t enant, even if you check and double check all references, even if y ou rent to a friend, you may still wind up with a damaged property.

title: A NUCLEAR-FREE ZONE SET IN MIDWEST SCHOOL
description: Signs in the corridors of Malcolm Shabazz High School warn that nuclear weapons are strictly forbidden. So is atomic weapons research, as well as the launching of nuclear missiles from the schoolyard.

title: Education Program for Deaf Infants
description: Because the excellent article ''Deaf Students in a Hearing World'' (Oct. 17) focused on mandatory education for deaf children from the age of 3, readers may not have realized that there is an educational program for hearing-impaired children below 3.

title: BAFFLING KILLING OF 'JOGGER' IN PARK BELIEVED SOLVED
description: With the arrest last week of a 20-year-old man, the police believe they have solved the baffling slaying of a youth whose body was found Nov. 1 in Central Park.

title: TRAINER KEEPS FIT AT 74
description: BRIDGEPORT ''NO women or unattended children,'' warns the sign on the door leading into the upstairs gymnasium. It's apparent that the people inside mean business, especially 74-year-old George Russo.

title: STATE CALLED UNFERTILE FOR TECHNOLOGY
description: THE Gold Rush of the 1980's is the push for high technology - the Open Sesame, it is said, to jobs and prosperity. But in New Jersey, people are asking whether the state's business climate is conducive to high-level prospecting.

title: Southern Cal 48, Arizona 41
description: Southern California set a N.C.A.A. record by returning three interceptions for touchdowns in a 48-41 Pacific-10 Conference victory over Arizona.

title:
STAMPS;
BIG FALL SHOW OPENS AT COLISEUM THURSDAY
description: The premiere fall stamp show in the East, ''National '82,'' which proclaims itself as the largest philatelic event in the United States, is returning to the New York Coliseum for a four-day stay beginning Thursday.

title: CHARTER REVISION URGED ON REPLACING ELECTED OFFICIALS
description: THE 1982 state elections are over and voters have spoken by electing County Legislator Richard L. Brodsky of Greenburgh to the State Assembly and County Executive Alfred B. DelBello as New York's Lieutenant Governor. It is ironic that while the 1982 state election showed democracy at its best, the procedures in our County Charter pertaining to the replacement of elected officials who do not complete terms of office is an example of democracy at its worst.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
BRINGING DEMOCRACY TO THE SPORTS WORLD
description: SOMETHING is wrong with the way we think about sports in this country. Athletics in schools, colleges and universities have become more and more influenced by money. As this influence further corrupts those who run sports, perhaps those who make the decisions should be changed. As evidenced by the many institutions in various forms of trouble for violating certain rules, it is obvious the present administrators are incapable of remembering what the original intents of athletics really are.

title:
OPINION;
'YOUR MOTHER WANTS TO TALK TO YOU'
description: WHEN our widowed mother reached her 70th birthday, my husband, my children and I asked her to come to live with us. She gave up her little apartment and moved in with more than just her worldly goods. She cooked for us, sewed for us and helped us rear children of good will. The extended family enjoyed a spirit of warmth and love for more than two decades.

title: BY SKIP ROZIN
description: SKIP ROZIN is writing a book about Daley Thompson, the Olympic decathlon champion, to be published in England next spring.

title: 19TH-CENTURY CHESS CLUB IN 20TH-CENTURY SETTING
description: The players may have changed, but the Marshall Chess Club, in the parlor of a Greenwich Village brownstone, has survived while many other chess clubs have faltered.

title: Mailbox; Another Tale At Swarthmore
description: To the Sports Editor: The account of the football situation at Swarthmore College (''Swarthmore's Shakespearean Character and Other Tales,'' The New York Times, Nov. 1) brings to mind our daughter's first letter home from there her freshman year. Her class was introduced to some of the faculty, including the football coach, who announced pleadingly, ''The library is that way and the field house is this direction. Please don't all of you go to the library! Please some of you go to the field house!'' KATHERINE MONTGOMERY

title: IRAQIS CONFRONTING IRANIANS IN THREE SECTORS ON FRONTIER
description: Iraqi ground and air forces are putting up an active defense against Iranian attacks at three points along the border, according to Western diplomats here.

title: THE SELF SUPPORTING: ARE THEY TRULY NEEDY?; Ba CHRISTOPHER WELLISZ
description: AFRESHMAN at a private college in New York left her mother's home after having graduated from high s chool. Her father had abandoned the family, and her mother had a lowi ncome. After two years of living and working on her own, she decidedt o go to college.

title: Cornell Beats Columbia, 35-26
description: John Witkowski continued to break records yesterday but not even his four touchdown passes could save Columbia from a 35-26 defeat by Cornell at Baker Field.

title: Reagan Chooses Dillon For Council on the Arts
description: C. Douglas Dillon, chairman of the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a former member of the Cabinet, was nominated by President Reagan today to serve on the National Council on the Arts.

title: WHY COLLEGE STUDENTS TAKE A 'SABBATICAL'
description: SALIL MEHTA, an undergraduate at Brown University, doesn't know whether he wants to be a doctor or al awyer, so for the last two years he has sampled courses in p olitical science and biology. This fall he is in Washington, i nterning for a Congressman and doing volunteer work for a public d efender; next spring he plans to be somewhere else, working in a h ospital, after which he expects to be sitting in Brown classrooms a gain this time with a major and a goal.

title: POLL FINDS MAJORITY OPPOSES WEAKER ENVIRONMENTAL LAWS
description: A majority of Americans, including business executives, believe that environmental protection should not be weakened for the sake of economic growth, according to a survey published this week.

title: BARNARD ALUMNAE ENJOY SECOND TIME AROUND
description: It was in 1920, when women's studies still meant education for ladies, that Eleanor Stapelfeldt enrolled at Barnard College. She majored in English and became good friends with a student named Margaret Mead.

title: PLAN SEEKS TO STEM TEACHER ABSENTEEISM
description: YONKERS THIS city's school system has offered to ''buy back'' from its teachers their unused days off for illness and personal reasons, paying the money into Individual Retirement Accounts it would establish for those teachers.

title: Letters;
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
WHERE TO DINE ON THANKSGIVING
description: HERE in the Northeast where it all began, Thanksgiving is that special moment between the falling of the last leaf and the falling of the first snow. It is an American holiday - a patriotic one whose magnitude is shared only with the Fourth of July. But while celebration of the Fourth demands picnics and cookouts, Thanksgiving takes its festivities indoors, foregoing the American hot dog in favor of the American turkey.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Some Turnaround

title: JERSEY DRUG VIOLATORS ALLLOWED TO CLEAR RECORDS
description: A program that allows many first-time drug offenders to erase records of their convictions by completing probation is gaining converts around New Jersey, though not every county uses the system.

title: 'TROUBLED' LISTING PERTURBS CAMDEN
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development is reviewing a plan that, in the opinion of the financially troubled Camden Housing Authority, will save the authority about $3 million in the next five years.

title: Miss Lockwood Will Be Married
description: Loraine Ann Lockwood, chairman of the art department at the Metairie Park Country Day School in New Orleans, and James Hooker Minge, a lawyer practicing in New Orleans, plan to be married there Dec. 11.

title: JERSEY TO TEST RESTRICTING MEDICAID RECIPIENTS TO ONE DOCTOR
description: New Jersey will soon test a Medicaid program that will restrict recipients to the care of a single general-practice physician who would manage all their medical needs. Such demonstration programs have also been proposed in New York and Connecticut.

title: Shadow Boxing In the Shadow Government
description: Republicans already have vowed to keep Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo in line, but for the moment they are in a line of their own to determine who will hold the whip. A battle for party leadership between Lewis E. Lehrman, loser in a close election to Mr. Cuomo, and State Senate majority leader Warren M. Anderson became more likely last week as each staked out his role as number one.

title: Under 40?
description: To the Editor:

title: A CAPTAIN'S STORE OF CHINESE RICHES
description: Formidable collections of Chinese art have, in recent years, enriched the auction market with stunning offerings in a variety of categories - from snuff bottles to Sung and Ming porcelains. Two years ago, Edward T. Chow's spectacular Ming porcelains sold in three sessions of an auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet in Hong Kong and London that totaled $20.1 million, the most important public sale held in recent years of such material and the fourth highest total ever gaveled for a single owner sale of art at auction.

title: FOOD By Moira Hodgson
description: A BIRD OF A DIFFERENT FEATHER

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
COMING OF AGE
description: ''GET rid of the parents!'' used to be a cliche directed at authors of kids' adventure stories. Here are four novels of a very different sort wherein parental absence may be anything from salutary to catastrophic.

title: TREASURE ON 'HOLD'
description: From 1892 until 1931, a small factory on Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, turned out terra cotta ornaments for 2,000 New York City buildings, some of them now landmarks, such as the Plaza Hotel and Carnegie Hall.

title: Kings 112, Clippers 111
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Eddie Johnson scored a career-high 35 points, including 10 in the final quarter, to help Kansas City snap a threegame losing streak.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: SCRUTINIZING THE AIRLINE ADS
description: U nderstanding airline advertisements can be a challenge. Try this one from Eastern Airlines: ''Nobody undercuts us, simply call Eastern. We will match any domestic nonstop or through-jet fare available on any major airline on a comparable Eastern flight.''

title: UTILITY TAKEOVER BEING CONSIDERED
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the dust has settled over the controversy around the Public Advocate's signing of a cost-containment agreement that will let the Public Service Electric and Gas Company complete its multibillion-dollar Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant, some observers see a larger picture that may involve the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
PHOTOGRAPHY
description: PHOTOGRAPHYMax Kozloff, a former Artforum editor who underwent a conversion to photograhy in l977, works in a style somewhere between Garry Winogrand and William Eggleston. He shares Winogrand's casual approach to framing; like Eggleston he uses color film, limning the world with an Impressionist's palette.

title: A DEBATE: ARE ENOUGH DATA IN HAND TO ACT AGAINST ACID RAIN?
description: EVERYBODY talks about acid rain, but nobody does anything about it. Why? Scientists and policymakers know that sulfur oxides and nitrogen oxides emitted into the air react with water vapor to form acids. These fall to earth in rain or snow, increasing land and water acidity and jeopardizing plant and animal life.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WHEN THE GOING WAS GOOD! American Life in the Fifties. By Jeffrey Hart. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title: KIN OF NAVY FLIERS KILLED IN '48 SEEK REMAINS
description: Thirty-four years ago, a Navy bomber with nine crewmen disappeared in fog over the Canadian Rockies. Thirteen years later, a prospecting nickel miner happened upon the splintered wreckage of the aircraft. For the last 20 years the men's families have been pleading with the Navy to bring the remains back, but the Navy refuses.

title:
GARDENING;
A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT FOR ROOTS
description: FROM time to time we have referred to the undesirable effect of soil compaction on plant growth. However, we have not discussed the reasons for it. Since the fall is an ideal time to take measures to overcome compaction, this a good time for us to examine the problem.

title: PARENTS TAP NEW IDEAS TO PAY CHILDREN'S BILLS
description: AMERICAN families have started paying for their children's college education much like they pay for their houses: with long-term ''mortgages'' that stretch tuition payments over a decade or more.

title: SURVEY COMPARES TAX RATES OF STATES
description: IT is better to earn your money in Connecticut, but spend it in neighboring states, according to a new study of tax rates in the area.

title: Solar Caveats
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDROPOV A SHREWD ADVERSARY FOR THE WEST
description: DURING Leonid I. Brezhnev's years of failing health, the old men in the Kremlin had plenty of time to prepare for the end. Last week, when the 75-year-old Soviet leader died, the gerontocracy moved swiftly to prolong its grip on power. Yuri V. Andropov, 68, who had kept dossiers on everybody for 15 years as head of the K.G.B., took over Mr. Brezhnev's base as general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.

title: THERE IS NO JOY IN FOOTBALLVILLE
description: The N.F.L. strike moves us to think of football in meter rather than yardage. The verses that follow are a ballad of the 1982 professional football season. The tear you see is in Pete Rozelle's eye, not mine.

title: No Headline
description: L.S.U. Is Upset By 27-24

title: TESTING TO PROTECT PRIVATE WELLS
description: WHEN Lewis Faccinto moved to Litchfield from California earlier this year, he was somewhat troubled because the house he had chosen for himself, his wife and three young children was served by a private well, as were most of the homes in that part of the state.

title: Karate Reinstatement
description: A Federal judge in Boston has ordered the United States national karate team to reinstate a top-ranked female competitor who missed tryouts for the world championships because of a conflict with a Jewish holiday. The team is headed for the world competition in Taiwan this month.

title: A CONTEXT FOR POEMS
description: THE SECOND LIFE OF ART Selected Essays. By Eugenio Montale. Edited and Translated by Jonathan Galassi. 354 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $17.50.

title: Genetic Screening Test Needs Wider Publicity
description: I am writing to commend your publication of an article by Rita Esposito Watson in the issue of Oct. 17, on developments in pre-natal screening for neural tube defects (''Yale Encouraging Screening Tests to Find Birth Defects''). The press has a tendency to sensationalize and oversimplify its coverage of medicine and medical technology, often to such an extent that the truth is seriously distorted.

title: CELLOS SHUCK OFF A STAID IMAGE AND GO JAZZY
description: In symphony orchestras and string quartets, the most full-throated, gutsy melodies go to the violoncello. The instrument warms to the fervent declamations of Ernest Bloch's ''Schelomo'' or Antonin Dvorak's Cello Concerto, and with its hearty tone and soulful phrasing it ought to suit jazz just as well.

title: THREE NEW WOMEN
description: LOOKING back over the "women's" writing published in the last 20 years, I suspect that its real literary contribution will not be that overtold tale of "how I got liverated." Rather it will be the works of writers - such as Jean Kerr, Sue Kaufman, Lois Gould, Erica Jong in "Fear of Flying" and even Erma Bombeck - whose rueful housewife humor reflects the sardonic dualism of the oppressed whose feet may be on the waxy kitchen floor but whose eyes and minds see all too far. Now that the heroines of novels are leaving for the office, we can only hope that misled awe at being accepted in a man's world will not rob them of their vision and sense of the ridiculous and that humor will prevail over polemics.

title: ROSSINI WAS A MASTER OF SERIOUS OPERA, TOO
description: In 1934, the British musicologist Francis Toye wrote the first serious biographical study of Gioacchino Rossini, the first attempt to resurrect his reputation as more than a purveyor of witty but trivial farces and a lazy bon vivant. Toye called his book ''Rossini: A Study in Tragi-Comedy.'' The title alluded to the stillmysterious tragedy of the nearly 40 years, after ''Guillaume Tell'' of 1829, in which Rossini composed no operas at all. But it also sought to redress Rossini's image as a composer of operatic comedies like ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' and little else.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cliffside Park $120,000 770 Anderson Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old condominium; *2*eat-in kitchen, charges $298; taxes $1,508. Cresskill $133,000 40 Center Street *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; *2*2-year-old roof, basement, patio; taxes $2,233. Demarest $170,000 6 Isabella Way *2*3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*beamed ceiling in family room, pool, 2 fireplaces; taxes $2,844. Haworth $265,000 376 Elm Street *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; *2*fireplace, basement, alarm systems; taxes $5,298. New Milford $113,500 660 Columbia Street *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old split-level; *2*pool, 2 fireplaces; taxes $2,479. Paramus $92,000 276 Wedgewood Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2*basement, pool, cabana; taxes $1,455. OTHER AREAS Greenwich, Conn. $220,000 Horseneck Mews *2*2-bedroom, 3-bath,new town house condominium; *2*charges $90; taxes $1,700. Hartsdale, N.Y. $115,000 29 Dalewood Drive *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old stone/ brick ranch; *2*2-car garage, slate roof, 150- by 225-foot lot; taxes $4,421. Northport, L.I. $76,000 4 Meadow Place *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old Cape Cod; *2*fireplace in living room, eat-in kitchen, *2*den, basement; taxes $2,019.

title: Bethel Not Passive In Face of Problems
description: Let me preface my response to Judith C. Benedict's Opinion article (''When a Town Needs to Change'') in the Oct. 24 issue by stating the following: I have been a Bethel resident with my family for the last nine years. I have three teen-agers, two of whom are in the high school and the third a recent graduate. I am a registered independent voter.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: A Basic Question On Oil Prices

title: GROWING UP AND DOWN
OF BEASTS AND HUMANS: SOME CONTEMPORARY VIEWS
description: Animals - with their challenging shapes, odd colors, affinity for symbolism and stand-in relationship to humans - have always served as virtually foolproof subjects for artists. Rosa Bonheur, who did poorly at people, could limn the soul in a horse's face; the German Expressionist Franz Marc said that painting animals brought out ''all the good that was in me,'' and Henry Moore, concerned with human figures on a monumental scale, not too long ago had a lovely bout of sketching woolly sheep.

title:
LEISURE;
NEW STRATEGIES FOR FEEDING BIRDS
description: Charles R. Smith is director of public education at the Cornell University Laboratory of Ornithology.

title: HUGE GATHERING OF WORLD LEADERS IS EXPECTED FOR BREZHNEV'S FUNERAL
description: Security was tightened today on the eve of the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev as this city prepared to receive what is likely to be the largestgathering of foreign leaders in Soviet history.

title: No Headline
description: Irving Howe's excellent account of the turbulence of the late 1960's underscores the sense of sadness I feel as I acknowledge the ''failure'' of that time. As a college student during that era, I remember well the feelings of camaraderie and energy that we all shared. PAMELA JOYCE FEIBICKE, New York City

title: Laurette Marrone Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Marrone of Flushing, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Laurette Marrone, to Cadet Christopher Mark DeToro of West Point, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond DeToro of New Castle, Del.

title: 'Pet' Killer Whale
description: For more than a month, the killer whale had romped in the harbor at Provincetown, Mass., accepting handouts of fish and affectionate pats from people in boats. Marine scientists, saying killer whales usually preferred Newfoundland waters, feared for the health of the 15-foot female, nicknamed Geraldine by onlookers.

title: TANZANIA: A DREAM DEFERRED
description: I first arrived in Tanzania in 1963, as a teacher in the Peace Corps, in the heady days just after independence from Britain. The school I was assigned to was in the southern highlands, in blue mountains shadowed by clouds and mist. It was a setting as pristine as the ideals that had brought me there.

title: A MUSICAL REOPENS PAPER MILL
description: MILLBURN WE'VE been waiting 18 years for ''Robert and Elizabeth,'' but it isn't quite what we've been waiting for. The popular English musical -based on ''The Barretts of Wimpole Street,'' a play about the real-life love between the poets Robert and Elizabeth Barrett Browning - opened in London in 1964, and the original-cast album, still available, became something of a cult favorite.

title: MICHIGAN ASSERTS CONTAMINANTS IS CLEANED UP
description: The Michigan Department of Agriculture, declaring that ''PBB is now behind us,'' has released its last report on a nine-year struggle to rid the state of its worst contamination problem.

title: No Headline
description: Devils' Streak Without a Victory Hits 13

title: Trottier, Devils Agree
description: Rocky Trottier, an 18-year-old forward who is the brother of Bryan Trottier of the Islanders, reached an agreement yesterday with the New Jersey Devils on a multiyear contract. Trottier, who was the No.1 pick of the Devils in the amateur draft and the eighth selection over all, had been assigned to the Nanaimo Islanders of the Western Hockey League.

title: FOUR RIDERS ARE KILLED IN CRASH OF CAR AND TRUCK IN LINDENWOLD
description: Four Camden County men were killed and a fifth was critically injured early today when the car they were riding in smashed broadside into a bread truck on White Horse Pike here.

title: Quick Dangers, Slow Responses
description: Nine years after earth containing dioxin was dumped in their yards, residents of a St. Louis, Mo., suburb still do not know whether to sit tight or bolt. State officials and congressional delegates have promised money for a cleanup if necessary, but the Environmental Protection Agency will not issue a report based on new soil samples until January.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review Nov. 7 misstated the number of Republican House candidates who won with 55 percent or less after outraising their Democratic opponents by more than $50,000 each. The number was 29.

title: Headliners; Richmond's Sentence
description: Seldom has a politician's road to jail been paved with as many and diverse crimes as the path of former Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn. His political career survived a 1978 confession that he had solicited sex from a teen-aged boy, but not the tax evasion, marijuana possession and illegal payment charges on which he was sentenced last week. Mr. Richmond admitted the crimes and resigned from office as part of a deal in which the Government agreed to drop a variety of other charges against him.

title: THE METEORITES OF WESTFIELD LEAVE SCIENTISTS BAFFLED
description: CONNECTICUT, ''The Meteorite State.'' That might be an appropriate, albeit unlikely, choice to replace ''The Nutmeg State'' or ''The Constitution State'' as a state nickname, but as far as some scientists around the country were concerned last week, Connecticut can claim a unique relationship with outer space.

title: Limon Dancers to Mark Their 35th Anniversary
description: The Jose Limon Dance Company will celebrate its 35th anniversary in performances at the Joyce Theater from Nov. 30 - a change from the previously announced opening date -through Dec. 19. The company will perform nine works, among them Mr. Limon's ''Missa Brevis,'' ''The Emperor Jones,'' ''Carlota,'' ''The Unsung,'' ''The Moor's Pavane'' and ''There Is a Time.''

title: A HARD LINE
description: English caricature, as practiced by two of its masters, James Gillray and Thomas Rowlandson, was known for its grotesquerie. These social satirists mercilessly lacerated kings, generals, clerics and aristocrats through savage graphic exaggerations and distortions.

title: NEW PANEL SEEKS MEDICAL EXAMINER
description: IN a departure from usual peer-review procedures, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan has appointed a committee to seek out and recommend a new medical examiner that includes the county's Health Commissioner, the District Attorney, a career politician and two police representatives.

title: The Bible's Inspired Art
description: In his article ''The Bible's Inspired Art'' (Oct. 3), Chaim Potok refers to a scholar who wants to translate the fourth verse of the 23d Psalm as ''Though I walk through a valley of deepest darkness'' instead of the traditional ''valley of the shadow of death.'' The scholar prefers a literal translation of the psalmist's poetic metaphor (surely, ''the valley ...'' is a metaphor for distress).

title: Amherst 52, Williams 26
description: Mark Vendetti, a fullback, scored on runs of 1, 4 and 2 yards to help Amherst claim the Little Three conference title. Amherst, now 7-1 and 2-0 in the conference, led by 45-0 at halftime, helped by two fumbles lost by Williams and an interception.

title: ON WITH THE SHOW
description: MILLBURN THE coincidence of the Paper Mill Playhouse's grand reopening and the first full-scale American production of the long-awaited English musical ''Robert and Elizabeth'' signals a double sense of occasion.

title: OPERA: AWARENESS UNIT WITH DONIZETTI'S 'RITA'
description: There are several ways of producing opera on a budget, all of them risky in inflationary times. The Association for Opera Awareness, in its production of two brief samplings of commedia dell'arte at the West End Theater, at 302 West 91st Street, has taken an up-front approach to its precarious financial condition. Utilizing a charming musty theater in the basement of a church, the group offered staging clearly meant to imitate the makeshift style utilized by the traveling shows of centuries past - down to fake patches on the curtain. The effect is joyously - defiantly - amateurish, except for the performances, which are spirited and imbued with a sense of playfulness.

title: Frederick Agate Took Some Lessons
description: It was too bad to see the article on the Westchester County 300th Birthday exhibition in Scarsdale (''A Show for the County's 300th Birthday,'' Oct. 17) spoiled by a statement reflecting incomplete research on the background on at least one of the artists there represented.

title: COAL COMPANY TO PAY $1 MILLION IN DISASTER FINES
description: A Federal district judge has tentatively approved a plea bargain in which the Westmoreland Coal Company would pay more than $1 million in penalties for its part in a 1980 mine disaster that killed five miners.

title: BY LINDA CHARLTON
description: LINDA CHARLTON is a writer who lives in Canaan, N.Y.

title:
OPINION;
WHAT SHE LEFT BEHIND WHEN SHE MOVED
description: MORE than a year ago my friend and neighbor, Barbara, moved to California. Hers was the typical story that affects so many families in corporate life - husband offered a big promotion, opportunity of a lifetime, too good to pass up. But for Barbara it was heartwrenching.

title: Rossi Eyes U.S.
description: Paolo Rossi, the star of the Italian team that captured the World Cup soccer championship last summer, has indicated that he would be interested in playing in the United States, perhaps for the Cosmos of the North American Soccer League.

title: TIME AGAIN FOR SALT II
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BRUNSWICK AND ORCHESTRA AT ODDS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ALTHOUGH a dispute between the American Philharmonic Orchestra and the New Brunswick corporations that run the State Theater remains unresolved, both sides still hope that the orchestra will give a series of concerts here.

title: FISHING-BOAT RULES MAY BE STIFFENED
description: THE sinking of the 47-foot fishing boat Joan La-Rie III off Point Pleasant three weeks ago with the loss of eight lives is leading the Coast Guard to restudy its safety regulations and has caused concern among fishing boat captains.

title: WITTY ART FULFILLS A MISSION
description: BROOKVILLE WHEN the Marjorie Strider exhibition opens at the C.W. Post Center on Friday, the community will have an example of the kind of stimulating message that Dr. Judith Van Wagner believes should be part of her mission as the art gallery's new director.

title: Sunny Prognosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Lever House: Too Nice to Die?
description: Can one of architecture's renowned examples of ''less is more'' survive in a city where big is not only beautiful but exceedingly profitable? In an effort to insure that Lever House will endure, the glass-and-steel tower that occupies only a fraction of its available space on Park Avenue was designated New York City's youngest landmark last week.

title: WAGNER EXPECTING BID ON 8-0-1 SEASON
description: Wagner College, led by Alonzo Patterson's running and two touchdowns, scored a 42-0 victory over Kean College yesterday at Zweidinger Field, Union, N.J., and completed its first undefeated season (8-0-1) since 1967.

title: 13TH YEAR IS LUCKY FOR ACADEMICALLY TROUBLED
description: MANY believe that the American high school student yearns for g raduation as fervently as the prisoner anticipates probation. But l ast year, more than 1,500 students chose to stay in high school an e xtra year for what is called the ''postgraduate program.''

title: 'TWICE AROUND THE PARK' IS A REUNION OF FAMILIAR FRIENDS
description: You absolutely have to allow for the fondness factor. It plays a part. For instance, it doesn't take you all that long in the theater to figure out that Murray Schisgal's new piece, ''Twice Around the Park,'' is a bit unsteady on its pins from time to time, causing the entire company - Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach - to toss off a few extra ballet steps and a few extra bars of ''Bye Bye Blackbird'' to fill in the gaps between their bigger laughs. But this is one of those social occasions when old times count and, instead of sitting back primly and adding up the lapses, you tend to lean forward, rooting for the next chuckle or boff to come in the nick of time and for that nice Wallach couple, together with that crazy man Schisgal, to put it all together again. I mean put together their special lunatic universe in which nothing is merrier than misery.

title: No Headline
description: NICARAUGUA PROPOSES SUMMIT TALK WITH HONDURAS

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1982. Judges who participated in this 31st annual selection were Seymour Chwast, illustrator and graphic designer; Gerald Gottlieb, Curator of Early Children's Books at the Pierpont Morgan Library and the author of ''Early Children's Books and Their Illustrators''; and Robert Andrew Parker, painter and illustrator.

title: LET'S NOT KNOCK A STRONG U.S. DOLLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS FALL TO 76ERS, 110 TO 100
description: It may not be time for the Nets to panic, says Foots Walker, the team's captain and point guard. But it just might be the right time for the first team meeting of the season.

title: The Decade That Failed
description: An essay on as polemical a time as the 1960's, written with such insight, is a rare and praiseworthy event (''The Decade That Failed,'' by Irving Howe, Sept. 19).

title: MILLIONS REPORTED AT A RALLY IN BAGHDAD IN SUPPORT OF WAR
description: Millions of people demonstrated in Baghdad and its outskirts today in support of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and his ''victorious leadership'' in the war with Iran, Baghdad radio said.

title: MILIEU OF COLD WAR IS RECALLED AT FALLOUT TRIAL
description: In 1951, when cold war anxieties seized the United States, the remote desert of southern Nevada was picked, at the highest levels of Government, as the site of a nuclear testing program. This history, a Federal district judge has been told, is important in considering damage claims arising out of 11 years of above-ground atomic testing.

title: The Osborne Collection
description: In 1949 Edgar Osborne, county librarian of Derbyshire, England, donated his collection of early children's books to the Toronto Public Library. The collection has grown by other donations and become a major resource for scholarly work in the field.

title: Lisa Flinker Engaged To William J. Curtis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph G. Flinker of Glen Rock, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Caroline Flinker, to William Joseph Curtis of Los Angeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Curtis of Garden City, L.I.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY SAYS PLASTIC LIQUOR BOTTLE IS NOT CANCER THREAT
description: Consumers may soon find their favorite gin, whisky or bourbon in plastic bottles because a Federal agency has decided the containers pose no cancer threat when they are filled with liquor.

title: Dizzying Time
description: To the Business Editor: ''A Dizzying Time for All Savers'' (Oct. 24) was a commendable effort to outline the investment choices available for consumers with maturing All Savers certificates. However, the section on Individual Retirement Accounts failed to mention that I.R.A.'s are also available from insurance companies.

title: PILOTS AND LOVERS
description: GOODBYE, MICKEY MOUSE By Len Deighton. 337 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: YOUNG MUSIC WINNERS GET A BOOST
description: SIX years ago, when he was 11, Jon Manasse of Glen Cove began studying clarinet, not because he had an overwhelming desire to master it, but because his teacher's studio was at Carnegie Hall and ''I liked telling people I took lessons at Carnegie Hall,'' he recalled.

title: Betsy DeGraff Engaged to C. H. Sands
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Arthur C. DeGraff Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Betsy Dodd DeGraff, to Christopher Hyde Sands, son of Mrs. Kenneth F. Sands of Durham, N.H., and the late Dr. Sands.

title: SOVIET INFLUENCE IN IRAN SHOWS A SHARP DECLINE
description: The influence of the Soviet Union, which saw in the Iranian revolution an opportunity to win a significant role in the Persian Gulf region, has apparently undergone a sharp decline here in the last year.

title: 22 Families in Dallas Sue Procter & Gamble
description: Members of 22 families have filed suit against the Procter & Gamble Company claiming they suffered respiratory damage from an accidental release of sulfuric gas in an accident two years ago.

title: Truman Rolls
description: Neither rain, nor cold, nor being out of the playoff picture could keep Truman's Devin Etheridge from having a banner day yesterday.

title: OPERA: ENSEMBLE GROUP
description: ''Werther,'' Jules Massenet's big-hearted Romantic opera, did not always fit comfortably on the tiny stage of the Opera Ensemble of New York Friday night, but both the principal singers and the visual aspect of John Sheehan's production had their attractions.

title: ANDROPOV
description: The sudden naming of Yuri V. Andropov as the new Secretary General of the Soviet Communist Party, coming as it did in response to a nomination put forward by Konstantin U. Chernenko, plainly suggests a prior arrangement, at least between these two men. And since they were obviously Leonid I. Brezhnev's two most-favored candidates for the succession, this choice may also be taken to represent a certain posthumous extension of his influence, at least for the immediate future.

title:
THE MAKING OF A WRITER;
WE NEED SILENCE TO FIND OUT WHAT WE THINK
description: EVERYONE who writes is asked at some stage, Why? Some writers give replies to that question, but I wonder if it is truly anserable. If there is a worthy response, it would to my mind have to do with a wish to close the discrepancy between human experience, with all its strangeness of the mind, as it is known to each of us, and as it is generally expressed. We live in a time when past concepts of an order larger than the self are dwindling away or have disappeared - the deference of the human species and of societies to nature and to the universe, to religions, to nationhood, to social systems. The testimony of the accurate word is perhaps that last great mystery to which we can make ourselves accessible, to which we can still subscribe.

title: AFTER BREZHNEV
description: WASHINGTON EACH hidden reshuffling of power in the Kremlin triggers a reflexive questioning in America: Will this make things better or worse for us and how should we handle it? Should we greet the new leadership with conciliatory gestures to lure them toward accommodation or with toughness to try to force them to ease off on the arms race and aggressiveness abroad.

title: SPACE WALK POSTPONED TILL MONDAY
description: A bout of motion sickness, one of the persistent problems of space flight, forced a one-day postponement of plans for two astronauts to take a walk outside the space shuttle Columbia. The space walk was rescheduled for Monday morning.

title: Rebel Suspect Killed in Italy
description: A suspected left-wing urban guerrilla fell to his death from a seventh-floor window here today when policemen raided an apartment and arrested three other suspects, confiscating arms and ammunition, the police said. The three arrested, two men and a woman, are believed to be connected with the Red Brigades guerrilla group, the police said. Their names were not disclosed.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
A TALK WITH NATALIE BABBITT
description: THIS month, Natalie Babbitt's 10th book (her sixth novel), ''Herbert Rowbarge,'' is being published. It will come as no surprise to her admirers that this latest work is as unlike ''The Eyes of the Amaryllis'' (1977), the ghostly tale of lost love that preceded it, as her exhilarating first novel, ''The Search for Delicious'' (1969), was radically different from its picture-book antecedent, the Edwardian rhymed farce, ''Phoebe's Revolt'' (1968).

EVEN before Leonid I. Brezhnev's death was officially announced, p olitical analysts began to speculate about who his successor might b e. Certainly the selection of Yuri V. Andropov is important for u nderstanding what Soviet domestic and foreign policy will be. E qually important, however, is an understanding of what the Soviet e conomic potential is.

title: WHEN DRAMA COLORS NEWS
description: The complaint from the White House that CBS overstated the dimensions of the Democratic victory in the House of Representatives on election night is but the latest of a series of assertions that television slants the news. By no means, however, do such sentiments emanate exclusively from the White House - or, for that matter, from conservative forces. Many on the left of American politics agree with many on the right that television is slanted - and in the wrong direction.
