Although they part company at once on the definition of ''wrong,'' both camps are convinced that conspiracy is afoot.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''JUMPIN' JIVE'' was pulsing from the tape deck in the County Executive's conference room and so was ''Minnie the Moocher'' with its unforgettable lyric, ''Hi dee, hi dee, hi dee, ho.''

title: AT WAR OVER THE PENTAGON
description: IN the fall of 1980, a triumphant Ronald Reagan captured Washington and renewed his campaign pledge to balance the Federal budget, cut taxes and give defense spending the biggest boost in decades.

title: Not Lightning, But Struck Twice
description: The sky is falling in Wethersfield, at least more than in most other places. For the second time in 11 years, a meteorite came to earth in the Connecticut town last week.

title: Sara Sue Strong To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Strong Jr. of Fairport, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Sue Strong, to E. Reed Wilbur Jr., son of Mrs. David B. VanDusen of Weston, Mass., and the late Mr. Wilbur.

title: New Goal Needed On Woodfield
description: Jary Rapaport calls attention to important problems in the Oct. 17 Opinion Page story on juvenile detention (''The Detention of Juveniles: A Point of Crisis and Separation''). Modifying our humanservice and corrective-service systems in response to the Juvenile Offender Law has taken much work and will take much more.

title: Mt. Hermon Runs to Title
description: Northfield-Mount Hermon's boys' and girls' teams swept the team titles today in the New England Prep School cross-country championships here.

title: ACTIVIST SINGLES FIGHT FOR RIGHTS
description: Most singles groups in the county are socially oriented, but there are also activist groups organized to fight for the rights of singles.

title: Allen Boyarsky, Lawyer, Miss Oppenheimer, to Wed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Janet Oppenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Oppenheimer of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Allen Boyarsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Boyarsky of Westport, Conn.

title: Columbia Phone Line Takes 500,000 Calls
description: More than 500,000 calls have been logged to a telephone number that lets people worldwide hear conversations between the space shuttle Columbia and Mission Control, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today.

title: NIXON SAYS U.S. CAN USE CARTER'S HELP ON MIDEAST
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon says he thinks President Reagan could use the ''input'' of former President Jimmy Carter in efforts to find a comprehensive formula for peace in the Middle East.

title: Swarthmore Loses First
description: Bob Mangold passed for one touchdown and ran for another as Widener defeated Swarthmore today, 24-7. The victory gave Widener (9-1) a share of the Middle Atlantic Conference southern division title with Swarthmore, and a likely Division III playoff berth.

title: THE COMPASSION OF PETER SEKAER
description: PETER SEKAER (1901 to 1950) was a fine photographer but not a famous one, and the show of his prints in the Esther Raushenbush Library, at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, hints at some of the reasons why.

title: PLAINTIFFS IN PANTHER SUIT 'KNEW WE WERE RIGHT'
description: ''At times, when we had to go to court almost daily and when all the decisions were coming down against us, it seemed that we should just give up,'' said William Hampton, reflecting on the 13-year court fight that grew out of the killing of two local Black Panther leaders by the Chicago police.

title: SOME DOUBTS BEDEVIL IRAN'S 'GREAT SATAN' VIEW OF U.S.
description: TEHERAN ''I feel sorry for the Iranians,'' said a Spanish journalist who was one of a small group of correspondents admitted to the country for the first 10 days of this month. ''They are taught to hate Americans, taught that America is responsible for all their problems, and yet they're desperate for your approval.''

title:
OPINION;
'YOUR MOTHER WANTS TO TALK TO YOU'
description: THE phone's ring pierced the Sunday silence. I lifted the receiver quickly to avoid rousing the family. A brief squint at the clock revealed it was only 7. Horace stirred sleepily on his side of the bed.

title: SUICIDE'S OTHER VICTIMS
description: Lisa Bergson is a freelance writer living in New York.Twenty-five years ago, my mother committed suicide. I was 7. No one told me how she died or why. I thought perhaps I had driven her away. And I prayed that someday she would return.

title:
DESIGN;
ORNAMENTATION
description: 'Useless' decoration had been in disfavor for decades. But now there is a movement toward embellishment for its own sake.Adapted from ''Ornamentalism: The New Decorativeness in Architecture and Design'' to be published by Clarkson N. Potter Inc.The urge to embellish and the love of ornament are basic to human nature. In all ages and cultures people have demonstrated a persistent impulse to decorate, whether by appeasing the gods with magical signs or by using false shutters to personalize tract houses. The universal appeal of ornament is precisely its ''uselessness.'' Because ornament does not hold things up or make things work, it is essentially free: free to move the eye, to intrigue the mind, to rest the soul; free simply to delight.

title: AN ALL-WEATHER CHANNEL?
description: Richard Zoglin is the television critic for The Atlanta Constitution. ATLANTA Television may not exactly have invented the weather, but there's little doubt that the medium has helped make it a star. The smiling weatherman has become a fixture on local TV newscasts across the country; the weather segment typically consumes more time than the biggest news story of the day; and stations are acquiring more and more elaborate technology, from satellite pictures to color radar, to bring viewers the ''complete'' weather picture.

title: NEW SOVIET AFGHAN BASES SEEN AS PERIL TO GULF
description: United States military analysts and Middle Eastern diplomats say the Soviet Union has nearly completed six airfields in southern Afghanistan that will put the Persian Gulf within range of Soviet jet fighters.

title: WHAT AILS TODAY'S BROADWAY MUSICAL?
description: It seems like only a faint memory now, but there actually was a time when it was a joyous experience to go to a Broadway musical. You'd dash down Shubert Alley with the cocky assurance that you were in for a lift. There was the ecstatic anticipation of hearing a rousing overture, of feeling that electric charge that comes when the house lights dim, of watching the curtain rise on performers who would sing and dance their hearts out. And if the show proved to be ''Bajour'' instead of ''My Fair Lady,'' you wouldn't feel heartbroken, just disappointed. A bad musical could be laughed off like a junky movie.

title: HERE'S A SURPRISE: WE NEED TEACHERS AGAIN
description: Opening his newspaper one morning recently, James Ward, director of research for the American Federation of Teachers in Washington, was hardly surprised to discover a news item noting that school officials in Alexandria, Va., had been caught off guard by the size of the sudden upswing in the number of children entering kindergarten and first grade.

title: NEW TAX PACKAGE PREPARED BY CITY TO CUT BUDGET GAP
description: The Koch administration has prepared a ''menu'' of proposed new taxes and tax increases on commuters, theater and movie tickets, taxi medallions, automobile registration and leaded gasoline, City Hall officials said yesterday.

title: STEVENSON KNOCKS OUT BRIGGS
description: Reno, Nov. 13 - Tyrell Biggs had said he wasn't impressed by Teofilo Stevenson. The three-time Olympic gold medalist was a onepunch fighter, Biggs said, and although he had a right hand that had been perfected, a clever fighter could beat him.

title: Publisher of The Times Is Honored by Columbia
description: One of Columbia University's highest honors, the Alexander Hamilton Medal, will be given to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times and chairman of The New York Times Company, the university announced.

title: A 'SMOOTHIE' CATCHING EYE OF AFRIKANERS
description: A relatively junior Cabinet minister with a reputation for not taking sides in the governing party's burning debates is widely regarded here as the man most likely to succeed P.W. Botha as South Africa's Prime Minister.

title: MENOTTI'S 'SAINT'
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, the operatic composer, will direct the production of his ''The Saint of Bleecker Street'' to be performed at 8 P.M. Saturday in Klein Memorial Auditorium, Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport.

title: GUITAR RECITAL: NARCISO YEPES
description: Narciso Yepes's concert in Carnegie Hall Thursday night tried hard to balance the big with the little. The ingredients, indeed, came in all sizes -a small Spanish man, his oversized 10-string guitar, music ranging from triviality to sizable substance, and all of this set in a hall designed more for symphony orchestras than for one man playing a relatively reticent instrument.

title: ALTHENA SMITH, PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Alathena Johnson Smith, a clinical psychologist internationally noted for her work with deaf children and their parents, died here Friday. She was 88 years old.

title: THE DEPARTMENT THAT WOULD NOT DIE
description: THE United States Department of Education has been in death row ever since Ronald Reagan became P resident, but Congress continues to stay its execution. As its fate h angs in the balance, friends and foes push in opposite directions - s upporters hoping to keep it alive until a Democratic Administration g ives it a more active role; the opponents to let the ax fall while M r. Reagan is in the White House.

title: CAPITALS SEND ISLANDERS TO 2D LOSS IN A ROW, 3 TO 1
description: The Islanders lost their second consecutive game tonight, by 3-1 to the Washington Capitals in Capital Centre. The defeat followed a 2-0 loss to the North Stars Thursday in Minnesota.

title: MAKING PUNISHMENT FIT FUTURE CRIMES
description: There has been a quiet revolution in the notion of what prisons are for. The criminal justice community has finally conceded that serving time does not rehabilitate criminals and that the threat of lengthy sentences does not deter crime.

title: ROBERT BENTON BREWS THRILLS AFTER 'KRAMER'
description: ''You find yourself in a trap if you do the thing that people expect you to,'' said Robert Benton thoughtfully. ''It seemed to me that I should go about as far away from 'Kramer' as I could with my next film.''

title: Water Pollution From Dams Is Ruled State Responsibility
description: Water pollution caused by dams is subject to regulation by the states, not the Federal Government, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: SUBURBIA MIRRORED
description: A suburban-style Pathmark supermarket opens today as the anchor of a new shopping mall in South Brooklyn that will have space for parking 410 cars.

title: Britain's Best
description: To the Editor: Readers are, no doubt, deluging you with their personal favorites to be added to Erica Brown's collection of sites included in ''Britain's Best on Exhibit'' (Travel, Oct. 17). Here are our choices:

title: NATURAL SCIENTISTS GAIN, SOCIAL SCIENTISTS LOSE
description: FOR 15 years University of Michigan researchers have watched the s ame 5,000 families go through marriages, divorces, births, deaths, r elocations and unemployment as they studied how family background a ffects income. When Reaganomics began to chip into university r esearch budgets and endanger the project, private foundations agreedt o give temporary support to this $1 million-a-year undertaking, but o nly because researchers are betting on the Federal Government to r esume financing for it.

title: No Headline
description: A quilt is about nothing if it is not about time. Artists who haven't time for quilts should not make them, and leave the recognition to those who do. ANN RALPH, New York City

title: GENERAL MOTORS: A GIANT IN TRANSITION
description: John Holusha is chief of the Detroit bureau of The New York Times. The robot arm bowed to the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, then swung around and did the same to Dr. Seiuemon Inaba, the president of Fujitsu Fanuc Ltd. Turning again, the unmanned machine reached forward, electric motors humming, and neatly snipped a ribbon in two, ceremonially opening the Troy, Mich., headquarters of the GMFanuc Robotics Corporation, the new company that G.M. hopes will become as prominent among industrial robots as G.M.'s Chevrolets once were on highways.

title: EASED STANDARDS FOR F.H.A. LOANS
description: EASED Federal standards for new houses eligible for G overnmentinsured mortgages have been put into place by the D epartment of Housing and Urban Development, but they are stirring l ittle builder interest in the tristate region.

title: JOHN HENRY 3D
description: Of the eight trainers who sent their runners against John Henry in the Meadowlands Cup tonight, only Bobby Frankel dared to predict that his horse, Mehmet, would beat the richest horse who has ever raced. And Frankel's prediction was right.

title: Peter Raymond to Wed Anne Willcox
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Lewis of Malvern, Pa., and Mount Desert, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lewis's daughter, Anne Keating Willcox, to Peter Dana Raymond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Merriam Raymond of New York and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Correction
description: In a letter from James McNally (Oct. 31), statistics for the Russian and Finnish losses in the 100 Day or Winter War were incorrectly cited. The pertinent sentences in Mr. McNally's letter should have read: ''The Society of Military History, Helsinki, states that the U.S.S.R. reported its losses as 217,500 men. ... It reported Finnish losses as 22,900 dead or missing.''

title: Intramural Sports As Healthy Alternative
description: An article in the issue of Oct. 17, ''Scholastic Sports Restored by Town,'' suggests that the press, and therefore the public, are still being misled on this subject.

title: OLD YOUNG WAUGH
description: CHARLES RYDER'S SCHOOLDAYS And Other Stories. By Evelyn Waugh. 292pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. Cloth, $12.95 Paper, $5.95

title: Greenwich Tops Westhill by 27-7
description: For the second year in a row, the Greenwich High School football team assured itself of a berth in the Fairfield County Conference championship game on Thanksgiving morning when it beat Westhill, 27-7.

title: RELIGIOUS IMPERATIVES AND MORTAL DESIRES
description: RABBIS AND WIVES, By Chaim Grade. Translated by Harold Rabinowitz and Inna Hecker Grade. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Colleen O'Brien Is Wed
description: Colleen Blanche O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. O'Brien Jr. of New London, N.H., was married yesterday in Newton Centre, Mass., to Jeffrey Arnold Clopeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Clopeck of Framingham, Mass. The Rev. James Burns performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart. The bride is supervisor of nursing at the Lane Health Clinic at Northeastern University. Mr. Clopeck is an associate with the Boston law firm of Herrick & Smith.

title: Miss Obuchowski Plans Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Chester W. Obuchowski of Manchester, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Janice Irene Obuchowski, to Albert Philip Halprin, son of George Halprin of Scarborough Manor, N.Y., and the late Julia Adams.

title: PLAYING COMEDY IS NO LAUGHING MATTER
description: For five years, from 1950 to 1954, a television program called ''Your Show of Shows,'' starring Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca, with Carl Reiner and Howard Morris, dominated the Saturday night viewing habits of millions of Americans. For many viewers, that show still represents television comedy at its funniest and most inventive.

title: AUTHOR CELEBRATES COLLECTION OF STORIES
description: KATINKA LOESER'S twin cats are featured on the dust jacket of the writer's third collection of short stories, ''A Thousand Pardons,'' which was published in September by Atheneum. A pristine pair, they have appeared in print in The New Yorker and elsewhere before, but only two months ago did they become cover cats. At that time, the author was warned that there would be no holding them now.

title: JILL KREMENTZ CARVES A NICHE
description: In 1961 Jill Krementz traded her sewing machine for a friend's Kodak Brownie. She used the camera to snap tourist-type photographs on a trip around the world, which she paid for with $1,000 in savings from her job as a Girl Friday.

title: 'FARM' INTO OFFICES
description: Her turn-of-the-centry brick chateau has been demolished, her fenced dog runs are gone and by the end of next year a portion of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge's 384-acre estate in Madison, N.J., will become the home of the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: LICENSES FOR HOME-SECURITY OPERATORS?
description: THE home-security business is growing so rapidly in New Jersey that i t is spawning what some established practitioners call ''weekend w arriors'' - part-time alarm-system installers operating out of the t runks of their cars who have no capacity to provide continuing s ervice on the systems they sell.

title: SOME NEWSPAPERS OPPOSING A.P. FEE CHANGE
description: A plan by The Associated Press to change the fee structure for newspapers using its news services is being challenged by some of the newspapers, which say they cannot afford the sharply higher rates.

title: CITY U. ALSO BESTOWS HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMAS
description: A 69-year-old woman entered Queensborough Community College last year to attend to some unfinished business. ''I saw an advertisement for a high school equivalency program while standing on line at my bank,'' she said. ''On impulse I went and earned my diploma. I never leave things undone, so I decided to do it.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jan Merrill of Waterford, Conn., who holds the women's American record for 5,000 meters, has entered the United State cross-country championships that will be held Nov. 28 at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. ... Don Hardeman, a running back who formerly played with the Houston Oilers and Baltimore Colts, and Kris Haines, a wide receiver who played the last three years with the Chicago Bears, have signed contract with the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League. Haines was obtained in a trade with the Chicago Blitz of the U.S.F.L. ... After many weeks of negotiations, the Golden State Warriors have signed Lester Conner, a guard from Oregon State who was their No.1 choice in the college draft.

title: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION: CUTS AND NEW REVISION
description: AS the Reagan Administration moves to revise vocational-education r egulations, officials in that field of schooling argue that Federal b udget cuts have crippled the development and expansion of programs a nd that any new legislation must provide funds in this and other e ducational fields.

title:
GARDENING;
A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT FOR ROOTS
description: FROM time to time we have referred to the undesirable effect of soil compaction on plant growth. However, we have not discussed the reasons for it. Since the fall is an ideal time to take measures to overcome compaction, this a good time for us to examine the problem.

title: VOTING RIGHTS LAW PROVOKES DISPUTE
description: Differing interpretations of the new voting rights law have provoked a sharp dispute between the Reagan Administration and civil rights groups.

title: Colgate's Role Is Questioned
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to take exception to Malcolm Moran's column about Colgate football (''Colgate's Victory'', The New York Times, Oct. 30). What has been gained when the president of a prestigious university makes a statement of principle and is then forced to reverse himself? What sense of priorities motivates a scholarathlete to threaten to transfer if he is not permitted to participate in a postseason tournament? Is this confrontation indicative of what has happened to the role of higher education in developing leadership and character?

title: Man Held in W. Virginia Confesses 31 Killings
description: A 34-year-old man who ''knows he did wrong and thinks he should pay for it'' has confessed killing 31 persons, a sheriff's corporal said today. They said many of the victims were professional men with whom he had sexual encounters.

title: BUILDING BRIDGES OF CLAY AND PAINT
description: WHEN the show ''Traditional Korean Pottery; Contemporary Korean Painting'' opens at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery on Tuesday it will mark the end of several journeys and the beginning of a new one. The new journey involves the opening of the East/West Institute for Art Studies, a recently established venture to promote cultural exchange between Korea and the United States and to provide a ''support system'' for the growing numbers of Korean artists, musicians and dancers in this country. The exhibition is its first event.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I are planning to visit the Leticia/Iquitos area of the Amazon, followed by a visit to Cuzco, Peru, in late January and early February. Your recent articles on the subject indicated that this is the rainy season. Please let us know how much rainfall we can expect: How many hours a day is it likely to rain; does it rain every day all day long? Should we postpone the trip to another month? - B.P., New York, N.Y. Answer:The western Amazon region between Iquitos, Peru and Leticia, Colombia is likely to have few, if any, lodges open during the rainy season (mid-October through mid-March), due to flooding of the river and its tributaries, according to a representative for Mountain Travel, an Albany, Calif. tour operator that offers expeditions in Peru. Last month, a traveler to Iquitos reported waiting out a torrential rain that lasted an hour. The rains usually come morning and afternoon but between April and October, the region's rains are frequently, but not always, described as drizzles. At Cuzco's 10,000 feet the rainy season, again October through March, means daily rain and mists.

title: DISCOVERING THE HIDDEN PARIS
description: One man's exoticism is another man's Hoboken. My theory is that Paris is a marvelous, extraordinary place for a visitor, on the condition that the city be treated like Cleveland or Bujumbura, Burundi. That means embracing its alienness, its exoticism and its vitality by running after what is both common and hidden.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: OLD FRIENDS RETURN
description: IT is the time of the year when every publisher of children's books is offering a reprint or a new edition of a favored classic. But Simon & Schuster, under its Wanderer imprint, has gone farther than most, with a whole series of new editions done in uniform format: gold lettering on leather-bound spines, marbleized end papers, medallionlike illustrations sunk into the front covers and good-sized type arranged spaciously on the pages, at the price of $14.95 each.

title: SPREADING RISK WITH COMMODITY FUNDS
description: THE recent flow of new commodity futures and options has drawn many n ew investors into these lively, but risky, markets, where one can m ake quick and large profits on relatively small cash outlays. These n ew products are also luring investors into the underlying c ommodities markets, where the risks are even greater.

title: LATIN AMERICAN SCHOLAR FIGHTS TO STAY IN U.S.
description: There is only one catch as Angel Rama, a Latin American scholar at the University of Maryland, sees it, and that is, in his words, Catch-28.

title:
THE REAGAN EFFECT;
TITLE I: HELPED OUT BY OLD FRIENDS IN CONGRESS
description: AT the Stowe middle school in St. Louis, just one of the Federal budget cuts in education this year has meant the elimination of an entire math program, the loss of a teaching position, a reduction in the number of students enrolled in remedial-reading classes and increased class sizes for other teachers. ''We were just beginning to see real achievement on the standardized-test scores among Title I students in remedial reading and math programs,'' said Edgar Burnett, principal at Stowe. ''Now we feel like we're being penalized.''

title: BILINGUAL FUNDS: A PROBLEM IN ANY LANGUAGE
description: WASHINGTON DWINDLING Federal financial support for bilingual education is putting limits on the service at a time when increasing numbers of youngsters need it, according to school officials.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Trains Delayed - On Purpose
description: Commuters on Conrail's New Haven line were both safe and sorry last week. Officials ordered all trains slowed to 55 miles an hour and stopped every 30 miles for inspection of potentially dangerous axles, adding up to an extra half-hour of traveling time in each direction.

title: IMPORTANT SAFETY STEPS TO FOLLOW WHEN USING A CHAIN SAW
description: AS an increasing number of homeowners turn to the use of wood for heating - at least as a source of auxiliary heating - more and more of them are using chain saws to cut their own firewood, as well as to prune and fell trees or heavy shrubs. Unfortunately, many who use these powerful saws injure themselves because of careless handling or ignorance of proper working procedures. More than 120,000 chainsaw-related injuries were reported last year, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: 5 Railroad Employees In Derailment Dismissed
description: The Illinois Central Gulf Railroad has dismissed five employees who were aboard a chemical-laden freight train that derailed in Livingston, La., and forced residents to evacuate the town. It was two weeks before the residents were able to return to their homes.

title: COLUMBIA WINS TITLE
description: Solomon Gayle's first-half goal enabled Columbia to defeat Cornell, 1-0, yesterday and win its fifth consecutive Ivy League soccer championship.

title: November 14, 1982
description: NONFICTION BERNARD SHAW AND ALFRED DOUGLAS: A Correspondence. Edited by Mary Hyde. 12 BEYOND THE COLD WAR: A New Approach to the Arms Race and Nuclear Annihilation. By E.P. Thompson. 7 BOLLINGEN: An Adventure in Collecting the Past. By William McGuire. 24 CHARLES BABBAGE: Pioneer of the Computer. By Anthony Hyman. 26 5001 NIGHTS AT THE MOVIES: A Guide from A to Z. By Pauline Kael. 9 GERALD SCARFE. 31 ISAK DINESEN: The Life of a Storyteller. By Judith Thurman. 1 MARSHALL: Hero for Our Times. By Leonard Mosley. 18 POUND/FORD: The Story of a Literary Friendship.Edited by Brita Lindberg-Seyersted. 13 RAOUL WALLENBERG: Angel of Rescue. By Harvey Rosenfeld. 16 THE SECOND LIFE OF ART: Selected Essays. By Eugenio Montale. 12 THOMAS MANN DIARIES 1918-1939. Edited by Hermann Kesten. 13 WALL-TO-WALL AMERICA: A Cultural History of Post-Office Murals in the Great Depression. By Karal Ann Marling. 9 WHEN THE GOING WAS GOOD! American Life in the Fifties. By Jeffrey Hart. 16 FICTION CHARLES RYDER'S SCHOOLDAYS: And Other Stories. By Evelyn Waugh. 25 A CRY IN THE NIGHT. By Mary Higgins Clark. 15 FLIGHT OF CRANES. By Christine Bruckner. 14 FORGIVING. By Shelley List. 14 GILLYFLOWER KID. By Christine Bruckner.14 GOODBYE, MICKEY MOUSE. By Len Deighton. 15 GOOD GOODS. By Phyllis and Richard Kluger. 14 LIFE SENTENCES. By Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. 14 RABBIS AND WIVES.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: MARY HIGGINS CLARK of Washington Township has written four bestselling mystery novels since 1974, including her latest, ''A Cry in the Night'' (Simon and Schuster, $13.95).

title: THE AMERICANIZING OF JAPAN'S CARS
description: generation Celica in 1978, consumers were attracted by its fuel economy, the reputation of Japanese quality and by the car's sporty good looks, which were something of a departure from the more austere model that preceded it.

title: STAGE: 'FINDING DONIS ANNE'
description: Child abuse is the underlying subject of Hal Corley's ''Finding Donis Anne'' at the Ark Theater Company. The play suffers from irresolution that is clearly a case of playwright neglect. Mr. Corley seems unwilling to confront the psychological disability of his central character, an uneducated poor-white Southern woman who is trying to find her runaway teen-age daughter, Donis Anne.

title: Chafee Opponent Concedes
description: Julius Michaelson, a former state attorney general who ran against Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island has conceded after a tally of absentee ballots showed the incumbent had an unofficial margin of 9,105 votes in a total of more than 343,000. Mr. Michaelson, a Democrat, conceded in a letter to his Republican opponent Wednesday.

title: Christine Dillon Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Dillon of Sea Girt, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine J. Dillon, to Francis X. McCarthy Jr., son of Mrs. McCarthy of Darby, Pa., and the late Mr. McCarthy.

title: A TALE OF TWO RABBITS
description: THE COMPLETE ADVENTURES OF PETER RABBIT Written and illustrated by Beatrix Potter. Foreword by Anne Emerson. 95 pp. New York: Frederick Warne & co. $9.95.THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT And Other Stories By Beatrix Potter. Illustrated by Allen Atkinson. 141 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf $16.95.

title: CUOMO APPOINTS 15 TO COMMITTEE TO SEEK TO FILL ADMINISTRATION JOBS
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday named 15 volunteers - among them leaders in business, labor, medicine and religion - to his transition advisory committee.

title: PUBLISHERS TO HEAR ONE OF LARGEST CRITICS
description: HIS invitation to be the closing speaker at a three-day management conference of the Association of American Publishers frankly came as a surprise to Leonard Shatzkin. It might also surprise some of the 450 middle- and upper-management representatives of the book publishers' trade association meeting at the Rye Town Hilton tomorrow through Wednesday.

title: HEAVY METAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sherwin D. Smith is an editor of The New York Times Magazine.

title: WORD AWAITED ON WALESA'S LOCATION
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity union movement, was released from internment today, the authorities said, but his whereabouts remained a mystery.

title: Sports of The Times; First Aid for Oiler Defense
description: AFTER the Edmonton Oilers sprang a leak in the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, their coach, Glen Sather, suggested he would go to the end of the earth to find new defenders.

title: Cemetery Sale
description: Reasoning that New York City ''should not be in the business of running a cemetery,'' the city's Department of General Services said last

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: ARMCHAIR TRAVELER Mark Twain summed up one school of literary thought when he said, "War talk by men who have been in a war is always interesting; whereas moon talk by a poet who has not been in the moon is likely to be dull." But perhaps the predominant view was expressed by John Updike, who in a recent interview in the New York Times said, "Ideally, it seems to me a writer sitting in New England should be able to write a perfectly persuasive novel about slum life in Mexico City." Anthony Grey would no doubt second Mr. Updike's position, for he wrote his new 789-page novel, "Saigon," without ever visiting Vietnam.

title: U.S. REPORTS WATER SUPPLIES AT HIGH LEVELS IN MOST AREAS
description: The country's water supplies are generally at good levels, although low readings in some areas have been recorded in the last month, the United States Geological Survey has reported.

title:
DINING OUT;
NOW, IF YOU'RE FOND OF FONDU ...
description: MUCKING about in a pot of molten cheese fondue with cubes of bread speared on long-handled forks is one of life's simple pleasures, one that's fun to revive now and then. An excellent version can be found at Auberge Swiss, where the fondue is an authentic concoction of bubbling Gruyere, white wine and kirsch, and can be accompanied by a chilled bottle of Fendant or Ermitage, the fruity white Swiss wines.

title:
PERSPECTIVES;
THE 'FRILLS' MAKE SCHOOLS MEMORABLE
description: LAST year, according to my records, I spent somewhere between the cost of a week on the Riviera and a new mid-size car on my children's public education.

title: NEW YORKERS MAY PAY MORE, GET LESS
description: THE news from City Hall is rarely good this time of year, as the onerous need to balance the budget makes it impossible for politicians to carry out the more pleasant tasks of their trade - announcing a new program, a construction project or, albeit infrequently, a cut in taxes. But this year the tidings are downright grim, as was apparent from last week's developments.

title: ALBANY'S IN A SQUEEZE, TOO
description: NEW YORK CITY got a helping hand from Albany when its budget went bust in 1975, but it may get the cold shoulder this year. Beset with a deficit Governor Carey has estimated at $579 million in the current fiscal year and up to $1.8 billion in the next one, the state got another jolt last week when credit ratings on its bonds and notes were lowered.

title: METEORITES LINKED TO MARS AND MOON
description: Two pieces of Mars and one piece of the moon may have been found lying on clear blue ice west of McMurdo Sound in Antarctica.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IS it possible the spirits of Connecticut statesmen of yesteryear are less than enchanted with the modern-day politicians making use of Hartford's historic Old State House? Devotees of the occult may want to theorize about the apparent jinx that continues to bedevil candidates utilizing the stately building that was first used in 1796.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: War Re-Creation This being a ''sweep'' period, that is, when the ratings services size up the home audience each network is attracting, the networks, seeking impressive numbers, put a good foot forward. In CBS's case this week, it's a bit more than a foot: a cast of 6,100, more than 100 horses and a production budget estimated between $16 million and $18 million have all been enlisted to fight the Civil War again.

title: Prime's Time
description: British officials would probably love to be able to say that painstaking spycraft helped them ferret out Geoffrey Arthur Prime, who sold secrets to Moscow for a decade. But the fact is, Mr. Prime's wife squealed on him.

title: 17 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named nine restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and nine that were closed for failing to do so.

title: Claudia Wallis Will Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wallis of Wilton, Conn., of the engagement of his daughter, Claudia Kay Wallis, to Hugh O'Neill Pynchon Osborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neill Osborn of Haverford, Pa.

title: No Headline
description: MCENROE WINS, OFFERS ADVICE ON CALLS

title: CLEMSON HOLDS OFF MARYLAND RALLY AND WINS, 24-22
description: Clemson, taking a seemingly safe 24-7 lead with less than 12 minutes remaining, staggered and stumbled to a 24-22 victory today over Maryland. The Tigers, last year's national champions, thus clinched at least a tie for the Atlantic Coast Conference championship and an almost sure bid to a postseason bowl.

title: DARTMOUTH GIVES SOBERING LESSONS ON DRINKING
description: It was 7:30 on a Wednesday night and David Stern, a senior at Dartmouth College, was in a dormitory lounge talking to about 30 other students about drinking.

title: COSTA RICA MOVES TO CLOSE DOOR TO FUGITIVES
description: Costa Rica's new President is moving to reverse his country's reputation as a good place for North Americans to escape the law.

title: DOUG KOTAR IS BACK HOME WITH HIS FAMILY
description: white smoke from the several chimneys of a chemical factory rising into the black and crimson sky.

title: KNICKS STOP PISTONS, 112-100
description: The three players whom the Knicks acquired during the offseason in the free-agent market demonstrated last night why the Knicks had pursued them so vigorously.

title: Celia Ann Nelson Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Moses Nelson of Brightwaters, L.I. of the engagement of their daughter, Celia Ann Nelson, to Michael Evan Avidon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob S. Avidon of Brooklyn principal and officer of the Domus Inspection and Appraisal Service,

title: Linda Joselow and Martyn Straw Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Morris Joselow of Westwood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Joselow, to Martyn Leslie William Straw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Straw of Leicester, England.

title: CUOMO'S AD MAN BESTS THE EXPERTS
description: THE public contest was between Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Lewis E. Lehrman, but behind the scenes there was another contest - that of a 34-year-old Long Islander against two of the giants of the political advertising business, David Garth and Roger Ailes.

title: THE FOX IS ON THE TOWN
description: Fox is the glamour fur this winter. As though to underscore its heightened prominence, Yves Saint Laurent opened his fall and winter fur collection by showing nine coats in fox - black and white fox, red fox, silver fox, natural cross fox - and four mohair ponchos with fox trim.

title: HARNESSING WIND TO GENERATE POWER FOR HOMES
description: MICHAEL Scaviola, an automotive manager for United Parcel Service, h as long been fascinated by windmills, and, prompted by Federal tax c redits for energy saving devices, he installed a 100-foot tower and w ind turbine outside his large ranch-style home in Prospect, Conn.

title: Reagan Officially Recognizes 1992 World's Fair in Chicago
description: President Reagan has granted official recognition to a 1992 World's Fair to be held in Chicago.

title: TRANSMISSION LINE NEEDED TO PROVIDE LOW-COST POWER
description: THE county's search for low-cost electric power, which moved a step closer to reality with the recent establishment of a county utility agency, will depend ultimately on construction of a new high-voltage line carrying that power southward.

title: LIFE FOR IBSEN'S 'GHOSTS'
description: TARRYTOWN YOU have to go a long way to pump some life into Ibsen's ''Ghosts,'' an intimidating classic that, for some most mysterious reason, has been too much with us of late.

title: PENN BEATS HARVARD ON A KICK
description: Dave Shulman, given a second chance, kicked a 27-yard field goal with no time left today to give Pennsylvania a 23-21 victory over Harvard and at least a tie for the Ivy League championship.

title: Open Door Started By Ossining Residents
description: Betsy Brown's recent feature on Project LIFE (''Five Begin New Life in House for Elderly,'' Oct. 3) highlighted some of the important aspects of this innovative shared-housing program for senior citizens in Ossining, however, it contained an error that needs to be corrected.

title: CHARTING NEW COURSES
description: HARTFORD FOR the last few years, Christopher J. Dodd and Toby Moffett had been almost a matched pair - prominent Connecticut Democrats of similar ages, views and votes in the House of Representatives, promising political futures, and occasional basketball teammates in the House gymnasium.

title: RAMAPO: THE LUMINOUS ART OF BLUEMNER
description: MAHWAH FROM 1916 to 1926, New Jersey served as the stamping ground for Oscar Bluemner, the Modernist painter who died in 1938. Bluemner specialized in vignettes of New Jersey locales, simplifying to basic forms the views he observed. At the same time, he overlaid these views with an intriguing symbolism.

title: WHY WE LIVE WHERE WE LIVE
description: ''WE looked at this house ...'' ''We saw this house ...'' However they said it, the first years we lived in the county the line seemed to be virtually the ticket of entry to our home. The house had been on the market for more than a year; been empty for several months when we came along. Touring it seemed to have been a local obligation somewhere in the order of importance with attending the parade opening Little League season and the caroling accompanying the lighting of the village Christmas tree. A nation of voyeurs, we apparently feel the next best thing to seeing how people live in strange houses is seeing the strange houses themselves.

title: CHURCHES EXAMINE GENETIC RESEARCH
description: Christians often sing a hymn that says, ''New occasions teach new duties, time makes ancient good uncouth,'' and nowhere is this more evident than in the field of social ethics and the new biological technology.

title: A LENS ON THE ELECTION
description: The election, like most, was characterized by cross currents, rip tides and whirlpools that deserve attention - including a blow to Reaganomics, a Democratic landslide missed by a hair, and traces of a missing election with profound future implications.

title: Margaret E. Moffitt a Bride
description: Margaret Elizabeth Moffitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Middleton Moffitt of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Roderic Warren Rahe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rahe of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James E. Annand performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church. Mr. Rahe is legislative director for Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Fairfield County. His mother is co-publisher of the New York Theater Critics' Review and Theater Information Bulletin in New York.

title: MEDIEVAL COWBOYS
description: Knights really did clank along the roads of Europe in the Middle Ages, armed not to the teeth, but to the tops of their heads-cowboys to be sure, but with a mythic power that springs from their romantic ideals, their deliberate search for violent and heroic encounters', their sense of brotherhood, their commitment to vows as binding as those of religion, and their total freedom from the normal rules of society. Julek Heller and five other artists bring medieval European knights to life in paintings and drawings in this book; and Deirdre Headon skilfully retells the quests of the most famous ones.

title: OPERATORS AT THREE MILE ISLAND DUE TO TESTIFY
description: The civil trial to place responsibility for the 1979 nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania enters its third week tomorrow in Federal District Court in Manhattan, and the operators who were on duty at the time of the accident are expected to testify later in the week.

That newcomer so unenthusiastically awaited was neither a dullard nor a troublemaker but a ''gifted child.'' And my appeal to heaven was not for help in dealing with the child but with the parents. Experience has taught me that parents of bright children coming to us have an exaggerated view, which we are not likely to share, of the abilities and potential of their offspring, and they expect certain accommodations for them that we are not disposed to give.

title: Making Schools Work For Students
description: Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola of the Board of Education claimed in his article ''Making Schools Work for Students'' (Sept. 26) that young people have suffered disproportionately from budget cuts because they do not vote or make campaign contributions and thus ''do not have to be taken into account.'' This is true, but does not have to remain so.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
GOOD THINGS COME IN TWOS
description: HERBERT ROWBARGE By Natalie Babbitt. 216 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 14 and Up)

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PARIS
description: Winter is still The Season in Paris, its glitter undimmed in this second year since the Socialists came to power. It's hard for the visitor to see signs that the wealthy are any less wealthy or, for that matter, ostentatious, or that life has become more sober. Mercedes, Rolls Royces and even the odd Cadillac or two still line up outside Maxim's at lunchtime or in the evening outside Le Doyen and Laurent, almost opposite each other in the gardens at the bottom of the Champs-Elysee. The windows of the jewelers in the Place Vendome and the fourreurs and couturiers along the Faubourg St. Honore glisten and gleam with their expensive displays as Christmas approaches.

title: YALE CANCELS GAME AFTER 30 YEARS
description: NEW HAVEN HUNDREDS of students wearing multi-colored shirts surged across the Old Campus of Yale University in New Haven a week ago Friday, trying to capture a huge, inflated ball that bounced high above their heads.

title: TULIP, JULEP, SLOSHES, GALOSHES
description: AS a teacher, I annually encounter students who explain, belligerently and/or apologetically, that they hate and/or cannot understand poetry. Some of the same individuals who will leap gamely into ''Moby Dick'' are paralyzed by a tiny verse by Emily Dickinson. What happens between toddlerhood, when children enjoy nursery rhymes and fairy tales equally, and late adolescence? One answer may be that young children most often encounter huge quantities of narrative fiction, in ascending degrees of sophistication, but very little poetry - and that little bit is mainly sappy and sentimental. By the time teen-agers hit ''real'' poetry in high school, they simply do not know how to read it. The obvious remedy is to offer kids plenty of real poetry, by which I mean poetry that is actually too hard for them but so exciting they don't notice.

title: CONDO PROJECT SET FOR GLEN COVE PARK
description: GLEN COVE PEOPLE fish and go swimming at Garvies Point, despite the background of rusted refrigerators and an abandoned barge. Couples park there at night. Gangs of youths have fought out their differences there.

title: NEW ROCHELLE PARADE
description: While it does not pose a threat to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York City, the New Rochelle Thanksgiving Parade, now in its 21st year, is the only one in Westchester, and it draws thousands of spectators from all parts of the county.

title: A DUTIFUL FAREWELL, AN ORDERLY SUCCESSION
description: MOSCOW THE lines formed on the Rozhdestvensky Boulevard more than a mile from the House of Unions. From there, six abreast, among the factories and institutes, the mourners moved briskly between ranks of militiamen and soldiers around the boulevards and down Pushkin Street.

title: Evils of Racing Immature Horses
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing in response to Dr. James Belden's article on thoroughbred racing injuries (''Why, Racing Fans Ask, Must Horses Be Destroyed?'', The New York Times, Oct. 31).

title: THOUGHTS ON AGING UNCOMPLAININGLY
description: INEVER knew my grandfathers but my first recollection of my grandmothers had to do with their immobility. They always seemed to be sitting, one in her stiff, hard chair waiting for her grandchildren's perfunctory kiss. The kiss was a greeting, a ritual that always began her visits to our house. More than anything else I recall that her lips looked like two thin blue pencil lines and when I kissed her I had the sensation of just touching loose flesh.

title: Cut in College's Aid Imperils The Antioch Literary Review
description: The Antioch Review, a prestigious literary journal published since 1941, may fold because of money problems, its editor says.

title: Bergen Catholic Is Victor in Paramus
description: Mike Morgan, the state's leading scorer, scored two touchdowns yesterday to lead Bergen Catholic to a 13-3 victory over Paramus in Paramus. Morgan has scored 144 points this season.

title: Settlements of $4.7 Million Awarded in Jonestown Deaths
description: A judge has ordered the court-appointed receiver for the People's Temple to pay $4.7 million in church assets to 578 relatives of cult members and survivors of the 1978 mass suicide and murders at Jonestown, Guyana.

title: NEW BUILDING IS STATE'S TALLEST
description: HARTFORD SINCE 1919, the Traveler's Tower has laid claim to the distinction of being the tallest building in Connecticut. That boast will become passe at 12:15 P.M. on Tuesday.

title: REPRODUCTIVE ILLS OF WOMEN ON THE INCREASE
description: NEWARK INCREASING numbers of Newark women in their 20's are suffering major reproductive health problems, ranging from ectopic pregnancies - in which the fertilized egg implants itself outside the ovary - to sterility.

title: City Playoffs Postponed
description: All four of yesterday's scheduled Public Schools Athletic League football semifinals were postponed by rain or wet ground and will be played today.

title: BAR TO CHINATOWN LUXURY UNITS
description: SOUTHEAST of Chinatown's core, in the shadow of the Manhattan B ridge, ramshackle, red-brick tenements stand row upon row. If the c ity has its way, real-estate developers will be able to build luxuryc ondominiums in this area, which has seen no new housing c onstruction for almost a century.

title: IN TODAY'S PHOTOGRAPHY, IMITATION ISN'T ALWAYS FLATTERY
description: Next to postmodernism, appropriation surely ranks as the most fashionable catchword in the lexicon of current art. Essentially the incorporation of someone else's imagery into one's own, appropriation is for some the hallmark of postmodernist art, since it calls into question modernist orthodoxy concerning originality as well as the entire notion of an avant-garde. But for an audience devoted to the sanctity of individual expression, which is to say the vast majority of photography's audience, appropriation looks a great deal like theft.

title: STOLEN CAT LEADS POLICE TO A BURGLARY SUSPECT
description: A stolen Abyssinian cat led the police to a suspect in burglaries that gathered $3 million worth of paintings, jewelry and antiques from 130 homes in affluent areas 30 miles south of here.

title: KEEPING HEILEMAN IN THE PACK
description: LA CROSSE, Wisc. IN his cluttered office by the banks of the Mississippi, Russell G. Cleary, president, chairman and chief architect of the House of Heileman, has made sure that one piece of paper does not get lost among the stacks.

title: REAGAN RECORD IN EDUCATION: MIXED RESULTS
description: Ronald Reagan entered the White House two years ago with a commitment to overhaul the Federal role in American education. ''Education,'' he told the country in a televised address, ''is the principal responsibility of local school systems, teachers, parents, citizen boards and state governments.'' In his view, two decades of proliferating Federal programs had seriously undermined this local control.

title: GOVERNORS TO ASK CONGRESS TO CURB ARMS SPENDING
description: The nation's governors will ask Congress to curb military spending unless a strong case can be made for the increases sought by President Reagan, the National Governors Association decided Friday.

title: STALKING THE COMMON COLD
description: This time of year, on the lip of England's Salisbury Plain, the north wind whistles through the weathered monoliths of Stonehenge. A few pilgrims brave the chill to visit this monument to man's ingenuity. They bundle up in woolen scarves and overcoats, then hurry home to a warm fire and a hot toddy to keep from catching cold.

title: BY STANLEY CARR
description: STANLEY CARR is assistant to the editor of the Travel section.

title: Dr. Anna Hopson, 58, Alcoholism Authority
description: Dr. Anna Lee Hopson Robinson, a clinincal psychologist and authority on alcoholism, died of cancer Friday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center.

title: TARGETING THE PENTAGON
description: President Reagan began his 14th news conference by listing the important events of the day - the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the fifth flight of the space shuttle, the return of Philip Habib to the Middle East. He did not mention a more immediately significant development.

title: ICP CELEBRATE EIGHT VITAL YEARS
description: The International Center of Photography, whose pioneering singlemindedness is embodied in its name, is eight years old this month, not a round-number milestone anniversary of the sort that warrants weighty festschriften by scholars, but one that will be marked in a fashion appropriate to a museum of what is still largely a living art. Each year, the center celebrates its birthday with a gala that introduces an exhibition of work by a living photographer - who this year will be the aged but very much alive Jacques-Henri Lartigue.

title: Asbestos Liability
description: Workers exposed to another toxic substance, asbestos, asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan last week to deny their employer's petition on the ground that it was an abuse of bankruptcy procedures.

title: DEMOCRACY IS MAKING A NEW IMPACT AT OXFORD
description: The winds of democratic change are blowing more freely than ever at venerable Oxford University. Having just absorbed the impact of going coeducational, the university is now hearing calls for a sweeping review of admissions procedures centered on a controversial proposal aimed at attracting more students from government-financed schools.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: WHAT are the effects of removing vast amounts of firewood from the state's woodlands each year? The first survey of deforestation and firewood use in New Jersey has found that 1,001,769 cords - enough to fill a 42-story building - were consumed last year and that 82 percent of it was used for major or supplemental sources of heat.

title:
SOVIET'S NEW ERA;
An era in Soviet history has obviously ended with the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev. We now await the unfolding of the succession process, which does not end with the appointment of Yuri V. Andropov as the new General Secretary of the Communist Party. The 1980's may well be decisive in determining the course of the conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union. The relationship will either move toward an accommodation or much closer to war. The odds are, however, that a superpower settlement of sorts will be reached.
description: The period of change in the Soviet Union will extend well beyond Ronald Reagan's Administration, even if he serves a second term. But Mr. Reagan occupies a pivotal position. As a conservative Republican, he can explore an accommodation with the Soviet Union without arousing a domestic backlash. He has a good chance of continuing the defense buildup that must form the backbone of any American foreign policy in the 1980's. After Mr. Brezhnev, the United States could easily pursue a policy of pressure on the Soviet Union's new leaders. Such a policy would force Mr. Andropov to dig in, if only out of self-preservation. It will take imagination and courage in Washington to introduce an element of conciliation.

title: 'ROMANTIC SPIRIT'
description: For its first ''Sunday at Seven'' concert of the season, tonight at Hofstra University, the American Chamber Ensemble plans to capture something of ''The Romantic Spirit'' by performing Brahms's Clarinet Quintet, Op. 115 and Schumann's Piano Quintet, Op. 44. The third work is even more suitable to the theme: ''Songs of Remembrance,'' Vally Weigl's song cycle for mezzo-soprano, clarinet and piano, based on the poetry of Emily Dickinson. Now 88 years old, Mrs. Weigl spent much of her life promoting the music of her husband, Karl, who died in 1949, and is finally coming into her own as a composer herself. In fact, the ensemble has received a grant to record ''Songs.''

title: TRIESTE, VICTIM OF GEOPOLITICS, FEELS BETRAYED
description: This city in a strip of Italian littoral between the Adriatic Sea and Yugoslavia feels more Italian, it seems, than many cities comfortably inside Italy, but also more alienated from Rome and its Government.

title: A 'CREATION' FOR THE CITY BALLET
description: A gala with a novel twist is coming up at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night. For the first time in the history of the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera, the two companies will join together in a performance given for the benefit of both of them. The program, which Jerome Robbins has helped to arrange, will feature vocal and choreographic selections to Verdi, Gluck, Lehar, Leonard Bernstein and Richard Strauss.

title: DAVID JOSEPH FITZMAURICE, 69, LEADER OF ELECTRICAL WORKERS
description: David Joseph Fitzmaurice, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers since 1976, died of cancer Friday night at Euclid General Hospital in Euclid, Ohio, where he lived. Mr. Fitzmaurice, who was 69 years old, was a vice president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: POP: PIERCE AND GUN CLUB
description: Jeffrey Lee Pierce's songs for the Gun Club's two albums tap blues and country music as sources for punk despair, reactivating old-time licks and lyrics about love, trains and the devil. It is a rude mix, callow and self-conscious at the same time.

title: NO END IS FORESEEN TO OCEAN DUMPING
description: Second of three articles The following article is based on reporting by Leo H. Carney and Karen Tortorella and was written by Mr. Carney.

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1982
description: International The U.S. lifted the trade sanctions it imposed on the American and other companies participating in the Soviet natural gas pipleline to Western Europe. President Reagan announced that he was doing so because the United States and its key allies had reached ''substantial agreement'' on an overall economic strategy toward the Soviet bloc. Mr. Reagan said the trade pact was ''a victory for the allies.'' But France announced that it ''was not a party to the agreement.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) The East-West trade pact that President Reagan linked to lifting the Soviet pipeline sanctions represented little in terms of new commitments by the United States' main European allies, Western European officials said. With one apparent exception -an undertaking not to sign or approve new contracts for the purchase of Soviet natural gas while studies are made - the pact covers areas where attempts have been made for years to coordinate Western policy. (1:6.)

title: THEATER: STORYTELLING BY THE MANHATTAN CLUB
description: Through the 1960's and 70's, the Free Southern Theater performed the valuable and sometimes dangerous service of bringing live theater to rural areas of the South. In the course of its travels, the company gathered stories from its audience, and some of them have been collected in ''Don't Start Me Talkin' or I'll Tell Everything I Know: Sayings From the Life and Writings of Junebug Jabbo Jones.'' The evening of storytelling, written by John O'Neal, Ron Castine and Glenda Lindsay, and delivered by Mr. O'Neal, is now playing in the Manhattan Theater Club's cabaret.

title: PUBLIC WORKS JOB PLANS ARE A CLEAR SUCCESS-POLITICALLY
description: On occasion, the winds of political necessity drive an idea like a brushfire. Last week, as politicians and political analysts returned to Washington on post-election visits, the words that leaped from mouth to mouth with astonishing speed were ''public works jobs.'' Copying machines whirred into the night as lawmakers from both parties cranked out proposals to spend billions of dollars creating jobs for the unemployed and goodwill for themselves.

title: ART
description: Kevin Cannon started working in leather in 1969, got into harnessand-saddlemaking, then moved out West to study American Indian art of the 1800's, particularly leather and silver work. He added ceramics to his interests in 1978, and did a stint as assistant to the noted West Coast ceramist and printmaker Kenneth Price.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
IT'S BEGINNING TO STRAIN A LOT LIKE CHRISTMAS
description: IT was a cool autumn day a month ago when my 5-year-old son and I set about the burdensome task of errand-running. Neither of us enjoy this chore but we were in good spirits - buoyed by the fresh, crisp weather.

title: Pax in Bello Captures Remsen
description: ''Nice ride,'' said Steve Jerkens, the winning trainer, with a big smile. ''Nice colt,'' said Jeff Fell, the winning jockey, with a bigger smile. They were in the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday, talking about Pax in Bello a few minutes after the Remsen Stakes. The first time that Fell saw the colt was when he got on his back yesterday afternoon, and it may have been the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

title: KENYAN FOSSIL FIND REPORTED
description: The paleontologist Richard E. Leakey has announced the discovery of new fossils that he said might contain the bones of distant ancestors of man.

title: Tax Evaders and the Banks
description: No one ever claimed that tax withholding on interest and dividends would be popular. On its face it makes payments seem smaller than savers and investors expect. Anticipating trouble, the nation's banks have fought the idea at every turn. But pressed by mounting budget deficits, Congress finally voted it in last summer. Regrettably, the banks are now trying to thwart it by stirring up public resentment at the very time they should be helping Washington get the process started.

title: Rhonda Ziegelmeier Wed
description: Rhonda Jane Ziegelmeier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Ziegelmeier of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Kent Brooks, son of Ralph F. Brooks of Greenwich, and the late Janet Abelhauser Brooks. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. The bride's father is president of the Haggerty Millwork Corporation in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The bridegroom's father is president of R.F. Brooks Inc., a Greenwich real estate firm.

title: CITY LOSES MOVE TO BAR RENT RISES IN PROJECTS
description: A Federal judge has dismissed an attempt by the Legal Aid Society and the New York City Housing Authority to block temporarily Federal rent increases for the nation's 3.5 million public-housing tenants, including 600,000 in New York City.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Staying On With a Pediatrician

title: CALIFORNIA FACING $3 BILLION BUDGET GAP
description: State and local governments in California face a deficit of $3 billion or more in the next 19 months, according to state officials, unless sharp reductions in spending or large tax increases are enacted.

title: 7 ACTORS IN SEARCH OF FARCE
description: THERE are six visible doors in ''Nurse Jane Goes to Hawaii'' - an observation that signals, straight away, the aspirations of the playwright, Allan Stratton, toward farce, that most elusive and difficult of all theatrical forms to pull off.

title: Week in Business; THE STOCK MARKET IN A STATE OF FLUX
description: The Dow fell just 11.86 points for the week, but it traveled a roller coaster to get there. The Dow alternated sharp slides and recoveries: It was down 14.34 points on Monday, up 22.81 on Tuesday, down 15.73 on Wednesday, up 10.21 on Thursday and down 14.81 on Friday. Volume was strong throughout the week. The Dow closed the week at 1039.92.

title: Dallas Pell to Be Wed Dec. 19
description: Nuala Dallas Pell, a literary agent with John Brockman & Associates in New York, and Eames Hamilton Yates, a senior production associate for ABC News Closeup Documentaries, plan to be married Dec. 19. The small family wedding will take place at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

title: BREZHNEV ERA AND BEYOND: THE LIMITS OF 'STABILITY'
description: THE death of Leonid Brezhnev marks the end of a long period of stability in Soviet internal affairs. Despite the apparent smoothness of the initial transition to Yuri V. Andropov, the beginning of a new era is likely to bring renewed conflict within the Soviet political establishment.

title: PITT'S EARLY OFFENSE STYMIES ARMY, 24-6
description: Army held Pittsburgh scoreless in the second half today, but Dan Marino had thrown three touchdown passes in the first half and they were more than enough for a 24-6 victory over the Cadets before a sellout crowd of 40,475 at Michie Stadium.

title:
DESPITE HISTORIC STATUS, OLD DAYLINER ROTS AWAY;
LEONARDO
description: DESPITE her status as a State Historic Site and her place on the National Register of Historic Places, the sidewheel steamer Alexander Hamilton -or what is left of her - lies rusting in 16 feet of water here.

title: FLATBUSH AVENUE TAKES ON NEW IDENTITY
description: THERE is nothing circuitous about Flatbush Avenue. It cuts a long and almost direct swath through thec enter of Brooklyn from the Manhattan Bridge to the Belt Parkway. A long the way, it passes neighborhoods that have been in flux for d ecades.

title: THE LIMITS OF URBAN GROWTH
description: FOR MOST OF ITS HISTORY, NEW YORK has carried on a romantic, not to say intimate, involvement with congestion. To be New York was to be crowded - out of crowding came energy, ideas, excitement, power. If traffic was a bit slower here than elsewhere, if the tall buildings gave you less sun and less sky than there was in Des Moines or Dallas - well, who really cared about moving fast once you were already here? And who came to New York in search of sun and sky, anyway?

title: POP: SARAH VAUGHAN RETURNS
description: Like most singers of pop songs, Sarah Vaughan seems more at home in the intimate atmosphere and close quarters of a club than in a concert hall or a large stadium. At Dangerfield's, First Avenue between 61st and 62d Streets, where, through next Saturday, she is making her first nightclub appearance in New York in three years, Miss Vaughan has such a confident command of the room that she makes her entrance not with an annunciatory flourish, but softly, sotto voce.

title: PREPS
description: Philips Andover salvaged one of its worst seasons when it defeated Philips Exeter, 17-6, in the l02d renewal of prep school's oldest continuous rivalry. It was the home team's first victory in seven games this year and it finished the year with the same record as Exeter: 1-5-1.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS ONCE upon a time, there was a magic house. Only it wasn't really a house, it was a room, a room in a big brick building. But size didn't matter, nor did the fact that it was in a psychiatric hospital. What mattered was the covenant that made it possible for a child to enter the house and act almost any way he wanted - to play with toys and other children and never have to worry about someone saying ''Don't'' or ''What did you mean by that.''

title: Carol A. Bassette Becomes Bride Of W.L. Schmidt
description: Carol Anne Bassette and Whitney Lawrence Schmidt were married yesterday in the First Church Congregational in Boxford, Mass. by the Rev. Stuart C. Nutter. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Buell L. Bassette of Boxford.

title: NASA WANTS CORPORATIONS TO HELP PAY THE FREIGHT
description: WHEN the Columbia's huge cargo-bay doors swung open Thursday, 184 miles out in space, the nation's space shuttle program was officially open for business. Four test flights over the last year and a half had proved that the winged spaceship could make repeated trips to and from orbit. On this fifth mission the shuttle hauled its first freight for paying customers, but it will take many more flights to prove whether the system is a sound economic venture.

title: TYLENOL TAKES THE OFFENSIVE
description: Johnson & Johnson's chairman, James E. Burke (left), said the company would resume selling Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules within a few weeks - but in triple-sealed, tamper-resistant packages. Mr. Burke said the company considered it ''a moral imperative, as well as good business'' to restore Tylenol's strong market share, lost after the death of seven people from Tylenol capsules that had been laced with cyanide. Mr. Burke said the company will absorb costs of about 2.4 cents per package to provide the new protection. Some 40 million coupons will be published to promote the product.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: MRS. HARRIS: The Death of the Scarsdale Diet Doctor. By Diana Trilling. (Penguin, $3.95.) For Diana Trilling, the Jean Harris case seemed the stuff of art, but our reviewer, Elinor Langer, thought the book succeeded as reportage. A best seller in hard-cover, ''Mrs. Harris'' now appears in paperback under two separate covers that express a slightly different dichotomy: The sedate, all-type version in purple, peach and white is designed, the publisher says, for ''those who recognize Mrs. Trilling's work as an enduring social document of our time,'' while the version that features photographs of the leading characters on a silvery background is for ''those drawn to the sensational aspects of this tale of love and revenge.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL SALE
description: The public auction sale of the United States Gold Coin Collection, which was held at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan on Oct. 27-29, was a glittering success and judging from the outcome, the longslumping coin market is now definitely on its way back up to the heights of former years.

title: Tamara Krendel To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ezra S. Krendel of Swarthmore, Pa., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Tamara Elizabeth Krendel, to David William Clark, son of Dr. James E. Clark and Mary Ellen Clark, both of Swarthmore.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of the Fall Survey of Education today, a chart on page 13 -''Who Qualifies for Federally Guaranteed Student Loans'' - incorrectly shows the average yearly cost at private universities. The figure should be $7,500.

title: DU PONT'S UNCONVINCING MERGER
description: TWO skirmishes marked the summer of 1981: The baseball strike and the battle that the pinstriped chairmen of Du Pont, Seagram and Mobil waged for control of Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company. The $7.8 billion corporate game - eventually won by Du Pont - caught the attention of Congressmen, academicians, financial analysts and editorial cartoonists, who all questioned the value of mixing together a major oil company and one of the country's largest chemical concerns.

title: No Headline
description: ARIZONA STATE IS BEATEN, 17-13

title: REPORTS ACCORD WITH ALLIES
description: President Reagan announced today that he was lifting sanctions against American and other companies participating in a Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe. He said he was doing so because the United States and its key allies had reached ''substantial agreement'' this morning on an overall economic strategy toward the Soviet bloc.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH IRONY, FRIVOLITY AND SUCH
description: Anyone who takes life seriously is likely, at unexpected moments, to have a spell of worrying about the ultimate questions. I, for instance, have occasionally found myself at a concert, tense and unable to sleep, pondering such eschatological perplexities as ''If God meant people to play the piano, why did he create them with weak fifth fingers?'' From there it is a short leap to dark musings such as ''Does a congenitally dull performer make a greater contribution to art by playing at a sane tempo or by buzzing frantically through the piece and getting it over with?'' And then, perhaps, it's on to decidedly marginally musical thoughts such as ''Is he going to bang away like this all night?'' and ''Is that his own hair?''

title: DANILOVA AND ASHTON SHED LIGHT ON THE PAST
description: Two films of dance interest - recently or currently on view - that deserve attention are ''Reflections of a Dancer: Alexandra Danilova, Prima Ballerina Assoluta'' and ''Frederick Ashton: A Real Choreographer.'' Produced and directed by Anne Bell, the Danilova film has just opened at the Public Theater and can be seen free of charge every Saturday and Sunday at 2 P.M. through Dec. 5. The Ashton film, written and produced by John Selwyn Gilbert, is seen periodically on Hearst/ABC's ARTS cable television service. ARTS will broadcast the Ashton ''Cinderella'' with the Royal Ballet next month (Dec. 20, 24, 27, 31) and while the program has a brief interview with Mr. Ashton, Richard Gale's interview in the Gilbert film has greater depth. Those who saw it last month might agree that Mr. Ashton's comments are more than a help in viewing even as accessible a ballet as ''Cinderella.''

title: UNCONVENTIONAL WISDOM; 'Quality Information'
description: For police seeking information on drug pushers to ask the public for it over the radio sounds naive. In fact, the idea is creative and, in Baltimore at least, vastly successful.

title: AS BRAZILIANS VOTE, MILITARY GETS TOUCHY ON 'REVENGE'
description: BRASILIA Awoman in a Rio de Janeiro supermarket stared disgustedly at some rotting apples in a bin beneath beneath a newly raised price one recent morning. ''This will stop,'' she announced, once Brizola is Governor.''

title: PROTECTING THE PINE-BARREN WATERSHED: NOT IF, BUT HOW
description: AGREEMENT abounds among elected officials and planners that protection of the Suffolk pine barrens is essential to assure future supplies of pure drinking water for the Island. There are conflicting views, however, on the methods by which protection can best be assured.

title: NEWARK DRIVE ON TRUANCY CALLED 'BIG SUCCESS'
description: Classroom attendance has improved by as much as 8 percent since a joint school and police task force began searching for truants in video game arcades, record stores and restaurants last March, officials say.

title: OWNERS WOULD RESUME TALKS ONLY TO CLARIFY OFFER
description: With the National Football League players' strike in recess for an eighth day, Jack Donlan told the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service yesterday that league negotiators would return to the bargaining table only to clarify contract language in their last offer to the Players Association.

title: Michael A. Jacobs to Wed Ellen Fuerst
description: The engagement of Ellen Laura Fuerst and Michael Allen Jacobs, seniors at the Yale University Law School, has been announced by Miss Fuerst's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Fuerst of Brooklyn. Mr. Jacobs is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerson Jacobs of Greenbrae, Calif.

title: Miss Morris Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Morris of Wilmington, Del., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lisa Morris, to Alan Levenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Levenson of Pittsburgh. A March 6 wedding is planned.

title: MOSCOW AFTER BREZHEW: WILL THE HAWKS GAIN?
description: T o the Editor: Your Nov. 3 editorial ''From Russia, With Worry'' correctly notes both the defensive tone in President Brezhnev's speech to the Soviet military two weeks before his death and the importance of the continued desire in Moscow for arms talks. However, there is more cause for worry about the speech than appears on the surface.

title: James John Brophy to Wed Bonnie Dixon Dec. 18
description: Bianca Chronowski Dixon and James John Brophy have announced their plans to be married Dec. 18 at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: IS WORKING YOUR WAY THROUGH STILL POSSIBLE?
description: Remember the old days, when one of the proudest statements a young adult could make was, ''I'm working my way through college''? Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan remembers. And a few months ago, Mr. Regan, a graduate of Harvard University, recalled those times in response to criticism of the Reagan Administration's proposed financial-aid cuts. ''I hate to seem old-fashioned and sort of square,'' he said, ''but there is a thing called working your way through school. I did it. It ain't easy, but you can do it.''

title: DIALECTICAL LONDON
description: R. V. DENENBERG, a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley, is a frequent contributor to the Travel section.

title: Future Events Wednesday's the Day
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Double Debut Nov. 17 - The Rockette Alumnae Foundation, in its 27th year of raising funds for charity, is initiating a series of fashion shows and luncheons under an invitation to ''Come Dance With Me.'' The first event in the Warwick Hotel Ballroom will introduce the George Stavropoulos ''Coming-Out Collection'' of evening classics, salute the debutante season and benefit the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Dancing models, including Elizabeth Bartlett, Fern Tailer Denney and their debutante daughters, Kimberley Bartlett and Tracy Denney, will be escorted by Peter Allen. Tickets are $50, from 838-7474.

title: HArd Numbers
description: The recession is one short-term thing wrong with Social Security. Fewer workers paying in the payroll tax makes for a smaller cash balance from which to pay out benefits.

title: 3 ON VIRGIN ISLANDS SENTENCED BY U.S.
description: In separate hearings today, two former high-ranking officials of the Virgin Islands government and a businessman were sentenced on charges of fraud, the latest step in a three-year Federal investigation of corruption in the territorial government.

title: HIS LIFE SPARED IN 3 KILLINGS, HE TELLS OF MORE
description: Gerald Eugene Stano, already serving time in prison for six murders, is continuing to confess additional killings of women and girls, according to the authorities here.

title: WAS HE THE GREATEST HAMLET?
description: Allen Churchill is the author of ''The Great White Way'' and ''The Theatrical 20's.''

title: RECIPIENT DIES 7 WEEKS AFTER LUNG TRANSPLANT
description: A 25-year-old Florida man who underwent a rare lung transplant seven weeks ago at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx died early yesterday, apparently of complications arising from the healing process.

title: Creative Quilting
description: Quilts are a touchy subject nowadays (''A New Kind of Quilt,'' by Dorothy Seiberling, Oct. 3). People fight over them at antiques fairs, while preservationists sue designers who cut them up into skirts and vests.

title: David J. Kramer to Marry Wendy Sue Philips in '83
description: The engagement of Wendy Sue Philips to David J. Kramer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Simon Kramer of Philadelphia, has neen made known by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Philips of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The wedding will be in February.

title: U.S. LISTS 5,639 SALVADOR DEAD
description: United States Embassy figures show that 5,639 people, nearly half of them civilians, have died violently in El Salvador since the beginning of the year, documents obtained today revealed.

title: Study Will Seek Drugs To Aid Bypass Patients
description: Ten hospitals and 1,100 patients will participate in a nationwide study to find drugs that could help reduce the 20 percent failure rate in heart bypass surgery.

title: Faintly Praised, Clearly Damned
description: President Reagan has ''full faith and confidence'' in his Ambassador in El Salvador, the White House said last week - so long as he keeps his voice down when criticizing right-wing goons and pliant judges.

title: TROUBLED CAMDEN SEEKS REVIVAL
description: CAMDEN THIS once-thriving city, which for a decade or more had been going downhill, is ''showing signs of coming back strong,'' Mayor Melvin R. Primas says.
