Although the only physical signs so far are lots that have been cleared of old houses, some areas where cleanup campaigns have succeeded and boarded-up houses awaiting rehabilitation, there is an even more-important sign, Mr. Primas said: A ''tremendous outpouring of support'' from business and industry.

title: POP: LUTHER VANDROSS
description: Luther Vandross, a former jingle singer who became a pop-soul superstar in the last year, possesses a smooth, low tenor whose mellowness of timbre, sureness of pitch, flexibility of phrasing and imposing power all suggest real operatic potential. Friday, at the first of two sold-out Radio City Music Hall concerts, Mr. Vandross turned in a crowd-pleasing performance highlighted by several extended ballad interpretations that enabled the singer to show off his formidable technical skills in a very operatic way.

title: FUNGUS FANS TAKE HEART, 'TIS TIME OF THE TRUFFLE
description: FRESH white truffles imported from Italy are in season from now until late winter. These odd brownish nobs should be shared only with those who love them, because they are one of the world's most expensive delicacies, running at around $30 to $35 an ounce in specialty stores. Those white-truffle fans for whom they're prized food seems priced out of reach can take heart, however. A small fungus weighing around a third of an ounce will run about $11. This, thinly shaved over pasta that has been cooked, tossed in cream and butter and sprinkled with freshly grated Parmesan cheese, or over risotto, is enough for two. If followed by a simple green salad and fruit, the cost of the meal will add up to about the same as if you had lamb chops, veal or even steak.

title: Punch Sober
description: After months of feinting and weaving around the issue, Sugar Ray Leonard entered the ring last week to announce that he wouldn't be climbing through the ropes again - at least not as a fighter.

title: N.F.L. STRIKE RECALLS OLD-TIME STRIFE
description: The professional football strike is being fought in a primitive way that, at times, smacks of the bitter American workplace disputes of the 1930's, 1940's and the early 1950's.

title: Creative Quilting
description: Dorothy Seiberling states that the quilter who made design decisions moved ''in on the artist's desmesne.'' Pshaw! Talented quilters have always been innovative designers.

title: COLLEGES OFFER MUSIC FREE OR AT LOW COST
description: IT may cost a fortune to send your kids to college these days, but it can be quite a bargain to go there yourself, since many universities are paying public dividends in the form of free or comparatively low-cost recitals, operatic performances, chamber programs and sundry other musical events.

title: CONCERT: VIENNESE STYLE
description: Because Viennese waltzes and operetta songs seem almost magical when played and sung with sensuous charm, this fan went to Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday ready to succumb once more to the lilt, wit and ardor of music as only Johann Strauss, Franz Lehar, Emmerich Kalman and Robert Stolz could write it. ICM Artists was presenting an ensemble called the Wiener Strausscapelle, and it seemed reasonable to expect excellence in this repertory from a Viennese group.

title: Levittown Division Triumphs For No. 16
description: Levittown Division, last year's Rutger's Cup champion, edged New Hyde Park, 14-13, yesterday for its 16th straight victory. Levittown took the early lead as Mike Galvin ran 23 yards for a touchdown and Mark Shermansky added the extra point in the first quarter.

title: JAZZ QUARTET: LES MCCANN AND LA VERNE
description: The use of two jazz groups on one bill, a standard practice in jazz clubs 15 and more years ago, has returned to Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, this week. The headliner is the veteran Les McCann Quartet, and the added attraction is Andy LaVerne's Paradise, a new instrumental trio with three singing women.

title: JUDGE DOUBTS HE'LL BAR HARRIMAN DEER HUNT
description: Renewed efforts by a group of preservationists against the deer hunting planned for this year in Harriman State Park have received a setback in State Supreme Court here.

title: BUDGET ILLS CRIPPLING DEFENSE OF POOR, LAWYERS SAY
description: Two years ago, Chester W. Fairlie, a lawyer in New London, Conn., agreed to represent an indigent black man accused of murder. He thought, he says, that he could manage both a murder case, his first, and his one-man private practice. Now, after more than 650 hours of work on the case at the state-paid rate of $12.50 an hour, the conviction of his client, the ruin of his practice and the liquidation of his savings, he realizes he was wrong.

title: IDIOSYNCRATIC SCULPTURE IN IDYLLIC GARDEN
description: THE ample lawn at 69 South Main Street in Essex slopes toward the harbor. In 1977, the sculptor John Chamberlain and his wife sailed into Essex harbor and spent the summer on their boat. Deciding to stay, they purchased the house and grounds at 69 South Main. Three and a half years later, Chamberlain moved to Florida. Twenty-four sculptures made out of crushed auto bodies stand on that lawn as the legacy of Chamberlain's residence.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: COURIER FROM WARSAW, by Jan Nowak. (Wayne State University Press, $24.95.) The World War II memoirs of a member of the Polish underground.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
LONELY MONSTER
description: THE GOLEM By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Illustrated by Uri Shulevitz. 85 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: Papal Marketing
description: Before Pope John Paul II visited Britain last spring, the Roman Catholic Church set up a corporation, Papal Visits Ltd., to license the manufacture and sale of souvenirs. The International Management Group in Cleveland was hired to handle the deals.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS NO LONGER FOR PRIVATE WEALTH
description: PRIVATE SCHOOLS are not just for wealthy youngsters anymore. Data m ay not be conclusive, but the impression is strong, based on a g eographic sampling of private schools, that the traditional elite c onstituency has changed decisively in the last decade to include m ore children of middle-class parents who are concerned primarily w ith the quality of education.

title: THE CONCISE PAULINE KAEL
description: 5001 NIGHTS AT THE MOVIES A Guide from A to Z. By Pauline Kael. 676 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $25.

title: Westlake (9-0) Captures Championship
description: Westlake finished its regular season with an undefeated record and the Conference B North championship by beating Byram Hills, 21-7. Coach Dino Garr's Wildcats ran their record to 9-0 and will play in a Section I bowl game next weekend. Westlake coasted to victory behind the passing and running of the quarterback Mike Jansen. Frank Filardo, the fullback, had two touchdowns.

title: WILL PRYOR TEMPT SUGAR RAY?
description: MIAMI IT'S now the fight that didn't happen, but it's also the fight that might still happen someday -Aaron Pryor against Sugar Ray Leonard for the world welterweight championship.

title: BOEING OFFERING NEW ANTI-ICING SYSTEM FOR 737'S
description: The Boeing Company has notified airlines that future twin-jet 737 planes will have an improved system designed to prevent wing icing while a plane is waiting to take off.

title: POISON CONTROL BEING CENTRALIZED
description: A statewide poison-control and drug-information center that will operate a toll-free, 24-hour hot line for use by physicians, as well as by poison victims, was scheduled to be signed into existence by Governor Kean last Friday.

title: The Pigskin Road
description: To the Editor:

title: ON L.I., THERE'S A WEALTH OF MILLION-DOLLAR HOMES
description: these are communities whose names are celebrated for affluence. Tourists and visitors course through them, craning to get fleeting glimpses of the sumptuous homes that line the streets. Some may dream of the people who live in the homes or fantasize about their chances of ever inhabiting one.

title: Headhunting
description: To the Business Editor: We are concerned about the impression left about our industry and our respected competitor, Gerard R. Roche, in your article, ''Casting About for the Corporate Elite'' (Oct.17).

title: 'Eugene Onegin'
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER PROBLEM: OVERFLOW CLASSES
description: ''COMPUTERS know more about me than I know about computers,'' said Mary DeSalva, explaining why she had enrolled in an adult-education class in computer programming. ''I don't want my children to get ahead of me,'' said Ellen Somberg, who has children 7 months old and 2 1/2 years old. ''I like to keep at least one step ahead of them.''

title: APPEALS RULE SPURS JUSTICES TO A DISSENT
description: When it comes to the common law, statutes and the New York State Constitution, the justices of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court must defer to the judges of the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal. But when the subject is drastic changes in state court procedures, they are free to dissent - and do.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I have never been one to lament the generation gap. When I was on t he other side of it - before your time, sonny - I enjoyed the c ompany of my elders who had much to tell me, even if they frequentlyr eached the stage of overtell. On this side of the gap, I find that w hat I have to tell the other side is scintillating, informative and h ighly helpul to them in charting their lives. It is so overwhelming t hat they apparently can take it only in small doses before pleading u rgent business elsewhere that curtails these sessions.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Roberta Rust is a powerhouse of a pianist - one who combines an almost frightening fervor and intensity with impeccable technique and spartan control. She began her Friday night Carnegie Recital Hall debut with a precisely accented and closely argued rendition of Haydn's Sonata in B minor (Hob. 32).

title: ADVISERS LOOK TO REAGAN FOR CLUES ON THE BUDGET
description: At first, the daily private Presidential sessions sound like a baroque music festival for an audience of one. David A. Stockman, the Administration budget maestro, is as intense as ever in directing the President's choicest staff ensemble through page after page of projected deficits and spending for 1984 as President Reagan, confident as the Dauphin, sits and listens for two or three hours a day.

title: SINGLES UNIT OUTGROWS ITS HOME
description: Wanted: Auxiliary social facilities with pleasant ambience for a 4,000-member regional singles group. Must have at least one large room capable of handling a crowd of around 400 people with a handful of smaller rooms for committee meetings and administrative purposes. Westport location preferred.

title: DELBELLO URGES HOUSING FUND
description: IN what may be his last opportunity to try to stimulate the growth of affordable housing in Westchester, outgoing County Executive Alfred B. DelBello plans to call for a $1 million-a-year fund to help local communities finance residential development. The fund, proposed in the 1983 county capital budget scheduled to be submitted tomorrow, would be targeted for projects such as the acquisition of land for building, the provision of water and sewer facilities and the improvement of road and mass transportation services.

title: NAVIGATING THE MAZE OF MUNICIPAL BONDS
description: INVESTORS who sampled the world of tax-free investments a year ago b y buying All Savers certificates are now shopping for the second c ourse. One obvious focus is the municipal bond market, which also g enerates investment income that is not subject to Federal income t ax. (And it can also be exempt from state and local taxes if it is i ssued within the state in which you live.)

title: EMBASSY SECURITY IS CALLED LACKING
description: Plans to improve security at United States embassies - made after the American hostages were seized in Iran - are falling far behind schedule, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: AN EARLY WARNING ON ALCOHOL
description: The campaign against drunken driving took aim at the very young this week with the unveiling of an alcoholeducation campaign for children in kindergarten through sixth grade.

title: INWOOD
description: Depending upon the sort of New Yorker one is talking to, Inwood is either where Columbia University plays its football games, or it is the area that lies below the south anchor of the Henry Hudson Bridge, or it is ultima Thule on the A train.

title: ITALIAN CHIEF QUITS FOR 2D TIME IN 3 DAYS
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini resigned today for the second time in three days, and President Sandro Pertini announced that he would open consultations on Monday to designate a new cabinet.

title:
ART;
STOCK MARKET REPORTS AND OVERTONES OF THE ARCHAIC
description: GREAT NECK THE premise for ''Then and Now'' at the North Shore Sculpture Center is that the three artists represented are influenced in some way by the past. For two of them, Mary Jane Moross and Dale Zheutlin, there are certainly overtones of the archaic in their work, but for the third, Jason Homer, the reference is to the artist's own immediate past rather than to antiquity.

title: O'NEILL STRESSES HE IS IN CHARGE
description: HARTFORD THE letters, which were mailed out of the Governor's office over William A. O'Neill's signature last Monday, were brief and to the point.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Free Appraisal

title: A SHOW WITH VERVE
description: BRIDGEPORT THE Downtown Cabaret Theater could as well be called a picnic basket or paperback playhouse. Audiences are invited to bring food and drink - candlesticks, too, if that's their style -and told to ''clean up your own junk on the way out.'' It turns out to be just the right ambience for good old ''Annie Get Your Gun.''

title:
HIGHER EDUCATION;
A MANAGEMENT GAME WITH REAL DIRECTORS
description: PITTSBURGH THE world needs more laundry soap, and Wenneco Inc., a leading detergent maker, wants to build a new plant to meet the strong demand. But Wenneco's board of directors, which has to give the green light for any expansion plans, isn't convinced that the company needs to make more soap.

title: BULL MARKET IN WORDS
description: Bearish Joseph Granville, the stock-market guru, sent out a flash to his subscribers during some recent happy days on Wall Street. ''Here we have stock market tsunami, the great Wall Street bet on economic recovery with 11 million people out of work. To escape tsunami, sell all stocks.''

title: Miss Block Plans Bridal
description: The engagement of Florence Willard Block to A. Andrew Levison has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Huntington T. Block of Washington and Nantucket, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Murray Levison of Stamford, Conn.

title: SUSPENSE STORY
description: A CRY IN THE NIGHT By Mary Higgins Clark. 317 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: GERMAN BEST SELLERS
description: GILLYFLOWER KID, By Christine Bruckner. Translated by Ruth Hein. 357 pp. New York: Fromm International Publishing. $14.95.FLIGHT OF CRANES, By Christine Bruckner. Translated by Ruth Hein. 372 pp. New York: Fromm International Publishing. $14.95.

title: JERSEY COMMUTERS ARE URGED TO ACT
description: The directors of New Jersey's financially tormented commuter transportation agency, the NJ Transit corporation, have warned the system's 300,000 rail and bus riders that a 25 percent fare increase will go into effect on Dec. 1 unless the Legislature appropriates $19.5 million more in operating subsidies.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIANS MAP CONSERVATIVE STRATEGY
description: Five Southeast Asian nations have drawn up a comprehensive plan to save such endangered creatures as the Pacific estuarine crocodile, the green sea turtle, the monkey-eating eagle and a species of buffalo known as the Philippine tamaraw. But officials say that their real objective is to secure the adoption of broader policies affecting all of their ecosystems.

title: Polish Regime Wins This Round Over Solidarity
description: Wednesday, the second anniversary of the official acceptance of Solidarity as Eastern Europe's first independent trade union, was to have been a big day of protest in Poland. For hope born, then dashed, underground leaders had called for strikes and demonstrations against the military regime's decision to outlaw Solidarity. But the calls went largely unheeded as the Government and riot police applied overwhelming force.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm pleased, today, to announce that the industrialized democracies have this morning reached substantial agreement on a plan of action. The understanding we've reached demonstrates that the Western alliance is fundamentally united and intends to give consideration to strategic issues when making decisions on trade with the U.S.S.R. As a result, we have agreed not to engage in trade arrangements which contribute to the military or strategic advantage of the U.S.S.R. or serve to preferentially aid the heavily militarized Soviet economy.'' - President Reagan. (24:5.)

title: DEATH AND MEMORY
description: By an odd coincidence, the Soviet Government announced the death of Leonid Brezhnev on Armistice Day, when the allied nations pause to remember that over 50 million people were killed in the two world wars of this century.

title: Black Sea
description: To the Editor: I would like to second Marvine Howe's excellent article on the eastern reaches of Turkey's Black Sea coast (''Black Sea Pioneering,'' Travel, Aug. 8). I have many fond memories of this region from my days as an interpreter at the American military site in the area and from a later visit there as a tourist.

title: AUDIO IS CUSTOM-FITTED TO CARS
description: If you go by car, the fastest shortcut to anywhere is a good sound system. Lately I have used my traveling time getting to know all of Haydn's 104 symphonies, and it seemed to cut my weekly trek from New York City to the Berkshires roughly in half. It is astounding how music, if properly reproduced, can lessen the strain of driving.

title: A CURIOUS PUSH TO WEAKEN F.T.C. ADVERTISING RULES
description: WASHINGTON CONSUMERS and advertisers are not usually in the same camp. But in an increasingly curious debate with the Federal Trade Commission these adversarial players are, for the time being, on the same side.

title: Concerts to Highlight Jewish Composers
description: The life and work of Sholom Secunda will be celebrated in the first of a series of concerts dedicated to Jewish composers in America, beginning next Wednesday at 7 P.M. in the Anne Goodman Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: A PROJECT TO RESCUE PUPILS HELD BACK TWICE
description: HE felt angry at his teachers, and was taunted by his classmates, most of them younger than he. He knew he wasn't stupid, but Gregory, 16 years old, somehow couldn't comprehend what he was reading. By the time he got to the end of a passage, he said, he had forgotten what he had read. He couldn't keep up with the ''smart'' kids or pass the tests. About to face his third year in the seventh grade, Gregory, like nearly 5,000 others who have been held back twice as a result of the city school system's toughened passing standards, felt like giving up.

title: PEYSER WEIGHING PLANS FOR THE FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON ON Capitol Hill last week, Congressional staffers in elevators and around coffee machines whispered the question: ''What are you going to do?'' As hundreds of workers, many on the staffs of Representatives who had suffered defeat at the polls, returned to Washington for the first time since Election Day, the topic of finding a new job took on a sense of urgency.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN SPEECH ON SOVIET UNION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's radio address today on relations with the Soviet Union, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MIners' Leader Gets the Boot
description: The United Mine Workers last week chose a leader with a law degree under his belt over one with coal dust under his fingernails. In their presidential, the miners sent tobacco-chewing Sam M. Church Jr. back to the ranks and gave a 33-year-old U.M.W. attorney and former miner (like his father and grandfather before him) the top job.

title: INCLUDING LAUNDRY LISTS
description: THOMAS MANN DIARIES 1918-1939, 1918-1921, 1933-1939. Selection and Foreword by Hermann Kesten. Translated by Richard and Clara Winston. Illustrated. 471 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $25 until Jan. 1, $29.95 thereafter.

title: The Fed's Doing?
description: To the Business Editor: In ''What's Behind Today's Disinflation'' (Oct.31), William Nordhaus asserts that the recent decline in inflation reflects declines in rates of rise of energy and other volatile prices, and declines in wage increases because of recession.

title: JACQUES TATI-COMIC ART FROM A HUMANE VIEWPOINT
description: The news of the death in Paris Nov. 5 of Jacques Tati was especially saddening and, although he was 75, a shock. Tati, like the films he made and starred in, seemed to exist outside particular time. Like Mr. Hulot, the civilizing focal point of those films, Tati was less a comic personality than an ageless, humane point of view. Tati was a method, a way of looking at the world to discover comic rhythms never seen before or since in movies.

title: BOUNTIES OF THE AUTUMN TABLE
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: THE ART OF PICTURE BOOKS
description: THE chimps are departed. Even the mice and bunnies are in short supply. Instead, this season, there are a lot of human beings in picture books. This does not imply the death of make-believe. The current cast of characters includes a fire-breathing man who used to be a dragon, a child the size of a snail who wears pajamas with feet and a skinny kid who throws his voice ... to the moon. It is often the select, realistic details that make fantasy persuasive. Which is why the search for a convincing combination of the real and unreal continues in these flights of the imagination now arriving on schedule.

title: HOW NUCLEAR FREEZE GOT ON THE BALLOT
description: ALONE among all of New York State's cities, counties, towns and villages, voters in Suffolk County faced a ballot on Nov. 2 that included a nuclear-freeze referendum. The advisory referendum called on the Soviet Union and the United States to adopt an immediate, mutual and verifiable freeze in the production and deployment of nuclear weapons, and the resolution was overwhelmingly approved.

title: BEING SINGLE: NOT QUITE SO SINGLE ANYMORE
description: IT is a Tuesday night at the Colony Club in New Rochelle and five lines of singles are moving across the ballroom in a 1960's line dance. Leading the pack, a blond woman in a sleek black jump suit moves to the taped strains of ''Manhattan Shuffle,'' while behind her about 100 balding or coifed heads bob up and down as the line snakes across the floor. Off in the shadows of the dance floor, another 100 or so singles in their 40's or 50's sit at tables, watching and talking and filling an evening with music and people.

title: PIECEMEAL TAKEOFF IN COLORADO FOLLOWS ONE-PIECE LANDING
description: Operators of a small airport high in the Colorado Rockies have shown that they mean it when they say private airplanes are unwelcome.

title: BRITAIN'S BEST
description: To the Editor: I recommend that Erica Brown be forced to walk the plank for omitting the Maritime Museum at Greenwich from her article, ''Britain's Best on Exhibit.''

title: Greece Says Common Market Will Help Build Pipeline Spur
description: The European Economic Community will almost certainly help build a branch from the Siberian pipeline to carry Soviet natural gas to Greece, an official statement said today.

title: ECONOMICALLY, THINGS LOOK THAT MUCH WORSE IN CANADA
description: TORONTO FROM the idle shipyards of the Maritimes to the lines of unemployed industrial workers in Ontario and the depressed grain markets in the prairies, Canada's economy is on the skids - high inflation, growing unemployment and flagging production. Compared to the United States, Canada's bad news is worse; inflation is nearly double the American rate, unemployment is one-fifth higher and interest rates are steeper.

title: A Tough Choice For U.A.W. Post
description: Walter P. Reuther was consolidating his power as head of the United Automobile Workers when a teen-aged Owen Bieber pulled his first shift in an auto plant in the late 1940's. Last week U.A.W. leaders nominated Mr. Bieber to see the U.A.W. through some of its roughest days since then.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Cover Story

title: UNCONVENTIONAL WISDOM; Misjudged
description: What signal about judicial integrity is New York's highest Court trying to send by censuring Judge Patrick J. Cunningham rather than removing him from the Onondaga County Court?

title: JAZZ
description: Strictly speaking, Laurindo Almeida is not a jazz guitarist since he is not an improviser. He is classically based and plays from written scores.

title: HOW STATE'S NEW CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION LOOKS
description: REAPPORTIONMENT and the midterm elections have displaced or replaced much of the New Jersey Congressional delegation that will be sent to the 98th session of Congress in January. For the first time in 20 years, New Jersey will be represented in Washington by only 14 Congressmen.

title: RECOGNITION ARRIVES FOR PRYOR
description: Aaron Pryor dispersed the clouds and earned his gold medal Friday night. He also earned his place in boxing history by knocking out Alexis Arguello in the 14th round of a fight that will link the Orange Bowl with Manila in boxing history.

title: Miss McCrystal, C.J. Sheerr Wed
description: Deirdre McCrystal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Teevan McCrystal of Shoreham, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents home to Clinton J. Sheerr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Sheerr of Greenwich, Conn. The bride's father, who is Village Justice of Shoreham, performed the ceremony.

title: FINANCIAL-AID OFFICES FLOAT NEW STRATEGIES
description: AS far as student financial aid goes, colleges have read the h andwriting on the wall. With the flood of Federal-aid plans for m iddle-income families that began in the mid-1970's having been d ammed up in part by the Reagan Administration, colleges across the c ountry are responding with a variety of programs and strategies to h elp students pay for their educations.

title: Mussolini's Son
description: To the Editor:

title: Zurich
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding a Building's Value
description: Question: I live in a building on Central Park South with 310 apartments. We have received a first offering of a plan to go co-op that shows the insider price is $82 million. How can we find out the value of this building? ...S.H., Manhattan. Answer:Experts use a variety of methods to determine the value of a building prior to conversion to a cooperative. John R. White, chairman of Landauer Associates, suggests a method known as capitalization of net income, in which the net income - that is, gross income minus taxes and operating expenses - is divided by a capitalization rate, usually 10 to 12 percent.

title: LOOKING BACK AT THE FIRST BERMUDA BOWL
description: The world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl, which began in 1950 as a head-to-head match between between teams representing the United States and Europe, has become progressively more complex with the passage of time. A year ago there were seven teams, two from Europe and one each from North America, South America, the Far East, Australia and Central Asia.

title: MILE-LONG FREIGHT TRAIN JUMPS TRACK IN CALIFORNIA
description: A Southern Pacific Railroad freight train nearly a mile long derailed today in a desert north of the Imperial Valley, scattering railroad cars and injuring one person.

title: Jersey Man Suspected Of Extortion Attempt
description: A North Brunswick man has been charged with trying to extort $150,000 from the president of a New York City construction company in exchange for arranging a $15 million utility contract, the F.B.I. said today.

title: Tear-Jerker
description: ''After giving it serious thought, I have decided on Dec. 31 at 11:59 P.M. I will end my life,'' the anonymous letter began. The writer went on to say that he was unemployed, had two children and would kill himself so his family could qualify for welfare.

title: Ellen Hemminger Wed to Peter Manian
description: Ellen Marguerite Hemminger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Hemminger of Massapequa, L.I., and Southbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter George Manian, son of Esther Manian of North Attleboro, Mass., and the late Dr. Samuel H. Manian. The Rev. John O. Mellin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: KING HUSSEIN TOUCHES OFF A DEBATE IN ISRAEL
description: Israeli Government officials say they are skeptical of what appear to be conciliatory remarks made recently by King Hussein of Jordan. But members of the opposition Labor Party insist that the remarks constitute recognition of Israel by the King and that ''the deafness of the Government is astonishing.''

title: The Best Bad News
description: You don't have to be an economic forecaster to know that the $5,000 Theodore S. Silbert Award is a tidy windfall, but you do have to be one to get it. In fact, you have to be the best of the 40 prognosticators who sit on the Blue Chip Economic Indicators Panel.

title: LEGISLATORS ATTACK PROPOSAL ON RENTS
description: APROPOSAL to set a separate scale of rent increases in apartment buildings undergoing conversion to cooperatives is expected to come under attack tomorrow from two groups of county legislators, who are concerned that higher rents may result in those buildings.

title: DIVERS DISCLOSE FINDINGS
description: EACH year between May and October, specially trained scuba divers from the American Littoral Society, based at Sandy Hook, monitor the health of the state's coastal waters.

title: Kathryn Hanson, Bank Aide Wed
description: Kathryn Irene Hanson and Philip Carroll, assistant treasurers with the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yesterday in St. John's Lutheran Church in Summit, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Franklin D. Fry performed the ceremony.

title: Index; International
description: Italian Premier resigns again, and is finally allowed to go 3 Trieste, once prominent under Austria, feels betrayed by Italy 4 Around the World 5 Costa Rica moves to close the door to fugitives 6 Security at U.S. embassies is called inadequate 11 Aides say Begin will resist freeze on settlements 14 Remarks by King Hussein stir skepticism and hope in Israel 15 Nixon says Reagan can use Car- ter's help on Mideast 16 Death toll at Israeli building in Lebanon reaches 89 17 A ''smoothie'' brings new style to Pretoria's hurly-burly politics 19 New Soviet bases in Afghanistan said to threaten Persian Gulf 21 Iraqis confront Iranians in three sectors on border 22 Reagan visits Soviet Embassy to express his condolences 24 Government/Politics First candidate announces bid to become Philadelphia mayor 28 Governors' group may ask Con- gress to curb arms spending 30 Rights groups and Justice Dept. differ on voting rights law 37 Two ex-Virgin Islands officials sentenced in fraud case 43 General Around the Nation 28 Jury in teamster trial finds some humor in wiretap tapes 42 Gas in beetle fumigation said to have safely dissipated 46 Arts groups confer on how to off- set cuts in financing 49 Health/Science Astronaut's motion sickness may delay space walk 38 Astronauts prepare for first U.S. space walk since 1974 38 Religion Study by churches weighs ethics of genetic research 39 Arts/Entertainment Music debuts in review 85 Association for Opera Awareness performs 90 Style Jill Krementz carves a niche 92 Warning the young on alcohol 92 Obituaries David Fitzmaurice, electrical workers union president 48

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 7 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 11 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 3 11 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 4 4 12 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 1 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Continuing the journey through the solar system begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 6 7 5 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: fourth volume of s.f. stories in ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 7 5 8 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A clandestine trans-Atlantic romance survives the stresses and strains of World War II. 8 6 15 DIFFERENT SEASONS, by Stephen King.

title: MAN AND WOMAN STABBED TO DEATH IN BROOKLYN
description: A man and a woman were stabbed to death early yesterday in an elevator of an apartment building at the southeast corner of Prospect Park in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: THIS TIME OUT, BLACK VOTERS GOT THEIR MESSAGE ACROSS
description: Black voters experienced perhaps their least fruitful political year since the late 1960's when Ronald Reagan and a host of other conservative candidates swept into office in 1980. But now, with their unusually heavy turnout in this month's mid-term elections, blacks appear to be regaining some political clout.

title: Lisbon Defeats Move To Legalize Abortion
description: The conservative coalition Government gained a victory on Friday when Parliament defeated a Communist-sponsored bill that would have legalized abortion in this predominantly Roman Catholic country.

title: CELEBRITY RECIPES AID CANCER SOCIETY
description: BERT PARKS prefers potato pancakes with his pot roast, Katharine Hepburn whips up a hot or cold zucchini soup with shallots and curry and Jim Fixx likes to run by the refrigerator, where he can indulge his passion for peanut butter ice-cream pie.

title: A LIFE WITH GANDHI
description: Not long ago, a small cavalcade of diplomatic cars traveled for an hour out of Vienna to a solitary cottage set in fields high on the edge of the Vienna woods. K.L. Dalal, India's Ambassador to Austria, was on a special mission: the unprecedented award of the Padma Vibhushan, his country's second-highest civilian medal of honor, to a nonagenarian, a European and a woman, for her services to India.

title: P.I.D. RATE IN NEWARK GROWING
description: NEWARK CAROLYN M. was helping her 10-year-old twins to dress when a stabbing pain in her right side forced her to the floor. ''I couldn't stand and I couldn't sit,'' the 28-year-old Newark woman later recalled from her hospital bed. ''The pain didn't go away, it just got worse.''

title: A FRIGHTENING SECURITY
description: BEYOND THE COLD WAR A New Approach to the Arms Race and Nuclear Annihilation. By E. P. Thompson. 198 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $15. Paper, $5.95.

title: GOALS ON HANDICAPPED MEET WIDE RESISTANCE
description: IN a final admission of defeat, Terrel H. Bell, the Secretary of Education, recently withdrew the Reagan A dministration's most controversial changes to the regulations g overning education for the handicapped. ''Repeatedly,'' he said, ' 'we have heard from mothers how they've struggled to have their c hildren educated. In response to hundreds of parents, several of thep roposed changes are withdrawn for further study.''

title: Kiel's Painful Pass Brought on Karcher
description: The secret did not remain a secret for very long. Ken Karcher, Notre Dame's sophomore second-string quarterback, knew all week that because of the injury to Blair Kiel's right shoulder there was a very good chance he would be a first-string quarterback on Saturday. ''All I told was my mother and father,'' Karcher said.

title: No Headline
description: Sonics Move to 9-0

title: A CALCULATING MAN
Emily Wood, S.B. Starkey Are Married
description: Emily Battle Wood, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Edwin Wood 3d of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married there yesterday to Samuel Borden Starkey, son of Mrs. Austin C. Starkey of Gulfstream, Fla., and Princeton and Bay Head, N.J., and the late Mr. Starkey. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

title: No Headline
description: Clearly, the 1960's were marked by revolutionary opportunities that for good or ill failed. Yet there were contributions that have lasted: the women's liberation movement; a healthy skepticism of the ''official'' version - as the ''paranoia'' of the New Left has time and time again proved true - and the awareness by more people than were directly involved that politics is not just Republican versus Democrat but points along a continuum where deep belief and personal experience connect us. FRANCES CHAPMAN, Irvington, N.J.

title: 3 Topics; Unconventional Wisdom; Death Triumphs
description: This year's most curious political footnote comes from Texas, where lively democratic voters in the 18th district elected a dead man to the state senate - fully aware that he had been called to a higher seat.

title: 29th Victim in Jail Fire
description: The death toll in a county jail fire climbed to 29 today when an inmate was removed from a life support system and pronounced dead. Randy Frank Overstreet, 20 years old, of Kosciusko, Miss., died this afternoon, according to the county coroner. The fire occurred last Monday morning.

title: THERE'S MORE AID THAN SOME PEOPLE THINK
description: FEDERAL financial support for college students has been tightened up in the Reagan Administration, but educators agree that there is more money available for student assistance than many students and parents believe.

title: SPECIAL KIDS AND PARENTS
description: In the past 10 years there has been a steady flow of books describing a new kind of love story: the love of parents for a handicapped, disturbed or terminally ill child. Josh Greenfeld's ''A Child Called Noah'' was the first of these books that I read and ''Intensive Care,'' by Mary-Lou Weisman, is the most recent. Before Josh Greenfeld, there was John Gunther's ''Death Be Not Proud'' and Peter De Vries's ''The Blood of the Lamb''; later, there was ''Journey,'' by Robert and Suzanne Massie, and many more whose titles don't come easily to mind because we tend to shy away from such books.

title: LEGAL ACTIONS CONTINUE IN DEATHS OF FIVE AT '79 RALLY AGAINST KLAN
description: Though three years have passed since five persons were killed at a ''Death to the Klan'' rally here, memories of the gun battle are being kept alive by a Federal grand jury investigation and other legal actions.

title: Letters; 'WEALTH' OF THE ELDERLY THAT BUYS NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: Manila Will Not Link U.S. Bases to Extra Aid
description: The Government will not demand more economic aid from the United States in exchange for its military bases in the Philippines but is ''making it plain that we are not getting paid enough,'' a high-ranking official said today.

title: BEETLE FUMIGATION GAS IS SAID TO HAVE DISSIPATED
description: The giant tarpaulins used to seal a TriBeCa warehouse while it was fumigated to kill an infestation of beetles were removed yesterday, and Federal officials said the toxic gas released during the procedure had safely dissipated.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IT CAN get mighty cold at WBGO-FM, a public radio station in Newark. The blowers for the heating system at the station's studios at 54 Park Place are loud - in fact, too loud to be turned on while the station is broadcasting its lively mixture of classical jazz and news.

title: Brooklyn Officer Slightly Hurt When Partner's Gun Goes Off
description: A police officer was accidentally shot in the left leg by his partner yesterday as the two chased four teen-agers suspected of stealing a car in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Tufts 21, Bates 7
description: Two second-half touchdown passes from David Piermarini to Bob Galvin led Tufts as both teams ended their seasons.

title: What's New on the Executive Bookshelf; THE JAPANESE WAY OF WORK, REVISITED
description: Japan in the Passing Lane, by Satoshi Kamata. Introduction by Ronald Dore. Pantheon Books, N.Y. 256 pages, $14.95.

title: FEW NEW PROMISES IN PACT WITH U.S., EUROPEANS CONTEND
description: The agreement on East-West trade that President Reagan linked to the lifting of the Soviet gas pipeline sanctions represents little in terms of new commitments by the United States' main European allies, Western European officials said tonight.

title: Margaret Ball Engaged To John B. Ottman Jr.
description: The engagement of Margaret Ralston Ball to John Budlong Ottman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ottman of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Miss Ball's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Burnham Ball Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Robbinston, Me.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Indiana vs. Soviet Union National Team, at Bloomington, Ind. The Soviet team, with a pair of 7-foot-2 inch centers, Arvidas Sabonis and Alexandr Belostenny, is 4-1 on its 12 game United States tour. lost their last game to Wichita State, 81-80. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) 76ers vs. Washington Bullets, at Philadelphia. This is the second weekend of early network coverage of the National Basketball Association season brought about because of the pro football players'strike. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Bucks vs. Boston Celtics, at Milwaukee. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.).

title: THE BEST COMES FIRST IN ODETS'S 'ROCKET'
description: ACCORDING to the critics of the time, Clifford Odets's ''Rocket to the Moon'' was a troubled and troublesome play when it opened in 1938, and so it remains. Then considered a departure for the playwright - from leftist politics to psychological probing - the play was praised for the promise and life of its beginning and panned for dangling inconclusiveness.

title: FOR POLAND'S CHURCH, A NEW RELATIONSHIP WITH THE STATE
description: WARSAW FOR the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, survival has always been the first duty. The church has nurtured Poles through the hard times, when their country was carved up or dominated by their neighbors. Particularly against the Russians, both Orthodox and Communist, the church was the historic refuge where the Polish language could be spoken and customs maintained, the repository and protector of nationalism.

title: Dr. Cunningham-Rundles Is Married
description: Dr. Charlotte Cunningham-Rundles, an immunologist at the Sloan-Kettering Institute, was married yesterday to Dr. James Bruce Bussel, a pediatrician at New York Hospital. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: A COMPOSITION OF ETHNIC TREATS
description: WESTPORT BEETHOVEN is playing to full houses every day on the Post Road in Westport. A restaurant with this auspicious name is ensconced in a dramatic new, contemporary building of rounded and vertical forms.

title: Comsewogue Rolls, 30-0, Behind Austin
description: Jean Austin scored touchdowns on a 52-yard interception return and a 34-yard run to lead Comsewogue to a 30-0 victory over Copiague. The victory, Comsewogue's eighth over all and sixth in League IV, gave the school its first undefeated season in 13 years.

title: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS: IT'S TIME FOR A TRUCE; BY CHESTER E. FINN JR.
description: AMONG the unfinished business awaiting Congress when it returns to W ashington is the disposition of President Reagan's tuition t axcredit proposal, as modified and approved by the Senate Finance C ommittee in September. This bill would provide the tuition-paying p arents of private elementary or secondary school students with a p artial credit against their Federal income tax. In its current form i t would be limited to $300 per student; would not be available to v ery wealthy families, and could be claimed only when the school i tself satisfied various requirements, including nondiscrimination ont he basis of race or disability. The estimated annual cost to the T reasury would be $750 million when fully implemented.

title: Wendy Maddocks, Speech Pathologist, And John C. Kriendler 2d Are Married
description: Wendy Alyn Maddocks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Preston T. Maddocks of La Mirada, Calif., was married last evening in Tucson, Ariz., to John Carl Kriendler 2d, a son of Mrs. I. Robert Kriendler and the late Mr. Kreindler, president of the ''21'' Club.

title: Whaling Nations Tough It Out
description: In July, when the International Whaling Commission got around to banning all commercial whaling starting in 1986, only 7 of 32 voting members were opposed. But that was some minority, including Japan, Norway and the Soviet Union, the biggest whaling nations.

title: EX-PHILADELPHIA AIDE MOVES TO GRAB MAYORAL CONTEST SPOTLIGHT
description: The plot is thickening in the Philadelphia mayoralty play. Always a colorful production, its drama has been heightened this year by the antics, maneuvers, soliloquies, harangues, asides and dialogues of the players, including some who are still in the wings.

title: BEGIN'S WIFE DIES AND HE CUTS SHORT HIS VISIT TO THE U.S.
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin abruptly canceled his visit to the United States tonight after learning of the death of his wife, Aliza, in Israel.

title: Betty Valdes Becomes Bride of Samuel Butler 3d
description: Beatriz Valdes and Samuel Butler 3d were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. The Rev. Gerard DiSenso performed the ceremony.

title:
CAMERA;
HAND-HELD METERS
description: Although the built-in exposure meter in your single-lens-reflex camera will usually give pretty accurate results, it may not always provide a continuous and correct light reading. For example, it may have trouble sorting out highlight and shadow readings when the lighting is particularly contrasty and the averaging meter in most SLR's may give you over-exposed or under-exposed pictures in many situations.

title: Man Drowns After Car Strikes a Fire Hydrant
description: A motorist who struck a fire hydrant and ruptured a water main drowned when the pavement collapsed and he fell into a water-filled hole next to his car.

title: Mazda GLC Is the 'Great Little Car'
description: FUEL economy may be more important now than ever, but the world's auto makers have come to realize that thrift goes just so far. As a result, they are scrambling to ladle excitement over their econoboxes, and the latest to benefit is Mazda's GLC sedan.

title: TRAINING DOCTORS EARLY WITH THE LIBERAL ARTS
description: JACKIE SUGARMAN has time for ballet and to pursue her interest in p oetry -though she is a premedical student at Boston University. And i nstead of cramming for heavy science courses, Kayan Zamgi has the t ime and energy to lead undergraduate discussions on subjects that i nterest him. And other students like them, also seeking to become p hysicians, have had the time to work in public-health programs or s pend weekends in Maine assisting a rural general practitioner.

title: Economic Affairs / Barbara R. Bergmann; SOCIAL SECURITY'S OVERBLOWN PROBLEMS
description: THE nation is facing a choice on Social Security. The issue can be put very simply: Do we, or do we n ot, want to continue to provide our old people with the level of r eal benefits they are now getting?

title: Miss Higgins And Banker Will Marry
description: Harriet Pratt Higgins, manager for corporate relationship banking of the Royal Bank of Canada in New York, plans to be married Dec. 18 to Ronald Francis MacDonald, vice president and manager of the New York office of the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.

title: LARGE INDOOR RANGE READIES FOR TEE-OFF
description: WHITE PLAINS ARRANGEMENTS were completed last week to erect what is believed will be the world's largest indoor golf driving range on the parking lot at the Saxon Woods Swimming Pool complex. The structure, an envelope of high-strength vinyl polyester, will be dismantled each summer so that the lot can accommodate swimmers' automobiles.

title: Wagner Wins Cross-Country
description: Susan Wagner, the defending champion, after suffering through a disappointing early part of the season, rose to the occasion in the Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: NEW CAREER AS ATHELETE
description: ROWAYTON FIVE years ago, at the age of 38, Millie Brown set out on her first run, a one-mile solo trek through the streets of this picturesque coastal village on Long Island Sound.

title: OF QUEENSIDE OPENINGS
description: Almost every principal defense to queenside openings (possibly excepting the Nimzo-Indian) evinces a characteristic advantage as well as a drawback.

title: Guest Observer By Robert Vare; Avoiding Success
description: Robert Vare is a writer who lives in New York. Russell Baker is on vacation.

title:
THE SCHOOLS;
FOR CHILDREN OF THE DIVORCED, A COURSE ON HOW TO COPE
description: ''W HO Gets Me for Christmas?'' is not your ordinary title for a course in a junior high school, but then this is not an ordinary course. It is about divorce - specifically the effect divorce has on children - and it is offered at the Mildred E. Strang Middle School in Yorktown Heights, a Westchester County suburb about 50 miles from New York City.

title: Gina Ellen Levey Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lionel M. Levey of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gina Ellen Levey, to Kenneth A. Mandelbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Mandelbaum of Livingston, N.J. Miss Levey's father is vice chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority. The future bridegroom is director of real estate for the Mandee Shops, a women's apparel chain. His father is president of Big M Inc., parent company of the Mandee Shops in New York and New Jersey, and the Annie Sez stores in New Jersey.

title: CAUCUSES TO ASSIGN MEMBERS TO PANELS
description: WASHINGTON D.C. CONNECTICUT'S Congressional delegation has lost some clout on environmental issues, but it still has influence when it comes to small business, banking and government appropriations.

title: North Rockland Gains Title
description: North Rockland completed its second straight undefeated season yesterday and earned its second straight Public Schools Athletic League championship by beating Nyack, 14-0.

title: Mrs. Bhutto to Receive Medical Aid Abroad
description: Nusrat Bhutto, widow of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, said on Friday that she had been given permission to go abroad for treatment of suspected cancer.

title: SO TANGO
description: The swiftness of the Soviet succession surprised the commentators, including us. Chastened, we decline to predict whether Yuri Andropov will be hard or soft, detentnik or warmonger in his new role as party chief. What is clear, depressingly so, is that President Reagan is passing up a precious chance to establish a personal tie with the new order, claiming that business and protocol leave no room for attending Leonid Brezhnev's funeral.

title: A PURCHASE PLUM
description: Rental Lottery A PURCHASE PLUM

title: ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY OPENS CRIMINAL ENFORCEMENT BRANCH
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has opened its own criminal enforcement division, and 17 new investigators have been hired for the operation.

title: Death in an Afghan Tunnel
description: Although reports from Afghanistan are sketchy, they all agree that Soviet forces are hard pressed to defend a puppet regime against rebel forces. When the outside world learned last week of hundreds of deaths in a mountain tunnel, even though they appeared to be the result of a traffic accident, the news further confirmed the picture of a difficult and costly pacification.

title: Lunch Mishap Sends Shultz to a Hospital
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was taken to the emergency room of George Washington University Hospital this afternoon after a piece of food stuck in his throat during lunch, according to a hospital spokesman.

title: AUSTRALIA LETS ITS HAIR DOWN FOR HORSE RACE
description: This is a stylish, conservative city, known for its Victorian architecture, its good taste and restraint. But every year, on the first Tuesday in November, it is the focus of all Australia, with round-the-clock revelry and a horse race, the Melbourne Cup, that is won occasionally by the favorite.

title:
GARDENING;
A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT FOR ROOTS
description: FROM time to time we have referred to the undesirable effect of soil compaction on plant growth. However, we have not discussed the reasons for it. Since the fall is an ideal time to take measures to overcome compaction, this a good time for us to examine the problem.

title: SELECTIVE SERVICE SYSTEM GETS DATA FROM JERSEY ON DRIVERS
description: New Jersey has given the Selective Service System computer tapes of the state's licensed drivers who would be eligible for the draft, to help Selective Service track down men who have failed to register, a spokesman said today.

title: THE RETURN OF THE HAT
description: There was a time when no well-dressed man would think of appearing without a hat. In recent years, that has not been the case. This fall, however, hats have returned as a key component of a man's wardrobe.

title: Aftershocks
description: While some are preparing to settle into office, others are bemoaning their loss in pursuit of it. Whitney North Seymour Jr. and Muriel Siebert, losers to Assemblywoman Florence M. Sullivan in the Republican primary for the United States Senate, sued the Conservative Party for publishing a pamphlet for the winner.

title: PETER HALL SHAPES VERDI'S 'MACBETH' FOR THE MET
description: Giuseppe Verdi stopped short of calling his first Shakespearean opera ''Macbetto,'' but the ''Macbeth'' that opens in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday still represents a fascinating transposition -a chilling English tragedy restated in the language of sultry mid-19th-century Italian temperament.

title: BRITAIN'S BEST
description: To the Editor:

title: DU PONT FINED $5,000 BY STATE FOR PLANT'S CHLORINE GAS LEAK
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company will have to pay a $5,000 fine and put new procedures into effect at its Niagara Falls plant because of a chlorine gas leak that felled 76 persons last month.

title: TEAMSTER JURY FINDS SOME HUMOR IN F.B.I. TAPE
description: Boasting, counterpointed by rage when the boasting proved premature, is emerging as a sometimes comic theme at the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: REAGAN VISITS THE SOVIET EMBASSY
description: President Reagan visited the Soviet Embassy here today to express his condolences on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev. He also used the occasion to express the desire that the United States and the Soviet Union ''live in peace.''

title: 'Wealth' of the Elderly That Buys Nothing
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN, BY 52-21, GAINS ROSE BOWL

title: Radio Marti Funds Asked
description: Pesident Reagan formally asked Congress today to provide $5.3 million to allow Radio Marti to begin broadcasting in 1983. The radio station is being set up to transmit broadcasts from the United States to Cuba.

title: AN INSIDER'S VIEW OF THE ONLY GAME IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY FORMER Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith, who is a possible candidate for Hudson County Executive next year, has completed his history of the county's politics, and it makes good reading - for those familiar with the events in the book, as well as those who may wonder what was so unusual about the political life of Jersey City and its environs.

title: MAN SENTENCED IN ARMED ROBBERY
description: WHITE PLAINS FRANCES BARRA said she has known Gennaro Purchia's father for several years, but she did not meet the son until last year, when the two were brought together by tragic coincidence.

title: TIME NEARS FOR CRITICAL DECISIONS ON DEFENSE
description: When Representative Joseph Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, raps his gavel in a cramped Capitol hearing room tomorrow, he will start a sequence of debates and votes that will determine levels of United States military spending for the rest of this decade.

title: THE PIGSKIN ROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTS GROUPS JOIN TO LEARN HOW TO OFFSET CUTS IN AID
description: ''How many of you were at the rally last year at Lincoln Center to protest budget cuts in the arts?'' Tony Randall asked yesterday as he stood before an audience that included artists and directors of nonprofit arts troupes.

title: CHORALE: COLLEGIATE SINGS 'ESTHER'
description: Handel's ''Esther'' is not often encountered these days, in New York at least. Friday night's performance at Carnegie Hall, which opened the Collegiate Chorale's season, was billed as the first in New York in more than a dozen years.

title: London Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DEBATE OVER THE ELECTRONIC OFFICE
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust Company, the sixth largest United States bank, boasts that it has made the ''office of the future'' a reality. From the robot that beeps through the corridors of the wood-paneled headquarters in Chicago, to the vast library of data stored in the bank's computers, Continental is visibly committed to office automation. It has acquired some 3,000 worldwide work stations - desktop computer terminals with typewriter keyboards and video display screens - and nearly half of its 12,000 employees tap in each day to get their messages from IRIS, the electronic mail system whereby messages are sent and received by computer. Louis H. Mertes, senior vice president and general manager of systems, who does not allow a scrap of paper to enter his own office, is one of 100 bank employees with a video display terminal at home. ''You leave on Friday, and you can have three turnarounds of a document by Monday morning,'' he says.

title: Television Is Planning Live Funeral Reports
description: Live coverage from Moscow of the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev is scheduled to begin Monday at 4 A.M. (E.S.T.) on the CBS, NBC and ABC networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on SNC, the Satellite News Channel.

title: Jeffrey W. Cooley Marries Dana Juliana Salzberg
description: Dana Juliana Salzberg, daughter of Murray M. Salzberg of Manhattan and Katrina van Oss of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Whitman Cooley, son the late Paul W. Cooley and the late Victoria Dubiel Cooley, both of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. John Verdery, an Episcopal priest performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Steven Lafferty Is Fiance of Elisabeth McClenahan
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. McClenahan of Villanova, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth McCauley McClenahan, to Steven Lafferty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Lafferty of Los Angeles. The wedding will take place next month.

title: FLAW FOUND IN RIDE AT JERSEY AMUSEMENT PARK
description: The kayak ride at Action Park at Vernon in Sussex County, N.J. - although properly installed and maintained - had an electrical problem that could have caused bodily injury, a state investigation has concluded.

title: JARS MORE DELICIOUS THAN COOKIES
description: EAST HANOVER WHAT could be more appropriate for the Nabisco Gallery than its current exhibition, which is called ''The Ultimate Cookie Jar''? That singular superlative currently applies to all of the 65 contemporary cookie jars that were selected from the more than 300 submitted to this national juried competition. However, when the show ends next month, that title will belong to only one.

title: Henry Bradford Gustavson Marries Ruby Schwartz
description: Ruby Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Schwartz of Manhasset, L.I., and Henry Bradford Gustavson, son of Shirley Gustavson of White Plains, and the late Henry B. Gustavson, were married yesterday at the Lutheran Church of Our Savior in Manhasset. The Rev. Thomas C. Spitz performed the ceremony.

title: FOR ISRAEL, A MIXED BALANCE SHEET ON LEBANON
description: Fourth article of a series appearing periodically on the new balance of power in the Middle East since the war in Lebanon.

title:
EDUCATION ABROAD;
'RE-EDUCATING' CHINA'S 'NAUGHTY GIRLS'
description: SHANGHAIASLENDER girl looks shyly at us as she sings a song she has c omposed. She sings about her past and how she strayed from the v irtuous life. ''I never paid attention to my teachers,'' she sings. ' 'Now I must fight for my bright future.''

title: FIRE OFFICIAL URGES CHANGES TO MAKE JAILS SAFE
description: The authorities have a responsibility to provide a ''safe refuge'' for prison inmates when fire strikes, the director of a new fire education group says.

title: BY GLORIA LEVITAS
description: GLORIA LEVITAS is an anthropologist and writer who lives in New York.

title: USE OF INSULIN INFUSION PUMP GETS PANEL'S VIRTUAL APPROVAL
description: A panel of health experts has given a virtual clean bill of health to the use of insulin infusion pumps in the treatment of diabetes after an investigation into the deaths of 35 people who used the pumps.

title: A TALE OF DESTINY
description: ISAK DINESEN The Life of a Storyteller. By Judith Thurman. Illustrated. 495 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: WIFE OF THE ISRAELI PRIME MINISTER
description: Aliza Begin, the strong-willed but publicity-shy wife of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, died early today following a lengthy respiratory illness. She was 62 years old.

title: Paul Weinstein Fiance Of Wendi G. Glassman
description: Marcia Glassman of Hillside, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Wendi G. Glassman, to Paul H. Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob M. Weinstein of Brooklyn and Neponsit, L.I. A Dec. 5 wedding is planned.

title: BY WENDELL RAWLS JR.
description: WENDELL RAWLS Jr. is a national correspondent based in the Atlanta bureau of The New York Times.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch by United Press International in some copies last Sunday incorrectly listed guests at a reunion of Richard Nixon's associates held on Nov. 6, the 10th anniversary of his 1972 re-election. William Safire and Diane Sawyer did not attend.

title: A SPEECH TEACHER WITH THE YANKEES
description: THIS is the story of two people who inhabit the same body. One of them is Robert Leo Sheppard, who spent more than 20 years as chairman of the speech department at John Adams High School in New York City before retiring and joining the faculty of St. John's University, where he holds the title of adjunct professor of speech.

title: AN EX-PLAYER'S WORK ETHIC PAYS OFF FOR DOBB'S FERRY
description: lined aqueduct, saving walkers about five minutes. But there have been no short cuts on the playing field - just hard work - on the path to the Westchester Class C Section 1 championship.

title: BOOKLET OFFERS FUNERAL ADVICE
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board has issued a booklet aimed at making the arrangement of funerals easier and cheaper in the state.

title: PREMIERE OF MUSICAL
description: Dolores Gray will star in the Whole Theater Company's production of ''All Dressed Up,'' a musical comedy having its world premiere in Montclair Tuesday night.

title: REINING: A BIT OF OLD WEST
description: MIDDLE ISLAND A STIFF autumn breeze whipped its way through the rear stable entrants of the Mid Island Arena, stirring up a potent mixture of dust, the musky aroma of horses and the sweet smell of hay. Except for the muffled sounds of horse hooves beating against the sandcovered concrete floor, silence pervaded as Bob Bonaimo put his quarter horse through the rigors of reining pattern No. 5.

title: ASSURANCE URGED ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The 15 members of the National Commission on Social Security Reform declared today that they and Congress must convincingly reassure the American people that Social Security will continue indefinitely without radical change.

title: Soviet Soldier to Be Released In Angola Prisoner Exchange
description: A Soviet soldier captured by South African forces in southern Angola last year will be included in an exchange of prisoners on Monday, military sources said today.

title: Deirdre Kinney to Wed in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kevin A. Kinney of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Kinney, to David Brian Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent P. Brennan also of Bronxville. A spring wedding is planned.

title: A Strike Back At Aid Lawyers
description: Mayor Koch, saying that a strike by 550 Legal Aid Society lawyers had created ''severe short-term problems for the city,'' last week appointed a panel to study alternatives ways of representing poor people charged with crimes in New York City. The walkout, over wages, has left many defendants without counsel and caused a backlog of court cases.

title: Sarah Myers Engaged To Gregory S. Morton
description: Mrs. Thomas D. Wellington of Princeton, N.J., and John Anderson Myers of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Wistar Myers, to Gregory Sheppard Morton, son of Mrs. William C. Mudgett Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla. and Bayville, Me., and the late Warner Groom Morton. The wedding is planned for January.

title: THEATER
description: THEATER Sam Shepard's ''True West'' (at the Cherry Lane Theater) is an irreverent romp about sibling rivalry and the artistic bankruptcy of the New Hollywood. A failure in its first New York production two seasons ago, the play has been completely revivified by the Steppenwolf Theater of Chicago.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Courteous Librarian
description: To the Editor:

title: LEBANON STILL THE KEY TO U.S.-ISRAEL HARMONY
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin arrived in the United States last week faced with a number of serious tasks, none of them more important than attempting to restore harmony between his Government and the Reagan Administration. Viewed from Jerusalem, the prospects of resolving the disputes between Mr. Begin and Mr. Reagan are not bright.

title: Walking Tour Of Mount Athos
description: ''The thrill of being invited into medieval monasteries and dining by candlelight while a priest chants from the Scriptures and all around you are 13th-, 14th-, 15th-century frescoes ...''

title: SPACE WALK: VERY HIGH-LEVEL RISK
description: Next to a launching or a moon walk, a space walk ranks as the spectacle of space flight most freighted with risk and suspense. From the security of his spaceship, the astronaut steps into an environment against which he has no natural defense. He has only the thin garment and backpack that surround him with the essence of Earth, oxygen and cooling water.

title: NEW DEAL PAINT
description: WALL-TO-WALL AMERICA A Cultural History of Post-Office Murals in the Great Depression. By Karal Ann Marling. Illustrated. 348 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $14.95.

title:
GARDENING;
A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT FOR ROOTS
description: FROM time to time we have referred to the undesirable effect of soil compaction on plant growth. However, we have not discussed the reasons for it. Since the fall is an ideal time to take measures to overcome compaction, this a good time for us to examine the problem.

title: IN THE WINGS, WILDE'S GHOST
description: BERNARD SHAW AND ALFRED DOUGLAS A Correspondence. Edited by Mary Hyde. Illustrated. 237 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $25.

title: Baby, Deported by U.S., Is Being Returned
description: A baby who was deported to Mexico in a raid by Federal immigration agents will be returned to his family in Colorado, according to the authorities.

title: No Headline
description: Longest Field Goal Helps Yale Win

title: LIFTING OF SANCTIONS PLEASES U.S. COMPANIES
description: An executive for General Electric, one of the concerns affected by the imposition of the pipeline embargo, said today that the company was ''pleased that an accommodation has been reached.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
SHOW RAISES FUNDS FOR A MUSEUM
description: NORWALK WITH its foyer and parlors richly decorated with fresh greens and flowers, the baronial Lockwood-Mathews Mansion will be the setting next weekend for the antiques show that annually raises funds to maintain this mid-19th-century house-museum on West Avenue.

title: Diane Bee, Roxburgh Rennie Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Norman Bee of London and San Francisco of the engagement of their daughter, Diane Irene Bee, to Roxburgh Rennie, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Roxburgh Rennie of Milwaukee and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: FAMILY VISIONS
description: SWEET WHISPERS, BROTHER RUSH By Virginia Hamilton. 215 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $10.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: 'Selling' Ideas
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Economist as Preacher'' (Oct.24) George J. Stigler said: ''Intellectuals ... cultivate those of their ideas which find a market. Ideas without demands are simply as hard to sell as other products without demands.''

title: UNBEATEN NORTH EDISON STOPS 7-1 COLONIA, 34-0
description: Jim Schedeneck, a senior quarterback, scored three touchdowns as North Edison surprised Colonia, 34-0, in a game between highly rated teams before 5,000 fans yesterday in Colonia.

title: Reagan Signals That He Has Read the Returns
description: No member of the White House press corps used President Reagan's first post-election news conference to ask him what he thought of the returns, but that could have been because any such question was unnecessary. Mr. Reagan's admission that he was ''looking if there are savings'' in military spending, his delivery of a ''guideline and criteria'' for jobs programs and his heated charge that the Democrats had ''frightened'' the elderly with loose talk about Social Security, made it clear that the loss of 26 Republican seats in the House and the near-misses of several Democratic aspirants to the Senate had had an impact.

title: U.S. 40, a New 12-Meter for Cup Defense
description: The America's Cup sailors have fled to warmer climates and taken their 12-Meter yachts with them. All but one. In the large white shed at Newport Offshore, the aluminum frames of U.S. 40, the newest United States 12-Meter yacht being built for the 25th defense of the America's Cup here next summer, are in place. In the blue-white light of the workers' welding torches, its horizontal line is accentuated by the long, finely tapered bow and the sweeping stern overhang.

title: KEAN ASKS ALL DEPARTMENTS TO CUT BUDGETS BY 3 PERCENT
description: Governor Kean has asked his Cabinet to study the feasibility of cutting departmental budgets by up to 3 percent as a way of avoiding a possible $62 million revenue shortage, according to an administration official.

title: A LORDLY APPROACH TO IRELAND
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a correspondent in the London bureau of The New York Times.

title: THE PRICE OF FAME
description: Andre Noblet is a rustic Burgundian, a hulk of a man in the clothes of a vineyard worker who oversees the cellars at Le Domaine de la Romanee-Conti, where some of the world's most celebrated wines are made. Visitors with the good fortune to be invited to taste in the cellars in the tiny village of Vosne invariably meet Andre, who takes them underground to the oak barrels with the purple stains around their bungs, stacked in long rows on the earthen floor.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: November 14, 1982 NONFICTION BERNARD. By Bernard Waber. 43 THE CARNIVAL IN MY MIND. By Barbara Wersba. 48 A CHAIR FOR MY MOTHER.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AS part of its program to become an influential force in Huntington Town affairs, the Huntington United Civic Association will meet Tuesday with the Town Planning Board to educate its members about the ways and means of planning and zoning.

title: GUITARISTS BLAZE FRESH AND VARIED TRAILS
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS' PARADE A BELATED WELCOME HOME
description: Thousands of Vietnam veterans marched away from a decade of indifference today and paraded proudly past the White House to a memorial whose history recalls the divisiveness of their war.

title: Weapons Search Stirs Up School
description: What students attacked as a violation of rights and administrators defended as a security precaution ended last week in a disorderly demonstration at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn.

title: Leslie Mintzer to be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Mintzer of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Alexandra Mintzer, to Brian Jeffrey Lutz, son of Mr, and Mrs. Julian Jay Lutz of Denver. A June wedding is planned.

title: WITH LOVE AND MONEY
SEASONAL FARE IN A SERENE SETTING
description: THE House on Toilsome opened its doors just a couple of weeks before Labor Day, a time of year when many of the other restaurants in the East Hampton area begin to think of closing for the season. Based on the success of this new place, it might pay to redefine what exactly constitutes the season. In the dining room of the House on Toilsome, it could be midsummer. Reservations for weekend dinners are still hard to come by and must be made many days in advance.

title: Fanny Turgeman Wed
description: Fanny Turgeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliyahu Turgeman of Jerusalem, was married yesterday in New York to Alan John Forman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob J. Forman of New York. Rabbi Avraham Benhaim performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue. The bridegroom is an assistant vice president of the brokerage concern of L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1982
description: International Lech Walesa returned to his family in Gdansk after more than 11 months of detention by the Polish Government. The leader of the outlawed Solidarity union told hundreds of welcoming neighbors that ''we have to reach an agreement, but not on our knees.'' He made the same remark in an interview on the Polish television, the contents of which have not been issued by the authorities, just before he was released from a Government-owned hunting lodge near the Soviet border. (Page A1, Column 6.) Hope for a turn to better Soviet ties was expressed by Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz on their arrival in Moscow for the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev. When they were about to leave the Soviet leader's bier, they were invited by the Soviet protocol officer to speak with Mr. Brezhnev's widow, Viktoria. The American delegation then moved to chairs placed near the bier for family members and Mr. Bush expressed the condolences of the American people. (A1:3.)

title: OILERS TOP RANGERS AS GRETZKY EXCELS
description: The Edmonton Oilers' dressing room door was kept locked longer than usual after last night's game at Madison Square Garden but not because the players were getting a coach's lecture. They didn't need that, having just trounced the Rangers by 7-2.

title: Cass Michaels, Big Leaguer For 12 Years With 4 Teams
description: Casimir (Cass) Michaels, who played in two All-Star Games during his 12-year major league career, died Friday in a hospital in Grosse Point at the age of 56.

title: Train Derailment Spills Wine
description: Tracks remained blocked here today as crews worked to clear debris left when 14 cars of a Santa Fe Railroad freight derailed Saturday, spilling 100,000 gallons of red wine and a load of wrapped Christmas presents. Several of the cars caught fire after the derailment, but the blaze was extinguished by the evening, officials said.

title: PIANO: ANNIE FISCHER RETURNS AFTER DECADE TO PLAY RECITAL
description: ANNIE FISCHER, the Hungarian pianist, came to her Carnegie Hall recital Sunday as somewhat of a mystery woman. Perhaps it was an unwitting and unwilling role, but she has been absent from this country for 10 years and remains adamantly publicity shy.

title: OUTSIDERS CHOSEN TO INSPECT ATOM PLANT THAT U.S. HALTED
description: A team from the Bechtel Group Inc. has been invited to inspect the William H. Zimmer Nuclear Power Plant and recommend how best to complete it, a spokesman for the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company said today.

title: McLouth Steelworkers Approve Concessions
description: Workers at the bankrupt McLouth Steel Corporation have overwhelmingly approved contract concessions, clearing the way for the Chicago industrialist Cyrus Tang to buy the company for $46.5 million, it was announced today.

title: No Headline
description: MCENROE STREAK GROWS

title: RETHINKING POLICY ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Why does the Reagan Administration believe that its policies are working in Central America when many Central Americans perceive a deteriorating political environment? These different perceptions suggest we should reconsider United States interests in the region.

title: News Analysis
description: Two different approaches to union democracy were demonstrated last week, one by the United Mine Workers of America and one by the United Automobile Workers.

title: WHY WORKERS HAVE LOST FAITH IN OSHA
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Arrest Gospel Singer On Drug Possession Charge
description: The gospel singer and composer Andrae Crouch has been arrested on a charge of possessing cocaine and dangerous drugs.

title: NEW MUSIC: A MARATHON
description: AN eight-hour marathon of new music is one of the last things new music needs to bring it closer to the mainstream of today's musical life. But hoping, perhaps, that quantity might carry the argument and that sampling it could be enlightening, the Composers' Forum presented such a marathon at Symphony Space on Saturday.

title: ILLEGAL U.S. AID TO GUATEMALA CHARGED
description: A leftist guerrilla group says it has found documents in the wreckage of a Guatemalan Air Force helicopter that indicate that the United States may be providing aid to Guatemalan military authorities in possible violation of Congressional restraints.

title: Samuel Margolis Dead at 99; Voice Teacher to Opera Stars
description: Samuel Margolis, a voice teacher who trained 19 leading singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company, including Robert Merrill and Jerome Hines, died Saturday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 99 years old and had been a resident of Englewood.

title: We Can't Afford the Butter Mountain
