description: Starting next month, the Agriculture Department will deduct 50 cents from the $13.10 per hundred pounds it now pays dairy farmers for surplus milk. Next April there will be a second 50 cent cut.

title: TELLS HIS BACKERS HE WILL SPEAK OUT
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the outlawed Solidarity union, returned to his home here tonight after 11 months of internment and 36 hours in which there had been no word on his whereabouts.

title: Memorial for June Shaplen
description: A memorial service for June Herman Shaplen of Princeton, N.J., a writer and editor who died Oct. 19 in New York City, will be held at 7 P.M. next Monday at the Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South. Mrs. Shaplen had been a newspaper reporter, an editor of the Scholastic Review and a senior editor at the Macmillan Publishing Company. At her death, she was an international political analyst for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: 7 Protesters Seized At Trident Yard
description: Seven antinuclear weapons protesters were arrested today for ''unauthorized entry'' into the shipyard where the Navy's Trident nuclear submarines are built, the police said.

title: Farberware Executive Moves to Wear-Ever
description: Wear-Ever Aluminum Inc., which recently changed ownership, now has a new chairman and chief executive. He is Arnold Dreyfuss, 54, who had been president of Farberware for the last 10 years.

title: 5 DAILY NEWSPAPERS VIE FOR PUERTO RICO'S READERS
description: For $1.25 a day, most of Puerto Rico's 3.2 million residents can start their morning with an eye-opening, if not always elevating, array of newspapers.

title: DIVERTISSEMENTS: 1984 AND THE STAFF
description: Nearly two weeks after the Congressional election, President Reagan and his aides are struggling through hours of budget meetings. And as if on cue, a twin set of concerns is rising to the surface as a divertissement at the White House.

title: DANCE: VARONE COMPANY
description: THE dances that Douglas Varone presented Saturday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y were certainly filled with the drama of motion itself, yet Mr. Varone was less successful when he tried to express specific dramatic situations as motion.

title: The Rev. Robert W. Gleason, Fordham Theology Chairman
description: The Rev. Robert W. Gleason, S.J., chairman of the theology department at Fordham University, died Thursday at the hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Christmas in November

title: SANDINIST RENEGADE SAYS C.I.A. HAMSTRINGS HIM
description: Eden Pastora Gomez paced impatiently around his small office, digging out old documents that he said showed his political consistency, removing an AR-15 rifle that hangs in front of a map of Nicaragua to point out which Sandinist garrisons had recently deserted to join forces with him.

title: UNION PREPARES A NEW PROPOSAL
description: Negotiators for the National Football League Players Association are drafting a new proposal in an effort to bring management back to the bargaining table, a source familiar with the union stance said last night.

title: THE KANGAROO ALLIANCE
description: The first international negotiation conducted exclusively by George Shultz's State Department has resulted in humiliation for the United States.

title: SOVIET CREW SETS A RECORD IN SPACE
description: Two Soviet astronauts, Lieut. Col Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev, today broke the 185-day space endurance record set by two of their countrymen in 1980, Radio Moscow reported.

title: 5 PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS WOO DEMOCRATIC LEADERS
description: With only 722 days to go until the 1984 election, five Democratic Presidential hopefuls today concluded a weekend of wining, dining and wooing several dozen party leaders.

title: SPACE WALK IS SET FOR TODAY
description: After a fairly relaxed day in orbit today, the Columbia's astronauts were reported to be ready for a space walk outside the shuttle Monday morning, an excursion delayed because one of the mission specialists had motion sickness.

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS SIZE UP THE MARKET FOR HYBRID VANS
description: In their struggle to recapture a share of the market perhaps lost to the Japanese forever, the nation's automobile manufacturers are thinking of bringing out a small, fuel-efficient alternative vehicle that does not exist in the United States today. It is the mini-van, a cross between a van and the traditional station wagon.

title: Miami Measles Outbreak Traced to Peru Case
description: Medical officials working to determine the origin of a measles epidemic here say it apparently could be traced to Peru.

title: Commodities
description: WHENEVER commodity exchanges solicit business for a new futures or options market, which seems to be the case almost every week, the first question brokers ask is: ''If we put our clients into your new market, how quickly can we get them out?''

title: Adviser Added to Cuomo List
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo's office said yesterday that it had inadvertently omitted the name of one person from a list of those appointed to Mr. Cuomo's transition advisory committee. He is John M. Gerity, counsel to the New York State Commission for the Blind.

title: Hardin to Resign
description: Wayne Hardin, the Temple football coach, said today that he would resign at the end of the season, his 12th with the Owls.

title: China Mountain Road Opens
description: China's first highway through the Tianshan range of the remote northwest Xinjiang region has opened to traffic, cutting 620 miles from the old route, People's Daily reported today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With two outs and a runner on second base, the batter hits a single to left field. The runner reaches third and, when it appears as if the left fielder is throwing the ball to home, the batter makes a wide turn and continues to second. The second baseman moves over to cover the bag, but the shortstop cuts off the throw and tags the batter as he reaches second. The batter claims obstruction because the second baseman blocked his route to the bag, even though they did not collide. Was it obstruction?

title: INDIANA LOSES TO SOVIET
description: Arvidas Sabonis, a 17-year-old from the city of Kaunas in the Soviet Union, stepped into the circle with Uwe Blab, a 20-year-old Indiana University junior who was born in Munich, West Germany. When the two 7-foot-2-inch centers shook hands, the 1984 Olympic Games did not seem so far away.

title: BUSH AND SHULTZ VOICE HOPE OF GAIN IN TIES WITH SOVIET
description: Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in Moscow today for the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev and expressed hope that Soviet-American relations could now take a turn for the better.

title: 3 Die as Bus and Car Collide
description: Three persons were killed and nine others were injured today when a Continental Trailways bus and a station wagon collided near the intersection of Routes 60 and 171. The names of the victims were withheld.

title: FLUID TEST PERFORMED FOR YOUTH
description: Dr. Joseph P. Allen, a physicist and astronaut, said today that an experiment designed by an 18-year-old student was telling scientists more about the behavior of fluids in space ''than maybe we wanted to know.''

title: NEW LAW CITED IN DROPPING RAPE CHARGE
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that a recent change in the state's rape law - intended to make prosecution easier - had prevented the filing of a rape charge in the case of a woman who said she was forcibly raped twice but had not feared death or serious injury.

title: IMMIGRANTS SPUR RENAISSANCE FOR QUEENS CHURCHES
description: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's A series of articles appearing periodically. They sit only blocks from one another - two landmark churches that have witnessed centuries of New York City history. At one, a pastor was kidnapped by Indians. At the other, a pastor was removed during the American Revolution because he prayed too often for the British King.

title: Wagner Host in Playoffs
description: Wagner College, which registered eight straight victories after playing a 40-40 tie with Montclair State in the season's opener, will be host to unbeaten St. Lawrence (9-0) in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs Saturday afternoon at Grymes Hill, Staten Island.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Slide Show For Potential Parents

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Abuse of Legal Drugs Is Cited
description: Abuse of prescription drugs causes far more deaths than use of illegal drugs, and state and Federal agencies must work harder to control legal drugs, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Randall Sunberg Weds Miss Cohen
description: Cindy Robin Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cohen of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., and Randall Bruce Sunberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fabian Sunberg of Baton Rouge, La., were married yesterday in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Solomon Roth performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom.

title: SHELTER IN BROOKLYN FOR THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: David Fremed, Accountant, And Gayle V. Sider Married
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday, Gayle Victoria Sider and David Jay Fremed, cum laude alumni of the State University of New York College at Albany, were married by Rabbi Theodore Jungreis, assisted by Cantor Chaskele Ritter.

title: Business Chiefs Ask Budget Cut
description: Representatives from four of the nation's top business groups have urged the Reagan Administration to cut both military spending and retirement and social programs in the effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Health on Horseback
description: A form of therapy for disabled people that began in Europe in the early 1950's has become increasingly popular in the United States in the last decade. Riding a horse is viewed as a pleasant sport by millions of equestrians, but for thousands of victims of such maladies as cerebral palsy, spina bifida, multiple sclerosis and impairments of sight, hearing or speech, horseback riding has proved amazingly beneficial.

title: GOVERNMENT RESTRICTING FLOW OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC
description: In its first 21 months in office, the Reagan Administration has taken several actions that reduce the information available to the public about the operation of the Government, the economy, the environment and public health.

title: ADIRONDACK GROUP CALLS STATE LAX ON ACQUISITION
description: Ten years after New York voters approved a $1.15 billion bond act to improve the state's environment, the Adirondack Council has criticized the state for not spending enough of that money to buy land for the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. filed with the S.E.C. an issue of 1.1 million shares of its common stock to be exchanged for up to $58.7 million of American's 25-year, 7 7/8 percent debentures, through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: No Inmates Injured Or Missing After Fire
description: Santa Rita prison officials said today that they had accounted for the 400 inmates taken from two housing units during a fire set by an arsonist.

title: GEORGIA-PENN ST. LOOMS
description: Again the Sugar Bowl appears to have come up with the lucky draw, the closest thing to a game that may decide the season's final No. 1 college football ranking. It happened when Penn State rallied in the fourth period Saturday to beat Notre Dame, 24-14, a few hours after Georgia had also rallied in the final quarter to beat Auburn, 19-14.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAVERICK CATS. Encounters With Feral Cats. By Ellen Perry Berkeley. Illus- trated by Sandra Crawford. 142 pages. Walker. $12.95.

title: ON BLACK AND WHITE
description: To the Editor:

title: RATE CUT STILL SEEN BY FED WATCHERS
description: A growing group of Fed watchers -economists and analysts who monitor the most minute actions of the Federal Reserve - remain convinced that the nation's central bank will encourage lower interest rates. Their rationale: such a course is necessary to stimulate the lagging economy.

title: 11 Challenges Resolved On Advertisers' Claims
description: October saw 11 challenges of advertising claims resolved by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, which reports that in only two of the cases did the advertisers substantiate their claims.

title: WESTERNERS HEAR TALK THAT ANDROPOV MAY HAVE BEEN VICTOR IN A STRUGGLE
description: The appointment of Yuri V. Andropov as General Secretary of the Communist Party may not have been made with the unanimity that the official account would indicate, according to reports circulating among Western officials here.

title: PARIS OPERA SIGNS NUREYEV AS CHIEF
description: Rudolf Nureyev has signed a three-year contract as director of the Paris Opera ballet that will involve him both in performing and choreography starting next November.

title: MRS. REAGAN FLEW AT EXPENSE OF U.S.
description: Nancy Reagan used helicopters from the Presidential fleet on three occasions when she traveled alone to Camp David, Md., at a cost to the taxpayers of $3,110, White House records show.

title: CONTEST CONTINUING FOR HORSE OF YEAR
description: After two upsets on the unofficial end of the Eastern racing season this weekend, John Henry was still going to Tokyo, and his crown as horse of the year was still up for grabs.

title: Advertising; Luxurious Goods Get TV Blitzes
description: THE Christmas Star, which once attracted the Magi bearing gifts of great value, still attracts the same kind of crowd. Today, however, we call them marketers of luxury goods, but they aren't exactly giving anything away.

title: G.R. ELLIS OF HOUSEHOLD COMPANY
description: Gilbert R. Ellis, chairman and chief executive officer of Household International, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: Diana Bletter, Writer, and Alan Singer Are Married
description: The marriage of Diana Katcher Bletter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Bletter of Great Neck, L.I., to Alan Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Singer of Woodsburgh, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony, asssisted by Cantor Barbara Ostfeld-Horowitz.

title: NEW PROGRAM FOR ADOLESCENT PARENTS
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The office of adolescent pregnancy programs of the United States Department of Health and Human Services is awarding $10 million for projects aimed at discouraging teen-age pregnancies and encouraging adoption as an option to parenthood or abortion.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN is expected to approve a plan devised by Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, to help the domestic specialty steel industry to fight imports. The approval is expected by tomorrow.

title: THE BEASTLINESS IN BOXING
description: IN one of the most beautiful films ever made, Jean Cocteau's ''Beauty and the Beast,'' a young woman is held captive in a chateau by a man who wears elegant lace shirts and speaks French in a husky, passionate voice.

title: BITTER MEMORIES OF WAR HAUNT U.S. RUMANIANS
description: Eugene J. Popescu spent four years and four months of World War II in a Soviet prisoner of war camp learning to cut hair and to hate Communists.

title: Spadolini Says Hypocrisy Wrecked His Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini blamed political ''hypocrisy'' today for bringing down his Government and warned that Italy has ''no future'' if its leaders do not concentrate on solving the country's problems.

title: IT TAKES TWO
description: To deal successfully with the Soviet Union, George Kennan has said, America must show sobriety, steadiness, objectivity, practicality of purpose. I thought of that wise comment the other night as President Reagan, reacting to the death of Leonid Brezhnev, displayed the opposite characteristics.

title: SPREAD OF NUCLEAR ARMS BY 2000 IS SEEN
description: A recent United States intelligence survey asserts that 31 countries, many of them engaged in longstanding regional disputes, will be able to produce nuclear weapons by the year 2000, according to military analysts.

title: BRIEFING
description: Of Ways and Means

title: BABETTE DEUTSCH, 87, NOVELIST, POET, TRANSLATOR AND EDITOR
description: Babette Deutsch, poet, novelist critic and editor, died in her sleep yesterday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 87 years old. Miss Deutsch began her career primarily as a poet and novelist before turning to criticism, editing and translating. She often collaborated on translations with her husband, Avrahm Yarmolinsky. Together they edited a number of anthologies, including ''Modern Russian Poetry,'' published in 1921, and ''Two Centuries of Russian Verse,'' published in 1966. Mr. Yarmolinsky translated from the Russian, and Miss Deutsch, who did not know Russian, polished the English version.

title: WORKERS RATIFY 2-YEAR CONTRACT FOR DAIRY PLANTS
description: Dairy workers in the New York metropolitan area ratified a two-year contract over the weekend, and industry spokesmen said the settlement would mean a rise of at least 2 cents in the price of a quart of milk.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bridge Tow Count: 45 Cars And a Would-Be Suicide

title: EXPERTS PREDICT CALIFORNIA OILFIELD WILL BE BIGGEST FIND SINCE 1968
description: An oil discovery off the southern California coast that has been the talk of the industry in recent weeks now seems certain to become the biggest find since Alaska's Prudhoe Bay field was discovered in 1968.

title: INSURERS' UNACCEPTABLE DISCRIMINATION BY SEX
description: T o the Editor: In a Nov. 9 letter, Richard Minck of the American Council of Life Insurance responded to an Oct. 16 Consumer column on whether insurers should charge women different premium rates than men.

title: U.S. TRADE OFFICIAL SEES LITTLE LASTING EFFECTS OF PIPELINE CURBS
description: The American sanctions against the Soviet natural gas pipeline, which were lifted Saturday by President Reagan, are unlikely to have significant lasting effects on the companies that were involved, a senior Administration official said today.

title: OPERA: 'DONNA DEL LAGO' IN A CARNEGIE CONCERT
description: IF you want to start a good argument among people who know and love the operas of the high bel canto period, ask them how and why these works should be produced and sung for modern audiences. One school believes that an opera such as Rossini's ''La Donna del Lago,'' which was presented Sunday night in a concert version at Carnegie Hall as part of a ''Gala Rossini Opera Festival,'' is about great singing and not much else. The other side insists there are pre-Romantic depths of expression to be plumbed in the best of these works and that to offer them as no more than a series of vocal showpieces is to distort their essence. After this performance, it must be said, the jury is still out.

title: MUSIC: ALI AKBAR KHAN'S BIRTHDAY
description: WITH his sly smile, rounded face and sparkling, almond-shape eyes, Ali Akbar Khan looked like a genie from the ''Arabian Nights'' on Saturday at Columbia University's McMillin Theater. Or perhaps he only seemed genielike because he was working such subtle magic with his gleaming sarod, the 25-string Indian lute of teak, steel, chrome and bronze.

title: Swiss Riders Win Prix des Nations
description: Switzerland upset the United States and France, the world champion, to win the Prix des Nations at the Royal Horse Show today.

title: Small but Deadly
description: A pint-sized hockey player from Winnipeg, Manitoba, who seems destined to arrive with a flourish in the National Hockey League within the next few seasons, is threatening records in Canadian Major Junior Hockey, evoking comparisons with such famed juniors as Jean Beliveau and Guy Lafleur.

title: Japan Wins Judo
description: Japan beat the Soviet Union in the finals to win the team title today in the 33-nation Kano Cup judo competition. Each side had two victories and one draw against two losses, but the Japanese were declared the winners because of their superior techniques. France and the United States shared third place.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CALIFORNIA'S CHIEF JUSTICE IS FACING A RECALL MOVE
description: Even though three of its seven members narrowly survived an attempt to deny them confirmation in the Nov. 2 election, the California Supreme Court still faces trying times in the next few months.

title: MORE WOMEN WORK AT TRADITIONAL MALE JOBS
description: An increasing number of women in the United States are working at what used to be men's jobs. Despite the unemployment rate, the number of women working in the United States has risen 21 million, or 95 percent, over the last two decades, according to a new study by the United States Department of Labor, and many of the jobs they have taken are in categories once largely the province of men.

title: MUSIC: FOUR MODERNS BY PARNASSUS
description: THE chamber group Parnassus played four 20th-century works Saturday evening at the Abraham Goodman House, and it was somewhat surprising to note that the oldest composition sounded the most recent. But Henry Cowell's ''United'' String Quartet, which dates from 1936, focuses on many current compositional ideas: it has a strong rhythmic pulse, frequent repetitions, a simple and direct tonal language, and it reveals the marked influence of Eastern music.

title: REBUILDING IRAN'S ECONOMY
description: The Iranian economy, battered by war and boycotts, is a patchwork of inconsistency. From one point of view ''the country is in a very pleasant economic situation,'' as President Ali Khamenei said in a recent television interview. Oil revenue, the backbone of the economy, amounts to $2 billion a month; the flow of oil money has buoyed Iran's foreign currency reserves, which were nearly exhausted a year ago. Those reserves, according to the estimate of bankers in Europe and diplomats here, stand at about $15 billion.

title: ILLEGALLY SELECTIVE NURSING HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Meatcutters Approve Pact
description: Southern California meatcutters today gave overwhelming approval to a new three-year contract with 18 supermarket chains. A spokesman for the 10,000-member United Food and Commercial Workers International said the meatcutters approved the pact, which was reported to provide about a 15 percent pay increase over the three years and cost-of-living adjustments.

title: DISCUSSION BEGINS OVER BUYING $35 BILLION IN F-18 JETS FOR NAVY
description: A debate has erupted in the Navy Department over a $35 billion program to buy 1,300 F-18 Hornet jet planes. On one side are the department's program managers responsible for buying and developing the aircraft. They briefed the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James Watkins, on Friday, asserting that the F-18 was reliable, effective and easy to maintain, according to briefing materials made available.

title: VACATION: STUDENTS VS. PARENTS
description: IT is the time of year when parents the country over are thinking a bout the college and boarding-school students who will be coming h ome for the first vacation of the academic year. Many parents are e nvisioning a time of family camaraderie, shared activities and c onversation to compensate for their separation from children at s chool.

title: Donna Lipman Is Wed
description: The marriage of Donna Lipman to Robert Michael Boni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Boni of Douglaston, Queens, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lipman, in Manhattan. Rabbi Judah Kahn performed the ceremony. The bride is media director of the Lipman Advertising Company, which was founded by her grandfather, Herbert M. Lipman. Mr. Boni is president of the International Standardbred Company, horse breeders and brokers in New York.

title: Basketball Immortal
description: A group of civic and athletic achievers whose roots were on the Lower East Side of Manhattan will be honored on Thursday night at the Plaza Hotel. One of them will be Nat Holman, now 86 years old, who has been called the ''Socrates of the basketball court'' for his playing and coaching accomplishments over more than half a century.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will assuredly speak out on all matters which interest us in the very near future.

title: Sysco's President Adds Chief Executive Duties
description: John F. Woodhouse, president and chief operating officer of the Sysco Corporation of Houston, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer of the big food distribution company.

title: Dr. Michele Brown And Dr. Gad Lavy Wed
description: The marriage of Dr. Michele Dory Brown and Dr. Gad Lavy, residents in obstetrics and gynecology at the Yale-New Haven Hospital, took place yesterday in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Lyle Fishman performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: A HOPEFUL, JITTERY, CABLE-TV MEETING
description: The ghost of CBS Cable - the cultural programming network that collapsed last September - hung heavily today over a cable television industry that, in many ways, couldn't be doing better.

title: MERGER RIVAL SUES HOSPITAL CONCERN
description: A woman who competed against the Hospital Corporation of America in bidding to buy a small group of hospitals in 1980 has charged that the company had brought pressure on two banks not to finance her offer.

title: FANS TURN TO THEIR OPTIONS WITHOUT PRO FOOTBALL
description: SUNDAYS are different in America these days. In Pittsburgh people flock to a flower show; in New York they crowd museums; in New Orleans they stream to the Gulf shores; in Green Bay they fill Kroll's West, a restaurant usually deserted because fans are in the stadium across the street; in Philadelphia they overrun the golf courses; in Miami they immerse themselves in culture, and in San Francisco they fill the parks.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Friday incor- rectly located the Liberty Bell. It has been moved from Independence Hall in Philadelphia to a nearby building.

title: Waters Dismissed
description: Muddy Waters was dismissed today as football coach at Michigan State.

title: A YEAR LATER, LOTTERY PRIZE STILL A 'FANTASY'
description: Thinking about it still gives them both a chill. And though it has been a year, and they've been over it hundreds of times, they still like telling the story - every glorious detail - of when and how they found out they had won $5 million in the New York State Lottery.

title: PRE-MENSTRUAL STRESS SYNDROME AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN URGES KOCH TO TIGHTEN WORK RULES TO HELP BUDGET
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan yesterday urged Mayor Koch to eliminate ''unproductive work rules'' to help balance New York City's budget. He said new taxes should be considered only as a ''last resort.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Figure Skating Superskates IX, benefit performance for the United States Olympic Fund, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M. Among those participating are the individual world champions, Elaine Zayak and Scott Hamilton; the three-time national pairs champions, Jo Jo Starbuck and Ken Shelley, and two former Olympic stars, Janet Lynn and Toller Cranston. Tennis Benson & Hedges Grand Prix indoor tournament, singles final, John McEnroe vs.

title: COBWEBS IN THE GYM
description: time world heavyweight champion, who will leave Wednesday for an exhibition tour of Saudi Arabia, India and Pakistan, has been working out in order to regain a semblance of his once sculptured shape.

title: U.S. Reporter Is Shot in Head During a Clash in El Salvador
description: An American journalist wounded Saturday in a clash between guerrillas and Salvadoran troops was released today from a hospital and said he was in excellent condition.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Looming Over the West Bank
description: Despite their overpowering military feats against Syria and the P.L.O. in Lebanon, Israel's leaders speak like an embattled lot. Rival visions of mortal danger dominate their bitterly partisan competitions and have reopened a 60-year-old Zionist debate about the nation's optimum size and character. The only agreement is that within the next year the nation will end up making a fateful choice.

title: Wagner, Adams Gain
description: Bayside High School of Queens, which had won the Public Schools Athletic League Division A the last three years, was eliminated in the semifinal round yesterday, 22-13, by undefeated Susan Wagner.

title: Required Reading; Telling the Story
description: Excerpts from a news briefing by Philip C. Habib, following a meeting with President Reagan, Nov. 11, 1982: LARRY SPEAKES, deputy White House press secretary: Ambassador Habib will tell you about his new appointment as Special Representative for the Middle East. He will limit his questions, as usual, to just a few.

title: ISSUES SET BY STATES AND DOW
description: With the Treasury's November re-funding operation now completed, activity in the new-issue market for fixed-income securities this week puts the spotlight on municipal and corporate offerings.

title: No Headline
description: SONICS REACH 10-0

title: Nabisco Embezzlement
description: Sally L. Hasper, the Nabisco Brands Inc. executive who admits embezzling $2.1 million, will repay as much of the money as she can, according to her lawyer. The 37-year-old San Mateo woman was arraigned Friday before United States Magistrate Frederick Woelflen, who formally entered an innocent plea for her although her attorney said he will plead her guilty before District Judge William Orrick on Dec. 16.

title: THOUSANDS MARK TALMUDIC MILESTONE
description: Thousands of Orthodox Jews, for whom the intense study of the Talmud is one of the most pious acts a man can perform, gathered in Madison Square Garden yesterday to celebrate the completion of a seven-and-a-half-year cycle of learning in which small study groups around the world met daily to pore over one of 2,711 pages of Jewish law.

title: VARIED ANSWERS ON SOCIAL SECURITY FORESEEN BY 2 LEADERS IN CONGRESS
description: The chairmen of the Congressional panels on Social Security said today that a number of different approaches would ultimately be adopted to stave off the $150 billion to $200 billion deficit expected by 1990 and the even larger shortage predicted over the next 75 years.

title: BEGIN, BEREAVED, ENDS U.S. TOUR
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's scheduled meeting this Friday with President Reagan has been postponed indefinitely because of the death of Mr. Begin's wife, Aliza, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: No Headline
description: Black Hawks Win, 5-4, on 4 Goals in 3d

title: Tip-Off TV Date Depends on Strike
description: The date of the annual Tip-Off Classic game, the official opening of the national collegiate basketball season, will depend on the National Football League players' strike.

title: ALIZA BEGIN, ISRAELI LEADER'S WIFE, DIES IN A JERUSALEM HOSPITAL AT 62
description: Aliza Begin, the wife of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, died in Jerusalem today after a long illness. She was 62 years old.

title: William Paterson Defeats Lowell
description: Kerry McCann scored twice on runs of 1 yard each as William Paterson (5-5) concluded its season with a 27-21 victory over Lowell University today.

title: O.A.S. Is Urged to Act In Human Rights Cases
description: Amnesty International said today that the Organization of American States should crack down on persistent human rights abuses by some O.A.S. members, including governmentsanctioned torture, killings and kidnappings.

title: COLONEL COUNTERS SHARON TESTIMONY
description: A top Israeli military aide, testifying at an inquiry into September's slaying of hundreds of Palestinian civilians at two refugee camps in Beirut, today contradicted testimony by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon about the decision to allow Phalangist militiamen into the camps.

title: THE DANCE: 'FESTIVAL OF THE NILE'
description: ''FESTIVAL OF THE NILE,'' presented Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, turned out to be an Egyptian variety show with some fascinating folk numbers and a lesson on how to communicate fabulously with an audience.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TAKE THE STAND

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision to lift some of the most stringent sanctions directed against the Soviet pipeline project is likely to become a continuing source of dispute in Washington and with some of the allies.

title: Nomura Head Aims For Higher Profits
description: Yoshio Terasawa, the new chairman and chief executive officer of Nomura Securities International, has ambitious plans for the expansion of the securities firm's business in the United States.

title: FRANCE DENIES TRADE PACT WAS REACHED
description: France today flatly contradicted President Reagan's statement that he was lifting Soviet pipeline sanctions because Western European governments had agreed to new curbs on trade with the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies.

title: SPORTS AND LEARNING
description: To the Editor:

title: FISCAL WOES OF STATE COULD PREVENT IT FROM HELPING CITY CUT DEFICIT
description: New York City's budget problems are being worsened by a growing state deficit that state officials say could prevent Albany from providing the amount of financial assistance the city is counting on to help close its deficit.

title: Hoch Takes Golf In Japan by 3
description: Scott Hoch, winner of the New Orleans Open, shot a three-under-par 69 today and won the $300,000 Pacific Masters golf tournament by three strokes.

title: Hidden Money for the Homeless
description: New York City's program for homeless men involves a lot of busing. Evenings, the men ride buses to shelters where they sleep. Mornings, they ride back to the men's shelter on the Bowery for meals and showers. City officials say that centralizing the eating and bathing reduces costs. New York Supreme Court Judge Richard Wallach, however, calls the system a ''cruel and unacceptable hoax.''

title: LEADERS OF DELEGATIONS TO BREZHNEV'S FUNERAL
description: Following are the leaders of national and other delegations arriving in Moscow for the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev on Monday: National Delegation Leaders Afghanistan - President Babrak Karmal, party secretary Austria - President Rudolf Kirchschlager Bangladesh - Rear Adm. M.H. Ali Khan Belgium - Prime Minister Wilfried Martens Botswana - Akuna Mpuchane, Ambassador to Britain Britain - Foreign Secretary Francis Pym Bulgaria - President Todor Zhivkov, the party secretary Cambodia - President Heng Samrin, the party secretary Cameroon - Agriculture Minister Samuel Ebua Canada - Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau China - Foreign Minister Huang Hua Colombia - Hector Cherry, representative at the United Nations in Europe Cuba - President Fidel Castro, the party secretary Cyprus - President Spyros Kyprianou Czechoslovakia - President Gustaf Husak, the party secretary Denmark - Prince Henrik East Germany - President Erich Honecker, the party secretary Egypt - Mamdouh Salem, the presidential secretary Ethiopia - Chairman Mengistu Haile Mariam Finland - President Mauno Koivisto France - Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy Greece - Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou Hungary - Janos Kadar, the party secretary India - Prime Minister Indira Gandhi Indonesia - Vice President Adam Malik Italy - Amintore Fanfani, President of the Senate Japan - Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki Jordan - Prime Minister Mudar Badran Kenya - Foreign Minister Robert Ouko Laos - Prince Souphanouvong Lesotho - Deputy Prime Minister Evarist Sekhonyana Libya - Abdul Salam Jalloud. Malta - President Agatha Barbara Mongolia - President Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal, the party secretary Mozambique - President Samora M. Machel Netherlands - Deputy Prime Minister Gijs Van Aardenne Nicaragua - Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the junta leader Nigeria - Vice President Alex Ekwueme North Korea - Vice President Pak Sung Chul Norway - Prime Minister Kare Willoch Pakistan - President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq Philippines - Imelda Marcos, wife of the President Poland - Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Prime Minister and party secretary Portugal - Foreign minister Vasco Futscher Pereira Rumania - President Nikolae Ceausescu, the party secretary Southern Yemen - President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani Spain - Foreign Minister Jose Pedro Perez Llorca Sweden - Prime Minister Olof Palme Syria - President Hafez al-Assad Tunisia - Justice Minister Mohammed Chaker Turkey - Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu Uganda - Vice President Paulo Muwanga. United States - Vice President Bush Venezuela - Foreign Minister Jose Alberto Zambrano Vietnam - President Truong Chinh West Germany - President Karl Carstens Yugoslavia - President Petar Stambolic Zimbabwe - President Canaan Banana Other Delegation Leaders Chile - Luis Corvalan, party leader France - Georges Marchais, party leader Italy - Enrico Berlinguer, party leader Palestine Liberation Organization - Yasir Arafat, chairman Portugal - Alvaro Cunhal, party leader United Nations - Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar United States - Gus Hall, party leader Uruguay - Rodney Arismendi, party leader Vatican - Prof. Giovanni Battista Marini Bettolo

title: GERTRUDE JARVIS
description: Gertrude Jarvis, an antiques dealer in Manhattan, died Saturday at Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Soviet Grain Purchases
description: The Soviet Union bought 850,000 tons of American corn last week, its first purchase of American grain under President Reagan's offer a month ago assuring shipment within six months, according to the Agriculture Department. The latest transaction brings total purchases by the Soviet Union to nearly 2.5 million tons of American corn in the current year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Forecasts for Mayors

title: A LEADER IS MISSED BY NETS
description: The corner in the back left side of the Nets' locker room here at Byrne Meadowlands Arena is quiet these days. Ray Williams used to sit there. And after every home game - win or lose - he was back there, lounging in his director's chair and unleashing a torrent of quips, barbs and one-liners toward teammates, reporters, or anyone else who happened by.

title: Briton Comes to U.S.  To Dry Up I.R.A. Funds
description: Dismayed by the acquittal of five suspected gunrunners in New York, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary has started a weeklong trip to the United States in an effort to stop Americans from giving money to what he calls front organizations for the Irish Republican Army.

title: PLUGGING PRODUCTS IN MOVIES AS AN APPLIED ART
description: THE script for ''Rocky III'' is amended to include a Wheaties scene, in which Rocky advises his young son to eat the ''breakfast of champions'' if he wants to grow up big and strong. In ''North Dallas 40,'' a scene involving salad dressing is inserted so that the actors can conspicuously use Bertolli Olive Oil. In ''Honeysuckle Rose,'' the beer bottles are carefully arranged so that a particular beer is by Willie Nelson's side when he's relaxed and happy. As for the troublemakers, they drink another brand.

title: FIGHTER LINGERS NEAR DEATH
description: More than 36 hours after he was knocked out by Ray Mancini, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, Duk Koo Kim of South Korea remained in critical condition and near death today at Desert Springs Hospital. The members of Kim's entourage kept vigil at the hospital, stunned by events in a country far from home.

title: New Bottle-Deposit Law In Effect in Delaware
description: Delaware's new bottle-deposit law takes effect Monday as beer and soft-drink distributors try to unload no-deposit containers that retailers can sell until Jan. 15.

title: OUT OF DEATH, A ZEST FOR LIFE
description: Every time Dr. Gisella Perl enters a delivery room, she stops first to pray: ''God, you owe me a life, a living baby.'' That debt was incurred in Auschwitz in World War II, when the Hungarian gynecologist, who was both inmate and physician at the concentration camp, realized that to save the lives of hundreds of pregnant women, she would have to prevent them from giving birth.

title: New Westphal Role
description: Paul Westphal, who has been a high-scoring guard in the National Basketball Association for most of his 11-year career with the Boston Celtics, the Phoenix Suns, the Seattle SuperSonics and the Knicks, is not about to consider retirement at the age of 31. But on Wednesday he is going to try something new in his career.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1982; International
description: France denied again that the U.S. and its allies had reached an overall agreement on East-West trade as a quid pro quo for President Reagan's decision to lift sanctions on companies supplying the Soviet natural gas pipeline. (Page A10.) The President's move left unanswered a number of diplomatic and economic questions. (A1.) The companies affected by the sanctions will probably recoup the lost business, a top Commerce official said. (A10.) Moscow's need for American technology is great, a Senate study concludes. (A10.)

title: McDonald Victor In Bicycle Race
description: Vince McDonald of the Century Road Club Association pulled away from two teammates, Thayer Hewitt and Jerry Malone, and won the Union Square Bicycle Criterium 35-kilometer race in 58 minutes 1.41 seconds yesterday afternoon.

title: News Analysis
description: Diplomats assessing the swift appointment of Yuri V. Andropov as General Secretary of the Communist Party believe that he wants to make an early beginning on a tightening of discipline through the whole of Soviet society, to lessen inefficiency and waste that caused widespread disillusionment in the last years of Leonid I. Brezhnev's tenure.

title: Sandra Schneider Is Bride
description: The marriage of Sandra Terry Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Schneider of Woodmere, L.I., to William Martin Lehman took place yesterday at the Helmsley Palace. The bridegroom, a partner in the accounting concern of Price, Waterhouse, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Lehman of Iowa City.

title: Swimmer Banned
description: Andrew Gray, a swimmer for the University of Houston, was suspended for two years by the British Swimming Federation today for use of a stimulant drug during the Scottish swimming championships last August. Gray, a 21-year-old South African, had been suspended earlier by the Scottish Swimming Association.

title: DANCE: TULSA SALUTES FIVE INDIAN BALLERINAS
description: Tulsa did American dance proud Friday. To start, there was the unveiling of ''Oklahoma Indian Ballerina,'' a larger-than-life-size statue by Jay O'Meilia that stands in a plaza next to the city's handsome Performing Arts Center. A composite of Oklahoma's five American Indian ballerinas - Yvonne Chouteau, Rosella Hightower, Moscelyne Larkin and Maria and Marjorie Tallchief - the statue was erected in celebration of the 75th anniversary of Oklahoma's statehood.

title: International Team Trials Start Today in Minneapolis
description: The International Team Trials to select the North American representatives for the 1983 Bermuda Bowl contest begin today in Minneapolis. Five expert teams will be competing.

title: PLAYERS LINK PENN WITH ITS TRADITION
description: Just before noon last Friday, Jerry Berndt, the ''reclamation man,'' sat himself in the front of a golf cart that was embellished by a covering in the shape of a football helmet, and he traversed the campus of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Christine Lortie Bride Of David H. Rosenthal
description: Christine Mary Lortie, daughter of Edward Lortie of Delmar, N.Y., and the late Jean Lortie, was married yesterday to David Harris Rosenthal, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Rosenthal of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi David Seligson, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

title: HOW TO HIT WATERFOWL
description: IF you've never gone waterfowling and are invited to do so, you should be aware, even if you've had considerable experience with upland birds or trap and skeet, that the shooting skills you required in those pursuits cannot be transferred immediately to the art of bagging ducks or geese.

title: HEARING TO BEGIN ON TRAIN ACCIDENT
description: The Federal Government is to open a formal hearing Monday on the causes of the derailment Sept. 28 of a freight train carrying chemicals, a derailment that, the police said, occurred after a clerk took the controls from an engineer who had been drinking.

title: U.S. TECHNOLOGY EXPORTS ASSAILED
description: A Senate subcommittee recommended today that the Government step up its efforts to prevent the movement of high technology equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS ARE TO OPEN NUCLEAR ARMS DEBATE TODAY
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States have achieved a consensus on the need to speak out against many aspects of the arms race but will debate some unresolved questions, principally nuclear deterrence, starting today at their annual meeting in Washington.

title: ECONOMICS FIRST
description: Over the last three decades, the economies of the world's industrial countries have gradually grown more integrated, but their economic policies have not. Sooner or later, the inconsistencies of such a system had to be tested.

title: POP: SWEET PEA ATKINSON
description: DAVID WEISS and Donald Feigenson, who record as the Was Brothers in the band Was (Not Was), recently produced an album for the band's singer, Sweet Pea Atkinson. While the Detroit-based Was (Not Was) is basically a studio outfit, it convened Saturday at the Peppermint Lounge to promote that LP, ''Don't Walk Away.''

title: Jersey to Study Bill On Business Moves
description: The Assembly plans to consider a bill Monday that would require businesses to notify state officials when they plan to leave New Jersey.

title: Atlantic City Casinos Pick Kaufman & Maraffi
description: Kaufman & Maraffi Advertising, specialists in travel and resort advertising, has become the first agency for the four-year-old Atlantic City Casino Hotel Association, composed of the resort's nine casino hotels.

title: DEBT CRISIS FORCES SHIFT BY BRAZIL
description: A balance-of-payments crisis is about to force Brazil to arrange a loan with the International Monetary Fund and accept direct assistance from the United States, two steps that it has long argued were fundamentally against its political interests.

title: Market Place; Buffering Growth Stocks
description: THE satisfying gains often provided by shares of rapidly growing companies can evaporate quickly in a selloff. How then can investors use these shares without undue risk?

title: THE PISTONS' 2 WORKING BUDDIES
description: When the players are introduced before a game, they usually greet one another at center court with handslaps. Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons can be more demonstrative when he greets Kelly Tripucka.

title: PRELIMINARY ISRAELI STUDY INDICATES NO TERRORISM IN BUILDING COLLAPSE
description: The collapse of Israel's military headquarters building in southern Lebanon last week was not the result of a terrorist attack, according to the preliminary results of an inquiry that were disclosed today.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Iraq Says It Foiled New Iranian Thrust

title: SIGNAL: 2 DECADES OF MERGERS
description: The Signal Companies has been reshaped in the last 20 years from an oil company dwarfed by giant competitors into a cash-rich conglomerate. Stock mergers have often provided its entry into promising businesses.

title: WHEN ENMITY KILLS A LONG PARTNERSHIP
description: For John Doran and Edward J. Lennon Jr., breaking up is hard to do. In fact, although the two elderly co-owners of the T.J. Ronan Paint Corporation still share an office at their small South Bronx paint manufacturing plant, they have barely been on speaking terms for the past six years.

title: KNIGHT ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a $940,000 writedown of the company's oil and gas properties and dry hole and abandoned lease expenses of $684,675...C-Net income

title: KOCH DECIDES TO FILL ALL POLICE VACANCIES, AIDES SAY
description: Mayor Koch, who said recently that the size of the Police Department would decline this fiscal year because the city could not afford to replace all the officers who retired or resigned, has decided instead to fill all vacancies, City Hall officials said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Drew Casen's Team Wins Finals of the Von Zedtwitz
description: A quintet headed by Drew Casen stormed through to victory Friday night in the final stages of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship at the Cavendish Club.

title: The Pipeline Pipe Dream
description: Why did President Reagan decide to lift his sanctions against European and American companies aiding the Soviet gas pipeline? For all the complicated, divergent explanations, there is one simple, overriding reason: the sanctions did more damage to the West than to the Soviet Union. Though allies may be led, they could not be forced to follow the American effort, misguided from the start. So there is little reason to cheer the President's belated move, welcome as it is.

title: OLDER WOMEN AND MALE MYTHS
description: Male fantasies about women over the age of 40 can be harmful to women's self-image, according to a Manhattan psychotherapist who has devoted a good part of her career to studying the so-called older woman.

title: Chrysler Layoffs Mounting in U.S.
description: Another 2,100 Chrysler Corporation auto workers in the United States began layoffs because of the strike by the company's Canadian workers, while a company spokesman said its five United States assembly plants could be closed before Christmas.

title: OFFICIALS TRY TO NEGOTIATE LIMIT ON RISE IN 75-CENT Fare
description: With new figures showing revenue from a New York State transit-tax package $250 million below expectations, legislative and transit officials are negotiating to try to hold down an anticipated increase next month in the 75-cent subway and bus fare.

title: Bloom Picks Up Some Schering-Plough Items
description: The Bloom Agency in Dallas has been assigned the creative responsibilities for the following Schering-Plough Corporation consumer operations:

title: HOME CARE AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO NURSING HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net income, including a tax credit of $65,000

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There was minority interest in net earnings of $134,000 in the latest qr and $488,000 in the latest 9 mos

title: TRIAL ON ARMS SMUGGLING OPENS AGAINST EX-AGENT
description: The first of four scheduled trials of Edwin P. Wilson began here today with a Federal prosecutor asserting that the former American intelligence agent had provided weapons to the Libyan Government in return for money, and a defense lawyer saying Mr. Wilson had been trying to help the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Friendly Departure From Williams Cos.
description: The Williams Companies, a Tulsa, Okla., energy, fertilizer and metals company, announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Barry J. Galt, had resigned.

title: No Headline
description: Virginia Quits the W.B.A.

title: The Empty Coffee Cups of Don Shula
description: MIAMI I n the wastepaper basket next to Don Shula's desk, more than a dozen empty, white Styrofoam cups testify to how he has been spending the empty National Football League season: drinking coffee instead of coaching the Miami Dolphins.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $164,917 from discontinued operations...C-Net income after a loss of $54,070 from discontinued operations

title: Boston College Set For Tangerine Bowl
description: Will Face Auburn

title: Plane Crash Kills Eight Near Virginia Airport
description: Eight persons were killed when a twin-engine airplane hit a tree after taking off Sunday night from a rural airport, but the wreckage was not discovered until 12 hours later, the authorities said today.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: Results were translated at the average rate of exchange: 26.9334 Israeli shekels per $1 for the latest second qr and 12.54 Israeli shekels per $1 for the yr-ago second qr

title: TV: NBC'S STYLISH 'ST. ELSEWHERE'
description: HOSPITALS are notoriously healthy sources of entertainment, from the drama of a play like ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' to the satire of a movie like Paddy Chayefsky's ''Hospital.'' On television, hospitals are an almost numbing constant. From ''General Hospital'' on down, the soap operas are teeming with men and women in white.

title: CONCERT: MUSICIANS OF SCANDINAVIA
description: AN important contribution to our understanding of some neglected music was available in a ''Saturday Afternoon of Scandinavian Music-Making,'' heard over the weekend in Alice Tully Hall.

title: TEAMSTER TRIAL POINT CLARIFIED
description: The defense in the trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, attempted today to clarify a taped reference to a ''commitment'' to Senator Howard W. Cannon, whom Mr. Williams and four others are accused of conspiring to bribe. Defense testimony in Federal District Court said the commitment was only to give the Senator ''fair treatment.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said it intended to file with the S.E.C. for an issue of up to 1.25 million shares of its common stock.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
G.O.P. GOVERNORS DISCUSS '82 LOSSES
description: The dwindling band of Republican governors sat down today to fix blame for their 1982 losses and cited unemployment, budget deficits, high military spending, loose talk on Social Security and their party's inattention to minority groups and women. Occasionally they even blamed the Democrats.

title: U.S. ASKS HIGH COURT TO RESTRICT NASHVILLE BUSING
description: The Reagan Administration stepped up its attacks on busing for the purposes of desegregating schools today, urging the Supreme Court to consider restricting integration efforts in Nashville.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Akron Sewer Explosions Follow Factory Spill
description: A series of explosions blew manhole covers off sewers on the city's east side today, after a chemical spill at a Goodyear Tire and Rubber plant that sent hundreds of gallons of flammable solvent into sewers.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
700 Sikhs Seized As Asian Games Are Due
description: The police, fearful that Akali Sikh activists may try to disrupt the Asian Games, have arrested more than 700 of them and mounted sentries on roads into New Delhi, news reports said today.

title: BREZHNEV BURIED IN MOSCOW POMP
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev was buried today in front of the Kremlin Wall after a state funeral exceeding in scale and pomp anything seen in the Soviet Union since the death of Stalin in 1953.

title: KNEES FEEL THE MILEAGE MOST
description: SOUTH BEND, IND. A fter the end of his final game at Notre Dame Stadium last Saturday evening, Kevin Griffith took down the black and white portrait of himself that had been taped to his dressing stall. There had been a picture waiting for each senior, but it would not be accurate to call Griffith a senior.

title: AMDISCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $482,000 for the qr and $687,000 for the yr...D-Net loss including income of $482,000 from discontinued operations...E-Including income of $634,000 from discontinued operations

title: LAUTENBERG OUTLINES KEY CHALLENGES HE EXPECTS TO FACE AS U.S. SENATOR
description: Frank R. Lautenberg relaxed in his office at Automatic Data Processing here the other day after completing a twoday statewide tour to thank supporters for electing him. In an interview with Jane Perlez of The New York Times, he talked about the challenges that he faced in Washington as the next United States Senator from New Jersey. Here are excerpts from that interview.

title: Turnpike Tokens For Connecticut
description: Connecticut Turnpike commuters began using tokens for the first time today at the eight toll plazas between New York and Rhode Island. The tokens will allow the use of more automatic lanes to speed traffic.

title: MAYORS, IN CITY, HAIL ALLIANCE FOR U.S. RECOVERY
description: Mayors from around the country met in New York yesterday with leaders of business and labor, and when it was all over, they said agreement had been reached on an economic recovery program for America's cities.

title: REVERE COPPER & BRASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $9,578,000 for the qr and $21,248,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per shr earnings reflect the effect of two 100 percent stock distributions in Oct 1981 and Apr 1982

title: GENE BARO, 58, ORGANIZER OF ART EXHIBITIONS
description: Gene Baro, internationally known as an organizer of art exhibitions, curator of this year's Carnegie International Exhibition in Pittsburgh, consulting curator of prints and drawings at the Brooklyn Museum and adjunct curator of contemporary art at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Old Bennington, Vt. He was 58 years old.

title: OWNERS AND UNION HOLD MEETING
description: Representatives of the National Football League owners and striking players met face to face last night for the first time in nine days. Management put forth a modified version of its last contract proposal, but the two sides appeared no closer to an agreement than they were before the meeting began.

title: TERA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RABBI ABRAHAM AVRUTICK, 72
description: Rabbi Abraham N. AvRutick, former president of the Rabbinical Council of America and a leading spokesman for Orthodox Judaism, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in West Hartford, Conn., two days after suffering a stroke. He was 72 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1982
description: International Washington-Bonn unity on a basically conservative approach to relations with the Soviet Union were expressed by President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl. After two hours of talks at the White House, they issued a joint statement expressing their willingness to increase cooperation with the new Soviet leadership but only ''if Soviet conduct makes that possible.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Vice President Bush met briefly with the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. The meeting was described by the American side as ''frank, cordial and substantive'' and by the Russians as an exchange ''on the fundamental matters of Soviet-U.S. relations.'' Neither side offered details. (A10:1-2.)

title: ASTRONAUTS' WALK CANCELED AS SPACESUITS FAIL
description: The fifth mission of the space shuttle Columbia had a disappointing failure today when the astronauts' spacesuits malfunctioned, forcing cancellation of what would have been the first walk in space by Americans in almost nine years.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Alberto Salazar, the American-record holder for 5,000 meters, will run that distance in the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Jan. 28. ... Ivan Lendl and Guillermo Vilas have become the second and third players to qualify for the $400,000 Volvo Masters tennis tournament. Jimmy Connors qualified last week. Spots for nine singles players and six doubles teams are still available for the tournament, which will be held Jan. 18-23 at Madison Square Garden.

title: COMMONWEALTH OIL REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $400,000 for the qr and $1.3 million for the9 mos...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $35.2 million; the company is listed on the Pacific and Phildelphia stock exchanges

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books Of The Times
description: THE MIRACLE OF DUNKIRK. By Walter Lord. 323 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $17.95.

title: ONE MAN'S VIEW OF RISING COSTS
description: After several years in which tuition costs rose significantly and financial aid became increasingly scarce, the economic news has recently brought some encouraging signs for college students and their parents. The rate of inflation has decreased; interest rates are declining and college endowments have increased dramatically as a result of the recent surge in the stock market.

title: News Analysis
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan had instructed Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz not to engage in any hostile exchanges with the new Soviet leaders and to emphasize that there would be no change in Administration policy.

title: Juniper Directors Selling to Damson
description: The Juniper Petroleum Corporation of Denver said a three-member committee of directors had decided that the Damson Oil Corporation's $10-a-share offer to buy 51 percent of Juniper was inadequate.

title: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including the cumulative effect of a change in accounting less related incomeof $373,000

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DISPUTED RAPE CASE WILL PROCEED, MISS HOLTZMAN SAYS
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn yesterday reversed her subordinates and said her office would seek a rape indictment in a case that provoked a sharp dispute over the state's recently amended rape law.

title: G.E. Divestiture
description: The General Electric Company said it wants to sell all eight of its radio stations and two of its TV stations, including WRGB-TV in Schenectady, the nation's oldest television station. G.E. will keep KOA-TV in Denver as its sole broadcast station. The other stations for sale are: WGY-AM and WGFM-FM in Schenectady; WNGE-TV, WSIX-AM and WSIX-FM, all in Nashville; KOA-AM and KOAQ-FM in Denver; WJIB-FM in Boston, and KFOG-FM in San Francisco.

title: STEEP ROCK IRON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIERCE CLOUD COLLISIONS AND THE RAIN
description: FOLK wisdom long blamed thunder on collisions between storm clouds and it was once even suggested that such encounters precipitated heavy rainfall. British weather researchers have now reported that cloud collisions - or, more properly, ''mergers'' - can increase rainfall fourfold.

title: UNDERRATED PERILS OF LOW-LEVEL NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPOSED WESTCHESTER BUDGET WOULD INCRESE TAX RATE 2.4%
description: An increase of 2.4 percent in the Westchester County property-tax rate was proposed today by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, as he submitted a $547.7 million budget for 1983.

title: Loan Defaults At Richmond
description: The Richmond Tank Car Company, a Houston-based railroad car maker, said that it is in technical default on certain of its loan agreements and that it does not expect to be able to make a $2 million payment due this month on its $32 million revolving credit. But it said that none of the defaults so far had involved actual failure to make payment of either principal or interest on its debt.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'Help Us by Cutting Aid'
description: The leaders of Israel feel themselves approaching the climax of a bitter, fratricidal conflict over the future size and character of their nation. Thus, despite the vigor and freedom of their open political debate, the highest officials and party leaders reserve their most startling opinions for unattributable conversation.

title: FAFCO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIAL OF SUIT AGAINST PRAYER LAW OPENS
description: A Presbyterian minister testified today that a ban on organized prayer in public schools would infringe upon children's right to freedom of religion.

title: News Analysis
description: Its 15 members may not reach complete, bipartisan agreement on how to cure the financial ills of Social Security, but the National Commission on Social Security Reform already has achieved a great deal.

title: Advertising; United Parcel Tries TV
description: ''I T'S not a chocolate brown,'' said Randolph H. Grotzinger, executive vice president and creative director at Grey Lyon & King Advertising. ''It's darker than that. It's a royal brown. It says: 'We're everywhere, and we're the one you've trusted for many, many years.' ''

IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
