title: ALMY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Winfield, Guidry Cited for Fielding
description: Two members of the Yankees, the outfielder Dave Winfield and the pitcher Ron Guidry, were cited for their fielding excellence today when they were named to the American League Gold Glove team by The Sporting News.

title: PRIMERS-IN OLD FASHIONED PRINTERS
description: THE world of personal computers is full of jargon - words like ''byte,'' ''ROM,'' ''global search'' and ''looping.'' A certain lexicographic expansion is perforce necessary in the approach to any new technology. When audiences switched from radio to stereo for tympanic stimulation, their vocabulary expanded to include such previously unneeded concepts as muting and mode and four-channel matrix. For that matter, the very word ''stereo'' was strange to most people's ears until a few decades ago, when we suddenly learned that what we called ''hi-fi'' was only ''mono.'' But computerese carries its vocabulary-building demands from the necessary to a degree bordering on the absurd.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Banks won authorization for a new federally insured account with a relatively low minimum deposit of $2,500 and no ceiling on the interest depositors are paid. The decision by Federal regulators is part of an effort to help banks and thrift institutions compete with money market mutual funds. The new account, depending on the institution, will pay a fixed interest rate for up to one month, a guarantee that the money market funds cannot match. (Page A1.)

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from equity in earnings of the Simplicity Pattern Co of $584,000 for the qr and $883,000 for the 9 mos; the latest qr net includes a loss of $859,000 compared to a loss of $657,000 for the yr-ago period of minority interests of MCO Resources and the latest 9 mos include similar losses of $2,861,000 against $657,000 in the yr earlier period

title: Harvester to Shed A French Unit
description: The International Harvester Company said it had agreed to sell a French subsidiary that makes construction equipment to executives of the division.

title: Judge Delays Bid For Dan River
description: A Federal judge for the Western District of Virginia issued a preliminary injunction that will give Dan River Inc. stockholders until Nov. 22 to decide whether they want to withdraw from a $16.50-a-share tender offer made by a group headed by Carl C. Icahn, a New York stockbroker.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE are 260 duchesses in the world and 320 of them were in town l ast week, their titles attached to what sounded like mostly m ythical kingdoms. Could anyone, except perhaps for its Duchess, e xactly recall the location of Feria and whether or not it is really b igger than a limousine?

title: WALESA, AFTER LONG ISOLATION, WEIGHS FUTURE
description: Under a portrait of Pope John Paul II, Lech Walesa moved his arms, rolled his eyes, smoked, gestured, laughed and tossed his stocky body about as he was once again the center of journalistic attention after being locked away in a remote mountain hunting lodge for 11 months.

title: Reds Waive Hurdle
description: Clint Hurdle has never been able to live up to the star billing he received as a 20-year-old rookie outfielder and first baseman at Kansas City's camp in the spring of 1978.

title: by Tony Schwartz
description: T hey are destined to be the most ambitious consecutive broadcasting events in the history of the medium - the 65 hours that ABC Sports will devote to the Winter Olympics at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, beginning in February 1984, and about 205 hours to the Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, beginning the following August.

title: VEPCO PLANS TO CANCEL NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
description: The Virginia Electric Power Company said yesterday that it would recommend to the board of directors on Friday that the utility cancel the North Anna Unit 3 Nuclear Power Plant because of a sharp increase in construction costs.

title: RICHARD POWELL, LAW PROFESSOR
description: Richard R.B. Powell, Dwight Professor emeritus at the Columbia University School of Law and the author of a leading work in property law, died last Saturday of a heart attack at Mills Memorial Hospital in San Mateo, Calif. He was 92 years old and lived in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Jagan M. Reddy, Paul Ramsden, Karyn C. Reynolds, Cecilia B. Richardson, Somchit Sertthin, Geoffrey E.M. Smith, Richard Tai Ning Tsoi and Primo Zanoni vice presidents.

title: Bonn Price Index Up
description: West Germany's wholesale price index rose six-tenths of 1 percent in October after a two-tenths of 1 percent fall in September, the federal Statistics Office said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Far-Flung Facts

title: Leveille Therapy
description: Tape recordings of his teammates' voices will soon become part of the therapy to help bring Normand Leveille, the 19-year-old Boston Bruin forward, out of his coma. Leveille, who suffered a brain hemorrhage two weeks ago, is at General Hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, where a spokesman, Michelle Gaudette, said yesterday: ''Part of the therapy in neurological cases like Normand's is having them listen to voices they know.

title: When 2 Equals 3
description: Southern California intercepted two passes in its 48-41 victory last Saturday night over Arizona. It also equaled the National Collegiate Athletic Association record of three interception returns for touchdowns in one game.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $59,100 for the qr and $181,600 for the 9mos

title: ANGOLA REBELS YIELD 2 SOVIET CAPTIVES
description: The two Russians, bearded and bronzed after two years of captivity in the bush, were seated beneath a large canvas mural that was said to depict the struggle of Jonas Savimbi's insurgent movement against Soviet and Cuban intervention. Next to them was a lean-to, draped with a banner that exhorted, ''Let's stop Soviet mad dreams.''

title: Chess: Soviet Wins the Olympiad For 14th Time in 30 Years
description: The Soviet Union won the 1982 Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland, with a 40-12 score after 13 rounds. This was the 14th time in 30 years that the Russians triumphed in the biennial tournament.

title: Giants and Jets Offer Refunds
description: The Giants and Jets are assuring people who hold tickets for home games not played because of the National Football League strike that they can get refunds whenever they want.

title: MONEY SUPPLY HAS SHARP RISE
description: The Federal Reserve System yesterday reported sharp increases in the three key measures of the nation's money supply, which pushed them all beyond their annual targets and dimmed market hopes for further interest-rate reductions.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Haywood Sidelined
description: Spencer Haywood, the 33-year-old veteran forward of the Washington Bullets, was placed on the injured-reserve list yesterday after meeting with Coach Gene Shue to settle differences that had arisen during the previous 24 hours. Haywood, who has been hampered by a strained calf muscle most of the season, had been angered by Shue's criticism of him during Sunday's loss to Philadelphia.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIAL OF GREGORIO FOR MISCONDUCT BEGINS IN JERSEY
description: The conspiracy, official-misconduct and taxevasion trial of State Senator John T. Gregorio opened today with the prosecutor charging that the defendant had been motivated by greed in hiding financial interests in two go-go bars in Linden. In addition to his post in the State Legislature, Mr. Gregorio has been Mayor of Linden for 16 years.

title: Court Will Hear Dirks Appeal on S.E.C. Censure
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal by Raymond L. Dirks, the securities analyst who blew the whistle on the Equity Funding Corporation of America, from his censure by the Securities and Exchange Commission for advising his clients before the debacle became public to sell their Equity Funding stock.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONEY NEWS WEAKENS PRICES
description: Yields on key Treasury debt issues climbed as prices dropped late yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported a larger-than-expected increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: CONVICT CONFESSES TO 5 MURDERS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City detectives said yesterday that a recently recaptured convict, who has reportedly confessed to 29 murders throughout the country from 1969 through 1971, killed a man in the city in 1970. And they are looking into his statement that he killed four other people in the city.

title: BIG LOSS POSTED BY WOOLWORTH
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, which has reduced its retailing operations sharply in recent months, reported yesterday a loss of $428 million in its fiscal third quarter as a result of special charges for discontinued operations.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
20th Century-Fox To Film Olympics
description: The Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee has accepted $1 million from 20th Century-Fox for the exclusive rights to produce and distribute the official films of the 1984 Games, it was announced today.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DeLorean Puts Debt at $40 Million
description: The DeLorean Motor Company listed its debts at $40 million, but creditors put the figure at $76.2 million, in estimates disclosed at a hearing in Federal Bankruptcy Court here. A creditors' committee was named to determine how money from the sale of the sports car company's United States assets would be distributed.

title: College Aide Faces Charge
description: A college account clerks' supervisor was charged today with theft in connection with the misappropriation of more than $338,000 from a college fund. The supervisor, Marion E. White, 30 years old, had been a city employee for 12 years.

title: U.S. Says Nuclear Plants Illegally Dismissed Aide
description: A worker who says he is being blacklisted by the nuclear power industry has been illegally dismissed three times, a Federal official said today.

title: RICHARD T. BARNS
description: Richard Turner Barns, custodian of maps for Westchester County and former town clerk of New Castle, N.Y., died Saturday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 75 years old and resided in Mount Kisco.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Great Wine Race

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $78,000 for the qr and $1,037,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $63,000

title: Arkansas Bank Closed by U.S.
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had closed the Bank of Quitman in Quitman, Ark., because of ''large and unusual losses which depleted the bank's capital account.''

title: Q & A
description: Q. How can contact lenses correct astigmatism? What keeps them right side up, as the axis on lenses for astigmatism requires?

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
7 Are Arraigned In Trident Protest
description: Seven persons charged with breaking into the Electric Boat Company shipyard here and damaging a nuclearpowered Trident submarine were arraigned today on conspiracy and trespassing charges.

title: BISHOPS' REMARKS ON PASTORAL LETTER
description: Following are excerpts from the comments of Roman Catholic bishops on a proposed pastoral letter on war and peace: John R. Roach Archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beatrice Foods Co. said it had purchased a majority stake in Winner Food Products Ltd., a Hong Kong producer and distributor of specialty Chinese foods, for a sum it did not disclose.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on Government information available to the public incorrectly quoted a statement by Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan. He said, ''Recent history has proven that a government shrouded in secrecy becomes not only unaccountable but eventually irresponsible.''

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CATHOLIC BISHOPS BEGIN ARMS DEBATE
description: Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin of Chicago, chairman of a special committee of Roman Catholic bishops that drafted a pastoral letter opposing nuclear arms, defended the document today as several other bishops asked for key changes in it.

title: RANGERS FAILING TO IMPROVE
description: A year ago yesterday, the Rangers played their 18th game of the season, and with Steve Weeks in goal, they lost to Edmonton at Madison Square Garden, 5-3, dropping their record to 7-10-1.

title: ANDROPOV READS AMERICA, FLUENTLY
description: An argument has already erupted in Washington over the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov. Some say he is a ''closet liberal,'' others that he is a brutal hard-liner. This seems like the wrong argument at the wrong time. It poses the wrong questions at a moment when we should be concentrating on analysis of the character, personality and background of the man with whom President Reagan must share responsibility for war and peace in a nuclear world.

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STRUMMER

title: CARNATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to the Dec 1981 retroactive change in accounting for the translation of foreign currencies

title: O'NEILL DISCLOSES THAT CONNECTICUT FACES BUDGET GAP OF $298 MILLION
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, acknowledging that it will be ''extremely difficult'' to avoid tax increases, said today that Connecticut faced a budget gap of $298.7 million in the state's fiscal year, which starts July 1.

title: Beetles in Disguise
description: An ant colony often attracts beetles that live in harmony or interdependence with the ants. Usually the beetle gains sanctuary by mimicking ant behavior or appearance.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Houston Rockets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. The Rockets, without Moses Malone, are the only team in the National Basketball Association that has yet to win a game.

title: TRAFFIC RULE FOR HOLIDAYS YIELDS CHAOS
description: A regulation designed to cope with pedestrian and vehicle traffic in midtown Manhattan during the Christmas shopping season went into effect yesterday, slowing motorists and leaving traffic enforcement agents harried.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been revised to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations; yr-ago sales do not include results of Control Laser Ltd which was fully consolidated as of Jan 1, 1982

title: A Party With Q's & A's; Charlotte Curtis
description: star group if I do say so myself.''

title: Field Plans Sale Of Boston Station
description: Field Enterprises Inc., a privately held communications concern with interests in newspapers, electronic publishing and cable television, said that it had agreed in principle to sell its Boston UHF television station, WLVI-TV, Channel 56, to the Gannett Company for $47 million in cash.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: MILLIONS of young Americans have trouble with reading, writing and mathematics, not because they are stupid or even because they are poorly taught, but because they lack ''self-organization'' and the capacity to commit themselves to anything beyond their egos. This is at the heart of a critique of the American school, along with the family and society in general, by Amitai Etzioni, a professor at George Washington University who is a former chairman of the department of sociology at Columbia University.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; most of the loss reported for the latest qr was due to a one-tomewriteoff of costs for developing and proving a new phosphoric acid process

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Defendants Must Have Counsel, Strike or No
description: To the Editor:

title: KIM'S LIFE SUPPORT MAY BE REMOVED
description: Dr. Lonnie Hammargren, the neurosurgeon who performed brain surgery on the boxer Duk Koo Kim, said today that the South Korean lightweight would probably be removed from lifesupport systems within 48 hours.

title: BRAZILIANS JAM POLLING PLACES IN FIRST FREE VOTE IN 17 YEARS
description: Brazilians voted today in the first free municipal, legislative and gubernatorial elections in 17 years. Lines had formed by the 8 A.M. opening hour and continued lengthy until the 5 P.M. close as the estimated 58.5 million voters participated in the latest stage in the gradual liberalization program under which President Joao Baptista Figueiredo has promised to return the country to democracy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Honeymoons and Wheels

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sep
REAGAN AND KOHL URGE COOPERATION IF SOVIET ACTS TOO
description: President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that the United States and West Germany were ready to broaden cooperation with the new Soviet leadership but only ''if Soviet conduct makes that possible.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''As we leave Moscow, we are well aware of the difficult problems that confront us.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rescheduling at the Amex

title: Accord Reached On Camden Jail
description: One-third of the inmates of the overcrowded Camden County Jail will be removed by the end of the year under an agreement reached today between the county and the state in Federal District Court.

title: Christian-Druse Clashes Go On in Lebanon
description: New machine gun and mortar battles between rightist Christian and leftist Druse militiamen were reported today in Lebanon's Israeli-occupied central mountains.

title: DISCUSSIONS BEGIN ON ARMS SPENDING
description: The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense started discussing the 1983 military appropriations bill today as the chairman, Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, said he would try to cut $20 billion from the $214 billion requested.

title: FILM STUDIOS AND ABC NEGOTIATE FOR SHOWTIME
description: Two major movie studios and a television network apparently are on the verge of purchasing the major share of Showtime, the second-largest pay-cable programming service.

title: Magazine Bans 'X' Ads
description: Barry Ancona, publisher of United Business Publications' Home Video magazine, has announced that - even though it will mean a loss of 10 percent to 15 percent of his advertising revenues - the magazine is banning advertising for X-rated programming with the January issue. The three-year-old monthly publication has a 125,000 circulation rate base, and 45 percent of its sales are at newsstands.

title: LOSERS YOU DIDN'T SEE ON THE BALLOT
description: Most voters in New Jersey's Ninth Congressional District have never met Susan B. Blackmore, a soft-spoken South Carolinian. But when they voted Representative Harold C. Hollenbeck out of office on Nov. 2, they also put Miss Blackmore out of a job.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Iran Says It Drove Off 15 Attacking Iraqi Planes

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PIPELINE POLITICS
description: President Reagan's decision to lift sanctions on European allies involved in the Soviet gas-pipeline deal had nothing to do with Leonid Brezhnev's death or Lech Walesa's release from internment.

title: AN OUTBURST OF CULT STRIFE TESTS NIGERIA'S CIVIL RULE
description: Armed with bows and arrows and spears, and believing themselves so blessed that bullets would not scathe them, members of an Islamic cult held out here against the police for four days last month until a mortar barrage broke their resistance. Scores of civilians and police officers died.

title: Goncourt and Renaudot Won by 2 Novelists
description: Dominique Fernandez won the Prix Goncourt today for ''Dans la Main de l'Ange'' (''In the Angel's Hand''), and Georges-Olivier Chateaureynaud received the Prix Renaudot for ''La Faculte des Songes'' (''Dreaming''). France's two important literary prizes, given annually for the best original novels of the year, both carry a nominal award of $7.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
BUSH MEETS WITH ANDROPOV IN BRIEF, 'SUBSTANTIVE' TALKS
description: Vice President Bush met briefly today with the new Soviet party leader, Yuri V. Andropov, in what was described by the Americans as a ''frank, cordial and substantive'' session and by the Russians as an exchange ''on the fundamental matters of Soviet-U.S. relations.''

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $370,000 for the qr and $1,737,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary credits of $81,000 for the qr and $243,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $425,000 and an extraordinary credit of $82,000...D-Net loss after a loss of $4,574,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $303,000

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Vietnam Area Reported Devastated by Typhoon

title: CONCERT: 8th DAY ORCHESTRA
description: IT was heartening to witness the ovation awarded Orchestra of the Eighth Day, a new-music group from Poland, at the Mudd Club Saturday night. That such splendidly strange, chiming and ethereal music could be so enthusiastically recieved in a pop club speaks well of the sophistication of the patrons.

title: CONCERT: RENAISSANCE
description: THE New York Renaissance Band's ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' in Alice Tully Hall Saturday night was a cheerful amalgam of Rabelaisian writings, period music on period instruments and late 20th-century hokum. Songs and dances by Arbeau, Josquin and others were occasionally punctuated by Basin Street glissandos on the sackbut or a chorus of ''For He's a Jolly Good Fellow.''

title: ISRAEL MOURNS MRS. BEGIN AND TYRE DEAD
description: Israel observed a moment of silence this morning in memory of the victims of the explosion that destroyed the Israeli military hedquarters in Tyre, Lebanon, last Thursday. A few hours later, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's wife, Aliza, was buried in a simple private ceremony on the Mount of Olives overlooking the walled Old City of Jerusalem.

title: European Tour for Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will visit seven Western European capitals next month for talks with high officials, the State Department announced today.

title: TRAINING A FUTURES TRADER
description: When the discount rate dropped half a point just before the session's end, the pit exploded. Prices shot up. Traders with contracts on the line screamed, sweated and muscled their way across the undersized, crowded floor as transactions flashed on the board above.

title: CARIBBEAN GETS BAD NEWS ON AID
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that Congress was unlikely to take up the remaining parts of the Administration's Caribbean aid plan when it reconvenes later this month and would probably not consider it for ''six to eight months.''

title: L.I.U. Gets a Bye In Soccer Playoff
description: Long Island University's soccer team, ranked second nationally, was awarded a bye in the Division I regional playoff yesterday. For the right to represent New York, the Blackbirds will meet the winner of tomorrow's game between Columbia and St. Francis at Columbia.

title: DANCE: INDRANI AND SUKANYA PRESENT 3 STYLES FROM INDIA
description: INDRANI and Sukanya are well-known exponents of India's classical dance in the United States, and Sunday night the mother-daughter team presented three styles of Indian dance in the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium.

title: FORTUNE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Nov. 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Fires Set in School In Bridgeport
description: The police are searching for vandals who broke into the Roberto Clemente Elementary School over the weekend, setting two fires and ransacking 10 classrooms.

title: PANELFAB INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a loss of $167,000 from discontinued operations

title: VINOBA BHAVE, A GANDHI DISCIPLE AND SOCIAL REFORMER, DIES AT 87
description: Vinoba Bhave, a widely venerated disciple of Mohandas K. Gandhi and one of India's best-known social reformers, died yesterday at his retreat in the west Indian state of Maharashtra, the United News of India reported. He was 87 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: And These Little Piggies Went to the A.S.P.C.A.

title: Scottish Ship Capsizes
description: Five crew members died when the Scottish cargo ship Nesam capsized in 40-foot waves and gale-force winds in the Atlantic about 100 miles off Land's End in southwest England on Sunday, but rescuers said today that they had saved the six other crew members.

title: Required Reading; Preventing War
description: Eugene V. Rostow, director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, speaking to the General Assembly of the United Nations on the place of arms control negotiations in the quest for peace, Oct. 27, 1982:

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Odds Seen Slim for Rise in Soviet Trade
description: While President Reagan's removal of sanctions against companies participating in the Soviet gas pipeline project is a step to ease a bilateral economic strain, many businessmen and experts expressed skepticism yesterday that it would result in increased trade with the Soviet Union.

title: NOISE POSES A GROWING THREAT, AFFECTING HEARING AND BEHAVIOR
description: IN trying to track a suspected Soviet submarine last month, the Swedish Navy had difficulty finding sailors who could hear well enough to operate the listening devices. The hearing of vast numbers of young people, a Navy captain said, apparently has been permanently damaged by years of listening to loud rock music.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENGINEER'S NAP CITED IN DERAILMENT HEARING
description: The Illinois Central Gulf train that crashed north of here seven weeks ago jumped its rails while the engineer was taking a nap because he was drunk, according to testimony at a hearing here today.

title: Bank Tenders Exceed Goal
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday that its tender offer for 875,881 shares of the Union Commerce Corporation of Cleveland had been oversubscribed. Huntington said 883,953 shares had been tendered in response to its bid of $22.50 a share.

title: ON A SOVIET TOUR: 'I CEASED TO EXIST'
description: To the Editor:

title: Errico Hearing
description: Con Errico, the 60-year-old former jockey who was convicted 18 months ago of racketeering for the purpose of fixing thoroughbred races in New York, will appear before a parole board today at a Federal correctional medical facility in Springfield, Ill. Gerald Shargel, Errico's lawyer, said that a member of his staff would argue for the early release of Errico, who has been in poor health. The sentence for Errico was initially 10 years, but was reduced to five after his health had been considered by the judge.

title: BISCAYNE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Three Lives
description: To study the plight of Tina, Skandy and Caroline - three residents of the Central Park Zoo now facing eviction - is to recognize once again the parallels in human and animal lives. Tina, Skandy and Caroline need new homes because their old one, soon to be demolished, will have no place for them.

title: THE $250 PROMISE
description: The city government is giving new meaning to the value of a promise. Back in 1979, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development told the low-income and working-class tenants who had agreed to apply their own sweat and labor and expenses to keep alive their city-owned buildings (which had been abandoned by tax-defaulting landlords) that it would eventually sell these tenants their apartments for $250.

title: ENDS AT 1,021.43
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as concern mounted among investors that the long decline in interest rates might be ending. The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 20.24 points in the first hour of trading, later recovered somewhat to close 18.49 points lower, at 1,021.43. The big drop in the Dow, following Friday's decline of 14.81, raised the possibility that the key indicator might soon fall below 1,000 again. It has been above that level since Nov. 1.

title: Article 035432 -- No Title
description: The record price for a broodmare was shattered by $1,650,000 today when Henryk deKwiatkowski purchased a mare in foal to Northern Dancer for $3.8 million at Keeneland's November Breeding Stock Sale.

title: RENTAL LIBRARIES ENJOYING COMEBACK
description: One of the most avid patrons of the Womrath Book Store at 971 Lexington Avenue in New York is a fireman who regularly stocks up on popular fiction, spy stories and mysteries. The Anderson's Book Shop in Larchmont, N.Y., sends about 10 books a week to a woman who rarely sets foot inside the store. A woman in Texas reads so many books that the owner of the Cobler Book Stores in Houston says, ''I don't think she bothers to sleep.''

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Change in Name
description: Dwight Braxton, the World Boxing Council's light-heavyweight champion, announced that in the future he would fight under his Muslim name, Dwight Muhammad Qawi. That future begins Saturday night in Atlantic City, where Braxton, who says he has been a Muslim for five years, will defend his title against No. 3-ranked Eddie Davis of Freeport, L.I.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTRIC MESSAGES BENEATH THE SEA
description: FROM the time when a fisherman first caught an electric eel by mistake and received a rude shock, scientists have been studying the different ways in which electric fish have developed their unique manner of sensing the nature of their surroundings and functioning successfully in their watery and murky world.

title: BRIEFING
description: Comrade Adenauer?

title: Nancy Reagan's Flights Termed a Security Need
description: Nancy Reagan occasionally uses a Presidential helicopter to fly alone to Camp David for security reasons, her office said today.

title: Dangers of Boric Acid
description: Boric acid, a common ingredient in many household and hygienic products can, when overused or consumed, cause skin reactions, hair loss and serious illness, according to dermatologists at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: 'SUBSTANTIAL AGREEMENT' REACHED, U.S. INSISTS
description: The White House insisted again today that there was ''substantial agreement'' by France and other key allied nations on a broad economic policy toward the Soviet Union. This, it said, enabled President Reagan to lift sanctions against companies supplying materials for the Soviet gas pipeline project.

title: A Wild Weekend
description: Eight-year-old Denise Albert had a great time and can't wait to make another trip with Daddy. Daddy hopes the next trip will be a little calmer.

title: Controls Still Remain On Trade With Soviet
description: Numerous controls over trade with the Soviet Union - affecting high technology, energy and military products - remain after President Reagan's weekend decision to lift sanctions against the Soviet pipeline.

title: A's to Name Manager
description: The Oakland A's have called a news conference for tomorrow to announce who the successor to Manager Billy Martin will be. Only two managerial vacancies remain in the major leagues - Oakland's and the Yankees' - and the A's have had no shortage of candidates for the post: Steve Boros of Montreal, Ray Miller of Baltimore, Jim Leyland of the Chicago White Sox and Hal Lanier of St. Louis, all coaches, as well as Jim Fregosi, former manager of California, and John Roseboro, former Dodger catcher.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept 30, 198

title: DANCE: PETER HEALEY
description: TO begin with, this viewer must confess that he had no idea what was going on for most of ''All Through the Night,'' which Peter Healey presented Sunday evening at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. Whereas separate events were usually clear enough, it was hard to determine the overall significance of this eveninglong dance to a musical collage that ranged from Bach and Mozart to Max Steiner and Brian Eno. And yet ''All Through the Night,'' though inscrutable, was oddly interesting.

title: ETHICS PANEL URGES CONSTANT VIGILANCE OVER GENE-SPLICING
description: SOCIETY must keep watch over future developments in genetic engineering research to avoid dangers such as misguided attempts to alter the human species by genetic manipulations, a Presidential commission has concluded after a two-year study.

title: DESIGNERS FORSAKE FORMALITY IN A SPRING ACCESSORY SPREE
description: Straw hats with shallow crowns and wide brims skim over tailored suits, complemented at the other end of the body by delicate shoes with tall, skinny heels, sending most of the mannequins, who are at least 5 feet 8 inches tall in their bare feet, to well over the 6-foot mark.

title: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McRae To Remain A Royal
description: Hal McRae, the designated hitter who led the major leagues in runs batted in last season, agreed today to a three-year contract that will keep him with the Kansas City Royals.

title: LOSS POSTED BY DOME FOR QUARTER
description: Dome Petroleum Limited, the huge Canadian oil company now going through a refinancing agreement that would put control of the company in the hands of creditors, reported yesterday a loss of $400,000 (Canadian) in the third quarter. In the same quarter of 1981, it earned $30.5 million.

title: McLouth Sale Is Completed
description: The $46.5 million sale of the McLouth Steel Corporation to a subsidiary of Tang Industries Inc. was completed tonight, an attorney for McLouth said.

title: HIGH COURT RULES ON RIGHTS OF ALIENS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a resident alien who leaves the United States briefly and tries to return may be barred from entry without full procedural protections to which aliens are entitled before they can be deported.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,988,472 for the qr and $5,097,439 for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,374,960 for the qr and $2,011,141 for the 9 mos and a nonrecurring gain of $731,729 for the 9 mos from the sale of lease rights

title: 'SHOVEL PASS' HELPS S.M.U. AVOID A TIE
description: T hey had practiced the play at least 60 times, according to Bobby Leach, and it had almost never worked. Small wonder, because the play required a cross-field lateral pass by Blane Smith, following a kickoff reception, to Leach at the sideline. Smith could seldom complete such a pass. ''It seemed they were always too high or too low,'' said Leach.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: There was news at a meeting of the American Heart Association today, but it was only part of the story. The news was that one buffered aspirin a day more than halved the incidence of both fatal and nonfatal heart attacks among a group of men suffering from a condition called unstable angina. The findings, which derived from a study of 1,338 men, added to a growing body of evidence suggesting that aspirin helps prevent a number of disorders, heart and circulatory problems among them.

description: During the years that it was headed by Yuri V. Andropov, the new leader of the Soviet Communist Party, the K.G.B. consolidated its internal-s@ecurity role and remained one of the most pervasive and feared institutions in Soviet society.

title: World Chief Yields Role
description: Edward J. Daly, the founder and driving force behind World Airways, has yielded a measure of executive control to a longtime aide, the airline announced yesterday. The carrier, based in Oakland, Calif., said that Brian Cooke, senior vice president, had been named president and chief executive.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP 18.5% IN PERIOD
description: The nation's Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that car sales rose 18.5 percent in the first 10 days of November, mostly because the companies have been cutting interest rates on car loans.
