description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $442 million for the qr and $465million for the 9 mos...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $12 million for the qr and $19 million for the 9 mos; Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: BRITISH TO BUY PART OF L.F. ROTHSCHILD
description: L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the Wall Street investment banking house, said yesterday that a British investment group including Jacob Rothschild, a prominent member of the British Rothschilds, plans to buy a 25 percent interest in the company.

title: No Headline
description: Blackman Retiring As Cornell's Coach

title: Top Credit Officer Quits At Continental Illinois
description: George R. Baker, executive vice president of the Continental Illinois Corporation and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has announced that he will resign Dec. 31 to pursue other interests.

title: Crown Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said it had agreed to sell its 50 percent interest in a Fair Haven, Calif., pulp mill to the Simpson Paper Company for a price that it did not disclose. Crown Zellerbach said it would realize a $4.3 million gain on the transaction.

title: New Geography
description: Newspaper advertisements and posters on the back of city buses urge people to go to Knicks games and watch ''the city's game.'' The advertisements and posters show a Manhattan skyline as seen from the Hudson River, with an oversized Madison Square Garden in the center.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $195,000 for the qr and $257,000for the 9 mos and a tax credit of $55,000 for the qr and 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,164,000 for the qr and $2,227,000 for the 9 mos and a tax credit of $1,344,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: RADIOFONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLITICS, AMBASSADORSHIPS: THE TWAIN SHALL MEET
description: Theodore Maino loves big game hunting. His living room in California is filled with African trophies, and he holds a record for killing the world's largest tahr, a Himalayan goat.
$3.1 million...C-After losses from of $1.3 million for the qr and $2.3 After a loss fromdiscontinued operations

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Six Federal agencies overestimated by $560 million the amount needed from Congress for the relief effort after the volcanic eruptions of Mount St. Helens in 1980 and then channeled that money into other projects, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: TAYLOR RENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After gain of $1,052,251 from settlement of lawsuit with the Peabody Coal Co

title: MOST COMPLEX GARMENTS EVER MADE
description: The space suits that malfunctioned yesterday, causing the cancellation of a space walk from the Columbia, are perhaps the most complex human garments ever made. Each one has all the support systems of a one-man spacecraft.

title: PURCELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; A Bellwether In Name Only
description: THE 10 3/8's of 2012 - those numbers may not convey the ring of poetry, but they now designate the United States Treasury bond with the longest maturity.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUGHES: JOLTED BY AN OIL GLUT
description: From the window of William A. Kistler Jr.'s 65th-floor office here, there are few apparent signs of trouble in the local economy. From this height, new office construction seems to spring up from a flat urban landscape like derricks in a rich Texas oilfield. But the view of prosperity below masks the growing problems in an industry whose wealth shaped this city.

title: TEXT OF ANDROPOV'S SPEECH AT BREZHNEV'S FUNERAL
description: Following is the text of a speech by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet Communist Party leader, at the funeral today of Leonid I. Brezhnev, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Shift at Fireman's Fund
description: Edwin F. Cutler and Myron DuBain both started working for the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company 36 years ago, and Mr. DuBain eventually became chairman, president and chief executive of the big insurer. Now, so has Mr. Cutler.

title: Laser Is Proposed To Clear Arteries
description: Pinpoint lasers successfully cleared fatclogged blood vessels in tests on 25 human cadavers - a technique that could one day be simpler and cost far less than traditional bypass surgery, a heart researcher said today.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC OF COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA
description: PROGRAMMATIC coherence has never been a principal goal of either Dennis Russell Davies or the American Composers Orchestra, which he led in its first concert of the season last night at Alice Tully Hall. Both have striven to provide New Yorkers the widest possible range of American new music. Last night's program still had a heady amount of diversity, even after the forced postponement to next season, because of a performer's illness, of Francis Thorne's ''La Luce Eterna.'' But its replacement, Lou Harrison's Symphony No. 3 in its New York premiere, made an especially appropriate pairing with Colin McPhee's often talked-about, rarely heard ''Tabuh-Tabuhan.''

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Greek Leader Accepts Offer For Official Visit to Warsaw
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has accepted an official invitation by Wojciech Jaruzelski to visit Poland, the Government announced today.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The 'Reappeared' in Argentina
description: After the Falkland war, sun and shadow contend in Argentina. A discredited junta is doing what it should have done years ago: agreeing to yield power to civilians.

title: INTEREST AND DIVIDEND WITHHOLDING IS BAD LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: HANDEL 'THEODORA'
description: ''THEODORA'' is one of Handel's late masterpieces: a grave, elevated plea for religious tolerance. It tells the story of two young lovers who are condemned to death by the Roman emperor Diocletian for their Christian faith.

title: Boy Held in Plot To Blow Up Van
description: A 16-year-old River Edge boy was accused today of pouring gasoline on a gym teacher's van in an apparent attempt to cause an explosion when the vehicle was started, the police said.

title: HARD TO 'GET FIX' ON SOVIET LEADER
description: The 30 minutes that Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz spent with Yuri V. Andropov marks the first time a top American official has had a serious talk with him despite Mr. Andropov's having been an important figure in the Soviet leadership for the last 15 years.

title: 6 GET JAIL TERMS IN RACKETS CASE TIED TO MOBSTERS
description: Six men convicted in a racketeering case that grew out of a major undercover investigation of the Bonanno crime family were sentenced yesterday to terms ranging from four to 15 years in prison.

title: CHAINED WOMAN DIES IN FIRE
description: An emotionally troubled 18-year-old Queens woman, who had been chained to a ceiling fixture while left alone in her family home, died when fire swept her basement room yesterday morning, authorities reported.

title: WHONNOCK INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Business and the Law; Imposing Rule Of U.S. Abroad
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN's gas pipeline sanctions have been lifted, but extraterritorial jurisdiction remains a troubling legal issue. Faced with the growing internationalization of business, the United States has been trying to assert its legal authority abroad with increasing frequency. Often, these extraterritorial forays have provoked the same kind of ''Yankee, go home'' reaction as assertions of political authority.

title: INFORMATION DISPLAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $75,000 for the qr and $122,500 for the 9 mos

title: NO INTEREST LIMITS SET AS U.S. ALLOWS NEW BANK ACCOUNT
description: Federal banking regulators decided today to let consumers begin to open money market accounts at banks and savings institutions on Dec. 14 with minimum deposits of $2,500.

title: Kroger to Acquire Dillon, a Retailer
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's fifthlargest retailing concern, said today that it had agreed to acquire the smaller Dillon Companies, a Kansas-based grocery, convenience and department store chain, in an exchange of stock valued at up to $750 million.

title: 2 Queens Teen-Agers Seized In the Stabbing of Bus Driver
description: Two Laurelton, Queens, teen-agers were arrested and charged with attempted murder last night in the stabbing and beating of a Jamaica Bus Lines driver who refused to let them board his bus without paying Friday night at a stop near their homes, the police said.

title: SELECTIVE SERVICE REGISTRATION LAW IS RULED INVALID BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the law requiring young men to register for the draft is invalid because it was improperly promulgated by the Carter Administration.

title: PPG to Shut Unit
description: PPG Industries said it would close its lead antiknock fluids production unit in Beaumont, Tex., early next year and withdraw from that business because of declining sales as a result of Government-ordered reductions in lead antiknock usage. PPG said the unit employed about 150 workers, some of whom would be reassigned.

title: Looking for Sponsor
description: Janet Guthrie, who in 1977 became the first woman to drive a race car in the Indianapolis 500, has had to give up racing because she can't find a sponsor.

title: MRS. VICTOR'S NOVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY GOES TO COURT TO BAR YANKEES FROM PLAYING 3 GAMES IN DENVER
description: New York City has obtained a court order against the New York Yankees to try to prevent the team from playing its opening home games in Denver next April instead of at Yankee Stadium.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income includes tax credits of $683,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $1,859,000 or 13 cents a shr for the 9 mos

title: Revised N.F.L. Schedule
description: Under the revised format to complete the National Football League season, the regular season will be reduced from 16 to nine games, followed by three weekends of playoffs involving 16 of the 28 teams. Super Bowl XVII will be played as scheduled on Jan. 30.

title: Procter & Gamble Ends Doyle Dane Account
description: Procter & Gamble has terminated its relationship with Doyle Dane Bernbach, and is reassigning the three brands currently handled by the agency to some of its other advertising agencies. The brands are Coast deodorant soap, which D.D.B. helped introduce, which goes to Taitham-Laird & Kudner; Gain detergent, to Wells, Rich, Greene, and Puritan Oil, to Grey Advertising, which in turn is losing Puff facial tissues to Cunningham & Walsh.

title: Israeli Theater Faces Charges For Performing Banned Play
description: Criminal charges will be filed against the Neve Zedeck theater company for twice performing a banned play, ''The Patriot'' by Hanoch Levin, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

title: U.S. RESTS ITS DEFENSE IN FALLOUT TRIAL
description: The Federal Government rested its defense today against charges that it negligently exposed residents of three Western states to radioactive fallout from nuclear tests in the 1950's and early 1960's, causing hundreds of cases of cancer.

title: STATE'S RATING SLIPS, BUT ENTHUSIASM DOESN'T
description: The rating had gone down from AA to A+, but when Wall Street offered New York State's general obligation bonds to buyers at 11 A.M. yesterday, Warren Kaufman found the change was just so much esoterica to his customers. The hot spiced garlic beef on his desk became cold spiced beef all too quickly as people jumped at the sale of $175 million in long- and short-term bonds.

title: 1. For Washing Lingerie
description: It's a risky business to launder lingerie loose in a washing machine. However, it can be done if the articles are put in a separate bag. A convenient idea called Hanky Panky is a porous zippered case of nylon lace that keeps fragile things from tangling and snagging. It also makes a handy lingerie case or laundry receptacle. Bendel's third floor has it, in ecru or black lace, at $11.

title: RECITAL: ADOLOVNI ACOSTA
description: THE first half of Adolovni Acosta's piano recital at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night was compromised by unsteady rhythm and unsteady nerves. Her distortions of note values and melodic proportion were wholesale in three preludes by Debussy, more subtle in Beethoven's ''Tempest'' Sonata.

title: Customers Protest Lilco's Rate Plan
description: Customers of the Long Island Lighting Company gathered at the Mineola firehouse Monday night to protest proposals that would raise electric bills by 50 percent over the next three years. Half of that increase, according to Lilco, would go to pay for the cost of starting up Lilco's $3 billion nuclear power plant.

title: WHY DID IT HAVE TO TAKE SO LONG?
description: With an agreement announced last night to end the football strike, both sides should be penalized for delay of game. It took eight weeks to reach even the highly tenuous settlement because both sides made serious miscalculations about their goals and about each other.

title: United Asks Delay On 20 Boeing 767's
description: Richard J. Ferris, the chairman of UAL Inc., said yesterday that its subsidiary, United Airlines, and the Boeing Company had reached an agreement under which United could stretch out to 1989 the delivery of some of the 20 remaining Boeing 767 aircraft it has on order.

title: IRAQ SAYS ITS TREATY WITH SOVIET HASN'T WORKED
description: President Saddam Hussein said today that Iraq's treaty of friendship and cooperation with the Soviet Union ''has not worked'' during the war with Iran. He expressed concern over Iraqi-Soviet relations and indicated that he was moving gingerly toward improving relations with the United States.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Benitez or Hearns To Fight Hagler
description: The winner of the Wilfred Benitez-Thomas Hearns title fight Dec. 3 will get a shot at Marvelous Marvin Hagler's undisputed middleweight crown early next year, it was announced today by the promoter Don King.

title: FOR THE HEALTH AND THE FEEDING OF AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FIRST WILSON TRIAL GOES TO JURY
description: The jury began deliberations today on Federal gun-smuggling charges against Edwin P. Wilson, the 54-yearold former American intelligence agent who made millions of dollars on contracts to sell arms and expertise to the Libyan Government.

title: 2 L.I.R.R. Unions Call Off Strike
description: President Reagan yesterday appointed an emergency board to investigate differences over a new contract between the Long Island Rail Road and labor unions, and two unions then called off plans to strike on Friday.

title: HEAD OF WORLD ARMS AGENCY SEES PERIL IN U.S CURBS
description: The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency said today that a prolonged ''reassessment'' by the United States of its participation in the organization could severely hamper the agency.

title: PENNEY, J C, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Mugabe Asks U.S. Help Against South Africa
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe told Vice President Bush here today that the Reagan Administration should ''side with Africa'' on the issue of Namibian independence.

title: DeLorean Sale Cleared
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge here cleared the way today for an Ohio auto parts company to purchase the United States assets of the DeLorean Motor Company for $1.5 million, plus assumption of about $9 million in debt.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JUST why has fate singled out Ronald J. Divito and made him the unwilling player in an Alfred Hitchcock melodrama? And what exactly did Mr. Divito witness while he was waiting for the Staten Island ferry? More important, will he live to regret it?

title: Producer Prices Up By 0.5%
description: Spurred by higher costs for new cars, producer prices rose a modest five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Labor Department reported today, after declining the previous month.

title: DOCTORS TO CONSULT WITH BOXER'S MOTHER
description: Officials from the South Korean Government and a neurosurgeon were planning to consult with the mother and brother of Duk Koo Kim tonight and to recommend that the boxer be removed from the life-support system that has been keeping him alive since last Saturday.

title: A DROUGHT ALERT IS ISSUED FOR CITY AND 25 COUNTIES
description: A New York State drought alert to encourage conservation in New York City and in all or part of 25 upstate counties was issued yesterday by Robert F. Flacke, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said the average yield at the auction of its 91-day paper rose to 9.491 percent from 9.172 percent last week.

title: Ramp to Kansas Bridge Falls, Crushing Concrete Inspector
description: An overpass leading to an unfinished Missouri River bridge collapsed today, crushing an inspector and injuring eight workers.

title: Seaver Looks East
description: Tom Seaver would like to finish his major league baseball career in the East, where he still maintains his home in Greenwich, Conn. The pitcher, who is celebrating his 38th birthday today, gave the Reds the names of four teams he prefers if he is traded by Cincinnati.

title: U.S. TELLS BISHOPS MORALITY IS GUIDE ON NUCLEAR POLICY
description: President Reagan's national security adviser, William P. Clark, sought today to persuade the nation's Roman Catholic bishops that the Administration's policies on nuclear arms were guided by compelling moral considerations.

title: New Speaker Chosen In Connecticut House
description: Democratic State Representatives tonight chose Irving J. Stolberg of New Haven to be the new Speaker of the House in the General Assembly session, which will convene Jan. 5.

title: ASSESSING THREE DIVERSE COOKBOOKS
description: THE ability to write a really good, useful cookbook is a special talent, one that may have absolutely nothing to do with being able to cook. Choosing recipes that are suitable for nonprofessional home cooks and explaining them clearly is often beyond the reach of the most able cooks, who are unaware of pitfalls that will defeat amateurs.

title: POLES ASK PAPANDREOU TO MEDIATE
description: The Polish leader Wojciech Jaruzelski has asked Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou to mediate between his regime and the West to prevent economic sanctions and win economic support for Poland, Greece's state-controlled news outlets said today.

title: FROM EPICS TO THE EPICUREAN
description: IMPECCABLY tailored in muted browns, balding with steel gray fringes of hair, wearing thick glasses, Dino De Laurentiis looks very much like the movie mogul he is. He gesticulates broadly, smokes incessantly and talks rapidly in heavily accented English.

title: Presley Estate and Manager Reach Accord on Payments
description: The estate of Elvis Presley and the singer's manager, Tom Parker, have reached an out-of-court settlement, The Memphis Press-Scimitar reported today.

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AGENCY'S MONEY POORLY WATCHED, OFFICIALS ADMIT
description: Officials of the New York State Dormitory Authority said yesterday that they had not adequately monitored the authority's investments with a securities firm that later went bankrupt.

title: Extradition Attempt Dropped For Woman Who Fled Prison
description: Last May, while being questioned as a witness in a bank robbery, May Dell Smith confessed that 10 years ago she escaped from an Indiana prison.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $18,536...C-Including a tax credit of $68,323 and an accounting change charge of $293,673

title: 5 Charged With Abuse Of Retarded Children
description: Two top adminstrators and two staff nurses at a home for retarded and handicapped children surrendered to the authorities today on charges of abusing children or failing to report such abuse.

title: VOYAGER GROUP INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
Canadian Inflation Off
description: Canada's inflation rate dropped to 10 percent in October, its lowest level in two and a half years, according to official statistics released today. The latest figures showed food prices and transportation costs significantly lower.

title: DOW OFF 13.43 ON RATE OUTLOOK
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday on expectations of rising interest rates and mounting concern over the nation's economy. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, closed 13.43 points down, at 1,008.00. In the last three trading days, this blue-chip barometer has tumbled 46.73 points, mainly because investors believe that the interest rate decline has ended.

title: ORGAN: 1830 APPLETON
description: AT the end of his organ recital last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Daniel Chorzempa played a few variations on ''America'' - selected possibly from the extended set by Charles Ives - that proved an apt encore for a musical evening of which Americans could well be proud.

title: SANITAS SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEFENSE NUTS AND BOLTS
description: President Reagan's defense budget will almost certainly be cut substantially next year. Federal deficits are intolerably high, social programs have been cut to the bone; the new, more liberal 98th Congress will surely insist that the Pentagon start making its share of sacrifices.

title: EARLY POP PIANIST
description: Al Haig, an early be-bop pianist, died of a heart attack yesterday in his Manhattan home. He was 58 years old. Mr. Haig was a member of the Charlie Parker Quintet, which performed at the Three Deuces on West 52d Street and which is credited with helping to introduce be-bop. The group was made up of Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Max Roach, Tommy Potter and Mr. Haig. He also played the piano on the classic Guild recordings made in 1945 with Mr. Parker, Mr. Gillespie, Curley Russell and Sid Catlett.

title: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MISTRIAL IS DENIED IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: The defense was denied a mistrial today in the trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
U.S. Drive on Drugs Outlined; Police Chiefs Are Told Of U.S. Drive on Drugs
description: Attorney General William French Smith and William F. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told police chiefs today that the Reagan Administration was committed to crippling organized crime.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Made in New York': Drive's Merits Disputed

title: AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: 95 SUBDUE BLAZE ON STATEN ISLAND
description: Ninety-five firefighters and 25 companies fought for more than five and a half hours yesterday to contain a stubborn, smoky blaze at a center to train cerebral palsy victims on Staten Island, authorities said.

title: 2 Thrift Units Are Acquired
description: Empire of America, a federally chartered savings and loan association, has acquired two Long Island-based savings and loans, it was announced today.

title: 'Hamlet' Star Injured, Previews Are Delayed
description: Previews of ''Hamlet'' at the Public Theater, which were to have begun last night, have been postponed until Tuesday because of an injury to Diane Venora, who is playing the title role.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income, including extraordinary income of $589,000

title: TV: NUCLEAR NIGHTMARE
description: FOR three decades now, the issue of nuclear arms has pitted those who insist that we think about the unthinkable against those who would force us to imagine the unimaginable.

title: Tennis Forecast: Damp and Slow
description: The decision to install a clay-court playing surface indoors for next week's Davis Cup final between the United States and France has been called ''The Miracle at Grenoble'' by some French newspapers.

title: PANEL CUTS $508 MILLION IN PERSHING MISSILE FUNDS
description: The House Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Defense has cut $508.6 million in funds to produce Pershing II medium-range missiles, jeopardizing the planned deployment of the nuclear missiles in Europe late next year.

title: POPE EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GUNS DISPLACE THE GRANDEUR THAT WAS PERSEPOLIS
description: The blue and gold dwellings look a little shabby now. There is no more Guerlain after-shave lotion or Joy eau de cologne in the bathrooms. The daisies that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi imported from France have long since died.

title: Nail-Wound Victim Able to Walk Again
description: Linda Archipolo, the Massapequa, L.I., teen-ager who was critically injured when struck in the head by a nail fired from a power gun, has begun walking again, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: The Realty Tax Double Reverse
description: A proposal to revive a tax on New York City real estate has become a clumsy political football that someone should deflate before it hits a vital industry in the nose.

title: Careers; Operating Your Own Enterprise
description: THE position of entrepreneur is of increasing interest to holders of M.B.A. degrees. At the Columbia business school's recent alumni day, an old-time entrepreneur, Royal Little, talked about running your own company.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: B-Net income after a recovery of $53,000 for the qr and 6 mos on loss from discontinued operations

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $342,000 for the qr and $809,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $85,500 for the qr and $180,000 for the 9 mos

title: FILM: ED PINCUS MAKES 'DIARIES' OF HIS OWN LIFE
description: ''DIARIES,'' which opens today in the Agee Room at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is Ed Pincus's filmed record of his own life and times from 1971 through 1976. It's a nearly 3 1/2-hour memoir about Ed, his wife Jane, their two children, Sami and Ben, their dog Tapper, some of the women Ed had affairs with, several colleagues, as well as Ed's travels to and from Vermont, California, Arizona and New York City.

title: SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income, including a credit of $1,909,000 from cumulative effect of changein accounting

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEST GERMAN POLICE SEIZE MOST-WANTED TERRORIST
description: The police arrested West Germany's most-wanted terrorist fugitive today in a wooded area outside Hamburg where he was digging an underground arms dump.

title: Executive Chosen Fannie Mae Leader
description: Robert J. Mylod, president of the Advance Mortgage Corporation, has been named president and chief operating officer of Fannie Mae, the Federal National Mortgage Association. Fannie Mae is a federally chartered but stockholder-owned mortgage bank and the nation's largest supplier of home mortgage funds.

title: A TAX-CUT SPEEDUP WEIGHED BY REGAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is considering whether to move up the 1983 income tax cut from July to January as a way to stimulate the economy, Administration officials reported today.

title: UNITED STATES REALTY INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $3,088,000 from the sale of properties and a gain of $30,000 on early retirement of debentures and a $12,000 tax-loss carryforward...C-Net income, after a $100,000 tax loss carryforward...D-After a gain of $15,069,000 from the sale of properties and an $87,000 gain on early retirement of debentures and a $12,000 tax credit...E-After a gain of $3,809,000 from the sale of properties and a $1,612,000 tax credit

title: Youngstown Remains at Top In Unemployment Rate, 18.7%
description: Although its unemployment rate fell to 18.7 percent in September, Youngstown, Ohio, remained the nation's highest unemployment area in statistics released today by the Labor Department.

title: SOVIET SAYS SANCTIONS MUST END
description: Senior Soviet trade officials told a group of American businessmen convening here today for the first time in four years that Washington would have to renounce trade sanctions if United States-Soviet trade were to revive. But they appeared eager for a resumption.

title: Soviet Looting Charged In Afghan Disaster
description: Soviet troops looted corpses of hundreds of Afghans killed inside a tunnel in Afghanistan after a fiery explosion early this month, Western diplomatic sources said today, quoting relatives of victims.

title: 2 NEW SATELLITES NEAR HOVER ORBITS
description: Both of the communications satellites nudged into orbit from the space shuttle Columbia, one American and one Canadian, have reached the vicinity of their geosynchronous orbits, some 22,300 miles above the Equator. In such an orbit their motion is synchronous with the Earth's rotation, causing them to hover over assigned sites on the Earth.

title: GROMYKO MEETS 90 MINUTES WITH PEKING OFFICIAL
description: The Soviet and Chinese Foreign Ministers met here today for 90 minutes in the highest-level encounter the two nations have had since 1969.

title: Brain Beating Is No Sport
description: Some people watch boxing to see skill, others just for the blood. Far worse than the blood is the unseen damage. Retinas are dislodged, kidneys bruised and, after repeated pounding, the cerebral cortex accumulates damage to the higher functions of the brain, leading to loss of memory, shambling walk: the traits of the punch-drunk boxer. Can a civilized society plausibly justify the pleasure it may gain from such a sport?

title: CARIBBEAN PARLEY TO FOCUS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: The leaders of the English-speaking Caribbean opened their first conference in seven years today, vowing to face not only their common economic problems but also the domestic human rights policies of some members.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary net gain of $487,000 from the extinguishment of debt; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: Plea of Racketeer On Term Rejected
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a request by a convicted labor racketeer, Vincent DiNapoli, that his five-year prison term be suspended and that he be permitted to work instead as a youth counselor in the Bronx.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Vets Help Vets

title: DORIS PFIESTER
description: Doris Pfiester, who became famous as the ''Valentine Lady'' for re-mailing Valentines for thousands of people around the world, died at a hospital last weekend. She was 70 years old.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $231,000

title: CANADIAN TV SHIFT URGED
description: A Government-appointed committee empowered to recommend broad changes in Canada's cultural policy called today for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation to abandon production of its own television shows and instead buy programs from independent Canadian producers.

title: Hoesch Partnership
description: A Hoesch A.G. shareholders meeting approved the company's withdrawal from its 10-year partnership in Estel with Koninklijke Nederlandse Hoogovens en Staalfabrieken, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1982. The companies each had 50 percent of Estel, but Hoesch will now take over 61 percent of its liabilities and Hoogovens the rest, Detlev Rohwedder, managing board chairman, said today.

title: EXHIBITION OF FOOD: AMERICAN IN PARIS
description: Blue cheese dressing, American-style hamburger buns, wine packaged in plastic-coated cartons and turtle livers preserved like foie gras were just some of the new and curious products introduced this week at the 10th annual SIAL (Salon International de l'Alimentation), the world food fair held here every two years.

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
M.T.A. and Canada Sign Pact for Cars
description: New York and Canadian officials have signed a five-year, $750 million loan agreement to finance the sale of 825 Canadian-made subway cars to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss of $919,297 from discontinued operations...C-Net income including income of $39,599 from discontinued operations

title: Arthur Askey, Comic Of British Stage and TV
description: Arthur Askey, one of Britain's favorite comedians, died today. He was 82 years old. Mr. Askey had been in the hospital since July for a circulation ailment and recently had his legs amputated.

title: VOLCKER REAFFIRMS VIEW ON USE OF FISCAL TARGET
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said tonight that the nation's central bank would not tighten monetary policy simply because two key money supply figures are currently above the Fed's target range.

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting method

title: Role for Ex-Player As a Go-Between
description: In 1968, when Paul Martha was playing for the Pittsburgh Steelers, National Football League management and players were involved in a serious labor dispute over pension money.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss, after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,481,000...C-After aloss from discontinued operations of $6,358,000

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HAZELTON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: THE SQUEEZE FACING INSURERS
description: The old saw about the business that lost money on every sale but made it up on volume has had a bitter ring for the property and casualty insurance industry in recent years.

title: LAMA, TONY, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Pointing Way For Tylenol
description: CONSUMER advertising may have only limited effectiveness in Johnson & Johnson's campaign to revive Tylenol sales, Larry N. Feinberg of the Wall Street house of Dean Witter Reynolds suggested the other day.

title: BIG TOLL IN STRIKE IS LOSS OF MONEY
description: The first midseason player strike in pro football history caused eight weekends of games to be missed and took a financial toll that appears to have approached $450 million.

title: SPACECRAFT'S FIRST OPERATIONAL FLIGHT ENDS SMOOTHLY IN DESERT
description: The Columbia, bathed in dawn's rosy glow, swooped out of the high clouds and landed safely here today for the successful conclusion of the space shuttle's first operational mission.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Volkswagen Group Has 9-Month Loss
description: The Volkswagenwerk Group, the big West German auto manufacturer, reported today that it lost 146 million marks - or about $56.4 million - in the first nine months of 1982 compared with a profit of 15 million marks - or about $5.79 million -in the 1981 period. The company said the loss resulted mostly from depressed sales in the United States.

title: Strike by Teachers Averted in Tenafly
description: A tentative agreement between the Board of Education and members of the teachers' union, which was reached during round-the-clock negotiations, averted a strike set for this morning at this Bergen County community's six schools, a spokesman for the school system said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is a mistaken notion in this country that hamburgers and almost all ground meat dishes are unknown in European kitchens, those of France in particular. Though it is true that in my childhood we never heard the word ''hamburger,'' we ate a good deal of ground meat, even horse meat.

title: Mexico Plans 106 Closings
description: Mexico announced plans today to liquidate 106 of the 743 companies and agencies that are wholly or partly owned by the Government. The move was called part of a program to streamline public administration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline on the Style page yesterday misstated the trend reflected in recent fashion showings. It should have said, ''Designers Turn to Formality in a Spring Accessory Spree.''

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $25,740,000 from the redemption of securities

title: Air France Loss
description: Air France, the French state-owned airline, said it expects to post a loss of 800 million francs, or about $109 million, in 1983. But Pierre Giraudet, Air France's chairman, told the French Aerospace Press Association that the company is in better shape than some other airlines and has no plans to reduce staff or cancel orders for aircraft, although it will slow its investment program.

title: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A NEW DIG UNEARTHS THE PATHOS OF VESUVIUS
description: Anthropologists reported today that the largest group of complete skeletons surviving from ancient Roman times had been unearthed at Herculaneum, a town buried in the volcanic eruption that destroyed Pompeii.

title: Social Security's Next Century
description: Everyone agrees that Social Security must put its finances in order. But nobody wants the heat for raising taxes or lowering benefits. That's why Congress and the President created a commission, headed by the economist Alan Greenspan, to run interference for necessary reforms.

title: OUR TROOPS IN LEBANON
description: President Reagan's deployment of United States Marines in Lebanon should have rekindled debate about the line between Congress's constitutional power to declare war and the power of the President as Commander in Chief, and on the scope of the War Powers Act of 1973.

title: KURDS IN THE U.S.S.R.
description: To the Editor:

title: A Carryout Shop
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I was quite surprised at the omission of Word of Mouth in your discussion of takeout food shops (''Carryout Food: The Choice Selections,'' Oct. 27). Word of Mouth was among the first and surely remains among the best in the city.

title: UNILEVER LTD AND UNILEVER NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TWO CHINAS

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Owner's About-Face
description: Sam Schulman, the owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said that after 16 years he had finally learned the hard lessons of fiscal responsibility. Schulman said he had made ''every effort to keep salaries down,'' but a number of owners in the N.B.A. ''are not showing any self-restraint.''

title: A PIONEER IN PSYCHOANALYSIS
description: Prof. Heinrich Winnik, a pioneer of psychoanalysis in Israel, died in Jerusalem last Thursday. He was 80 years old.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNILEVER PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Aces Opposing Canadians In the International Trials
description: The semifinal stage of the International Team Trials, which will determine the North American representation in the 1983 world championships in Stockholm, began here tonight. The Aces were opposing Canada in one match, and Texas played California in the other.

title: Suns 113, Lakers 105
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Maurice Lucas scored 27 points and Walt Davis had 9 of his 24 in the fourth period as Phoenix won its fifth straight victory.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WINE TALK
description: PITY the poor soul who coined the slogan ''red wine with red meat, white wine with white meat,'' for he obviously had never tasted game or experienced a fine red Burgundy with a roasted turkey on Thanksgiving Day. The slogan should be abandoned as a relic of yesteryear, the time before American consumers discovered how much wine could enhance a gastronomic occasion.

title: HARVARD PROTESTS LOSS
description: Joe Restic, Harvard's football coach, upset over a last-play call that helped Penn post an important Ivy League victory over the Crimson last weekend, said today that he had protested the decision.

title: HOW DIET CAN AFFECT MOOD AND BEHAVIOR
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. THE timing and contents of meals, as well as the consumption of certain individual nutrients, can have subtle and occasionally dramatic effects on mood and behavior, according to a series of new studies described at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last week.

title: Kaiser Steel Officer Is Assuming New Post
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday that the board had elected Richard N. Gary president. Mr. Gary, 39, succeeds Stephen A. Girard, 69, who continues as chairman and chief executive. The financially troubled company has seen several changes at the top in the last few years. Mr. Girard, who had been vice chairman, took over in 1981 when Edgar F. Kaiser Jr. resigned as chairman.

title: Boros to Be A's Manager
description: Steve Boros, a former major league infielder, will be named manager of the Oakland A's today, replacing Billy Martin, who was dismissed four weeks ago after three years with the team.

title: 3 AMERICANS FREED BY ANGOLA
description: Three Americans who had been held prisoner in Angola arrived in Lusaka today in a Red Cross plane as part of a complex exchange for three Soviet military men and 94 Angolan soldiers. The Americans were then flown to Paris.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Protecting Joggers

title: Big Volume Keeps Rates Up; Two Issues Are Put Off
description: A heavy volume of borrowing in the bond markets yesterday kept interest rates high compared with levels that prevailed several weeks ago and caused two large potential borrowers to postpone their issues.

title: BREEZY POINT CO-OP WINS IN COURT
description: The Federal appeals court in Manhattan has upheld a ruling that favors a community group on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens in its battle with the city, state and Federal governments over ownership of beach rights.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,000 for the qr and $141,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $642,000 for the qr and $210,000 for the 9 mos

title: ISRAEL IS NO PAWN OF U.S. AMBITIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1982
description: International Soviet and Chinese Foreign Ministers met in Moscow for 90 minutes in the highest-level encounter the two countries have had in 13 years. The meeting was held in the context of the gathering of foreign dignitaries for the funeral of Leonid I. Brezhnev. Tass said the two ministers had reaffirmed an accord to continue the discussions agreed upon last month in Peking. (Page A1, Columns 1-3.) A cooling in Iraqi-Soviet ties was suggested by President Saddam Hussein. Speaking at a news conference in Baghdad, he said that the Iraqi-Soviet treaty of friendship and cooperation ''has not worked'' during the war with Iran, and he indicated he was moving gingerly toward improving relations with the United States. (A3:1-4.)

title: HARASSMENT AT MOVIES: COMPLAINTS RARE
description: Victoria Balfour is a New York writer who frequently attends movies alone.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
PAPERS INDICATE A MEESE ROLE IN POLICY ON DRAFT PROSECUTION
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, was involved in establishing the system to select which young men would be prosecuted for refusing to register for the military draft, according to documents introduced in a Los Angeles trial.

title: BUSH SAID TO VIEW ANDROPOV AS SURE AND FIRM
description: Vice President Bush has reported that Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet Communist Party leader, impressed him as self-confident, firmly in command, clear about policy positions and quick and concise in making points, American officials disclosed today.

title: Goring's Goals Pace Islanders
description: The Islanders, showing some of the drive and determination that were absent the last two weeks, beat the powerful Edmonton Oilers, 4-2, in Nassau Coliseum tonight. Butch Goring led the victory with two goals.

title: Gould Unit Sale
description: Gould Inc., a maker of high-technology electronics components, said that it had received a proposal from Siemens-Allis Inc. of Atlanta to purchase most of Gould's distribution and controls business, and said it expected to work out a definitive agreement based on the proposal.

title: 'ASHES AND EMBERS'
description: HAILE GERIMA, the Ethiopian born film maker whose ''Bush Mama'' was included in the New Directors/New Films series several years ago, has now made ''Ashes and Embers'' in a similar style. ''Ashes and Embers,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, explores the experience of a black Vietnam veteran trying to come to terms with American life.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Craig Joins U.S. Team
description: Jim Craig, the goalie for the gold-medal winning 1980 United States Olympic team, has been added to the national team of the United States for the 1983 world championships in Tokyo. The 25-year-old Craig had difficulty in his National Hockey League career, suffering several injuries and shuttling between the N.H.L. and the minor leagues. Craig will join a group of amateur and professional players who will play 37 games in preparation for the Tokyo competition.

title: WESTCHESTER'S REPUBLICANS READY TO TAKE CONTROL
description: The departure of Lieutenant Governor-elect Alfred B. DelBello, the three-term Democratic Westchester County Executive, will create an unusual opportunity for Westchester Republicans, who will designate his successor as the county's top administrator.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Geothermal Plant
description: The Southern California Edison Company said it had canceled its plan to construct the nation's first major geothermal electrical power plant fed by hot water. The plant had been budgeted at $147 million. The utility said the project, planned in partnership with the Standard Oil Company of California, was canceled because the California Public Utilities Commission refused to allow it to pass through all costs to customers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it had set Nov. 29 as the record date for determining what shareholders will be entitled to vote at a special meeting schedule in January; shareholders are to vote on a proposed securities issue.

title: REAGAN BARS MOVE TO CURB TAX CUTS AND ARMS BUILDUP
description: President Reagan defended his economic program today against mounting Congressional criticism, denying that increased military spending would compound the recession and warning that curtailment of future tax cuts would show ''the white flag of surrender to big spenders.''

title: BIO-MEDICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $631,000 for the qr and $1,627,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $715,000 for the qr and $2,025,000 for the 9 mos

title: New RCA Service
description: The RCA Corporation said it had developed a service to permit word processors to communicate with telex machines over telephone lines, eliminating the need to retype information already stored in the word processor's memory into a telex terminal.

title: Italian Senate Leader Asked to Form Cabinet
description: Amintore Fanfani, a 74-year-old Christian Democrat who was Prime Minister four times in the 1950's and 1960's, was asked today to try to form Italy's 43d Government since the founding of the republic in 1945.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Chinatown Jail Protest

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Production In October Down 0.8%; Drop Biggest Since April; Autos a Factor
description: The nation's industrial output fell eighttenths of 1 percent in October, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the biggest decline since April and evidence that the slumping economy has still not touched bottom.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Varied Talents
description: Steve Small's mother is director of nursing at the Greater Bridgeport Mental Health Center. His brother works for a stock brokerage firm.

title: AMERICAN WELL SERVICING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Also in Auch
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: It may have taken an express highway to attract French diners to Andre Daguin's restaurant in Auch (''A Gascon Chef Boasts of His Region's Food,'' Oct. 27), but the cathedral, a short walk from the restaurant, has been drawing visitors since the 16h century. There are 113 flamboyant-style choir stalls, vividly sculpted in oak, as well as 18 stained glass windows by the Gascon artist Arnaut de Moles. The Michelin raters (green guide ''Pyrenees'') award three stars to the stalls, while Mr. Daguin must make do with two. JUDITH G. BERGOFFEN Manhattan

title: Oregon Retains Coach
description: Rick Bay, the athletic director at the University of Oregon, said the school had extended the contract of Rich Brooks, its football coach, for two years. Ray said he took the action to reaffirm support for Brooks, whose team has an 0-8-1 record this season. ''We have had an incredible run of bad luck the last two years,'' Bay said, and specifically cited injuries this season and last season. ... Steve Spurrier, the 1966 Heisman Trophy winner who is now the offensive coordinator at Duke, is a leading candidate to coach the Tampa franchise of the United States Football League, D.J. Mackovets, a team spokesman, said.

title: Reagan Steel-Curb Hint
description: President Reagan said today he had determined that the specialty steel industry was being unfairly hurt by subsidized imports and that he might erect trade barriers to protect it.

title: ECONOMIC COUNCIL'S TIME OF CHANGE
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the 13th chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, might be called the Lee Iacocca of the group. Like the chairman of the struggling Chrysler Corporation, he is moving to rehabilitate his organization, in this case a very small and often outgunned agency.

title: POP-ROCK: NICOLETTE LARSON
description: based singer who performed at the Bottom Line on Monday, belongs to the same eclectic pop-rock school as Linda Ronstadt and Bonnie Raitt. Her repertory, like theirs, is a stylistic grab bag that ranges from Sam Cooke to Neil Young.

title: Lawyer Curbed In S.E.C. Suit
description: Kenneth Rubinstein, formerly a lawyer with the firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson in New York City, was enjoined yesterday by the Federal District Court in Manhattan from violating the fraud provision of the securities laws regarding trading in securities involving tender offers.

title: Economic Scene; A Lesson From Japan
description: WHY has productivity been growing so much more slowly in the United States than in Japan? A new study conducted by the New York Stock Exchange under the direction of its chief economist, William Freund, finds that the fundamental answer is to be found in the Japanese educational system.

title: K MART, MACY AND DAYTON-HUDSON RISE
description: Three of the nation's largest retailers, the K Mart Corporation, R.H. Macy & Company and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, yesterday reported sharply higher profits in the fiscal quarter ending in October. But a fourth large chain, the J.C. Penney Company, said its earnings were down 10.3 percent from the year before. Sales fell below last year's at both K Mart and Penney.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: He came in through the bedroom window on a hot night in August. He had a knife and a stocking pulled tight over his face, making his features a blur. On the last night of her life as she had previously known it, Shirley woke to the feel of a hand pressed over her mouth and the insistent point of metal just below where the pulse beats in her neck.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FOR PROBLEM STUDENTS, A 2D CHANCE
description: Ringed by crumbling, smoke-blackened buildings, Bronx Regional High School stands alone. Set in a neighborhood where it has been all too easy for children to drift toward drugs and violence, the school serves students who are former disciplinary problems, people who were labeled failures but who say they are now prepared to learn.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $216,000 for the qr and $381,000for the 9 mos...C-After a loss of $51,000 for the qr and income of $63,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: TEXT OF ADMINISTRATION'S LETTER TO U.S. CATHOLIC BISHOPS ON NUCLEAR POLICIES
description: Following is the text of a letter from President Reagan's national security adviser, William P. Clark, to the chairman of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops Committee on War and Peace, Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin of Chicago, for distribution to the bishops here to debate a pastoral letter on nuclear arms:

title: C.A.B. Reports More 'Bumps'
description: There were more ''bumps'' this past summer, according to a report by the Civil Aeronautics Board. But, as of last month, anyway, the bumps didn't bruise as much.

title: GIANT AND JET STAFFS ARE STILL PREPARED
description: The coaches for the Giants and the Jets are ready to resume the season, as are the teams' trainers. But they are not sure about the players.

title: Conoco Signs Deal With Petro-Lewis
description: Conoco, a wholly owed subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said it had reached a final agreement with the Petro-Lewis Corporation to sell some domestic oil and gas reserves for $775 million. The properties include 100 percent of Conoco's interests in four offshore fields and 26 percent of the oil company's interests in 22 onshore fields in nine states.

title: DANCE AND SONG OPEN CITY BALLET'S SEASON
description: When the curtain rose last night on the New York City Ballet's fund-raising gala at the New York State Theater, Merrill Ashley and Adam Luders led a scene from George Balanchine's ''Chaconne,'' to Gluck. But when they left the stage, on came Stephanie Sundine to sing a soprano aria from Gluck's ''Alceste.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Additives in Drink

title: ANDROPOV COULD SHOW HAND IN 2 MEETINGS EXPECTED SOON
description: With Leonid I. Brezhnev's funeral over, Western diplomats here are watching for any moves by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Communist Party leader, to strengthen his position by adding new members to the two decisive bodies in the Kremlin hierarchy, the Politburo and the Secretariat of the Central Committee.

title: PLAYERS AND COACHES EAGER TO RETURN TO WORK
description: Pro football players, coaches and officials, eager to get back to work, reacted with enthusiasm yesterday after an agreement was reached to end the National Football League players strike. The enthusiasm remained even as union leaders argued into the night over details of the plan before finally accepting it.

title: DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oven Seized After Burning
description: The state police seized a microwave oven for testing after an infant suffered severe burns that ''cooked'' her toes, officials said today. The girl, a month old when she was hospitalized Oct. 31, was in stable condition.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AN Ohio girl aged 5 was recovering from chicken pox, an 11-yearold boy from Washington was just getting over what seemed like a bad cold and a 16-year-old Wisconsin boy had a flulike illness. Instead of recovering fully, all suddenly and inexplicably got worse and within a day had lapsed into comas, which only the older boy survived.

title: Top Credentials
description: Yeshiva University's new fencing coach carries some unusually impressive references. In his native city of Odessa in the Soviet Union, Stanislaw Bardakh produced about 20 fencing champions.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT HAS ITS DEFENSE IN FALLOUT TRIAL
description: The oak and the ash are bare, and any view down the Ohio River from anywhere in Moscow is blocked by the cooling tower at the William H. Zimmer nuclear power plant. The tower rises like an Scandinavian-modern egg-cup the size of a football field from behind an old schoolhouse.

title: Republic Dividend
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said it had halved its quarterly dividend to 12 1/2 cents a share from 25 cents, payable Dec. 20, to shareholders of record Nov. 26. The reduced dividend reflects the company's loss for the third quarter and the low level of steel demand, Republic said. For the third quarter, Republic reported a loss of $74.6 million, compared with earnings of $92.7 million a year earlier.

title: THOMSON MAY GET GRUNDIG
description: Thomson-Brandt, a nationalized French electronics group, is close to an agreement to acquire control of Grundig A.G., a major West German electrical concern that is partly owned by N.V. Philips of the Netherlands, corporate sources said today.

title: Amway Faces Fraud Charges
description: The Amway Corporation, one of the largest direct sales companies in the United States, and four top executives have been indicted on charges of defrauding the Canadian Government of more than $28 million, the authorities said.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1982; The Economy
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan may recommend that the 1983 personal income tax cut be advanced from July to January, Administration officials said. They said he feels the continuing lag in industrial activity requires Federal action to avert another year of slow growth and high unemployment. (Page A1.)

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Area Codes; Dialing the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Harris Conviction Upheld on Appeal
description: Jean Harris's conviction for murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, the author of ''The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet,'' was upheld today by New York State's highest court.

title: ALLCITY INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After gain on the sale of securities of $3,239,000

title: KOHL, IN NEW YORK ADDRESS, BACKS A U.S.-SOVIET MEETING
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said yesterday that he was in favor of a summit meeting between President Reagan and the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov.

title: Clippers' Sale on Hold
description: An attorney who has been empowered by Donald Sterling, the owner of the San Diego Clippers, to arrange the sale of the Clippers, said the pressure is off Sterling to sell the National Basketball Association team, and it could take some time to find a new owner willing to pay the asking price, which has been reported as high as $15 million. ''I don't think the league will do anything if he hasn't sold it soon,'' said Alan Rothenberg, the attorney.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $48,031 and a tax credit of $303,000...C-After income from discontinued operations of $287,645 for the qr and $563,502 for the 9 mos...D-After a gain from discontinued operations of $230,330 again on the sale of a life insurance operation of $2,016,224 and an extraordinary credit of $1,324,000

title: A TALK WITH SCHMIDT
description: For 13 years Helmut Schmidt was an influential figure in the Federal Republic of Germany, and for the last eight years its decisive voice as Chancellor. Now he has been defeated - no longer obliged to be on display or on guard when he talks to reporters - but liberated to say what he thinks about the condition of the world. He thinks some scary things.

title: Uranium Found Missing At 5 Nuclear Complexes
description: A Department of Energy study released today showed that 183 pounds of uranium and plutonium could not be accounted for at five Government nuclear complexes. But a department spokesman said none of the material appeared to have been stolen.

title: Braves Sign Niekro
description: Phil Niekro, the 43-year-old knuckleball pitcher of the Atlanta Braves, has signed a one-year contract, reportedly for $800,000. Niekro, who was 17-4 this year, was eligible to enter the free-agent draft, but he told Atlanta officials last month that he would sign another contract.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $4.5 million from discontinued operations...C-Including income of $515,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $100,000...D-After a loss of $4,692,000 from discontinued operations, an extraordinary charge of $1,296,000 and a charge of $2,078,000 for the effect of an accounting change

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Sunday accompanying an article on the decline of Soviet influence in Teheran misidentified an Iranian official. He was Oil Minister Mohammed Gharazi.

title: MAJORITY OF BISHOPS SAID TO BACK ARMS LETTER
description: More than two-thirds of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops basically agree with a proposed pastoral letter that strongly opposes the use of nuclear weapons, according to results of a survey made public today.

title: Huntington's Bid for Union
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, freed by a Federal Court decision, moved yesterday to merge the Cleveland-based Union Commerce Corporation into Huntington.

title: Work Records of Two Assailed in Derailment
description: The dismissed engineer and brakeman of a 101-car train that derailed in Livingston, La., in September had been dismissed twice before the wreck, testimony showed today.

title: Bobbie Brooks
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc., a women's apparel concern, announced it had filed a plan of reorganization with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland. The company said the plan provides for the payment of 100 percent of the amount owed its creditors at the time it filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last Jan. 15.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: YOUR MONEY AND YOUR LIFE. By Robert Z. Aliber. 238 pages. Illustrated With Tables. Basic Books. $15.95.

title: ULSTER'S GENUINE REVOLUTIONARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Blues Beat Devils, 7-2
description: Brian Sutter scored three goals in a game for the second time this season and assisted on one goal as the St. Louis Blues defeated the New Jersey Devils, 7-2, tonight. The victory, the first in six games for St. Louis, extended the Devils' streak to 14 games without a triumph, including 11 defeats.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Queen Beatrix Visits London
description: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands sailed up the Thames to London in a Dutch guided-missile frigate today to begin a four-day state visit to Britain. She and her husband, Prince Claus, were greeted at Westminster pier, adjacent to the houses of Parliament, by Queen Elizabeth and her husband, Prince Philip.

title: 'UGLY DUCKLING' OF SPACE TAUGHT SKEPTICS TO BELEIVE
description: The Columbia did it. When it first stood on the launching pad, back in April 1981, no spacecraft had ever gone into orbit and then returned, gliding, to a wheeled landing. The Columbia was the first true spaceship, not a capsule, not a vessel to be discarded after a single voyage, and it combined the elements of rockets, spacecraft and airplanes.

title: ALA MOANA HAWAII PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KNICKS SEND ROCKETS TO 9th LOSS IN ROW
description: It was not clear last night whether the Knicks were that good or the Houston Rockets were that bad. But in their best performance of the season, the Knicks rolled to a 120-93 victory at Madison Square Garden, extending their winning streak to three games and the Rockets' losing streak to nine. Houston has not won this season.

title: Arafat Visit to Jordan
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will visit Amman this month for talks with King Hussein, the Iraqi press agency reported from the Jordanian capital today.

title: HOSPITALS SEEK RULES ON WITHHOLDING LIFE-SUPPORT PROCEDURES
description: Hospitals in New York City have asked state health officials to adopt regulations for withholding emergency life-saving procedures from terminally ill hospital patients who suffer cardiac or respiratory failure.

description: ''This was an inaugural flight, like the first train over the golden spike in the 1800's.'' - James A. Abrahamson, a NASA official. (A24:1.)

HOUSE REPUBLICANS SEEK WIDER ROLE
description: In the wake of Democratic election victories this month, House Republican leaders agreed at a private meeting today to demand a greater voice in White House decisions in the next two years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

description: Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: BRZEZINSKI ASSAILS U.S. FOREIGN POLICY
description: In what he described as his first major speech on foreign policy since leaving his job as national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski said last night that Soviet-American relations were ''stalemated and potentially dangerous.''

title: Nan Robertson to Get Newswomen's Award
description: A special award for ''excellence in journalism'' will be presented to Nan Robertson of The New York Times, the Newswomen's Club of New York has announced. The award is for Miss Robertson's article ''Toxic Shock'' in the Sept. 19 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Yoko Ono Is Stepping Out on Her Own
description: REMINDERS of John Lennon are everywhere in the spacious Manhattan apartment the late Beatle shared with Yoko Ono. Collages he made from magazine and newspaper clippings are framed and hanging in a hall, a guitar he gave to their son, Sean, is in his room, a ''Double Fantasy'' shrub that furnished the title for the last album Mr. Lennon made with Miss Ono is potted in a planter in the kitchen.

title: THE GREAT THANKSGIVING TURKEY DEBATE
description: Robert Farrar Capon is an Episcopal theologian, author and food writer whose next book, ''The Youngest Day: An Island's Seasons in the Light of Grace,'' will be published next spring by Harper & Row.

Heileman Brewing
description: Irwin L. Jacobs announced that he and four of his associates, individually and as shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company, had begun litigation in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware against the G. Heileman Brewing Company, Pabst, the Olympia Brewing Company, their directors, and HBC Acquisition, a wholly owned subsidiary of Heileman that is acting as the ''bidder'' in the tender offer for up to 5.5 million shares of Pabst at $27.50 a share. The plaintiffs contend that the HBC offer is an illegal selftender offer made by Pabst through the use of Heileman as Pabst's agent. Mr. Jacobs has a competing offer that Pabst opposes.

title: HEWLETT INTRODUCES A DESK-TOP COMPUTER
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a desk-top computer yesterday that it said was far more powerful than other machines of its size on the market.

title: Equal-Time Rule Criticized by Paley
description: William S. Paley, the founder and chairman of CBS Inc., said last night that Congress should eliminate the Federal regulations of equal time and reasonable access prior to the 1984 Presidential election campaign. He charged that the requirements had negated their original intent and were no longer in the public interest.

description: To the Editor:

Reagan's Broadcasts Expected to Continue
description: White House officials say President Reagan will continue his Saturday radio broadcasts indefinitely.

title: GAMES SUNDAY
description: The strike by the National Football League's players, the longest in the history of professional sports, ended on its 57th day when union and management leaders reached agreement last night on a fiveyear contract.

title: FOR LEBANON, WAR IS OVER, NOT THE DYING
description: The war in Lebanon is over but the violence and killing go on. Some of the killing stems from the continued presence in fourfifths of the country of foreign forces - Israeli and Syrian troops and Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas. But most of the violence is between Lebanese.

title: THE LAST WORD IN KITCHEN GADGETS
description: Make your own soft drinks, bake your own dog biscuits, mix your own mustard. Obviously there has been something for everyone at the first New York Gourmet Products Show at the Coliseum, which closes today.

title: DISCOVERY REPORTED ON GENETIC MESSAGES
description: Researchers at the University of Colorado have isolated a form of RNA, ribonucleic acid, that does not rely on enzymes to alter its structure, the university reported today.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officer's Assailant Is Killed by Police
description: A man slashed a police officer with a hunting knife yesterday and then was shot and killed, authorities said. A second officer was slightly hurt when one of 14 shots fired by the police ricocheted and grazed one of his legs, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. SAYS PARIS PROTEST CAME ONLY AT 11TH HOUR
description: Reagan Administration officials, angered by France's insistence that it was not a party to the allied agreement on economic policy toward the Soviet Union, said today that France had agreed to the document a week ago and raised objections only an hour before President Reagan was to announce it last Saturday.

title: Brazilian Leftist Wins Key Governorship
description: Pro-Government candidates led in 12 of 22 gubernatorial races today, but a leftist was victorious in the largest and richest state of Sao Paulo, returns from Brazil's first free elections in 17 years showed.

title: FRENCH SAID TO URGE ARABS TO RECOGNIZE ISRAEL
description: An eight-member Arab League delegation headed by King Hussein of Jordan was told by President Francois Mitterrand today that Arab governments and the Palestine Liberation Organization should go beyond their present negotiating position and announce their explicit recognition of Israel, French Government sources said.

description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had infiltrated and smashed a New York City-based operation that used legitimate businesses to ''launder'' more than $100 million from illegal trafficking in drugs.

description: Mayor Koch yesterday presented city and state officials with outlines of his plans for balancing the city's budgets this fiscal year and next, largely through a combination of new taxes and a reduced work force.

Even the most basic custard or pudding can be transformed into a showpiece when cooked or chilled in a mold and presented attractively.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am fascinated to note how often you use the term ''piping hot,'' to indicate foods taken off the stove or out of the oven. I know it means as hot as possible but how does the word ''piping'' apply?

description: Raul Julia slinked across the floor at Roseland on Monday night, zoomed to a corner, and lifted Natalia Makarova straight into a tango. She barely had time to hand her cigarette holder over to her tablemate, Yves Montand.

description: TELEVISION cults are beginning to proliferate. Otherwise-normal adults tend to get soppy about the ''Golden Age'' of television drama. Sid Caesar and the ''Your Show of Shows'' gang are terribly fashionable these days. The earlier ''I Love Lucy'' series are beginning to take on the sheen of Charlie Chaplin shorts. In the popular arts, appreciation deepens with time.

title: Market Place; G.M. Showing A New Luster

This is the first of a six-game, 10-day road trip for the Nets. (Radio - WVNJ, 620 AM; 9:30 P.M.) Soviet National Team vs. University of Virginia, at Richmond Coliseum, 8 P.M. The Soviet squad is 5-1 after beating Indiana Sunday; its defeat was to Wichita State by 1 point.

In this undeveloped but sporadically promising memory play, the author, Ward Morehouse 3d, has attempted to write his own variation on ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

description: The change of government in Moscow confronts Washington either with great peril or rich opportunity, though possibly neither. Only time will tell. This is why we must be patient. Nor must we relax our guard. At the same time, our posture must be absolutely correct. As President Reagan has pointed out, it takes two to tango, but the correct posture for doing the tango is quite different from the posture that must be assumed for doing the rhumba.

The sale, valued at $44.5 million, does not require Xerox to make a cash investment of its own funds. Xerox Realty has arranged a long-term leveraged lease with the buyer, Lacris Associates, a New York-based limited partnership.

title: Soviet Pepsi Plants
description: The Soviet Union is negotiating with Pepsico Inc. to build 15 new factories to make Pepsi-Cola under license, Nikolai Oreshkin, deputy food minister, said today. Pepsi now has 10 factories in the Soviet Union and 7 percent of the softdrink market, Mr. Oreshkin said. He said Moscow was also planning to nearly double production of American cigarettes under license to one billion cigarettes a year. The Marlboro brand is produced in Moscow, Baku and Kishinev under license from Philip Morris Inc.

title: ASIAN-GAMES FEVER ADDS ZIP TO AUTUMN IN INDIA
description: 5 - There's a certain snap to life in New Delhi during these crisply golden weeks of November, when India's heat has fled for the year and every soft, sunny day is like September in New England. It's a time when energy multiplies, joggers and lovers once more gravitate to the parks, and the thwack of cricket bat on ball sounds from a hundred lanes and alleys.

title: PARIS ASKS FOR PRIVATE FINANCING
description: France decided today to ask private investors to finance more than half of the large industrial investment programs it wants the 11 major companies it nationalized earlier this year to start in 1983.

description: A key member of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party has told a group of Japanese journalists that talks with China could result in a pullback of troops from the Soviet-Chinese border.

title: PROPERLY FIGHTING INFLATION
description: The Federal Reserve Board's policies have at last reduced inflation, but nobody except Wall Street is cheering. The rest of us are too conscious of casualties in the war against inflation: 11.55 million unemployed, a wave of business failures, three years of stalling in both United States and world economic growth.

title: CONCERT: THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: GARY GRAFFMAN has been taking an enforced rest from the concert stage because of a right-hand disability similar to the one from which his friend and fellow pianist Leon Fleisher recently recovered. The muscular-neurological problem, apparently as yet imperfectly understood, is being treated by the same methods that proved successful with Mr. Fleisher, who earlier this season made a dramatic return to two-handed playing. So far, Mr. Graffman has not made enough progress to resume his career completely, but last night at Carnegie Hall he showed that his left hand, at any rate, is still in fine shape.

description: Gould Investors Trust said it had agreed to a transaction providing for a financial restructuring of BRT Realty Trust.

title: Indonesian Official Jailed

Investigations showed that the ferry, the Tampomas II, did not have adequate firefighting and life-saving equipment.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STEVE REICH'S MUSICAL ATTEMPTS TO HALT TIME'S CLOCK
description: STEVE REICH'S music may or may not offer enduring profundities, but it shows with unusual clarity music's attempts to reinvent time. The ticking of the clock is, of course, killing us all. Music is one of the ways we resist its flow. If, for example, we align the thematic and harmonic changes in Mr. Reich's ''Music for 18 Musicians'' with our everyday clock, they run their course in moments. But the soothing encouragement of this music, the sonorities of its mallet instruments and their gentle repetitions - all act to confuse and disorient time in its passage. They serve as a temporal relaxant, softening time's muscle tissue, inducing seconds to believe they are minutes, stretching one minute into 10.

title: Straight Talk

title: HOUSE VISITED BY THE SPIRIT OF GOOD FORTUNE

EIFIONYDD, Wales IAM told that when the Chinese, who know everything, build a house, they consult the precepts of an ancient science, feng shui, which tells them exactly how, when and where the work must be done and so brings good fortune to the home forever.
