title: Market Place; Does the Tail Wag the Dog?
description: THE November series of put and call options expires after tomorrow's trading and, if the past is any guide, a familiar misconception about options and how the tail wags the dog is likely to be widely debated again.

title: REVIVING FRAMES OF VAGUE ANCESTRY
description: FLEA markets and auctions, particularly those serving local causes or benefits, are often a good source for old picture frames of all sizes and conditions. Most are plain, though some painted, and most are in ordinary sizes, but once in a while one comes across a large and elaborate frame that, although it has seen better days, is worth taking a gamble on for stripping and restoration.

title: 3 in Britain Tried on Charges Of Arms Smuggling for Libya
description: Three British businessmen went on trial today on charges of smuggling arms and ammunition to Libyan diplomatic posts in Europe and North Africa.

title: Big Numbers For Dunston
description: If Shawon Dunston's first season in professional baseball is any yardstick, the Chicago Cubs may have found their shortstop or third baseman of the future.

title: TEXACO FINDS OIL OFF CALIFORNIA COAST
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that a well it operates off the coast of southern California had yielded large oil reserves. It said the well, one of six drilled in the area, confirmed that a ''giant oil discovery'' had been made.''

title: AUTUMN AT THE MOVIES: FALLING BOX-OFFICE RECEIPTS
description: The best summer in the history of Hollywood has been followed by a depressing fall at the box office. The biggest successes in movie theaters this autumn have, in fact, been two summer movies, Universal's ''E.T., The Extra-Terrestrial,'' and Paramount's ''An Officer and a Gentleman.'' Of the fall movies, only Orion's ''First Blood'' - with Sylvester Stallone as a berserk Vietnam veteran who wages war on a whole police force and several army regiments -can be considered a winner. Universal's ''Halloween III'' had a brief flurry, and M-G-M/UA's comedy, ''My Favorite Year,'' with Peter O'Toole, which started slowly, seems to be building something of an audience. Warner Bros.'s ''Creepshow'' has started strongly with an excellent $8 million box-office gross for its first five days. Funeral services for most of the other fall movies have been held quickly.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The headline yesterday on a Washington dispatch about the United States' reassessment of its participation in an international organization incorrectly characterized the agency. The reference, to the International Atomic Energy Agency, should have read, ''World Atom Agency.''

title: Japanese-Americans Win Pay For Time Lost in World War II
description: Japanese-Americans who lost their county jobs in World War II will receive $5,000 each over a period of four years to make up for the time they were denied employment after the Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor.

description: IMAGINE if a person had a single phone number that would allow him to be reached anywhere, whether he was at home or at work or at a hotel in Chicago. The person could program his schedule into the telephone system, which would then automatically direct calls to the proper place.

title: White Alabama Mother Wins Custody Round
description: Kathleen Blackburn won another court victory today in her battle to regain custody of her 3-year-old son, who was taken away from her after she gave birth to an illegitimate and racially mixed daughter.

description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times and chairman of The New York Times Company, called last night for an end to the ''fairness doctrine'' under which television and radio broadcasters are required to give equal time to the various participants in a political campaign.

title: John Nelson Named Director of Caramoor
description: John Nelson, music director of the Indianapolis Symphony since 1976, has been appointed music director of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y. Mr. Nelson will start his tenure at the 38th annual Caramoor Festival, which will open July 2.

title: Bridge: Aces Meet Texans in Final Of the International Trials
description: The Aces, with a 29-point carry-over, met Texas in the final of the International Team Trials here tonight. The Aces - made up of Ron Rubin, Mike Becker, Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag, all of New York, and Bob Hamman and Bob Wolff of Dallas - defeated a young Canadian team by an overwhelming margin of 209 international match points.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRAT URGES HIGHWAY-TRANSIT BILL
description: The chairman of a House committee said today that he would urge Congress in its post-election session to approve a four-year highway and mass transit bill to be financed in part by a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in Federal gasoline taxes.

title: 3d L.I.R.R. Union Ends Strike Threat
description: The Railway Carmen's union has resolved differences over work rules with the Long Island Rail Road and has dropped plans for a strike tomorrow, Robert Cullen, the union leader, said yesterday.

He thought he would have the chance to watch Augustana College, the team he played for a long time ago.

He spent the 1981 season on the Giants' injuredreserve list. The other players signed were Ted Vincent, a defensive tackle from Wichita State; Richard Murray, a defensive end from Oklahoma; James Moore, a center from Wisconsin; Donald Love, a cornerback from Houston, and Gary Moore, a running back from Tennessee.

description: The Vote Count Goes On A t the Board of Elections in downtown Brooklyn, two weeks after most candidates heard whether they had won or lost, the counting of paper ballots continues in the struggle over the 23d State Senate District. It is a primitive scene in a computerized age - more like a treasure hunt than the bedrock process of our nation.

title: ALTERING OLD QUILTS CAUSES A DISPUTE
description: QUIET but fervent controversy is brewing over the antique patchwork quilt. Entrepreneurs from Los Angeles to Atlanta have been drastically altering some of these century-old works of folk art and transforming them into teddy bears, baseball jackets, pillows, shower curtains and Christmas ornaments. It is not surprising that many antiques dealers and collectors are concerned.

title: MUSIC: SOVIET JEWISH THEMES
description: MORE than 90,000 Soviet Jews have immigrated to the United States in the last eight years, and roughly half of them have settled in New York City. Therefore, Sunday's ''Festival of Soviet Jewish Traditions,'' held at Symphony Space, was not only an evening of ethnic celebration but a reflection of a strong new indigenous culture as well.

title: PLANS UNVEILED FOR 125 M.P.H. LOS ANGELES-SAN DIEGO TRAINS

title: WHERE SIDEWALKS MAKE THE SCENE
description: If you were in California and a man and a woman wearing the latest warmup suits strolled by a couple walking a pair of Russian wolfhounds, chances are you would be in Beverly Hills. Or if you happened upon a couple with distinctly Middle Western faces draped in the exotic white robes of the Sikhs, you would probably be in Venice. But if these encounters took place in the space of a single block, then it must be Westwood Village.

title: Advertising; The Error Of the Mass Audience
description: IN recent years, says Robert H. Levenson, vice chairman and senior creative person at Doyle Dane Bernbach International, he has sensed a growing tendency among advertising people to think of their audiences ''in terms of multitudes.''

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: L'ENSEMBLE OFFERS RAVEL AND SCHOENBERG
description: STEVE REICH'S music may or may not offer enduring profundities, but it shows with unusual clarity music's attempts to reinvent time. The ticking of the clock is, of course, killing us all. Music is one of the ways we resist its flow. If, for example, we align the thematic and harmonic changes in Mr. Reich's ''Music for 18 Musicians'' with our everyday clock, they run their course in moments. But the soothing encouragement of this music, the sonorities of its mallet instruments and their gentle repetitions - all act to confuse and disorient time in its passage. They serve as a temporal relaxant, softening time's muscle tissue, inducing seconds to believe they are minutes, stretching one minute into 10.

description: * Aminoil U.S.A. Inc., Houston, has elected Robert S. Petty executive vice president, international operations.

Sales rose to $1.8 billion, up 8.6 percent from a year earlier.

description: International The Soviet-Chinese talks could lead to a mutual pullback of troops from the Soviet-Chinese border, according to Viktor G. Afanasyev, the editor of Pravda, who is a key member of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party. His comment was reported by Japanese and Soviet journalists now conferring in Moscow. (Page A1, Column 6.) Reagan Administration strategists have privately expressed concern about the improving Soviet-Chinese relations. The score came just 12 seconds after Russ Anderson of the Whalers was penalized for holding.

description: We are crossing a seam of history, watching a rare change in the Soviet leadership, yet American analysts struggle with ignorance even on modest questions. The disputations are worthy of medieval theologians: Does Yuri Andropov, the new Soviet Communist Party leader, like jazz, or does he prefer more middlebrow popular music? Does he speak English? Some authorities say yes, some say they don't know and American visitors who saw him Monday couldn't tell.

title: Coal Venture Set

They were employed by the Chinese Petroleum Corporation and had just completed a work shift aboard the drilling ship 100 miles off Keelung.

title: Delay in Loan For Argentina
description: Argentina's negotiations for a $1.1 billion loan have been delayed until the Government ratifies a provisional agreement with a consortium of 11 foreign banks, banking sources said today. The agreement was worked out in New York last week.

title: MISGUIDED CALL FOR A PERMANENT ENERGY 'CRISIS'
description: To the Editor:

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DANCE: CITY BALLET OPENS WITH GALA FUND RAISER
description: ON the face of it, it promised to be a gala program designed to make both ballet and opera fans unhappy. But as it turned out, the New York City Ballet's opening on Tuesday night at the State Theater - an experimental joint bill with the New York City Opera -went smoothly, briskly and enjoyably.

title: Newark Firemen Get Layoff Notices
description: Layoff and demotion notices have been sent to 115 members of the Newark Fire Department, according to a spokesman for the department. The cutbacks are needed ''because of the financial situation in the city of Newark and the need for economy in government,'' read the letter, which was mailed Monday, to the 115 members.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Consumers Power Co. filed with the S.E.C. for a $75 million series of first mortgage bonds, to be offered through Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Trainer of Tiger Denies Guilt
description: An animal trainer whose tiger bolted from a cage and mauled a child at Lion Country Safari pleaded not guilty today to two misdemeanor animal-control violations. John Campolongo of Garden Grove was charged with keeping animals in cages that were too small and not having proper permits. The child, Anthony Stopani, 2 years old, was released from a hospital Monday after undergoing extensive brain surgery.

title: TDA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from continuing operations of $142,211 and income from discontinued operations of $3,393...C-Including income from continuing operations of $215,798 and income from discontinued operations of $4,305

description: B-Including a gain of $337,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the retirement of debt

UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; revs includes commission income of $444,000 in 1982 and $689,000 in 1981

title: HILL REPUBLICANS VS. WHITE HOUSE ON '82 MANDATE
description: Discontent is brewing through the ranks of Republicans on Capitol Hill and elsewhere around the country. Every post-election period in Washington is a time to pause, to take stock. And, as Republican lawmakers trickle back from the campaign trail, many of them are persuaded that the voters are demanding some important changes in their party's agenda for the next Congress. Since their political survival depends on a perceptive reading of the public mood, these Republicans are determined to respond to the mandate of 1982 and to play the game by a new set of rules.

title: KEAN FEARS MORE LOSSES BY G.O.P. IF REAGAN DOES NOT MEND FENCES
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey said today that if the Reagan Administration did not improve its relations with blacks, women, environmentalists and union members, Republicans would be hurt in the 1984 elections.

title: 2 WEST BANK ISRAELIS ARE INDICTED
description: One official and one former official of a Jewish settlement in the West Bank have been charged with destroying possible clues to unsolved bombings that crippled two Palestinian Mayors in the occupied territory in June 1980.

title: The Best Defense
description: The Federal budget has gotten so far out of hand that it cannot soon be brought back to reasonable balance. Annual deficits are headed toward $200 billion. No amount of trimming costs or raising taxes - much less lowering them - can check the immediate flow of red ink. It's time to start working on long-term corrections, and the place to start is the Pentagon. The next six weeks are crucial.

title: First Woman Joins Jersey's Top Court
description: Marie L. Garibaldi, a 47-year-old tax-law expert, was sworn in today as the first woman on the State Supreme Court. The oath, administered by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz, made Miss Garibaldi the 18th woman to serve on a State Supreme Court in the country.

title: Bell Says Student Aid Policy Did Not Spur Freshman Drop
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell says hard times, not the Reagan Administration's curbs on student aid, are to blame for a drop in freshman enrollments at private colleges.

title: Value of House Sitters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Overlooked in Patrick Flanagan's article (''Securing Second Homes Against Fire, Theft and the Elements,'' Nov. 11) is the utilization of the barter services of a ''home sitter.''

title: G.E. CABLE SYSTEM
description: The General Electric Company said it was developing a process, called the Comband System, that would permit cable television system operators to double the number of channels they can transmit over existing cable systems. G.E. was to display the system today at the Western Cable Show in Anaheim, Calif. The company said the system provided an alternative to expensive conventional upgrading techniques, which involve installing additional cables.

title: Tennis Stalwart
description: Men's tennis has never had a commissioner, preferring to pass policy through a nine-member council comprising players, officials and tournament directors. But by rewarding Marshall Happer with a five-year contract last week to continue as administrator of the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the circuit has come as close as it ever has to having a commissioner.

title: JURY HEARS TALK ON TAPE ABOUT A TEAMSTER PLEDGE OF PROPERTY
description: The jury in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, heard a tape recording today of a conversation in which Mr. Williams was described as promising Senator Howard W. Cannon, ''You take care of your end and we'll take care of our end for you.''

title: STATE FIGHT LIKELY
description: Mayor Koch yesterday released details of his plan for closing New York City's budget deficits this fiscal year and next, but the executive director of the State Financial Control Board responded immediately by saying that he did not think the board would approve the plan without ''major changes.''

title: Mothers of 2 Veterans Angry at Vietnam List
description: The mothers of two Vietnam veterans whose names were not included on a national memorial because of regulations said Tuesday that the exclusion brought back bitter memories.

title: WARNER AIDE, IN COURT, DENIES CHARGE
description: Solomon Weiss, assistant treasurer of Warner Communications, vehemently denied yesterday that he had participated in a ''crooked scheme'' involving Warner's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: Cigna to Cut 4,000 Jobs
description: Robert D. Kilpatrick, president of the Cigna Corporation, said yesterday that the company intended to cut costs - $40 million by the end of 1983 and $100 million by the end of 1984 - by reducing its work force by 4,000 positions by the end of 1984.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a snow thrower can save many hours of backbreaking work during the winter, it can also be a frequent source of frustration if it refuses to start, stalls or becomes jammed with snow. Even when it runs properly, careless handling can cause accidents and serious injury.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT GUILTY IN GIVING GUNS TO LIBYANS
description: Edwin P. Wilson, the former American intelligence agent who made millions of dollars selling arms, explosives and expertise to Libya, was found guilty today of smuggling four pistols and an M-16 automatic rifle to Libyan agents overseas in 1979.

title: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ethnic Albanian in Yugoslavia Gets 15-Year Prison Sentence
description: Hidajet Hiseni, 28 years old, an ethnic Albanian journalist, was jailed for 15 years today on charges of antistate activities in Kosovo Province, where nine people were killed in ethnic Albanian riots last year.

title: Makeup Games Are Set
description: The National Football League has determined the matchups for the one game that, under the agreement ending the player strike, each team will make up on either Jan. 2 or Monday night, Jan. 3. The schedule for the makeup games, all of which are intraconference, pits the Giants against the Eagles at Philadelphia and the Jets against the Chiefs at Kansas City.

title: Jersey Studies Boxing
description: New Jersey Attorney General Irwin Kimmelman said he would propose that fighters undergo more extensive medical examinations before bouts.

title: Penalty Is Stiffened
description: Kerwin Bell, tailback on the University of Kansas football team, has pleaded guilty in Lawrence, Kan., to a misdemeanor drinking charge and has been given one month to perform 40 hours of public service work or face a possible $200 fine and 30 days in jail. Bell, a junior from Huntington Beach, Calif., admitted to drinking as a 19-year-old minor on March 11 and Judge Mike Elwell had ordered Bell to donate 20 hours of public service work in lieu of a jail sentence. When the judge reviewed the case and found that Bell had not performed any work, he ordered Bell retried this week and then doubled the amount of public service work.

title: TRAINING TO BREAK AWAY FROM THE WELFARE CYCLE

HERS
description: WHEN I look into the crystal ball to see myself in my old age, I see a figure of some authority, a grande dame in a wheelchair, a cane in hand to rap recalcitrant men over the knuckles with. One way or another, I've been having it out with recalcitrant men all my life, my father leading the way. Four sons was the order he put in initially when he married my mother. When his fourth daughter was born, he is reported to have fainted away in the telephone booth.

title: HABIB IS LEAVING FOR MIDEAST EARLY
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's chief Middle East negotiator, has advanced his travel plans and leaves for the region tonight to try to resolve the impasse over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon, State Department officials said today.

title: WOMEN'S ELECTION ROLE IS DISTURBING TO G.O.P.
description: Women's votes appear to have cost Republicans a few key elections this month, polls conducted by television networks indicate. While the number is small, party leaders and experts remain worried about the tendency of women to vote for Democrats more than men do.

description: A fugitive in the Brink's armored-car robbery and shootout in Rockland County last year has been arrested in Central America and returned to the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: MAJ. HADDAD DENIES ROLE IN PALESTINIAN MASSACRE
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the commander of an Israeli-supported militia in southern Lebanon, said today that, despite many reports to the contrary, none of his men were involved in the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian civilians by Phalangist Christian militiamen.

title: MURDOCH TO BUY BOSTON NEWSPAPER
description: Rupert Murdoch, the newspaper publisher, has reached an agreement to buy The Boston Herald American from the Hearst Corporation, agreeing to pay Hearst $1 million in cash and up to $7 million from the paper's future profits.

description: Gary Lewellyn, a former stockbroker who was found guilty in September of defrauding two Iowa banks of $17.7 million, was sentenced today to 20 years in prison.

SUPPRESSING FIRE
description: Wieslaw Gornicki is a Communist propagandist now working for the Soviet puppet regime in Warsaw. For nearly a generation, at the U.N. and elsewhere, he has devoted much time and expense trying to disparage and discredit the works of a free man from Poland, Jerzy Kosinski.

description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it planned a joint venture in Indonesia with the Nissho-Iwai Corporation of Japan to explore and develop coal resources in the eastern part of Kalimantan, along the Berau River.

Named as coaches Ron Schueler f or pitching; Billy Williams for batting; C lete Boyer for third base; Jackie Moore a nd Ed Mottle, who was manager at the T acoma affiliate. title: Drug Raid on Destroyer
description: One crewman has been arrested and 31 others assigned to the Navy destroyer Oldendorf have been implicated in drug use and trafficking, the Naval Investigation Services reports. The arrested crewman was caught in an undercover drug purchase. He was released on his own recognizance.

title: WORDS AND MUSIC; All That Jazz
description: The People's Music Press, in Peking, has issued a little lavender book, the better to guide China's young, titled ''How to Distinguish Decadent Songs.'' What's decadent, it turns out, is generally what's Western, and that includes jazz.

title: INVADING RACCOON HORDE TRIES SUBURBAN PATIENCE
description: Peter Woodcock, the Scarsdale Village Naturalist, was trying to be reassuring. ''If you see five or six sets of eyes in a storm drain, don't worry,'' he said, ''they're only raccoons moving from place to place, trying to avoid dogs and cars.''

THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1982; The Economy
description: Factories operated at a record low level of capacity in October. The Federal Reserve Board put factory use at just 68.4 percent, meaning that nearly a third of the nation's production lines were idle. The figure was seen as evidence that many factories will not be equipped to deal with recovery when it comes. (Page D1.) Housing starts rose a modest 1 percent in September, but permits for future construction gained 17.7 percent.(D11.)

title: Coach Testifies
description: According to Bobby Lee Hurt's high school coach, some of the money raised to pay for the basketball player's dental work was donated by Edward Seal, the principal of Butler High School in Huntsville, Ala.. Coach Jerry Rice testified yesterday in a libel suit that he had raised $1,100 to pay for the dental work and that $200 came from the principal in an envelope. Hurt is now at the University of Alabama.

title: STUDENT FROM CHINA DEFECTS TO ESTABLISH NEW RIGHTS JOURNAL
description: A Chinese physician who earned a Ph.D. in Canada while on a Chinese Government scholarship has defected to publish a magazine reflecting what he calls ''the ideals of the Chinese democracy movement.''

title: Progress, of Sorts, in Salvador
description: It says a lot about El Salvador that a decision to try anyone for murder is news. Nearly two years have passed since four American churchwomen were raped, murdered and buried in a makeshift grave; five accused killers - all former National Guardsmen - are soon to stand trial. The question is whether this constitutes enough progress on human rights to pass muster in January, when it again comes time for Congress to ratify El Salvador's eligibility for aid.

title: Reform the Rape Law Reform
description: Progress in writing fair, effective rape laws is an uneven thing. Consider the recent change in New York's law that has caused such furor in a pending rape case in Brooklyn. The new law was designed to make prosecutions easier for district attorneys to conduct and victims to endure. Here it has jeopardized a case that would have been fairly simple to prosecute before ''reform.''

title: CITY U. TEACHER WINS RIGHT TO CHECK ON TENURE DENIAL
description: A black instructor who was denied tenure at the City University of New York has won the right to find out how certain people voted in an effort to determine whether he was a victim of racial discrimination.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JETS FIND TRAINING FACILITY IS CLOSED
description: The Jets' players, thinking they were returning to practice this morning from a 57-day strike, found instead that Jim Kensil, the team's president, had ordered that the training camp remain closed because the agreement between the National Football League and the N.F.L. Players Association was not yet official.

title: Martin Won't Talk On Yank Situation
description: Right now, Billy Martin said yesterday, ''I don't have a job. I'm a professional commercializer.'' Martin, let go last month as manager of the Oakland A's and considered the strongest candidate to become manager of the Yankees, was in New York to make a carpet commercial.

title:
ON CENTRAL AMERICA;
WASHINGTON - In January, President Reagan is expected to ask the new Congress to stay the course in Central America by continuing to underwrite, with millions of dollars in economic and military aid, a policy that shows even fewer signs of success than the Administration's economic recovery program.
description: Congressional resistance is virtually certain - not only because President Reagan's policy has failed to yield any notable success in the region but also because of the disdain, sometimes verging on contempt, that the Administration has shown for Congress's role in making foreign policy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News article in Business Day last Friday incorrectly reported a transaction by Empire-Crown Auto Inc. Empire-Crown bought 182,420 shares of its common stock from the Northland Insurance Company and Edward H. Hamm, a Northland investor.

title: Italian Socialists Set Forth Demands
description: The Socialist Party, which holds the key to solving Italy's latest political crisis, today set forth its demands for joining a new coalition government led by Amintore Fanfani, a Christian Democrat.

title: Continuing Bank Aid Is Urged
description: The director of the International Monetary Fund, Jacques de Larosiere, has been meeting with major international banks to urge that they continue to maintain a flow of funds to developing nations, particularly to Mexico and Argentina.

description: One Albanian voter cast his ballot against the Communist Government, while 1,627,959 citizens voted in favor of the single slate of candidates in parliamentary elections, the official press agency said today.

title: Court Backs Elderly On Co-op Protection
description: Landlords seeking to convert rental apartment buildings to cooperatives must produce evidence of fraud in order to challenge the eligibility of elderly or handicapped tenants for special protection under the state law governing co-op conversions, the Appellate Division for the First Department of State Supreme Court has ruled.

title: HOW TO SEND A SIGNAL
description: Yuri Andropov has moved quickly as Soviet leader to signal an interest in better relations with the United States. When President Reagan paid a condolence call on the Soviet Embassy, Soviet television played it up. On the day of the Brezhnev funeral Mr. Andropov chose to meet with Vice President Bush and Secretary of State Shultz. His funeral oration said the Soviet Union was ready for international cooperation.

title: PARTIAL WALLS: NEW WAYS TO SHAPE SPACE
description: LOFT and apartment renovation used to involve a lot more tearing down than building up. Walls, in particular, were often ripped out to create open areas. But nowadays a growing number of architects and designers are balancing a desire for privacy and spaciousness by modulating space with partial walls. The walls they use are either free-standing partitions that do not reach the ceiling or portions of walls that simply suggest enclosure. The result is a layout that architects are calling the modified open plan. ''People today seem tired of living in one large loftlike area,'' said Peter Wilson, a New York architect, who recently used this partial-wall technique in a major renovation job. ''Most of my clients ask for the privacy of enclosed rooms, but at the same time they want a feeling of more spaciousness than the traditional apartment can offer.'' What the partial wall provides that the conventional wall cannot is flexibility at a reasonable cost. In apartments or lofts where windows are on only one side of the space, for example, using a partial-height wall can achieve visual enclosure while allowing light and air circula-tion to filter in from the rest of the loft or apartment. The expense of installing separate heating and airconditioning units is then avoided.

title: Savin Corp. Hires A G.E. Executive
description: Richard T. Gralton, a General Electric executive, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Savin Corporation. Mr. Gralton, 52 years old, was general manager of G.E.'s major-appliance marketing operations and a vice president.

title: Reagan Note on Transplant
description: The parents of Jamie Fiske, the baby girl who is recovering from a liver transplant operation, say they have received about 100 letters a day, including a personal note from President Reagan. ''It was a very personal letter expressing the fact that both he and Nancy were well aware of the situation and had offered prayers for Jamie's recovery,'' Charles Fiske, the father, said Tuesday.

title: Brodhead Uses Option
description: Bob Brodhead was hired last June to replace Paul Dietzel as athletic director at Louisiana State University, after Dietzel was released when a large deficit was projected for the athletic department. Last weekend, Brodhead declined an offer to move Saturday's football game against Florida State from 7:30 P.M. to noon for national television.

title: 7 MEDICAL EXPERTS WIN LASKER PRIZES
description: Five scientists who have made key contributions to the understanding of how viruses are related to cancer were named yesterday as winners of the 1982 Lasker Award for basic biomedical research.

title: HYSTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Nov. 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RATE HOPES LIFT DOW 19.50 IN BROAD REBOUND
description: Stock prices, after falling sharply in the last three sessions, rebounded yesterday on renewed expectation of a cut in interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost almost 47 points in the last three sessions, climbed 19.50 points yesterday, to 1,027.50. On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues far outnumbered stocks that declined; about 11 rose for every 4 that fell.

title: BONDS FALTER AFTER ADVANCING
description: The credit markets continued their preoccupation yesterday over whether the Federal Reserve would cut its discount rate, the interest it charges on loans to banks.

title: 1642 OPERA MASTERPIECE GIVEN 1982 ROCK SOUND
description: MONTEVERDI met ''The Wiz'' last night at Xenon, and although the meeting might have seemed improbable, and although there was much that remained dubious, the encounter proved surprisingly engaging.

title: Q & A
description: Q. We own a 100-year-old country house that we plan to close for the winter. We were going to shut down the heating system, but some friends have recommended that we leave it on because an unheated house of that age is likely to develop mildew over the winter. They say that this mildew will then be impossible to get rid of. What do you recommend?

title: WIDER GAP IN TRADE PREDICTED
description: President Reagan's new chief economist said today that record Federal budget deficits could push the country's deficit in international trade to a record $60 billion to $70 billion next year, nearly twice the level expected for this year.

title: NEW NICARAGUAN BANANA WAR
description: Bananas and politics, long one of the more incendiary combinations in the Western Hemisphere, are again stirring bad blood. The principals in the newest dispute are Castle & Cooke, a multinational food company, and the leftist Government of Nicaragua. Tempers frayed between the two when Castle & Cooke decided recently to close its banana operation in that Latin American nation. The Nicaraguans accuse the Honolulu-based company of trying to destabilize their Government by its withdrawal. Castle & Cooke emphatically rejects the charge, saying it was motivated only by economic reasons. Nicaragua's Response

title: BELMONDO AND CRITICS IN A FEUD
description: As unusual and quixotic enterprises go, here was a curious one: a group of 76 French film critics took out a newspaper advertisement today urging people to go to a movie they are avoiding.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT took Barry Harwood more than two and a half years to put together the collection. Starting tomorrow he will show some 45 pieces of child-size Thonet bentwood furniture at Harwood Galleries.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING TO RESTORE FUNDS FOR PERSHING MISSILES
description: Defense Department officials today planned a campaign in Congress to have $500 million restored to a military appropriation bill for Pershing II nuclear missiles. The funds were cut in a 7-to-6 subcommittee vote Tuesday.

title: PRELATES BACKED IN DISPUTE ON ARMS
description: Twenty-four former Government officials, prominent scientists and scholars today defended the right of the Roman Catholic bishops to speak out on the issue of nuclear arms, asserting, ''If nuclear war were to come, present silence on their part would be unforgiveable.''

title: ART MUSEUM SHIFTS CHIEFS
description: Pontus Hulten's reign as director of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art will end next March, even before the museum opens. The board of trustees has appointed him founding director and named Richard Koshalek, now deputy director and chief curator, to replace him.

title: LLOYD'S ELECTS MEMBERS OF NEW OVERSIGHT UNIT
description: The 20,000 members of Lloyd's of London, the world's largest insurance market, today elected eight British investors and four working members to a new governing council charged with overseeing sweeping regulatory reforms mandated by Parliament.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $368,857 for the qr and 9 mos

title: ARGENTINE LEADER IS SAID TO REJECT REAGAN'S PROPOSAL FOR A MEETING
description: Argentina has rejected an offer by President Reagan to meet with its President during Mr. Reagan's trip to South America next month, according to sources in Brasilia and Washington.

title: CITY JUVENILE JUSTICE CHIEF RESIGNS, CITING PROPOSED DETENTION CENTER
description: New York City's Commissioner of Juvenile Justice resigned yesterday, citing his opposition to elements of a plan to house a juvenile detention center in a jail the city would like to build at the edge of Chinatown.

title: Caffeine-Free Dr Pepper Set
description: The Dr Pepper Company entered the decaffeinated soft drink market, announcing it would begin selling a Pepper Free brand next year.

title: Queens Defendant Disrupts Hearing
description: A man convicted of attempted murder in the shooting of a police officer disrupted a court hearing in Queens yesterday, calling the judge a ''jackal'' and a ''snake.''

title: SALES DROP IMPERILING HARVESTER
description: The International Harvester Company, which recently avoided default by negotiating an agreement with its lenders, said failure to reverse its declining sales in the next few months could force it to file a bankruptcy petition.

title: OM A STILL FRONT, IRAQ LIES IN WAIT FOR THE IRANIAN MILITARY MACHINE
description: Seen from this Iraqi border command post 170 miles southeast of Baghdad, the front was mostly quiet. A small wood that was said to shelter Iranian troops two and a half miles away could be seen through field glasses.

title: BRUINS SET BACK ISLANDERS
description: The Boston Bruins disarmed the Islanders tonight with a close-checking, defensive game and scored a 3-1 victory in Nassau Coliseum. As Roland Melanson, the losing goaltender, put it: ''They put us to sleep.''

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan was told that the G.O.P. lacks the votes in the House to advance the 1983 tax cut by six months. Congressional leaders said they expect Congress to demand cuts in the proposed arms budget and to reject further cuts in social programs. (Page A1.) Martin S. Feldstein, Mr. Reagan's chief economic adviser, told him that a highway repair plan urged as a way to create jobs might actually cost jobs. (D16.)

title: News Analysis
description: In July, Herald Price Fahringer, the defense attorney for Edwin P. Wilson, vowed that if the Government put the former spy on trial he would ''be forced to reveal information that will shake the C.I.A. to its foundations.''

title: VIRGINIA ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REAGAN PLANS SPEECH MONDAY TO OFFER MOSCOW BETTER TIES
description: President Reagan will make a televised speech Monday night offering to seek improved relations with the Soviet Union. He will, however, reassert that peace depends on building up American military strength and reaffirm his existing arms control proposals, Administration officials said today.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARGENTINA TO DELAY REPAYMENT
description: Argentina's central bank, in a major restructuring of part of the nation's crushing foreign debt, announced today that it was substituting five-year bonds and promissory notes for $4.7 billion in debt that private concerns must repay foreign creditors over the next six months.

title: European Study Shows Increase in Harp Seals
description: The number of harp seals in the world increased in the late 1970's despite Canada's seal hunts, a study issued today showed.

title: Tightrope Sketches
description: Philippe Petit, the French tightrope walker who tiptoed to fame walking between the World Trade Center's towers in 1974, is also a professional artist, and a free exhibition of 10 pencil drawings by him can be seen through Sunday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue. Each drawing represents a rope tied with knots that Mr. Petit has used for his tightrope walks. Information: 678-6900.

title: Violin Premiere Sunday
description: A violin concerto by Leonardo Balada will be presented in its world premiere Sunday evening at 8 in Carnegie Hall in a concert by the Carnegie-Mellon University Philharmonic and Chorus. The Pittsburgh institution's concert will be conducted by Werner Torkanowsky. Tickets are free, but must be obtained in advance by calling 430-6407.

title: Gelsey Kirkland Signs With Ballet Theater
description: Gelsey Kirkland has signed a new contract with the American Ballet Theater and is expected to perform on its coming tour, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $160,000

title: NATIONAL STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; the latest yr loss includes special charges related to plant closings of 68 cents a shr; the prior yr had a similar charge equal to $2.10 a shr

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,236 and an extraordinary charge of $11,000...C-Net loss including an income from discontinued operations of $9,943 and an extraordinary charge of $36,700...D-After a loss of $16,328 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $18,000...E-Including income from discontinued operations of $153,456 and an extraordinary gain of $36,700

title: GENEVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including realized gains on investments of life insurance operations of $649,733 for the qr and $178,914 for the 9 mos...C-Including realized gains of $31,696 for the qr and $85,658 for the 9 mos

title: Yamani Hints Oil Price Flexibility
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister was quoted by a Kuwaiti newspaper today as saying he favored retaining the benchmark price of $34 a barrel set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but that he did not rule out a reduction.

title: MUSICIANS FIND A PERFORMING HAVEN IN CHURCHES
description: IT would seem a normal weekend in New York's musical heartland. Tonight, the Sylvan Wind Quintet is playing Ravel and Rossini and the Wond'rous Machine is singing ensemble music by Byrd, Lassus and Palestrina. Tomorrow in Brooklyn, there's Boito's opera ''Mefistofele'' and not far away a 40-piece orchestra playing Haydn and Mozart. Sunday, Lynne Aspnes plays her harp on Manhattan's Upper West Side and not far from there the Bach series called ''Evenings With Johann S.'' continues.

title: Sealaska Chairman Adds Another Post
description: Byron I. Mallott, chairman of the Sealaska Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer following the resignation of the company's president, Michael H. Chittick.

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
MACHINE TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dow Advances 4.60, to 1,032.10
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in slower trading following Wednesday's sharp rally. The best gains were posted by some of the special-situation issues that responded to specific news developments.

title: WEIBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a net gain of $1,198,200 from the sale of leasehold rights...C-Including a net gain of $4,403,000 from the sale of a one-third interest in a shopping center

title: Policy on Refunds Set
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, has required all 28 N.F.L. teams to meet the following criteria for games that have been canceled or games that have been rescheduled for Jan. 2-3: Canceled Games

title: WHAT IF REAGAN AND BEGIN HAD MET
description: Had the script been followed, ''The Confrontation'' would have occurred tomorrow. The scene was to have been the Oval Office. The stars, Ronald Reagan and Menachem Begin, were to play themselves. The plot line called for what is known in diplomatic parlance as a ''spirited discussion and frank exchange of views,'' which means tough talk.

title: 3 Feel Bear's Wrath
description: Coach Bear Bryant dropped three senior running backs from his Alabama team yesterday, saying they did not have a winning attitude. None of the three - Charlie Williams, Ken Simon and Earl Collins - is a starter.

title: U.S. Seeks New Study On Reye's Syndrome
description: The Government today ordered more research on a possible link between Reye's Syndrome and aspirin before it decides whether warning labels are necessary on aspirin products.

title: No Headline
description: Rogers Leads in Australia

title: Army Exercises in Sinai
description: The Egyptian Army carried out military exercises today in the Sinai Desert, which Egypt recovered last April under a peace treaty with Israel. The Defense Minister, Field Marshal Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, who attended the war games about 50 miles east of the Suez Canal, was quoted as saying that the exercises were ''defensive in character'' and that Egypt was committed to peace with Israel.

title: SRC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INPUT BUSINESS MACHINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRADERS AWAIT SIGN ON RATES
description: The credit markets remained listless yesterday as investors waited for a clear sign of whether the Federal Reserve will continue to maintain a fairly easy monetary policy or whether it will tighten up in response to the rising monetary supply.

title: TAURUS OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Scrabble Players to Vie For Times Square Title
description: Scrabble players from around the country will demonstrate their skill at the board game this weekend at the sixth Nathan's Times Square Scrabble Championship, at Nathan's Restaurant, Broadway at West 43d Street.

title: CARIBBEAN LEADERS IN ACCORD ON RIGHTS
description: The leaders of the English-speaking Caribbean agreed tonight to abide by international declarations on human rights and gave limited support to two members, Belize and Guyana, in their territorial disputes with their neighbors.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said the interest rate on its floating rate notes due in 2010 had been set at 9.05 percent per annum for December, down from 9.20 percent for November.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union has been and is for normal, and even better, friendly relations with the United States of America.

title: Auto Layoffs Reach a Record
description: The number of auto workers on indefinite layoff this week rose to a record 254,914, major car makers said.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Requiem for Reaganomics
description: Martin Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, warned last week that ''unless there is dramatic action, the United States will experience an unprecedented series of deficits during the years ahead.'' It was an unspoken but obvious message to Congress: raise taxes or cut spending.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Associated Dry Goods
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, operator of 15 department store divisions, said yesterday that net income in its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 31 fell 19.6 percent, to $8.2 million, or 45 cents a share, from $10.2 million, or 56 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 4.8 percent, to $744.4 million, from $710.1 million.

title: UNLIKELY TOWER OF RELIGIOUS TOLERANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: LATE RALLY STOPS KNICKS' STREAK
description: The Knicks' three-game winning streak ended last night when they were outmuscled and outshot by the Milwaukee Bucks in an 89-77 defeat at Madison Square Garden. It took a powerful revival by the Bucks in the final period to escape a swarming defense that for two quarters threatened to beat them.

title: SAN DIEGO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating loss...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $63,334 for the qr and $183,204 for the yr and gains on the disposal of subsidiaries of $2.5 million for the qr and $2.6 million for the yr and extraordinary gains of $56,100 for the qr and $181,800 for the yr...D-Including income from discontinued operations of $59,291 for the qr and $153,283 for the yr

title: A U.S. COMPANY'S CASE AGAINST JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Semaphore for Riders

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LITTLEFIELD ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
West Side Italian old and new style.
description: EVERY once in a while, a restaurant seems to fall between two ratings. A case in point is Altri Tempi, which opened last year on 58th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, a block that has 10 Italian restaurants.

title: W.B.A. Defection
description: Defections from the World Boxing Association continue. The latest to leave is Missouri, which followed earlier pullouts by Virginia and the Canadian Professional Boxing Federation.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's 268 money market funds dropped $469 million, to $230.5 billlion, in the week ended Wednesday, following a decline of $309 million the week before, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Red Holzman, who retired as Knicks coach after last season, will be coaching again tomorrow night in the City College alumni game at Nat Holman Gym before the school's season opener against Morgan State. Holzman was co-captain of the 1941-42 Beaver team under Holman. ... Charlie Brown of North Haledon, N.J., was scratched from a lightweight bout in Totowa last night by Robert W. Lee, the New Jersey State deputy boxing commissioner, because Brown had participated in a fight Tuesday night in Memphis, knocking out Gene Taylor in the first round.

title: Hockey Suspension
description: Paul Higgins of the Toronto Maple Leafs, a right wing, has been suspended for four games for a high-sticking incident Nov. 7 in which his stick struck Darryl Sutter of the Chicago Black Hawks in the face and broke his nose. The immediate suspension was levied by the National Hockey League's executive vice president, Brian O'Neill, after a hearing in Toronto Tuesday.

title: Pentagon Aides Seek More Lie-Detector Use
description: Pentagon lawyers have drawn up revised rules that would broaden the use of polygraphs, or lie detectors, for the first time in about 17 years.

title: 7 U.S. Ships Due in Mombasa
description: The aircraft carrier Enterprise and the six other United States Navy ships of its battle group are to arrive here Monday for a seven-day visit. Officials said 8,700 officers and enlisted men were aboard the ships. The others are the destroyer tender Samuel Gompers, the guided missile cruiser Bainbridge, the guided missile frigate George Philip, the frigates O'Callahan and Reasoner and the combat support ship Sacramento.

title: Patriots Decide to Play
description: The New England Patriots, who were considering a boycott of their game Sunday against Cleveland, decided tonight to play after a meeting with Ed Garvey.

title: Bolivia to Try 3 Ex-Rulers
description: The Supreme Military Court said today that three members of a former Bolivian junta would be tried by a military court on charges of illegal dealing in semiprecious stones. The three -Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, Gen. Waldo Vernal and Rear Adm. Ramiro Terrazas - came to power in July 1980 and ruled for a year.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHERE TROUT STILL FLOURISH
description: That time of year is here when those Northeast anglers not excited by the prospect of ice fishing are confined to retrospect and refurbishing their gear. This is particularly true of those who enjoy taking trout on a fly.

title: CBS-WESTMORELAND TRIAL IS MOVED
description: A Federal judge today ordered the trial of retired Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit against CBS moved from South Carolina to New York.

title: ART: WORKS OF HODGKIN DISPLAYED AT KNOEDLER'S
description: THE paintings of Howard Hodgkin - now on view at M. Knoedler & Company - are not in the least like anyone else's. Irresistible from the first glimpse onward, they could be mistaken for specimens of painting divorced from all objective significance. We have a sensation here and there of deep space, but as to what, if anything, is going on, there we should initially not find it easy to say.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Club Whispers
description: The whispers around Manhattan College are that Tom O'Neill, the Jaspers' sophomore club-football quarterback, may be headed for loftier pastures - with a scholarship to a Division I school next year.

title: Searle Appoints Head Of Its Sweetener Group
description: G.D. Searle & Company of Chicago has announced plans to form a separate business group to manage its Nutrasweet low-calorie sweetener and has named Robert B. Shapiro to head it.

title: MAYOR TO DISCUSS HIS BUDGET PLANS WITH BLACK AND HISPANIC LEADERS
description: Mayor Koch, responding to a request from three Assemblymen, said yesterday he would meet with black and Hispanic political leaders to discuss his plans for closing budget deficits exceeding $1.6 billion in this fiscal year and the next.

title: Eye on New League
description: Jack Thompson, the backup quarterback to Ken Anderson of the Cincinnati Bengals, is negotiating with a team in the United States Football League and has no immediate plans to return to the Bengals. Mike Brown, the assistant general manager and legal counsel for the Bengals, said Thompson was under contract to the National Football League team for two years and that legal action would be taken in an effort to retain him. Brown said Thompson had written the Bengals during the players' strike and said he considered his contract breached because he thought that as a nonmember of the union he should be paid. Thompson was the Bengals' top pick in the 1979 draft, from Washington State. ... Bo Matthews, a former fullback for the San Diego Chargers and the Giants, was signed by the Denver Gold of the U.S.F.L.

title: DOME CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE WORKERS TO PAY 10% SHARE OF INSURANCE IN COST-SAVING MOVE
description: New York State's 190,000 employees will pay 10 percent of health insurance premiums for individual coverage under a major restructuring of the state's health insurance program, the state's Director of Employee Relations said yesterday. The state had formerly paid the full cost.

title: CITY BALLET: THREE CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: THE New York City Ballet, following its offbeat opener with the New York City Opera, swung into its regular repertory Wednesday night at the State Theater.

title: BRAZIL BANK'S LOAN BID STIRS CONCERN
description: Many international bankers in the United States were no doubt unpleasantly surprised recently when they received a memorandum from Brazil's Banco do Commercio e Industria de Sao Paulo. The three-page memorandum, dated Sept. 23, was an attempt to convince the foreign bankers to continue lending to Banco do Commercio.

title: S.E.C. Shifts Its View on Disclosure
description: In a speech prepared for delivery Friday, John M. Fedders, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division, says he does not believe Federal securities laws require disclosure of all illegal behavior. The statement represents a much narrower view of disclosure than was held by Mr. Fedders's precedessor, Stanley Sporkin.

title: Devine Is Available
description: Dan Devine said he would consider the head coaching job at Michigan State if he were offered it. Devine, former head coach of Arizona State, Missouri and Notre Dame, as well as the Green Bay Packers, is now the head of the Sun Angel Foundation, a money-raising group supporting Arizona State. Michigan State has dismissed Muddy Waters, effective after tomorrow's game against Iowa. ... Chuck Davis, the tailback who is Wisconsin's No. 2 rusher this season with 351 yards in 61 carries, was suspended for the third time this semester for failure to attend classes.

title: A 'Conservative' Union Man
description: day strike. Powell lifted his tattered practice T-shirt and exposed a roll of flesh around his waist.

title: I.B.M. Introduces Document System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a computer terminal designed to transmit and store images of documents electronically.

title: Amoco Gas Finds
description: The Amoco Production Company said it had discovered three ''significant'' natural gas fields in the northeastern Utah-southwestern Wyoming area of the Overthrust Belt. An Amoco official in Denver said it was too early to make any reserve estimate. Amoco is the exploration drilling leader in the Overthrust Belt along with the Champlin Petroleum Company and Chevron U.S.A. Inc. and owns interests in 24 of the 26 fields discovered to date in the Wyoming-Utah border area of the Overthrust Belt.

title: WHY RUSSIA WOULD RATHER NOT FEED ITSELF
description: To the Editor:

title: Breyers Closing
description: The Kraft Dairy Group said it would close its Breyers ice cream plant in Long Island City, Queens, next April as part of a companywide consolidation program. The plant, which employs 350, also manufactures Sealtest ice cream and sherbets and Light 'n' Lively ice milk. Fred Rasmussen, vice president of the Kraft Dairy Group, a unit of Dart & Kraft, said the company would also discontinue its frozen dessert distribution facilities in Farmingdale, L.I., and Hillside, N.J. The company will maintain its sales ofices in Fairlawn, N.J. and distribute its frozen desserts made elsewhere in the Northeast.

title: BASEBALL
description: Named Bill H aller assistant supervisor of umpires. BOSTON (AL) - Promoted Juan Bus- t abad, shortstop, and Gus Burgess, out- f ielder, from minor leagues to 40-man w inter roster. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Rehired all f ive coaches for 1983 season: Cloyd B oyer, pitching, Rocky Colavito, hitting, a nd Joe Nossek, third base, all complet- i ng second year of two-year contracts. A lso, Jose Martinez, first base, and J immy Schaffer, bullpen, signed new o ne-year contracts. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Traded Juan E ichelberger, right-handed pitcher, and B roderick Perkins, first baseman, to C leveland Indians for Ed Whitson, right- h anded pitcher.

title: Yorkville Group Sues on Housing
description: A Yorkville citizens' group filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan against the city and private developers in a dispute over the density of housing planned for the last phase of an urban-renewal project on the former Ruppert brewery site.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax credits of $495,000 for the qr and $670,000 for the 9 mos

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUGS BUNNY MEDLEY
description: ''BUGS BUNNY'S 3D MOVIE: 1,001 RABBIT TALES'' is another featurelength retrospective of the art of Friz Freleng and Mel Blanc, the creators of such classic Warner Bros. cartoon characters as Bugs Bunny, Tweety Bird, Sylvester the Cat and Daffy Duck.

title: 'STILL OF THE NIGHT,' IN HITCHCOCK MANNER
description: ROBERT BENTON'S ''Still of the Night,'' the writer-director's first film since his Oscar-winning ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' is something else entirely, a velvety-smooth looking romantic mystery melodrama that has far less to do with life than with other movies. It's clever but chilly in the way of something with a mechanical heart.

title: 2.9 Million Dana Bequest Fulfills Philharmonic Goal
description: The Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York announced today that a $2.9 million bequest from the estate of Mrs. Charles A. Dana has completed the $18 million phase of the Philharmonic's endowment campaign, several months ahead of schedule. The bequest from Mrs. Dana, who died last May, combined with support from the Charles A. Dana Foundation, which she headed, now totals $6.45 million.

title: Demand Stirs Suit On Recovery Plant
description: Presiding Supervisor Thomas S. Gulotta said today that the builder of a $145 million resource-recovery plant had demanded $12.5 million from the town to complete work on revisions designed to rid the plant's emissions of bad odors and any possible toxins.

title: CBS SLAYING SUSPECT LINKED TO FRAUD
description: For the first time since the slayings last April of a witness in a $5 million Federal fraud case and three CBS technicians, a prosecutor said yesterday that there was evidence of a connection between a man charged with the slayings and a diamond company owner who has been convicted in the fraud case.

title: PUERTO RICAN PRISONS 'READY TO EXPLODE' DESPITE REFORM EFFORT
description: Something remarkable has been going on in Puerto Rico's prisons for the last three weeks or so: Not a single inmate has been put to death by a fellow inmate.

title: Running Forever
description: On the belief that a handful of ultramarathoners will run forever to earn money and prove a point, the New York Road Runners Club is exploring the possibility of staging a six-day run at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island sometime next spring.

title: ART: WHAT COLOR MEANS TO WHOM, THREE VIEWS
description: WRITING in 1912, Wassily Kandinsky contended that only the ''more sensitive soul'' could fully appreciate color, savoring its spiritual as well as its physical effects. Psychologists and interior designers have long since proved that color operates democratically; besides, the notion of class distinction in souls, however much some may cherish it in private, is no longer in vogue.

title: Article 043218 -- No Title
description: The Board of Estimate voted last night to approve a Koch administration plan to sell apartments in city-owned buildings to their tenants for $250 each with the condition that the city receive 40 percent of the profit from subsequent resales.

title: Al Haig Services Set Today
description: Funeral services for Al Haig, the early be-bop pianist who died Tuesday, will be held today at 2 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church at 53d Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: King Hussein Meets With Turkey's Leader
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for a two-day official visit that was seen as a new move toward the consolidation of Turkey's ties with its Middle Eastern neighbors.

title: Jacobs Group Lifts Pabst Offer to $30
description: A group headed by the Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs has raised its offer for 3 million shares of the Pabst Brewing Company to $30 a share from $24. The withdrawal deadline remains midnight next Friday, the group said, and the offer will expire at midnight, Dec. 2, unless further extended.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: The 1981 results were restated for an accounting change

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ISRAEL DESCRIBES MASSACRE REPORT
description: Israel's Communications Minister, Mordechai Zipori, testified today that he was told that civilians were being killed in Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut on Friday morning, Sept. 17, and that he then informed Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the report of a massacre.

title: Friday; NEATEST TRICK OF WEEK
description: If all goes according to plan, 17-year-old Miguel Vazquez will fly from a trapeze into the hands of a catcher today, completing four full turns at 80 miles an hour on the way and thus repeating his recent feat as the first human known to have successfully performed a quadruple somersault. The Mexican-born Flying Vazquez family is a highlight of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, running through Nov. 28 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. It's about 10 minutes from the Lincoln Tunnel; buses from the Port Authority go there frequently. Today's shows at 10:30 A.M. and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $6 to $9.50 and may be purchased through Chargit, 944-9300, or Ticketron offices. Information: (201) 935-8500. TRIBAL ARTS ON PARADE

title: AMQUEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'HEAR NO EVIL,' WEST COAST POLICE STORY
description: STRAINING for a new gimmick in the old police-drama formula, ''Hear No Evil,'' tomorrow's television movie on CBS, Channel 2, at 9, comes up with a deaf cop. Played by Gil Gerard, who was formerly ''Buck Rogers in the 20th Century,'' Bill Dragon is a San Francisco detective stalking a motorcycle gang suspected of running drugs and prostitution rackets. The ''bikers'' put out a contract on Dragon's life. When his car is rigged with explosives, he survives the murder attempt but is left totally deaf.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch from Moscow yesterday about Soviet-American trade incorrectly quoted Arthur A. Hartman, the United States Ambassador. He said the United States would not relent in its determination to link trade issues to ''our overall political relationship'' with the Soviet Union.

title: OVERTHRUST RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today; Nov. 19, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: ROSE AWARD GOES TO I.M. PEI
description: A rose is a rose is a rose, except at Lord & Taylor, whose annual Rose Award is a classy etched-rose prism from Tiffany. This year's Rose, presented Wednesday evening at a black-tie dinner-dance in the store, was given to I.M. Pei for ''dedication to humanity through architecture and perfecting the quality of life throughout the world with creative building.''

title: STAGE: 'HOLLY AND IVY,' PARSON AND 2 DAUGHTERS
description: WITH its successful productions of ''The Winslow Boy'' and ''The Browning Version,'' the Roundabout Theater has made a persuasive case for the enduring value of the old-fashioned plays of Terence Rattigan. Last night the Roundabout advanced this cause further, albeit unintentionally, by reviving a lookalike, Rattigan-style work, ''The Holly and the Ivy,'' which Rattigan did not write.

title: 'LAST UNICORN,' AN ANIMATED FABLE
description: ''THE Last Unicorn'' is an unusual children's film in many respects, the chief one being that it is unusually good. This animated fable also features a cast that would do any live-action film proud, a visual style noticeably different from that of other children's fare, and a story filled with genuine sweetness and mystery. Children, except perhaps for very small ones, ought to be intrigued by it; adults won't be bored. And no one of any age will be immune to the sentiment of the film's final moments, which really are unexpectedly touching and memorable.

title: VERDI OPERA HAS GONE FAR SINCE 1847
description: Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' was the 10th of the composer's 26 operas and the first of three based on Shakespeare. It had its premiere in Florence in 1847, 40 years before the first performance of ''Otello'' and 46 years before ''Falstaff.'' (A long-projected ''King Lear'' was never carried through by the composer, who said he felt intimidated by the mad scene.)

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Western Electric In Marketing Pact
description: The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it has signed contracts for the first time to sell its products to non-Bell telephone companies.

title: UNION CONCESSIONS IN STEEL REPORTED
description: The executive board of the United Steelworkers of America approved a tentative agreement yesterday that calls for a cut of about 10 percent in wages and benefits and other major concessions, according to union and company officials.

title: Jersey Accepts Ruling on Jockeys
description: State Attorney General Irwin Kimmelman said today that his office would not appeal last week's decision by a Superior Court judge dismissing indictments that accused four jockeys of conspiring to fix Meadowlands races.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
LEBANON FOR THE LEBANESE
description: The prevailing wisdom in the United States is that the Israeli invasion has created new opportunities for ending civil strife in Lebanon. As a Lebanese who sees the invasion as a catastrophe exceeding all other horrors during years of violence in my country, I concur in this statement, but with an important qualification: The new opportunities come not from the Israeli attack itself but rather from the potential for unity among those who oppose the Israeli occupation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aminoil USA Inc., Houston, has elected Jimmie T. Glover a vice president.

title: POUND FALL INTENSIFIES INFLATION
description: The sharp decline in the British pound this week has created a mixture of jubilation and concern among businessmen and politicians here.

title: SAUL, B F, REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for QTr to Sept 3
description: B-After reversal of a tax credit of $915,000...C-Net income after a tax loss carryforward of $1,598,000 and a loss of $768,000 on early extinguishment of debt

title: The magic of producing a 'Unicorn.'
description: ARTHUR RANKIN Jr. and Jules Bass have been partners (both produce, both direct) for 25 years. But ''The Last Unicorn,'' opening all over the country today, is their first major theatrical animated feature. Most earlier Rankin-Bass animated movies - ''Little Drummer Boy,'' ''Frosty the Snowman'' - were made for television, and so was their two-hourlong ''The Hobbit.''

title: BISHOPS SUPPORT LETTER ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The country's Roman Catholic bishops indicated today that they solidly supported a proposed pastoral letter on nuclear arms although they still had questions about a section on the morality of nuclear deterrence.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $13,000 and a tax credit of $66,000...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $10 million,a gain on the public offering of a subsidiary of $7.2 million and a tax credit of $4.7 million; the 1982 results included a nonrecurring charge of $280,000 forrelocating a manufacturing plant

title: CLERICS SAY NO
description: The collected works of St. Maksymilian Kolbe contain a number of comments that indicate that the Polish priest who became a saint last month may have shared in the anti-Semitism current in the Polish Roman Catholic Church in the 1920's and 30's.

title: Required Reading; Costs and Benefits
description: From ''Cost-Benefit Analysis and Regulation: Expressway to Reform or Blind Alley?'' by Marguerite Connerton, Department of Labor, and Mark MacCarthy, House Energy and Commerce Committee, October 1982:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: PEOPLE kept coming up to Ann Pease and asking if she was warm enough, which might sound like a r ather peculiar thing to do at a party with 500 guests except for thef act that Miss Pease didn't have on a stitch of clothing.

title: Polish Hijacker Is Sentenced To 2 Years by Austrian Court
description: A Pole accused of air piracy was sentenced today to two years' imprisonment, and his wife, charged with conspiracy, was given a one-year suspended sentence by the Vienna city court.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss, after a loss from discontinued operations of $8,246,000...C-After aloss from discontinued operations of $20,438,000...D-After a loss from discontinued operations of $14,286,000

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The City Council's Finance Committee has unanimously approved a proposal for a tax on newspaper advertising and circulation income and on the advertising income of radio and television stations, to raise more than $1 million in revenue.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bees on 48th Street

title: SCREEN: ANIMATED 'HEIDI'
description: THE Hanna-Barbera Heidi is a cheerful creature, an angelic, animated child who says things like ''But Grandfather, every day can be Christmas if you're happy!'' She also sings frequently. She is the star of ''Heidi's Song,'' a children's entertainment of the oldfashioned school, full of friendly bunnies and lovable kittens and demure girls hoping to meet Prince Charming. This is the first such film in years to be even marginally entertaining, but the genre's golden Disney days are clearly over.

title: Rangers Score Goal In a Flash
description: Almost everything happens fast in a hockey game. But there are occasional plays that happen so fast that they almost defy belief. One example is when an attacking player seems to materialize directly in front of the goaltender, so suddenly that it seems impossible to comprehend how he got there.

title: PLANT SUPERVISOR AT 3 MILE ISLAND SAYS ALL SAFETY STEPS WERE TAKEN
description: The supervisor in the control room at the time of the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania testified in Federal District Court here yesterday that the accident occurred even though the operators followed all safety procedures to the letter.

title: The Great Token War
description: Said New York to Connecticut: Please, sirs, think again before your cheap turnpike tokens start plopping wholesale into 3,357 subway turnstiles. We're willing to try quiet diplomacy, but look: our tokens are worth 75 cents, your dinky imitations are sold at toll booths for 17 1/2 cents, and you've minted 10 million of them!

title: Dora Brenner Is Dead at 93; Headed Center for the Aged
description: Dora Brenner, for 31 years the president of the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, now known as the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center, died Wednesday at the Miami Heart Institute. Mrs. Brenner, who had been living in retirement in Miami Beach, was 93 years old.

title: Reagan to Meet Dane Leader
description: President Reagan will confer with Prime Minister Poul Schluter of Denmark in Washington on Dec. 13, the White House said today. A White House spokesman noted that Denmark now holds the presidency of the European Economic Community.

title: Book Sculpture at Pace
description: Rebecca Rass, poet-writer and English teacher, has recycled old and used books to create art objects from printed words, using the material rather than the contents. More than 20 works of book sculpture from mutilated pages are on view through Nov. 27 in a free exhibition at Pace University's Art Gallery, on Spruce Street in Lower Manhattan. Hours: Monday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: POLITICAL 'OUTSIDER' IS PICKED BY CUOMO TO HEAD DEMOCRATS
description: Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo, saying he wanted ''a knowledgeable outsider'' to head the Democratic Party in New York State, has recommended William C. Hennessy, the state's Transportation Commissioner, to replace Dominic J. Baranello.

title: CANADIAN STEEL: GRIM WINTER
description: On Canada's Remembrance Day, Nov. 11, some 70 workers at Stelco Inc.'s sprawling steel mill here pinned on aging combat decorations and marched beneath a metallic sky to bagpipes and drums. Old-timers recalled when upward of 450 war veterans would join the annual observance.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in some editions of Metropolitan Report on Tuesday in- correctly identified the winner of an upstate Assembly election. The win- ner, in the 112th District, was John G.A. O'Neil, a Republican.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET DELEGATES SEE U.N. CHIEF ON CURBING COSTS
description: Representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain met today with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar for a 45-minute discussion on holding down the rising cost of the United Nations.

title: Sambo's Aid Plan
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc., which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code for the past year, said it had received commitments for $30 million of new financing required to put its reorganization plan into effect. It said it would file the reorganization plan soon. Sambo's said the financing had been received from Gov Inc., which holds all of the company's preferred stock and which will receive 24 percent of the common stock of the reorganized company, and the Foothill Group, which will receive 1 percent.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After charges of $163,000 for the qr and $296,000 for the 9 mos and income of$37,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net income including a tax credit of $44,000 and a loss of $131,000 from discontinued operations...D-Including a tax credit of $124,000 and a loss of $130,000 from discontinued operations

title: Union Commerce Chief
description: Frank Wobst, chairman of Huntington Bancshares Inc., yesterday was named chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Commerce Corporation and chairman of its subsidiary, Union Commerce Bank. He succeeds Lyman H. Treadyway.

title: Market Place; Guarded View On Rail Cars
description: RAILROAD stocks have performed handsomely in recent months. They have benefited in some instances - notably Rio Grande Industries and Kansas City Southern Industries - from takeover rumors.

title: ART: YVES KLEIN SHOW AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: HE was a Rosicrucian, a judo expert, a Knight of St. Sebastian and a relentless self-mythologizer who saw himself as superman. He ''painted'' on canvas with women's bodies, sold air as art and took a flying leap from a second story to prove his levitational skills. He was a showman, a self-promoter, a megalomaniac hooked on his own mystique and a real - albeit minor - talent, whose life and work have often inspired high twaddle from writers and made him a cult figure in Europe.

title: COMMUTERS START LEGAL JOURNEY AGAINST CONRAIL
description: Twenty-six commuters who have been taking Conrail into the city for years are now taking it to court as well.

title: 'ALONE IN THE DARK'
description: THE best thing about ''Alone in the Dark,'' a horror-movie spoof that is sometimes droll, sometimes silly, is that its central character, Dr. Dan Potter, is a psychiatrist. This affords Jack Sholder, who directed the film and wrote it with Robert Shaye and Michael Harpster, plenty of opportunity to make fun of the profession.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
FOR FRANCE'S ELITE FRATERNITY, A MODICUM OF EGALITE
description: Socialist France is moving these days to reform the institution that traditionally molds the national governing elite. It is a painful process because many of President Francois Mitterrand's most important aides have diplomas from the school for power - and some of the attitudes and style that marked politics here from Charles de Gaulle through Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CASTLE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mayor Koch on Thin Ice
description: Mayor Koch's proposals for meeting New York City's midyear budget problem leave it balanced on very thin ice. The slightest new difficulty - a drop in state subsidy, a rise in city costs, a further fall in tax receipts - would plunge it into illegal full-year deficit. To prevent that, the Mayor should impose a deeper hiring freeze.

title: SCALPING RING BROKEN, STATE SAYS
description: The New York State Attorney General's office said yesterday that it had broken up a ticket-scalping ring at Madison Square Garden that traded in scarce tickets to concerts at the garden and a hit Broadway show.

title: UNDER THREAT, NEW DELHI BRACES FOR SIKH PROTESTS
