description: The authorities set up checkpoints today at New Delhi's entrances and mustered more than 10,000 extra police officers in the capital to prevent militant Sikhs from disrupting the ninth Asian Games opening Friday.

title: Kim's Kidneys Are Removed
description: A team of doctors removed the kidneys of the South Korean boxer Duk Koo Kim, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: HYSTER CO reports earnings for QTr to Oct 31
CHARLIE HADEN LIBERATION BANK BACK
description: CHARLIE HADEN, the bassist and composer, has recited the history of his celebrated ''Liberation Music Orchestra'' album so many times that it rolls quickly off his tongue.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALKER, HIRAM, RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a $177 million writedown on U.S. oil and gas properties...C-Net income

title: Robbery Suspect Surrenders After Police Siege in Queens
description: A 22-year-old man wanted in connection with two bank robberies in Yonkers last month was arrested yesterday in his Queens apartment after holding F.B.I. agents and police officers at bay for two and a half hours, authorities said.

title: IN ANTICIPATION OF A NON-HOSTILE WEST BANK-ISRAELI BORDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Bell Seeks New Rate Increase
description: New Jersey Bell today filed a request for a $215.8 million rate increase that would raise the average bill paid by residential customers by nearly $4 a month.

title: GENERAL AIRCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHULTZ SAYS U.S. LOOKS TO DEEDS FROM NEW LEADERSHIP IN KREMLIN
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov said today that President Reagan's recently expressed desire for improved relations was in full accord with Soviet intentions.

title: French Missiles En Route to Argentina
description: NAZAIRE, France, Nov. 18 (AP) - An Argentine cargo ship carrying French-made Exocet missiles and other materiel left this Atlantic coast port today for Argentina, port officials said.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago shr earnings adjusted to give retroactive effect to 10 percent stockdivd declared Sept 7

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CANADA SOUTHERN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $16,000

title: Looking Like Jimmy
description: As a manager of the national economy, Ronald Reagan is beginning to look as indecisive as Jimmy Carter ever did:

title: IN IRAN, BRAVADO IS IN WHILE FEAR IS EVERYWHERE
description: The Iranian Archeological Museum has very few visitors these days. But it is patrolled by Revolutionary Guards armed with submachine guns, and anyone who wishes to enter must undergo a rigorous body search.

title: RESIDENTIAL CONVERSION IN WEST VILLAGE
description: Ten years ago the western border of Greenwich Village was primarily an industrial zone, with sturdy factory buildings housing a variety of occupants from manufacturers of light machinery to distributors of meat and produce.

title: CONFERENCE AT THE CABINET LEVEL ON THE BLACK VOTE
description: Worrying about the black vote is a post-election tradition among Republicans, and all across the country party leaders are joining in the customary anxiety.

title: NATO Aide Ties Soviet To Antimissile Groups
description: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance, Joseph M .A .H. Luns, said today that intelligence reports indicated that the Soviet Union was aiding movements in the West that oppose nuclear weapons.

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES 0.7%
description: Americans' personal income rose a moderate seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Choice items in Latin art.
description: SEVEN paintings by the Colombian artist Fernando Botero are among the highlights in an auction next Tuesday at 7 P.M. and Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, one of two sales of Latin American art next week.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Man Pleads Guilty In Waste Bribes
description: A man imprisoned for dumping toxic wastes in Pennsylvania pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to bribe a City Sanitation Department superintendent and others to allow him to dump chemical wastes at five city landfills from 1972 to 1980.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: B-Including a gain of $466,000 from the retirement of industrial revs bonds

title: ASKS TAX RISES AND LAYOFFS
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that the city faced a projected $28 million budget gap in the coming year and that he would be forced to ask for increased taxes and the layoff of 131 city employees, including 62 firefighters. No policemen would be laid off, he said.

title: GIANTS PROMOTE UMPHREY
description: One day after their return from the 57-day strike of National Football League players, the Giants found their lineup shuffled today.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After tax loss carryforward of $400,000 for the qr and the yrC-Net loss, after losses from discontinued operations of $929,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the yr

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
G.O.P. LACKS VOTES ON EARLY TAX CUT, PRESIDENT IS TOLD
description: Republican Congressional leaders told President Reagan today that their party lacked the votes in the House of Representatives to speed up the 1983 tax cut by six months, a possibility mentioned yesterday by Mr. Reagan as a means of stimulating the economy.

title: FORD TO CLOSE LAST WEST COAST PLANT
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would close its last major auto assembly plant on the West Coast. It said it was taking the action because of the success of Japanese imports.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $29,100...C-Net income aftera loss from discontinued operations of $116,100

title: JAZZ: A TRIO IN CHAMBER STYLE
description: The pianist Anthony Davis, the flutist James Newton and the cellist Abdul Wadud performed without amplification Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall, like a chamber trio. But they are known as jazz musicians, and their pieces mixed composed and improvised music.

title: Harvester To Pay Fine
description: The International Harvester Company pleaded guilty today to Federal charges that one of its former divisions had bribed a Mexican Government official to obtain lucrative contracts.

title: BURGER, AT N.Y.U. DINNER, SAYS HEAVY CASELOADS IMPERIL U.S. JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said yesterday that unless drastic changes were made, the American system of justice ''may literally break down before the end of this century.''

title: MOSCOW CONFIRMS AFGHAN DISASTER
description: The Soviet press agency Tass acknowledged today that, as Western news outlets reported, there had been a disaster in a tunnel in Afghanistan. But the agency did not confirm reports that Soviet troops were involved.

title: Spendthrift Bid Reported
description: One of the largest race-horse farms in the world, Spendthrift, is reportedly considering the sale of a substantial part of its assets to a syndicate next month.

title: BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $235,000

title: SWEEPING PURGE IS REPORTED UNDER WAY IN ALBANIA
description: The Albanian leadership is undergoing a new purge conducted by Enver Hoxha, the party chief, United States Government specialists said today.

title: Economic Scene; A Reformer For Both Blocs
description: AT a time when economic policies seem to have become principally political and ideological weapons to be used in combat by politicians and their agents, it may be useful to remember the contributions of Abba P. Lerner, one of the greatest economists of this century.

title: ACTION ON CHINATOWN JAIL PUT OFF AFTER PROTEST
description: A plan was approved for selling apartments in city-owned buildings to their tenants for $250 each. Page B2.

title: Bridge: Aces Leading Texas Team In International Trial Final
description: Going into the third and last session of the International Team Trial final this evening, the Aces, who include four New York experts, held a commanding lead over the Texas team.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REVUES RETURN, SPOTLIGHTING NEW COMIC FACES OF 1982
description: IN the Broadway hit ''A Chorus Line,'' a young woman named Morales denounces her drama teacher at the High School of Performing Arts, Mr. Karp, for making her feel like ''Nothing!'' because she wouldn't do the assigned improvisation and pretend she was a bobsled.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CUSTOMERS TOAST WOMEN BEHIND THE BAR
description: The phone is ringing at the 12th Street Bar in Greenwich Village. A man looks up from his drink and says, ''I'm not here.'' The bartender, Beth Harrison, nods and picks up the phone. ''No, I haven't seen him,'' she tells the man's wife. ''He hasn't been in all day.''

title: PLESSEY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Per Class A common stock...C-Per Class common stock

title: BRIEFING
description: Switchboard for Lugar

title: REAGAN REBUFFED ON PARK POLICIES
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee dealt the Reagan Administration's public lands and energy policies a series of rebuffs today. Among its actions was the endorsement of a proposal to continue a ban on oil and gas leasing in Federal wilderness areas through the current fiscal year, which ends next Sept. 30.

title: AIDE WARNS REAGAN A GAS TAX RISE MAY COST JOBS
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser has told him that raising the Federal gasoline tax by 4 cents a gallon to pay for expanded Federal repairs of highways and bridges ''may actually increase unemployment during the first year or two.''

title: 22 Fans Killed
description: Twenty-two people were killed and 100 were injured today as a result of a stampede of fans in a soccer stadium.

title: WEINBERGER SUGGESTS DEFENSE CONTRACTOR TO REPLACE DEPUTY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today offered Paul Thayer, chairman of the LTV Corporation, the position of Deputy Secretary of Defense, according to Administration and industry officials.

title: POP: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ, SINGER
description: DURING the seven singing engagements that Jonathan Schwartz has had at Michael's Pub in the last four and a half years, he has salted his programs generously with songs written by his father, Arthur Schwartz. His current appearance at the East 55th Street restaurant (through Dec. 4) is no different in that respect except that, having gone through his father's best-known songs, he is now bringing out some that are rarely if ever heard.

title: Management Shifts At Leo Burnett
description: Norman L. Muse, 48 years old and president of Leo Burnett U.S.A. since August 1981, has been elected vice chairman and chief creative officer of the parent Leo Burnett Company, the seventh-largest United States ad agency.

title: INTERTEC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROCHE SISTERS' BIG STEP: A GIG AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE appearance by the Roches tonight at Carnegie Hall will mark a symbolic milestone in the career of one of the most interesting singing groups American pop has ever produced. Nearly six years since they began performing together on the streets of New York, this trio of sisters who sing, play acoustic guitars and write most of their own songs, will be making their first major uptown concert appearance. The Carnegie Hall date follows by several weeks the release of the third Roches album on Warner Bros., ''Keep on Doing,'' in which the trio's close-harmony singing reaches an unprecedented richness and complexity.

title: Stokely Calls A Trading Halt
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the big Indianapolis-based food packer, asked the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to halt trading in its shares pending an announcement today.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
OPERA: A NEW PRODUCTION OF VERDI'S 'MACBETH'
description: THE quicker said, the better: Peter Hall's ''Macbeth'' may just be the worst new production to struggle onto the the Metropolitan Opera's stage in modern history. That claim, admittedly, covers a lot of territory and could be disputed by oldtimers, but it is not made lightly. What Mr. Hall and John Bury, who designed the sets and costumes, could have been thinking of when they devised this lumpish and often ludicrous staging of Verdi's first Shakespeare opera last night is difficult to imagine. Nothing really worked well and certain scenes (such as all those involving the witches) aroused the firstnight audience to outright laughter and angry booing.

title: Damson Acquires New Energy Stake
description: The Damson Oil Corporation, an independent oil and gas production company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy interests in 2,182 oil and gas wells, as well as three gas processing plants, from the Petroleum Corporation of Texas for $160 million.

title: A Prescription for Heroin
description: Heroin: spoiler of youth, corrupter of law enforcers, catalyst for violence. If this derivative of opium did not already exist, is there any decent person who would wish to invent it?

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch on City Life (Cont.) It was the deteriorating quality of life in New York that brought on its coming move to Rhode Island, according to word this week from the Automobile Insurance Plan Service Office.

title: WORRIES ON LENDING ABROAD
description: Although many banks are edgy about the huge size and growing risk of their lending abroad, bankers and central bankers say the real fear is that the lending may slow down too fast.

title: 'Windfall Profits' Plea
description: The Justice Department said today that it would appeal a lower court ruling that the law establishing the ''windfall profits'' tax for oil companies was unconstitutional. The department told the United States District Court in Wyoming, which made the ruling, that it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

title: MARGOT KIDDER IN 'HEARTACHES,' COMEDY
description: ''HEARTACHES,'' a sentimental romantic comedy that talks tough but means to break your heart with its sweetness, is about the fast friendship of two totally dissimilar young women on the loose in Toronto. That it isn't unbearable is due largely to the enjoyable performances of Margot Kidder as Rita, a glib, aggressively hip, peroxide blond, and Annie Potts who plays Bonnie, a pregnant waif who is not so naive as she initially seems.

title: To the Finish
description: The computer has begun dishing out its usual wealth of numbers on last month's New York City Marathon, with these statistical nuggets: more men over 60 finished the race than teen-agers; twice as many men from the ages of 30 to 39 finished than those 20-29; of the 14,308 starters, 95.3 percent, or 13,599, finished.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After charges of $218,000 for the qr and $197,000 for the 9 mos related to a retroactive adjustment in the cost of processing natural gas in Canada

title: ALLEGHENY LAND & MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTOMATED MEDICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. Chief Drops Westchester Bid
description: Anthony J. Colavita, the Westchester County Republican leader, withdrew unexpectedly Wednesday night as a candidate to replace County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, the Lieutenant Governor-elect.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHINESE FOREIGN MINISTER VOICES OPTIMISM ON IMPROVED SOVIET TIES
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua said on his return from Moscow today that he was optimistic about the prospects for the next round of consultations with the Soviet Union.

title: Of course, it's heady fun, even flattering, being summoned from the library basement where I was hunched over dusty copies of Pravda, having makeup cover my bald spot and being thrust before the bright lights of television to tell the world not only all I know - but more besides.
description: When a historic development like the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev comes along, it creates a media event. The combination of TV, radio and newspaper hype and the normal quota of vanity among those of us who study the Soviet Union produces a flood of solemn, confident and confusing prophecies whose only saving grace is that they will not be long remembered.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE SECRETARY OF STATE'S NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

title: Middle East Hopes
description: Jordan's King Hussein is a profoundly cautious man. So it is encouraging to know that he feels optimism about a Middle East settlement now, although he admits to being anxious lest the current momentum toward negotiation be allowed to fritter away.

title: Sazerac Gets President
description: Peter Bordeaux, 34, has been named president of the 132-year-old Sazerac Company of New Orleans. Sazerac, along with marketing the Sazerac Cocktail, a drink associated with the city's French Quarter, makes and imports a variety of distilled spirits and is moving from a regional supplier to a national distributor.

title: JOSEPH KIPNESS, THEATER PRODUCER AND RESTAURANTEUR, IS DEAD AT 71
description: Joseph Kipness, the theater-district restaurateur and co-producer of such Broadway hits as ''High Button Shoes,'' ''La Plume de Ma Tante'' and ''Applause,'' died of cancer yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: KAPLAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Appeal Heard
description: Attorneys for the National Collegiate Athletic Association argued before a three-judge panel of the 10th United States Circuit Court of Appeals today in an effort to overturn a ruling that struck down the N.C.A.A.'s right to negotiate television football contracts for the nation's colleges. The panel took the case under advisement and said it would issue a written decision at a later date.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Buying the Memorabilia Instead of the Bridge

title: JUDGE CHALLENGES CREDIBILITY OF WITNESS IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: The Federal district judge trying the Government's bribery conspiracy case against Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, drew attention again today to inconsistencies in the testimony of the key prosecution witness.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FULLBACK HURT AS JETS RESUME
description: The Jets, many of whom had been at odds over union policy during the players' strike, did not have one quarrel today after they again put on uniforms and returned to the practice field.

title: 2 Black Activists Seized in Protest
description: Two black activists were arrested in Harlem yesterday in the latest incident involving protests against the appointment of a white man to head the archives section of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

title: Advertising; A Captive Ivy League Audience
description: WHEN the noted architect James Gamble Rogers designed the New York Yale Club in the modernized Italian Renaissance style, he surely did not foresee that its Florentine salons, which were completed in 1915, would one day echo to video advertising.

title: VIEWS OF NEW YORK IN THE 20'S
description: IT has become so common now to romanticize the New York City of the 1920's and 30's, to think of it only in terms of Cole Porter songs and Art Deco spires, that we often forget what a clear and consistent vision of it is like. There are so few artists, after all, who bequeathed one to us. Berenice Abbott, the photographer, is surely one of them; Louis Lozowick, the printmaker, who died in 1973 but was especially active in those early decades, was another.

title: SALVADOR OFFICIAL, IN U.S., GIVES RIGHTS PLEDGE
description: El Salvador's Foreign Minister, Fidel Chavez Mena, said after a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that his Government would make the necessary efforts to insure that United States military aid is not suspended on human rights grounds.

title: Colin Carr Is Y Soloist
description: Colin Carr, winner of the 1981 Naumburg Competition, will be cello soloist with the Y Chamber Symphony tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue. The program, conducted by Gerard Schwarz, consists of Haydn's Cello Concerto in D major and music by Richard Strauss and Schumann. Tickets, at $9.50 and $11, are available at the box office (427-4410) or through Chargit (944-9300).

title: JUDGE BACKS 9 FARM UNION AIDES WHO WERE DISMISSED BY CHAVEZ
description: Nine farm workers who brought a suit challenging the authority of Cesar Chavez, president of the United Farm Workers, to dismiss them from their paid positions as union representatives have won the first round in their legal effort to be reinstated.

title: POP JAZZ
description: IN the four decades since Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie revolutionized the approach to jazz with a style that was identified as ''be-bop,'' most young jazz musicians have followed their lead. Since the mid-1940's, scarcely a handful of musicians who were nurtured in the Dixieland and traditional jazz styles that flourished before World War II have managed to rise to positions of stature in the jazz world.

title: TALE OF NOAH'S ARK, UPDATED, AT CENTRAL PARK ZOO
description: The Great Evacuation began yesterday. The first of the more than 200 animals at the Central Park Zoo were moved out in preparation for a $15 million renovation of the zoo.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Including a gain of $75,000 from an accounting change

title: MEDIEVAL ART EXPERT WAS YALE PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Sumner McK. Crosby, professor emeritus of art history at Yale University and an authority on medieval art and architecture, died Tuesday at Waterbury (Conn.)

title: H.J. GIBBONS, 72, ONCE VIEWED AS HOFFA'S HEIR
description: Harold J. Gibbons, the St. Louis union leader who had been a high offical of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for decades, died of a ruptured aneurysm Wednesday night in Inglewood, Calif., the Centinela Hospital and Medical Center said. He was 72 years old.

title: Article 042049 -- No Title
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a settlement to clean up four toxic waste sites in Michigan that will cost the Velsicol Chemical Company an estimated $38.5 million. The agency said it was the biggest financial settlement ever reached with a company for a cleanup.

title: DELAYS IN JOB TRAINING FEARED
description: A training center recently established by the Urban League on a vacant floor of a printing company in downtown Baltimore looks much more like a small, modern business office than a classroom.

title: WESTERN PREFERRED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain on investments of $280,716...C-After a loss on investments of $397,399...D-After a loss on investments of $44,343...E-Including a gain on investments of $1.1 million

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including a gain of $6,066,000 from the sale of a joint venture investment

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include pretax gains of $3.9 million for the qr and $9 million for the 9 mos from the sale of real estate; yr-ago results include pretax gains of $4.1 million for the qr and $8.4 million for the 9 mos

title: Peanuts's dog Snoopy is coming for Christmas.
description: THE ''Peanuts'' cartoon-strip gang, which originally came to the stage in the 1967 musical ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown,'' has been reunited for a sequel called ''Snoopy.'' The sequel, featuring the lovable beagle created by the cartoonist Charles M. Schulz, is trying out in Boston and will open in New York on Dec. 20 at the Lambs Theater.

title: The Jazz of Gil Evans Conducted by Gil Evans
description: The composer and arranger Gil Evans, a strong voice in modern jazz for three decades, will play the piano and conduct the City College of New York Jazz Ensemble in a concert of his own music tonight at 8. Mr. Evans is best known for his work with Miles Davis, including such albums as ''Sketches of Spain'' and ''Birth of the Cool.'' His own big bands, which he has assembled over the years, show Mr. Evans's partiality for lush combinations of winds and brass, and mixtures of acoustic and electric instruments.

title: POLICIES ARE SCARCELY AT ISSUE IN RACE FOR PREMIER OF JAPAN
description: The race to succeed the retiring Prime Minister has entered its final week, with policy issues scracely mentioned by the four candidates.

title: 'SMITHEREENS'
description: PUNK screen heroines, of whom there are now a couple, are a little like the French movie waifs of yesteryear. They seem to wake, sleep, live and breathe with an utter spontaneity bordering on recklessness, and to enjoy their freedom inordinately while it lasts. ''Smithereens,'' which was resourcefully directed by Susan Seidelman on an outstandingly meager budget of under $100,000, presents just such a character, and presents her with wit, style, and even more nerve than the heroine's own.

title: Kohl and Pope, at a Meeting, Talk About Rights and Poland
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Pope John Paul II met today and discussed Poland, human rights and other issues.

title: 'Great Day in Morning,' Spirituals Program, Cut
description: ''Great Day in the Morning,'' scheduled as part of the Next Wave series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for four performances between Dec. 18 and 24, has been canceled. The production of black spirituals was to have been staged by Robert Wilson and to have starred Jessye Norman, the operatic soprano.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
College Top 20 Computer ranking based on games through Nov. 13;  OPPONENTS' PERFORMANCES
DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dichters Play Tonight
description: The pianists Misha and Cipa Dichter will appear in joint recital tonight at 8 at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, playing music by Brahms, Saint-Saens and Rachmaninoff. Admission is $12; the telephone number is 570-3949.

title: Elway Decision: Hitting or Passing
description: Heisman Trophy ballots are in the hands of voters this week, and the sectional support for Herschel Walker of Georgia and John Elway of Stanford should be especially interesting. So is the debate over whether Elway will pursue a professional career in football or baseball.

title: NATIONAL UTILITIES & INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes capital gain on sale of oil and gas properties of $1,239,000

title: SYMPHONY SPACE WILL CUT A CAKE
description: Almost five years ago, a capacity crowd filled the Symphony Theater, an old, decaying movie house at Broadway and 95th Street, to hear, play, sing and generally exalt the music of Bach. The free, 12-hour festival, was called ''Wall to Wall Bach,'' and its smashing success led to the theater's eventual revitalization as Symphony Space - a not-for-profit, community-sponsored center for the performing arts.

title: A Stamp for Stravinsky Is Issued at Ceremony
description: In a ceremony accompanied by the performance of Igor Stravinsky's music at the State Theater, the Postal Service yesterday issued a new postage stamp in honor of the late Russian-born composer. The two-cent stamp was introduced by George F. Schuman, Postmaster of New York, as part of the service's ''Great Americans'' series. Mr. Stravinsky became a United States citizen in 1945.

title: Della Femina Officers Take On New Venture
description: While continuing in their management roles at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, Jerry Della Femina, 46, chairman, and Louise McNamee, 33, senior vice president of research, have formed an independent marketing consulting company called Della Femina/McNamee Marketing Inc.

title: DYSAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHANNON OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
THE EGYPTIAN PRIORITY IN ARAB PEACE FEELERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: For France's elite fraternity, a modicum of egalite A2 Caribbean leaders in accord on security and rights A3 Israeli Communications Minister testifies on massacre A3 Salvadoran official, in U.S., gives pledge on rights A3 U.S. and Soviet delegates see U.N. chief on curbing costs A4 church says no A5 Under threat, New Delhi braces for Sikh protests A6 Policies are scarcely at issue in race for premier of Japan A8 Purge reported under way in Al- bania A9 Tass acknowledges Afghan tun- nel disaster A10 Australia's founding felons get a long-delayed pardon A12 Ex-prisoner in Iran says he was a pawn in U.S.-Iran dispute A13 Reagan to speak Monday on ties with Soviet A16 Chinese Foreign Minister opti- mistic on Soviet talks A17 Government/Politics Delays of money feared under new job training act A18 Gibson asked tax increases and layoffs to meet budget deficit B2 Koch to discuss budget with black and Hispanic political leaders B5 General Around the Nation A18 Judged rules for union workers who opposed Cesar Chavez A19 Judge in teamster case chal- lenges key prosecution witness A20 Nuclear plant supervisor testifies at Three Mile Island trial A21 Commuters taking Conrail to court with suits on service B2 Industry/Labor U.A.W. and Chrysler to resume talks in U.S. and Canada D16 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: FROM SIDELINES TO MANAGING
description: Joe Altobelli's attitude about his job and the game gave him instant credibility with the players, Roy Smalley says. Mike Ferraro was the best coach in the league at getting things organized, Clyde King says.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs Trail Blazers, at Portland, Ore. Darwin Cook, the New Jersey reserve guard, returns to the scene of his college days.

title: Shoemaker Spilled
description: Bill Shoemaker suffered bruises on his left calf and right forearm in spill during the fifth race at Hollywood Park yesterday.

title: FIGHT BILL SOUGHT
description: A state assemblyman said today that he would introduce legislation to make prizefighting safer in New Jersey.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS BY CATHOLIC BISHOPS ON ISSUES OF WAR AND PEACE
description: Following are excerpts from remarks on a proposed pastoral letter on war and peace at the National Conference of Catholic Bishops: Alfred C. Hughes Auxiliary Bishop of Boston We really do not have two different traditions; we have one tradition: which as the just-war theory deals with the moral parameters for entering and prosecuting a war in defense of important values (cf. Augustine); which as the nonviolent stance really deals with the Gospel ideal to which individuals have aspired with the endorsement of the church, but which has never been considered mandatory for all, especially for governments entrusted with the responsibility to protect their citizenry.

title: PACIFIC EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CREDIT FOR MEXICO IS REPORTED
description: Leading foreign banks have agreed to provide Mexico with an emergency $1 billion credit and allow the country to postpone repayment of principal on its huge foreign debt until next March, foreign bankers said today.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNION TO RESUME TALKS AT CHRYSLER
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation are to return to the bargaining table in the next few days in an effort to resolve the impasse that produced a strike by the company's Canadian workers and the rejection of a tentative contract in the United States.

title: OXYGEN ENRICHER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUSTRALIA'S FOUNDING FELONS GET A LONG-DELAYED PARDON
description: In the 1950's, it was against the law to embarrass an Australian whose ancestors included convicts by mentioning them in public.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Net
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., operator of high-fashion specialty stores, said yesterday that net income in its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 30 dropped 30.9 percent, to $4.7 million, or 14 cents a share, from $6.8 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. Sales edged up 3.3 percent, to $705.2 million, from $683 million.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Walter Goodman RABBIS AND WIVES. By Chaim Grade. Translated from the Yiddish by Harold Rabinowitz and Inna Hecker Grade. 307 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: RUTH DONNELLY, COMEDIENNE AND CHARACTER ACTOR IN FILMS
description: Ruth Donnelly, one of Hollywood's most durable and well-loved character comediennes, known for rapid-fire wisecracks offset by a droll expression, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived at the Wellington Hotel.

title: 4 INDICTED BY U.S. IN ESCAPE OF JOANNE CHESIMARD IN '79
description: Four persons were accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of having helped the black activist Joanne Chesimard to escape from a New Jersey prison in 1979. Miss Chesimard, a former leader of the Black Liberation Army, had been serving a life term for the slaying of a New Jersey state trooper.

title: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to the adoption of LIFO inventory accounting method for certain inventories; shr earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a 5-for-4 stock split in May 1982

title: HOUSTON POLICE FORCE ENTICES 2,600 DURING RECRUITING DRIVE
description: Michael Zimmerman seeks a more fulfilling career. Daniel Hannon envisions a dynamic, growing city. Lorraine Rodriguez longs for sunshine and serenity.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1982
description: International Washington is ready to negotiate on differences with Moscow, but is looking for ''a change in behavior on important matters'' by the new Soviet leadership, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. At a news conference, he said that both sides indicated this week they were prepared for substantive talks, but that what mattered was ''deeds'' rather than ''rhetoric.'' (Page A1, Column 1.) The warmest Soviet statements expressed toward Washington in a long time were voiced by Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov. Addressing American businessmen at a Kremlin dinner, he said Moscow endorsed ''better, friendly relations with the United States.'' (A1:2.)

title: CYMATICOLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Residents Protest Plan for Shelter
description: Between 75 and 100 residents demonstrated yesterday outside a former public school near the site of the old Polo Grounds to protest the city's plans to use the building as a residence for homeless men, the police said.

title: KINGS ROOKIE OUT
description: Bernie Nicholls of the Kings who is the leading scorer among the league's rookies, injured his right knee in the first period of a 4-1 victory over the Red Wings. Nicholls, with 16 goals and 8 assists, suffered a tear of the medial lateral ligament in his right knee when he was checked by Detroit's Willie Huber. The Kings said Nicholls would be sidelined for four weeks.

title: Dome Sees Progress
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. has said it can meet its operating and capital requirements, as well as interest and dividend payments in 1983, without the need for additional funds. But it said its financial status had not improved enough to allow it to make principal payments on its huge debt. The statement came in the company's quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed this week.

title: NEW YORK ASKS CONNECTICUT TO HALT SALE OF 17 1/2 TOKEN
description: In the latest volley of the war of the tokens, the president of the New York Transit Authority called yesterday for Connecticut temporarily to stop selling turnpike toll tokens that also work in New York City's subways.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Including a tax credit of $234,265

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: After the Fire, What Happens to Kids?

title: N.F.L.'S NEW FORMAT IS AIMED AT FANS
description: It took the National Football League's Competition Committee about two hours last Tuesday to complete the format for the remainder of the schedule - seven weeks of regular-season games and three weeks of playoffs leading to Super Bowl XVII Jan. 30.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISRAEL AND THE U.S. GAINED IN LEBANON
description: Ever since the beginning of the Israeli military operation in Lebanon, the public has seen a curious divergence of attitudes between Administration policy makers and news media opinion makers about the effect of the war on the United States' national interests.

title: South Africa Frees Reporter
description: Anthony Holiday, a political reporter for The Cape Times, was freed today after serving six years on charges of furthering the aims of the outlawed African National Congress. Mr. Holiday, 41 years old, was detained for producing and distributing pamphlets about the congress, a black group that has vowed to overthrow the white-minority South African Government.

title: Kean Cites Need For Spending Cuts
description: Governor Kean said today that the state's budget problems could not be totally resolved by raising taxes, and that the Legislature must consider spending cuts as well.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: About 100 angry farmers shouting ''no sale, no sale'' and shoving auctioneers forced the Farmers Home Administration to cancel the sale of equipment today on a bankrupt farm.

title: THE FIGHT GAME PLAYS IN A SUBURBAN SETTING
description: The Sweet Science, as professional boxing is sometimes called, came again to the suburbs tonight. The glare of the ring lights, the smell of liniment and the sight of blood all can be found here, a few hundred yards from such docile suburban haunts as the Channel Home Center and the Toys R Us store. It may be an incongruous setting for the sport, but it is prizefighting nonetheless, with all its sometimes banal, sometimes bizarre myths and illusions.

title: Heritage Foundation Gives Lehrman Post
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor of New York, is one of four political and business figures named to the board of trustees of the Heritage Foundation conservative ''think tank.''

title: Back to Normal
description: The two Manhattan couples had planned the early dinner for tomorrow night for several weeks.

title: ARMY SUCCEEDS IN FOURTH ATTEMPT TO TEST-FIRE THE PERSHING 2 MISSILE
description: On its fourth attempt, the Army successfully fired a new Pershing 2 medium-range missile today. Army officers were relieved by the test firing because the Pershing program has been troubled with one failure, two delays in the missile launched today and a Congressional cutoff in funds to produce missiles next year.

title: NICARAGUA FEARS REBEL ATTACK
description: Nicaragua's Deputy Foreign Minister said today that the Sandinist leadership expected attacks from Honduras in the next few weeks from forces associated with the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $299,000 for the qr and $1.1 million for the yr and tax credits of $212,000 for the qr and $835,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $355,000 for the qr and $720,000for the yr and tax credits of $617,000 for the qr and $862,000 for the yr; yr-ago results are restated

title: Letter: On Withholding; Let the U.S. Police Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: THOMPSON SETBACK
description: The Cincinnati Bengals have won a court order enjoining Jack Thompson, their backup quarterback, form signing a contract with the rival United States Football League. Thompson, who has two years left on his contract, has not reported to the Bengals' traning camp.

title: Reynolds Dividend Cut
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said today that it had cut its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 45 cemts, payable Dec. 21.

title: Lack of Witness Frees Death Row Convict
description: A man convicted of raping his young daughter was set free today after almost five years on death row when prosecutors said they could not proceed with a new trial.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dome Speculation
description: The Canadian Energy Minister, Jean Chretien, said he does not know whether Dome Petroleum Ltd. plans to sell up to $1 billion in preferred shares to circumvent its $1.5 billion bailout agreement with the Government and its bankers. The Globe and Mail newspaper quoted industry sources as saying that Dome, whose financial position is improving, is unhappy with the refinancing. But a senior Dome official said this week that Dome was not trying for a new package.

title: LET THEM CASH IN ON THEIR HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: O.A.U. MEETING THREATENED, THIS TIME BY A CHAD DISPUTE
description: Foreign ministers from African countries that term themselves moderates are locked in a dispute with the selfstyled radicals that may jeopardize a second attempt to hold a meeting of heads of government of the Organization of African Unity.

title: Wilander to Monaco
description: As an indication that he may be following two other Swedish stars, Bjorn Borg and Ingemar Stenmark to a tax haven in Monte Carlo, the teen-age tennis sensation Mats Wilander has applied for residence in Monaco. Wilander shot into prominence this year by winning the French Open and three other Grand Prix events. He won more than $255,000 in prize money and is expected to at least equal that figure in endorsements.

title: COURT LETS CITY USE MORE RIKERS CELLS
description: The city's Correction Department said yesterday that it would have enough jail space to get through at least the next week, after a Federal judge allowed the agency to open 245 unused cells in a Rikers Island facility.

title: Inco Layoffs
description: Inco Ltd., citing sharply lower demand for nickel, said it would lay off 2,200 white-collar employees who had been earning half pay since July. The layoffs will continue until nickel production resumes in April. Inco said the workers would be eligible for government jobless benefits and that the company would supplement those, so that workers would continue to receive half their regular salaries.

title: Bridge: A 33-to-1 Chance Pays Off, And Aces Win Team Trials
description: An exciting finish in which the fates played a considerable role left the Aces team victorious in the final of the International Team Trials here early today.

title: Holy Cow!
description: Phil Rizzuto, the former Yankee shortstop and current Yankee broadcaster, has enjoyed numerous experiences in his long career in baseball. But today, he is experiencing two firsts: he will be the best man at a wedding for the first time and he will wear tails for the first time.

title: Silent Treatment
description: The ''Section 7 Mezzanine New York Jet Fan Club'' will distribute leaflets before tomorrow's game against the Colts at Shea Stadium. The message: total silence during player introductions.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 21. 1. At Herculaneum, a town buried in the volcanic eruption that destroyed Pompeii, archeologists unearthed more than 80 human skeltons, the largest group of complete skeltons surviving from ancient Roman times.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd paid in Nov

title: NLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHURCH DENIES REPORT ON WALESA
description: An official of the Polish Roman Catholic Church yesterday denied an NBC News report that Polish security agents, apparently in an attempt to discredit Lech Walesa, had presented church officials with tape recordings and photographs that showed the leader of the outlawed Solidarity union in ''sexually compromising situations'' with women.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO 9% FROM 9 1/2%
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in what it described as a move to counter the continued sluggishness in the economy, cut its key lending rate today to 9 percent, from 9 1/2 percent.

title: SUMMATION SET MONDAY IN WARNER AIDE'S TRIAL
description: Summations are scheduled for Monday in the trial of Solomon Weiss, assistant treasurer of Warner Communications, who is charged with fraud involving the company's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: AMERICA'S EARLY RISE FROM THE DEPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
A CITY AND TAXPAYERS WITH A STAKE IN $250 APARTMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Boston Celtics, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1:30 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7 P.M.) St. John's vs. North Carolina, Tip-Off Classic, at Springfield, Mass. This is the season opener for both teams. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M. Radio -WGBB, 1240; 2 P.M.) City College vs. Morgan State, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, 8 P.M. This is the homecoming game for City College, as well as its season opener. Two members of the college's athletic hall of fame, Red Holzman and Red Phillips, will be the coaches in the old-timers' game, which begins at 6 P.M. Boxing Dwight Muhammad Qawi, champion, vs. Eddie Davis, World Boxing Council's light-heavyweight title bout, 15 rounds, at Atlantic City. On the undercard, Tony Ayala meets Carlos Herrera in a junior-middleweight bout, and Mustafa Hamsho fights Bobby Czyz, middleweights. (Television - Channel 4, 9 P.M.) Hector Camacho vs. Greg Coverson, lightweights, 10 rounds, at Las Vegas, Nev. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8 P.M. The Black Hawks have had the best power play in the National Hockey League. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 97.5; 8 P.M.) Rangers vs. Maple Leafs, at Toronto. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.) Devils vs. Minnesota North Stars at Bloomington, Minn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A book review of ''Empire of Signs'' by Roland Barthes on Nov. 10 incorrectly described the work as the last before his death. The book was originally published in 1970 and was followed by several others before it was reissued in 1980, the year Barthes died.

title: JO W. SAXE, 57, AN ECONOMIST AND OFFICIAL OF WORLD BANK
description: Jo W. Saxe, an economist and former chief of the international finance division of the World Bank, died of a liver ailment yesterday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Washington.

title: ALLEGHENY LAND & MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOUNDER OF THEATER IN DUBLIN
description: Hilton Edwards, the actor and director who founded the Dublin Gate Theater with Micheal MacLiammoir in 1928, died Thursday in a Dublin hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Tricentrol Acquisition
description: Tricentrol P.L.C. said it had acquired an 8.3 percent interest in eight offshore blocks in the Gulf of Mexico for a total $11.3 million. Its total participation in the Gulf of Mexico, it said, is now 12 blocks and 58,220 gross acres.

title: Better Than Ever
description: Kurt Thomas's last performance as an amateur gymnast was at Madison Square Garden several years ago. In his last event, on the horizontal bar, Thomas achieved a perfect score of 10.

title: DEFEAT BY IGNORANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Group Seeking Pabst Is Tendered 7.7% Block

title: WASHINGTON, GEORGE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $75,000 for the qr and $115,000 for the 9 mos

title: PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a securities gain of $13,000...C-After securities losses of $51,000for the qr and $59,000 for the 9 mos...D-After a securities loss of $4,000

title: CHINA SAYS BETTER TIES REQUIRE ACTION BY MOSCOW
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that any improvement in Chinese-Soviet relations depended upon whether the Soviet Union took action to remove its threats to China.

title: BRASS-CRAFT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Private Conversations Are a Public Concern

title: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EMOTIONS OF A JET CRITICIZED
description: Mark Gastineau, the effervescent defensive left end for the Jets, showed up a day late for practice today because, he said, he had been discussing a business deal in California with Sylvester Stallone, the actor. That left Gastineau only two days to prepare for the 1 P.M. game Sunday with the Baltimore Colts at Shea Stadium.

title: GARVEY AND AGENT IN CONTRACT TALKS WITH STEINBRENNER
description: Steve Garvey and Jerry Kapstein, his agent, spent a satisfying day yesterday in New York, the second stop on their five-city, free-agent tour. Garvey, however, apparently still has not cracked the lineup of three free agents in whom George Steinbrenner is most interested.

title: 2 Giants Aren't Ready
description: When the National Football League season resumes Sunday after the 57-day players' strike, 47 of the 49 players on the Giants' active roster will probably be ready for the 4 P.M. game here against the Washington Redskins. The only exceptions are Gary Jeter and Jim Burt.

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Yr-ago figures are unavailable because the company changed to Mar 31 fiscal yr from calendar yr...C-Including a capital gain of $16,863

title: HISTORY'S SADAT
description: It's just five years since Anwar el-Sadat electrified the world with his daring journey to Jerusalem - the first Arab leader ever to visit Israel. For his courageous effort, he was awarded the return of the Sinai Peninsula as part of a peace treaty, he shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and he secured a cherished place in history.

title: HEAVY LOSSES CONTINUE AT STATE SAVINGS BANKS
description: Operating losses among New York State savings banks continued to mount in the third quarter despite the decline in interest rates that began in mid-August, Alan R. Cohen, Acting Superintendent of Banking, reported yesterday.

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1982; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve Board cut the discount rate to 9 percent from 9 1/2 percent in a move to counter what it called continued sluggishness in business activity. The long-expected cut was the sixth since mid-July, when the key lending rate stood at 12 percent. Analysts said the Fed is now likely to let interest rates fall only gradually. The central bank's concern about the state of the economy was reflected in the minutes of a meeting in early October of the Federal Open Market Committee, its policy-making arm. (Page 1.)

title: Yaakov B. Zolti, Chief Rabbi Of Ashkenazim in Jerusalem
description: Chief Rabbi Yaakov Bezalal Zolti, the top religious official of the Ashkenazic Jews in Jerusalem, died suddenly this week at the age of 62.

title: Spurrier Leaves Duke
description: Steve Spurrier, the former college and pro quarterback, has resigned as offensive coordinator at Duke. ''I can't say I'm gone forever,'' he said, ''but I won't be here next season.'' Where will he be? Probably with the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League, who are expected to appoint the 37-year-old Spurrier as head coach on Monday.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Best-Laid Plans

title: MATINA HORNER: A DECADE OF LEADERSHIP AT RADCLIFFE
description: ''I really didn't know what I was getting into,'' Matina Souretis Horner said the other day, contemplating her 10th anniversary as president of Radcliffe College. ''It was presented to me as a half-time job. Of course, it's really two or three jobs, but I knew that it presented an interesting set of possibilities and challenges.''

title: VERDI'S 10TH OPERA HAS GONE FAR SINCE 1847
description: Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' was the 10th of the composer's 26 operas and the first of three based on Shakespeare. It had its premiere in Florence in 1847, 40 years before the first performance of ''Otello'' and 46 years before ''Falstaff.'' (A long-projected ''King Lear'' was never carried through by the composer, who said he felt intimidated by the mad scene.)

title: U.S. CUTS ESTIMATE ON G.N.P.
description: The Government scaled down its growth estimate for the economy in the third quarter to zero today and the Commerce Department's top economic official said that the current quarter will do no better and possibly worse.

title: KOCH IS SEEKING TO COMPROMISE ON JAIL DISPUTE
description: Unable to win the votes on the Board of Estimate for approval of a proposed jail on the outskirts of Chinatown and Little Italy, the Koch administration turned yesterday to talk of compromise.

title: CENTURY OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Protester Is Shot At Bronx Job Site
description: One man was shot and several others were arrested yesterday in a dispute between construction workers and protesters seeking jobs for minority workers at a Bronx construction site, according to the police.

title: FOES OF RIGHTIST LEADER IN SALVADOR TO WEAKEN HIS POWERS
description: Christian Democratic politicians and some top military officials in El Salvador have taken a series of steps aimed at weakening the power of Roberto d'Aubuisson, President of the Constituent Assembly, and his rightist National Alliance Party.

title: ROOSEVELT ISLAND NEEDS A NEW BRIDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cummins-Mexico
description: The Cummins Engine Company said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent interest in a new Mexican company, Dina Motores S.A., which will make Cummins small V-diesel engines in Mexico. The partner, Diesel Nacional S.A., also known as Dina, is owned by the Mexican Government. It will hold 60 percent of the venture.

title: DAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BOOK AND BOTTLE

title: Botha Opens Talks On Future of Namibia
description: West Africa, Nov. 19 (Reuters) - Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa began two days of talks here today aimed at breaking the impasse over the future of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.

title: 'Rondine' for City Opera
description: The first new production of the New York City Opera's 1983 summer season will be Puccini's ''La Rondine,'' supported by a $175,000 gift from the Gramma Fisher Foundation. The director will be Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, who will be making his company debut.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28. 1. ''A masterpiece of pathos,'' said an archeologist about a find, part of which is pictured above. Where was the excavation and what was unearthed?

title: Kim Is Mourned In Nevada Services
description: Boxing fans joined members of the Korean community and the mother of Duk Koo Kim today at funeral services for Kim, the boxer who died after taking a brain-damaging punch from Ray Mancini in a championship bout here last Saturday.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Judge Dismisses Suit Against Billie Jean King
description: A former lover's lawsuit against Billie Jean King, the tennis player, was dismissed today by a judge, who said there were no grounds for the action.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everybody says help the homeless; help them, help them, but somewhere else.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 21
description: B-After an accounting change of $188,000; the shrs outstdng have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split on Oct 29

title: NATO Chief Warns Of a Warsaw Pact Lead
description: The Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, said today that the Warsaw Pact countries held more than a 2-to-1 edge over NATO in both nuclear and conventional forces and that the gap was widening.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The police had a body, or at least what was left of one. It was too late to determine easily the race, the age, even the sex of what had once been a human being. So they did what many before them had done: They took it to the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Man Shot to Death At Party at N.Y.U.
description: One young man was shot dead and another was critically wounded late last night when two Chinatown gangs clashed at a Thanksgiving party being held in a residential hall at New York University, according to the police.

title: REAGAN URGES BUSINESS TO HELP IN JOB TRAINING
description: President Reagan, in an appeal to business leaders for help in carrying out the new job training act, said today that recovery from the recession would ''come gradually.'' And he said it would be a ''new kind of recovery'' in which unemployment would be steadily reduced without increasing inflation.

title: THE TWIN TEMPLES OF BOXING
description: D uk Koo Kim was the youngest of five children born to the H.Y. Kims, rice and ginseng farmers in the Kan Wan-Do province of South Korea, 100 kilometers east of Seoul.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EDWARDS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Girl, 5, and Father Die in Fire on L.I.
description: A fire swept through a Williston Park home early today, killing a man and his 5-year-old daughter, authorities said. Five persons, including the girl's sister, were injured.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
The Fans Is Disgusted
description: I don't know what the good news is, but the bad news is that the football season will reopen tomorrow and continue, unless a benign providence intervenes, deep into the blizzards of January.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-After a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $2,259,740

title: THOMSON ACQUISITION
description: In an effort to counter Japan's dominance of the electronics market in Europe, Thomson-Brandt, the nationalized French electronics group, announced today that it would acquire a majority interest in Grundig A.G. of West Germany.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: End of a Repository Of Vanishing Lore

title: More Palmer Candor
description: Jim Palmer has grown accustomed over the years to making controversial remarks about his employers, the Baltimore Orioles, and so there shouldn't have been much surprise yesterday when he had something to say about Baltimore's new manager, Joe Altobelli; the previous manager, Earl Weaver, and the once and current general manager, Hank Peters. Palmer said that either Cal Ripken, the third-base coach, or Ray Miller, the pitching coach, would have been a better choice to replace Weaver but that ''the kiss of death for Ripken was when Earl said Cal ought to be manager, especially when Earl said if Cal had any problems, he could just call him.''

title: STOCKS OFF 10.85 AFTER LATE SALES
description: Late selling pressure sent the Dow Jones industrial average down sharply yesterday with some of the blue-chip, energy and technology issues posting the largest losses.

title: TEXAS PRISON CASE LAWYERS TO GET $1.71 MILLION IN FEES
description: A Federal district judge in Texas ordered the state today to pay $1.71 million in fees and expenses to the attorneys for prisoners who won a lawsuit challenging conditions in the state prison system, the nation's largest.

title: Chrysler Cuts Financing Rate
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it was joining General Motors and Ford Motor in offering low-interest financing for car and truck purchases.

title: Car Registrations Canceled in Error
description: The State Department of Motor Vehicles admitted today that it had mistakenly informed 10,000 New Yorkers that their automobile registrations had been canceled.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MELVYN M. KATZ
description: Dr. Melvyn M. Katz, an associate professor of psychology at Hofstra University, died on Nov. 12 of a heart attack at his home in Merrick, L.I. He was 58 years old.

title: BAILING OUT MEXICO
description: The United States and Mexico have only begun to grapple with the full implications of Mexico's economic crisis. Urgent short-term problems have obscured the damage that the crisis may cause to economic links between the two countries. The Governments and private leaders of each must provide a solid footing for restoration of trade, investment and economic growth in Mexico.

title: FARMERS ACCUSTOMED TO MISSILES BUT LEERY OF MX
description: For the last 25 years people in these parts never gave much thought to the nuclear-tipped missiles buried beneath the rolling prairie of Cheyenne County. Like telephone poles and grain elevators, the chain link and barbed wire fences around each of the silo sites were just another break on the long horizon.

title: Columnist's Son Is Sued
description: The wife of Edward J. Phillips, an official of a liquor distributorship whose mother writes the ''Dear Abby'' advice column, today sought temporary support of $19,000 a month for the couple's two sons until a divorce is final. Deanna Phillips, 37 years old, Mr. Phillips' wife for 12 years, was represented by Marvin Mitchelson, a lawyer of Beverly Hills, Calif. Mr. Phillips, also 37, is the son of Morton and Pauline Phillips. His mother writes under the name Abigail VanBuren.

title: Free Democrat Leaves Party To Protest Its Change in Bonn
description: Andreas von Schoeler, formerly the second highest official in the Interior Ministry, has resigned from the Free Democratic Party and plans to join the opposition Social Democrats, Free Democratic officials say.

title: ISRAEL CRITICIZES SHULTZ ON P.L.O. PLEDGES
description: The Israeli Government today criticized remarks made by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who said Thursday that a requirement for foreign teachers in the Israelioccupied West Bank to sign an oath disavowing the Palestine Liberation Organization was a ''problem of freedom, freedom of thought.''

title: WEIGHING THE TAX COURSE
description: What is the better way to help the economy grow and hold down deficits - by cutting taxes or by raising them? President Reagan has brought that old question back to center stage by expressing interest in a proposal by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan that would make the next scheduled tax cut effective in January 1983 instead of July, a six-month speed-up.

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP CHIEF IN BID TO BUY COMPANY
description: William B. Stokely 3d, the 42-year-old chairman of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., has formed an investor group to acquire the company, the Indianapolis-based food processor announced yesterday.

title: Cessna Layoffs
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company plans to lay off ''several hundred'' more employees, starting Monday, a spokesman said. Cessna will also extend its regular Christmas holiday shutdown at all but one plant from one week to three. Cessna has 7,200 employees, down from 19,000 in 1979.

title: BIO-RESPONSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Deadline For Braniff
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines said it would end talks on a venture with Braniff International unless Braniff signed contracts with four of five unions by Tuesday.

title: SCOT LAD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $38,000 for the qr and for the 6 mos

title: IF HORMONES HAVE THEIR DAY IN COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: SETBACKS AT SOUTHERN PACIFIC
description: Much of the Southern Pacific Company's 13,740 miles of rail runs through areas of the Sun Belt that have exploded in growth over the last several years.

title: PEKING ANOUNCES CHANGE OF CHIEFS AT TWO MINISTRIES
description: The Chinese Government announced the appointments today of a new Minister of Foreign Affairs and a new Minister of National Defense.

title: Kidnapped Man Is Found Dead
description: The state police said they had found the body of a 60-year-old Elmsford businessman who was abducted last month from the driveway of his partner's home here while reportedly carrying a $10,000 payroll.

title: Wu Xueqian
description: A relative unknown in the country's political hierarchy ... Sixty years old ... Wu Xueqian (pronounced woo shweh-tshee-en) spent most of his career as an official in charge of youth activities ... Most of his experience in foreign affairs until recently was as a leader of youth delegations to Europe, Africa and other parts of Asia ... Native of Shanghai ... Mr. Wu (formerly romanized as Wu Hsueh-ch'ien) emerged after World War II as a lieutenant of the party Secretary General Hu Yaobang, then the leader of the Communist Youth League ... During the Cultural Revolution that began in 1966 he was purged along with many former Communist Youth League members, and he did not surface until 11 years later when he became deputy director of the international liaison department of the Communist Party's Central Committee, a middle-level post ... Named as a Deputy Foreign Minister in May 1982 ... Little is known in the West of Mr. Wu's early years, his education and his career before the revolution ... Said to speak some English. Zhang Aiping

title: BOWL PICTURE IN FOCUS, WITH BIDS EXTENDED TODAY
description: Southern Methodist, led by the spectacular and alternating tailbacks, Eric Dickerson and Craig James, will try to complete its first undefeated and untied regular season in 47 years Saturday when the Mustangs play Arkansas at Texas Stadium.

title:
Patents;
Clearing Blocked Arteries
description: WASHINGTON ROBERT T. GORDON, a heart surgeon and member of the medical faculty at the University of Illinois in Chicago, was granted a patent this week for treatment of atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries, without surgery. Some of his associate cardiologists have called it a landmark in the treatment of heart disease.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avnet Corp. called a special shareholders meeting for Jan. 19 to consider an increase in the number of authorized shares in order to split its stock 2 for 1.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A variety of books of interest will be reviewed in brief on occasion in this column. Clinging to the Wreckage. A Part of Life. By John Mortimer. 200 pages. Ticknor and Fields. $12.95.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including net from discontinued operations of $255,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,226,000

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 20,1982
description: International Two changes in China's hierarchy were announced by the Government, confirming rumors that had been talked about for several months. Huang Hua, who had been Foreign Minister for nearly six years, was succeeded by Wu Xueqian, who left the party bureaucracy last April to become a Deputy Prime Minister. Geng Biao, the Defense Minister since April 1981 was succeeded by Zhang Aiping, who has headed the Science and Technology Commission. (Page 1, Columns 1-2.) Improved Chinese-Soviet relations depend upon whether the Soviet Union acts to remove its threats to China, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said during a second round of talks in Peking with the Thai Prime Minister, Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda. (6:-4-6.)

title: AGENCY STAND ON DIOXINS AND PCB'S IS CHALLENGED
description: Public health officials and environmentalists accused the Environmental Protection Agency today of failing to take quick and effective action to protect citizens threatened by highly toxic dioxins in Missouri and by PCB's in Arkansas.

title: NETS SUFFER 4th STRAIGHT LOSS
description: Before tonight's game at the Memorial Coliseum, much of the talk about the Nets centered on their poor execution on offense and their turnovers. But against the streaking Portland Trail Blazers, their downfall was poor defense.

title: WAY SUGGESTED TO HALT MISUSE OF 17 1/2-CENT TOKEN
description: Connecticut's Transportation Commissioner yesterday proposed a way in which he said New York City could prevent 17 1/2-cent Connecticut Turnpike tokens from being used illegally in the subway system. New York officials said they wanted to discuss the idea further.

title: Cribbs Will Play
description: A holdout that began when the Buffalo Bills went to training camp last summer ended yesterday when Joe Cribbs, the star running back, met with Coach Chuck Knox and then said at a news conference that he was returning even though ''nothing has been settled.'' Cribbs, whom the Bills drafted out of Auburn in 1980, rushed for more than 1,000 yards in each of his first two pro seasons.

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bethlehem Ratings Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had lowered the rating on Bethlehem Steel Corporation's senior debt to BAA-2 from BAA-1 and on the company's subordinated debt to BAA-3 from BAA-2. It said that the downgrading, which affects about $884 million of outstanding debt, reflected continuing and increasing operating losses resulting from current low levels of demand.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cooper Tire and Rubber Co. filed with the S.E.C. for an offering of 650,000 shares of common stock through Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title:
PATENTS;
Compilations of Patents Offered for Sale
description: Reports on special subjects of interest to inventors and researchers -such as lists of all United States patents in a given field of technology or those held by specified owners - are now offered by the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: FOX FILMS AND PRODUCER ARE CLEARED IN INQUIRY
description: A highly publicized inquiry has found nothing to substantiate rumors that 20th Century-Fox and the producer Daniel Melnick engaged in shady dealings before Mr. Melnick left the studio last July.

title: Bethea To Quit Union Position
description: Elvin Bethea, the Houston Oilers' player representative, says he is unhappy with the tentative agreement that ended the pro football strike Tuesday night and will resign from the seven-member executive committee of the National Football League Players Association.

title: Vatican Bank Study Reported
description: A committee of 15 cardinals today began a review of Vatican finances aimed largely at clarifying the role of the Holy See in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, Vatican sources said.

title: News Analysis
description: The leadership of the United Automobile Workers appears to be trying to find a formula that will satisfy rebellious rank-and-file workers at the Chrysler Corporation without a strike that could cripple the company's financial recovery.

title: CAREY TO MEET WITH LEADERS OF LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Carey said today that he would meet Monday in Manhattan with leaders of the Legislature to discuss the state's fiscal standing, financing of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and other issues scheduled for a legislative session next month.

title: 12 REPORTED HELD IN BEIRUT MASSACRE
description: A report that Lebanese authorities have made their first arrests in their investigation of the massacre of Palestinian civilians here in September was distributed today by a local news agency close to the militias of the Lebanese Christian Phalange Party of President Amin Gemayel.

title: CMI CORP reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Spill Shuts Brooklyn Highway
description: A section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in downtown Brooklyn was closed for two hours last night after a low-level radioactive liquid spilled from a canister when the small truck carrying it hit a retaining wall at 10:30 P.M., the police said. The liquid, which contained iridium 192 and was stolen earlier from a Bronx laboratory, was flushed off the roadway after Federal officials declared it within acceptable limits, the police said.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; the latest qr and first-half results are after a net charge of $800,000 representing estimated cost associated with divestiture of two product lines

title: Morse Shoe Plans To Shut 165 Stores
description: Morse Shoe Inc., a Canton, Mass., company that operates 1,356 shoe stores and footwear departments in the United States, said it would close 165 unprofitable stores in the first half of next year.

title: A COLUMBIA FOOTBALL ERA ENDS AT BAKER FIELD
description: The wooden stands of Baker Field, a many-splintered thing to generations of Columbia students since 1928, will support the university's football fans for the last time today. When the Columbia and Brown teams trudge to the field house at dusk, one of the last remaining monuments to the era of iron-man football will be ready for the wrecking crew.

title: Bolling Is Hospitalized
description: Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, was hospitalized with what a spokesman for the hospital described as ''circulatory problems.'' He was admitted to the intensive care unit of the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y., last night. The 68-year-old chairman of the House Rules Committee, who is retiring this year after 14 years in Congress, has a history of heart problems.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $135,000 for the qr and $233,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sunbeam Closing
description: Allegheny International Inc. said its Sunbeam subsidiary would phase out operations at its appliance plant in Chicago. Most of the plant's 650 production and clerical employees will lose their jobs. Sunbeam said the plant, which makes electric frypans and parts for other appliances, had unacceptably high overhead costs and outdated and inefficient equipment.

title: BRESLER & REINER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary net gain of $1,314,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: Soviet Embassy Hit in India
description: A grenade exploded Thursday night in Soviet Embassy premises in New Delhi but no one was hurt, the police said today. They said the grenade, which was apparently thrown into the residential area behind the embassy, damaged a door and some windows. The police quoted a Soviet diplomat as saying he had seen two people, including a Sikh, going past the building just before the explosion.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GERSHWIN, PORTER, AND RODGERS SCORES FOUND
description: A treasure-trove of musical manuscripts and orchestrations by George Gershwin, Cole Porter and Richard Rodgers has been discovered in a Warner Brothers warehouse in Secaucus, N.J.

title: UNESCO DELEGATE NAMED
description: --President Reagan today named Jean Broward Shevlin Gerard of New York to be the Americn representataive at the General Conference of the United Nations, Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Mrs. Gerard, a lawyer, has been with the firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft since 1977.

title: Anne V. Miller Is Wed To Charles Poekel Jr.
description: Anne Vahey Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wherrett Miller of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday evening to Charles Axel Poekel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Poekel of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David St. George performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
RESIDENTS BALK AT CITY SHELTER ON HARLEM SITE
description: Demonstrators formed a human chain across the Harlem River Drive yesterday morning to stop rush-hour traffic in protest against the city's use of a former elementary school in Harlem as a shelter for homeless men.

title: Size of U.S. Household Is Becoming Smaller
description: American households are getting smaller, largely because of falling birth and marriage rates, higher divorce and separation rates and the fact that more people are living alone, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: WOODHEAD, DANIEL, INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 2
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to comply with F.A.S.B. No 43 and F.A.S.B. No 52

title: Bank in Texas Ruled Insolvent
description: Paul M. Homan, the Acting Comptroller of the Currency, today declared the Ranchlander National Bank of Melvin, Tex., insolvent and appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Treasure Is Rescued From a Deep Predicament

title: CITY BALLET: A PREMIERE OF 'LA CREATION DU MONDE'
description: The New York City Ballet's latest premiere is ''La Creation du Monde,'' with the original ballet score by Darius Milhaud and new, highly abstract treatment by Joseph Duell, a young dancer in the company.

title: Football; All-America; FOOTBALL WRITERS ASSOCIATION; OFFENSE
description: Wide Receiver - Anthony Carter, Michigan. Tight End - Jordon Hudson, Brigham Young.

title: Nicklaus, at 145, Shares Golf Lead
description: Jack Nicklaus shot a two-underpar 70 today and shared the lead with Bob Shearer through two rounds of the Australian Open.

title: Martha Graham Feted For Excellence in Arts
description: Martha Graham, whose trailblazing technique and independent spirit started a new dance form in America, was the recipient today of the 1982 Algur H. Meadows Award for excellence in the arts given by the Meadows School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University.

title: ARA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: B-Including a credit of $8 million for the qr and yr...C-Including a credit of $4,969,000

title: No Rush in N.B.A.
