description: The National Basketball Players Association has set no deadline for reaching agreement with pro basketball owners on a collective bargaining agreement to replace the one that expired after last season, according to Larry Fleisher, the union's general counsel. ''We're at the stage,'' Fleisher said, ''where we're gathering facts.''

title: SHULTZ, RESUMING CRITICISM, CALLS THE OATHS UNNECESSARY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz resumed his criticism today of Israel's requirement that foreigners teaching in the occupied West Bank sign pledges not to aid the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: AT AUCTION OF WINES, PRICES DIP
description: THE decline in wine prices that consumers have been noticing in s tores has spread to the auction market, where reduced prices have b egun to appear for the first time in years. The trend was e specially evident at a sale held by Christie's, the auction house, l ast week in Chicago.

title: Salazar Is Taking Well-Earned Rest
description: Saying ''I'm just going to try and take it easy for a while,'' Alberto Salazar has decided to bypass The Athletics Congress national cross-country championships next Sunday at the Meadowlands.

title: Children, Sung and Unsung
description: The father of a baby born with unformed bile ducts made a moving speech to the American Academy of Pediatrics a few weeks ago. His daughter would die without a liver transplant; could they help? His plea was heard all over the country: the parents of a baby killed in a Utah car crash donated their child's liver. ''Gift of Life for Baby Jamie,'' said one headline.

title: Insurance Exchange
description: The New York Insurance Exchange announced yesterday that premium volume for the nine months ending Sept. 30 soared 109 percent, to $102.2 million, from $49 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. The total surplus of the 32 underwriting syndicates on the exchange amounted to about $160 million as of Sept. 30.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'MacBETH'
description: THE quicker said, the better: Peter Hall's ''Macbeth'' may just be the worst new production to struggle onto the the Metropolitan Opera's stage in modern history. That claim, admittedly, covers a lot of territory and could be disputed by oldtimers, but it is not made lightly. What Mr. Hall and John Bury, who designed the sets and costumes, could have been thinking of when they devised this lumpish and often ludicrous staging of Verdi's first Shakespeare opera is difficult to imagine. Nothing really worked well and certain scenes (such as all those involving the witches) aroused the first-night audience to outright laughter and angry booing.

title: TURNSTILE-JUMPING BY CORPORATIONS
description: The coming debate in a special session of the state Legislature over how to save the 75 cent New York City subway and bus fare and current Long Island and Westchester commuter fares will be the first post-election test of whether New York State rejects the Reaganomics of ''tax and tax'' (the working and middle classes) and ''spend and spend'' (for the benefit of the wealthiest corporations).

title: BONBONS: SOME NEW TASTES AND NEW SHOPS
description: Solid chocolate, undiluted with flavored fillings, is the only thing that really satisfies the most serious chocolate buffs, but there is a time and place for bonbons, and Thanksgiving dinner may well be it. Intricately formed and filled with creams, liqueurs and nuts that may be whole or pralineed, bonbons make tiny but luxurious desserts that are usually more than enough after big holiday meals.

title: KING KULLEN GROCERY CO INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 2
NOVUS PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vigil for Flying Saucer Brings Death to Woman
description: A man and woman apparently waiting for a flying saucer spent a month in a car in the snowy wilderness of northeastern Minnesota before the woman died and the man fell unconscious, the authorities say.

title: EXAMINERS FAULT HEAD OF BANK
description: Federal bank examiners have reported they have information indicating that officers of Penn Square Bank, which failed and was closed in July, engaged in improper financial actions, including misapplication of bank funds.

title: It's Time To Share The Pain
description: Two messages kept leaping out at me as I leafed through the 103 pages of Mayor Koch's latest budget and four-year fiscal plan. One was that, no matter how experienced we New York Cityites have become at adjusting to shrunken services and tax pain, these new cuts in basic services are going to be visible in many instances and they are going to hurt.

title: Mildred Starke Married
description: Mildred Meagher Starke, widow of H. Jackson Starke, and Louis Thornton Steele, both of East Hampton, L.I., were married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity. Msgr.

title: EXPERTS TO REVIEW EARTHQUAKE ODDS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission will reassess the earthquake potential for every nuclear power plant site east of the Appalachians, the commission staff said today.

title: Talbott Advances
description: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Denver and second-seeded Michael Desaulniers of New York advanced to the quarterfinals of the $25,000 Chivas Regal Squash Open yesterday at Uptown Racquet Club. Talbott beat Bill Kaplan of Boston, 15-8, 15-10, 15-9, and Desaulniers beat Larry Hilbert, Rye, N.Y., 14-16, 15-8, 15-8, 15-6. Unseeded Ned Edwards of Philadelphia who eliminated Sharif Khan, the four-time champion, on Thursday, also won.

title: Capitals Tie Jets On Gartner's Goal
description: Mike Gartner scored his 11th goal of the season at 8 minutes 4 seconds of the third period tonight to give the Washington Capitals a 3-3 tie with the Winnipeg Jets.

title: SPIRAL METAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter losses from discontinued operations of $3,023,000 for the qr and $3,534,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $500,000 forthe qr and $680,000 for the 6 mos

title: HOW ANDROPOV OILED THE ELECTION MACHINE THAT PROPELLED HIM TO THE TOP
description: There was no campaign in any Western sense, no rallies and certainly no opportunity for the average Russian to make his weight felt. But Yuri V. Andropov had an election machine of a kind working for him long before the decision by the Communist Party's Central Committee last week to choose him as the party's new General Secretary.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Little Salutary Panic

title: News Analysis
description: Poland's martial law authorities appear to be successfully pursuing a complex strategy that will allow them to lift martial law by the end of the year - thus mollifying international opinion -while at the same time stamping out the remnants of the Solidarity labor union and any other form of political dissent. The strategy balances highly visible gestures of conciliation, particularly toward the Roman Catholic Church, with a steely use of the powers of state, including a new framework of laws and the overwhelming deployment of masses of special riot policemen to make sure the populace stays in line.

title: Hospital Corp.  To Sell Properties
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell 18 hospital properties to the Republic Health Corporation, a privately held health-care company based in Dallas, for about $200 million.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fighter Retiring
description: Ayub Kalule, the former junior-middleweight champion of the World Boxing Association, announced in Copenhagen that he was retiring. Kalule, a Ugandan who now lives in Denmark, fought for the last time a week ago in Atlantic City and was stopped by Mike McCallum of Jamaica.

title: Delco Job Security
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union said hourly workers at G.M.'s Delco Electronics division plant in Kokomo, Ind., would be eligible for guaranteed employment, under a program set up in the labor contract signed this year. Under the contract, 80 percent of the workers at four plants are guaranteed their jobs, at least through the end of the contract in September 1984.

title: Seagram to Shut Plant
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. announced today that it had reached a tentative decision to close its production facility here because of diminished demand for distilled spirits. William E. Wunder, Seagram's vice president for production and engineering, said about 400 employees would be affected by the action.

title: CYCLOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PEPPER TO CLAIM HOUSE RULES POST TO SHAPE BILLS ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Representative Claude D. Pepper of Florida, the oldest member of Congress, has declared his intention to become chairman of the House Rules Committee, an influential post that would give him the power to shape Social Security legislation to be considered in the next Congress.

title: A Model for His Old School
description: The word has flashed through Junior High School 167 in the West Farms section of the Bronx that Billy Goodwin will be playing on television again today. His St. John's team will be playing in Springfield, Mass., against North Carolina, the defending National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball champion, and Goodwin, who once sat in the same classrooms and played in the same gym as the students at 167, will be in a game that the whole country can watch.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE DEMOCRATS' ILLUSORY ELECTION LAURELS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEAK PAY-TV RESPONSE TO 'LADIES'
description: A lukewarm response to the first live pay-television presentation of a Broadway show, ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' has prompted its producers to reassess the challenge of successfully marketing theater to a mass audience.

title: Article 044546 -- No Title
description: The shuttered Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, which has been plagued by problems over the years, received yet another setback yesterday when the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation withdrew its $4 million grant for the interior renovation of the playhouse.

title: DOCTORS EXPECT THE USUAL INJURIES
description: The prognosis is for more injuries than usual tomorrow when the National Football League resumes play after an eight-week strike and only four days of practice. But although team physicians expect more muscle pulls, sprains and general soreness, Dr. Allan Levy of the Giants said ''there's not going to be a disaster out there.''

title: VIRGIN ISLANDS WORRIED AS FEWER SHIPS COME IN
description: At midafternoon on a day with three cruise ships in port, the narrow streets of this American-owned Caribbean port are jammed.

title: Court Overturns Curb on Icahn
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit voted 2 to 1 in Alexandria, Va., to overturn a preliminary injunction that prevented Carl C. Icahn and companies he controls from voting his stock in the Dan River Company. Mr. Icahn, who is offering to acquire the textile company, owns about 15 percent of its stock.

title: DeLorean Co.  Fund Inquiry
description: The Northern Ireland police are investigating the finances of John Z. DeLorean's bankrupt auto plant in Belfast, the British Government announced today.

title: McEnroe Defeats Vilas in 3 Sets
description: John McEnroe defeated Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4, tonight in the second of three matches in the Lite Tennis Challenge.

title: James Allen, 75, Dies; Was Northrop Official
description: James Allen, a public relations specialist who retired as a vice president of the Northrop Corporation in 1974, died Nov. 9 in the Van Nuys Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: DEFENSE AND SOCIAL SECURITY NOT 'SACROSANCT' TO D'AMATO
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that neither the defense budget nor Social Security were ''sacrosanct'' and that he had told the President he did not think Congress could cut any social programs without also looking very carefully at military expenditures.

title: WHEN ALL IS NOT LOST, CHICAGO FANS FIND IT TOUGH TO LIVE THE SPORTING LIFE
description: Here it is mid-November and the Chicago Bears have lost only two football games all season. Under some circumstances, that kind of record might threaten Chicago's well-deserved sports reputation as the city of losers. Of course, everyone here knows all the Augusts when the Chicago Cubs were as hot as the roofs overlooking Wrigley Field and then faded come September. And, to be sure, the Bears' inability to lose more than two games so far this fall is entirely due to the fact that the Bears have played only two games so far this fall. The Bears will put this perfect loss record on the line against Detroit here this Sunday as the National Football League season resumes after a twomonth strike, which Bears players voted to continue, possibly fearing a narrow victory or two.

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
5 Airlines Reducing Fare to Coast to $99
description: The transcontinental air fare war intensified yesterday when American Airlines said it would offer a $99 one-way, coast-to-coast fare without restrictions during the pre-Christmas season.

title: MONOSIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRESIDENT SEEKING $25 BILLION IN CUTS
description: President Reagan, setting the stage for a budget fight with Congress, has tentatively decided to seek $25 billion to $30 billion in domestic spending cuts in next year's budget, White House officials disclosed today.

title: Soviet Bans Breeding Of Minks and Foxes
description: The Moscow authorities today banned a popular Russian hobby - breeding fur-bearing animals like minks and foxes to make hats and coats.

title: HARVESTER SEEKS AID FROM MORE SUPPLIERS
description: The International Harvester Company plans to ask for $35 million more in concessions from suppliers, in addition to the $50 million already granted to the company to help it survive, Donald D. Lennox, president and chief executive officer, said today.

title: IN SPITE OF DIP, SUBWAY CRIME NEARS A RECORD
description: Despite a cut in serious subway crime over the last five months, the number of such offenses reported in New York City's system appears to be climbing toward a record in 1982.

title: Two States of Innocence
description: Connecticut's Surprising Deficit and Predictable Response

title: FED USES RATE AS POLICY SIGNAL
description: Under Paul A. Volcker, the present chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the discount rate, which was lowered half a percentage point today, to 9 percent, has become the Fed's subtle -and sometimes not so subtle - signal of current policy.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results were translated at the rate of 23.97 Israeli shekels equals $1 for the latest periods and 13.67 Israeli shekels equals $1 for the yr-ago periods

title: Your Money; Year-End Tax Moves
description: IT is not too late to make decisions that may affect the amount of Federal income tax you will pay for 1982. There are many areas in which adjustments can be made between now and the end of the year that will determine the size of your tax bill.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Events and Openings column in Weekend yesterday gave incorrect dates for two dance companies and an incorrect time for a musical event. Programs were given yesterday and are being repeated today by Dutch and American Choreographers (Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, 8 P.M.) and Strackmotion Production (Dance Works, 242 East 14th Street, 8 P.M.). The Polish Chamber Orchestra will appear at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 3 P.M. The Carnegie Mellon Philharmonic and Chorus will be there at 8 P.M.

title: Exocets for Argentina Worry Mrs. Thatcher
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that she was disappointed and concerned by France's shipment to Argentina of more of the Exocet missiles that sank two British ships in the war over the Falkland Islands.

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-AFter a loss of $27,000 for the qr and income of $1,638,677 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-Including a gain of $1,301 for the qr and a loss of $53,489 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MAN CHARGED IN SLAYING OF JUDGE TELLS JURY ABOUT HIS LIFE OF CRIME
description: Charles Voyde Harrelson, the convicted killer-for-hire accused of assassinating a Federal judge, took the witness stand today and began telling the jury the story of his life: the Navy, marriages, family, gambling, robbery, murder, courtrooms and prison.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for QTr to Sept 30
description: B-Including a gain of $395,992 on the sale of real estate

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Catherine Stone Is Bride of Barry Silber
description: Catherine Abbot Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Stone 3d of Washington, was married there yesterday to Barry Michael Silber, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Silber of Plantation, Fla., formerly of Bethpage, L.I. Deputy Clerk Robert T. Nash of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the courthouse.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a $87,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: LOCAL STEEL UNION LEADERS REJECT PROPOSED WAGE AND BENEFIT CUTS
description: Local leaders of the United Steelworkers of America, opposing their top leaders, today overwhelmingly rejected a tentative agreement that called for major concessions in wages and benefits. In return, the union would have gained more aid for laidoff workers and a profit-sharing plan.

title: IMAGINE, TRYING TO HOLD UP THE POLICE
description: ''You'd think this would be one of the last places on earth anyone would try to rob.'' The speaker was John Grillo of the Police Conference of New York, and the place was his Manhattan office.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JUDGE RAISES BAIL OF FIGURE IN FRAUD-MURDER CASE
description: A Federal judge imposed stringent bail conditions on the central figure in a $5 million fraud case yesterday because ''he may be involved in the conspiracy'' to murder witnesses in the fraud investigation.

title: Ann Flocken Wed to George Wilbanks
description: Ann Elizabeth Flocken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. P. Jay Flocken of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married there yesterday in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church to George Rivers Wilbanks, son of Dr. and Mrs. George D. Wilbanks Jr. of Chicago. The Rev. David Denison Cockroft performed the ceremony.

title: WAYS TO MAKE A DOOR UNINVITING TO BURGLARS
description: ALTHOUGH many homeowners (and apartment dwellers) diligently install the best locks they can find on their entrance doors to thwart potential burglars, many do not realize that all the locks in the world will hardly slow up an experienced burglar if the door itself, and the frame in which it is mounted, can be easily pried open or broken through.

title: THE ETERNAL HUSBAND'S STORY
description: MY WIFE MARIA CALLAS By Giovanni Battista Meneghini. Written with Renzo Allegri. Translated by Henry Wisneski. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.50.

title: JEWS PRESS THE CANADIANS TO SEIZE SUSPECTED NAZIS
description: A Jewish group here has threatened to make public the names of at least 10 men living in the Toronto area who it says are Nazi war criminals, unless the Government arrests them within four weeks.

title: HEAD OF HUMANITIES FUND ASSAILS 'OBSCURE' STUDIES
description: William J. Bennett, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, told 150 teachers of English today that they and their colleagues were failing to teach the humanities properly because they were too caught up in trends that were often shallow.

title: WORLD: STILL UP IN THE AIR
description: Edward J. Daly, chairman and chief stockholder of World Airways, said last winter that the airline might fail by summer. It came close.

title: LUKAS FOSS STILL DELIGHTS IN THE UNPREDICTABLE
RISE IN TAX FOR COMMUTERS SEEMS UNLIKELY
description: IF Mayor Koch has his way, Long Island residents, along with other suburbanites, will soon have to pay more for the privilege of working in New York City. But before the Mayor has his way, he will have to overcome formidable, well-entrenched opposition from suburban legislators of both parties, and most legislators say that his proposal - for a $100 million increase in the income tax on commuters - is not going anywhere.

title: Study Says Tax Breaks Benefit Wealthy Most
description: Income tax breaks added to the nation's Internal Revenue Code over the years, including the first two of the Reagan Administration, are weighted toward the most affluent Americans, according to a new Federal study.

title: Rudolph Schlobohm, Victoria Noyes to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Beardslee Noyes of Glen Ridge, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Jane Noyes, to Rudolph Grant Schlobohm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Francis Schlobohm Jr. of Montclair, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Rep. Bolling Is Listed In Serious Condition
description: Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, was listed in serious condition yesterday in a Westchester County hospital after choking on a piece of lobster and going into cardiac arrest Friday night.

title: Sanitation Litter
description: The New York City Sanitation Department was accused last February by the City Comptroller's office of cluttering its storerooms with, among other items, a six-year supply of cotton swabs, a 21-year supply of plumbing equipment and 1.5 million obsolete snow-removal forms.

title: Susan B. Rhein Is Married to Donald E. Dubowski
description: Susan Betz Rhein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hancock Willing Rhein 3d of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Donald Edward Dubowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Dubowski of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation by the Rev. John H. W. Rhein, grandfather of the bride, assisted by Canon David B. Lowry and the Rev. Salvator Riccardi, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ANDROPOV'S PROBLEM: EAST EUROPE INSTABILITY
description: Perhaps the main problem confronting Yuri V. Andropov as he takes over the top post of the Soviet Union is how to manage and contain the growing forces of instability and change sweeping across Eastern Europe. In the past, Moscow has sought to do this by a policy of political and economic integration, and where necessary outright repression. It is increasingly questionable, however, whether either of these methods alone will suffice in the future. If the Soviet Union is to preserve its Eastern European empire, it will have to adopt new more flexible methods of control.

title: WITH PLEASURES WENT PERILS
description: ALTHOUGH the cookbook recently published by the New Jersey Historical Society is entitled ''Pleasures of Colonial Cooking,'' I suspect there were more problems than pleasures associated with food preparation 250 years ago.

title: Out of Season; Blossom Time
description: November is an astringent month -it brings a cooling off of air, a closing up of homes, a hardening of trees. What then does the witch hazel, the most contrary of shrub-trees, do in November? After its sensible brown leaves have dried up and dropped off, like all the other sensible deciduous leaves, it blooms.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PORTRAITS REFLECTING A CERTAIN SENSIBILITY
description: The viewer will spend a morbidly fascinating half-hour or so at the exhibition entitled ''Faces Photographed,'' which will be at the Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place, through Dec. 23. But there is something deceptive about the title. Only half of the 16 photographers included really concentrate on the human face, as opposed to larger segments of the human figure. And though the show is billed as an assessment of contemporary portraiture, some of the work included is not portraiture even by rather elastic standards.

title: CONCERT: BROOKLYNITES PLAY AMERICIAN MUSIC
description: Lukas Foss opened the first season of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -after 28 seasons in which the same orchestra was known as the Brooklyn Philharmonia - with a proud attestation of affinities.

title: WAYS TO MAKE A DOOR UNINVITING TO BURGLARS
description: ALTHOUGH many homeowners (and apartment dwellers) diligently install the best locks they can find on their entrance doors to thwart potential burglars, many do not realize that all the locks in the world will hardly slow up an experienced burglar if the door itself, and the frame in which it is mounted, can be easily pried open or broken through.

title: THEY LOVED NEW YORK
description: THE WPA GUIDE TO NEW YORK CITY, The Federal Writers' Project Guide to 1930s New York. With a new introduction by William H. Whyte. Illustrated. 680 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.

title: SETTING A FAST PACE
description: For more than a century, Manhattan and Van Heusen have been virtually household names in popularly priced men's shirts. Yet, for the two men who now run each of these large men's-wear companies, the swing of the fashion pendulum has necessitated alterations in both the products they produce and the manner in which they guide their companies.

title: Detective Shoots Officer In Argument in Queens
description: An off-duty city detective shot and wounded another off-duty officer in the leg yesterday during a traffic dispute in Queens, the police said. Neither apparently knew the other was a policeman.

title: HOW AN UNKNOWN BECAME A BRITISH STAR
description: John Duttine. The name is hardly a household word in this country, or in his native Britain, for that matter. Yet, here he is, week after week, giving one of the season's most sensitive and touching performances in the BBC-Australian Television mini-series ''To Serve Them All My Days.'' The ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation, which can be seen Sundays at 9 P.M. on WNET/13, reaches the seventh of its 13 episodes tonight. Mr. Duttine is providing still another stunning example of how British television seems to have a bottomless reservoir of extraordinary acting talent.

title: FAMILY CHALLENGES A 'SUICIDE' FINDING
description: ALPINE THE widow of a New York City man found dead here 13 months ago has sued two police departments, several police officers and an Englewood housing inspector, accusing them of causing her husband's death.

title: Reagan Sticks To His Guns
description: In his first post-election speech outside the White House, President Reagan staked out the rhetorical ground from which he would prefer to conduct the 1983 spending - especially the defense spending - debate. ''Propaganda'' that his proposed five-year, $1.6 trillion military buildup and his 1981 supply-side tax cut have produced estimated deficits of $200 billion or more through 1986 is ''real dipsy doodle,'' Mr. Reagan told savings bankers meeting in New Orleans last week. Nondefense spending, Mr. Reagan said, was the cause, and would have to bear the burden.

title: MORRISTOWN: 2 VENERABLE PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: MORRISTOWN BERENICE ABBOTT and Brett Weston do not sound like an ideal match. She is well-known for her photographs of New York City and of scientific principles in action, and he for his diamond-hard views of Western landscape.

title: PARALLELS ARE EVERYWHERE
description: REGINA By Leslie Epstein. 251 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95.

title: COMPUTER-CURIOUS CLOG HOTLINE
description: IT comes from Scotland, is called the TS1000, and questions about it backed up long-distance phone lines in Middlebury. When the Timex Computer Corporation began to sell the TS1000 in July and then set up a toll-free number in September to handle consumer questions about it, the company office in Middlebury did not anticipate receiving up to 50,000 calls a week.

title: No Headline
description: A picture caption on page 22 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives the wrong time for a concert this afternoon by the Polish Chamber Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. The concert begins at 3 P.M.

title: WEATHERIZING HOMES OF THE POOR
description: WHEN fire destroyed a four-story, 16-unit apartment building at 2303C larendon Road in Brooklyn recently, all but six tenants in the a djoining structure, at 2307, had to move out of their apartments. ' 'They were identical buildings served by the same boiler,'' said B rent Sharman, the tenant organizer for the Flatbush Development C orporation, a community housing group. ''After the fire, the boiler c ouldn't be used.''

title: AMID SLUMP, TRADE-OFFS IN WORLD TRADE SEEM UNLIKELY
description: Dozens of American trade experts will descend on Geneva this week for a rare ministerial conference on world trade. In a rambling, lakeside chateau once used by the League of Nations, delegates from 88 countries will try to strenghthen a world trading system under siege.

title: GATEWAY: HALF-FULFILLED DREAM
description: IT WAS a bold break with a century-old tradition. In 1972, a Congress roused by growing urban unrest voted to lump together an amalgam of obsolete military emplacements, underfinanced state parks and decrepit beachfront facilities around New York Harbor to form America's newest national park: Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: POLLS INDICATE THAT CATHOLICS MAY BACK BISHOPS ON FREEZE
description: The nation's Roman Catholics are likely to welcome their bishops' pastoral letter on nuclear war, according to results of several Gallup Polls of Catholics and Protestants alike, taken this year and in 1981.

title: Margaret Izard Is Married to Eugene Valentine Jr.
description: Margaret Thompson Izard and Eugene Massie Valentine Jr. were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Roanoke, Va. The Rev. Clay Turner performed the ceremony.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THANKSGIVING: TRADITIONS IN TRANSITION
description: Over the river and through the woods To Grandmother's house we go! The horse knows the way to carry the sleigh Through the drifts and blinding snow. - LYDIA MARIA CHILD

title: RECITAL: FERNANDEZ IN GUITAR PROGRAM
description: Eduardo Fernandez, barely 30 years old, is already a first-rate guitarist. At the 92d Street Y on Thursday night, he offered the antithesis of the standard wearying guitar concert, which too often seems designed merely to show off the performer's virtuosity in a succession of mindless displays of local color. Mr. Fernandez's recital combined attractive and substantial music with an impeccable technique, and the result was a delightful evening.

title: AT 70, SOLTI MAY BE READY TO DELIVER HIS BEST
description: International careers in music today are increasingly defined by recordings. Artists must still tour, but their reputation among classical-music cognoscenti, and from there eventually to the public at large, is made more than anything else by their recordings - the tangible documents of their artistry, which can be heard and reheard, over and over again.

title: Florida Player, 15, Dies During Basketball Drill
description: The police said today they did not know when an autopsy would be performed on 15-year-old George Wade to determine the cause of death for the high school basketball player.

title: Shearer Shoots 72-217, Leads by 2 in Australia
description: Bob Shearer of Australia shot a par-72 today for a three-round total of 217 and a two-stroke lead in the Australian Open.

title: COURSES FOR ADULTS GAIN
description: THE course list for Learning Unlimited reads a lot like that of most municipally sponsored adult education programs - ceramics, stopsmoking classes, Japanese cooking instruction and music appreciation. Although some of the titles are a bit esoteric (Rainbow Handwriting Analysis, Thoroughbred Horse Racing Handicapping), the difference goes further than that.

title: WHAT ISN'T IN A NAME
description: GREENLAWN THE exhibition entitled ''Constructivist Forms,'' now installed in the Huntington Township Art League Gallery, is based on an inaccurate premise, but it nevertheless offers the visitor a wide range of lively approaches to sculptural construction. If one can overcome the show's misleading title, the viewing experience will be a fulfilling one.

title: ABOUT BOOKS: FAMILY 'RECIPTS'
description: ''MORE than just a cookbook'' and ''not just pumpkins, cornmeal and molasses.'' That is the way Dr. Don C. Skemer of Nutley, general editor of books for the Newark-based New Jersey Historical Society, describes the society's new cookbook, ''Pleasures of Colonial Cooking'' (N.J.H.S., 230 Broadway, Newark 07104: $7.95, plus $1.50 for postage and handling).

title: Massachusetts 29 American International 13
description: The halfback Gary Pearson of Massachusetts rushed 288 yards and set New England single-season and career rushing marks.

title: Investing; IS IT TIME TO TAKE PROFITS IN THE MARKET?
description: ''I N a lifetime you don't get many chances to make 35 percent on your money in just a few months. Why risk trying to make it 50 percent?'' Those were the sentiments of money manager Robert Torray, after several furious weeks in October of taking profits by selling off $500 million in stocks and moving the proceeds into Treasury bills and other short-term securities. The money is still there, according to Mr. Torray, whose firm manages a total of $1.5 billion for pension funds, waiting ''until we find stocks we think are too cheap. Right now there are not many around.''

title: A Trial at Last In Nuns' Murder
description: El Salvador's judicial system opened one eye slightly last week. A criminal court judge ordered five national guardsmen to stand trial in the killing of three American nuns and a Catholic lay worker who were taken from their van near the national airport in December 1980 and raped, killed and buried in the countryside.

title: Shoreham Loses in Soccer
description: Pittsford Mendon of Rochester rallied to defeat Shoreham Wading River of Suffolk County, 3-1, yesterday and won the New York State Class B soccer championship at Hofstra University.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Man's Death Laid to Natural Causes
description: A medical examiner on Thursday ruled out foul play in the death last month of a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency who was to have been a key prosecution witness in the just completed trial of Edwin P. Wilson for arms smuggling.

title: Rimington Gets Outland Award
description: Dave Rimington, the center for Nebraska, has become the first two-time winner of the Outland Award, which for 37 years has been given to the outstanding college football guard, tackle or center selected by the Football Writers Association of America.

title: SEEKING RESPECT IN ROCK
description: ROSLYN MANY Long Island rock musicians report that a certain stigma stands between them as Long Islanders and the musical respect they seek in the marketplace. Varying degrees of success achieved by Kiss, Lou Reed, Billy Joel, the Ramones, the Good Rats, the Stray Cats and other Island rockers notwithstanding, there is a ring of truth to the contention.

title: NEWARK GOVERNMENT ASSAILED
description: NEWARK THE Essex County grand jury that indicted Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and other officials last March on charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office in effect also indicted the operations of the Newark city government.

title: Beth Mara Sorrel Married To Michael A. Oil, Student
description: Beth Mara Sorrel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last night to Michael Allen Oil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Oil of New York. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: RECITAL: COLIN CARR, CELLIST
description: Colin Carr is a thoroughly modern cellist - one who combines a sumptuous tone with invariable technical accuracy. If there was any problem with his Alice Tully Hall recital Tuesday night, it was the presence of a certain reserve, which sometimes bordered on the chilly. Mr. Carr's emotional range is not always what it could be but one never fails to respect his intelligence.

title: Catherine Mackin, 42, Reporter for ABC News
description: Catherine Mackin, a television correspondent based in Washington for ABC News for the last five years, died yesterday morning in Baltimore after a long illness. She was 42 years old.

title: DANCE: DEBRA ZALKIND
description: Debra Zalkind is a dancer with a piquant face and real comic flair. When she was on stage with something to do, on Wednesday at the Symphony Space, the dance component of ''One Evening of Piano and Dance'' came to life.

title: CINEPROBE BEGINS ITS 15TH SEASON
description: With the showing Isa Hesse-Rabinovitch's ''Siren Island,'' starring Dana Bree, above, the Museum of Modern Art ushers in its 15th season of Cineprobe tomorrow night at 6.

title: THE BENEFITS OF A SWAP INSTEAD OF A SALE
description: SWAPPING high-priced homes is unusual but it offers advantages to t he swappers that are not available in ordinary sales. A case in point is the swap worked out between Dr. Alexander B onacarti and his wife, Patricia, who wanted to sell their Georgian c olonial house in Tenafly, and Hiroki and Pamela Aoki, who wanted to m ove from their stucco contemporary in Englewood.

title: Katharine Day Is Wed
description: Katharine Langdon Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Day of Douglaston, Queens, was married yesterday to Alan Scott Bremer, son of Maybelle R. Bremer of Jacksonville, Fla., and D. Wilmore Bremer of Macon, Ga. The Rev. John Meyer performed the Congregational ceremony at the Community Church of Douglaston.

title: FOR PROMINENT TURKS, SHAVED HEADS AND JAIL GARB
description: The 26 prisoners looked ill at ease as they appeared in a military court in Istanbul last week with newly shaved heads and blue prison uniforms.

title: OFFICIAL OUTLINES TOXIC-WASTE ROLE
description: On Oct. 27, Judge Martin Nigro of Superior Court was named as a one-man grand jury to investigate allegations of illegal dumping and storage of hazardous waste by three Connecticut companies, including Environmental Waste Removal Inc. of Waterbury. The other companies were the Connecticut Treatment Corporation of Bristol and Tri-Chem Environmental Industries Inc. of Stamford.

title: GLEN RIDGE (8-1) IS CHAMPION
description: Greg Ortman and Mike Stanisci provided 3,000 fans in Glen Ridge with a scoring display yesterday as they combined for four touchdowns and gave Glen Ridge a 28-14 victory over New Providence and the championship of the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 1 playoffs.

title: FEDERAL SHIELD
description: Still gracing both sides of East 73d Street in the block between Lexington and Third Avenues and forming a kind of mews there are 15 buildings dating from the turn-of-the-century or before. They were not included in the East Side Historic District, which runs roughly from Fifth to Lexington Avenues between 59th and 79th Streets, but they were officially recognized as city landmarks by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1979.

title: NO END TO SEA DUMPING SEEN
description: Last of three articles

title: KEAN FINDS A SPLIT IN DEMOCRAT'S UNITY
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN probed and found a weak spot last weak in the united front usually put up by the Democratic leadership in the State Legislature.

title: Commuter Mayor
description: When the John Morrell & Company meat plant in Cincinnati closed last August, Melvin Griffin of adjacent Elmwood Place, Ohio, lost his job and pondered his fate: he had put in 29 years and eight months as a meatpacker and needed but four months to qualify for a pension.

title: OLD CRANBERRY BOG IS FAMILY BUSINESS
description: KILLINGWORTH IN the 20's and 30's, New England was full of cultivated cranberry bogs; carefully maintained marshy meadows covered with tiny pink flowers that, in autumn, turn into hard, deep-red berries.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: CRISIS IN THE COURTS?
description: The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, said in New York the other day that the courts of this country were being overwhelmed by legal conflict and that the American system of justice ''may literally break down before the end of this century.''

title: 3 KILLED AS 2 LIGHT PLANES COLLIDE OVER COMMUNITY IN ESSEX COUNTY
description: Three persons were killed this afternoon when the two small planes they were in collided and crashed in this suburban section of Essex County, 18 miles west of New York City, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. The three were the only occupants in the planes.

title: Wedding Planned By Nancy Edler
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George C. Edler Jr. of Kensington, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Edler, to Charles Smith Cadigan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Cadigan of Towson, Md. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: POLICE INVESTIGATE GANGS' FATAL FIGHT
description: Several members of rival Chinatown street gangs were being questioned by the police yesterday in the fatal shooting of a gang member and the wounding of another in a clash that erupted at a Thanksgiving party given by Asian students in a New York University dormitory Friday night.

title: Gorton Wins Title Game Against New Rochelle
description: Unbeaten Gorton, playing a controlled game, scored an upset victory yesterday against New Rochelle, winning by 15-8 in the championship game of Section 1, Class A-1 at Mount Vernon Memorial Field. It was the first loss of the season for New Rochelle.

title: NUGGETS FOR SALE
description: The North Shore of Long Island is known as Nassau County's Gold Coast, so when a for-sale sign goes up on waterfront property there, it should come as a surprise to no one that the price is going to be high. Still, the asking price for acreage at Land's End, a new development in Lattingtown between Sheep Lane and the Creek Club, may be an eye-opener to some.

title: ABOUT SQUIRRELING AWAY THOSE ACORNS
description: DEAR Mother Squirrel: With full realization that you do not have access to media reports as we mothers of human offspring do, I have to pass on a dire warning to you: the National Weather Service has predicted very frigid weather for this winter.

title: DEBUT OF TOKENS IS MARKED BY MIXUP
description: CONNECTICUT officials expected few troubles, if any, last week with the start of the new token system for tolls along the Connecticut Turnpike, and very few they got.

title: HOW HARD TO BE A FATHER
description: CONFESSIONS OF A SINGLE FATHER By Jim Covington 181 pp. New York: The Pilgrim Press. $13.95.FATHER AND SON By Darrell Sifford. 168 pp. Philadelphia: Bridgebooks/The Westminster Press. $9.95.FROM the shelves of a modest private library I draw down some books: "My Father and Myself" by J. R. Ackerley, "Father and Son" by Edmund Gosse, "Photographs of My Father" by Paul Spike, "A Letter From My Father" (edited by Ward Smith's son, Page), "Best Father Ever Invented" by Mark Harris (and, ironically, about himself), "The Old Man and Lesser Mortals" by Larry L. King (collected essays, the title piece heart-stopping) and "Forgive the Father" by Howard Wolf, creator of the ultimate title in this genre. I recall Vladimir Nabokov's portrait, toneperfectly tough and tender, of his assassinated father in "Speak, Memory" and Frank Conroy's exactly befuddled memory of his in "Stop-Time." I call to mind Michael J. Arlen's memorial to his father in "Exiles," and his exclamation in "Passage to Ararat": "Ah, fathers! How hard it is to be a father!"

title: HARLEM'S NEW CATHOLIC BISHOP MEETS HIS PEERS
description: Bishop Emerson J. Moore of Harlem, recently named an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, was introduced to his new colleagues last week at the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

title: CITY FINDS A HEAVIER FEDERAL ROLE IN PUBLIC HOUSING
description: THE New York City Housing Authority wants to know what has become oft he ''new Federalism.'' Under President Reagan's doctrine of greater r eliance on state and local authority in running social programs, t he agency had expected a lighter hand from Washington in public h ousing administration. But officials say the opposite has been the c ase. They contend that Washington is setting up complex regulatory p rocedures that add to paperwork and costs without offering the p rospect of productive results.

title: RICHARD STRAUSS AND THE THIRD REICH
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: DUO PIANO BY THE DICHTERS
description: Misha and Cipa Dichter are husband and wife. Perhaps this is one reason why their work as duo pianists has the sense of extramusical communication it does.

title: ST. JOHN'S TOPPLES N. CAROLINA, 78-74
description: Could it be possible that Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, will finally enjoy a Thanksgiving dinner? He insists there have always been too many coaching worries to allow that to happen.

title: No Headline
description: U.C.L.A. BEATS SOUTHERN CAL BY 20-19

title: ADLER TO ZEYDES
description: More than the usual appreciation of the Yiddish language, LIVE & BE WELL (Ballantine/Hilltown Press, cloth, $20, paper, $9.95) is, as its subtitle advertises, ''A Celebration of Yiddish Culture in America From the First Immigrants to the Second World War.'' Richard F. Shepard, a cultural news reporter for The New York Times, and Vicki Gold Levi, a picture researcher, have collected a verbal and visual abecedarium - from ''Jacob P. Adler'' to ''Zeydes and Bobes.''

title: Wedding Planned By Sarah Etzler
description: The engagement of Sarah Elizabeth Etzler to Robert Barnecott Peake has been announced by the future bride's mother, Kathryn A. Etzler of Pleasantville, N.Y. Her fiance is the son of Jessie Peake of Bronxville, N.Y., and Kirby Peake of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: AS THE STAGE TURNS AT THE MALL
description: PARAMUS PRODUCERS committed to developing new plays would hardly be expected to stage a Neil Simon comedy - and a negligible one at that. For Fourstar Productions, however, that seems to be the surest route to survival.

title: Miss Sproul Is the Fiancee Of Bank Aide
description: Margaret Pratt Sproul, a loan officer with the Chemical Bank's energy division, plans to be married Jan. 1 to Henry Jackson Sargent Cheever, a vice president and assistant director of Chemical Bank International Ltd. in London.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: GRANT: A Biography. By William S. McFeely. (Norton, $9.95.) The enigmatic figure who was a fierce and effective warrior but also a bumbling, possibly crooked politician appealed to William McFeely as a subject because he didn't look like either sort of man in his pictures; instead he looked mild and small and ordinary. Winner of a Pulitzer Prize and a Francis Parkman Prize, this is biography at its best, according to our reviewer, Marcus Cunliffe. President Grant's autobiographical account, PERSONAL MEMOIRS OF U.S. GRANT, edited with notes by E.B. Long (Da Capo, $10.95), which focuses almost exclusively on military matters, is ''one of the most unflinching studies of war in our literature,'' Mr. McFeely says in an introduction prepared for this edition.

title: THE PARTITION OF PALESTINE 35 YEARS AGO
description: Peter Grose, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, adapted this article from his forthcoming book on American attitudes toward Israel, to be published next autumn by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: A CHINESE SURPRISE IN NEW CANAAN
description: NEW CANAAN SOMETHING new has been added to the New Canaan restaurant scene - Mr. Lee. Named after its ''angel,'' the condominium developer Johnson Lee, it is a welcome addition, the first professional Chinese restaurant in town.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MARTING LUTHER MEDAL
description: Martin Luther's role in triggering the Protestant Reformation won him a lasting place not only in church history, but also in the annals of numismatics. There is perhaps no other individual in history that has been honored on so many coins and medals, and now that lengthy list is getting an attractive new addition, thanks to a church in Westchester County, N.Y.

title: 'STEAMING': AWASH IN THE ORDINARY
description: STAMFORD IN ''Steaming,'' five women meet in a London Turkish bath once a week, on ''ladies day,'' ''to get wet and sweaty and dry and wet again.'' They jump into a sunken pool on stage, they take their clothes off (sometimes draping parts of themselves in towels) and they chatter -mostly about men.

title: CONSERVATION IS FOCUS OF JERSEY UTILITY'S PLAN
description: Homeowners and apartment renters will be able to get loans for energy conservation at little or no interest under a $10.2 million conservation plan approved by the Board of Public Utilities for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the state's largest utility.

title: CABBAGE LEFT UNHARVESTED
description: HUNDREDS of acres of cabbage are rotting in the fields on eastern Long Island again this season. They were left unharvested because of high costs and low market prices, which makes it only marginally profitable for growers to pick and sell the vegetable.

title: Shuttle Proves Its Point and Gets a Rest
description: ''We deliver'' was the motto of the latest space shuttle crew, and when Columbia landed last week at Edwards Air Force Base in California, they had. Two commercial communications satellites had been put into orbit, proving the re-usable space vehicle's feasibility as a for-hire cargo ship.

title: U.S. JUDGE IN TEXAS DRAWS WIDESPREAD HOSTILITY WITH LIBERAL RULINGS
description: It was another quiet Election Day for Federal District Judge William Wayne Justice, often described as the most powerful and the most controversial man in eastern Texas, a man whose power would vanish quickly if the voters had anything to say about it.

title: MOSCOW
description: Aweek after the event, little doubt lingers in Moscow that the fourth leadership change in Soviet history went smoothly and that Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov has assumed a position of unassailable primacy and power.

title: The Amazon
description: To the Editor:

title: Tulane Scholar Named As President of Oberlin
description: S. Frederick Starr, a Soviet affairs specialist and a professor of history and architecture at Tulane University, was elected today as the 12th president of Oberlin College by its board of trustees.

title: A FULL LOG OF SAILINGS
description: T he following guide to cruise ships is arranged by destination and primarily covers saltwater cruises. Cruises are also offered on many of the world's major rivers, such as the Mississippi, the Nile, the Rhine and the Yangtze, but details on these and on most freighter cruises - an exception is Delta Cruise Lines' 100-passenger cargo vessels -are not included. The guide, which primarily covers sailings from Nov. 22, 1982, to March 31, 1983, is the fourth to appear this year in Travel. In 1983 guides are planned on March 6 and Nov. 13.

title:
DINING OUT;
TWO OLD HANDS IN A NEW VENTURE
description: ARESTAURANT named Baker & Lloyd opened very quietly in Morristown during the summer. It is directly across the street from The Grand Cafe, an establishment that received two stars on these pages almost a year ago, and it is owned by the same two people, Jack Baker and Desmond Lloyd.

title: No Headline
description: OHIO STATE UPSETS MICHIGAN BY 24-14

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS
description: LONGTIME residents, and very often new visitors, use words like stability and dignity to describe Brooklyn Heights. They also say it is convenient.

title: WORES RETROSPECTIVE IN BRIDGEPORT
description: BRIDGEPORT A CALIFORNIAN painter, Theodore Wores (1859-1939), is the subject of the retrospective now on view at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry (4450 Park Avenue) through Nov. 28. The show, which originated at Alabama's Huntsville Museum of Art in 1980, is remarkable on several counts. Chief among these is that it was organized by the owners of most of the 90 or so canvases it contains, Ben Shenson and his brother A. Jess Shenson, of San Francisco.

title:
GARDENING;
PUTTING PLANTS TO BED FOR THE WINTER
description: AS the season draws to a close, several suggestions are in order for putting the garden to bed for the winter. At the time of this writing, there is such a deficiency of moisture that New Jersey officials may declare a drought emergency. While we recently pointed out that research has shown late August and September to be the most critical period in relating soil-moisture deficiencies with winter damage, it is still important that plants, especially those that are evergreen, not be allowed to go into the winter dry.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Worker Falls 8 Floors in Car
description: A car dealership worker backed a car into an empty elevator shaft Friday and plunged eight stories. The worker, 37-year-old Jose Alfaro, was listed in stable condition at a hospital here.

title: CONSPIRACY TRIAL IS A TALE OF TAPES
description: Thousands of words of involuntary testimony are being given to the jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but so many of them are obscene that newspapers are finding much of the testimony unprintable.

title: GREECE IS PRESSING BRITAIN FOR RETURN OF ANTIQUITIES
description: The Greek Government, in a campaign headed by Melina Mercouri, the Minister of Culture, has stepped up its pressure on Britain for the return of prized antiquities taken by Lord Elgin from the Acropolis nearly two centuries ago.

title: Judith Notley Engaged To Edward E. Stone
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Collier Notley of Elkins Park, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Esther Notley, to Edward Eldredge Stone, son of Mrs. William S. Blanchard of Southport, Conn., and the late Charles Lynn Stone.

title: Hundreds Wait to Apply For Jobs of Strikers
description: Hundreds of people waited in the rain Friday to apply for jobs at a wholesale grocery concern where 100 members of the teamsters' union are on strike protesting a proposal to cut their wages.

title: Miss Schlesinger To Wed in June
description: Edward S. Schlesinger of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Renee C. Schlesinger of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jill Schlesinger, to Michael Gary Izenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Izenson of Okemos, Mich. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE HAUNTING By Margaret Mahy. 135 pp. New York: Atheneum/ Margaret K. McElderry. $8.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: How Nasty Is That?
description: Apparently no one told Air Force Lieut. Gen. Charles Donnelly that the honeymoon with the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, isn't over yet. The general raised a few eyebrows and a hackle or two last week when he publicly referred to Mr. Andropov as ''nastier than a snake.'' General Donnelly, the commander of United States forces in Japan, offered that and other disparaging remarks before the Kiwanis Club in Agana, Guam. The Pentagon, carefully choosing the form of chastisement, said he had been ''counselled'' for his comments.

title: G.O.P. Governors Nurse Wounds, Point Fingers
description: For crankiness there is nothing quite like a Republican governor who has just lost his election or managed to hang on to his job by the narrowest of margins. Or so it seemed last week when some of each gathered in Kansas City and immediately turned their fire on the Republican in the Oval Office, clearly believed to be the source of many of their political scars.

title: FIGHTING ARSON BEFORE THE ASHES COOL
description: Secrecy is the watchword of many investigators, but members of a special New York City arson squad owe much of their considerable success to visibility. Red Cap fire marshals get their name from the conspicuous headgear they sometimes wear, are based in a distinctive trailer, drive marked cars and saturate a small area, responding to every fire, night or day. They make their presence known not only to residents, whose help they cultivate and rely on, but also to the drug dealers, addicts, squatters and scavengers who cause much of the problem the Red Caps were formed to combat.

title: MEXICAN WOMEN CROSS BORDER SO BABIES CAN BE U.S. CITIZENS
description: Ilda Leal, a small, shy, 27-year-old woman, is fairly typical of the Mexican women, now numbering in the thousands, who are coming across the border every year to have their babies in the United States.

title: Equal Pay
description: In one of the largest sex-discrimination lawsuits filed against a university, 117 women at the University of South Alabama in Mobile won a back-pay award estimated at $1.3 million last January. A Federal Court ruled that the school had paid women on the faculty and in administrative posts less than it paid men in comparable jobs.

title: FOR DOVISH ADDABBO, SETBACKS ON DEFENSE BILL
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, was defeated on almost every vote on major expense items in the 1983 military budget that came before his subcommittee this week.

title: Lee Ann Mazzacca Wed
description: Lee Ann Mazzacca, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mazzacca of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church of Reading, Pa., to James Douglas Penturelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Penturelli of Reading. The Rev. Russell Feroe performed the ceremony.

title: Cey Approves Trade
description: Ron Cey, the starting third baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers for most of his 10-year major-league career, has agreed to let the Dodgers trade him to one of seven other teams, according to a report published in The Torrance Daily Breeze, a California newspaper. ''We've gotten his O.K., but it doesn't necessarily mean we will trade him,'' said Al Campanis, the Dodger vice president.

title: WILL THE RULES RAISE THE SCORING?
description: BOBBY CREMINS of Georgia Tech was one of many coaches who opposed the use of 24-, 30-or 4 5-second shot clocks last May, in a National Collegiate Athletic A ssociation Rules Committee questionnaire. Of the 394 coaching b allots cast for the use of the 45-second clock, Lou Carnesecca of S t. John's was one of 119 in favor.

title: BRICK ROLLS, 16-13, INTO A GROUP FINAL
description: Gary Bonavito threw a 17-yard touchdown pass to Mike Luis in the fourth quarter to send Brick to a 16-13 victory over Washington Township and into the South Jersey, Group 4 final yesterday before 4,000 fans in Brick.

title: 'GUIDES' HELP AGED UNDERSTAND BENEFITS
description: ''THERE is a need among the senior citizen group to know what benefits are available to them and how to apply for them,'' said Ruth M. Ahearn, project director of the Westchester Retired Senior Volunteer Program. She was discussing an R.S.V.P. advocacy project, which was established to train elderly volunteers to assist their peers in areas of special concern to them, such as Social Security, Medicare, Blue Cross-Blue Shield and food-stamp eligibility.

title: New Pieces in Brink's Puzzle
description: Authorities still don't know where Joanne Chesimard is, but a Federal grand jury last week indicted four persons on charges of helping the fugitive Black Liberation Army leader get there.

title: Ana Julia Castillo, Michael Ericksen To Wed in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pedro A. Castillo of Darien, Conn., formerly of Havana, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ana Julia Castillo, to Michael Ross Ericksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark A. Ericksen of Cincinnati.

title: Predatory Urchins
description: To the Editor: Oh, did the letter about predatory urchins from Charles Burroughs Jr. (Travel, Oct. 24) ring a bell. This summer my husband and I were sitting in the little park behind Notre Dame in Paris.

title: REDISCOVERING THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
description: RICHARD J. MEISLIN is the Caribbean correspondent of The Times and is based in Miami.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: DANCE Sunday is the last day of the season to catch the Murray Louis Dance Company at the Joyce Theater. The two programs together offer a crash course in Mr. Louis's choreography, ranging from his recent world premiere, ''A Stravinsky Montage'' to the veritable retrospective of film clips with live solos entitled ''Repertoire.''

title: AIDES CONFIRM DROP IN MAGAZINE'S CIRCULATION
description: Officials of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States reported today that the circulation of the organization's magazine, Nation's Business, dropped by at least 30 percent in the last year.

title: Town's Terror Frozen in Time
description: From the silence of antiquity comes the death cry of a Roman town, Herculaneum, preserved in the remarkable discovery of more than 80 complete human skeletons where there should have been none. Scholars had long believed the town's inhabitants fled safely when Vesuvius erupted 1,900 years ago, destroying Herculaneum and Pompeii.

title: LESSONS IN MORTALITY: ROSES FROM BOXERS' GRAVES
description: TO maintain a sense of proportion it is well to remember that one does not mention rope in the house of a hangman or speak of compassion in the presence of a fight promoter. Each can be depended upon to turn a deaf ear, because neither is a god nor a visitor from another planet. They are bound by a common pursuit of pelf, much as the butcher, the baker and the unfriendly neighborhood bookmaker.

title: BURN SITE APPROVED
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency last week approved a site approximately 140 miles east of Cape May for hte at-sea incineration of a specific class of extremely hazardous chemical wastes.

title: 'STEAMING': AWASH IN THE ORDINARY
description: STAMFORD IN ''Steaming,'' five women meet in a London Turkish bath once a week, on ''ladies day,'' ''to get wet and sweaty and dry and wet again.'' They jump into a sunken pool on stage, they take their clothes off (sometimes draping parts of themselves in towels) and they chatter -mostly about men.

title: CELTICS SET BACK KNICKS, 97-83
description: The Knicks held the Boston Celtics without a basket for 8 minutes 21 seconds in the final period last night at Madison Square Garden. But the best New York could do during that time was cut a 12-point deficit to 7, and the Knicks lost, 97-83.

title: Virginia A. Kent Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Kent of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann Kent, to Malcolm Stuart Dorris of Brooklyn. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Dorris of Wyncote, Pa.

title: 2 HIGH SCHOOLS AIDING STUDENTS WITH CHILDREN
description: The nursery at Bay Ridge High School in Brooklyn looks much like any other. The walls are a sunny yellow and the children's names and ages are printed on brightly colored construction paper and tacked to the walls.

title: FORDHAM BEATEN, 14-10
description: Kelly Englebart, a freshman halfback, scored two fourth-quarter touchdowns to lead St. Norbert's to a 14-10 victory over Fordham yesterday in the Vince Lombardi Memorial Game at Lambeau Field in Green Bay, Wis.

title: SCHOONER BUILT BY CAPTAIN SAILS THE SOUND WITH CARGO
description: EVERY day at exactly 10 A.M., Capt. Greg Brazier casts off the lines from Bayles Dock in Port Jefferson Harbor and the schooner Phoenix moves out, headed for the breakwater. As soon as the schooner clears the dock, the captain and his mate, Gary Holmes, secure the engine, hoist the sails and set a course for Bridgeport, Conn.

title: D.F. Thomas, Karen Kelsey Are Married
description: Karen Mayhew Kelsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Marion Kelsey Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married at Christ's Episcopal Church there yesterday to David Fenton Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Thomas of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Johnston.

title: CORNELL FOILS PENN IN BID FOR TITLE, 23-0
description: Cornell spoiled Penn's efforts to take the Ivy League title outright tonight and sent Coach Bob Blackman to retirement with tears of happiness.

title: Sister of Poison Victim Sues
description: The sister of one of seven people killed by cyanide in Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules filed suit Friday for $5.1 million in damages from Johnson & Johnson, McNeil Consumer Products and the Walgreen Company.

title: Sikhs Pressing Demands For Greater Autonomy
description: Thousands of Sikhs marched today to mark the death more than 300 years ago of one of their early spiritual leaders, Guru Tegh Bahadur.

title: FUNK TAKES A PROVOCATIVE TURN
description: The word ''funk'' is difficult to define. But in today's pop music, funk is generally understood as a rhythmic language that involves chattering, telegraphic percussion; a fat and basic backbeat from the drums; and melodic bass patterns that tend to lope or stutter. The roots of funk are in Latin music, in New Orleans rhythm-and-blues, and above all in the stripped-down, ferociously rhythmic music of the mid-1960's James Brown band. But by now, musicians and bands all over the world are trying their hands at funk. It's the common rhythmic language that allows British new wave rock to fit snugly into the musical formats of black-oriented innercity radio stations and unites whites and blacks on night-club dance floors.

title: A TENANT'S EQUITY IN CONVERSION
description: BECAUSE of the special nature of the New York cooperative market, tenants can sometimes make a bundle ofc ash when a rental building is converted to cooperative ownership. J ust for being in the right place at the right time, tenants with no i nterest in buying their apartments and no interest in remaining as r enters in the building can earn substantial sums by selling their s o-called insider rights.

title: 2 Kickers Reinstated
description: Tom Skladany and Tom Murray, two kicking specialists who were suspended four days before the beginning of the National Football League schedule because they left the Detroit Lions in contract disputes, have been reinstated and will be eligible to play today against the Bears in Chicago. Skladany, a punter, and Murray, a place-kicker, were back in the lineup, according to Coach Monte Clark because ''I feel it's my responsibility to field the best people with the talent to give us the best chances to win.'' The Lions waived the two players who had replaced the suspended kickers -John James, a punter, and Bob Thomas, a place-kicker.

title: EROS AND DEATH
CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: OPERA The Metropolitan Opera's production of Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' returns to the repertory Thursday night, which seems a suitable enough excuse for Thanksgiving all by itself. This year's cast offers Eva Marton's first Met performances of Elisabeth; Miss Marton has been warmly received in her recent outings at the Met, the Empress in Richard Strauss' ''Die Frau ohne Schatten'' and the title role in ''La Gioconda.''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE political disagreements and tensions of the past were nowhere in sight last Tuesday night as Democratic State Representatives held their first caucus to elect leaders for the new legislative session, which will convene Jan. 5.

title: THEOLOGY GETS DOWN TO CASES ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The nuclear age has ushered in what many of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops call a ''new moment'' in moral theology that demands a fresh way of thinking about the ethics of war and peace. Last week, at its annual meeting in Washington, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops took decisive steps to draft a pastoral letter that solidifies the church's opposition to nuclear arms, tentatively stakes out some new ground on deterrence and, in general, reflects a striking change in attitude.

title: THE GIRL FROM NEW ZEALAND
description: TO THE IS-LAND An Autobiography. By Janet Frame. 253 pp. New York: George Braziller. $10.95.

title: CITY TO RECRUIT NURSES WITH FORGIVABLE LOANS
description: New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is offering forgivable loans and considering providing subsidizing housing in an effort to recruit nurses for the city's municipal hospitals.

title:
GOING ON RECORD WITH FUNKY ORIGINALS;
ROOSEVELT
description: SPEND three years in Hollywood writing songs and getting the name around. Along the way, rub musical elbows with the likes of Eloise Laws, Rose Royze, Sly Stone and Marvin Gaye. Bring the songs back to New York and put together a small, dedicated group. Find a studio to work out the material on tape, picking up a few studio players along the way. Then emerge with the whole package and an accumulated entourage, selectively hitting the club scenes for exposure while peddling the songs and the group.

title:
WHAT IS NEEDED FROM THE GATT TALKS?;
JAPANESE GOOD WILL
description: THE focus of United States trade policies has shifted, and a reneweda ttack on Japan Inc. is about to begin. Desperate to stave off an e xpected wave of protectionist sentiment in the next Congress, the R eagan Administration feels it must bring about a major reorientationo f Japan's economy.

title: SPANO PREPARES TO CHALLENGE PLAN ON AUTO BUREAUS
description: ANDREW SPANO, the Democrat who won a narrow and unexpected election victory recently in the race for County Clerk, found an unexpected ally last week in George Morrow, the Republican who lost the job. Mr. Morrow said he would seek to persuade county legislators to maintain local automobile bureaus in Westchester.

title: LITCHFIELD SAVES ITS OLD POST OFFICE
description: A roar of protest went up in Litchfield, Conn., eight years ago when word came from Washington that the United States Postal Service planned to vacate the century-old, ramshackle frame building where it rented space and move to more contemporary and serviceable quarters. That the new post office was to be on the outskirts of town added insult to injury for residents, who saw the move as an erosion of Litchfield's ''village green'' atmosphere.

title: AWARD FOR PEACE
description: Randall Forsberg, director of the Institute for Defense and Disarmament Studies in Brookline, Mass., will receive the Ghandi Peace Award at 7:30 P.M. on Wednesday at the United Church on the Green, Temple and Elm Streets in New Haven.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Mary Dorsey Is a Bride
description: Mary Lee Dorsey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Baker Dorsey, was married yesterday to Brian Donald Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Lee. Both families are of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., where the Rev. Francis Gargani performed the ceremony in St. Clement's Roman Catholic Church.

title: KHOMEINI'S GRIP APPEARS AT ITS TIGHTEST
description: The Islamic Government led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appears to have fastened its grip more firmly on this country of 38 million people than at any time since the revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi almost four years ago.

title: Queens and S.I. Gained Private Jobs During '81
description: Job growth in private business continued in Queens and on Staten Island in the year that ended March 1982, but came to a stop in Manhattan, according to the Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: India
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs SuperSonics, at Seattle, The Sonics, with David Thompson showing the way, have won their first 12 games. The Nets have lost four in a row. (Radio - WVNJ 620 AM 9:25 P.M.).

title: Triple-Threat Shultz
description: The second half of the Reagan Administration begins with George Shultz firmly established at quarterback, handling all aerial diplomacy and also participating in major ground assaults against the recession. When the team's in trouble, he even punts brilliantly. It's formidable duty under an arrangement that leaves the President calling the plays, but mostly on Mr. Shultz's counsel. What can they thus achieve?

title: THEATER: 'THE GREAT MAGOO,' COMEDY REVIVED
description: As activist journalists, Ben Hecht and Gene Fowler became as famous as the stories they covered. Each also succeeded in flamboyant literary careers - as authors, screenwriters and, in Hecht's case, as a playwright. Briefly, in 1932, they collaborated on a Broadway comedy, ''The Great Magoo.'' It was lambasted by the critics - Hecht felt they attacked it as a ''lynching mob'' - and for 50 years it was a footnote in their lives.

title: 6 CITY WORKERS GIVEN PUBLIC SERVICE AWARDS
description: With a flurry of office parties, some impromptu speeches and a great deal of back-slapping, six city employees have received awards for outstanding public service.

title: DELBELLO'S FINAL BUDGET: HOW IT WORKS
description: IT was County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's last budget, and the county legislators being briefed last Monday, often his adversaries, could not have been more affable. If Mr. DelBello did not leave them laughing, they were at least smiling.

title: Sharon Roth Engaged To Stephen A. Alpert
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Roth of White Plains have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Elizabeth Roth, to Stephen Abram Alpert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Alpert also of White Plains. The wedding is planned for March.

title: THE CHRONIC ACHES OF HEALTH CARE COSTS
description: Administration officials are confronting the unpleasant axioms of health care economics as they prepare the 1984 budget. If the Government increases access to health care without making any other change in its delivery or financing, costs will rise. But if Washington cuts its own costs, it tends to reduce access to health care or to shift costs to private patients and state and local governments.

title: No Headline
description: Pam Shriver Gains

title: BACK TO SCHOOL AND BACK IN TIME
description: ''I THINK this is a time when many women in my position are thinking about going back and starting a career -and do hesitate,'' said Joan H. Geismar. ''Dare I go back to school? Will my head work? What will it lead to?''

title: Joyce Goldklang, Jay Diamond, Lawyers, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Goldklang of Teaneck, N.J. and Becket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joyce Ellen Goldklang, to Jay Harrison Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis P. Diamond of Allentown, Pa.

title: Jeffrey B. Becker to Marry Cynthia Hinrichs Dec. 30
description: Constance M. Hughes of Northport, L.I., and Herbert C. Hinrichs of Lloyds Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Abbie Hinrichs, to Jeffrey Branaman Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl B. Becker of Sudbury, Mass. A Dec. 30 wedding is planned.

title: New Hyde Park Moves Into Final
description: New Hyde Park defeated Roosevelt, 35-6, yesterday and advanced to next Saturday's National B championship game; it will meet Oyster Bay at C. W. Post College. The victory was the seventh against one loss for New Hyde Park and Roosevelt finished the season with a 5-3 record.

title: GOOD THINGS FOR ALL SORTS OF PACKAGES
description: Take an American stoneware bowl and nestle within it uneven pieces of caramelized almond candy. Pack individually wrapped spice bars, chewy with apricots and dates (or poppy-seed shortbread stamped out with a bell-shaped cookie cutter), in a shiny black antique cake tin. Stuff a nest of old dry measures - those beautifully simple lidless containers -with thick butterscotch granola cookies made from your own oat mixture.

title: WAR BY ACCIDENT
description: More than 100,000 American military personnel have some form of access to or responsibility for nuclear weapons. A House subcommittee has reported that in 1977 - a typical year - 1,219 of them had to be removed from such duty because of mental disorders, 256 for alcoholism and 1,365 for drug abuse.

title: No Headline
description: DEVILS' SLUMP AT 16; STARS TRIUMPH, 5-1

title: LONG BEFORE 'CATS,' ELIOT WOOED THE THEATER
description: T.S. Eliot - St. Louis-born and Harvard educated - wrote not only the lyrics for ''Cats'' but also the most famous English poem of the 20th century: ''The Waste Land.'' And, thanks to his brilliant albeit contentious essays, he established himself as the absolute arbiter of taste in the Anglo-American literary world. When he attacked Milton, Milton's reputation plummeted. When he praised John Donne, the metaphysical poets, and the Jacobean playwrights, their reputations soared. Mr. Eliot's personal values shaped the literary judgments of his age.

title: A SAMLL BUT CHOICE EXHIBITION AT THE LOUVRE
description: PARIS Short of resorting to what Henry James once called ''the vulgar expedient of leaving the room,'' there is no way these days of avoiding talk about how exhibitions are getting bigger and bigger. Hard and stony is the road of those who think that in general great works of art should stay where they are and that as far as exhibitions are concerned ''small'' may mean ''just as good.''

title: LIGHTNING STARTS OIL BLAZE
description: --Lightning set off a spectacular fire Friday that burned through six 10,000-gallon oil storage tanks before Air Force fire-fighters brought it under control.

title:
DESIGN;
CALIFORNIA DREAMING
description: The whiplash-patterned masonry and broken-tile roof bring to mind such repositories of Art Nouveau architecture as Paris and Barcelona. Yet, given that the structure is brand-new, it probably could exist only where it does -Beverly Hills, Calif., that stronghold of esthetic lawlessness where rules confining style to a particular period and place have never held much sway.

title: NAVAJOS MAY QUIT INDIAN 'OPEC' UNIT
description: When the Council of Energy Resource Tribes was formed in 1975 by leaders of 25 of the West's largest Indian reservations, it boldly compared itself to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: NEW ROCHELLE LAUDS CROWS AND MOUSE
description: NEW ROCHELLE is honoring three of its most famous citizens - Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle -with a sculpture in their honor at the Public Library downtown. The bronze sculpture, created by Michael Lantz, is the first to be dedicted to the Terrytoon Studios, which operated in the city for almost 40 years.

title: WAYS TO MAKE A DOOR UNINVITING TO BURGLARS
description: ALTHOUGH many homeowners (and apartment dwellers) diligently install the best locks they can find on their entrance doors to thwart potential burglars, many do not realize that all the locks in the world will hardly slow up an experienced burglar if the door itself, and the frame in which it is mounted, can be easily pried open or broken through.

title: 3 GOALS FOR RANGERS
description: Mike Rogers scored three goals tonight to lead the Rangers to a 6-3 victory over the Maple Leafs. It was the sixth three-goal performance of Rogers's National Hockey League career, and it came in a variety pack: one power-play goal, one short-handed goal and one goal at even strength.
