His last goal, midway through the third period, was a tip-in of Anders Hedberg's shot, with Hedberg earning his third assist of the game.

title: What's New In Commodities; ANOTHER WAY TO HEDGE: SUB-INDEXES
description: The offspring of the nine-month-old stock index futures markets are now starting to make their appearance -in the form of dozens of subindex futures and options markets.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HONG KONG
description: STEVE LOHR is a correspondent in the Tokyo bureau of The Times.
To the Editor:

title: Just in Case of Frankensteins
description: After two years of examining the possibilities of genetic engineering, a Presidential commission recommended last week that the new technology be assigned a permanent watchdog to guard against all-too-human abuse of power. Advances in controlling inherited characteristics might yield cures for congenital diseases or ways to ease aging, the study group said, but they might also lead to ''unacceptable'' tampering with human genes.

title: CITY AGENCIES TOLD TO SLASH SPENDING 1.5 PERCENT MORE
description: Mayor Koch, accused last week by state officials of not taking strong enough steps to deal with the city's budget problems, has ordered municipal agencies to make deeper cuts in their spending plans.

title: Patricia Vignolo, Dr. John Ranson Have Wedding
description: Patricia Lawrence Vignolo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lawrence Vignolo of Westfield, N.J., and Dr. John Hugh Charles Ranson, son of the Rev. Dr. Charles Wesley Ranson of Lakeville, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Grace Gibb Ranson, were married yesterday in New York.

title: SANTA BARBARA BRACES FOR A NEW BOUT OF OIL FEVER
description: Oil fever is gripping this pleasant community on the California coast again. But instead of riches, many people here are thinking about a day in 1969 when the sea, the beaches and the mood of Santa Barbara turned black.

title: FRIENDS AND OPINIONS AND INFLUENCES
description: THESE THE COMPANIONS Recollections. By Donald Davie. Illustrated. 176 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $22.50.

title: In Albania, They Get Out the Vote
description: Few national leaders can boast of the kind of electoral support Enver Hoxha can marshal in Albania, as he once again demonstrated last week. Still, things may not be as shipshape as the 74-year-old Marxist dictator would like in the isolated Balkan country he has run since 1946.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Timed Sequence Of Price Lowering

title: WILLIAM P. MCGIVERN, 60, IS DEAD, WAS AUTHOR OF 23 MYSTERY NOVELS
description: William P. McGivern, the mystery writer who saw many of his most popular novels adapted for the screen, died Thursday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. Mr. McGivern, who was 60 years old, had been suffering from cancer.

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: Nearly all of the women interviewed in Susan Bolotin's article are pursuing careers in publishing, writing and other fields traditionally more accessible to women.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Where can I get information about group cross-country ski trips that go from country inn to country inn in about five days (with luggage being taken to each stop daily)? - F.M., New York, N.Y. Answer:One group of country inns in Vermont that offers inn-to-inn cross-country skiing consists of the Long Run Lodge in Bristol, the Chipman Inn in Ripton, the Churchill House Inn in Brandon and the Tulip Tree Inn in Chittenden. The five-night package, which costs $325 a person in double occupancy, includes breakfast, trail lunch, dinner and car shuttle service as well as accommodations. The package is available Sunday through Thursday nights (with some exceptions) during January, February and March. For reservations and details write to the Churchill House Inn, R.D. 3, Brandon, Vt. 05733 (802-247-3300).

title: MOLDAVIAN MASTERPIECES
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The Times.

title: 2 CALIFORNIA PAIRS LEADING IN BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: Two top-ranked Californian partnerships were in the lead at the end of the first day's play in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Friday night.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ''IT almost brought tears to your eyes,'' said Dan Toma, who teaches stage lighting at the State University of New York at Purchase, but he nevertheless walked out with an amplifier, some rheostat dimmers and gel frames from the ''tag sale'' at the defunct New Westchester Theater in Tarrytown

title: 'Liberation From The Bronx'
description: To the Editor:

title: LOUISVILLE MAYOR A CANDIDATE
description: Mayor Harvey I. Sloane has declared himself a candidate for Governor in next year's Democratic primary in Kentucky. The Mayor, who is in the first year of his second four-year term, made the announcement Friday at a hospital where he had undergone back surgery. Thursday, Lieut. Gov. Martha Layne Collins, a Democrat, joined the primary race. Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. is barred form seeking re-election.

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: Susan Bolotin's article ''Voices From the Post-Feminist Generation'' (Oct. 17) was splendid.

title: FORECASTERS STUDY NATIONS'S ECONOMY FOR TRENDS ON L.I.
description: THIS is the season of economic forecasts on Long Island. Economists are gathering statistical material and running it by their crystal ball, with the general consensus that 1983 looks like a good year, depending on how long the national recession continues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Free trade serves the cause of economic progress and it serves the cause of world peace.

title: A CAST OF AMERICAN ORIGINALS
description: CADILLAC JACK By Larry McMurtry. 395 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: STOP THE DRIFT TOWARD ECONOMIC ANARCHY
description: The nations of the world are at a crossroad in the conduct of their trade relations. Forces are at work that threaten the international trading system which has been built up since World War II and which has made possible an unparalleled expansion of trade among nations and stimulated economic growth in most parts of the globe.

title: 'FIDDLER' REVIVED
description: ''Fiddler on the Roof'' opens Friday at Neil's New Yorker, a dinner-theater on Route 46 in Mountain Lakes. Larry Zavaglia of Lake Hopatcong will play Tevye, the dairyman in the Russian village of Anatevka, and Stephen Newport of Parsippany will portray Perchik.

title: UP FROM TEXAS
description: THE PATH TO POWER The Years of Lyndon Johnson. By Robert A. Caro. Illustrated. 882 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: PAKULA'S APPROACH
description: John Culhane, author of ''Special Effects in the Movies,'' is writing a book on the making of Walt Disney's ''Fantasia.''

title: RIVER EXHIBIT
description: A 19th-century painting of two girls enjoying a boating idyll on the Bronx River, a work now on view at the Scarsdale Historical Society, pictures a far different waterway than the little-known, half-hidden, rerouted creek of today.

title: MARGIOTTA SHOWS WHO CALLS THE SHOTS
description: DESPITE the turmoil surrounding his leadership, Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, was able to exert a decisive influence in the selection of an upstater, Assemblyman Clarence D. Rappleyea of Norwich, as the new minority leader of the Assembly.

title: AILING DRIFTER GAINS CONTROL OF HIS SHARE OF INHERITANCE
description: Four years after an investigator found him living in a Detroit boarding house, an ailing drifter has won control of his share of a $1.2 million inheritance.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE LITERARY UNDERGROUND OF THE OLD REGIME By Robert Darnton. 258 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $16.50.

title: HE WRITES FOR THE AUDIENCE, BUT ON HIS OWN TERMS

GARDENING;
PUTTING PLANTS TO BED FOR THE WINTER
description: AS the season draws to a close, several suggestions are in order for putting the garden to bed for the winter. At the time of this writing, there is such a deficiency of moisture that New Jersey officials may declare a drought emergency. While we recently pointed out that research has shown late August and September to be the most critical period in relating soil-moisture deficiencies with winter damage, it is still important that plants, especially those that are evergreen, not be allowed to go into the winter dry.

title: 2 DRAMAS SOAR WITH GIANT THEMES
description: JUST when the arts are suffering setbacks because of economic cutbacks, the producers-directors of two local theaters are going all out with productions of extravagant size and sweep.

title: CORONA RETRIAL SPURS LEGAL AND FISCAL BATTLES
description: A protracted legal battle that could result in a third trial for Juan V. Corona is being waged in Alameda County Superior Court in Hayward.

title: THE JOBLESS CAN'T AWAIT AN ECONOMIC UPSWING
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: BULLS HOLD OFF PISTONS, 131-128

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SHOP WITH TIME ON ITS HANDS
description: HADDONFIELD THE shop at 128 Kings Highway East speaks for itself when you open the door -with ticks and bongs and dings and dongs. Appropriately called Timepiece, the store is the repository for the large collection of antique clocks and watches of its owners, Jack and Toni Rubin. As if to attest to a seriousness of purpose, a halfdozen grandfather clocks stand near the entrance.

title: DANCE: MANUEL ALUM PRESENTS NEW 'WOMEN'
description: Manuel Alum, a choreographer who continues to go his own often secretive way, presented a work at St. Mark's Church on Friday night that he calls ''Women.'' Eventually, this will be included in a larger piece called ''Manmade,'' with sections for men, children and what a program note calls ''older dancers.''

title: Why Pelham Dropped Student Soliciting
description: To set the record straight, the Pelham School Board's decision two years ago to stop its elementary students from school-sponsored door-to-door soliciting was not related in any way to Unicef, contrary to the erroneous statement by Edith B. Segall in her otherwise excellent article ''Problems Beset Unicef Drive'' (Opinion Page, Oct. 31).

title: WHEN THANKSGIVING FED IMAGINATION
description: FORTUNATELY, I have not been truly hungry since the Depression days of the 1930's, a time when Thanksgiving was anticipated by children with the same joy reserved for Christmas, birthdays and father's payday. Thanksgiving was a time to happily satiate a hunger that had built throughout the year as rapidly as the rolls of the unemployed.

title: VOLUNTEERS AID STROKE VICTIMS
description: NEW HAVEN THE chance meeting last year on a train from Boston between a speech pathologist, Norma Horwitch, and the actress and stroke victim Patricia Neal, led not only to a friendship between the pair, but also to the eventual establishment of an unusual volunteer program that helps stroke victims.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Revise, Redact, Rewrite

title: Ban on Sail Fiber Stirs a Controversy
description: A decision by the international authority that governs grand prix yacht racing to prohibit the use of Kevlar in sails appears to have stirred strong but varied reactions among United States sailors and sailmakers. At issue, ultimately, is whether grand prix yacht racing should be the open, developmental, end of the sport.

title: TURKEY
description: To the Editor: Eric Newby's article on ''The Romance of Marble Ruins'' prompts me to share an interesting experience on a recent trip to Turkey. v. hile visiting Troy, I noticed a common pattern followed by my tour companions.

title: COMMEMORATING PRINTS
description: Back in 1957, when Universal Limited Art Editions was established in West Islip, prints were considered an outdated medium whose potential had been exhausted. But by persuading such promising young artists as Jim Dine, Helen Frankenthaler, Grace Hartigan, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenberg and Robert Rauschenberg to work with her, Tatyana Grosman, founder of Universal Limited Art Editions, brought the genre back to prominence - and, in the process, established her firm as one of the leading publishers of fine-art prints in the United States.

title: ISRAEL'S LEFT VS. AMERICAN SECURITY INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK REGENTS AGAIN PROPOSE EQUALIZATION OF SCHOOL SPENDING
description: The Board of Regents has recommended that New York State end all operating aid to its wealthiest school districts and use the money to help raise pupil expenditures in the poorest school districts.

title: A RESTORATION
description: After the Trust Company of New Jersey vacated its neo-classical bank building at 12 Hudson Place in Hoboken 10 years ago, an architecture buff, Edward Flaherty, bought the imposing Ionic-columned structure with acanthus-leafed roofline he had long admired.

title: Holes Punched In Draft Law
description: The draft registration law, on the books since the summer of 1980, was declared unfit for further duty last week by a Federal district judge in Los Angeles.

title: John Abernethy Plans To Wed Tracey Smith
description: Mrs. Joseph E. Smith of Port Washington, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Tracey Anne Smith, to John Abernethy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Abernethy of Kingston, N.Y. An April 30 wedding is planned.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BACKS DOWN ON PLAN TO INSTALL BLACK RULE IN NAMIBIA
description: West Africa, Nov. 20 - South Africa was forced to back down today from its plan to install a black-led government in this disputed territory after the leader of the present governing coalition refused to be dislodged.

title: HERO'S SON QUESTIONS PILLAR OF YUGOSLAV STATE
description: Rade Koncar, the father, was a Yugoslav war hero whose name decorates factories, work brigades and streets in many a town and city. Now Rade Koncar, the son, has become a household word as a result of a political dispute he started four months ago.

title: KABUKI: AYAKO UCHIYAMA
description: Ayako Uchiyama presented an ambitious program of classical and contemporary kabuki dance Thursday at the Schimmel Center of Pace University. Known for her research into the culture of the aboriginal Ainu people of Japan, Miss Uchiyama has studied both kabuki and noh dance, and she performed a variety of kabuki styles in a way that never left one in doubt as to her taste and serious intentions.

title: WAYS TO MAKE A DOOR UNINVITING TO BURGLARS
description: ALTHOUGH many homeowners (and apartment dwellers) diligently install the best locks they can find on their entrance doors to thwart potential burglars, many do not realize that all the locks in the world will hardly slow up an experienced burglar if the door itself, and the frame in which it is mounted, can be easily pried open or broken through.

title: 'MESSAGE' CHOREOGRAPHY
description: Birgit Cullberg is one of the best known choreographers in the dance world. It is ironical then that the Cullberg Ballet Company had to wait until this month for its United States debut, which it made as the second entry in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Ballet International'' series. In a way, it has come both too early and too late. Since 1980, the artistic directors have been Miss Cullberg's younger son, Mats Ek, and herself, and the New York engagement was divided between ballets by both. A retrospective of Miss Cullberg's career was not on view. And since Mr. Ek, for all his sophistication as a theatrical director, is a relative novice at choreography, the season did not show a mature artist at work but one who is still finding his way.

title: BLACK POLITICIANS SAVOR NEW STRENGTH
description: During a recent meeting of 100 Black Men, a citywide civic and social group of blacks from business, government, academia and politics, the subject of Brooklyn politics arose. Some suggested that the Nov. 2 elections confirmed a shift in black political power in the city from Manhattan to Brooklyn. Though there was no consensus on that, there was general agreement that the election marked a postponement, if not an end, to feuds between black elected officials in Brooklyn.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Main Event

title: GUIDE TO TRENDS ON DECK
description: VERNON KIDD is a New York-based actor, singer and writer.

title: EAGLE POPULATION INCREASES IN STATE
description: VINCENT DAMONE of Stratford has had a different bird - a much larger one - on his mind during this Thanksgiving holiday season. While fishing recently with a friend at Lake Lillinoah in Brookfield, he caught not a large bass, but the hard gaze of a bald eagle, a bird whose population is increasing in Connecticut.

title: A SON COMES HOME FROM COLLEGE
description: MY stepson, Michael, was standing alone on the platform shifting from one shabby sneaker to the other. He was surrounded by an immense steel and concrete frame. All I heard as my car and I tore up the ramp was the roar of the trains below and the wind sweeping through the empty parking lot. Michael must have arrived early; I never would have been late after waiting, what seemed like forever, to have him home on his first vacation from college.

title: OF SCHOOL 'COMPLIANCE'
description: AS GOVERNOR KEAN and Saul Cooperman, his recently appointed Commissioner of Education, ease into their first year of leadership, the issue of a ''thorough and efficient'' education system for New Jersey looms large.

title: POP: THE ROCHES SING AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Roches fans, a dedicated, even reverent lot, tend to keep their beady eyes glued to the three singing sisters from New Jersey, watching their every move, taking note of the minutest shifts in the group's balance of voices and personalities. And it's catching; the unwary listener suddenly finds himself subjecting Roches performances to detailed analysis -whose idea was that nifty polyphonic passage? Is Suzzy singing better since she lost weight? - instead of having a good time.

title: COURT HEARS APPEAL BY CASINO UNION
description: PHILADELPHIA THE New Jersey Casino Control Commission asked the Federal Court of Appeals here last week to uphold a state mandate that permits it to regulate labor unions in the casino industry.

title: Miss Commander Becomes a Bride
description: Wylene Righton Commander, daughter of Mrs. A. Thomas Bradbury of Atlanta, and the late Robert Charleton Commander, was married yesterday to Robert Francis Baker Jr., son of Mrs. John H. Tiencken of Pinopolis, S.C. The Rev. Harry Fifield performed the ceremony in the chapel of First Presbyterian Church in Atlanta.

title: SOVIET RULERS CHANGE, BUT NOT REAGAN'S VIEWS
description: When urged by top aides to attend the funeral of Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, President Reagan was reported to have responded that going would be un-Presidential and ''hypocritical grandstanding.'' To Mr. Reagan, it all comes down to what he said in January 1981: the Soviet Union reserves to itself ''the right to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat'' to achieve world domination. He has made plain in recent days that he believes this is the way the Soviet Union will be under Brezhnev, Yuri V. Andropov or any other figure.

title: DAVIS STOPPED BY QAWI
description: Dwight Braxton changed his name, but not his nickname. Tonight, fighting for the first time as Dwight Muhammad Qawi, the Camden Buzzsaw defended his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title with an 11th-round technical knockout of a very tough and very game Eddie Davis.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: An Egoistic Diktat In Fortuity

title: WARNING: SEAGOING CAN BE HABIT FORMING
description: ENID NEMY is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: SUBURBAN BUDGETS FEEL THE REFERRED PAIN FROM ALBANY
description: Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, submitted his ninth and final budget last week before he takes up his new job as Lieutenant Governor in Albany, where he says much of his county's fiscal problems originated. ''It all comes down to mandated costs,'' he said. ''The Feds set the direction but the state makes the regulations, and then it becomes a system that is administered by local governments.''

title: TROOPERS SET SIGHTS ON DRIVERS WHO DRINK
description: BLOOMFIELD ''WHEN I've pulled someone over,'' State Trooper Howard Hubbard said, ''I mentally put myself out on the road with my family - not alone, but with my family. From there, I determine whether I want the guy to go on driving.''

title: Hempstead Harbor Art Group's Start
description: Referring to the welcome and generally quite accurate description of new stirrings of unity and activity among the Nassau County artists' groups (''Arts Groups, Buoyed, Act to Unify,'' Oct. 31), I wish to make a correction about the Hempstead Harbor Artists Association Inc.

title: LITCHFIELD SCHOOOL HELPS DYSLECTICS
description: LITCHFIELD ''SPELL 'certain,' Peter.'' ''S-U-R-T-A-N. No, S-U-R-T-I-E-N? No, that's wrong, too.'' ''That's O.K., Pete. You're doing a good job.'' ''C-E-R-T-A-I-N?'' ''Right! That's beautiful.'' Peter is 18 years old, an attractive teen-ager with thick, straight brown hair. He is wearing a tweed sports jacket and corduroy trousers, much like what other boys wear at the Forman School, an independent coeducational college preparatory school in Litchfield.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: EASTCHESTER IT looks like an ordinary horse show. Parents stand around the ring, clutching Instamatics and sipping coffee from styrofoam cups. Ribbons of shiny blue, red and yellow satin are laid out on tables. The animals paw the cold, muddy ground, whinny and exhale clouds of vaporous breath.

title: THE BOYCOTT AGAINST RCA-NBC
description: The Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, chairman of the Coalition for Better Television, does not mince words, especially when it comes to NBC-TV. The network promoted sexual promiscuity and violence, he said last March in announcing a consumer boycott of the RCA Corporation, NBC's parent. ''RCA-NBC,'' he said, ''has excluded Christian characters, Christian values and Christian culture from their programming.''

title: FROMM MOVES UP IN WORLD TENNIS
description: GLEN HEAD WHEN Jimmy Connors, John McEnroe and Martina Navratilova keep winning matches, nobody in this tennis-hotbed area is surprised. After all, they are the world's best. But when a native son makes a breakthrough, as Eric Fromm has done, there is a buzz of excitement.

title: Kerosene Heater Perils Cited
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency is opening an advertising campaign to warn people about the dangers of misusing portable kerosene heaters. The $20,000 campaign is designed to reduce the number of fires and fatalities caused by the heaters.

title: A COLLECTIVE END TO PROTECTIONISM
description: IT comes as no surprise that many search for the quickest, simplest,l east painful solutions to the world economic ills. Unfortunately, m any of those solutions are beggar-thy-neighbor policies. They are like a cancer. They infect even the healthiest of systems. They often masquerade as the temporary quick fix that can be discarded once the crisis passes. But that never seems to happen.

title: Authorities Find Hoard Of Phony Credit Cards
description: A search of a basement apartment in Queens by the state's Organized Crime Task Force yesterday yielded about 3,000 fraudulent credit cards and the pressing and embossing equipment used to manufacture them, authorities said.

title: DANCE: WERKCENTRUM AT SCHONBERG
description: If nothing else, Wednesday night's performance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater suggested how wide the gulf between theory and practice can be.

title: A PERFECTIONIST ON THE PODIUM
description: John Rockwell is a music critic for The New York Times.

title: SELLING OPTIONS ON YOUR I.R.A. STOCK
description: SELLING options on stock in an Individual Retirement Account is b ecoming an increasingly popular strategy. To be sure, it's not for i nvestors who need every penny squirreled away in their I.R.A.'s or t hose who don't have stock in them. But for investors who understand t he strategy, some brokers say, it could help beef up an I.R.A. p ortfolio's return while sheltering that income.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN FIXING INDIAN PT. ATOM-DISASTER PLAN
description: Half of the 34 deficiencies in the emergency plan for New York's Indian Point nuclear power plants have been ''sufficiently addressed,'' officials told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission Friday.

title: HUNTINGTON
description: ON particularly humid summer days, an acrid blend of sewage and perfume intended to mask it permeates the air around Huntington's main sewage-treatment plant on Creek Road in Southdown. The clam beds in Huntington Harbor are polluted and closed. And heavy downpours overload the cracked sewage lines with more ground water than the treatment plant, built in 1917, can accommodate.

title: SPECIALISTS ASSESS REAGAN AT MIDTERM
description: In a midterm assessment of the Reagan Presidency, scholars and specialists gave Ronald Reagan high marks for ideological consistency and technical political prowess.

title: No Headline
description: PITT WINS, 52-6, AND ACCEPTS BID TO THE COTTON BOWL

title: PINTER RETURNS TO PROBE THE DARKNESS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes frequently about theater in London. LONDON

title: STAGE: 'DAVID & PAULA,' BEN-GURION AND WIFE
description: ''David and Paula,'' the new play by Howard Fast in performance by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y, is a two-person drama about two periods in the lives of David Ben-Gurion, the first Prime Minister of Israel, and his American-born wife, Paula.

title: RACES SAID TO TURN ON ABORTION
description: WHITE PLAINS ''IF Lehrman had been 'pro-choice' he would have won in Westchester and New York State,'' Polly W. Rothstein, director of the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion, said in a post-election statement last week. ''If George Morrow had not taken the Right to Life line, he would have been re-elected.''

title: CITIZEN'S GUN USE ON RISE IN HOUSTON
description: Tommie Phillips conceded that he was ''pretty nervous'' when he pointed his 20-gauge shotgun at the tall man in black gloves who had pried open the back door of his trailer home.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: CITY REJECTS PENTAGON PACT FOR HOSPITAL BEDS
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, which operates the largest municipal hospital system in the country, has rejected a request by the Defense Department that it formally allocate a percentage of its beds to the care of American military casualities in the event of a conventional war overseas.

title: LAME AND DEAD DUCKS
description: Congress and the nation are once again faced with the dismal prospect of a lame-duck session - one that is held after Congressional elections but before newly elected Senators and Representatives begin in January to serve their terms.

title: Cynthia Furco Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Furco of West Haven Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Furco, to Dennis Thoelen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thoelen of Brooklyn. An April wedding is planned.

title: 'FATHER SERGIUS,' FROM RUSSIA
description: ''Father Sergius,'' the 1978 Russian film that opens today at the Film Forum, is like its title character -sorrowfully handsome, passionate and unworldly. It's Leo Tolstoy's posthumously published novella, adapted and directed by Igor Talankin, about a fearfully self-righteous aristocrat, Prince Stepan Kasatsky (Sergei Bondarchuk), and his lifelong search for spiritual perfection.

title: NIGERIANS PREPARE FOR 1983 ELECTION
description: Next year Nigeria will stop doing most other things for a month, and the nation's attention will be focused exclusively on a series of state and national elections.

title: AN ERA ENDS AS CASSETTES SURPASS DISKS IN POPULARITY
description: Not all historic moments announce themselves with a fanfare. Some happen quietly, almost unnoticed, like the turning of the tide. A tidal change of this kind now seems to happening in music. After nearly a century of undisputed dominance, the traditional phonograph is yielding to the challenge of cassettes.

title: BASKETBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (NBA) - Activated La- S alle Thompson, top draft choice, and w aived Leon Douglas, veteran forward- c enter. FOOTBALL HOUSTON (AFC) - Activated Adger A rmstrong and Stan Edwards, running b acks.

title: 5-Lateral Kickoff Return
description: Kevin Moen, a defensive back, scored on the end of a five-lateral kickoff return with no time left on the clock today to give California a 25-20 upset victory over Stanford in a Pacific 10 Conference game.

title: Garvey Limited by Pressures
description: A year ago, the National Football League Players Association said its top priority in the 1982 negotiations was to win ''a fixed percentage of the tremendous revenues'' generated by professional football.

title: NEW GUINEA
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the article on New Guinea in the round-up, 'Venturing Into the Primitive World' (Travel Oct. 10). I spent four weeks there this summer and would like to share some of my own observations.

title: IN VERMONT, SKIERS SCHUSS TO 'SLOPESIDE'
description: CONDOMINIUMS By CAROL LAWSON IN THE not-so-distant past, people looking for a skiing base in V ermont were shown ''chalets,'' the real-estate industry's romantic t erm for a single-family dwelling in the snow. These days, however, t he chalet and the fanciful Swiss mountain images it suggests are t aking a backseat to a more practical creation of contemporary life - the condominium.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Parade Watching Decades ago department stores around the country launched the Christmas shopping season with the Thanksgiving Day parades. For 56 years Macy's has sponsored the local Turkey Day strut, which will be telecast by NBC on Thursday from 9 A.M. until 12 noon - rain or shine, snow or sleet. CBS will also cover New York's parade in addition to four others nationwide, though NBC's coverage of the New York affair is far more extensive than CBS's - NBC cameras not only cover the actual parade but also record the staged variety show in Herald Square.

title: SOUTHAMPTON FINDS A PATH TO UNITY
description: SOUTHAMPTON THE people in this resort town fall into three groups. Some are permanent residents who live and work here year-round. Some make it their secondary residence and earn their money elsewhere. Some just come for a fling.

title: PLUM I. MAY TURN TO OUTSIDE LABOR
description: SECURITY is tight at the Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center, where Government scientists in sterile smocks study virulent foreign animal diseases in biologically sealed laboratories. And until recently, job security at the United States Department of Agriculture facility was one of the assets of some 255 Government support-workers there.

title: WHY ONLY ONCE A YEAR?
description: AS the great American feast-day approaches, Long Islanders prepare their thanks - to the Providence that has provided the bounty, to the relatives for still speaking to one another, and even to the turkey for not being tough and inedible. Why, though, must all this thanking be reserved for one day in the month of November? Couldn't we spread the gratitude around all year and upgrade all of our lives?

title: Black Arizona Bishop Is Jailed Over Shootout
description: A bishop of an all-black church in Miracle Valley has been jailed in lieu of $25,000 bond on charges stemming from a shootout last month that left two church members dead.

title: WINTER'S FOREBODING
description: THE blackbirds swept down from the top of the hill today, devouring the beckoning red dogwood berries, stripping each tree as they came to it.

title: What's New In Commodities; BETTING THE DOW WITH YOUR TURF ACCOUNTANT
description: One of the fastest - and riskiest -ways to trade the stock market today is to take out a bet with a London bookmaker on the Ladbroke Index.

title: IDLED STEELWORKERS SAY UNION MUST MAKE STAND
description: Outside the tunnel entrance to the sprawling Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation plant, Rick Gratson recalled that his father's generation, in May 1937, staged a strike that added pressure for the first major agreement negotiated by the fledgling steelworkers' union. It established a 40-hour work week and a wage of 63.5 cents an hour.

title:
DINING OUT;
BEYOND THE MOCK BATTLEMENTS
description: YOU might have noticed the Castle Continental Restaurant, smiled at the frankly silly mock battlements and passed it by. We had, until one Saturday evening caught in a heavy rain we sought shelter within the crenelated walls. Judging by the number of cars in the parking lot, the place has an enthusiastic following of those who have seen beyond the facade and the two humorless, white plaster gladiator guards to the homey comfort within. This castle is indeed a snug haven, nurturing and protecting its inhabitants from the dusty common traffic of Route 9. Red-curtained picture windows allow only the view from the back: greenwood stands, stream and statuary.

title: RUDIMENTARY TOOLS HELPED PILGRIMS SURVIVE FIRST YEAR
description: LATE in November 1621, members of a small English colony, survivors of a year of devastating sickness and near-starvation, celebrated the symbol of their endurance - their first harvest of a crop of maize or Indian corn, planted near their small fort and hastily built huts, where they shared a meager inventory of utensils and tools.

title: WHY 'TUCKER'S WITCH' MISSED THE MARK
description: It was an unabashedly derivative idea - a detective drama centered around a married couple - with a tiny novel twist: the female character would double as a witch with telekinetic powers.

title: Sue Ann Dubin Is Engaged to David Jeffrey Wald
description: Jane Binder Dubin of Valley Stream, L.I., and Howard Dubin of Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sue Ann Dubin, to David Jeffrey Wald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Wald of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CRANBERRIES: USE NOW AND FREEZE FOR LATER IN YEAR
description: BAGS of cranberries are making their yearly appearance in markets everywhere, in time for the holiday season. Prices seem to be holding at last year's level, generally about 79 cents for a 12-ounce bag. This year's harvest was a record, up 10 percent over last year. But despite the abundance, by December the cranberries will be gone until next year.

title: PLAIN FOLKS AND PUZZLING CHANGES
description: SHILOH AND OTHER STORIES, By Bobbie Ann Mason. 247 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: SYMPHONY WINS APPLAUSE
description: THERE were many new faces in the ensemble as the White Plains Symphony began its 28th season and Paul Dunkel his first as the orchestra's music director. As a longtime orchestral musician - the young maestro is also a superb flutist - Mr. Dunkel obviously knows how to get the best from his players, and he has also recruited a number of top New York freelancers to fill first and even secondchair positions. I have never heard the White Plains Symphony sounding better than it did Nov. 6.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LAST spring, a bright orange swath of canvas with beige lettering that read ''Chinese Cuisine'' was stretched around a square frame above a Main Street doorway in Port Jefferson. The new awning provoked a dispute that may lead to an amendment to the village zoning code.

title: EMOTION UNMASKED AT RACCOON DEBATE
description: MAYOR Jean L. Stone welcomed Scarsdale residents to ''Raccoon Night'' last week and, soon after, the fur began to fly. ''Are we here to protect the raccoon or to kill the raccoon?'' asked Quentin McDonald, one of about 75 village residents at the meeting.

title: Elizabeth A. Dillworth, John Pitney Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John T. Dillworth of St. Davids, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Dillworth, to John Duncan Pitney, son of Mrs. Anderson Fowler of Gladstone, N.J., and J. Duncan Pitney of Mendham, N.J.

title: Opposition To a Landfill
description: This letter is in response to the article ''Protests Rise Against Oceanside Landfill'' (Oct. 31). The people of Oceanside are justified in demonstrating their opposition to the continued operation of the local landfill.

title: SHORE REGIONAL RETAINS TITLE
description: Tim Britton, a senior tailback, ran for 136 yards and two touchdowns to help Shore Regional defend its Central Jersey, Group 2 title with a 23-3 victory over Princeton yesterday in Princeton.

title: Elizabeth Kendrick, W.M. Garner Wed
description: Elizabeth Dale Kendrick, an assistant corporation counsel with the Office of the Corporation Counsel for the City of New York, and W. Michael Garner, an associate with the New York law firm of Rivkin Sherman & Levey, were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Albert Ahlstrom, a Lutheran minister.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: Eric Newby's interesting account of a trip to the ancient sites of Turkey, ''Romance of Marble Ruins'' (Travel, Oct. 16), contained one glaring error: The famous basilica in Ephesus is indeed built over the tomb of John, but not John the Baptist. Admittedly, there is confusion over exactly which John tradition refers to when speaking of the site, but John the Baptist was long deceased, beheaded by Herod in Judea during the time of Christ's early ministry.

title: BREAKING TRADE BARRIERS
description: ON WEDNESDAY, trade representatives from the United States and more than 80 other nations that are signatories to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) will meet in Geneva to establish an agenda of trade issues to be negotiated during the remainder of this decade.

title: West Georgia 31 Widener 24
description: Harold Long scored on a 5-yard run in the third overtime period as West Georgia eliminated Widener, the defending national champion from Chester, Pa., 31-24, to advance to the semifinals of the Division III playoffs.

title: SCHEDULE FOR HEARINGS
description: Following is the schedule of hearings by the Bipartisan Commission on State Tax Revenue and Related Fiscal Policy to get the views of the public on the commission's proposed options to deal with Connecticut's fiscal problems:

title: THE HEROES WHO LIVE NEXT DOOR
description: IT'S a scenario that is acted out many times in the course of a year. The calm that settles on the world in the middle of the night is shattered by a call for help. In house after house, the pager blares out and immediately rouses a sleeping man, who propels himself like a guided missile into his car while struggling all the way into turn-out gear.

title: SOLAR POWER PLANT IN CALIFORNIA SHINES IN ITS PRELIMINARY TESTS
description: The biggest solar power plant in the world is working well enough in preliminary testing so that construction of another, 10 times as big, is under consideration.

title: ARTISTRY ABOUNDS IN EXHIBIT OF CRAFTS
description: NEW HAVEN THERE are some beautiful pieces of contemporary decorative art on view at the Creative Arts Workshop, which is holding its 14th ''celebration of American crafts'' through Dec. 23. Objects in the exhibition and sale, held every year at this time to benefit the workshop, are chosen partly by jury and partly by invitation, and include some of the finest work by the nation's artists and craftsmen.

title: Poi
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TOWN MEETING' DEBATES THE BOMB
description: THE debate over the morality of nuclear arms stretched from Washington, D.C. to Irvington last week. As the nation's Roman Catholic bishops met in the capital to discuss the draft of a pastoral letter opposing nuclear weapons, about 500 students and adults from Irvington gathered to debate ''Living in a Nuclear Age - What Are Our Choices?''

title: Recent Sales
description: Holmdel $145,000 24 Heyward Hi Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; *2*deck, partially finished basement, carpeting; taxes $2,258. Long Branch $127,500 Marine Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; *2*deck, waterfront property; taxes $1,900. Manalapan $150,000 6 Crown Court *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; *2*air-conditioning, full basement, deck; taxes $2,058. Middletown $89,000 245 Harvey Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 28-year-old ranch; *2*new roof, air conditioning, screened porch; taxes $1,458. Monmouth Beach $199,000 18 Gull Point Road *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; *2*waterfront property, Jacuzzi, sauna, double *2*fireplace, air-conditioning; taxes $3,406. Rumson $260,000 102 Ridge Road *2*6-bedroom, 6-bath colonial; slate terrace, *2*partial basement, 2 acres; taxes $5,050. OTHER AREAS Ossining, N.Y. $99,500 1 White Birch Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old raised ranch; deck,patio, *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, 1/2 acre; taxes $3,307. Westport,Conn. $136,500 10 Covelee Drive *2*3-bedrooms, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old ranch; *2*near private beach and boat club; 1/4 acre, taxes; $2,166. Huntington, L.I. $240,000 218 Bay Avenue *2*5 bedroom, 3-bath 10-year-oldcustom ranch; *2*2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen, family room; taxes $4,525.

title: A NEW MESSAGE FROM WESTERN UNION
description: TWO notable telecommunications companies are approaching $1 billion in revenues this year. One is 14-year old MCI Communications, a long distance telephone service provider. The other is Western Union, the oldest company in the business, founded in 1851.

title: LAWYER TELLS OF LYING BY DELOREAN INFORMER
description: A court document is said to show that the man identified as the Government's chief informer in the drug case against John Z. DeLorean and William M. Hetrick had lied twice under oath about Mr. Hetrick in an earlier, unrelated case.

title: CITY AND STATE JOUST OVER REMOVAL OF BILLBOARD
description: The top legal offices of New York State and New York City have been asked to help resolve a jurisdictional dispute involving state and city agencies on who has authority to order the removal of a billboard cigarette advertisement on the Upper West Side.

title: STATE AUTHORITY SEEKS PERMIT FOR CONTROVERSIAL POWER LINE
description: The State Power Authority has formally applied for a permit to build a controversial 180-mile high-voltage power transmission line through central New York State at a cost of $555 million.

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: My reaction to the ''the post-feminist generation'' is outrage. There stands Rachel Flick, age 23, secure in her editorial job, disdaining older feminists for their ''incredible bitterness.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Some copies of today's Times carry an incorrect picture caption with an article on page 72 about Presidential Christmas cards being donated to the Smithsonian. The photograph shows President Carter's 1977 card.

title: ST. JOSEPH PREVAILS, 13-7, TO TAKE CHAMPIONSHIP
description: St. Joseph of Trumbull won the Metropolitan Bridgeport Inter-Scholastic Athletic Conference championship for the second straight year yesterday, defeating Fairfield Prep, 13-7, at Bridgeport's Kennedy Stadium.

title: IRAQ SAYS U.S. AND SOVIET ALLOW IRAN TO BUY ARMS
description: A high-ranking Iraqi official said today that the United States was permitting the sale of arms to Iran by American companies overseas.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CRUISE CONSULTANTS
description: In this era of increased specialization, it should come as a surprise to almost no one that even travel agents are confining their activities to particular areas of the industry. Hence, the advent of the cruise consultant.

title: CAN IMPARTIAL COURTS COEXIST WITH PRETORIA POLICE POWER?
description: White South Africans, who are sensitive to the charge that their country is a police state for most of its inhabitants, habitually comfort and defend themselves by pointing to the tradition of an independent judiciary that coexists in a seemingly permanent state of paradox with the system of arbitrary police powers.

title: FED FINALLY CUTS THE DISCOUNT RATE
description: The Federal Reserve Board cut its key discount rate to 9 percent from 9.5 percent, effective Monday. In an unusual statement accompanying the announcement of the cut, the Fed cited the economy's continued sluggishness. The markets have been waiting for the cut, but analysts said that the delay since the last cut on Oct.8 indicates that the Fed now will allow rates to fall only gradually. This interpretation is based on a speech Tuesday by Fed chairman Paul A. Volcker in which he said the Fed would not tighten monetary policy simply because money supply indicators were above targets.

title: Jury Convicts Drifter In 3 Shooting Deaths
description: Robert Dale Henderson, a 37-year-old drifter who has admitted to killing 12 people in five states, was convicted today of first-degree murder in the shooting deaths of three hitchhikers.

title: Philip Frances Rizzuto Jr.  Marries Ann Guthrie Smith
description: Ann Guthrie Smith, daughter of Mrs. Charles Joseph Miller of Kiawah Island, S.C., and the late William Faber Smith Jr., was married yesterday to Philip Frances Rizzuto Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rizzuto of Hillside, N.J. The Rev. Morris J. Lent Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C.

title: CYNICAL JETS FACE KUSH AND COLTS TODAY
description: More cynical than they were two months ago, the Jets go back to work today at Shea Stadium by playing the Baltimore Colts, a team with a hard-driving coach who hopes his players are too young to have been affected by the 57-day players' strike.

title: Diana Laylin Is Married
description: Diana Morgan Laylin of Great Falls, Va., widow of John Gallup Laylin, was married yesterday in Washington to Philip Young of Van Hornesville, N.Y., a widower. Superior Court Judge Robert M. Scott performed the ceremony at a private home. The bridegroom, former dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, was with the Eisenhower Administration as Ambassador to the Netherlands, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, adviser to the president on personnel management and a member of the White House staff.

title: Charitable Offerings
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Art Is the Ploy Nov. 27 and 28 - Art '82, the 15th annual art and sculpture show and sale sponsored by the Greater Teaneck (N.J.) Section of the National Council of Jewish Women offers something for everyone from a $15 print to a $6,000 sculpture. The event in the Field House on the Fairleigh Dickinson University campus in Teaneck gets under way with a preview reception Saturday from 7:30 to 10:30 P.M., followed by a supper dance at the Commons. The hours Sunday are 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. with an admission charge of $1.50 ($1 for the elderly and students.) Patron tickets, $30 per couple, admit holders to the preview. Angel tickets, $75 per couple, admit holders to the preview and the supper dance. Golden Angel tickets, $130 per couple, not only admit holders to the preview and the supper dance but also entitle them to a lithograph by Tony Canger. The show, the section's major fund-raising endeavor, netted more than $10,000 last year for community services in Bergen County and Israel.

title: ON MAUREEN HOWARD
description: After reading ''Grace Abounding,'' Maureen Howard's latest novel, I went back and reread ''Not a Word About Nightingales,'' her first one. I had liked it when it was originally published in 1960, and now, as I read and liked it again, I wondered whether this meant that I hadn't ''grown'' or advanced in 20 years, as the novel form itself is said to have done.

title: A HARLEM HOSPITAL SURVIVES ITS CRISIS
description: A year ago, North General Hospital was in jeopardy. A severe financial crisis had forced the facility, the only voluntary teaching hospital in Harlem, to defer paying its employees and contemplate closing its doors to the medically underserved community.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: NOT unlike most of the nation and the world, New Jersey is still compiling an inventory of its fauna and flora and trying to piece together a picture of its ecological history.

title: A RESTAURANT SAVED
description: WATERBURY AT FIRST glance, the one-story red-brick building seems to have stood forever where it is now, on Leavenworth Street, across from the courthouse. A sign, ''Drescher's Restaurant,'' is still in place, but the door and several of the windows are boarded up, and the greenand-white scalloped awning is ripped.

title: WHOSE LIFE IS IT, ANYWAY? LEGALLY IT'S HARD TO TELL
description: What Elizabeth Taylor wants to know - and what the law doesn't clearly tell her - is whose life is it, anyway? More specifically, can ABC go ahead and produce a ''docu-drama'' based on Miss Taylor's life even over the movie star's vociferous objections?

title: Pakistan's Leader Sees; Fresh Soviet Approach
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that he detected ''some freshness'' in the Soviet approach to Afghanistan during his talks this week with the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov.

title: SETTING A DIPLOMA'S VALUE IN DIVORCE
description: Matrimonial lawyers call it the medical school syndrome. The classic case is that of the young nurse who puts her husband through medical school. When he receives his diploma, she receives a divorce summons.

title: LEVER HOUSE AWAITS THE DECISION ON ITS FUTURE
description: Is Lever House worth saving? Nothing could speak more clearly of the passage of time than the mere fact that such a question might have to be asked. Lever House, after all, is a modern building, and a postwar one at that: it is the glass tower on Park Avenue that was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and hailed as the vision of a new age when it was completed in 1952. Lever House's thin vertical slab, which appears to float on a horizontal slab that is set on columns in an open plaza, was one of the most powerful images of modernity produced by the 1950's. It was Park Avenue's first glass skyscraper, and only New York's second after the Secretariat Building of the United Nations, and it is no exaggeration to say that it was Lever House, more than any other building, that set midtown Manhattan's postwar redevelopment in a new direction.

title: East Islip and West Islip Win Semifinals
description: Pat McIntee rushed for 145 yards on 24 carries and scored three touchdowns to lead East Islip to a 25-3 victory over Northport in the Division I semifinal playoffs. It was the ninth straight victory for undefeated East Islip, which will meet West Islip for the championship next Saturday. West Islip gained the championship round by defeating Sachem, 10-0, for its eighth triumph against one loss.

title: WHEN TWO OLD FRIENDS MAKE A FRIENDLY MERGER
description: AFRIENDLY merger is Forrest N. Shumway's idea of a good match. And now the cigar-smoking head of t he Signal Companies has just put together what could be the f riendliest combination of his career: a merger with W heelabrator-Frye, an environmental, energy and engineering company h eaded by his good friend, Michael D. Dingman.

title: Mrs. Bhutto in Munich
description: Nusrat Bhutto, the widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former Pakistani Prime Minister who was executed in 1979, arrived here from Karachi today to cheers and floral tributes from about 100 supporters who oppose Pakistan's military Government. She is in West Germany for treatment of suspected lung cancer.

title: INDONESIA SQUEEZING GUERRILLAS IN EAST TIMOR
description: Western diplomats here say the leftwing guerrilla movement that has warred since 1975 against Indonesia's occupation of the former Portuguese colony of East Timor has been reduced to a force of several hundred.

title: What's New in Commodities; A PLAN TO SIC THE EAGLE ON THE KRUGERRAND
description: At last the Treasury thinks it has found a way to curb the outflow of billions of dollars that American gold bugs spend each year on South African Krugerrands and other foreign gold bullion coins. Their solution: Mint and sell one-ounce and half-ounce ''American Eagle'' bullion coins - and make any trading profits on them immune from Federal capital gains and state sales taxes.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JAZZ A celebration of the music of Thelonious Sphere Monk - started when a quartet of musicians calling themselves Sphere recorded an album of Mr. Monk's compositions last February - is continuing this week at Lush Life, Thompson and Bleecker Streets, where Sphere is playing for five days beginning Wednesday.

title: Met Opera to Start Vocal Recitals Dec. 12
description: The Metropolitan Opera will begin a new annual series of vocal recitals Dec. 12 with a recital by the tenor Nicolai Gedda, who will be celebrating the 25th anniversary of his Metropolitan Opera debut.

title: First Bowl Bid For Kansas St.
description: Kansas State, which has played football for 87 years and had never gone to a bowl game, today accepted a bid to the Independence Bowl after defeating Colorado, 33-10, in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: 'Purring Bundles' at the Polls
description: Dr. Edgar Berman, he of the raging hormones theory of female vulnerability, is not a man to change his mind about woman's place. ''Just as the rowdy kiddies of the 60's went back to home economics and dental school at the birth of the 70's,'' he said recently, ''so shall this feminist uprising recede into history in the 80's.''

title: IMPERIAL ADVENTURE
description: ''BENEVOLENT ASSIMILATION'' The American Conquest of the Philippines, 1899-1903. By Stuart Creighton Miller. Illustrated. 340 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: HARVARD TROUNCES YALE, 45-7
description: The 99th Harvard-Yale game today provided the second most decisive victory by Harvard in the series, a 45-7 decision that earned the Crimson a share of the Ivy League title.

title: On Whom the Toll Falls
description: While legislative leaders and transit officials pondered how high to raise the fare last week, some subway riders in New York City were taking matters into their own hands and lowering it. A token costing 17 1/2 cents issued for the Connecticut Turnpike, they discovered, also fit turnstiles in the city.

title: NEW GUINEA
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-HOSTAGES TALK OF IRANIANS
description: Two of the 52 Americans held captive in the United States Embassy in Teheran said today that they felt no animosity toward the Iranian people.

title: ON THE FRONTIER
description: To the Business Editor: Karen Arenson has lost a good point. The stagnancy that existed in 1932 was by no means lifted by F.D.R.'s New Deal, nor by Keynesian moves.

title: A 'HIGH-WIRE ACT' IN ZIMBABWE DESERVING OF WESTERN APPLAUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: J. Cowan Stark to Wed Jane Hyland in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Hyland of Nissequogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Leslie Hyland, to J. Cowan D. Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. David C.C. Stark of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Christina Susan Irwin Will Be the Bride In June of Steven Roger Astrove, Lawyer
description: The engagement of Christina Susan Irwin to Steven Roger Astrove has been announced by Elizabeth Irwin of Norfolk, Conn., and Dr. Michael H.K. Irwin of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Astrove of Larchmont, N.Y.

title:
ART;
SNUFF BOTTLES AT THE HAMMOND
description: NORTH SALEM AT the Hammond Museum through Dec. 12 is one part of an extraordinary four-museum exhibition devoted to Chinese snuff bottles. Asia House in Manhattan and the Montclair and Newark Museums in New Jersey are collaborating with the Hammond in the unusual joint enterprise, in connection with the 14th annual conference of the International Chinese Snuff Bottle Society that was recently held in Manhattan.

title: WHEN CLARITY IS THE DEVIL'S WORKSHOP
description: Now that almost everyone is convinced that complete understanding is the key to a good relationship, along come communications experts who disagree. Not only is complete understanding irrelevant and unexciting in a relationship, they believe, but it can even be dangerous.

title: SAVORING THE ISLAND HARVEST
description: For the visitor to the Caribbean, the abundant pineapples, bananas, coconuts, grapefruits, avocados, limes, corn and okra require no introduction. Even the bunches of tiny, finger-size bananas look familiar.

title: S.M.U. IN BOWL AFTER 17-17 TIE
description: Down by 7 points with six minutes left, undefeated Southern Methodist University drove to a touchdown on a 2-yard quarterback keeper by Lance McIlhenny and kicked an extra point for a 17-17 tie with Arkansas today.

title: International
description: Pope arrives in Sicily for long- awaited visit 3 Around the World 5 Indonesian troops are squeezing guerrillas in East Timor 7 Son of a war hero challenges the pillars of the Yugoslav state 10 Report says rights situation in Nicaragua deteriorates 11 Costa Rica's pro-American policy wins support 12 Mexican leaders warn U.S. on immigration legislation 13 In a Lebanese mountain village, a clash in a new civil war 15 Nigerians' attention focusing on next year's election 17 Nazi war criminals become an issue in Canada 19 U.N. employees complain of ''a crisis of morale'' 20 Prominent Turks protest being jailed as ''common criminals'' 22 Government/Politics Head of Humanities Endowment assails some course offerings 32 Polls indicate Catholics will back bishops on nuclear wars 34 Stevenson looks forward to Illi- nois recount in governor race 37 Billboard poses jurisdictional problem for city and state 39 City rejects Pentagon plan for hospital beds 43 Dovish Rep. Addabbo delivers war work to his district 47 General Around the Nation 26 Number of citizen shootings ris- ing sharply in Houston 27 Much of the recordings from Wil- liams' trial are unprintable 29 Draft resister sees court victory as vindication of his views 33 Navajos threaten to quit Indian energy group 36 Three persons die in the collision of two planes in Jersey 40 Two California partnerships lead in bridge pair tourney play 45 Religion Church reassigns three aides in dispute over case in South 35 Black Harlem bishop meets his collegues amid controversy 41 Arts/Entertainment Music debuts in review 70 ''The Great Magoo'' is revived 70 ''Father Sergius,'' 1978 Russian film, opens 71 Style Setting a diploma's value in di- vorce 72 Christmas cards of Presidents go to the Smithsonian 72 Obituaries William P. McGivern, the mys- tery writer 44 Abraham Pomerantz, pioneered lawsuits for sharholders 44

title: Wilson Convicted Of Aiding Libya
description: Edwin P. Wilson, the former intelligence agent accused of using his black talents to help Libya arm and train terrorists, had maintained all along that he was acting on behalf of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: AIR QUALITY IS GROWING CONCERN
description: TWO Long Island communities, two environmental quandaries. In Port Washington, tests by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency revealed small amounts of vinyl chloride on a golf course and at an elementary school. The findings rekindled concern about hazardous substances emanating from the Town of North Hempstead's landfill, which borders the two sites where the chemical was detected.

title: ALL-PURPOSE MENU FOR ALL PALATES
description: REMSEN'S GARDEN RESTAURANT in Greenvale tries to offer something for everyone. One element that seems to be missing from this new, large and elaborately decorated multilevel installation in the Wheatley Plaza shopping center is the actual garden. Instead, there are abundant plants, brass railings, ceilings that are either tented in fabric or coffered in plastic, discreet neon signs, lampposts and touches of Art Nouveau. The dining room is bathed in a rosy glow.

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: Susan Bolotin suggests that ''college may no longer be a good place to have one's consciousness raised.'' I disagree. The young women and men in their 20's are light-years away from the sex-role stereotypes prevalent when I went to Northwestern in 1955.

title: Bonn Captures No. 1 Terrorist
description: West Germany's most sought-after terrorist was nabbed last week while working hard at his trade. Christian Klar, one of the few leaders of the Red Army Faction still at large, was digging an underground arms dump in the woods near Hamburg, when police caught him.

title: Giants Are Healthy And Ready To Play
description: The Giants can hardly wait to hear the cheers - and the boos -from spectators deprived of half of the National Football League season when pro football returns to Giants Stadium at 4 P.M. Sunday. The Giants will reopen the season against the Washington Redskins.

title: A Boxer's Plan To Help Boxing
description: To the Sports Editor: I'd like to express my condolences to the family of Duk Koo Kim. This was a tragedy to the Kim family and also to boxing.

title: GROWING UP JAPANESE
description: TOTTO-CHAN The Little Girl at the Window. By Tetsuko Kuroyanagi. Translated by Dorothy Britton. 195 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $9.95.

title: HOTEL-CASINO ACQUIRES TEMPLE
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE final religious service to be conducted at Beth Israel Synagogue, which was dedicated in 1914, took place early this month. At the conclusion, the keys to the 68-year-old temple were turned over to Resorts International Hotel-Casino.

title:
GARDENING;
PUTTING PLANTS TO BED FOR THE WINTER
description: AS the season draws to a close, several suggestions are in order for putting the garden to bed for the winter. At the time of this writing, there is such a deficiency of moisture that New Jersey officials may declare a drought emergency. While we recently pointed out that research has shown late August and September to be the most critical period in relating soil-moisture deficiencies with winter damage, it is still important that plants, especially those that are evergreen, not be allowed to go into the winter dry.

title: THE LIPPIZAN STALLIONS WILL BE PRANCING INTO TOWN
description: When the organizers of the forthcoming American tour by the Spanish Riding School of Vienna asked the chief of the renowned horse ballet to supply some promotional art, he sent nothing but photos showing the graceful heads of 26 white stallions.

title: Heights Oversight
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Plans Safety Experiment With Air Bags in Police Cars
description: Air bags will be installed in 130 Arizona police cars as a safety experiment, the Transportation Department said Friday.

title: WALESA HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH PRELATE
description: Lech Walesa, the recently freed leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, met for two hours today with the Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp.

title: Susan Schelpert And Kent Murray To Wed in Spring
description: Dr. and Mrs. John William Schelpert 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., have annouced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Appleyard Schelpert, to Kent Lachlan Murray, son of Fay Stickney Murray of Ardmore, Pa., and Donald Lenford Murray of Gloucester, Mass.

title: LEARNING THE CITY POSITION
description: THIS is a city of point guards. That was another thing Edmund Sherod had to learn in his crash course as a New York Knickerbocker: Everybody sitting in Madison Square Garden has the mentality of a point guard.

title: NEW SUPPORT GROUP IS FORMING TO AID CRIB DEATH PARENTS
description: ''MY son Daniel was two days short of 4 months old. It was the day of Christmas Eve. I had put him down for a nap. When I found him, he was slightly blue and limp. I grabbed him and my daughter, Laura. There was snow on the ground and I had no shoes on.'' She rushed out as she was.

title: What Price Security?
description: Question: When my wife and I moved into a one-bedroom apartment, we paid two months' security, approximately $1,000. Does New York law prohibit taking more than one month's security?... B.M.,Nanuet, N.Y. Answer: The state General Obligations Law requires that interest be paid on deposits in buildings with six or more units, and sets other standards. But there is no state law that sets a limit on the amount of deposit that can be charged, although various localities have their own regulations. Charging two months' security is less common than charging one month's, but it is a practice of some landlords, according to the Citizens Guide to Housing, published by the Office of the State Ombudsman. For a copy, write to Raymond Charles, Room 4530, 2 World Trade Center, New York 10047.

title: MORE THAN EVER; COMMUTERS NEED ROLE IN POLICY
description: ABOUT a year and a half ago I decided that commuter silence is not golden and became active in various organizations that give the weary train traveler a clear, resounding voice. I exchanged my lunch-hour shopping for meetings on how bonds float and trains lose their shoes, and gave up ''Hill Street Blues'' for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's ''Performance Progress Report.''

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: Susan Bolotin was shocked that 60 percent of the young women interviewed in a recent poll plan to stay home with their children anywhere from two to six years.

title: MUSIC: CONERTO BY KEN NODA
description: The key element in any performance of a Mozart piano concerto is balance. Any lack of synchronization between piano and orchestra is, of course, immediately apparent.

title: The Need for Doctors On the East End
description: The Oct. 31 article ''East End Seeks More Doctors'' might appear to counter the scenes viewed by a visitor to Southampton. Judging from the plethora of luxury automobiles bearing M.D. license plates seen here, one wouldn't think of Southampton as being a ''medically underserved'' area.

title: Bargain Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; 57 + 9 + 16 Equals XVII
description: WHEN the National Football League's 57-day strike ended, Jim Murray, the general manager of the Philadelphia Eagles, joked: ''Retire that number. Nobody should ever wear 57 again.'' But today John Woodring will be wearing that linebacker's number for the Jets and Byron Hunt will be wearing it for the Giants in the resumption of the nine-game season that will qualify 16 teams for the Super Bowl XVII tournament.

title: Suzanne R. Israel Married To Robert Tufts, Athlete
description: The marriage of Suzanne Rose Israel, daughter of Henriette Israel of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Abraham Israel, to Robert Malcolm Tufts, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Tufts of Lynnfield, Mass., took place yesterday.

title: BLACKSMITHS STILL FORGING CAREERS
description: BEDFORD HILLS THE horse-and-buggy age may be only a memory, but there are believed to be more blacksmiths in the rolling hills of northern Westchester today than there were 100 years ago.

title: A MAVERICK AND A STAR REMAKE THE CLASSIC 'BREATHLESS'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. LOS ANGELES

title: THE PSYCHIC TOLL OF THE NUCLEAR AGE
description: The Psychic Toll of The Nuclear Age Thank you for Robert Jay Lifton's article ''The Psychic Toll of the Nuclear Age,'' Sept. 26. Dr. Lifton eloquently states the case for the abolition of nuclear weapons because of what their existence is presently doing to humanity.

title: PRESIDENT'S PROCLAMATION
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation

title: Christie A. Lozier To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Christie Allison Lozier, to Poul-Erik Heilmann has been announced by her father, Raymond Westervelt Lozier of Suffield, Conn., formerly of Closter, N.J. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Heilmann of Greenwich, Conn., and Norwood, Va.

title: TURKEY
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed the article about travel in Turkey, since we followed essentially the same route as the author last year and had a wonderful time, much of it attributable to the charm of the Turkish people. How they love to talk.

title: MEDICAL BOARD IS HELD UNLIKELY TO ALTER POLICY
description: CARE leaders in New Jersey predict that the latest appointments to the state's Board of Medical Examiners, whose disciplinary practices have been the focus of controversy, are not likely to change the board's direction.

title: WILD TURKEYS MAKE A COMEBACK
description: WILD turkeys were once 12,000 strong in Connecticut, and their abundance, coupled with their size, and of course taste, made them so valuable to New England settlers that turkey was the main course at the first Thanksgiving dinner.

title: CONCERT: NEW WORKS BY YOUNG VOICE
description: At first, devoting an entire concert to new works of a 27-year-old composer seemed foolhardy. Even the composer's program notes, written with a self-conscious sense of ''oeuvre,'' seemed more precious than prescient.

title: Debra Pergament Is Betrothed to Andrew Levine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pergament of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Pergament, to Andrew Levine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Levine of New Haven.

title: 'Capturing' Winter
description: A leading nuclear physicist, Theodore B. Taylor, set out in 1980 to develop a new energy-saving concept at Princeton University: a thermal storage system that used insulated ponds of water to heat and cool buildings.

title: PHILADELPHIA PRESS PACT
description: --The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News reached agreement on a new contract Friday with a mailers' union, averting might have been the second strike against the newspapers in less than two months. 'We are very satisfied, very happy about the whole thing,' said Andy Walter, a member of the Newspaper and Magazine Employees Union. The settlement was approved by the union.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH CAROLINA FALLS TO DUKE, 23-17

title: UNDERWATER SITE PROMOTED
description: JERSEY CITY MUNICIPAL officials here are making elaborate plans to market 16 acres, 14 of them under the Hudson River, for commercial development. The underwater property, which would extend the downtown commercial district at Exchange Place right into the river, almost became the new home of the American Stock Exchange in 1977. It has been considered prime development property ever since.

title: Singles
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Waits for a Signal from Moscow, Peking Gets One
description: Hardly had Leonid Brezhnev been laid to rest than the Kremlin, under the new management of Yuri V. Andropov, got down to official business - most conspicuously the business of a reconciliation with China. The largest gathering of foreign dignitaries in Soviet history was on hand, including 32 heads of state and 15 prime ministers, but the Soviet leaders and press singled out Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua for special attention and unusual warmth.

title: Cambodian Rebel Arrives in Peking
description: Son Sann, a leader in the Cambodian rebel coalition formed to drive Vietnamese troops out of Cambodia, arrived in Peking today for a state visit, the official New China News Agency reported.

title:
GARDENING;
PUTTING PLANTS TO BED FOR THE WINTER
description: AS the season draws to a close, several suggestions are in order for putting the garden to bed for the winter. At the time of this writing, there is such a deficiency of moisture that New Jersey officials may declare a drought emergency. While we recently pointed out that research has shown late August and September to be the most critical period in relating soil-moisture deficiencies with winter damage, it is still important that plants, especially those that are evergreen, not be allowed to go into the winter dry.

title: AREA WATER SHORTAGE 'BEARS WATCHING'
description: GUSHING through a 500-foot deep tunnel, under pressure, a major portion of New York City and Westchester water supplies pours into the Kensico Reservoir after a journey of 70 miles or so from the Neversink Reservoir.

title: Dorothy Darlington to Be Wed Dec. 24
description: Staff Sgt. Dorothy Sillcox Darlington and Gunnery Sgt. Charles Francis Findley, both of the Marine Corps, plan to be married Dec. 24 in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Andrea Miller Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Miller of Cincinnati have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Elysse Miller, to Jay Robert Hyman, son of Elsie Hyman also of Cincinnati, and the late Charles Hyman. A June wedding is planned. Miss Miller is a buyer at Gidding Jenny, a Cincinnati clothing specialty store, of which her father is president and owner. Mr. Hyman is an assistant buyer with the H.& S. Pogue Company, a department store in Cincinnati.

title: N.F.L. ATTEMPTS TO RETAIN IMAGE
description: In 1977, after the National Football League had signed new fiveyear contracts with the players association and with the major television networks, Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, was asked what possible problems the league might encounter in this period of expected equanimity.

title: STATE POLICE BADGES GO TO NEW GRADUATES: 7 DOGS
description: It was graduation day today for the newest members of the state police - seven German shepherd dogs. They had just completed an 23-week training course in police work, with emphasis on sniffing and tracking.

title: Koch's New Balancing Act Hits the Road
description: Mayor Koch's latest medicine for fiscal deficiency was too much for the State Financial Control Board to swallow last week. No sooner had the board taken its first official glimpse at the tax-raising and belt-tightening plan than a call was made for immediate and ''major'' changes.

title: 'A Hockey Solution'
description: The telegram was concise. ''Congratulations,'' it began. ''It took a hockey man to straighten out football with a hockey solution.''

title: Emily Rose Pitman Wed
description: Emily Rose Pitman, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Adams of New York and Dr. Ernest Richard Pitman of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric Pugatch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pugatch of Manhasset Hills, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at Temple Judea in Manhasset.

title: Reagan Lifts Sanctions While Standing on 1 Leg
description: President Reagan got precious little quo for his pipeline quid last week from the West Europeans. Acceding to their demands, he lifted sanctions on equipment for the Soviet natural gas pipeline. But the French promptly dismissed as ''premature'' the President's accompanying announcement of ''substantial agreement'' on stronger measures to control trade with Moscow in future. And British Foreign Secretary Francis Pym insisted that the Europeans had made ''no concessions'' in return for the pipeline action.

title: Malta Curbing Imports
description: The Government of Malta, where 7.8 percent of the work force is unemployed, has banned the importation of 49 items and announced plans to promote local industry. The list includes products already made locally and ranges from soap and shampoo to shoes, clothing and leather goods. The Government attributes the high unemployment to the international recession, which has resulted in a drop in exports and a slump in tourism.

title: Coast Judicial Panel Lifts Ban On Tape Recorders in Courts
description: Tape recorders will be allowed in California courtrooms for use by lawyers, journalists and the public for the first time next year, the California Judicial Council decided today.

title: E.P.A. Makes a Deal on Toxics
description: In what the Government called the biggest financial settlement of its kind and environmentalists considered an escape from potentially higher costs, the Velsicol Chemical Company agreed last week to spend $38.5 million cleaning up four toxic waste sites in St.Louis, Mich.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ART The first thing to be said about Robert Colescott's paintings at the Semaphore Gallery, 452 West Broadway, is that they make us laugh aloud. Sass personified, he is to painting what Richard Pryor is to the nightclub.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
HOW SUPERB ACTORS CAN EMBARRASS A SCRIPT
description: Everybody knows, or at least everybody's always said, that truly superlative actors can salvage almost any kind of text, beginning with the telephone book. And each of us could undoubtedly make up a considerable list of theatrical experiences in which wobbly scripts were ennobled, or enabled to turn a profit, by the powerhouse skills of the people who played them. I personally do not intend ever to subject myself to a reading of the telephone book by anyone, but I agree that the miracle can and does happen. It's not even a miracle, it happens all the time.

title: SHE DOES HER DANCING WITH STRINGS
ROMANTICISM LIVES
description: The romantic period of chess came to an end about 100 years ago, yet some of today's players perform as though 100 years of progress has escaped their attention.

title: Portuguese President Vetoes a Military Law
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes vetoed a military law today, fueling tension between the President and Portugal's rightist Government.

title: IOWA TOWN, RACKED BY FLOOD, SEEKING AID FROM 23 NATIONS
description: Mayor Jack Evan, his appeal rejected by the Federal Government, says he hopes that at least one of 23 foreign governments will respond to his plea for financial aid for Emerson, racked by a flood in June.

title: NEW BREED OF BOTANIST TURNS FROM MONOGRAPHS TO MANKIND
description: In an earth-floored laboratory at the Cary Arboretum in Millbrook, N.Y., David Karnosky piped polluted air into a plastic tent under which several young trees were growing. In a nearby field Jay MacIninch hung balls of human hair on tree branches. Some 2,000 miles away in the jungles of Colombia, Ghillean Prance made notes on a species of palm tree.

title:
STAMPS;
NEWEST ADDITION TO THE GREAT AMERICANS SERIES
description: Igor Stravinsky, who has just become the latest personality to be honored in the new Great Americans series of definitive United States issues, was once asked by a guard at a border crossing to declare his profession. His answer was ''an inventor of music.''

title: F.D.A. REGULATION--AT WHAT PRICE?
description: IN response to the Tylenol poisonings, the Food and Drug A dministration on Nov. 5 issued new regulations for tamper-resistant p ackaging for over-the-counter drugs. The regulations followed weeks o f investigation by the F.D.A., which established that the greatest d anger to consumers comes from tampering with products after they h ave been placed on the retail shelf. Thus, regulators specified thatn ew packaging should first and foremost alert the consumer that the c ontainer has been opened. Now that the alert is on, it is time to a lert the consumer to excessive regulation.

title: COSTA RICA'S PRO-U.S. POLICY SEEMS TO PAY OFF
