description: When President Luis Alberto Monge took office last May, he inherited a country gripped by its worst economic crisis this century and caught in a region convulsed by political violence. His only hope, he told aides, was to convince Washington that Costa Rican democracy was worth saving.

title: Judge Backs Namath
description: Joe Namath will be able to keep his driver's license, even though he refused to take a Breathalyzer test after being arrested on charges of drunken driving in Tamarac, Fla., last Sept. 23. Under Florida law, drivers who refuse to take such a test can lose their licenses for 90 days.

title: AN ASSAULT ON RELIGIOUS FREEDOM IS BEING MOUNTED
description: THE scene is Rome, the time A.D. 64. A fire destroys much of the city. Nero, by now the unpopular Emperor, is suspect. Desperate, the fearful leader blames the Christians, a small cult that refuses to worship Caesar and that is rumored to practice incest and cannibalism. Many Christians are tortured to death.

title: ABRAHAM POMERANTZ, 79, PIONEERING LAWYER
description: Abraham L. Pomerantz, a lawyer who pioneered shareholder suits against major corporations and for a time directed the prosecution of German industrialists after World War II, died yesterday in New York City. He was 79 years old and lived in New York.

title: THE POST-FEMINIST GENERATION
description: If young women today are more career-oriented and pragmatic than the ''idealists'' of the 1960's, consider the educational debts of thousands of dollars that we must begin to repay upon graduation from college, due in part to Federal cutbacks in educational grants. CAREN HALBFINGER Bennington College Bennington, Vt.

title: VOTING DOWN A NEW STEEL PACT
description: United Steelworkers president Lloyd McBride (right) said he was ''disappointed'' by the rejection of a renegotiated contract with eight major steel producers.

title: No Headline
description: PHALANGISTS' RADIO SAYS BEIRUT REJECTS TERMS SET BY ISRAEL

title: JUDGE TELLS F.B.I. TO PAY COST OF ARIZONA NEWSPAPER'S SUIT
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to pay $14,225 in legal costs incurred by The Scottsdale Daily Progress in connection with litigation involving the Freedom of Information Act.

title: A Clarification From Mel Brooks
description: Mel Brooks reluctantly denied last week that he is the funniest man in America.

title: WAITING FOR RECOVERY, EVEN OPTIMISTS BEGIN TO WORRY
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, the Administration's chief economic spokesman and frontline optimist, is getting scared. And so are many others. Short-term interest rates have dropped about three percentage points since July. The underlying inflation rate, reflected in last week's report that wholesale prices rose a seasonally adjusted 0.5 percent for October, is down to 5 percent from the 1980's double-digit rates. The Fed has cut the discount rate, the rate it charges financial institutions, from 12 percent to 9 percent - the last half percentage point came Friday - and says it won't get in the way of recovery.

title: DANCE: RACHEL HARMS
description: Good dances speak for themselves through movement and, in the long run, what is most important is not what choreographers have in mind but what is in their dances. Nevertheless, it can often be instructive to hear choreographers describe how certain ideas for moving were eventually put into motion.

title: CANADA SEEKS TO RESTORE SOVIET SCIENCE EXCHANGES ,
description: A Canadian delegation has completed two days of discussions in Moscow on the possible restoration of scientific and cultural exchanges that were ended by Ottawa after the 1979 Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 8 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 12 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 3 12 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 4 4 13 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 5 6 6 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction sequel to ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 6 15 2 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 7 5 2 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Continuing the journey through the solar system begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 8 7 9 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel.

title: THANKSGIVING EVENTS RECALL PAST FEASTS
description: LIKE Thursday's traditional turkey dinner, Thanksgiving-related activities in the county will linger on beyond the official holiday. Most, in fact, won't even begin until after the holiday.

title: Nascar Title Is on the Line
description: In each of the last four seasons, the championship of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing has been decided in the last race of the year. Today, like last year, the winner of the Winston Cup, either Darrell Waltrip or Bobby Allison, will be determined on a road circuit in the desert near Riverside, Calif., far from the sport's base in the Southeast.

title: MEXICANS OPPOSE U.S. ENTRY CURBS
description: Business and political leaders in Mexico have told the United States that passage of a comprehensive immigration bill now pending in Congress would seriously harm relations between the two countries and ''foster political unrest'' if it was effectively enforced.

title: Johanna O'Brien to Be Bride
description: Johanna Sage O'Brien and Rodolphe Eric Hottinger will be married on Dec. 9 in Boissy St. Leger, Val De Marne, France. The bride-to-be is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. O'Brien of Washington, Conn. Mr. Hottinger is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henri Hottinger of Paris.

title: IN FRANCE, A PILGRIMAGE INTO PREHISTORY
description: JEAN M. AUEL is the author of ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' and ''The Valley of Horses'' (Crown). She lives in Oregon.

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1982
description: International Unrestricted world trade was endorsed by President Reagan amid growing demands for protection of domestic industries in the United States and Europe. In a radio speech on the eve of the meeting of the world's trade ministers in Geneva, Mr. Reagan said that government restriction on free trade ultimately posed a threat to peace. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES RESTRICTING TRADE TO HELP INDUSTRY
description: President Reagan sought today to quiet growing demands for protection of domestic industries in the United States and Europe, saying that Government restrictions on free trade ultimately posed a threat to peace.

title: 7 Selected for Lasker Awards
description: Seven medical scientists noted for their work in the small world of enzymes and viruses last week were honored by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation for their basic and clinical research.

title: Auction Action
description: To the Editor Your interesting article on ''Bidding for Bargains at House Auctions'' (Oct. 24) should have included the thorny aspect of how to get the former owner out of the house once you have become the successful bidder.

title:
LEISURE;
WILDFLOWER PROTECTION BEGINS IN THE HOME GARDEN
Same Old Crisis, Same Old Faces
description: After 42 governments since 1945, Italy may be running short of Prime Minister material. Last week, 74-year-old Amintore Fanfani, who led four of those governments, was brought out from the relative obscurity of the presidency of the Senate to try to end the latest crisis.

title: PEKING LEADER ACCUSES SUPERPOWERS OF BEING THREAT TO ASIA
description: China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, was quoted today as saying that the United States was unpopular in Asia because of its regional interference.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: volume edition. A MARGIN OF HOPE, by Irving Howe. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.)

title: John Gault Jr. to Wed Deborah Gutoff
description: Announcement has been made by Simone Firestone Gutoff of Westport, Conn., and Reuben Gutoff of Bridgehampton, L.I., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Lynne Gutoff, to John Edward Gault Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gault of Chicago.

title: WALL STREET'S CASH MANAGEMENT BATTLE HEATS UP
description: AT a quick glance, Wall Street has never seemed more like Easy S treet for the nation's largest securities firms. Since the bull m arket took shape in August, business has been booming - the Dow J ones industrial average has pierced its way to a record high, t rading volume seems to top 100 million shares every day and the p rice of brokerage stocks is soaring. After a recent trading session,o ne firm even ordered champagne sent to the floor of the New York S tock Exchange.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: PIG farming used to be a big business in New Jersey, with Secaucus as one of the leading areas for raising and slaughtering. Most of this business is now in the Deptford area of South Jersey, where farmers raise as many as 1,500 pigs at a time; however, the farmers are learning that getting the waste food they need to feed their hogs is becoming more and more difficult.

title: Adelaide Sinclair, 82, Former Unicef Official
description: Adelaide Sinclair, one of the highest ranking women at the United Nations until her retirement in 1967, died in Ottawa Thursday night. She was 82 years old.

title: MIND'S BIOGRAPHER' PLANNING TV SERIES
description: ''BETWEEN my bald head and my Viennese accent,'' said Leopold Bellak of Larchmont, ''I guess I represent psychiatry.'' Dr. Bellak, a psychologist, psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, has written and will narrate a series on ''The Human Mind'' for the Public Broadcasting Service. He completed the pilot last month and the series' 10 episodes, he said, will ''trace the human mind from ancient culture, including later developments, the contributions of Freud and current advances.''

title: NEWSLETTER STARTED FOR FOREIGN BORN
description: ''WE are starting a newsletter in simple English. It is for the foreign born in Westchester. It is for speakers of all languages and levels of English. We want it to be about what you need to know. We want it to be about what interests you.''

title: IN A YEAR OF CONCESSIONS, THIS UNION MADE GAINS
description: EGGED on by a demonic gaggle of snugly insulated sportswriters, a lot of Ed Garvey's members in the National Football League Players Association are calling for their leader's scalp. As a reporter who has kept an eye on strikes and settlements in industry generally for nearly half a century, I wonder what all the screaming is about. The contract Mr. Garvey began initialing last week may go down to defeat in Tuesday's ratification vote, but it is light years ahead of any contract negotiated by other unions this year in the dramatic nature of the advances it promises for the players and their organization.

title: THANK YOU ---EVEN FOR REAGANOMICS
description: THANK you for this house, which has managed to accommodate our active family of four for two years and still keeps humming. Except for the refrigerator. Which is now trilling.

title: SANDINIST RULERS CHIDED ON RIGHTS
description: Human rights in Nicaragua have ''deteriorated, though not irreversibly,'' according to a new report about to be released by the Americas Watch Committee, a New York-based human-rights group.

title: THE PSYCHIC TOLL OF THE NUCLEAR AGE
description: It is difficult to think of anyone who wants nuclear war or who isn't touched by the threat of it, but preoccupation to the point of attributing all current behavior patterns to our fear of nuclear war is quite another thing.

title: FOOTBALL: IT'S NOT FOR MEN ONLY
description: EAST HARTFORD THE wide receiver sprints down the sideline, feints going right and, with the defensive back faked out of the play, cuts left and gathers in a 35-yard pass from the quarterback for a touchdown.

title: A YOUTH ORCHESTRA AND HOW IT GREW
description: THERE'S an old joke about the man who stood crying at the back of the auditorium while the school symphony played ''My Old Kentucky Home.'' ''Are you a Southerner?'', asked a neighbor, touched at this display of sentiment. ''No,'' sobbed the man, ''a musician.''

title: COLUMBIA LOSES BAKER FINALE
description: In the last football game in the 60-year history of Baker Field's wooden stadium, Columbia lost to Brown, 35-21, in a contest that ended with the fans on the home side booing and literally tearing up the seats.

title: Suspected Smuggler Slain at Texas Border
description: A man suspected of smuggling marijuana was shot and killed and two United States Customs Service officers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire on the Rio Grande late Friday.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Last week proved to be a unusual for debuts, presenting much strong playing and at least one concert that seemed to break out of the genre.

title: Hilary Fowler Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Emma Fowler Black of New York and Lawrence, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Hilary Ludlow Fowler, to Antony Patrick Clinton Northrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony E. Northrop of Hadlow, Kent, England.
Hoboken MUSIC was percolating through the streets of this riverfront city well before Frank Sinatra sang at the Clam Broth House and then did his best to obliterate his ties to his native town.

title: ONE DAY HE SPOKE THE NAME OF GOD
description: THE FALSE MESSIAH By Leonard Wolf. 278 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: Mary Anne Wadsworth to Be Married
description: The engagement of Mary Anne Wadsworth to Lawrence Allnutt Darby 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis L. Wadsworth Jr. of Plymouth, Mass. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Darby Jr. of Dawsonville, Md., and the late Mr. Darby.

title: A TIME TO CHEER CHEERLEADERS
description: ALMOST 1,000 girls from 60 county schools wil be competing in the 34th yearly Westchester Cheerleading Festival at the County Center in White Plains on Nov. 30 and Dec. 1, in what is generally considered on of the most sparkling shows on the center's calendar.

title: 'VAC-WOMAN' STRIKES AGAIN
description: EVERYWHERE these days you read helpful hints on how to make a better body, a better quiche and a better bust line. But seldom do you run across hints that truly revolutionize your life, such as one I recently read, advising housewives how they could combat boredom on the job.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS BUCKING ECONOMIC TIDE
description: NONPAROCHIAL private schools are flourishing in New Jersey, despite a declining number of school-age children and a stagnant economy.

title: POPE BEGINS VISIT TO MAFIA STRONGHOLD
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in Sicily today on a long-awaited pastoral journey to Italy's most troubled region, where the Roman Catholic Church has recently taken its strongest action against the Mafia.

title: ST. JOHN'S PATIENCE REWARDED: SCHOOL WINS 3d STRAIGHT TITLE
description: The St. John the Baptist football team has proved this season that patience pays off. The Central Islip, L. I., squad lost two of its first four Catholic High Schools Football League games, but did not panic and went to win its four games to qualify for the league championship contest.

title: FOR LEBANON, 'A DIRTY WAR' IN MOUNTAINS
description: At a bend in a road of this foggy mountain village, an Israeli Army major confronted the commander of a group of local Moslem militiamen today. They had a terse discussion about the latest killings in what appears to be turning into a new, small but growing Lebanese civil war.

title: Eat What You Are
description: Russell Baker's article ''Eat What You Are'' (Sunday Observer, Oct. 10) accurately expressed my own ambivalent feelings about health-food regimens.

title: Executive Stress
description: To the Business Editor: N.R. Kleinfield's article, ''The Chief Executive Under Stress'' (Nov.7), over-emphasizes the prevalence of stress for upper-level management and totally excludes the notion of stress as an ''energizer,'' which often leads to productivity.

title: SINKING FAST
description: For a suburban Chicago couple, a peaceful evening at home was shattered some time ago when an avalanche of National Geographics crashed through an attic floor into their upstairs bedroom. An hour later, and the couple would have been buried alive in bed in mounds of glossy photographs of weird fish and scantily clad natives with salad plates under their lips.

title: CONDOS VS. WATER?
description: A NEW militancy is arising among some Hamptons property owners in regard to new housing and condominium projects around them. One hundred fifty residents of the Red Creek enclave in Hampton Bays have banded together as Save Good Ground Water to block a planned community of 216 homes and condominiums on 290 wooded acres near bucolic Red Creek Pond.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Shipping Cars To Florida
description: Ducks and geese are not the only birds that head south for the winter. Thunderbirds and Firebirds and the like - as well as their owners - winter there, too.

title: WAGNER BOWS IN PLAYOFF, 43-34
description: Undefeated St. Lawrence came back with 30 points in the second half to eliminate previously unbeaten Wagner, 43-34, in the quarterfinals of the Division III football playoffs yesterday on Staten Island.

title: UNCOMMON DEFENSE
description: Arecent attempt to arrange a match in Washington between the Senate and the British House of Lords fell through when overtaken by political events. If, as is likely, the idea is revived, the outcome of the match is perhaps predictable.

title: HUNTERS' TABLES IN THE NETHERLANDS
description: MICHAEL KAMMEN, a professor of American history and culture at Cornell University, received the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1973 for ''People of Paradox: An Inquiry Concerning the Origins of American Civilization.''

title: PANEL TO TAKE TAX OPTIONS TO THE PUBLIC
description: HARTFORD AFTER seven months of studying how Connecticut raises and spends its tax money, a bipartisan commission will tour the state starting at the end of the month to get public reaction to a package of options that likely will presage new or higher state taxes in 1983.

title: Two-Time Rookie
description: Cal Ripken Jr., the Baltimore Oriole shortstop, became the first player in the 24-year history of the Topps Major League Rookie All-Star Team selection to be named to the team for the second year. How can a player be considered a rookie two times? A rookie is defined in baseball as a player who has not exceeded 130 times at bat in a season.

title: On the Frontier
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''On the Frontier of a New Economics'' (Oct. 31) by Karen Arenson.

title: Gazpacho
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking It Rich Off California
description: When oil companies paid record prices to lease unexplored tracts off the California coast last year, they were pretty sure of finding something other than fish. Last week, as Texaco Inc. added a ''giant oil discovery'' to others already announced in the Santa Maria Basin, industry experts said the field was probably the richest discovered since Alaska's Prudhoe Bay find in 1968.

title: PRICE SUPPORT FEE ON MILK DUE DEC. 1
description: Despite an impending reduction in price support payments, American dairy farmers have continued to increase milk production, causing another sharp rise in the amount of butter, cheese and dried milk that the Government must buy and store.

title: A Spanish Colonel Is Charged With Plotting to Stage Coup
description: A Spanish infantry officer who was transferred soon after the discovery of a coup plot last month has been charged with conspiracy to rebel, the Defense Ministry said today in a statement.

title: Q. & A. WITH VICE PRESIDENT OF BUILDERS ASSOCIATION
description: JOSEPH MARGOLIS is executive vice president of the New York City B uilders Association. The organization's 300 builders, s ubcontractors, engineers, suppliers and brokers construct most of t he private homes in New York City. In 1981, their production fell by4 0 percent, and this year's completions are expected to be even l ower. In a recent interview, Mr. Margolis discussed what may be a head for builders and home buyers.

title: ANTIQUES: THE QUEST FOR ANCIENT GREEK RARITIES
description: The appetite for Greek antiquities, always strong, has increased dramatically since ''The Search for Alexander'' opened two years ago at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. Since then, the exhibition has been viewed by about 1.4 million people in five other cities, a national tour that will end when the show, now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, closes there Jan. 3.

title: Glens Falls Paces Swim
description: The 200-yard medley relay team from Glens Falls broke its own state record and qualified for all-America status to highlight the New York State girls' scholastic swimming championships at Nottingham High School today.

title: A NEW AND CONTROVERSIAL SHORT-TERM PSYCHOTHERAPY
description: Like a drowning man, Richard Jones was floundering in panic, losing hold on his life. A multitude of phobias made it impossible for him to drive a car, board an airplane, ride the subway, enter an elevator or be alone in an open space. The thought of going to a movie or to a restaurant paralyzed him with fear that the place might catch fire and that he would be trapped inside. As he became more frightened, he grew increasingly depressed and was plagued by chronic headaches. Richard's efforts to get help - seven years in treatment with two psychotherapists and attendance at a special phobia clinic - had failed. Desperation made him test one more hope of cure - a psychiatrist who specializes in an unusual form of brief therapy.Within six weeks, Richard began to feel positive signs of change. After 32 hourlong sessions, he was completely cured, and in a followup meeting with the therapist four years later, Richard could honestly report that not one of his symptoms had ever returned.

title: JOHN ADAMS AND MADISON CAPTURE P.S.A.L. TITLES
description: James Madison High School of Brooklyn won its second Public Schools Athletic Association B Division title with a 36-8 victory over previously undefeated Far Rockaway.

title: Carey Lowers Sentences For Nine State Inmates
description: Four state prison inmates are now eligible for parole and five have had their sentences for drug convictions reduced, under a series of executive clemencies ordered by Governor Carey.

title: Steelworkers Not Budging
description: Threats of more layoffs or no, it's better to get than to give back, the United Steelworkers of America decided once again last week.

title: STEVENSON LOOKING FORWARD TO A RECOUNT IN ILLINOIS
description: It has long been assumed that, one way or another, the Cook County Democratic Party can be depended on to deliver votes for a candidate, and it happened again Nov. 2.

title: NEW YORK CITY FINANCES---REASON FOR WORRY, AGAIN
description: ''THE worst pain is behind us,'' Mayor Koch said last January when presenting his financial plan for 1981. And it seemed to many that New York City's chief executive was right.

title: THREE OFFBEAT SHOWS WITH A CONCEPTUAL BENT
description: No one can demolish an artist's work with quite as much flair as another artist. There's considerable evidence of this in ''The Destroyed Print,'' a show billed as a ''collaborative artwork'' between Jeff Russell and some 60 other artists at the Pratt Manhattan Center Gallery, 160 Lexington Avenue (at 30th Street, through Dec. 11). On the other hand, it's a show that despite its title deals more with ''con-'' than ''de-''struction, and in the process sets us to marveling once again at the power of art to make something out of nothing.

title: Deborah Dietzer To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. M. Walter Dietzer of Old Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ayers Dietzer, to Vance E. Polley, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Max E. Polley of Davidson, N.C.

title: RHETORIC DOING THE WORK OF THOUGHT
description: THIS QUIET DUST And Other Writings. By William Styron. 305 pp. New York: Random House. $17.50.

title: EXECUTIVE STRESS
description: To the Business Editor: N.R. Kleinfield notes early that drinking is one of the maladaptive coping methods that some business leaders use. Recent years have seen a rapid growth in Employee Assistance Programs (E.A.P.) designed to identify and help workers whose personal problems are adversely affecting job performance.

title: YOUNG PRO AT HOME ON COURT
description: Mark Talbott, the youngest player on the World Professional Squash Association tour, lives in a squash court. The 22-year-old Talbott is the only touring pro who makes his living entirely from tournament winnings. His home, while he is on the eight-month circuit that runs from Mexico City to Toronto, is a pickup truck with a white camper that he constructed with wood from a squash court that was dismantled by the Detroit Athletic Club.

title: IRAQ HAS POLTICAL GAINS TO SHOW FOR ITS TROUBLE
description: This country, now in the third year of its war with Iran, is in a paradoxical position. Militarily, Iraq is on the defensive, protecting its borders against Iranian attacks - thus far with success. Politically, it has taken the offensive - emerging, in the view of its leaders and of diplomats here, as the defender of stability in a region where instability is among the great fears, especially for Saudi Arabia and other rich but almost defenseless nations of the Persian Gulf.

title: RECITAL: KIM KASHKASHIAN, YOUNG VIOLIST
description: Kim Kashkashian has become a regular on the local music scene, with recitals and frequent chamber-music concerts. Her work has long been congenial, especially in chamber music, but it has not always suggested a very bold self-assertiveness. Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House, Pro Musicis presented the young violist in a recital that at its best revealed a growing artistic command.

title: BETWEEN SCYLLA AND CHARYDBIS
description: LOUIS INTURRISI, who teaches English at the University of Rome, lived in Messina for a year as a Fulbright scholar in Sicily.

title: PREDATORY URCHINS
description: To the Editor: Let me add another story to that recounted by Charles Burroughs Jr.

title: No Headline
description: Dartmouth 43, Princeton 20

title: RECITAL: VADIM BRODSKY
description: Vadim Brodksy, the first Soviet artist to perform in New York City since the cultural freeze three years ago, is an excellent violinist. His tone is full-bodied, his temperament directly emotional, his playing breathtakingly accurate.

title: SUTHERLAND AND BERGANZA-A STUDY IN CAREER CONTRASTS
description: The recent appearances here of Joan Sutherland and Teresa Berganza, each a highly successful event in its own way, had to set off a chain of memories and speculations for anyone whose listening experience dated back to the beginnings of two important though very different careers. Both Miss Sutherland, the Australian super-soprano, and Miss Berganza, the Spanish coloratura contralto, have specialized in florid singing of the sort associated with the vague but useful term, bel canto. Although Miss Berganza, at 47, is nine years younger than Miss Sutherland, their international careers actually began about the same time. Miss Sutherland was a comparatively late bloomer, but when she broke into view it was as a fully formed singer, a soprano Athena springing fullblown from the head of Richard Bonynge, her mentor, husband and designated conductor.

title: Kathleen E. Richards Engaged to Gordon Babcock
description: The engagement of Kathleen Elizabeth Richards to Gordon John Babcock has been announced by her mother, Dr. Mary Robinson Richards of Tenafly, N.J. Mr. Babcock is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hamilton Babcock of Massey, Ont.

title: NEW GUINEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Skidding Nets Still Make Costly Errors
description: When the door to the Nets' locker room was opened after they were drubbed Friday night by the Portland Trail Blazers, 118-108, Buck Williams anticipated the questions:

title: Bennett G. Schmidt Is Fiance of Shelley Jill Cohn
description: The engagement of Shelley Jill Cohn to Bennett Glick Schmidt has been announced by Marcia Y. Cohn of New York and Gerald L. Cohn of Hazleton, Pa., and Sacramento, Calif., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Alfred Friedman and Marvin Schmidt of St. Louis.

title: DESPITE U.S. RECESSION, AN OPTIMISTIC L.I. FORECAST
description: Long Island's economic tempo can be expected to improve modestly in 1983 despite the continuing national recession, according to Chemical Bank's annual economic forecast.

title: METHODIST CHURCH SHIFTS 3 IN DISPUTE
description: A top executive of the United Methodist Church and two other staff members have been reassigned after a dispute over their support for Eddie Carthan, the former Mayor of Tchula, Miss., who was recently acquitted of charges of conspiracy in the murder a political opponent.

title: WHY SOME ECONOMICS WORK
description: THE RISE AND DECLINE OF NATIONS Economic Growth, Stagflation, and Social Rigidities. By Mancur Olson. 273 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $14.95.

title: EXPERIMENT IS OUT, CONCERN IS IN
description: THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1982 Selected from U.S. and Canadian Magazines. Edited by John Gardner with Shannon Ravenel. 374pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95.

title: 2 More Latin Leaders To Meet With Reagan
description: President Reagan will meet with leaders of two more Central American countries on his tour of Latin America next month, the White House announced today.

title: ELECTRONICS IS CREEPING INTO THE CONCERT HALL
description: Once again the word ''acoustics'' penetrates th'ambient ether all over the hemisphere. There has been much publicity about the five grand concert halls that, in September, opened in New Orleans, Toronto, Baltimore, Peoria and Eugene (Oregon). Actually there are more. The New York State Theater in Lincoln Center has had an acoustic overhaul by Cyril Harris, to its infinite betterment; and the old City Center in New York rejoices in a new look. In September the Wharton Center for the Performing Arts opened at Michigan State University. In October the Pikes Peak Center in Colorado Springs was unveiled.

title: Pakistani in Iran for Talks
description: Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan of Pakistan arrived in Teheran today for talks with Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, the Teheran radio reported. The Pakistani official said in an interview monitored here that ''we would like to expand relations between Iran and Pakistan.''

title: FOR INVESTMENT FIRMS, THE WORLD'S AILING NATIONS MEAN HEFTY FEES
description: JUST last week, Brazil reluctantly agreed to a loan from the International Monetary Fund to forstall a balance-of-payments crisis. And Argentina, whose economy is near collapse, only last Thursday made arrangements to delay repayment on some $4.7 billion of its $36.6 billion in debt.

title: POPE JOHN ROMPS, 27-0
description: Glen Green ran for three touchdowns to send Pope John of Sparta, the defending champion, to a 27-0 victory over Montclair Immaculate in the championship of the North Jersey, Parochial A playoffs yesterday in Sparta. It was Pope John's fourth state title since the playoffs began in 1974.

title: ALTOS DE CHAVON, VILLAGE OF ARTISTS
description: T here is a special magic when cultural endeavors work as they were planned to, and that magic suffuses Altos de Chavon, the artistic village in the southeast of the Dominican Republic.

title: Trying to Protect The Black Duck
description: TO many waterfowlers, particularly those along the seacoast in the Northeast, a brace of black ducks slicing over a salt marsh at dusk on a gray and gusty winter's day is recompense enough for cold, inactive hours in the blind.

title: CITY YOUTH PROBATION SYSTEM CALLED 'TOTALLY INADEQUATE' BY CIVIC GROUP
description: A civic group devoted to the welfare of children has found in an 18-month study that New York City's probation services for juveniles are ''rife with problems'' and have become ''totally inadequate for the needs of children before the Family Court.''

title: NEW DISKS FOCUS ON MODERN WORKS
description: We hardly need any further proof that Elliott Carter - winner of two Pulitzer Prizes, as well as honorary degrees from many major universities and all but universal critical praise - is one of our major composers. However, those who find much of Mr. Carter's recent work overly complex and aggressively dissonant may find Composers Recordings Incorporated's new disk devoted to his early music (CRI 475, ''Elliott Carter: The Early Music'') a pleasant surprise. This commendable album, featuring Paul Dunkel and the American Composer's Orchestra, includes three important formative compositions: Symphony No. 1 (1942), ''Holiday Overture'' (1944) and the popular ''Suite from Pocahontas'' (1939), and can serve as an easy introduction to Mr. Carter's work. The music herein is tonal, accessible, colorfully orchestrated, determinedly communicative.

title: CAREERS AND THE LURE OF MOTHERHOOD
description: Anita Shreve, a freelance writer, is working on a book about twocareer families for Catalyst, an organization that aids working women.

title: Karen Thomson Plans Bridal With J.C. Cantor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hennessey Thomson of Murray Hill, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Thomson, to Joshua Charles Cantor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Cantor of Westfield, N.J.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Plot Quickens

title: A 'Very Prudent' Time in Poland
description: Underground leaders of Solidarity made no secret last week of their despair over the poor response to their latest call for strikes and demonstrations. The banned union's Warsaw weekly conceded that ''emotions had subsided'' and that the low turnout on Nov. 10 was a ''serious blow.''

title: WHAT IS SCHOOLS' MISSION
description: IT is often stated that ''public education is the answer,'' but one must ask, ''What was the question?'' As a schools superintendent, I am concerned that the mission of public education has broadened to the extent that it is extremely difficult to ascertain what the mission of public education really is.

title: DISGRUNTLED U.N. EMPLOYEES COMPLAIN OF 'CRISIS IN MORALE'
description: Heated debate at the United Nations is not uncommon, though it is generally confined to partisan speeches delivered on the floor of the Security Council or the General Assembly. But these days loud voices are being heard outside the diplomatic chambers, from disgruntled United Nations employees.

title: CRAFTS
description: CECILY LAIDMAN, crafts coordinator for the State Council on the Arts, has resigned. New Jersey is one of only a few states to have a full-time crafts coordinator, and Miss Laidman was the second person to hold the position. She submitted her resignation earlier this month to Clement A. Price, chairman of the council, and Wendy McNeill, its acting executive director. It becomes effective Dec. 17.

title: Connecticut's Sneaky Deficit
description: The depth of Connecticut's financial problems apparently came as news to Gov. William A. O'Neill, who said he had no idea, until he was handed the proposed $3.62 billion budget last week, that the state faced a $298.7 million deficit.

title: PRINCETON'S NEW POLICY ON LIBRARY PROTESTED
description: PRINCETON NEARLY four months after Princeton University began restricting access to Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library, the move continues to draw protests, and residents see the barrier across the main lobby as a symbol.

title: MEPHAM'S RUNNERS REPEAT
description: Chris Curtin defended her individual title in the team race and led Mepham to its second consecutive girls' team championship yesterday in the New York State Federation cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS NEED MORE THAN A SALUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUTER-TAX PLAN DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: IF Mayor Koch has his way, Westchester residents will soon have to pay more for the privilege of working in New York City. But before the Mayor has his way, he will have to overcome formidable, wellentrenched opposition from suburban legislators of both parties -and most legislators say his proposal for a $100 million increase in the income tax on commuters will not go anywhere.

title: HUNTERS TAKE AIM AS DEER MULTIPY
description: THE deer are coming out of the woods because they are hungry, much to the chagrin of farmers, gardeners and motorists in Suffolk County who are going to greet them at gunpoint this season.

title: HOMELESSNESS: A HIDDEN PROBLEM
description: SHE seems to carry most of her belongings with her in two plastic shopping bags as she makes her way, every day, through the streets of Great Neck. In the city, she would be a common enough sight: a middle-aged woman with blond hair gone gray, wearing layers of ragged sweaters and socks. Here she is an anomaly, as she stands near a Dan's Supreme supermarket, smoking a filterless cigarette, sometimes eating from one of the bags.

title: JAZZ: OREGON, SEMINAL GROUP
description: After taking a two-year sabbatical to pursue individual projects, the seminal chamber-jazz ensemble Oregon has reconvened. And Friday at Town Hall, the quartet, which includes the guitarist and keybordist Ralph Towner, the sitarist and percussionist Collin Walcott, the multiple-woodwind player Paul McCandless and the bassist Glen Moore, put on an impressive two-and-a-half hour concert that emphasized free-form percussive improvisation.

title:
CAMERA;
USING AVAILABLE LIGHT
BLOODBATHS DEBASE MOVIES AND AUDIENCES
description: Most moviegoers know them only as names on marquees, and the names are ugly and interchangeable. Whether the title is ''The Burning'' or ''Maniac,'' ''The Slumber Party Massacre'' or ''Humongous,'' it's the same old story. There is a killer on the loose. He is mean, mysterious and apparently unstoppable. Murdering pretty young women excites him most, but he's really not particular. He'll gladly butcher anyone who gets in his way.

title: DRESSING UP AMERICA
description: Adolfo was in Beverly Hills, Chicago, Detroit, Dallas, Fort Worth, Kansas City, Las Vegas, New York, Washington and San Francisco. Dallas, Chicago, New York, Kansas City and Washington (twice) were among Bill Blass's stopovers, too, not to mention Central City, Colo., Houston, Nashville, San Antonio and Philadelphia. Oscar de la Renta made some of the same calls, adding Charlotte, N.C., and New Orleans. And while James Galanos visited fewer cities than is his wont, during a 10-day stay in New York the California-based designer helped to sell more than $400,000 worth of his high-priced merchandise at the Martha specialty store.

title: A Roman Soldier
description: The man was about 37 years old, didn't get enough calcium when he was a kid (he was probably poor) and is missing three of his front teeth (he was probably a brawler). His arms are muscular and his shoulders tend to bulge.

title: ISLANDERS DOWN HAWKS BY 5-4
description: The Islanders snapped out of their doldrums of the last two weeks and scored two goals late in the final period tonight to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-4, in a hardfought, see-saw game in Nassau Coliseum.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ROSLYN HARBOR BARBARA and Joel Greenberg had sensed there was something unusual about Charles. Even when he was only 5 years old, he was always finding things in trash cans - old toys that he repaired, bits of tape that he unwound and made serviceable.

title: The Ford Foundation And the Poor
description: It was refreshing to read about Franklin A. Thomas, director of the Ford Foundation, who seems to be sensitive to the needs of the poor and disadvantaged (''Franklin A. Thomas: Streamlining the Ford Foundation,'' by Kathleen Teltsch, Oct. 10).

title: AN ECONOMIC PUSH TO PULL TOURIST DOLLARS
description: JO THOMAS, formerly Caribbean correspondent of The Times, is now an assistant national editor.

title: CHRISTMAS CARDS OF RESIDENTS GO TO SMITHSONIAN
description: A collection of 2l official Christmas cards sent by seven American Presidents from Dwight D. Eisenhower to Ronald Reagan is now on display at the National Museum of American History in Washington.

title: The Trance Returns
description: Until the final whistle blows on Super Sunday, the trance is back. Millions will once again devote Sunday afternoons and Monday nights to professional football.

title: ANTITRUST DEBATE: THE BIG, THE BAD AND THE BEAUTIFUL
description: THROUGH continued regulation of industry, interference with free trade and so permissive an attitude toward corporate mergers or combinations as to wink at threats of monopoly, some critics believe, the Reagan Administration has violated one of its fundamental tenets -free competition in the market place, whether domestic or international. Lately, antitrust policy -the faded darling of liberal reform, the late historian Richard Hofstadter once called it - has come under particular scrutiny. The Week in Review asked William F. Baxter, Mr. Reagan's Assistant Attorney General for Antitrust, and Almarin Phillips, Professor of Public Management, Economics and Law at the University of Pennsylvania, to talk about the theory and the practice of antitrust. Excerpts of their discussion with Leonard Silk, economic columnist for The New York Times, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cradlesongs at N.Y.U.

title: Tylenol Reappearing
description: Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules will be back on some store shelves by the end of the week in tamperresistant packaging, and Johnson & Johnson is hoping to lure back customers with 80 million coupons worth $2.50 each. All Tylenol capsules were withdrawn from the market in late September after seven persons in the Chicago area died after taking capsules poisoned with cyanide. No arrests have been made.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News item in Business Day Saturday incorrectly reported the terms under which Carl C. Icahn, a New York investor, is offering $16.50 a share for two million shares of the Dan River Company. The offer is not contingent on a move by Dan River to halt its litigation against Mr. Icahn's takeover bid.

title: WHAT THE LEGAL AID ATTORNEYS WANT
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1982
description: International A crisis in Arab politics of revolutionary proportions has followed Israel's invasion of Lebanon. A tour of the Middle East indicates that Arabs are deeply humiliated over the lack of any concerted response by Arab governments to the invasion. (Page A1, Columns 3-5.) An effort to bolster Poland's economy has reached a crucial point. Political disturbances have cut factory and farm production and, in addition, without the money to meet payments on foreign debts of more than $24 billion Poland cannot afford to import vital machinery and raw materials from the West. (A1:1-2.)

title: PACKERS STAY UNBEATEN, 26-7
description: Not only is the National Football League back in business, but so, apparently, are the Green Bay Packers. The Packers, who ruled the league in the 1960's but have foundered since the late Vince Lombardi gave up the coaching assignment in 1967, scored their third victory without a loss yesterday by defeating the Minnesota Vikings, 26-7, in Milwaukee.

title: A LATIN AMERICAN TRIP ORGANIZED FOR BUSINESS
description: From palace to castle to chateau, President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, sped last June through a series of ceremonial functions in Europe, some of which were timed for live broadcasting on television in the United States.

title: Budget Car Account
description: The Budget Rent-A-Car Corporation, a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation, has retained D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, Chicago, as agency of record for consumer advertising in the United States.

title: Shearer, on 287, Is 4-Shot Winner
description: Bob Shearer of Australia shot a steady, two-under-par 70 today and scored a four-stroke victory in the $225,000 Australian Open golf tournament.

title: News Analysis
description: Significant opposition to concessions exists in the labor movement, as demonstrated in the decision last week by local leaders of the United Steelworkers of America to reject management demands for a $1.50-an-hour cut in wages, and other major concessions.

title: MOTHER REUNITED WITH SON, 3
description: A trembling Kathleen Blackburn, who lost custody of her white son last year after she bore an illegitimate, racially mixed daughter, was reunited today with the 3-year-old boy under an order of the Georgia Supreme Court.

title: California Sells Notes To Pay November Bills
description: In order to pay the state's November bills, Ken Cory, the California Comptroller, has sold $400 million in short-term notes to a syndicate headed by the Bank of America.

title: INDEPENDENCE BOWL, DEC. 11; At Shreveport, La.
description: Wisconsin (6-5) vs. Kansas State (6-4-1), 8 P.M. HOLIDAY BOWL, DEC. 17 At San Diego, Calif. Brigham Young (8-3) vs. Ohio State (8-3), 9 P.M. CALIFORNIA BOWL, DEC. 18 At Fresno, Calif.

title: NETS SEND SONICS TO FIRST LOSS, 111 TO 91
description: The Nets accomplished tonight what no other team has been able to do this season -they defeated the SuperSonics. New Jersey's 111-91 victory snapped Seattle's 12-game winning streak, the third longest at the start of a National Basketball Association season.

title: ISRAELI AIDE TELLS PANEL OF A WARNING BY DRAPER
description: Israel's Foreign Ministry representative in Beirut, testifying before a panel looking into the September slayings of hundreds of civilians at two Palestinian refugee camps, said today that Morris Draper, the special United States envoy, had warned him that there would be ''horrible results'' if Christian Phalangist militiamen entered the predominantly Moslem sector of the capital.

title: STEELERS WIN
description: After only three days of practice, it was not surprising that Terry Bradshaw of the Pittsburgh Steelers threw 24 incomplete passes and had two intercepted yesterday. But more importantly, he completed 16 for 228 yards, including three touchdowns, as the Steelers downed the Oilers in Houston, 24-10. The Steelers' record went to 3-0.

title: TRUMKA SET TO LEAD MINE WORKERS
description: Wearing his usual three-piece pin-stripe suit and exhibiting the businesslike style that marked his campaign, Rich Trumka, the newly elected president of the United Mine Workers of America, is beginning a monthlong transition this week to the leadership of the troubled union.

title: BUSH REMAINS FIRM ON NAMIBIA POLICY
description: Vice President Bush said here today that despite criticism by black African leaders, the Reagan Administration would continue to link the issue of independence for South-West Africa with the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Chinese Coal Drive
description: China has imported $1 billion worth of technology and equipment and used $700 million in foreign funds to increase coal production, the official Xinhua News Agency reported today.

title: MIDWEST REVISITED: MANY DISAPPOINTMENTS PLUS A TOUCH OF GOOD NEWS
description: Superman is gone. Too many friends have died. Phil Ruppe lost. Great America has arrived. The buzzards still come back to Hinckley. But Pearl gave up.

title: Advertising; Getting the Best From An Agency
description: IF you graduated from the Harvard Business School in 1934, you probably remember that Stanley J. Goodman was first in your class. And if you worked at the May Department Stores Company in the 1960's and 70's, you doubtless recall that sales doubled from $1 billion in 1968, the year before he became chief executive, to $2 billion in 1976, when he stepped down at the mandatory retirement age. Profits spurted, too.

title: F.A.A. STUDIES COLLISION FATAL TO 3
description: Federal investigators examined the wreckage yesterday of two small planes that collided in midair and crashed in a suburban area of Essex County, N.J., killing the three men aboard the craft and scattering debris over a six-block area of the community of Livingston.

title: Is Consumerism Dead?
description: Consumerism reigned invincible in the early 70's, recounts Michael Pertschuk, a hero of the consumer movement and author of a new book, ''Revolt Against Regulation.'' Congressmen who had toadied to business interests inveighed instead against Washington's failure to protect Joe Lunchbucket from every peril of the marketplace.

title: News Analysis
description: Irritating, petty, contrary, childish: the old vocabulary concerning France's relationship to its Atlantic allies is being used again with the refusal here to go along with President Reagan's deal for dropping the Soviet pipeline sanctions.

title: OLDER WOMAN: THEIR LEAGUE GAINS STRENGTH
description: The button on the neck of Miriam Chrisler's turtleneck sweater seemed to sum up the sentiment at the first national convention of the Older Women's League here. It said: ''How dare you presume I'd rather be young.''

title: JAZZ: CLUB HONORS THE NEGLECTED ANDY KIRK
description: THE Overseas Jazz Club devoted its monthly twilight concert at the Overseas Press Club on Friday to a tribute to Andy Kirk, a name not likely to bring smiles of recognition to jazz followers of today.

title: Washington Watch; Regan Awaits His Innings
description: WASHINGTON DON REGAN likens being head of the Administration's economic team to being a baseball manager. If the team is losing, the Treasury Secretary says, the manager can expect to be let go.

title: BRIEFING
description: Prickly Salary Question

title: NONFICTION 'SCHINDLER'S LIST' AND A FICTION PRIZE
description: The always edgy, often intimate relationship between fact and fiction in modern letters was underlined when Britain's most highly regarded literary award, the Booker McConnell Prize for fiction, recently went to Thomas Keneally's new book, ''Schindler's List,'' a story in which truth is indeed stranger than fiction.

title: Waltrip Clinches Stock-Car Title
description: Tim Richmond raced to victory in the Winston Western 500 Grand National stock-car race today and Darrell Waltrip clinched his second straight Winston Cup season championship with a third-place finish in the race.

title: CUOMO MOLDS ROLE IN OFFICE IN A FIRM WAY
description: In his World Trade Center office and by telephone from his home in Queens, Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo is working intensively to form a government, interviewing job candidates, reorganizing the Governor's office and setting positions on major issues.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News item in Business Day on Nov. 11 incorrectly reported on two steel plant closings. Roblin Industries said its plants in Dunkirk and North Tonawanda, N.Y., would reopen Jan. 4.

title: BARNES, UNDER LIFE SENTENCE IN DRUG CASE, IS AIDING U.S.
description: Five years after he was convicted of heading ''the most venal drug ring'' in New York City and sentenced to life in prison without parole, Leroy (Nicky) Barnes has become a Federal informant, according to Federal law enforcement officials and Mr. Barnes's former lawyer.

title: HELP WANTED: A CARPENTER
description: FOR the Giants, a player who's not in uniform, Rob Carpenter, has emerged as more important this season than all those players who are. But even if Rob Carpenter were to be signed now, it's probably too late for the Giants to qualify for the Super Bowl playoffs in this strike - shortened nine-game season. After yesterday's 27-17 loss to the Washington Redskins, the Giants have an 0-3 record. Unless they win on Thanksgiving Day in Detroit, they will be 0-4 with three of their last five games on the road. Even if they do win Thursday, a 1-3 record is hardly a recommendation as a Super Bowl contender.

title: M.T.A. LEADERS INTENSIFY WARNINGS OF FARE RISES
description: On the eve of a special meeting today between Governor Carey and state legislative leaders, officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority stepped up their warnings that unless the Legislature came up with new money, subway, bus and commuter fares would go up next month.

title: ASIAN BRONZE AGE FINDS ON VIEW
description: The six-inch tall, chalice-shape clay pot has a bowl that balloons out of its base like a ripe bulb. The bowl is decorated with a redand-white swirling pattern that winds around the bowl like a succession of waves.

title: Brooklyn Youth Is Slain In a Times Sq. Dispute
description: A Brooklyn youth was shot to death early yesterday morning in Times Square, and the police said they had a photograph, taken only minutes before the shooting, of a man who might be the killer.

title: BOOKS: POLAND UNDER NAZI HEEL
description: COURIER FROM WARSAW. By Jan Nowak. 477 pages. Illustrated. Wayne State University Press. $24.95.

title: Monumental Courses
description: A truly avid golfer was Frank Cox, a newspaper executive who played on more than 1,500 courses before his death earlier this year. A feature of the recently published ''100 Greatest Golf Courses - And Then Some'' from Simon and Schuster is ''The Frank Cox Gazetteer,'' a compendium of the most unusual courses that Mr. Cox discovered and played on during his worldwide travels.

title: Reinventing Banks
description: Starting Dec. 14, Washington will allow banks and savings and loans to offer federally insured accounts with interest rates that can compete with money market funds. That is not necessarily good news for the weaker banks and ''thrift'' institutions, which may be forced to pay very high interest to attract new deposits. But it is another welcome step in the gradual deregulation of the overregulated banking system.

title: Market Place; Super Bowl Among Omens
description: THE end of the National Football League strike last week brought joy to tens of millions of fans who could watch the pro games once again. It also brought cheers on Wall Street, where market prophets, who constantly search for methods to divine the direction of stock prices, lean on the ''Super Bowl Omen.''

title: Nordiques 9, Oilers 7
description: Marian, Anton and Peter Stastny of Quebec combined for five goals and 11 points to overcome Wayne Gretzky's three goals and 6 points.

title: THE RUSSIANS COMING? IN A NONEXISTENT TANK?
description: So bad were the reviews of the performance of Soviet weapons in Lebanon last summer, it seemed for a moment as if the ''threat'' on which the prosperity of the defense business is based had suffered an irreparable blow. To assume that, however, is to misunderstand a crucial aspect of ''threat inflation,'' as the exaggeration of Soviet military capabilities is jocularly known among Pentagon iconoclasts.

title: REAGAN'S DECISION ON MX IS REPORTED
description: President Reagan has tentatively approved a plan to pack 100 MX missiles armed with nuclear warheads into a narrow, 14-mile-long strip, White House officials said today.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT DESTROYED FIVE TANKERS AT IRANIAN PORT
description: Iraq said it conducted a combined air and naval strike against Iran's main oil export terminal on Kharg Island today, sinking five unidentified oil tankers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Casablanca' at La Guardia

title: GRIM VIEW OF LATIN ECONOMIES
description: Latin American economies, which have recorded growth rates of nearly 6 percent a year over the last decade, are facing a decline to 1.6 percent this year, according to the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: THE BATTLE OF POITIERS
description: In 732 A.D., as the Saracen invaders from Syria and North Africa threatened to sweep across Europe, an intrepid French duke called Charles the Hammer assembled an army at Poitiers, near Tours, and saved the European continent for Christianity by beating back the Moslem horde.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OPENINGS

title: U.N. FIGHT OVER PRESS FREEDOM: THE NEXT ROUND
description: The Western press is preparing for another confrontation with the developing countries and the Soviet bloc over questions of press freedom.

title: DOLPHINS CAPITALIZE ON ERRORS BY BILLS
description: Following four days of practice, the Buffalo Bills had a wide repertory of offensive plays ready for the Miami Dolphins today, if not a complete one, according to the coach, Chuck Knox. But there was one play too many in the game plan, the halfback option pass, and it figured prominently as the Bills lost, 9-7.

title: Federal Firearms Agents Keeping Busy in Florida
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to choke the flow of illegal drugs into Florida has led to a related crackdown on the weapons traffic that has made Florida the nation's leading center for illegal arms sales, Federal agents said.

title: Bruins 2, Flames 1
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Mike Krushelnyski and Tom Fergus scored Boston's goals in the first period. Krushelnyski opened the scoring on a power play at 5:20 when he took a pass from Peter McNab and beat a sliding Reggie Lemelin, the Calgary goalie, between the pads.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch in Business Day on Nov. 11 incorrectly reported the relationship between Air Canada and Altair Airlines. Air Canada's agreement with Altair called solely for the sale, for $20 million, of four DC-9's, one spare engine and assorted spare parts.

title: Justice Aide Is Suggested As 'Deep Throat' Source
description: John D. Ehrlichman, a White House aide to President Nixon, said today he thought that Henry Petersen, a former assistant Attorney General, was probably the never-identified ''Deep Throat'' source used by two Washington Post reporters investigating the Watergate scandals.

title: Commodities; Problems In Trading Of Hybrids
description: WHILE the once formidable walls between the commodity and securities markets have been tumbling down, the exchanges, brokerage houses and traders have been discovering a host of legal problems in the debris. Most of the problems arise from the many futures and options on financial instruments and stock indexes recently introduced by the commodity and securities exchanges.

title: 'Friendly' Ties With U.S.  Urged by Pravda
description: In a front-page editorial, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda repeated the Kremlin contention today that the Soviet Union seeks ''normal, and better yet, friendly'' relations with the United States.

title: MUSIC: HADEN REASSEMBLES ORCHESTRA
description: CHARLIE HADEN introduced the concert by his Liberation Music Orchestra at the Public Theater on Friday evening by saying that he would play music from El Salvador, Chile, Spain, Portugal, music composed by himself and by Carla Bley and music from the 1970 album on Impulse Records that introduced the Liberation Music Orchestra.

title: Auto Parts Group Signs With Fahlgren & Ferriss
description: The National Automotive Parts Association, an organization of 6,100 independent stores, has shifted its $11 million advertising account to Falhgren & Ferriss, Cincinnati. Matthews, Muhleman, McLean, of Charlotte, N.C., had been handling the account, but N.A.P.A., with a growing realization that the account's size would be better served with a larger agency, began holding discussions with a number of shops earlier this year. But Fahlgren & Ferriss acquired Matthews, Muhleman, McLean, and was added to N.A.P.A.'s list of prospective agencies.

title: BRINK'S HEARINGS HIGHLIGHT THE DEBATE OVER HYPNOSIS
description: The pretrial hearings in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and triple slaying have become the latest forum for a growing national debate on the use of hypnosis on crime victims and witnesses.

title: John Ashbery Is Chosen For Poetry Fellowship
description: John Ashbery has been named the 43d recipient of the $10,000 fellowship given by the Academy of American Poets for ''distinguished poetic achievement.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Sumitomo Corp. said it had won a $64 million contract from the Trinidad-Tobago Electricity Commission for a 196,000-kilowatt combined-cycle power plant.

title: TO FANS, STRIKE LINGERS
description: There was plenty of home-team green in the stands at Shea Stadium yesterday, in the ski caps and jerseys of the 46,970 fans who turned up for the first Jets home game since the season opener against Miami Sept. 12. But there was also plenty of red, blue and orange - the colors of the 13,402 seats that had been sold but were unoccupied.

title: President of Continental Led Pan Am Marketing
description: With fare wars raging and traffic gains spotty among airlines, Stephen M. Wolf knows he will have his hands full when he becomes president of Continental Air Lines on Dec. 1. He will be trying to extend Continental's recent return to profitability.

title: Argonauts to Face Eskimos in Final
description: Condredge Holloway threw three touchdown passes, two to the wide receiver Terry Greer, as the Toronto Argonauts routed the Ottawa Rough Riders, 44-7, today in the Canadian Football League's Eastern Division playoff final.

title: IRAQIS, AT LEAST TEMPORARILY, TURN A KIND EYE TO THE WEST
description: An American diplomat on a routine visit to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry found the Hungarian Ambassador waiting in the outer office of the official the American wished to see.

title: Talbott and Miss McConnell Take Titles
description: Mark Talbott continued his dominance of men's professional squash racquets yesterday with a 15-10, 15-9, 15-17, 15-6 victory over Ned Edwards in the final of the $27,000 Chivas Regal Open at the Uptown Racquet Club in Manhattan.

title: BROADCASTERS AND NEWSPAPERS NEED REGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Big E Keeps On
description: Elvin Hayes celebrated his 37th birthday last Wednesday, playing for the Houston Rockets against the Celtics in Boston Garden. The oldest player in the league made the occasion an auspicious one by scoring the 26,000th point of his National Basketball Association career, which began in 1968 with San Diego.

title: Tracy-Locke/B.B.D.O.  Is Selected by Taco Bell
description: Taco Bell, a Pepsico unit that operates 1,500 Mexican fast-food resturants, has picked Tracy-Locke/ B.B.D.O. in Dallas as its new advertising agency. Billings in 1983 are expected to be $20 million.

title: LOS ANGELES RAISES SIGHTS OF ATHLETES
description: Dorsey High School's football players were psyched up for the last game of the season this weekend, Tim Williams more so than most. Like hundreds of Los Angeles high school athletes who do better on the field than in the classroom, he faces a challenge next season that could derail the ultimate dream of his 16-year-old life, which is to make it to the golden circle of professional sports.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Remembering the '32 Race

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Subway 'Solutions'

title: GIANTS BEATEN BY REDSKINS
description: The Jets yesterday put on their full array of padding for the first time since the football strike ended, and then they whipped the Baltimore Colts so easily that it might have been a practice session.

title: Black Hawks 3, Red Wings 0
description: CHICAGO (AP) - A pair of power-play goals by the defenseman Bob Murray and outstanding goaltending by Murray Bannerman led Chicago to the victory.

title: Ruling Speeds Foreign Issues
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a set of rules intended to speed up and simplify the filing of information required of foreign corporations to market securities in the United States. The S.E.C. argued that the package would cut disclosure costs of public companies and eliminate much duplication under current disclosure rules.

title: ECONOMIC REFORMS IN POLAND FACING A GROWING OPPOSITION
description: Almost a year after the declaration of martial law, the battle to save Poland's collapsing economy has reached a crucial point.

title: VATICAN'S PLANS TO SEND ART ON TOUR STIRS PROTEST
description: The dispatch to the United States next year of a major show of works from the Vatican Museum is giving rise to a mounting press campaign in Italy accusing the Vatican of exposing priceless works of art to unacceptable risk.

title: DEER POPULATION AT RECORD LEVEL FOR HUNTING SEASON IN NEW YORK
description: On the eve of lower New York State's deer-hunting season, which starts at dawn on Monday, the state's deer population has risen to a record 650,000, according to the State Environmental Conservation Department.

title: IMAGIC SCORES IN VIDEO GAMES
description: Some day in mid-December, Imagic Inc. will come to Wall Street, the first public company born out of the video game explosion.

title: Peete's 281 Wins
description: Calvin Peete shot a par 72 today and won the $409,000 Dunlop Phoenix golf tournament by three strokes. The 39-year-old American completed 72 holes in 281, seven under par on the 7,030-yard Phoenix Country Club course.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LIMAN COMMISSION REPORT ON CRIMINAL JUSTICE
description: Following are excerpts from the final report on New York State's criminal justice system by the Executive Advisory Commission on the Administration of Justice.

title: 2D MEDIATION EFFORT FAILS IN LEGAL AID STRIKE
description: Negotiators for both sides in the 30-day-old strike by 550 Legal Aid Society lawyers met yesterday with a New York City mediator in the second attempt at mediation since the strike began.

title: U.S. POLICY DISMAYS NUCLEAR INDUSTRY
description: Leaders of the nation's nuclear industry have begun to express disappointment with the Reagan Administration, on which they had once pinned their hopes for a reversal of the industry's precipitous decline.

title: Florida Students Ordered To Get Measles Vaccine
description: In the wake of the nation's largest measles outbreak, some 40,000 students must provide proof that they have been vaccinated against the disease or risk being barred from school Monday, health officials said.

title: OFFICIALS SAY ROAD PROJECTS COULD START ALMOST AT ONCE
description: More than $6 billion worth of road and bridge improvement projects are ready to go almost immediately if Congress increases the Federal gas tax to pay for them, state highway and transportation officials said today.

title: SKY DIVES: THE THRILL AND THE THREAT
description: They came sailing down from the sky at an angle and practically tiptoed across a field here, their parachutes billowing behind them as they landed. No hit and roll. They didn't even get dirty, unless they were aiming for a target. When they did that, they came in like baseball players sliding into home plate, legs stretched out, toes reaching for a rubber disk the size of a dinner plate.

title: JERSEY'S ROADS CHIEF PLACES A MORATORIUM ON HIGHWAY REPAIRS
description: New Jersey's Commissioner of Transportation announced a moratorium yesterday on about $86 million in road construction projects, in anticipation of a 3 percent cut in his department's budget.

title: Loss of Revenue Sharing Is Feared by Cities in Poll
description: The Government's failure to renew the $4.6 billion general revenue-sharing program next year would seriously harm the nation's towns and cities, especially small cities, according to a survey made public today by the National League of Cities.

title: 2 Men Hurt Atop Train By Electrical Apparatus
description: Two Connecticut men were injured early today by the high-voltage electrical equipment atop a moving Conrail commuter train, the police said.

title: ISRAEL CALLS TYRE BLAST ACCIDENTAL
description: An investigation into an explosion that destroyed the Israeli military headquarters in Tyre, Lebanon, killing 75 Israelis and 14 Arabs, has determined that it was an accident.

title: Flyers 3, Blues 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Darryl Sittler, Glen Cochrane and Brian Propp each scored a goal for Philadelphia. The victory extended the Flyers' 10-year home unbeaten record against the Blues to 26 games. St. Louis last defeated the Flyers at the Spectrum on Jan. 6, 1972.

title: Zaccio Romps
description: Mrs. Lewis Murdock's Zaccio became steeplechasing's all-time money-earning jumper today when the 6-yearold chestnut gelding romped to an eight-length victory in the $50,000 Colonial Cup.

title: REVENUES SOARING, ATLANTIC CITY'S CASINOS PLAN GROWTH
description: Despite the recession, the nine casinos here are enjoying what one executive called an ''avalanche of revenue,'' and developers were being encouraged to proceed with plans for a second wave of casino construction.

title: No Headline
description: Connors Turns Back Borg, 7-5, 7-6, in Series Finale

title: Adaptable Dusan
description: Gene Dusan, who will be coming to New York as the bullpen coach of the Mets next spring, may undergo a radical change of environment, but he says he is immune to culture shock.

title: NEW TECHNIQUE REMOVES FAT
description: The plastic surgeon cuts a small incision, a half-inch to one inch long into the thigh or other area of the body, inserts a hollow instrument that loosens undesirable fat and, with a suction apparatus, vacuums it out. The patient leaves the hospital with nothing more to show for the experience than a scar that is tucked, when possible, into a natural body fold.

title: ERVING GOFFMAN, SOCIOLOGIST WHO STUDIED EVERY DAY LIFE
description: Erving Goffman, a sociologist who searched for the meaning in the routine transactions of everyday life, died Friday in Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: DANCE: OHIO BALLET PRESENTS EAST COAST PREMIERES
description: THE Ohio Ballet, which appeared on tour Saturday night at the State University of New York College at Purchase, was founded in 1968 as a chamber group in Akron by the German-born choreographer, Heinz Poll.

title: Cordero Is Suspended For 7 Days at Aqueduct
description: Angel Cordero Jr., who set a record last week for purse money won in a single year, was suspended yesterday for seven days by the stewards at Aqueduct.

title: POPE REPROVES MAFIA OBLIQUELY IN SICILY
description: Pope John Paul II, ending a two-day pastoral visit here, called on Sicilians today to construct a society without violence or war, without unemployment or narcotics.

title: SHIITES SEIZE A LEBANESE CITY IN PROTEST
description: Several hundred Lebanese Shiite Moslems who said they were followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini stormed the town hall of this city in eastern Lebanon today in an armed protest against the Government of President Amin Gemayel.

title: Investors Shied From Britoil
description: Public and institutional investors apparently sat out the sale by the British Government of a controlling stake in Britoil P.L.C., leaving a large group of underwriters stuck with about $600 million worth of stock in the oil exploration company.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OPERA: 'SEVILLE' CAST CHANGES
description: ROSSINI'S ''Il Barbiere di Seviglia'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera last week. The production, retained from last season, has its virtues - a witty and original staging chief among them - but Saturday's performance was an oddly joyless affair.

title: Russians Defeat Kentucky, 89-86
description: Coach Aleksandr Gomelsky of the Soviet national basketball team said his players were fatigued after a bus ride from West Lafayette, Ind., but turned in the finest performance of their tour in defeating the University of Kentucky today, 89-86.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED BY THE RANGERS, 7-3
description: There is no such thing as a routine game when the Rangers and the Islanders play each other. Surprises always pop up, and the Rangers' 7-3 victory last night at Madison Square Garden was no exception.

title: Household's Chief Expert in Finance
description: Donald C. Clark, 51 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of Household International. Mr. Clark, who previously served as president and chief operating officer, succeeds Gilbert R. Ellis, who died of a heart attack on Nov. 13. Mr. Ellis was 66.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAYS U.S. JOBLESS RATE WILL FALL IN 1983
description: President Reagan's chief economist said today that without ''significant actions by Congress and the Administration,'' the budget deficit could be $150 billion to $200 billion in the fiscal year 1984. He also predicted an unemployment rate of about 9 percent next year.

title: A Bad Case of Hot Wheels
description: The faceless folks who run Conrail have hit upon a new way to make life wretched for 44,000 commuters for months on end. Twice this year wheels have spun off trains serving suburban New York and Connecticut. No one can say why. The cars were made by General Electric in the mid-1970's, and have been just fine until this year. Wheels don't pop off trains on other commuter lines, even on the rinky-dink Long Island Rail Road.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Puget Sound Power and Light Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 400,000 shares of adjustable rate cumulative preferred shares, series A, through Salomon Brothers.

title: RUSH TO MARKET NEW ACCOUNT
description: With the zeal of carnival barkers, banks and savings institutions are bidding for the $100 billion that a new type of money market account is expected to attract. The accounts go into effect Dec. 14.

title: MOBIL RESTRUCTURING SENIOR MANAGEMENT
description: The Mobil Corporation, in a major restructuring of senior management, said yesterday that Rawleigh Warner Jr. and William P. Tavoulareas would relinquish their positions on Jan. 1 as chairman and president, respectively, of the Mobil Oil Corporation, Mobil's principal subsidiary.

title: Cellular Permit; For Boston
description: The Federal Communications Commission has issued its second construction permit for a cellular mobile telephone system, this time for the rights to operate in Boston.

title: 'IT'S STILL NOT OVER' FOR GARVEY
description: It was early afternoon of the first Sunday after the eight-week football strike and the players were back at work on the field, and Ed Garvey, the executive director of their union, was back at work in his office.

title: COMMISSION URGES CUOMO TO CREATE NEW JUSTICE POST
description: A New York State commission yesterday urged Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo to create a strong central administration, headed by a new cabinet-level appointee, to take control of what it said was a ''feeble and ineffective'' system of criminal justice.

title: House That $ Built
description: The rich are getting richer in a hurry in the Atlantic Coast Conference. The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball champion, North Carolina, has played before sellout crowds at Carmichael Auditorium on its Chapel Hill campus since 1966, winning 141 of 158 games there. In 1976, the building's seating capacity was increased from 8,800 to 10,000, and still the clamor for tickets in ''Blue Heaven'' remain far greater than school officials could accommodate.

title: All Cambodian Rebels Embraced by China
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that China would equally favor the Communist and non-Communist factions in the Cambodian rebel coalition fighting the Vietnamese occupation, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: Thomas E. Martin Weds Katherine Jee, a Teacher
description: Katherine Rita Jee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Jee of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Thomas E. Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin also of Riverdale. The Rev. David D. Cockroft, pastor of the Riverdale Presbyterioan Church, performed the ceremony at the Beau Rivage in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: CHANNEL 3!-83!-HUUUT!-HUUT!-HUUT!
description: At 1:01 P.M. today, National Football League games were restored to the television sets of this suburban community, ending a 61-day drought. Mayor Joseph Parisi confirmed that the borough's 5,900 residents had endured complete deprivation of the live telecasts and had subsisted on a thin gruel of reruns and Canadian football games.

title: CONCERT: MISS VON STADE WITH CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: ANYONE who attends many musical events has noticed that certain singers excite their devotees to extraordinarily vehement outpourings of admiration. Love is not too strong a word for it. The relationship can be strong, deep and enduring, often far outlasting the favored artist's voice itself. ''Adorable'' is a word frequently bandied about by such a singer's followers and it does not seem hyperbolic in the least. In fact, it is an encomium that audiences seem to reserve for beloved vocalists. I doubt you have heard it applied to many famous pianists or conductors, unless in jest.

title: MICHAELS A HIT WITH PLAYERS
description: WALT MICHAELS had a victory and he had a game ball and maybe, without trying to be a revolutionary, he had concocted a new approach to preparing for football games, too. The Jets' defensive unit awarded its game ball to Michaels yesterday after the 37-0 victory over a young Baltimore team, the most lopsided shutout in the history of the Jets' franchise.

title: SALVADOR AID: U.S. RESOLVE IS QUESTIONED
description: Mixed signals from Washington recently have reinforced the conviction among a number of conservative politicians and top military officials here that the United States will not take the drastic step of suspending aid to El Salvador as long as the guerrilla war goes on, Western diplomats here say.

title: KISSINGER ON THE MIDEAST
description: Israel has the undoubted military power now to proceed with the de facto annexation of the West Bank. That process has already gone very far, and it is accelerating. Is it conceivable, then, that there can still be negotiation about the future of the West Bank? That question was put to Henry Kissinger recently. He answered:

title: Books Of The Times
description: CHARLES RYDER'S SCHOOL DAYS AND OTHER STORIES. By Evelyn Waugh. 292 pages. Little, Brown. $12.95, hard cover; $5.95, paperback.

title: Floridians Make a Trial Run At Starting Passenger Train
description: The Silver Palm pulled into the Amtrak train station here seven minutes ahead of schedule Saturday, completing Florida's first in-state passenger train run since the late 1960's.

title: Bridge: Mixed Pair Title Is Taken By Crane and Mrs. Shuman
description: The National Mixed Pair Championship, opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, was won here Saturday night by the favorites: Barry Crane of Studio City, Calif., and Kerri Shuman of Los Angeles. They led into the final session and moved away from their pursuers.

title: AEG Quits Venture
