description: AEG Telefunken A.G. has given up all interests in its joint-venture telecommunications company, AEG-Telefunken Nachrichtentechnik A.G., a spokesman said. AEG is relinquishing its 51 percent share to the three other partners, Robert Bosch G.m.b.H., Mannesmann A.G. and Allianz Versicherungs A.G., at the end of this year. The spokesman said the decision had been taken against AEG's wishes but could not be prevented as a clause in the joint venture contract gives other shareholders a right to take over AEG's stake if it entered into bankruptcy proceedings.

title: CITY BALLET: 'COPPELIA' IN TWO TEMPERAMENTS
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Coppelia'' is a sunny delight that takes the ballet's silly story and lilting Delibes score with just the right amount of seriousness. And the New York City Ballet gave the production the verve that it demands, in performances Friday night and Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: CHAMBER: POLISH ORCHESTRA
description: CULTURE is so important a commodity around the world, that even countries whose relations with each other are not at their best engage in ''cultural exchange.'' Each country believes itself to be doing the other a favor; each believes it reaps the benefits.

title: EMPLOYERS OFFER HELP IN DIVORCES
description: Fred Dulaney, an advertising executive in Fairfield, Conn., remembers the breakdown of his marriage five years ago as a period of more than just personal anguish. Working at the time as a communications specialist for a major company, he became keenly aware as days went on that the strain was beginning to affect his performance in the office.

title: Shortages in East Germany Are Reported to Stir Unrest
description: Shortages of meat, butter, chocolate and other consumer items have caused unrest and threats of protest action in some East German factories, industrial sources said today.

title: VATICAN BANK CLEARED, CARDINAL SAYS
description: Three financial experts have concluded that the Vatican bank is not obligated to cover loans that led to the collapse of an Italian bank, John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia said today.

title: Auto Dealers In F.T.C. Bid
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. and 11 independent Subaru and Toyota distributors are seeking exemption from the Federal Trade Commission's franchise rule, according to the agency.

title: THE DAY A 37-POUNDER FELL FROM HEAVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1982; The Economy
description: Discussing economic prospects, Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the Government's budget deficit could reach $200 billion next year, with unemployment at 9 percent in 1983 and 8 percent in 1984. (Page A1.)

title: Kim's Body Flown Home to Korea
description: The body of Duk Koo Kim was returned here today. About 150 family members, friends, ring colleagues and Korean boxing officials waited at Kimpo International Airport for the flight from Los Angeles that carried the boxer's body.

title: Saints 27, Chiefs 17
description: NEW ORLEANS (UPI) - George Rogers, the New Orleans running back, whose pulled hamstring healed during the strike, ran for 123 yards on 34 carries and a touchdown.

title: Elise Michelle Bloom Bride
description: Elise Michelle Bloom, a lawyer with Mitchell, Loggins, Campbell & Elsberry in Atlanta, was married yesterday to Dr. Mitchell Silverman, a resident physician at the Emory University Medical Center in Atlanta. Rabbi Mordechai Waxman performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bloom of Great Neck. Dr. Silverman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Silverman of Massapequa, L.I.

title: VOLCKER'S TESTIMONY AWAITED
description: Credit market participants are eagerly awaiting tomorrow's testimony before the Joint Economic Committee by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. They hope he will spell out more clearly the Fed's game plan for monetary policy.

title: SPENDING PROPOSALS CRITICIZED
description: Proposals under consideration in Washington that are aimed at spurring economic growth and cutting unemployment might do more harm than good, private analysts contend. Instead, these economists say, the Government should concentrate on easing monetary policy further and on reducing what are likely to be rising Federal budget deficits in the 1984 and 1985 fiscal years.

title: COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AS IT OUGHT NOT BE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Africa To International House

title: Chairman of Domtar Will Retire on Dec. 1
description: Domtar Inc., Canada's largest maker of fine papers, said Alex D. Hamilton will retire as chairman and chief executive officer, posts he has held since 1974. Mr. Hamilton, 65, will also resign as a director. The resignations take effect Dec. 1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Fletcher National Bank, Indianapolis, elected to its board William P. Vititoe, president of the Indiana Bell Telephone Company.

title: LOCAL COLLEGE BASKETBALL: THE BATTLE FOR STATUS IS ON
description: IONA traveled to the Great Alaska Shootout last November to further its plan of gaining a national reputation in college basketball. Victories over Ohio State and Washington State enhanced that effort and started the Gaels to a 24-9 season.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYERS RETURN TO FIELD, BUT MANY FANS REMAIN AT HOME
description: The National Football League returned yesterday from meeting rooms to the more familiar surroundings of stadiums around the country. But the 57-day players strike left an unmistakable mark of skepticism on many of the fans who were watching the first games played since Sept. 20.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Russians, frankly, laugh at the sanctions. They feel the only people who lost were some people who furnished the technology in the United States.''

title: K.P.S. Menon of India Dies; Ex-Envoy to Soviet and China
description: K.P.S. Menon, a retired career diplomat who served as India's Ambassador to Moscow and Peking, died today at his home in Ottappalam in southern India, news reports said. He was 84 years old.

title: Nevada Plane Crash Kills 5
description: A single-engine plane crashed near here Saturday, killing the five occupants, an Elko County sheriff's deputy said. The authorities said they were not sure what caused the crash, about 10 A.M., and that they believed the aircraft was from Colorado.

title: OFFERS AN OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP REMEDIES
description: The world economy is facing the most serious threat to its cohesion and prosperity in the postwar period. Inflation, recession, high unemployment and extraordinary trade and financial pressures are placing the principles and institutions of international economic cooperation under enormous stress.

title: 2.8 Million Afghans In Pakistan, Zia Says
description: Nearly three million Afghan refugees have been driven into Pakistan by the Soviet military intervention in their country, and the number is growing, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today.

title: James Lee, Ex-Vice President; For Pratt & Whitney; Aircraft
description: James S. Lee, retired vice president of worldwide marketing for Pratt & Whitney, now part of United Technologies, died last Friday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. Mr. Lee, who had lived in Key Largo, Fla., since retiring in 1972, was 71 years old.

title: 2 TEXANS HELD IN ABDUCTION OF ABORTION CLINIC'S OPERATOR
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two men today and was seeking another in the kidnapping of an abortion clinic operator and his wife in August, the officials said.

title: BROADCASTERS AND NEWSPAPERS NEED REGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Insurance
description: Continental Insurance Companies has announced that it has developed a new policy to help protect buyers of commercial liability insurance against inflation. Called Inflation Protection, the policy, Continental said, was the first of its kind to be marketed in the United States. It correlates liability limits to the Consumer Price Index and can be written for most classes of business and a wide range of risks.

title: AFTER LEBANON: THE ARAB WORLD IN CRISIS
description: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has set off a crisis in Arab politics of revolutionary proportions. This perception emerges from conversations with Arabs in a tour of Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, Bahrain, Kuwait and Tunisia and talks with Arabs from Egypt and Qatar as well. People say they are deeply humiliated by what took place in Lebanon and despairing of the failure of Arab governments to act Fifth article of a series appearing periodically on the new balance of power in the Middle East since the war in Lebanon. in concerted fashion, or even to let them demonstrate in defense of the Palestinian cause. At a time when the Arab rulers are seen as needing a settlement of the Palestinian problem to defuse the frustration in the Arab world and to spare themselves the wrath of the Palestine Liberation Organization, they are reported in too precarious a position to take the steps needed to start the peace process.

title: ROBERT E. SHORT, BUSINESSMAN, DIES
description: Robert Earl Short, a wealthy lawyer and businessman from Minneapolis who played a role in national politics and sports, died Saturday night of cancer at a Minneapolis hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: RECITAL: MATTHIAS PRESENTS NIGHT OF GREEK PIANO MUSIC
description: THE unusual Greek piano music presented by Miltiades Matthias at Merkin Concert Hall at Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night might have had more of an impact had the pianist been more at home with it. For despite his obvious interest in the music of his native land, the Greek pianist was dependent upon the printed scores, breaking musical gestures to look up.

title: Walesa Attends Mass In Suburban Gdansk
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity union, disappointed thousands of supporters in Gdansk, his home city, today when he failed to attend a mass at a downtown church, as expected, but he attended a service at a church near his suburban home instead.

title: Wrong Vehicle, Wrong Bus Stop
description: Still trying to turn back the civil rights clock, the Reagan Justice Department has found a case in which to argue against school desegregation. Nearly 30 years after Brown v. Board of Education, Solicitor General Rex Lee now urges the Court to grant the Nashville school board's petition to review and reverse a busing order designed to achieve a unitary school system. It's the wrong trip, and the Nashville case is the wrong vehicle.

title: ISRAEL DROPS TEACHERS' PLEDGE
description: The Israeli civil administration in occupied Arab territories has dropped an anti-Palestine Liberation Organization pledge that had been demanded of foreign educators and replaced it with a new work permit for all foreign workers, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a National Basketball Association game, a player dribbling the ball comes to a sudden stop. As he does so, and without moving his feet, the ball pops into the air; he catches it before it falls to the floor. Is this a violation?

title: VICTOR H. LAWN
description: Victor H. Lawn, a New York Times reporter from 1943 until his retirement in 1958, died last Saturday at the Oakwood Nursing Home in Manchester, Mass. He was 90 years old and lived in Rockport, Mass.

title: Stations to Broadcast Reagan's Speech Live
description: President Reagan's speech at 8 o'clock tonight on military affairs will be broadcast live by the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and by the Cable News Network. WNET will broadcast a delayed tape at 11:30 P.M.

title: THE DAY A 37-POUNDER FELL FROM HEAVEN
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Raiders vs. San Diego Chargers, at Los Angeles. This will be the Raiders' first home game in the Coliseum since the team moved from Oakland.

title: GOVERNORS WANT WATT TO RESCIND NEW COAL RULES
description: In their first face-to-face showdown with Interior Secretary James G. Watt over Federal land policy, several Western governors will push Monday for a stronger role in shaping the pace of coal development.

title: L.I.U. 3-0 VICTOR IN PLAYOFF
description: Long Island University defeated Columbia, 3-0, in the New York regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament yesterday at Baker Field.

title: Thompson Sues
description: Jack Thompson, a reserve quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, has filed a Federal breach-of-contract suit in Seattle against the National Football League.

title: WAVERLY CONSORT OFFERS MUSIC OF VENICE
description: THE WAVERLY CONSORT, in its Alice Tully Hall program Saturday night, offered something more than a simple concert. The well-known early music ensemble, in its ''Music of Venice'' program, delivered something along the lines of a sonic travelogue.

title: A CASE OF HONOR IN CANADA: REDRESS FOR ITS JAPANESE
description: A group of third generation Japanese-Canadians is demanding that Canada apologize and pay cash reparations to elderly Japanese men and women who have been quietly bearing 40-year-old memories of wartime humiliation, internment, dispossession and forced labor.

title: AMERICAN MANAGERS HEAR JAPAN'S VIEW
description: Is Japanese management as good as it is supposed to be? The answer evidently depends on which side of the Pacific is home. East met West at a two-day conference at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last week, and exchanged views about the management techniques and Government policies that have been credited with what has been commonly described as Japan's postwar economic miracle.

title: WITH SONICS, THOMPSON HELPS MAKE THE PIECES FIT
description: SEATTLE FOR one brief moment last week, it was almost as if the nightmares that had haunted David Thompson's past never existed. He was flying again. But the scene was not Denver, where Thompson soared and tumbled many times, but here in the Kingdome, where he is a new member of the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: TAX-FREE OFFERINGS POUR OUT
description: This week's supply of new tax-exempt bond issues continues at a record pace, but the corporate market has subsided. Investment bankers say, however, that the number of corporate and foreign borrowers could increase quickly.

title: People
description: * Lawrence Singer appointed president of Wells, Rich, Greene/Chicago.

title: UPSETS IN WEST SHIFT BOWL SCENE
description: Some of the best made plans between bowl committees and universities went astray on football fields in the West last Saturday. Notre Dame was knocked out of bowl consideration at Air Force, Washington was denied a third consecutive trip to the Rose Bowl in a major upset by Washington State, and Stanford was the victim of one of the most bizarre finishes in a college game when California won on a fivelateral kickoff return on the last play.

title: Three Novelists Win French Literary Awards
description: The Canadian-born author Anne Hebert won the Prix Femina, one of France's top literary awards, today for ''Les Fous de Bassan,'' a poetic novel about two female cousins who disappeared in 1936.

title: Article 050079 -- No Title
description: An emergency appeal has brought $35 million in cash and food donations for refugees in Lebanon, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said today. The agency estimates it needs about $8 million more for postwar emergency work for 175,000 displaced Palestinians.

title: Suspect in Abortion Extortion Held on $1 Million Cash Bond
description: A United States magistrate today set $1 million cash bond for Wayne A. Moore, one of three men charged with extortion in the ''Army of God'' abduction of an abortion clinic owner and his wife.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Myron Du Bain, 59 years old, has been elected president of Amfac Inc., a widely diversified processor and distributor of food and sugar based in Hawaii, effective Jan. 1. He is expected to tack on the post of chief executive officer on April 20, the date of Amfac's annual meeting.

title: COOK INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After a reversal of a tax credit of $462,000...C-Net income including a tax credit of $305,000

title: Mancini Won't Quit
description: Ray Mancini says he has no plans to retire from boxing after the death of Duk Koo Kim, whom he knocked unconscious in their title bout Nov. 13.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * ARA Services Inc.'s offering of $25 million of notes, due in 1992, was priced at par with a 12 percent coupon, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations which increased netincome by $80,000 or 2 cents a shr

title: MONUMENT ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RADIOLOGISTS URGE FEWER CHEST X-RAYST
description: THE American College of Radiology in Chicago, which represents 13,500 board-certified radiologists, has endorsed new restrictions on the use of chest X-rays in routine examinations and screening programs.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Water: the Nature, Uses, and Future of Our Most Precious and Abused Resource By Fred Powledge. 423 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. Water is ubiquitous. It's found underground, on the earth's surface and in the air. It is the only substance on earth that exists in all three physical states - liquid, gas and solid. We depend on it for drinking, brushing our teeth, growing our food, heating and cooling our homes, manufacturing our goods, bathing, and playing with. It's so common we take it for granted.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $4,018,000 and an estimated loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $5 million...C-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $3,618,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of$40,000

title: Hopes for 1983 Airline Upturn
description: The airline industry has been battered not only by the recession but also by the lingering effects of the air traffic controllers' strike of 1981 and by profit-sapping fare wars. In the first three quarters of this year, 11 major airlines suffered losses totaling $330 million, which exceeded their $210 million of losses in the comparable period of 1981.

title: Ex-Prosecutor in Lead For Cuomo Justice Job
description: A former district attorney in Monroe County, Lawrence T. Kurlander, is the leading candidate for appointment to the new post of state coordinator of criminal justice, top aides to Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Leaders at Fall Nationals Include New York Players
description: Players from New York State were among the leaders here this afternoon going into the final two sessions of two major events at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
WALESA SAID TO HOPE TO REVIVE SOLIDARITY
description: Lech Walesa has held meetings with his associates in Solidarity and told them that he hopes to revive the banned union, according to a Pole who has attended the meetings.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Harvester Chairman Grades Himself 'Superb'
description: When the board of the International Harvester Company asked Archie R. McCardell, its chairman and chief executive, to step down last May, he quickly disappeared from view and said he would spend two or three months on the golf and tennis courts before making a move.

title: Drew Leaves Jazz To Get Treatment
description: John Drew, the Utah Jazz forward, left the team today to undergo rehabilitative treatment for undisclosed personal problems, the club said.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: B-Including pretax income of $1,092,700 from the sale of securities

title: Rashad Retiring
description: Ahmad Rashad, the Minnesota Vikings' leading career receiver with 5,334 yards, has announced that he is retiring at the end of the season to pursue a career in broadcasting. ''I've always wanted to go out feeling well and go out on top,'' said the 33-year-old Rashad, who has caught 472 passes for 6,598 yards since he entered the league in 1972 as a first-round draft choice of the St. Louis Cardinals. He has been working with a CBS affiliate in Minneapolis, and before the season was offered a contract, which he rejected.

title: Steel Statistics at Lows
description: Steel production fell 4.6 percent last week, to 1.055 million tons, its lowest level since 1971, while factory use slowed to a 49-year low, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Production in the week ended Saturday compared with 1.106 million tons the previous week and was the lowest weekly output since the 947,000 tons produced in the week ended Aug. 7, 1971, the industry group reported. The industry's production stood at 35.7 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 37.4 percent in the previous week.

title: CONGRESSIONAL AIDES HELPING TO FEED THE HOMELESS
description: It was not the typical ''Dear Colleague'' letter appealing for votes. The request was much simpler: Join the Sandwich Brigade.

title: TWO GROUPS BACK ALTERNATIVE-TO-PRISON PROGRAMS
description: Two private groups that monitor New York's criminal-justice system called on Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders yesterday to give high priority to programs providing ''meaningful alternative penalties'' for certain convicted offenders who the groups feel should not be sent to prison.

title: MAN ACCUSED OF KILLING JUDGE DENIES HE IS GUILTY
description: Charles Voyde Harrelson, who is charged with assassinating Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., testified today that he was in Dallas running errands on the morning the judge was killed in San Antonio.

title: The Editorial Notebook; New Windows on Cancer
description: Eighteen months ago, the nature of the cancer cell was an almost total mystery. Two bright windows have suddenly opened up into the darkness, and new details emerge weekly. A fundamental understanding of cancer seems to be within reach at last.

title: DESIGNERS' TOUCH FOR MIDTOWN MALL
description: Developers of Herald Center, Manhattan's first shopping mall, disclosed design plans yesterday for the $50 million multilevel retail project at the site of the old Korvettes building on Herald Square.

title: DANCE: POSTMODERNS BY WERKECENTRUM
description: WERKCENTRUM DANS presented an ambitious three-program season at the Bessie Schonberg Theater last week, ending Sunday afternoon with two dances that suggested much about the Rotterdam-based modern-dance company's image as a group and its anthologistic approach to repertory.

title: I.B.M. SUIT ON SECRETS IS WIDENED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has settled a lawsuit against one of three former employees it accused of stealing corporate secrets, but has added new accusations to its suit against the two other defendants.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 5
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FAST HANDS

title: 25 MILK COMPANIES ADMIT OVERCHARGING FOR A DECADE
description: Twenty-five milk companies have admitted that they overcharged consumers in the New York metropolitan area for a decade through a price-fixing and distribution conspiracy, the State Attorney General announced yesterday.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Reflects a deferred income tax charge of $1,993,000

title: News Analysis
description: In their first exchange since the shift of Soviet leadership, President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet Communist Party leader, left the impasse in Soviet-American relations essentially unrelieved by declaring their desire for arms control without offering new public concessions.

title: HGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Father Unable to Help as 8 In His Family Die in Home Fire
description: Eight people, including a mother and her five children, died in a fire early Sunday that destroyed their wood-frame home in 15 minutes.

title: O'NEILL AND BAKER TO SEEK TAX TO AID ROAD REPAIR PLAN
description: The Speaker of the House, a Democrat, and the Republican Senate majority leader agreed today to press, in the post-election session, for an increase in the gasoline tax to finance a $5.5 billion program to repair highways and bridges and to assist urban mass transit systems.

title: Yankees, Rawley Agree
description: Acting with uncharacteristic timing, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, has locked up Shane Rawley with a long-term contract a full year before the left-handed pitcher is eligible to become a free agent. Tony Attanasio, Rawley's agent, said yesterday that he had reached an agreement in principle on a new contract for the pitcher.

title: LONDON DEFENDS BRITOIL'S SALE
description: Energy Minister Nigel Lawson said today that investors had bid for only 27 percent of the Britoil P.L.C. shares that the state-owned company had offered in its move to go private. Confirmation that the sale had been so undersubscribed touched off a new round of political attacks and calls for his resignation in the House of Commons.

title: FOR CUBA'S STEVENSON, QUEST GOES ON
description: The Latin music was playing loudly and three youthful Cuban boxers broke the monotony of the workout by forming a pugilistic chorus line and dancing as if they were the lounge act in the hotel where the team was training. They were backstage in a cabaret room filled with American fans who had come to catch a glimpse of the Cubans, in particular Teofilo Stevenson. He was sitting just out of view, meticulously applying tape to a favorite jump rope that had become frayed.

title: FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $299,000 for the qr and $1,123,000 for the yr and tax credits of $212,000 for the qr and $835,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $355,000 for the qr and $720,000 for the yr and tax credits of $617,000 for the qr and $862,000 for the yr

title: Missing: Fans
description: Where did the football fans go during the 57-day strike by the National Football League players? Surveys have suggested that many fans rediscovered their families, their automobiles, their local shopping malls and their friendly Offtrack Betting parlors. But the latest television survey suggests that one thing they did not discover en masse was the Saturday afternoon college football game.

title: Harnischfeger Debt Discussions
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation, a heavy machinery company that lost $13.9 million in the third quarter, said it is beginning a costcutting plan but said the cuts will not help the company's fourth quarter, when it expects ''substantially greater losses.''

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ REPORTS EXPELLING IRANIANS IN ONE AREA

title: FORD SAYS REAGAN IS MOVING TOWARD THE POLITICAL CENTER
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford said yesterday that he sees strong indications that President Reagan is shifting from the right toward the center of ''the Republican political philosophy,'' perhaps at least in part because of the party's recent losses in the House of Representatives.

title: Princeton Gets $4 Million Gift
description: Malcolm S. Forbes, editor in chief of Forbes Magazine, today announced a gift of $4 million on behalf of the Forbes Foundation and the Forbes family to Princeton University's five-year, $275 million fund-raising drive.

title: Eisenreich Improved
description: Jim Eisenreich, the Minnesota Twins' rookie center fielder, is apparently winning his battle to overcome a nervous disorder that forced him onto the disabled list for a second time last June 18. Howard Fox, the Twins' executive vice president, said team doctors had told Eisenreich that he was responding well enough to the treatment and would be able to go to spring training. Dr. Leonard Michienzi said the treatment was a ''self-learning discipline'' and that it did not involve the use of drugs.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne, declaring that she had rescued Chicago from the ''greatest crisis'' in its history, formally announced today that she would seek re-election.

title: SEVERE SANCTIONS LEVIED ON CLEMSON
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, citing a ''large number'' of serious recruiting violations, today placed Clemson University's football program on probation with severe sanctions. It imposed a two-year ban on television and postseason appearances on the school, and stripped the program of 20 scholarships.

title: U.S. Begins Case In Rigging Trial
description: The Government opened its case today in the trial of the harness driver Ben Webster and two other men accused of scheming to rig races at the Meadowlands in the summer of 1981.

title: PHILIP FINKELSTEIN, 51, OFFICIAL IN THE LINDSAY ADMINISTRATION
description: Philip Finkelstein, former deputy city administrator in the Lindsay administration and the director of the Henry George School of Social Science, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 51 years old.

title: POP: DEVO PERFORMS WITH THEATRICS
description: IF video games are the main threat to rock-music profits, Devo has nothing to worry about. The quintet's show Friday at the Palladium paid off with the same uncomplicated thrills as an arcade favorite.

title: People
description: * Jay Beckerman, Michael J. Drake, Charles J. Hasser, Larry Hoffner and William Wiener have been elected senior vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: DONLAN ACCUSES GARVEY
description: Jack Donlan, the executive director of the National Football League Management Council, accused the N.F.L. Players Association yesterday of trying to ''sabotage'' the five-year contract that was tentatively agreed upon last week.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM ANDROPOV'S SPEECH TO THE SOVIET PARTY'S CENTRAL; COMMITTEE

title: Dow Drops By 21.25, To 1,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 21.25 points yesterday, finishing at 1,000, as traders and investors engaged in the classic Wall Street exercise of ''selling on the news.''

title: I.B.M. Typewriter
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would begin limited marketing of a compact personal typewriter for home, student and professional use. The correcting typewriter, called the I.B.M. Personal Typewriter, will have a suggested retail price of $695 and will be marketed starting this week in Atlanta, Dallas, Houston and Chicago.

title: Rule Change For Pensions
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, issuing a ''preliminary view'' that promises to trigger sharp debate in American business circles, proposed yesterday that companies be required to reflect pension liabilities on their balance sheets and to standardize the way in which pension costs are reported.

title: INTECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: 'COBALT BLUES,' ON STRATEGIC MATERIALS
description: FOR its first half, ''The Cobalt Blues'' presents the case that America is in a perilous condition, dependent for strategic materials on countries that are shaky at best and unsavory at second best. ''What the Persian Gulf is to oil,'' we are told, ''Africa is to strategic minerals.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unless we demonstrate the will to rebuild our strength and restore the military balance, the Soviets, since they are so far ahead, have little incentive to negotiate with us.

title: Dome Petroleum Holds Payment
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it continues to hold a $100 million (Canadian) down payment it received from its subsidiary, Dome Canada Ltd., in a deal that fell through in July.

title: Vanity Fair Promotion Is Planned for January
description: Rapp & Collins, the direct-marketing agency that is handling circulation promotion for Vanity Fair magazine, is arranging a 4.5-million-piece mailing in January.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTANA AND STABLER EXCEL
description: On most of the 57 days that the National Football League players were otherwise occupied because of the strike, Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback, found someone to catch his practice passes. On none of the 57 days did Ken Stabler, the New Orleans Saints' quarterback.

title: Max Goldenberg Is Dead at 80; Active in City's Hotel Industry
description: Max Goldenberg, executive director of the Metropolitan Hotel Industry Stabilization Association, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: U.N. UNIT BACKS LIMITS ON NEWS
description: The third world and the Soviet bloc today outvoted the West and upheld the right of governments to veto incoming satellite television broadcasts from abroad.

title: ELECTION OF ANDROPOV HINTS A SECOND KEY POST IN SOVIET
description: Reports that Yuri V. Andropov was to be appointed to the second of the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev's two posts, that of chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, or head of state, were strengthened when the Supreme Soviet met early today and immediately elected Mr. Andropov to the Presidium,

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPORTS SAYS ATOMIC WASTE POLICY COULD BE MODIFIED TO SAVE MONEY
description: The Inspector General for the Department of Energy said today that scaling back and revising the atomic waste treatment program at West Valley in western New York could save the Federal Government a substantial amount of money.

title: 7 Injured in Fire In Jersey City
description: Seven persons, including five firefighters, were injured today in a four-alarm fire that destroyed three houses here, authorities said.

title: Market Place; Thrift Industry Profitability
description: A former official in the thrift industry who lost his job when his f ailing institution was forced to merge with a healthier partner r ecently said with bitterness that he saw no future for the industry.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain from equity investment of $434,000...C-After a loss from equity investment of $179,000 for qr and 9 mos

title: STAGE: RADIO CITY CHRISTMAS
description: THE carolers could have stepped out of a Currier and Ives print and the sentiments expressed on stage might have been written by Hallmark. The Christmas show at Radio City Music Hall, otherwise known as ''The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' is a 144-footwide greeting card, and thousands of people will have received the traditional message before the show has ended its holiday engagement.

title: ISRAELIS TO DISCUSS RULE SHIFT WITH ARAB SCHOOL PERSONNEL
description: The chief of the Israeli adminstration in the occupied West Bank will meet with officials of Arab universities on Wednesday to discuss a change that is intended to end protests over the special work permits that have been required for foreign teachers. Whether it will be acceptable to the protesters was not clear.

title: 'A Hell of a Mess'
description: The remark was facetious, but it did come from the President of the United States and it rang with truth. Testing his voice level for a radio broadcast Saturday, Mr. Reagan quipped that the economy was in ''a hell of a mess.'' He's right. The hard part is what to do about it, and so far the answers coming out of Washington are contradictory.

title: Columbia Retools
description: Gray and grimy from its fifth mission, the space shuttle Columbia returned to its launch site today to begin nine months of changes for bigger crews and bigger duties.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $2,682,741 for the qr and 9 mos from the sale of the company's leasehold interest in a Miami apartment complex

title: 'We must get to the causes of our difficulties.'
description: THE subject was Soviet-American relations, a field in which Richard M. Nixon has more than passing knowledge and no little experience, and the former President, once a hawk's hawk, the classic Cold Warrior, relished delivering what became an exuberant lecture, pausing periodically, half amused, to remind his listener that he was not a dove.

title: AWARDS FOR WOMEN WHO BEAT THE ODDS
description: Two extraordinary women, Mae Bertha Carter of Drew, Miss., and Phyllis Old Dog Cross of Rapid City, S.D., met for the first time last weekend, part of a group of 18 women selected from across the country as winners of the first Wonder Woman Foundation Financial Awards. The women, all more than 40 years old, received grants of $7,500 each.

title: 'Peacemaker' Loses Missile Name Game
description: In addition to the hard time the Reagan Administration had in finding a home for the MX missile, the Government also had a hard time finding a name for the new weapon.

title: MOVING BEYOND MERELY PLAYING GAMES
description: VIDEO games are the pop music of the 80's. Complete with superstars, Top 40 lists and even electronic groupies tagging along, hoping to get one of Nasir Gebelli's data-entry routines or John Harris's autograph on a high-resolution graphics print. Like pop music, video games combine those central elements of entertainment, money and fame that seem to be the driving forces of life these days.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL ADMISSIONS DOWN
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, first-year enrollment is down this fall at the nation's medical schools.

title: SEEKS ARMS PACTS WITH SOVIET; Andropov Speech; Excerpts from speech, page A13.
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, said Monday that the Soviet Union would seek detente with the United States. He also heralded a new drive to aid the domestic economy through incentives and decentralization.

title: Bank Is Fined
description: The Philadelphia International Bank, a subsidiary of the Philadelphia National Bank, has agreed to pay a record civil penalty of $189,000 in connection with 220 letters of credit that sought to promote the Arab trade boycott of Israel, the Department of Commerce said. The department, which did not say what countries were concerned, said the bank was not accused of cooperating with the boycott, but was late in reporting receipt of the letters. The bank neither admitted nor denied the charge, but promised to take what the department called corrective measures.

title: MUSIC: THE MINIMALISM OF GLASS, GIBSON, MORAN
description: AT the end of a tribute to musical minimalism at the Third Street Music School Settlement last night, the composer Jon Gibson was asked how the style came into existence. He mentioned Terry Riley, who in 1964 composed ''In C.'' Mr. Gibson, who played in that performance, and has also worked with Steve Reich, Philip Glass and other ''minimalists,'' mentioned the influence of pop music, the influence of Indian music and eventually confessed, ''I don't know.''

title: BANKS ASKED TO LEND $6.5 BILLION TO MEXICO
description: The International Monetary Fund's managing director has asked commercial banks to agree to lend Mexico up to $6.5 billion in fresh credits over the next 13 months.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to include the adoption of Zynolyte Products Co in Nov 1981; per shr figures reflect LIFO charges equal to 7 cents a shr in 1982 and 30 a shr in 1981 and a gain equal to 6 cents a shr for the yr-ago periods on real estate transactions

title: EFFORTS WIDEN TO CURB SEXUAL ABUSE IN THERAPY
description: THE essential foundation on which the patient-therapist relationship rests in psychotherapy is that of a basic trust. - Dr. Judd Marmor, past president of the American Psychiatric Association. Perhaps the most glaring breach of trust in psychotherapy, in the view of many practitioners, is the therapist's use of the vulnerable patient for sexual gratification. And while sexually exploitative therapists were almost ignored a few years ago, a growing number of patient complaints and court cases - as well as new research - has impelled leaders in the field toward seeking control of wayward practioners.

title: NEW CHARGES ARE RAISED ON PLOTS BY THE C.I.A. TO TOPPLE ALLENDE
description: American intelligence officers maintain that efforts to overthrow President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile continued long after Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger testified they had stopped, according to an article in The Atlantic Monthly.

title: DAN RIVER RESISTS BID FROM ICAHN
description: Dan River Inc., the textile company, appeared last night to have fought off - for the present - a hostile takeover bid by Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: Britain's visible trade showed a surplus of 259 million in October on a seasonally adjusted basis, compared with a surplus of 239 million in September.

title: WATT ACCEPTS RULE CHANGES PROPOSED BY WESTERN STATES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt agreed today to broad changes in Federal coal leasing regulations demanded of him by a group of Western governors.

title: First Paycheck
description: Pro football resumes after the 57-day strike. It is Sunday, the day of reunion. In Orchard Park, N.Y., the Buffalo Bills play the Miami Dolphins (and lose, 9-7).

title: RAIDERS, DOWN BY 24-0, WIN
description: It took Al Davis more than two years to bring his football team here from farther up the coastline in Oakland. Tonight, showing the same persistence as their owner, the Los Angeles Raiders were undaunted by a 24-point deficit and scored a 28-24 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

title: TV: DRAMA OF COUNTRY MUSIC
description: ALTHOUGH it doesn't give any credit to Joseph L. Mankiewicz, the screenwriter, ''Country Gold,'' the made-for-television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight, owes its very existence to his memorable film ''All About Eve.'' That production, which starred Bette Davis in what came to be her signature role, has now been converted into a countrymusic saga, starring Loni Anderson as a platinum-wigged singer bearing more than a passing resemblance to Dolly Parton. The ways of television repackaging are indeed wondrous to behold.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 1.7 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was down 1.2 percent, or 1.7 million shares, in the month ended Nov. 15, to 139.7 million shares.

title: TEEN-AGER HELD AFTER FIRE KILLS HER BROTHER, 9
description: The 18-year-old daughter of a high school vice principal was charged today with killing her 9-year-old brother in a fire she is accused of setting in the family home after a series of disagreements with her parents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Rent: Gubernatorial Offices

title: Military Analysis
description: Since Iraq's forces are well organized and trained, deploy thousands of tanks, guns and missiles and are superior in the air, why are they not winning the war with Iran? Why are Iraq's frontiers threatened by an Iranian army that includes thousands of untrained boys and whose air support is negligible?

title: QUEENS ASSEMBLY RACE SPURS DISPUTE ON TACTICS
description: Three weeks after Election Day, a State Assembly election in Queens has produced a forgery investigation, charges of questionable campaign tactics and a protest meeting of civic activists.

title: Suspect Arrested In Midtown Killing
description: A 20-year-old Queens man was arrested and charged with murder, assault and reckless endangerment yesterday in the slaying of a Brooklyn teen-ager in Times Square early Sunday morning, the police said.

title: Stuffing Fruit Flies
description: Scientists seeking substitutes for toxic chemicals used to eradicate fruit flies in Florida and California have discovered new and less harmful pesticides that either kill the insects directly or cause them to commit suicide by overeating.

title: SAFETY AND DELAYS FOR NEW HAVEN LINE RIDERS
description: For more than a week, commuters on Conrail's New Haven line have been delayed as much as an hour by safety inspections while the trains were in service. The inspections were undertaken after two incidents in which wheels fell off the line's $1 million rail cars. No injuries resulted.

title: KENNEDY CONFIRMS HE IS IN THE PROCESS OF GETTING A DIVORCE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy and his estranged wife, Joan, are in the process of obtaining a divorce, a spokesman for the Massachusetts Democrat said here today.

title: Boeing and China
description: The Civil Aviation Administration of China has agreed to buy 10 B-737-200 airliners from the Boeing Company, the New China News Agency said. But in Seattle, Boeing said it was unable to confirm reports that China would buy the 737's for about $160 million. Boeing said it was also awaiting word on whether Peking will order two 747 jumbo jets for some $150 million.

title: IN AMAZON, HUGE STUDY AIMS TO SAVE JUNGLE LIFE
description: AT night, bats swooped through the jungle lean - to as the group of visitors to the Amazon lashed their hammocks in place. By morning, the group was picking its dark and damp way along the forest floor, 130 feet beneath the canopy of treetops and the spotty dawn's light. ''Hear that squeaking hinge? That's a toucan,'' said Richard Bierregaard Jr. Moments later, he was training his binoculars on a formation of five parrots that had swept into view. ''That's an odd sighting,'' he said. ''Parrots mate for life. The odd one must be an early widower or a juvenile.''

title: 3 MILE ISLAND SUPERVISOR APPEARS TO CONTRADICT PREVIOUS STATEMENTS
description: The supervisor in the control room at the time of the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant appeared to contradict himself yesterday while testifying in Federal court about whether he knew a key safety valve was malfunctioning before the accident.

title: No Headline
description: Drop in OPEC Output Is Seen

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-After a charge of $998,000 for a change in accounting for inventory

title: CITY TAKES FIRST PRISONERS IN 17 1/2 TOKEN WAR
description: The first prisoners were taken in the war of the tokens yesterday morning, and hours later, Mayor Koch called Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut in an effort to resolve the six-day dispute. But the diplomatic efforts failed.

title: FLICK TAX DEAL UNDER SCRUITNY
description: The Economics Ministry announced today that it was investigating the Friedrich Flick Group, a private holding company, to determine whether it had fradulently obtained major tax concessions when it acquired an interest in W.R. Grace & Company of New York.

title: BONN AIDE REPROACHES U.S. BISHOPS FOR NUCLEAR ARMS STAND
description: A senior West German official said today that the opposition of American Roman Catholic bishops to the first use of nuclear weapons was ''a selective ethical view'' that weakened the credibility of the United States nuclear deterrent in Europe.

title: Wrong Harness for Angola
description: The last time we looked, the Reagan Administration was saying that its patient diplomacy would lure South Africa out of its illegal tenancy in Namibia. On looking again, it seems more likely that the luring has been done by South Africa. It has deftly seized an American idea to condition its departure on Cuban troops leaving Angola and thus disguised its recalcitrance.

title: FIRST MATAGORDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DENTAL WORLD CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW CONCERN SELLS INTELLIGENCE TO GO
description: First they contacted Edward Heath, the former Prime Minister of Britain, and persuaded him to serve on the board. Then they called Robert S. McNamara, the former president of the World Bank and Secretary of Defense, and got him to sign up, too. A former finance minister of Colombia and a former trade minister of France also became involved, along with a handful of foreign correspondents. They chose as the leader a former senior executive for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Wins at A.T.&.T.
description: THE big shootout at American Telephone and Telegraph's Basking Ridge, N.J., headquarters complex is over. When the smoke cleared yesterday, the winners were Kenneth Roman and his hard-riding posse from Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Arguello Votes No on 12 Rounds
description: Alexis Arguello votes no: He does not think that shortening championship fights from 15 rounds to 12 would reduce the number of deaths in the ring.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are counterrotating propellers used on large turboprop aircraft, such as the Soviet Tu-114 transport and Tu-95 bomber?.

title: PRIME CUT TO 11 1/2, A 26-MONTH LOW
description: Major banks across the country cut their prime lending rates by half a percentage point yesterday, to 11 1/2 percent, the lowest level since September 1980.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Entomology To Origami

title: SEEKS ARMS PACTS WITH SOVIET; Reagan transcript, Page A12.
description: President Reagan called today for the ''dense pack'' deployment of the MX intercontinental missile to modernize American nuclear forces, but said he was committed to seeking sharp reductions in strategic arms by mutual agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: 7 Not Guilty Pleas In Trident Protest
description: Pleas of not guilty were entered today for seven nuclear-arms opponents accused of trespassing on the grounds of the Electric Boat shipyard and damaging a Trident nuclear submarine, the Georgia.

title: City Subway Deal Assailed by U.S.
description: The Canadian Government is unfairly subsidizing the sale of 825 subway cars to be built in Canada for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York, the Commerce Department announced in a preliminary finding yesterday in Washington.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1982; Markets
description: Stock prices plummeted, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 21.25 points, to precisely 1,000. Analysts said the Federal Reserve's cut in the discount rate Friday had already been anticipated by the market and thus failed to provide support. (Page D1.) Prices of Treasury bonds also fell sharply. At the weekly auction, three-month bills averaged 7.944 percent and six-month bills, 8.109 percent. (D14.) Short interest on the Big Board was down 1.2 percent. (D24.)

title: FILED IN 1969, SUIT ON RIGHTS GETS TO COURT
description: A civil damage suit filed by two former antipoverty workers came to trial today after a 13-year wait. The plaintiffs' attorney told a jury that the two had suffered a ''sordid history'' of legal harassment by a United States Senator and his aides.

title: PRIME RATE LOWERED TO 11 1/2%, BUT DOW AND BONDS PLUNGE
description: The nation's major banks lowered their prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday, to 11 1/2 percent, the lowest level since September 1980.

title: HAROLD DIAMOND
description: Harold Diamond, an art dealer who specialized in 20th-century works, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan and Huntington, L.I.

title: Japan-U.S. Trade Talks
description: Japan and the United States will hold two high-level meetings in early December to discuss bilateral trade issues, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. Among issues to be discussed are American requests that Japan liberalize markets for beef and citrus fruits, expand tobacco imports and reduce tariffs on several other United States farm products, the spokesman said. The Japan-United States trade subcommittee is scheduled to meet in Tokyo Dec. 3-4, followed by subcabinet level talks Dec. 6-7.

title: Chairman of Minet Holdings Quits
description: Minet Holdings P.L.C., a British insurance brokerage firm, announced yesterday that John Wallrock, its chairman and chief executive, had resigned after disclosing he had a personal interest in the reinsurance arrangements effected by PCW Underwriting Agencies Ltd. and WMD Underwriting Agencies Ltd., both units of Minet Holdings.

title: 2 Nuns to Spend Six Months In Prison for Nuclear Protest
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns were sentenced today to six months in prison for forging Government passes and trespassing at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, where they hoisted a flag with ''Death Factory'' on it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fumigation 'Reparations'

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON NUCLEAR STRATEGY TOWARD SOVIET UNION
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech on arms policy tonight, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: GOVERNOR FORESEES SUPPORT IN WYOMING
description: Gov. Ed Herschler of Wyoming said today that he would back President Reagan's decision to deploy the MX missile in his state and predicted that most people in Wyoming would accept it as well. ''There is a great deal of support in our state for the MX,'' said Governor Herschler, a Democrat, at a news conference. He was in Denver attending a meeting of other Western governors.

title: Grant to Finance City Water Study
description: A $174,000 grant has been made to the Citizens Union Research Foundation to undertake a comprehensive examination of New York City's water supply system. The grant from the Charles H. Revson Foundation will be used for a two-year study and the publication of a Plan of Action for New York City's Water Supply.

title: Protests Continue At Harlem Shelter
description: Two hundred Harlem residents protested yesterday at a former school that has been turned into a shelter for homeless men, the fifth day of demonstrations against the shelter.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Business People article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported Donald C. Clark's new position at Household International. Mr. Clark, president of Household, was elected to the additional post of chief executive officer.

title: Crash Stalls Investigators
description: An Air Force investigation team said today it had failed to find the cause of the crash of a C-141 cargo jet on a rugged Tennessee mountainside in August. According to officials, the investigation of the crash, which killed nine crewmen, found no evidence of mistakes by the pilots or ground controllers or of major mechanical difficulties, although it did turn up a flight error in takeoff and two minor maintenance problems reported on an earlier sortie the same day.

title: VIOLINS: WHAT PRICE PRICELESS?
description: WHEN Salvatore Accardo played the Guarneri del Gesu ''Cannon'' in Carnegie Hall earlier this month, the violin he used, which once was owned by Niccolo Paganini and is now in the possession of the city of Genoa, was insured for $800,000. Some violin dealers in New York were amused at that figure. They think it should have been well over $800,000. And one of them, Mosa Havivi, was outraged, but for a different reason.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Woman, 91, Slain
description: A 91-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Washington Heights apartment last night, the police said. The victim, Betty Flatow of 89 Fairview Avenue, was found at 10:30 P.M. by a daughter who lives in another apartment in the same building, a police spokesman said.

title: AFRICAN ISLE'S STORY: SLAVERY AND A NEW SERVITUDE
description: There is a house in this sunstruck place that is called the House of Slaves and many Americans, both black and white, have stood before its somber dungeons in homage and quest, recalling the human traffic that once linked Africa to a cruel, new world across the Atlantic.

title: 10,000 Pupils Sent Home In Florida Measles Drive
description: Officials at 150 schools in northern Dade County today turned away more than 10,000

title: Director Andrzej Wajda Wins $100,000 Prize
description: Andrzej Wajda, the Polish film maker who directed ''Man of Iron,'' has been named winner of the $100,000 Athinai Prize, awarded by the Onassis Foundation, for his ''contribution to human dignity.''

title: CONCEIVED HOUSTON'S ASTRODOME
description: Roy Mark Hofheinz, who rose from a radio disk jockey to Mayor of Houston and was the entrepreneur who conceived of the Astrodome, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: CHEWING TOBACCO PERIL
description: An alarming increase in precancerous mouth lesions has been noted among young people who use chewing tobacco and snuff. Dr. Irving Meyer, an oral pathologist at Tufts University, told a meeting of the American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons that 3 to 5 percent of the precancerous lesions eventually become malignant.

title: COMPUTERS: FOCUS ON SCHOOLS
description: The country's leading personal computer manufacturers are betting that the fastest route to placing a small computer in every American living room is to first get one through the schoolhouse door.

title: U.S. AND TRUCKING INDUSTRY MAY FIGHT ON TAX PLAN
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis fired the first volley today in what may develop into a battle with the trucking industry over his plan to raise gasoline and other taxes to provide $5.5 billion in revenue for transportation programs.

title: ECONOMISTS, IN POLL, SEE 'MODEST' 1983 RECOVERY
description: The national economy will recover from the recession next year, but growth will be ''quite modest'' and unemployment will remain above 9 percent, according to a new poll of business economists.

title: 2 STYLISH LOOKS FOR WOMEN IN BUSINESS
description: Some executive women believe that to be taken seriously in a man's world they must conform to a masculine dress code. Other executive women believe they can look both businesslike and feminine without wearing man-tailored suits.

title: HOWARD R. BLOOMQUIST
description: Howard R. Bloomquist, former senior vice president and director of the Warner-Lambert Company, died Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE sense of fair play of a few teen-agers has exposed serious flaws in the security of the important college board achievement tests. The youngsters, students at the Dalton School, a private school in New York City, had taken special instruction from two private tutors in preparation for the achievement tests in English and mathematics. When they took the test two weeks ago, they found the version before them was the very test their tutor had used to coach them, and reported the matter to school officials.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that it, Bendix Corp. and Martin Marietta Corp. had agreed to extend the closing date of Allied's offer for stock of Bendix and Marietta until Dec. 13, to provide additional time for the Justice Department's antitrust investigation.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trantino Parole Formally Denied
description: Thomas Trantino, the convicted killer of two policemen, is ineligible for parole because of ''the shocking nature of the homicides'' and other aggravating factors, the State Parole Board said today. The formal opinion confirmed a 5-2 vote by the board, announced Oct. 21, to keep Mr. Trantino in prison.

title: FIVE-LATERAL KICK RETURN ONE FOR BOOK
description: R ichard Rodgers, the special teams' captain, called for a huddle before California's kickoff return unit lined up near the end of the game Saturday against Stanford at Berkeley, Calif. The Cardinals had just gone ahead, 20-19, on a 35-yard field goal by Mark Harmon and there were four seconds remaining. In the huddle, Rodgers told his teammates that if they got the ball on the kickoff return they were not to let themselves be tackled - ''Don't go down,'' he said - but to lateral the ball back to a teammate to keep the return going.

title: Clemson Speaks
description: Dr. Bill Atchley, the president of the Clemson University, will hold a news conference today to comment formally on the bad news that had long been expected and was announced last night: that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had put Clemson's football program on probation, with severe sanctions, because of recruiting violations. But Dr. Atchley will also call for sweeping reforms in all college recruiting.

title: Chess: Czechs Second in Lucerne; United States Finishes 3d
description: Czechoslovakia clung to its half-point lead over the United States to capture second place in the Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland. In the final round, the United States team's 2 1/2-1 1/2 victory over Sweden gained no ground, since the surprising Czechs won from the Netherlands by the same score.

title: Bid for Pabst Is Advanced
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said yesterday that it had received qualified approval from the Justice Department to buy a controlling interest in the Pabst Brewing Company.

title: CONCERT: CARNEGIE U. MUSICIANS
description: IN a concert played by and for students, alumni and faculty of the Carnegie-Mellon University on Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, Leonardo Balada's Violin Concerto was given its premiere. Mr. Balada, a member of the faculty at the university, is also having a new work presented by the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday night.

title: NEW YORK DOESN'T NEED A JUDICIAL GERONTOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYERS' STRIKE FORCES 10 COURTS TO CLOSE DOWN
description: A New York City court official said yesterday that some courtrooms for criminal trials in State Supreme Court were being closed because of the strike by Legal Aid Society lawyers.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
A HEALTHY MCNEIL IS ELUSIVE
description: Today was as normal as any Monday can be at a Jet camp after the end of a player strike, a 37-0 victory and the re-emergence of a second-year running back who is on his way to being a star. Players got in and out quickly, the television set showed a tape of Sunday's triumph over the Baltimore Colts, and Coach Walt Michaels, characteristically, refused to gloat over the rout of a rival team.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BRIEFING
description: So Much for China Lobby

title: SEEKS ARMS PACTS WITH SOVIET
description: President Reagan urged Congress tonight to give sympathetic consideration to his proposed MX missile basing plan, but it is certain to meet substantial Congressional opposition.

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mattel's Western To Close a Plant
description: The Western Publishing Company said it would end operations here by July, phasing out 770 jobs.

title: O.A.U. Chairman Tries To End Chad Impasse
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, the outgoing chairman of the Organization of African Unity, began informal talks today in an effort to end the impasse over Chad delaying the opening of a meeting of the O.A.U.

title: SFN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Treasury Bond Prices Plunge
description: Prices of Treasury bonds fell sharply yesterday, as traders and investors decided that the Federal Reserve's modest move late Friday to encourage lower interest rates was not enough to warrant holding large inventories of bonds or making additional purchases.

title: Dutch Announce Austerity Measures
description: The new Dutch Government formally announced tough spending cuts and a public-sector wage freeze today, and unions responded with a threat of long strikes.

title: U.S. SHIFT MAY SPUR COMPUTER BONANZA
description: ABROAD new program of Federal assistance for elementary and secondary education that virtually eliminates restrictions on how the schools may use the money may inadvertently turn out to be a boon for computer-assisted instruction.

title: Correction: N.J. Taxes
description: An editorial Saturday on the New Jersey budget misstated the revenues that a 5 percent sales tax on gasoline would produce this budget year if enacted by Jan. 1. The correct estimate is $90.5 million, not $905 million.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief Operating Officer Resigns at Hi-G Inc.
description: Hi-G Inc. announced yesterday that Terrence Geoghegan, 61, president and chief operating officer of the Windsor Locks, Conn., manufacturer of electronic and electromechanical components since May, had resigned ''to pursue other activities.'' Mr. Geoghegan could not be reached for comment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Credit Markets column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the schedule for testimony before the Joint Economic Committee by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He is to appear tomorrow.

title: High Court Gets Lindbergh Case
description: The widow of the man executed for killing the infant son of Charles A. Lindbergh asked the Supreme Court today to review a part of her lawsuit for monetary damages.

title: BRAIN'S 'GLUE' DISCOVERED
description: SCIENTISTS at Rockefeller University have discovered a cellular glue that they believe is crucial to the development of the brains of humans and all other vertebrates.

title: NEW YORK;
description: No failure by government at all levels has been more obvious than its inability in recent years to provide or generate low- and moderate-income housing.

title: Cordero Appeals Ban
description: Angel Cordero, the New York jockey who is bidding to win titles in both money won and victories this year, appealed his seven-day suspension to the State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday. It is possible the appeal will put off the suspension long enough to allow Cordero to ride the rest of the year. Aqueduct stewards suspended him Sunday for ''careless riding'' last Saturday aboard Philanthropic in the third race.

title: THE DEAD SEA SCROLLS YIELD CHEMICAL HISTORY
description: YEAR study of the parchment of the Dead Sea Scrolls has resulted new insights into the chemical structure of the 2,000-year-old scrolls and the factors that can cause them to deteriorate.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. Louis Orr, who came to the Knicks from the Pacers just before the season opened, faces his old teammates for the first time.

title: THEATER: 'RHINESTONE,' RACISM IN HOLLYWOOD
description: ''RHINESTONE,'' a new musical at the Richard Allen Center, is something of a trial to sit through, but at least it's a trial by fire. In this show, an account of a black screenwriter's humiliation by white Hollywood sharks, one almost always feels the heat of genuine rage; not even the singing and dancing can make the audience forget that it is spending nearly three hours staring into a gaping wound.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After pretax gain of $5,855,000 or 34 cents a shr from insurance settlement

title: IRELAND VOTES: ROUND 3
description: Once again, Charles J. Haughey is fighting for his political life. Easily the Irish Republic's most controversial politician in modern times, he is considered a consummate survivor. But as the country heads for its third general election in 18 months, tomorrow, even his friends admit that he faces an enormous task in trying to cling to power.

title: PRESIDENT
description: As part of an effort to project more good news in articles written about Dartmouth College, its president, David T. McLaughlin, has done something that no one can remember an Ivy League university president doing.

title: Chrysler Reopens Talks With Workers in U.S.
description: The Chrysler Corporation reopened talks with the United Automobile Workers today on contracts in the United States and Canada.

title: HOW HORNET WAS STRIPPED OF VALUES IT BEGAN WITH
description: When the Navy announced seven years ago that it had decided upon the McDonnell Douglas F-18 Hornet as its new lightweight, low-cost fighter plane, the announcement stirred more than ordinary interest.

title: THE UNCERTAINTIES OF A JOURNEYMAN
description: T he dark blue mark under Dave Silk's left eye and the six black stitches above it are a reminder of where he has just been. ''A little disturbance in the Central League,'' he said Sunday night in the Ranger locker room each time someone asked how his face had come to look like that.

title: SHAD WINS CLEARANCE IN INQUIRY
description: After a long inquiry, House investigators have found no impropriety in the way the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission disposed of shares in a major brokerage house upon his nomination last year to head the commission.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1982
description: International A ''dense pack'' deployment of the MX intercontinental missile was urged by President Reagan to modernize American nuclear forces, but he said he was also committed to seeking sharp reductions in strategic arms by mutual agreement with Moscow. Mr. Reagan presented his plan in a nationally televised speech six hours after his Administration announced it planned to base the proposed MX missile next to an Air Force base outside Cheyenne, Wyo. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan urged Congress to give sympathetic consideration to his proposed MX missile basing plan, but it is certain to face substantial Congressional opposition. The immediate reaction in Congress ranged from skepticism by conservatives to opposition by liberals. (A1:4-5.)

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Those 'Milwaukee' Packers
description: T hey're mostly the Milwaukee Packers now. Of their four home games in the strike-shortened National Football League season, only one will be played up there in little ol' Green Bay - on Dec. 12 against the Detroit Lions. The way the schedule has fallen, the Packers have already played two games in Milwaukee, with another there Dec. 5 against the Buffalo Bills.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The yr-ago results restated to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Oct 1982and adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52

title: Albania Replaces Its Chief of State
description: Ramiz Alia was named Albania's head of state today in place of Haxi Lleshi, who held the post since 1953, the Albanian press agency reported.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a gain of $4,084,000 or $1.10 a shr on the sale of investments...C-Including a gain of $38,000 or 1 cent a shr on the sale of investments and past due income of $358,000 or 10 cents a shr

title: Thompson Is Certified As the Winner in Illinois
description: The State Board of Elections today certified Gov. James R. Thompson as the winner of the Nov. 2 governor's race. But Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the Democratic challenger, said he would seek a recount.

title: DITTA PASZTORY, 80, PIANIST AND WIDOW OF BELA BARTOK
description: Ditta Pasztory, a pianist and widow of Bela Bartok, died Sunday in Budapest, the Hungarian Ministry of Culture announced yesterday. She was 80 years old.

title: Ashland Abandons Synthetic Oil Plans
description: Ashland Oil Inc. has withdrawn its sponsorship of a multibillion-dollar project to produce synthetic oil from coal, the company said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was almost as if the fashion pack had secretly decided that a l ittle culture is a good thing. During the past two weeks many of t hem could be found not at dinners or balls but at the openings of s everal photographic exhibits around town.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Threshold Of Sanity
description: At a recent private meeting of international economics experts and bankers, a painful figure was disclosed and a crucial question asked.

title: China Plans to Start Building Its First Atomic Power Plant
description: China will break ground early next year for its first nuclear power station and expects to complete it in seven years, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Duke Dropping Wilson
description: Duke has decided not to extend Red Wilson's football coaching contract. The university's decision came two days after the Blue Devils had upset North Carolina, 23-17, and finished a second straight 6-5 season.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Queen in Search of a Pig

title: PROSECUTION NEARS END OF TAPES ON TEAMSTERS
description: Federal prosecutors neared the end of their concerto of wiretaps today in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: JUDGE VOIDS CREATION LAW IN LOUISIANA
description: A Federal district judge today struck down a Louisiana law requiring the public schools to teach ''creation science'' with the theory of evolution.

title: CONGRESS, P.A.C.'D
description: When we think of corruption in Washington, Abscam swims into focus: televised images of politicians pocketing bribe money, embarrassed only by the lack of depth of their pockets. Frequent news media accounts perpetuate the image of illicit deals between private interests and lawmakers. Yet, so far as I can tell after four years in Washington, one of them in the White House, and an examination of whatever data are available, most members of Congress do not accept bribes. Nonetheless, the capital is corrupt to the core.

title: 2 FEDERAL JURIES INDICT AN F.B.I. AGENT
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was indicted today by two Federal grand juries on a variety of charges, most of them stemming from a 1977 theft in North Carolina of diamond jewelry that he is accused of transporting and selling.

title: 500 Sikh Militants Arrested in Punjab
description: The police arrested 500 Sikh militants today at a Punjab railway station as they were about to board a train to New Delhi to demonstrate for autonomy during the Asian Games, the authorities said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 11.50-12.00 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MISSILES THAT TOLERATE NO SLIP-UP IN ALERTS
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PRO FOOTBALL MAKES A STRONG COMEBACK
description: F ans may have been angered by the 57-day National Football League strike, but they still returned to their television sets in large numbers Sunday.

title: PUBLIC WORKS CRUCIAL TO PRIVATE-SECTOR RECOVERY
description: T o the Editor: In a Nov. 11 editorial, The Times questioned the value of Congressional efforts to develop a public-works program. ''What was once known as pork-barrel,'' you said, ''is now costumed as 'infrastructure.' Before Congress gets carried away in a trendy tide, there is need for some honest cost-benefit analysis.''

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Net income...C-Including a tax credit of $11,900

title: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Service For Kim
description: About 300 persons attended a memorial service today for Duk Koo Kim, the South Korean lightweight who died of brain injuries after losing a championship bout to Ray Mancini in Las Vegas, Nev., a week ago. Meanwhile, in San Francisco, a spokesman at the University of California Hospital said that two patients, described only as male adults, had received Kim's kidneys in transplant operations. Both are ''progressing well,'' the spokesman said.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Egypt's Oil Outlook
description: Egypt hopes to produce one million barrels of crude oil a day by 1985, a quarter of a million barrels more than its present production, Ezzedin Hilal, the oil minister, said today. He told a symposium on oil that Egypt had 70 oil exploration agreements with foreign companies covering the western and eastern deserts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Logic Systems, Sunnyvale, Calif., has appointed to its board of directors Steve Wozniak, co-founder of Apple Computer Inc.

title: Mobil's Ward Plans Disposal
description: Montgomery Ward, the financially troubled retail subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, said it is seeking to sell its insurance operations. The operations reported assets of $240 million last year and contributed earnings of $17.3 million on premiums of $134 milion.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Oct 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $532,000 or 32 cents a shr for the qr and $830,000 or 51 cents a shr for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: MARION W. BOYER, OIL EXECUTIVE
description: Marion W. Boyer, former executive vice president of the Exxon Corporation and the general manager of the United States Atomic Energy Commission from 1950 to 1953, died Saturday at the Hilton Head Hospital in South Carolina. He was 81 years old and lived in Hilton Head, having moved there from Greenwich, Conn., seven years ago.

title: Books Of The Times
description: SHILOH AND OTHER STORIES. By Bobbie Ann Mason. 247 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MERCANTILE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After gain of $916,000 or 16 cents a shr from sale of land...C-After gain of $365,000 or 6 cents a shr from sale of a closed store

title: REAGAN PICKS PENTAGON AIDE AS HEAD OF VETERANS AGENCY
description: President Reagan announced today that he had nominated Harry N. Walters, an Assistant Secretary of the Army, to be the chief of the Veterans Administration, succeeding Robert Nimmo.

title: Award for Rogers
description: Mike Rogers of the Rangers won the National Hockey League's player-of-the-week award, after having scored 10 points in three games. ... The Rangers' Pat Conacher is out at least two weeks with a sprained left shoulder suffered in the 7-3 victory over the Islanders Sunday night. David Cogan, the agent for the Islander defenseman Denis Potvin, refused to confirm or deny reports that the Internal Revenue Service was seeking $154,961 in back taxes and $4,217 in fines from his client.

title: METTA V. VICTOR'S DISTINCTION IN U.S. LITERATURE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TRADE STRUGGLE: SERVICES
description: No operating license has been given to a foreign insurance company in Norway in four decades. Foreign engineers pay higher income taxes in Brazil than native-born engineers. American Express cannot offer its credit card in Japan. And the United States bars foreign shipping companies from competing for American coastal trade.

title: JURY TO GET WARNER AIDE CASE
description: The prosecutor told the jury in a Federal District Court trial in Manhattan yesterday that a 1973 stock purchase by Warner Communications had involved ''a high-level corporate fraud.''

title: Seventeen Plans Japanese Edition
