description: Seventeen magazine will introduce with the May issue a Japanese edition. The edition, called San Sun Seventeen-Japan, will be published by the Gakken Company Ltd. of Japan, and will feature selected art work and articles translated from Seventeen, as well as each month's cover layout.

title: CAREY SUGGESTING A STATE FURLOUGH
description: Governor Carey yesterday proposed a five-day furlough for state employees and cuts in state aid to schools, cities and local governments to close what he said was a $579 million state budget deficit.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Speechless Virtuoso

title: PATTERN FOR SUCCESS IN FASHION IS FOUND BY WACOAL OF JAPAN
description: Koichi Tsukamoto, president of the Wacoal Corporation, has changed the shape of Japanese women. It began soon after World War II. ''I could see that women would be wearing Western clothes and would want to look prettier to Western eyes,'' he recalled in a recent interview. ''Nothing could be done about the height, but something could be done about the shape.''

title: B.P. Approves Plans for Ula Field
description: Directors of the British Petroleum Company have approved plans to develop the Ula field in the Norwegian North Sea at a cost equivalent to $1.03 billion, a spokesman said.

title: SHIITES IN LEBANON SAID TO ATTACK ARMY BARRACKS IN CITY THEY TOOK
description: Several hundred armed men reportedly attacked a Lebanese Army barracks today in the eastern city of Baalbek and besieged it for two hours before retreating.

title: Eva Schainbaum, 92, Is Dead; Sang on Stage as Eva Shirley
description: Eva Schainbaum, who sang in vaudeville in the early years of this century as Eva Shirley, died in Doctor's Hospital Saturday. She was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AN ERROR NAMED RAPID DEPLOYMENT FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWMAKERS CHALLENGE PLANNED MEDICARE SHIFT
description: Members of Congress made it clear today that they wanted to make substantial changes in the Reagan Administration's proposal to pay hospitals a set fee for treating all Medicare patients who have the same ailment.

title: GIANTS TROUBLED BY POOR DEFENSE
description: Last year the defense did it. This year the defense often seems lost. Last November, when the Washington Redskins beat the Giants here in overtime, the Giants' record fell to 5-6. Then they won four of their last five games and made the playoffs.

title: M-1: THE WORLD'S 'MOST SURVIVABLE' TANK
description: To the Editor:

title: PROPOSAL
description: Following are the texts of a statement today by President Reagan on his decision approving a plan for the basing of the MX intercontinental missile and a statement issued by the Defense Department explaining the plan: The President's Statement

title: 2 BIG WHOLESALERS CUT HEATING OIL PRICES
description: Two of the largest suppliers of heating oil in the Northeast, the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, again cut their wholesale heating oil prices yesterday. Analysts said the move had resulted from an unexpected drop in demand.

title: JETS FOUND HEALTHY
description: Before the Jets went on strike with the rest of pro football's players for eight weeks, before Coach Walt Michaels allowed them light-contact practices in preparation for the Baltimore Colts, before they routed the Colts by 37-0 in their first game back, Dr. James A. Nicholas used to be confronted by a long list of names on the midweek injury report.

title: CHANNEL 13, IN FUND SQUEEZE, HALTS SERIES AND WEIGHS CUTS
description: Caught in the worst financial crisis in its 20-year history, Channel 13, WNET-TV, the New York metropolitan area's major public television station, has abruptly postponed a multimillion dollar series and is likely to lay off staff and reduce programming.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN PROPOSES 5 CENT RISE IN GAS TAX FOR ROAD REPAIRS
description: Under pressure from Congressional leaders, President Reagan today proposed a five-year, $32.9 billion program to repair highways and bridges and to assist mass transit projects.

title: Bridge: Lipsitz and Gerstman Win Men's Pairs Championship
description: A most remarkable, if unobtrusive, record was kept alive here at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Robert Lipsitz of Annandale, Va., who won the life master men's pairs championship Monday night with Dan Gerstman of Buffalo, has never failed to reach the final of a major national pairs event in almost 20 years of competition.

title: THANKSGIVING AND THOREAU
description: Alexander Theroux is the author of ''Darconville's Cat,'' published last year by Doubleday.

title: STAGE: PRAGUE'S SYSTEM
description: ''CEREMONY IN BOHEMIA,'' a play rooted in the record of an actual trial of Czechloslovak dissidents in Prague in 1979, simultaneously invites judgment as both fact and drama. The audience's awareness that the defendants were real people who stood up for their freedom against the stolid system becomes a factor in the play, evincing a sympathetic response even before the lights dim.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 24, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Francis W. Watlington; Recorded Whale Songs
description: Francis W. Watlington, a sonar expert and specialist in underwater acoustics who recorded the songs of humpback whales, died Saturday at his home in Pembroke, Bermuda. He was 66 years old.

title: People
description: * Timothy P. Cronin has been appointed executive vice presidentcreative director for D'Arcy-Macmanus & Masius/Western operations, San Francisco.

title: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $544,000 for the $892,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after loss from discontinued o of $1,426,000...D-After net of $9,327,000 from spunoff and disc operations; the yr ago figures were restated

title: Downbeat Ending For Stanford
description: They went out to Ramona's pizza parlor on Saturday night, 11 of them in a group, drinking a lot of beer and laughing a lot, mostly to keep from crying. Every so often, one of them would moan: ''Why us? Why did it happen to us?''

title: BIAS BLAMED FOR HIGH MINORITY JOBLESS RATE
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that persistent discrimination was the main reason that blacks and Hispanic Americans had much higher rates of unemployment than whites.

title: E.P.A. SEEKS DELAY ON DIESELS' FUMES
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency today proposed a two-year delay on rules requiring the reduction of emissions of small particles of spent fuel by automobiles and trucks that burn diesel fuel.

title: Reliable Life
description: The Reliable Life Insurance Company of St. Louis announced it had agreed to purchase the Torchmark Corporation's Rockford Life Insurance Company unit for $57 million, subject to certain adjustments. The transaction is still subject to the approval of both companies' boards and government regulatory authorities.

title: SOME STATE, SOME ART; Let's say you've got $25 billion on hand and you want to drive the Russians up the wall. So you build, say, 100 very elegant new missiles, using all the latest gadgets. Everything ''state of the art,'' as they say. Don't ask me why they say ''state of the art.'' You'd think a country that spends $25 billion on missiles and wouldn't give Rembrandt $2.75 for a can of paint thinner would refer to missiles as ''the art of the state,'' but we are speaking now about Washington people, and Washington people tend to talk backwards.
description: Anyhow, you go for the 100 missiles and fit each missile with 10 thermonuclear bombs, enabling you to ''hit,'' as they say, 1,000 targets. I could be wrong here. Maybe they say ''flatten'' 1,000 targets. Bomb people habitually talk about ''flattening'' things, although what they really do is dig huge holes. But let's not get bogged down in the craters and rubble of bomb lingo. Let's get to the problem.

title: Ownership Expanded At Hong Kong Agency
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton has acquired the majority holding in Chase Compton Advertising Ltd., Hong Kong. Fifteen years ago Compton International purchased a minority interest in what was then known as Chase Advertising.

title: Philippine Steel Agreement
description: The Philippine state-owned National Steel Corporation is negotiating to buy an unused five-year-old cold rolling mill from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, sources at the National Steel Corporation said.

description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $63,000...C-Net income inclu a tax credit of $478,000...D-Including a gain of $2.4 million o extinguishment of debt and a tax credit of $2.2 million...E-Inc a tax credit of $634,000

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are some things in life that are inevitable. They are proof against the best laid plans and the strongest wills. Sometimes it isn't even a matter of planning or willpower, it's simply fate.

description: A to Z

title: Jet Feast Canceled
description: Now that the football strike is over, the Jets want it known that their annual Thanksgiving Day dinner for the players and their families has been canceled by logistics, not politics.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dow Off 9.01 Points, to 990.99
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.01 points yesterday to finish below the 1,000 mark for the first time since the end of October as stock prices continued to retreat on relatively modest trading volume.

title: THE STAGE: 'WELCOME TO THE MOON'
description: ''IT'S a relief to say things, even if they are sophomoric,'' says one of the many young lovers in John Patrick Shanley's ''Welcome to the Moon.'' No doubt that's true for the person who's doing the talking, but what about those who have to listen? In this collection of eleven playlets at the estimable Ensemble Studio Theater, Mr. Shanley says many sophomoric things, and, however relieved he may feel by evening's end, the audience is bored silly.

title: THE MUSKIE LINE ON '84
description: Former Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine has spent most of his adult life in active politics, including unsuccessful attempts to become Vice President in 1968 and President in 1972.

title: Rayovac Sale Complete
description: Three suburban New York City investors completed the purchase of the Rayovac Corporation Monday from Inco Ltd. of Canada.

title: No Headline
description: Nuggets Set Mark But Lose to Spurs

title: DYATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GEMAYEL BEING PRESSED TO ACT TO COUNTER BAALBEK UPRISING
description: The Government of President Amin Gemayel showed official concern today over the armed insurgency that has threatened its authority in the eastern city of Baalbek since Sunday.

description: William M. Kunstler, the lawyer, was cited for contempt yesterday by a judge who presided at the trial of two former Black Panthers convicted of attempting to kill two Queens police officers.

Those Disputatious Bishops
description: It's surprising that the Roman Catholic Church, which has always shown a genius for moral disputation, took so long to enter the atomic lists. But enter them it did when the National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced support of a proposed pastoral letter on nuclear arms. There is, however, as yet no final draft; along with the rest of the world, the bishops find themselves in a quandary.

title: FED POLICY BACKED BY FELDSTEIN
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser, said today that for the present the Federal Reserve should stick to its policy of not worrying about over-target growth in its key gauges of the money supply.

title: WHEN HOLIDAY JOY BECOMES ONLY A FADED MEMORY
description: Now it begins again, the season of tinsel and white lights, the time that is supposed to be the best of times and yet so often is not.

title: KEAN, IN ADDRESS ON BUDGET, ASKS CUTBACKS AND TAX RISES
description: Governor Kean, in a special address to the State Legislature today, proposed a package of budget cuts and tax increases on gasoline and alcoholic beverages to avoid what he said was a possible $150 million budget deficit in this fiscal year.

title: STINGY DISPENSERS OF FEDERAL INFORMATION
description: To the Editor:

title: WYOMING BUSINESSMEN TEND TO FAVOR MX PLAN
description: Down at the Chamber of Commerce, staff members were fielding telephone calls from job-seekers as far away as Hawaii. And on Main Street businessmen could hear the ring of cash registers.

title: M.I.S.L. Players Approve Contract
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League and the M.I.S.L. Players Association announced today that they had ratified a one-year contract.

title: Massey Reshaping
description: Massey Ferguson Ltd.'s new restructuring package is unlikely to be in place until early 1983, but it should be in time for the company to take advantage of any upturn in the farm and industrial machinery market, a senior banking source said. He said the company was not under any day-to-day pressure because it will not make the Nov. 30 deadline that it had previously announced.

title: Chargers Fail to Grasp Opportunity
description: For a few tense moments in Los Angeles Coliseum Monday night, Ray Guy probably wished he had accepted one of the major league baseball contracts offered to him when he was a high school pitcher in Thomson, Ga.

title: ISRAEL'S WEST BANK PLAN SEEKS JORDAN'S EXCLUSION
description: Israeli military officials have issued a directive that instructs administrators in charge of the occupied West Bank to keep up pressure on ''extremist mayors'' while trying to neutralize pro-Jordanian Palestinians.

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $142,000 for the qr and $2,755,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Toyota Optimistic on Tie
description: The chairman of the Toyota Motors Corporation said here today that negotiations on a plan to jointly produce small cars in this country with the General Motors Corporation are moving forward.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Officer at Wyly Takes Early Retirement
description: The Wyly Corporation, a diversified computer software and computing services company based in Dallas, announced yesterday that John Kason, 60, had taken early retirement as chairman and president for ''personal reasons.''

title: All Goals Met, Holmes Ready to Retire
description: Next month, Larry Holmes will tape some commercials for Coors Beer, and the world heavyweight champion will gladly drink to that. The toast would not be to his long-sought recognition, but to the end of his boxing career.

title: SUSPECT IN A BRINK'S CASE AIDING U.S.
description: A self-styled leader of a group charged with several armored-car robberies and murders pleaded guilty to Federal charges yesterday, representing the first conviction growing out of the 1981 Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: Begin Resumes Duties After Mourning Period
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin resumed his official duties today after a period of mourning for his wife, Aliza. Mr. Begin cut short a visit to the United States on Nov. 14 after receiving word in Los Angeles that Mrs. Begin had died that day in Jerusalem of cardiac arrest after a long respiratory illness.

title: Casino Profits Post 25% Rise
description: Third-quarter net income for New Jersey's nine casinos rose 25 percent, to $50.4 million, from $40.3 million a year earlier, the Casino Control Commission said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dance review on Monday incorrectly described two works by the Ohio Ballet. The dances, ''Songs Without Words'' and ''Excursions,'' had their East Coast premieres Nov. 12 and 13 at the Hub Entertainment Center in Hempstead, L.I.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Balcor/American Express Inc., Skokie, Ill., has promoted Allan W. Hoekstra to president of its wholly owned subsidiary, Balcor Property Management Inc.

title: Mrs. King Upset
description: Billie Jean King and Wendy Turnbull were upset by unseeded players today in the $125,000 New South Wales Open tennis tournament. Mrs. King, who became 39 years old Monday and was seeded ninth, lost a first-round match, 6-4, 6-4, to Sherry Acker, an American who had to qualify. Miss Turnbull, seeded third, was beaten by Marcella Mesker of the Netherlands, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3, in the second round.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute to Robert Moses

title: MORE MONEY SOUGHT FOR MEALS ON WHEELS
description: MAY CORNELL is 94. Yesterday she attended Mayor Koch's news conference on the city's Meals-on-Wheels program as a representative of the 6,000 homebound elderly who are participants. And she took over.

title: Man Accused in Slaying Testifies About $250,000
description: The man accused of killing Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. for $250,000 acknowledged today that he had sent his stepdaughter to pick up money from Jamiel (Jimmy) Chagra, but he denied that it was payment for the killing.

title: OUR MAN FROM ALASKA GOES OVER BIG IN BRASILIA
description: When Langhorne Anthony Motley was named the United States Ambassador to Brazil a year ago, a lot of people grumbled.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD EXPECTS A BATTLE ON CITY BUDGET
description: Nearly all members of the Board of Estimate, angry that Mayor Koch's latest financial plan eliminated many of the items they and the City Council added to the budget last June, said yesterday that they would try to change the plan.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Yet Another Generation Enjoys the Unicycle

title: El Paso Co. Plans To Cut '83 Outlay
description: The El Paso Company said it expected to reduce its 1983 capital spending to $317 million from more than $700 million this year.

title: Nigeria Decides to Withdraw From U.N. Force in Lebanon
description: United Nations officials said today that Nigeria had withdrawn a company of soldiers from the peacekeeping force in Lebanon and would soon withdraw the remainder of its troops.

title: EX-CHILD CARE HEAD AT CATHOLIC CHARITIES
description: Msgr. John J. Lennon, former director of child care for Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York and pastor of St. Sylvester's Church in Concord, S.I., died Monday at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I. He was 74 years old and had been living in semi-retirement at St. Pius X Seminary in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a sad day for the American public. Pure and simple, today's action means that the Government does not want television broadcasters to attempt to govern themselves by voluntarily limiting the amount of advertising broadcast into the public's homes.''

title: TV: 'IN LOVE WITH AN OLDER WOMAN'
description: REFLECTING what seems to be fashionable in the gossip columns, television seems preoccupied these days with love affairs involving presumably mature women and younger men. Made for television movies on the subject tend to favor titles along the lines of ''Forbidden Love.'' Tonight's exercise on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock goes more directly to the point. It is called ''In Love With an Older Woman.''

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CRIME: PITFALLS OF 'SELECTIVE INCAPACITATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR REOPENED TO EMBASSY FAMILIES
description: The United States has decided to allow the families of American diplomats and other embassy workers to return to El Salvador at the end of this month.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net in the latest periods include a $466,000 writedown on the value of reserves

title: SCAN-DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Screening Applicants For Circulation Jobs
description: According to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, the job of district circulation manager has a high turnover rate.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES IN CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: HRT Industries, formerly Hartfield-Zody's, a major regional retailing chain, announced yesterday that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in New York City.

title: AREA'S PRICES UP 1.5% IN OCTOBER
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area advanced sharply, by 1.5 percent, in October on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 6
Brunners Start a Rivalry
description: If the Giants' quarterback situation looks more settled than his own, Coach Monte Clark of the Detroit Lions can blame one of his assistants, John Brunner, who coaches the Lions' offensive backfield.

title: British Union Acts to Halt Steel Imports; Britons Set Steel Protest
description: The main British steelworkers' union announced today that it planned to blockade ports to halt steel imports. It said the imports were ruining the British steel industry and contributing to unemployment.

title: ANDROPOV IS ADDED TO TOP STATE BODY
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, was named today to membership in the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, but he was not immediately named chairman, or chief of state, an office left vacant by the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev .

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 10 Cabinet Ministers Replaced in Albania

title: PERSHING MISSILE TEST NOT A TOTAL SUCCESS, ARMY ACKNOWLEDGES
description: The Army said today that the test firing of its Pershing 2 missile, which was billed as a success last Friday, turned out to be a partial failure when the warhead missed its target.

title: UNESCO OPENS 2 DAY PARIS PARLEY ON SETTING AGENDA FOR REST OF 80's
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opened a two-week special conference here today to try to work out the framework for the organization's activities over the rest of the decade.

title: PRICES EASE AMID BIG SUPPLY
description: A heavy supply of new issues in all sectors of the note and bond markets led to slightly lower prices yesterday. Treasury notes and bonds, for example, fell about three-eighths of a point after trading in a relatively narrow range with prices higher than Monday's close for much of the day. The indecisive pattern of trading was consistent, analysts said, with the varying forecasts on interest rates for the near future.

title: CONCERT: EMIGRES PLAY SHOSTAKOVICH
description: ''TIRED with all these,'' reads the Shakespeare sonnet, ''for restful death I cry.'' These were the words set to music by Shostakovich when he wrote, in 1942, ''Six Romances on English Verses.'' The sonnet catalogues the evils of the world - honor misplaced, virtue strumpeted, perfection disgraced, ''art made tonguetied by authority.''

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an adjustment for application of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 to the 1981 figures

title: Careers; The Edge In a College Education
description: ANN M., age 45, assistant chief nurse in a major New Jersey hospital, expected promotion to the top job, but when her superior retired she was told she could not be promoted because she lacked a college degree.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ISHALL never forget the awfulness of the last moments of my mother's life. Though it had been clear for days that her death was imminent, in her final hours she lay in a hospital bed surrounded by strangers and attached to a terrifying array of medical equipment that poured life-sustaining fluids and drugs into her cancer-wasted body. And as she struggled to take her last breaths, an oxygen mask was put on her face, effectively cutting off all goodbyes to her family.

title: AREA'S RISE AT 1.5%
description: The Government reported today that consumer prices rose by five-tenths of 1 percent in October, a little more than expected but not enough to disturb the projection that inflation for 1982 will be down to roughly 5 percent.

title: INACCURATE DATA ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial on Utility Suit Is Set
description: A Jan. 10 trial date has been set in a lawsuit by the Chemical Bank aimed at insuring that 88 Northwest utilities and the Washington Public Power Supply System will pay the $7 billion debt on two terminated nuclear power plants.

title: ANTI-ARMS GROUPS REBUT PLANS FOR MX
description: They lacked the electronic charts with the moving blue and red lines that President Reagan used in his speech Monday, but leaders of the nuclear freeze movement and other arms control groups were prepared today with a well-coordinated rebuttal.

title: M.T.A. CONFERS IN CONNECTICUT ON TOKENS' USE
description: New York and Connecticut officials held their first face-to-face talks in the token dispute yesterday - at, of all places, a Connecticut Turnpike toll plaza - but failed to reach a solution.

title: Dense Pack or Dense Think?
description: By deciding to deploy 100 MX missiles in a ''dense-pack'' base, President Reagan is planning strategic warfare according to the principles of jujitsu - using the opponent's own strength and weight to flip and defeat him. The closely spaced silos are meant to save at least half the missiles under attack. The blast, radiation and debris from the first enemy warheads would deflect or destroy those that follow; that's ''fratricide.'' If this scheme assured the survivability of our land-based missiles, it would be worth $26 billion.

title: KETCHUM & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results include tax credits of $134,000 for the qr and $258,000 for the 6 mos

title: A.M.C. to Cut Salaried Workers
description: The American Motors Corporation said it will lay off several hundred of its 6,300 salaried workers by Dec. 3 to cut costs.

MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $411,000 for and $1,213,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinue of $856,000 for the qr and $2,159,000 for the yr; shr earnings a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 21, 1982

title: Frank McCormick, Reds' Star Who Won 1940 M.V.P. Award
description: Frank McCormick, the National League's most valuable player in 1940, died Sunday of cancer at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 70 years old, resided in Manhasset, L.I., and worked as director of group sales for the Yankees.

title: 'FAT CHANCE,' COMEDY OF NEAR MISSES
description: ''FAT CHANCE'' makes an awful lot out of nothing, the nothing being a hokey, old-fashioned story of how boy-doesn't-quite-meetgirl. The boy, in this case, is a 27-year-old New York pianist named Michael (Farnham Scott). And he is hugely overweight, hence the title. He's also lonely enough to answer a classified ad from a woman in Miami named Mary (January Stevens), who shares his interest in old movie musicals.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada and the Quebec government should form a new company to take over operations of Quebecair, a financially troubled regional airline, the Canadian Government recommended.

title: Players' Champ
description: Larry Holmes, the heavyweight champion, wants there to be no mistake about it: He was solidly for the players in the football strike. For a while, the champion's interest was practical: His title fight in Houston this Friday against Randy Cobb might have been switched to last Monday to replace the missing football game on television.

title: TOYS-R-US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including pretax gains of $256,000 for the qr and $1,053,000 9 mos and net gains of $171,000 for the qr and $705,000 for the from the sale of property

title: DETERRENTS; Milked
description: Something about milk makes customers drive for miles to save a few cents on a half gallon. Meanwhile, milk companies make it necessary to drive those miles: they conspire to fix prices and keep them high.

title: News Analysis
description: Yuri V. Andropov has begun his tenure as head of the Soviet Communist Party with a forthright acknowledgment of the system's economic problems and a call for prompt action to correct them.

title: TALKING TURKEY, HISTORICALLY
description: The bird adorning the first Thanksgiving table bore little resemblance to the one that is center stage tomorrow. History's first Thanksgiving turkey was a wild bird, svelte and sleek, with shimmering bronze feathers. As avian mentalities go, the wild turkey, while not brilliant, undoubtedly is more intelligent than the barnyard variety. Domestication has not been kind to -shall we say bird brains? It was only a small flight for our language to start characterizing certain dim-witted types of creatures as ''turkeys.''

title: Index; International
description: Our man from Alaska goes over big in Brasilia A2 U.S. embassy families can return to Salvador A3 U.S. weighs arms aid for Guatemala A3 Vote-weary Irish doing it again A5 Gulf war said to strengthen mod- erate Arab countries A6 Around the World A9 Andropov is added to top state body in Soviet Union A10 Gemayel urged to counter Baalbek uprising A14 Soviet calls MX plan new, costly step in arms race A19 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Working Profile: Jack Valenti A20 Working Profile: Charles D. Ferris A20 The Muskie line on '84 A20 HOLIDAY TOMORROW Tomorrow is Thanksgiving. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West; moves south to Columbus Circle, down Broadway to Herald Square, ending at 34th Street and Seventh Avenue. Parking - Sunday regulations. Sanitation - No collections;no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed tomorrow and Friday.

title: Serious Student Of High Finance
description: An economics major from Stanford was in town yesterday with a blue pinstriped vested suit, an entourage and a chance to become very rich soon, by any theory of economics. He was John Elway, quarterback, senior and blue-chip prospect in both football and baseball.

title: Real Estate; Suburban Strength in Office Field
description: THE Westchester County office market has not been immune to the problems of the economy. But at a time when many office markets around the country are experiencing a slowdown, if not paralysis, this one appears to be doing well.

title: Court Sets Hearing On the Homeless
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered New York City officials to appear next Wednesday to explain why a referee should not be appointed to find sites that are suitable for use as shelters for homeless men.

title: WAR DOESN'T DETER LEBANESE VINEYARD
description: acre vineyard lies in the Bekaa Valley on the flanks of Mount Lebanon near Ghazir, 20 miles north of Beirut.

title: CHINA MOVES TO BUY A MODERN AIR FLEET
description: China's state airline has agreed to purchase 10 Boeing 737-200 jetliners for $160 million as part of a drive to overhaul its largely outdated fleet of aircraft and carry more passengers.

title: REIN IN BANKRUPTCY
description: The net effect of our Federal bankruptcy laws is to subsidize the least productive and most inefficient segments of the economy at the expense of borrowers generally and, most regrettably, new and imaginative enterprises. This unwise allocation of economic resources may be a sad necessity for some unfortunate consumers who have accrued debts they simply can't pay. But its availability for businesses ought to be restricted.

title: Injury Brings Flowers Back to the Giants
description: Here today, gone tomorrow and back again another day, maybe. That's the way it goes for the marginal players in the National Football League, and with the Giants today Mike Mayock's misfortune became Larry Flowers's good fortune.

title: American Express Stock
description: The American Express Company announced yesterday that its board had voted to split its common stock on a 4-for-3 basis. In addition, directors voted to raise the company's regular quarterly dividend by 5 cents a share, to 60 cents, on the currently outstanding shares.

title: ICAHN DRAWN BY DAN RIVER'S BOOK VALUE
description: Dan River Inc. seems an unlikely company to be fighting a heated battle for control of its stock. In the last decade, the large textile manufacturer has been a sluggish performer in an industry hit hard by rising imports, increasing competition and damaging price wars. Profits have tumbled since 1979, the company's best year, and long-term debt remains high.

title: YANKS HIRE ZIMMER
description: The Yankees have yet to name a manager for 1983, but they began replenishing their coaching staff yesterday by hiring Don Zimmer, whom they wanted as a coach two years ago.

title: APRES FEAST
description: Oh they may help you clear the table stack the dishes wrap the bone, but when the guests have gone, it's over - you wash the turkey pan alone.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After net LIFO charges of $1,256,000 for the qr and $5,555,00 for the 9 mos...C-After net LIFO charges of $1,648,000 for the and $6,833,000 for the 9 mos

title: Litton Net Falls 31.7%
description: Litton Industries, a diversified manufacturer of high-technology equipment based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said yesterday that net income in its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 declined 31.7 percent, to $52.9 million, or $1.26 a share, from $77.4 million, or $1.86 a share, a year earlier.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Crime in City Down For the 9th Month
description: For a ninth consecutive month, reported crimes in New York City decreased last September over the year before, the Police Department said yesterday.

title:
A JEWISH HUEY LONG? NO. BEGIN'S BACKED BY THE EDUCATED, TOO.;
Many Americans believe that Menachem Begin is reaching the end of his political rope. This belief is, I think, an illusion, and in the foreseeable future Mr. Begin will continue to be the dominant figure in Israeli political life.
description: During his five years in office, Prime Minister Begin has been portrayed in the American press as a contentious and fanatic nationalist. The democratically elected leader of one of America's principal allies has become the man the American foreign policy establishment loves to hate.

title: Avery Fisher Grants Made
description: Five musicians have been awarded the first Avery Fisher Career Grants, established to provide recognition and support to outstanding young solo instrumentalists in the United States.

title: KNICKS BEATEN
description: The Knicks, the lowest-scoring team in the National Basketball Association, failed to match their season average of 94 points last night in losing to the Indiana Pacers, 94-90, at Madison Square Garden. They scored only 39 points in the second half, a performance that drew boos from a crowd of 7,845.

title: U.S. WELCOMES MOSCOW INTEREST IN EASING STRESS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it welcomed Yuri V. Andropov's interest in a relaxation of tensions and was ready ''to respond positively to any positive Soviet action.''

description: To the Editor:

LIMITS ON DURATION AND FREQUENCY OF TV COMMERCIALS ARE DROPPED
description: The broadcasting industry and the Justice Department agreed today to eliminate restraints on the duration of television commercials.

title: WOODWARD & LATHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
PAPAL CURB ON VATICAN BANK SEEN
description: Pope John Paul II issued today, at the opening of a meeting of the Sacred College of Cardinals, a document apparently intended to limit the Vatican's financial activities.

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
National Gypsum Appoints New Chief
description: The National Gypsum Company has elected John P. Hayes, 61 years old, chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Hayes, who had been vice chairman, will succeed Robert E. Scifres, 65, who is retiring after four decades with the Dallas-based company. Mr. Scifres, who had been chairman and chief executive since 1977, will remain on National Gypsum's board.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in October, the Labor Department reported. The increase was slightly larger than officials had expected, but not enough to upset a projection that inflation will be down to about 5 percent for the year. (Page A1.) Prices in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (D3.)

title: WINE TALK
description: IT is said in France that three rivers flow from the eastern part of the country: the Rhone, the Saone and the Beaujolais. The Beaujolais, of course, is a river of wine that climbs quickly to flood level each autumn after the grape harvest and then continues coursing all over the world toward consumers who anticipate its arrival with elan and are expected to gulp it down in great quantities.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Clippers, at San Diego. Bill Walton is playing only one game a week for San Diego, and he'll skip this one.

title: FRANCE AND ENGLAND FEUD ABOUT FOOD
description: The latest salvo in the long-running series of skirmishes between British and French agriculture was fired last Tuesday at the Salon International de l'Alimentation (S.I.A.L.), this year's international food fair in Paris. French farmers demonstrated in front of the British stand, in protest against the importation of British lamb.

title: First of two articles
description: More than a dozen Federal investigations and a related inquiry by the Manhattan District Attorney are under way into the laundering of more than $1 billion in illegally obtained money through offshore banks and trust companies, according to sources familiar with the investigations. Several of these inquiries are investigating laundering schemes that are said to use conduits in the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands. One subject of some of these inquiries is the head of a Bahamian trust company, the Columbus Trust Company, according to public documents.

title: WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE POP LIFE
description: RECORDS have been substantially unchanged since the 1950's; they still come in two forms - singles with a song on each side and albums with roughly 15 to 30 minutes per side. But with the record business undergoing a period of technological transition and sagging sales, alternative formats are becoming more and more important.

title: Britoil Drops 19% in Trading
description: Shares of Britoil P.L.C., trading for the first time since last week's public offering of the stock, closed today on the London Stock Exchange at 81 pence, equal to $1.30, down a surprising 19 percent from the 1 (or $1.60) a share that some private investors paid in the offering last week.

title: THE CHRISTMAS SALES OUTLOOK
description: The recession and the high unemployment rate weigh heavily on this Christmas shopping season - huge hurdles, retailers say, to the upturn in business that is essential for a profitable year.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1982
description: International Washington said it welcomed Yuri V. Andropov's interest in an easing of tension and was ready ''to respond positively to any positive Soviet action.'' However, the Reagan Administration added that Monday's speech by the new Soviet leader ''contained no substantive change in familiar Soviet positions.'' (Page A1, Col. 5.) Pressure on ''extremist mayors'' in the West Bank should be maintained, according to a directive that Israeli military officials issued to administrators in charge of the occupied territory. The directive also instructs the administrators to neutralize pro-Jordanian Palestinians. (A15:1-3.)

title: Dispute on Chad Blocks Opening of Africa Parley
description: A conference of the Organization of African Unity failed to open on schedule today because of a deadlock over Libyan objections to seating a delegation from the new pro-Western Government of Chad.

title: CHRYSLER MAY SHIFT WORK TO U.S.
description: The Chrysler Corporation's chief bargainer said today that the company is retooling its United States plants to produce parts made by striking Canadians and will use outside suppliers if Americans refuse to do the work.

Market Place; Cellular Radio Promise Cited
description: CELLULAR radio, which holds the promise of making phones in cars commonplace, is a technology that has been long in coming but still holds tremendous potential profitability for companies that eventually make a success of it.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS GUATEMALA ARMS AID
description: State Department officials said today that the Reagan Administration was considering the sale of helicopter spare parts and communications equipment to Guatemala because the human rights situation there was improving.

description: Republican Congressional leaders said today that President Reagan's plan to deploy 100 MX intercontinental missiles in Wyoming would face serious trouble in the post-election legislative session that begins next week.

title: Deterrents; Retargeted
description: Even if the MX missile were, as the President asserts, the right missile at the right time, the Administration has just in the nick of time avoided giving it the wrong name.

title: Poor Lawyers for the Poor
description: Ethical concerns surround the usual picket-line rhetoric in the monthlong strike of 550 lawyers working for the New York Legal Aid Society. The strikers accuse the society of maintaining work routines that deprive indigent clients of their right to counsel. The society says the lawyers, by striking, have abandoned 30,000 clients. The parties are battling it out in court while the caseloads mount.

title: JURY HEARS FIRST TAPE OF SENATOR AT TEAMSTER TRIAL
description: The jury in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, today heard the wiretapped voice of Senator Howard W. Cannon commenting on a statement that his ''deal'' with Mr. Williams was falling apart.

title: RATIFICATION VOTE SET FOR DEC. 3
description: The National Football League Players Association said today that the league's 1,500 players would vote Friday, Dec. 3, to accept or reject the five-year collective bargaining agreement that ended their strike.

NIGHT ON THE TOWN FOR SOVIET IMMIGRANTS
description: ''ZAICHIK,'' said Igor Sverellin, nudging a companion in the ribs and pointing. ''Zaichik.'' The word is Russian for ''little rabbit,'' and Mr. Sverellin, one of a group of 49 Russian immigrants having a guided evening out at the Playboy Club in Manhattan, was demonstrating by pointing at Bunny Robin and Bunny Cynthia that he knew a real zaichik when he saw one.

description: A meeting in State Supreme Court yesterday between lawyers for the city, which owns Yankee Stadium, and George M. Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, failed to resolve the dispute over whether the Yankees will open their 1983 home season in the Bronx or in Denver's Mile High Stadium.

title: Brush Wellman To Sell Sawyer
description: Brush Wellman Inc., a Cleveland company, announced its board had authorized management to divest the Sawyer Research Products Inc. quartz products subsidiary.

title: Joy Baker Has Lung Surgery
description: Joy Baker, the wife of Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, underwent surgery today for removal of a malignant tumor from her right lung, the Senator's office said. She was reported in stable condition after the 90-minute operation at Georgetown University Hospital. Mrs. Baker, who is 52 years old, is the daughter of the late Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, an Illinois Republican.

title: U.S. Gets Berth In World Soccer
description: The United States national team will be the regional representative in the World Youth soccer championship next June, replacing Honduras.

title: TOP-NOTCH LOBBYISTS ON TAPE ROYALTIES
description: Since he decided, one spring day in 1966, to leave the service of Lyndon B. Johnson and to head the film industry's trade organization here, Jack Valenti has become one of Washington's premier producers, a master at the kind of special effects that are so important in the capital.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Hurricane Iwa Hits Hawaiian Island of Kauai
description: Hurricane Iwa, with winds of up to 110 miles an hour, hit the southern side of Kauai in the Hawaiian Islands tonight, night, knocking out power on the entire island. No injuries were initially reported.

title: Bank Acquisition Voted
description: The Security Bancorp Inc. said today that shareholders of the First National Bank of Monroe, Mich., at a special meting had approved the bank's $15.3 million acquisition by Security for $60 a share in 10-year subordinated variable rate installment notes. The acquisition is still subject to regulatory approval.

title: DIES
description: Burton B. Turkus, who prosecuted Murder Inc. as a member of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office and sent seven of its members to the electric chair in the 1940's, died at his Madison Avenue office on Monday. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clearing the Hurdles
description: One player who thinks he benefited from the eight-week National Football League strike is Renaldo Nehemiah, the 23-year-old worldchampion hurdler who is a rookie wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers. ''I got my little nicks in training camp, and I was still bothered by a hamstring injury in September,'' said Nehemiah, who had not played football in six years.

title: Article 053089 -- No Title
description: The film rights to ''Schindler's List,'' the prize-winning nonfiction novel by Thomas Keneally about the German industrialist who helped save hundreds of Jews during World War II, will be purchased by Univeral Pictures for $500,000, according to Sidney Sheinberg, the president of Universal's parent company, MCA.

title: Entenmann's Takeover
description: The General Foods Corporation has completed its $315 million acquisition of Entenmann's Inc., a maker of baked goods, from the Warner-Lambert Company, the companies announced yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Singing and Listening At Carnegie Hall

title: Robinson In New Job At U.S.C.
description: John Robinson of Southern California, one of the most successful coaches in college football, announced today that he was leaving the coaching profession and would become senior vice president for university relations.

title: Governors Counter Offer Of Reagan on Federalism
description: The nation's governors have sent President Reagan an amended federalism proposal that would require the Federal Government to pay a much larger share of the Medicaid insurance program for the poor while making no change in the Federal food stamp and joint Federal-state welfare programs.

title: CREDIBILITY OF BASING SYSTEM FOR MX AFFECTS MILITARY,; MONEY AND POLITICS
description: President Reagan's announcement that he has chosen to base the proposed fleet of MX intercontinental missiles in a closely spaced, slender column near Warren Air Force Base in Cheyenne, Wyo., will probably not end debate about the issue even within the executive branch of the Government, much less in the Congress and among military analysts outside the Administration.

title: 2 More in the Running
description: The field for the women's senior division of the United States cross-country championships on Sunday grew to four former champions with the entries of Mary Shea, who won in 1980, and Margaret Groos, the 1979 winner. Also entered are Jan Merrill, the winner in 1976 and 1977, and Julie Brown, the defending champion.

title: CRIMINAL-JUSTICE CHIEF
description: On Mario M. Cuomo's very first trip to Rochester, one of his hosts was an insurgent Democrat named Lawrence T. Kurlander. ''I slept in his kid's bedroom,'' Mr. Cuomo recalled.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
SUPERVISOR AT REACTOR QUESTIONED
description: Contending that the 1979 nuclear accident at Three Mile Island could have been averted, an attorney for the Babcock & Wilcox Company outlined in cross-examination yesterday what he contended were additional discrepancies in the testimony of the supervisor on duty during the accident.

title: Share Increase For Macy Backed
description: R.H. Macy & Company's stockholders approved an increase in the company's authorized common shares to 100 million from 45 million. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer, said that the new shares, which would be held in the company treasury, was not intended for use in acquisitions or other major projects at this time.

title: FROM ARMY RESEARCH TO CIVILIAN CONSUMERS
description: NATICK, Mass. THE soldiers plod on through the desert, their foreheads agleam, their sweat dissipating into still, dry air. Nearby, other soldiers, wrapped up like snowmen in insulating garb, shiver with the fall of a frosty arctic night.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KATHERINE ANNE PORTER, A LIFE. By Joan Givner. 456 pages. Simon & Schuster. Illustrated. $19.95

title: IRISH VOTERS, VOTE-WEARY, TRY IT AGAIN
description: Politicking Irish-style lost a lot of its appeal Sunday night for the handful of party faithful waiting on the sidewalk outside Our Lady of Refuge Church for the evening mass to end.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
NEW YORK FACES NEW WATER CURB AT END OF WEEK
description: Water levels in New York City's upstate reservoirs are continuing to fall, and the chief engineer for the Delaware River Basin Commission said today that, if the trend kept up, the agency would be forced to make new cuts on Saturday in the city's water allocation.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KARCHER, CARL, CO reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 5
description: Results for the latest 12 weeks include a gain on the sale of restaurants equal to 3 cents a shr

title: INTEGRATION RULES ON TEACHERS EASED
description: The United States Department of Education said yesterday that it was easing its requirements for the integration of the teaching staffs in New York City's public schools.

title: 1. Boots That Say ''Mush!''
description: Weather forecasters keep predicting a rugged winter. If you're heading for snow country or thinking forward to local blizzards, you might check out boots meant to keep feet dry and warm in the worst of climates. The boots, made by Chris-Craft, are of black rubber with thick tread soles, have a yellow stripe at the foot and top and loops to pull them on. They're lined with thick pile and have removable inner soles. They come in women's sizes 5 to 10, are priced at $25 at Vermont Classics, 284 Columbus Avenue (73d Street).

title: Reagan Appoints Head Of Labor Relations Panel
description: President Reagan has named Assistant Labor Secretary Donald Dotson as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Advertising; Changing Times as Ad Vehicle
description: "Pawnshops: Quick Money at High Cost."... "Could You Win in Small Claims Court?" ... "The Care and Feeding of House Plants."

title: WILLIAM JONES, 43, '71 PULITZER WINNER AT CHICAGO TRIBUNE
description: William H. Jones, managing editor of The Chicago Tribune, winner of the 1971 Pulitzer Prize for local investigative reporting, died today at the M.D. Anderson Hospital in Houston of leukemia. He was 43 years old.

title: EUROPEANS REBUFF U.S. ON FARM SUBSIDY ISSUE
description: A top official of the European Common Market today flatly rejected American demands to phase out government agricultural export subsidies totaling $8 billion a year, clouding the outcome of the world trade conference that opens here on Wednesday.

title: ISLANDERS TIED BY NORTH STARS
description: The Islanders and the North Stars played an 8-8 tie tonight, a wide-open game that was a far cry from Minnesota's 2-0 victory over New York on Nov. 11.

title: UNGLAMOROUS WAYNE STATE STILL STRIVES TO EDUCATE URBAN POOR
description: They are fairly typical undergraduates at one of the biggest universities in the Middle West, but neither Terry O'Brien nor Milton Duerod is sure of the football team's nickname.

title: MX PLANS: 'HOW MUCH IS ENOUGH?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Petro-Canada
description: Petro-Canada's takeover of the refining and marketing assets of B.P. Canada Inc. will cost close to $600 million, rather than the previously announced $347 million, company officials told the Canadian House of Commons Energy Committee today.

title: JMSL Raises Bid for Pabst
description: The battle for control of the Pabst Brewing Company intensified yesterday when the JMSL Acquiring Corporation increased its offer for three million shares of the beer company's stock to $35 a share from $30.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CELEBRATING THE ARRIVAL OF THE NEW BEAUJOLAIS
description: AS midnight approaches, cars, trucks and horse-drawn wagons roll onto the tarmac in Macon, France, amid the roar of aircraft engines. Men in blue aprons and berets glance at their wristwatches and begin loading boxes and cartons into small propeller planes, corporate jets, a vintage DC-3. Soon the planes are climbing into the blackness, speeding toward Paris, Brussels, London, eventually New York, as silence descends.

title: RAVITCH ASSAILS FINDING BY U.S. ON CANADA DEAL
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today described as ''greatly unfair and senseless'' a preliminary finding that 825 subway cars ordered from a Canadian company by the authority were being unfairly subsidized by the Canadian Government.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FILM IS RUINED, ABC SAYS
description: The producer of an ABC News television documentary on black labor unions in South Africa said that the film his crew had shot was ruined in a way that led the network's technical experts to conclude that the destruction was sabotage.

title: TIMES SQUARE BY 1990
description: To the Editor:

title: DURABLES ORDERS FALL STEEP 4.9%
description: In another discouraging sign for the economy, the Government reported today that orders to manufacturers for durable goods dropped 4.9 percent in October, the biggest decline in a year.

title: Wilson to Get Hearing On Arrest Circumstances
description: A Federal judge has ordered a hearing next Monday to determine whether Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence agent accused of smuggling explosives to Libya, was returned to the United States illegally before his arrest.

title: A POTATO-NEST BASKET
description: MANY years ago, before restaurant inspectors became so vigorous, I used to enjoy making faisan en voliere, a roast pheasant dish that was presented with a reconstruction of the bird using its head, wings and feathers.

title: KOCH TO DROP NEW CONSTRUCTION POST
description: Fourteen months after creating the Office of Construction Industry Relations to fight discrimination and extortion in the industry, Mayor Koch will abolish the unit as a budget-cutting measure, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: CHICAGO'S LYRIC OPERA IN COMEBACK
description: Stripped of its assets and working capital, $500,000 in debt and shaken by the death of its general manager, the Lyric Opera of Chicago was on the edge of disaster only a year ago. But today, as a result of a major restructuring of its financial policies, the Lyric is again solvent - and in the midst of its most successful season.

title: JAPANESE PARTY PRIMARY PICKS LIKELY NEXT PREMIER
description: Yasuhiro Nakasone today scored a landslide victory in the primary election for the presidency of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ICAHN SUES DAN RIVER
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier attempting to take over Dan River Inc., yesterday accused the big textile producer of starting an illegal tender offer to buy its own stock -thus depriving Mr. Icahn of the stock.

title: Horner Is Puzzled
description: Bob Horner, the Atlanta Braves' third baseman, who asked to be traded two years ago, now wants to know: ''What do I have to do to be wanted here?'' Reacting to a comment from the Braves' executive vice president, Al Thornwell, that the odds were even that Horner would be traded before next season, Horner said he did not want to leave the Braves. ''We just came off a National League West championship year, and why would anyone want to start tearing things down? I don't know how much better I can do.

title: 13 Going on 50
description: The second race at Laurel Race Course today is an end-of-the-line event, matching horses who can be claimed for as little as $4,000. For the most part, horses at this level are the slowest and most physically suspect on the grounds. But much of the racing world, particularly in Maryland, will be awaiting today's results with keen interest and rooting hard for the big gray gelding named Port Conway Lane.

title: BENNY FRIEDMAN, STAR PASSER AT MICHIGAN AND WITH PROS
description: Benny Friedman, whose career as a football player and coach spanned 40 years, died yesterday in his East Side apartment of what the police described as a self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 76 years old.

title: MOSCOW CALLS MX PROPOSAL DANGEROUS AND COSTLY MOVE
description: President Reagan's proposal for a means of deploying the new MX intercontinental missile was condemned in the Soviet press today as a ''new dangerous step'' that would raise the arms race to a ''higher, more expensive and dangerous level.''

title: Let Us Give Thanks?
description: A modern Thanksgiving Day Proclamation: For all that we are about to receive - new ''peacekeeping'' nuclear missiles in Wyoming, the highest unemployment rates since the Great Depression, and the biggest Federal budget deficits since the last World War - let us give thanks.

title: Cavanaugh on Spot
description: After winning the starting quarterback's job for the New England Patriots in training camp, Matt Cavanaugh may have lost it. ''The quarterbacking job is wide-open again at this point,'' the Patriots' coach, Ron Meyer, said yesterday.

title: GULF WAR SAID TO STRENGTHEN MORE MODERATE ARAB NATIONS
description: Diplomatic sources here and in Baghdad say that Iraq's apparently deadlocked war with Iran has had the effect of strengthening the positions of the more moderate Arab Governments in the region.

title: Hudson Bay Settlement
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said its Churchill River Power Comapny Ltd. would receive $29 million in an out-of-court settlement for the April 1, 1981, transfer of the Island Falls power plant to the Saskatchewan Power Corporation, which is owned by the provincial government. Hudson Bay Mining said the payment included interest and was in addition to the $39.5 million previously paid to Churchill River Power.

title: BAN ON RICHARD STRAUSS REIMPOSED IN ISRAEL
description: Israel today reimposed the ban on the music of Richard Strauss, ending a two-week period in which the Nazi-era composer's works were allowed on the airwaves.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I serve fish soup, guests frequently ask whether it could be called a bouillabaisse. To me that is a fairly facile point, and my immediate response is ''No, you can only find a genuine bouillabaisse in Provence'' or at least where the fish of that region can be procured. They include Saint-Pierre and rascasse or devilfish, which is sometimes referred to as ''the soul'' of bouillabaisse. It is not a common fish, but I am told it can be found in American waters, where it is sometimes called sculpin or red scorpion. I think the whole argument is a bit specious, however. If the soup - by whatever name - is good, dine well and be happy.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arkansas Power and Light Co.'s $100 million issue of 13 3/8 percent first mortgage bonds, due in 2012, was priced at 99.453 percent of par, to yield 13.45 percent, through First Boston Corp.

title: PAGE AMERICA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMI Reports Narrower Loss
description: AM International, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, said yesterday that its loss for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 30 narrowed to $4.6 million from $15.8 million in the same quarter a year earlier.

title: SUTTERS PUT MARK ON N.H.L.
description: The six Sutter brothers are scattered all over the hockey map, and Duane and Brent count themselves lucky to be on the same club, the Islanders. In uniform, and wearing their helmets, they look so much alike that they have confused referees and linesmen and occasionally Duane's wife, Cindy.

title: VICTOR IN JAPANESE PARTY VOTE IS NEARLY SURE TO BE PREMIER
description: Japan's Liberal Democratic Party elected Yasuhiro Nakasone as its president today, assuring that he will be named the new Prime Minister on Friday.

title: Royals Drop Lee May
description: The Kansas City Royals announced that Lee May, the 39-year-old first baseman and designated hitter, had been put on waivers, gone unclaimed and been released. May played in only 42 games last season, batting .308 with 3 home runs and 12 runs batted in. But during a major league career that began in 1965, he hit 354 homers, and he enjoyed his finest season in 1969 with the Cincinnati Reds, when he hit 38 homers and drove in 110 runs.

title: NEW PANTHEON LABEL TO ISSUE 3 SERIES
description: ONE of the most ubiquitous classical-label companies current, especially in the budget-priced cassette field, is the Moss Music Group, which issues Vox, Allegro and Turnabout.

title: OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FUGITIVE UNIONIST JAILED IN POLAND
description: A Solidarity underground leader was sentenced to six years in jail today for trying to carry on union activity under martial law.

title: CLEVELAND E. DODGE, BUSINESSMAN AND PHILANTHROPIST, IS DEAD AT 94
description: Cleveland Earl Dodge, a businessman and philanthropist who remained active all his life in various religious and charitable organizations, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 94 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $6.6 million for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $428,000 for the qr and $691,000 for the 6 mos

title: THOROUGHLY MODERN GRANDMA: GOOD JOBS AND JOGGING SUITS
description: ON the eve of Thanksgiving Day the new grandmother was up to her elbows in cranberry sauce and bragging about the baby again: ''He's the most beautiful, smart, funny, unique, absolutely incredible grandbaby. He's seven months old and his name is Rafael. Rafael Friedan.''

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
MAGNETS TO HOLD TOOLS
description: TWO new magnetic holders for organizing and holding tools or kitchen implements have large magnetized areas that hold tools firmly enough so they don't fall off if bumped.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clemson's Loss
description: Clemson's football team has a knack for making news. Last year, it was ranked No.1 in the nation. Two days ago, it was penalized for violations in its recruiting methods. Saturday, it will play Wake Forest in Tokyo in the annual invitation game between American colleges.

title: 'SAFE, EFFECTIVE AND WIDELY USED' ELECTROCONVULSIVE THERAPY
description: To the Editor: You suggest in your editorial that a Government agency should investigate electroconvulsive therapy. The fact is that the Food and Drug Administration held a public hearing just last week (Nov. 4) to decide whether it should investigate this treatment.

title: HURDLES ON THE ROAD TO ZERO POPULATION GROWTH
description: To the Editor:

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERN ABOUT WEST BANK REPORT
description: The State Department said today that the United States had officially expressed concern to Israel about reports that the Israeli military authorities were trying to reduce the influence of Palestinians living in the occupied territories who favor cooperation with either the Palestine Liberation Organization or Jordan.

title: Deer Hunter Needs to Prepare
description: A bout one of every 12 hunters taking part in New York State's Southern Zone modern-firearms season for deer - it opened last Monday and closes Dec. 14 - will be successful.

title: Required Reading; Why There Are Deficits
description: Martin Feldstein, Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in an address before the Commercial Club of Boston, Nov. 9, 1982: In short, then, the primary cause of our current and projected budget deficits is that nondefense outlays have grown more rapidly and G.N.P. has grown more slowly than was anticipated in the 1960's and 1970's when new programs were enacted and old programs enlarged. We have deficits because we made decisions on the basis of economic assumptions that have turned out to be wrong. We have deficits because as a nation we are not as rich as we thought we would be at this time.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Plane but Not Simple

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rates Are Basically Steady; 1-Year Bills Dip to 8.372%
description: Interest rates were unchanged or slightly lower for most Treasury issues yesterday, and closed in about the middle of the day's narrow trading range.

title: TEXT OF A WARNING BY ISRAELI PANEL OF LEGAL RISKS IN MASSACRE FINDINGS
description: Following is the text of a decision issued here today by the panel looking into the killing of civilians in September at two Palestinian refugee camps, as issued in translation from the Hebrew by the Government press office:

title: HAROLD KENDRICK
description: Harold Kendrick, former manager of the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, died last Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital in Milwaukee, where he was undergoing a heart operation.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Safecracker Pleads Not Guilty to Theft Charges
description: H. Edward Tickel Jr., a former agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, pleaded not guilty Tuesday to charges that he had stolen walkie-talkie radios and entered the credit union offices at the bureau's headquarters here with intent to steal.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My flagstone sidewalks have had some paint spots on them for a number of years. How can I get those spots out?

title: GENERAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $695,954 from discontinued operations and a charge of $10,382,545 for depletion depreciation and amortization...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $795,057...D-Including income from discontinued operations of $21,226,032 and a gain of $20,366,881 from the sale of the company's Kentucky coal properties in April...E-After a loss of $441,491 from discontinued operations

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Giving Thanks

title: CHINA, NOTING TALK BY ANDROPOV, URGES MOSCOW CONCESSIONS
description: China today responded to conciliatory remarks by Yuri Andropov, the new Soviet party leader, by again calling on Moscow to make new efforts to eliminate obstacles hindering the normalization of relations.

title: BOUDIN LAWYERS ASK FOR TRANSFER OF BRINK'S TRIAL
description: Attorneys for Kathy Boudin, a defendant in the Brink's armored-car robbery and triple slaying, asked yesterday for a transfer of the forthcoming trial from Rockland County because, they said, fear and hostility generated by the crime had prejudiced potential jurors.

title: Daughter of an Ulster Judge Escapes Death in Bomb Blast
description: The daughter of a leading judge in Northern Ireland narrowly escaped death today when a bomb planted by guerrillas exploded under her car outside a Belfast court, the police said.

title: GENERAL PRODUCTION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-No comparable yr-ago results are available because the company became public on Feb 3, 1982

title: BRITISH CREDIT CARD NOW BUYS ANTIQUES
description: Michael Davis, who has built a career dusting cobwebs off the British antiques business by streamlining the shipping process, has developed a credit card. It allows foreign buyers, both dealers and private customers, to purchase antiques and then pay for them on delivery.

title: IF SOCIAL SECURITY OFFERED A CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
PACKERS IMPROVE FOR JET PASS RUSH
description: Last Dec. 20, Lynn Dickey, the quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, spent a significant portion of a cold afternoon on his back staring at the sky above Shea Stadium. The New York Sack Exchange dropped Dickey nine times and the Jets won by 28-3, a decision that put them and the Giants, who also won, into the playoffs and kept the Packers out.

title: Pabst Bid Revised
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said it had reduced the number of Pabst Brewing Company shares it was seeking under a current tender offer to 4.25 million. Heileman, which originally offered to pay $27.50 a share for 5.5 million shares of Pabst, also said it planned to make another announcement by noon Friday regarding its offer, which expires Dec. 2.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: EFFORTS to reduce home ''operating costs'' by conserving energy and doing many repair and improvement jobs are essential for many people, and they are on the lookout for new tools and other products to ease the task.

title: President Quits At Dr Pepper
description: The Dr Pepper Company, a maker of soft drinks, said today that its president, Charles L. Jarvie, had resigned in a dispute over management strategy and was replaced by Richard Q. Armstrong, president of its Canada Dry subsidiary.

title: A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's A series of articles appearing periodically
description: They have never heard of the Pilgrims. Plymouth Rock might as well be a new kind of dance or a type of car. They have only eaten cranberry sauce as a jam on bread, and the only place they have ever expressed their thanks before is inside a cathedral. But no matter that they are not especially fond of turkey or that it makes no sense to them to stage a celebration on a Thursday instead of a weekend night, members of the Niquio family -who arrived in the United States several months ago from Argentina - will be sitting down today to their first Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Rangers Rally to Win 4th in Row; Rangers 8, North Stars 5
description: Rob McClanahan scored three goals as the Rangers defeated Minnesota, 8-5, at Madison Square Garden last night for their fourth straight victory.

title: ART AND CRAFTS FROM LAPLAND
description: ''Sami Art Today'' is the theme of the exhibition at the art gallery of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, 127 East 73d Street, that will run through Dec. 18.

title: Ian Smith Queried in Harare
description: Ian D. Smith, former Prime Minister of Rhodesia and leader of the Republican Front Party, said today that he was questioned by the Harare police for six hours Tuesday night. Mr. Smith said the incident was part of a Government plan to get rid of his party. ''It is a monstrous situation,'' he said. The national news agency reported that Mr. Smith and 15 other whites, including two members of Parliament, were questioned in connection with the holding of an illegal meeting.

title: DAMAGE TO 3 ISLANDS SEVERE
description: Hurricane Iwa blasted the northern Hawaiian Islands with a 110-mile-an-hour winds Tuesday night, leaving one Navy seaman dead from huge waves slamming his ship, millions of dollars' worth of homes and businesses in ruins and the fate of those on Niihau, the hardest hit island, unknown.

title: Holiday Cheer
description: For six football players trying to crack the pros, this may become a special Thanksgiving Day: Contracts were mailed to them yesterday by the New Jersey Generals of the new United States Football League.

title: Making Jobs - and Saving Them
description: ''Our first priority,'' says House Speaker O'Neill, ''must be to put the millions of unemployed back to work.'' The Speaker has his social priorities straight; he's willing to act urgently to make jobs. But is he equally willing to act urgently to save them? Doing that is within his grasp, and that of the lame-duck Congress starting next week - by passing the nearly finished legislation to reform the immigration laws.

title: INSTITUTIONAL NETWORKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including a $70,500 nonrecurring recovery of a prior period loss

title: EPIDEMIC OF RECESSION POSES HARD CHOICES FOR ALL NATIONS
description: First article of a series appearing periodically on world economic problems. Not since the Depression of 50 years ago have the nations of the world faced such a bewildering multitude of economic and financial problems. In country after country, as if caught in a global epidemic, the world is afflicted with high unemployment and falling production and is beset by sagging trade, failing businesses and huge foreign debts.

title: Savin Narrows Quarterly Loss
description: The Savin Corporation, a marketer of copying machines, said yesterday that it lost $1.4 million in the second quarter, ended Oct. 31, compared with a loss of $4.1 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Money Market Reserves
description: Reserve requirements on the new money market accounts that will be offered by banks and thrift institutions beginning Dec. 14 will range from zero to 12 percent, the Federal Reserve Board said today. Accounts opened by individuals will be subject to no reserve requirement if transfers are limited to six a month. Accounts opened by businesses will carry a 3 percent reserve requirement if transfers are limited to six a month.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the Octo- ber increase in the Consumer Price Index misstated the 1981 increase. It was 8.9 percent.

title: Gulf Oil Write-Off
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced it would take a $50 million after-tax write-off against fourth-quarter earnings to cover the permanent closing of its 75 percent owned refinery near Milan, Italy. The write-off was disclosed in Gulf's third-quarter report to shareholders following the termination of talks with the Kuwait Petroleum Company for sale of that refinery and other European operations.

title: SUSPECT IN LAUNDERING MONEY
description: By all appearances, Eduardo Orozco-Prada was a very successful coffee importer. He lived on a two-acre estate in an affluent New York suburb, with an indoor swimming pool in a half-million-dollar home. From offices on Wall Street, Mr. Orozco owned or controlled numerous companies and had accounts in some of New York's biggest banks. Through these accounts and companies, Mr. Orozco, his brother and other associates moved tens of mil Last of two articles. lions of dollars in cash, say Federal authorities, whose curiosity was piqued by the large money flow. Was the 43-year-old Mr. Orozco a terrific exporter-importer, investigators asked, or was his wealth primarily from another source - money laundering?

title: FIVE YEARS TO WEST BANK INTEGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN NIGRO
description: John Nigro, a founder of Nigro Brothers Paving Inc. of Mount Vernon, N.Y., died Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. Mr. Nigro, who was a resident of Mount Vernon, was 55 years old.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1982
description: International The Israeli commission of inquiry on the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut notified Prime Minister Menachem Begin and eight other top officials that there was a possibility they might be harmed by its findings. The panel said Mr. Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon might be found to have failed in their duties by ignoring the dangers of asking Lebanese Christian militiamen to go into the Palestinian refugee camps and, in the cases of some of the other officials, by neglecting to report or act quickly to halt the killings. (Page A1, Column 4.) Foreign Miniser Yitzhak Shamir testified it was not true that a fellow Israeli Cabinet member told him Sept. 17 that Lebanese Christian militiamen were killing Palestinian civilians in Beirut. In a 40-minute appearance before the Israeli judicial commission investigating Israeli involvement in the killings, Mr. Shamir denied testimony given by Communications Minister Mordechai Zipori. (A10:4.)

title: S.I. DUMP SURVEY FINDS NO SERIOUS HEALTH PERIL
description: A Health Department survey of people living next to a Staten Island landfill where toxic wastes were illegally dumped has found a significantly greater degree of minor respiratory complaints but not serious illness, a new city report said yesterday.

title: Jersey City Schools Seek Theft Inquiry
description: The State Attorney General was asked today to investigate what school officials suspect is the misappropriation of more than $1 million from the Board of Education.

title: Third Suspect Arrested In Kidnapping of Doctor
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested the last of three men charged in the kidnapping of an Illinois doctor, who operated an abortion clinic, and his wife.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Columbia's Funds
description: I n a fresh effort to improve its community image, Columbia University has put $150,000 of its money in two nearby minority banks. The Puerto Rico-based Banco de Ponce's branch at Broadway and 96th Street received a deposit of $100,000 Tuesday.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MID-NOVEMBER SALES BY BIG 3 CAR MAKERS UP A STRONG 41.7%
description: The nation's three largest auto makers reported a surge in car sales in mid-November, largely because of incentive programs that featured lower interest rates on auto loans.

title: RICHARD BARR WINS A THEATER AWARD
description: Richard Barr, the theatrical producer, has won the third John F. Wharton Theater Award. The award, named for the late theatrical lawyer John F. Wharton, will be presented Dec. 13 at a reception at Sardi's.

title: Paper Is Cleared
description: A jury today cleared The Birmingham Post-Herald of libel charges brought by Edward Seal, who contended that he had been defamed by a report that Bobby Lee Hurt had been paid to play basketball at Butler High School, where Mr. Seal was the principal.

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After extraordinary gains of $1.3 million for the qr and $6.1 million for the9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $73,000 for the qr and $395,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary gains of $672,000 for the qr and $855,000 for the 9 mos

title: AGENCY FAVORS 5-CENT GAS TAX RISE
description: The Department of Transportation, turning away from an earlier plan, now favors a 5-cent-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax to finance the Federal share of President Reagan's proposed $32.9 billion program to rehabilitate highways and assist mass transit systems.
