title: REAGAN AIDES SAID TO BE SHAPING NEW PLAN TO FIGHT UNEMPLOYMENT
description: Administration officials are preparing for President Reagan's consideration a package of proposals for combating unemployment that a White House spokesman said today would be ''far more comprehensive'' than the highway repair measure the President endorsed for passage in Congress's special session.

title: No Headline
description: GHANA SAYS IT CRUSHED A COUP

title: Harvester In Soviet Talks
description: The International Harvester Company disclosed today that it had reopened talks with the Soviet Union on the construction of a combine-manufacturing plant in that country. Harvester said it expected to complete contract negotiations with Moscow before the end of the year, and to begin work on the project by next spring.

title: Ailing Landaluce Is Out of Starlet
description: Landaluce, undefeated in five starts, must pass up the mile-and-a-sixteenth Starlet Handicap for 2-year-old fillies at Hollywood Park Sunday because of a fever.

title: First National Boston
description: The First National Boston Corporation said yesterday that its board had agreed to a plan for First National to acquire the Fall River Trust Company through a stock exchange.

title: EUROPEAN TREASURES
description: IN the late 1960's aspiring hippies used to buy their bell-bottom blue jeans at the Different Drummer, a store at 60th Street and Lexington Avenue. Fifteen years later Todd Merer, above left, and Paul Siegenlaub, who owned the store, have changed their tune.

title: Assets Rise at Money Funds
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds rose $543 million in the four business days ended Tuesday, to $231 billion, after two weeks of declines.

title: METEORS IN THE CAMPAIGN MANAGING FIRMAMENT
description: David Doak, a member of the class of young professionals who came of age in this year's elections, is a babyfaced campaign manager with a duelist's feel for the killing stroke.

title: 1978 MISHAP DISCUSSED AT 3 MILE ISLAND TRIAL
description: Had the operators on duty at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania studied the report on an incident at the same plant in 1978, they could have avoided the billion-dollar accident that occurred there on March 29, 1979, a lawyer for the Babcock & Wilcox Company said yesterday in Federal District Court here.

title: Burnup Reports a Loss
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., a cable communications concern, had a loss of $5.5 million in its second quarter, ended Oct. 31, on revenues of $51 million, compared with earnings of $2.5 million on revenues of $47 million a year earlier. Burnup attributed the loss in part to the impact of law suits between the company and Victor Posner, who has a 35 percent interest in Burnup.

title: U.S. Calls on the Soviet To Leave Afghanistan
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, called on the Soviet Union today to negotiate its withdrawal from Afghanistan or stand accused of ''having no serious interest in a settlement.''

title: WALLACHS LIVE THE LIFE OF SCHISGAL
description: ANNE JACKSON was carrying on about something or other - ''doing a Medea,'' as she put it later - in the Riverside Drive apartment she shares with her husband, Eli Wallach, when she interrupted her tirade to ask matter-of-factly what time it was. ''That's a Schisgal,'' their daughter Roberta called out, and they all grinned.

title: OTTAWA TO SELL ITS STAKES IN 5 COMPANIES
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau authorized today the formation of a new Government corporation to direct the sale of the Canadian Government's interests in five companies.

title: MATTERS OF TASTE; Ant Eaters
description: What to have for dessert is not much of a Thanksgiving problem; what to call it might be. The specific question we have in mind is, what do you call the tiny multicolored flecks of candy that are sometimes scattered on chocolate cakes, or into which ice cream cones are dipped?

title: A JOYOUS TRIP TO NEW YORK, HARD TIMES OR NO
description: At 4:30 P.M. Tuesday, the moment listed in the itinerary, five huge red and silver motor coaches pulled away from the front of Chrysler High School in New Castle, Ind., and headed up Parkview Drive for Macy's Thanksgiving Parade in New York.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
T.C.U. Chooses Wacker
description: Jim Wacker, who has compiled a record of 39 victories and 8 losses in the last four seasons at Southwest Texas State, was named head football coach at Texas Christian. He replaces F.A. Dry, who was dismissed last week after six losing seasons. ... Art Baker was discharged as head coach at the Citadel after five seasons there.

title: Morton Is Benched
description: Craig Morton, at 39 the oldest player in the National Football League, will apparently end his 18-year pro career on the bench. Coach Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos said yesterday that Steve DeBerg had succeeded Morton as the team's No.1 quarterback and that Mark Herrmann had been elevated to the backup role.

title: A GENTLEMAN'S QUARTERS, MADE TO ORDER
description: WHILE most apartment renovations are made-to-measure projects, some, like good English tailoring, just fit their owners better than others. The Central Park West apartment of Ashton Hawkins, for example, is like a custom-made suit: It becomes the wearer perfectly, and many of its best qualities are, at first glance, undetectable.

title: ACTIVIST CHARGES LEGAL HARASSMENT
description: A former civil rights worker who says a United States Senator and a Kentucky prosecutor violated his constitutional rights testified today that he was unable to find steady work after he felt forced to quit his community organizing job with poor whites in Pike County, Ky.

title: CABARET: GIL SCOTT-HERON
description: COMPARED to his days as an insurrectionist firebrand of the early 1970's, the poet and singer Gil Scott-Heron is now a relatively mellow protest singer. And on Monday at the Bottom Line, where he opened a two-night engagement with his band, The Amnesia Express, he was positively affable, with much of his rhetoric obscured in cool pop-jazz arrangements.

title: Miss Boston Returns As a Brink's Witness
description: Cynthia Boston surrendered in Manhattan yesterday as a material witness in the 1981 Brink's robbery case. Her husband, William Johnson, has been indicted as a conspirator in Rockland County holdup, in which three persons were killed.

title: Bridge: New Partnership Leading In Blue Ribbon Pair Play
description: Two famous players in a first-time partnership led the blue ribbon pair championship in the semifinal stage at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.

title: U.S. and Soviet Clash At East-West Talks
description: Delegates at the conference on European security here said the United States and the Soviet Union clashed directly today for the first time since the marathon meeting resumed two weeks ago.

title: GARDEN BOOKSHELF: GOOD READING FOR WINTER NIGHTS
description: ALTHOUGH it sometimes seems as though every inch of the ''sceptered isle'' has been exhaustively catalogued and evaluated or at least excavated, British houses and gardens seem to generate a steady stream of new books that, interesting and amusing on their own terms, are also handsome gifts and guides. . THE LAST COUNTRY HOUSES, by Clive Aslet, 344 pages, illustrated; Yale University Press, $29.95.

title: DOW UP BY 9.01, TO 1,000
description: Retail, broadcasting and other blue-chip issues led the stock market higher yesterday to reverse three days of declining prices. Trading volume slowed markedly in the pre-Thanksgiving Day session.

title: Hearing Delayed By Labor Board
description: The National Labor Relations Board announced today a one-week postponement, from next Monday until Dec. 6, of a hearing on charges of unfair labor practices against the National Football League.

title: STAGE: 'PENELOPE,' COMEDY
description: JUST when one thought that the theater season had scraped bottom along comes ''Penelope'' to put everything in perspective. This alleged farce by J. Radloff, which opened last night at the Perry Street Theater, is beneath the barrel.

title: UNESCO TO FIGHT GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR
description: The head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said here today that the contrast between the very rich and the very poor among nations and individuals kept deepening in spite of technological progress and growing interdependence among nations.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CELEBRATING CRAFTS
description: Crafts Sale, Pindar Gallery, 127 Greene Street; 212-553-4881.

title: At 30, 'The Mousetrap' Is Having a Party
description: There will be a party Thursday for 1,000 guests to celebrate the birthday of a stage play.

title: INDIAN LEADER PLANS TO FIGHT EXTRADITION BID
description: With his seven-year sanctuary in California threatened by a change in political administrations, Dennis Banks, a co-founder of the American Indian Movement, said Tuesday, ''I'm going to fight it out to the end,'' rather than try to go underground to avoid extradition.

title: A Principle for Choosing Principals
description: In four years as head of New York City's public schools, Chancellor Frank Macchiarola has replaced more than half of the 110 theoretically tenured high school principals. The changes were accomplished by forced retirements, reassignments and outright dismissals.

title: FOX FILM TO RAISE PRODUCTION
description: Despite its ''disappointing performance'' in making motion pictures this year, the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation will increase future production schedules, Alan J. Hirschfield, chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: DEFENSE SAYS IT WILL CALL SENATOR IN TEAMSTER TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers said today that they would summon as a witness Senator Howard W. Cannon, whom prosecutors say was the target of a bribe attempt by Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, as the Government completed its case in the bribery conspiracy trial.

title: DISCORDANT NOTES MAR TRADE TALK
description: A world trade conference here opened today on a discordant note, with the French Foreign Trade Minister questioning the value of the sessions and directing harsh criticism at the United States.

title: MASSACRE INQUIRY SAYS TOP ISRAELIS ARE AT LEGAL RISK
description: The state commission investigating the Beirut massacre notified Prime Minister Menachem Begin and eight other top Israeli Government, military and intelligence officials today that there was a possibility that they could be harmed by its findings.

title: JOHN WARD RUSH
description: John Ward Rush, inventor of the ''dead man's control'' used in the safety system of every train, died Friday at the age of 87.

title: RAPID-AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after a charge of $6,049,000 mostly for foreign exchange loss on sale of the company's Canadian alcoholic beverage operationa and an income tax provision of $9,748,000 in connection with the sale of the Canadian operation

title: LED U.S. AID AGENCY
description: James H. Smith Jr., a former Assistant Secretary of the Navy and foreign aid administrator under President Eisenhower, died yesterday at a hospital in La Jolla, Calif., after suffering from cancer for two years. He was 72 years old.

title: THE QUIET MAN
description: Can one man make a difference? George Shultz has been reminding us of the right answer to that old question. In a few months as Secretary of State he has shown that even in a Government of highly ideological cast a man of determined common sense can make an enormous difference.

title: Comptroller Clears NCNB Acquisition
description: The NCNB Corporation, holding company for the North Carolina National Bank, said its previously proposed acquisition of Bancshares of North Carolina had been approved by the Comptroller of the Currency.

title: Tricentrol Clarification
description: Tricentrol P.L.C. said today that it had acquired interests of 8.3 percent in six offshore blocks in the Gulf of Mexico rather than eight as reported in its statement last Friday. The company's share of the bidding was $11.1 million rather than $11.3 million, as stated earlier.

title: GTE's Acquisition Of Sprint Delayed
description: The Justice Department delayed the proposed acquisition of the Southern Pacific Company's ''Sprint'' long-distance telephone network by the GTE Corporation by asking both companies to provide more information.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Swan the Sailor Studying Charts
description: Craig Swan of the Mets will be spending a busy Thanksgiving Day studying charts. Ocean charts, not pitching charts. He wants to sail around the world some day, and next week he will go into serious training.

title: A FEW THANK-YOU NOTES
description: T his is a day to forget the villains, to ignore Ed Garvey and Al Davis and George Steinbrenner, to think instead of those in sports who deserve a thank-you note just for being themselves. Some are in the headlines often, some aren't. But in sports' little corner of the world, each makes it a better place to be - whether they happen to win or lose, whether they happen to be still competing or not. So here's one man's list of a few people to be thankful for today:

title: Driver Not Drunk In Crash Fatal to 4
description: The 16-year-old driver of a station wagon in which he and three other teen-agers were killed in a crash after a police chase in September had been drinking but was not legally intoxicated, according to a state toxicologist.

title: IF SOCIAL SECURITY OFFERED A CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SAFE, EFFECTIVE AND WIDELY USED' ELECTROCONVULSIVE THERAPY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CULTURAL CARETAKER OF PUERTO RICAN CRAFTS
description: VEGA BAJA, P.R. THE Saez brothers, Juan and Andres, brushed off their baggy black trousers as they stood to greet a friend who drove from the city to see them.

title: No Headline
description: Hawks 7, Jets 5

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WATERMAN MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income of $2,495,548 from the settlement of litigation

title: Devils' Slump At 17
description: Mario Lessard achieved his first shutout of the season and was credited with an assist tonight as the Los Angeles Kings beat the New Jersey Devils, 3-0.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Prime Minister, Mr. Menachem Begin, may be harmed if the commission determines the following findings or conclusions: ''A. That the Prime Minister did not appropriately consider the role to be played by the Lebanese Forces during and due to the I.D.F.'s entry into West Beirut, and ignored the danger of acts of revenge and bloodshed by these forces against the population in the refugee camps.

title: U.S. IS URGED TO LET STRANDED POLES STAY
description: Polish-American groups have called on the Reagan Administration to grant another extension to Polish citizens who arrived in the United States before the imposition of martial law in Poland and face an expiration of their visas.

title: COUPLE BESET BY ILLNESS FINDS SOLACE IN NEEDIEST CASES CHARITY
description: When they met 67 years ago in Little Italy, he knew right away. ''You tell her I want to get married with her,'' he remembers saying to a mutual friend that evening. But she was wearing black in mourning for her mother and would not marry for two years. ''You tell her I will wait,'' he countered.

title: Technology; The Kerosene Heater Dispute
description: THE rising cost of fuel has spawned a huge new market for small, energy-efficient space heaters. But now, one of the most economical and popular kinds of these new products, the kerosene heater, has become the center of a dispute over product safety.

title: ORGAN RECITAL: PETER HURFORD
description: PETER HURFORD, best known for his recording of the complete Bach organ works, made his only New York appearance of the year Sunday afternoon at the Park Avenue Christian Church. The lovely chapel, which dates from 1911 and boasts Louis Tiffany stained-glass windows, has recently installed a three-manual organ designed by Walter Holtkamp and has begun to devote Sunday afternoons to concerts by some of the most interesting organists from the United States and abroad.

title: Chicago Tylenol Ban Lifted
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne today lifted the ban on the sale of all Tylenol products that she imposed citywide after seven persons in the Chicago area died two months ago from cyanidefilled capsules of the pain remedy. At a news conference, the Mayor said that new triple-sealed bottles of Tylenol would be on store shelves in about two weeks. The pills, manufactured by the McNeil Consumer Products Company, are protected by a glue flap on the box, a red plastic wrap around the bottle's neck and foil across the top of the bottle.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1982; The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, opposed advancing the July 1 tax cut but backed an increase in the gasoline tax to finance a highway repair program. He told Congress he welcomed the recent decline in interest rates but opposed any effort to ''force'' them lower. (Page A1.) Transportation officials, in a shift, now favor a straight five-cent rise in the gas tax to finance the Federal share of President Reagan's highway and transit aid program. (D1.)

title: THE LIGHTER SIDE OF ELECTRONICS
description: Ivan Berger is an editor and writer specializing in home electronics.

title: HERS
WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: South African Police Ordered to Be Humane
description: New instructions have been issued to the South African police on the treatment of political detainees, Law and Order Minister Louis Le Grange said today.

title: REGIONAL PARTY AIDE IS CATAPULTED TO NATIONAL PROMINENCE IN SOVIET
description: The Supreme Soviet, the nominal parliament, today approved the appointment of Geidar A. Aliyev as a First Deputy Prime Minister, two days after he had been made a full member of the ruling Politburo.

title: THE FREQUENT FLIER BONUSES
description: Chalk up 75,000 miles on United and take off first class to Hawaii for free. Fly 95,000 miles on T.W.A. and get tickets to Rome, plus a cut-rate room at Hilton and a discount on an Avis car. At American, you can even accumulate miles sailing on a cruise.

title: BRANIFF FAILS IN ITS BID TO FORM A JOINT VENTURE
description: An attempt by Braniff International to begin flying again and put about 1,500 of its employees back to work foundered yesterday when it could not reach a seniority agreement with its pilots that would have been acceptable to Pacific Southwest Airlines.

title: LEUKEMIA SOCIETY OFFERS PATIENTS A VARIETY OF AID
description: In 1944 the family and friends of Robert Roesler de Villiers, devastated by the death of the 16-year-old New York City youth from leukemia, committed themselves to a memorial that would aid other victims of the then mysterious form of cancer.

title: MONACO: BEREFT OF A PRINCESS AND DOWN ON ITS LUCK
description: This place is neither so small nor so rich that it can hide from bad times like a peacock ducking out of a storm.

title: OFFICIALS ASSAIL EASING OF U.S. HOSPITAL RULES
description: Public Health Service officials, including the Surgeon General of the United States, have expressed concern over the Reagan Administration's plan to repeal or relax many of the Federal regulations for hospitals.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Football Giants vs. Detroit Lions, at Pontiac, Mich. John Brunner, who coaches Detroit's backfield, finds himself opposing his son Scott, the Giants' quarterback.

title: ROBERT M'CORMACK
description: Robert McCormack, the chairman of the trustees of the Duke Endowment, died at his office at the organization's headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., on Nov. 8. He was 69 years old.

title: Careers and Babies
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The anger, hostility and frustration of the women described in ''Job vs. Baby: A Dilemma Persists'' (Nov. 18) is obviously based on emotion rather than fact. Women have rarely had the opportunity to ''have it all'' as they do today. Yet many claim to be dissatisfied and unhappy.

title: New Guinea Premier Is Ill
description: Prime Minister Michael Somare was hospitalized briefly today for what doctors described as exhaustion after he left a marathon session of Parliament complaining of chest pains and nausea. Mr. Somare was said to have been released this afternoon from Port Moresby General Hospital and sent home to rest at least five days.

title: Closings Today
description: Stock and commodity markets, banks and government offices in the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. The Federal Reserve Board will postpone its release of weekly money supply figures from Friday afternoon to Monday afternoon.

title: SAVIN BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RESEARCH TEAM FINDS FIRST ANTIDOTE FOR DIGITALIS OVERDOSES
description: A substance extracted from sheep's blood is the first antidote for potentially fatal overdoses of digitalis, a widely used heart medicine, researchers say.

title: MARINES SEE NEW FACES ON RETURN
description: A 1,600-man Marine Corps unit returned from Beirut today to a homecoming marked by cheers, tears, praise for a ''magnificent'' job and, for a few, a look at babies they had never seen.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income including a tax credit of $45,000 for the qr and 9 mos

title: BRAZIL ELECTIONS BRING VICTORIES FOR OPPOSITION
description: In the first three nationwide elections in Brazil in 17 years, opposition parties won an overwhelming majority of the vote and control of several major states.

title: TRANSITIONS IN BALLET WHEN DIRECTORS RETIRE
description: THE passage of the years has brought several ballet companies to the time when their directors or choreographers are at what in other professions might be termed the retirement age. Although most of these luminaries remain active, the problem of directorial succession is one that all companies will someday have to face.

title: Topics; Matters of Taste; Cold Turkey
description: There's no argument about how many minutes per pound to cook the turkey in Kikuya, a country inn in Shihoro, Japan. There, The Wall Street Journal reports, turkey is served raw.

title: MEMO BY KOCH CITES POSSIBILITY OF CITY LAYOFFS
description: Mayor Koch, in a memorandum sent yesterday to municipal agency heads ordering them to show how they could further cut their budgets for the 1984 fiscal year, said layoffs might eventually be necessary in some agencies.

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After loss of $13,969 from discontinued operations...C-Net income after income of $15,924 from discontinued operations

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BRIEFS
description: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc., a Houston company, said it intends to sell a least half of its producing oil and gas properties in an effort to avoid default on certain provisions of its loan agreements.

title: Former Coach Reacts
description: In the wake of the announcement that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had imposed stiff sanctions against Clemson for football recruiting violations, Coach Charley Pell of Florida said he was ''shocked and disappointed'' to learn that about 20 percent of the violations occurred in 1977 and 1978, when he was Clemson's coach. As a result of the N.C.A.A.'s findings, Pell said, he is asking that a faculty committee be created at Florida for a thorough check on his current program.

title: Judge Tells U.S. to Free 108 Cubans From Prison
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Government to start releasing 108 Cuban refugees who have been held in the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary since their exodus by boat from Cuba in 1980.

title: U.S. SAID TO GIVE UP ON A U.N. INQUIRY
description: A United States official said today that Washington planned to allow the United Nations inquiry into the use of chemical weapons in Asia to die because the investigators had made themselves powerless to reach judgments.

title: HOLDERS OF EL AL VOTE TO LIQUIDATE IT
description: The shareholders of El Al Israel Airlines voted in Jerusalem today to liquidate the strike-disrupted carrier, which has accumulated deficits of about $300 million.

title: TRICENTROL PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5 Arrests for Using Turnpike Tokens
description: Five people, including a stock-broker and a bond trader, were arrested at subway stations in the financial district during yesterday evening's rush hour for using Connecticut Turnpike tokens in subway turnstiles, according to Jeanne Edelson, a spokesman for the Transit Authority.

title: Ford Layoffs in Britain
description: The Ford Motor Company has laid off 5,000 workers at its Halewood plant because of a strike over manning, a company spokesman said today.

title: SHAMIR DISCLAIMS TESTIMONY ON CALL
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir testified today that it was not true that a fellow Cabinet member told him on Sept. 17 that Lebanese Christian Phalangists were killing civilians in two Palestinian refugee camps on Beirut's southern outskirts.

title: RECITAL: DIMITRI SGOUROS, 13, MAKES A DEBUT AS PIANIST
description: VERY few 13-year-old pianists are ready for a New York debut, let alone one at Avery Fisher Hall. But, in what must be a record of sorts, Dimitri Sgouros's Sunday evening recital, with the violinist Erick Friedman, lasted three hours and contained, among other works, two crushingly difficult warhorses - Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Paganini and Schumann's Symphonic Etudes.

title: Annenberg Grant Aids Channel 13's 'The Brain'
description: A grant of $1.3 million was awarded to Channel 13 (WNET-TV) yesterday by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting/Annenberg School of Communcications Project to enable the station's planned 10-part series, ''The Brain,'' to continue production on schedule.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Warner Case Is Undecided
description: The jury in the three-week fraud trial of Solomon Weiss, assistant treasurer of Warner Communications Inc., completed its second day of deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Wesleyan's Reward
description: An alumnus of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., has donated $34,000 to the school for rejecting an offer by CBS, which wanted to televise a football game against Tufts last month. CBS had offered Wesleyan and Tufts $15,000 each for permission to televise the game as substitute Sunday programming during the pro football strike.

title: THANKSGIVING DINNER AT THE AUTOMAT, '37: GOOD EATS CHEAP
description: In 1937, '38, it was a big deal, Thanksgiving dinner in mid-Manhattan, especially if you had fled from, say, Easton and the coal mining, and lived alone in a furnished room in the 50's, near Madison, for $8 a week, and landed a clerical job with Metropolitan Life for $18 a week, and were going to school nights to get a degree, and money was, to say the least, tight.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The latest 9 mos net was reduced by pre-opening expenses of new stores aggregating $587,196 compared to $276,845 during the yr-earlier period

title: Key Block Saves Game For the Nets
description: B uck Williams saw Michael Ray Richardson, and Richardson didn't see Williams. That, in essence, was the difference in what was a wild ending to the Nets' 110-103 triumph over the Golden State Warriors Tuesday night at the Oakland Coliseum.

title: SULLIVAN AND A 2D MAN GUILTY IN 2 L.I. MURDERS
description: Joseph John Sullivan, a 42-year-old Queens man, was convicted today with a co-defendant of the 1981 shooting-slashing murders in Selden, L.I., of a woman and a man and the attempted murder of another man.

title: London Inquiry Clears Queen's Ex-Bodyguard
description: Queen Elizabeth's former police bodyguard was cleared today of breaching Buckingham Palace security while he lived a secret double life as a homosexual having affairs with male prostitutes.

title: 38 Injured in Bus Accident
description: One bus smashed into the rear of another in the Loop today, injuring 38 people, none seriously, the authorities said. Two hospitals reported treating 38 persons involved in the rush hour accident, mainly for cuts, bruises and soreness. Michael Horowitz, a spokesman for the Chicago Transit Authority, said passengers reported hearing a popping noise shortly before the crash.

title: Bojangles Units
description: The Horn & Hardart Company said it planned to raise up to $50 million for the development of 85 new Bojangles restaurants by franchisees next year. The chain is a Horn & Hardart subsidiary. The company said the financing would be provided by the Franchise Finance Corporation, which has registered to sell limited partnerships in Bojangles units.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: APPETITE

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TEACHING A STONE TO TALK. Expedi- tions and Encounters. By Annie Dillard. 177 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Giants Face Lions In Holiday Game; Less Time to Prepare is Concern
description: The Giants played so erratically in losing to the Washington Redskins last Sunday that they might have benefited from an extra week to prepare for their next game.

title: Mikhail Georgadze, 70; Soviet President's Aide
description: Mikhail P. Georgadze, secretary of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet for 25 years, has died, the Government announced today. He was 70 years old.

title: BRIEFING
description: Baker's Revenge

title: LAKER'S LIQUIDATOR SUES
description: The liquidator for Laker Airlines Ltd. filed a suit today in United States District Court in Washington, charging several airlines and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation with conspiracy to drive Sir Freddie Laker out of business.

title: ONCE-UPON-A-TIME PRICES AT SEARS
description: Read it and weep for times long gone: A balloon-tire Elgin bicycle for $30.95. A .22-caliber Springfield rifle for $4.25. An all-cotton man's shirt for $1.79. Women's leather shoes for $1.98 a pair. An 18-karat wedding ring with three small diamonds for $5.98. A five-pound box of candy for 98 cents.

title: CUOMO REMARK DRAWS SOME FIRE FROM ANDERSON
description: The majority leader of the New York State Senate yesterday accused Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo of making ''completely indefensible'' statements about the state's fiscal problems and misrepresenting the views of Republicans in the Senate.

title: COUNTERCHARGES IN JUDGE'S DEATH
description: Charles V. Harrelson emphatically denied today that he murdered Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. and charged that the prosecution knew he was not guilty.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: Shr earnings reflect 4 percent stock divds distribution in Sept 1981 and Sept 1982

title: An Economic Holiday
description: Alone among its holidays, Thanksgiving is America's celebration of the material side of life. The day inspires awe of nature and nature's God, for they have allowed the people to bring in a harvest. Over the three and a half centuries since the holiday was first celebrated in a tiny hunting and agricultural settlement, the nation has grown until its harvests are almost too large and various to tally. The settlement has become a nation, in a world so interdependent that its residents feel harvest failures 10,000 miles away.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New England Corp. filed an offering of 700,000 depositary preferred shares, 1982 series, through Goldman, Sachs.

title: AWARD TURNS UP 'JOURNALISTIC MISDEMEANOR'
description: Several passages from a prize-winning sports article in The Miami News were copied without attribution from a book on the same subject, according to a report in this month's issue of the journal of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
MATTERS OF TASTE; Cross Words
description: Those whom the gods disfavor, they name highways after. Who can iden-tify Major Deegan, he of the expressway? Or Wilbur Cross, whose name adorns a stretch of parkway in Connecticut succeeding the other one bearing the name of Merritt (Joe? Jack? George?).

title: NETS SQUANDER LEAD AND FALL TO CLIPPERS
description: The Nets' two-game winning streak ended tonight when they were defeated by the San Diego Clippers, 114-109, at the Sports Arena.

title: Aims of the Trade Forum
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was formed in 1948 in an effort to encourage international trade. A major purpose was to reduce tariffs and other barriers to trade, but of equal importance was to assure all trading nations equal access to one another's markets.

title: TV: MOLLY PICON STARS IN VIGNETTE ABOUT SENILITY
description: THERE is one big reason for watching the little film that is on WNBC-TV tonight at 7:30. ''Grandma Didn't Wave Back'' is about an 11-year-old girl and her reactions to the fact that her treasured grandmother is sliding into senility. The girl, Debbie, is nicely played by Lara Berk, who currently is appearing as Tessie in the film version of ''Annie.'' But the extra and special ingredient is Molly Picon in the role of the grandmother.

title: CHICAGO SEES 2 DECADES OF ABAKANOWIZ WORKS
description: CHICAGO ''EMBRYOLOGY,'' by the Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz, is an arrangement of 800 rounded forms, some bigger than a body, some smaller than a fist. At a distance, they appear as solid as stones, but up close they reveal an unexpected, vulnerable softness, a tangle of string beneath a thin membrane of mesh or burlap.

title: THE ULTIMATE SETTLEMENT
description: The charge was made in this space two months ago that the Reagan Administration was in cahoots with Shimon Peres, the opposition party leader in Israel, to promote a West Bank giveaway and to undermine Menachem Begin's Government.

title: RESORT & URBAN TIMESHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-There are no comparable figures because the company was in a development stage; the results of Sweetwater are included in the company's financial statements since July 1,s common shrs by Resort & Urban Timeshares

title: Iranians Say 900 Iraqis Were Killed
description: Iran reported today that 900 Iraqis were killed in two battles Tuesday in the Missan sector of the border battlefront. Iraq had earlier reported that 2,262 Iranians were killed in the area in fighting Monday night and Tuesday.

title: 50th Victory For Gelding
description: Racing yesterday for the 227th time in his career, the 13-year-old white gelding Port Conway Lane won for the 50th time and was extolled by his trainer as ''a remarkable old fellow.''

title: Excitement High for U.S.-French Final
description: As Yannick Noah walked onto the red clay court to begin the morning workout with Henri Leconte today, hundreds of French schoolchildren shrieked and whistled from their high-level seats in the Palais des Sports. Noah smiled and raised his arms.

title: A CITY WHERE MAN AND NATURE COEXIST
description: One can hardly see this city for the trees. Columbia, an experimental ''new town'' started in the 1960's, was laid out to harmonize with the environment and serve as a model for an urban ecology where nature and humanity are not estranged.

title: Japanese Smuggling Network Said to Be Spreading to Coast
description: A Japanese organized crime network may be establishing itself in Hawaii and California to distribute drugs, Attorney General William French Smith said today.

title: BUYING CANDLES: WHAT AND WHERE
description: NOTHING blots out the gentle glow of candlelight more effectively than sooty smoke, dripping wax and ill-fitted tapers that teeter precariously over the table linen. Fortunately, ways to avoid such problems are available in New York stores that feature fine and unusual candles and accessories. Here is a sampling.

title: THE PLEASURES OF A VISIT TO THE SOVIET UNION
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: JUDY VAN DER VEER

title: Laid-Off G.M. Workers To Receive $300 Each
description: About 100,000 workers who had been laid off by the General Motors Corporation are to recieve special payments of $300 in time for Christmas as a result of an agreement between the company and the United Automobile Workers.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ISLAND TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TO THE HOME SECTION
description: I am a former teacher, presently a housewife, the mother of a 9-month-old baby. On reading the career woman's remark (''Job vs. Baby: The Dilemma Persists'') that ''there just might be - dare I say it? - something more breathtaking, more awe-inspiring and wonderful than working your tail off seven days a week,'' I chortled. JAN DAWSON-HEMPEL Princeton, N.J.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHBRED BREEDERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Uncertainty On Qadaffi Visit

title: ON WARNING POSTERITY ABOUT A NUCLEAR TOMB
description: The Federal Government is not sure where it is going to bury all of the highly radioactive nuclear waste that is piling up around the country. But it has received some recommendations about how to mark the grave so that anyone stumbling upon it 10,000 years from now will know there is danger below.

title: Norwalk Vandals Break Windshields
description: Vandals shot out or cracked the windshields of about 80 cars parked in driveways in a wide area throughout Norwalk early this morning, the police reported.

title: Gloria Swanson Gives Memorabilia to School
description: The Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas announced Tuesday that it had acquired 100,000 items of memorabilia from Gloria Swanson.

title: U.S. Envoy Not Worried About Immigration Bill
description: The United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, said today that he did not share the ''dire expectations'' of some Mexicans about the repercussions in Mexico of adoption of a comprehensive immigration bill ending in Congress.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PHILHARMONIC: LOPEZ-COBOS CONDUCTS PREMIERE
description: BARRELED novelty gave last night's concert by the New York Philharmonic more than the usual amount of interest, at least in prospect. The Spanish conductor Jesus Lopez-Cobos, beginning his first engagement with the orchestra, offered the world premiere of a piece by Leonardo Balada, who was born in Barcelona and now lives in Pittsburgh. Later, Youri Egorov came on for his Philharmonic debut, as piano soloist in Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini.'' In fact, there was so much new about the program that one went away wondering why it all did not seem fresher.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Warner and Hasbro In Sale Agreement
description: Warner Communications said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell certain assets of its Knickerbocker Toy unit to Hasbro Industries in a transaction that would result in Warner's acquiring 40 percent of Hasbro's common stock.

title: No Headline
description: TRIPUCKA HURT AS PISTONS LOSE

title: JAZZ: SAM BURTIS BAND
description: SAM BURTIS is a trombonist who makes his living in New York's recording studios and who has played in a couple of short-lived big jazz bands. Undaunted, he organized a big band of his own.

title: DREW NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $838,000 for the qr and $1,002,000 forthe yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $62,000 for the qr and $21,000 for the yr and extraordinary tax credits of $713,000 for the qr and $933,000 for the yr

title: GRADY NUTT, TV HUMORIST DIES WITH 2 OTHERS IN PLANE CRASH
description: The Rev. Grady Nutt, a Baptist minister and humorist who appeared regularly on ''Hee Haw'' on syndicated television, was killed last night in a plane crash, the police reported.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $78,000

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Staying Close to Home, Gastronomically

title: BALLET: TWO BALANCHINE MASTERPIECES
description: HOW well the New York City Ballet is dancing these days was made clear by recent performances at the New York State Theater that included two masterpieces by George Balanchine: ''Serenade,'' to Tchaikovsky, and ''Divertimento No. 15,'' to Mozart.

title: Texan's Temptation
description: Eric Dickerson, the star tailback at Southern Methodist, said that recruiters made ''all kinds'' of illicit offers to him when he was a high school player in Sealy, Tex.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.3 million for the latest first qr and $872,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: MITTERRAND VISITING MUBARAK
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived in Egypt today for three days of talks with President Hosni Mubarak aimed at strengthening the ''special relationship'' between the two countries.

title: Jewelry Company Is Robbed Again
description: A Manhattan jewelry manufacturer that had lost an estimated $2.5 million worth of gold chains in a holdup by two gunmen on July 6 suffered another major loss Tuesday night when burglars broke into its plant at 227 West 29th Street and escaped with gold chains valued by the company's owners at over $1 million, the police said.

title: BACKS RISE ON GAS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today opposed acceleration of the July 1 tax cut, now under consideration by the White House, but endorsed an increase in the gasoline tax to finance a highway repair program.

title: JAPANESE PURSUE M.T.A. BUS ORDERS
description: Hino Motors Ltd. of Japan has taken a $100,000 option to buy a factory in upstate New York's Greene County, where it says it is prepared to assemble hundreds of buses for New York City, Governor Carey's office announced yesterday.

title: WHEN FORKS CLASHED
description: As grandfather lifted his long carving knife before he cut the first slice of turkey, we could see hanging on the wall the saber he had carried as a cavalryman in the Civil War. It was the right ornament for Thanksgiving, which was not only a holiday but something of a battle in which the participants groaned as well as the loaded table.

title: BOSTON BANK CHIEF YIELDS POST
description: Richard D. Hill, New England's most influential banker, announced yesterday that he will step down Jan. 1 as chairman and chief executive officer of the First National Boston Corporation, holding company for the nation's 17th-largest bank.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Manville to Sell U.S. Pipeline Unit
description: The Manville Corporation, which has been operating under the protection of Federal bankruptcy laws since August, said its Johns-Manville Corporation unit had agreed to sell its United States pipeline operations.

title: STANDARD METALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IT'S ALREADY A SPECIAL SEASON
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. T welve days ago, during the traditional chapel service that the Iona College basketball team observes before an exhibition game, Ray Horton had something to say.

title: Jokes Are a Part of Randy Cobb's Style
description: The one-liners came steadily in the modest condominium apartment where Randall (Tex) Cobb, the comic challenger, has been staying before Friday night's fight with Larry Holmes at the Astrodome.

title: THRIFT UNIT DEPOSITS OFF $3.5 BILLION IN OCTOBER
description: Americans withdrew $3.5 billion more than they deposited in savings and loan associations in October as depositors took out some of the money invested in maturing ''All Savers'' certificates, the Government said today.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Yonkers Upsets Gorton
description: Yonkers High School had won only two games going into yesterday's contest with undefeated Gorton, but records were not a factor as Coach Ron Santavicca's Bulldogs provided an upset, surprising the Wolves, 16-13, behind a pair of third-quarter touchdowns.

title: ART: STUNNING SCULPTURE FROM JAPAN'S BUDDHISM
description: ANKOKU DOJI was an aide to the kings of Hell, and Mr. Nice Guy he wasn't. Sporting a tiny hat with propellerlike projections, holding a brush and a plank to take notes, his face screwed up in a knowing scowl, he served as a clerk of the court where the kings tried each sinner for his misdeeds on earth. A dramatic, larger-than-life-size image of this most uncelestial deity, carved of Japanese cypress in the 13th century, is one of the many stunning surprises in ''Japanese Buddhist Sculpture: A.D. 600-1300,'' a marvelous exhibition at the Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street (through Jan. 16).

title: Pepsico Fills Two Jobs
description: Pepsico Inc. said it was naming Darell Agee, 52 years old, and Oscar Rojas, 44, to replace two executives who were dismissed recently from the company's bottling operations in the Philippines and Mexico.

title: Stolen Rare Coins Turn Up in Jersey
description: More than $500,000 in gold and silver coins have been recovered from a collection of rare coins worth $1 million that was stolen from a dealer in a New York hotel, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Foundry Shut By Wheland
description: Wheland Foundry, the nation's largest independent automotive foundry, has shut one of its two Chattanooga plants and laid off 180 employees.

title: A WALK AROUND BATTERY AS THE SUN IS SETTING
description: ''Did not get out till near 6 o'clock,'' wrote George Templeton Strong, the diarist and indefatigable explorer of New York streets, on May 14, 1838. ''However, the Battery is very pleasant at that hour.'' The park and waterfront promenade that Strong loved have gone through many changes. Their history will be explored by the Urban Park Rangers in a free, autumn sunset walk through the Battery tomorrow.

title: Giants-Lions Summary
description: Scoring FIRST QUARTER

title: GREECE SHOWS ANTI-U.S. BIAS WITHOUT ZEST
description: As United States military personnel enter the Hellenikon Air Base near here, they pass by huge banners at the entrance reading, ''Yankees Go Home.''

title: Turnout for Games Lags, New Delhi Paper Says
description: More than 1,000 expected American and European tourists have failed to arrive for the Asian Games, leaving expensive hotels with hundreds of empty rooms, a news report said today.

title: A Loud Vote for Hrbek
description: Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Minnesota Twins, says that the selection of Cal Ripken Jr. over the Twins' Kent Hrbek as the American League rookie of the year was ''an out-and-out travesty.'' Hrbek was considered a shoo-in for the award at midseason but finished second in the voting this week after Ripken, Baltimore's shortstop, had recovered from a poor start to finish the season with 93 runs batted in and a .264 batting average.

title: Tests for Tripucka
description: An examination yesterday morning confirmed that Kelly Tripucka had strained the medial collateral ligament of his right knee, but it will not be known until further tests this weekend how long he will be sidelined. Tripucka was injured Wednesday night in a game against the Kansas City Kings, after which a spokesman for the Pistons said that the high-scoring forward might be out for six to eight weeks. But Dr. Gerald O'Connor, the team physician, said yesterday that additional tests were necessary to gauge the damage.

title: Kings Win, 88-79, For Fifth Straight
description: Eddie Johnson, a Kansas City forward, scored 10 of his game-high 19 points in the third quarter tonight and led the Kansas City Kings to an 88-79 victory over the Houston Rockets.

title: FOUR IN CHICAGO ARE ACCUSED IN SERIES OF SLASHINGS
description: In the past month, four suspects have been arrested in connection with a series of murders and abductions in which women were raped and mutilated.

title: 'Dangerous' Elephant To Get Bigger Quarters
description: Cindy, an elephant with a reputation as a dangerous animal after staying 17 years alone in cramped quarters, will be able to roam free, play in the dirt and take a dip in a pool at a new home here in the San Diego Wild Animal Park.

title: WORLD OIL GLUT CRAMPS NIGERIA'S DEVELOPMENT
description: After years of unfettered spending, Nigeria's leaders are seeking to lower the expectations of their citizens, and have warned that the economic future can no longer be computed on high oil production levels or high oil prices.

title: TAYLOR NOT FOOLED THIS TIME
description: Fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me. Lawrence Taylor, fooled once this season, vowed he would not be fooled again if the same situation happened. The situation happened yesterday, and Taylor was not fooled.

title: McEnroe-Noah to Open in Cup
description: After today's Davis Cup draw paired Yannick Noah and John McEnroe in Friday's opening singles match of the France-United States final, Noah clearly emerged with the burden of French hopes in the three-day series.

title: Eagleton to Offer Amendment For a Foreign-Born President
description: Because of his admiration for the investment banker Felix G. Rohatyn, who was born in Austria, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton said today that he would propose a constitutional amendment allowing naturalized citizens to be President.

title: Arrest of Ian Smith Is Urged On Zimbabwe's Radio and TV
description: The Government-owned radio and television have called on the Government to jail Ian D. Smith, Prime Minister when the country was called Rhodesia, after a report that he denounced Zimbabwe on a recent visit to the United States.

title: Bluegrass Green
description: Money from abroad has been pouring into the horse country of Kentucky for several years. The latest description of the situation is this: ''The whole scene has changed.''

title: NEWCOMERS FIND CAPITAL ENRICHING
description: When Dr. and Mrs. Richard Haas, a German couple with homes in London, Paris and Zurich, were unable to extend their reservation at the Four Seasons Hotel here, they walked across the street to the Westbridge and purchased a $300,000 condominium apartment. Now they have their own pad in Washington.

title: Charlotte Auger Strouse,79; A Collector of Rare Books
description: Mrs. Charlotte Auger Strouse, a rare-book collector and wife of Norman H. Strouse, retired president and board chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company, died Wednesday after a long illness in St. Helena, Calif. She was 79 years old.

title: Real Estate; PRESERVATION OF AMBIANCE IN MANHATTAN
description: THE man who built the new condominium called the Viscaya on East 71st Street thinks there will never be another building like it on the Upper East Side, and it is hard to argue with him.

title: Oldest Inmate in the Nation Dies of Cancer at Age of 106
description: John Davis, 106 years old, who was believed the oldest prison inmate in the nation, died of cancer at a prison hospital, officials said today.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Nine New York Times critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment on this long holiday weekend. It is generally a good idea to telephone ahead just to make sure that everything is on schedule.

title: BIDDING LAW IS SAID TO COST CITY MILLIONS
description: A state law on construction bidding is costing New York City $40 million to $70 million a year in unnecessary building costs, according to city officials and some independent experts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Naming Winter's Nemeses, Including Irving

title: CHINA SAYS IT AWAITS CONCESSIONS FROM THE NEW SOVIET LEADERSHIP
description: Having extended condolences to the Soviet Union on the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, China is making clear that it expects his successors to come up with the concessions that will open the way to more normal relations.

title: Help for Athletes
description: So you want to major in engineering, play hockey and attend a small college in the Northeast. Where do you go? Who's the athletic director? What's his telephone number? How good is the team? What is an athletic scholarship worth?

title: Frank King, Banker Who Led 11-State Group, Is Dead at 85
description: Frank King, who rose from a small town bank examiner to become chairman of an 11-state banking corporation, died Tuesday. He was 85 years old.

title: Ireland's Election Treadmill
description: Voting is a good thing, but Ireland is getting too much of it. Wednesday's election was the third in 18 months, leaving the country winded. Also relevant was an October vote in British-ruled Northern Ireland for a new assembly, with results that confirmed the province's bitter divisions. Impending is a British general election, involving among other things a contest for 17 House of Commons seats in Northern Ireland.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IRAQIS TRY TO IGNORE WAR
description: It was 8 in the morning and the childern were going to school. By twos and threes they trudged across bare fields to the neat, white schoolhouses. Not an unusal sight in the West. But here in Iraq it was a testament to the introduction of universal education by President Saddam Hussein - a program for which he will be remembered long after the ubiquitous posters bearing his face are torn down and replaced by those bearing another visage.

title: Leslie Allen Beats Hana Mandlikova
description: Leslie Allen of the United States upset fifth-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, and sixthseeded Barbara Potter of the United States was defeated today in the third round of the New South Wales Open women's tennis tournament.

title: Playing It Again, For High Stakes
description: If you have the feeling that Colgate is always playing Boston University these days in football, you may be right. They played a regularly scheduled game last Saturday, with Colgate winning, 22-21.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE first guests got on at Jamaica, most of the others at Merrick, L .I., and by the time the Montauk-bound train arrived at Babylon and T ed and Laura Brickman came aboard, more than 100 friends and r elatives were ready to pop out of the four rented parlor cars and s hout ''Surprise! Happy Birthday!''

title: Couple Seek to Adopt Orphan After Surgery
description: Robert and Diane Ulchak were looking forward today to spending many more Thanksgiving Days with Anita Asto, the 3-year-old Peruvian orphan they brought to this country for heart surgery and hope to adopt.

title: Turkey City Postmark Is in Demand Again
description: Thanksgiving is the busiest time of the year for Naomi Sheesley, the postmaster in this tiny western Pennsylvania town 60 miles northeast of Pittsburgh.

title: WEICKER WILL 'TRY TO REBUILD' CONNECTICUT G.O.P.
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., ending what he called ''six years of exile'' from the Republican organization in Connecticut, says he is moving toward a more active role in state party affairs.

title: GIANTS WIN FIRST ON INTERCEPTION
description: When the Giants lost to the Washington Redskins last Sunday in their first game after the eight-week strike of National Football League players, Lawrence Taylor was almost invisible.

title: DR. ARTHUR FOXE, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Arthur Norman Foxe, a psychiatrist and author of books and articles on subjects ranging from neurology to art, died on Nov. 19. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LONG SHOT BY BOSSY GIVES ISLANDERS TIE
description: With 3 minutes 43 seconds left in the game tonight, Mike Bossy of the Islanders scored on a wobbly 65-foot shot to tie the Bruins, 1-1, in Boston Garden.

title: Wyeth work leads art sale.
description: ANDREW WYETH'S ''Jacklight,'' painted in 1980, is the star of a sale of American art works of the 19th and 20th centuries at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. Painted in the orchard behind the home of his father, the illustrator N.C. Wyeth, in Chadds Ford, Pa., this large tempera on panel depicting a deer by a tree, is described by Sotheby's as the most important work by Andrew Wyeth ever to appear at auction. It is expected to sell for as much as $600,000.

title: 700,000 E.P.A. FILES SUBPOENAED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: A House committee, angered at the Environmental Protection Agency's failure to aid its inquiry into the handling of hazardous waste sites, has subpoenaed the agency to turn over more than 700,000 files on 160 sites by Dec. 2.

title: NO PRICE INCREASE SEEN ON MOST MEAT
description: There will be good news for consumers of beef and broiling chickens in the next four months. Large supplies of both will be arriving on local meat counters at prices expected to be the same as those last year or lower.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DUPREE EARNS A LETTER, THE I
description: It has taken Marcus Dupree, the 228-pound freshman tailback, barely two months to run the University of Oklahoma out of a football recession.

title: A 60-YEAR RIVALRY COMES TO AN END
description: This year's Putnam-Killingly high school football game was like many in the last 60 years: close, hard-fought and, ultimately, heartbreaking.

title: DECODING NUCLEAR JARGON
description: President Reagan and First Secretary Andropov have made parallel proclamations of continued interest in arms control, and parallel pledges in effect to continue the arms race. Each was trying simultaneously to appease a frightened world and to satisfy his own military-industrial complex.

title: No Headline
description: "Excommunication' of Jews Challenged by Rabbis' Group

title: Cordero's Appeal Set
description: Angel Cordero's appeal of a seven-day suspension for careless riding has been scheduled for next Wednesday before the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. Cordero, who is locked in a battle with Laffit Pincay Jr. for the national riding title, has said he will appeal in the courts if he is rebuffed by the board.

title: THEATER: RICHARD III AT THE RIVERSIDE
description: IN its six seasons, the Riverside Shakespeare Company has moved from itinerant performing in city parks to a year-round professional Shakespearean theater in a newly renovated home in the West Park Presbyterian Church. With increased recognition and financial support has come a gradual improvement in performance.

title: JOHN D. BERGAMINI
description: John D. Bergamini, an author and historian, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness.

title: HOW TO TURN MOZAMBIQUE TOWARD MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Seeks Massive Loan
description: Brazil is seeking to raise $2 billion to $3 billion in a loan from international banks to help service its foreign debt of about $85 billion, foreign banking sources said today.

title: Addendum
description: * Effective January, Restaurant Design magazine is changing its name to Restaurant and Hotel Design, and its frequency from quarterly to six times a year.

title: U.S. Prepares for Klan Rally
description: Attorney General William French Smith said Wednesday that he had asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation for information to help the authorities plan for a Ku Klux Klan demonstration and counterdemonstrations Saturday in the nation's capital. Under guidelines in effect since 1976, Mr. Smith said the F.B.I. was authorized to gather information to make sure there will be orderly conduct of demonstrations involving Federal property. He said the information would help the United States Attorney's Office, the United States Park Police and the Capitol Police in their planning.

title: Penn State Trying to Avoid Pitt Obstacle
description: For the second time in four years, Penn State enters its regular-season finale against Pitt with the chance to win the final No.1 ranking in the nation. With victories in Friday's annual intrastate clash at Beaver Stadium and then over Georgia in the Sugar Bowl on Jan.1, Penn State could be selected as the No.1 team for 1982. The Nittany Lions have never been No.1 in the final polls, taken after the bowl games.

title: GRANGER, MO., WELCOMES BACK AN EX-FUGITIVE
description: A convicted killer who won the hearts of the people of this hamlet while he was hiding from th e prison authorities four years ago has been reunited with the friends who pleaded, ''Let Joe come home.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Cabaret

title:
RELIEVE HUNGER WITH 1;
During a holiday season in which we celebrate and are given to plenty, the attention of New Yorkers should be drawn to a problem that afflicts too many and of which too few are aware.
description: The problem is hunger. Its magnitude is shocking and tragic. The misery and suffering is all the more deplorable because so much of it could be relieved with merely a 1 percent solution that would cost the Federal Government a relatively small $22 million in addition to a program that already costs the taxpayers $2.2 billion a year.

title: CARDINALS DISCUSS TIE TO BANK
description: The Sacred College of Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church held discussions this morning on the links between the Vatican's bank and Italy's largest private bank, which collapsed last summer. Pope John Paul II attended the session.

title: BID FOR COALITION CABINET EXPECTED
description: Former Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald claimed victory early today in the Irish election and said an attempt to help settle the ''desperate tragedy of Northern Ireland'' would be one of the highest priorities of the new government that he would try to form next month.

title: REDMAN A TENOR SAX PLAYER WHO BLOOMED LATE IN LIFE
description: FOR a ''late bloomer,'' as he describes himself, the tenor saxophonist Dewey Redman hasn't done too badly. He was an integral member of groups led by the alto saxophonist Ornette Coleman and the pianist Keith Jarrett in the late 1960's and early 70's - two of thate period's finest bands - and in 1977 he was a founder of Old and New Dreams, ''Ornette's band without Ornette,'' as Mr. Redman calls it.

title: Dollar Declines Abroad While Gold Is Mixed
description: The dollar declined in slow trading today against all major currencies except the British pound, which fell close to an all-time low. Gold prices were mixed.

title: Kenyan Betters Record in Race
description: Gabriel Kamau of Kenya set a course record of 23 minutes 25.2 seconds in the Prospect Park Turkey Trot 5-mile run yesterday as a preparation for The Athletics Congress's national cross-country championship on Sunday.

title: Holiday Note
description: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Markets and banks will be open today as usual. The Federal Reserve Board will postpone its release of weekly money supply figures from this afternoon to Monday afternoon.

title: Mexico Oil Deflected for Debt
description: Mexico is setting aside about 200,000 barrels a day of crude oil in the near future to repay three or four short-term loan commitments, according to Gilberto Escobedo, trade director of the Mexican oil monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex).

title: Judge Seeks Aspirin Accord
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Government and a group financed by the aspirin industry to settle a dispute over a Federal warning linking aspirin to Reye's syndrome, a rare but often fatal childhood disease. Judge David Nelson told attorneys for the Committee on the Care of Children and for Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to report to him Monday. The committee had filed suit seeking a restraining order to halt the department's warning about a link between Reye's syndrome and the use of aspirin for chicken pox or influenza.

title: Economic Scene; The Rebound: So Very Slow
description: WHAT is delaying the recovery? The latest piece of worrisome news was the 4.9 percent drop in orders for durable goods in October, the biggest decline in a year. And there are persistent anxieties over the heavy overhang of manufacturing and trade inventories, weak sales and rising unemployment.

title: RETAILERS OF WOMEN'S APPAREL UNEASY AS PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: Markdowns on women's apparel at leading department stores across the country are exceeding those for any Christmas season in the recent past. Retailers are expressing concern about what the trend bodes for merchandising, and some even suggest it could change the face of fashion retailing.

title: A Top Officer Resigns At Dean Witter Unit
description: Gary Klesch, 36, has resigned as president of Dean Witter Reynolds Overseas Ltd., London. He will be replaced temporarily by John Pelling, 55, who is now executive vice president and director of Dean Witter Reynolds in the United States.

title: Salvadoran Indicted In Death of U.S. Nuns
description: A former national guardsman who confessed to participating in the slayings of four American churchwomen was formally charged with murder today. He will stand trial with four other men.

title: Advertising; Animated Messages At Airports
description: OF-HOME advertising -loosely called outdoor advertising - was already an established art form when the ancient Persian kings ordered messages carved on the walls of their splendid capital, Persepolis.

title: Caesars Net Down
description: Net income of Caesars World in its first fiscal quarter, ended Oct.31, dropped to $379,000, or 2 cents a share, from $12.4 million, or 46 cents, the year before. The hotel and casino operator said poorer results at its Nevada operations were the primary cause of the drop. Revenues tumbled to $145.4 million, from $166.4 million.

title: Bodyguard Is Seized In Ghanaian Plot
description: An attempted coup against the Ghanaian leader, Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, may have been mounted by soldiers loyal to a member of his ruling council, The Guardian reported today from Accra.

title: 10-0 Bergen Catholic Romps
description: Bergen Catholic's unbeaten team dominated rival Don Bosco Prep of Ramsey, 33-0, yesterday for its 10th success before 3,500 in Ramsey. Mike Morgan, coming off the injured list, scored twice on short runs and raised his season point total to 156 to remain the state's leading scorer. He leads Craig Heyward of Passaic, who scored 13 points yesterday against Montclair, by 2 points. Bergen Catholic will meet Immaculata of Somerville Dec. 4 in the North Jersey, Parochial A final.

title: 3 Die in Spanish Train Crash
description: Three people were killed and 13 were injured today when a passenger train hit a stationary freight train about 50 miles southeast of Bilbao, national railroad officials said. Officials said they did not know why the freight train was waiting on the track or why the passenger train, on its way from Bilbao to Burgos, was not warned.

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDES STUDY PLAN TO TAX JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: The Reagan Administration, searching for ways to deal with continuing high unemployment, is studying such proposals as taxing unemployment benefits and lowering the minimum wage for teen-agers for the summer.

title: Auto Layoffs Reach a Record
description: The number of American auto workers on indefinite layoff rose this week to a record 257,627, according to industry reports.

title: ELECTIONS: THE OTHER SIDE OF 'WHAT IF'
description: To the Editor:

title: Montclair's Rally Surprises Passaic
description: More than 10,000 hometown fans were provided with an exciting show as James Overby scored two touchdowns in the fourth period and Ben Brennan booted the extra points to provide Montclair with a 14-13 victory over formidable Passaic yesterday in Montclair. It was the first Thanksgiving Day game between the teams.

title: ART: ILLUMINATED BOOKS, FRANCE'S LAST AND BEST
description: EVEN by the standards of the Pierpont Morgan Library, which rarely or never puts on an ad hoc assemblage for the sake of filling the space, very high claims can be made for ''The Last Flowering: French Painting in Manuscripts, 1420-1530.''

title: A LEGACY OF MILAN'S ARCHITECTS
description: THERE is something coy about a title like ''Precursors of Post-Modernism,'' the Architectural League of New York exhibition that opened last week, and the coyness is no accident. Can something be a precursor of a follower, without actually being the thing that is followed?

title: TASMANIANS WEARY OF BEING THE BUTT OF JOKES
description: This island state of Australia is tired of being laughed at. Its people get defensive and angry whenever it is made the butt of such jokes as, ''How many Tasmanians does it take to screw in a light bulb?''

title: Garden City Falls To W. Hempstead
description: Coach Doc Dougherty of Garden City had his team gather around him for a brief post-game speech. ''You're still champs,'' he said. ''Nothing always goes the way you like it.''

title: WHAT THE BRETHREN ATE
description: This is the holiday for American cooking, and that's reason enough for thanks. It's also a good time of year to think about the American past, since Thanksgiving is the only truly American holiday (all nations have their independence and memorial days), one rooted solidly in the pioneer tradition.

title: Lindt Plans Print Ads
description: Lindt chocolates of Zurich will start its first American campaign next month in print ads scheduled for The New Yorker, Town & Country and Gourmet magazines. The ad headline reads ''Lindt and the seductions of chocolate,'' and copy chronicles the history of chocolate. The advertising agency behind the print campaign is Waring & LaRosa, the agency for Grand Specialties, the importer of Lindt chocolates.

title: COAST JOBS DISAPPEAR THROUGH 'GATEWAY TO PACIFIC'
description: Joe Pargaz pounded his fist on the bar at Lina's, a cafe near the Ford Motor Company plant here where he has worked for 17 years. He groped for words to express the anger and frustration that he felt over Ford's announcement that it would close the plant next spring.

title: ART: KNOT-THEME SCULPTURES BY LYNDA BENGLIS
description: LYNDA BENGLIS'S new sculptures, on view at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, though called ''Idols'' in Greek, are but more variations on the knot theme that has occupied the artist on and off for the last decade. They measure roughly two to three-and-ahalf feet across and are made of bronze wire mesh that has been gessoed and sprayed with a metal solution - bronze, aluminum or zinc or combinations thereof.

title: Mubarak Asks P.L.O.  To Recognize Israel
description: President Hosni Mubarak urged the Palestine Liberation Organization today to recognize Israel - a move that would meet a precondition the United States has put on including the P.L.O. in Middle East peace talks.

title: Murdoch Setback in Boston
description: The negotiating committee for the pressmen's union at The Boston Herald American has rejected a proposal from representatives of the publisher Rupert Murdoch, prospective buyer of the Hearst Corporation's financially troubled tabloid.

title: Market Place; Tough Going For Steel
description: HOW weak is the steel industry? A new report from Oppenheimer & Company says that even a favorable labor settlement and complete exclusion of imports would not restore its profitability.

title: STAGE: 'IT'S ONLY A PALY,' AN IN-JOKE ABOUT THEATER
description: IN its previous incarnation under another title (''Broadway, Broadway''), Terrence McNally's comedy ''It's Only a Play'' folded during its pre-Broadway tryout in Philadelphia in 1978. Seeing this play now, in a revamped version staged by the Manhattan Punch Line, one can guess what the trouble was. ''It's Only a Play'' is an uncompromising in-joke about current personalities and fashions in the Broadway theater. Like so much of Mr. McNally's work (''The Ritz,'' ''Bad Habits''), it is often very funny - if you know the territory. Philadelphians and other nontheater buffs are likely to laugh only if they're provided with a glossary at the door. Those who don't need that glossary are in for a treat.

title: ISRAEL ELABORATES ON WARNING BY MASSACRE COMMISSION
description: A spokesman for the commission investigating the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut said today that the warnings issued Wednesday to nine senior Israeli officials did not constitute ''interim findings, interim results.''

title: GATT FRUSTRATES U.S. SO FAR
description: Common Market representatives held firm today on their refusal to consider phasing out agricultural export subsidies, one of the major demands of the United States at a world trade conference here.

title: STRESSES NEED TO IMPROVE U.S. TIES
description: Yasuhiro Nakasone was elected Japan's 71st Prime Minister today, succeeding Zenko Suzuki, who resigned in mid-October.

title: Bridge: Cohen and Bergen Retain Lead in Blue Ribbon Pairs
description: A partnership from New York continued to lead the blue ribbon pair championship as it went into the two final sessions at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.

title: NEW YORK CITY ADDICTS FROM OUT OF TOWN
description: Most of them wouldn't dream of living in New York. Visiting, however, is quite another matter. Most of us know a few people out in that vast patch of America west of the Hudson and east of the Pacific who are of that opinion, many of whom do manage to visit the city occasionally. But there also exists a somewhat distinctive breed of out-of-towner who does more than drop in on the city. For visitors such as these the city is a repository of special and unique pleasures that demands periodic visits, and when they come here they dive into the city, soak it up, taste it, feel it wash around them. Some of them are revitalized by its pace and its energy. And then they go home.

title: No Headline
description: A&M LOSES, 53-16, TO TEXAS IN FINALE

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1982; The Economy
description: A recovery in housing construction has begun and will continue into 1983, say industry analysts. But the rebound will be modest compared with the surge that followed the 1974-75 recession. (D1.)

title: Team Is Barred
description: Because of its Government's apartheid policy, the 12-member South African team was barred today from the international karate championships, which begin here Friday. The decision to prohibit the South Africans was made by secret ballot of members of the World Union of Karate Organizations. The vote, 19 to 17 with two abstentions, came after several nations had threatened to withdraw unless the South Africans were excluded.

title: KARLE AMEND'S SCENIC DESIGNS ON VIEW
description: THE business rather than the show of show business is the subject of ''Behind the Scenes: the Theater Art of Karle O. Amend,'' an exhibition at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, through Feb. 28.

title: Viewing Earth's Riches On Big Museum Screen
description: The giant-screen film ''Man Belongs to the Earth'' will have its first New York showings tonight and tomorrow at 6 and 7:30 P.M., in the American Museum of Natural History's Naturemax Theater. The film, which is about Earth's finite resources, opens with a rollercoaster-like flight into the Grand Canyon.

title: MOSCOW DISPUTES REAGAN ON THE MX
description: Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, carried a detailed rebuttal today to President Reagan's arguments for deploying the new MX missile, charging that the plan would violate the accords limiting strategic arms.

title: HARVARD STUDENTS CALL FOR AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: Students at Harvard Law School have overwhelmingly approved a resolution urging the school to expand its faculty recruiting efforts to attract more women and members of minority groups.

title: Clemson Loses Austin
description: Cliff Austin, the Clemson tailback, had to withdraw from the team's lineup for the Mirage Bowl in Tokyo tomorrow to attend his mother's funeral. Austin, who set a Clemson record by scoring 14 touchdowns this season, learned of his mother's death after arriving in Tokyo Wednesday night and boarded a plane home to Scottsdale, Ga., yesterday. Clemson, which must defeat Wake Forest in the Mirage Bowl to win its second straight Atlantic Coast Conference championship outright, rather than settle for a tie with Maryland, will start Chuck McSwain, another senior tailback, in Austin's place.

title: APPLE'S NEW COMPUTER FACES UNEXPECTED RIVAL
description: A battle is about to break loose in the small-computer business involving a new generation of machines far more sophisticated and easier to use than those now on the market.

title: Proposed Inserts Would List Birth Pill's Possible Benefits
description: A revision has been proposed for the patient information leaflets that are enclosed with birth control pills that would for the first time list the possible benefits of the drug in cutting the risk of disease, Reagan Administration officials have say.

title: SOUND: THE PHONOGRAPH
description: THERE is no minimizing the importance the phonograph has had on 20th-century music, and the idea of devoting an evening to ''His Master's Voice: The Art of the Record Player'' was a good one. But Wednesday evening's presentation at the Kitchen, produced by Tim Carr, was a pretty disappointing affair.

title: Friday Sports
description: Basketball Nets vs. Suns, at Phoenix. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 9:30 P.M.) Joe Lapchick Tournament, opening round, at Alumni Hall, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica, Queens. St. John's vs. Army, 7 P.M., followed by Ohio University vs. St. Mary's of California. (Radio - WGBB, 1240; WNYE-FM, 91.5; 6:55 P.M.) Brigham Young vs. U.C.L.A., at Provo, Utah. (Television - USA Cable, 9:30 P.M.) Great Alaska Shootout, at Anchorage, Alaska. Florida vs. Louisville, Washington vs. Alaska-Anchorage, Clemson vs. Texas A&M, and Vanderbilt vs. Illinois.

title: NORCROSS STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE ITS DEBT
description: Norcross Greeting Cards has had four owners since its founder, Arthur Norcross, died in 1968. Now the company is close to extinction.

title: Erica Horowitz Wed To Federal Defender
description: Erica Horowitz and David Gordon, criminal defense lawyers in New York, were married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Eugene Lipman of Washington performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Norman Horowitz.

title: JERSEY STATE TROOPER IS INDICTED IN DEATH OF A MAN IN CUSTODY
