description: A New Jersey state trooper has been indicted on a charge of reckless manslaughter in the death of a man while he was in the custody of the trooper and his partner last July.

title: GOVERNMENT SPENDING EXCEEDS $1,000 BILLION
description: Both the income and spending of Federal, state and local governments exceeded $1,000 billion for the first time in the fiscal year that ended in 1981, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: MISSING JERSEY CHEERLEADER IS FOUND STABBED TO DEATH
description: An 18-year-old high school cheerleader, who had been missing for more than 36 hours, was found stabbed to death in a remote part of Randolph Township around noon today. The body was found by a couple walking a dog, the Randolph police said.

title: AN EMBARRASSING U.S. QUARREL WITH A LATIN AMERICAN SCHOLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Dance

title: North Carolina 33, Bowling Green 14
description: Scott Stankavage passed for two touchdowns, and Brooks Barwick tied a school record with four field goals.

title: EXERCISING IS LINKED TO A BODY SUBSTANCE THAT PROTECTS HEART
description: A scientist says exercise increases the level of a substance that may protect against heart attacks in men, but he cautions that the substance disappears if exercise is halted for even three weeks.

title: POLES VOW TO END MARTIAL LAW IN '82
description: Poland has told West European governments that it will end martial law in mid-December if there are no unforeseen snags, official sources said today.

title: Japan Auto Talks
description: Japan and Canada will hold talks Monday and Tuesday in Ottawa on the volume of Japanese auto exports to Canada in January-March 1983, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: BALLOONS CREATE A NIGHT OF WONDER
description: ''At midnight, the tunnel is ours!'' exclaimed Ronnie Taffet, a Macy's official, as, muffled in raccoon skins to guard against the chilly night, she approached the old Tootsie Roll factory in Hoboken, N.J., where the Thanksgiving Day Parade takes shape.

title: Chicagoans Combating Graffiti and Gangs
description: Residents of a Chicago neighborhood are waging a battle to keep walls and buildings free of graffiti and to control gangs who spray messages on walls.

title: People
description: * Alan Hirsch appointed chief executive officer of Gross & Associates.

title: MISSISSIPPI GETS A REPRESENTATIVE, FROM INDIANA
description: When Katie Hall turned 21 years old in 1959, she was living in Mound Bayou, an all-black town of 3,000 in the Delta region of Mississippi. She was not allowed to register to vote or to take a seat in a local restaurant.

title: Steel Cutback In Europe
description: The European Commission today rejected plans by Common Market countries to reduce their steelmaking capacity, saying the cuts were insufficient.

title: MAINE OFFICIALS KEEPING TABS ON THE ACIDITY LEVELS OF RAIN
description: Every Tuesday morning Peter Lowell walks up a ridge near Highland Lake to measure the acidity of the week's rainfall.

title: HAWAII STORM COST NEAR $200 MILLION
description: The estimated cost of damages wrought by Hurricane Iwa neared $200 million today and Gov. George Ariyoshi, calling the battered islands of Kauai and Niihau disaster areas, asked for a Federal disaster declaration.

title: RICHARD E. HIXSON
description: Richard E. Hixson, a bass trombonist who played under Igor Stravinsky and Kiril Condrashan, died at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. yesterday.

title: 2 Women Accused In Fatal Drugging
description: Two New York City women were charged with killing a man after they assertedly drugged his drink in order to rob him, authorities said.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS ABANDON EFFORTS TO CONVENE AN O.A.U. CONFERENCE
description: African leaders today abandoned attempts to convene a meeting of heads of government of the Organization of African Unity because they could not resolve a dispute over the seating of Chad.

title: JEWISH DAY SCHOOL ENROLLMENT RISING
description: Bolstered by an influx of immigrants and a renewed interest in religious education by young Jewish couples, enrollment at Jewish day schools in the New York area has been rising for the first time in a decade, according to a group that monitors Jewish education.

title: Article 057365 -- No Title
description: President Reagan will ask Congress to finance his program to combat narcotics trafficking with $130 million pared from other budget areas, Administration officials said today.

title: BALLET: INVESTIGATING 3 COMPOSERS
description: TCHAIKOVSKY, Stravinsky, Gershwin. Hearing those names in connection with a dance performance is not unusual nowadays, but there was a time when this musical range would have been identified with only one ballet troupe.

title: Holmes's Trainer Sees No Contenders
description: Eddie Futch, Larry Holmes's trainer, is expecting more trouble from Randall (Tex) Cobb, Holmes's opponent, than the oddsmakers, who list the heavyweight champion as an 8-1 favorite Friday night. But it's what comes later that really worries Futch.

title: Minneapolis Skyscraper Burns After Store Blast
description: A five-alarm fire today caused up to $30 million in damage to the Northwestern National Bank's headquarters and a department store that was being demolished. The police were searching for a man and woman seen running from the scene shortly after an explosion on one of the upper floors of the old Donaldson's department store.

title: The Inside Man
description: Some of the best distance runners in the country will be competing Sunday in the United States cross-country championships at the Meadowlands in New Jersey, and they will include Eamonn Coghlan, an Irishman now living in New York and a man with a mission.

title: Warsaw Pact Meeting Reset
description: A meeting of the Warsaw Pact in Prague, originally planned for early December, has been postponed until January because of the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, Western diplomats in Prague said today. They did not know whether a precise date had been fixed. The military alliance embraces the Soviet Union, Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania.

title: AD RESEARCH GAINING GROUND
description: People who eat frozen TV dinners are harassed and hard-working, a researcher found. Based on that finding, Leo Burnett, the Chicago advertising agency, created ads for Swanson frozen TV dinners that showed an overworked housewife reaching for the product. The campaign proved ill-conceived when it made its debut some years ago. Harassed consumers, it turned out, did not like to be reminded of how hectic their lives were.

title: BULGARIAN HELD IN '81 ATTEMPT TO KILL THE POPE
description: An employee of the Bulgarian national airline and tourist office was arrested here today and charged with complicity in the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II last year.

title: LAPCHICK TOURNEY RULED BY ST. JOHN'S
description: Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's basketball coach, says, ''I'm happy that the Army can still keep some secrets,'' but he would prefer to know more about the West Point team that is in the Lapchick tournament starting tonight at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: Debt Relief For Saarstahl
description: An accord with creditor banks on a plan to ease the burden of commercial debts on Arbed Saarstahl, a steel producer, is near completion, a company spokesman said.

title: Braun Sent Down
description: Steve Braun is going back to the farm. Braun, a utility player for the St. Louis Cardinals, delivered 12 pinch-hits last season and forced home the winning run with a bases-loaded walk in Game Two of the World Series.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Phonemeter Corp., Ridgefield Park, N.J., elected Allen B. Du Mont Jr. president, succeeding Sidney S. Barzman, who was elected chairman.

title: Dr. Sherman Barr, 57, Chief; Of Social Welfare at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Sherman Barr, associate professor of social work at New York University and chairman of the social-welfare programs and policies curriculum at the university's School of Social Work, died last Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFING
description: Energy Choice Under Fire

title: CHEERS MIXED WITH SHIVERS GREET PARADE
description: Over and over, they came dashing out from the sidelines, going a few feet into the street and then stopping. Bundled in scarfs and hats and snowsuits - their mouths sometimes ringed with traces of hot chocolate - they gaped, marshaled their nerve and called out to the balloons. ''Hi, Superman.'' ''Hi, Mickey.''

title: A 'SINCERE' ACT, QUEBEC KILLER SAYS OF '70 DEED
description: One of four secessionist extremists imprisoned 12 years ago for murdering a Quebec Cabinet minister has termed the decision to strangle the official ''a sincere gesture to show that what we were saying was not just words.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: THE BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Pop

title: MORGAN HAILS HAYDN AND STRAVINSKY
description: Franz Joseph Haydn and Igor Stravinsky, so far apart in time yet linked in so many ways, are enjoying anniversary years, and the Pierpont Morgan Library is taking note of them with an exhibition of their manuscripts in the library's entrance hall.

title: Energy Resources
description: The Energy Resources Corporation has announced that M.F. Schwenk had resigned as president, but would continue as chairman and chief executive officer until Jan. 31. Kenneth Wanamaker, formerly treasurer of the company, has been named president.

title: U.S. Sues to Recover Money From Convicted Ex-Lawmaker
description: The Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit Wednesday to recover $48,700 in money paid to former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. and a co-defendant convicted in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation.

title: NO 'TEARFUL ADIOS' FOR MEXICAN LEADER
description: During his final weeks in office, President Jose Lopez Portillo has revisited every state in Mexico, dedicating public works worth billions of dollars, listening to speeches lauding his performance and addressing crowds of peasants and workers trucked in to bid him farewell.

title: 8 Face Charges On Slot Machines
description: Eight persons have been charged in a purported scheme to collect payoffs by tampering with progressive slot machines at Caesar's Boardwalk Regency casino in Atlantic City.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN FOLLY
description: ''Pay no attention to the rhetoric; just pay attention to the deeds,'' pleaded a State Department official defending the Administration's Central American policy the other day. The remark was exquisitely if unintentionally ironic. In Central America, more than anywhere else, this Administration's confrontational actions are totally consistent with its militant rhetoric.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1982
description: International A suspect in the attack on the Pope in mid-1981 was arrested in Rome. An employee of the Bulgarian national airline and tourist office who has lived in Rome for four years was charged with complicity in the attempt on the life of John Paul II. A Turk is serving a life sentence for the attempt and has repeatedly asserted he acted alone. (Page A1, Column 5.) Pravda carried a detailed rebuttal to President Reagan's arguments for deploying the MX intercontinental missile, charging that the plan would violate the Soviet-American accords limiting strategic arms. (A1:6.)

title: STATE WORKERS' LESS THAN 'VERY GENEROUS' PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERE, in roughly ascending order of expensiveness, is a roundup of books that, whatever else their merits or flaws may be, seem plausible for proffering as gifts this year.

title: CAREY ADVOCATING PACKAGE OF TAXES FOR TRANSIT HELP
description: Governor Carey has proposed a package of taxes to aid mass transit that would avoid any need for increases in bus, subway and commuter rail fares through the end of next year, legislative aides said yesterday.

title: Seth Stein Weds Carol Ann Geller
description: Carol Ann Geller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Geller of New York, was married yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue to Seth Avram Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Stein of Providence, R.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Judah Nadich of the synagogue and Meyer Greenberg of Jerusalem, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Peter Falk returns to Broadway in a comedy.
description: ''I'D never do another play,'' Peter Falk announced right after his triumphant Broadway opening in Neil Simon's ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue'' in 1971. ''I didn't know what Valium was until I read the play. I never had an anxiety attack before.''

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Holiday Race Is Child's Play
description: year-old Claire Quaderer added an extra thrill for 1,500 runners yesterday as she set a national age record in the Port Washington Thanksgiving Day Run.

title: Mexico Bank Outlook
description: The new President, Miguel de la Madrid, is likely to reduce the number of nationalized banks here to 10 or less from 53, private Mexican bankers reported.

title: OPTIMISM IN THRIFT INDUSTRY
description: The worst of times may be over for the nation's savings and loan associations. Until recently, the thrift institutions were battered by high interest rates, resulting in huge losses for thousands and the demise of hundreds. A brighter picture began to emerge last summer, however, when rates began a sharp decline. In early July, for example, the prime lending rate of major banks stood at 16 1/2 percent; today it is 11 1/2 percent.

title: NAVAJOS MOURNING THE DEATH OF PRIEST WHO TENDED THEM
description: Each day since Sunday, when the Rev. Harold Baxter Liebler died quietly in a remote hospital in southeastern Utah, Navajo women and children have filed into St. Mary's of the Moonlight Church to pray and extend sympathy to his widow.

title: U.S. APPROVES MAJORITY OF BELL OPERATING AREAS
description: The Justice Department says it is willing to accept most of the proposals advanced by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for staking out the operating areas of the Bell System companies once they are divested in 1984.

title: GAS WELLS A BOON TO TOWN IN KANSAS
description: This town of 800 people has no paved streets and its current annual budget is $250,000. But now it is trying to figure out how to spend millions.

title: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ CONNECTS IN SONG
description: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ is a man who knows his own mind. ''There are two kinds of music - good music and bad music,'' the 41-year-old author, radio personality and singer said the other day at his home in the Chelsea section. ''And I know what the difference is. I'm not going to go on the stage with laziness accompanying me. I'm going to go with intelligence, hard work and talent. I won't sing an untrue rhyme like 'home and alone.' I turn up my nose and my heart to 'home and alone.' ''

title: In cartoons, all blood is red paint.
description: feature films, not short subjects - come to town? In the last few weeks, we've had ''The Last Unicorn,'' ''Heidi's Song,'' ''Bugs Bunny's 3d Movie: 1,001 Rabbit Tales'' and a revival of ''Fantasia,'' with a new sound track.

title: No More Warehouses for the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonavena Suit Settled
description: The heirs of Oscar Bonavena, the heavyweight boxer from Argentina who was shot to death in 1976, have received a $600,000 settlement in a suit against the owners of the Nevada brothel where he was slain. Under terms made public in United States District Court in Reno, Bonavena's widow, Dora Bonavena, and his two children, Natalio and Adriana Bonavena, received $200,000 each from an insurance company representing the Mustang Ranch, a legal brothel north of Las Vegas that is owned by Joe and Sally Conforte. Mrs. Conforte became Bonavena's manager in 1976, a few months before he was shot to death by Willard Ross Brymer, Joe Conforte's bodyguard. Mr. Brymer was convicted of murder and was released after serving 15 months in prison.

title: LIBRARIANS ASSAIL CHILD PORNOGRAPHY STATUTE
description: Librarians have called for changes in a sweeping ordinance intended to halt the spread of child pornography in Cook County.

title: HOPES RISE WITH GAINS IN HOUSING
description: After four years of steady declines, the housing industry finally has cause for optimism. Housing experts are increasingly confident that a recovery, albeit modest, is building and will continue into 1983. The optimism is sparked by mortgage interest rates that have declined more than four percentage points since mid-July.

title: RAIDERS TRAVEL TO CINCINNATI TO TEST BENGALS' PASSING GAME
description: For the second straight weekend of games after the player strike, the Los Angeles Raiders' defense will be staring down the barrel of one of the National Football League's most feared offenses.

title: Magazines Revenue Up
description: Magazine advertising revenues in October increased 5 percent, to $351.1 million, from October 1981, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. But the number of monthly pages fell 5 percent, to 11,803. For the first 10 months of the year, revenues are up 6 percent, to $2.7 billion, but pages are down 2 percent, to 97,648.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Screen

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Concerted Family Effort

title: 2 Die in Custody in Namibia
description: West Africa, Nov. 25 (Reuters) - Two black men, a schoolteacher and a reputed nationalist guerrilla, died recently in police custody, the police authorities announced today. A full investigation is under way.

title: A STRIVING WOMAN IN A MAN'S WORLD
description: WHILE the titles of television movies get worse these days, content seems to be getting perkier. Tomorrow night at 9 on CBS, a production called ''Games Mother Never Taught You'' turns out to be a decently provocative portrait of a woman, played vivaciously and winningly by Loretta Swit, entering a preserve that is usually limited to white males. When her boss is named chairman of his marketing company, Laura Bentalls is promoted from executive secretary to a top-ranking management position. She then has the unenviable task of learning the nasty little corporate games that are supposed to insure survival.

title: 3 FIRE BATTALIONS TO BE CUT IN MOVE TO TRIM BUDGET
description: Forced by the city's budget problems to cut its firefighting operations, the Fire Department is planning to eliminate three battalions - in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. The fire companies in those areas will be taken over by neighboring battalions.

title: EXPLOSION IN A BEIRUT SUBURB KILLS 6 AND INJURES 20 OTHERS
description: An explosive charge nearly destroyed a building in Beirut's southern suburb of Shiyah today, killing six people, injuring 20 and trapping an undetermined number of people, a Lebanese security source said.

title: A taste of India on the East Side.
description: MANY of the city's neighborhoods are being enriched with modest storefront Indian restaurants that provide engaging food at moderate prices. One newcomer is Tanjore, an informal, brightly attractive restaurant on First Avenue, between 66th and 67th Streets. Opened just four months ago, it is owned and managed by Ashok Seth, who has managed the Persian restaurant Tavoos, the Bombay Palace, Gaylord's and Sahib.

title: When Steelworkers Won't Bend
description: Defying the union's national leadership, local officials of the United Steelworkers have rejected wage concessions for their financially pressed industry. That is hardly surprising; equally well-paid workers in the ailing auto, airline and mining industries have been similarly reluctant to give back their hard-won gains. Still, the decision powerfully demonstrates the problems we all face in restructuring the economy.

title: MITTERRAND HOPES WEST WON'T FORGET SOVIET EXPANSIONISM
description: President Francois Mitterrand, commenting for the first time on the change in Soviet leadership, said today that it would be fatal for the West to forget that the Soviet Union will seek ''to continue its ideological and political progression on every continent.''

title: Virginia Tech 21; Virginia 14
description: Mark Cox, a sophomore quarterback who replaced Todd Greenwood after he threw two first-period interceptions, passed for one touchdown and ran for another to help Virginia Tech win.

title: Stolen Honeybee Pollen May Contain Poison
description: About $60,000 worth of honeybee pollen stolen from a Miami factory has probably been mixed with poisoned pollen and could be on its way to area health food stores, the authorities warned today.

title: KOHL FOR MISSILES IF IMPASSE GOES ON
description: In his first foreign policy address to Parliament, Chancellor Helmut Kohl today affirmed his Government's determination to deploy American-made medium-range missiles next year if arms limitations talks in Geneva remain deadlocked.

title: Dr Pepper's Leader Sizes Up Industry
description: When Richard Q. Armstrong steps in as president of the Dr Pepper Company next week, he will take charge of a company looking for identity in the free-for-all soft-drink industry.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: THE BEST ENTERTIANMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Music

title: NEW RULES ON PESO LURE SOME DOLLARS
description: New rules that permit money changers and merchants along the American border to offer close to black market rates for much-needed dollars appear to have resulted in some influx of dollars and an improvement in the flagging economies of Juarez and other Mexican border cities.

title: SPACECRAFT DETECTS SAHARA'S BURIED PAST
description: Interpretation of radar studies made by the space shuttle Columbia reveals a whole new body of geologic knowledge of what lies under the Sahara: buried sites of possible Stone Age settlements and subterranean traces of rivers that once flowed there and carved out valleys as broad as those of the present Nile.

title: Turks Accuse Greeks Of Evasive Tactics
description: Turkey accused Greece today of trying to evade the resumption of discussions between them with ''baseless'' claims of airspace violations.

title: College Found at Fault In Discrimination Suit
description: Albany State College, a predominantly black school, practiced racial discrimination in passing over a white man to name a black woman as chairman of its history department, a judge has ruled.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memorialized in Metal, And by Good Works

title: McLouth Owner Wary
description: The McLouth Steel Products Corporation requires an improved economic climate to survive, its new owner says. ''Regardless of how much you cut costs, you must have business to turn this company around,'' Cyrus Tang, president of Tang Industries of Elk Grove Village, Ill., said this week. He completed his purchase of McLouth last week.

title: AN EMBARRASSING U.S. QUARREL WITH A LATIN AMERICAN SCHOLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Charity's Practicalities

title: REAGAN CALLS IT MX; ACTUALLY, IT'S M-HEX
description: In taking up the proposed MX missile basing plan, Congress should consider not only whether President's Reagan's ''dense pack'' approach is workable but also whether the MX is needed - or even desirable - for national security.

title: Friday; LIPPIZANERS ON PARADE
description: Madison Square Garden has laid nine inches of soil and shavings on its arena floor to help 26 Lippizaner stallions feel at home. The famous white horses - from Vienna's centuries-old Spanish Riding School - will perform there tonight through Monday and Dec. 7 to 10. With signals from riders in Renaissance-style costumes, the stallions will leap, trot sideways in precision formations, prance, pirouette and accomplish other feats to the music of Mozart, Strauss and Chopin. Performances at 8 P.M. (except this Sunday, at 2 P.M.). Tickets, $10 to $25, at Ticketron outlets and through Chargit, 944-9300. Information: 564-4400. CELEBRITY DOODLE SALE

title: U.S. Coal Faces Competitive Challenge
description: The United States, the world's biggest coal producer, is running into stiff competition from other exporting countries in its efforts to capture a bigger chunk of the world's coal markets. Depressed economic conditions, which are curbing industrial demand over much of the globe, have added to American producers' problems.

title: Bar Dexter Wins Aqueduct Feature
description: Woodside Stud's Bar Dexter drew out for a 3 3/4-length victory over Castle Knight in the 77th running of the $54,800 Queens County Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Accounts
description: * SCI-COM Computer Systems Inc., Bridgewater, N.J., to AC&R Advertising Inc.

title: Dogs Patrolling Groton Shipyard
description: Trained guard dogs began patrolling today inside the Electric Boat shipyard in an effort to deter another break-in by anti-nuclear protesters, company officials said.

title: Trans World Stake Reported
description: Lester Pollack, a principal in Odyssey Partners, has declined to comment on reports that the partnership had acquired about 5 percent of the Trans World Corporation, parent of Trans World Airlines.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Galleries

title: Screen
description: If you don't believe the punk ethos can make for palatable movies, this just may be your weekend to find out otherwise. There are two new punk films in town -both with wild, funny heroines, both directed by women and both unexpectedly worthwhile.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Museums

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: THE BEST ENTERTAINMENT THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Jazz

title: ECONOMIC THEORY WITH A BLIND SPOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we had our druthers we wouldn't eliminate any battalions. Fewer will not make us better.

title: Last 'Incredible' Days
description: ''The Incredible Feeling Show,'' a children's musical with music and lyrics by Elizabeth Swados, closes a monthlong run this weekend at the First All Children's Theater, 36 West 65th Street. Performances are at 2 and 4 P.M. today, tomorrow and Sunday.

title: Cowboys Defeat Browns
description: The Dallas Cowboys, harassing the quarterback Brian Sipe with a swarming defense, rode the passing of Danny White and the slashing runs of Tony Dorsett to a 31-14 victory over the Cleveland Browns today.

title: Minister Defiant Over School Must Go to Jail, Court Rules
description: The fundamentalist minister protesting the state's education laws must serve his jail term for operating an illegal school, the Nebraska Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

title: 40 Hurt in Argentine Protest
description: More than 40 people were injured when the police used tear gas and dogs to break up a protest by 15,000 demonstrators against increases in utility rates in the middle-class suburb of Lanus, officials said today.

title: MAN IS ARRESTED IN SLAYING CASE TIED TO CAR AD
description: A man who apparently answered an advertisement offering to sell a car was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing the automobile and murdering its owner, the police said.

title: 3 SNATCH THE PURSE OF EMILY KENNEDY ON UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The purse of Emily Ruth Kennedy, a Legal Aid Society lawyer and the wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., was stolen Wednesday night by three teen-age boys on the Upper East Side, but she has refused to press charges against them, the police said.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR RECALLS TRIALS AND TRIUMPHS
description: The renaissance of Philadelphia is no longer ''one of the country's best-kept secrets,'' as William J. Green called it when he campaigned for Mayor in 1979. For that, some people here say, Mayor Green can claim part of the credit.

title: A Walk That Explores Hell's Kitchen History
description: Starting at 2 P.M. today, Adventure on a Shoestring will conduct a walking tour of the west side of midtown, a neighborhood once known as Hell's Kitchen and now called Clinton.

title: What Criminal Justice System?
description: The proper measure of the justice system's effectiveness is not solely the crime rate, which it cannot control, but the efficiency - and justice - of a system laboring to function under the stress of the great demands placed upon it. So says Governor Carey's commission on the administration of justice, and there is little doubt about its conclusion that, measured by its efficiency, New York's justice system fails dismally. The main recommendation of the commission, headed by Arthur Liman, is for a cabinet-level coordinator of criminal justice. It seems somewhat utopian. A proposal for revamping the management of criminal records is far more practical.

title: Deficit of U.S.  Again at High
description: The Government has started its new fiscal year the same way it ended the old - with a record budget deficit.

title: Sun Electric Executive Welcomes Turnaround
description: Keith P. Mazurek, the recently elected chairman and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Sun Electric Corporation, says he is especially looking forward to the new year. One reason is that effective Jan.1, Mr. Mazurek will officially succeed Louis G. Langpop, 61, who will retire after 40 years with Sun Electric but will continue as chairman of the board's executive committee.

title: Letter: On Withholding Why Penalize Honest Taxpayers?
description: To the Editor: Your editorial view (''Withholding, in the Public Interest,'' Nov. 9) that it is fair for the Federal Government to withhold taxes on interest and dividend income ''to assure that taxpayers pay what they owe'' fails to recognize that there are alternative and better means of assuring compliance.

title: THE CHEERY SKIES
description: For the benefit of people who have never traveled by air but plan to do so and think it will make them as happy as those travelers they see on airline commercials, here are the facts:

title: Elaine Townshend and David Paley Have Nuptials
description: Elaine Joyce Townshend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis S. Townshend of Fair Haven, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Alan Paley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Paley of Chicago. The Rev. Richard C. Brietske performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity with Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism in New York.

title: SIMPSONS-SEARS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: B-Net income; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: CHINA SAYS TAIWAN COULD OPERATE AS SPECIAL ZONE TIED TO MAINLAND
description: A senior Chinese official said today that the new state constitution to be adopted soon would let Taiwan operate as a new special administrative zone of mainland China.

title: WILSON, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Nancy Troy Bride Of Wim de Wit
description: Nancy J. Troy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Troy of New York and Milford, Pa., was married yesterday to Wim de Wit of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, son of Piet de Wit of Breda, the Netherlands, and the late Mrs. de Wit of Breda. The ceremony was performed at the country residence of the bride's parents by Judge Harold A. Thomson Jr. of the Court of Common Pleas for the 60th Judicial District in Pennsylvania.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kean Has Talks With Lawmakers
description: Governor Kean met for two hours yesterday with New Jersey legislative leaders to find some agreement on tax measures needed to deal with a projected $150 million deficit in the state's current budget.

title: BRITAIN'S JOBLESS: LITTLE SUFFERING
description: In this troubled country of nearly 14 percent unemployment, the jobless are discovering the true value of the phrase ''welfare state.''

title: U.S. RETURNS STOLEN ITALIAN ARTWORKS
description: The head of the United States Customs Service, pledging vigilance against international art smugglers, today returned seven rare works stolen from Italy and recovered in the United States.

title: Rumania Near Debt Accord
description: After months of waiting, Rumania and its Western creditor banks are to sign in London on Dec.9 an agreement restructuring $1.7 billion in commercial debt that Rumania owes from 1981 and 1982, banking sources here said today.

title: MULLIN LEADS ROUT BY REDMEN
description: St. John's opened its Lapchick basketball tournament at Alumni Hall last night by dominating Army as clearly as the Redmen have dominated the tournament during its eight years. No team has beaten St. John's in the tournament, named for Joe Lapchick, the Redmen's late coach.

title: TIME TO SCRAP SUBWAY TOKENS
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH ASKS HELP OF LOCAL BOARDS WITH HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday asked the heads of all New York City's community boards to prepare a list of buildings in their areas that might be used to shelter homeless men and women this winter.

title:
PATENTS;
Nonabsorbing Solar Cell Proves More Efficient
description: NASA received a patent this week for a solar cell described as high in intensity and efficiency.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $471,000 for the qr and $294,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $601,000

title: GORDON GRAY, PRESIDENTS' ADVISER AND BUSINESS EXECUTIVE, IS DEAD
description: Gordon Gray, a former Secretary of the Army who served in high national security posts from the Truman through the Ford Administrations, died of cancer yesterday afternoon at his home in Washington. He was 73 years old.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Different Rights Dispute

title: IF BROTHERS COULD COOK
description: There are times when it's appropriate for the journalist to step aside and let others say it better for him.

title: GIVING PEACE'S FRIENDS A CHANCE
description: Politicians, commentators and, most blatantly, diplomats regularly laud ''peace movements all around the world.'' Surely, they must know by now that no such phenomenon exists. They must sense that genuine peace movements are as rare as free societies - rare, indeed, for the two can only exist together.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $777,000 for the latest 6 mos and $362,000 for the yr-ago 6 mos

title: ALLEN EXPANDING HEISMAN LEGACY
description: Marcus Allen knows all about the legacy. During his sophomore year at the University of Southern California, the year Charles White became U.S.C.'s third Heisman Trophy winner, Allen did not have a very good view. Defensive linemen, and the grass floor of the Los Angeles Coliseum, kept getting in the way.

title: MINNEAPOLIS FIRE CAUSES LARGE LOSS
description: A fire engulfed a full downtown block here early today, destroying an abandoned department store and burning the top 11 floors of an adjacent high-rise bank building. Damage from the five-alarm blaze, which burned out of control for 12 hours, was estimated at up to $30 million.

title: No Headline
description: VIRGINIA SETS 2 MARKS IN ROUT

title: Weather Satellite Fails; Repairs Are 'Doubtful'
description: The weather satellite that monitors the West Coast and much of the Pacific Ocean has failed, robbing meteorologists of pictures from the breeding ground for the major winter storms that sweep the United States.

title: 'Village' Man Is Found Dead of Stab Wounds
description: A 39-year-old Greenwich Village man was found stabbed to death in his ground-floor apartment yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Bridge: Blue Ribbon Tourney Won By Meckstroth and Rodwell
description: A strong claim to be considered the world's best partnership became stronger here last night when Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, and Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., captured the blue ribbon pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: A Difficult Decision
description: The place-kicking brothers, Luis Zendejas and Max Zendejas, will be booting the ball against each other tonight when Arizona State plays Arizona. But their parents, who had hoped to fly to Tucson to watch them, will miss the family reunion after an agonizing decision.

title: BRIAN P. LEEB
description: Brian P. Leeb, a former senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died Wednesday at his home in West Orange, N.J. He was 86.

title: ITALIANS SAY NOTHING YET LINKS POPE ATTACK TO A GOVERNMENT
description: The magistrate whose office is conducting the inquiry into the 1981 attempt to kill Pope John Paul II said today that evidence gathered so far proves that the assassination was the work of several people but does not sustain assertions that it was the result of a conspiracy on the international level.

title: Like Mother, Like Daughter
description: Once women began riding horses professionally as jockeys, it probably became inevitable: One day, a mother and a daughter would ride against each other in a race. Now, the day is practically at hand.

title: Mozambique Rebels Release 6 Missionaries After 70 Days
description: Rightist guerrillas in Mozambique have released six Roman Catholic missionaries, including four nuns, after holding them captive for 70 days, a rebel spokesman said today.

title: CINDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Governor Kean's Chewing Gum
description: New Jersey's Governor Kean offered a bold challenge to a special joint session of the Legislature this week. ''Erase forever,'' he said, ''the term 'budget crisis' from the legislative and executive branch of state government.'' Yet his proposals for doing so are in no sense bold.

title: COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AND POLITICS DO MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM AND THEATER TICKET TAX OPPOSED
description: The Koch administration's plan to impose a 3 percent tax on movie and theater admissions was questioned yesterday by the politician who could do the most to halt it, the majority leader of the City Council.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are absolutely unequivocal on the principle of safeguarding China's sovereignty, unity and territorial integrity. At the same time, we are highly flexible as regards specific policies and measures and will give full consideration to the concrete situation in the Taiwan region and the wishes of the people in Taiwan and those of all personages concerned.'' -Peng Zhen, deputy chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. (5:1.)

title: Zimbabwe Gets U.S. Loan Aid
description: The United States has guaranteed $25 million worth of loans from American banks to the Government of Zimbabwe for urban housing.

title: Computer Study Too Popular
description: So many students want to enroll in computer science courses at Northern Illinois University that school officials are turning them away. ''We're holding the number of computer majors to 1,000 students,'' said John McCharen, chairman of the computer sciences department. ''My estimate is that 700 more students want to become majors.''

title: Uruguay Plans To Float Peso
description: The Government of Uruguay declared a bank holiday today and said the peso would be allowed to float when business was resumed on Monday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At Illiteracy Conference, A Sign Is Reformed

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Unwitting New Entrant In the Token War

title:
PATENTS;
Warhead Is Shaped To Pierce Armor Better
description: A warhead with a shaped charge invented for the Army is said to improve the armor-piercing capability of the metal particles discharged.

title: Instant Replay
description: Remember when Red Barber and Mel Allen used to recreate baseball games off the Western Union ticker? Well, this weekend, the people at the ESPN network are updating the trick and carrying it into the era of the international feed, the earth satellite and color television.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Teaching Austerity Amid the Holiday Cheer

title: James Broderick Memorial
description: A memorial to James Broderick, the actor, who died Nov. 1, will take place Monday at 11 A.M. at the Public Theater. Jason Robards, Sada Thompson, Sidney Lumet, Vivian Matalon and Barbara Cook are scheduled to participate.

title: Gabriel Quits as Coach
description: Roman Gabriel, the former pro quarterback, says he is resigning as head football coach at California Poly-Pomona, because nobody will tell him if the school intends to continue playing football. During his professional career, he was a star with the Los Angeles Rams and the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: HOLMES RETAINS HIS TITLE ON UNANIMOUS DECISION
description: Randall (Tex) Cobb did not beat Larry Holmes by a chin tonight. Cobb's chin gave the impression it could stand up to an onrushing bus, but it bothered little the undefeated heavyweight champion's plan to keep hitting it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Traditions of the Day After, Old and Newly Discovered

title: MAKERS OF WESTERN APPAREL SUFFER FROM DEATH OF THE URBAN COWBOY FAD
description: When the urban cowboy fashion fad died suddenly earlier this year, East Side New York fashion plates lightly discarded their $300 hornback lizard boots and moved on to preppie loafers or whatever the latest rage commanded.

title: SCURRY-RAINBOW OIL LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
I.T.T.'s New TV
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said its West German subsidiary, Intermetall, had developed a digital television using a computer chip that permits viewers to watch two different channels at once. One picture would appear without sound in the corner of the screen.

title: THEATER: 'LAST TANGO' FROM SAN FRANCISCO
description: ''No resemblance between the personages and events of this play and actual persons and events is entirely coincidental.'' That reverse disclaimer, tucked into the program for the San Francisco Mime Troupe's new show, ''Americans, or Last Tango in Huahuatenango,'' exactly summarizes the topicality and the relevance of this fearless political assault. With the Mime Troupe, everything is intentional.

title: CHAMBER: COMPOSERS QUARTET
description: Mendelssohn's String Quartet in A minor - played by the Composers String Quartet at Merkin Hall on Wednesday night - opens with a musical epigraph, one of the composer's own songs. It begins, ''Ist es wahr? Ist es wahr?'' - ''Is it true? Is it true?'' The question itself is almost less important than its invocation of the inscription of the final movement of Beethoven's Opus 135 Quartet: ''Muss es sein? Es muss sein!'' -''Must it be? It must be!''

title: DEMOCRATS' GAINS CARRY OBLIGATIONS
description: As their initial euphoria over the election has faded, Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives have come to realize that added strength imposes a new responsibility on the next Congres: to go beyond opposition to President Reagan and devise a clear alternative to his program.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, a Los Angeles-based financial institution that owns the Security Pacific National Bank, said it had received regulatory approval to proceed with its acquisition of a 29.9 percent equity interest in Hoare Govett, the London-based brokerage house. Security Pacific has agreed to pay about $13.7 million for the equity interest, of which about $5.7 million will be used to purchase existing Hoare Govett shares; the remainder represents new equity. The investment is part of a continuing strategy to develop its financial services worldwide, Security Pacific said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. The paratrooper, in a spectacular effort to win the annual Beaujolais nouveau race from France to foreign capitals, was carrying a few bottles of the wine to London when he dropped into the Thames.

title: VESSEL'S POWER MAY AID STORM-DAMAGED ISLAND
description: Gov. George Ariyoshi today declared the three hurricane-damaged islands of Hawaii as major disaster areas. Meanwhile, the United States Navy studied the possibility of providing emergency power to one of the islands with a nuclear submarine.

title: VETERAN WORKERS FORCED TO CLING TO CITY JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nebraska Achieves Orange Bowl Berth
description: Nebraska defeated Oklahoma, 28-24, today to win the Big Eight Conference championship and the spoils that go with it, a berth in the Orange Bowl on New Year's Night.

title: U.S. REBUTS SOVIET ON MX DEPLOYMENT
description: The Reagan Administration rejected today assertions made by Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, that American deployment of the MX missile would violate the accords limiting strategic arms.

title: Hawks 4, Whalers 3
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Bill Gardner of Chicago scored at 15:45 of the third period to snap a 3-3 tie. Gardner took a pass from Doug Wilson and beat the goalie Mike Veisor.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Yr-ago results are not available since the company was not in full operations

title: RICH LITTLE POOR BOY
description: To the Editor:

title: If Not Here, Where?
description: Sadly but inevitably, the newest fad in New York jokes focuses on where to put prisoners and the homeless. Representative LeBoutillier started it when he proposed an island prison colony off Alaska. A columnist at The News would send them to work on the Soviet gas pipeline. A colleague suggests housing them in the tunnel of the abandoned Second Avenue subway.

title: Late Start and Eyes Hinder Jets' Ramsey
description: Chuck Ramsey still has $100,000 worth of unsold glassware and novelty items from this year's World's Fair, and the conjunctivitis has spread from his left eye to his right, and his glasses fog up, and he will probably be fined for sleeping through the Jets' first post-strike practice.

title: Toshiba Makes 'Seeing' Robot
description: The Toshiba Corporation said that it had developed and put into operation the world's first visual sensorequipped robot system, in which the arms and hands of two assembly line robots interact with each other to duplicate the complex movements of an actual production line worker.

title: E.E.C. Steel Cuts Urged
description: The European Economic Community's executive commission said today that steel production capacity in the 10-nation group should be cut more than twice as much as member states have proposed.

title: 6 White Zimbabwean Officers Ask Court to Bar Statements
description: Six white Zimbabwean Air Force officers charged with aircraft sabotage have taken court action to prevent statements made during their interrogation from being used at their trial, legal sources said today.

title: Help for Mancini
description: Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, drove over to Youngstown, Ohio, the other day to visit a young friend with a problem: Ray Mancini, the World Boxing Association's lightweight champion. They spent the day driving round the countryside and talking, while Tanner tried to help Mancini clear his troubled mind.

title: REPAYMENT BY BANK
description: Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano, the successor bank to the one that collapsed, has repaid about $910 million of Euromarket borrowings, Giovanni Bazoli, president of Nuovo Ambrosiano, said today.

title: MAKE NEW YORK A CENTER OF BIO-TECH
description: It's fashionable to equate government with red tape. But government can also help bring together disparate groups in a common interest. Such a gathering took place earlier this year in City Hall when the deans of New York City's very competitive medical schools and research institutions convened to discuss the city's potential as a center for the commercial development of bio-technology.

title: PRUDENTIAL-BACHE
description: Bache Securities Inc., a statement on behalf of the investors said. One of the investors, Alec Snobel, said that he had the names of 60 investors who had suffered losses.

title: DECOROUS SANTAS MAN THEIR CHIMNEYS
description: It's not easy being Santa Claus these days. Santa etiquette requires that you be jolly with taste. Ho-ho-ho's must be kept to a minimum (and minus the onion you had for lunch on your breath). You must stick close to your chimney, keep your whiskers on straight and, please, kiss only the children.

title: Tass Denounces Group For Peace as West's Tool
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today denounced members of Moscow's only independent peace group as ''criminals'' sponsored by Western secret services.

title: TIME TO SCRAP SUBWAY TOKENS
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA COUNTY BANS 3 HARMFUL EXOTIC TREES
description: Three types of tree in South Florida have been outlawed because they are harmful to human health or destroy other plants and wildlife.

title: RAYMOND E. SALVATI
description: Raymond E. Salvati, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Island Creek Coal Company, died Monday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: NETS FALL TO SUNS BY 110-99
description: After almost two weeks away from home, the Nets concluded their exhausting western tour tonight by losing to the Phoenix Suns, 110-99, before 11,678 fans at Memorial Coliseum.

title: SUITOR CLUE IS REPORTED IN JERSEY SLAYING
description: An 18-year-old high school senior, stabbed repeatedly and left floating face down in a holding tank of a reservoir here, may have been murdered by a rejected suitor, the police said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LAST-DITCH BARGAINING FOR GATT
description: Key participants in a world trade conference called to halt global protectionism went into last-ditch bargaining sessions tonight to forestall its collapse, with basic differences still separating the major trading blocs.

title: SOFT BLUES: SUBTLETIES OF MOSE ALLISON
description: Two of the most virile streams of music in the 50's, when Mose Allison came up out of Mississippi, were folk and jazz. Mr. Allison, as pianist and singer, combined aspects of both -the Delta blues singers he had listened to first-hand in Mississippi and the jazz musicians such as Louis Armstrong and Nat (King) Cole that he heard primarily on records.

title: JAPAN'S NEW PRIME MINISTER: YASUHIRO NAKASONE
description: Yasuhiro Nakasone, who was elected Japan's 17th postwar Prime Minister today, is a conservative, pro-Western, 35-year veteran of mainstream Japanese politics who is expected to seek better ties with the United States but no abrupt military or economic changes. In foreign affairs the new Prime Minister is known to regard the United States and Japan as leaders of an emerging economic and cultural sphere in the Pacific. He has indicated that he will try to ease recent strains with Washington over military matters and rising Japanese trade surpluses.

title: BOOKLET SIMPLIFIES INSPECTION OF CARS
description: A few years ago Don Fried, then a law student living in San F rancisco, was in the market for a used car, a subject he knew very l ittle about.

title: CONCERN ON PARENT EDUCATION
description: Parent-education programs have increased so rapidly and have such diverse origins that there may be no reliable way to evaluate them, experts say.

title: Lions' Owner Fumes
description: More woe for the Detroit Lions. They not only suffered a 13-6 loss to the New York Giants on Thanksgiving Day but also suffered a tongue-lashing from their owner, William Clay Ford, who complained of ''a ragtag operation.''

title: Emily Kennedy Pressing Case Against 3 in Purse Snatching
description: Emily Ruth Kennedy, a Legal Aid Society lawyer and the wife of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., has decided to press a complaint against three teen-agers suspected of snatching her purse as she was walking on the Upper East Side, the police said yesterday.

title: AUTHORITIES STUDYING DEATHS OF OFFICER AND FRIEND LINKED TO INQUIRY
description: The Queens District Attorney has opened an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the deaths of a Queens detective and the woman with whom he lived, both of whom were apparently connected to a inquiry of police corruption, authorities said this morning.

title: BANK CRISIS IN VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Venezuela's largest deposit bank, Banco de los Trabajadores de Venezuela, faces a severe liquidity crisis and needs an immediate increase in capital of $250 million, the bank's president, Eleazar Pinto, said today.

title: Recipient of Two Lungs Is in Serious Condition
description: James Franzen, the first transplant patient to receive two lungs from separate donors, was in serious but stable condition today after surgery to stop internal bleeding, a hospital spokesman said.

title: James Duncan Phyfe and Winifred Herrick Wed
description: The marriage of Winifred Swoyer Herrick, secretary to the headmistress of the Spence School, to James Duncan Phyfe, an associate in the corporate department of the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, took place yesterday in New York.

title: BANK OF BRITISH COLUMBIA reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Florida Study Reported
description: Although there has been no announcement of an official investigation, the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been interviewing football players recruited by the University of Florida, according to a published report. The report, in The Fort Lauderdale News and Sun-Sentinel today, came just three days after Coach Charley Pell called for a ''blue-ribbon committee'' review of his program.

title: Regan Urges Curb on Panel
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan is urging the White House to exclude Congress and lobbyists from a task force to study the merger of Federal agencies that regulate financial institutions, the Treasury Department confirmed today.

title: CITY'S COURTS CLOGGED BY INCREASE IN CASES AND LACK OF JUDGES
description: Nearly two years after court officials began a new effort to speed the processing of criminal cases, judges and criminal-justice officials say that the criminal courts in New York City are overwhelmed, choking under the greatest flow of new cases in recent years.

title: BMW Factory Planned
description: Bayerische Motorenwerke A.G. plans to build a new autombile plant in the northeast Bavarian city of Regensburg, the company announced today.

title: British Tourism Up 4%
description: More than 9.5 million foreign tourists came to Britain in the first nine months of 1982, a 4 percent increase over the same period last year, the Department of Trade reported today.

title: Delaware 13, UConn 7
description: Rick Scully threw a 7-yard touchdown pass to Kevin Phelan in the opening minute of the fourth quarter to help Delaware to a 13-7 victory today over Connecticut in the final game of the regular season for both teams.

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1982; International
description: Participants at the GATT trade conference in Geneva began intense, last-minute bargaining to forestall its collapse. Basic differences on a wide range of issues separated the major trading blocs. The Common Market delegates went into extraordinary session to discuss issuing a separate policy statement, which would mean a breakdown in a 35-year consensus on world trade rules. (Page 35.)

title: HEILEMAN, JACOBS SET PABST DEAL
description: The hotly contested battle for control of the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fifth largest, appears to have been all but won by the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: CAMCHIB RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LED PRESS INSTITUTE
description: J. Montgomery Curtis, former executive director of the American Press Institute and retired vice president of Knight-Ridder Newspapers, died Thursday at the Miami Heart Institute. Mr. Curtis, who was a resident of Miami Beach, was 77 years old.

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1982
description: International The P.L.O.'s leaders denounced President Reagan's proposal for selfrule for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories in association with Jordan. The statement followed a stormy meeting of the Palestine Liberation Organization's Central Council, a 60-member consultative group. It said the Reagan plan for Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza Strip did not ''satisfy the inalienable national rights of our people,'' but it did not say that the entire plan was unacceptable. (Page 1, Col. 6.) The worldwide economic slowdown has caught up with the centrally planned Communist economies in Eastern Europe. Poland's empty shop windows are only one manifestation of the hard times afflicting the region. Moscow's East European satellites are also weighted down by an immense burden of foreign debt and can no longer hope to borrow their way our of trouble as they did in the past. But the economic stagnation is leading some governments to re-examine their commitment to classic Communist economic dogma. (1:1-2.)

title:
PATENTS;
Use of Preheated Fuel Eliminates Spark Plugs
description: Charles Citelli, a real estate broker in Lexington, N.Y., who once was an airplane mechanic, was awarded a patent this week for a gas turbine that burns preheated fuel and is intended for automotive use.

title: DESPITE BIG CROP, L.I. FARMERS ARE WORRIED
description: The potato harvest is over, and Albin Pietrewicz's two little white barns are filled from floor to ceiling - thin-skinned Katahdins on top, more-durable Superiors near the floor.

title: News Analysis
description: Amid palms where vultures preen in the tropics' damp verdancy, a settlement is rising up in Conakry, its spendor distinct from the encircling slums and from Guinea's pervasive decline.

title: BRUSTEIN'S TROUPE FACES A SEASON OF UNCERTAINTY
description: For Robert Brustein's American Repertory Theater, it is the start of a season that promises to be both auspicious and somewhat problematic.

title: PRESSURE GROWS TO ALTER RULES ON WORKER SAFETY
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, after years of lobbying by labor and health groups, issued a regulation in 1980 requiring all employers to disclose health records to employees or their representatives.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $5,924,000...C-After an extraordinary chargeof $1,278,000

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45. 1. In London there may have been fewer drops to drink because the parachutist pictured at right dropped into the drink. Explain. 2. Serge Ivanov Antonov was arrested in Rome and charged with complicity in the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II last year. Mr. Antonov is a citizen of (Bulgaria/Rumania/the Soviet Union).

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $209,000 for the qr and $440,000for the 6 mos...C-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $58,000 for the qr and $132,000 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $117,000 for theqr and $234,000 for the 6 mos

title: THE DISMISSED CASE OF THE HOMELESS MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Nov. 27, 1982 GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 1 P.M. -------------------

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WIDER IN OCTOBER
description: The foreign trade deficit of the United States widened to $5.3 billion in October and now seems certain to rise to a record of more than $42 billion for the year, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: SYSTEMHOUSE LTD reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring loss of $17.3 million...C-Net income

title: MOTOROLA UNIT ADDS HOURS, BUT NOT PAY
description: Motorola Inc., the communications company with major interests in semiconductor products and electronic data systems, has instituted a 48-hour workweek for its professional employees while paying them for only 40 hours, a company spokesman confirmed today. The company said the program was voluntary and was intended to reduce operating costs without resorting to layoffs.

title: Lisa Antupit, a Teacher, Married to Peter D. Besen
description: Lisa Antupit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel N. Antupit of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Douglas Besen, son of Judith Silverman of Sarasota, Fla., and Dr. Lester Besen of Port St. Lucie, Fla. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at Waveny, the former Lapham estate that is owned by the Town of New Canaan, Conn.

title: No Headline
description: CELTICS' STREAK AT 7

title: IDEA OF TAXING JOBLESS BENEFITS HAS ARISEN BEFORE
description: From the Thanksgiving Day calm of the Western White House emerged a proposal under study for dealing with the problem of high unemployment. The suggestion was that unemployed workers pay taxes on their unemployment benefits.

title:
PATENTS;
A Rugged Wheelchair Designed for Sports
description: A wheelchair designed for sports use and patented this week is already in use by racers and basketball players.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: International Brotherhood Through Poetry

title:
Patents;
Computer To Teach First Aid
description: WASHINGTON A computer-controlled instruction system that trains people in cardiopulmonary resuscitation was patented this week for the American Heart Association. David Hon, manager of Advanced Technology, obtained patent 4,360,345 on the equipment and its operation.

title: STAR MAY BE FLASHING 642 TIMES EACH SECOND
description: Astronomers are looking intently at a star in the constellation Vulpecula that they believe may be flashing on and off almost 642 times a second. That extraordinarily rapid pulse rate has already been observed in the radio emissions of a pulsar, or pulsating star, at that same location.

title: Malagasy President Re-elected to New Term
description: Didier Ratsiraka was officially proclaimed President for the next seven years of this Indian Ocean island republic today.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAYS A TAX ON BENEFITS TO JOBLESS IS DEAD
description: A high White House official said privately today that a study proposal to tax unemployment benefits to make them ''less attractive'' was suffering a quick death in the face of widespread opposition.

title: J. ALLAN ABBOTT
description: J. Allan Abbott. former president and chairman of the Homelite Company and a developer of the one-man chain saw, died Thursday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: ACTION ON ENVIRONMENT BILLS IN SPECIAL SESSION UNCERTAIN
description: Despite a plea by President Reagan to give the measure high priority, Congress is unlikely to revise the Clean Air Act in the post-election session that starts Monday, according to key legislators and other experts.

title: I.M.F. Talks Set in Paris
description: Talks aimed at speeding up negotiations on an increase in resources for the International Monetary Fund will take place in Paris on Monday, European monetary sources said today.

title: POPE, IN SURPRISE MOVE, CALLS 1983 A HOLY YEAR
description: Pope John Paul II today declared the year 1983 a Holy Year in commemoration of the 1,950th anniversary of the Year of Redemption - the year Jesus died.

title: No Headline
description: MISS NAVRATILOVA GAINS

title: Matsushita Deal With I.B.M. Japan
description: Matsushita, one of the world's leading makers of electric appliances, has signed a contract to make small computers for the Japanese subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation, according to the newspaper Asahi Shimbun.

title: Mobil Unit Faces Age Bias Suit
description: A group of 25 former executives and managerial employees of Montgomery Ward & Company said a suit would be filed Monday in Federal court here against the retailer and its parent company, the Mobil Corporation, charging that they were forced from their jobs in an illegal campaign to rid Montgomery Ward of its older employees.

title: Fujitsu Agrees To Pay Agie
description: A Swiss electronics company said it had won several million francs worth of damages from the Fujitsu Fanuc Company of Japan in a settlement over infringed patents.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Fall
description: Prices on the Hong Kong stock market fell to their lowest level in two and a half years today as news of a widening trade deficit accelerated a long-term downward trend.

title: Lloyd's Studies Executive Post
description: Lloyd's of London may appoint an independent chief executive to help restore the battered reputation of the world's largest insurance market, according to insurance industry sources.

title: SINCERLY, R. REAGAN P.S. WHO CARES?
description: Dear President Reagan I am writing on behalf of my daughter, Kelly. She has written to you twice, and each time she has been disappointed with your reply. Letters in the mailbox with a return address of ''The White House'' can be exciting to a child of 9.

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Hiram E. Manville Jr., Ex-Asbestos Executive
description: Hiram Edward Manville Jr., a former director of the Johns-Manville Corporation, died Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital in Reno after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had lived in Reno for 23 years.

title: Kentuckians Get Phone Line To Turn In Drunken Drivers
description: Kentuckians are helping the state police arrest drunken driving suspects by turning them in on a tollfree telephone line.

title: DETROIT WOOS YOUNGER BUYERS
description: American auto makers this fall are offering a variety of sporty, performance-oriented cars - all backed by aggressive advertising - in a bid to win back younger car buyers who have shifted to imports in large numbers.

title: Stevenson Forces Move Toward Illinois Recount
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the Democratic candidate defeated by a narrow margin in the Illinois gubernatorial race, hopes that petitions for recounts will be filed in 58 of the state's 102 counties by late Monday, an aide to the former Senator said today.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Time to Keep the Fares Fair
description: New York's legislative leaders, split by party and geography, preparing for Mario Cuomo's governorship and worrying about deficits, cannot allow these excuses to block action on transit fares. Unless they act on suggestions attributed to Governor Carey or adequate substitutes, they will force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to raise fares by as much as 75 percent on commuter lines and 33 percent in New York City. As Assembly Speaker Fink urges, agreement must be reached on the subsidies committed in 1981.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
JANET MACKAY COLE, RIDER IN HORSE SHOWS
description: Janet MacKay Cole, a former horse-show rider and judge, died Thursday in Boonton, N.J. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Cole and her husband, John Tupper Cole, who died in 1975, performed in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden and at local shows on many occasions. Among Mrs. Cole's best known horses were My Love, Cherokee Princess and Checkmate.

title: Lawrence E. Delmar Marries Evelyn Eman
description: In the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday Evelyn Kay Eman, president of Perception +, public relations consultants in Colorado Springs, was married to Lawrence Edward Delmar, vice president of the Integrated Communications Corporation in Colorado Springs. The Rev. Clifford Johnson performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The other night, a group of people clutching floor plans gathered in an office off East 149th Street to sign contracts on the first homes that most of them would ever own.

title: SIGMA MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NURSING HOME CARE: A GUIDE PROVIDES STEP-BY STEP ADVICE
description: The situation arises suddenly. An elderly relative is felled by a stroke. The hospital says recovery prospects are good but the relative can no longer live on his or her own. A nursing home must be found immediately.

title: Striking Greeks Block Entrance to U.S. Base
description: Hundreds of Greek workers on strike at four United States military installations blocked the entrance today to the Hellinikon base at Athens Airport, virtually closing the installation.

title: POPE VOWS TO ASSIST BANK STUDY
description: Pope John Paul II pledged the Vatican's full cooperation with Italian authorities today in the investigation of the relationship between the Vatican bank and Italy's largest private bank, which collapsed last summer.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Pistons said goodbye to their high-scoring forward, Kelly Tripucka, for six to eight weeks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chinese Petroleum Corp. of Taiwan said it had imported one million barrels of crude oil from Egypt through the Amoco subsidiary of Standard Oil Co. (Indiana) for $32 (U.S.) a barrel, marking its first oil purchase from Egypt.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
STUDENTS EXPLOITING HOLIDAY BREAK
description: They spilled into Greenwich Village, sporting college uniforms of down jackets, Norwegian sweaters, tweedy sport jackets, Norma Kamalistyle sweats and the occasional letter sweater.

title: RECESSION IN EASTERN EUROPE FORCES REAPPRAISALS OF POLICY
description: Poland's empty shop windows are only the most extreme manifestation of the hard times setting in throughout Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as the worldwide economic slowdown catches up with the centrally planned Communist economies. In all these countries, the rates of economic expansion are slowing and are likely to continue slowing, and shortages of manufactured goods and food are becoming more acute. The Soviet Union's harvest was poor again this year, and its new five-year economic plan projects the lowest growth ever for industrial output.

title: FROM FIRE TO FLOOD, THEY CLEAN UP DISASTERS
description: Fires are routine for Ron Alford. So are floods. He figures he tackles several exploding furnaces a year. He does blown-up eggs. He does moth balls. He's good on blood.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEMOIRS OF SLAVERY

title: BOMBS SPUR KANSAS EVACUATION
description: A man who said he was ill and needed help tried to extort $2 million from a bank today by planting three bombs in the downtown area and attempting to wire dynamite to a bank clerk, the Dodge City police said.

title: POP: MCLEAN'S 'ANNIVERSARY'
description: Don McLean's folk-pop ballad, ''American Pie,'' 10 years old, still marks a watershed in pop history because it codified the rock mythology of the previous two decades while issuing a roll-call of the dead, from Buddy Holly to Janis Joplin.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REJECTS NAMIBIA PROPOSAL
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa said today that his Government rejected any suggestion that Cuban troops in Angola could be replaced by a foreign peacekeeping force to break the impasse in talks to negotiate independence for neighboring South-West Africa.

title: ON THE NEED FOR A MANHATTAN CONNECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: INCOME REPORTS UNDER CITY LAW CURBED BY COURT
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a constitutional right to privacy had been violated by a New York City law requiring police and fire officials to disclose details of their personal finances if they earn $30,000 a year or more.

title: U.S. Leads France In Davis Cup, 2 to 0
description: John McEnroe trailed, two sets to one, Yannick Noah was serving and hitting the ball like Ivan Lendl. France was poised for a rousing start to the Davis Cup final against the United States today at the Palais des Sportes.

title: FED FUNDS IN AMPLE SUPPLY
description: The Federal Reserve is providing the banking system with an ample supply of funds at the same time that business credit demands are weakening, according to Fed data published late yesterday.

title: Penn State Rallies To Overcome Pitt
description: Todd Blackledge brought Penn State from behind once again for a 19-10 victory today over Pitt. Penn State, which has never been the top-ranked team in the final polls following the bowl games, is now virtually assured of the No.1 ranking if it beats Georgia in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Night.

title: Solar Flare Expected to Bring Northern Lights Show Sunday
description: Residents of some states might be treated to a display of northern lights late Sunday because of a major solar flare detected on Thanksgiving Day, Government scientists reported today.

title: John Sussek 3d Marries Emily Russell in Georgia
description: Emily Russell, daughter of Lieut. Col., Walter B. Russell Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Russell of Avondale Estates, Ga., was married yesterday to John Sussek 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sussek Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. John A. Via performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Decatur, Ga.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * AFG Industries filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 900,000 shares, through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: SMUCKER, J M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dr. Kantrowitz Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Lisa Robin Kantrowitz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian Kantrowitz of Pontiac, Mich., was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Elliott Fankuchen, son of Faye Fankuchen of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Dr. Sam X. Fankuchen. Rabbi Allen S. Kaplan performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Are Killed and 8 Injured As Bus Crashes in Texas
description: A bus overturned in a rainstorm this afternoon and rolled into a ditch, killing a teen-ager and an elderly woman and injuring at least eight others, the officials said.

title: Referee, 41, Dies Of Heart Attack
description: A basketball referee collapsed tonight during a tournament game between Tulane and Wyoming, and a spokesman at Baptist Hospital said he died about an hour later.

title: DOW GAINS 7.36 POINTS, TO 1,007.36
description: Adhering to its usual post-Thanksgiving Day pattern, the stock market rose yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.36 points, to 1,007.36. Its loss for the week was 13.89 points. Selected retail issues were among the better performers. Precious-metal stocks, reflecting higher prices for gold bullion, also moved in the forefront of the general advance.

title: THE PERENNIAL QUESTION: WHOM AND HOW TO TIP
description: Among the most frequent requests from readers are those for information on the correct amount and method of tipping in restaurants. Although much has been written on the subject, many people apparently are ill at ease when called upon to tip.

title: JAZZ: ELVIN JONES QUARTET
description: The jazz drummer Elvin Jones has always preferred to lead groups that do not use a piano on the theory that this creates a challenge for the other members.

title: Your Money; Withholding On Pensions
description: MILLIONS of Americans are aware by now that withholding on interest and dividends will begin next July 1. But less known to the public is the fact that there will also be withholding on pensions and annuities - and that, in many instances, this withholding will start next Jan. 1.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 9 P.M.) Fordham vs. Syracuse at Carrier Dome, Syracuse, N.Y., 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV FM, 90.7; WNYE 91.5 FM, 7:55 P.M.).

title: El Al Closing Is Delayed
description: Employees of Israel's national airline, El Al, today foiled - at least temporarily - a planned move by management to put the company into voluntary liquidation.

title: Gretzky Extends Streak
description: Pat Hughes, a right wing, scored with 3 minutes 4 seconds remaining tonight to complete a rally that gave the Edmonton Oilers a 6-5 victory over the Winnipeg Jets in a National Hockey League game.

title: LEE PATRICK, ACTRESS PLAYED SECRETARY IN 'MALTESE FALCON'
description: Lee Patrick, who portrayed Sam Spade's secretary, Effie, in two versions of ''The Maltese Falcon,'' and Cosmo Topper's dotty wife on television, died of a heart seizure Sunday, the day before her 71st birthday, it was announced here today.

title: GATEWAY PARK SETBACK NEEDS A REVERSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Copelan Racing On Coast Today
description: Copelan, coming off a disappointing fourth-place finish in the Young America at Meadowlands, makes his West Coast debut Saturday in the $107,850 Prevue Stakes at Hollywood Park.

title: BY TV, JURORS HAVE THANKSGIVING VISIT
description: Home is 300 miles away for the sequestered jurors hearing a triple-murder case, but they got to spend a little time with their families on Thanksgiving Day, by closed-circuit television.

title: Lakers 117, Clippers 115
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 32 points, including a decisive basket with 27 seconds left, to lead Los Angeles.

title: Canada Accepts Division Of Northwest Territories
description: The Canadian Government, in a landmark decision recognizing a 20-year fight by Eskimos of the Northwest Territories, today accepted division of the huge region into two governments.

title: Devils Demote Broten
description: The New Jersey Devils, looking for help as well as a victory, gave up on one of their young players en route to their game in Vancounver last night.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $284,598 for the qr and $868,000 for the yr and income from discontinued operations of $510,095 for the qr and $895,227 for the yr

title: DRUGS IN PSYCHIATRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Perkins Complains to League
description: Leon Bright of the Giants was in fine condition except for a sprained neck today, but Coach Ray Perkins remained upset about the tackle that knocked Bright out of Thursday's 13-6 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: A WRITER'S COLLECTION
description: THIS QUIET DUST. By William Styron. 305 pages. Random House. $17.50.

title: Union's Casino Bid Rejected by U.S.
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that a union that has been trying to organize security guards at casinos in Atlantic City is not a legitimate labor organization and cannot continue its efforts.

title: W.G. Morton Jr. Weds Miss Halleron
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, Margaret Rose Halleron, manager of the Union Pacific Foundation in New York, was married to William Gilbert Morton Jr., a senior vice president and director of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read.

title: BULLETPROOF BOXER IS HEALTHY AGAIN
description: For one month last summer, Jeff Sims was ranked 10th among heavyweights by the World Boxing Council. ''Then I got health problems,'' he said. The health problems were due to a bullet that had been shot into his left shoulder, a bullet shot into his left side and another into his right buttock.

title: Seafirst Calls Off Alaska Merger
