description: Action by the Seafirst Corporation, the holding company of Seattle-First National Bank, to acquire Alaska Mutual Bank has been called off, Alaska Mutual said.

title: Examiners Find No Fraud at Itel
description: Court-appointed examiners for the Itel Corporation, a Los Angeles-based financial services company now in bankruptcy proceedings, said in a report that the company collapsed in 1981 because of its former management's ''style and attitudes, weak controls, major business problems and heavy debt.'' Itel's current management announced earlier this week that it had cooperated in the investigation.

title: Sonics' Thompson Out
description: David Thompson, whose 19.2 points-a-game scoring average helped the Seattle SuperSonics roll to 13 victories in their first 15 National Basketball Association games this season, has been sidelined indefinitely with a knee problem. The 6-foot-4-inch guard, who was traded to the Sonics last summer after spending seven seasons with the Denver Nuggets, did not play Friday night in Seattle against Denver because of an accumulation of fluid in his right knee.

title: In-fra-struc-ture
description: What's a 14-letter word that means all things to all politicians? It creates 320,000 jobs, fills potholes, doubles the gas tax, fixes subways and trims the Federal deficit. ''Infrastructure'' has become Washington's new anthem. President Reagan, swallowing his objection to new taxes and to Federal funding for local streets, has finally joined the chorus.

title: THE ODD COUPLE
description: Between now and the end of the year, much will depend on whether President Reagan and Speaker Tip O'Neill get together and talk privately and seriously about the economic crisis of the nation.

title: RABE'S 'STREAMERS' SEETHES WITH RAGE
description: LINDENHURST AWORLD WAR I British musical recording, ''I Didn't Raise My Boy to Be a Soldier,'' is played before the Studio Theater's staging of David Rabe's ''Streamers'' starts - and we know, straightaway, that we're in for more than a bit of universal, timeless irony.

title: MEDIAN PRICE OF JERSEY HOME SAID TO HAVE TRIPLED SINCE '70
description: The median price of a home in New Jersey nearly tripled between 1970 and 1980, according to figures released by the Census Bureau.

title: THE ISRAELI OPPOSITION WANTS NO AID CUTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain's Best
description: To the Editor: In reference to the article by Erica Brown, ''Britain's Best on Exhibit'' (Travel, Oct. 17), I would like to add that no one should miss the National Railroad Museum in York, a short five-minute walk from the gloriously Edwardian train station. All manner of railroadiana is there, including royal cars, and there are slide shows and lectures and innumerable steam giants.

title: CHRYSLER'S SPORTS SEDAN
description: ORIGINALITY hasn't been much of a key word in Detroit for a long time, but Chrysler Corporation does seem to have come up with an unusual new idea: a $40,000 car for $10,000.

title: Mitsuko Honda Fiancee Of S.Sgt. David Ornauer
description: Mitsuko Honda of Tokyo will be married there Dec. 27 to S.Sgt. David Stephen Ornauer of the Air Force. Miss Honda is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kinjiro Honda of Suwa, Japan.

title: Gale Carothers Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William K. Carothers of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gale Ann Carothers, to Donald Jonathan Clark Freeman, son of Mrs. Kenneth Clark Freeman of Rahway, N.J., and the late Mr. Freeman. Miss Carothers is a buyer for Herman's World of Sporting Goods in Carteret, N.J. Mr. Freeman is national customer service manager for Volvo Recreation Products, a Rockleigh, N.J., division of the Volvo of America Corporation. A May wedding is planned.

title: A TRIBUTE TO MEDICAL BULLETIN
description: Just before Christmas 1932, James E. Bryan, a young Wesleyan University graduate from Asbury Park, N.J., answered a two-line advertisement in the old New York Herald Tribune and soon became the first administrator of the Westchester County Medical Society, which was founded in 1797. As part of the job, he was also the first managing editor of the society's Westchester Medical Bulletin. Now a writer and consultant living in Washington, D.C., Mr. Bryan was a guest speaker recently at a dinner in Purchase marking the Bulletin's 50th anniversary. The following is adapted from his remarks.

title: STUDENTS PICK UP PROS' JAZZ BEAT
description: STONY BROOK ''THE blues all come from this - these 12 bars - and then you take off. But you've got to be able to write it down. Charlie Parker did it that way; wrote it down the way he wanted it to go.''

title: Kindest Veteran
description: To the Sports Editor: In 1975, I received an invitation to try out for the New York Giants football team. I arrived at their training site in Pleasantville, New York, and I was assigned with the running backs.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: STEVEN had his day in court, and the outcome was just ducky. Steven is, in fact, a duck, specifically a hybrid domestic duck. He has lived in the Port Washington area in the care of Jeanette Scaros for more than a year, ever since she spotted him by a pond.

title: Guns Reported to Kill 440,000 In U.S. Since Kennedy's Death
description: Since Nov. 22, 1963, when President Kennedy was mortally wounded by a shot from ambush, more than 440,000 Americans have been killed by gunfire in their own country. And, according to an advocate of gun licensing, the nation still lacks an adequate firearms policy.

title: Florida Faculty Asked For Review of Football
description: The president of the University of Florida, Robert Q. Marston, said today that he had asked his faculty committee on intercollegiate athletics to look into reports of possible recruiting violations in the football program.

title: Polish Jokes
description: The Illinois division of the Polish-American Congress feels strongly about Polish jokes. In 1976 it petitioned the United States Supreme Court to grant it equal time on ABC-TV to respond to four Polish jokes told on an evening talk show.

title: INDUSTRIAL TIME CLOCKS-OFTEN AT ODDS WITH THOSE INSIDE A WORKER'S BODY
description: SCOTT NIELSON, a potash harvester in Ogden, Utah, is a happy man these days. Thanks to a newly designed shift schedule at the Great Salt Lake Minerals and Chemicals Corporation where he works, Mr. Nielson now sleeps only 6 1/2 hours a night, gets along better with his co-workers and no longer imagines his wife is being ''ornerier than usual'' every time he works the graveyard shift.

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE LITTLE HOUSE FROM THE PRAIRIE
description: In 1914, workers completed one of Frank Lloyd Wright's most spectacular houses, a large residence in Wayzata, Minn., built for Mr. and Mrs. Francis Little. About 60 years later, the house was headed for demolition until its impending doom was brought to the attention of the Metropolitan Museum of Art by a former apprentice to Wright, Edgar Tafel, a New York architect.

title: 'KOSINSKI IS WORTHY OF OUR SUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:

title: OF PALS AND POLS
description: Any day now you're suddenly going to hear a lot of politicians being ''mentioned'' as good Presidential candidates, and I'd like to do some ''mentioning'' of my own before the hullabaloo becomes overpowering. For this reason I herewith ''mention'' Senator Howard Baker.

title: A NOVEL AND SOME STORIES
description: PROMISE THE EARTH By Clive Irving. 402 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. A QUIVER FULL OF ARROWS By Jeffrey Archer. 189 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $9.95.

title: LETTERS
description: The Primacy of Performance

title:
GARDENING;
SOME HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR THE GARDENER
description: IF all those on my holiday gift list were gardeners, shopping would be much easier. There are so many garden-oriented gifts to choose from, and many can be selected from bookstores, garden centers or mail-order catalogues.

title: 34 on Seychelles Raid Freed by South Africa
description: Thirty-four mercenaries convicted of air piracy in a bungled attempt to overthrow the Seychelles Government last year were given time off for good behavior and released today after four months in prison.

title: ANDROGYNY EXPLORED AS ART THEME
description: OUR era of openness encourages the presentation of subjects that might have once been considered awkward. This is very much the case with ''Androgyny in Art,'' a broad exploration of sexual duality on view at the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University. It deals with spirituality, philosophy, transformations, psychic states and private obsessions, with results that appeal to the intellect as well as to the eye.

title: Caroline Coleman Is Married
description: Caroline Comstock Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Simmmons Coleman of New Canaan, Conn., was married in St. Mark's Episcopal Church there yesterday to the Rev. Frank Charles Strasburger, an assistant rector of the church and son of Charles Milton Strasburger of Baltimore and the late Mrs. Strasburger. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. John Booty, dean of the School of Theology of the University of the South, and the Rev. Alfred Whisler, rector of St. Mark's.

title: UNAUTHORIZED
description: To the Editor:

title: FAREWELL MY LOVELY
description: As the collect telephone call comes to an end, the kid in college says, ''Lay-tuh!'' The parental voice replies, ''Buh-bye.'' The rich and varied language of farewells is thus advanced. In olden times, a few years ago, the collegiate call would be ''See you later, alligator.'' From this neo-Cockney rhyming source, by the natural process of shortening, seeya became popular; recently, the end of that first phrase, later, has come into its own. With the emphasis on the final syllable, the favored farewell is lay-TUH.

title: STEVENS DESIGNING NEW LANDING CRAFT
description: HOBOKEN FROM combat on Iwo Jima to peacekeeping in Beirut, the Marine Corps often begins its missions by hitting the beaches. At times, however, landing craft have become stuck on sandbars and there have been agonizingly slow, seasickness-inducing trips to the beaches.

title: Agent Accused of; Misusing Skills
description: H. Edward Tickel Jr., a Federal Bureau of Investigation specialist in court-ordered safecracking and break-ins, was accused last week of illegally moonlighting.

title: CITY DRINKING WATER RUNS UPSTATE GENERATOR
description: The State Power Authority today dedicated a small hydroelectric plant that generates electricity by using New York City drinking water stored in the Ashokan Reservoir here.

title: JERSEY CITY BEGINNING REPAIR OF DETERIORATED WATER SYSTEM
description: Jersey City is embarking on a six-year repair program for its deteriorated water supply system, which in the last year and a half has had four major breaks.

title: Tacking This Way and That
description: President Reagan and his crew, apparently concerned about the political effects of not attempting to do something about the deadin-the water economy, were back at their charts last week.

title: Taube Levine Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham I. Levine of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Taube Levine, to Ira Korn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Korn of Monsey, N.Y. A March wedding is planned. Miss Levine is doing graduate work in occupational therapy at Columbia University. Mr. Korn is a rabbinical candidate at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary of Yeshiva University and is a candidate for his master's degree in computer science at the Polytechnical Institute in New York.

title: ENTER THE DUTCH NATIONAL BALLET
CONCERTS, SING-INS, FOLK TUNES AND MORE READIED
description: THE Pleasantville Chamber Music Society, using some form of financial wizardry, continues to present great musicians in concert as an ongoing cultural gift to the community. ''We open our sixth season with many more patrons and sponsors than gave us support last year,'' said Joseph Goodman, a member of the society's planning committee.

title: SOVIET WORKERS WARNED TO GET CRACKING-OR ELSE
description: When Yuri V. Andropov addressed the Communist Party Central Committee last week, the new leader spoke first and longest about economic problems. Rather than vaunting Soviet progress as Leonid I. Brezhnev did before turning to shortcomings, Mr. Andropov gave it straight.

title: Labor 'Dropout'
description: For seven years, Randy Reagan of Wyandotte, Mich., made good money working for a supplier of corrosion-resistant metals for the auto and building industries. When these industries sagged, Mr. Reagan was laid off.

title: Michael Willner Weds Ellen Katz, an Oboist
description: The marriage of Ellen Katz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Katz of Fort Lee, N.J., to Michael Willner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Willner of North Miami, Fla., took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GRAVEN IMAGES By Paul Fleischman. Illustrated by Andrew Glass. 85 pp. New York: Harper & Row/ Charlotte Zolotow. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 13)By ANN CAMERON

title: Trade Parley Turns Sour
description: In Geneva last week, the strains of world economic crisis made the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade look more like general disagreement. Many officials called the third ministerial session since 1948 a failure.

title: ROOSEVELT STADIUM: GLORY FADING FAST
description: JERSEY CITY IN YEARS gone by, Thanksgiving mornings at Roosevelt Stadium were filled with life as the St. Peter's Prep and Dickinson High School football teams renewed their long-standing rivalry. Two years ago, that rivalry was suspended. Now the ballpark itself approaches its end.

title: Bradley Razook, Mary D'Agostino To Marry Feb. 12
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. D'Agostino of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Josephine D'Agostino, to Bradley G. Razook, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Razook of Rye and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: POLICE CONTINUE SERCH FOR STOLEN MAYAN JADE
description: Over the Sept. 24 weekend, 25 Mayan jade artifacts were stolen from a display case in the Hall of Mexico and Central America on the second floor of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Letters; Cheaper Power
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS GOOLAGONG IN FINAL
description: Evonne Goolagong Cawley of Australia upset Andrea Jaeger today to advance to the final of the $125,000 New South Wales Open.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHY AND SCULPTURE IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK AT THE City Without Walls gallery here are two photography exhibitions of much more than usual interest. And a few blocks away, at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, is an opportunity to see the recent metal sculpture of Paul Sisko, one of the best-known artists from this area.

title: 24 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violating the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and five that were closed after failing to do so.

title: LETTERS
description: The Great Stagnation Lester Thurow's analysis of the current difficulties facing the American economy provided a convincing description of the structural causes of the present depression (''The Great Stagnation,'' Oct. 17). His portrayal of the inadequacies of current policy initiatives was a compelling one.

title: A HAND ON THE CITY BUDGET AND AN EYE ON REVENUES
description: Fighting broke out on another front in New York City's battle of the budget last week. Nearly all of Mayor Koch's fellow members on the Board of Estimate served notice that they would try to change his latest plan to close deficits projected at $1.6 billion over the next 19 months. City Council President Carol Bellamy was particularly irked that the Mayor seemed to be ''throwing overboard'' $20 million of the $48 million in modifications the board and the Council made in June. And even as Mr. Koch warned in a memo to city department heads that layoffs might be needed after all - he issued a similar alarm earlier this month, only to change his mind 24 hours later -Harrison J. Goldin, the City Comptroller, challenged the Mayor's conclusion that the city could not afford 1,000 new police officers. ''I cannot believe this program will emerge unscathed,'' said Edward L. Sadowsky, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Council, which must approve the $22 million in new and increased taxes Mr. Koch is seeking this fiscal year and the $200 million he wants in the year beginning July 1. Another official with a say in the matter is Comer S. Coppie, Executive Director of the Emergency Financial Control Board, which must approve the city's fiscal plan. Mr. Coppie discussed the budget problems and the Mayor's proposed solutions last week with Josh Barbanel, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe for bishop's bread in the Nov. 14 issue of The New York Times Magazine should have called for one-quarter pound of unsalted butter.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR THE GARDENER
description: IF all those on my holiday gift list were gardeners, shopping would be much easier. There are so many garden-oriented gifts to choose from, and many can be selected from bookstores, garden centers or mail-order catalogues.

title: WARNER EXECUTIVE CONVICTED OF FRAUD IN PURCHASE OF THEATER STOCK
description: An executive of Warner Communications was convicted yesterday of fraudulently arranging the company's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: DAIRY FARMERS TO BEGIN PAYING FEE ON SALES
description: Procedures were announced Friday under which dairy farmers will begin helping to pay for the program of milk price supports that costs the Government $2 billion a year.

title: Miss Burks, Paul Becker To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. William Parnelle Burks of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hollister Burks, to Paul Avery Becker, son of Roland George Becker and the Rev. Jane Barnes Becker of Westborough, Mass.

title: OPINION;
description: IN this callous, suspicious, competitive world of today, does it still pay to do a good deed? Are there any heroes left? One must begin to wonder.

title: Future Events; Out Every Night
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Dutch Treat Dec. 1 - A black-tie ''Sinterklaas-Feest'' (Santa Claus Feast) at Gage & Tollner, Brooklyn's landmark restaurant, will follow the opening performance by the Dutch National Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Leopold Quarles van Ufford, Consul General of the Netherlands, will be guest of honor. The troupe from Amsterdam is the third in BAM's Ballet International Series presented in association with the Doll-Lepercq International Dance Fund. Tickets for gala evening to benefit BAM, $125.

title: CAUTIOUS AGGRANDIZERS OF POWER
description: BUREAUCRATIC DEMOCRACY The Search for Democracy and Efficiency in American Government. By Douglas Yates. 224 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.50.

title: NO SUNGLASSES FOR TEX COBB
description: HOUSTON SOMEBODY in the entourage usually has the sunglasses, just in case the fighter needs them. Through the years, most of boxing's most famous gladiators were never ashamed to hide a damaged face behind those sunglasses when they left the arena. Muhammad Ali, Joe Frazier, Joe Louis, Rocky Marciano, Sugar Ray Robinson, they all slipped on shades at one time or another so they wouldn't look too bad in the newspaper photos. Sugar Ray Leonard, his left eye swollen and shut, even wore sunglasses in the interview area only half an hour after his 14th-round knockout of Thomas Hearns in Las Vegas last year. Cool.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS TOP JAZZ, 126-113, AS MALONE HAS 32

title: Fare Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Crete
description: To the Editor:

title: That Season
description: It is at the end of November, usually on a Sunday afternoon, that one is suddenly reminded of what the past 11 months have so kindly erased. On that afternoon the passenger in the cab trapped in traffic on Manhattan's East Side is told that it's all those people who came out to shop.

title: Watt Appeases Governors on Coal Leasing
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt may be controversial but he can read election returns as well as anybody.

title: CONNECTICUT'S BUMPY ROADS
description: HARTFORD THE 10-year plan to resurface and repair Connecticut's highway system sent by the state Department of Transportation to the General Assembly last year contained page after page of trouble spots, but the drawing on the cover said it all. It was a large dollar sign.

title: COST AN OBSTACLE TO A 911 SYSTEM
description: HARTFORD AS the call to 911 for emergency assistance was dialed, a digital readout at the public-safety answering point immediately flashed the telephone number from where the call originated.

title: Michael Moran Weds Sheila Claire Monagan
description: Shelia Claire Monagan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Mulry Monagan of Waterbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Thomas Moran, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William L. Moran Jr. of New York. The Rev. James O'Dea performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John of the Cross in Middlebury, Conn.

title: FALSE BURGLARY ALARMS SURGE
description: FIRST there were the burglars, then there were the burglar alarms, and now police departments in the Hamptons must contend with a growing number of false alarms.

title: JERSEY CITY OFFERS WATER-FEE BOUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY WHEN it comes to water and accounting, Jersey City has been down on its luck lately. In July, an aqueduct ruptured, leaving the city without water for days. And in September, investigators unearthed widespread abuses and poor accounting practices in the Jersey City Redevelopment Agency.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eddie Robinson, the football coach at Grambling State University who has won more than 300 games and sent more than 200 players on to professional football, will receive the Walter Camp Football Foundation's 1982 Distinguished American Award at a dinner at Yale Feb. 12. ... Kent Hrbek, the first baseman who had an outstanding rookie year with the Minnesota Twins, has been named to the board of governors of the National ALS Foundation. Hrbek's father died last September of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), the neuromuscular disease that killed Lou Gehrig in 1941. ... Because of a recurring back injury which he aggravated last week in an exhibition match against Bjorn Borg, Jimmy Connors will not play on the American team in the three-day Europe vs. America tennis tournament.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT MICHIGAN'S BUSINESS SCHOOL;
HOW TO TAME THE COMPUTER
description: How do you know if you're managing your computer system - or it's managing you? Don't just look at how well your needs are being met, suggests Professors Robert Mautz, Alan Merten and Dennis Severance, whose popular courses teach students not just to use computers in management decision-making but how to be wary of conflicts between the computers and the people who use them.

title: EXPLOITATION COLORS 'THE EXECUTIONER'S SONG'
description: An unusual feature of ''The Executioner's Song,'' the dramatization of Norman Mailer's praised and popular book about Gary Gilmore, is the appearance of a character called Larry Samuels. He represents Lawrence Schiller, the show's producer-director, who out-bargained David Susskind and others for the exclusive book and film rights to the story of the murderer whose demand to be executed turned him into a media superstar in the mid-70's. The four-hour adaptation begins tonight at 9 on NBC and concludes tomorrow night.

title: MAGNETIC DEVICE LIFTS HOPES FOR DIAGNOSIS WITHOUT X-RAY
description: Radiologists say they have developed another revolutionary technique for medical diagnosis that they expect to perform significantly better and more safely than the advanced X-rays that overtook the field only a decade ago.

title: Provence
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CONDUCTOR AS ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: Someday, if man and all archeological evidence of his existence have managed to escape incineration, cultural historians may look at the last half of this century and wonder how the symphony orchestra conductor could possibly have become extinct at the height of his power and glory. For, improbable though it might seem to us now, when renowned though sometimes modestly gifted conductors can become multimillionaires whose names are clues on television game shows, the chances for their surviving - at least in their traditional role as conduit between audience and composer - look dim. The principal reason their disappearance is likely is that conductors have lost the tight one-to-one connection with living composers that traditionally has provided the performing musician with his reason for existence. The conductor's most important job is to find new music an [ TEXT OMITTED ] Granted, it is entirely possible that the symphony orchestra conductor will survive in any of several roles superficially similar to his present one. But, barring some cultural upheaval still unforeseen, he is fated to play a part profoundly different from that of his predecessors in earlier centuries. Spenglerian thinkers have been suggesting for some time that Western music is entering a period of dormancy or decline, like the classical art of certain ancient civilizations. If that is so, the conductor could become our version of the Kabuki artist, the singer-actor-dancer who has for centuries been entrusted with the duty of preserving a Japanese performance tradition that long ago passed into that shimmering state of stability known as entropy.

title: WOMEN WRITERS
description: To the Editor:

title: On Mexico
description: To the Business Editor: ''Mexico's Cambridge Connection'' (Oct.24), your presentation of the Cambridge economists' analysis of that economy and our role in policy formation, was seriously misleading in some ways.

title: EMPHASIS IS LIKELY TO BE ON ARMS, NOT ARMS CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON THE mood music from Washington and Moscow in the last few weeks has been comparatively upbeat. Leaders on both sides were busy welcoming each other's protestations about improving relations and getting on with the business of arms control.

title: POP: PETER GABRIEL STRIKES A BALANCE
description: Peter Gabriel's songs are often about conflict, about opposing cultures and philosphies and individuals, and his music is rife with opposing tendencies. His background is in art-rock, in spectacle and sweep and classical borrowings. But he is most interested now in music that is rawer, fiercer, more rhythmically alive, than with borrowings from African music and punk rock.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FRIENDS Written and illustrated by Helme Heine. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $10.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Robert DeSanctis, 85, City Veterans Official
description: Robert J. DeSanctis, a former New York City welfare official and director of the city's Division of Veterans Affairs, died last Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan.

title: 'Robert Lowell'
description: THOUGH there were rival claimants, Robert Lowell throned it over American poetry for 20 years. He was determined to be at the center of his age, as he thought Hart Crane had been at the center of the 20's. He dexterously maintained his position during the seedy affluence following World War II, the rebelliousness of the Vietnam generation and the slackness that came after. In the form as well as the subject matter of his poems he registered dissent. His early poems, we now learn, were in free verse. Later, under the influence of new critical theories, he revolted toward strict forms; at this point William Carlos Williams called him ''a tiger behind bars.'' He uncaged himself in ''Life Studies'' and subsequent volumes. In response to internal as well as external challenges, he adopted various strategies. His aim was to make himself a representative man, whose reactions to war, politics, love, family and friends would add up to archetypal completeness. For a man so unlike other men, it was a singular ambition. That he largely achieved it was a triumph.

title: ESTATE DIVISION: A LONG ROAD
description: IN 1915, Dr. Dennistoun Bell bought 155 acres in Amagansett, the first of many parcels he was to purchase as he patiently amassed an estate that covered 550 acres and included a 21-room Georgian-style mansion, four guest cottages and many outbuildings by the time he died in 1954. The process of breaking up what Dr. Bell assembled over four decades has not been quite as prolonged, but it, too, has required considerable patience.

title: U.S. DECISION NEAR ON NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The Reagan Administration is close to approving a proposal that would require on-site inspection as a condition for ratifying two treaties with the Soviet Union on underground nuclear testing, according to Administration officials.

title:
DINING OUT;
HOMEGROWN COOKING IN TEANECK
description: A few years back, when the construction business took a downturn, Cliff Fowlin decided to try his hand at cooking for a living. Having learned to cook at his mother's knee in Jamaica, Mr. Fowlin started out by delivering his homemade lunches by bicycle. Then, three years ago, he and his wife, Ann, took the plunge and opened an informal storefront restaurant in what had been an antiques shop in Teaneck.

title: CANADA FOCUSES ON ITS VERSION OF SUPER BOWL
description: In this quietly fractious country, where the French feel alienated from the English, the agricultural west complains about the industrial east and just about everybody is uneasy over the enormous American influence, many Canadians argue that the professional football championship game Sunday is a centerpiece reflecting that ephemeral quality known as Canadian nationalism.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT MICHIGAN'S BUSINESS SCHOOL;
OF MERGERS, SYNERGY AND THE STOCKHOLDER'S GAINS
description: In the state with the highest unemployment rate, where bankruptcies reach record levels every month, the Graduate School of Business at the University of Michigan is something of an anomaly. Unlike many other graduate business schools, Michigan is enjoying a rise in enrollments and its dean, Gilbert R. Whitaker Jr., recently raised $10 million for a library and a new computer-executive education center. The school, however, has not been untouched by Michigan's economic malaise. Its long-time drawing card, the accounting department, is losing students at a fast pace to such fields as finance and computer science, where starting salaries are much higher. Michigan, however, remains one of the strongest research schools in the country, according to business scholars. Here is a look at some of the work going on now at the Ann Arbor campus.

title: Louisa Gebelein Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Louisa Allen Gebelein to Jeremiah Walcott Jones has been announced by Mrs. Bruce Crawford of Grafton, Mass., mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Anstiss D. Jones of Manchester, Mass., and the late Arthur M. Jones.

title: GLoomy Words On Jobs and Race
description: Some analysts cite factors such as age or education to explain the high percentage of black and Hispanic Americans who are out of work. Last week, though, the United States Commission on Civil Rights, reporting on a three-year study of minority unemployment, said that the fundamental cause was persistent racial discrimination.

title: AMERICAN COOT; Fulica americana
description: Size: 13 to 16 inches. Color: Slate gray with black head and neck.

title: YOUTH FILM-ADMISSION CURB STIRS DEBATE
description: AGERS who want to catch an evening performance of ''E.T.'' at the Movieland theater complex in Yonkers are finding that they must now be accompanied by an adult.

title: MUSIC: CHICAGO ART ENSEMBLE
description: Sometimes the Art Ensemble of Chicago comes up with wise, ambiguous group improvisations. Sometimes it's just a bunch of virtuoso wise guys.

title: India and China to Hold Talks
description: India and China will hold talks in Peking in January on their longstanding border dispute, the Press Trust of India reported today. The news agency said final dates had yet to be fixed.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 9 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 13 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 4 14 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle. (Putnam's, $6.95.) Abridged, profusely illustrated version of the novelization of the current film. 4 3 13 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) Continuing the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 5 5 7 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction, sequel to ''The Foundation Trilogy.'' 6 6 3 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 7 7 3 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Continuing the journey through the solar system begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 8 8 10 CROSSINGS, by Danielle Steel.

title: POSSIBLE WEST GERMAN NEUTRALISM?
description: Today, 33 years after the founding of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, West Germany's ties to the Atlantic alliance and the European Community are dangerously frayed. Were West Germany to find itself cut off from these two postwar anchors to the West, it would be seriously tempted to seek a neutralist solution to the question of West Germany's place in Europe. To prevent such a shift, NATO must revise its military strategy in order to create a realistic alternative to using nuclear weapons against a Soviet conventional attack in Europe.

title: TURMOIL OVER TOKENS BREWS AN INTERSTATE TIFF
description: NOT since the Civil War, some joked last week, had two states battled so much. Charges were traded, negotiations broke down and - although no shots were fired - prisoners were taken into custody.

title: Melissa Apperson Becomes a Bride
description: Melissa Heywood Apperson, daughter of Brig. Gen. Jack A. Apperson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Apperson, of Glenside, Pa., and Narragansett, R.I., was married yesterday at the home of her parents, to Steven Bruce Bloomfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sylvan Bloomfield of Kings Point, L.I. The Rev. Richard Shimpfky, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: FOLK-ROCK: R.E.M. USES FILTER OF PUNK
description: There was a jingle-jangle folk-rock guitar line or two at the center of every song R.E.M. played Thursday at the Peppermint Lounge. Those lines were authentically 1960's-style, down to the instruments they were played on, although many were in minor keys.

title: SCHOOLS INCREASE USE OF COMPUTERS
description: LAST year, Betsy Ratner had a computer ''at my disposal every minute of the day'' to help her teach gifted and talented children in Guilford's Melissa Jones Elementary School. This year, Mrs. Ratner has to scramble to find space on a crowded sign-up sheet for computer use at the school.

title: MT. VERNON TENANTS TO SUE CITY TO STAY
description: empty Willwood Gardens complex in September, has ordered the remaining 120 families to get out by Tuesday - but the tenants have said they won't go.

title: UNTHINKABLE CHITCHAT
description: WITH ENOUGH SHOVELS Reagan, Bush and Nuclear War. By Robert Scheer. Assisted by Narda Zacchino and Constance Matthiessen. 285 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: FAMILIES COUNT, AND SCHOOLS DO TOO
description: HIGH SCHOOL ACHIEVEMENT Public, Catholic and Private Schools Compared. By James S. Coleman, Thomas Hoffer and Sally Kilgore. 289 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.75.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE BALLAD OF JOHN AND YOKO By the Editors of Rolling Stone. Edited by Jonathan Cott and Christine Doudna. Illustrated. 317 pp. New York: A Rolling Stone Press Book/ Dolphin Books/Doubleday. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: HOW DO ZIGGY AND PAC-MAN CELEBRATE CHRISTMAS? BY MERCHANDISING
description: Ziggy has it made. Defeated but never destroyed, the short, potatoshaped figure appears on an estimated $180 million worth of T-shirts, greeting cards, socks, mugs and other paraphernalia, as well as, of course, in the widely syndicated newspaper comic strip. In that strip today, Ziggy, impossibly idealistic, bemoans the commercialism of Christmas. ''They sure are rushing the season,'' he clucks - until he sees something that changes his mind: a poster advertising ''Ziggy's Gift,'' a half-hour special to be shown Wednesday evening at 8 on ABC.

title: TRANQUIL & TREMBLING
description: TEACHING A STONE TO TALK Expeditions and Encounters. By Annie Dillard. 177 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: A Penny Saved ...
description: The plans, in honor of Philadelphia's 300th anniversary, called for a 103-foot-high monument consisting of a kite, a key and a bolt of lightning -the elements of Benjamin Franklin's experiment that proved lightning is electricity. The problem was no one wanted to pay for the electricity.

title: THE ARMY'S NEW FIGHTING DOCTRINE
description: Deborah Shapley is Washington editor of the British scientific journal Na-ture. She writes frequently about military affairs.Edward C. Meyer, the Chief of Staff of the Army, tells a story about a typical experience he had as commander of the Third Infantry Division in West Germany. During a gaming exercise in 1975, the enemy team simulated an attack through a mountain pass known as the Meiningen Gap, employing the relentless, tank-heavy approach the Warsaw Pact forces would be expected to use if they invaded Western Europe. The Third Infantry Division was defending the pass. ''I asked for permission to attack behind enemy lines,'' General Meyer says. ''My superiors had to relay the request all the way up to the highest level of Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers (Europe).'' By the time the request was approved and sent back down the chain of command, the enemy had attacked. When the exercise ran out, General Meyer's division faced defeat.

title: SMOLDERING LANDFILL JERSEY CITY LIABILITY
description: JERSEY CITY FEDERAL, state and local environmental authorities have acknowledged that, for 10 years now, they have not fully assessed the public-health dangers of a smoldering, continually erupting fire in an abandoned landfill here, nor determined the extent of the underground pollution that has fueled the fire.

title: EAST TIMOR'S FOOD SITUATION IS REPORTED IMPROVING
description: Western diplomats and international aid workers here who have traveled in East Timor over the last few months say that food supplies there are gradually increasing.

title: Wendy Rubicam Is Bride Of Robert Lorn Evans Jr.
description: The marriage of Wendy Rubicam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Rubicam of Old Greenwich, Conn., to Robert Lorn Evans Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Villanova, Pa., took place yesterday.

title: STATE LAUDED ON SCHOOL AID
description: IT LOOKS as if New Jersey will earn an ''A'' for its implementation of a major new Federal aid-to-education law. The legislation, Chapter 2 of the 1981 Education Consolidation and Improvement Act, consolidates into a block grant 28 separate Federal elementary- and secondary-school education programs ranging from basic-skills development to desegregation efforts.

title: LIPIZZANER STALLIONS PERFORM DRESSAGE AT GARDEN
description: The measured, gentle art of dressage came to New York on Friday, when the famed Lipizzaner Stallions of the Spanish Riding School of Vienna appeared at Madison Square Garden.

title: UNITED WAY GAINS OVER FIRST HALF OF '81
description: THE United Way of Westchester released a report on its 1982 fundraising campaign last week, indicating that its effort for the first six months of the year was more than $300,000 ahead of the same period last year.

title: U.S. Aide Held in India In Smuggling Inquiry
description: State Department officials say that a ranking American official of the United States Agency for International Development in New Delhi has been detained by Indian authorities and has been ''cooperating'' with their inquiry into dutiable goods seized at Delhi International Airport.

title: AFTER THE HOSPITAL ADDITIONAL CARE
description: WHEN 40-year-old Ellen Goodman's widowed mother, who was 70, was hospitalized after a massive stroke, the daughter's anxiety was limited to the fear of her mother's imminent death. She took a leave of absence from her job, left her husband in charge of the family and traveled the 90 miles to be at her mother's side.

title: A POPULAR LABORITE HOVERS IN AUSTRALIA'S POLITICAL SKY
description: Hundreds of jobless miners and steelworkers stormed Parliament in Canberra a few weeks ago while other workers marched in Melbourne demanding something be done about the downturn in the Lucky Country's prosperity. Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser happened to be in a hospital recovering from back surgery and the opposition Labor Party seized the moment to make political hay. Labor Leader William Hayden took to the newspapers to attack the Government's record on unemployment and inflation. But it was Robert Hawke, Labor spokesman on employment and industrial relations, who dominated the debate through television and showed that his political fortunes were on the upturn.

title: A DAMAGING FEAR OF RISING DEFICITS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1982
description: International An 88-nation meeting failed to agree on the question of how to shore up the world trading system. Failure of the participants in the four-day conference in Geneva of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to conclude fundamental agreements is likely to heighten the dangers of increased economic nationalism and protectionism. The conference had been called expressly to check the protectionism that has already been triggered by the worldwide recession and rising unemployment in most countries. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: ARMS OUTLAY A KEY ISSUE TO L.I. UNIT IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON AS members of Congress return to the capital tomorrow for a postelection session, the Long Island delegation will face a heavy workload with an eye out for defense spending that will affect the Island.

title: CAROLINA POSTMASTER ACTING TO GUARD CARRIERS FROM DOGS
description: After a letter carrier was disabled by a dog, officials here decided to place color-coded stickers on mailboxes.

title: RECYCLING DISPUTE IS REIGNITED
description: HEMPSTEAD WITH paint peeling from its twin smokestacks and rust spreading across its sheet-metal walls, the $145 million Hempstead Resource Recovery Plant stands idle beside the Meadowbrook Parkway at the very heart of Nassau County, a monument to a protracted dispute between the recycling plant's neighbors, its owners and town officials.

title: Andropov Gets; A Partial Salute
description: The 1,500 members of the Supreme Soviet, Russia's rubber-stamp Parliament, snapped their hands into the air on cue last week for Yuri V. Andropov. But for now they were only endorsing his appointment to the 39-member Presidium, which directs the Government on orders from the Communist Party - not putting him in charge of it.

title: LOWELL AND BERRYMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH SIGN AN ACCORD WITH INDIA TO FUEL U.S.-BUILT NUCLEAR PLANT
description: After four months of negotiations, France has formally agreed to supply enriched uranium for an American-built nuclear power plant near Bombay, spokesmen for the two Governments said today.

title: TIMES NEEDIEST CASES APPEAL OPENS
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened its 71st annual appeal today. The fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, in response to reports of hardship and misery among New York City's many destitute families. In the decades that followed, with a steadily growing number of benefactors and contributions to the fund, the yearly appeal has brought comfort to thousands of impoverished or distressed people in the New York metropolitan area who might otherwise be neglected or overlooked.

title: Dangerous Bees Destroyed
description: A small swarm of dangerous South American bees turned up in June in a container delivered to a marine terminal in Baltimore, and the insects were destroyed, Federal officials said this week. It was apparently only the second time the bees, which reportedly can kill humans, have reached this country, said Charles C. Jackson, head of the Department of Agriculture's Animal Plant Health Inspection Service.

title: Convention Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR OF TERROR BY ALBANIANS IN YUGOSLAVIA STRAINS UNITY
description: The convoy of 20 cars that arrived at the railway station on this dusty South Serbian plain on a Sunday afternoon was a wedding party, but also something of a political demonstration. The first and last cars bore red flags with twin black eagles topped by gold stars - the flag of the People's Socialist Republic of Albania.

title: A REDESIGNED WING ADDS LUSTER TO THE GUGGENHEIM
description: By the end of the present decade we simply won't recognize Manhattan Island in its relation to museums of modern art. The father and mother of them all - the Museum of Modern Art itself - will long have been in possession of its new and enlarged premises. The Metropolitan Museum's department of 20th-century art will occupy a large part of the projected new southwest wing. The Whitney Museum of American Art hopes to be all done with its projected extension to the south of the present museum. Wherever we step, we shall be thighdeep in 20th-century art.

title: SOME LEGISLATORS BID CHARTER REVIEW
description: IF a small but determined number of Democratic and Republican county legislators have their way, the method of filling a vacancy in the county executive's position will be scrutinized next year with an eye toward making the process what they say will be less political and more responsive to public sentiment.

title: BAZAAR OFFERS AN ARRAY OF GIFTS
description: GREENWICH YEARS before the ancient tree fell in 1856, history-minded Hartford residents now and again snipped off small limbs or branches from the famous Charter Oak and had the pieces made into souvenir boxes and other trinkets.

title: LOUISIANA AWAKENING TO THE NEED TO DEAL WITH THE POLLUTION OF ITS PARADISE
description: Widespread pollution in southern Louisiana, an area known as a sportsman's paradise, is arousing concern about public health hazards across the state.

title: OF HUNTER AND HUNTED
description: LINDA McK. STEWART is a writer who lives in Rumson, N.J.

title: OCEAN DETOUR TO FLORIDA
description: JIM DANCE is a Miami-based writer and columnist.

title: For Elderly Mother, 'Heartening Warmth'
description: Elenora Lea Fankushen shows a heartening warmth and generosity of spirit in her article ("Your Mother Wants to Talk to You,'' Opinion Page, Nov 14).

title: ELDERLY GETTING A 'SHARED HOME'
description: RIDGEWOOD ''I DO NOT want to go into a nursing home,'' the elderly woman said. ''I need to be part of an ongoing community, not part of an institution.''

title: A GUIDE TO LOW-COST AUDIO
description: Future anthropologists, taking the measure of our age, may observe that in industrial societies the observation of holidays is usually linked with the preparation of shopping lists. This is quite traditional, and those who take long views recall that, throughout the various phases of social development, ritual often reflects the economic process. At any rate, during the season of Advent, this desk piles up with letters urging me to forgo general topics and discursive comment and come up instead with specific suggestions for listeners planning to treat themselves to new sound gear for Christmas. So, enough of rumination and into the fray of the marketplace.

title: THE DISTILLATION OF TWO WORLDS
description: IN the world of top corporate management, Gery Misson is a chief executive whose responsibilities might be considered by his peers to be either improbable or unbearable.

title: UNESCO PANEL MODIFIES PLAN FOR PRESS
description: A compromise plan for future Unesco activities in communications was worked out here today after a drafting panel agreed to change or delete a number of passages that Western journalists felt would be prejudicial to press freedoms.

title: BOSTON NEON SIGN MAY BE LANDMARK
description: For years the 60-foot-square splash of red, white and blue neon was a beacon of Boston's night life. Now the city's landmark commission must decide if Boston's Citgo sign, the last surviving bit of so-called public neon art, should be spared the wrecker's ball.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ONE group of tenants hoped rents would go down and another feared they would go up if the Rent Guidelines Board passed some special legislation - but the board didn't, and the rents on 9,000 apartments undergoing conversion will be treated in the same manner as 57,000 other rent-stabilized apartments in 18 Westchester communities.

title: Arizona State Is Upset
description: Arizona upset Arizona State, 28-18, tonight, preventing Arizona State from going to the Rose Bowl. Arizona State's loss meant that U.C.L.A. won the Pacific 10 Conference title and a Rose Bowl berth against Michigan (8-3). U.C.L.A. finished the regular season with a 5-1-1 conference record, 9-1-1 over all.

title: U.S.C. AIMS FOR LOUISIANA TECH'S TITLE
description: The 436 pages of this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball guide are bound with a cover that, for the first time in the organization's history, bears the picture of a woman. Anne Donovan of Old Dominion University shares cover honors with Virginia's Ralph Sampson and thus marks the beginning of full N.C.A.A. governance of women's college athletics.

title: Kyle Leverett Is Married
description: Kyle Lee Leverett was married yesterday in Vienna, W.Va. to Whitney Hopkins Wilcox.

title: 'KOSINSKI IS WORTHY OF OUR SUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Grammatical Insecurity LUIGI BARZINI was in New York recently, seeming as fit and vibrant at 73 as he did almost 20 years ago. Riding the crest of popularity from his best-selling ''The Italians,'' a portrait of his countrymen, he seemed in those days a fixture on American television, particularly after ''The Italians'' was made into a network television documentary.

title: Proper Credit For Bird Collages
description: In the Long Island/This Week listings and photo of Nov. 14, ''Bird Collages'' are listed as being by Joan Digby in Sea Cliff.

title: ON WAY OUT, SPADOLINI URGES REFORMS
description: Amintore Fanfani, who became Prime Minister of Italy during Dwight D. Eisenhower's first term as President and ended his fourth stay in the office while John F. Kennedy was in the White House, is about to begin his third week of efforts to form the country's 43d government in 37 years. If he can't put together the reluctant pieces of one more fragile coalition, he will return the mandate to President Sandro Pertini. And if the 74-year-old Mr. Fanfani fails, it is likely that Mr. Pertini will dissolve Parliament and send Italian voters to the polls, 18 months before the natural end of the Parliament's life.

title: FRANCE'S NEW INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: PARIS T he French Socialists don't use the word, recession, when they talk about the nation's struggling economy. Instead they speak of la crise, the crisis, a word that implies a challenge that can be overcome.

title: A.E. Di Laura Jr.  Weds Mary Ernst
description: Mary Kathleen Ernst, daughter of Mrs. John Ernst Barton of Eggertsville, N.Y., and the late John James Ernst, was married yesterday to Arnold Edward Di Laura Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Di Laura of Buffalo and Thunder Bay, Ontario. The Rev. Thomas Beasley performed the ceremony at the Blessed Sacrement Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo.

title: The Other Side Of Auto Reviews
description: To the Sports Editor: I object to Marshall Schuon's glowing report of another Japanese sub-compact (''About Cars: Mazda GLC Is the Great Little Car,'' The New York Times, Nov. 14). Isn't it about time that reviewers concerned themselves with safety instead of the ''ride and handling'' approach?

title: KILLING OF KANGAROOS IS RISING AS SALE OF HIDES IN U.S. GROWS
description: Australian conservationists say that American imports of kangaroo products are endangering the country's best known animal. They are preparing a campaign to persuade the United States to restore a ban on importing the products, principally hides used for high quality shoes and other items.

title: AFTER THE GAMES ARE OVER: ATHLETES IN THE WORK FORCE
description: They often are left behind when their class graduates, but a degree is not the only thing many athletes are lacking. Whether they pursue their careers first on a college campus or proceed directly to the major leagues, they tend to live in an insulated environment that encourages them to defer responsibility. Trainers wash their sweat socks as their mothers once did, and agents, acting as surrogate fathers, give them weekly allowances. When the time comes to enter what is popularly called the real world, many athletes are incapable of making everyday decisions that are considered routine.

title: I ENCLOSE, $12.80, TAKES NASHUA STAKES
description: Eddie Kelly stood in the winner's circle at Aqueduct yesterday trying to remember the last time he had trained a promising 2-yearold.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
GUESS WHO WAS IN THE SUPERMARKET?
description: I ran into Svetlana Stalin the other day. She was trying to cash a check at the customer-courtesy counter of the local supermarket. The children and I were there for our weekly shopping chores late that rainy afternoon. And there she was -Stalin's daughter - going through the same hassles as anyone else who tries to cash a personal check in a supermarket.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAY FIND TRAINS STOPPED ON JAN. 1
description: More than 50,000 rail commuters in this area will begin the new year without trains to ride unless a Presidential emergency board can resolve an impasse between the region's transit agency and 15 unions.

title: TRADE CONFERENCE IN GENEVA DIVIDED OVER BASIC ISSUES
description: An 88-nation trade conference here was extended tonight into an unexpected fifth day as participants sought to overcome deep divisions over how to shore up the world trading system. ''We are making progress, but work needs to be done,'' said Gerald Regan, Canada's Trade Minister.

title: All Sides Happy In Brazil Vote
description: Brazil's first free elections in 17 years were held Nov. 15 and the results that became apparent last week contained something for almost everybody - and perhaps some seeds of future conflict.

title: STALLED ECONOMY SPEEDS PUERTO RICO'S BRAIN DRAIN
description: There is a mounting restlessness these days among Puerto Rico's best and brightest. With increasing frequency, engineers and other skilled professionals are moving to the mainland to seek their fortunes - or to simply make ends meet.

title: THE ISRAELI OPPOSITION WANTS NO AID CUTS
description: To the Editor: The internecine political battle in Israel that surfaced in Max Frankel's articles is not so startling when viewed in its historical perspective.

title: Black Museum Work Starts
description: Ohio officials have broken ground for the National Afro-American Museum and Cultural Center. John Fleming, director of the center, said Tuesday that the $25 million project would be the first complete historic collection on the American black experience from slavery to the present. Wilberforce, home of two predominantly black colleges, Wilberforce University and Central State University, was the site of seven Underground Railroad stations before the Civil War.

title: REVAMPED PACKERS TEST JETS
description: They have been scolded by Coach Walt Michaels, and even their wives have tried to help restore the harmony that made the New York Sack Exchange the most formidable unit in pro football.

title: GO-BETWEEN SAYS NASSER SOUGHT ISRAELI PACT
description: In the spring of 1955, the Egyptian Government asked a prominent American Quaker to undertake a secret diplomatic assignment intended to bring about a political settlement with Israel.

title: New York Times Magazine November 28, 1982
description: William Safire 16 On Language Farewell, My Lovely Russell Baker 32 Sunday Observer Of Pals and Pols Deborah Shapley 36 The Army's New Fighting Doctrine In what may be the most fundamental change in its approach since the Civil War, the Army is emphasizing maneuverability, mobility and quick counterattack behind enemy lines. Donal Henahan 58 The Conductor as Endangered Species A conductor's most important job is to find new music and promote it. By losing their vital connection with living composers, however, modern maestros are turning not only the symphonic repertory but themselves into museum pieces.

title: Vermont Fir for Capitol Lawn
description: A 35-year-old balsam fir from Vermont will will adorn the Capitol this Christmas, the Department of Agriculture says. The 50-foot tree, from the Green Mountain National Forest, is to be cut Dec. 4 and arrive at the west front lawn of the Capitol on Dec. 7.

title: BURNED OUT,3 YACHT CLUBS REFIT
description: IN the Gold Coast days of the Island's North Shore, Hempstead Harbor was a playground for the yachting set. Three boating clubs were established along the harbor's shores around the turn of the century, and all three still actively promote the sailing, racing and fishing that have characterized summers at the harbor.

title: No Headline
description: COLGATE WINS IN PLAYOFF, 21-7

title: Murdoch and Another Union Get Accord at Boston Paper
description: Negotiators for the publisher Rupert Murdoch reached a tentative contract agreement today with The Newspaper Guild as Mr. Murdoch continued to seek labor settlements that he says are necessary if he is to buy The Boston Herald American.

title: Egypt Confirms a Prohibition On Travel by Sadat's Brother
description: An Egyptian court today confirmed an order prohibiting Esmat Sadat, the younger brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat, from traveling abroad before he stands trial.

title: LOOKING FOR WORK---AND HOPE
description: BRISTOL MAUREEN GRIPPO stood against a coat rack in the Salvation Army headquarters on Stearns Street, her arms folded across her volunteer's smock. She frowned and shook her head.

title: Israel's Leaders On the Hot Seat
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin and eight other top Israeli leaders were warned last week of possibly grave and damaging findings of negligence in allowing Christian Phalangist forces to massacre hundreds of Palestinian men, women and children in West Beirut in September.

title: Soviet Renews Attack On Reagan's MX Plan
description: The Soviet Union renewed its attack today on President Reagan's plan to deploy 100 new MX missiles, saying it was a breach of the second strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: Emily Taylor Has Bridal
description: Emily Clark Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Taylor Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Bennett Charles Carlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Carlin of Jersey City. The Rev. John Rodland, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Ridgewood Country Club.

title: '5TH OF JULY': AIR OF ADEQUACY
description: MADISON LANFORD WILSON'S ''5th of July,'' which takes place in 1977, is about resilience and survival. Feelings are sorted out, relationships are resolved and the characters get on with their lives ''now that the days of power to the people are over.''

title: EILEEN HOEY TO BE BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Josephine Gehrdes Hoey of New Springville, Staten Island, of the engagement of her daughter, Eileen Frances Hoey, to Matthew Charles Albanese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Albanese of Jericho, L.I. The future bride, daughter also of Raymond N. Hoey of Suffield, Conn., is a reinsurrance underwriter with the AFG Reinsurance Corporation of the United States. Her fiance is a treaty/facultative broker with Greig Fester( North America) Inc., reinsurance intermediaries. An April wedding is planned.

title: MAO'S BIRTHPLACE IS LOSING LURE FOR TOURISTS
description: This small village, nestled in the pine-dotted hills of Hunan Province, once attracted visitors by the tens of thousands, for it was here that Mao Zedong was born. Now a few hundred tourists show up daily to inspect the sprawling mud-brick farmhouse of his childhood.

title: EASTERN BLOC NATIONS SEEM TO BE COURTING TURKEY
description: The Prime Minister of Hungary spent three days in this North Atlantic Treaty Organization nation this week on a state visit intended to develop economic and cultural cooperation.

title: COUPLE LAW ASKED FOR SAN FRANCISCO
description: A proposed ordinance supported by San Francisco's large homosexual community would create a new class of ''domestic partners,'' allowing live-in lovers to be covered by the city's employee insurance programs.

title: Niki L. Hutchinson, Lawyer, Married To William U. Wright, Gallery Owner
description: Niki Lauren Hutchinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Edward Hutchinson 3d of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Urquhart Wright, son of Mrs. John H. Summerskill of Athens and the late Richard Arthur Wright of Palo Alto, Calif.

title: WOMEN NETSTERS TO VIE FOR TOP SPOT
description: EAST RUTHERFORD WHO will be No. 1 among women tennis players this year? The showdown between Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova for the top spot will be decided Dec. 14-19 on a synthetic indoor court at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena here.

title: AN ISLAND FOR RENT
description: Maybe it will appeal to people who value fitness above convenience. Enoch Island, 1,190 feet long, 110 feet wide, sits in the Amityville River and is accessible from the mainland of Long Island only by boat.

title: SECRET GUILTY PLEA FOUGHT BY 2 CO-DEFENDANTS
description: A hearing is under way to determine whether the Brooklyn District Attorney's office engaged in prosecutorial misconduct when it failed to inform two defendants in an arson case that a co-defendant had secretly pleaded guilty and agreed to become a prosecution witness.

title: STATE LOOKING INTO COURTROOM SEX BIAS
description: WHEN Marilyn Loftus graduated from Rutgers University Law School in 1961 as the only woman in her class, she soon got her first taste of life in a predominantly male profession.

title: RECESSION AND AID CUTS ARE CITED
description: Many colleges and universities around the country are reporting a substantial drop in the number of minority freshmen, especially blacks, who enrolled this fall.

title: 10 Convicted in Drug Case
description: Ten Florida men, including Gary Balough, a professional stock-car racer, were convicted today of conspiring to smuggle tons of marijuana into Florida aboard high-powered speedboats. The verdicts came after eight days of deliberations and 10 weeks of testimony and arguments before Federal District Judge Sidney Aronovitz. Seventy people have been indicted in the so-called ''race-car driver'' drug-conspiracy case, although few of those charged were actually drivers on the stock-car circuit.

title: LIVES OF THE WRITERS
description: We're bursting out all over with biographies of writers: ''Robert Lowell'' by Ian Hamilton; ''Katherine Anne Porter'' by Joan Givner; ''Isak Dinesen'' by Judith Thurman; ''Mailer'' by Hilary Mills; ''The Life of John Berryman'' by John Haffenden; and ''Early Auden'' by Edward Mendelson, to name just a few current and recent titles. The question is why biographies of writers are so popular.

title: Incorrectly Portrayed, School Group Contends
description: In the New Jersey Journal column of Nov. 7, the New Jersey School Boards Association was incorrectly portrayed as an opponent of public commentary at local Board of Education meetings.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: LOITERING WITH INTENT. By Muriel Spark. (Putnam/Perigee, $5.95.) Muriel Spark's 16th novel is the story of Fleur Talbot, a young writer in postwar London who's having a love affair with art. Our reviewer, Barbara Grizzuti Harrison, who declared she had read the book ''in a delirium of delight,'' called it ''robust and full-blooded ... a wise and mature work, and a brilliantly mischievous one.'' Three other Muriel Spark novels - THE GIRLS OF SLENDER MEANS, MEMENTO MORI and THE BALLAD OF PECKHAM RYE - are also now available in Perigee editions.

title: HOSPITAL ZONE STIRS DEBATE
description: MANHASSET AT a recent hearing, the North Hempstead Town Board approved two proposals: a change in zone for North Shore University Hospital and a site plan for a new four-tier, 561-car garage to be built on the 57-acre grounds of the hospital complex.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
A PROPOSED FLAT RATE FOR FAT CATS
description: NOW that the Reagan program of supply-side miracles is bogged down i n recession, controversy and red ink, it is time for a bright new i dea to capture the fancy of journalists and divert the attention of v oters. What will this new fad be? A good guess is that the ''Flat T axers'' will replace the ''Supply Siders'' on the hit parade of e conomic slogans.

title: A 20-YEAR STRUGGLE PUTS 'GANDHI' ON SCREEN
description: For 20 years, Richard Attenborough has been a man with an obsession: to bring to the screen the life of Mahatma Gandhi - and to prove in the process that there is a place in contemporary cinema for the big biographical film. The hope at last a reality, ''Gandhi,'' more than three hours long and made at a cost of $22 million, opens this week in New Delhi and London, next week in New York at the Ziegfeld..

title: IN CONGRESS, 1983 MAY BEGIN TOMMORROW
description: The post-election session that begins on Capitol Hill tomorrow may turn out to be a preview of the new Congress that takes office in January.

title:
LEGISLATURE WEIGHS ACUPUNCTURE BILL;
One Patient's Chronicle
description: the Chinese system of healing that originated 5,000 years ago - may soon be more widely available in New Jersey, as its small circle of adherents has been hoping.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

title: Julia A. Wendell Becomes a Bride
description: At Trinity Memorial Episcopal Church in Warren, Pa., yesterday Julia Allison Wendell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Potts Wendell of Warren, was married to Jack Edward Stephens Jr., son of Mr. Stephens of Olympia, Wash., and Mrs. Ronald Anderson of Sacramento, Calif. The Rev. Richard H. Baker performed the ceremony.

title: A 'FAMILY ALBUM' OF CLOTHES
description: FASHION exhibitions at museums can be awesome experiences, as if the sponsors must justify the frivolous subject by embuing it with a heavy freight of aesthetic and social significance. ''Silhouettes of Style,'' the current show at The Hudson River Museum, which runs through Jan. 9, is nothing like that. It's as cozy as poring through an old family album or opening attic trunks filled with ancestral clothes.

title: ARTHUR BENNINGTON
description: Arthur Bennington, a partner since 1977 in the Wall Street brokerage firm of Alex Brown & Sons, died yesterday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: GEORGIA (11-0) IN 38-18 ROMP
description: Herschel Walker scored two touchdowns and rushed for 162 yards today to lead Georgia to a 38-18 victory over Georgia Tech so the Bulldogs ended their regular season as the only undefeated and untied major college football team in the nation.

title: EXECUTIVE SEES HOTELS AS 'THEATER'
description: ''WE are, as you know, selling the most perishable item in the world,'' said Alphonse W. Salomone. ''You can't inventory a hotel room.''

title:
GARDENING;
SOME HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR THE GARDENER
description: IF all those on my holiday gift list were gardeners, shopping would be much easier. There are so many garden-oriented gifts to choose from, and many can be selected from bookstores, garden centers or mail-order catalogues.

title: Buse Rejects Offer
description: Don Buse, a free agent, has rejected the final contract offer from the Indiana Pacers, for whom he played last season. Garry Donna, the guard's agent, said the offer carried a salary cut of 40 percent, which would reduce Buse's salary to $90,000.

title: Ithaca
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOOTING OR NONSHOOTING?
description: Investigators in Italy believe Serge Ivanov Antonov did more than sell tickets for Bulgaria's national airline. They arrested him in Rome last week at the office of the Balkan Airlines and Tourist Organization where he works and charged him with complicity in last year's attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II.

title: ST. JOHN'S SETS BACK OHIO IN FINAL, 62-52
description: St. John's won the Lapchick tournament last night for the eighth straight year with a 62-52 victory over Ohio University, but it proved to be a more difficult chore than expected.

title: Hawaii Hurricane Path Declared Disaster Area
description: President Reagan today declared the section of Hawaii struck by Hurricane Iwa a major disaster area, clearing the way for Federal agencies to help thousands of residents on Kauai, Niihau and Oahu to restore theirs homes and businesses.

title: Rachelle H. Klapper And Jack Meth to Wed
description: Rachelle H. Klapper, a third-year medical student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Jack Meth, a data base analyst and administrator at the City University Computer Center, plan to be married in March.

title: SALVADOR SOLDIERS SHOW HOW THEY KILLED AMERICANS AND LAND AIDE
description: Two former national guard corporals returned to the Sheraton Hotel here today and re-enacted for a judge how they killed two United States land-redistribution specialists and a Salvadoran official nearly two years ago.

title: ZOILO VERSAILLES'S PLIGHT
description: During the 1960's, he was a slick-fielding shortstop for the Minnesota Twins who hit well enough to become the American League's most valuable player in 1965. Now, Zoilo Versalles and his family live in a rented home in Bloomington, Minn., hoping they won't be evicted during the holiday season.

title: HOLIDAY CHEER
description: The practice of giving wine at holiday time has grown in lockstep with the overall increase in consumption; more and more American consumers have begun to feel comfortable choosing a special bottle for a friend and more recipients are delighted to receive one. Virtually all stores will make recommendations, but much of the fun in giving wine is in selecting it.

title: YEAR-END PLANNING FOR INCOME TAXES
description: SPECIAL year-end strategies to minimize taxes have always been de r igueur for upper-bracket taxpayers, but this year new and recent taxl egislation makes such planning a virtual necessity even for those w ith more modest incomes. Indeed, people with casualty losses or s ubstantial medical expenses may sacrifice hundreds of dollars in taxs avings unless they take action now to nail down those deductions fort he 1982 tax year.

title: THE ECONOMIC PIE ISN'T GROWING, BUT MORE AMERICANS NEED SLICES
description: "New occasions teach new duties; time makes ancient good uncouth,'' warns the old Presbyterian hymn. One of the new ''occasions'' that is altering the nature of politics in the United States is the unchanging economic pie. The implications for American public policy are immense. Very seldom, if ever, has American public policy faced such a series of dramatic and traumatic choices.

title: A ROUNDTABLE: GIVEN MX, IS ABM SURE TO FOLLOW?
description: In explaining his decision last week to approve a 'dense pack' system for the MX missile, President Reagan said he did not want to endanger the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty with Moscow or build ''even the minimal ABM system allowed us by the ABM treaty.'' Most experts believe, however, that pressure to protect the MX makes new pressure for an ABM inevitable. The Week in Review asked three specialists to talk about the values and the risks of deploying an ABM. Excerpts of their discussion, with Leslie H. Gelb, national security correspondent of The New York Times, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: WILDERNESS AREAS ARE DEBATED AGAIN
description: High above the timberline, in a protected wilderness region below the summit of 13,590-foot Matterhorn Peak, lies a small but level section of gravel.

title: THE MEN BEHIND THREE LABELS
description: Who's running the record industry? Here are brief biographical sketches of three leading record executives, two from the major labels, CBS and Warner Brothers, the other from Island, a leading independent label.

title: LETTERS
description: The Weekend Mother Christine Doudna's article ''The Weekend Mother'' (Oct. 3) elicited relief, grief and deep interest from me. As the live-out mother of three sons, 2, 4 and 6 years old, I was relieved to hear that there are others who struggle with the issues I do, and that some of them have created positive outcomes from extremely difficult circumstances.

title: 'KOSINSKI IS WORTHY OF OUR SUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: DEVILS END 18-GAME DROUGHT

title: D.B. Newman to Wed Candiss Lynn Cowan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Cowan of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Candiss Lynn Cowan, to David B. Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Newman of Jamaica, Queens.

title:
BRAVING THE SEA FOR SCALLOPS;
William McGowan is a freelance writer living in Manhattan
description: It was about midnight. The seas on Georges Bank, 100 miles off the New England coast, were running eight feet and building. It was hard to stand on deck let alone work on it.

title: Amy K. Parker Is Bride Of Ens. T. E. Mangold Jr.
description: Amy Katherine Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde William Parker of Menlo Park, Calif., was married yesterday to Ens. Thomas Edward Mangold Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mangold of Livingston, N.J. The Rev. Francis McDonnell performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Treasure Island Naval Base Chapel in San Francisco.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
HOUSE SETS HEARING ON OLYMPIC COIN DESIGNS
description: In a highly unusual move a House subcommittee has scheduled a hearing this week to air the many complaints concerning the designs of the three coins being issued for the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. The hearing, scheduled for Wednesday, before the House Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs and Coinage, is apparently aimed at pressuring the U.S. Treasury to upgrade the designs, and possibly even to scrap one or more.

title: Fashion Pressed Into Personal Service By Ralph DiGennaro
description: Linda Lee, the director of Macy's personal shopping service, says her customers are ''professional or business people who have considerable needs but not a lot of time because of demanding schedules.'' ith the often frenetic day-to-day, minute-to-minute demands of business and professional life, finding enough time to shop for clothes, or special gifts, can be as difficult as actually deciding what to buy.

title: Mary Webb, Grant Sperry Are Engaged
description: Dr. H. Murphy Webb of Houston has announced the engagement of his daughter, Mary Ann Webb, to Grant H. Sperry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth P. Sperry Jr., of Middlebury, Conn.

title: A BACH OFFERING
description: The flutist Eugenia Zuckerman will appear in a free concert with the harpsichordist Anthony Newman at 8 P.M. tomorrow in the recital hall of the Music Building at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: KNIFE SOUGHT IN JERSEY SLAYING
description: Police investigating the death of an 18-year-old New Jersey high school senior drained three holding tanks at a reservoir in Morris County yesterday and raked the sandy bottoms but did not find the knife they believe was used in the slaying.

title: 'KOSINSKI IS WORTHY OF OUR SUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:$

title: RESULTS PRAISED IN STATES REQUIRING AUTO SAFETY DEVICES FOR CHILDREN
description: An increasing number of states are passing laws requiring that children ride in special car seats or wear seat belts. According to limited information from people in this still fairly new movement, the laws are saving young lives.

title:
STAMPS;
THE U.S. HIGHLIGHTS SCIENCE ON ITS 1983 ISSUES
description: Science and good causes are going to be much in evidence on stamps next year, especially in the early months, according to the 1983 program announced by the United States Postal Service. There will also be the usual quota of commemoratives for milestone anniversaries and special events, plus special stamps and commemorative postal stationery.

title: 30,000 Swiss Stage Protest
description: About 30,000 Government employees marched through Bern today to demonstrate for shorter working hours and salary increases in line with inflation, the police said. They want the workweek reduced to 42 hours from 44.

title: TROJANS DEFEAT IRISH
description: John Robinson can still recall the first time he wondered if the job as the football coach at the University of Southern California was really for him. It wasn't very far into his tenure at the helm of the tradition-rich team. In fact, it was during his first game.

title: No From the P.L.O.
description: The P.L.O.'s rejection of President Reagan's proposal for Arab-Israeli negotiations only proves the adage that those who make a bad war cannot make a good peace. After decades of futile but costly violence, culminating in the Lebanon debacle, the Palestine Liberation Organization seems totally incapable of turning a frustrated nationalism into constructive political action.

title: 300 CHURCH LEADERS PROTEST U.S. POLICIES IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: More than 300 religious leaders in the United States, including 22 Roman Catholic bishops, have issued a message denouncing the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America.

title: Bermuda's Miss World Entry Jailed on Smuggling Charge
description: Bermuda's entry in last week's Miss World contest, Heather Michelle Ross, was remanded in custody today on charges of trying to smuggle nearly $320,000 worth of cocaine into Britain.

title: Creationism; Loses Again
description: So far, there are as many reasons to throw out ''creation-science'' laws as there are laws on the matter. Such legislation requires public schools to teach the relatively recent creation of all things by a supernatural force, alongside the theory of evolution.

title: Denis J. O'Malley Weds Maura Anne Brannelly
description: Maura Anne Brannelly, daughter of Mrs. Jeanne G. Brannelly of Bridgeport, Conn., and the late John M.
