Brannelly, was married yesterday to Denis Joseph O'Malley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis O'Malley of Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Andrew Cusack performed the ceremony in the St. Augustine Roman Catholic Cathedral in Bridgeport.

title: CONDOMINIUMS TAKE THE LEAD
description: ON EAST 47th Street at Second Avenue a new residential building called Dag Hammarskjold Tower is under construction. It is a condominium. On West 61st Street near Lincoln Center another residential tower, the Beaumont, is nearing completion. It also is a condominium. And on East 22d Street, on the southern edge of Madison Park, still another tower residence, Madison Green, is under construction. It, too, is a condominium.

title: WILL '2d WAVE' OF CASINOS CREST?
description: ATLANTIC CITY BLOCKED for almost two years by soaring interest rates, a ''second wave'' of hotel-casino construction is under way here now, with one such project already going up on the Boardwalk and two more ready to rise next year.

title: SHAKY BRIDGES IN NEW YORK
description: HIGHWAYS crumble and bridges shake, sewer systems are overtaxed, reservoirs underfilled and dams overflowing. Is it any wonder, after years of not-so-benign neglect, that officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut decry the state of their states? But if infrastructure has become a watchword, finding the funds for the increasingly huge public works bills spawned by postponement of perhaps a decade's worth of rebuilding, resurfacing and repairing seems as hard as ever, even if such work can no longer safely be delayed. There was good news, however, from an unexpected quarter last week, as President Reagan endorsed a 5-cent-a-gallon Federal gasoline tax to help the states and the unemployed. In New Jersey, Transportation Commissioner John P. Sheridan Jr. estimated that the five-year, $32.9 billion program under discussion on Capitol Hill could boost the state's share of Federal transportation aid from $183 million to $270 million and provide 7,500 new construction jobs of the 320,000 to be created around the country (assuming New Jersey provides the matching funds to qualify for the new aid). It couldn't have come at a more opportune time: Mr. Sheridan had just announced the indefinite postponement of $100 million in new road construction. Staff cutbacks brought about by the state's budget squeeze, he said, left too few supervisors to oversee the work. Of course, roads are by no means the region's only problem. The articles below examine some important public works needs in New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: BED, BREAKFAST AND HOSPITALITY
description: A YEAR ago, Maxine Kates and Phyllis Nova were former teachers in search of a part-time business. Their goal was to find a peopleoriented enterprise that would not take them too long or too far from their families.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Steadily Improving As a Peruvian orphan with a terminal heart condition, 3-year-old Anita Asto had prospects that were, at best, dim.

title: FAIRFIELD
description: IT IS neither an exaggeration nor a matter of chauvinism to say thatt he Town of Fairfield has a rather strong sense of itself. Because t he British burned the village in 1779, for instance, Fairfield r efused to celebrate the American Centennial with everyone else in 1 876. It held its own festivities in 1879.

title: 'Rondine' for City Opera
description: The first new production of the New York City Opera's 1983 summer season will be Puccini's ''La Rondine,'' supported by a $175,000 gift from the Gramma Fisher Foundation. The director will be Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, who will be making his company debut. Diana Soviero and Barry McCauley will sing the leading roles.

title: DIDJA SEE THE BAR EAT THE TATERS?
description: GRAMMAR AND GOOD TASTE Reforming the American Language. By Dennis E. Baron. 263 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: WOMEN AND FICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: AID SOUGHT FOR BRAIN INJURED
description: SERIOUS brain injuries can immediately transform active, healthy youngsters and adults into immobile, institutionalized patients. And of the more than 250 people currently in Connecticut who have suffered very serious head injuries, many of them are young people who were victims of auto accidents. Some will need care in an institution for the rest of their lives. Some will be sent to nursing homes temporarily. And some will be brought home to be cared for by parents.

title: THE WEEKEND MOTHER
description: Christine Doudna's article "The Weekend Mother" (Oct. 3) elicited relief, grief and deep interest from me. As the live-out mother of three sons, 2, 4 and 6 years old, I was relieved to hear that there are others who struggle with the issues I do, and that some of them have created positive outcomes from extremely difficult circumstances.

title: LONG-CONTESTED HOUSING PROJECT OPENS AMID CALM IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Whitman Park, a subsidized housing development that became a symbol of this city's racial and political struggles in the 25 years since it was proposed, opened this month amid striking calm.

title: WHY COLLEGES NEED THE 30-SECOND CLOCK
description: COLLEGE basketball is great entertainment, but it can be improved. Contrary to what traditionalists would have us believe, adoption of the 30-second clock would neither jeopardize the game's character nor its popularity. In fact, fans will be pleased at how it enhances the quality of the game, greatly develops individual and team play and helps emphasize coaching innovation and strategy.

title:
OPINION;
THE LURE OF THOSE MAGIC BOXES
description: ''PAC-MAN Not Pot,'' a bumper sticker suggests. Is there no alternative for the bored young people today? In the Fairfield County town in which I live it seems as if Ray Bradbury's visions have come true: no more books or self-organized sports. In their places an electronic temple stands, luring the young with its blinking lights, plush carpets and row upon row of lighted magic boxes that match wits with humans at the drop of a quarter.

title: Eliza Montgomery, Teacher, Is Married
description: Elizabeth Packard Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald R. Montgomery 3d of Summit, N.J., and Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., was married at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., yesterday to Peter Herbert Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Zimmerman of Newtown Square, Pa. The Rev. Charles Sheerin, assistant headmaster of the Trinity-Pawling School, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Pickering, rector of the church.

title: KAREN THOMSON PLANS BRIDAL WITH J.C. CANTOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hennessey Thomson of Murray Hill, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Thomson, to Joshua Charles Cantor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Cantor of Westfield, N.J.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Oil Price Worries

title: Index; International
description: African leaders condemn the U.S. on Namibia 3 Unesco panel modifies draft of press guidelines 3 Around the World 5 Nakasone provides U.S. with a summary of his views 6 Conditions in East Timor appear to be improving 8 Mao's home is drawing fewer visitors these days 12 Canada focuses on its version of the Super Bowl 13 300 church leaders protest U.S. policies in Central America 14 U.S. is close to approval of proposal on nuclear testing 15 Iraq, despite war, seems eco- nomically healthy 17 Egypt reportedly tried to arrange a settlement with Israel in '55 20 Communist bloc nations seem to be courting Turkey 21 Canada considers establishing relations with Albania 22 Government/Politics Reagan still trying to quiet furor on jobless benefits study 29 Reagan to propose less Federal aid for rural areas 37 Warner official guilty of fraud in theater stock purchase 42 General Around the Nation 26 Pollution arousing widespread concern in Louisiana 26 Police use tear gas on anti-Klan demonstrators 26 Tellico Dam farm land is sold again as former owners watch 27 San Francisco set to recognize unmarried domestic partners 31 Government to collect fees from dairy farmers 34 Mineral exploration in the wilderness is debated 35 More states require car safety seats for infants 36 Number of imprisoned women rises 25% in past two years 40 A test is pitting court reporters against tape recorders 45 Brooklyn judge studying prosecutorial misconduct charge 46 No link has been found yet between a detective and friend 47 City budget cuts affect cultural institutions 48 Religion Wider role for women in the church gains with bishops 33 Arts/Entertainment Peter Gabriel rocks at the Palladium 74 Lipizzaner horses at the Garden 74 Music debuts in review 75 Style Conquering the fear of flying 76 Obituaries N. Eldon Tanner, an official of the Mormon Church 44 Features/Notes Man in the News: Sidney Schwartz, state watchdog 42

title: CITY BUDGET CUTS AFFECT CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS
description: Trims in New York City's budget are affecting not only the basic municipal services - fire, police, sanitation and education - but also the operation of some of the nation's most prominent cultural institutions.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ONE pioneer woman in state government was honored in memory of another, at a recent ceremony in Hartford. Ellen A. Peters, a Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court, received the first Ella Grasso Distinguished Service Medal. The award, and its sponsor - the Ella Grasso Foundation - were created to keep alive the spirit of the late Governor.

title: BRIDGEPORT PUPILS BACK IN SUBURBAN SCHOOLS
description: WESTPORT THE bus from Bridgeport pulled up to Westport's Bedford Junior High School on Nov. 1, two months after the start of the semester. Eleven boys and girls trooped out, too busy chattering among themselves to take note of the principal and the guidance counselor who had been waiting to greet them.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Return to Moviemaking

title: FOSTER PARENTS GETTING HARDER TO FIND
description: WHEN Peggy Tomasicchio of Stony Brook learned that she could not have children, she and her husband, Michael, began exploring the possibility of adoption. But officials at the Suffolk County Department of Social Services told them that they were not likely to be given preference because they had a family - Mr. Tomasicchio's two children from an earlier marriage.

title:
SPARE-PARTS MEDICINE;
Stephen Solomon is contributing editor to Science Digest
description: Doug lay on an operating table at the University of Western Ontario Hospital as Dr. John Girvin removed a 2-by-3-inch piece of bone from the back of his skull. The surgeon then carefully placed a onesquare-inch Teflon wafer on the visual cortex of Doug's brain. Because the brain has no sensation of pain, only local anesthesia had been administered and Doug was awake, talking with his surgeon. Doug could not see his surgeon, however; he had been unable to see anything since that day in 1966 when a Vietcong land mine exploded in front of him.

title: STUDY SAYS BRAINS OF TORTURE VICTIMS ATROPHY
description: Torture victims may suffer irreversible brain damage with debilitating psychological symptoms similar to those suffered by the survivors of concentration camps, a study says.

title: FOLLOWING THE FOOTSTEPS OF THE BARD
description: The chief pleasure of living in an old country - as against the discouragements of the brave new social order - is that it is feet deep in assoications, historical, literary, and visual, for those that have eyes to see. And actually there is much more in existence of the England that William Shakespeare knew than people realize.

title: A LONG AND BLOODY STORY
description: THE ARAB-ISRAELI WARS War and Peace in the Middle East. By Chaim Herzog. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York: Random House. $20.

title: DIDN'T ANYONE LISTEN ON NOV. 2?
description: THE nuclear-freeze resolutions on the ballot in eight states and more than 30 municipalities on Nov. 2 came as close to a national referendum as anything this country has ever seen.

title: NUMBER OF WOMEN IN PRISONS RISING
description: Linda Shaw, imprisoned for stealing to support her drug addiction, might not have been jailed a decade ago. Today, she is serving a one-year sentence in Framingham State Prison.

title: Time Off, Anyone?
description: Such is the seriousness of New York's plight that Governor Carey last week suggested state workers take a week's vacation without pay and Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo said he regretted he wasn't on one.

title: Still Rooting For Doug Kotar
description: To the Sports Editor: I am writing in response to Ira Berkow's article on Doug Kotar (''Doug Kotar Is Back Home With His Family,'' The New York Times, Nov. 14).

title: Q&A
description: Question:During January my wife and I would like to bicycle around Sarasota and on Sanibel Island in Florida. Are there rail or air carriers operating from New York that will permit us to take our bikes with us without having to crate or dismantle them? - R.W., New York, N.Y. Answer:An Amtrak representative said that all bicycles that are carried on its trains must be in containers; appropriate containers can be purchased from Amtrak for $4.32 and there is no extra fare for a bicycle that accompanies a passenger.

title: U.S. CLINCHES DAVIS CUP
description: John McEnroe is the best doubles player in tennis. Today, teaming with Peter Fleming, he again demonstrated his excellence during a 6-3, 6-4, 9-7 victory over Yannick Noah and Henri Leconte of France that gave the United States an unbeatable 3-0 lead and clinched the Davis Cup.

title: 3 ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS SUE 9 COMPANIES OVER POLLUTION
description: In an unusual series of lawsuits, three environmental groups that call the Federal Government lax in enforcing antipollution laws have filed their own actions, charging nine corporations with ''systematically and significantly'' violating their waste-waterdischarge permits in New York State.

title: MUSEUM IN BOSTON ASKING PUBLIC AID
description: The Museum of Transportation is turning to the public for help in putting off a bank sale of $1.3 million worth of the museum's antique fire engines, cars, trucks, bicycles and carriages.

title: THE FEAR OF FLYING: ONE ATTEMPT TO CONQUER IT
description: The voices at the bank of telephones at Logan International Airport in Boston ranged from thrilled to ecstatic. The phrases varied, but what each person was saying in his or her own way to the family back in New York or New Jersey or Connecticut, was ''I did it.''

title: THE POET AT THE CENTER
description: ROBERT LOWELL A Biography. By Ian Hamilton. Illustrated. 527 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Deborah Hidalgo and John Culligan Have Nuptials
description: Deborah Ann Hidalgo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rachel Hidalgo of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Joseph Culligan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Edward B. Karl performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family.

title: PROJECT TO ADD TO LIBERAL ARTS
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has initiated a new liberal arts program with grants totaling $3,077,000 to 32 colleges and universities.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about new futures and options trading gave an incorrect starting date for the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's foreign-currency options as well as the number of currencies that will be offered. Trading will begin Dec. 10 in five currencies.

title: 'EVITA' CRIES FOR THE RANGERS
description: MINUTES before the puck is dropped, the most nervous performer in Madison Square Garden makes warbling noises deep in her throat and paces back and forth near the ice.

title:
LEISURE;
ON CHOOSING THE RIGHT PLANT FOR THE RIGHT PLACE
FOR DAVID STOCKMAN, IT'S ROUND 3
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, David A. Stockman celebrated his 36th birthday with a staff party. It was Nov. 10 - coincidentally, the first anniversary of the appearance of ''The Education of David Stockman'' in the Atlantic Monthly. To celebrate, one of Mr. Stockman's aides wrote and read this poem and called it ''Ode to the Washington Rumor Mill.''

title: SWITCHING SKIS AT SUN VALLEY
description: MICHAEL WRIGHT is an editor of The New York Times Week in Review.

title: Gordon Gray 3d Weds Miss Bentivegna
description: Concettina Bentivegna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Bentivegna of Montreal, was married there yesterday to Gordon Gray 3d, son of Mr. Gray Jr. of New York and Virginia Garbers of Boston. The Rev. Sebastian Juneau performed the ceremony in St. Bernardin de Sienne Roman Catholic Church.

title: Chess; WHEN TITANS OF TWO GENERATIONS MEET HEAD-ON
description: The most momentous individual confrontation of the 1982 Olympiad in Lucerne, Switzerland, was the one between Viktor Korchnoi, playing on the territory of his adopted country, and Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union.

title: Hitting a Nerve; On Atomic Waste
description: Since the nuclear waste plant at West Valley, N.Y., closed in 1972 as an economic and technical imbroglio, government has groped for a way to sweep up the mess. Last week, a report from the Energy Department's Inspector General said that the cost of decontaminating the facility - as required by a cooperative agreement with New York State - could be avoided by building a new one.

title: A Time of Special Need
description: It should begin at Thanksgiving - the reflection on blessings for which to be grateful. And it should carry through the season of good will and fellowship.

title: Arson Likely in Bank Blaze
description: An arsonist may have set a Thanksgiving Day fire that engulfed a downtown block, injured 11 firefighters and caused $30 million in damage, investigators say. Jim Carlson, an arson investigator, said the authorities were following up two or three ''street rumors'' Friday. The fire, which began in the vacant Donaldson Department Store, destroyed the top 12 floors of the adjacent 16-story Northwestern National Bank building, headquarters of the largest bank organization in the upper Middle West.

title: CANADA'S COUNTRYSIDE IS ITS PATRIMONY
description: What light is to Greece, space is to Canada. The ubiquitous awareness that in almost every direction lie oceans of uninhabited land has shaped the perceptions of artists, defined national character, determined an architecture and established a Canadian way of seeing.

title: Holly S. McCloon To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard McGloon of Nashua, N.H., formerly of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Susan McGloon, to Arthur Andrews Gosnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hale Gosnell of Rochester.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A raid by Federal agents on a Passaic clothing factory earlier this month may force the deportation of 40 illegal Polish aliens, all of them women who worked as sewing-machine operators. The raid, which was conducted by 50 agents of the Internal Revenue and Immigration and Naturalization Services, centered on Fashion Associates Inc.

title: Kean's Plan to Close the Gap
description: One way or the other, New Jersey's budget has to be balanced. That's the law. And last week, after Governor Kean presented the Legislature with a package of tax increases and spending cuts to close a budget gap of perhaps $150 million, the other way was distinctly possible.

title: DOCTORS FASHIONED BY THE 'ME' GENERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: AETNA SUED FOR COST OF WELL-BABY CARE
description: IN LITIGATION that could affect millions of parents, a Piscataway couple has sued the Aetna Life Insurance Company because, despite what they believed to be their ''full coverage'' maternity benefits, they were billed $650 for their newborn's six days in the hospital nursery.

title: IONA'S GAELS GIRD FOR RUGGED SEASON
description: NEW ROCHELLE IONA COLLEGE'S varsity basketball team, the county's only National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball team, is considered among the top five in the East this season by many basketball followers. Nevertheless, Pat Kennedy, the Iona coach, is operating as if he had a group of green players facing a rugged schedule.

title: Secrets Under; The Sahara
description: Sand and sediment of the ages have blinded aerial photography to the Sahara's pre-desert landscape. Where photography could not go, however, the deep-seeing radar aboard the space shuttle Columbia went in November 1981, revealing ancient waterways, valleys and possible Stone Age settlements.

title: JAPANESE PREMIERE URGES AN INCREASE IN ARMED STRENGTH
description: The new Prime Minister of Japan said today that Japan had to strengthen its military position to ''uphold unity and cooperation with the United States and the free nations of Europe.''

title: Nets Unable to Maintain Poise
description: Len Elmore is 30 years old, and one of the elders on the youthful Nets. Thus, he often has a more thoughtful view of what is happening to the team than many of his teammates. But after most games, he is often off by himself, for he is rarely the star performer on any night. But when the chaos settles, his opinion is usually the most valued.

title: GOOD ACTORS IN SERVICE OF A CREAKY DRAMA
description: Someone has got to come to the defense of the vicar of Norfolk and I'm going to do it. Norfolk, England. 1949. In a play by Wynyard Browne called ''The Holly and the Ivy,'' now available in a letterperfect if accent-studded production staged by Lindsay Anderson for the Roundabout Theater's tiny house on 26th Street, recently renamed the Susan Bloch.

title: Jack Fields Fiance Of Anne C. Kearns
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. Kearns of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne C. Kearns, to Jack C. Fields Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fields of Madison, N.J.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit to Stop Deer Hunt at Harriman Park
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a lawsuit aimed at stopping a controversial deer hunt in a section of Harriman State Park.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Reagan Presents Missile Plan and Braces for Fight
description: How much does deterrence take? President Reagan's conclusion, delivered last week, surprised no one. No less, Mr. Reagan said, than $26 billion for a new intercontinental missile based outside Cheyenne, Wyo. -100 of them, packed 1,800 feet apart in a 14-by-1.5 mile strip of silos and (so goes the theory) able to survive Soviet attack and strike back.

title: NAKASONE GIVES THE U.S. A SUMMARY OF HIS VIEWS
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan has informed the White House and the State Department of his views in an unusual document that he called ''a political resume.''

title: BRITISH LANDSCAPES EXHIBIT IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN UNTIL about 300 years ago, mountains were regarded by Europeans as nature's defects - wrack left by the Flood - and, in painting, they were generally relegated to the background. Then, because of changes in the theological climate (and probably because of new scientific ideas prompted by the Age of Discovery, too), mountains began to come up in the world.

title: No Headline
description: Missouri Surprises Carolina

title: PACE QUICKENS IN MARKET FOR NEW HOMES
description: THE housing market in the metropolitan area is responding positivelyb ut unevenly to the decline in mortgage interest rates, many home b uilders and mortgage lenders report.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOULDER
description: WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT is chief of The Times bureau in Denver.

title: PRODUCTIVITY WATCHDOG
description: New York City's Budget Director, Alair A. Townsend, remembers a budget session last June when the city wanted to ''roll'' $30 million from fiscal year 1982 to fiscal year 1983. She was up against Sidney Schwartz, the state's special deputy comptroller for the city.

title: TRAIN ITEM DERAILED
description: An item here last week mentioned two model-railroad shows in Union; however, because of a production error, it described only one of them. What was deleted was the 11th annual Union County Model Railroad Show, which opened this weekend and will continue for the next two.

title: SECURITY MAY TIGHTEN AT TRIAL IN JUDGE SLAYING
description: A Federal marshal may accompany Charles Voyde Harrelson, on trial here in the murder of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., when he retakes the witness stand Monday.

title: Giants' Bright Is Considering a Safer Style on Punts
description: In his year and a fraction in the National Football League, Leon Bright of the Giants has fielded 66 punts without ever having made a fair catch. That may soon change.

title: Which Way Out of Transit Fare Maze
description: New York City's 75-cent subway fare came under pressure from two directions last week - riders with those 17 1/2-cent Connecticut Turnpike tokens pulled it down while deficits threatened to push it up.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS OVER SMALL KLAN RALLY IN CAPITAL
description: The police used tear gas today to contain an unruly crowd that was protesting the first Ku Klux Klan rally here in 57 years.

title: A SPIRITED SALTBOX
description: Ghost stories are always fun, whether you believe in them or not, and in that spirit we offer the tale of Sandra and Richard Hamilton, who are trying to sell what they claim to be a benignly haunted house in Easton, Conn.

title: And Now These Messages ...
description: At least in theory, television stations are now free to program toilet paper commercials all day long with maybe a few minutes of an old movie thrown in for kicks. A Federal judge approved last week a consent decree between the Justice Department and the broadcasting industry that eliminated restraints on length and frequency of ads.

title: FRENCH CUISINE IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD THERE'S a newcomer in Stamford - Le Parisien, a French restaurant ensconced on Hope Street in a building formerly occupied by an Italian restaurant. If you enter from the rear parking lot, you'll pass a long, dark bar before reaching the lighter dining rooms that are separated by open arches. The cream-colored walls have been decorated with lighthearted Paris scenes painted on the stucco. Acoustics could be improved: the sound level is shrill at times.

title: THREE NOVELS
description: RUN WITH THE HORSEMEN By Ferrol Sams. 422 pp. Atlanta: Peachtree Publishers. $12.95.ALMOST FAMOUS By David Small. 416 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $13.95.A BOOK OF SONGS By Merritt Linn. 309 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95.

title: KEAN'S QUEST FOR FUNDS RINGS A FAMILIAR BELL
description: TRENTON FORMER Gov. Brendan T. Byrne was back in his old office last week to watch his official portrait being unveiled and hung next to those of his predecessors.

title: Recent Sales
description: Madison, Conn. $88,000 36 Hilltop Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; *2*walk to town and beach, 1/2 acre; taxes $1,180. Bethel,Conn. $64,000 80 Chestnut Street *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 11-year-oldtown house condominium; *2*electric heat, garage, basement, charges $57; taxes $834. Brookfield, Conn. $140,000 37 Arapaho Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; *2*3 fireplaces, electric heat, 1 acre; taxes $2,247. Bedford, N.Y. $180,000 Cedar Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2 -bath, 17-year-old colonial; *2*3 fireplaces, 2 acres; taxes $3,388. New Rochelle, N.Y. $215,000 71 Beechtree Drive *2*6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor/Norman; *2*family room, breakfast room, maid's room, *2*screened porch, 100 by 179 foot lot; taxes $5,550. Ossining, N.Y. $43,500 49 Old Albany Post Road *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old frame; *2*studio, dark room, sauna, on Croton River. 1/3 acre; taxes 2,108. OTHER AREAS Edison, N.J. $85,000 3 Barbara Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 17-year-old *2*split level; pool, air-conditioning, taxes $1,600. Woodbury, L.I. $122,000 7 Irving Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; *2*dining room, family room, sun porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,408. Wantagh, L.I. $60,000 3199 William Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; *2*fireplace, basement; taxes $1,800.

title: Brooklyn Teacher Shot In Robbery on Subway
description: A Brooklyn teacher was shot in the abdomen early yesterday while riding the subway when he resisted at least four teen-agers who were trying to steal his sheepskin coat at gunpoint, the Transit Authority police said.

title: Boss of Bosses In Crime Fight
description: A commission last week came up with a prescription for what ails New York's criminal justice system and Governor-elect Mario M. Cuomo took little time in filling it. In his administration's first appointment, Mr. Cuomo selected Lawrence T. Kurlander for a newly created job as Albany's top crime fighter.

title: 'BARNUM' IS IN NEED OF MORE BARNUM
description: ELMSFORD BEFORE ''Barnum'' begins at An Evening Dinner Theater, the customers have already been regaled by a sideshow of sorts. Performers walk (sometimes backward or upside down) on the rails in front of - and, it almost appears, atop - the tables. Balloon-dueling and hoop-twirling tumblers and jugglers are all over the theater, which is dressed up for the occasion with high flying multicolored banners, streamers and, of course, balloons.

title: A GUIDE FOR MODERN ELIZABETHANS
description: DAVID WICKERS is a writer who lives in Norfolk, England.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe that our country's defense efforts have not been adequate. And I understand the argument put forward by the United States and its European allies that Japan should increase its military spending now that it has become a great economic power.'' - Yasuhiro Nakasone, Prime Minister of Japan. (7:1.)

title: THE POP RECORD INDUSTRY IS UNDER ELECTRONIC SIEGE
description: The American record industry will sell a projected $3.6 billion worth of albums, singles, and music tapes in 1982, earning more money than movies, the theater, video arcade games, or any other form of amusement. More than 90 per cent of the records sold are of rock and pop music, with classical, jazz and other categories accounting for the rest. In terms of dollars and cents, popular music is America's biggest entertainment industry, and has been for the past decade.

title: SOLIDARITY CHIEFS CALL OFF PROTEST
description: Underground leaders of Poland's outlawed Solidarity union announced today that they had called off protest demonstrations planned for next month. They said recent actions by the Government had created a more conciliatory atmosphere.

title: DR. ALEXANDER RICHMAN
description: Dr. Alexander Richman, emeritus professor of clinical medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and a consulting physician at Mount Sinai Hospital, died yesterday at Mount Sinai. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SNOW MAKERS VITAL TO SKI AREA
description: CORNWALL ALMOST 50 years have passed since Walter Schoenknecht convinced the Connecticut State Forest and Parks Commission to allow him to operate a ski area on public land at Mohawk Mountain.

title: Rare Hurricane; Batters Islands
description: ''It was down there moving slowly in this direction,'' a weather service official said last week after Hurricane Iwa had taken its toll, ''and then it just took off.'' Indeed it did, and for 10 hours the three northernmost of the Hawaiian islands were raked by waves powerful enough to drag a hotel into the surf and by winds that reached 110 miles an hour.

title: CHINA'S NO. 1 DEPARTMENT STORE
description: Once it was called Dai Sun and it was the biggest, most lavish department store in Shanghai, and therefore in China, rising 10 stories above Nanking Road, Shanghai's busiest, most Westernized shopping street.

title: SWIMMING AND SURVIVING
description: WATER DANCER By Jenifer Levin. 368 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95. MATTERS OF CHANCE By Gail Albert. 254 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT M.T.A.'S PROJECTS TO AID ECONOMY
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's program for rebuilding New York City's subway and bus system will significantly bolster the region's economy, particularly the construction trades, according to an economic analysis by the Port Authority.

title: Coming Unglued: Just a Figure Of Speech?
description: What holds together two neighboring nerve cells in the brain? What else but glue, according to scientists at Rockefeller University who have discovered that a kind of molecular adhesive binds nerve cells to form nerve fibers, which constitute the complex ''wiring'' of the brain.

title: YESHIVA U. IS GIVEN $3.75 MILLION GIFT
description: Yeshiva University has been endowed with the largest single scholarship program ever given the institution with the establishment of a $3.75 million fund by the Max Stern Foundation, the university's trustees announced.

title:
AMERICAN JUMPSHOTS IN EUROPE;
G Y Dryansky is an American writer living in Paris
description: For John Gianelli, a quiet Californian and a former New York Knick now playing for an Italian club, Billy Milan, the evening's playing conditions in Bologna are what he has more or less become accustomed to after three years of Italian basketball. A sputtering, derisive rain of 50-lira coins is falling on the court -launched by worthies in furs and the normal run of fans, all in an exalted state of animosity. They have filled the 8,000 seats and are making more noise than is made by 20,000 New York spectators. At least five out of six of them are here for every home game throughout the eight-month season.

title: BARANELLO LEAVING POST 'WITH CLASS'
description: THE morning after Gov.-elect Mario M. Cuomo disclosed that he wanted a new Democratic state chairman, the present state chairman, Dominic J. Baranello, who is also Suffolk Democratic leader, managed a stiff upper lip.

title: CAREY TO RECEIVE $6,000-A-YEAR STATE PENSION
description: Governor Carey, when he finally files the proper papers, will get a state pension of about $6,000 a year for his eight years' service as Governor.

title: SPOOF BY USHERS ENDS OPERA SEASON
description: EAST HADDAM GOODSPEED Opera House normally closes its fall season with performances for special audiences, and this year was no exception. ''You got the bug! You got the bug! You got the jitterbug!'' they sang. ''Your fingers snappin' while you're tappin' the beat.'' The song and accompanying jitterbug steps were classic Goodspeed Opera House fare, but the number was not being performed by the stars of ''The Great American Backstage Musical,'' which ends its run today, closing the opera house season.

title: AT HOLIDAY TIME, LET THE BUYER BEWARE
description: With the holiday season almost here, many people will be shopping for cameras, lenses, and other photographic accessories - for friends and relatives, as well as for themselves. Unfortunately, many will wind up paying more than they should for some items and others will be end up making unsatisfactory purchases because of the deceptive advertising and selling practices that some camera stores engage in.

title: MEXICO WANTS INDEPENDENCE BUT NEEDS U.S.
description: When they met in San Diego last month, President Reagan casually recalled that Mexico's incoming President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, had studied for a time at Harvard. Suddenly, his guest looked embarrassed. Personal identification with the United States is something no Mexican official wants publicized.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in October, led by higher prices for new houses and increased transportation costs. The rise was slightly more than expected but not enough to cause an adjustment in the projected annual inflation rate of 5 percent.

title: BROAD RECOVERY CALLED ESSENTIAL TO JOB CREATION
description: President Reagan and Congress will not succeed in reducing the unemployment rate without a broad and vigorous economic recovery, many economists say.

title: NEW CHINESE PLACE AT A MALL
description: DAVID'S CHINA GARDEN in Massapequa opened a few months ago at the edge of the Sunrise Mall. But don't wait for a shopping trip before dining at David's. This is one of the better Chinese restaurants in the area.

title: Rimington a Finalist
description: Nebraska's center, Dave Rimington, who has won the Outland Trophy the last two years as the outstanding lineman, is one of the four finalists for the 13th annual Lombardi Award as college football's best lineman, which will be presented Dec. 9 in Houston. The other three are Arkansas' Billy Ray Smith Jr., a defensive end; Arizona State's Vernon Maxwell, an outside linebacker, and George Achica of Southern California, a nose guard. All are seniors.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: MONUMENTAL SQUEEZE FOR OFFICES
description: If you have whizzed by the huge ziggurat-shaped mound of earth that has appeared along Route 3 in Lyndhurst, N.J., and thought that an Assyrian or Mayan religious cult had taken over the former site of the Route 3 Drive-in theater, you were wrong. What is going on there is in the cause of a material, not a spiritual, goal.

title: YOUTH EXCHANGE VISITS SET UP
description: Charles Z. Wick, director of the International Communications Agency, has announced the start of an international youth exchange program that is expected to bring as many as 15,000 foreign students to the United States.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Stimulating Conversation It could be a case of misery in search of company. But it seems more likely that convicted heroin dealer Leroy (Nicky) Barnes has found that the easiest way to get out of prison is to help put other people in.

title: No Headline
description: The division of labor between composer and performer, playwright and actor is relatively recent. The two functions used to be combined in one by the minstrels and bards of old, who improvised their own variations on works passed on by oral tradition from generation to generation. This should give pause to anyone trying to make hard-andfast distinctions; common origins suggest that the two functions may still have more in common today than meets the eye.

title: AFTER BERTRAND RUSSELL
description: PHILOSOPHY IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY By A.J. Ayer. 283 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: Fire Near Akron Kills 2
description: A fire swept the lobby and office of the Bunker Ridge apartment complex in Green Township south of Akron today, killing two people and injuring seven.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: TARRYTOWN IT doesn't make much of an impact in print, but in its immediate form, this sentence was supposed to be quite revealing: ''I am writing something so that each of us can look at our handwriting.'' The occasion was a course in graphoanalysis, and four individuals - earnest, smiling, eager to tap any source of potential self-knowledge - were scrawling words across paper in an effort to unearth clues to their own psyches.

title: AN INVITING CANAPE
description: To most people a canape means an appetizer. The bridge term, common in Europe but unfamiliar on this side of the Atlantic, also refers to a something that whets your partner's appetite.

title: FAMILY QUESTIONS SALVADOR INQUIRY
description: WHEN Raymond Donovan retired in 1977 as chief of design for the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of United Technologies, after a 32-year career with the company, he planned to move to Florida and take up a new life combining business and pleasure.

title:
OPINION;
LONG DIVISION WITH DESSERT
description: '' 'Going Dutch' (each person - or couple - paying his own way) is the universally accepted way of paying for a meal enjoyed with friends .... The very best way of doing this is to ask for separate checks.'' - ''The New Emily Post's Etiquette'' I have news for you, Emily. In this hurry-up, high-pressure, h ighoverhead world, restaurants today are not about to waste time andm oney preparing separate checks.

title: ANSWERS SOUGHT TO TRAFFIC WOES
description: ATLANTIC CITY FOUR high-level parking garages planned by hotel-casinos here for already highly congested Pacific Avenue, their back door, and a fifth garage that the Atlantic City Medical Center plans to begin soon will either bring traffic to a standstill or benefit it, according to two divergent ''official'' viewpoints.

title: THE VISION IS EUROPEAN
description: Dance for dance's sake is not on the agenda on the ''Ballet International'' series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The kind of formalist and plotless ballets or modern-dance pieces that have dominated American dance in the past 20 years are unlikely to be prevalent among the six European companies appearing at the Academy from this autumn through May.

title: Eve Dunbar Jones and Zack H. Bacon 3d Married
description: Eve Dunbar Jones and Zack Hampton Bacon 3d were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Jacksonville, Fla., by the Rev. Barnum McCarty.

title: TRIUMPHS & TROUBLES
description: CAIN By Roy Hoopes. Illustrated. 684 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $25.

title: DAVID SMITH SEEN IN HIS FULL RANGE AND SCOPE; WASHINGTON
description: David Smith (1906-65) personifies our hero image of the great American artist. We admire his prodigious talent, which brought a transcendental Yankee vision to the ideas and forms of European Modernism. We respect his practical inventor's mind, his versatility and his large appetite for work, which made him one of the most prolific of sculptors. And we're also intrigued by the legend of his life, a largely solitary one on a farm in Bolton Landing, N.Y., surrounded by mountains, sky and the sculptures he placed outdoors that served as a surrogate family - a life ended at the age of 59 when his pickup truck swerved off the road. (It's a legend not dissimilar in some respects to that of another American hero-artist, Jackson Pollock.)

title:
OPINION;
LAWS WONT'T HELP IN PLANT CLOSINGS
description: AT a time when national unemployment figures are at alarming levels and jobs appear to be shifting from one part of the country to another, legislatures at both the state and Federal levels have been flirting with some form of restrictive plant-closing legislation as a means of preserving jobs.

title: TIRUMALA: THE PROGRESS OF A PILGRIM
description: ELEANOR MUNRO, the author of ''Originals: American Women Artists''(Simon & Schuster), has recently been traveling to places of pilgrimage around the world for a book to be published by Thames and Hudson.

title: MORICHES INLET: NEW INSIGHTS
description: DATA being made available for the first time are helping scientists better understand the dynamics of Moriches Inlet and the impact of the troubled and often treacherous link to the Atlantic Ocean on shoreline communities from Mastic Beach to Westhampton.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Lakers vs. Golden State Warriors, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) Cross-Country The Athletics Congress national championships, at the Meadowlands, East Rutherford, N.J., noon, junior women's race, followed by open women's race, both five kilometers (3.1 miles) at 12:30, and men's 10-kilometer race, 6.2 miles at 1:30. Henry Rono and Eamonn Coghlan are among the men entered. Among the women are Julie Brown, the defending champion, Jan Merrill, Joan Benoit and Julie Shea. The top seven women qualify for the world championships March 21 in Gateshead, England.

title:
OPINION;
WHY NOT STAY MARRIED?
description: AN aunt of mine, in her 80's, is sorting out her papers, the accumulation of many years. ''I've found old letters to and from H.,'' she writes, ''that I am leaving bundled. If the boys wish to read them sometime, they are welcome to. They will find the letters reflect two very compatible people, who were deeply in love for over 50 years, and who had great respect for each other.''

title: WELCOME BACK TO THE PHYSICAL WORLD OF PRO FOOTBALL
description: ANYONE who doubts that the pro football strike involved any real working men should look at players' hands. Fingers like rocky-soil carrots. Scars on the backs of the hands like moon craters, where scab after scab after scab has been knocked away too soon. ''The greatest poverty is not to live in a physical world,'' wrote Wallace Stevens. Players, while they are playing, don't have that economic problem.

title: POP: BALLADS IN RARE DUET BY 2 WOMEN
description: Olivia Records, a West Coast-based record label that was formed in the early 70's by women to make feminist pop music, celebrated its 10th annivesary with two gala concerts Friday at Carnegie Hall. Featuring its best-selling artists, the singer-songwriters Cris Williamson and Meg Christian, the event had the emotional aura of a victory celebration.

title: REAGAN TO ASK CUT IN RURAL AREA AID
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing to prescribe formally for small towns and rural communities much what it did for cities last summer: less Federal money, more state and private authority and encouraging investment in depressed areas through its ''enterprise zones'' program.

title: A PRECOCIOUS ARTIST WHO WAS NO NAIF
description: Chance is the hobgoblin of photography as an art form. Skeptics are convinced that anyone - even a monkey - given enough time and enough film, could produce pictures like those seen in museums and praised by the medium's critics. Modern photography is especially susceptible to this argument, since it emphasizes and values precisely those characteristics - frozen gestures, accidental compositions, unlikely juxtapositions - which seem most ''natural'' to the camera.

title: REMEMBER THE WINTER OF '88? FORGET IT
description: ''ACOLDER than normal winter is coming!'' ''The worst winter of the century,'' says one climatologist. ''Frigid temperatures are forecast for the next four months.'' It's that time of year again - the climate pundits are at it once more, knowing full well that we'll be so happy at the end of winter that few of us will really care if a climate prediction made four months earlier was correct.

title: Disney Approves Hiring Plan
description: Blacks and members of other minority groups trying to get jobs in the film industry will receive a helping hand from Walt Disney Productions, which announced a series of actions to be taken after 10 months of talks with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT MICHIGAN'S BUSINESS SCHOOL;
THE NUMBERS THAT DISCOURAGE ACCOUNTANTS
description: For more than a decade, there was a double standard in Michigan's Graduate School of Business: first came the accountants, then came everyone else.

title: James D. McMahon Weds Elizabeth Kirby in Jersey
description: Elizabeth Ann Kirby, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James C. Kirby of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to James David McMahon, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. McMahon of Bahama, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Gerald S. Mills performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J.

title: BOARD WORKS AGAINST A BUDGET DEADLINE
description: COUNTY legislators began work on the 1983 budget last week, and not a moment too soon. Although final approval is still a month away, an initial deadline looms up for next Thursday, when they must decide on additions to the proposed financial program. Pressure to do so is coming from several directions.

title: TELL US ABOUT YOURSELF, NEW NEW JERSEY
description: QUESTION: It's so seldom that I get to interview a state, so let's get right to it. Answer: Go right ahead. Q: Tell us, how does the New New Jersey differ from the Old New Jersey?

title: IT'S MAN VS. MACHINE IN COURTROOM REPORTING TEST
description: Joseph Barbella has two keen ears, 10 swift fingers and a 22-key stenography machine. The large tape recorder near Judge Jack B. Weinstein's bench in Federal District Court in Brooklyn has five levers for volume and tone and other controls marked ''stop,'' ''fwd,'' ''play'' and ''rec.''

title: Antioch Review Finds Money For at Least Two More Issues
description: The Antioch Review, a nationally known literary magazine that faced the prospect of closing because of financial problems, has been given a reprieve, its editor says.

title: Vatican Shelter?
description: The news report last Feb. 21 said the Vatican would begin building ''a $1.6 million bomb shelter in June to protect its library collection against nuclear attack.'' It quoted the head of the Vatican Library, the Rev. Alfons Stickler, as saying the underground shelter - 18 feet deep - would be in the library courtyard at Vatican City.

title: HOW TO CUT UTILITY COST IN A CO-OP
description: ON one floor there may be a bachelor who travels a lot on business a nd rarely is at home. He does not own an air-conditioner; he sends h is laundry out and he eats so few meals at home he usually leaves t he refrigerator unplugged.

title: WEAPONS TO THE END
description: THE PURSUIT OF POWER Technology, Armed Force and Society Since A. D. 1000. By William H. McNeill. 405 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $20. THE THIRD WORLD WAR The Untold Story. By General Sir John Hackett. 372 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $15.75.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 3-0
description: The Rangers, riding a wave of success and playing at the top of their form, shut out the Islanders tonight, 3-0, in Nassau Coliseum.

title: TIPS ON HOW TO TAKE CARE OF THE HOUSE WHILE YOU'RE AWAY
description: THE prudent homeowner who takes a winter vacation and leaves his house unoccupied for days, or even weeks, should take steps to protect his home from weather damage, as well as from intruders who often find an empty house an irresistible target for a break-in.

title: SOVIET AFFAIRS EXPERTS WITH NOTHING TO DO
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING LONDON A KEY OF MUSICAL 'CAROL'
description: week holiday run. But the main character in this latest version of Charles Dickens's seasonal classic will be London, according to Peg Murray, the veteran character actress who has adapted and directed the productions.

title: CASINO GAMBLING IS A SUCCESS
description: CASINO gambling in Atlantic City is a success. Every measure of growth indicates that the gaming and hotel industries there have met or exceeded the economic projections of 1976. For example:

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE announcement last weekend that the state's Department of Environmental Protection had proposed a $200 million bond issue to help save open spaces came as a surprise to Assembly Democrats. They generally are said to work closely with the Kean administration on environmental matters.

title: SHOULD YOU GO TO A MOVIE BECAUSE IT'S GOOD FOR YOU?
description: If you want to convince a friend to see a particular film, don't, for heaven's sake, call it ''worthy.'' Call it ''great,'' ''a turnon,'' ''a side-splitter,'' ''filthy,'' ''a joy'' or, maybe, just ''tolerably good.'' Whatever you say, don't suggest that seeing it is a necessity or an obligation, which is the quickest way to reduce potential interest to acute boredom. The people who buy the tickets that turn movies into smash hits know that necessities are purchased at the drug store and obligations are handled at the bank. Going to the movies is not a duty.

title: Melinda Hevner Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vernon L. Hevner of Park Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Verel Hevner, to David E. Canty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Canty of Teaneck, N.J.

title: LAWYERS STILL SOUGHT FOR DETAINEES FROM HAITI
description: Six months after a judge ordered the parole and release of the 2,000 Haitians in Federal detention centers, a program to find volunteer lawyers for them is making substantial progress but is short of assuring full representation, according to organizers of the drive.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TOUCH OF THE SWISS IN OSSINING
description: BRASSERIE SWISS is a comfortable, rustic restaurant enlivened with international prints, clippings, posters and maps, all in all prettily arranged in a space that is essentially a square box. The owners, Rolf Baumgartner, who is the chef, and Max Buser, who is everything else, have been extending warm Swiss hospitality in their restaurant for five years. A blackboard menu announces about a halfdozen daily specials that supplement the brief regular menu. Orders from either source will bring freshly made, hearty, countrified food, food in hefty portions, not surprising for a cuisine developed from a national need for thick, stick-to-the-ribs fare, food to climb mountains by.

title: 'KOSINSKI IS WORTHY OF OUTSUPPORT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Alison H. Mundy Plans a Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Robert Mundy of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Heath Mundy, to Charles Stuart Schwartz, son of Shepard Schwartz of West Hartford, Conn., and Provincetown, Mass., and Gerda Shepardof New York.

title: November 28, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE ARAB-ISRAELI WARS: War and Peace in the Middle East. By Chaim Herzog. 10 THE BALLAD OF JOHN AND YOKO. By the Editors of Rolling Stone. 16 BUREAUCRATIC DEMOCRACY: The Search for Democracy and Efficiency in American Government. By Douglas Yates. 10 CAIN. By Roy Hoopes. 13 ELVIS. By Dave Marsh. 16 GRAMMAR AND GOOD TASTE: Reforming the American Language. By Dennis E. Baron. 11 GREAT BALLS OF FIRE: The Uncensored Story of Jerry Lee Lewis. By Myra Lewis with Murray Silver. 17 HIGH SCHOOL ACHIEVEMENT: Public, Catholic, and Private Schools Compared. By James S. Coleman, Thomas Hoffer and Sally Kilgore. 11 PHILOSOPHY IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY. By A.J. Ayer. 3 THE PURSUIT OF POWER: Technology, Armed Force, and Society Since A.D. 1000. By William H. McNeill. 7 ROBERT LOWELL: A Biography. By Ian Hamilton. 1 'SUBTLE IS THE LORD ...': The Science and the Life of Albert Einstein. By Abraham Pais. 9 TEACHING A STONE TO TALK: Expeditions and Encounters. By Annie Dillard.13 WITH ENOUGH SHOVELS: Reagan, Bush and Nuclear War. By Robert Scheer. 7 FICTION ALMOST FAMOUS. By David Small. 27 THE BLACK ANGEL. By Cornell Woolrich. 20 THE BLACK CURTAIN. By Cornell Woolrich. 20 THE BLACK PATH OF FEAR. By Cornell Woolrich. 20 A BOOK OF SONGS. By Merritt Linn. 27 MATTERS OF CHANCE. By Gail Albert. 12 PROMISE THE EARTH.

title: SHANGRI-LA
description: To the Editor:

title: 'BARE KNUCKLED BUTCHERY' WAS SANER
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE WAR IRAQI ECONOMY PLOWS AHEAD
description: A nation that proceeds with work on a subway system in its capital while locked in a long war with a revolutionary and populous neighbor might strike some as foolhardy. But work on the Baghdad subway - among other major development projects - is continuing here despite a war that is costing Iraq, according to foreign estimates, $600 million to $1 billion a year.

title: STEEL'S ELUSIVE SEARCH FOR A NEW DEAL
description: WHEN the chief negotiators for the United Steelworkers of America and the steel industry shook hands 10 days ago on a package of wage concessions to replace the current contract, it seemed that the industry's labor problems were finally on the way to resolution. The union had rejected a similar giveback scheme last July. But this time the deal looked like a sure bet.

title: PUTTING JURIES ON THE COUCH
description: In a United States District Court in Chicago two years ago, a 12-member jury listened for 15 weeks to dozens of witnesses and mountains of evidence in an antitrust suit brought by M.C.I. Communications Corporation against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The jurors then retired, deliberated for three days, and emerged to announce that they believed M.C.I. had been damaged; that they found A.T.&T.'s monopolistic practices to blame, and that they were awarding M.C.I. $600 million. Since antitrust awards are automatically tripled for punitive purposes, the net due was $1.8 billion - the largest antitrust judgment in history. The attorneys at Jenner & Block, M.C.I.'s Chicago law firm, were delighted - but perhaps not entirely surprised. With the help of a new breed of specialists known as ''jury researchers,'' they had already tried the case three times in varied forms before carefully constructed mock juries and had gleaned experimental evidence as to how things would go in court.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: THEATER The C.S.C. is continuing its dauntless exploration of dramatic masterpieces. The company opened the season with both parts of Goethe's ''Faust,'' and has now brought back last spring's production of Strindberg's ''Ghost Sonata.'' All three plays are being performed in repertory.

title: NUTS: FOR THE HOLIDAYS, FOR MANY PURPOSES
description: NUTS, for many, have always been synonymous with the holidays, eaten by a fire along with tangerines and dates after a good dinner. The bowl that is passed around includes walnuts, hazelnuts, almonds and those recalcitrant Brazil nuts, always the last to go because even the toughest nutcracker has difficulty opening them.

title: HIS VISION IMPAIRED, CRASH VICTIM LEADS SEARCHERS BY PHONE
description: Bloodied and partly blinded by an automobile accident, Kenneth Meggison listened for sirens as he clutched a telephone in an empty house, using the sounds to guide rescuers.

title: Miss Day Has Nuptials
description: Catherine Theodora Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aristides A. Day of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruno Bertocci, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ugo Bertocci of Rockville, Md. The Rev. Robert G. Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Holy Trinity Cathedral in New York.

title: DRAINPIPER'S JERSEY LAMENT
description: TRENTON ''SEWERS and drainpipes don't make attractive political platforms,'' Governor Kean said last month. Maybe not, but along with the state's pock-marked and crumbling highways and the dozens of bridges in danger of collapse, the inadequacies of New Jersey's water supply and treatment systems could undermine the goals of any administration, as Mr. Kean recognizes.

title: WHY NOT A WOMAN AS HAMLET?
description: When Joseph Papp's new production of ''Hamlet'' opens at the Public Theater on Thursday, audiences will see a lithe, dark Hamlet, slight but athletic and aggressive. This Hamlet fences with the best, throws Ophelia to the floor during his ''Get thee to a nunnery!'' speech, and wrestles his mother to the ground during the closet scene.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The flutist Marilyn Leigh Mead deserves praise for courageous programming. Of the five composers represented at her debut concert Sunday at Carnegie Recital Hall, three - Ned Rorem, Olivier Messaien and Robert Craig Bohmler - are still active, and a fourth, the late French composer Georges Hue, is little known in the United States.

title: U.M.W. Chief Married; Threat Upsets Schedule
description: Richard Trumka, the new president of the United Mine Workers, was married at a private ceremony today, hours before a scheduled public ceremony, family members said. A priest said he had been told there had been a threat on Mr. Trumka's life.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT MICHIGAN'S BUSINESS SCHOOL THE ROPE THEORY OF MANAGEMENT
description: Each year Prof. Noel Tichy tells the 30 M.B.A. students in his oversubscribed Organizational Change class that they can learn a few things from a rope. Too many managers, he says, act without thinking of their organization as one system and they make decisions as though each decision in each department were independent of any other.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
EARLY 'MESSIAHS'
description: Two vocal troupes have the distinction of being the first on the Island to offer Handel's ''Messiah'' this year. The Long Island Singers Society stages its annual ''Sing-Along'' today at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove, and the Long Island Choral Society mounts a full-scale production on Saturday in Hempstead.

title: J.J. Brady to Wed Janice E. Major
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Major of Weston, Conn., and Kennebunkport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janice Eileen Major, to James J. Brady 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Brady Jr. of Hamden, Conn. A late June wedding is planned.

title: Liverpool Wins by 3-0 For 9th Victory in Row
description: Kenny Dalglish scored twice in the second half to lead Liverpool to a 3-0 victory over Tottenham today in an English League First Division soccer match.

title:
OPINION;
THE PRINCESS AND THE COMPUTER
description: ONCE upon a time there was a Princess who lived in a tower and was quite ignorant of computers and ''smart machines.'' She lived an isolated life, and many thought that she was even happy.

title: Japan's Capsule Hotels
description: Think small. That's by way of preparation for introduction to an innovation in accommodations -the capsule hotel, which is springing up in increasing numbers in Japan in such cities as Tokyo and Osaka.

title: Mollie Seignious Wed in South Carolina
description: Mollie Seignious, daughter of Lieut. Gen. George M. Seignious 2d, U.S.A., retired, of Charleston, S.C., and the late Anne P. Seignious, was married in Charleston yesterday to Richard A. Makepeace Jr., son of Mr. Makepeace of New Bern, N.C., and Mrs. Robert L. Emanuel of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Frank Seignious, cousin of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Summeral Chapel at The Citadel.

title: BOOKS
description: DON'T miss, if possible, ''Pleasures of a Private Library,'' an exhibition on the joys of book collecting that will be on display at the Englewood Public Library through Dec. 31.

title: CRAFTS
description: THREE annual events, each to be held at centers of learning in northern New Jersey and New York City next weekend, attest to the emphasis by crafts professionals on the educational, as well as the commercial, benefits of quality crafts.

title: PORTRAIT RESTORED WITH SLICES OF BREAD
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS RALPH TUBBY regards events at Roslyn School Board meetings with a quizzical gaze, leaning back in his chair with the air of a man who knows he is an important figure in the community.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THOUSAND- POUND GOLDFISH By Betsy Byars. 153 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14)By MARILYN KAYE

title: TRADITION SHAPES BRITISH MUSIC
description: Tradition and superior craftsmanship are two hallmarks of some of the best British products, and this is true of British music as well. At least that is the impression given by a set of eight recordings on England's Lyrita label, newly available here, and two disks from other companies. (Lyrita disks are distributed by International Book & Record Distributors, 40-11 24th Street, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101.)

title: 3 to Get Medallions
description: The American Hungarian Foundation will present three George Washington Award Medallions at its 21st annual dinner on Dec. 6 at the Plaza Hotel. The recipients will be Eugene Fodor, editor and publisher of Fodor travel guide books; Andre Kertesz, artist and photographer, and Eugene M. Lang, president of the Refac Technology Development Corporation.

title: Penn State Wins Trophy
description: For the 16th time, Penn State has been named winner of the Lambert Trophy, which goes to the outstanding Division I team in the Northeast.

title: LIFE AMONG THE RUSSIANS
description: As long as Marc Greenfield reported his impressions of everyday life in the Soviet Union, he was most informative. However, Mr. Greenfield chose to go beyond this and make speculations that ill serve our understanding of the true nature of Soviet society.

title: Sales Through the Mails
description: The Literary Guild's annual fall gala, held earlier this month on the roof of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, was called for 6 to 8 P.M., and by 6:30 the influx of authors, agents, editors and other publishing folk was so heavy that people had to queue up in the lobby for elevators. Upstairs, guests circled the mammoth red-carpeted room, drinks in hand, stopping to talk with celebrities and colleagues.

title: KOREA'S CHURCH MILITANT
description: Tell me,'' said the Rev. Choi Soong Mook, ''do you know of another country where they arrest priests?''

title: 'MAGOO' IS A CURIOUS PIECE
description: HARTFORD IT isn't likely that the local theater season will come up with a more curious period piece than ''The Great Magoo'' the Hartford Stage Company's extravaganza that began performances two weeks ago.

title: Swallowing Hard After Irish Vote
description: The fruits of victory in last week's Irish election won't go down easy, Garret FitzGerald admitted. The Fine Gael Party leader seemed assured of another turn as Prime Minister, but he forecast ''a long tough struggle ahead to fend off the worst and try to get our finances in order.''

title: Japan Chooses Leader on Cue
description: Japan's political barons proved anew last week that their system of controlling the Liberal Democratic Party and the Parliament ''ain't ready for reform,'' as an alderman once said in Chicago. Yasuhiro Nakasone, leader of a party faction and the candidate of the other principal barons, became party president and Prime Minister in three well-disciplined organization votes.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Seventh Avenue Furs Come to Ossining

title: WHAT AND HOW HE THOUGHT
description: 'SUBTLE IS THE LORD ...' The Science and the Life of Albert Einstein. By Abraham Pais. Illustrated. 552 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: LETTERS
description: Life Among the Russians As a businesswoman who travels to Moscow frequently, I read with delight Marc Greenfield's article ''Life Among the Russians'' (Oct. 24).

title: SEXAGENERIAN JOB HUNT?
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 BELIEVED DEAD IN FIRE AT MX MISSILE TEST FACILITY
description: Four men working near the bottom of a 250-foot MX missile test cell were missing and presumed killed tonight in a fire that started as workers were cleaning up from an explosion 10 days earlier, the Air Force said.

title: Music; HE'S AN OUTSIDER WHOSE TIME IS NOW
description: Although he lived in New York for 12 years, Dennis Russell Davies has always been a little bit of an outsider as far as the American symphonic mainstream is concerned. First geographically - he made his national career unattached to a major orchestra or even a major coastal city. Between 1972 and 1980, he was the music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra. And now he serves as music director of the Wurttemberg State Opera in Stuttgart, West Germany.

title:
ART;
CERAMIC AND FIBER WORKS SHOW KINSHIP TO PAINTINGS
description: HUNTINGTON IN recent years, a trend in painting known as the ''pattern and decoration'' movement has borrowed forms, textures and motifs traditionally associated with the crafts. Designs loosely based on tiles, textiles, inlays and other decorative-arts media have turned up on canvases, and, at the same time, craft-derived materials are becoming more common in fine-arts contexts.

title: Walesa Seeks Compromise, but Is It Possible?
description: Solidarity as a free and independent union of almost 10 million workers is dead as far as Poland's military rulers are concerned; their docile Parliament will vote on ending martial law next month. But Lech Walesa, the independent union's leader until it was suspended last December, was reported last week to be clinging to the hope that something could still be salvaged.

title: JEWELRY WITH A LINK TO THE PAST
description: Marilynn Gelfman, a sculptor, is a compulsive collector of curios. For about two decades she has haunted antiques shows and flea markets acquiring the sort of miniature oddments most people overlook unless they are furnishing doll houses.

title: HI-Fi Evidence Against Williams
description: Federal prosecutors have done their best to remove reasonable doubt in the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: 'WHERE ARE THE NEW DIRECTORS?'
An Easier View Of Integration
description: The beauty of political football is that it has few rules. Last week, after five years of scant progress toward compliance with agreed-upon guidelines for integrating New York City's public school faculties, officials simply picked up the goal post and brought it to the ball.

title: CRIME
description: Cornell Woolrich's books have been hard to locate in recent years, but now five more of them are available in paperback, including THE BLACK CURTAIN, written in 1941, THE BLACK ANGEL of 1943 and THE BLACK PATH OF FEAR of 1944 (Ballantine, $2.25 each, with an introduction by Francis M. Nevins Jr.).

title: Vatican Gives Opus Dei Status of Religious Order
description: The Vatican gave Opus Dei a status equal to a religious order today, but issued strict guidelines for the secretive and conservative group.

title: RENT EXEMPTIONS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: LEE BRANDT, who is 83 years old, is the owner of building in which h alf of the tenants are exempt from rent increases because they q ualify for SCRIE, the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption p rogram.

title: Malaysia and Rumania Voice Their Concern at Arms Race
description: Malaysia and Rumania said today that they were deeply concerned by a dangerous stepping up of the arms race and called for complete disarmament, particularly in nuclear weapons.

title: DEMPSTER ROLE IN ADS DEBATED
description: THE ''Made in New York'' campaign of the state's Department of Commerce, which emphasizes television and radio advertisements featuring George G. Dempster of Woodbury, the department's Commissioner, has created hostility among a number of Albany lawmakers, who question exactly what all the hoopla generated by the campaign has done to improve the state's economy. Other critics contend that if the Commerce Department wanted to increase New York's economic productivity, it should have tried to attract industry from outside the state.

title: Dianne Lob Plans January Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Werner Lob of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dianne Friedel Lob, to Andrew Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx. A January wedding is planned.

title: Interim Licenses For Nuclear Plants
description: Re: the article by Congressman Tom Downey regarding the topic of interim operating licenses for nuclear power plants (''Shoreham: 'No' to Interim Licensing,'' Opinion Page, Nov. 7):

title: REAGAN SEEKS END TO BENEFITS FUROR
description: President Reagan, attempting to end a damaging controversy, has personally ''vetoed'' the Administration's study proposal for taxing the unemployment benefits of jobless people, the White House said today.

title: RENAISSANCE ITALY
description: One mile from the Connecticut border in Westerly, R.I., a recreation of street life in Renaissance Italy will be staged from noon to 8 P.M. Thursday through Sunday and Dec. 9 through 12.

title: WHAT'S AHEAD IN TRANSPORTATION STOCKS?
description: FOR those investors who picked railroad, trucking and airline stocksa t the beginning of the bull market, their wisdom was abundantly r ewarded. The transportation group soundly outperformed the rest of t he market, as the Dow Jones transportation index of 20 stocks s oared 55 percent from Aug. 12 to early November, compared with a 37 p ercent gain by the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: BRIDGE
description: Five teams of contract bridge stars, including some of the world's best players, were bunched at the head of Reisinger team standings at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: BALLET: GERSHWIN RECALLED
description: The New York City Ballet made the Jazz Age a happy age with its Friday night performance of Jerome Robbins's ''Gershwin Concerto'' at the New York State Theater. Just as the Gershwin piano concerto to which it is set combines symphonic structures with jazz rhythms, so the ballet spices Classical technique with bits of 20's jazz and ballroom dancing.

title: CANADA CONSIDERS SETTING UP DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ALBANIA
description: Canada is considering establishing diplomatic relations with Albania in a move that appears to reflect Canadian desires for a foreign policy independent of the United States.

title: DISTRACTIONS AND SURPRISES FOR COLLECTORS
description: PRINCETON AT MOST auctions, potential buyers can read catalogues, do research and view the objects in advance of the sale, and then decide quickly during a brief but specific time of bidding.

title:
ART;
CREATIVE ENCOUNTER WITH THE HUDSON
description: A LOT of water has passed under several bridges since the flourishing of the Hudson River School about a century and a half ago. In today's parlance, it's time for an update. ''Hudson River Update,'' a show of contemporary art inspired by the river, is at The Gallery in Hastings-on-Hudson through Jan. 2.

title: Susan McClanahan Wed To Donald Paul French
description: Susan Diffenderfer McClanahan, daughter of Mrs. David R. Diffenderfer of Lincoln, Neb., and the late Mr. Diffenderfer, was married in New York yesterday to Donald Paul French, son of Mrs. Cecil French of Camden, Del., and the late Mr. French.

title: Camel Backed
description: To the Business Editor: In ''The Americanizing of Japan's Cars'' (Nov.14), the old saw ''a camel is a horse designed by a committee,'' appears.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: IF ILLNESS STRIKES ONE FAR FROM HOME
description: L ittle can be more frightening than to be suddenly injured or become critically ill far from home. There is the initial shock, and concern about what the medical future may mean and about the bills that soon begin to come in. These bills can easily run into thousands of dollars, with little if any part of it covered by insurance unless precautions are taken in advance.

title: 7 Cities Vie for '84 Convention
description: New York, Detroit, Chicago, Miami Beach, New Orleans, Houston and San Francisco are expected to make formal bids next month for the 1984 Democratic National Convention.

title: N. ELDON TANNER, 84, BUSINESSMAN AND OFFICIAL OF MORMON CHURCH
description: N. Eldon Tanner, a Mormon Church leader who guided the church's building program for nearly two decades, died today of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: A MOTHER'S WORK COMES IN DEGREES
description: FEVER is Mother Nature's warning signal that says someone's not just sick -he's really sick. The signal tells the company nurse to send a worker home for a period of time, depending on how much sick leave he has accumulated. The school nurse takes a look at the thermometer and telephones Mother to come for Junior.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ETHEL had had us out to her country place on the North Fork last year for a most pleasant day. The town is as removed in distance from where we live as the Fire Island of my boyhood summers is removed in time from the present. The North Fork village reminded me of Ocean Beach in the 1930's. Ethel was pleased that it did.

title: SAFETY AGENCIES FIND THEIR COMMON GROUND ERODING
description: Although OSHA and Niosh sound as if they came from the same kettle of bureaucratic soup, and both deal with occupational safety and health, they are arms of two different Federal departments. In the Reagan Administration, they are also at arm's length - indeed, barely on speaking terms.

title: Kitchen Conundrum
description: Question: I am residing in a two-family home in South Orange, N.J., and want to find out if the landlord is required to provide a stove and refrigerator. Is there a state law for this?...M. E.B.,South Orange, N.J. Answer: No. In New Jersey, two-family buildings are governed by local ordinances. Check with local authorities. The State Hotel and Multiple Dwelling Law in New Jersey governs units with three units or more. Your landlord's obligations probably are spelled out in the lease; you should examine the lease to determine what he has agreed to provide.

title: SPEEDWAY'S FUTURE IN DOUBT
description: LIME ROCK EVENTS in the past few months have raised questions among zoning board officials here, as well as among car-racing enthusiasts, about the future of Lime Rock Park, the auto speedway.

title: THE STRATEGIC TANGO
description: President Reagan's televised announcement that he means to deploy the MX missile in the ''dense pack'' basing scheme seemed particularly maladroit, coming at a time when he is calling upon a new Soviet leader to take positive steps toward better Soviet-American relations.

title: Miss Murphy To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Lee Murphy of Orchard Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Murphy, to Jeffrey W. Jacobs, the son of Mr. and Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Jacobs of Silver Spring, Md.

title: No Headline
description: On Adult Education On Nov. 7, Briarcliff resident John Chervokas poked fun at adult education in general and Briarcliff-Mount Pleasant-Pleasantville C.O.E.D. in particular (''A Reconsidered Look at Adult Education,'' Opinion Page). As a student of many C.O.E.D. courses over the 12 years of its existence and a recently appointed administrator of the Mount Pleasant end of the ''coalition,'' I would like to take issue with a few of Mr. Chervokas' ''cute'' remarks.

title: Susan Eschweiler, Architect, Is Wed To John M. Rivlin
description: Susan Marie Eschweiler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Quintus Eschweiler of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married there last evening to John Michael Rivlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Samuel Rivlin of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. John M. Whallon performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Chuch.

title: LANIER PACES BUCKS OVER KNICKS, 109-96
description: Bob Lanier showed tonight how dangerous he can be at age 34, given a couple of days off and having the luxury of pacing himself. After missing two games with a sore elbow and several other nagging injuries, the 6-foot-11-inch Milwaukee Bucks center returned to the starting lineup and scored a season-high 26 points as the Bucks beat the Knicks, 109-96, at the Milwaukee Arena.

title: OLD LYME RETAILERS TO OPEN AFTER FIRE
description: OLD LYME FOR the second time in five months, calamity has struck this small town. Last June, floods wrecked three bridges over streams and forced dozens of residents from their homes. The town was among several Connecticut communities declared a Federal disaster area.

title: If mortgage rates continue to decline, the amount of seller financing involved in home buying also should decline. That would please many housing economists and probably most of the sellers as well. With institutional mortgage rates so high, even after recent declines, many buyers have been unable to qualify for traditional loans of 75 percent of the purchase price. So to make the sale possible, the sellers themselves have been granting loans to the buyers - in effect, deferring the withdrawal of all or part of their equity in the house.
description: The practice is extensive. The National Association of Realtors estimates that 40 percent of the resales of existing houses throughout the country are now achieved with seller financing in some form.

title:
CRAFTS;
A RUSTIC APPRECIATION OF FOLK ART
