description: A charming show entitled ''American Folk Art Tradition'' has opened at the Pelham Art Center, highlighting crafts and paintings whose subject matter has an early-American flavor. The exhibition, a year in the making, features artists from across the country and has as curators two members of the center - Pat Reed, a collector, and Candy Tauber, an artist.

title: A VERSATILE SOPRANO TACKLES WAGNER
description: Eva Marton, a Hungarian soprano who, since her first performances ten years ago has tackled some of the most dramatic roles in the operatic repertory, already enjoys a well-established reputation. With her dynamic mix of the earthy and the ethereal, she commands a gallery of volatile Italian heroines. Now, however, she's at that career crossroads when a dramatic soprano becomes a contender for the heavier German roles. Operagoers this season have a chance to sample her versatile artistry in Ponchielli's Gioconda and Wagner's Elisabeth at the Met. She'll be performing the latter tomorrow night and five more times in December.

title: Black Couple in Illinois Get $159,000 in Bias Case
description: A United States Supreme Court Justice has ordered a housing association in the Chicago suburb of Oak Brook to pay nearly $159,000 to a black couple whose attempt to buy a $675,000 home it had blocked.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS ASSAIL U.S. ON NAMIBIA
description: African leaders condemned the United States and South Africa today for trying to link the withdrawal of Cuban troops in Angola with independence for South-West Africa, the disputed territory also known as Namibia.

title: No Headline
description: AUBURN BEATS ALABAMA, 23-22

title: GIVE THE COMPOSER A BREAK
description: In the pop-music world they used to call it ''jazzing the classics.'' One of George Gershwin's early piano pieces, for instance, was ''Ragging the Traumerei.'' John Scott Trotter, a band leader, made a pretty penny or two out of ''In an 18th Century Drawing Room,'' a direct steal from the first movement of Mozart's Piano Sonata in C (K. 545), but with a tick-tocky accompaniment. The common practice was to borrow a good tune, disguise it as much as possible in Tin Pan Alley clothes and try not to act embarrassed when some tune detective pointed out that it was taken directly from Chopin (''I'm Always Chasing Rainbows'') or Tchaikovsky (''Tonight We Love'').

title:
GARDENING;
SOME HOLIDAY GIFTS FOR THE GARDENER
description: IF all those on my holiday gift list were gardeners, shopping would be much easier. There are so many garden-oriented gifts to choose from, and many can be selected from bookstores, garden centers or mail-order catalogues.

title: BED-AND-BREAKFASTS GET MIXED RECEPTION
description: A YEAR ago, Enid and Gabriel Ford decided to spare no expense in their effort to restore the five-bedroom Victorian house they had bought in Mystic, Conn. The spacious old homestead seemed ideal, they had thought, not only as a charming residence but also as a bed-andbreakfast establishment.

title: LINK DOUBTED BETWEEN DEATHS OF OFFICER AND FRIEND
description: The police and the Queens District Attorney said yesterday that no connections had yet been found between the death of a detective involved in a police corruption inquiry and a friend slain on the day that the detective was fatally injured.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday gave the wrong day for a memorial for James Broderick, the actor. It will take place today at 11 A.M. at the Public Theater.

title: HOLMES CHARGES KING WITH ASKING FOR REDUCED PURSE
description: Randall (Tex) Cobb, Larry Holmes was informed this morning at breakfast, ''would like to fight you every night of the week because eventually you'd get tired.''

title: FRESH THINKING REVISES THE ROLE OF THE ROCK GUITAR
description: A peculiar creature appeared in rock as the 1960's ended. It was the Guitar Hero, a lead guitarist with an overlay of myth. Pop fans learned to listen to guitar improvisations during the late-60's blues revival in England and America, and when blues-based trios like Cream and the Jimi Hendrix Experience moved toward hard rock, fans continued to focus on guitar solos. For the first time, pop listeners began to appreciate virtuosity for its own sake, and they swamped certain guitarists with a combination of musicianly respect and popstar adulation: hero worship.

title: Julia Ten Eyck Wed to Lawrence Lerner on Coast
description: Julia Ten Eyck and Lawrence Richard Lerner were married yesterday at the Unitarian Center in San Francisco. The Rev. Stanley R. Stefancic performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Mexican Refinery Blows Up
description: Two explosions at a natural gas refinery in this Texas-Mexico border town early today sent flames into the air and illuminated the sky. An official at the Progreso International Bridge said there were two explosions, the first at about 3:15 A.M., Eastern standard time, and the second 15 minutes later. Initial accounts said no one was believed injured.

title: LATE GOAL GIVES ISLANDERS TIE
description: In a remarkable improvement of their play Saturday night against the Rangers, the Islanders kept trying right down to the buzzer tonight. They were rewarded when, with 1 minute 10 seconds left, Clark Gillies scored to give them a 3-3 tie with the Washington Capitals.

title: Dog Food Campaign
description: The General Foods Corporation has added a new product to its lineup of dog foods: a soft, moist food called Improved Gaines Burgers Cheese, made with cheddar cheese. It will be backed by over $9 million in advertising and promotion from Young & Rubicam beginning the first of the year. The campaign will include television commercials and the delivery of 50 million coupons, worth over $13 million, via on-pack, bonus-pack and off-pack distribution between the months of January and June.

title: A NEW YORK VOTE FOR LESS WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: Doc Cheatham Honored
description: ''A Salute to Doc Cheatham'' will be presented as part of ''Highlights in Jazz'' at New York University's Loeb Student Center on Dec. 8 at 8 P.M. Mr. Cheatham, the 77-year-old trumpeter and vocalist, will perform with such colleagues as the trombonist Vic Dickenson and the saxophonist Budd Johnson.

title: M.T.A. CHIEF OFFERS TO MAINTAIN FARES
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority pledged yesterday to hold off increases in subway, bus and commuter fares until 1984 if the State Legislature acts to close the authority's $300 million operating deficit.

title: BALANCHINE ILL, DANCERS GO ON
description: To many, George Balanchine is the New York City Ballet. It's not that the company doesn't perform the work of other choreographers. And City Ballet has its star dancers. Then, too, Mr. Balanchine seldom steps in front of the curtain to take a bow before the fans. But his ballets have been the raison d'etre for City Ballet since 1934, when Mr. Balanchine choreographed ''Serenade'' for advanced students from the School of American Ballet, founded that year at the invitation of Lincoln Kirstein. And City Ballet dances in Mr. Balanchine's distinctive brand of classical ballet.

title: Title to Lawrence
description: John Cannizarro's extra-point conversion was the margin of victory Saturday night as Lawrence High School surprised undefeated Farmingdale, 7-6, in the Nassau County Scholastic American League Conference I championship at Hofstra University. The loss left Farmingdale with an 8-1 mark and spoiled any hopes of wresting the Rutgers Cup from the current holder, Levittown Division.

title: CONCERT: LIVEOAK, TRIO, LOOKS AT 13TH CENTURY
description: ONE of the major composers of the Spanish Renaissance, Juan del Encina, took his name from the ''live oak'' -an evergreen oak, known for its strength and long life. The tree's name, which has been used as a verb, meaning ''to revitalize,'' has also been taken by the Trio LiveOak, a musical group that played as part of the ''Music Before 1800'' series at Corpus Christi Church yesterday afternoon.

title: Bills 20, Colts 0
description: Roosevelt Leaks plunged over from the 1-yard line twice in the second quarter as Buffalo won in a steady drizzle before only 33,985 fans, the lowest home turnout since November 1978. Buffalo improved its record to 3-1. Baltimore is 0-4.

title: BODY UNDER TOOLSHED FLOOR: GOOD OR BRUTAL FATHER
description: In the three weeks since Chuck Whatley's decomposed body was dug out of a shallow grave beneath the toolshed floor on his farm near here, there have been conflicting versions from his family of what kind of man he was and why he died.

title: COPING WITH TRAVAIL OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
description: Lucile and Bernard Nathanson had sailed together for three decades, so both were astonished when Mrs. Nathanson suddenly forgot which side of the boat was port and which starboard.

title: MAYOR DRAPEAU OF MONTREAL: THE LONG-DISTANCE RUNNER
description: Despite two mild strokes and six years of unanswered questions about astronomical cost overruns for the 1976 Olympic Games, 66-year-old Jean Drapeau, who was first chosen Mayor of Montreal 28 years ago, has just won election to his ninth term.

title: S.A.S. Reports Record Profit
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System has reported that it earned a record $71.3 million in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, in contrast to a loss of $8.2 million in the previous fiscal year.

title: 5th Grey Cup for Eskimos
description: Warren Moon and Brian Kelly teamed for two touchdowns today, leading the Edmonton Eskimos to a 32-16 victory over the Toronto Argonauts and a record fifth consecutive Canadian Football League title in the 71st Grey Cup game.

title: MARITAL RAPE AS AN ISSUE
description: WHAT is the difference between victims of marital rape and other r ape victims? ''It's the difference between living with the f rightening memory of having been raped, which is bad enough, and a ctually living with the rapist,'' said Dr. Kersti Yllo, assistant p rofessor of sociology at Wheaton College in Massachusetts. ''The e ffect on these women is profound.''

title: No Headline
description: Miss Navratilova a 3-Set Winner in Final

title: NEW SCHOOL LUNCH RULES STIR DEBATE
description: Changes in the Federal school lunch program have raised privacy issues and caused some administrators to question whether the added work is worth the money saved.

title: PORTER IS SURPRISE CROSS-COUNTRY VICTOR
description: Pat Porter surprised a world-class field of more than 500 runners and easily captured The Athletics Congress national cross-country championships at the Meadowlands today.

title: DEBT RETIREMENT PARTY BECOMING AN INSTITUTION
description: The fund-raising invitation was standard. Drinks next Wednesday at the home of Bill Brock, former Senator from Tennessee and the Administration's trade representative. Price of admission: $250 per person.

title: Cardinal Returns to Boston After Hospital Stay in Rome
description: Humberto Cardinal Medeiros of Boston has returned home from Rome and is described as ''doing well'' after spending several days at a Rome hospital for treatment of fluctuating blood pressure.

title: LOCOMOTIVE BUILDERS HURTING
description: As recently as early 1981, the managers of the General Motors locomotive plant in the western suburb of LaGrange were overflowing with optimism. Production was near capacity as railroads ordered the latest in energy-efficient equipment.

title: News Analysis
description: Many of the underlying problems that contributed to New York City's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's remain unresolved, although the immediate cause of the crisis - the city's inability to finance itself - has been corrected, according to a study released yesterday.

title: THE DANCE: GINA BUNTZ COMPANY
description: GINA BUNTZ is an intelligent choreographer. She is also an appealing dancer, moving with deft efficiency. But the dances that the popular young choreographer presented Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater were often troubling.

title: CHARGERS STOP BRONCOS, 30-20
description: Kellen Winslow's third touchdown catch of the game, with 6 minutes 16 seconds remaining, gave the San Diego Chargers a 30-20 victory over the Denver Broncos today.

title: Florida Town Outlaws Nudity And X-Rated Films in Taverns
description: The City Council of this Panhandle town near Eglin Air Force Base has voted unanimously to ban nudity and X-rated movies in taverns.

title: Gentry Magazine Aims For Black Male Readers
description: A new magazine called Gentry, directed exclusively toward the black male between the ages of 18 and 34, will begin publication in mid-December.

title: SOVIET AGRICULTURE: DON'T BLAME BREZHNEV
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUL AND JAZZ: ETTA JAMES ON BILL WITH DANIEL PONCE
description: ETTA JAMES made some of the earliest rock-and-roll records when she was a teen-ager in the 1950's, and some of the most powerful soul records a decade later. At various stages in her up-and-down career, she has performed for black audiences in the South and opened rock concerts for the Rolling Stones. Miss James was at Symphony Space over the weekend, on an unusual double bill with an Afro-Cuban jazzfusion band led by the percussionist Daniel Ponce. On Saturday, she performed a set of soul music that would not have been out of place in a rowdy bar.

title: Redbook to Rosenfeld
description: Redbook magazine has selected Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson as its advertising agency.

title: MACHINES MAKE MORE SKI TIME
description: THESE are the die-hard skier days when the most avid participants seek out any patch of snow, machine-made or natural, to get an early start on the season. Each year the number of such dedicated skiers grows as snow-making and snow-grooming techniques improve and expand at areas in the East.

title: VALUE OF MX PLAN IS CITED AS 'SMALL' BY BUDGET REPORT
description: The Congressional Budget Office has concluded that President Reagan's $26 billion plan to deploy MX missiles would make ''a relatively small'' contribution to the nation's strategic capabilities.

title: Following are excerpts from ''Setting Municipal Priorities, 1983,'' the fourth in a yearly series of volumes written by urban affairs specialists to set out policy options for New York City. It was compiled by Charles Brecher, an associate professor at New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration, and Raymond D. Horton, a professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business.; Local Economy and Local Revenues
description: Analysts have suggested that New York City's recent economic recovery has been geographically uneven and that the city is, in fact, becoming two cities - an affluent, economically vital Manhattan and an impoverished, shrinking economy in the outer boroughs.

title: TV: A DRAMA ABOUT HITLER YOUTH
description: ''BLOOD AND HONOR,'' a two-part, five-hour production that begins on WPIX-TV, Channel 11, tonight at 8 (the second part will be broadcast next Monday), explores not so much the effects of Adolf Hitler's Germany as one of the causes. The subject is the tremendous effort made by the Nazis to transform youth movements into vehicles for indoctrination in and total obedience to the policies of Hitler. The result was the creation of a national machine that still almost defies comprehension.

title: ANTIWAR LEADER OF THE 60's NOW HELPS WORKERS AS A LAWYER
description: When a plant is going out of business in this manufacturing area of the Middle West, or when workers feel wronged by their unions or employers, or when workers seek legal help for any number of job problems, the man they are likely to call is Staughton Lynd.

title: THE STORY OF A THANKSGIVING TURKEY
description: Ronald Reagan's masterful sense of stage presence and camera angle is never better demonstrated than when he is in isolation at his ranch and it comes time for a horseback ride.

title: WARNER CHIEF'S ROLE ARGUED
description: Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., has played the role of the missing star in a criminal trial involving the company's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: FREE SPEECH SHOULD BE A VICTIMLESS RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Useful Accord on Corrections
description: Ideological controversy is commonplace in the field of corrections. In the 19th century, the most passionate arguments raged over the design of prisons and the wisdom of isolating inmates.

title: 7-3 LOSS SNAPS RANGERS' STREAK
description: The Rangers saw their five-game winning streak ended tonight as the Sabres scored four times in the final period for a 7-3 victory before 12,731 fans at Memorial Auditorium.

title: Oilers 7, Red Wings 5
description: DETROIT (AP) - The National Hockey League's leading scorer, Wayne Gretzky, assisted on four goals as Edmonton rallied.

title: CHAMBER: THE SONS OF BACH
description: JOHANN SEBASTIAN BACH must have been an imposing father. Seeing him from the perspective of his sons Saturday night at the 92d Street Y, as Gerard Schwarz conducted the Y Chamber Symphony in music of the Bach family, the distinguished elder was a stodgy fellow indeed, so hopelessly learned, so old-fashioned with his high Baroque sensibility, so solemn, so mannered.

title: Saints Upset 49ers
description: Ken Stabler completed all five of his passes on a 99-yard touchdown drive in the rain, giving New Orleans an early lead, and the surprising Saints survived a late San Francisco rally to beat the 49ers, 23-20, today.

title: U.C.L.A. Helped to Rose Bowl
description: U.C.L.A. finished its regular season a week ago when it beat Southern Cal, 20-19. That was all the Bruins could do to keep their slim Rose Bowl chances alive. Their fate was in the hands of Arizona, which was expected to lose to Arizona State, the team seemingly headed for its first Rose Bowl trip.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Commercial Funding Inc. has elected Robert L. Krause a senior vice president.

title: PAKISTANI SEES POSSIBILITY OF ELECTIONS
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq says that Pakistan's first general elections since 1977 could be held ''within two to three years.''

title: Pay Talks Start Today For Sanitation Union
description: One of the last municipal unions in New York City that is still without a contract settlement will begin talks today with city negotiators.

title: A BAD NIGHT FOR BOXING
description: IF Randy Cobb were a bear instead of a boxer, the humane societies would be protesting the public bloodying he suffered Friday night. Picture a bear in a small enclosure being pounded from all sides while it lumbered forward for more. That's cruelty to animals. Put yellow trunks and striped socks on the victim and call it a sport, licensed by the State of Texas and sent into living rooms by ABC.

title: LANDALUCE DIES FROM VIRUS
description: year-old filly ever, died of a viral infection early yesterday morning at Santa Anita Race Track in Arcadia, Calif.

title: MUSIC ON CABLE TV PROVOKING A DEBATE
description: In a year of red ink and belt-tightening for cable television programming networks, at least one network appears headed for success.

title: VIOLIN: MILSTEIN DAZZLES
description: IN his 79th year, Nathan Milstein remains one of our most challenging and continually intriguing violinists. Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, he sped through delightful divertissements by Wienawski and Liszt - showpieces clearly calculated to dazzle. But he also presented a sizable quantity of more substantial and contemplative fare.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TWO FROM EUROPE

title: 2 Held in Air Base Protest
description: Two people were arrested and two others were banned from the K.I. Sawyer Air Force Base today at a small antinuclear demonstration. About 30 people watched as the four concluded a dawn candlelight service by climbing through the base's fence. Jim Smit of Marquette, Mich., who was given a letter banning him from the Strategic Air Command base, said the trespassing while carrying candles was symbolic of ''bringing the light of God's peace into the darkness of the nuclear arms race.''

title: JAZZ: TENOR SAX BY DEWEY REDMAN
description: The tenor saxophonist Dewey Redman (and everyone else in jazz) learned from Ornette Coleman that a melody could inspire, not circumscribe, solos. In the quartet Mr. Redman led last weekend at the Jazz Forum, his tunes started off as ballads or blues or be-bop.

title: A. RAYMOND KEY
description: A. Raymond Key, former president of Johnson, Matthey & Company of New York, refiners and manufacturers of precious metals, died last Thursday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 66 years old and had a home in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a summer home in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: AUTO MAKERS PRESSED BY A BLACK GROUP
description: Operation PUSH, bolstered by its agreement last summer with the Seven-Up Company and an earlier pact with the Coca-Cola Company to increase black participation in the soft-drink industry, is pressing the nation's auto industry for similar action.

title: Dr. John Henderson, 76, Writer And Johnson & Johnson Official
description: Dr. John Henderson, retired medical director of Johnson & Johnson and author of medical books, died Wednesday at the Merwick Unit of the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. Dr. Henderson, who lived in Kingston, N.J., was 76 years old.

title: High Waves Hit California
description: Ten-foot waves, remnants of the hurricane that battered Hawaii, pounded southern California's beaches over the weekend, and the authorities had to go to the aid of 16 people.

title: FINAL N.F.L. ACCORD EXPECTED IN DAYS
description: By the end of the week, the National Football League's long and often-acrimonious labor dispute could end with agreement on the final draft of a new five-year collective bargaining contract.

title: Patriots 29, Oilers 21
description: Steve Grogan, making his first start in more than a year, passed for three touchdowns, and the New England defense sacked Archie Manning six times. New England is now 2-1, and Houston dropped to 1-3.

title: War in Gulf Centers On South Iraq Pocket
description: Air and ground fighting raged along the Iran-Iraq battlefront today and the ruling Islamic Republican Party in Iran called on Iraqi citizens to overthrow the Government in Baghdad.

title: Lauren Wolk Wed To Richard Hall
description: Lauren Elizabeth Wolk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Wolk of Washington, and Cotuit, Mass., was married yesterday in Providence, R.I., to Richard Marvyn Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvyn A. Hall of Toronto. The Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, a Congregational minister and chaplain at Brown University performed the ceremony there in the Manning Chapel.

title: British Aluminium-Alcan
description: The proposed merger of British Aluminium P.L.C. and Alcan Aluminium Ltd. is not being referred to the Monopolies Commission, the Trade Department has announced, meaning it is free to take place. Alcan, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Canada, has offered 60 pence cash, about 96 cents, per ordinary share for British Aluminium, which is 58 percent owned by Tube Investments P.L.C.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Lake Grows In a Brooklyn Basement

title: ARTISTIC FIGHT RAGES OVER FARM IN CONNECTICUT
description: Almost a century ago, Julian Alden Weir, carrying his oils, brushes and canvas, would set forth into his farm here. He jokingly called the land ''my unprofitable rock pile,'' but its soft beauty inspired some of his most famous paintings.

title: TRADE CONFEREES REACH CONSENSUS DESPITE DISPUTES
description: A conference of 88 nations reached a consensus this morning on ways to strengthen the world trading system, although differences remain between the European Economic Community and other countries over subsidized competition in agriculture.

title: Pistons' Benson On Injured List
description: The Detroit Pistons placed Kent Benson, forward and center, on the injured list today with a strained ligament in his left knee.

title: Sports World Specials; The Weakling
description: The first thing you notice about Benn Fields is his legs. He stands 6 feet 4 inches tall and his inseam is 41 inches. Marvin Webster of the Knicks, who is 7-1 and well proportioned, has only a 44-inch inseam.

title: Noranda Hearing Set in Ontario
description: The Ontario Securities Commission has announced that it will hold a hearing on Dec. 20 to determine whether it should revoke the trading rights of three senior executives of Noranda Mines Ltd., accused of improper trading in the shares of Noranda Mines during the 1981 takeover of Noranda by Brascan Resources Inc.

title: CONNECTICUT DOWNS L.I.U. IN A SHOOTOUT
description: Connecticut defeated Long Island University, 1-0, today on the basis of penalty kicks in a shootout after the teams had played 120 minutes without scoring.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Gail Einbender Married to Paul Timothy Jacobson
description: Gail Einbender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Einbender of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Timothy Jacobson, son of Col. Gerhard L. Jacobson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jacobson of Hamilton, Va., and Glenwood, Minn. The Rev. Junius S. Koiner and Rabbi Alvin J. Reines, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York,

title: Loner to Go on Trial In Slaying of a Mayor
description: Harold W. Lang, known as an offbeat loner, is to go on trial Monday, hours before the citizens of this grieving small town bury the popular mayor he is accused of killing.

title: REDSKINS DEFEAT EAGLES FOR 4th STRAIGHT
description: When Joe Gibbs succeeded Jack Pardee as coach of the Washington Redskins last season, his debut was not exactly auspicious: his team lost its first five games. The Redskins attained respectability, however, by winning eight of their final 11 games to finish the season with an 8-8 record.

title: LOVE FINDS A WAY PAST SOUTH AFRICA'S RACE LAWS
description: In every respect except one, Ian Whiteley and his wife, Sherrin, lead an entirely conventional married life here in this town in the northern Transvaal, where white racial attitudes are generally described in geological similes such as granite-like.

title: Charred Body of a Man Found at Kennedy Grave
description: A group of tourists visiting Arlington National Cemetery today discovered the charred body of a man at the grave of President John F. Kennedy, the authorities said.

title: NEW BUILDINGS IN BUFFALO CAN'T OVERSHADOW BLIGHT
description: At Main and Huron Streets, two new bank buildings and a modern hotel are in various stages of completion, their facings of glass, granite and steel reflecting the optimism of what would appear to be a Buffalo reborn.

title: Fire in Chicago Kills 3 Children And Another Dies in Evanston
description: Three children were burned to death early today when a fire attributed to careless smoking swept their South Side apartment. In Evanston, Ill., a 6-year-old girl died in a predawn fire attributed to a malfunctioning electrical outlet.

title: HUNTING ON A PRESERVE
description: AN innovative approach to starting a private shooting preserve has been launched on Long Island by Robert Krudop, a high school teacher and businessman, and his friend Myron Kaplan.

title: Questions BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: Is the distance between the markers on the golf tee to the pin meant to be the same as the official measurement of the length of the hole? In other words, if the markers are moved forward, is the cup moved back, and vice versa?

title: Vikings 35, Bears 7
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Tommy Kramer passed for 342 yards and a careerhigh five touchdowns, three to the wide receiver Sammy White, to lead Minnesota past Chicago. Kramer completed 26 of 35 passes as the Vikings evened their record at 2-2. The Bears are now 1-3.

title: Top Guerrilla Chief in Zambia Is Reported Killed in Ambush
description: Zambian soldiers shot dead a guerrilla leader whose attacks on remote communities earned him the title of Public Enemy No. 1, the official Zambia News Agency said today.

title: Washington Watch; A Six-Month Capital Gain?
description: IF a couple of other tax matters can be resolved, Congress just might, in the special session that opens today, shorten the holding period for long-term capital gains to six months. Profits on an asset are now taxed as long-term capital gains only if it has been held for a year.

title: ROSTROPOVICHES UNITED
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist and conductor, his wife, their daughter and son-in-law performed together here Saturday for the first time in the United States, drawing three standing ovations and playing two encores.

title: Accounts
description: * Belleek Ireland Inc. to Opt-X Concepts in Advertising Inc., Clifton, N.J.

title: Swiss Back Price Curbs
description: Swiss voters today approved a constitutional amendment that commits the Government to permanent price controls. The measure was drafted by consumer groups.

title: No Headline
description: JOHN HENRY 13th IN JAPAN CUP

title: WAR POWERS RESOLUTION IN NEED OF CONGRESSIONAL BACKBONE
description: To the Editor:

title: MA BELL'S STAKE IN ASSIGNING AREA CODES
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIBERY TRIAL ACTIVIST JUDGE: PRENTICE HENRY MARSHALL
description: When Prentice H. Marshall, who is presiding over the trial of the teamster union's president for bribery and conspiracy, was appointed to Federal District Court here by President Nixon in 1973, 46 Illinois legislators signed a public letter ''deploring'' his nomination.

title: Commodities; Watching Lumber's Price Rise
description: LIKE sticking a toe in the ocean to test the water temperature, taking a look at changes in lumber prices offers an idea about the condition of the nation's economy. The reason is simple: lumber goes into new homes and condominiums, and the housing market is often regarded as a leading indicator of changes in the economy.

title: Market Place; Regional Bank Positions Itself
description: SOME banks will be more equal than others once the day arrives - and the banking industry is sure it will arrive - when the Glass-Steagall Act is modified and limitations on interstate banking are eased.

title: FOES OF ENERGY SECRETARY NOMINEE HOPE TO HINDER HIS CONFIRMATION
description: Acting Energy Secretary Donald Hodel faces a Senate confirmation hearing this week that will focus on his push for nuclear power development in the Pacific Northwest.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football Tampa Bay Buccaneers vs. Miami Dolphins, at Tampa, Fla. A matchup of unbeaten Dolphins and victoryless Buccaneers after three games.

title: REECE TRIES TO REGAIN HIS CONCENTRATION
description: This has been a difficult pro football season for Beasley Reece. But, the Giants' free safety insists, things are getting better and will keep getting better.

title: Clemson Wins Title
description: Homer Jordan thrilled a crowd of 80,000 with his passing and running today and led Clemson to a 21-17 victory over Wake Forest in the Mirage Bowl for the Atlantic Coast Conference championship.

title: SWISS WATCH INDUSTRY SLUMP
description: If Switzerland's delicate economy has been described as a finely tuned watch, then something seems seriously wrong with what might be called its mainspring.

title: A Soccer School
description: One American college which has for a long time answered the pleas from professional soccer leagues to produce native-grown players has been Hartwick College of Oneonta, N.Y. The college dropped football in 1953 and began a soccer program in 1956. Since then, Hartwick has been one of the powers of Eastern and national college soccer.

title: Celtics Top Bucks For 8th Straight
description: Larry Bird led all scorers with 37 points tonight as the Boston Celtics raced to their eighth straight National Basketball Association victory, 124-110, over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: FED'S GUIDEPOSTS SOUGHT BY TRADERS
description: Federal Reserve officials have made clear that monetary policy is aimed at more than controlling money supply growth. But people active in the credit markets are left wondering what information will guide the Fed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Obviously I used this opportunity to brief the Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Officials Press to Find Cause of Minnesota Fire
description: Investigators are still trying to determine the cause of a fire that gutted a vacant department store building and most of a bank building in downtown Minneapolis Thursday, causing an estimated $30 million in damages.

title: Italy's Socialists Clear The Way for a Coalition
description: Socialist Party leaders cleared the path today for formation of a new coalition cabinet by approving Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani's plan for curing Italy's economic ills, party officials said.

title: Beth Titunik Becomes the Bride of Philip D. Emery
description: Beth Titunik, daughter of Alan Titunick of New York and Woodstock, N.Y., and Elizabeth C. Titunik of Oakland, N.J., was married yesterday in Silver City, N.M., to Philip D. Emery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Emery of Garden City, Mich.

title: ARTICLE HEMINGWAY WROTE FOR PRAVDA IN '38 IS PUBLISHED IN ENGLISH
description: The prose and the passion of Ernest Hemingway against fascism in Spain have come to light anew in a 1,500-word article, published for the first time in English, that he wrote for an antiwar issue of the Soviet newspaper Pravda in the summer of 1938.

title: 96 Starving Wild Horses Rescued at Texas Ranch
description: Volunteers rounded up 96 weakened wild horses today from an eastern Texas ranch where about 30 mustangs starved to death over the last three or four months, the officials said.

title: Debra Loring Married To Alan H. Mechanic
description: Debra Karen Loring, daughter of Joseph R. Loring of New York and Naomi Ann Loring of Fort Lee, N.J., and Alan Howard Mechanic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Mechanic of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., were married yesterday at Temple Emeth in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Louis J. Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT WOMEN EARN
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Peace Delegation Cancels London Talks
description: A seven-member Arab committee that planned to visit London to explain an Arab peace plan has canceled the trip because British officials refused to receive the P.L.O. representative, the Algerian Foreign Ministry said today.

title: ARMS NONPOLICY
description: President Reagan's address supporting ''dense pack'' basing for the MX missile, deep cuts in strategic arms and a stable strategic balance was a testament to confused and contradictory thinking.

title: CHINA SAYS VIETNAM IS TRYING TO SEIZE PARTS OF TONKIN GULF
description: China accused Vietnam today of trying to encroach on its territory by claiming vast areas of the Tonkin Gulf and two disputed island groups.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MOONS and porcupines seem to be something of a preoccupation in many of the hundreds of illustrated childrens books I read this year. Perhaps this signifies the difficulty of achieving love. Then again, perhaps it reflects a weariness with pigs, frogs, bears and alligators. Whatever it means, here, in no particular order, are 10 illustrated books that appealed to me especially this year. That the moons outscored the porcupines 2 to 0 means nothing at all.

title: The Editorial Notebook Make Grass Greener
description: The sweet-acrid scent of marijuana is everywhere these days - suburban cocktail parties, college dorms, shopping malls, street corners at rush hour. According to the National Institute of Drug Abuse, roughly 30 million Americans smoke it regularly. Yet possession of pot remains a crime in 39 states, and selling it remains a felony in all 50.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1982; International
description: Major trading nations reached a consensus early today on an agreement to strengthen world trade and limit restrictive export competition. But despite the trade ministers' declaration in Geneva, differences still remained between members of the European Economic Community and the principal farm exporting nations, including the United States, over agricultural subsidies. (Page A1.)

title: Hoch, on 70-282, Wins in Japan Golf
description: Scott Hoch won his second golf tournament in Japan in two weeks today, shooting a 70 for a 282 total and a one-stroke victory in the $245,280 Casio open.

title: TAX EXEMPT LIST IS BIG
description: The tax-exempt bond market is facing one of its heaviest financing weeks ever, allowing investors to pick from a wide variety of issues. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimate that $4.1 billion of new issues might come to market this week and that, for November, bond sales will total $8.5 billion.

title: Nuclear Plant Operators Discover Altered X-Rays
description: Officials at the Comanche Peak nuclear power plant have found that 156 X-rays of pipe welding were altered by one of the plant's major suppliers, The Dallas Times Herald reported Saturday.

title: CALIFORNIA SEEKS TO CUT COSTS OF HEALTH CARE WITH BIDDING
description: California is making sweeping changes in its system of medical care for the poor in an effort to lower the cost of treatment by using competitive bidding.

title: The Caribbean Basin Blues
description: True to American custom, the Reagan Administration came to office avowing its deep concern for neglected hemisphere relations. Just as traditionally, Air Force One is flying south tomorrow for the usual grand tour. But in politics, it's the follow-up that matters. If President Reagan were to wring his Caribbean Basin Initiative from a lame-duck Congress, that would confound tradition.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: How Not to Demonstrate The Merits of a New Bus

title: POACHERS PUT INDIAN RHINO AT GREAT RISK
description: More than 1,050 great Indian one-horned rhinoceroses roam the Kaziranga preserve here in northeastern India, coexisting with tigers, elephants, buffalo and deer. But, although the rhinos' numbers have nearly tripled in a decade, conservation officials warn that they could join their two-horned African relatives as an endangered species.

title: OTHER STOPS IN THE AREA EXPECTED
description: Pope John Paul II will visit El Salvador early next year, a Roman Catholic Church official said here today. The trip is expected to include stops in other Central American countries and in Haiti.

title: Kenny Neil Earns Cigar
description: JUST when it appeared that the Jets had stopped making mistakes yesterday, they made another. Mike Augustyniak fumbled away the ball at the Green Bay Packers' 47-yard line, jeopardizing the Jets' 15-13 lead with two and a half minutes remaining. In two quick plays, the Packers moved to the 33. Now, in a second-and-5 situation, the Packer fullback Gerry Ellis started to run to the left, where the Jets were supposed to be vulnerable with Kenny Neil a stand-in for Joe Klecko, their all-pro defensive end who is still recuperating from knee surgery.

title: REVUE: VETERANS OF THE STAGE SALUTE 'OLD FRIENDS'
description: WHEN the first scene of a cabaret revue sends off electric waves of excitement, the assumption might be that the show has nowhere to go from there but down. But that is not the case with ''Old Friends,'' a singing entertainment by a cast of nine show-business veterans in their 50's and 60's, which plays Tuesdays at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street.

title: Barbara Ann Zalusky Married to Jordan L. Bleznick
description: Barbara Ann Zalusky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salomon Zalusky of Franklin Square, L.I., was married yesterday to Jordan L. Bleznick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald W. Bleznick of Cincinnati. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff performed the ceremony at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Bridge: Canadian Team Leads Field Into Finals of the Reisinger
description: A Canadian squad, aided by one American, led a star-studded field into the final session of the Reisinger Team Championship here tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. Their closest rivals were an East Coast quartet headed by Edgar Kaplan of New York.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1982
description: International The Geneva world trade conference reached a consensus on ways to strengthen the international trading system, even though differences remained between the European Economic Community's 10 members and other countries over subsidized competition in agriculture. Deadlocks between the United States and the Common Market were broken after the conference went into an extended session over the weekend under the chairmanship of Canada's Deputy Prime Minister, Allan J. MacEachen. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Pope will visit El Salvador early next year, a Roman Catholic Church official in San Salvador said. The visit by Pope John Paul II is also expected to include other Central American countries and Haiti. (A1:3-4.)

title: Clemson's Mirage
description: Less than a week after Clemson University was assessed some of the strictest penalties in history for violations in recruiting from 1977 through 1982, the Tigers' football team was taking part in its last bowl game for at least two years. Clemson, the nation's top-ranked football team with 12 consecutive victories a year ago, was in Tokyo, not in exile but playing in the Mirage Bowl against Wake Forest.

title: RETAILERS' WEEKEND IS UNEVEN
description: Sales on the first weekend of the 1982 Christmas shopping season proved strong in New York, San Francisco, Washington and Cleveland, but failed to reach merchants' hopes in Chicago and Detroit.

title: UNION SQUARE PARK TO UNDERGO OVERHAUL
description: Union Square Park, a historic New York City park that has become a dilapidated hangout for drug pushers and derelicts, is scheduled for a $1.5 million renovation, starting in the spring.

title: STEELERS BLANKED BY SEAHAWKS, 16-0
description: There is an awful traffic jam developing in the upper reaches of the American Football Conference. The Miami Dolphins, who play at Tampa Bay tonight, sit on top of the standings with a 3-0 won-lost record.

title: A Founder of Adler Is Micropro Chairman
description: Frederick R. Adler, one of the country's most successful individual venture capitalists, has been elected chairman of the board of the Micropro International Corporation, a fast-growing developer and marketer of microcomputer software.

title: U.S. Warns of Hazard; From Water Heaters
description: The Government has warned consumers that certain water heaters powered by fireplaces could explode and cause serious injury if they did not have an adequate device to relieve pressure.

title: West Germans Get A New Political Party
description: More than 1,500 liberal rebels formed a new left-liberal political party today to protest an alliance between Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Free Democratic leader, and Helmut Kohl, the conservative Chancellor.

title: Abductors Torch Auto With Woman Inside
description: A Queens woman was abducted and assaulted by two men yesterday afternoon who then left her bound in a burning car at Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority police said.

title: Current Interest Rates; Long-Term Rates
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.16 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST: PLANTS THAT THRIVE IN OFFICE SPACE
description: An office plant's life is not an easy one. Watering chores are overlooked, fertilizer is forgotten, leaves are rarely cleaned and repotting is unheard of. The care is casual, not because office folk are callous, but because they may be just too busy to minister to their plants, no matter how much they may treasure them.

title: Attendance Is Down Again
description: During the second week of National Football League play following the 57-day strike by the Players Association, in-house attendance continued to sag.

title: Guinness Peat Debts
description: Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. is considering legal action against those responsible for the bad debts incurred by its subsidiary, Performance Tyre Ltd., its chief executive, Alastair Morton, has disclosed. Guinness Peat has received a file on the case and will be trying to recoup the $24 million provision made in last year's accounts, Mr. Morton said after the annual meeting on Friday.

title: Oil Supply Drop Is Seen
description: Conoco Inc. predicts that the total United States oil supply will fall by 200,000 barrels daily in 1983, to 10.6 million barrels daily.

title: ISRAEL EASES TERMS FOR LEBANON TALKS
description: Israel, which has been at odds with the Lebanese Government over how to begin negotiating a withdrawal of its troops from Lebanon, today dropped a demand that the talks be held at a ministerial level.

title: GEORGIANS WILL VOTE IN LAST TWO HOUSE RACES
description: While most of their constituents spent the weekend digesting their Thanksgiving dinners and preparing their Christmas shopping lists, two Georgia Congressmen and their opponents campaigned for the last two undecided seats in Congress.

title: JOBS A PRIORITY
description: The 97th Congress will return to work Monday for a final, three-week post-election session, grappling with the same fiscal issues and priorities that have been its major concern for the last two years.

title: Minister Slays an Intruder
description: A 79-year-old minister shot and killed a man he said had broken into his church, the police said Saturday.

title: BALLET: ZAGREB TROUPE
description: BALLETGOERS were able to discover an unfamiliar company last weekend when the Zagreb Grand Ballet of the Croatian National Theater ended its first United States tour with performances at Brooklyn College.

title: Judy Kalman Is Bride
description: The marriage of Judy Kalman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kalman of Brooklyn, to Donald G. Markus, son of Dr. Werner Markus of Bel@lerose, Queens, and Ruth Markus of Floral Park, L.I., took place yesterday at the Park Avenue Synagogue. Rabbi Judah Nadish performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a sports reporter for The Record in Hackensack, N.J.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Perfect Pitch on a Platform

title: AFTER THE HOLIDAY COME TRAFFIC JAMS AND WAITS
description: A surge of travelers at the close of the long Thanksgiving weekend yesterday jammed highways and clogged bus and rail terminals with college students and other visitors leaving the city and with New Yorkers returning home.

title: TOOL ORDERS UP, SHIPMENTS DOWN
description: New orders for machine tools by the nation's manufacturers rose 37 percent in October, to $119.2 million, from the September level, according to the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: AUSTIN BIGELOW WOOD
description: Dr. Austin Bigelow Wood, a retired professor of psychology at Brooklyn College, died Friday in San Diego, where he had been living in retirement.

title: Habib, in Cairo, Urges Expanded Peace Talks
description: The special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, met today with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt to discuss ways of expanding the Middle East peace process by bringing additional Arab parties into negotiations, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: Advertising; The Boom In Direct Marketing
description: A billion dollars here, a billion dollars there - it's all in a day's work for John C. Holt, the new head of the Direct Marketing Association.

title: URUGUAYANS ELECT PARTY LEADERS IN ONE STEP TOWARD DEMOCRACY
description: Uruguayans voted for the first time in nine years of military rule today to elect political leaders who will negotiate a return to democracy.

title: EXPROPRIATIONS
description: America's long-run economic decline cannot be reversed by manipulating the money supply, taxes and Government expenditures, because the underlying problem has become more social than economic.

title: LEBANESE SAID TO SEIZE HOSPITAL'S DRUGS
description: Soldiers of the Lebanese Army seized at least $250,000 in drugs from a hospital serving the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps, the hospital's director said today.

title: OPEC Sets Dec. 19 Talks
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna on Dec. 19 to try to reach a new agreement on prices and production and to stop a developing price war, the Kuwaiti Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs, Abdul-Aziz Hussein, said today.

title: Nashville Handyman Wants to Raffle Skills
description: The state's Attorney General questioned today whether David Stillman, who is unemployed and plans to raffle off his services as a handyman for a year, would be selling himself into bondage.

title: California Irked by Removal Of a Commuter Locomotive
description: Locomotives used for the California Transportation Department's commuter service between Los Angeles and Oxnard will be removed for safety testing Monday by the Southern Pacific Railroad over the objections of the state agency.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Japanese postwar economic miracle owes much to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, the armchair general of Japan's industrial policy. The ministry also directs the nation's trade policy.

title: BENGALS STOP RAIDERS' ALLEN
description: Marcus Allen, the Los Angeles Raiders' splendid rookie running back, knew all he needed to know about the Cincinnati Bengals' defense today on the first play of the game. Taking a handoff from Jim Plunkett, the quarterback, he tried to turn the corner on the right side, only to be smothered by Reggie Williams, the Bengals' right outside linebacker, for a loss of 5 yards.

title: IS JAZZ GREEK TO CHINA?
description: To the Editor:

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhhod Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically
description: In 1981, in what officers of the 23d Precinct consider the most blatant example of systematic corruption there in recent years, two officers pleaded guilty to Police Department charges of having taken groceries from an A.&P. at First Avenue and 89th Street over a sixmonth period. As officers elsewhere in the city stood accused of stealing drugs, protecting gamblers or extorting bribes from bar owners who violated state liquor laws, Officers Robert Peluso and Angelo Norberto were brought to departmental trial for their failure to pay for salami and cheese and other items, perhaps with the store manager's consent.

title: Swift President Plans Wider Beef Operation
description: John A. Copeland, the 59-year-old president and chief executive officer of the Swift Independent Packing Company, is ''bullish on beef.'' That's no surprise.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Real Thing

title: Follow-Ups
description: * ''For about two years now, all I have been hearing is that I could play again in the National Basketball Association if I only lost weight,'' said John Williamson last week from Las Vegas, Nev. ''Well, I have lost it, and now I'm going to go out and prove that I deserve to be back in the big leagues again.''

title: Must the Duck Be Lame?
description: The lame-duck session of Congress that convenes today was requested by President Reagan to complete work on this year's budget. But other work is crowding in and if six such sessions since World War II are any guide, Congress's output in the next few weeks could be considerable. To make this duck as healthy as those that went before, we have some suggestions.

title: GOLDIN FAULTS CITY PROGRAM ON COLLECTING CHILD SUPPORT
description: New York City has shown a ''lackluster performance'' in collecting child-support payments from absentee parents for families on welfare, the City Comptroller's office said in an audit report issued yesterday.

title: PHILIPPINE PRIESTS RECEIVE A WARNING
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos vowed today to crack down on what he called rebel priests who help anti-Government guerrillas.

title: McENROE IS HAILED IN 4-1 CUP VICTORY
description: The side lineswoman made the call decisively, her right arm outstretched to indicate that Henri Leconte's high backhand volley had been wide, if only by inches. The partisan crowd of 14,000 in the Palais des Sports whistled, booed and cheered loudly, but the woman sat resolutely, her arm firmly extended for almost a minute until the noise had subsided.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 29, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 4 P.M. on mandate on Golan Heights observer force. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NAVY SEEKS TO RETURN POWER TO STRICKEN HAWAII ISLAND
description: Navy personnel were at work today on hooking up a portable 1,500-kilowatt generator to help turn on the lights of Kauai, an island whose 39,000 residents have been mostly without power since a hurricane struck Tuesday night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hot Rod Razzmatazz At the Coliseum

title: BODY FOUND IN MX TEST SITE WHERE FIRE KILLED 4
description: Rescue workers late today recovered the body of one of four men killed in an MX missile test silo during a flash fire that ''went off like a sparkler,'' the authorities said.

title: People
description: * Thomas W. Schafer named a senior partner at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: KNICKS HOPE FOR BREATHER
description: Dave DeBusschere returned to head the Knicks last spring with the hope of bringing them the kind of glory they had enjoyed when he was a player helping them win their only two championships. Instead, they lost their first seven games and were off to the worst start in their 37-year history with a 3-11 record.

title: QUEEN HELPS TO OPEN MOORE SCULPTURE CENTER
description: Shortly before 4 P.M. on Friday, there was enacted on the steps of the City Art Gallery in Leeds a most remarkable event. The doors were opened, two people came out of the building, and a huge and sustained cheer went up from the people massed in the street below, in every window in sight and on every roof that offered even part of a view.

title: THE N.S.C. AFTER CLARK
description: Why are we reading so much about the grand strategies of former National Security Advisers? Almost every news magazine expounds the views of ''Kissco,'' the intellectual power conglomerate elongating the shadow of Henry Kissinger, which now employs former National Security Council head Brent Scowcroft and is likely soon to employ the State Department's Lawrence Eagleburger. Kissco both shapes U.S. policy and passes editorial judgment on it, like a playwright writing rave reviews for his own show.

title: TRIALS INVOLVING A KLAN INFORMANT MAY DEFINE F.B.I. DUTY TO PROTECT
description: The turmoil and bitterness of attacks by members of the Ku Klux Klan on civil rights workers in the South in the early 1960's will be relived in Federal courts in New York and Michigan over the next two months, when three long-pending lawsuits are scheduled to go on trial.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's planned visit to Central America this week has already stirred political passions in that highly polarized region.

title: JETS TOPPLE PACKERS, 15-13
description: Stumbling toward the final whistle in an erratic fourth quarter that dazed both teams, the Jets surfaced with a 15-13 victory yesterday over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Sporty Cars Will Be Shorter
description: The sporty cars to be introduced by American auto makers over the next few years will be shorter than in the past and are likely to be front-wheel drive models, a trade publication is reporting.

title: Money Data Due Today
description: The Federal Reserve Board is scheduled to issue its latest money supply report today at 4:15 P.M. Announcement of the figures, normally released Friday afternoon, was delayed because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: No Headline
description: Villanova Tops Colgate, 83-63

title: SOCIAL SECURITY ALARM
description: Social Security is regarded by most of us as a fundamentally sound institution with some temporary financial problems that Congress is about to fix. That perception grossly understates a reality that threatens not only our national pension system but the whole economy.

title: Advertising; Measuring The Impact Of Publicity
description: HERE is a rude shock for all you public relations men and women who think of your calling as an art and not a science. Ketchum Public Relations, which boasts that it is one of the world's largest public relations agencies, has come up with something called the Ketchum Publicity Tracking Model, which the organization's president, Paul H. Alvarez, said is, ''to my knowledge, absolutely the first computer-based measurement system in the public relations business.''

title: 2d Expert's Body Recovered After Fire in Missile Test Cell
description: The body of a second rocket expert killed by a flash fire in an MX missile test cell was recovered late tonight by divers searching in 10 feet of water at the bottom of the 250-foot facility.

title: NEW CITY COUNCIL WILL TAKE OFFICE
description: Almost a year behind schedule, a new City Council is preparing to take office tomorrow with some old problems still facing it. The local legislature's election was delayed a year because the Federal Government objected to the Council's initial reapportionment lines. Certification of its election was delayed another month by a recount of a legislative race in Brooklyn.

title: KAPOK TREE INNS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
4 Join Board Of Wieboldt
description: Four members of a dissident group were elected to the board of Wieboldt Stores Inc., the Chicago department store chain, as the new board members assumed a majority of the seven directorships.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated

title: Warner Records Head Brings Family Tradition
description: Lenny Waronker, the newly appointed 39-year-old president of Warner Brothers Records, brings family tradition to the record industry. He had started in the early 1960's at Liberty Records, a competing firm founded by his father, Si Waronker, where the son had worked in the promotion department.

title: RISE IN WORKER OUTPUT SET AT 4% IN 3d QUARTER
description: Worker productivity in the nonfarm private sector advanced in the third quarter at an annual rate of 4 percent, according to revised figures released by the Labor Department today.

title: Dunes Stock Halt
description: Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc. asked the American Stock Exchange to halt trading in its stock pending the outcome of ''significant negotiations'' expected to be concluded this week. Duane Krohn, vice president and treasurer, said the talks involve the possible sale of the Dunes Hotel and Country Club in Las Vegas to Clifford and Stuart Perlman, who formerly ran Caesars World Inc. Dunes Hotels closed Friday at 15 3/8, up 3/4. Trading was halted yesterday with the stock at 14.

title: NEW SPY SCANDALS WORRY THE BRITISH
description: A new espionage trial opened here today, and a British diplomat was given a suspended sentence in another. The continuing revelations of security breaches have brought new demands for a full inquiry into Britain's ability to keep a state secret.

title: Required Reading On Taiwan's Law
description: Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, in The Letter on Taiwan, published by the Taiwanese-American Society, November 1982: It is tragic that the ruling Kuomintang in Taiwan continues to impose martial law after three decades of peace. Few governments in the world have as stable an economic infrastructure, as great social cohesion and as high levels of literacy. To maintain martial law under these circumstances is inexcusable.

title: MASTERS MERCHANDISE MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect refundable corporate income taxes

title: HOUSE OPENS DEBATE ON SETTLING NATIONAL POLICY ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: The House of Representatives, opening its post-election session today, took up much-disputed legislation that would establish the first national policy for storage and disposal of nuclear wastes.

title: COURT TO DECIDE I.R.S.-BANKRUPTCY ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Internal Revenue Service can be required to return property it has seized from a company that later seeks reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: WHITES IN ALASKA ASSAIL TRIBAL RULE
description: The inscription near the entrance of the Bob Bartlett School in this native village reads, in the dialect of the Athabascan Indians, ''Welcome to the Home of the Chiefs.''

title: FINALE FOR A MUSIC FUND IS MARKED BY A CONCERT
description: Since 1957, the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music has provided support for hundreds of artists, composers and scholars. Last night some of them appeared at Alice Tully Hall to salute the foundation and memorialize its creator at a special concert as the fund comes to the end of its 25-year life.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON EVIDENCE CASE
description: The Supreme Court, invoking an unusual procedure, set the stage today for an important ruling on whether to revise the 68-year-old rule that requires the exclusion of illegally seized evidence from a criminal trial.

title: POWER STILL OUT IN PARTS OF KAUAI
description: Nearly a week after Hurricane Iwa struck Hawaii, more than 5,000 homes and business on the island of Kauai still had no electricity today, and three communities relied on trucks to bring in drinking water.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Benn & MacDonough Inc. has named Barbara Ambrose a vice president.

title: Denmark Cuts Discount Rate
description: Denmark's national bank today announced a long-awaited cut in its discount rate, reflecting a turnaround in the fortunes of the Danish currency and Government hopes of spurring corporate investment.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Including income of $21,000 for the qr and a loss of $506,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations, income of $212,000 for the qr and a loss of $12,470,000 for the 9 mos on the disposal of discontinued operations and gains of $3,000 for the qr and $9,708,000 for the 9 mos from the forgiveness of debt...C-Net inc includ inc from disc oper of $201,000 for the qr and $893,000 for the 9 mos and extraor tax credits of $421,000 for the qr and $1,502,000 for the 9 mos

title: Crash Survivor Rescued After 8 Days in a Swamp
description: A mechanic who crashed a stolen plane into a remote, mosquito-infested swamp survived eight days by drinking marsh water and eating grass before he was rescued today, the state police said. The authorities said he would be charged with theft.

title: Elf Aquitaine Stake
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine is negotiating with several companies to sell part of its two-thirds holding in the North Alwyn oil and gas field in the North Sea, energy industry sources said today. They said the company wants to sell about one-fifth of its holding. The concession's reserves are put at 200 million barrels of oil and 27 billion cubic meters of gas.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday, with Treasury bill rates rising more than a quarter of a percentage point, while long-term Treasury bond prices fell more than two points.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Glittering Gala At the Met Museum

title: LEGISLATION TO RAISE THE GAS TAX BY 5 CENTS IS INTRODUCED TO SENATE
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, today introduced a Reagan Administration bill that would raise Federal gasoline taxes by 5 cents to provide funds to complete the Interstate highway system, repair aging roads and bridges and rehabilitate urban mass transit systems.

title: PROFESSOR CHALLENGES MATERIAL IN ARTICLE IN TIMES MAGAZINE
description: A college professor has discovered similarities between quotations and phrasing in a recent article in The New York Times Magazine on a woman who spent many years with Mohandas K. Gandhi and the woman's autobiography published 22 years ago.

title: ONE YARD IS LONG GOAL, AT TIMES
description: T he longest yard is the one near the goal line, where defenses stack up, where offenses find running room suddenly tight. That is why teams with the ball on the 1-yard line, and fourth down looming, often attempt the safer field goal rather than trying to punch the ball home.

title: Utility Chief Resigns Post
description: The managing director of the troubled Washington Public Power Supply System announced his resignation today.

title: DISPUTE DELAYS NAMING JUDGES, CAREY DECLARES
description: The appointment of 19 new Court of Claims judges, most of them scheduled to hear criminal cases in New York City, has been blocked by a dispute over the appointment process, Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Hurt In West Bank Protests
description: Two soldiers were slightly wounded today when student protesters in Ramallah and Nablus in the West Bank hurled rocks, smashing the windows of their vehicles, Palestinian sources reported.

title: Chrysler Office In Japan Reported
description: The Chrysler Corporation is planning to open an office here early next year to procure parts for its plants, according to a spokesman for Mitsubishi Motors, of which Chrysler owns 15 percent.

title: SHOREWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rohr Net Up; Sales Off
description: Rohr Industries Inc., a California-based maker of aircraft components, said yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of its fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31, rose to $5 million, or 76 cents a share, from $4.5 million, or 70 cents, in the same period of 1981.

title: CONCERT: NEW JERSEYANS
description: SOMETIMES skill in programming an orchestral concert can have as much effect as the way it is performed. A conductor must know his own strengths, balance those strengths with diversity and judge the attention span of the audience. Had Thomas Michalak given some consideration to these factors when he conducted the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra on Sunday in Avery Fisher Hall, the musical moments in the program would have been far more effective.

title: CITY AGENCIES FIND ALL SORTS OF BLADES FOR CUTTING THEIR BUDGETS
description: What do you get when you turn out some lights, allow the weeds to grow and let someone else slice the meat and prune the trees? The City of New York is hoping to get $2.1 million in savings for this fiscal year and $4.6 million for the next from these actions. Amid talk of layoffs and tax ''menus'' and much-needed revenue from elsewhere, the city's financial plan shows some of the other ways that municipal agencies propose to balance the budget.

title: CONTINUING GROWTH IN RURAL AREAS APPEARS IMMUNE TO THE RECESSION
description: Population growth and development in rural areas has become so pervasive that neither sharp cuts in Federal funds nor the recession is likely to stop it in this decade, according to the authorities who have studied the phenomenon.

title: TOKLAN OIL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Fanfani Says He'll Form A Four-Party Cabinet
description: Prime Minister-designate Amintore Fanfani said today that he would submit a four-party coalition Cabinet to President Sandro Pertini on Tuesday after the Republican Party of the departing Prime Minister, Giovanni Spadolini, refused to join.

title: PAKISTAN BALKING AT JET PURCHASE
description: Defense Department officials said today that Pakistan had refused to accept delivery of six F-16 jet fighterbombers from the United States because they lacked the most advanced American electronic warfare system.

title: Skipper Rescues Rival
description: An American skipper in the single-handed, round-the-world race was rescued by a fellow competitor yesterday after abandoning ship in the blustery southern Indian Ocean.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $240,000 for the qr and $1,090,000 for the9 mos...C-Net loss...D-After a loss of $700,000 from discontinued operations

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $745,000 or 18 cents a shr from the sale of real estate and the favorable settlement of litigation

title: Dome Balks On Bailout
description: Energy Minister Jean Chretien said today that Dome Petroleum had told him the company wanted to avoid taking up a bailout proposal offered to it by the Canadian Government and Canadian banks.

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a charge of $332,100 from the extinguishment of debt...C-Net income

title: Oilers Drop Punter
description: Punting is about as specialized a skill as a player can have in football, and when the ball doesn't sail deep, the specialist is in trouble. ''If you don't produce, you expect the consequences,'' said Cliff Parsley of the Houston Oilers, who lost, 29-21, to the New England Patriots on Sunday.

title: SEYMOUR LUBMAN
description: Seymour Lubman, president of the Purepac Pharmaceutical Company of Elizabeth, N.J., died Saturday of a heart attack in Convent Station, N.J. He was 60 years old and lived in Convent Station.

title: Construction Contracts Fall
description: New construction in October fell a seasonally adjusted 10 percent from a year earlier, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: MAN WHO KILLED 6 TO GET A 'HIGH' GIVEN LIFE TERM
description: A 22-year-old killer who had described in court how he murdered six people for the pleasure it brought him, was sentenced yesterday to life in prison.

title: Board in San Francisco Backs Couples' Benefits
description: The Board of Supervisors voted 8 to 3 today in favor of an innovative plan to give live-in lovers of city employees the same health benefits as spouses.

title: DONALD A. HENDERSON
description: Donald A. Henderson, a former financial vice president and board member of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, died Sunday at a nursing home in Westport, Conn.

title: ACCOUNT OF AMERICAN'S DEATH IN EL SALVADOR IS PUT IN DOUBT
description: An autopsy on a young American who was killed by Salvadoran soldiers last month cast doubt today on military claims that he was shot while trying to escape.

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $282,300 for the qr and $597,000 for the 6 mos

title: ONLY MEMORIES LEFT FOR HIM
description: R ob Lowry still plays basketball, but the season has started without him. Games are going on in Memorial Gymnasium at the University of San Francisco, but now they are limited to intramurals, or extramural competition against teams from local schools.

title: Lawyers for DeLorean Assert U.S. Illegally Entrapped Him
description: Lawyers for John Z. DeLorean filed legal documents today asserting that the auto executive was ''lured'' into a narcotics scheme ''through the extraordinary and illegal efforts'' of a Government informant, James Hoffman.

title: TANK TRAPS AHEAD
description: The other morning at an intersection on Third Avenue, a large piece of the roadbed suddenly sank about a foot, as if underground trolls had decided to create an instant tank trap to head off an enemy panzer attack. Someone stuck a steel mesh trash basket into the huge depression as a kind of red flag to warn advancing tank drivers and other motorists.

title: 10 Members of Church Are Freed Without Bail
description: Ten members of a religious group that was involved in a fatal shoot-out with Cochise County Sheriff's deputies last month were ordered released from jail today.

title: HISTORIC S.I. COMMUNITY FIGHTS TO PRESERVE PAST
description: Amid signs of urban progress, the rustic Staten Island community of Sandy Ground is fighting to preserve its past. The two-square-mile pastoral poem of small frame houses, bucolic woodland and neighborly people is one of the oldest surviving communities in the nation founded by free blacks. Although roughly 160 years have blended into history since the first settlers migrated from Maryland to dredge for oysters in this area of sandy land on the southwestern tip of the island, a cluster of their descendants still remains.

title: HENRY WINGATE, 77, RETIRED EXECUTIVE
description: Henry S. Wingate, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the International Nickel Company of Canada Ltd., died Thursday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan and Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RAY WILLIAMS RETURNS TO FACE THE NETS
description: It was many years before Ray Williams moved away from home, away from the security of his family and lifelong friends. But when he finally left last spring, it wasn't because he wanted to. It was for a reason that Williams says he will never understand.

title: SANDINIST CALLS REAGAN'S TRIP DISRUPTIVE
description: The Nicaraguan Government fears that President Reagan's visit to Central America this week will lead to the intensification of the diplomatic and covert military offensive it says is already under way against Nicaragua.

title: U.S. ASSAILS SOVIET FOR REPORTED USE OF TOXIN WEAPONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, charging the Soviet Union with a ''cynical disregard for international law,'' said today that the Russians and their allies were continuing chemical warfare activities in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Utah Jazz, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. The Knicks, off to the worst start in their history with a 3-11 record, try to turn things around against the Jazz, whom they have beaten four consecutive times over two seasons.

title: PANEL CENSURES JUDGE FOR RULE IN NASSAU CASE
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has censured a State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County for presiding over a case in which he had close political, business and personal relations with several of the defendants.

title: KREMLIN OVERTURE TO ALBANIANS SEEN
description: Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, today marked Albania's national day with an unusually warm article. Although the paper has printed similar articles in previous years, the commentary today was notable for its emphasis on the importance the Soviet Union attaches to improved ties with Albania, which has lived in diplomatic isolation since it broke with China five years ago, and for the link the paper made between the overture and the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov.

title: AGENT ORANGE: DESPITE SPATE OF STUDIES, SLIM HOPE FOR ANSWERS
description: WASHINGTON SCIENTISTS are moving far faster than is widely recogized to investigate the riddle of Agent Orange, a herbicide that was sprayed over perhaps 20 percent of South Vietnam to defoliate trees and kill crops, and is now blamed by many veterans for a host of health problems.

title: 'Throwaway Children'
description: About 22,000 young people a year are herded through New York City's Family Court system as accused felons, juvenile delinquents or simply youngsters badly in need of supervision. But in the grim conclusion of a report to the Citizens Committee for Children, they get very little help from probation officers, who are supposed to provide the first line of service.

title: Westinghouse, EG & G Project
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had joined EG & G Inc.'s synthetic fuels project and would supply coal gasification technology to be used at the Fall River, Mass., facility.

title: Gerry Hart Retires
description: After 730 professional hockey games, Gerry Hart, one of the original members of the New York Islanders and now an occasionallyused defenseman for the St. Louis Blues, has called an end to his skating career.

title: WALL STREET'S FURIOUS SWINGS
description: The stock market has never been a placid place. But in recent months, the normally hectic tempo has turned furious, with day after day of swings of 10, 20 and even 30 and 40 points in the Dow Jones industrial average and similar moves in other market indexes.

title: CUTTING DEFENSE SPENDING
description: Despite President Reagan's intransigence on budgetary matters, it seems clear that his proposals for defense spending will be cut by Congress - and cut quite substantially, in all probability. How these cuts will affect national security will depend very much on where they are applied. It will take an organized effort to clarify the choices and their differing consequences.

title: WHEN GROWING OLD IS PUNISHABLE BY DEATH
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: AFTER so many years of reading children's books I've come to believe in strange and mysterious things others might consider impossible. I know, for instance, that somewhere out there elves and trolls are lurking, that wild things cavort in the night, that mice drive little motor cars and swans eat watercress sandwiches. I believe these things because a long time ago some authors wrote books so powerful and convincing that I have never doubted in the existence of their creations.

title: No Headline
description: VENEZUELA ACTS TO AVOID FAILURE OF BIGGEST BANK

title: STOCKS FALL IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday in heavier trading with issues that responded to specific news developments posting the biggest price moves.

title: Leveille Improves
description: Normand Leveille, the 19-year-old forward for the Boston Bruins who suffered a cerebral hemorrhage Oct. 23 after the first period of a game against Vancouver, was well enough to be taken out of intensive care Sunday at the Montreal Neurological Institute after emerging from a coma. ... Also on the recovery trail is Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox outfielder who was stricken with a massive heart attack 10 months ago at the age of 37. Conigliaro's brain functions and physical mobility have slowly but steadily improved, and he may be moved back to a rehabilitation clinic, said a spokesman at Salem Hospital in Boston, where he is recovering from pneumonia.

title: Bridge: Team Led by Edgar Kaplan Wins the Reisinger Crown
description: An East Coast team headed by Edgar Kaplan of New York scored a relatively easy victory here Sunday night in the Reisinger Team Championship, the final event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Steel Output Drop Continues
description: Steel production plunged to its lowest level in at least 20 years last week, with plant use in the beleaguered industry at a 50-year low, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: G.E. Layoffs
description: The General Electric Company said 900 workers at its dishwasher division here were beginning a temporary layoff. It added that the Appliance Park plant will be closed from Dec. 20 to Jan. 3 as part of a holiday and vacation program.

title: Queen Helen of Rumania, 87; Was Forced Into Exile in '47
description: Queen Helen of Rumania, second wife of King Karl II, died peacefully in Lausanne Sunday night after a short illness, her family said today.

title: Katharine Gibbs
