description: Gerald Patlis Advertising has reacquired the Katharine Gibbs School account that it lost to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners in May. The account is valued at $1 million plus, including television, radio, print, direct mail, catalogues and other collateral areas. The Katharine Gibbs School is a division of the Macmillan Company.

title: LEGISLATURE'S LEADERS REBUFF KEAN REQUEST FOR NEW TAXES
description: Governor Kean's proposals to close a projected $150 million deficit in the current state budget failed in their first legislative test today.

title: ACRONYMS FIND A WELCOME AT E.P.A.
description: At the Environmental Protection Agency, E.T. is not an endearing visitor from another world and Tosca is not even remotely connected to Puccini's opera.

title: W. HAMILTON WEBER
description: W. Hamilton Weber, who was associated with the rental and management of the Empire State Building from 1929 to his retirement in 1980, died of pneumonia Sunday at Bayshore Hospital in Holmdel, N.J. He was 87 years old and lived in Springfield, N.J.

title: BL Adding Staff
description: BL, Britain's state-owned car maker, said it would hire 1,100 extra workers to help produce the first of a new range of family cars. This would be the first sizable increase in five years in BL's car-production staff, which has dropped to 38,000 from 80,000.

title: Latin Loans At Continental
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation reported today that its public and private bank loans to the troubled economies of Mexico and Argentina total about $1.1 billion.

title: DEPRESSIONS ARE TOO COSTLY A CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-After special gain of $86,000; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: AMWAY REJECTS CANADA COURT ORDER
description: The Amway Corporation said today that its chairman, president and two other top executives would not appear before a Canadian court to face criminal charges that they cheated the Government of $28 million in customs duties.

title: Seahawks Are Adding to Achievements
description: Not since the middle of the 1977 season had the Seattle Seahawks shut out a team so convincingly, although back then, the victory was hardly a great achievement: Losing to the Seahawks that day were the Jets, who were losing to nearly everyone that season, finishing at 3-11.

title: Hugh Harman, 79, Creator Of 'Looney Tunes' Cartoons
description: Hugh Harman, the Oscar-winning creator of the ''Looney Tunes'' cartoons, died Thursday at his home in Chatsworth after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: ROCKWELL WILL PAY $1.5 MILLION TO U.S. IN SPACE SHUTTLE SUIT
description: The Rockwell International Corporation today agreed to pay the Government $1.5 million to settle a civil suit charging the company with overbilling taxpayers as the prime contractor for the space shuttle, the Justice Department announced.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EX-PRESIDENTS: PUBLIC ASSETS?
description: RICHARD M. NIXON has become something of an authority on the relationship between former Presidents and the occupants of the Oval Office, having dealt with predecessors (from Herbert Hoover) and successors (to Ronald Reagan). And, he says, his relations with President Reagan are ''good.''

title: Crash of Van Kills Brooklyn Woman
description: A 55-year-old woman, Dora Yankanofski of 2920 West 21st Street in Brooklyn, was fatally injured at 8:50 A.M. yesterday when a van transporting retarded adults to a training center overturned on rainslick Atlantic Avenue near Georgia Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Eight other passengers, the driver and a matron were injured.

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge from litigation of $3,464,678; the rev figures for the 1981 qr and yr were restated

title: CLUES TO HEALTHY OLD AGE FOUND IN SOVIET VILLAGES
description: DESPITE earlier skepticism, Soviet and American researchers believe they have found that, in a number of mountain villages in the Caucasus, people remain vigorous into years when most Americans are in nursing homes. They attribute this in large measure to the special status that the elderly enjoy in their communities.

title: WAYS TO LOOK AT DEFICIT VARY
description: President Reagan contends that neither his tax cuts nor his large increase in military spending is the cause of the rising Federal budget deficit.

title: STEVE GORDON, SCREEN WRITER, 44
description: Steve Gordon, who wrote and directed the hit movie ''Arthur,'' collapsed and died Saturday at his home at 815 Park Avenue. He was 44 years old.

title: Mexico Stand On OPEC
description: Mexico is expected to remain independent of OPEC but nonetheless stay close to its price guidelines when President-elect Miguel de la Madrid takes office on Wednesday, oil analysts say.

title: WHAT THE LEGAL AID SOCIETY CAN AND CANNOT OFFER ITS ATTORNEYS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Major Party For a Minor Party

title: LEBANON ASKS THREE NATIONS TO SEND MORE TROOPS
description: President Amin Gemayel formally asked the United States, France and Italy today to increase the size of their peacekeeping contingents to help the Government end deterioration in his country's internal security.

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
72,754 Datsuns Are Recalled
description: The American distributor of Datsun and Nissan vehicles is recalling 72,754 Datsun model 310 hatchback cars from the 1979-80 model year because of potentially faulty tail and brake lights.

title: COMPUTER INPUT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: The company became a public corporation in April 1982 and therefore there are no comparable yr-ago results available

title: Zahringer Repeats
description: George J. Zahringer of the Sands Point (L.I.) Golf Club did it again this year by winning the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur player of the year award.

title: '83 FARM PROFIT RISE IS HELD UNLIKELY
description: American farmers, already experiencing one of their worst years since the Depression, were warned today by the Department of Agriculture that 1983 income would probably be just as poor.

title: THE ROLL-CALL ON AFGHANISTAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the General Assembly approved a resolution today demanding that the Soviet Union withdraw its troops from Afghanistan: In Favor - 114 Albania Antigua & Barbuda Argentina Australia Austria Bahamas Bahrain Bangladesh Barbados Belgium Botswana Brazil Britain Burma Burundi Cambodia Cameroon Canada Central Af. Republic Chad Chile China Colombia Comoros Costa Rica Denmark Djibouti Dominica Dominican Republic Ecuador Egypt El Salvador Fiji France Gabon Gambia Germany, West Ghana Greece Guatemala Guinea Guyana Haiti Honduras Iceland Indonesia Iran Iraq Ireland Israel Italy Ivory Coast Jamaica Japan Jordan Kenya Kuwait Lebanon Lesotho Liberia Luxem- bourg Malawi Malaysia Maldives Malta Mauritania Mexico Morocco Nepal Nether- lands New Zealand Niger Nigeria Norway Oman Pakistan Panama Papua New Guinea Paraguay Peru Philippines Portugal Qatar Rwanda St. Lucia St. Vincent & Gren. Samoa Saudi Arabia Senegal Sierra Leone Singapore Solomon Islands Somalia Spain Sri Lanka Sudan Suriname Swaziland Sweden Tanzania Thailand Togo Trinidad & Tobago Tunisia Turkey U. Arab Emirates United States Upper Volta Uruguay Venezuela Yugoslavia Zaire Zambia Zimbabwe Against - 21 Afghanistan Angola Bulgaria Byelorussia Cuba Czechoslo- vakia Ethiopia Germany, East Grenada Hungary Laos Libya Madagas- car Mongolia Mozam- bique Poland Soviet Union Syria Ukraine Vietnam Yemen, Southern Abstentions - 13 Algeria Benin Cape Verde Congo Cyprus Equatorial Guinea Finland Guinea- Bissau India Mali Nicaragua Uganda Yemen Absent or Not Voting - 9 Belize Bhutan Bolivia Mauritius Rumania Sao Tome & Principe Seychelles South Africa Vanuatu

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $23,000...C-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $29,000

title: STAGE: 'MENS ROOM'
description: in-law in the ''Rocky'' movies, is a short, stocky actor with the look of an average man. He could pass for your neighborhood meter reader, which is one of several professions once held by his character in ''The Men's Room,'' the title work in an evening of three undistinguished one-act plays by Jess Gregg. The plays, now running at the Actors Repertory Theater, all deal with the loneliness of losers.

title: THE PRIMROSE PATH
description: International trade has come to fit the comment on the weather attributed to Mark Twain: everybody talks about it but nobody does anything about it.

title: RULE DUE ON WASTE ISSUE IN NUCLEAR LICENSING
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must consider, as part of the licensing process for every nuclear power plant, the environmental consequences of the long-term storage of nuclear waste.

title: Thompson Is Granted Recount in Chicago
description: Gov. James R. Thompson, re-elected by 5,074 votes, the narrowest margin in state history, was granted a recount today in Chicago, part of his plan to blunt a drive by Adlai E. Stevenson Jr., his challenger, for a statewide recount.

title: Canadian Killed in Avalanche
description: Seven people on a wilderness trip from a youth corrections camp were caught in an avalanche that killed one teen-ager.

title: Panel to Weigh Option Trading
description: The staff of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission recommended that the agency allow the New York Futures Exchange to trade futures on the New York Stock Exchange's large composite index. The commissioners will vote on the proposed contract Tuesday.

title: Syracuse Routs Cornell, 110-69
description: Erich Santifer scored 22 points on perfect shooting for Syracuse, which smothered Cornell defensively tonight en route to a 110-69 victory.

title: TRAILER TRUCKS ARE RATTLING A SMALL TOWN'S TRANQUILLITY
description: Marjorie Hoey has had 19 tractor-trailer trucks overturn in her front yard during the last 10 years, usually in the early morning, when she is awakened by a thunderous crash and the sound of heads of lettuce, sides of beef or frozen turkeys thrown against the front of her house.

title: SAMBO'S reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hub Walker, Played Outfield With Detroit and Cincinnati
description: Harvey W. (Hub) Walker, who played the outfield for Detroit and Cincinnati, died last Friday in a convalescent hospital at the age of 76.

title: KEY ISSUES ON AGENDA OF SPECIAL SESSION
description: Following are the major issues that may be considered by Congress in the post-election session that convened today:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Judicial Tradition Is Vetoed in Court

title: Soviet Trade To West Up
description: Citing a faster flow of Western pipeline shipments, a United Nations survey said today that there had been a ''surprising'' surge in Soviet-Western trade.

title: HABIB CONFERS WITH MUBARAK ON LEBANON AND WEST BANK
description: President Hosni Mubarak met for 80 minutes today with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, on how to obtain a rapid withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon and how to include Palestinians and Jordanians in peace talks.

title: Turner & Newall Appoints Chairman
description: Sir Francis Tombs has been named chairman of Turner & Newall P.L.C., Britain's largest manufacturer of asbestos products, after the resignation of Stephen Gibb, who quit unexpectedly only nine months after he had agreed to stay on as chairman until 1985.

title: Cam Fella Named Horse of Year
description: Cam Fella, who won two legs of pacing's triple crown for 3-year-olds, has been selected as the harness horse of the year.

title: Du Pont Lowering Its Merger Debt
description: Edward G. Jefferson, chairman of the Du Pont Company, told members of the Boston Securities Analysts Society that by the end of this year, the chemical producer will have lowered its debt by about $1 billion from the $7.3 billion level it had reached after the merger last year with Conoco Inc. Only about $200 million of this debt reduction would be from the sale of assets; the rest, he said, is from ''drawn-down cash and cash flow.''

title: ACTIVIST DENIES BID TO PUBLICIZE RAID
description: Alan McSurely, a former civil rights worker seeking damages for what he says were violations of his constitutional rights stemming from a 1967 raid on his home, denied today that he had sought publicity after the raid.

title: CULTURE RIDES SHOTGUN ON THE PARIS METRO
description: The concierge tapped her slipper in time to the music. The retired cellist smiled. The rest of the 500 or so members of the audience shouted ''Bravo!'' as the satin-sheathed dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet performed ''Massacre on Macdougal Street'' by the choreographer Karole Armitage.

title: Allis Plant for Sale
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation announced plans to sell its agricultural-implement plant in LaPorte, Ind., because of weak demand.

title: Better Trade Gripes Than Trade War
description: The conference was ''badly prepared, badly organized and should never have been held at this time.'' So said the chief of the European Common Market delegation to the 88-nation trade conference just concluded in Geneva. He's entitled to his opinion on the first two points but he's decidedly wrong on the third. The world now needs every sign of recognition that trade war can be deadly.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The life sentence this court now imposes means life. You are going to die in prison and then go before the Supreme Judge of us all and let Him impose whatever additional sentence He feels you so rightfully deserve.''

title: Market Place; Cities Merger: The Tax Effect
description: SHAREHOLDERS of the Cities Service Company, badly frightened last August when the Gulf Oil Corporation called off a $5 billion deal to buy the company, will convene in Dover, Del., this Friday to vote on a merger with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: Atari Sues Imagic On Copyright Issue
description: Atari Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a copyright infringement suit against the Imagic Corporation, a maker of home video game software.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the qr and $117,000 for the yr...C-After a loss of $109,800 from discontinued operations and a provision for loss on disposal of assets and closedown costs of $181,000

title: DEPRESSIONS ARE TOO COSTLY A CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * James G. Carter has been appointed vice president, director of marketing for the Somerset Wine Company.

title: L.I. Jobless Rate Fell in October
description: Unemployment in Nassau and Suffolk Counties dropped slightly in October after a sharp jump in September, according to State Labor Department figures.

title: SINGLED OUT; Tom and Michele
description: What was there about the first Morris the Cat that caused a talent agent to pluck him from his cage at the pound and catapault him to stardom? Was it the slant of his eyes? The set of his tail? The way he wore his fur?

title: INTEGRITY FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
M.T.A. USE OF CHEAP POWER RULED ILLEGAL BY GOVERNMENT
description: The Federal Government has ruled that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is no longer entitled to purchase low-cost hydroelectric power to operate subway and commuter lines because it does not meet the Federal definition of an eligible municipal entity, the M.T.A. said yesterday.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT'S OVERSEER CHALLENGED AT TRIAL
description: In the final day of cross-examination of the shift supervisor on duty at the time of the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, an attorney for the reactor's builder attempted yesterday to show wide discrepancies between the supervisor's testimony and previous investigations.

title: HOW DO CHILDREN LEARN TO WRITE?
description: MOST children who enter first grade think they already know how to write, and many of them actually do. But many teachers who do not believe this fail to build on the momentum and instead postpone the teaching of writing for a year or two.

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: The yr-ago results include a gain of $6.6 million or $1.30 a shr for the qr and9 mos from the divestiture of the company's New Jersey supermarkets; shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split on Oct 29, 1982

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including the reversal of approximately $11 million of deferred income taxes resulting from changes in Britian's tax law; Marmon Group has no publicly tradedcommon shrs

title: Textile Importers Sue, Challenging U.S. Quotas
description: Importers of textiles and apparel sued the Government today in a major challenge to the procedures it uses to impose quotas on these goods, according to lawyers here for the American Association of Exporters and Importers.

title: ON CAMPUS, NUCLEAR WAR GAINS NEW FOCUS
description: MOST students arrive at Allan Brick's section of of the freshman writing course at Hunter College expecting to be confronted with books of rhetoric and grammar. Instead, they find themselves delving into such works as ''Nuclear Madness'' by Helen Caldicott and ''Nuclear Witnesses,'' a series of interviews by Leslie Freeman.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $351,000 from discontinued operations

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: Shr earnings previously reported have been restated for the 5-for-4 stock spliton Sept 10

title: Fuschi Recital Postponed
description: Olegna Fuschi, a pianist, was involved in an automobile accident last night as she drove from her Riverdale home to her scheduled recital at Carnegie Hall. Miss Fuschi was treated at Roosevelt Hospital for a possible neck injury. Ticket holders were told to telephone the box office today to ascertain whether Miss Fuschi's recital would be rescheduled.

title: Dow Banking Loss Provision
description: The Dow Banking Corporation, which is 75 percent owned by the Dow Chemical Company of Midland, Mich., has not ruled out a cut in its dividend this year to finance provisions for doubtful loans, a bank official said.

title: 9 More Subway Riders Seized as Fare Cheats
description: Seven women and two men were arrested yesterday and charged with trying to slip Connecticut Turnpike tokens or other slugs into three city subway stations, Transit Authority officials said.

title: Accounts
description: * Camp Hosiery, a division of Genesco, to Altman, Stoller, Weiss Advertising, a division of Nadler & Larimer.

title: Don't Bail Out the Price Fixers
description: Having had their day in court, where they face millions in damages, some leading price fixers have taken their case to the floor of the United States Senate. The legislation they seek would not only change the rules for future antitrust suits; it would also apply them retroactively - and permit the price fixers to evade big damage judgments.

title: INDIA AS A SUITABLE HOST TO THE WORLD'S ATHLETES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW 'HIGHWAY' OF GALAXIES SEEN
description: Evidence is growing that the largest units of the universe are huge assemblages of galaxies that, far from being randomly scattered through space, are organized into vast rotating structures that are either cigar-shaped or flattened like pancakes.

title: Ballet on Skates
description: Six skating champions are practicing these days for an unusual performance: all six in one ballet at the same time. It sounds like a traffic jam, but it's a television production of a Hans Christian Andersen fable, ''The Snow Queen,'' which will be shown on public television stations in December.

title: Ticket Prices Cut
description: The Indiana Pacers were admitted to the National Basketball Association in 1977 and have not made an overwhelming impact since, reaching the playoffs only once, in 1980. But despite the so-so record of the team, the 17,000-seat Market Square Arena in Indianapolis was mostly filled in previous years.

title: EAST AND WEST JOIN IN TOKYO FASHION SHOW
description: Two Europeans and an American joined two Japanese designers in a celebration of fashion called ''The Best Five's '83'' this week. The conferences, parties and fashion shows mark a serious attempt by the Japanese fashion industry to give Tokyo its place alongside Milan, London, Paris and New York, where the current spring and summer collections have been introduced, as a leading fashion center.

title: Ford British Strike
description: Ford Motor Ltd. said today that it had lost production of 4,300 Escort cars with a showroom value of $31.9 million because of a weeklong unofficial strike by 420 workers at its Halewood, Merseyside, factory. The strike ended today and production resumed as the 5,900 workers who were laid off last week returned to work after settlement of a dispute over manning levels, a Ford spokesman said.

title: KOCH URGES RESTORATION OF STOCK-TRANSFER TAX
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he favored reinstating a tax on stock and security transactions to help New York City close its budget deficits.

title: WITH KLECKO OUT, MEHL PROVES WORTH
description: Lance Mehl used to tackle tottering opponents whom Joe Klecko left in his wake. But since Klecko, probably the most powerful right defensive end in pro football, has been lost for the season, Mehl has proved that, on his own, he is a key force for the Jets.

title: Marsh & McLennan Inc.  Has New Top Officer
description: Marsh & McLennan Inc., the world's largest insurance brokerage and risk management firm, has a new president and chief operating officer. He is Bruce W. Schnitzer, who is 39 years old and who has spent much of his career not in insurance but in investment banking.

title: BROWN APPOINTEE WILL LEAVE CALIFORNIA COURT
description: Justice Frank Newman resigned from the California Supreme Court today, clearing the way for Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., a Democrat, to name a successor before Governor-elect George Deukmejian, a Republican, takes office Jan. 3.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Foes of Army Rule Win An Election in Uruguay

title: Chock Full Court Suit
description: A dissident group seeking to take over the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation yesterday lost its fight to bar the voting by management of shares at the company's annual meeting tomorrow.

title: Memorial for Kipness
description: A memorial for Joseph Kipness, the Broadway producer who died Nov. 18, will be held at noon tomorrow at the Palace Theater, Broadway and West 47th Street. Lauren Bacall, Michael Bennett and Alexander H. Cohen are scheduled to be among the speakers. Jule Styne, Cy Coleman and Charles Strouse will play songs they wrote for three musicals Mr. Kipness produced, ''High Button Shoes,'' which had music by Mr. Styne; ''Seesaw,'' music by Mr. Coleman, and ''Applause,'' music by Mr. Strouse.

title: TAMPA BAY HANDS MIAMI FIRST DEFEAT
description: Doug Williams and James Wilder of the Buccaneers scored on short touchdown runs in the second half tonight, and Tampa Bay held on to beat Miami, 23-17, sending the Dolphins to their first loss.

title: TV: 'SOMETHING SO RIGHT,' STORY OF BIG BROTHER
description: WITH this being the start of the incessantly heartwarming holiday season, and with the made-for-television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight being a G.E. Theater presentation, which always signals an exercise in uplift, the chances that ''Something So Right'' might have an unhappy ending are clearly remote. The opening teasers, which reveal most of the plot, are laden with crises of various sorts, but veteran television watchers will easily suspect that everything will be resolved in a flurry of hugs, kisses and loving tears.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal National Mortgage Association announced that it would sell $1.2 billion of new debentures on Wednesday - $800 million due in 1986 and $400 million due in 1989.

title: G.M. Cutbacks
description: The General Motors Corporation's Fisher Body division said it would close three plants in Detroit because they are obsolete and the company has excess capacity. The move will idle 1,200 hourly workers. G.M. said the closings will begin soon and be completed in 18 months. About 300 of the workers are already on indefinite layoff.

title: WHAT THE LEGAL AID SOCIETY CAN AND CANNOT OFFER ITS ATTORNEYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Shield Rates To Rise in Jersey
description: Small-group and individual subscribers to Blue Shield medical insurance will pay an average of 24.5 percent more for coverage beginning Jan. 1, the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, Joseph Murphy, announced today.

title: Indoor Track Feels the Pinch
description: The indoor track season is drawing near, and there are already casualties: Meets have been canceled in Philadelphia, Kansas City and Edmonton.

title: 'EXTINCT' OXEN ARE SEEN
description: DURING the last decade the kouprey, one of the world's largest wild oxen, has not been seen close enough for positive identification anywhere in its war-torn habitat of Laos, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam. Many wildlife scientists assumed it had become extinct. But a Thai mammalogist has now reported recently sighting five of the six-foot-tall animals near the Cambodian border.

title: Robert Noah Janeway, Auto and Rail Designer
description: Robert Noah Janeway, an inventor of automotive and rail car designs and brother of the economist Eliot Janeway, died Saturday at his home in San Diego. He was 80 years old.

title: REGO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific and Spokane stock exchanges

title: SENATOR DENIES BRIBE FROM TEAMSTERS
description: Senator Howard W. Cannon denied on the witness stand today that he had ever been offered a bribe by a teamsters' union official. The Nevada Democrat replied ''absolutely not'' to questions about any agreement by him to scuttle a trucking deregulation bill.

title: Massey Sees '83 Refinancing
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it now expects to complete its refinancing with its 200-member banking group by early 1983, and not by the end of this month, as it had expected.

title: Chess: When Positional Sacrifice Is Only Possible Solution
description: The difference between players who go in for positional sacrifices and those who won't is perhaps more a question of temperament than foresight.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IN November, the fashionable do what they always do: exercise the f ull repertory of their manners and test the validity of their new c lothes. Nowhere was that more apparent than at a cocktail party g iven by Arianna Stassinopoulos in honor of the little-known French f ashion designer Paul-Louis Orrier, who, though tall and tan, was a lmost ignored in a crowd that included 200 of New York's h eavyweights.

title: REAGAN OFF FOR LATIN AMERICA TODAY
description: President Reagan will leave Tuesday for a five-day visit to Latin America to repair relations that were strained by the Falkland conflict, strengthen economic ties and rally support for the United States role in Central America.

title: 'FREE' EMIGRATION MADE UNAFFORDABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
THE DAY THE NUCLEAR AGE WAS BORN
description: FORTY years ago this week, on the afternoon of Dec. 2, 1942, a group of 42 scientists, working under the direction of Enrico Fermi, gathered in an indoor squash court under the west grandstands of Stagg Field, the football stadium of the University of Chicago.

title: COMMON MARKET'S VIEW
description: Following are excerpts from a declaration of the executive commission of the European Economic Community issued by Wilhelm Haferkamp, the commission's vice chairman, commenting on the ministerial declaration adopted today at the conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade:

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 30, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Would the original site of the Big Bang have any distinctive characteristics today or would it have the same generally uniform appearance cosmologists attribute to the universe as a whole? Also, would this area still be considered the center?

title: Mannesmann Spending
description: Mannesmann A.G. said today that it had approved a $252.7 million investment program, similar to the $251.1 million program set a year ago. The focus of the company's $200.9 million domestic investment will be in steel pipe plants. Mannesmann will continue to concentrate its foreign investment in Brazil, a spokesman said.

title: BARBARA D. DANIELSON
description: Barbara Deering Danielson, wife of a former publisher of The Atlantic magazine and a former owner of a palatial Florida estate, died Saturday after a long illness. She was 93.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Centex Corp., which sold two subsidiaries to Grace Petroleum Corp. for $87 million in 1980, said Grace had sued Centex, charging misrepresentations and omissions relating to the sale.

title: Ziff-Davis Purchase
description: Software Communications Inc., the San Francisco-based publishers of PC: The Independent Guide to IBM Personal Computers, has been acquired for an undisclosed price by the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. Ziff-Davis already publishes several microcomputer magazines, including Computers and Electronics, Creative Computing, Microsystems, Small Business Computers, and Sync. PC, a monthly microcomputer magazine of 400-plus pages, began publication in February and has a current circulation of 75,000.

title: THEATER: 'SAIGON ROSE'
description: ALTHOUGH David Edgar has written some 40 other plays, chances are that he'll always be most remembered as the man who adapted ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' for the Royal Shakespeare Company. If you want to learn why, you'll find at least a partial answer in ''Saigon Rose,'' an earlier Edgar effort that is receiving its New York premiere under the auspices of a young troupe called the Actors' Producing Company.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1982
description: International The use of chemical weapons by the Soviet Union and its allies is continuing in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan, according to a detailed report submitted to Congress and the United Nations by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He accused Moscow of displaying a ''cynical disregard for international law.'' (Page A1, Column 2.) A demand for Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan was issued again by the United Nations General Assembly. The resolution was approved by a 114-to-21 vote. (A6:1-3.)

title: STATE TAXES UP $2.93 BILLION IN RECESSION, REPORT SHOWS
description: The recession has prompted 21 states to enact $2.93 billion in annual tax increases this year, mostly in sales and personal income taxes, the Washington-based Tax Foundation, a nonprofit research group that monitors tax and fiscal activities, reports.

title: BRIEFING
description: Donovan Out Front

title: Kodak Offering An X-Ray System
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had introduced a system to handle X-ray and related films without a darkroom.

title: Business and the Law; Using 'Golden Parachutes'
description: FACED with an alarming proliferation of hostile tender offers, more and more corporations have given their most valuable executives ''golden parachutes'' - contracts guaranteeing them several years of salary and benefits if they are thrown out by a new ownership.

title: CARPENTER ENDS HOLDOUT
description: Rob Carpenter and the Giants reached agreement late this afternoon, ending a holdout by the 27-year-old fullback that began last Feb.1 when he became a free agent.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: year-old Johnny's cheeks turned fiery red, as though they had been slapped. Except for the rash, Johnny seemed to be fine. His temperature was just above normal, so his mother decided that he had simply been playing too hard.

title: FUELING THE ARMS RACE IN LATIN AMERICA
description: An arms race is rapidly escalating in Latin America, fueled in large part by policies and signals emanating from Washington. This trend can lead only to disaster in Latin America - polarization, militarization, instability, impoverishment - and runs directly counter to the United States' longstanding interest in preserving hemispheric stability.

title: HEISMAN TROPHY ON WALKER'S MIND
description: F or three seasons now, the Heisman Trophy has been a silent inspiration for Herschel Walker, a silent ambition. Not simply the idea of winning the Heisman Trophy, but the actual bronze Heisman Trophy itself - the one that Frank Sinkwich of Georgia was awarded in 1942, the one that he donated to the university about a decade ago, the one that is inside a glass case perched on a pedestal near the student mail boxes in the lobby of McWhorter Hall, the athletic dorm where Herschel Walker lives.

title: MURDER TRIAL DEFENDANT SAYS U.S. IS HIDING FACTS
description: An angry Charles V. Harrelson maintained today that the Federal Goverment was suppressing evidence that would clear him of the charge that he assassinated Federal District Judge John H. Woods Jr.

title: Shifts on Giants
description: The Giants made two roster changes today. Dee Hardison, the defensive end, was placed on the injured-reserve list as a result of a groin injury from the Detroit came.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Weinberger in Brussels To Explain MX Decision

title: EVANS, BOB, FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
ELEANOR SMEAL MUSES ON 5 YEARS
description: Five tumultuous years as a force behind the losing campaign for the equal rights amendment have deepened Eleanor Smeal's determination to see women win equal rights. The twoterm president of the National Organization for Women steps down Wednesday.

title: GIFTS: FOR THAT ADD-ON STAGE
description: EVEN if, like me, you're a diehard late-shopping traditionalist, you'd better start right now if you're planning to buy someone computer accessories or that very first computer itself for Christmas. For if industry observers are right, this will be the year of the personal computer as far as holiday gifts are concerned. There may well be last-minute shortages of both the particular computers and the add-ons you're contemplating. Then too, if you know less about computers than the recipient you have in mind, it may take you a while to even figure out what it is you're looking for.

title: Caring for Leary
description: The care and feeding of pitching prodigies is being fine-tuned into a science in these days of high stakes in baseball. Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, had this in mind this week when he wrote a memo to Harry Minor, the club's West Coast scout. Subject: the winter's care and feeding of Tim Leary.

title: News Analysis
description: A chaotic world trade conference wound up at about 6 A.M. today after five days of confrontations that gradually gave way to negotiating positions and, finally, a measure of compromise among the 88 participating nations.

title: FROM SPORTSWRITER TO FIGHT MANAGER
description: One telephone, then another rang in Dave Wolf's Upper West Side apartment only moments after Larry Holmes had been awarded a unanimous decision in his one-sided fight against Randy (Tex) Cobb last Friday night. Wolf leaned back on the sofa with a look of someone who has heard them ring too often lately. ''Reporters,'' he said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING CARDS

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Dispossessed Elderly Get a Small Haven

title: ISLANDERS REGAIN CONFIDENCE ON TIE
description: The Islanders went through a vigorous practice today, buoyed by having apparently turned things around Sunday night in a 3-3 tie with the Washington Capitals. There was considerable zest, shouting and horse play as they prepared for Tuesday night's game against the St. Louis Blues.

title: Lewises Enter Meet
description: Carl Lewis and his sister Carol hold world records for men and women in the same track and field event - the long jump. They will compete in the United States Olympic Invitational track meet at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Feb. 12. ... Herschel Walker, the University of Georgia's celebrated tailback. has been named 1982 college football player of the year by the Walter Camp Football Association. Walker will be honored Feb. 12 at Yale University. ... Doug Flutie, the sophomore quarterback who led Boston College to the Tangerine Bowl, was named the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Division I player of the year.

title: CASELOAD COMPLAINTS ARE UP, BUT CASELOAD IS DOWN
description: One Supreme Court Justice after another has taken to the stump in the past few months to issue a dire warning about the Court's growing caseload. But with the Justices' complaints falling like autumn leaves, something else has been quietly falling as well: the Court's caseload.

title: DEEP IN SIBERIA, 3 CENTURIES OF FAITH IN GOD
description: Karl Osipovich Lykov was raised to honor God, keep the ways of his ancestors and to distrust men. His forebears had fled into the Siberian wilderness three centuries ago to elude ecclesiastical changes and the modernizations of Peter the Great. When revolution and civilization intruded in the 1920's and 1930's, Karl Osipovich moved his dwindling community of Old Believers farther into the primeval taiga until it was only he, his wife and two children who pressed on deeper and deeper into the uninhabited forest.

title: EX-COVERT AGENTS WIN BENEFITS CASE
description: In a decision that could alter the way intelligence agencies operate, a Federal administrative law judge has ruled that a group of former covert agents who worked under contract for the Navy are entitled to Civil Service benefits.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Dublin on Friday incorrectly described the fall of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald's Government in January. The coalition of Mr. FitzGerald's Fine Gael Party and the Labor Party was defeated when independent members of Parliament withdrew their support, but the coalition held firm throughout.

title: Egyptian Oil Prices
description: Oil traders said today that, according to widespread market reports, Egypt had cut its official crude oil selling prices for December by up to 85 cents a barrel. But traders said the cut had not yet been confirmed. The reported cut would take the key Egyptian crude to $31.75.

title: WEATHER SERVICE WARMS UP FORECAST FOR WINTER ON EAST COAST
description: The National Weather Service broke ranks with other forecasters today and said there was at least a 60 percent chance that the East Coast would have a winter warmer than normal.

title: Sanitationmen Ask Equity in Raises
description: The head of the city's uniformed sanitationmen said yesterday that members of his union, on the basis of improved productivity, deserved wage increases as large or larger than those firefighters and police officers had received.

title: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
description: Gastroenterologists in Cambridge, England, believe they have discovered that sensitivity to certain foods is a frequent cause of irritable bowel syndrome, a disorder usually attributed to psychological factors.

title: Syncor and France
description: The Syncor International Corporation said the Atomic Energy Commission of France planned to buy nearly three million Syncor common shares for $8.15 each, or a total of $24.2 million. Syncor said that both sides were planning an exclusive distribution and licensing agreement for eight product lines. Under a letter of intent, the French investor agreed not buy or sell additional shares of Syncor for 10 years except under certain conditions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Decking the Halls - And Everything Else

title: DEVILS LOSE IN RETURN
description: The Devils returned from a long road trip tonight to face two formidable opponents - poor ice and the Chicago Black Hawks, who scored three goals within 5 minutes 29 seconds of the first period and beat New Jersey, 3-1.

title: Tale of 2 Cities
description: In the crazy geography of the Los Angeles Raiders, everything is in place for the team's next ''home'' game Sunday against the Seattle Seahawks: the players and coaches are practicing in Oakland, the executive and administrative staffs are working in Los Angeles and the charter plane is standing by, ready to carry the players 400 miles on the week's longest commuting shuttle in pro football.

title: BALLET: CHICAGOANS PRESENT 'CINDERELLA' BY PAUL MEJIA
description: The Chicago City Ballet's production of Paul Mejia's ''Cinderella,'' starring Suzanne Farrell and Adam Luders, closed an 11-performance run today at the Auditorium Theater here. It is a version of Prokofiev's score that showed Mr. Mejia, a former soloist with the New York City Ballet and Miss Farrell's husband, as a choreographer who has become more fluent and sophisticated in his approach to movement since fragments of his choreography were first seen several years ago in New York.

title: JOHN COONEY, 77, EGYPTOLOGIST, DIES
description: John D. Cooney, an Egyptologist and a curator for the Brooklyn Museum and the Cleveland Museum of Art, died Friday at his home in Sherman, Conn., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: No Headline
description: McENROE AND BORG WIN IN EUROPE VS. AMERICAS

title: Shell and Exxon Weighing Venture
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation's Esso Petroleum unit are considering a 900 million investment to increase gas production from the south of the North Sea, a Shell spokesman said.

title: INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $59,000...C-Net loss

title: FILIPINO BISHOPS URGE TOLERANCE
description: Twelve Roman Catholic bishops told top officials of the Defense Ministry today that the Government should be more tolerant of responsible dissent and should focus its efforts on solving the causes of unrest.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
PERKINS SHUNS TINSEL QUALITY
description: I t would be unrealistic to expect a program like ''The Ray Perkins Show'' to be a venture in sports journalism. It would also be unfair. Perkins, the head coach of the Giants, has no training as a journalist, or even as a television commentator. And his modest pregame show, aired at noon Sundays on Channel 2 during the football season, makes no pretense of being anything more than an entertainment package for Giants fans.

title: DEMOCRATS DRAFT PROPOSAL ON JOBS
description: As Congress returned to Capitol Hill today, House Democratic leaders began drafting an additional proposal designed to create jobs.

title: WESTERN MARINE ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary gain of $958,903 from the sale of building; all shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Sept

title: Singled Out; 11 Million to 1
description: There was a $1.25 million winner in Atlantic City yesterday; there may also be a $2,000 loser. New Jersey's consumer protection agency wonders whether the Sands hotel and casino violated a fraud act by abruptly canceling a promotional game scheduled to run until Jan. 3.

title: BONN CHEMICAL INDUSTRY LAGS
description: West Germany's giant chemical companies are finally showing the strains of the world recession, newly reported thirdquarter earnings show.

title: China Leader To Disclose 5-Year Plan
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang will disclose a new five-year economic plan Tuesday that is intended to increase efficiency in China's outmoded industries at least partly by increasing management initiative.

title: OFFSHORE BANK MONITOR
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The campaign for the parliamentary elections in March has started, and the battered and demoralized Free Democrats appear to be stumbling.

title: FELDSTEIN SEES SLOW JOB GROWTH
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic aide, said today that it would take five or six years to bring the unemployment rate down to 6 or 7 percent from the postwar peak of 10.4 percent reached in October.

title: Poland Reports Release of 327
description: In what appears to be another step toward the lifting of martial law, the Polish Government announced today that 327 people interned under martial law would be released.

title: Miss Holtzman Fights Subpoena
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn has been subpoenaed to testify today in a case in which her office is accused of prosecutorial misconduct. But she said she would fight the subpoena, which was served on her yesterday after she had refused to appear voluntarily at a hearing before Justice Gerald Adler in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: INTERPROVINCIAL STEEL & PIPE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
NEW STUDY ASSESSES SEX HABITS
description: More young women are becoming involved in extramarital affairs than are young men, and women are losing their virginity at an earlier age than men, according to a study of Americans appearing in the January issue of Playboy and made public yesterday. The survey also found that many people considered themselves happier with their sex lives than they were five years ago.

title: Amarex Inc. Debt
description: Amarex Inc. said it was trying to restructure its debt and that of some of its general partnerships, and would determine whether to seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The oil and gas drilling concern, based in Oklahoma City, said it planned to schedule meetings with major lenders, trade creditors, securities holders and others to discuss how to restructure the debt. For the quarter ended July 31, Amarex had a net loss of $2.9 million on revenues of $9.7 million.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEMTEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the qr and $210,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after a loss of $54,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $106,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gainof $173,000

title: REAGAN CAUTIONS MAYORS ON U.S. AID
description: President Reagan said today that the ''Federal choke-hold on the American economy'' was slighting the cities and building ''structural deficit'' into the Federal budget.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MINISTERIAL DECLARATION AT GATT CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from the ministerial declaration adopted today at the conference of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade:

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1982; Markets
description: Interest rates rose sharply in the credit markets. Treasury bill rates were up more than a quarter of a point, while Treasury bond prices fell more than two points. Securities dealers said the cause was more the absence of good news than any specific development. The Federal Reserve reported a $2.8 billion increase in the basic money supply for the week ended Nov. 17. The report, late in the day, was said to have had little impact on trading. (Page D1.)

title: STUDENTS AND STAFF FLARE AT WOUNDING OF TEACHER
description: More than 50 students and teachers at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn gathered in a basement classroom yesterday afternoon, drawn together by anger and frustration at the assault on a favorite teacher over the weekend.

title: Clots Led To Death Of Filly
description: Landaluce, the outstanding 2-yearold filly who was unbeaten in five starts, died because of clots in her blood vessels and lungs that were caused by a still undetermined disease, an autopsy revealed today.

title: Northwest Stewardesses Win $52 Million in Suit
description: More than 3,000 former and current female flight attendants of Northwest Airlines have been awarded $52.4 million in a settlement of a job discrimination lawsuit.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY AGAIN BIDS SOVIET QUIT AFGHANISTAN
description: The General Assembly, by a vote of 114 to 21, renewed its demand today that Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan.

title: Donlan, Garvey to Meet
description: Jack Donlan, chief negotiator for the National Football League owners, agreed to meet with Ed Garvey, the players' union executive director, tonight to discuss unresolved issues in the five-year agreement which came out of the 57-day player strike.

title: Amex Opens Mezzanine
description: The American Stock Exchange opened its new $7 million mezzanine yesterday, adding four trading posts and expanding its capacity by 40 percent.

title: FOES OF NEW JAIL NEAR CHINATOWN SEEK ALTERNATIVE
description: Opponents of a proposed Manhattan jail on the outskirts of Chinatown and Little Italy told Mayor Koch yesterday that it would be cheaper to build new cells on Rikers Island.
